column2: WASHINGTON, May 15. -- In the face of an impending Supreme Court decision concerning the constitutionality of the National Industrial Recovery Act, House leaders took sharp issue today with the Senate's action in voting to extend an emasculated NIRA for only ten months, and announced that a two-year extension would be passed in the House within a few days.

PARIS, May 15. -- With the reopening of Parliament next week France will again be obliged to grapple with her financial and monetary policy. Finance Minister Louis Germain-Martin has prepared a program for maintaining the present deflationary system and will ask full powers to execute it during the Summer vacation period.

An additional $7,000,000 of gold was engaged in Paris yesterday for shipment here, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This made $38,000,000 engaged in France since last Thursday and $185,000,000 engaged abroad or shipped here since April 5.

Following its approval Tuesday of readjustment of the traditional Jewish marriage law to permit an agunah (deserted wife) to obtain a divorce without the consent of the husband, the Rabbinical Assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America provided facilities yesterday to enforce the new regulation when it becomes effective in September, 1936.

Several. dinners were given before the cabaret entertainment in behalf of the First Division Cardiac Clinic of Bellevue Hospital, which was held last night at the Stork Club. Among those who took part in the entertainment were Ethel Merman, William Gaxton, Paul Draper, Dwight Fiske and Victor Moore.

Four awards, each with a value of about $4,000, enabling the winners to study two years at the American Academy in Rome, were presented yesterday to four young men who have been studying painting, sculpture, architecture and landscape architecture in American colleges.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Early passage by the Senate of the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill was predicted by administration whips today after a check had revealed little or no opposition to the measure in that body.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the first three months of 1935 a net profit of $4,917,627, after expenses, interest, provision for taxes, depreciation, depletion, reserves and other charges. This is equivalent, after allowing for preferred dividend requirements, to 30 cents a share on 14,584,025 no par common shares. In the corresponding period of 1934, the net profit was $5,049,275, or 31 cents a common share.

A critical analysis of the proposals of Father Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit has been made by a fellow-Roman Catholic priest. The appraisal, by the Rev. Wilfred Parsons, appears in the current issue of America, national Catholic weekly, of which magazine Father Parsons is editor-in-chief.

Wage increases of 20 per cent and a 30-hour week were among the demands presented last night by representatives of the Joint Board of Cloakmakers Unions and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to the officials of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers at a conference in the Hotel New Yorker.
Brooklyn College evened its two-game baseball series with City College yesterday, triumphing by a 9-8 score. C.C.N.Y. had taken a 9-5 decision from the Maroon in their first game.

The body of Frederick Gross, 9 years old, whose death on March 29 started the series of deaths which has since taken his mother, two sisters and a brother, will be exhumed at 11:30 o'clock this morning from St, John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, and taken to the city morgue at Bellevue for an autopsy.

Doubts that the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation would apply for permanent registration under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 were removed yesterday when the company announced simultaneously its intention to register and the retirement of Orlando F. Weber, chairman of its board, who two years ago strongly resisted demands of the New York Stock Exchange for disclosure of details of the company's operations.
ALBANY, May 15. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Joseph bill prohibiting any new guaranteed mortgage issues until July 1, 1936.

MADISON, Wis., May 15 (AP). -- Jostled and pummeled by University of Wisconsin athletes and fraternity men, three liberal leaders tonight were ducked into the chilly waters of Lake Mundota as a stormy climax to an organization meeting of the League for Industrial Democracy.
Controller Frank J. Taylor moved yesterday to enforce collections from upward of 16,000 local merchants who willfully or otherwise failed to pay the first instalment of the city 2 per cent sales tax.

Major L.L.B. Angas, British market commentator and economist, who caused a stir in financial circles a year ago with his brochure, "The Coming American Boom," has just finished a new work, "The Boom Begins," which will be placed on sale here on Monday.

Declaration yesterday of the regular dividend of $2.25 a share on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's stock had been fully anticipated, but short selling earlier in the week had dropped the price nearly 4 points below the recent high mark.

Charles Seay, a 13-year-old Negro boy from Brooklyn, won the boy's marble-shooting championship of New York City in the finals of the Park Department's annual contest yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park.

From old habit as a political manager Senator HASTINGS can't look at even the most obviously spontaneous ebullition of pure sentiment without asking himself in effect "Who's back of it? Who gets it up? Who puts up for it?" Thus he permits himself to call the 4,000 farmers whose visit to Washington has touched every feeling heart, "farm lobbyists whose expenses are "being paid directly or indirectly by "the Federal Government."

PARIS, May 15. -- Two hundred and fifty passengers who arrived in Havre today to embark for New York on the French liner Champlain remained there tonight when a strike of the ship's crew delayed their departure.

Some improvement in retail trade locally has been registered so far this week, it was reported yesterday by retail executives here. Slight increases in dollar volume over a year ago have been noted, as compared with general decreases last week.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture and director of the rural phase of the new relief program of the Roosevelt administration, pledged tonight a battle to the limit to carry out the plan without sacrifice of vital objectives.

The undefeated Manhattan College freshman baseball team downed St. Peter's high of Staten Island, 9 to 3, yesterday at Manhattan Field for its eleventh triumph. Jack Daly led the Manhattan yearling batting attack, making a triple and a single in three trips to the plate.
CLEVELAND, May 15 (AP). -- The Indians, led by Ab Wright, rookie outfielder, who pounded out a home run and a triple, defeated the Senators, 5 to 4, today.

BALTIMORE, May 15. -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, through I.A. Hirschmann, has asked Mayor Jackson to lend New York City the services of Frederick R. Huber, municipal director of music, to assist in organizing an orchestra there along the lines of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra.

The progress of medical science during the past 100 years holds out the hope that cancer, too, will be conquered eventually, speakers declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Plaza formally opening an educational exhibit by the New York City Cancer Committee. Twenty hospitals have cooperated in arranging the exhibition, which will continue until May 20.
ROME, May 15 (AP). -- Italian newspapers openly demanded today the imposition of a new "organization" upon Ethiopia, which was taken by diplomatic circles to mean civil or military control by Italy.

Speaking last night at the nineteenth annual meeting of the Women's City Club, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, listed sixty-five Tammany district leaders and co-leaders "who are still on the city payroll in exempt and elected positions at generous salaries in spite of the Fusion shake-up in the city government."
Business in money being limited to renewals of expiring obligations, no change in quotations was reported for any classification.

After making phonograph recordings of the radio speeches of 1,000 men and women prominent in American and European life, Professor Jane D. Zimmerman, speech instructor at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday that not only is President Roosevelt the best radio speaker in the world but that, in general, Senators and business men of this country sound better over the air than most radio announcers.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Steps were taken today by advocates of the Patman "Greenback" Bonus Bill to prevent a recurrence of the veterans' march of 1932, under the belief that such a demonstration might cripple what chances they have of forcing payment of the adjusted service certificates over a Presidential veto at this session of Congress.

New York received its first glimpse of "dead-pan" Joe Louis yesterday. The 21-year-old Negro heavyweight from Detroit arrived at the Grand Central Terminal at 9:35 A.M., and was greeted by several hundred admirers.

Going into the ninth with a one-run lead, the St. John's University baseball team made three errors, which enabled Panzer College to score four runs and defeat the Redmen in a weird game at Dexter Park yesterday. The score was 8 -- 6. St. John's made nine errors in all, Panzer six.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 15. -- The Westchester Hills Golf Club team of Jack Sabol and Richard A. Jones Jr., playing on the Hudson River Country Club links today, won the pro-amateur tournament sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association.

The Tercia Trading Corporation, which bought a Varick Street block-front on Tuesday, added another downtown property to its holdings yesterday, when it acquired the Green Gardens Apartments at 464-78 Hudson Street and 72-84 Barrow Street, northeast corner.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

ROME, May 15. -- The Italian press today expressed satisfaction with the reaction abroad to Premier Mussolini's speech yesterday on the Italo-Ethtopian crisis. It is felt that Signor Mussolini's words have served to clear the air and make every one realize that whatever may happen Italy is determined to see things through to their logical conclusion.

The Republican party in New York State has the greatest opportunity it has had in many years on the issue of "Washington dictatorship with its gag rule, stem-roller methods and extravagance," Assemblyman Irving M. Ives, State, minority leader, told members of the Westchester County Women's Republican Club at a luncheon at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club found the Oakland links more to her liking than did others who turned out for the second one-day tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association yesterday.

Harry A. Gordon, as referee, recommended yesterday the allowance of four claims totaling $16,816 at the continuation of the fraud hearings against S.W. Straus Co., bankrupt mortgage bond house, in the office of Louis F. Schultze, the receiver, at 9 East Forty-sixth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Albert Einstein, who has upset many a tradition in the world of science with his startling mathematical and physical theories, set a precedent of a different kind today for men of science to ponder about.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The $4,880,000,000 work-relief program will get into full swing tomorrow when the Advisory Committee on Allotments, meeting at the White House, takes final action on all or part of about $1,000,000,000 worth of projects which have been tentatively approved by the Public Works Administration and by the Division of Applications and Information, headed by Frank C. Walker.

Edward Johnson, Canadian tenor, was named general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday. He will succeed Herbert Witherspoon, who died suddenly last Friday. Edward Ziegler will remain as assistant manager.

ATHENS, May 15. -- The Greek Cabinet today partly lifted martial law, established at the outbreak of the recent revolt, to permit the press to discuss freely the restoration of the monarchy as an issue at the elections June 9, but retaining the right to suspend the Constitution's liberal articles in case of emergency.

Philip De Ronde, banker and former army officer, appeared as a surprise witness before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury yesterday in the trial of the $100,000 slander action brought by William L. Graham, former butler, against Miss Margot Flick and Mrs. Henrietta Flick.

The Federal Grand Jury Association for the Southern District of New York challenged yesterday the denial last week by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, that relief funds are used in the teaching of Communist propaganda.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- The absolute control of the Communist party over the written and spoken word, over schools, clubs and theatres, and even over architecture and science, in the Soviet Union was strikingly shown today in a decision of the Central Committee of the party splitting up the cultural and propaganda department into five divisions.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 15. -- Princeton crews were victorious in two informal races on Lake Carnegie today, the third varsity defeating the Manhattan varsity, and the second freshmen beating the Lawrenceville first eight and the Manhattan freshmen.

Three grand larceny indictments were handed up to Judge Collins in General Sessions yesterday against John Flaherty, 46 years old, former Tammany election district captain in Greenwich Village; Arthur Courtney, 29, a Sanitation Department employe, and an uhidentified man in alleged "shakedowns" of! aspirants for appointmen to the police force.

To the surprise of 12,000 persons, including his owner, Identify won the forty-second running of the featured Toboggan Handicap as Belmont Park opened its Spring meeting yesterday. Lengths back at the finish and out of the money was Identify's stable-mate Discovery, which had been counted on to carry the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt colors to a decisive victory.

LONDON, May 15. -- With the centuries-old ceremonial, the master, the Earl of Athlone, and the wardens of the Worshipful Company of Vintners tonight feasted the Princes of Wales, York, Gloucester and Kent. Prince Arthur of Connaught also would have been a guest of honor but for a severe indisposition.

ST. LOUIS, May 15. -- On the eve of the eighth anniversary of Colonel Lindbergh's New York-Paris solo flight came announcement today that he had deeded to the Missouri Historical Society his all but priceless collection of trophies here.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today gave encouragement to New Jersey proponents of beach erosion prevention by assuring Representative Bacharach, Republican of New Jersey, that he and his advisers would give "sympathetic consideration" to an application by New Jersey for works which would carry out the purposes of the works-relief appropriations.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Holding that the Omnibus Banking Bill contained possibilities of "a vicious and perhaps uncontrollable conflagration" of inflation, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank of New York, declared today that it would not liberalize the Federal Reserve System but would make "it over into an instrument of despotic authority."

Preparations went forward rapidly yesterday for the great frog derby that will be jumped off next Sunday on the Mall in Central Park. It was announced also that former Governor Smith would be master of ceremonies. He is the zoo's "night superintendent."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 15. -- Max Baer, training here for the defense of his world's heavyweight championship against James J. Braddock in the Madison Square Garden Bowl on June 13, went through four rounds of sparring today.
Counsel for Insull creditors who are suing five New York banks and the General Electric Company were split into two camps yesterday by John W. Davis with the question "What do you want?"

Officials of the city of Chicago were reported yesterday to be weighing the advisability of refunding an issue of 5 1/2 per cent bonds maturing on Jan. 1, 1940, which originally were issued in the amount of $15,000,000 and today are outstanding in the amount of $8,903,000.

BASLE, May 15. -- A warm welcome to Secretary Morgenthau's speech on stabilization of currencies as the "most constructive contribution" any one has yet made on that subject and strong support of his tactics in refusing to stabilize first and in placing "responsibility for delay where it properly belongs, namely on the Government of Great Britain," was expressed today by Leon Fraser, retiring president of the Bank for International Settlements.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Sewell L. Avery received $100,000 compensation in 1934 as president of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., and R.H. Fogler and Walter Hoving, vice presidents, got $40,000 each, the corporation's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

DENVER, May 15. -- The test case through which the Federal Government hoped to dam the nation-wide flood of cash chain-letters failed today when a grand jury refused to indict three Denver business men.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 15. -- Ballot boxes were impounded here tonight and disputes over the returns in yesterday's commission election were suspended temporarily as State Senator Albert S. Woodruff, Republican, indicated that the New Deal Non-Partisan League, whose fusion ticket he supported, might demand a recount.

Once again, it being Spring, the boys are talking wistfully about musical shows and their hopes, aspirations and plans therefor. A couple of them -- shows, that is -- are drifting around now, in the lazy, preamble stage that is sacred to Tin Pan Alley Co. To wit:

Of nine new singers engaged for the Metropolitan Opera next season six are classed as Americans, one as a German, one a Belgian and one a Chilean. All but one have had appearances in New York. Two have been prominent in the opera performances given at the Juilliard School of Music.

Sales of cars and trucks by the General Motors Corporation in the overseas market, including all territory outside the United States and Canada, reached 93,908 units in the first four months of this year. The total, a new high level, compared with 59,817 in the corresponding period in 1934, the corporation announced yesterday.

Morris Stevens, 20 years old, of 1,400 Second Avenue, was cleared of a disorderly conduct charge yesterday by Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky in the Bronx court, in connection with an anti-war demonstration Sunday afternoon near Van Cortlandt Park, when several youths interrupted a parade of junior military and naval organizations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15. -- Timothy F. Leahy, chief of police of Cambridge, will seek indictments at the next session of the county grand jury of those who were responsible for the April issue of The Harvard Lampoon, sale and circulation of which were banned here.

The subcommittee on education of the Mayor's Commission on Conditions in Harlem, at a hearing yesterday afternoon, heard Charles J. Pickett, principal of the New York Industrial High School, Fifth Avenue and 138th Street, tell of overcrowding in the institution and of the "urgent need" for a similar school in the area.

CLEVELAND, May 15 (AP). -- Malcolm Muir, president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, pictured the Eccles Banking Bill today as a potential weapon for a Federal administration attack on big business.

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower here yesterday. An exception was hides, which moved forward in active trading. On the cash markets new high prices for the year were made by hides, iron, lead, zinc and gasoline. Cotton, corn, cocoa, silk and lard were firm and rye and oats were lower.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15. -- Timothy F. Leahy, chief of police of Cambridge, will seek indictments at the next session of the county grand jury of those who were responsible for the April issue of The Harvard Lampoon, sale and circulation of which were banned here.

The subcommittee on education of the Mayor's Commission on Conditions in Harlem, at a hearing yesterday afternoon, heard Charles J. Pickett, principal of the New York Industrial High School, Fifth Avenue and 138th Street, tell of overcrowding in the institution and of the "urgent need" for a similar school in the area.

CLEVELAND, May 15 (AP). -- Malcolm Muir, president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, pictured the Eccles Banking Bill today as a potential weapon for a Federal administration attack on big business.

ST. LOUIS, May 15. -- A legal battle within the once closely connected Standard Oil family of petroleum companies founded by John D. Rockefeller in Ohio in 1870 developed today when the Standard Oil Company of Indiana filed suit in the Federal District Court here against the Standard Oil Company. of New Jersey.

The National Civil Service Reform League, in its annual report, just made public following the fifty-third annual meeting of the league here on May 10, criticizes President Roosevelt for failing to abide by the spirit expressed in his book, "On Our Way," in which he wrote: "We need a trained personnel in government: we need disinterested as well as broad-gauged public officials."

Sharply contrasting views on the Feld-Crawford bill, now before Governor Lehman, which grants manufacturers the right to fix the resale prices of trade-marked merchandise, featured the luncheon meeting yesterday of the American Marketing Society at the Advertising Club.
DETROIT, May 15. -- Edward Johnson left for New York tonight, declaring that it was an "obligation to carry on the work of Herbert Witherspoon."

LONDON, May 15. -- The British Government has decided to establish a permanent Central Supply Board to plan the sudden expansion of industries, particularly the aircraft industry, in case of war, Viscount Hailsham, Secretary of State for War, informed the House of Lords today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15. -- As a result of the scheduled feature race being canceled, the Olive Hill purse over the mile and a sixteenth course attracted the major share of attention at Churchill Downs today. H. Oot's Panalong was the victor.
BUENOS AIRES, May 15. -- More than a year of freakish weather in Argentina came to a climax this week. Although it is late Autumn in this part of the world, fruit trees have burst into bloom.
LONDON, May 15. -- The famous Jonker diamond has been sold to Harry Winston of New York for about 150,000 ($730,000 at yesterday's rate), it was learned today.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries report for the twelve months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $9,370,082, after all deductions, equivalent after preferred dividends to 21 cents a share on 11,738,591 no-par common shares, comparing with $12,534,692, or 50 cents a share, in the preceding year.

GOSPORT, England, May 15. -- From all parts of the country people are coming to Gosport to have a look at Gerard B. Lambert's racing sloop Yankee. Public interest, stirred by Yankee's voyage across the Atlantic and the forthcoming races with British yachts, equals that shown for T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour when she was preparing to leave for the United States in quest of the America's Cup.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 15. -- Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. of Bergen County, made known here today that he would ask the Bergen County grand jury next Tuesday to return indictments charging murder in the first degree against five alleged members of the gang of bank robbers who got $15,000 in Newburgh, N. Y., last Thursday and escaped by airplane.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15. -- Eyes of delegates to the National Association of Junior Leagues of America in conference here today turned critically upon themselves in an effort to appraise their value to the Commonwealth.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 15 (AP). -- William Berrigan won $61,600 today when the ice at Nenana, fifty miles west of Fairbanks on the Nenana River, broke at 1:32 P.M.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 15. -- Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith, Australia's trail-blazing aviator, said "I thought we were gone" today after he and two companions had won a fight for life over the storm-lashed Tasman Sea in the veteran airplane Southern Cross.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $631,000 Borough of Fair Lawn, N.J., 4 1/2 per cent bonds by J.S. Rippel Co. of Newark, Paine, Webber Co. and Ewing Co., priced to yield 3.50 to 4.60 per cent. The bonds, dated June 1 next, will mature serially on June 1, 1936 to 1953 inclusive.

BERLIN, May 15. -- The government's declaration on foreign policy will be submitted to the National Socialist Reichstag by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler next Tuesday, it was officially announced today, and the session has been set for 8 o'clock in the evening so that his speech may be broadcast at home and abroad at a convenient hour.

The United States liner Manhattan will arrive today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. Among her passengers are Hugh Gibson, United States Ambassador to Brazil, with Mrs. Gibson; Leo J. Keena, recently appointed Minister to Honduras, and Mrs. Keena, and Edward I. Furman, vice president of the Macaulay Publishing Company, and:

ANTLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 15. -- With an imposing list of entries belonging to exhibitors from all parts of the country being scheduled to compete, the fourth annual Atlantic City Horse Show opened today in the spacious ring of the Convention Hall Auditorium.

Brisk bidding marked the sale at auction yesterday of the eleven-story apartment house at 60-62 University Place, northwest corner of East Tenth Street. The house was offered by Major William Kennelly, as auctioneer, and before it was struck down a total of forty-eight bids had been made.

Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, appealed to private welfare agencies yesterday to help him with their advice in running the relief machinery of the city.

Criticism of ship operators and of Federal regulations for inspection of ships was voiced in a discussion of safety of life at sea yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Maritime Law Association of the United States at the Block Hall Luncheon Club, 23 South William Street.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP). -- Behind a superb three-hit pitching performance by the veteran Ted Lyons, the White Sox closed their surprising home stay today with a neat 5-to-0 shut-out victory over Philadelphia. The victory sent last year's cellar occupants on the road in first place.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- The French and Soviet Foreign Ministers issued tonight a joint statement that in effect is an acceptance of Germany's offer of April 13 to enter into an Eastern European non-aggression pact, even though other members sign mutual assistance treaties among themselves.

With the early pollack snapping at trolled lures off Montauk and weakfish making their seasonal bow in Peconic Bay and along the New Jersey coast, the horizon widens for salt water anglers of the metropolitan area.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Employment, payrolls and hours for the construction industry continued upward in April. Industrial Commissioner Andrews stated today that employment advanced 19 per cent, payrolls 12 per cent and man-hours 13 per cent from March to April.

WARSAW, May 15. -- Through silent thousands of his fellow-countrymen massed twenty deep along three miles of Warsaw's wide avenues, Josef Pilsudski, Poland's creator and first citizen, began after dusk tonight the first stage of his journey from Belvedere Palace to his final resting place at Cracow, Warsaw is a city of 1,250,000 souls, yet it is conservative to estimate that 500,000 persons gathered to see his passing.

A small but distinguished "radio party" was held yesterday in the financial district when high officials of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad listened to a broadcasting of the dedication of the Abraham Lincoln, a B. O. streamlined steam train of advanced design which is to begin service between Chicago and St. Louis on June 1.

Halvor Jacobsen, who retired nine years ago as general passenger agent of the Scandinavian Line in America, and whose seventieth birthday occurred yesterday, was guest of honor at a dinner party last night at the Swedish Engineers Club, 27 West Fifty-first Street.

The Federal court was called upon here yesterday to decide whether corporations being reorganized under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act were required to abide by closed-shop contracts with labor organizations.

Items from the art treasures and furnishings of Ophir Hall, the residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid at Purchase, N.Y., were sold at auction yesterday for $29,590. This makes a total of $53,150 for the four sessions so far of the public sale, which began on Tuesday under the management of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., of New York.

Michel Chekhov, it was generally agreed, proved to all and sundry during the Moscow Art Players' engagement here that he is quit an actor -- and a director, too. The result: the Group Theatre is now dickering with him to join its Summer faculty and provide lessons in acting to those engaged in the Group's laboratory exercises.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Private airplanes for the average citizen may soon become a reality, resembling the new speedy craft now in use on many airlines.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16. -- At the 151st annual commencement of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary in Kirkpatrick Chapel here today, the degree of Bachelor of Divinity was awarded to thirteen graduates. The commencement address was given by Professor Andrew W. Blackwood of Princeton Theological Seminary.

One of the major tasks that confronted Edward Johnson yesterday as he took office as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera was arranging to retain the services of stars like Lawrence Tibbett and Rosa Ponselle, who have not yet been re-engaged.
RYE, N.Y., May 16. -- The women golfers from Long Island won the intersectional team matches for the Golf Illustrated trophy for the third year in succession today.

The medical board of the Metropolitan Hospital, a city institution on Welfare Island, is investigating the death of one person and the illness of four others following tooth extractions in the hospital dental clinic, Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater announced yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 16. -- Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina left today for New York, en route to Washington, after suspending until October the investigation of the administration of Governor Paul Pearson of the Virgin Islands.

Paul Lukas, Madge Evans and May Robson are the featured players in "Age of Indiscretion," opening this morning at the Capitol and Loew's Metropolitan in Brooklyn. Rudy Vallee and his Connecticut Yankees head the stage show at the Capitol.

MOSCOW, May 16. -- The freely expressed belief of Soviet officials that the visit of Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, not only will be followed by closer cooperation between France and the Soviet Union for peace but will inspire other countries to join in collective action for security was amplified today in editorials in the newspapers Izvestia and Pravda, chief government and party organs, respectively.

The Peace Council, a student organization at Hunter College, held a meeting yesterday although entrance to its meeting room was barred by patrolmen and detectives and although its guest speaker, Bert C. Leech of Union Theological Seminary, had been escorted from the college building by a patrolman at the order of Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president.
I wish to congratulate you upon and endorse your editorial "Divided Counsels."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16. -- The student body of the New Jersey College for Women is divided sharply over the status of Dr. Leinhard Bergel, instructor in German, who has been notified that he will not be reappointed in June, allegedly for his lack of sympathy for Nazism.

More than 1,500 sets of the four-volume "The Mind and Society," by Pareto, have already been sold, although the work will not be published until May 23, Harcourt, Brace report. In anticipation that the first edition of 2,500 copies will shortly be exhausted, paper for a second edition of 1,000 has been ordered.

PARIS, May 16. -- One of the greatest exhibitions of Italian art ever seen was officially opened today by President Albert Lebrun in the presence of Count Galeazzo Ciano, Premier Mussolini's son-in-law, and the podestas of Rome, Naples and other large Italian cities that have contributed works.

TOKYO, May 16 (AP). -- A spokesman for the Japanese Naval Office said today he believed naval circles in the United States and Japan were not alarmed over each other's manoeuvres in the Pacific Ocean.

Yale and Princeton, two of the oldest rivals in college sport, will meet in the first game of this year's intercollegiate polo championship at Governors Island, according to the draw made public yesterday by the Intercollegiate Polo Association.

The Traders Construction Corp.. Ruth A. I i Thompson, vice president, bought from the] Engrant Bank le southwest corner of Park -v. and 120th St., 25x90, for a con[ sideratlon shown as $.1,000, the bank taking back a purchase money mortgage for $21,232 due on demand. The bank made m another loan of 13,000 also due on demand puluant to a building loa:c agreement I dated Way 16,

A resolution urging the creation of a Federal Department of Conservation and Public Works will be presented at the annual meeting and exhibit of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers to be held tomorrow in the Hotel Roosevelt.

OTTAWA, May 16. -- Canadian political parties are turning anxious eyes on Alberta, where William Aberhart, an evangelist-economist somewhat after the Father Coughlin style, has formed a new party to establish a "basic dividend" of $25 a month for everybody.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 16. -- The Alabama Supreme Court paved the way today for reindictments and retrial in the Scotsboro case by ordering existing indictments against two of the nine defendants quashed.

NEWARK, N.J., May 16. -- Against a background depicting a Spanish market place, with baskets of fruit, vegetables and flowers on display, the scene enhanced by members of the Newark Junior League in colorful costume, the eighth annual flower show of the Newark Garden Club was held today in the parish house of the Third Presbyterian Church here.

Three men made a mysterious raid yesterday afternoon on the studio of Michael Califano, 43-year-old painter, at 40 West Fifty-third Street, beat and bound him and destroyed between twenty-five and thirty oil paintings, including one denouncing Hitler.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- New Deal officials set out today to establish the most elaborate and intricate publicity unit that this capital has yet seen.

WARSAW, Friday, May 17. -- At 12:30 o'clock this morning after the people of Warsaw had been streaming all day past the body of Marshal Josef Pilsudski, it became necessary to close the cathedral where he lay in state.

Joseph Lieb Steinmetz, who brought a tragic end to a fortnight's wedding trip by shooting to death his 17-year-old bride and a priest he suspected of being too friendly with her, went to trial yesterday before General Sessions Judge Nott and a jury.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Way 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve ]s, was $2,485,000,000, an increase of $!4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $3,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Federal Government swung decisively into action today on its $4,000,000,000 work relief program by allocating $1,091,802,200, or more than a fourth of the huge outlay, subject to final approval by President Roosevelt.

The first instance in which a Coast Guard plane has apprehended an alleged rum-runner occurred yesterday afternoon off Chesapeake Bay when a plane from the Cape May station captured the speedboat Artemis and held her until aid arrived. The Artemis, later towed to New York, was held on technical navigational infractions while Federal agents investigated her career.

The searching analysis of the proposed Banking Bill by the Guaranty Trust's chairman and by the chairman of the Chase Bank is in both cases a sober and impressive examination of the arbitrarily centralized powers which would be conferred by the measure's Second Section.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The following work relief projects for Connecticut and New Jersey were recommended to President Roosevelt by the Advisory Committee on Allotments:

The legend of Daniel of Calaveras, famous frog in the Mark Twain story, notwithstanding, a frog must weigh a pound and three quarters to be eligible for the heralded Frog Jumping Derby on the Mall in Central Park next Sunday, it was decided by an equally heralded committee yesterday afternoon at the Central Park Zoo.

MANILA, P.I., Friday, May 17 (AP). -- Twenty "Communist bandits" were slain in a battle with constabulary in Laguna Province today, a correspondent for the Spanish language newspaper the Vanguardia reported.

The New York Stock Exchange suspended dealings yesterday in Laclede Gas Light Company 5 per cent mortgage bonds, due on April 1, 1934, of which only a small amount are outstanding because holders failed to assent to a maturity-extension plan.

The rich greensward on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park was transformed yesterday afternoon into a colorful scene when 2,500 schoolgirls danced and sang about Maypoles to the lilting folktunes of a band.

BERLIN, May 16. -- A new government loan to consolidate at least part of the vast short-term indebtedness created by the government's employment and rearmament programs and relieve the Reichsbank of its top-heavy load of "labor creation bills" is now in preparation, it was semi-officially announced today.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 16 (Canadian Press.) -- The Bank of Canada continues to record expansion of business. In the weekly statement released today an increase of approximately $8,000,000 in deposits is reported, with total assets up more than $6,500,000.

Alexander Smallens, symphony and opera conductor, and Mrs. Ruth White Wertheim, former wife of Maurice Wertheim, banker, art patron and owner of the weekly publication The Nation, were married on Tuesday in Reno, Nev., according to word received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Justi Department announced today the appointment of Martin Conboy, who recently resigned as Federa/District Attorney at New York, as a special assistant to the Attorney General to obtain evidence in connection with the grounding of four American airplanes at Lima, Peru, several weeks ago. He probably will sail for Lim Saturday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 16. -- Squire, aged bay gelding belonging to Mrs. Daniel Shea of Dover, Mass., was the only entry in a field of fifteen to register a clean performance, and as a result carried off premier laurels in the Marlborough-Blenheim $1,000 jumper stake tonight.
Sixty-five King's Crowns, the highest honor conferred by Columbia College for non-athletic activities outside the classroom, were awarded to leaders on the campus yesterday.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYVANIA IN THE PACIFIC, May 16. -- With the red, four-starred flag of Admiral Harris Laning flying from her main truck the battleship California led the last of the White forces to sea from Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, early this morning.

FERNDALE, N.Y., May 16. -- Barney Ross and Jimmy McLarnin, only six miles apart, swung imaginary punches at each other today as they continued their preparation for their battle at the Polo Grounds on May 28.
PARIS, May 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Men are the most important single item in the minds of the Barnard College seniors, according to the annual poll conducted by The Barnard College Quarterly. Their second choice was fun, followed by literature, social problems, material success and music.
Sixty-seven additional listed companies have applied for permanent registration under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. They were:

Robert C. Morris, of the law firm of Morris, Plante Saxe, was re-elected president of the New York County Lawyers Association at its annual meeting last night at 14 Vesey Street. Vice presidents re-elected to serve with him were Judge Clarence J. Shearn, Bernard S. Deutsch and Charles E. Hughes Jr.

An argument on the nature of debentures, representing the combined thought of counsel for the Guaranty Trust Company, the Irving Trust Company, the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, the Commercial National Bank, the Bankers Trust Company and the General Electric Company, was delivered yesterday before Federal Judge Mack by John W. Davis.
Francis W.H. Adams, who is 30 years old, was sworn in yesterday as United States Attorney, to take the place of Martin Conboy, whose resignation from that office went into effect last Wednesday.

The United States Department of Commerce has advised the New York Produce Exchange that the figures given out on May 14, for cottonseed, from which is estimated the visible supply of refined cottonseed oil, included stocks of imported as well as American cottonseed oil, the Exchange announced yesterday.

Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Company, is among the passengers sailing tonight for the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others going on the ship include:

With fourteen others driving to no avail behind her, Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Sorrow, a Pennant filly from Mea Culpa, captured the featured Artful Purse yesterday at Belmont Park. It was a race to delight long-shot players, as the choices finished far back.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Controverting published reports of apparent indifference by President Roosevelt to the fate of a veto of the Patman inflationary Bonus Bill, a White House spokesman stated emphatically today that Mr. Roosevelt would veto the measure with the strongest message he could compose, in the hope that his veto would be sustained.
All commodity futures except coffee advanced sharply yesterday. The advance on the cash markets was general with lead making a new high price for the year.

Decision to poll their membership on continuance of the NRA was reached yesterday at a special conference of representatives of apparel trade associations and code authorities held at the offices of the Dress Code Authority, 1,440 Broadway.

AMHERST, Mass., May 16. -- The American premiere of Denis Johnston's experimental drama, "The Old Lady Says 'No,'" presented tonight by the Amherst College Masquers, was enthusiastically received by a large audience in spite of the obscurity and confusion inherent in the structure and dialogue of the play.

Stockholders of the Shell Union Oil Corporation at their Annual meeting yesterday approved a reduction in the number of directors from seventeen to twelve. James H. Brookmire and G. Legh-Jones retired from the board, in which there were three vacancies.

PITTSBURGH, May 16. -- Two mound veterans of many a baseball battle matched skill and experience for a dozen scoreless innings today but the 38-year-old Tom Zachary received the breaks and the 35-year-old Waite Hoyt's fine effort went to waste.

Mayor La Guardia joined with civic, business and science leaders yesterday in a movement to make New York "safer, quieter and more delightful" by reducing noise. Representatives of the Police and Health Departments, the Academy of Medicine, industry, real estate and other New York organizations met at the Engineers Club and organized the League for Less Noise to fight for a quieter city.

The Emergency Relief Bureau, through its works division, has completed preparations for the transfer of all work relief projects to the jurisdiction of the Federal Government as soon as the latter is ready to put its new $4,000,000,000 public works program into effect, Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the ERB, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- For the first time in several days, inflation talk and strength in stocks influenced the grain markets and short covering in both wheat and corn on the Board of Trade advanced prices around 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish.
Auctioneers offered a dozen Manhattan properties at foreclosure sales yesterday. All the parcels were bought in by the plaintiffs. One scheduled sale was adjourned.

Secretary Morgenthau in his radio address made the statement that "In 1934 * * * export sales were 59 per cent greater than in 1932." He referred to the export sales of a particular group of companies. The data on which the statement was made are published along with the speech.

Arrangements have been made for the transfer of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange for $104,000, or $1,000 less than the price in the last previous sale on Monday, the Exchange announced yesterday. At the same time, the purchaser of the seat for $105,000 was revealed as Leonard W. Dangler and the seller as Henry D. Stoddard.

Taking of testimony in the United States Customs Court action revolving about the assessment of duty on newsprint imported for The Christian Science Monitor of Boston was completed before the second division of the court here yesterday.

John Flaherty, 46 years old, the former Tammany politician who is suspected of having defrauded aspirants for city jobs of more than $200,000 under pretenses that he could have their names placed on Municipal Civil Service eligible lists, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to five indictments.
MONTREAL, May 16 (AP). -- The Newark Bears regained the International League lead today by defeating the Montreal Royals, 6 to 4, in ten innings for their only victory in the three-game series.

Everything went well with the Yankees yesterday. With Manager Joe McCarthy back on the bench, the New Yorkers, behind Vito Tamulis, collected fifteen hits from three Cleveland pitchers in winning, 10 to 0, upon their return to the stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The speeches delivered in the radio symposium on work relief tonight by Frank C. Walker, chairman of the Division of Application and Information; Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, and Secretary Ickes, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Allotments, were in part as follows:
Yesterday's statement for the twelve reserve banks showed total holdings to be at the highest point of the year to date.

ORANGE, N.J., May 16. -- The Rev. William H. McAllister of Jersey Shore, Pa., who delivered a sermon in his pulpit last Sunday morning on evil companionship, visited Kunz's morgue here today to claim the body of his son, William Jr., 23, who was shot dead by a policeman Sunday night during a robbery in Glen Ridge, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- More than 100 men and women representing civic, educational, religious and social organizations in all parts of the country will attend a conference Saturday at the White House to consider a nation-wide program of social education on crime as a community problem.

Harry Casper purchased for investment the six-story apartment house accommodating eighty-two families at 1,649-53 St. Nicholas Avenue through Slawson Hobbs, brokers. The seller is a client of Mervin Danzig, attorney. The property is assessed for $260,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $199,000, held by the Bowery Savings Bank.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16. -- In these days when youth seems to have the golf situation so completely under control it was comforting to those who have passed beyond that period of life to watch the veterans on parade in the twenty-seventh invitation tournament of the Garden City Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- A treatment for nightmares in which they are dissipated by means of a combination of perfume, will-power and music, was described today to the American Psychiatric Association.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Beginning May 22, the Treasury will market $100,000,000 in bills weekly for an indefinite period in order to refund maturities of $75,000,000 and to supply $25,000,000 each week in new money to the general fund.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Permission to amend that part of the tax appeal petition of Andrew W. Mellon relating to the $3,247,000 worth of "old masters" bought in 1931 by the former Treasury Secretary from the Hermitage Galleries in Petrograd, was granted today by the Board of Tax Appeals.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Compensation of $296,500 was paid in 1934 to ten officers and employes of Marshall Field Co., the corporation's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. Payment of $60,000 was made to John McKinlay, president.

When the big-league teams staged a concerted rush for the railroad stations on Wednesday evening the Giants and White Sox were leading their respective leagues and the two Philadelphia clubs were nestling in adjoining cellars.

The will of Herbert Witherspoon, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, who died suddenly on May 10, was filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. It provides for a memorial to his second wife and pupil, the late Florence Hinkle Witherspoon, and bequeaths his residuary estate to his widow, Blanche Sternberg Skeath Witherspoon.

Mayor La Guardia's campaign against drunken drivers will move forward today when Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, Hospitals Commissioner S.S. Goldwater and Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald confer on methods to check the evil.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 16. -- Play continued to speed up in the two Meadow Brook Club members' polo games played today on the J.S. Phipps estate.
LONDON, May 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions formally committed Martin Mooney, reporter for The New York American, to the workhouse yesterday. On Tuesday, Judge Koenig had imposed on Mr. Mooney a thirty-day term and a $250 fine for refusing to answer questions before the grand jury in its investigation of the policy racket.

As the flight of capital from France continued to force down the franc yesterday and to advance the pound sterling, another $8,000,000 of gold was engaged in France for shipment here. This engagement made the total taken for shipment in the past week $46,000,000 and the total takings abroad since April 5, $193,000,000.

The aldermanic investigation of the Emergency Relief Bureau having terminated, the suffering taxpayer may now, as he rebinds his wounds, speculate on the improbability of any reduction of the burden he now bears. Tammany's rapacity and corruption have been succeeded by Fusion's well-meaning incompetence and blundering.

The unbeaten Textile High School baseball team scored its thirteenth straight victory and its fourth in P.S.A.L. competition, blanking Tottenville, 15 -- 0, in a Lower Manhattan-Richmond division game at the Parade Grounds, Brooklyn, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A seven-point program for a two-year extension of an amended National Recovery Act was approved by President Roosevelt today following closely on the adoption by the Senate of the Clark resolution that would continue the NRA only until April 1, 1936, in an emasculated form.

Predicting that the political battle raging around the New Deal will become more bitter in the coming year, Howard Heinz, president of H.J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh, expressed confidence yesterday that ultimately the American people would veer away from what he termed the present confusion of political and social thought and return to old fundamentals.

LONDON, Friday, May l7. -- Only the most slender hope remained early this morning that the life of Colonel Thomas E. Lawrence could be saved. At 2 o'clock he had been unconscious for about eighty-six hours as the result of the motorcycle accident in which he was injured Monday morning.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The "splendid record of achievement" of the Boy Scouts of America, now 1,323,819 strong, was praised in a letter from President Roosevelt read today to 500 Scout leaders at the annual meeting of the National Council.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose to a new high level of about $2,350,000,000 last Wednesday, it appeared from the weekly report of the system, published yesterday, which showed a gain of $64,000,000 in total reserves of the banks to a high record of $4,822,000,000.

SALEM, N.H., May 16. -- The veteran W.R. Flemming, who spent many years riding in a sulky served notice on owners of running horses today that he intends to play as important a part in the running game as he did in the light-harness field.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The Boerse was firm although quiet today. Activity centred on a few specialties expected to benefit from Minister of Economics Schacht's foreign-trade subsidy program and from the armament program. Heavy industrials were stronger, Rheinstahl gaining 2 points.
loney market was without feature. VVhile funds were in good supply the demand was small, replacements alone being reported.
Leasing of business space yesterday was featured by the renting of a downtown store to a steamship agency and contracts in which firms are expanding their quarters.

Cruising dates held the yachting spotlight yesterday as the New York Yacht Club, the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead and the American Yacht Club of Rye announced the itineraries for their annual fixtures.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 16 (AP). -- The release under bail of Amadeo Barletta, former Italian Consul, who is held on charges of plotting the assassination of President Rafael Trujillo, has been ordered, it was learned today.

LONDON, May 16. -- Making his first speech since his doctors ordered him to bed on his return from his Continental tour six weeks ago, Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, warned tonight that all the power of Britain would be marshaled against any country that might try to break the peace.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 16. -- Mrs. Calvert Holt was the principal winner in the annual flower show of the Greenwich Hortulus Club, held at the home of Mrs. J. Stillman Rockefeller this afternoon. Mrs. Holt received the sweepstakes in artistic arrangements, taking two other firsts in this class.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -The principal features of the Wagner Labor Bfil would:

COLUMBUS, Kan., May 16 (AP). -- A jury deliberating a "dog murder" here was discharged in a 5-to-7 deadlock at midnight after five hours of deliberation over charges against Otis Stevens, a relief worker, that he killed Duke Black, a Gordon setter which was the town pet. The case is to come up again at the next term of court.

A clock made by young Pharaoh Tut-ankh-Amen of Egypt 1,300 years before Christ was described last night by Professor James H. Breasted of the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, in the annual James Arthur Lecture on "Time and Its Mysteries," at Gould Memorial Library, University Heights, New York University.

MADISON, Wis., May 16. -- Seven University of Wisconsin students, most of them athletes, were subpoenaed today in a John Doe investigation of a campus riot last night in which four persons were thrown into Lake Mendota by a crowd who raided a meeting of the League for Industrial Democracy, Socialist organization.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey reported yesterday for 1934 a consolidated net income of $45,618,960 after all charges, reserves and taxes. This was equal to $1.76 a share on 25,856,081 capital shares outstanding. In 1933, the company had a net income of $25,084,310, or 97 cents a share.

Price movements followed an irregular course in yesterday's moderately active trading in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Second-grade railroad bonds were conspicuously strong. Utilities, industrials and foreign groups were mixed.

Reports that E.H.H. Simmons, former president of the Stock Exchange, who will serve as vice president in the administration of Charles R. Gay, would be named chairman of the public relations committee of the Exchange received little credence yesterday in well informed quarters.

Organization of holders of life insurance policies and of depositors in savings banks in defense of their interests, for sound currency and in opposition' to government ownership and control of businesses of any sort is the aim of the Life Policy Holders and Thrift Depositors Association of America, formed yesterday.
Reflecting especially the reaction in the grains, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined 0.2 point to 126.4 in the week ended on Tuesday, from 126.6 the Tuesday previous.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 16. -- A woman passenger aboard the Bremen reported she had been robbed of jewelry valued at 6,000 (approximately $29,000) shortly after the ship had sailed from New York on Feb. 8, it was revealed today when Southampton police were asked to assist in investigating the robbery.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Forty-seven specific Federal work-relief projects to be supervised by the Army Corps of Engineers, with the cost of one year's work estimated at $112,186,500, were recommended today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments as follows:

Miss Mills was secretary of the Democratic State Committee at her death. She was known for more than forty years as a reformer who worked for improved conditions for women and children, better housing, prison reform and better schools. Her parents were active abolitionists and took part in the "underground railway," aiding runaway slaves to escape.

MOSCOW, May 16. -- It looked like May Day eve again in Moscow tonight, for the city suddenly decided that the opening of the new subway to commercial operation rated a first-class parade and forthwith arranged one.

NEWARK, N.J., Friday, May 17. -- Carrying several small vials of a newly developed serum for the treatment of influenza, two young physicians left Newark Airport by plane at 12:30 o'clock this morning on a trip to Alaska in an effort to stop an epidemic of the malady among the Eskimos of Point Barrow.

The Sportsmanship Brotherhood, which has taken on the sports welcoming functions that Grover Whalen and the Macom once handled so well in other fields, feted the Scottish international soccer team yesterday at a luncheon at the Cornell Club.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 16. -- Senator Huey P. Long stands to make hundreds of thousands of dollars as special legal representative of State boards which he controls.
A demand for apartment houses and dwellings in Brooklyn was indicated by sales announced yesterday. Many of the properties were disposed of by banks and other lending institutions.

New York is rapidly acquiring one of the finest systems of parks, parkways and playgrounds in the world. For current improvements and extensions it has chiefly Mr. MOSES and the depression to thank. One has given direction to the work, the other, in the name of unemployment relief, has supplied the funds.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 16. -- Reaching the peak of his form again, not long before they start shooting for keeps, W. Lawson Little, British and American amateur golf champion, gave England a painful vision of another Prestwick today by touring the Royal Lytham course, where the British amateur championship will be played next week, in a spectacular round of 71.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Brock Pemberton, New York play producer, told the House Immigration Committee today that a proposed measure to restrict entry of alien actors would impair a "renaissance of the theatre."

Placards attesting that the first instalment of the city's 2 per cent sales tax has been paid into the city treasury are being sent to every retailer in the city who made the payments, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.
MIDDLETON, Ohio, May 16. -- The $25,000,000 financing program of the American Rolling Mill Company was approved today in the annual stockholders' meeting here.

RED BANK, N.J., May 16. -- John Colt of Princeton, former State Commissioner of Finance and chairman of the New Jersey Emergency Relief Administration, was elected president and a director of the Second National Bank and Trust Company of Red Bank at a meeting of directors today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Apparel Codes Council, to strengthen the efforts of the code authorities of clothing manufacturers to obtain enforcement of the label provisions of their codes, was approved today by the National Industrial Recovery Board.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Two special reports on the administration's pending Social Security Bill, prepared for the Business Advisory Council and made public today, approve the general objectives sought in the legislation but not each specific section of the bill.

During the week since the Senate passed the Patman bill for the soldiers' bonus the air at Washington has been filled with rumors of political scheming and bargaining. By filing a motion to reconsider the bill it was kept from the White House, apparently in the hope that some "adjustment" could be made with the President.

PARIS, May 16. -- An increase of 61,000,000 francs in exports during April permitted France to halt the downward trend of her foreign trade, at least temporarily. Imports fell 19,000,000 francs during the month, while comparisons with April, 1934, and the first four months of this year with last year also show important declines.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Following long agitation by China to have foreign powers raise their legations to embassy status, the United States Legation in Peiping will be elevated to that rank under a State Department recommendation approved by President Roosevelt. The proposal is to be submitted to Congress at this session for legislative authorization.

PARIS, May 16. -- The failure of the French Government to settle the strike of crew and personnel which yesterday prevented the departure of the French liner Champlain kept that vessel tied up today. Her sailing was canceled and the line lost the passenger business and profitable gold shipments to competitive companies.

The International Marimba Symphony Orchestra, with a personnel of 100 players, gave its first New York concert last night in Carnegie Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. Clair Omar Musser is the conductor of this organization, which has recently been touring Europe.
To the surprise of nobody, stocky Gene Sarazen, the "double eagle kid," is a prime favorite in the future books to regain the United States open golf championship in June at Oakmont.

In a market faintly reminiscent of the busy days of 1929, stocks were bid up briskly yesterday, influencing generally higher prices for bonds and commodities. The size of the advance, however, broke no record of longer standing than May 8, which was the day on which the present upward movement began.

The Brooklyn Museum will open today, in its new Gallery for Living Artists on the sixth floor, an exhibition of portraits and figure subjects in oil by Brooklyn painters. This show is scheduled to remain current until June 16, while elsewhere in the building the large sculpture exhibition and the showing of Persian ceramics and miniatures will continue through the Summer.

Glen Varick Foster gave a dinner last night at his home, 950 Park Avenue, and later took his guests to the Pierre Roof Garden for supper and dancing. In the party were Mr. and Mrs. Ralston H. Coffin, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred McNutt, Mrs. James Struthers, the Misses Elizabeth H. Van Tine, Margaret U. Gregory and Ruth H. Foster; Henry Pratt Foster, Gardiner Booth, Gregg Birdsall, Alexander Smith, Raymond de Castro and J. Hegeman Foster.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Proposals for a general revision of the code governing operations of the country's grain exchanges met opposition today when a score of representatives of the Chicago Board of Trade and other markets testified at a Federal hearing here.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
BERLIN, May 16 (AP) -- Two anti-Jewish parades led by brass bands marched through the streets of Berlin today, intensifying a fresh anti-Semitic campaign.
ALBANY, May 16. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today three McNaboe bills designed to end the monopoly of the Irving Trust Company on receiverships in the Federal court in New York City.

Business activity decreased further last month, according to The Annalist. Average daily freight-car loadings, pig iron production and cotton consumption declined, contrary to their customary seasonal movements, and average daily steel ingot production, electric power production and silk consumption recorded greater than seasonal drops.

It took some of us a long time to forgive IRVING IVES of Chenango for being minority leader in the Assembly. That honor belonged of right and good custom to that trusty and well-beloved ancient, JOE MCGINNIES. Yet Mr. IVES'S speech to the Westchester Women's Republican Club is so full of persuasive unction and blithe prophecy, so round, robust and ringing, that there is no resisting it.

The possibility that the Consolidated Gas System, as the result of the abolition of submetering of electricity, might be forced ultimately to seek higher rates that would more than offset the estimated saving of $5,000,000 to general consumers was called remote yesterday by Robert B. Grove, executive vice president of the New York Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A vigorous defense of the meeting planned here next Wednesday for business men who favor continuance of NRA codes, called by the Industry and Business Committee for NRA Extension, was voiced today by the committee chairman, Ward Cheney, who at the same time criticized Herbert Hoover's attack on the NRA as "a disappointment but not a surprise."

Most people will agree with the elocution expert at Teachers College who has been studying radio voices for several years and finds that President ROOSEVELT is the best of all speakers on the air waves. There will also be general agreement that HUEY LONG'S manner over the radio is far from perfect and that Father COUGHLIN, purely from the technical viewpoint, is not a very good radio speaker.

Plans of New York City and Jersey City to raise new funds, mainly for refunding purposes, were announced yesterday. The City of New York will open bids today on $11,100,000 of securities. Jersey City expects to refinance $5,000,000 of its floating debt early next month.

More than 600 delegates from different parts of the State attended a dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night opening the twentieth annual conference of the New York State Association of Boards of Child Welfare. The conference will continue today and tomorrow.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- Jack Honore, barber to Princeton University students for twenty years, has been missing from his home here since May 1, it was disclosed today by his wife. Honore left in his automobile, saying he was going to pass two days at Cape May resting.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economic adviser of the Chase National Bank, testifying today before the Senate Subcommittee on Banking and Currency at a hearing on the administration's Omnibus Banking Bill, told Senators that the present currency of the United States is unsound.

Large delegations from the Daughters of the American Revolution, the United Daughters of the Confederacy and a score of other societies and clubs attended a memorial meeting yesterday afternoon for Mrs. Alfred W. Cochran at the Plaza Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, May 16. -- Denying published reports that he plans to retire at the end of the current Western invasion with the Boston Braves, Babe Ruth tonight indicated he might place himself on the voluntary retired list.

Although bank clearings showed a fair total for the week ended on Wednesday, there was an irregular decline. Twenty-two leading cities showed an aggregate of $4,724,753,000, against $4,991,490,000 for the same week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Here's a week-end trip for surf fishermen. Pack up that old rig, fill the tank in the family flivver with gas and head for one of the inlets or a likely stretch of beach on the Jersey coast, anywhere from Sandy Hook to Cape May.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A committee composed of educators, broadcasting officials, physicians, Federal officers and probably welfare specialists will be assigned by the Federal Communications Commission to study further a plan under which more hours will be allotted to purely educational programs, according to Eugene O. Sykes, chairman of the commission's broadcasting division.

Captain Alfred W. Peterson, who was master of the Ward liner Havana when it went aground Jan. 6 on the Mantanilla reef in the Bahamas, defended his seamanship yesterday afternoon at a hearing before the local steamboat inspectors at the Custom House. The inspectors announced they would withhold a decision until they had studied the testimony.

Two magnificent seventeenth century silk-woven Gobelin tapestries were purchased for $11,000 each by French Co., internationally known art dealers of New York, at the public sale yesterday of items from the art treasures and furnishings of Ophir Hall, the residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid at Purchase, N.Y.

UTICA, N.Y., May 16. -- "The Asiatic policy of Japan is a menace to the peace of the world," Jacob Gould Schurman said tonight at the banquet of the convention of the International Association of Torch Clubs. "It cannot be formulated in any terms which do not involve a challenge to other nations," he added.

The Spring exhibition of student work at the John Reed Club School of Art, 430 Sixth Avenue, will open Sunday evening at 8 o'clock. A program has been arranged, including short talks by artists and by instructors in the school, together with a demonstration of fresco technique.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 16. -- Holy Cross continued unbeaten in college baseball ranks by downing Colgate, 11 to 6, today, although the home team made four sparkling double plays.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 16. -- Scoring three runs in each of the last two innings, Lafayette defeated the Princeton nine, 7 to 3, at University Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Of eighteen followers of Father Divine, New York Negro preacher and self-appointed God, who were taken to Bellevue Hospital for observation, sixteen were found to have well-defined psychoses, Drs. Zuleika Yarrell and Lauretta Bender said in a paper presented today to the American psychiatric Association.
A stoker was killed yesterday morning in a head-on collision between the Argonaut Line freighter Charles H. Cramp and the tanker R.D. Leonard of the Atlantic Refining Company.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Financial statements substantially more detailed than have heretofore been available to investment company stockholders are required under a form for the permanent registration of such corporations ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Human living conditions rather than real estate should be accentuated in any program of city planning and building, speakers declared yesterday at the ninth annual luncheon of the United Neighborhood Houses in the Hotel Commodore.

Retail deliveries made by the United Parcel Service for the week ended May 11 showed a decline of 1 per cent under the same period a year ago, officials of the service announced yesterday. For the four weeks ended May 11 an increase of 1 per cent over 1934 was shown in the figures which cover deliveries for approximately 260 stores in the metropolitan area.

The nineteenth anniversary of the People's Chorus of New York was observed last night at the Waldorf-Astoria in the annual Spring concert, under the direction of the founder and leader of the organization, Lorenzo Camilieri. The assisting artists were Carola Goya, dancer, and Beatrice Burford, harpist.

Five new world air records and nine new American records for speed with load were established early this morning as D.W. Tomlinson and Joseph Bartles zoomed over Floyd Bennett Airport at 1:50:09 A.M., completing a 5,000-kilometer non-stop flight over a closed course in 18 hours 22 minutes 49 seconds.
In sympathy with strength in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved into new high ground again yesterday and closed at a loss of 2 to a gain of 5 points.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges pitched the Tigers into a tie with Washington for fifth place in the American League standing today, holding the Senators to six hits to win, 7 to 2. It was the Tigers' tenth victory in their last thirteen games.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- Senate leaders today denied reports that Vice President Garner was advising enactment of the Patman Bonus Bill over the assured veto, but Mr. Garner, in conformance with his established practice of keeping aloof from controversial issues, refused to comment.

BOSTON, May 16. -- Greeted by booming cannon, shrieking sirens, roaring planes and the cheers of 200,000 Bostonians, Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd was welcomed home today from his second Antarctic venture.

NORWICH, Conn., May 16. -- An assertion was made here tonight by Dr. Stephen J. Maher of New Haven, chairman of the Connecticut Tuberculosis Commission, that he had succeeded in achieving cures in a number of cases of asthma, "where all kinds of injections have failed," by the oral application of the "progeny" of the avian tubercle bacillus.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- The business of deciding whether active life for a Junior Leaguer begins at 40 or ends there was taken up today by more than 300 delegates at an open forum of the national association of that body in convention here.

Polar explorations, old and new, were reviewed yesterday by men who have been actively engaged in this field at a luncheon of the Advertising Club, at 23 Park. Avenue. Russell Owen, who accompanied Admiral Richard E. Byrd on his first expedition to the South Pole, and Captain Bob Bartlett, an associate of Admiral Robert Peary at the North Pole, were the speakers.

PARIS, May 16. -- The Bourse resumed today its trend of falling rentes and rising industrials which has been evident for weeks. Weakness in rentes, with losses of 40 to 70 centimes, was ascribed to general uneasiness over the government's plans to meet the budget deficit.

Andrew McHarg, a loom inspector in a mill in Central Falls, R.I., appeared as a surprise witness before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury yesterday in the trial of the $100,000 slander action brought by William L. Graham, former butler, against Mrs. Henrietta Flick and her daughter, Miss Margot Flick.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The far-reaching effects of expiration of the National Industrial Recovery Act on June 16, should Congress fail by that time to provide for its continuation in some degree, is indicated by the number of organizations that would fall with it unless otherwise extended by Congress.
Frederick Jacobi's "Sacred Service," for cantor, choir and organ, will be sung at 5:20 o'clock this afternoon at Temple Emanu-El.

BERLIN, May 16. -- Germany, as was to be expected, sees nothing but evil in the demonstration of Franco-Soviet intimacy through the Moscow visit of Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister. References in Moscow communiques to an Eastern European pact on the model proposed in Stresa are rejected bitterly or ignored.

ATLANTA, May 16. -- Dry for twenty-seven years, Georgia refused to permit the return of liquor by the slim margin of ninety votes, it was shown tonight on the basis of unofficial returns from yesterday's referendum. It was indicated, however, that an official tabulation will be necessary before the question definitely has been settled.

While police in eight States were searching for her, and her husband, David M. Sandler, young attorney and editor of a financial magazine, was assuring reporters that she would positively return "tonight," Mrs. Janet Modry Sandler, 23 years old, was found dead yesterday in a room in the Hotel Astor.

The same Senate which voted only a few days ago to beat a retreat on NRA has now passed a measure which would take the Government back along another road into much the same territory. This is Senator WAGNER'S "Labor Relations Bill," proposing a new and far more ambitious substitute for the much disputed Section 7a.

A petty criminal with a long record who once, according to the police, wielded the submachine gun with which Vincent Coll had been killed, and a young woman companion were shot to death about 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning on Thirty-ninth Avenue, a short distance north of Queens Boulevard, Long Island City.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 16. -- Meadow Farm, the estate of Governor and Mrs. Lehman in Purchase, and Hilhome, the place of Mr. and Mrs. Percy S. Straus in Port Chester, will be opened to visitors on Saturday afternoon in the second of a series of garden pilgrimages in behalf of the Westchester County Children's Association.

LONDON, May 16. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced tonight for the first time that the British Government was "watching" the currency situation to determine whether the time was ripe for some move toward world stabilization. He words were vague but they were unmistakably friendly to the idea.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- An overwhelming victory for the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, the most drastic labor measure passed by a house of Congress, was won in the Senate today when the measure was passed by a vote of 63 to 12. The vote followed vain efforts by Senator Tydings to amend the bill to prevent what he regarded as coercion of workers by labor unions.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 17(AP). -- The Albany Senators of the International League overcame Newark's lead of six runs and stood off a ninth-inning rally by the Bears to win, 11 to 10, today in the first meeting of the teams this season.

Weakness in foreign government bonds, which on the average were down more than 1/2 point, was the principal feature yesterday of relatively quiet bond trading on the Stock Exchange. United States Government loans were somewhat easier, but there was nothing of unsettlement apparent in this group, which for several days has been less active than it had been.

Formal guard mount and a first aid drill were features of the seventeenth annual Military Field Day of the New York University Reserve Officers' Training Corps at Ohio Field, University Heights, yesterday. More than 3,000 witnessed the exercises, and Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase reviewed the cadet regiment.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on April 30 a consolidated net income of $7,839,851 after all deductions. This was equal to $5.23 a share on 1,499,463 no-par shares of $6 dividend preferred stock.

In a letter of the Yugoslav Consul General published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 15 I am quoted as characterizing an article by G.E.R. Gedye "entirely incorrect." In my letter, published in your issue of May 8, which my colleague purports to cite, I stated, quite to the contrary, that "no exception can be taken against the general trend of the article."
