NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17. -- Donald A. Millard, '35, of Watertown, Conn., received the Daughters of the American Revolution medal for the best student in the Rutgers University Cadet Corps at the annual military field day exercises here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A new form for the registration of voting trust certificates on stock exchanges, under which the securities represented by the certificates must also be registered, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and designated as Form 16.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Offerings of hogs were limited today and it took only fair buying to lift prices as much as 10 cents a hundredweight above yesterday's level. The top price was advanced 5 cents to $9.55, the best paid here since March 12. The day's average also was up 5 cents at $9.30.

PRAGUE, May 17. -- At the instance of the German Government police invaded the premises of the Graphia Publishing Company in Carlsbad, Czechoslovakia, today and confiscated all the copies they could find of the little volume entitled "Deutsche Flusterwitze" [German whispered jokes].
Recently there was published an item about an increase in payrolls throughout the State, as shown by the higher wage figures as reported by the State Compensation Insurance Fund.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17. -- The annual senior ball opened tonight at the Hartford Club the festivities of the Trinity College senior week-end. More than two hundred guests attended the dance. The patronesses were Mrs. Arthur Adams, Mrs. William C. Helmbold, Mrs. Thurman L. Hood, Mrs. Blanchard W. Means, Mrs. Roger H. Motten, Mrs. Remsen B. Ogilby, Mrs. Henry A. Perkins and Mrs. Charles J. Rohr.

Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia, latest influential Democrat to declare against President Roosevelt, asserted last evening that he would do everything in his power to prevent the renomination of the President, predicted that President Roosevelt, if renominated, would be defeated, and indicated a willingness to run for President himself.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Cities throughout the country were urged today by Mayor La Guardia to submit immediately to State highway departments specific programs for highway and street construction and grade-crossing elimination in order that they may obtain their full share of the $400,000,000 allotted yesterday for these purposes by President Roosevelt's Advisory Committee.

It is unlikely that the present minimum charge of $1 a month to individual consumers of electricity will be decreased or eliminated in the new rate schedules now being drawn by the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas system, Robert B. Grove, executive vice president of the New York Edison Company, testified yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

TRENTON, May 17. -- The 1934 law legalizing dog racing with pari-mutuel betting was held unconstitutional today by the Court of Errors and Appeals in a decision that also declared Charles D. Hyman of Atlantic City entitled to a judgment of $4,000 against the Long Branch Kennel Club, Inc.

WAKE ISLAND, May 17 (By Wireless) -- With several thousand miles of water in every direction, Wilkes Island, originally chosen as a Pan American Airways base on the projected United States-Asia airline, has not a drop to drink.

A sudden buying spurt by spot interests in the last trading here yesterday on the Cotton Exchange sent up the July delivery a dollar a bale. In the heavy government operations of the last week July contracts appeared available when purchasing of the new crop was in progress, but yesterday, after fluctuations had held within a range of about 5 pionts for several hours, July tightened and buyers had difficulty in obtaining near-month contracts.

Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald revealed yesterday that, since disclosures several months ago of bail bond abuses in the magistrates' courts, he had established a "blacklist" of professional bondsmen for use by the magistrates in all the courts.

A drive to bring in subscriptions for next season's concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony was announced yesterday by the management, together with the appointment of two committees for the campaign. Arrangements for the drive were made at a meeting held last week at the home of Mrs. Vincent Astor.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 17. -- Led by Frank Bowden and Melvin Partridge, twenty netmen started play in the invitation fixture of the Amackassin Club today, marking the first amateur tournament of the 1935 metropolitan tennis season.

ATHENS, May 17. -- A ban has been placed on monarchist propaganda advocating a forcible restoration in the present election campaign. Venizelists are at the same time forbidden to use suppression of their revolt as electoral campaign material.

BERLIN, May 17. -- The German foreign trade balance for April, just published, closed with another deficit, amounting to 19,100,000 marks, bringing the total deficit for the year thus far to 168,500,000 [the mark was quoted at 40.27 cents yesterday].

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt announced that he would deliver in person his message vetoing the Bonus Bill. He also made known that he would confer with Congressional leaders on the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill.

Both Paraguay and Bolivia are said now to have accepted the terms of peace offered to them time after time in vain. There can hardly be any connection between the cessation of fighting in the Gran Chaco and the efforts now making in Europe to prevent active military operations in Ethiopia.
WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Plans for a White House conference this week-end on the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill were announced by President Roosevelt today at his press conference.

A fairly substantial increase in new financing by States and municipalities is in prospect for next week, according to surveys made yesterday by authorities in this field. The schedule by thirty-nine municipalities involves $14,182,001 face amount of loans.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Disclosure that the Boy Scouts of America maintain a "red flag list" of persons regarded as undesirable influences on youth was made by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt today before the twenty-fifth anniversary meeting of the Scouts National Council.

Commemorating the feat of D.W. Tomlinson in a TWA Douglas transport plane on Thursday in breaking or setting fourteen records for land planes with load, the Sperry Gyro-scope Company of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon placed atop the R.C.A.

Mrs. Anne Sullivan Macy, companion and tutor of Helen Keller, returned yesterday from Doctors Hospital to the Keller home at 71-11 112th Street, Forest Hills, with assurances from her physician that she would be able to see better than ever before as the result of an operation on her left eye three weeks ago.

Two solemn public celebrations will be held in St. Patrick's Cathedral tomorrow to honor John Cardinal Fisher and Sir Thomas More, English martyrs, a few hours after Pope Plus XI, at solemn canonization ceremonies in St. Peter's, Vatican City, will have declared them saints.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

Verdi's "Traviata" will be the opera tonight at the Hippodrome, instead of "Samson et Dalila," as first announced. In the cast will be Annunciata Garrotto, Luigi Ruffini and Rocco Pandiscio. Donizetti's "Lucia" will be sung Sunday night with Ettore Verna, a tenor lately arrived from Italy, cast as Edgardo and Virginia Le Rae as Lucia.

In 1907 prohibition became Statewide in Georgia. Historically the Georgian aversion to strong drink goes further back. No rum was allowed in the Colony in General OGLE-THORPE'S time. It was found impossible in the eighteenth century to make the colonists dry. In the twentieth the same regrettable state of things seems to have continued.

The annual baseball game, Keg-rolling and stein-lifting competition and umpire-calling contest between the detectives of the Bronx homicide squad and the reporters who cover that borough closed at dusk last night at Castle Hill Athletic Park, Castle Hill and Havemeyer Avenues, in Unionport, the Bronx, without a single case of manslaughter, justifiable or otherwise, on the record.
TOKYO, May 17. -- The work of preparing the public for still bigger naval budgets has begun already, well ahead of the usual time.

ROME, May 17. -- News was received from Addis Ababa today that the Italian Minister in taking cognizance of the Abyssinian appointments to the Conciliation Commission made ample reservations, as the Italian Government still is of the opinion the Abyssinian conciliators should be Abyssinians.

Terence J. McManus, representing J. Richard Davis, counsel for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, fought for more than an hour yesterday to induce General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig to dismiss a subpoena duces tecum served on Mr. Davis to produce his checks and office records before the grand jury investigating the policy racket.

Three choral singing groups from Public School 91 on Central Avenue, Glendale, Queens, won first places in three of the seven classes for the finals of the public school choral contests held yesterday at Town Hall.
Prominent persons sailing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Ile de France include:

PARIS, May 17. -- A decree restricting the importation of electric refrigerators and similar products was published today in the Journal Officiel. American manufacturers have greatly increased their exports of refrigerators to France this year and it is assumed French competitors forced the government to act.

Burton Hendrick, editor of "The Letters of Walter Hines Page." has written a book called "The Lees of Virginia," which Little, Brown will publish in October. It tells the story of the family of which John Adams said, "The Lees have produced more men of merit than any American family," and attempts to place them in American history.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A favorable report on the administration's far-reaching Social Security Bill was voted today by the Senate Finance Committee after a number of changes had been made in the bill as passed by the House.

With a bid of par plus a premium of $300 for securities bearing interest at 1.35 per cent, the National City Bank and its associates yesterday won the award of $11,100,000 of City of New York obligations. The Chase National Bank and associates bid a premium of $555 for 1 3/4 per cent obligations.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- With the Senate and the House unable to resolve their differences on the extension of the NRA, it became known today that in the next six weeks there would probably be an exodus of executives from the Recovery Administration.

Joseph L. Steinmetz was so jealous of his 17-year-old bride of a fortnight that he objected to her dancing with a 70-year-old man, the State established yesterday in his trial before General Sessions Judge Nott and a jury on a charge of shooting her to death.

The Reichstag will soon hold another of its historic convocations. There is nothing quite like it in the world today for brevity or dispatch. A Reichstag session under HITLER consists of several hundred men in swastika armlets leaping to their feet with thunderous salute when the Leader comes in.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Union Pacific Railroad Company will accept the Interstate Commerce Commission order of Jan. 26, 1933, for the acquisition of control of four roads by lease. These are the Oregon Short Line Railroad Company.

THERE was some discussion as to whether or not Steve O'Neill, the stout coach of the Cleveland Indians, played the accordion. It was decided to have this important matter settled by a man who should know, namely, Steve O'Neill. About noon yesterday the trail led to the hostelry where the Cleveland Indians are quartered, but there the pursuit failed.

An interesting aspect of our government's silver-buying policy, brought into the limelight by Secretary Morgenthau, is the beneficial effect which it has exerted on exports and employment. It is common knowledge that if we want to sell abroad we must buy, and in 1934 we bought foreign silver to the amount of $86,000,000 and thereby supplied our foreign customers with dollar exchange to that added amount.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP). -- Judge Elisha H. Brewster of the United States District Court ruled tonight that the Federal license for the Greater Boston milk market, established under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, is void and unenforceable.

PARIS, May 17. -- The strike of the French Line crews at Havre entered its third day tonight, despite government threats of sanctions. The liner Champlain remained at her dock. With the new Normandie deserted by her crew, it is becoming hourly more problematical whether she can leave for New York on her maiden voyage on May 29.

LONDON, May 17. -- Great Britain has announced plans to develop oil fields in the United Kingdom with the hope of freeing herself from dependence upon American and Russian sources for the supplies she needs to keep her fleet in operation in time of war.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade today showed the effect of the short covering of the two previous days, aggressive support being lacking following yesterday's rally. At no time were futures as high as yesterday's final prices, and the close was at the bottom at net losses of 2 1/4 to 2 5/8 cents a bushel, July leading.

With one of its finest entries in years, the fourteenth annual hunts meeting of the West Hills Racing Association will be held today on the estate of T.F. White at West Hills, L.I. The card of five races will start at 2:15 P.M.

CINCINNATI, May 17. -- The Giants opened their first invasion of the West today with hopes of making it with a grand flourish. But they swerved slightly from their course and instead of passing the Reds, Colonel Bill Terry's finely geared machine all but wrecked itself.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of Miss Natalie Couch of Nyack, Rockland County, as a member of the executive committee of the State committee to succeed John C. Clark of Binghamton, who resigned.

Argument to prevent liquidation of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was waged yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler by counsel for the company's board of directors and 20,000 stockholders in opposition to the application of the State Superintendent of Insurance, who asked permission to end the life of the company.

Out of 10,000 boys and girls of the Children's Aid Society's club centres throughout the city, Frances Bologna, 13 years old, of the Avenue B Girls Club, and Frank Dixon, 15, of the Harlem Centre Boys Club, were judged the healthiest at the closing ceremonies of the society's Milk Week yesterday afternoon.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 17. -- America's contingent of golfers, headed by suntanned Lawson Little, began to look around for dog sleds and parkas as a regular Arctic blizzard raged this morning, blanketing the Royal Lytham course, where Little will begin the defense of his British amateur championship Monday, with an inch of snow.
BERLIN, May 17. -- Trading on the oerse was mixed today, with a tendency to strength still predominant.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Government ownership of all stock in Federal Reserve Banks and centralization of credit facilities in a nonpolitical independent government agency, presumably to act as a sort of supreme court of finance and banking, was advocated today by Secretary Morgenthau as he appeared before the Senate Banking Subcommittee to testify on the Banking Reform Bill.

MEXICO, D.F., May 17. -- By winning the opening two singles matches today, the United States gained a commanding lead over Mexico in the finals of the North American Zone Davis Cup series. Only one more victory is needed by the invading squad here for it to earn the right to go to Europe and compete in the interzone final.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, May 17 (AP). -- Only the possibility of presidential clemency stood tonight between four Nazis accused of plotting to return the Memel territory to Germany and death before a firing squad.

This is the open season for school shows to blossom out in number. The annual exhibition of student work at the New York School of Fine and Applied Art (Parson), 2,239 Broadway, at Eightieth Street, opened yesterday and will continue through Monday evening.

The racing string of the late Sylvester W. Labrot was dispersed in the paddock at Belmont Park yesterday for a total of $59,750, an amount which brought great satisfaction to Humphrey S. Finney, manager of the Labrot Farm. The Fasig-Tipton Company conducted the sale, at which thirty head were disposed of.

Holders of $6,482,000 of Portland (Ore.) General Electric Company first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds due on July 1 next have been asked to extend the bonds for fifteen years to July 1, 1950, at the present rate of interest without change in the existing senior-lien position of the bonds.

ST. PAUL, May 17. -- Five defendants in the Edward G. Bremer kidnapping case were convicted and two were acquitted by a jury in United States District Court here today. Those convicted face maximum sentences of life imprisonment.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 17. -- One in every three school and college students who received tuberculin tests in surveys conducted throughout the State were found to be infected with tuberculosis, it was reported at the annual clinical session of the workers conference of the New Jersey Tuberculosis League here today.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, and Harry Hansen, literary critic, spoke last night over a nation-wide network of the NBC at a reception to signalize publication of Mr. Smith's book, "The Citizen and His Government."

The board of trustees of the Edison Electric Institute on Thursday unanimously adopted a resolution opposing the passage of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill and authorizing the distribution to members of a detailed statement on the aims of the legislation, alleging that "the true purpose of the bill is to socialize the business of providing the homes of the nation with electric light and power."

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- A threat of a "crack-down" by the middle-class group against those who put forward the legislation for abolishing public utility holding companies came today from Hugh S. Magill, president of the American Federation of Utility Investors.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- The Curtis Publishing Company has notified advertising agents that it is discontinuing the 10 per cent discount on advertising rates of The Saturday Evening Post, effective with the issue of Jan. 18 next. This means that beginning on that date advertisers will pay 10 per cent more for Post copy than at any time during the last three years.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 17. -- Mrs. M.E. Risley of the Echo Lake Country Club today scored an 83 to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Crestmont Golf Club. Mrs. Risley reached the turn in 43 and returned in 40, finishing the last three holes in even pars to top her clubmate, Mrs. A.D. Faxon, who posted an 84.

The share market yielded yesterday most of its moderate improvement of the day before, leading stocks closing irregularly lower but with a fair degree of steadiness. During the first hour of business on the Stock Exchange the trading pace presaged an even livelier market than that of the day before when transactions reached 2,400,000, but when the taking of profits had reached sizable proportions, buying enthusiasm was dampened.

RIGA, Latvia, May 17. -- After sitting since Monday the Lithuanian Supreme Court at Kaunas upheld on appeal the death sentences recently imposed on four Memel Nazis for high treason. All prison sentences except that of Baron von der Ropp were reduced from eight to six years.

The annual convention of the Associated Stock Exchanges, comprising twenty-one of the largest markets in the country, will be held next Monday and Tuesday in the Chase Hotel, St. Louis, it was announced yesterday.

Surrogate James A. Foley in a decision yesterday denied the executors and trustees of the $400,000 estate of Ernest B. Muller the right to substitute common stocks for legal investments now held in the estate. The court held that "any change in the class of legal investments must be the subject of legislative and not judicial action."

Outstanding acts of heroism performed last year by eight firemen have won for them the department medals for valor awarded annually, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday. Two other medals were awarded for departmental service.

Private Silas King, United States Army, is a deckhand on the army ferry General Charles H. Humphreys, plying between Governors Island and Manhattan, but he hails from Coaldale, Pa., and has killed his share of Pennsylvania rattle snakes.

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP). -- With Larry French pitching shut-out ball, the Cubs today turned back the Phillies, first of the Eastern invaders, 5 to 0. French allowed seven hits and was at his best with men on in scoring his second victory of the season.

ATLANTA, May 17 (AP). -- A lead of 227 votes for the drys was recorded tonight in the latest recheck of returns from Wednesday's repeal referendum in Georgia. Twenty-two counties still had not reported to Secretary of State John B. Wilson, but unofficial returns from these counties were rechecked.

Out of a bag of comparatively familiar tricks of the amusement trade, the gentlemen responsible for the new "Summer revue" at the Paradise Restaurant have fetched -- oddly enough -- a pleasingly novel and entertaining floor show, which had its premiere on Wednesday evening.

The section of the Doughton Social Security Bill, which proposes a grant of $24,750,000 to the States for aid to dependent children during the next fiscal year, was discussed yesterday afternoon by speakers at the twentieth annual conference of the New York State Association of Boards of Child Welfare.

Manhattan forgot its happy faculty of snapping winning freaks yesterday and, with it, lost a ball game. A robust hitting Holy Cross nine spent an afternoon rattling the fences at Manhattan Field, tamed the quite talented Xavier Rescigno and marched off with its tenth victory in as many starts by an 8-4 score.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 17. -- The senior crew won the interclass competition at Wellesley Float Night this evening for the fourth successive year and thereby received the Athletic Association Cup as its permanent possession. Miss Margaret Connors of Bridgeport, president of the association, made the award.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A revised edition of the recently invalidated Railroad Retirement Act was introduced in the House today, and the twenty-one standard railway brotherhoods threw their full strength behind it in a final effort to win their members from open advocacy of government ownership and operation of railroads.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17. -- Experts of Westchester County and of the State and Federal governments have been unable to ascertain definitely the cause of the pastry cream poisoning which recently brought illness to more than 1,000 residents of Westchester and neigiboring areas, County Health Commissioner Matthias Nicoll Jr. announced today.

LONDON, May 11. -- People who study maps and books of reference and who know a great deal about rainfall and water levels in Northeast Africa shake their heads when the chances of an Italian campaign against Abyssima are discussed. Military experts shake their heads, too.

Federal work-relief projects in this city will give employment to 250,000 persons when the Federal program gets into full swing, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday on his return from Washington, where the $4,000,000,000 Federal fund is being allocated.

WARSAW, May 17. -- Amid the most impressive pageantry Central Europe has witnessed since President Paul von Hindenburg of Germany was laid to rest at Tannenberg, Poland sent her military hero, Marshal Josef Pilsudski, from his nation's capital today to his last resting place in Cracow.

On the second day at his desk as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Edward Johnson let it be known yesterday that he plans to go abroad probably in June, in search of new artists for the company.

Grace Moore, opera and motion-picture star, received the annual gold medal fellowship award of the Society of Arts and Sciences at its fifty-third annual dinner last night at the Ritz-Carlton. The award, which previously has gone to such persons as Thomas A. Edison, John Philip Sousa, Albert A. Michaelson and Harlow Shapley, was "for conspicuous achievement in raising the standard of cinema entertainment."

YONKERS, N.Y., May 17. -- The police of five bureaus in three States cooperated in rushing a package of serum from Philadelphia to this city early yesterday in an effort to save the life of a 13-year-old boy suffering from an unusual blood infection.

The recent appointment of Richard Whitney, former president of the Stock Exchange, and Nelson I. Asiel to the Exchange's special committee on bonds has increased the importance of this group and has given rise to reports that it is considering seriously some interesting innovations to bring business now transacted over the counter to the floor of the Exchange.

Replete with bands, a barnyard, peanuts and popcorn, clowns and marionettes, Greenwich Village's annual festival, this year closely approximating good old village fair, opened yesterday with a Fifth Avenue parade and its own animal show.
Revised legislation intended to put news stands on a business basis in the city was discussed at a public hearing yesterday before the general welfare committee of the Board of Aldermen in City Hall.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 17. -- More than 1,000 alumni of Lawrenceville School returned to the campus here today to celebrate the 125th anniversary of the founding of the school in conjunction with the annual alumni week-end festivities.

LONDON, May 17. -- Jane Cowl and Reginald Lawrence, joint authors of "Hervey House" under the single pseudonym C.R. Avery, have attempted, in this play, produced tonight at His Majesty's Theatre, to do for the English family what Noel Coward did for the empire in "Cavalcade."

The Harvard varsity crew will meet Columbia and M.I.T. on the Harlem River this evening at 7 o'clock in a race over a one-and-three-quarter-mile course. It will be the first appearance of a Crimson eight in this city in more than ten years, and rowing authorities believe it will be a successful invasion for Harvard.

A celebrated landscape by Thomas Gainsborough entitled "A View in Suffolk," brought the highest price at yesterday's auction of art treasures at Ophir Hall, the residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid at Purchase, N.Y. It was bought by Lenygon Morant, Inc., decorators, of this city, for $6,700.

Horace Mann School's unbeaten baseball team downed Poly Prep, 3 to 1, on the latter's field in Brooklyn yesterday for its seventh victory of the season and its fourth Eastern Private Schools League triumph. The defeat was the first for Poly Prep in eight contests.

In reporting a net income of $2,477,307, or 19 cents a share for the three months ended on March 31, the Pennsylvania Railroad set aside $1,746,648 for liabilities under the railway pension law, which has been declared unconstitutional. Release of these funds would bring the ratio to 32 cents a share.

An application for a mandamus directing the Commissioner of Public Welfare to furnish city children of school age suitable clothing, food, medical attention and other necessities to enable them to attend classes was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.
Each passing day brings additional evidence of the arrival of game fish in near-by coastal waters. The latest species to be reported is the Boston mackerel.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Between 7,000 and 8,000 men will be employed at the peak of work this year on the task of "harnessing the moon and the ocean tides" through the $86,284,000 Passamaquoddy (Me.) work-relief project to produce electricity for human use, Major Philip B. Fleming, chief of army engineers in charge of the job, declared today.

It is both a temperate and a sound criticism that the Business Advisory Council, President ROOSEVELT'S "contact agency with private industry," has made of the pending Social Security Bill. Expressing sympathy for the broad objectives of the measure, the council finds that some important changes are highly desirable.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Plans of Armour Co. to refund $50,000,000 of bonds into obligations with lower coupons were revealed today with the issuance of a call for a special stockholders' meeting of its subsidiary, Armour Co. of Delaware, on June 10 to vote on an amendment to the mortgage indenture.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- Close to 20,000 cap and millinery workers in New York City have been instructed in a union order to cease work next Thursday at 3 P.M. to participate in the first of a series of demonstrations throughout the nation to demand an "improved" National Industrial Recovery Act and the enactment of the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill and the Connery Thirty-Hour Work-Week Bill.

PARIS, May 17. -- A sign of public unrest over the monetary situation was shown today when the stock market boomed for equities and fell for the government's bonds as it has not done for ten years. In recognition of the change in the situation, Finance Minister Louis Germain-Martin issued the following statement to the press after a Cabinet council this morning:

Signs of the rising flight of capital from France accumulated here yesterday. The franc fell to 6.58 1/4 cents, the lowest price since April 5, and was offered in the futures market at 10 1/2 points discount from this figure.

Five years ago, under the auspices of the Noise Abatement Commission, an energetic campaign was conducted to moderate the city's din. The commission accomplished something. It curbed the loud-speakers for a time. It secured the cooperation of the masters of harbor tugs accustomed before to whistle to their hearts' content.

BOSTON, May 17 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell topped the 43-year-old Sad Sam Jones in thirteen-inning pitching duel today to give the Red Sox a 2-1 victory over the pace-setting Chicago club before a crowd of 9,400 that assembled to welcome the Croninmen after their successful Western tour.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 17. -- This hill-encircled college town was filling rapidly tonight with the fore-runners of tomorrow's crowds, coming here for Cornell's annual Spring Day. The feature of the sports program will be the most interesting boat race the season has yet produced.
ALBANY, May 17. -- Governor Lehman almost entirely ignored the wishes of Postmaster General James A. Farley in acting today on the Nassau County ripper bills.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- The Pennsylvania varsity defeated the alumni in the tenth inning today on Franklin Field, 8 to 7, when "Shorty" O'Donnell scored the winning run on the squeeze play.
RENO, Nev., May 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Lois Clarke de Ruyter Spreckels won her second Nevada divorce today, this time from Adolph B. Spreckels. She would not comment on reports that she would remarry soon.

BELGRADE, May 17. -- Twelve-year-old King Peter of Yugoslavia is beginning to think for himself. While his great-aunt, the Infanta Beatrice of Spain, was recently visiting Dowager Queen Marie, the conversation turned on the Spanish revolution and the expulsion of King Alfonso.

There is a strong contemporary New Deal in poetry, especially in England. Poetry is progressive. Poetry is being rejuvenated, like the Republican party. The singers are so many that it is hard to keep track of them. Mr. E.E. CUMMINGS, an accomplished artist in more than one art, may be reckoned among the members of the Old School by this time; but it is good to find him ever faithful to the destruction of capitalism.

One of the most interesting renewals of the famous Metropolitan Handicap looms for this afternoon at Belmont Park, with King Saxon and Discovery named to clash in a field of ten, each of which seems to have a chance to triumph.
BERLIN, May 17. -- Germany's newest naval weapon -- swift, deadly "vest-pocket" torpedo boats as revolutionary as her "vest-pocket" battleships -- was revealed today.

The city, business men and the Poultry Code Authority joined yesterday for a new onslaught on New York's poultry racket, which was revealed as having been revived at a cost to the public of almost $10,000,000 last year. Speaking for the police, Commissioner Valentine urged merchants to slug racketeers and promised to help them get revolvers.

Dr. Alexander O. Gettler, city toxicologist, announced yesterday that a four-day test had shown no thallium sulphate, a poison, in a can of cocoa taken from the home of Frederick Gross at 179 Eldert Street, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, May 17. -- Garbed in the habit of the Vincentian order, of whose Cologne chapter she was secretary, Sister Wernera, born Katherina Wiedenhoefer, 42 years old, stood with bowed head in the dock in the lower criminal court in Moabit jail today as she received a five-year sentence of penal servitude for violation of the German laws governing the transfer of money abroad.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17. -- It's a good thing the Garden City Golf Club is just old-fashioned enough to frown on the Calcutta pool idea, which is part and parcel of almost every golf tournament held these days.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt will go to the Capitol early next week to deliver in person his message vetoing the Bonus Bill. This will be the first occasion in history that a President has journeyed the historic mile down Pennsylvania Avenue to utter his arguments against a vetoed bill.

Relatives, friends and former associates of Mrs. Charles Cary Rumsey, an organizer of the Community Councils of National Defense and at the time of her death last December chairman of the National Consumers Board in Washington, joined yesterday in honoring her memory at exercises in Central Park.

The average American murderer is native born, a laborer or factory worker, and has hardly more than an elementary education, according to the results of studies made by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company statisticians, the company announced yesterday. The statisticians, according to the announcement, were able to paint only a "shadowy" picture of the slayer, but gathered, nevertheless, a considerable amount of data.

Net profit of the Columbia Pictures Corporation for the nine months ended on March 30 amounted to $1,572,720 after Federal taxes and all other charges. This was equivalent, after dividend requirements on the $3 convertible preference stock, to $8.62 a share on 177,933 shares of common stock outstanding.

JOLIETTE, Que., May 17 (Canadian Press). -- The eighteenth century manor of the Seigneur de Joliette, long since converted into the convent of the congregation of Notre Dame, was destroyed by a fire today with the loss of three lives.
ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, AT SEA, May 17. -- Unusual interest in the naval manoeuvres now approaching a climax in the Northeastern Pacific is being shown this year by the War Department.

GENEVA, May 17. -- Much satisfaction is expressed in international labor circles that the United States will be represented by a complete delegation to the annual International Labor Conference, beginning June 4. There is much regret, however, that the continuance of Congress prevents both Secretary Perkins and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, from coming as they had planned.

The $100,000 slander suit brought by William L. Graham, former butler, against Mrs. Henrietta Flick and her daughter, Miss Margot Flick, was dismissed yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

The many friends of Superintendent Van Schaick will be grateful for your recent editorial on his administration. Some of us who are responsible for the management of insurance companies and have been in close contact with him during these trying years have found it difficult at times to refrain from rushing to his defense when attempts were being made to weaken his grasp on the mortgage situation.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 17. -- The representatives of the Westchester Country Club won the women's Westchester-Fairfield team golf championship for the second successive year at the Tamarack Country Club today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 17. -- Knight Bachelor, high stepping brown gelding, owned and shown by Miss Judy King of Atlanta, Ga., won the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall $1,000 championship harness horse stake tonight, the most sought after prize during the third day of the Atlantic City horse show.

The hope of recovering $30,000,000 of Insull collateral from five New York banks and the General Electric Company was rested yesterday in behalf of 23,000 Insull debenture holders on a closing argument in the Federal court here based on the distinction between a bank and the bankers who compose it.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 17. -- The Lakeville Golf and Country Club's women's class A team earned the right to represent the Long Island district as the interclub matches in this area came to an end today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Most commodity futures were easy yesterday in light trading. Coffee was somewhat stronger. On the cash markets, tin, cotton, silk and dairy products advanced, while all the grains, coffee, cocoa, lard and rubber declined.

ALBANY, May 17. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Fold-Crawford "fair trade" bill in a surprise move as he completed action on 140 bills in the final rush to dispose of the last of the "thirty-day bills."

DUBLIN, May 17. -- The transport tie-up of eleven weeks ended tonight when the trolley and omnibus workers accepted new terms from the Department of Industry and Commerce under which the lines agree to pay increased wages to all grades of workers, the increases totaling $200,000 annually.

STOCKHOLM, May 17 (London Times dispatch). -- A German press description of the visit to Sweden of Rudolf Hess, Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's deputy as leader of the Nazi party, as an outstanding success has been received here with surprise tempered with amusement.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP). -- The Athletics opened their home stand against the invading Western clubs today with an 8-to-0 triumph over the Browns. The victory lifted the Mackmen to seventh place and dropped the Browns into the cellar.
Johnny Allen is suffering from a blistered index finger on his good right hand. Otherwise he might have had a shutout over the Cleveland Indians yesterday at the Yankee Stadium.

LONDON, May 17. -- Last night's speech by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, was regarded here today as the first sign that the British and American Governments would soon be feeling their way toward a tentative agreement of stabilization of currencies.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- President Roosevelt expects to sign early next week orders for the $1,000,000,000 work relief allotments recommended to him yesterday. The President said at his press conference he expected to get the orders over the week-end for final study.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- After two of the loudest negative voice votes heard in years had been registered against proposals to outlaw Congressional nepotism in clerk hire and to abolish the mileage allowance of members of Congress, an appropriation of $20,357,165 for running the Federal legislative establishment was passed today by the House as the last of the routine supply bills to be acted on by this body.

More than 200 members of the Drama League of New York saw Katharine Cornell receive the new Delia Austrian Medal yesterday for the performance they had voted to be the most distinguished of this theatrical season. The award was made at the league's annual Spring luncheon at the Central Park casino.

Public offerings of new bonds this week amounted to $10,139,000, two State issues for a total of $4,000,000, which were placed on the market yesterday, lifting the total slightly above the previous week's figure of $9,461,000. All the financing consisted of tax-exempt issues.

MUNICH, May 17. -- Another American citizen was taken off to prison here today by the secret political police. He is Charles Nisselbeck, 35 years old, who was born in Germany but naturalized in 1931 in New York City and who has been carrying on an import and export business here for about a year.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Compensation of $100,500 was paid in 1934 to R.W. Woodruff, president of the Coca Cola Company, its registration statement has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission. Harold Hirsch, vice president, got $46,450, including legal fees, and Harrison Jones, also a vice president, $30,395.
ALBANY, May 17. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill creating the Wendel Foundation to handle the real estate left by Miss Ella Wendel and her sister, Mrs. Rebecca Wendel Swope.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 17. -- The annual military ball of Rutgers University was attended by more than 400 couples in the new gymnasium here tonight. The weekend program, which began this afternoon with the exhibition of the Rutgers unit of the R.O.T.C., will include a baseball game with Lafayette tomorrow afternoon and fraternity house dances in the evening.

No attractions are formally scheduled to leave Broadway this evening. Lest that sound too optimistic, however, the chances are that "To See Ourselves" will take its delayed departure from the Ethel Barrymore, where it was slated to expire a week ago tonight.

Colby College (once Waterville College, Waterville, Me.) today commemorates one who a century ago in defending the freedom of the press "forgot himself into immortality" -- ELIJAH PARISH LOVEJOY, the Abolitionist editor, publisher, teacher and preacher. In doing so, this little college, which has given thirty-nine presidents to colleges, nearly twice as many missionaries and a "notable list of editors," proclaims the "free press" as the theme of the day.

An extensive survey of all industrial operations in New York City is being made for the more effective placement of job applicants by relief workers of the Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the ERB.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- After Detroit had rallied to tally seven runs in the seventh inning and tied up the game Washington scored three runs on Buddy Myers's double in the same frame to whip the Tigers, 10 to 8, today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Further evidence of the movement by corporations to refund callable securities at lower interest rates in the present easy money market appeared today when the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago applied for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of an issue of $29,500,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4% per cent bonds, Series H, to mature April 1, 1965.

The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler denying the Italian Government the right to file a complaint for $100,336.63 damages against the international committee of the Young Men's Christian Association.

On May 22, 23 and 24 the Nearly New Shop, 913 Eighth Avenue, will hold three-day sale of Spring clothing for men, women and children. The proceed will go to the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, the Berkshire Industrial Farm the Cribside Committee of Babies Hospital, the Masters School Day Nursery the Winfield Day Nursery and the New York Diet Kitchen Association.

NANKING, China, May 17. -- Praising the American, British and Japanese Governments' decisions to raise their legations in China to embassies, and noting China's like action in those countries, a Foreign Office spokesman today especially commended Foreign Minister Kori Hirota of Japan.

Major Frank Hanscom, a member of the State Parole Board, denied at Auburn Prison in Auburn, N.Y., yesterday that friends of Owen Madden, the racketeer, had offered a bribe of $1,000,000 three years ago for Madden's release if he was returned to Sing Sing as a parole violator.
ALBANY, May 17. -- Governor Lehman approved two bills today adding four municipal court justices in the Bronx and one in Queens.

The employment of "too much common sense rather than the needed uncommon sense" in the education of school children was held to be partly responsible for the fact that 300,000 children appear yearly in the juvenile courts and that 262,000 are retarded in the New York City public schools, by Dr. Ira S. Wile in an address at the Chanin Auditorium last night.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., May 17 (AP). -- Aching muscles, weary feet and sunburn were forgotten today as an unbroken line of thirty-eight members of the "dietitians' derby" marched into this village, tired but triumphant at attaining their goal after 325 miles of tramping on a diet consisting principally of cracked wheat, raisins, honey and brown sugar.

PITTSBURGH, May 17. -- Last night Manager Pie Traynor predicted at a fan meeting that his Pirates would "start clicking soon." So today Prophet Pie was proved without honor in his own country when Casey Stengel's Dodgers romped away with the second game of the series, 7 to 1.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, former tennis champion, left tonight for England and an expected comeback attempt on the courts at Wimbledon.

The demonstration described in THE TIMES which took place during the parade of the junior military and naval organizations of Greater New York was indeed a remarkable demonstration of patriotism and Americanism. Especially noteworthy was the spirit of fair play manifested by the participants, obviously the consequence of military training and discipline.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Proposals of a committee of the Chicago Curb Exchange to liquidate the seats of members desiring to withdraw were unanimously adopted by the members today. The asset value as of June 1 will be the basis.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Newark Airport will be among the first twelve metropolitan fields on which the Bureau of Air Commerce will install the new blind landing equipment now being constructed by the Army Air Corps at Dayton, Eugene L. Vidal, director of the bureau, said today.

PARIS, May 17. -- Foreign Minister Pierre Laval's visit to Moscow has produced in France much the same confusion of opinion and controversy as did his famous visit to President Hoover in Washington. On one side it is greeted as an immense success.
" The Battle," disguised under a new title, "Thunder in the East," begins a revival engagement today at the Globe. The cast is headed by Charles Boyer, Merle Oberon and John Loder.

SALEM, N.H., May 17. -- A.G. Vanderbilt's Bachelor Dinner won the handicap for a purse of $1,500 that featured the racing at Rockingham Park today. The handsome 3-year-old bay colt conquered the 3-2 favorite, Happy Knot, in a five and a half furlong sprint.

The Treasury announced yesterday that it has stepped up to $100,000,000 its weekly offering of short-term discount bills. For some time it has held such offers to $50,000,000 weekly, and relied on the sale of the new "baby bonds" to bring in such additional funds as were required to meet its immediate needs.

ST. LOUIS, May ,17 (AP). -- Manager Frankie Frisch's search for a fourth starting pitcher again met failure today as the Braves bombarded rookie Ed Heusser, continued the attack on three other hurlers and defeated the Cardinals, 7 to 1.

Almost a year after the mysterious disappearance of Mrs. Florence Neacy Paul, Flushing, Queens, divorcee, Patrolman Frank L. Schultz of the Flushing precinct, the last person to have been seen with her, was ordered dismissed yesterday from the department by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 17 (AP). -- How a Methodist minister befriended a hitch-hiker who robbed him of his money and abducted him in his own automobile, only to be "taken in" a second time, was revealed here this afternoon with the arrest of Robert G. Thornton, 20, of Binghamton.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 17. -- General Pedro Altamirano, nicknamed Pedron, who was reported assassinated with his two sons almost two years ago, is now said by the Nicaraguan National Guard to be very much alive.

For the first time in the history of Protestant missionary activity in this country a definite agreement between various denominations has been entered into to discontinue all competitive mission work, it was announced yesterday by the Home Missions Council, 287 Fourth Avenue.

The Paulist Choristers, conducted by Father Finn, gave their Spring festival concert in the Town Hall last night. A large audience applauded a program of special interest to teachers and music supervisors in the schools because of the manner in which it illustrated the employment of children's voices and alto or counter-tenor parts.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 17. -- An American educator, Pitman Benjamin Potter, today was nominated by Ethiopia as one of her two members of the conciliation commission in the dispute with Italy. The other member is Albert de la Pradelle, a French lawyer.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Hailing the verdict in the Bremer kidnapping trial as "highly gratifying," Attorney General Cummings declared tonight that the result was "a renewed illustration of the value of persistence and tenacity in following up crimes of this character."

Irregular trade movements of recent weeks gradually are giving way to a more uniform upward trend, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Settlement of labor difficulties has permitted industrial operations to hold to a steadier level, and buying in wholesale markets is on the increase, as Summer requirements press more strongly for attention, the agency states.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP). -- The kind of worry that puts many persons in hospitals, even gives them angina pectoris pains, and sometimes hastens death, was analyzed for the American Psychiatric Association today by Dr. H. Flanders Dunbar of the Columbia University School of Medicine.
BERLIN, May 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
The New York of the Hamburg-American Line arrived yesterday with a number of rare birds and animals from Abyssinia for various zoos in this country.
Let me take a whack at Edwin J. Jones. He is the guy who, in your paper, suggests that the government tax bachelors and maidens over the age of 25.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Continuing today their efforts before the Board of Tax Appeals to show that Andrew W. Mellon placed a proper 1913 value of $500 per share on the structural steel stock whose worth is in issue, his attorneys called to the stand today A.B. Hossack, an appraiser, who testified that Mr. Mellon's estimate represented a fair market value of the securities.

The population of the Barrett Park Zoo in West New Brighton, S.I., was increased yesterday by the addition to its monkey colony of a nine-ounce newcomer. The baby, a male, is the first monkey ever born in the zoo. Both he and Icky, the mother, a rhesus Indian monkey, were reported in the pink of condition last night.

The wedding plans of Victor Wendelin, 29 years old, were interrupted yesterday when the Kings County Grand Jury indicted him for robbery and kidnapping in connection with a Brooklyn theatre hold-up, and police from Eden, N.Y., sought to question him about a bank hold-up in that city.

OVERBROOK, Pa., May 17. -- The Philadelphia women's lacrosse team began its bid for national honors today in convincing fashion, as it defeated New York, 15 -- 1, on the field of the Sacred Heart Academy.

MOSCOW, May 17 (AP). -- Reports from Teheran, capital of Iran (Persia), to the Tass (Soviet) News Agency tonight, said earthquakes which, during two months, had taken a toll of perhaps a thousand lives were continuing to spread death and destruction.

A mammoth rock, weighing about fifty tons, broke away from the Palisades fifty feet above the main highway leading from the 125th Street ferry at 5 P.M. yesterday and splintered on the roadway a split second after automobiles had passed in both directions.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Word that President Roosevelt would deliver his bonus veto message in person caught Congressional leaders unaware. They set immediately about arranging for the joint session of the House and Senate before which the President will appear, probably on Monday.

Enough thallium sulphate to cause death was found in the organs of Frederick J. Gross Jr., 9-year-old son of the crippled bookkeeper, who is charged with poisoning his wife and four of his children, according to a report made to District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan yesterday by Dr. Alexander O. Gettler, city toxicologist.

About 1,800 years ago, in the days of Trajan, the Roman world stretched from the hills of Scotland to the mountains of India, from the Danube to the Sahara and from the Rock of Gibraltar to the Black Sea and the Caucasus. In that vast territory under the Pax Romana lived Britons and Babylonians, Libyans and Latins, Greeks and Gauls and many other peoples.

The New Jersey Bankers Association will hold its annual convention on the last three days of this week in the Ambassador Hotel, Atlantic City. The program will give particular emphasis to monetary and banking problems and the possibilities of inflation.

While the code, association and business executives who will descend on Washington Wednesday will make a determined effort to have the NRA continued for two years, they might be willing to accept a compromise extension for one year, provided that price-fixing is clearly defined and the "intrastate" provision of the Clark resolution is amended, it was indicated here yesterday.

MR FORD'S titles are always too good to be forgotten. His readers will easily remember a novel of this title, written in Carcassonne in 1910, when Mr. Ford was Mr. Hueffer. It was well liked and went into a popular edition and even, as lately as 1931, into a pocket edition.

It is saddening to see you "running with the pack" in condemning the Pulitzer Prize award to "The Old Maid." * * * Can you honestly believe an unacknowledged daughter with an unacknowledged father is a so much simpler problem to its mother in 1930 than it was in 1880?

The twenty-four boys making the University Settlement's practical study of the crime problem learned yesterday from Irving W. Halpern, chief probation officer of the Court of General Sessions, that only 20 per cent of criminals convicted in the court win probation and they are held strictly accountable for their future acts.

ALBANY, May 18. -- Governor Lehman declared today that he would not issue a call for an extraordinary session of the Legislature to consider reapportionment of the State Senate and Assembly districts and of the State's seats in Congress unless he was assured that there would be enough votes to pass measures providing for a change in the present set-up. Thus far, he has no such assurance.

While reports on retail trade showed a slight improvement last week, activity in the wholesale markets here was not up to expectations, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

BUENOS AIRES, May 4. -- The United States has at last recaptured its lost leadership in the South American markets after steadily losing ground for nearly five years. The speed and huge volume of the American come-back make it one of the most remarkable trade recoveries in recent years.

LONDON. BOOK publishing has always been a more or less venturesome business, but lately its risks seem to have been intensified. Great care is evidently needed nowadays to avoid coming into conflict with the law of the land.

PREVIOUS comment on murals executed under the direction of the College Art Association has appeared from time to time in these columns. A few days ago another tour was made, among the places visited being the Brooklyn Technical High School, Green-point Hospital, Seward Park High School, Woodside Library and the new, not yet opened, Samuel Gompers High School in the Bronx.
RYE, N.Y., May 18. -- Miss Lorna Whittelsey scored an eyelash victory with C.B. Stuart's Ariel in the interclub class race conducted by the American Yacht Club today.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18. -Word was received here today that the Rev. Edward Payson Rankin of Monrovia, Calif., second oldest living alumnus of Princeton University and one of the two surviving members of the Class of 1865, would return to the campus on Commencement Saturday, June 15, to celebrate the seventieth anniversary of his graduation.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended May 11 totaled 324,682,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Sales tax figures announced by Controller Frank J. Taylor show that of every eight storekeepers who should be paying one is refusing to do so. There are in the city 185,000 storekeepers who were registered in connection with the sales tax.

In the late Spring of 1935, says Professor Wotan von Dunkel in his colossal work, "The Natural History of the North Americans," we find the inhabitants of the United States chiefly concerned with streamline trains and ever faster airplanes.

LONDON, May. 18 (AP). -- Strict Soviet censorship kept the world waiting more than ten hours before fears that the worst airplane disaster in history had occurred on the outskirts of Moscow could be confirmed.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A new frontier in which the initiative of private industry, the people and the government will have ample opportunity for expansion and achievement has been opened in a large and comprehensive program of rural electrification for which Congress has just provided $100,000,000.

THE mental processes which result in murder have long been a favorite study of novelists, and one especially in vogue now. Mr. Bierstadt has chosen to present those of a slayer who was a homicidal maniac, and, by way of contrast, places them side by side with the thoughts which, in his belief, passed through the minds of three famous murderers: Lizzie Borden, Dr. Crippen and Jack the Ripper.

The need to adapt the teaching of commercial education to changing economic conditions was emphasized by speakers yesterday at the ninth annual Spring convention of the Commercial Education Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ROME, May 18. -- No official protest against Ethiopia's designation of two foreigners as her members of the mixed conciliation commission has yet been made. The Italian Foreign Ministry still has the matter under consideration.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A message by President Roosevelt of good-will to the world, declaring that "it must be the honest endeavor of all peoples to arrive at a sympathetic understanding" of others' problems, was delivered over the radio today in connection with Good-Will Day, sponsored by the World Federation of Education Associations.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 17. -- Manufacturers, processors and middlemen who have combined to resist further encroachment upon industry by the pending amendments to the AAA program are about to find themselves fighting an unexpected force in the Midsouth.

ON the bare stage at the National Theatre -- bare except for a few scattered chairs and tables and homely theatrical oddments -- a group of people were behaving in what seemed an insane and inane fashion. Four of them sat on a bench and one of the four held a script.

CINCINNATI, May 18. -- Flanked by an array that seemed to have its maimed and wounded strewn all about the place, stout-hearted Freddy Fitzsimmons fired a four-hit shut-out into the amazed Reds today to bring the Giants home in front, 4 to 0.

I read with considerable interest THE TIMES article concerning the petroleum industry's decision to launch an educational campaign against extension of bureaucratic control over that industry. The whole matter of government interference with the present high-type, inexpensive service rendered by the oil industry is one of grave concern and should be an open book.

OVERBROOK, Pa., May 18. -- A refreshed and alert New York twelve took the field against West Chester in the second session of the national lacrosse tournament at the Sacred Heart Academy today and although West Chester won, 6 to 3, the New York showing was highly creditable.

Stanislaus Felix Hausner made two unsuccessful attempts to fly across the Atlantic. In one he floated helplessly on half-sunken plane in the ocean for eight days before being rescued. In that flight he took off on the morning of June 3 from Floyd Bennett Airport.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Alvin Crowder pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 6-to-4 victory over Washington today to send the American League champions one up in the current series.

THE question of the doctor's bill and how his patients are going to meet it, or, in more generalized statement, of how the community, as a whole and individually, can best meet the increasing expense of medical care, has for some years been gaining more and more importance in the public eye and receiving wider discussion.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 18. -- Greystone, the estate of Samuel Untermyer here, was opened this afternoon for the benefit of the cooperative committee of Big Sisters -- Catholic, Jewish and Protestant. The proceeds will be devoted to the care of neglected children.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- William Guggenheim told fellow-members of the University of Pennsylvania college class of 1889 today that the country had been "overfed with inflationary processes and corporation baiting" but that "very bright times" should be just ahead by next Spring.

Holy Cross continued on its winning way yesterday at Baker Field by defeating the Columbia nine, 12 to 3, before 1,000 spectators. It was an impressive performance that the Crusaders put on. They hit the ball hard and came up with sparkling defensive plays. On top of this, Bill Sline turned back the Lions with six hits.

IT sometimes takes only a clown's hat and a piece of stale crust to give the illusion of unlimited bread and circuses. The crowd concentrates on the illusion. The critic concentrates on the delusion. By the time they are wiser it's apt to be too late.

THE unusual charm of this notable short novel lies in the profound kinship to a real boy embodied in the character of Dan, the dreaming 15-year-old, run away from his quiet home in the East to seek adventure in the fabulous, far-off West.

A sturdy, 28-foot motor cruiser, built in the Bronx on Pugsley's Creek last Winter, is going places this Summer never before visited by white men and yet will stay in United States waters. At the wheel will be one of New York's best-known power yachtsmen, Vice Commodore Leuman M. Waugh of the New York A.C. Yachting Department.

Many reservations have been made for the garden festival in behalf of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery on Tuesday at the formal opening of the Park Lane Gardens. A display of latest costumes for adults and children in which women and children of well-known New York families will act as manikins will be a feature of the luncheon hour.

LONDON, April 26. ROBERT E. SHERWOOD'S version of Jacques Deval's "Tovarich" has now reached us and has been so acclaimed that there seems little doubt of its enjoying a success commensurable with that which it has won in other capitals; but it appears to me to be, in its present form, an uneven and in parts a shoddy play.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The county residents are laying plans for the Upperville colt and horse show, to be held at Grafton, the Dulany place, on June 12 and 13. This show, true to the tradition of its organization in 1853, makes a specialty of colts and breeding stock, having as its object the promotion of interest in better breeding and care of colts.

THE Constitution declares that a "person" shall not become a Senator until he is 30 years old, but Senate life began at 29 for Rush Dew Holt of West Virginia. Although he may not take the oath until his birthday. June 19, he enjoys almost all of the perquisites of office.

Frequent disorder among more than 400 spectators, mostly Negroes, marked the hearing yesterday of a subcommittee of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem. On several occasions it became necessary for the chairman to call five-minute recesses to restore order.
Almost 10,000 men, women and children protested against war yesterday afternoon in a parade on Fifth Avenue and at a mass meeting in Union Square.
HAVANA, May 18. -- Barring of officials of the Machado regime from participation in the coming elections was approved by the Cabinet today.

AGAIN a royal wedding fills two countries with a pleasant buzz of excitement. When Princess Ingrid of Sweden and Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark are married next Friday, Stockholm will say good-bye to yet another of the little handful of highnesses who have grown up at its austere court; but the Swedish capital has learned by this time to manage its farewells with smiles as well as with tears.

I have just read the verbose criticisms of the Hecht-MacArthur picture "The Scoundrel" by two of your correspondents, Mr. Cusack and Mr. King. Dear me, they seem a trifle contradictory. If the thousands who have suffered all manner of torture in the past few years don't want to see and enjoy something light and amusing, something beautifully done, what do they want?
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 18. -- The Manhattan College nine defeated Upsala with a barrage of fifteen hits today, 12 -- 6. Each team used two pitchers.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 18. -- The polo season at the Meadow Brook Club officially opened today with four of the teams entered in the coming Spring twenty-goal tournaments taking part in practice matches.
IF the experience of Teachers College, Columbia University, is any criterion, this Summer should see four times as many American teachers and student-teachers studying in Europe as ever before.

MODESTLY announced as a book "to blow the roof off Washington," this volume seems more likely to the humbler purpose of enabling its authors to blow off steam and perhaps talk themselves out of a neurosis.

CLYDE BEATTY might learn something from Samuel Marx, head of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's story department. Mr. Beatty, with whip and kitchen chair, enters a cage filled with lions and tigers; Mr. Marx, armed only with tact and a friendly grin, rides herd on the ninety-odd playwrights, novelists, short story writers, gagmen and former newspaper men who turn out screen scripts for Metro.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 18. -- Best in show his last two times out, Nancolleth Marquis, the fine pointer owned by Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, won for the third time in a row in the Ladies Kennel Association event at the Fair Grounds today. The thirty-second exhibition brought out 802 dogs.

THE series of seven "Modern Dance Recitals" which has recently been concluded at the New School for Social Research has served a useful and encouraging, if not always an entirely entertaining, purpose in giving a cross-section of the field of younger dancers.

WHILE the rest of the country speculates as to whether a third party will take part in the national elections next year, two State third-party movements, in power in Wisconsin and Minnesota, are already beginning to head up toward 1936.

MUNICH, May 18. -- The charge of treason was made against another American citizen and resident of Munich today. Leonard G. Dawson, United States Consul, visited Karl Nisselbeck, American, arrested yesterday by secret political police, in his cell in the regular police prison this morning, and the consul was informed that the charge of treason had been brought against the prisoner and a second charge of smuggling money across the border would probably be added.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18. -- A race for second place, usually unnoticed and unimportant, bulked large in the picture of the thirty-third annual Yale-Princeton dual track meet today. It was a two-inch success for Edge Smith of the Elis over Jimmy Curran of Nassau that gave Yale a 68-67 victory in the gusty, wind-blown setting of Palmer Stadium.

There are various grades and classes of solecisms, all of which are more or less offensive to the cultivated ear, but I think that the most offensive of all are those which carry with them an affectation and assumption of elegance and refinement.

ADVERSE weather conditions again reduced retail trade for the week in many sections of the country. Some improvement was noted here toward the close of the period, but barely enough to bring sales volume up to the level of a year ago.

RICHMOND, Va., May 17. -- After successfully blocking the wets during a legislative session of five months, the drys in the North Carolina Assembly lost control of the situation in the closing hours and one of the most grotesque liquor systems ever heard of was set up.

AN ancient English landmark, the 800-year-old village smithy at Newton Longville, Bucks, has been demolished after a controversy which lasted more than a year. Its situation, in the middle of the town where four roads meet, made it an obstacle to traffic, and road improvement plans finally were its downfall.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Starting a new campaign against the administration's utility holding company legislation, Philip H. Gadsden, chairman of the Committee of Public Utility Executives, urged in a nation-wide broadcast tonight that those listening immediately write or wire the President and their Senators in opposition to the pending bill.

A REPRESENTATIVE of a little known but widely noticed division of the cinema reached this city last week. She was Lillian Templeton, the "Lillian" whose name pops up now and then in those dull prologues to pictures that credit John Blimp with photographic effects, Horatio Slowfoot with art direction and Arnaldo Wiskisor with additional dialogue.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Walter Duke Wood Jr. of Summit, N.J., proved an important factor in Cornell's victory over the Pennsylvania track team on Franklin Field today. The score was 91 -- 44.

Legal and moral pressure was brought to bear last week on those storekeepers of New York who collected the 2 per cent emergency relief sales tax from their customers but failed to send the money to the city government.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 18. -- Army, in its first outdoor polo game of the season, defeated Harvard today in a well-played contest by 13 to 5. The Army attack was fast throughout and consistently effective, the cadets scoring in every chukker.

ANY book by Laurence Binyon -- a translation of Dante's "Inferno," a new volume of poems or a critical work on Eastern art -- is an event. "The Spirit of Man in Asian Art," which contains the Charles Eliot Norton Lectures at Harvard, 1933-34, is a beautiful and sensitive exposition of Oriental esthetics by one of the most sympathetic interpreters of the subject writing today.

ONE could guess, if Miss Scarborough did not admit it, that this is an anthology based frankly on personal predilections. No apparent principle of choice, no set standard, governs it -- with the result that "Selected Short Stories of Today" is a more catholic and all-inclusive volume than most of the story anthologies that have appeared recently.

An all-day police search yesterday failed to yield a clue to the where-abouts of Shirley Evans, 8-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Evans of 82-16 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, who has been missing from her home since 7 o'clock Friday night.

The fight over the Roosevelt administration's new Banking Bill is rapidly approaching a climax, with Governor Eccles urging its adoption, Secretary Morgenthau suggesting government ownership of the stock of the Reserve Banks, Republican critics in Congress insisting that the new bill would destroy the Federal Reserve System and Father Coughlin denouncing it as an "unholy alliance" between politics and the "money changers."

DEMOCRACY, in these critical times, faces an attack from each of two opposing fronts -- from Right-Wing groups who maintain that it is inherently defective in that it does not conform to the law of nature that the strong shall rule the weak; from Left-Wing groups who assert with equal vigor that it is always exploited by the powerful and the greedy to defeat social justice.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 18. -- Fulfilling the expectations of the committee which seeded them at the top of the respective halves of the draw, Frank Bowden, former Columbia captain, and Melvin Partridge, the defending cup holder came through to the final round of the invitation tennis tournament of the Amackassin Club today.

THE Pacific has been for centuries an ocean of adventure and romance. Even today men cruise there for pleasure, lured by the strange people, the languorous tropical air, the luxuriant foliage of islands lapped by the summer sea.

THERE are in England so many more interesting old castles and country houses open to the public than American travelers usually know about that all who look forward to a visit there owe a debt of gratitude to these two authors for their diligence in collecting the information contained in this little book.

EXHIBITIONS of water-colors seem to increase conversely with the decrease in the total number of exhibitions as the Spring wanes. Work in the slighter medium is much in evidence in large group shows at this season as well as among the one-man offerings in the galleries.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 18. -Miss Jane Knapp of the Rosemary Hall School was adjudged the best girl rider in the twenty-first annual junior riding competition conducted under the auspices of the Greenwich Riding Association in the outdoor ring of the Round Hill Stables today.

PARIS. MARCEL ROCHAS, the enfant terrible of Paris couturiers, showed his midseason collection early this year. He is the youngest dress creator in Paris and his new mode typifies youth -- demure, willful and whimsical; it was minus the eccentricities that marred some of his previous showings.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18. -- Harvard's undefeated track and field team routed Dartmouth in a dual meet at the Harvard Stadium today, 84 to 51, despite the absence of Milton Green, Harvard's high point scorer.

May I say a few words before leaving this great city to express my thankfulness and appreciation for helpfulness, kindness and hospitality shown me during my short visit here for the past few weeks? I am particularly obliged to those institutes and persons who are authorities on foreign affairs and international relations for the American viewpoint of some problems which it is the aim of my visit to study.

Two no-hit games featured the high school baseball program in the metropolitan district yesterday, Mallon of White Plains hurling a 3-to-0 victory over Gorton High, and Rivas of Tottenville halting Seward Park, 7-1.

FOR several years this department has made a practice of printing, at the beginning of each theatrical season, an extensive list of dramatic and musical prospects for the immediately ensuing months, compiled after a careful survey of each accredited producer's portfolio.

HOLLYWOOD. JOSEPH I. BREEN, producduction code authority of the Hays office, was scheduled to leave this week for a two-month holiday in Europe. Such a venture may be thought to be more properly a Social note.
BOSTON, May 18 (AP). -- After being held scoreless and to three hits in eight innings, the league-leading White Sox put on a five-hit rally in the ninth to defeat the Red Sox, 3 -- 2, today.

The most satiric book ever written about public controversy -- which is perhaps SCHOPENHAUER'S on that art -- could not surpass in its imaginary specimens of bad reasoning the actual examples now furnished us every day. There is, for example, a favorite argument now used at Washington against the opponents of the banking bill.

A HUGE department store is a little world of its own. Rian James is thrilled with admiration and awe for the complicated mechanics which keep Buntling's great store humming with business. In a loose, swift, breathless style, he pictures the intricate and far-flung functioning of the big shop.

POSSIBLY that antediluvian none-such crawling through a window in one of Mr. Thurber's recent New Yorker drawings was just dropping in to welcome Clarence Day's new stone age menagerie. "Scenes From the Mesozoic" brims with that kind of delirious company.

ABOUT fifteen years ago Mr. Stoddard frightened us almost to death with a book called "The Rising Tide of Colour." It was an interesting argument that the brown and yellow men would soon dominate the globe. Since then Mr. Stoddard, along with the rest of us, has learned a good deal.

Personality, circumstance and destiny contrive to meet at a single time and place but seldom in the course of history. When they do, a hero emerges and legends grow up about him until they reach the dimensions of a Homeric epic. Such a hero was Thomas Edward Lawrence, who, having created kingdoms, scorned honors and riches, died, after his brief hour, in dramatic, self-imposed simplicity.

THE nearly four centuries of progress and achievement in the West with their climax in the gigantic works now being constructed will be portrayed in bold strokes at the California Pacific International Exposition, which will open in Balboa Park, in San Diego, on May 29 and continue until Nov. 11.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., May 18. -- An automobile crashed into an airplane on the highway near here today, wrecking the plane and injuring its two occupants seriously. The driver of the car was not even scratched, and aside from a bent fender and a cracked window, the automobile was not damaged.

While financing for the account of the United States Government and of States and municipalities has largely dominated the market for new issues in the last several years, indications are increasing that 1935 will witness a pronounced swing back to corporate financing.

A LIFETIME'S study and thinking were recognized when Charles M. Andrews received the Pulitzer Prize for "The Colonial Period of American History." Professor Andrews, now living in retirement at New Haven, looks back on more than forty years of college teaching.

A NEW tower is rising on the campus of Mount Holyoke College. By its completion in June it will mark for returning alumnae the entrance to a college library quadrupled in size. The old Williston Memorial Library, which is to be remodeled to contain a larger main reference and reading room, is incorporated in the new structure.
Women are lost intellectually and spiritually because their education has not prepared them for the changing world, according to Mrs. Charles A. Beard, author and historian.
