HONGKONG, May 18. -- The Chinese military authorities at Kaiping have reported to Swatow that the 200 soldiers who have been searching Northeastern Kwangtung Province have found no trace of the Rev. Harold Bush, American priest at the Maryknoll Mission, who recently disappeared.

DETROIT, May 18. -- Before the eyes of 6,000 persons who had gathered to listen to high mass for Marshal Pilsudski of Poland, Stanley Hausner, Polish-American aviator, fell to his death at 12:45 o'clock this afternoon. He had planned a flight from Detroit to Poland next month.

AS a matter of historical fact the Charles Lamb centenary was on Dec. 27. At that time this column was giddy with comments on the new plays that arrive at Christmas time; it had no space for superannuated codgers, no matter how ingratiating they might be.

ANGELS CAMP, Calif., May 18. -- Angels Camp "whooped it up" for pony express riders instead of frogs when amphibian entries failed to show much zip in preliminary competition of the seventh annual jumping jubilee today.

A special three-day sale of Spring and Summer clothing for men, women and children will open on Wednesday at the Nearly New Shop, 913 Eighth Avenue. Useful articles besides clothing also are offered, at this permanent thrift shop, which is maintained in aid of several charitable organizations.

SHORT-WAVE listeners will have the opportunity this week of eavesdropping on a diversity of events, ranging from England's Empire Day celebration to tests of stratosphere radio equipment at Rapid City, S.D. The atmospheric conditions are forecast as distinctly favorable for world-wide reception over the next seven days.

RYE, N.Y., May 18. -- More than 900 persons, including members and their guests, tonight attended the opening dinner dance of the season of the Westchester Country Club here. There was an entertainment during dinner.
LONDON, May 18. -- Jacob Epstein, American-born sculptor, has written to the Royal Academy asking that his name be withdrawn from the list of candidates for membership.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 18. -- Reaching two Army pitchers for nineteen hits, the Fordham University nine overwhelmed the Cadets today, 14 to 2.
ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Sports and social events lead the calendar at Asheville and a number of conventions are scheduled for the latter part of the month.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 18 (AP). -- Southern California's track and field team retained its unbeaten status for the season with a one-sided victory today in the California Intercollegiates, a quadrangular meet bringing together the State's "Big Four."

Vindicating the faith of those in the crowd of 20,000 who had made him an odds-on favorite, C.H. (Pat) Knebelkamp's King Saxon yesterday won the forty-second running of the Metropolitan Handicap in game and gallant fashion at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, May 18, -- Cornelius F. Kelley, president of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and several subsidiaries, received compensation of $171,666 in 1934, the corporation revealed today in a registration statement put before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HANOVER, N.H., May 18. -- Captain Bill Clark's single in the eleventh inning gave Dartmouth a 7-to-6 victory over Harvard today in a wild game. Ted Olson annexed his sixth victory in Eastern Intercollegiae League competition and further entrenched Dartmouth in first place.

Technically it is the vegetable garden. But it is familiarly known as the kitchen garden because the stuff it produces goes directly to the kitchen and turns up on the table at dinner and supper. By comparison with the field corn and the potato patch it is a trivial part of the annual cultivation, and rather less important to the welfare of the farm next Winter.

Deficiencies of environment in which New York's public school pupils live will be one of the most important problems for which solution will be sought at two conferences called by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, the first of which will be held tomorrow night in the Board of Education building.

Rulings on the eligibility of mothers to receive financial aid for their dependent children under the Child Welfare and Public Welfare Laws have been in many instances contradictory and confusing, it was charged yesterday in a report by Mrs. Sarah Nicholson of the New York City Child Welfare Board.

BOMBAY -- Japan' s commercial invasion of the Indian market has begun in real earnest. That Indians seem to have taken a special fancy, to Japanese goods is strikingly demonstrated by the great increase in imports from Japan and a corresponding shrinkage in imports from other countries.

Maritime Day, on May 22, commemorating the sailing of the Savannah, first steamship to cross the ocean, in 1819, brings to attention the present condition and problems of our merchant fleet. Flags will fly in harbor and town, by proclamation of President Roosevelt, and in Washington there will be much active discussion of the many pressing needs of our merchant marine.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 18. -- Four sports contests with teams of The Hill School were included in the 125th anniversary celebration program at Lawrenceville today, but from the victory standpoint the 2,000 Lawrenceville alumni, students and guests had little over which to rejoice, for the Pennsylvanians won three of the events.

Another of the Rodman Neck clubs ousted last Fall by Park Commissioner Robert Moses has found a new home. The Morrisania Y.C., organized forty years ago, has moved across Eastchester Bay to affiliate with the Westchester Country Club on Throgs Neck, and held its Going-Into-Commission Day yesterday.

LONDON, May 18. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today. Gold was unchanged at 141s 8d an ounce. About 258,000 of the metal was sold. Silver also was unchanged at 35d an ounce for spot and 35 3-16d for forward delivery. Loans were in fair demand at one-half of 1 per cent.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18. -- Sex discrimination among workers, lack of interest among women in politics, the NRA and bills for unequal working days for men and women were attacked here today by speakers at the session of the New Jersey Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.

Opposing points of view on the question of an American labor party and comment on the recent visit to Washington of farmers pleased with the AAA program were heard yesterday by fifty persons attending an educational conference under the auspices of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union at 3 West Sixteenth Street.

The five Borough Presidents of New York City will confer in Washington Wednesday with Federal officials on plans to have work relief projects in the President's $4,000,000,000 program shifted from the Works Division of the Emergency Relief Bureau to the Borough Presidents.
PARIS, May 18. -- The former heir to the throne of Spain disclosed today his hope for a fresh start in democratic America with his beautiful commoner wife.

IT is a short visit that Gilbert Miller is paying this country, and he who obtains news from him must run -- or ride in his automobile. To be sure, a good many of the Miller plans were revealed in the public prints following his arrival last Tuesday.

A runaway plane flew off with first prize yesterday in the model airplane contest held by the New York University Flying Club at Van Cortlandt Park in the morning and at the University Heights campus in the afternoon.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, telegraphed Colonel Theodore Roosevelt yesterday asking him to make public the "red-flag list" of 2,904 persons said to be unfit to lead or influence boys which Colonel Roosevelt has announced is maintained by the Boy Scouts of America.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- President Roosevelt's decision to deliver in person his message vetoing the Patman Soldiers' Bonus Bill, now tentatively scheduled for Wednesday before a joint session of the Senate and House, caused expressions of resentment today from currency inflationists in Congress.

BEING chiefly concerned with the recording of impending events along the local cinema front, this column dispatched two scouts the other day with instructions to eavesdrop if necessary on the various theatre managers to ascertain their plans for the immediate future.

While his mates were reaching Al Jordan, a sophomore starting his first varsity game, for twenty safeties, Bob Owston. Temple University pitcher, held City College hitless to score a 17-1 victory over the Lavender yesterday afternoon at Lewisohn Stadium.

With about fifty teachers and students enrolled, a field course in music education under the auspices of Teachers College, Columbia University, will be held in England, Germany, Austria and France this Summer, the party being booked to sail from New York on June 29 on the Europa.

A SHORT time ago-in the Summer of 1933, to be exact -- I was shown, through the courtesy of John Hay Whitney, a series of test films made in color by the newly perfected Technicolor process. The subjects of these color tests were many and varied.

A degree of improvement featured retail trade in the metropolitan area last week, with reports indicating that sales volume was about on a parity with last year's figures for the period, against general declines in the preceding week. Estimates put department store trade for the month thus far at about 4 to 5 per cent under 1934.

PITTSBURGH, May 18. -- Darrell Elijah Blanton is bad news for Brooklyn. All of Casey Stengel's strategy, which dictated sending an entire right-handed hitting line-up against the screwball star, couldn't put power in the Dodger bats.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 18 (AP). -- The $4,000,000 narcotic farm established by the Federal Government in the heart of Kentucky's blue grass country for the segregation and rehabilitation of narcotic addicts will be dedicated next Saturday.

The City Affairs Committee sent a telegram last night to Governor Lehman demanding that he supersede District Attorney William C. Dodge with a special prosecutor to take charge of the 'vice and crime situation."

MUCH work is being done in New York's metropolitan section that will speed the way for motorists in the near future. In addition to repaving and widening construction on a number of streets in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, work is progressing on various links in the highway network, the Automobile Club of New York reports.

Ten alumni and two alumnae of New York University who will receive Alumni Meritorious Service Awards at the commencement exercises on Wednesday, June 12, will be honored Tuesday night at a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore by nearly 100 alumni who have previously received the award.

Vermont authorities turned to the dentists of New York and Boston yesterday for help in identifying three skeletons unearthed in gunny sacks on Wednesday near Middlebury. The victims of the crime, a woman and two children, are believed to have been slain about three years ago.

ROME, May 18. -- Italy's determination not to abandon the gold standard was again affirmed today by Paolo Thaon di Revel, new Finance Minister, in presenting to the Chamber of Deputies the State budget for the next financial year beginning June 1.

If Mr. Snyder had included a picture of a yellow primrose in this book of seventy-three camera studies even Wordsworth's phlegmatic "Peter Bell" must have been moved to enthusiasm. These pictures, largely close-ups, should open up a new world to the child -- and adult, too -- who has had heretofore no eye for the miraculous detail of nature's work.

FLINT, Mich., May 18. -- A pilot and two passengers were killed and eight other occupants of a tri-motored plane were injured, two seriously, here today when the plane plunged to the ground while a new airport was being dedicated.

Captain Adolf Ahrens, master of the Europa, said before sailing early yesterday, that there would be no attempt by the Bremen or the Europa to try to beat the thirty-knot speed of the Normandie. "Our ships are built to maintain twenty-eight knots and they do it and arrive on time like trains if the weather is at all decent," he said.

BERLIN, April 20. THAT a city of over four million inhabitants hould find two operetta stages a surfeit seems incongruous. Yet this is exactly the situation in Berlin, where of the six musical houses today only the Metropol and Schiller 'Theatres are playing operetta.

For the second time within three months, Mrs. Evelyn Morfesis, 25-year-old partner in a lunch room at 1,763 York Avenue, yesterday was the victim of hold-up men. This time they took $1,020 from her, she told the police, in the hallway of her home.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 18. -- The town of Hyde Park, through an association of residents, will manufacture and market a buffing wheel invented by John Steiner of this village. A tentative agreement between Mr. Steiner and the association was reached at a public meeting tonight.

THE announcements of Edward Johnson's succession to the position previously held by Herbert Witherspoon as artistic leader of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and of the singers so far engaged and the operas from which the repertory will be arranged for the season of 1935-36, are to be taken as only partial indication of what the character of the first season under the new management will be.

The Aldermanic Committee Investigating Relief in New York City has only "muddled" the situation and not clarified or helped it, Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, declared in an address broadcast last night.

LEE LASH, best known as a designer for the theatre, is exhibiting at the Keppel Gallery; a one-man show made up of oil paintings, pastels, pencil drawings and delightful little sketches in oil. While with color he can frequently achieve arresting effects of atmosphere, it is with the pencil that Mr. Lash attains his finest expression.

As they read "After Three Centuries," by Drs. ELLSWORTH HUNTINGTON and MARTHA RAGSDALE of Yale, the Trumbulls, Coolidges, Lymans, Hooker and Edwardses will be more than ever convinced that they are a tribe apart. To be sure, they have studied smug genealogies and read with much satisfaction such priggish works as "The Adams Family," in which only notable leaders stand forth.

WHAT American tourists will say about prices in Paris during the Summer of 1935 is agitating every hotel keeper, restaurant keeper and shopkeeper in that city today. And on this side of the Atlantic prospective tourists are wondering if they will have to abandon their plans for visiting the French capital.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- Weary of the religious persecution which they charge to Canadian authorities and have publicly resented by parading in the nude, 15,000 members of the Russian sect of Dukhobors are planning to leave their Saskatchewan homes for the wilds of Paraguayan Chaco.

SEND-A-DIME TEST: The Federal Government instituted a test case in Denver last week in an effort to put a stop to the send-a-dime, send-a-dollar and similar chain-letter schemes. Indictments were sought against three business men, who admitted that they had started a chain but argued that there was no reason for the government to single them out for punishment.

ELEANOR EARLY is the author of those two competent and entertaining guide books, "And This Is Boston!" and "And This Is Washington!" Any one who has used either of them as a guide book or has read it at home will not willingly miss this new one, which is concerned with the mountains and the legends and the people of New Hampshire.
LONDON, May 18. -- What the Labor party may think of Britain's foreign policy is not such an academic question today as it was in 1931.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18. -- The contention of former Police Justice Wilbur K. Hitchcock of Pleasantville and his wife that nineteen English sheep dogs in their home and kennels constitute a "reasonable number" was upheld today in a decision by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

LA SALLE, Ill., May 18. -- Heavily armed State policemen had control of the situation at the Apollo Metal Works today after it had been besieged most of the night by a mob of about 500 strikers and sympathizers.

Approval of a long-range program of research dealing with the effects of future social and economic trends upon department store retailing will come before the executive committee of the Retail Research Corporation and the Associated Merchandising Corporation at its meeting here next month, it was learned yesterday from Colonel P.J. Reilly, executive director of the corporation.

CAIRO, April 20. -- New evidence of Greek influence on the early civilization of Middle Egypt has been revealed by the excavations at Tuna el-Gabel that have been carried out during the past season by Professor Sami Gabra under the auspices of the Egyptian University.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Dr. Hugh M. Smith, former chief of the United States Bureau of Fisheries, who has just returned after ten years as biological adviser to the Siamese Government, brought some stories of Siam's strange "walking fishes."

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- With the inauguration of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program at least three new alphabetical units have been added to the abbreviated agencies carrying forward the New Deal, bringing the total to eighty-one. The latest additions are the DAI, ACA and WPA. The alphabetical progeny of the New Deal and some of its adopted children, and what the initials stand for, are:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Senate, which had been blocking the narrow legislative pass, suddenly moved this week as if stung by a swarm of bumblebees. In rapid succession the body, where the work-relief resolution alone had been held up for more than two months, passed broadening amendments to TVA, the Clark resolution that gently chloroforms the NRA, and the Wagner Trades Disputes Bill.

Slum clearance in New York City received impetus last week from a new allotment from the Federal Government which may reach $40,000,000. This fund will enable the city to proceed with several plans, still in the blue-print stage, for transforming its most unwholesome, congested areas into neighborhoods in which air, light and sun will go with modern housing at cheap rentals.

Announcement was made yesterday by Ralph Dellevie, head of the National Tours, that he has chartered the Panama Pacific cruising steamship Columbia to make four thirteen-day cruises to South America and the West Indies this Summer.

More than eighty-five will begin play tomorrow in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tourney at the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y. This is one of the largest fields ever to compete in the event. Mrs. John D. Crews, the former Maureen Orcutt, will not defend the crown she won last year for the fifth time.

Dr. James F. Rooney of the Medical Society of the State of New York sent you a letter some time ago which referred to German experiences with health insurance. I regret not having read this letter earlier. May I call your attention to the following facts:

Transformation of the Department of the Interior into the Department of Public Works, with an engineer as head, was urged on Congress yesterday in a resolution adopted at the annual meeting and election of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers, in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Governor Lehman wound up action Friday on the bills left over by the Legislature, completing a most strenuous session. He had signed 980 bills since the first of the year and vetoed 344, thus surpassing the previous record for vetoes of 341, established in 1931 by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.

While Columbia University's favored track and field combination was gaining the glory of annexing eight first places, New York University was busy fortifying itself with plenty of points in the minor positions to emerge victorious in the three-cornered meet with Rutgers at Ohio Field yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 17. -- With approximately 164,000 ballots cast Wednesday in the repeal election, the drys won by some 228 votes, and this scant margin of victory keeps the State legally dry but cannot evaporate the wetness of a number of alcoholic cases.

LOOKING back on those theatrical years between the great war and the great depression. Robert Ullin has made a brave but fruitless attempt to capture their essence in a novel. Some feeling for the larger aspects of his subject he undeniably has, and this is better expressed in his title than elsewhere in his story.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- A double by Pitcher Morris into the right field stands gave Princeton's baseball team a ninth-inning victory over Penn today, 8 to 7. The wallop scored Hill, who had walked and stolen second.

IN the short history of American sculpture we find variations as wide as in the American scenery, the racial distributions, the social habits and the taste of individuals and communities; in fact we find exactly what we should expect to find in this astonishing country.

THERE are two amateur detectives in this story of life and death in Washington and its suburbs. One of the sleuths is a newspaper woman, the writer of a widely syndicated gossip column. The other is a member of Congress. Sally Shaftoe, the columnist, does not believe that Marshall Rich is the murderer of his wife and her alleged lover, although Rich has confessed.

TWO interesting contracts have recently been signed by the D. Appleton-Century Company. One is for the publication next Fall of "Gracious Lady: The Life of Sara Delano Roosevelt," the authorized biography of the President's mother, written by Rita S. Halle Kleeman.

Two Philadelphia women golfers, Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd and Miss Frances Williams, top the 1935 handicap list issued by the handicap committee of the Women's Eastern Golf Association. They are rated at plus 1.

The Russians claimed that the Maxim Gorky, eight-motored aerial giant, was the largest land plane in the world. Built primarily to distribute propaganda on a mass scale to the most remote parts of Soviet Russia, the ship had accommodations for a crew of twenty-three and for forty passengers, but for ordinary passenger work it could be arranged to accommodate from sixty to seventy passengers.
ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, AT SEA, May 18. -- Americans need have no anxiety about their navy.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 18 (AP). -- In a sweeping decree today, Emperor Haile Selassie abolished serfdom throughout the nation.

The Lefty Vernon Gomez who won twenty-six games and lost five for the Yankees last year was on exhibition yesterday at the Stadium, to the joy of some 20,000 fans and the dismay of Walter Johnson and his Cleveland Indians.

New financing by States and municipalities in prospect for the next few reeks took an unexpectedly sharp upturn yesterday, when it was announced that three issues of bonds, aggregating approximately $11,000,000, would be placed on the market soon.

LONDON, May 11. -- When nowadays in London, in the presence of a government expert, you mention the year 1937, the man looks at you closely, and then he tries to discover how much you know. For 1937 is the year which the specialists of the Committee of Imperial Defense now assign as the first in which German militarism may be expected to strike.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Changes produced in the national life of the United States by the impact of economic factors of the period of depression and recovery are analyzed in the annual "social changes" number of The American Journal of Sociology, published today by the University of Chicago Press.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 18. -- Cornell's baseball team scored its fourth victory in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition today, defeating Yale by 4 to 3.

THE Spring shrubs and flowers, now in a full burst of glory, sometimes keep the gardener's eyes so filled with color that he fails to use them to study the bare soil where seeds have recently been planted, or where rows of little seedlings are just breaking through the soil.

WRITTEN on the same lines and much in the manner of E.M. Delafield's witty and entirely delightful "Diary of a Provincial Lady," this new book by the writer who prefers to be known as Martin Hare is an amusing account of the experiences of a young Irishwoman in a French pension.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., May 18. -- A new athletic policy which will enable Harvard to "get away as soon as possible from the vicious connection between football gate receipts and expenditures for the athletic program" was explained here tonight by President Conant of the university at the annual dinner of the Associated Harvard Clubs.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, May 18. -- The threat of grave complications between Lithuania and Germany was partly removed today when President Anatanas Smetona saved from a firing squad four Nazis convicted of plotting Memel's return to the Reich.

The committee on quotations and commissions of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a new ruling clarifying the regulation governing the rate of commissions charged by a Stock Exchange member or firm on "give-up" orders received from out-of-town members.

MUNICH, May 18. -- Nazi bands broke up a Catholic charity drive here today, finally staging citywide anti-Catholic riots. Catholics fled to their churches for refuge while the Nazis marched through the streets and tore from the coats of contributors to the Catholic fund the badges that had been given to them.

A trim, sun-tanned, efficient team of seven tennis players wearing the dark green blazers of William and Mary invaded the North last weekend and departed again with three well-earned victories in their racquet cases.

MOSCOW, May 18 (AP). -- The Red Army has reached the point of efficiency where it compares favorably with "the armies of the countries whose attack we may some day have to repulse," President Mikhail Kalinin of Soviet Russia asserted in a speech today to a group of crack parachute jumpers.
Staving off courageous bids on the part of Columbia and M.I.T., Harvard's varsity crew rowed to victory on the Harlem River early last evening.

EASILY grown Summer-flowering annuals add variety and color to the garden and provide a wealth of cut material for decoration. For the beginner's garden, or for filling the borders in a new garden, they are unexcelled because they mature quickly, do not require expert care, and give a fine display.

MOSCOW, May 18. -- This week saw the second important diplomatic conference that has taken place in Moscow within two months. And the second, like the first, produced better results than even the most optimistle Russians had foreseen.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18. -- The fourth annual Atlantic City horse show was brought to an auspicious close tonight, with important championship and stake events being decided before a crowd of 12,000 in the spacious Convention Hall auditorium.

The title of this book may have a meaning, but if it has it is so well hidden that your reviewer has failed to find it. Not that it matters much. What does matter is that James Edward Grant has written a story that will make the other exponents of the hard-boiled school of detective fiction look to their laurels.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as depositary for American shareholders of the Belgian National Railways, has protested to the Belgian Government against the action of that government in reducing the guaranteed dividend on the company's participating preferred stock.

GEORGE F. JOHNSON, head of the Endicott-Johnson Corporation, is a phenomenon in American industrial life that cannot anywhere else be duplicated. Success stories of boys who started at worker's benches there are plenty in this country but none is tied up with a vision that holds the happiness of the worker still remaining on the bench as its inspiration.

THIS is Al Smith's platform. It comprises all the reforms to which he has dedicated his statesmanship in this and future years, and for which he will spend his energies whether as a private citizen or in one of the posts of trust to which the State and city keep on calling him when some problem is to be solved and brains and vision are needed.

THE typical specialization of the modern world has now invaded the province of even the most modest gardening project. In fact, an individual technique has been developed for dish, tray, window, rock, water and path gardens.

An exhibition and sale of pottery made at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, will be held next Saturday, Sunday and Monday from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. in the garden of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Swope at The Croft, Ossining, N.Y.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Tommy Walker, Billy Mills and Dally Duncan starred today as the Scottish Football Association players opened their tour of the United States and Canada with a 3 -- 0 victory over the Philadelphia Germans. A crowd of 15,000 witnessed the contest.

Immediate abolition of the NRA and the AAA with the processing tax and immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus as the only way to recovery were urged last night by Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia in a radio speech from Station WEAF.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine article. "Apple Pie Raises an Issue," Catherine Mackenzie asks "And where is the Shendandoah Valley?"
NEWTON, Mass., May 18. -- Boston College set back New York University's varsity baseball team today, 5 to 1.

To eliminate some of the evils of indiscriminate distribution -- substitution of products, "footballing," dealer apathy and profitless volume -- many drug manufacturers throughout the country have switched to the selective method of distribution, according to a nation-wide survey completed last week by the National Wholesale Druggists Association.

An exhibit of illustrative materials of value as teaching aids will be displayed in Public School 17, Manhattan, 328 West Forty-eighth Street, beginning tomorrow and continuing through May 28. Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, has called attention to the exhibit as one that should aid principals and teachers in planning school museums or class-room exhibits.

A filibuster against amendments to the law establishing the Tennessee Valley Authority collapsed in the Senate Tuesday. The amendments, sponsored by Senator Norris, empowered TVA to generate, transmit and market electric power (thus striking at court decisions which have held that the TVA might perform none of those functions).

EUROPEAN observers, visiting Washington when the New Deal got under way, wondered at times whether some of this country's experiments could not have been facilitated by utilizing experience which had been gained in Europe on similar lines.

A small group of boys and girls was whisked in elevators yesterday morning to the Gardens of the Nations on the eleventh floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center to enter a garden portraiture contest. The children, all between the ages of 12 and 16 years, were students in art classes at settlement houses in the city.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- Hun School of Princeton put on a stirring finish to win the annual Stotesbury Cup eight-oared race on the Schuylkill River today before a large crowd.

Are most people snobs? For surely most people affect to despise guidebooks. Yet without them, what is the traveler? He eats, drinks, rides, walks, according to the suggestions of these all-knowing handbooks. What could be more pleasant, some of us must have thought when our hearts, legs and stomachs were younger, than to compile a guidebook, especially one of those regional or provincial gastronomical or oenological treatises so happily composed in France.

We mothers who have labored singly to bring forth children and to rear them nobly are beginning to see that a joint motherhood also is required of us. We see that we must labor together to bring forth a decent world in which our children can live.

STORMS of words are filling the air and blazoning the skies these days, showing with very convincing argument that war must cease, that another great conflict will mean the end of our civilization. Everybody, humble and powerful, admits the danger; few pay any real heed.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP). -- Bucky Walters, one-time third baseman, hurled the Philadelphia Nationals to a spectacular ten-inning 1-to-0 victory over the Cubs today. He won his own game with a sharp single which scored his boss, Manager Jimmy Wilson, from second base.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 18. -- There will be no Carnegie Cup regatta this year. A meeting of graduate managers and rowing representatives tonight postponed the race because of rough waters on Cayuga Lake. The following statement was issued:

A MAGNIFICENT volume, a worthy companion to the book about the Stradivarius family published some thirty years ago by the distinguished Hill family of London, has come from the presses of the same publishing house.

TO write of the present in a fashion of the past may be considered (says the ingenious author in the preface of this volume) a somewhat strange thing. Yet here is a case where it would be an equally strange thing to write of the past in the fashion of the present.

OMAHA, Neb., May 17. -- The critical suspicion which the farmers ran into at Washington from Senators Hastings, Dickinson and others was not altogether new to the corn group. They had heard something like it before from Dan Hildebrand, president of the United States Livestock Association, who is far to the right of the AAA, and from Milo Reno of the Farm Holiday Association, on the left.

Sixty-five babies walked, rode and were pushed in the baby parade held yesterday morning in connection with the Greenwich Village Fair. The babies ranged in age from 5 years to only a few months, and at the end of the parade every one of them received a large red apple from the farm of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.

THE National Advisory Council on Radio in Education held its fourth annual meeting last October in Chicago and in this volume whoever is interested in either radio or education can read the verbatim reports of the full proceedings of all of its six sessions.

MEDIA, Pa., May 18. -- Mrs. Lewis A. Park's Walnut Creek won the Rose Tree Plate Steeplechase, closing day feature of about two miles and a half over a difficult brush course at the Rose Tree Hunt Club's Spring meet today.

MICHAEL FESSIER was born in a California mining town. Like many other American writers, he worked on local newspapers, then began selling short stories to magazines, and finally landed in Hollywood. This career has not served to dilute the Irish influences in his blood, which bring to him a gift for fantasy, a tendency toward supernaturalism, and the yearning to forge out of the chaos of this life a vocabulary of symbols of unearthly perfection.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The open interest in May grain contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade is to be scrutinized daily by the business conduct committee of the Exchange. As the result of what appears to be congestion in May corn, the Grain Futures Administration has notified members that, commencing today, open contracts of 25,000 bushels or more in all May grain futures must be reported daily.

SOMETHING fine and generous has gone out of the collecting game with the passing of Burton Emmett. Not only book collecting but the world of arts and letters as well has lost one of its most valuable friends. For Mr. Emmett was a liberal patron, and the encouragement he gave to contemporaries is shown by his extensive collection of paintings, prints and manuscripts of living artists and writers.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The National Industrial Recovery Board today terminated the stay of the customer classification, price filing and uniform terms of sale provisions of the Mechanical Rubber Goods Divisional Code. This termination does not affect the code provisions for a waiting period before filed price schedules may become effective for those giving the Code Authority power to reclassify customers; those provisions are still stayed and inoperative.

Here are three more exploits of that debonair adventurer, Simon Templar, best known to fame as the Saint. The three stories in this volume are "The High Fence," "The Elusive Ellshaw" and "The Case of the Frightened Innkeeper." The best one of the lot is "The High Fence," in which Simon Templar cooperates with Inspector Claud Eustace Teal to the undoing of a dealer in stolen jewels.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP). -- A default divorce was granted Baroness Fern Andra today by Judge William J. Lindsay in Superior Court from her actor husband, Ian Keith.

ON the Szabadsag ter, a gardenlike square near the House of Parliament in Budapest, four statues stand, facing north, east, south and west. Withered old men and women, weatherbeaten peasants, business executives and boys and girls romping home from school suddenly become grim when they pass by the statues.

ONE cannot go far into this volume without realizing that Compton Mackenzie has a great deal more to say about Bonnie Prince Charlie than he had room for in the brief biography he published in the Appleton Series two years ago.
Your Audubon article in a recent issue mentions a crisis in the great naturalist's life which came at 35 when his wife "for twelve years supported herself and her sons by teaching."

DOCUMENTS in the Public Record Office in London, never hitherto published, give information of the practice of English sovereigns and the Exchequer of presenting to "Royal Chapels" in 'the American Colonies sets of communion plate.

GREAT NECK, L.I. May 18. -- Jumping faultlessly Michael Walsh's chestnut gelding, Ardpatrick, gained the first award in the $100 open jumping stake which featured an excellent program of events at the second annual Oaks Hunt Horse Show today.

Last Sunday marked the passing of the world's "grand old man" of gardening -- William Robinson. To him, more than to any other one person -- more, perhaps, than to any other group of persons -- modern gardening owes its existence. For he alone, at a time when English horticulture was still following blindly the stilted formalism that had been imported from France, had the courage to strike out in revolt.

EVERY day new horticultural events occur at the New York Botanical Gardens, especially among the flora of foreign origin. Bushes of oriental quince apple vie with flame-colored American azalea in the park, the medinilla, or meadow-beauty, from the Philippines flaunts a pink shower of bloom, and fingers of bright yellow-green have appeared on the dwarf Japanese yew.

FAILURE of the FERA to supply financial first aid in time has caused more than 2,400 schools in seventeen States to close their doors before the end of the term. So the National Education Association announces after receiving telegraphic reports from State Departments of Education throughout the country.
A letter from Elias Ginsburg goes into a long encomium of the glory of revisionism, using the Histadrut as a foil. In whatever way one looks at revisionism, it is a Jewish brand of fascism.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 18. -- Rutgers downed Lafayette in baseball, 10 to 3, on Neilson Field today, evening the series and establishing a tie for middle three honors in the sport. Bender pitched well after a ragged start, keeping the Leopards' ten hits well scattered except in the last inning, when four were bunched for two runs.
OTTAWA, May 17. -- Prime Minister Bennett returns to Ottawa at the end of this week to find himself, the Conservative party, and possibly the whole course of politics in Canada at the crossroads.

KENT, Conn., May 18. -- Rowing against three crews from Manhattan College over the mile distance on the Housatonic course at Kent today. Kent School crews scored two victories and suffered one defeat. The Kent first eight, rowing against the Jasper varsity, overcame a deck length lead in the first quarter-mile to triumph by two lengths in 5:03.

EMPLOYING a graceful and often distinguished prose style, Mr. Bromfield writes about nothing very much. A short version of this new novel originally appeared in a magazine under the title "The Three Faces in the Mirror."
DURHAM, N.C., May 18 (AP). -- For the third straight year the University of North Carolina today won the Southern Conference track and field championships.

In a recent communication, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne calls attention to the attractions of the forest preserve, embracing the mountain regions of the Catskills an Adirondacks. He reminds us of its 4,604,000 acres of beauty, its white-water streams and majestic hills -- "the former hunting ground of the Iroquois or Six Nations, a land of romance and tragedy, a happy hunting ground for vacationists, fishermen and hunters."

BUCHAREST. IN military aviation Rumania is striving to become independent of the factories of France, Great Britain and the United States. According to The Associated Press, one of the projects of the Air Ministry is to increase the capacities and effectiveness of the Rumanian aircraft plants.

TO engineers Dr. F. Ljungstrom is known as the inventor of an ingenious turbine which has been used to drive a locomotive in Sweden. To Swedish yachtmen he is a revolutionist in designing small sailboats.
PARIS, May 17. -- France's internal political situation, which was always complicated, has become much more so as a result of the municipal elections held during the past two Sundays.
HERE is London's forthcoming theatrical business as the cable reports it, with only a few late Jubilee celebrants:

In the short trading period yesterday, the share market had to contend with the further taking of profits and closed easier, although at the outset there was some promise of slight betterment. On the week, the market did manage to show a slight gain, thus carrying for the seventh consecutive week an advance in prices.

THIS volume by Joseph Auslander, with its more than one hundred and sixty separate titles, gives us all of what he considers the best of his writings during the past six years. A precocious boy who ran among the blooms of the Parnassian slopes, plucking here stud there as fancy dictated, Mr. Auslander never in the past failed to arouse interest.

GENEVA, May 18. -- The eighty-sixth regular session of the League of Nations Council will open Monday, presenting an unusual combination. Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, will serve as president for the first time, and an Italo-Ethiopian war is looming as the most urgent problem on the agenda.

From the vantage point of 55 Onslow Gardens, London, the suburb of Kensington to be precise, that indefatigable pamphleteer, Major L.L.B. Angas, has just given us another view of the American scene in his newest work,. "The Boom Begins," a sequel to his "The Coming American Boom," that created considerable stir a year ago.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 18. -- Colgate University debaters have just completed one of the most successful seasons in years, with a record of not having lost a single debate which was judged. The only adverse decision was by an audience vote.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 18. -- Declaring that education must be made an "intensely individual affair" and that modern youth must be made aware of the "world's sore spots," Dr. Allan V. Heely, headmaster of Lawrenceville School, called for more dependable educational leadership in the keynote address delivered at Lawrenceville today at the exercises celebrating the 125th anniversary of the founding of the school.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 18. -The action of a small group of Wesleyan University undergraduates in joining the picket line of the strikers at the factory of the Colt's Patent Fire Arms Manufacturing Company at Hartford several times in the past month has called forth a rebuke from the editor of the college semi-weekly paper and a letter of criticism signed by a dozen upper classmen.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 18. -- General Enrique Penaranda reports the Paraguayans last night launched a violent surprise attack, "attaining certain advantages at Camdeyapecua at a heavy cost." He declared heavy fighting was continuing.
LEWISBURG, Pa., May 18. -More than 2,000 visitors were on the campus at Bucknell University this week-end during the annual Spring festival.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 18. -- Dorothy Canfield Fisher, novelist and educator, will be the speaker at the fourteenth annual commencement exercises at New Jersey College for Women June 1. Activities for senior week include baccalaureate service, class day, senior ball, the dean's reception and other events which are being planned by Miss Elizabeth Lodge, '35, of Montclair, assisted by Miss Marjorie Fisher, '36, of Montclair.

BERLIN, May 18. -- After a recess of ten months the National Socialist Reichstag has been summoned for a single session Tuesday to receive "from Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler a significant statement of Germany's foreign policy and her reactions to the present trend of European political currents.

WITH production and sales continuing throughout the industry at high level, companies last week reported increased activity in many instances. Despite the fact that output schedules had been set at quite a high point earlier in the year, readjustment upward has been the order of the day for a number of manufacturers.

ATLANTIC CITY, -- A church convention and a contract bridge tournament, bankers' meetings, golf, field and water sports and a flower show all are included in the program of events here in the next two weeks.

Captain Sam Nahem pitched a three-hit game and struck out nine batters to earn a 2-1 victory for Brooklyn College over the St. John's University nine before 2,500 at Manhattan Beach yesterday. It was Brooklyn College's last home game of the season.

For the fourth time in recent months identical bids were submitted yesterday by manufacturers on lots of fire hose the city wants to buy. And, for the fourth time, Purchase Commissioner Russell Forbes rejected all the bids.
ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 18. -- Lawson Little will defend his title as British Amateur Champion on the links of the Royal Lytham and St. Anne's Club in Lancashire, play starting Monday.

AFTER twenty-eight years of service, the Mauretania has been consigned to the ship-breakers. Except for some of her metal, wood and furnishings, which will adorn other vessels, the old-time speed favorite of trans-atlantic passengers will become just another pile of scrap.

Some 1,500 doctors of medicine have joined in a movement for improving their financial condition through concerted action. Through the Physicians Equity Association of America, Inc., whose formation was announced last week, they say they intend to urge legislation favorable to their profession and discourage that which they consider injurious to members' interests or the public health, and in general to obtain for the profession and those allied with it "a square deal."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17. -- The opening of Kentucky's quadrennial campaign for the Governorship -- one of three in the United States this year -- finds the voters in active rebellion against a 3 per cent sales tax and the administration of Governor Ruby Laffoon, the champion of Colonel Creators, with its back to the wall, fighting to hold intact a powerful political machine which has controlled State government for twenty years.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 18. -- Army's track squad won from Manhattan College today in a dual meet, 68 to 58. The teams divided honors with seven first places each but the cadets had nine seconds and as many thirds, whine Manhattan entrants were in second place six times and registered five thirds.

Promotions for 106 students in the advanced courses of the R.O.T.C. unit at City College were announced yesterday by Colonel George Chase Lewis, Professor of Military Science and Tactics. The highest rank went to Christian Hanburger, who became a cadet colonel.

New York's first, and henceforth probably annual, outdoor motor boat show will be held this Summer as the result of definite action taken at last week's meeting of the Marine Trades Association at the Hotel Lexington. The vote among more than a score of members representing builders, yacht yards, dealers, distributers and accessory firms was practically unanimous.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 18. -- Kelly Petillo, daring little Italian-American driver from Los Angeles, mashed all Indianapolis speedway records for twenty-five miles late today when he whizzed over the bricks at an average speed of 121.687 miles per hour.

Princess Chlodwig HohenloheSchillingsfurst and several of her friends are planning a dinner-dance and game tournament to be held on May 28 in the Italian Garden of the Ambassador for the benefit of the general fund of the National Republican Builders, Inc.
The yachting season formally will get under way on Saturday when the first of twenty-three Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship regattas is held.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18. --Young Hamilton Wright, formerly of Yale, today added his name to the list of winners of the Garden City Golf Club invitation tournament, one of the oldest competitions in the country and that has the names of many famous golfers on its scroll.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., May 18. -- W. Stanton Barbour of the Siwanoy Country Club, winner of the qualifying medal yesterday with a par round of 73, had little difficulty today in winning the annual Morris County Club's Invitation tournament.

MOSCOW, May 18. -- The airplane Maxim Gorky the world's largest land plane and the pride of the Soviet Union, crashed in complete destruction near here today, killing forty-eight persons, every soul aboard it. The pilot of another plane, which collided with the Maxim Gorky in midair and caused the disaster, also was killed.

Frederick Douglass Junior High School retained its title in the annual P.S.A.L. junior high school track meet yesterday at the General George W. Wingate Memorial Field, while New Utrecht, for many years a power on the track, relinquished its crown in the senior high school novice competition to Evander Childs.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Marked improvement in the farm capital structure in the last two years is revealed by various government indices and surveys. The farm mortgage debt, estimated at less than $8,000,000,000, is the smallest in fifteen years; farm foreclosures have decreased; farm land values have gone up for the first time in more than a decade.

IF urgent inquiries are worth any more than the paper upon which they are written and the stamp, there should be something more than the ordinary resulting from the release of Richard Strauss's "Also Sprach Zarathustra" which has arrived in Victor Album M-257.

AUTOMOBILE manufacturing breathed a composite sigh of relief when news of the Toledo strike settlement was broadcast. The effect of it was to start more than 31,000 persons on the way back to Work and to allow twelve factories in ten cities to resume production.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 18. -- Spectacular Jesse Owens today bettered one world's record, matched another and shattered a pair of meet marks as he carried Ohio State to an easy triumph over Wisconsin, Northwestern and Chicago in their annual quadrangular track and field meet at Dyche Stadium.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 17. -- One year after the outbreak of the turbulent longshoremen's strike the Pacific Coast again is confronted with a succession of industrial struggles. On far-flung sectors of the Western seaboard, labor once more is on the picket line.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the following hearings have been called at the office of the commission in Washington:

Commodity futures were mixed in price results and trading was quiet in the short session yesterday. The sugar market was the slowest in several months, transactions amounting to only 1,400 tons in new contracts, old contracts not being traded.

IT may be safely predicted that Ursula Parrott's latest novel will be widely read. It bears the unmistakable stamp of authenticity; it is pleasant and easy reading; and it present a contemporary view of marriage in its relation to careers and of careers as they affect marriage.

WOODBURY, L.I., May 18. -- Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins Jr. were hosts tonight at Ben Robyn Farm, their country home, for the West Hills race ball that followed the Spring meeting of the West Hills Racing Association this afternoon on the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White.

A survey of the American merchant fleet to determine the condition of ships and their needs with respect to improvement of their safety facilities is urged by Theodore E. Ferris, naval architect, in a statement to the Maritime Law Association of the United States.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., May 18 (AP). -- General Evangeline Cory Booth, international commander of the Salvation Army, came to the United States today bringing with her an enthusiastic belief that the world is rapidly coming to recognize youth as the driving force behind its advancement.

THE South provides an inexhaustible source of material for literary folk. T.S. Stribling, in accepting the Pulitzer award last year, remarked that it was not difficult to write interestingly about a region so rich in color and story, and spoke with some pity of less fertile sections in which authors had to be content with only the barest necessaries of plot beyond the simple human race.

Children's Day will be observed in some of the churches today, following Mother's Day of a week ago. Commencements of Sunday Schools will be held and certificates presented. A number of Sunday Schools will close until Fall. It also will be "Poppy Sunday," as the annual poppy drive of World War veterans will begin tomorrow.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 18. -- In a combination sail and rowboat of fifteen feet overall, two men will sail from here for New York on May 27 with the expectation of completing the 700-mile voyage in a week, if favorable weather is encountered.

Efforts are under way to revive the United States Express Company, which has been inactive since 1914, and launch it into some branch of banking, it was disclosed yesterday. Like the Adams Express Company, it was organized in 1854 as an association under New York laws.

LONDON. -- Great Britain's new Housing bill, to be reported in Parliament from committee the week of May 19, is expected to pass without material amendment. By means of this bill and the slum clearance program Great Britain proposes to make the most thoroughgoing and systematic effort she has yet made to solve the housing problem.

IT is a testimony to the vitality of the Whiteoaks that they can even survive transplantation to the past. Miss de la Roche risked a good deal when she staged her latest Jalna story in 1906 -- twenty years earlier than the opening of her saga -- but the results of the experiment are remarkably successful.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The leading tennis tournament of May, the Colony tournament, will be played off on the En-Tout-Cas courts down by the Casino on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week. There will be men's and women's singles, and doubles and mixed doubles.

Making his own pace from start to finish, Joe Moclair of Manhattan Prep won the one-mile run for the third successive year to accomplish the outstanding individual feat at the fourth annual track and field championships of the Manhattan-Bronx-Westchester division of the C.H.S.A.A. at Manhattan Field yesterday.

WARSAW, May 17. -- A new political battlefield has been created in Europe by the death of Marshal Josef Pilsudski. Here in the next few months will centre a great struggle for Poland's exclusive friendship.

Louis A. Cuvillier, veteran Democratic representative of the Twentieth Assembly District, who was the oldest member of the Assembly in years of service, died at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning of bronchial pneumonia at the home of his sister, Mrs. Alice Cooley of 1,120 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx. He was 64 years old.

The first time I saw T.E. Lawrence was in Jerusalem soon after its capture by General Allenby. Strolling past the bazaars on Christian Street I had observed a Bedouin arrayed in the agal, keffiyeh and aba worn only by the princes of the desert.

IS free speech an essential part of the American college and university system? This question, never for long obscured, has again become of major importance. Clarence E. Lovejoy, secretary of the Columbia University Alumni Federation, has charged that radical activities on the campus are alienating alumni support.

The performers, celebrities and carnival atmosphere usual to a "monster benefit" were on view last night at Madison Square Garden, where the National Variety Artists and the Masonic Clubs of New York State joined forces in their Actors Day Charity Jubilee.

CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP). -- Leaders of Fundamentalists in the Presbyterian Church in the United States mustered their forces today for a drive on so-called modernism at the 147th General Assembly of the church here May 23-29.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., May 18 (AP). -- Joseph J. Bruno, former Schuylkill County detective, was convicted tonight of murder in the second degree in the slayings of three victims of the Kelayres "massacre" of last election eve.

A few yacht skippers won't rejoice seeing this suggestion that Northport should be a port of call for a week-end or two this season. They have been "in the know" about this well-nigh perfect anchorage, but have guarded the information too closely.

ABOUT HER TRAVELS: Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh, poet, has turned prose writer. Last week it was announced that her "North to the Orient" will be published in the Fall. The book tells about her air jaunt to Japan with her husband four years ago.

INTO an Alaskan valley sixty-six families of colonists from the drought-stricken areas of Minnesota have come to settle. It makes a dramatic episode which probably calls to many minds the tales of Jack London and Robert Service. Most of all it suggests, no doubt, hard journeys by dog teams over the great, unsettled spaces.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 18. -The Bach Choir's twenty-fifth festival in Packer Memorial Church at Lehigh University closed today with a performance of the Mass in B minor, sung in commemoration of the 250th anniversary of the birth of the composer.

EVEN with the limitations of that strict disciplinarian, the microphone, the Bishop of Broadminster, ne Walter Connolly, seemed to have enough elbow room to misbehave with that unconscious spirit of misbehavior so characteristic of the Bishop -- and Mr. Connolly.
ONE of the reasons why the New Yorker loves his city is that he can so easily leave it behind -- if only for a day.
Major passenger airplane disasters in recent years included:
ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- With Babe Ruth the magnet, baseball's faithful continued today to flock to Sportsman's Park despite an organized labor boycott of the world champion Cardinals.
GALLERY D6 at the Metropolitan has witnessed the staging of many triumphs. To this long and distinguished list must now be added the loan exhibition of Oriental rugs and textiles.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 18. -- G.E. Mole and W.A. Ketcham each broke 48 out of 50 targets in the skeet shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. As the latter was shooting for targets only, the scratch trophy was taken by Mole. T. Dancroft, A.R. Kennedy, D. Sklar and W. F. Mathewson tied for the handicap cup.

SONG swells from the taut throats of Harlem's "angels" in the squat, maroon-brick building in West 115th Street which is their heaven. Almost every day, at about 2 o'clock, a short Negro, with dose, sparse hair and a wide, smudgy mustache, sits at the head of a U-shaped board and sips milk slowly from a conical green glass.

THIS practical and richly informed handbook will be a godsend for persons concerned with the production of amateur plays and pageants. For it is designed and developed on simple, practical lines, so fully described and illustrated that the directions can be easily followed.

Pig iron production in the United States last year was 15,676,889 gross tons, the largest for a year since 1931, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Output in 1933 was 13,000,719 tons.

Aroused by recent charges of several alumni that radicalism was widespread at Columbia University, many graduates have written to the Alumni Federation expressing their disbelief in the statement that "dangerous doctrines" were supported by students and teachers, Clarence E. Lovejoy, secretary of the federation, declared yesterday.

The bond market yesterday closed its abbreviated session of the week with a display of general firmness. United States Government loans were a shade stronger, most quotations closing 1-32 to 3-32 point higher on the day. Foreign government bonds, which were pronouncedly weak on Friday, rallied moderately.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- The committee of the Illinois Senate, appointed to hunt for possible sedition in the teaching at tax-immune educational institutions throughout the State, indicated a disposition to confine its inquiry to class-room instruction when Charles R. Walgreen, accuser, and the University of Chicago, defendant, appeared at its first hearing held here this week.

Criminology is merely a hobby with Riley Blackwood, who is a dramatic critic on a Chicago newspaper. Unlike most of the amateur sleuths in fiction, he is not infallible. He makes mistakes a-plenty, and for one of them he almost pays with his life.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- A direct challenge that it press officially the government-owned central bank proposal advocated by Secretary Morgenthau was hurled at the administration today by Senator Glass of Virginia.

MANY a modest little newspaper squib probably has a long and involved story behind it, or ahead of it. Lillian Maize Taft selects an innocent looking item of the kind one often skips in the papers: "Will any one having knowledge of the whereabouts of James Lancelot Bryndham, who left England for the United States in 1876, or any of his descendants, communicate at once with Messrs.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP). -- The Athletics gave the Browns a second straight whitewashing today, beating them 3 to 0. Vernon Wilshere, Indiana University collegian, stopped the visitors with four hits and struck out nine.

SALEM, N.H., May 18 (AP). -- Identify, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt s 4-year-old son of Man o' War, proved that his victory in the Toboggan Handicap last Wednesday at Belmont Park was no part of a fluke when he captured the Granite State Handicap at Rockingham Park today.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- While the secret service, charged with protection of the currency of the United States, is always alert in the war against counterfeiters, present conditions have necessitated even greater vigilance.

SYRACUSE, May 18. -- With announcement today of the valedictorian and salutatorian of the class of 1935 and the names of highest ranking seniors in each college and school, plans for the sixty-fourth annual commencement week program at Syracuse University are practically complete.

l A tea dance will be given on May 28 at the Park Lane under the auspices of the Bide-A-Wee Homa for Animals. The occasion will cele brate the opening of a 'PuppF, Club" on the roof of the hotel where the dogs of hotel residents will be housed, fed and cared for under the supervision of Dr. Charles E. Fletcher, veterinarian in charge.

COLLECTING Oriental rugs is not an inexpensive hobby, but it has many followers. Almost every one who has an antique or semi-antique rug eventually becomes an exponent of the rug lore. The tremendous variety of designs and their meaning; the subtleties of color and indications as to period and age of a particular example -- a knowledge of these things contributes to appreciation.

ROME, May 18. -- When Premier Mussolini spoke this week on the Italo-Abyssinian crisis he was at great pains to reassure those who watch with some anxiety the dispatch to Africa of large bodies of troops and fear Italy's military efficiency will be impaired in the event of serious complications in Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The increase in building activity, unbroken in 1935, continued during April, while the value of permits issued was 65 per cent above that of the corresponding month in 1934, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The sound of an auctioneer's hammer at 7 o'clock last night brought to a close the sale of art treasures and furnishings of Ophir Hall, the residence of the late Mrs. Whitelaw Reid at Purchase, N.Y. The last sale set a grand total of $290,322.50 for the series of public auctions that opened last Tuesday.
LEXINGTON, Va., May 18. -- Washington and Lee scored in the tenth today to defeat the Navy, 3 to 2, and write finis to a season that gave them the Southern Conference championship.
UTICA, N.Y., May 18. -- Protest against bills in Congress aimed at private enterprise wag urged by speakers here this afternoon at a meeting of the newly organized Women Investors in America, Inc.

DODGE CITY, Kan., May 17. -- The purge order of J.D.M. Hamilton, Kansas member of the Republican National Committee, to restrict the Kansas delegates to the Springfield convention to those who are anti-New Deal from triple A to ZED, lays the ground work for a party scrap in Kansas.

WHENEVER the American radio system of broadcasting is attacked, some Patrick Henry always jumps to his feet to exclaim that the American plan, unhampered by many strict rules, as in foreign lands, is as free as the trees in a March gale to be pruned naturally by the winds of public opinion.

WASHINGTON, May l8 -- Creation of a National Commission on Social Education to "mobilize the civic, educational, religious and social forces of the country in a community attack on sources of delinquency and crime" was voted at a White House conference of more than 200 social workers today.

Postponement of reform legislation until national recovery is assured is advocated by editors and publishers of half of 228 newspapers of a combined circulation of 2,946,620 in thirty States, in response to a nation-wide poll taken in the newspaper industry by Newsdom, newspaper publication.

HAMBURG, Germany, May 18. -- Because the members called their club the "Citizens Society" a Jewish organization here has been suppressed by the police. The club drew its membership largely from Hamburg's old Jewish commercial aristocracy, which has been intimately associated with the city's development as a port and commercial centre.

Five hundred delegates are expected to attend the eleventh annual convention here of the Hospital Association of New York State next Thursday and Friday in conjunction with meetings of the New York Association of Medical Record Librarians, the Nurse Anesthetists and the Greater New York Dietetic Association.

As a result of a correspondence between Sophie Tucker, actress, and Mayor La Guardia, ten elderly women, all residents of the city's Shelter for Homeless Women on West Fourteenth Street, attended the actors' day charity jubilee for the National Vaudeville Association fund last night in Madison Square Garden as the Mayor's guests.

Highest quotations of the week were recorded for old-crop positions at the opening of the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but the market ran into much cotton above the 12-cent level for the July position, and the list ended with losses of 4 to 10 points.

IT was Harry Leon Wilson who, rolling all the movie stars of the period into one, evolved the archtype, Merton. This symbol of ancient Hollywood came from behind the soda fountain of a small Middle Western town. He was dedicated to his Art.

SYLVIA THOMPSON'S special talents as a novelist are better exemplified here than in any of her recent works -- perhaps, also, her special limitations. Though, in the case of the limitations, one feels that they may be a matter of choice rather than of any deficiency in skill.

Revolutionary changes in the traditional protectionist outlook of Americans toward foreign trade will be stressed by speakers here this week at gatherings sponsored by exporters and importers to mark the first nation-wide observance of a "Foreign Trade Week."

Members of 160 posts of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in the metropolitan area will begin solicitations today for the annual "buddy poppy sale," continuing through Memorial Day. The poppies are made by disabled and needy ex-service men and the proceeds of the sale will be devoted to welfare and relief work.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18. -- Princeton's varsity lightweight crew won the Goldthwaite Cup, emblematic of 150-pound supremacy among Harvard, Yale and Princeton, in the seventh annual race on the Charles River today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- America's wary bid for international currency stabilization appeared sharply rebuffed tonight from the viewpoint of immediate results, but unshaken as a future objective.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Word of the crash of the Russian airliner Maxim Gorky reached its designer and builder, Andrew Toupoleff, this afternoon in Chicago. With his wife and a party of fifteen other Soviet engineers, M. Toupoleff has been in this country for the past two months, inspecting airports, airdromes and airplane and automobile factories, and the party is scheduled to return to Russia early next month.

WITH Mischa Elman as soloist, the National Orchestral Association, conducted by Leon Barzin, will give a series of five concerts devoted to the violin concerto in Carnegie Hall next season. The series will occupy five Saturday afternoons in January, February and March and will serve as a parallel for the piano concerto series given in the season just concluded, in which Ossip Gabrilowitsch was the soloist.
THE latest of the German music dictionaries, Dr. H.J. Moser's "Musik-Lexicon," 1935 edition, has been issued by the Max Hess Verlag of Berlin. It is a volume, octavo size, of over a thousand pages.

Highest quotations of the week were recorded for old-crop positions at the opening of the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but the market ran into much cotton above the 12-cent level for the July position, and the list ended with losses of 4 to 10 points.

IT was Harry Leon Wilson who, rolling all the movie stars of the period into one, evolved the archtype, Merton. This symbol of ancient Hollywood came from behind the soda fountain of a small Middle Western town. He was dedicated to his Art.

SYLVIA THOMPSON'S special talents as a novelist are better exemplified here than in any of her recent works -- perhaps, also, her special limitations. Though, in the case of the limitations, one feels that they may be a matter of choice rather than of any deficiency in skill.

Members of 160 posts of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in the metropolitan area will begin solicitations today for the annual "buddy poppy sale," continuing through Memorial Day. The poppies are made by disabled and needy ex-service men and the proceeds of the sale will be devoted to welfare and relief work.

" EGGS is eggs," said the loquacious Sam Weller, but he was beset by none of the problems that confront the city housewife. Eggs to her are eggs only when they fresh; the rub is that during nine months out of the year no one except the hen knows when an egg is fresh.

More than ninety employes of the Beth Moses Hospital, Stuyvesant Avenue and Hart Street, Brooklyn, were discharged by the hospital management at noon yesterday after a two-hour walkout in protest against the discharge of eight other workers.

Nine seniors will receive "H" pins for their meritorious service to Hunter College at a Council Day chapel next Wednesday morning. The awards will be presented in the chapel of the college, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue, by Soia Mentschikoff, '34, who was president of the Student Council 1933-34.

The final garden tour in a series for the benefit of the School Nature League will be held on Wednesday afternoon when Inisfada, the estate of Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady in Manhasset, L.I., and Cedar Hill, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer in Brookville.

THOSE of us who admire virility on the screen were of the fearful opinion that Miss Mae West would be the first major casualty when the legionaires of filmic purity trained thei heavy artillery on the Babylon of the Pacific.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18. -- Princeton's varsity lightweight crew won the Goldthwaite Cup, emblematic of 150-pound supremacy among Harvard, Yale and Princeton, in the seventh annual race on the Charles River today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP). -- America's wary bid for international currency stabilization appeared sharply rebuffed tonight from the viewpoint of immediate results, but unshaken as a future objective.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Word of the crash of the Russian airliner Maxim Gorky reached its designer and builder, Andrew Toupoleff, this afternoon in Chicago. With his wife and a party of fifteen other Soviet engineers, M. Toupoleff has been in this country for the past two months, inspecting airports, airdromes and airplane and automobile factories, and the party is scheduled to return to Russia early next month.

Hitting two pitchers viciously behind the effective hurling of Larry Burger, southpaw ace, the Long Island University baseball team overwhelmed St. Peter's College of Jersey City, in Jersey City, yesterday, 15 to 2. It was L.I.U.'s fifteenth victory in eighteen starts this season. Burger limited the home team to eight hits.

CINCINNATI'S thirty-first biennial May Festival will open Tuesday evening in Music Hall under the direction of Eugene Goossens. Six concerts will be given, four evening and two matinees. The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, augmented for some of the performances, will participate, in conjunction with the May Festival Chorus of 364 voices, trained by Alfred Hartzel, who has been chorus master of the festival since 1908.

A total of 1,280 golfers, representing 133 of the 154 clubs in the district, have applied for handicaps for the 1935 season, according to the first list of handicaps released by the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday.

Stout-limbed frogs, some of them from the Louisiana bayous, where frogs are frogs, will jump in Central Park today, weather permitting, for the honor of representing the East in the annual frog-jumping tournament in Calaveras County, Calif., later in the season.

To show how the imported manufactured article actually creates more employment in the United States than the manufactured article exported from this country, the American Manufacturers Export Association has included the above chart in a booklet entitled "Foreign Trade and Domestic Markets,'' released yesterday in connection with the national celebration of "Foreign Trade Week."

BASLE, Switzerland, May 18. -- The visit to Berlin of Leon Fraser, former president of the World Bank, was for a talk with Chancellor Hitler at the invitation of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister and president of the Reichsbank. This became known here today. Mr. Fraser also was invited to luncheon with the board of the Reichsbank.

A sharp rise in sales of mechanical refrigerators and a decline of approximately 8.1 per cent in unit prices are noted for the first quarter of this year compared with the corresponding period of 1934, in a report made public yesterday by the household refrigeration section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Foreign holders of the dollar bonds of a foreign company may not obtain enforcement of the gold clause originally inserted in the trust agreement under which such bonds were sold here, according to an order handed down last week by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upholding an order of the Supreme Court in New York County to that effect.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 18. -- Meadow Farm, the estate of Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman in Purchase, and Hilholme, that of Mr. and Mrs. Percy S. Straus in Port Chester, were opened to visitors this afternoon, in the second garden tour of a series to aid the Westchester County Children's Association.

A HOT-SPELL is likely to come along at any time during the next few weeks, and many smart women are assembling their warm-weather wardrobes now while shopping can still be done in comparative coolness.

THE history of the past four months in Europe falls into three chapters, all written under pressure. The first is summed up in the Rome and London conferences and outlines an emergency plan for a reorganization of Europe. The plan was meant to deal with the new status of Germany, and the second chapter centres in the rupture caused by the sudden and one-sided German repudiation of the existing system.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 18. -- Lawson Little, who is a 3-1 favorite in the field of 225 players, is going to have a harder test to retain his British amateur golf championship than when he won it in such spectacular fashion at Prestwick last year.

ALTUS, Okla., May 18. -- Tornadoes and floods killed at least ten persons, left five missing, injured seventy-two and wrought damage officials estimated at $1,000,000 in the once dust-harrassed sister States of Oklahoma and Texas tonight.

Boys High School of Brooklyn won first team prize in the second annual interscholastic mathematics contest held May 4 at the New York University Washington Square College under the auspices of the college chapter of Pi Mu Epsilon, national mathematics honor society, Howard E. Wahlert, faculty director of the society, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Approval by the Senate of the Wagner National Labor Relations Act and the termination of the Chevrolet Motor Company strike in Toledo in the same week were of outstanding significance to organized labor.

MOSCOW, May 18. -- The Maxim Gorky, largest land airplane in the world, crashed after a collision with a small airplane today, killing forty-nine persons, including eight women and six children, in the worst disaster ever to befall a passenger plane.

PARIS, May 18 (AP). -- Superiority in the doubles today enabled France to assume a lead of seven matches to three in the opening of the international team series between France and the British Empire.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 (AP). -- Communists and communism received a tongue-lashing today from Upton Sinclair in a heated controversy which broke on the convention floor of his "End Poverty in California" forces.

THE flight last week of Jack O'Meara, one of the world's leading experimenters in motorless flight, including both gliding and soaring, from Miami to Key West and then to Havana across ninety miles of sea, has aroused anew in the minds of many persons the question of the commercial possibilities of this type of air transport.

THE New York Public Library is forty years old this week -- forty years and no more. For an institution so young it has a remarkable patina of reputation and venerability, so that New Yorkers of nowadays think of it as ancient and immemorial; as having been here, if not since Peter Minuit's time, at least since Governor Clinton's.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP). -- Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church today announced a three-year evangelistic campaign aimed to attain reunion of the three historic denominations coincident with the 200th anniversary of John Wesley's conversion.
