A COMPETENT piece of research in a phase of American farming history followed by skillful weaving together of its results has been done by Wayne Caldwell Neely, Assistant Professor of Sociology in Hood College, in this story of the inception, development and present status and significance of the agricultural fair in the United States.

IN this book one gets the latest conclusions of science concerning how heredity works its wonders to perform, whether or not and how and why disease is transmissible, how sex is determined, and similar matters. They are authentic as far as those scientists are concerned who hold the same convictions as Dr. Mohr, who is an eminent Scandinavian medical scientist and Professor of Medicine in the Royal Frederiks University, Oslo.

WELL provided with group shows the late Spring season proves. At the Marie Sterner Gallery may be seen, until June 10, a delightful group of "Portraits of Children," the earliest being a "Shepherdess" by DeGeest, who was born near the close of the sixteenth century.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 18. -- The Japanese Economic Mission visited the Brazilian Congress today after Hachisaburu Hirao, head of the mission, addressed the Brazilian nation last night by radio. He broadcast in Japanese, which was translated into English and Portuguese.

THE days for really Summery dresses are at hand -- frocks made of fabrics that have a cool transparency and a freshness that defy the heat. More and more we are living in the open in America. Even the city-bound are getting greater enjoyment from the out-of-doors nowadays.

WHAT is a "typical American"? Is there any possible answer to the question? That is, can we put our finger upon any traits so distinguishing as to set the American off definitely from citizens of other countries?

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18. -- Cargo and passenger movements in and out of this port, in common with other shipping centres of the Pacific Coast, continue to be curtailed to some extent on account of unsettled labor conditions.

WOOL, Dorset, England, Sunday, May 19. -- After an amazing struggle for life Colonel T.E. Lawrence, "Lawrence of Arabia," succumbed this morning to the severe injuries he had suffered last Monday in an accident on his motor cycle.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- President Roosevelt again sought relaxation today in a cruise aboard the yacht Sequoia, which he boarded at Quantico, Va., for a trip that will end tomorrow evening at Annapolis.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 18. -- A front running race enabled Mrs. Elsa H. Voss's Desert Thorn to capture the featured Mannetto Steeplechase Handicap at the meeting of the West Hills Racing Association today on the estate of Thomas F. White near Woodbury in Huntington Township.

JIMMY SAVO was two days late for his first appointment with the Theatre Guild. He spent the forty-eight hours looking for the fellow who was playing the joke on him. However, it was no joke. Tomorrow night Mr. Savo will face the somewhat austere Guild first night audience from the same rostrum from which Eugene O'Neill's heroes and George Bernard Shaw's heroines have strutted their stuff.
For the first time in history a President of the United States will read a veto message before a joint session of Congress this week.

PLAY a game and see the world. Our Davis Cup players are sojourning in Mexico temporarily. Lawson Little is over in England. So is Twenty Grand. We had one track team in Europe last Summer and another in Japan. Gene Sarazen went to South America and Australia with his golf clubs. Fred Perry of jolly old England went practically everywhere with his racquet.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Divergent movements in individual industries with little change in the general trend of business activity are shown in the survey of the Department of Commerce of domestic conditions for the week ended on May 11.

With a record entry list of more than 3,000 dogs competing for the numerous cash and silver prizes the ninth annual exhibition of the Morris and Essex Club on the Giralda Farms near Madison, N.J., Saturday will be the largest dog show ever held in this country.

The tide of economic events, having in the past four years swept all but a handful of currencies down the course of depreciation, may be close to a turning. World conditions have now reached a point where a general return to the gold standard would serve to raise prices, instead of depressing them, it was declared in the annual report of the Bank for International Settlements issued last Monday.

BERLIN, May 18 (AP). -- Sister Wernera, Catholic nun convicted of smuggling German exchange out of the country, will not appeal the decision, high Catholic quarters said tonight, but will accept her punishment.

Mrs. James W. Toumey heads a group of women, members of Auxiliary No. 6 of Stony Wold Sanitarium, in charge of the arrangements for a luncheon and card party to be held Thursday at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park for the benefit of the sanitarium.

ALBANY, May 18 (AP). -- Eddie Cihocki's single with the bases full and one out in the tenth gave Albany a 4-to-3 victory over Newark today. The triumph was the second in a row for Albany over Newark and pulled the Bears out of first place in the International League.

PARIS, May 16. -- Mainbocher's new mode is restoring fluffy-ruffle girls to fashion; he dresses them in slim evening gowns made entirely of tiers of small ruffles. He shows novel sashes edged all round with tiny ruffles; they are tied in huge bustlebows and match the full chiffon frocks they accompany; these are finished with ruffled decolletes.

Period furniture, English and American silver, and other furnishings and decorations will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons.

BOSTON, May 17. -- Revolutionary happenings in Massachusetts: The first professional horse racing with legalized betting in the history of the State starts at Suffolk Downs, in East Boston, almost in sight of the gilded dome, on July 8. The Governor has just signed a bill which transforms the taverns that came in with repeal into old-fashioned saloons.

WATERVILLE, Me., May 18. -- Colby College, on the shores of the Kennebec River here, held a special convocation today in commemoration of one of its sons, Elijah Parish Lovejoy, a militant defender of the freedom of the press, who gave his life at Alton, Ill., in 1837 in defense of that principle.

On account of the marked expansion in labor union activities and the consequent greater need of revenue caused thereby, the extent to which payments of dues and assessments are allowed as deductions for income tax purposes has become of relatively more importance to the members of such organizations.

Interest in redemption of bonds last week was centred more in the plans of several industrial corporations to retire soon large amounts before their dates of maturity than in the actual calls, which were few compared with previous weeks. Redemptions added to the May list were all municipals, while those posted for later months included several sizable corporate operations as well as a miscellaneous assortment of municipal bonds of several States.

TORONTO, Ont., May 18. -- Gold mines of Ontario for the first three months of 1931 milled 1,648,882 tons of ore and produced 486,887 ounces of gold and 80,411 ounces of silver of a total value of $16,447,321. For the same quarter of 1934, 1,509,755 tons of ore were milled, from which was produced 495,191 ounces of gold and 111,318 ounces of silver valued at $16,996,305.

Speaking last week on the President's behalf, three of his aides -- Messrs. HOPKINS, ICKES and WALKER -- outlined the new $4,000,000,000 program which is intended to take up the slack of unemployment. Mr. WALKER stressed the question of speed. Heretofore, he said, the primary elements of consideration in planning projects have been "utility, engineering, soundness and legal authority."

MUKDEN. IN a vacant lot adjacent to the Mukden police station and only a few yards from the building that housed the headquarters of General Honjo during the troubled times of late 1931, there stands an old tree that has recently become an object of veneration to the Chinese population of this city.

THE march of time does not seem to have lessened Mr. Oppenheim's productivity, the first of his books having appeared forty-eight years ago, with the latest giving no sign of exhausted inventiveness, nor of any waning capacity to spin tales in the manner of his prime.

CINCINNATI, May 18 (AP). -- Ailments of cities will be diagnosed and methods of making them more healthful, beautiful places in which to live will be discussed in a national conference on planning beginning here Monday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. -- A collection of ancient rifles, all gathered within a radius of 150 miles of White Sulphur Springs, will be placed on exhibition today at the Greenbrier. They are well preserved specimens of long-range muzzle-loaders used by mountaineer huntsmen during the Civil War period and before.

The increased volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last week, which at times swamped the ticker, served to remind members of the efforts that engineers for the Exchange are making to speed up the quotation system. Principal attention is being given now to perfecting the express stock ticker and to developing a short-wave radio apparatus by which quotations may be transmitted from the floor to the telephone quotation bureau fifteen stories above.

One of your more irate correspondents has seen fit to flay the figurative hides of the Messrs. Hecht and MacArthur for their "obvious bit of tomfoolery," "The Scoundrel." I, for one, cannot agree with this easily aroused gentleman who so eagerly entered the portals of Mr. Rockefeller's Cinema Cathedral to worship at their flickering shrine but instead remained to scoff.

Net income of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation of New Jersey and the United Shoe Machinery Corporation of Maine for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28 amounted to $8,825,514, after Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent after dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock to $3.65 a share on 2,292,064 shares of common stock, excluding 37,525 shares held in the treasury.

CRACOW, Poland, May 18. -- After a new demonstration of national affection surpassing in fervor even his funeral in Warsaw, Marshal Josef Pilsudski's body today was placed in the crypt in Wawel Cathedral, where it will remain permanently.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18. -- At the Ardsley Country Club at Ardsley-on-the-Hudson, which included among its founders in 1897 members of the Gould, Rockefeller, Whitney and Vanderbilt families and many other wealthy New Yorkers, there resounded this afternoon the crack of the hammer of Auctioneer Edwin Storms as he sold much of the furnishing for a song.

ALBANY, May 18. -- For the first time in the history of the State three women members of the Legislature will speak from the same public platform. Senator Rhoda Fox Graves of Gouverneur and Assemblywomen Doris I. Byrne of the Bronx and Miss Jane H. Todd of Tarrytown will be the principal speakers at a "Review of the 1935 Legislature" Monday night at 7 o'clock in the Assembly chamber at Albany.

THE Town Meeting, an American institution dating back to the earliest Colonial days; will be expanded to a national scope in a series of weekly broadcasts beginning May 30, under the auspices of the League for Political Education.

WITH vigor the "battle of the airports" proceeds. Last week Newark celebrated "Air Transport Day," marking the seventeenth anniversary of the first commercial air mail flown between Hadley Field and Washington. The airport's new administration building, built with public works funds, was thrown open to the public and modem air transports of the four major lines were put on view.

Slipping down out of the sunset sky at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday, Lieut. Commander D.W. Tomlinson added three new world's records for speed with load for land planes and two new American records to the fourteen he set on Thursday.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 19. -- A chubby, soft-spoken little man who is "daddy" to more than 2,000 children is receiving his annual flood of commencement invitations -- each begging him to come and see the graduation of the sender.

PARIS, May 19 (AP). -- Thousands of marching Frenchmen celebrated Joan of Arc Day and commemorated a firing squad's execution of insurgent Parisians of the 1871 Commune in demonstrations today of the political Right and Left.

VATICAN CITY, May 19. -- The first English saints proclaimed since the Reformation were canonized in St. Peter's this morning with all the splendid ritual and mystic symbolism that the Catholic Church reserves for its most solemn occasions.

Proportional representation is stressed by the Merchants Association in a fourteen-point program for charter revision, filed with the Charter Revision Commission and made public by the association yesterday.

EASTON, Pa., May 19. -- Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, delivered the baccalaureate sermon to 160 members of the graduating class here today and told them the years they had spent in college constituted a period of national chastening.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,508,970,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

The city of Indianapolis, Ind., has advertised for the third time in three weeks the sale of a new issue of $8,000,000 of bonds, the award to be made tomorrow if the underwriters of the bonds and the city can come to an understanding on several points which on the previous occasions were a stumbling block.

A 15-year-old Brooklyn girl, whose father had warned her to be home by midnight from a neighborhood birthday party, was killed by a fall from the roof of a three-story apartment house yesterday as she tried to descend a clothesline to her bedroom on the top-floor at 2:30 A.M.

The annual award of honor to that member of the Town Hall Club who, in the opinion of fellow-members, "has in the past year made the most conspicuous contribution to the enlargement and enrichment of life" is now being selected by vote, it was disclosed yesterday.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 19. -- The persecution of Catholic nuns and monks by the German Nazis was condemned today by Samuel Untermyer in a plea for a boycott to "starve out these bandits." Mr. Untermyer, who is chairman of the Westchester unit of the United Jewish Appeal for German Refugees, spoke at a meeting in his Greystone home here for the purpose of establishing a Yonkers division of the drive.

During the two months following Feb. 1, when surface cars were supplanted by buses on Madison and Fourth Avenues, the Madison Avenue Coach Corporation carried 87 per cent more passengers than were carried in the street cars during the same period in 1934, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.
The cotton futures market was more active last week than for some time. At the close on Saturday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 10 points from a week earlier.

Spring and Autumn, blossom time and harvest time, are two seasons of the year when HUEY LONG'S program of every man a king begins to take on plausibility. More often it is every woman a queen, but men are growing more frequent in the role of consort.

BERLIN, May 19. -- The killing cost of a bureaucratic organization of business in National Socialist Germany, long a subject of complaint in business circles, is beginning to find open expression in public speeches and the public prints.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- With better prospects for small grain crops in leading producing sections of the United States, also reports of rain where needed in Argentina, while the showing in Europe is somewhat better, there is a feeling in the wheat trade that there must be more outside and general speculative buying to sustain present price levels.

A group of ten special Treasury agents has been working in cooperation with the undercover squad of the Police Department for the past two weeks listing and investigating the seven most vicious gangs in the metropolitan area, it was learned at police headquarters yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 19. -- Buying of steel of some descriptions decreased slightly last week, but steel men view the state of demand with complacency because uncertainty about the continuance of the NRA has made buyers so conservative that the only steel that they take is that which they must have, and this indicates a good rate of ultimate consumption.

The development of foreign trade for the United States and the facilities of the Port of New York will be discussed this week at a series of luncheon meetings in connection with the observance of National Foreign Trade Week and Maritime Day.

The Twentieth Century Fund, Inc., announced yesterday that A.A. Berle Jr., Chamberlain of the City of New York; Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, and Morris E. Leeds, president of the Leeds Northrup Company, Philadelphia, had been appointed to the fund's board of trustees.

HEWLETT HABOR, L.I., May 19. -- Champion Torohill Trader, black cocker spaniel owned by Leonard J. Buck, won the best-in-show prize for which 725 dogs competed in the thirty-fourth annual exhibition of the Long Island Kennel Club at the Seawane Club today. Former Governor Smith presented the Seawane Club Trophy offered for best in show.
FOND DU LAC, Wis., May 19. -- Thousands of Wisconsin Progressives crowded this little city on Lake Winnebago today to celebrate the first anniversary of the founding of their party.

MANILA, May 19 (AP). -- The seizure of more than ninety home-made shotguns and the implication of four prominent Filipinos in the May 2 Sakdalista revolt resulted today from government efforts to dissipate unrest in the provinces.

LONDON, May 19. -- Many military officers of the old school have belittled Colonel Thomas E. Lawrence in the past but Viscount Allenby, who was his commanding officer when he was in Arabia, paid a tribute to his military genius tonight.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here closed yesterday 1 7/8 to 2 7/8 cents a bushel lower for the week; corn, 1/2 to 2 1/8 cents higher, with July leading the bulge; oats, 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents lower, May leading the break; rye, 1 7/8 to 3 1/8 cents lower, the latter on May.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Cheaper grades of live cattle have advanced 75 cents to $1.25 a hundredweight since the close of March, with those selling below $11 up as much as $1.50. Steers which brought $12 to $14 have advanced only 10 to 25 cents, says The Chicago Drovers Journal.

With the beginning of the third week in May the decline in the number of attractions in the local art exhibition field becomes marked. Including not less than seven shows of student work by art schools, not more than a score of exhibitions are on the calendar for the week or as having opened over the weekend just past.

NEW HAVEN, May 18. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.3, which compares with 82.2 the week before, 82.1 two weeks before, 81.8 three weeks before and 81.5 four weeks before.

In Topics of The Times of May 15 you discussed the action taken by the New York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the matter of the failure of the New Deal, and, indeed, the failure of the entire profit system.

Every bill which shall have passed the Senate and Assembly shall, before it becomes a law, be presented to the Governor; if he approve, he shall sign it; but if not, he shall return it with his objections. -- New York State Constitution.
Sales of apartment houses in Brooklyn by savings banks featured recent activity there.
HAVRE, France, May 19 (AP). -- A seamen's strike that had threatened to delay the maiden voyage to America of the French Line's mammoth Normandie ended today.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S announced intention to read his veto of the Patman bill before a joint session of the two houses of Congress has greatly stirred Washington. The Constitution choppers cry out that it would be an unprecedented and probably illegal act. What right has the President to throw himself into the legislative proceedings of Congress? Well, the Constitution plainly gives him that right.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 19.- Their second victory this season rewarded the efforts of the cricketers of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today when they defeated the Flatbush Cricket Club of Brooklyn by 128 runs. The Crescent players ran up 198 runs, and then declared with eight wickets down. Flatbush was all out for 70.

Recognition of the sound film as a mechanical aid to learning as important as the telescope and the microscope is urged by James Marshall, a member of the Board of Education, in a report to the board issued for publication today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 19. -- While business generally has improved and prospect for further improvement are good, the possibilities of this forward development apparently rest to a considerable degree on the expression of a confidence-begetting attitude by the government, in the opinion of the industrial securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

OVERBROOK, Pa., May 19. -- The third and concluding day of the woman's national lacrosse tournament on the Sacred Heart Academy grounds was climaxed by a game between the newly named 1935 all-America first and reserve teams today. The first team won, 9 to 2.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 19. -- Twelve players participated in an eight-period cut-in polo match on Waterbury Field at the Meadow Brook Club today that resulted in 12-to-8 victory for the Reds over a white-shirred combination.

Two solemn public celebrations were held in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in honor of the canonization by the Pope earlier in the day at St. Peter's, Vatican City, of Bishop John Fisher and Sir Thomas More, British martyrs. Both local services were under the auspices of the St. Paul Guild.

A growing sentiment for inter-denominational unity among Christian churches was reported yesterday morning, by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street, at communion services.

PRAGUE, May 19. -- The Hitlerite "Sudeten German party" took between 70 and 80 per cent of the entire German vote in some districts of Czechoslovakia in today's general election. The gains were registered at the expense of the German Socialists, Agrarians, Catholics and Communists, apparently in about equal proportions.

In our work at the Legal Aid Bureau of the Educational Alliance, thousands of cases are handled involving every phase of human conduct, many of them displaying man's inhumanity to man. But still worse are the cases involving woman's inhumanity to woman.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 19. -- The first contingent of Scottish enthusiasts arrived today for the amateur golf championship, which starts tomorrow, with news there will be a "dark horse" running against Lawson Little.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP). -- A home run over the right-field fence by Roger Cramer in the seventh inning gave the Athletics their third straight victory over the Browns today, 6 to 5. A crowd of 8,000 saw the game.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP). -- With Rookie John Whitehead pitching his sixth straight triumph, the White Sox downed the Red Sox, 6 to 5, today, to take their first series in the East and maintain their hold on the American League leadership.

Twenty-one field expeditions of the American Museum of Natural History made important contributions to scientific knowledge or to the collections of the museum in 1934, according to the annual report of that institution, made public yesterday by its director, Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 19. -- Further severe fighting on the battlefront north of Villa Montes, in consequence of an attempt of the Paraguayans to retrieve their losses by breaking through the Bolivian centre, was reported today. Military headquarters said the enemy's attacks had been defeated.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Severance of diplomatic relations between the United States and Germany might be "justified" by the cruelties of the religious and racial persecutions of Jews by the Hitler government, Senator William H. King of Utah asserted today in an address before 500 delegates to the Southeastern regional convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.
In connection with the old-age compulsory pension system set up by the Economic Security Bill, now pending before the Senate, I would like to make the following comments:

The city's financial condition has improved sufficiently to permit its sinking fund to enter into competitive bidding on the bond issue now contemplated to finance the purchase of 500 steel cars for the municipal subway lines, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

Salt-water anglers of the metropolitan area who area planning trips to Peconic Bay for the early weak-fishing apparently need hesitate no longer about making charter reservations. Catches over the week-end indicated that visitors to that popular rendezvous may count on experiencing reasonable success henceforth. The run is expected to reach its peak in about two weeks.

PARIS, May 19. -- Having obtained satisfaction in a large proportion of their demands, the personnel of the French Line decided today to return to work and the liner Champlain, which had been held in port at Havre since Thursday, sailed this evening with twenty-two passengers and 500 tons of freight.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean, pitching despite a slight knee injury, turned in his fifth victory of the season today as the world champion Cardinals defeated the Braves, 7 to 3, in their series finale before 12,000 fans.
After sixty-three years with the same concern, the Johns-Manville Corporation, William Waldron (Pop) Hanold debated yesterday the question of retirement.

Mr. JOHN RIDLEY MITCHELL, Representative in Congress of the Fourth Tennessee District, is to be praised for his constancy. He served his first term in the Seventy-second Congress. It was and is the desire of his soul to prevent the practice of nepotism. He introduced a bill making it unlawful for a member of Congress to appoint any relative within the third degree to a job in the legislative branch.

The stubborn blowing of the wind Saturday on Cayuga Lake brought bitter disappointment to thousands of persons who had helped to make Cornell's Spring Day as colorful an event as it ever had been in the past, but it is probable that a little group of young men in blue uniforms were more thoroughly disappointed than any of the others.

The wholesale markets here were stimulated last week by a more active demand for Summer merchandise, particularly from those sections of the country which have been experiencing more seasonable weather conditions. Popular-price lines of women's apparel for warm-weather wear, especially washable and sheer dresses, were ordered quite liberally, some retailers sending orders by wire and mail for quick deliveries.

The Rev. Edmund A. Steimle, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Augustus Steimle of New York City, was installed yesterday afternoon as pastor of the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour, Bergen Avenue and Atlantic Street, Jersey City. Many parishioners of the Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street, Manhattan, of which Dr. Steimle is the pastor, were present.

ALBANY, May 19. -- From February to March, New York City wholesale concerns increased the number of their employes 0.2 per cent. Payrolls increased 0.8 per cent. A year ago increases of 1.6 per cent in employment and 1.0 per cent were recorded from February to March.

Women interested actively in the Prosperity Shop, a permanent thrift shop devoted to the needs of various charitable organizations in the city, have arranged a luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the shop for May 28 in the Renaissance Room and Louis XV Ballroom of the Ambassador.
" A Shot in the Dark," a Chesterfield Picture with Charles Starrett and Robert Warwick, will open at the Mayfair with a 6 o'clock preview this evening.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 19. -- The morale of the Naval Academy is praised in a report of the board of visitors appointed by the President and the heads of the houses of Congress. Dr. K.C.M. Sills, president of Bowdoin College, was chairman of the board.

Plans for a joint committee to force official action against vice, gambling and racketeering in the city are under consideration by the City Affairs Committee as a measure to follow up its recommendation to Governor Lehman that he appoint a special vice prosecutor to supersede District Attorney William C. Dodge.

The old McClure property at Fair Haven, N.J., has been sold by William B. Potts Jr. to Henry E. Butler, it was learned yesterday. The original residence was built by the late David McClure about sixty years ago but was remodeled in 1930.

LONDON, May 18. -- Secretary, Morgenthau's remarks on stabilization this week were welcomed here politically and financially, but it cannot be said that any hopes of bringing the present currency chaos to an early end have been aroused.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The status of important legislation pending in Congress is as follows:

CHICAGO, May 19 (AP). -- A home run with two on bases by Lou Chiozza in the third inning and more than eight innings of shutout relief pitching by Sylvester Johnson, who fanned ten, today gave the Phillies a second straight triumph over the Cubs, 3 to 2, and the series, two games to one.

GENEVA, May 19. -- Great Britain, it appears on the eve of the eighty-sixth League of Nations Council session, will make a strong effort this week to prevent by some form of collective action through the League any clash between Italian and Ethiopian forces in the next fortnight.

The commodity futures markets here had periods of strength last week, but advances in prices were checked by profit-taking. At the close on Saturday some of the principal staples were slightly below the prices at the close of the previous week, notably sugar and coffee.

Just before 11 o'clock yesterday morning a stream of water under high pressure arched from the twenty-sixth floor of the Municipal Building, cut a rainbow-like trajectory into the blue sky and fell in a shimmering sheet of mist.

Charley (Red) Ruffing shut out the Indians for ten innings yesterday at the Stadium, but unfortunately Wally Stewart subjected the Yankees to the same treatment and the teams were deadlocked in a thrilling duel before 28,000 as they entered the eleventh.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Clark resolution, limiting the extension of the NRA to ten months, was designed to, and unquestionably will, bring to an immediate end the entire code program, according to a report made public tonight by the legal subcommittee of the Industry and Business Committee for NRA Extension.

BERLIN, May 18. -- The unprecedented fluidity of the money market this week has led to further conjectures about the impending reduction in the Reichsbank discount rate and also about the rumor of a large Reich loan.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Passage of the bill advocated by Governor Horner increasing the State sales tax from 2 to 3 per cent in a modifield form and an early settlement of the Illinois relief crisis this week were predicted today.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- World trade will not expand appreciably until international currency relationships have been established upon a basis more inspiring of confidence than the "present improvised system of clearing transactions between nations," according to a report of a survey made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

The disaster to the airplane Maxim Gorky had apparently nothing directly to do with the size of the machine. Two planes clashed in midair and the result was the one usual in such circumstances. Yet the disaster serves to call attention again to the problem presented by giant airplanes.

The Governors Island polo team rode to a 10-to-3 triumph over the New York A.C. four in a return engagement at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday. Last week, the teams battled to an 8-all deadlock.

William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the Progressive Republican State Committee, which he and W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican State chairman, organized to rid the party of alleged Old Guard control, made public yesterday a list of members of the committee covering most of the counties in the State.

BERLIN, May 19. -- Fresh orientation of Franco-German relations is expected to issue from the meeting between French Foreign Minister Pierre Laval and Prussian Premier Hermann Wilhelm Goering, at Cracow Saturday, and the circumstances attending it impress onlookers here as something implying more than a casual exchange of views.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19. -- Ten appointments to the faculty of Harvard University were announced tonight by President Conant. Nine are for a full year and one for a half term.

BURKBURNETT, Texas, May 19 (AP). -- Texas and Oklahoma counted thirteen persons dead, six missing and scores injured tonight in flood and wind storms as swollen streams continued to exact heavy damage.
Members of the New York State Optometric Association opened their fortieth annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, where the sessions will continue through tomorrow.

Three national art organizations will hold their annual conventions in Washington, D.C., this week -- the American Federation of Arts, the College Art Association and the American Association of Museums. The sessions, as usual, will cover a wide range of pertinent interests and many prominent speakers will take part in the programs.
In excess of 500 tournaments for seniors and juniors have been sanctioned for 1935 by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

ROME, May 19. -- Only one man knows precisely what Italy hopes to achieve by her increasingly portentous concentration of forces in East Africa or how far she will go to attain her objectives. So far he has not disclosed his plans to discreet but insistent inquiries from London and Paris.

PITTSBURGH, May 19. -- The Dodgers left for Cincinnati tonight still hanging on to second place. They lost the final of their series to the Pirates today, 9 to 6, but the Phillies' conquest of the Cubs enabled the Stengel clan to remain in the runner-up position in the league race.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin hailed Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. tonight as the first Federal official "to propose the government ownership of the central banking system," and again defended the Patman Bonus Bill, which faces a Presidential veto.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Supplies of American cotton in this country on April 30 were considerably smaller than on the corresponding date in recent previous years, but they were much larger than before the depression, the New York Cotton Exchange Service reports.

More than 2,000 nurses of hospitals in the metropolitan area attended the eleventh annual service in honor of Florence Nightingale and all nurses who have died in service, held last night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
John J. Raskob, former national Democratic chairman, is among nearly 500 passengers due to arrive today on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain from a round-the-world cruise.
ALBANY, May 19 (AP). -- Newark obtained an even break in the four-game series with Albany by winning both ends of a double-header today, 11 to 8 and 7 to 3.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 19. -- Today's general election passed off without disturbing incidents, according to all reports so far received. In the German area, however, there was a surprise development in the success of the Sudeten German Party founded by Henlein the "Czechoslovak Hitler."
Greenwich Village, having devoted itself unselfishly for a couple of days to a country fair and a baby parade, turned yesterday to its annual outdoor poetry show.

Following is the text of the dress by Mayor La Guardia delivered at 6:15 P.M. yesterday at the radio studios of Station WINS here and carried to amplifiers at the meeting in Fond du Lac, Wis., to celebrate the first anniversary of the Progressive party:
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 19. -- The New Jersey State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs went on record today in opposition to the dismissal of married women school teachers.

The religious democracy for which the Methodist Church stands is attested by its world-wide, inter-racial and international character, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver said yesterday in his first sermon as minister of the Old John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street.

Resentment that it should be necessary to battle against racial prejudice in "free America" was expressed last night by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora in a dinner address to the eighty-third annual convention of B'nai B'rith District 1 at the Hotel Commodore.
YONKERS, N.Y., May 19. -- Melvin Partridge of New Rochelle, former Dartmouth College captain, won the invitation tennis tournament of the Amackassin Club for the fourth time today.

Religion today is too often centred on man rather than God, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, asserted in a sermon yesterday morning. Preaching at the James Memorial Chapel, at the seminary, he said there was grave danger in letting the soul's horizon be filled with man.
MEXICO, D.F., May 19. -- The United States and Mexico completed play in the Davis Cup tennis American zone final today, the invaders carrying off the honors by a final score of 4 to 1.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 19. -- The North Shore Skeet Club of Huntington successfully defended its title as the Long Island skeet champion at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The Blue team of the Huntington organization led a field of nine by compiling a total of 468 out of 500 targets. Last year the same organization won over its own traps.

PARIS, May 19 (AP). -- Playing in mid-Summer form, Christian Boussus defeated H.W. (Bunny) Austin, British Davis Cup ace, in straight sets today, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, as France conquered Great Britain, twelve matches to seven, in their annual tea, series.

BERLIN, May 18. -- The reversion of Germany to an import surplus in April after an export surplus in March merely repeats the event in 1934, when, however, the unfavorable balance was four times larger than last month. It is noteworthy that imports increased more than in April of last year, while exports declined much less, and absolute exports were 25,000,000 marks above April of last year.

WARSAW, May 19. -- General Hermann Wilhelm G oering, Reich Air Minister and Prussian Premier, who represented the German Government at the funeral of Marshal Josef Pilsudski, conferred today with Colonel Jo sef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, and expressed his confidence that the good relations between Poland and Germany, established by the late Marshal, would continue to be cordials and friendly -- according to a statement issued by the German Embassy here.

William Solomon, now one of the Tammany leaders of the Seventeenth Assembly District, will be asked this week to be a candidate for the Tammany leadership of the Ninth Assembly District against Dennis J. Mahon, former acting president of the Board of Aldermen, at the primary election in September.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, May 19. -- The first completed section of the system of motor speedways that are to criss-cross Germany and that constitute the kernel of the government's labor creation program was opened today, in the presence of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and numerous government officials.

CINCINNATI, May 19. -- The Reds, feeling they had the crippled Giants badly on the hip, today made a terrific effort to crush that singularly magic spell which Harold Schumacher has cast over them ever since Prince Hal entered the National League, back in 1932.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 19. -- A forest fire raging on a twenty-mile front and covering more than 12,000 acres of valuable woodland in Ocean County was started this morning by a pyromaniac who was seen setting the blaze near Buckingham by the State Fire Warden, who was making an air survey of yesterday's fires.

WHAT would happen if some Luther Burbank of human beings should cross Robert Nathan and the James M. Cain of "The Postman Always Rings Twice"? Surely the resultant literature would be as strange and as fascinating and as impossible an amalgam as one could wish. Well, the impossible has happened; Robert Nathan has been crossed with James M. Cain.

OTTAWA, May 19. -- Prime Minister Bennett will be back in his place at the head of the government when the Canadian Parliament resumes tomorrow for its final pre-election sitting. It is possible that he will carry on until the end of the session, but there are few among his own supporters who now expect that he will lead the party into the election.

BERLIN, May 10 (London Times Dispatch) -- While attention has been concentrated on international affairs, the superficial tranquillity imposed on German internal life since before the Saar plebiscite shows signs of cracking here and there.

Men's straw hats will be displayed today for the first time in the windows of twenty-five of the leading department and specialty stores and hat chains, with Saturday the official opening day, as a result of the movement to put off the showing of straws, started by M.R. Litman, president of Brigham-Hopkins Company, Inc.

" Winter Orchard," a book of short stories by Josephine Johnson, whose first novel, "Now in November," has just received the Pulitzer Prize, is being made ready for publication this Summer by Simon Schuster. Many of the stories have not previously been published.

ANGELS CAMP, Calif., May 19 (AP). -- Zip, husky frog owned by Eddie Robinson of Stockton, Calif., lived up to his name today and won the seventh annual Angels Camp jubilee frog-jumping championship from a field of 300 other amphibians.

It is apparent that the article published in your paper May 12, entitled "Rising Food Costs as Viewed by AAA," by Calvin Hoover, was written in answer to the complaints of worried housewives at the rapidly increasing food prices without a corresponding increase in their incomes.

Swamplands and great waste areas covered with tall reeds and marsh grass were combed in vain yesterday by troops of Boy Scouts and adult volunteers seeking Shirley Evans, 8 years old, who vanished Friday night in the street near her home at 82-16 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

" The church's business is not politics, sociology and economics, but religion," the Rev. Dr. E. Graham Wilson, secretary of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

The annual Spring flower sale arranged by members of the executive committee of the Bargain Box will be held today at the shop, 1,175 Third Avenue, for the benefit of several charitable organizations in the city. Miss Nancy Ewing heads a group of younger members of society who will act as saleswomen.

LEWES, Del., May 19. -- Two boys, one of whom swam a mile through the rough waters of Delaware Bay, were the heroes of a rescue late this afternoon after a fishing boat had capsized off the breakwater.

In a spectacular fire which threw a smoke pall over the Glenn H. Curtiss Airport at North Beach, Queens, and halted flights there yesterday afternoon, twenty-five garbage barges were partially destroyed in Bowery Bay. The barges were being towed to Rikers Island from the Bronx and Manhattan piers of the Department of Sanitatation when they burst into flames from spontaneous combustion.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- It was "foodless" Sunday for thousands in Illinois today, as the grim race between widespread hunger and the dissolution of the relief crisis became, it was hoped, a matter of hours.

This is to be a Big Night on Fifty-second Street, with orchestras playing, dancers hopping around -- and the spirits of this world's O'Neills and Shaws whirling about like disgruntled dervishes. The Theatre Guild, to come down to the point, is offering at the Mother House her most recent revue, "Parade."

Business in the foreign exchange market last week was chiefly interesting by reason of the sharp advance in sterling, with a contrasting downward movement in the French franc. The Scandinavians, linked to the pound, also showed a substantial advance, while the Continentals were irregularly lower.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Ten additional applications for registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933, involving issues of $6,882,167.07, have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, May 19 (AP). -- An attempt to frame a new international wheat pact to replace the 1933 agreement which will expire on Aug. 1 will be made at the wheat conference opening here on Wednesday.
Almost 4,000 Polish-Americans gathered in the grand ballroom of the Manhattan Opera House yesterday afternoon to commemorate the late Marshal Josef Pilsudski.

Charging the National Biscuit Company with violating the agreement of April 29, settling the 95-day strike of 3,000 employes of the company in New York City, the Inside Bakery Workers Federal Labor Union, Local 19,585, announced yesterday its plans for a "re-strike" to protest the "company's tactics."

LONDON, May 19. -- Wrapped in the Union Jack he served so well, the body of Colonel T.E. Lawrence was borne this morning to the little slate-roofed mortuary adjoining the hospital at Bovington Camp in Dorset, where the organizer of the great "Revolt in the Desert" had died a few hours earlier.
Mr. Bernhard states that apparently Louis H. Pink, the newly appointed Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York. is not informed on the functions of the Federal Housing Administration.

The Cafeteria Workers Union, Local 110, called a strike of bakers, butchers and kitchen help in the commissary of Bickford's, Inc., 360 West Fiftieth Street, yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock in an effort to cripple the company's chain of more than forty self-service restaurants in New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP). -- A "Russianization" of American agriculture into "a government-sustained peasantry" was viewed by the American Liberty League today as a "probable" result of enacment of the Bankhead Farm Tenant Bill.

The factor to be reckoned with in this world and in the kingdom of heaven is life, Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church declared in his sermon yesterday morning at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, May 19. -- Although trading generally was rather quiet last week on the Cotton Exchange here, there were periods in which operations spurted because of activity in spot cotton and strength in securities. Speculation continued to be checked by uncertainty over the administration's course on the new crop.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- A recommendation that all members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States urge rejection by Congress of the administration's omnibus Banking Bill was contained in a letter sent out today by Harper Sibley, president of the organization.

SEATTLE, May 19 (AP). -- The steamer Denall ran aground on a lonely rock island in British Columbia waters early today but all the passengers and crew were reported safe, with a Coast Guard cutter standing by, Guard headquarters here announced.

A tall, slender goalie, with an amazing ability for making all kinds of saves, was all that prevented the United States from utter rout at the Polo Grounds yesterday as a picked American team bowed to Scotland's soccer internationalists, 5 to 1.

BOSTON, Mass., May 19. -- Organization of Stores Commodity Service, Inc., by a group of leading Boston merchants acting through Daniel Bloomfield, manager of the Retail Trade Board, has been completed.

If the sleeping soul of Jim Smiley, the Mark Twain character who educated the notorious frog Dan'l, bothered about such things, it perhaps remarked with regret yesterday afternoon the decadence of the venerable pastime of frog jumping.

SEA GIRT, N.J., May 19. -- A plea to permit New Jersey to escape the diversion penalty in Federal road awards to the State, to finance emergency relief requirements until next January without recourse to sales and income taxes, will be presented to Federal officials by a nonpartisan committee of five men.

MOSCOW, May 19. -- The Council of Peoples Commissars decided tonight to construct three new planes of the Maxim Gorky type, to be named Vladimir Lenin, Joseph Stalin and Maxim Gorky. [Nikolai Lenin's real name was Vladimir Ilyitch Ulyanoff, and he was known to his close friends and followers as Vladimir or Vladimir Ilyitch, not as Nikolai.]

Since last September, 3,655 home relief families have been dropped from relief rolls because special investigators found that they had concealed resources, the Home Relief Division reported yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

VIENNA, May 19. -- In a speech to armed Austrian Fascist formations today at Innsbruck Vice Chancellor Prince Ernst von Starhemberg proclaimed the triumph of the Heimwehr and fascism over what he called "bolshevist-democracy" and liberal ideas in politics and culture.

Seventy taxicab drivers, listed in the Police Department's Hack License Bureau as having performed meritorious acts of public service, will receive public recognition from the police within a few weeks, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Changing the church "from an organization into a fellowship" and building character to combat a "corrupt" social order were urged yesterday at a "Spiritual Emphasis Conference" of the national council of the Young Men's Christian Association at the William Sloane House, 356 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Although beaten for the first time in league competition, Dartmouth still is firmly entrenched in first place as a result of the games played during the past week in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League.

PARIS, May 18. -- The campaign now developing here in favor of a devaluation of the franc would be less active if stability of the remaining gold currencies were re-established. Therefore, Secretary Morgenthau's speech was favorably received in financial circles here, which noted that the United States Government, like the French, favored a speedy return to currency stability, which is considered capable of reviving international trade and attenuating the effects of the world depression.
Supreme Court Justice Burt Jay Humphrey, who during his quarter of a century on the bench has dealt severely with criminals, was a victim of a burglar early yesterday.

A trend on the part of corporations whose securities have been admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange to seek formal listing on the Exchange is seen by the Exchange in the applications of the Consolidated Gas Light and Power Company of Baltimore and the Standard Oil Company of Ohio for formal listing.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -The lumber industry, to retain the "small house market," is advised to start at once an organized research in architectural style studies and engineering designs in prefabricated dwellings and in other forms and methods of building economies.

ALBANY, May 19. -- Governor Lehman is determined not to be a candidate for re-election in 1936, and the major State leaders of the Democratic party have started a quiet survey of possible Gubernatorial candidates for the Presidential election year, it became known today.

The rise of American Catholic educational institutions has played a major role in the development of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, the Rev. John F.X. Pyne, regent in the Fordham University Law School, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Patman bonus bill advocates contended today that a single Senate vote might spell victory or defeat for them Wednesday after President Roosevelt delivers his veto message.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 19. -- The Maidstone Club was the scene of many informal parties this week-end. Among those giving luncheons there were Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Roberts, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. Leaman 3d, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Gilbert, Mr. and Mrs. H.J. Robertson Jr., Mr. and Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey and Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Sinclair.

PARIS, May 18. -- With supplies on the money market small, call loans and outside discount rates here were slightly higher this week than in recent months. The increasing shortage of money was characterized by the rise in the rate for contangoes on the Bourse, which were 1 3/4 per cent on May 15, compared with 1 per cent at the end of April and five-eighths of 1 per cent on April 15.

NUTLEY, N.J., May 19. -- Fire companies from three municipalities battled a fire here today that destroyed five small garages, damaged three residences and held up for two hours a dedication ceremony for a new Italian community house.

Memorial services in honor of Jewish war veterans, held yesterday morning by the Jewish War Veterans of the United States and the Ladies Auxiliary at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, were attended by 2,500 persons.

According to a press dispatch from Berlin, the German people are being urged by Julius Streicher to demonstrate their patriotism by wiping out all scientific discoveries attributed to Jewish men of medicine or even to gentile scientists with Jewish wives or assistants.

BERLIN, May 18. -- Rumors that the government planned to issue a large long-term loan had their origin in the fluidity of the money market here. Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht's view is that superfluous short-term funds should be diverted into the capital market, which has been showing signs of improvement.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19. -- Two hundred and fifty women representing almost every State in the Union are at the Garden City Hotel to attend the forty-fourth annual convention of the Daughters of the Revolution, which opened here this afternoon with a vesper service at the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

A baton used by the late Victor Herbert will be presented to Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince when Justice Prince conducts his orchestra of 100 young men and women at a benefit concert on June 1 in the auditorium of the City College School of Business.

Now that the relief investigation is over, it is proper to suggest remedies and improvements. There is no justification for looking outside of Greater New York for capable persons to fill executive positions.

The steadfast conscientious objector is the strongest weapon that can be used to curb the militarists in this country, Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church said yesterday afternoon at a meeting under the auspices of the national religious committee of the American League Against War and Fascism.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Traders in corn on the Board of Trade here are interested in the stubborn action of the May delivery, which is said to be held by processing interests and is difficult to buy at times without advancing prices. Trade in the May delivery runs less than 1,000,000 bushels dally, compared with almost 4,000,000 bushels for July.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The Home Owners Loan Corporation today called for redemption on July 1 the $325,000,000 of its outstanding 4 per cent bonds of the series of 1933-51. Simultaneously the Treasury, acting as the fiscal agent of the HOLC, offered to exchange the bonds offered for four-year 1 1/2 per cent bonds of the corporation, which will begin to pay interest as of June 1.
HOLLYWOOD, May 19. -- Jiggs was just another $50-a-week movie chimpanzee a few years ago. But he played in the two Tarzan pictures as Johnny Weissmuller's pal and that made Jiggs a star.

The movement for Alfred E. Smith for President is gaining headway, Charles C. Hellinger, chairman of the Smith-for-President Committee, declared yesterday. Mr. Hellinger announced that the committee would open headquarters this Summer and start an Intensive campaign to sell Mr. Smith to the voters of the nation as the one man in sight who can stimulate recovery and lift the country out of the depression.

PARIS, May 19. -- Foreign Minister Pierre Laval's two interviews yesterday with General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Air Minister, at Cracow after Marshal Josef Pilsudski's funeral have far eclipsed in interest here all the speeches and declarations made during M. Laval's visits either to Warsaw or Moscow.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The message President Roosevelt will deliver to Congress this week vetoing the Bonus Bill will be the fifty-fourth communication presented in person by a Chief Executive, but the first veto message read directly by a President.

Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said yesterday that applications for the renewal of drivers' licenses that expire at midnight, May 31, were lagging. Although 1,000,000 new applications are expected, fewer than 250,000 had been received up to Saturday night.

A perfect pancake landing in the East River that was manoeuvred by the pilot of a sight-seeing cabin land plane after his motor had died probably saved the lives of the pilot and his three passengers at 7:45 o'clock last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The receiverships of thirteen national banks were liquidated and finally closed and four receiverships were restored to solvency during April, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today. Receivers were appointed for two national banks in voluntary liquidation, making a net reduction of 15 receiverships during the month and leaving a total of 1,524 national bank receiverships.

On the Stock Exchange, prices for stocks advanced again last week, the "averages" reaching the highest figure since April 26, 1934, the day when that season's upward movement definitely culminated. Last week's rise was accompanied by increased trading; transactions on each full day exceeding a million shares and on Thursday footing up 2,400,000, the largest since last July.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Reaction in Congress to President Roosevelt's decision to deliver in person his veto message on the Pat-"greenback" bill encouraged the belief among administration leaders tonight that they might be able to dissipate the bonus movement for this session or to reach a compromise acceptable to the White House.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20. -- An unsalaried banking advisory board of eight members was appointed by Governor Hoffman tonight under the newly passed law creating the body and authorizing it to recommend approval or disapproval of charters and changes in capitalization and to make suggestions on other banking matters.

The charge that Frederick Gross, crippled Brooklyn bookkeeper, had slain his wife and four of his children by administering thallium sulphate, was dismissed by Magistrate John D. Mason in Brooklyn Homicide Court yesterday morning at the request of District Attorney Geoghan.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 20. -- The Straub brothers, Arthur, a professional, and Peter, an amateur of Manasquan River, today won the season's opening pro-amateur tournament of the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association, scoring a best-ball 66.

Business and industrial leaders of New York City will support the President's stand against the Patman Bonus Bill and will give whatever aid is possible in sustaining the veto, it was indicated yesterday. Both the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and the Merchants Association of New York, whose memberships include the leading business and industrial figures of the city, will be allied with the forces opposing the bonus.

United States Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate subcommittee investigating the administration of Governor Paul M. Pearson in the Virgin Islands, returned yesterday on the steamship Coamo after spending five days on the islands.

PEORIA, Ill., May 20 (AP). -- Farmers from ninety-five Illinois counties, estimated by their leaders to number 16,000, responded to Secretary Henry Wallace's attack on AAA foes today with a vote of approval for the law and the amendments asked by the Secretary to strengthen it.

Publication of an Albany dispatch that Governor Lehman was determined not to be a candidate for re-election brought a quick reaction yesterday in Democratic circles. The local Democratic leaders showed great interest in the report and it seemed certain that there would be many aspirants for the nomination if Governor Lehman declined to run again.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Approval of a PWA loan and grant a $5,000,000 to $9,000,000 for construction of buildings of Brooklyn College has been urged by Mayor La Guardia of New York City, he revealed here today after he had called on Secretary Ickes, Harry L. Hopkins, Director of the Works Progress Division, and Colonel Horatio Hackett, Assistant PWA Administrator.

Recruits in the campaign against war and fascism certainly cannot be accused of setting themselves a limited objective. Eradicating the war-instinct in men and nations should be in itself a fair-sized task. The struggle against Fascist dictatorship in itself should keep a person busy.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP). -President Roosevelt nominated today Norman Armour of New Jersey, present Minister to Haiti, to be Minister to Canada, succeeding the late Warren Delano Robbins.

As a result of a growing realization that the tempo of modern city life exacts a toll in physical and mental energy that proper spectacles can reduce, the use of eyeglasses is increasing remarkably, speakers declared yesterday at the fortieth annual convention of the New York State Optometric Association.

Miss Eileen Wenzel, former show girl with Earl Carroll and Florenz Ziegfeld, appeared before Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy and a jury yesterday to show that she had lost her beauty in an automobile accident in Central Park on June 19, 1232.

PITTSBURGH, May 20. -- Aching more or less in every joint, the Giants rolled out on Forbes Field today and were immediately rolled over so fast by a singularly aggressive Pirate horde that it took them all of eight rounds to recover.

Gene Tunney, Shakespearean student, oil prospector, world traveler and former heavyweight boxing champion, gave advice to the city's school authorities yesterday. In an address at the opening luncheon of the twenty-ninth national convention of the Boys Clubs of America at the Hotel Commodore he urged that boys and girls be taught to study newspaper sports pages with the same diligence they applied to their academic chores.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 20. -- A mutual will to cooperation was expressed by Charles R. Gay, new president of the New York Stock Exchange, and James M. Landis, member of the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission, tonight in addressing a joint dinner of the St. Louis Stock Exchange and the Industrial Club at the Hotel Coronado.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20. -- When the Assembly resolution for a constitutional amendment to legalize pari-mutuel betting on horse racing was received in the Senate tonight, President Prall referred it to the Committee on Revision and Amendment of Laws.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Terming the relief crisis "a keg of dynamite," Mayor Kelly left for Springfield this afternoon to throw the weight of the city administration's influence into a fifth attempt tomorrow to pass the sales tax bill for raising relief funds.
LONDON, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- Derby registered a ten-wicket victory over Leicester, and Lancashire defeated Worcester by nine wickets in first-class county cricket matches concluded today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 20. -- A Paraguayan general offensive appears to have gotten under way in an effort to reconquer more than 25,000 square miles yielded to the Bolivians in the past thirty days.

In his first public address since taking office, delivered last night before the Associated Stock Exchanges in St. Louis, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, struck what appears to be the keynote of his public-relations policy. Apparently Mr. Gay intends to devote more attention to eradicating the public's misconceptions than to attempting to apply a whitewash brush to the Exchange's reputation.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 20 (AP). -- Captain A. Webster-Bullock of Monterey Park, Calif., was among the American victors in the amateur championship today. He eliminated H. Eatough of Burnley, 4 and 2.

RYE, N.Y., May 20. -- The qualifying honors in the women's metropolitan golf championship went to a 22-year-old Westchester golfer, Miss Betty Pietsch of the Lawrence Farms Club, Mount Kisco, as the tournament started at the historic Apawamis Club today.

RYE, N.Y., May 20. -- There is "no reality to the much-advertised strike epidemic" of the last eight months, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told about 400 women at luncheon today in the Westchester Country Club at the annual convention of the Westchester League of Women Voters.

PRAGUE, May 20. -- The results of yesterday's Czechoslovak elections, which it was known would show a considerable vote for the Hitlerite Sudeten Deutsche Front or Henlein party, surprised even Konrad Henlein's most confident supporters in that his group recorded more votes than any other party in the country.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The schedule of monthly wages by regions and types of work specified in the executive order which President Roosevelt issued this evening was as follows:...

The league-leading White Sox looked like last year's lagging Chicago crew yesterday at the Stadium as the Yanks buried them under a 7-2 setback before about 4,000 fans. Johnny Broaca was on the mound for the McCarthymen and scored his third conquest of the season.
UNION, N.J., May 20. -- A four-run rally in the ninth inning gave Upsala College a victory over Panzer College in the annual meeting of the East Orange Colleges at Tri-City Stadium today. 12 -- 11.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Thomas H. McInnerney, president of the National Dairy Products Corporation received $108,700 in compensation in 1934, the corporation's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. L.A. Van Bomel, vice president, received $60,800, and Wilbur S. Scott, vice president, $38,700.

I note an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Reclassification," in which you state that "previous attempts at reclassification, in the city as in the State, have been wrecked at the hands of organizations of employes fearful over the possible effect on salaries" and that the Civil Service Commission has given its word that its new schedules "will not change anybody's salary."

The sixty-fifth anniversary of the Harlem Medical Association was celebrated last night in conjunction with the annual president's dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt, which was attended by 250 physicians and surgeons.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Employable women eligible for work relief will receive the same consideration as men under the new work relief program, it was announced today at the White House.

Most staples were lower in light trading on the commodity futures markets here yesterday. Cottonseed oil, rubber, hides and lead advanced slightly in face of the easiness elsewhere. On the cash markets, oats, lard, lead, rubber and hides gained, while declines occurred in all the grains, dairy products cotton, silk and wool tops.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20 (AP). -- Displaying brilliant horsemanship, J. Byron Hilliard piloted Mrs. Hilliard's Mountainy Man to spectacular victory as gentleman's cup racing was revived at Churchill Downs after a lapse of fifteen years today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20. -- The president, treasurer and secretary of The Harvard Lampoon resigned today at the request of the graduate trustees of the magazine and the Lampoon Building, on Mount Auburn Street, was padlocked for one month by the trustees in sequel to the paper's parody last week of the magazine Esquire.

Residents of East Seventy-ninth Street were joined yesterday by the Todhunter School for Girls, in Eightieth Street between Madison and Park Avenues, in opposing the application of Henry Mandel, builder, for a mandamus to compel the city , to grant him a license to erect a motion picture theatre on the southeast corner of Seventy-ninth Street and Madison Avenue.
Louis Bromfield, whose "The Man Who Had Everything" has appeared, is at work on a lengthy novel about India, Ramona Herdmann of Harpers, who returned recently from Europe, reports.

BERLIN, May 20. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler issued a summons tonight for a Cabinet meeting tomorrow afternoon to precede his address to the Reichstag on what the Nazi regime has to offer to alleviate European tension.

Private industry cannot absorb the current crop of university graduates, even though large corporations are taking on more graduates this year than at any time since 1930, W. Emerson Gentzler, secretary of appointments at Columbia University, reported yesterday.

Workmen unearthed the body of Shirley Evans, 8 years old, at 9:30 A.M. yesterday under twelve inches of dry, porous sand in a narrow trench back of her home at 82-16 Thirty-fourth Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens.

Heavy orders resulting from the belief that commodity prices will rise sharply and business activity itself improve, were forecast yesterday for industry for the rest of this year by executives assembled for the opening of the four-day international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Housing and business parcels were included in the city real estate turnover reported yesterday.

Resignations of members of the Jersey City Rotary Club are reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES because, as one of them phrased it in his letter of withdrawal, the decision to hold a Rotary convention [both international Rotarians and Lions plan conclaves in Mexico City this Summer] in a country where "Catholics have been persecuted is an affront to all Catholics in the Rotary Club."

From the jumbled utterances of Joseph L. Steinmetz, 22-year-old former divinity student, made shortly after the crime, a jury before Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. in General Sessions drew yesterday a dramatic picture of what may have happened in the early afternoon of Nov. 26, when his bride of a fortnight, Ruth Armstrong Steinmetz, 17, and the Rev. Father Joseph J. Leonard were shot dead in the priest's room.

The largest earnings in the history of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., will be announced today by L.B. McKitterick, president, in the annual report of the company for the fiscal year ended March 31. The consolidated net earnings were $1,556,565 after all charges, including provision for Federal income tax.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 21. -- A detachment of Japanese troops under an officer named Sugihara, whose rank was unstated, yesterday marched from Manchukuo into Chinese territory south of the Great Wall and began operations against soldier-bandits around Tsunhua, according to telegrams received by the War Office.

Bonus champions at Washington, visibly fearful that the Senate will uphold the President's veto, are already asserting that they have other shots in their locker. If the Patman bill falls, they are prepared to introduce and press to enactment two or three others equally bad, so far as the main purpose is concerned. These will be bills to pay off the soldiers' certificates in cash, but will leave the President three options.

PITTSBURGH, May 20. -- The Federal Securities and Exchange Commission took its first court action in Pennsylvania today when it petitioned in Federal District Court here for an injunction against four brokerage firms for alleged violation of the Securities Exchange Act.

Mischka, the irrepressible little Indian sun bear at the Central Park Zoo, went on her annual Spring rampage yesterday. She escaped again, this time from what zoo officials had believed was an escape-proof cage.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 20. -- The trial by court-martial of the leading Estonian Fascists belonging to the dissolved "Front Soldiers League" will begin soon. It is awaited with the keenest interest in the whole of Estonia.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP). -- With Oral Hildebrand pitching effectively, the Indians defeated the Red Sox, 4 to 1, in the series opener today. The victory, coupled with the defeat of Chicago, reduced the White Sox margin over the Indians to one and one-half games.

Miss Gloria Hollister, research associate of Dr. William Beebe, director of the department of tropical research of the New York Zoological Society, awaited yesterday the arrival from Venice, Fla., of the tail of an adult 100-pound tarpon.

Science, contrary to current belief, is fifteen or twenty years behind social and economic development, according to Charles F. Kettering, president of the General Motors Research Corporation, whose message was read last night at a dinner meeting of the boards of the national engineering societies and affiliated groups at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

Indications yesterday were that the new Federal work relief program will be in effect in New York City by July 15, by which date, it is expected, the Federal Government will have taken over direction of the works division of the Emergency Relief Bureau, with its more than 87,000 employes.

Another $20,000,000 of gold was engaged in Paris yesterday for shipment here as the franc continued to fall under pressure of the flight of capital and bearish speculation. The French currency dropped to 6.58 cents the cheapest price since Feb. 11, and closed at 6.58 3/8 cents, off 1/3 point.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 20. -- The United States Chamber of Commerce has no quarrel with the present administration, although there appears to be a difference in their respective philosophies, according to Harper Sibley, president of the chamber, who spoke here tonight.

Fifty-three students of the day and night art and architectural classes at Cooper Union received prizes and medals last night at the opening of the seventy-sixth annual exhibition of the work of students.
Several flats and two garages were among the New Jersey properties listed in conveyances yesterday.

Following the death of a third patient in Metropolitan Hospital yesterday after the administration of novocaine for dental extractions, Hospitals Commissioner S.S. Goldwater sent samples of the anesthetic to the United States Bureau of Food and Drugs for analysis.

The light business and steady array of quotations which has been the chief characteristic of the trading in the money market for many weeks was carried into the opening session of the week. Beyond replacements little new money was engaged.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on May 15 shows increases for the week of $143,000,000 in net demand deposits, $10,000,000 in time deposits and $78,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and decreases of $76,000,000 in total loans and investments and $62,000,000 in government deposits.

LONDON, May 20. -- King George, Whose honors "Lawrence of Arabia" once spurned, sent today to A.W. Lawrence, brother of Colonel Thomas E. Lawrence, who died yesterday morning following a motorcycle accident, this message of tender sympathy:

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The administration's $459,000,000 naval supply bill was being held temporarily in check in the Senate today by a combination of bonus advocates and members of the Special Munitions Investigating Committee, who were insisting upon amendments to curb the profits of armament makers.

Foreign Trade Week, originated by the United States Chamber of Commerce and supported by the Departments of State and Commerce, opened here yesterday as in 200 other cities throughout the country, with a luncheon intended to impress on the public the doctrine that regaining of foreign trade is essential to national recovery.

Unless special arrangements are made for them to fly from Pittsburgh to New York immediately after the United States open golf championship to make boat connections, Gene Sarazen and other professional stars will abandon plans to go abroad for the British open tournament next month at Muirfield, Scotland, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- President Roosevelt signed an Executive order setting up wage scales under the work relief program. The White House announced that the President would go to West Point in early June to present to the graduating class their commissions.

WINNIPEG, May 20 (Canadian Press). -- A 10 per cent reduction in wheat acreage, the best moisture conditions in four or five years and a sowing season ten to thirty days later than usual were shown today in The Winnipeg Free Press's first crop report of 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- Within twenty-four hours after 800 produce truck drivers went on strike without warning, leaving the city facing a shortage of fresh fruit and vegetables, a two-week truce was announced late tonight following a conference at the offices of the Regional Labor Board.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Sanford Bates, Federal prison commissioner, was appointed today as chairman of the delegation which will represent the government at the eleventh international penal and penitentiary congress in Berlin from Aug. 18 to 24. Other delegates are:

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, May 20. -- For 400 years the woman with the enigmatic smile who posed for the famous painting, "Mona Lisa" has been falsely identified, Dr. Raymond S. Stites, Professor of Aesthetics at Antioch College, asserted today.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that bids would be opened on June 14 for construction of the Henry Hudson Bridge across the Harlem River ship canal from Inwood Hill Park to Spuyten Duyvil.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The statement by James H. Perkins. chairman of the board of the National City Bank of New York, before the subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, was as follows:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20. -- Stringent rules against pre-bickering, a return to formal club calling in February, and the establishment of a committee on enforcement are the chief innovations in the new plan for election to the eighteen upper-class eating clubs at Princeton University passed at a meeting of the 1936 interclub committee today.

Surrogate FOLEY has refused to permit the executors of an estate to vary the investments in their trust. The application was peculiar. What the trustees alleged was fear of inflation of the currency. If that should result the value of some parts of their trust fund, such as Government bonds, would be impaired, and consequently they asked the court to sanction investment of several hundred thousand dollars in common stocks.
