The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
SIX in a row. That's the pitching record of John Henderson Whitehead, the rookie right-hander of the White Sox. Not a bad start for a young fellow taking a first peek at the big-league hitters.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP). -- The eighth anniversary of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's solo flight to Paris was celebrated here tonight by the unveiling of a bronze tablet commemorating that epochal trip across the Atlantic.
Squash tennis has been played around New York for more than forty years but it was not until yesterday that the doubles game was introduced to these parts.

LOS ANGELES, May 20 (AP). -- Harry Bannister, actor and former husband of Ann Harding of the movies, asked the Superior Court today for a temporary injunction prohibiting the actress from removing their 6-year-old daughter Jane from the jurisdiction of the California courts.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20. -- The City Commissions of Camden, Passaic and New Brunswick will organize tomorrow without interference By the Supreme Court, although there will be recounts in the latter two municipalities.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 20. -- Members of the student body and faculty of New Jersey College for Women will appear before a special committee of five members of the board of trustees of Rutgers University here tomorrow afternoon.

Europe's next crisis will probably concern the demilitarized zones, Frank H. Simonds, well-known analyst of European affairs, declares in the leading article, "What Next in Europe?" in the June Current History.

In 1854 the Republican party was born in the Wisconsin Ripon. In 1934 the Progressive party was born in the Wisconsin Fond du Lac. The La Follette Republicans had to get out of the Republican party, whose name they had used so long. They made a platform and carried the State, though young PHIL'S return to the Governorship was frowned upon by Mr. ROOSEVELT.

Abe Wasserman of the Bronx received credit for a one-round knockout victory over Al Rowan of Jersey City last night in the feature bout, scheduled for six rounds, at the St. Nicholas Palace. Rowan was cut so badly on his forehead that Referee Al Reich stopped the contest after two minutes of action.

At the close of a discussion by educational experts last night of how the city's public schools should meet problems of maladjustment, Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, struck a different note by chiding the Department of Education for failing to present a budget that reflected an "ideal set-up for the school system."
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP). -- Battering two of three St. Louis pitchers for ten hits, the Senators today defeated the Browns, 8 to 2, in the first game of the series.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Brooklyn Ash Removal Company, Inc., lost today in the Supreme Court in its attempt to recover $289,955 in income taxes paid in 1929 and 1930. The court refused to review a Court of Claims decision upholding the government's right to collect the tax.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., May 20. -- Almost on the eve of the opening of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Cincinnati, it was disclosed today that not one of the twenty-three members of the Fundamentalist Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions had obeyed the mandate of last year's general assembly to resign from the board.

Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican County Committee, issued a statement yesterday calling upon W. Kingsland Macy, former State chairman, to cease his. "sniping" campaign against the State committee and to show his devotion to Republican principles and party regularity by aiding in the election of a Republican Assembly.

The director of the American Association for Adult Education, Mr. MORSE A. CARTWRIGHT, speaking yesterday at the annual meeting in Milwaukee, in assuming that the country is emerging from the depression, has a grateful word to say for it in that it has proved an asset to adult education.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley signed a temporary injunction today restraining the Rev. George Tukacs from entering the Hungarian Dutch Reformed Church of Peekskill, of which he is pastor.

Secretary ROPER'S speech at Boston yesterday introduced "National Foreign Trade Week," during which special efforts will be made to focus attention on the importance of our commercial ties with other nations. Only a few years ago this would have been an occasion for patriotic fireworks.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The proposed substitute for the Clark resolution to extend the NIRA, introduced in the House today by Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee, read as follows:

James A. Lanze, 35 years old, a boss truckman, wept on the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday as he testified in his defense on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Horace Malone, his discharged foreman, last Nov. 21, at Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

If you have a copy of Goethe's "Faust" at hand and will turn to Act I you will find the Lord High Steward commenting in this fashion on Faust's scheme to distribute notes to all the people after describing the untold wealth buried in the land:

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 20. -- While the combined efforts of more than 900 men checked the forest fires which laid waste 20,000 acres of woodland in Ocean County, police arrested two men, who are charged with having set the major fires near Bamber yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Presentation to the President today of a 4,000-word brief in behalf of the soldiers' bonus by a committee of twenty-two House members had no effect on his determination forcefully to urge the Congress to uphold the veto message that he will read to a joint session on Wednesday.

Not much progress was made yesterday by the security and commodity markets. Stocks held steady enough, following a hesitant start, and closed irregularly higher, more then twoscore issues in various groups selling at their best prices for the year thus far; trading on the Stock Exchange was a little less than a million shares.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- In a six-to-three division, the Supreme Court refused today to interfere with the conviction of Angelo Herndon, Negro Communist of Atlanta, who was sentenced to eighteen to twenty years in prison under an old Georgia law forbidding the inciting of violence.
The baccalaureate sermon was preached by Bishop William T. Manning last night at the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, Chelsea Square, at the opening of the commencement week.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP). -- Emphasizing the importance of foreign trade, Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce declared his conviction today "that greater study must be given to the specific requirements of foreign countries." Mr. Roper spoke before manufacturers, exporters and importers at a Foreign Trade Week gathering.
WOODMERE, L.I., May 20. -- The annual tulip show of the Lawrence Garden Club was held today at the home of Mrs. Ethelbert L. Low on Noye Lane, Woodmere, at which seventy-one entries were exhibited.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- A note of compromise is being sounded in the testimony about Title II of the Administration's latest banking reform bill. More than ever it appears possible that, as in the instance of the Federal Reserve Act, friends and some foes of the measure will resolve their difficulties, and the completed legislation will not be viewed with the alarm now expressed by certain bankers and newspapers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- Diplomas were presented to 110 students and degrees in course to thirty-five this afternoon at the second annual commencement exercises of the Curtis Institute of Music in Casimir Hall.

Trading in Home Owners Loan Corporation 4 per cent bonds of 1951, which have been called for redemption on July 1, eclipsed the activity in other United States Government loans on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's generally quiet bond market.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 20. -- The case of the German sculptor Gutzeit, against whose abduction from Netherlands territory by the German police this government protested, obtaining a promise from Berlin to let him return to this country, is occupying public attention again because of Herr Gutzeit's alleged refusal to return.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 20 (AP). -- There was not much hope left for the rest of the field in the annual Big Ten golf championship tonight after Michigan's quartet of stars, led by Johnny Fischer and Charlie Kocsis, stopped firing at par over the wooded expanses of the Kildeer Country Club.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20. -- About fifty delegates to the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Society of the Daughters of the Revolution, being held at the Garden City Hotel, visited Jones Beach and had luncheon at the Lido Country Club at Long Beach today.

GENEVA, May 20. -- In an unprecedented move Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia today appealed in person to the League of Nations Council on the opening day of its eighty-sixth session. From his camp at Harrar, where an Italian attack seems most expected by the Ethiopians, he sent to the President of the Council, Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff of Russia, a telegram dated today which ended:

Reorders on Summer lines were larger in the market here yesterday, with indications that the week would see much more activity in apparel and accessories. The mail orders received indicated retailers were rounding out stocks prior to extensive Memorial Day promotions.

Samuel Goldwyn announced yesterday through the local United Artists office that the contract between himself and Anna Sten, the Russian actress, has been terminated by mutual agreement. Miss Sten's last picture under the Goldwyn banner was "The Wedding Night."
Jerry the aard-vark, a highly unattractive member of the anteater family, began life anew yesterday morning as the chief of eight new African arrivals at the Bronx Zoo.

BERLIN, May 20. -- The Boerse was weak and irregular at the opening today, but showed firmness at the close. Financial commentators assert that the relatively heavy volume of buying orders at the end of last week resulted from talk about devaluation of the currency in connection with Dr. Schacht's export subsidy plan.

The Northern States Power Company of Delaware reports a consolidated net income of $5,175,603 for 1934, after all deductions, equal after preferred dividends and under the participating provisions of the stocks to 25 cents a share on 341,551 shares of $100 par Class A common and to 2 cents a share on 729,166 shares of Class B no par common stock.

The Hapag Lloyd liner Berlin, which was transferred last June to another service out of Bremen, but now restored to the North Atlantic run, arrived here yesterday morning on her first transatlantic crossing of the season. She is scheduled to sail tomorrow morning with more than 600 passengers and will be continued throughout the Summer as a North Atlantic ship.

Owners of real estate and representatives of civic associations on the West Side voted at a meeting last night to appear before the Board of Estimate on Friday morning to oppose the Riverside Drive improvement plan sponsored by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Around the 12-cent level for July, the price for cotton continued yesterday to attract more selling, and quotations on the Cotton Exchange here closed with losses of 1 to 3 points. Fluctuations held within a 10-point range as mills fixed prices on slight recessions, while straddle interests again bought here against liquidation of near deliveries in Liverpool, where month-end calling absorbed contracts.

With the assistance of Jimmy Savo, who is a prince of mountebanks, the Theatre Guild has endeavored to take a frisky view of things in "Parade," which marched earnestly across the Guild stage last evening. After all these years it is hard for the Guild to cultivate the antic mood successfully.
The Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain will sail at noon today for Cherbourg and Southampton. The passenger list includes:
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- President Roosevelt will go to West Point on June 12 to present in person the commissions granted to the graduating class of the Military Academy.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses gave written assurance yesterday that there would be no change in the "present basic character and design" of Washington Square Park. His message, addressed to Mrs. V.G. Simkhovitch, director of Greenwich House, was read last night at the annual dinner of the Greenwich Village Association, at the Stonewall Inn, 51 Christopher Street.

A definite plan of reorganization was adopted last night at a special meeting of the American Power Boat Association at the Hotel Lexington. As a result of the action of the members, President George W. Sutton Jr. was empowered to set up a regional plan by which the organization will truly be national in scope for the first time in its thirty-one-year history.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Wage scales for the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program ranging from $19 monthly for unskilled rural workers in the deep South to $94 monthly for professional services in New York City were prescribed today by President Roosevelt in an executive order.

The warning sounded by a candidate for public office back in 1932 that grass might grow in the city's streets if certain impending developments came to pass seemed prophetic yesterday, with the discovery that farms in the five counties of New York City had increased 33 1-3 to 350 per cent since 1930.

Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, yesterday called upon garment and clothing manufacturers, piece goods jobbers and retailers to unite in opposition against pending amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act, which would give the Secretary power to impose a marketing agreement contemplating an increase in the price of wool up to 133 per cent of its present level.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 20. -- John H. Trumbull, former Governor of Connecticut, and Mrs. Trumbull entertained Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Wheeler of Plainville, Conn., at dinner at Fassifern Farm last evening.

Several hundred alumni of the Union Theological Seminary and their guests heard Dr. Henry Goddard Leach, editor, praise Father Coughlin for "his stand as a prophet," and the New Deal as a "reinterpretation of the Sermon on the Mount," at the annual alumni dinner in the refectory of the seminary, 120th Street and Broadway, last night.
BELLAIRE, Ohio, May 20 (AP). -- Hundreds of feet beneath the great hills of Belmont County, the first lady of the land will travel through coal mine tunnels tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Sentiment among wheat traders here has become extremely bearish and the belief that lower prices were to prevail was heightened today by further heavy rains in the South-western and Western Winter wheat belts over the week-end and the favorable comments on the Spring grain crop.
MOSCOW, May 20. -- The forty-eight dead of the disaster to the huge airplane Maxim Gorky were buried today with high official honors amid moving expressions of mass grief.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Limited offerings here today with an active demand lifted prices of hogs 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight. The buying was stimulated by reports of a good demand for fresh pork at higher prices and the strength in lard. The top price was up 20 cents from Saturday's figure at $9.75 and the day's average advanced a like amount to $9.50.
WELLESLEY, Mass., May 20 (AP). -- The Roger W. Babson Statistical Organization announced today the results of a survey which indicated that President Roosevelt would be re-elected in 1936.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- Denny Shute, winner of the 1933 British open golf championship, and John P. (Sonny) Rouse, shot their ways over two Medinah Country Club courses today in 148 strokes to lead home the fourteen Chicago district qualifiers for the national open championship tournament.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Plat Eye, early pacemaker in the Kentucky Derby, qualified for the Withers, to be run on Saturday, when he was a gallant winner of the Campfire Mile at Belmont Park yesterday. Timed in 1:38 over a fast track, Plat Eye once more gave evidence that he is the toughest kind of a racer at about a mile.

PARIS, May 20 (AP). -- Wilmer Hines of Columbia, S.C., and young Henry Culley of Santa Barbara, Calif., smashed their way to a straight-set doubles victory over R. Journu and M. Glasser of France today to give the United States an opening triumph in the French hard court tennis championship.
ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 20. -- Play began today in the British amateur golf championship in weather sufficiently uninviting for May, but delightful compared with what we have been having.

WAKE ISLAND, May 20 (By Wireless). -- Like the years that have faded into shadowy memories, men have come to these barren islands, Wake, Wilkes and Peale, tarried awhile and departed, never to return to the group that will shelter a base in the new air route from the Pacific Coast to the Orient.

RAMALLAH, Palestine, May 1 (By Mail). -- Discovery of a large burial cave in the biblical city of Mizpah, making plain the customs described in the burial of Sarah by Abraham as told in the Old Testament, is announced by Professor William F. Bade, director of the Tell en-Nasbeh Expedition of the Pacific School of Religion.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- An accusation that the Tennessee Valley Authority had committed itself to spend $101,000,000, but had talked with Congress only on "a $75,000,000 basis," was handed to the House Military Committee today by a leader in a Republican drive against the agency.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- Tests of the Glenn Martin-Pan-American clipper ship No. 7, largest flying boat built in the United States and designed for transpacific service, were resumed this week, officials of the Martin plant announced today.

LONDON, May 20. -- The Pope's unusually warm tribute today to the King and Queen and the British nation may do much to improve official relations between Britain and the Vatican, which already are more cordial than they have been since the Middle Ages.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Apparently determined to fight to a finish for its seven-point program for NRA reinforcement and extension despite threats of a Senate filibuster beyond the June 16 expiration date, the administration caused to be introduced in the House today a new measure extending the agency's life for two years and placing beyond question many disputed phases of code regulation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP). -- After the Athletics put on a two-run rally in the ninth to tie the score at 5-all, Detroit came back with three runs in the eleventh to win the series opener today, 8 to 6.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP). -- A marked upturn in Great Lakes freight traffic here and through the Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., locks, with heavy automobile production forcing ship owners to increase their fleets, was reported today by private dock operators and the Federal Government.
CHEFOO, China, May 20 (AP). -- Prosperity arrived for Chefoo today in the form of a part of the United States Asiatic fleet, which will be based here for the four Summer months.

OTTAWA, May 20. -- Prime Minister H.B. Bennett told the House of Commons today when that body resumed after its five weeks' adjournment that he had returned to work against the advice of his doctors. His statement strengthened a general belief that Mr. Bennett will lead the government for some time in Parliament, but not in the coming general election campaign.

The record of the Fusion city administration will be set forth Thursday night at a dinner of the City Fusion party at the Astor Hotel by Bernard S. Deutsch, Aldermanic President; Raymond V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn, and Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, according to a statement issued yesterday by Ben Howe, city chairman.

MILWAUKEE, May 20. -- Declaring that the public had little confidence in educators' abilities as statesmen, and citing public opinion of the "brain trust" to support his assertion, Morse A. Cartwright of New York sounded a call for the Roosevelt "brain trust" to retreat, when he addressed the annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education today.

Continuation of the present program with respect to cotton will necessitate a complete reconstruction of the economic and social position of the Cotton Belt, C.T. Revere, of Munds, Winslow Potter, said yesterday at the monthly luncheon meeting of the New York University Men in Finance Club at the Bankers Club.

With the opening of the pickerel season in New Jersey yesterday we are reminded that this is an opportune time to call attention to the virtues of a game fish which all too often is overlooked in the piscatorial picture.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 20 (AP). -- Tornadic winds which have been moving through Southern States killed three persons today and injured a score of others, while floods threatened further damage in Oklahoma and Texas.

SALEM, N.H., May 20. -- Mrs. W.W. Vaughn's 3-year-old chestnut colt Brillfalon provided an upset today in the featured Derry Purse at Rockingham Park, reaching the wire first after a stirring contest with Sun Erin, the favorite.

FOR this is life, life as it is spoken in the twentieth century," says Cornelia North in one of the short stories of Tess Slesinger's "Time: The Present" (Simon Schuster, $2.50). The phrase "life as it is spoken" is the key to Miss Slesinger's work. As her novel, "The Unpossessed," demonstrated with such force and aplomb last Spring, Miss Slesinger is past-mistress of the art of the literary ambuscade.

As one who had occasion to meet Miss Harriet May Mills in connection with the movement for woman suffrage in this State, and who deeply appreciates the splendid work which she did for that cause, permit me to correct the statement that she was the "first woman to run for State office in New York."
Mayor La Guardia's Municipal Art Committee yesterday announced plans for the celebration of the "July Festival," to be the second of the series of four annual festivals planned for New York City.

Manufacturers of trade-marked lines of merchandise began steps yesterday to operate under the permissive right granted by the Feld-Crawford bill, signed last Friday by Governor Lehman, to make contracts with retailers establishing the resale price of their goods.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The wide powers proposed for the Federal Reserve Board under Title II of the Omnibus Banking Bill were attacked today by James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of the National City Bank.

WANTAGH, L.I., May 20. -- Unless the Oyster Bay town board at its meeting tomorrow offers a new lease on substantially the same terms as the old, the Long Island State Park Commission on Saturday will cease operation of the Jones Beach Bird Sanctuary, officials of the commission said today.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- A general court-martial of a high army official, definitely understood to be a general officer, was begun behind closed doors at the Army War College today on charges reported to involve alleged acceptance of a favor from a lobbyist.

The report of the International Mercantile Marine Company and wholly owned domestic subsidiaries for 1934, issued yesterday, showed a net loss of $2,100,682. No provision has been made for International's proportionate share of the $888,129 loss last year of the United States Lines Company and the net profit of $311,063 reported by the Roosevelt Steamship Company.

The State of Minnesota, it was reported yesterday, may enter the market next month for an $8,000,000 highway loan, the proceeds to match a grant of similar proportions from the Federal Government for road building. The State Legislature recently authorized such procedure, and also an additional $4,000,000 to be sold in 1936, this sum likewise to meet, dollar for dollar, an advance under authority of the national public works legislation.

LONDON, May 20 (AP). -- A lawyer for the Duke of Manchester, sentenced to nine months' imprisonment for fraud, told a Chancery Court today that the American trustees were withholding payments to the duke from his mother's estate.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 20. -- Arthur G. Dutcher, 55, prominent Rochester attorney and a former Monroe County Assistant District Attorney, was shot and killed here today in his office by a Venezuelan Negro client.
HANOVER, N.H., May 20. -- Dartmouth, after seven league games, took a breather today and defeated Vermont, 7-3, using a makeshift line-up.

Robert B. Odom, amateur of the home club, and the Wheatley Hills pro, Willie Klein, helped clarify a rather complicated situation yesterday at the St. Albans Golf Club when they came home with a 68 to win the best-ball amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association.

Manhattan's baseball team defeated Brooklyn College, 8 to 3, at Manhattan Field yesterday. The victory raised the Jaspers' seasonal average to .500 for the first time, the triumph being their sixth in twelve starts.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP). -- Four double plays and three hits apiece by Bill Jurges and Phil Cavarretta led the Cubs to a 5-to-0 triumph over the Braves in the opening game of the series today.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Advocating optimism and more optimism, Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, told the Board of Tax Appeals today, while he was testifying in defense of Andrew W. Mellon, that "the longer the depression lasts the greater will be the following prosperity."

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 20. -- Greater activity by the American public in governmental affairs to end political corruption at home and to remove the possibility of war from the international relations of the United States was urged today in an address by General John F. O'Ryan, former Police Commissioner of New York City.

The first arrests by the New York police under the recently enacted Brownell amendment to the "public enemy" law were made last night in Brownsville by four detectives under Acting Lieutenant George Colgan. Ten men, all with criminal records and described by the police as petty racketeers, were seized in a group outside a resort at Sutter Avenue and Amboy Street, Brooklyn, about 10 o'clock.
Plans of two six-story houses for Brooklyn sites were among the building projects filed yesterday.

Walter Pach's new fresco, "Respice, Adspice, Prospice," has moved into the Knoedler Galleries, where it will be on public view through June 1. Then the mural will be installed in the entrance foyer of the College of the City of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- Allegiance to American institutions was pledged anew tonight by descendants of many of the nation's founders when the National Society of New England Women opened its annual congress here with a memorial service.

Tonight's theatrical event takes place considerably north of Broadway-the part of Broadway, that is, which is concerned by theatrical events. It will be the revival by the Harlem Players, an all-Negro repertory company, of the slapbang farce, "The Front Page," at the Lafayette Theatre, Seventh Avenue and 131st Street.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Disclosing extreme sweatshop conditions among the "family" silk weaving shops of Paterson, N.J., with entire groups working long hours weekly for a mere pittance, the Silk Textile Work Assignment Board reported today that only by the creation of a Rayon and Silk Adjustment Board would it be possible to cope with the conditions in these shops which were held to be demoralizing the reputable silk and rayon mills of the nation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 20. -- The financial condition of Westchester County was set forth today in a statement for the first quarter of the year by William S. Coffey, County Treasurer. The county will sell about $2,000,000 o2 construction bonds on Wednesday.

HANOVER, N.H., May 20. -- The local chapters of Alpha Chi Rho and Phi Kappa Sigma at Dartmouth College voted today to surrender their national charters and sever connections with their national organizations. They will combine into a local club to be known as Gamma Delta Chi.

The negotiations Between the Public Service Commission and the Consolidated Gas system for a substantial reduction in electric rates for New York City consumers have reached the point where the commission has received informally the outline of the rate cut that the company proposes to make.

A denunciation of the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, recently passed by the Senate and now before the House for action, was delivered yesterday by James A. Emery, general counsel for the National Association of Manufacturers, before 1,000 members of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce meeting in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- An order prohibiting, except under license, the importation into the United States of foreign silver coins and other forms of silver commonly used as money was issued tonight by the Treasury with President Roosevelt's approval.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Fear of strikes among the unemployed in protest of the wage scales under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program announced today by President Roosevelt was expressed by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, when he was notified of the signing of the executive order.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 20. -- Postmaster General Farley, as the guest of Sullivan County today, dedicated the new postoffice at Monticello and participated in the laying of the cornerstone for Monticello's new high school.

Twenty hat-check and cigarette girls employed in midtown night clubs and restaurants visited the State Department of Labor yesterday afternoon to protest against not being permitted to work after 10 P.M. Their visit followed a hearing before James L. Gernon, director of the Division of Inspection, at which fifteen employers were warned that a second violation of the law forbidding night work by women in restaurants would be punished.

Twenty hat-check and cigarette girls employed in midtown night clubs and restaurants visited the State Department of Labor yesterday afternoon to protest against not being permitted to work after 10 P.M. Their visit followed a hearing before James L. Gernon, director of the Division of Inspection, at which fifteen employers were warned that a second violation of the law forbidding night work by women in restaurants would be punished.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Fear of strikes among the unemployed in protest of the wage scales under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program announced today by President Roosevelt was expressed by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, when he was notified of the signing of the executive order.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 20. -- Postmaster General Farley, as the guest of Sullivan County today, dedicated the new postoffice at Monticello and participated in the laying of the cornerstone for Monticello's new high school.
ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 21. -- W. Lawson Little Jr. came right back on his game in the second round of the British amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Despite his overwhelming personal victory as reflected in the Congressional elections of 1934, the President has from the first had trouble with the Seventy-fourth Congress. This struggle has been visible not so much in final actions as in repeated attempts to upset his policies and his program, and narrow squeaks in committee and on roll-call.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Despite the storm of protest from labor leaders and their friends in Congress which broke after the announcement last evening off the wage scale for projects under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program, the administration stood firm today.

A resolution favoring the President's program for two-year extension of the NRA and condemning the Clark resolution was adopted yesterday at a meeting of trade association executives and representatives in the women's apparel industries held at the Hotel Astor.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 21. -- Melvin C. Eaton, State Republican chairman, expressed confidence here today that his party would recapture the Assembly this Fall. At the same time he predicted that Attorney General Bennett would be the Democratic gubernatorial candidate in 1936 and not James A. Farley, if Governor Lehman stepped out of the political picture.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- A plan whereby manufacturers of cotton textiles for export would receive a basic rate of 7 cents a pound as a tolerance on raw cotton bought from government supplies at the market price was approved in principle today at a meeting of the Cotton Textile Institute and the Code Authority of the cotton textile industry.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Breakdown of negotiations for a new wage scale in the bituminous coal industry was announced today by Duncan C. Kennedy, chairman of the Joint Conference Committee of Operators and Miners in the Appalachian area.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 21. -- Czechoslovak public opinion is still mesmerized by the astonishing success of the "Czechoslovak Hitler,'' Konrad Henlein, in Sunday's elections.

Four of six men who were indicted on charges of attempting to extort $5,000 from Mrs. George U. Harris, wife of a broker, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Koenig in General Sessions. The two others are to be called for trial on Monday, Charles Pilatsky, Assistant District Attorney, announced.

A devaluation of the Pennsylvania Railroad's $63,000,000 investment in the control of the Wabash Railway is in prospect, it appeared yesterday when it was disclosed that a reorganization of the Wabash was under consideration. The Pennsylvania controls 362,900 shares of common and 312,900 shares of preferred A stock of the Wabash, or 49 per cent of the voting stock.

The theft of four .45-calibre army service Colt automatic pistols from the 101st Cavalry Armory at Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street on Monday became known yesterday when detectives and agents of the Federal Department of Justice went to the building to investigate.

A new system of radio communication by which the captain of a vessel is able to talk to any or all persons on board was demonstrated yesterday on the Colombian of the Colombian Line at Pier 9, Brooklyn. The demonstration was given by Norman H. Lorimer, vice president of the Guided Radio Corporation, and was watched by representatives of various steamship companies as well as by representatives of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- In this city, where the month began with an unusual tribute to Jane Addams, word of her death brought sadness. Only nineteen days ago, at a dinner here, Miss Addams heard herself praised.
SALEM, N.H., May 21. -- Mrs. W.C. Weant's 4-year-old bay filly Fairsickle, a long shot, captured the featured New York Press Handicap with a $1,500 purse at Rockingham Park today.

The More Game Birds Foundation of this city is sending letters to 6,000 sportsmen's clubs in the United States urging that influence be brought to bear in behalf of House Resolution 7982, introduced in congress by Representative Richard M. Kleberg, a member of the committee on conservation of wild-life resources.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The defense in the Mellon tax case will rest tomorrow when the Board of Tax Appeals convenes. The government will then begin its rebuttal in an attempt to show that the $500 a share which Andrew W. Mellon returned as the value in March, 1913, of McClintic-Marshall stock owned by him was far too high.

The $250,000 alienation of affections suit brought by Mrs. Augusta Pinza, wife of the Metropolitan basso, Ezio Pinza, against Mme. Elisabeth Rethberg, Metropolitan dramatic soprano, has been dropped. This was disclosed yesterday when a stipulation of discontinuance of the suit was filed in the Supreme Court.

A succession of detectives marched to the stand yesterday before Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. and a jury in General Sessions and faced a cross-examination intended to convey that questionable police methods had been used in developing evidence against Joseph L. Steinmetz, 22 years old, on trial for the murder of his bride, Ruth, 17, in the Knights of Columbus Hotel, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- Six red roses filled the great vase on the Speaker's rostrum today as the last roll-call for members who have died in the past year was read in a joint memorial service of the Senate and House.

The results of an election at Hunter College in which almost 6,000 students voted for candidates to fill three offices under the Student Self-Government Association were announced yesterday by Ethel F. Schwartz, Student Council head.
Industrial activity as a whole declined during April and the first half of May, according to the monthly business survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday.

The Board of Higher Education unanimously upheld last night the action of the City College faculty in expelling twenty-one students last Fall in connection with a series of anti-Fascist demonstrations at the college.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- An urgent plea that President Roosevelt's veto of the Bonus Bill be upheld was made today by Harper Sibley, new president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The Rev. Morgan Phelps Noyes of the Central Presbyterian Church, Montclair, N.J., addressing the graduating class of Union Theological Seminary, declared in the seminary's chapel last night that the transfer from the field of academic studies to the field of operation would present many difficulties to the students.

Shows of student work continue to elbow each other on the calendar and they provide a diversity even greater than might, strictly speaking, be expected. Among them are paintings by a group of adults, several of whom are physicians, who have been working under the guidance of Jessie Ansbacher at her studio in the Hotel Hyde Park, 25 East Seventy-seventh Street.

PARIS, May 21. -- The Bourse reacted today and rentes rose, while industrials fell, thus reversing the recent general trend. The decline was variable in revenue stocks due to speculative profit-taking. The rise in rentes shows that the authorities have the situation well in hand after the sharp drop last Friday, when the market got out of control.

Alumni Day was celebrated yesterday at the General Theological Seminary in Chelsea Square, where commencement exercises will be held this morning. A class of thirty-eight seniors will be graduated this morning and degrees conferred upon twenty ministers. The seniors do not receive degrees until after they have been ordained.

An investment banking syndicate headed by E.H. Rollins Sons yesterday won the award of a new issue of $1,500,000 of city of Pittsburgh, Pa., School District, 2 1/2 per cent bonds dated June 1, 1935, and due on June 1, 1936 to 1965 inclusive.

STUTTGART, Germany, May 21. -- Wuerttemberg civil employes have received official warning from the local chief of the National Socialist Civil Servants League that they are expected to withdraw their children from Catholic and Protestant Youth organizations and place them in the Hitler Youth group.
There was a slight raising of eyebrows in the esthetic world yesterday at news that local politics had been flirting with art.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- National banknotes, doomed to disappear completely a few months hence, were reported today to be slowly dropping from sight.

Ralph T. Crane vice president of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., has been nominated for president of the Bond Club of New York for the next fiscal year to succeed Harry M. Addinsell, it was announced yesterday. The election will be held on June 21.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Good Gamble and Postage Due gave that young owner another double when they were best in their respective fields at Belmont Park yesterday. The former was the easiest sort of a five-length winner at 30 to 1 in the fifth running of the $9,000 Acorn Stakes, while Postage Due was an odds-on favorite in the juvenile dash which immediately followed.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 21. -- Mrs. Walter Brundage received the greatest number of first prizes in the cultural classes yesterday at the Spring flower show of the garden section of the Manor Club, presented in the auditorium of the clubhouse.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21. -- Testimony in support of Dr. Lienhard Bergel, instructor in German at the New Jersey College for Women, who contends he is not to be reappointed in June because his anti-Nazi views conflict with those of the head of his department, was presented here this afternoon.

At Hull House, in the squalid slums of Chicago's West Side, Jane Addams, a priestess of understanding among neighbors and of peace among nations, kept open house for prince and pauper alike. It was her shrine and it will remain her monument.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

In the New York University Law Quarterly Review AUGUSTIN DERBY, a Professor of Law who spent a year as secretary to the late Justice HOLMES thirty years ago, gives some recollections which, while they do not essentially change our picture of the Justice, supplement it by some interesting and amusing sidelights.
CINCINNATI, May 21. -- Both the weather and the Reds were pleasant today, Danny MacFayden's pitching and the Reds' hitting and the temperature being extremely mild.

Friends of former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney started yesterday a boom to make him the Democratic nominee for Governor on the assumption that Governor Lehman, as reported by despatches from Albany, would not be a candidate for renomination next year.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- Colonel Alexander E. Williams was reported tonight to be the defendant in court-martial proceedings conducted in secrecy at the Army War College here.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- A label of "haphazard legislation" was flung abruptly at the Tennessee Valley Authority Act today by Controller General J.R. McCarl, in testimony delivered to the House committee which drafted the law.

The seeming ease with which the share market moved into higher ground yesterday indicated the reluctance of recent buyers to claim profits just at this time; many prefer to be in rather than out of the market to await the President's bonus veto address today and subsequent Congressional action.
This is the melancholy vignette of the ram, the lamb and the nine ewes discovered yesterday on the motley sidewalks at Madison and Oliver Streets, hard by the birthplace of Al Smith.

A mortgage for $2.000.000 covering a leasehold of the plot on the west side of Green Sl., I0O.g fl. north of V'averly PI., 25x75,, on a lease given by the 27 %'overly P1. Corp. to the General Realty and lltilities Corp. on Nov. lg. 1929. was assigned by .No,,,,. York Title and IMortgage Co. to the New Yru-k l.:fe insurance Co.

Emerson Gilbert, 35 years old, the fashion-plate spiritualist, faith healer and clergyman, ordained by the Independent Spiritualists National Association at Lansing, Mich., escaped a six-month workhouse term in Special Sessions yesterday by agreeing to leave this city at once.

BOSTON, May 21 (AP). -- Manager Joe Cronin dropped himself to seventh place in the Red Sox batting order today and paved the way for a 7-2 victory over the Indians with a triple with two on base on his first trip to the plate.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday granted a stay against the holding of a special meeting of stockholders of the Bush Terminal Company, which is undergoing reorganization.
May I refer to the statement of Mr. de Ghika, Hungarian Consul General in New York. which was published in THE TIMES under the title "Consular Controversy,'' and review the facts in the matter?

Prices of commodity futures were moderately firmer yesterday, with trading slightly more active. A better grain market helped sentiment to some extent. On the cash markets wheat, rye, silk, rubber and wool tops advanced, while corn, oats and dairy products declined.
Housing deals featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

Your correspondent who designates himself Bachelor and who replies to Edwin J. Jones, who suggests a tax on bachelors and maidens over the age of 25, states his case as follows: "We bachelors and maidens as a group are good spenders and help keep money in circulation; the maidens patronizing the department stores and beauty shops, and the bachelors taking the maidens out and treating them to swell times."

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Two groups of building trade unions, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, today found themselves stalemated in an attempt to win the sanction of the District of Columbia Supreme Court for their acts at two recent conventions.

Mr. CHASE MELLEN Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, has deemed it necessary to reply to the manifesto issued by his old friend and associate Mr. WILLIAM ZIEGLER Jr., chairman of the Progressive Republican Committee, a body of improved Republican thinkers created by the two statesmen as a sort of testimonial and monument to Mr. W.K. MACY, retired from the State chairmanship.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Before a group of prominent engineers and scientists in the field of aviation, the Langley Medal for Aerodromics was presented this afternoon to Dr. Joseph S. Ames, chairman of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, by Chief Justice Hughes.

PARIS, May 21. -- France heard Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's address tonight with the usual tendency to incredulity applied here to German official statements. Official quarters were inclined to think it over before stating whether they believed the Fuehrer's offers contained anything that might lead to improvement in the diplomatic situation.

The death yesterday in the Rockaway Beach Hospital of Mrs. Rebecca Pollak, 45 years old, of 148 Beach Ninety-fourth Street, Rockaway Beach, from an illness that followed a novocaine injection at the Kings County Hospital dental clinic last week is being investigated by the Hospital Department.
FERNDALE, N.Y., May 21. -- Barney Ross is in the pink.

BERLIN, May 21. -- The issue of an indefinite amount in three months' promissory notes by the Gold Discount Bank, a Reichsbank subsidiary, was explained today by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, who heads both institutions. The notes, Dr. Schacht said at the annual meeting of the Gold Discount Bank, were designed to meet an urgent demand of the money market, flooded with idle funds, for some safe but highly liquid investment.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reported yesterday for itself and affiliated companies a net profit of $5,315,254 in 1934 after taxes, depreciation depletion, amortization, retirements minority interest and other charges.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange improved yesterday, United States and foreign government loans advancing while corporate bonds as a whole were steady. The tone was better in Federal issues, institutional buyers, who were absent from the market on Monday, being again reported making purchases.
THE TIMES published a letter from Nathan I. Bijur under the heading "Federal Obstruction." Unfortunately, Mr. Bijur was not in possession of all the facts.

A plea for party harmony to elect a Republican Assembly this Fall and prepare the way for a Republican victory in the State and nation in 1936 was made last night by Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican County Committee. He spoke at a meeting of the Republican Club of Staten Island, at 102 Victory Boulevard.
The Rev. John H. McComb was installed by the Presbytery of New York last night as pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church at 114th Street.

GENEVA, May 21. -- Efforts to prevent an Italo-Ethiopian war reached a complete deadlock here today after a triangular talk between Anthony Eden of Great Britain, Rene Massigli of France and Baron Pompeo Aloisi of Italy.

The Loew's New York and Criterion Theatres, Times Square landmarks occupying the blockfront on the east side of Broadway, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, will be demolished soon, it became known yesterday.

Staging a four-run rally with two out in the seventh inning, the St. John's University baseball team avenged an 8-to-7 defeat suffered last week when it nosed out City College by a similar score at Dexter Park in Woodhaven yesterday. The Redmen rallied after the Beavers had scored three times in the first half of the seventh to break a 4-all tie.

Public offering of $15,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures of the National Distillers Products Corporation will be made today through a banking group headed by Field, Giore Co. and including Brown Harriman Co., Inc., Blyth Co., Inc., and Hayden, Stone Co.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP). -- Officials of the White Motor Company closed the plant today as the United Automobile Workers Federal Union called a strike affecting about 2,500 workers.

BUENOS AIRES, May 21. -- The good-will visit to Buenos Aires of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil will be the occasion for the greatest peacetime military spectacle in South American history. Argentina expects to outdo Brazil's military display on the occasion of President Agustin P. Justo's good-will visit to Rio de Janeiro last year.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- It was generally agreed in both branches of Congress today that, far from killing the issue, the upholding of a veto of the Patman bill would signal the start of a new drive to enact bonus legislation this session.
BERLIN, May 21. -- Following are textual excerpts from Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech before the German Reichstag today, embodying his most important points:

The International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries showed in their pamphlet report for 1934, issued yesterday, a consolidated net profit of $1,433,104 after depreciation, Federal taxes, charges, underlying dividends and minority interest.
PITTSBURGH, May 21. -- Forgetting for the moment their various aches and ailments, the sorely tormented Giants turned on the Pirates with considerable violence today.
NEWARK, N.J., May 21. -- The Bears returned home today to take a 7-to-4 trouncing from the Syracuse Chiefs.

The Cinema Guild of the Young Men's Hebrew Association. Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue, will bring to a close tonight its Spring series of distinguished film presentations with a showing of the old Russian production, "China Express," and "The Master of Existence," a Soviet marionette musical short subject.
ST. LOUIS, May 21. -- Dizzy Dean was led from the field under police escort today after a near riot in the fifth inning had interrupted Philadelphia's 7-to-6 conquest of the world champion Cardinals.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 21. -- The majority of top-notchers in metropolitan district golf assembled at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today for the practice round preliminary to the annual triangular team matches tomorrow.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,650,300 barrels, compared with 2,619,800 in the previous week, a gain of 30,500 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 20,650 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma was the most important change.

Excessive zeal on the part of American port cities to win traffic from competitors was cited as the outstanding weakness of port development programs in an address yesterday by J. Caldwell Jenkins, vice president of the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation, before a luncheon meeting of the Young Men's Council of the United States, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Plans of two buildings for midtown sites were filed in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- Harvard's acceptance of a picture of John Reed, a hero of the Bolshevik revolution, was described today by one of his former classmates as "deplorable" because those who presented it were largely "Communists, Socialists and pink intellectuals."

Gilbert Miller, scheduled to sail Friday on the Majestic after one of those brief and impetuous visits here, will be away this time until Oct. 1. At least one of his side trips in the interim will take him to the drama festival in Moscow (Sept. 1-10).

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- A request for White House support of the newly introduced Crosser bill providing pensions for railroad employes was put before President Roosevelt today by a committee of the Railway Labor Executives Association, headed by Timothy Shea, vice president of the Brotherhood of Firemen and Enginemen.

A tight pitching duel cracked open at the seams in two spots yesterday. The first cost Fordham a victory and the second came close to costing Long Island University the same thing. The Blackbirds pounded over a cluster of four runs in the sixth and the Rams left the tying tally on third base after a three-run rally in the ninth.

BERLIN, May 21. -- Before a brown-clad Reichstag amid dramatic settings now familiar in this new Third Reich, Adolf Hitler tonight made his promised speech upon European affairs and Germany's attitude toward the controversial points involved in their present status.
Numerous textile firms were represented in the long list of business rentals reported yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21. -- A committee of five pastors and the faculty of the Philadelphia Lutheran Seminary were authorized today to investigate an undercurrent of dispute between the "high" and "low" church of the denomination as efforts to bring the matter out on the floor of the 188th annual convention of the Lutheran Ministerium of Pennsylvania and Adjacent States were rebuked.

Premature notice that the New York police and Federal agents are out to rid the city of top-rung racketeers by applying the new Brownell public-enemy law and by citing them for income tax evasion has driven the underworld leaders out of their usual haunts, it was learned last night.

Curtailment of the working hours of city firemen through the addition of 700 new men to the uniformed force is proposed in a local bill introduced in the Board of Aldermen yesterday by Alderman Walter H. Farrar. The bill was sent to committee.

The Cutting Fellowship of Columbia University, awarded annually to four men graduate students "who have given evidence of ability to make contributions of value to letters, science, law, medicine or the fine arts," have been given to Charles A. Bradley Jr. of Cambridge, Mass.; James L. Clifford, Evansville, Ind.; John R. Dunning, Shelby, Neb., and John P. Summerville of New York City.

STOCKHOLM, May 21 (AP). -- A gayly bedecked Swedish royal barge, propelled by twenty blue oars, moved across the harbor today to lend a traditional welcome to King Christian and Queen Alexandrine of Denmark. The Danish royal couple arrived to attend the wedding Friday of Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark and Princess Ingrid of Sweden.

The election of seventeen Mayors at reorganization meetings of New Jersey municipalities yesterday was marked in some quarters with factional controversies and wholesale dismissals of old regime members.

A field of eighty-four golfers, headed by Paul Runyan, last year's winner, is entered in the metropolitan open championship, which will be held at the Lakeville Club, Great Neck, L.I., starting tomorrow.
ST. ANNE'E-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 21. -- The first day's play in the British amateur golf championship had been so full of drama that the second day's matches seemed to open very quietly.
CHICAGO, May 21. -- Miss Jane Addams, world-famous social welfare worker and peace advocate, died at 6:15 P.M. today in Passavant Hospital, where she had undergone a major operation Saturday.

The Board of Education, in preparing its school budget for 1936, is expected to ask the city for at least $10,000,000, or about 12 per cent, in excess of the $79,000,000 it received last year. Spurred by the promise of Bernard S. Deutsch, Aldermanic President, to support a budget that reflected an "ideal set-up," the school authorities are believed certain to include appropriations for Summer schools, extended evening classes and smaller class registers.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- The almost complete cessation of relief aid in Illinois caused hungry unemployed and their dependents to besiege private charities today and has prompted 10,000 transients to leave the State to find relief camps and shelters elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The Code Authority for the marine auxiliary machinery industry asked the National Industrial Recovery Board today for approval of a $1,450 budget for Feb. 9 to June 16.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- The reopening of all textile codes and the establishment of master codes for major functions of textile production was urged upon NRA officials today by members of the Code Authority for the silk textile industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21. -- "All this conversation about the 'mystery' of this year's naval manoeuvres is nothing but a lot of 'hooey.' This year and every year they are designed to acquaint American navy officers with home ports many of them have never seen before, and if foreign powers find anything provocative about that, then that's too damned bad,"

Mrs. Willard S. Brown gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Princess Pignatelli di Montecalvo, Mrs. Jorge R. Andre, Mrs. Charles E. Pettinos, Mrs. Cecil Barret, Mrs. Robert E. Tod and Mrs. Dorothy L. Norris.

With labor in this State and city "deeply disappointed" with President Roosevelt's executive order promulgating the wage scale to be applied under the Federal Government's new works relief program, Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday, upon his return from Washington, that as far as possible the prevailing wage rate in this State would be applied on public works performed under contract in this city.

LONDON, May 21. -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, after his recent spurt of renewed participation in international affairs at Stresa and at home in parliamentary debate, has again effaced himself completely at the most critical stage in the development of Britain's position.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 21 (AP). -- Due to the elimination of Jock McLean, C. Ross Somerville and Hector Thomson, the odds against W. Lawson Little Jr., the defending champion in the current British amateur golf title tournament, today were shortened to 3 to 1.

A long net lease on the property at 565 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-sixth Street, has been taken by a syndicate organized by Henry Mandel, marking a continuation of the brisk trading which has been noted in the midtown Fifth Avenue district in recent weeks.

The women's division of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights adopted a resolution yesterday urging the League of Nations to delay no longer in enforcing economic sanctions against Germany.
The mightiest forehand drive with which a woman has propelled a tennis ball has lost none of its potency after an absence from the lists of twenty-one months.
Money market remained dull and quotations unchanged for all classifications. New business was at a minimum.

The Transradio Press Service, Inc., and its affiliate, the Radio News Association, began suit yesterday in United States District Court for more than $1,100,000 damages. They charge that three major press associations and two radio network systems have conspired to destroy their business of selling news to be broadcast.

CINCIATNATI, May 21. -- Perhaps Mendelssohn's "Elijah" should only be heard at a choral festival with a long and impressive history behind it, a festival which has been for years one of the significant nuclei of American musical life, and from singers to whom practice and familiarity have endeared the music.

The offer of stockholders of the Commercial Credit Company for an exchange of securities, which was announced on May 1 and expired on last Monday, was reported yesterday to have been accepted by holders of more than 90 per cent of the company's preferred stock.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 22. -- A British mission headed by Sir Percival David, famous collector, which has been in Japan for a month seeking a loan of Chinese art objects for the forthcoming Silver Jubilee exhibition in London, sails Friday deeply disappointed at having failed to obtain a single piece.

The Yankees finished one down to the White Sox in a battle of home runs yesterday at the Stadium and, before a crowd of 5,600, dropped the second game of the series to Jimmy Dykes's Chicagoans, 3 to 2.

Increased use of the motion picture as an instrument for propaganda was urged yesterday by James W. Gerard, wartime Ambassador to Germany, in an address at the luncheon forum of the Motion Picture Club of New York at 1.560 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Internal revenue collections for the ten months of the 1935 fiscal year, through April, were nearly 26 per cent more than in the corresponding period last year, the Treasury announced today. Total collections for the ten months were $2,664,853, 327, an increase of $549,150,374.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- President Roosevelt worked late into the night polishing his bonus veto message. He conferred with his chief advisers on the work-relief program.

Routine price-fixing and government purchases of new-crop positions held fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange within narrow limits yesterday, but absence of outside interest left the market narrow. Improved weather west of the Mississippi River offset the influence of a strong stock market and after a quiet session, the list ended 3 points higher to 7 lower than on Monday.
EASTON, Pa., May 21. -- Lafayette went down to defeat, 3 -- 2, at the hands of the University of Pennsylvania nine on Fisher Field today before the largest crowd of the season.

BERLIN, May 21. -- The Boerse was quiet today. Speculators withdrew from the market and the publie remained indifferent. Heavy industrials were quiet but firm. Machineries were only slightly weaker, Orenstein Koppel losing point. Electricals were weaker, A. E. G. losing I point.

ALBANY, May 21. -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the decision of the Transit Commission denying the Third Avenue Railway Company permission to issue $240,000 in notes to buy thirty motor buses for use by the Westchester Electric Railroad Company and the New York, Westchester Connecticut Traction Company.

His name is Joe Jones, and in the catalogue of the Sixteen Cities exhibition held at the Museum of Modern Art in December, 1933, his was the shortest of all biographies. It read: "Born St. Louis, 1909, self-taught."

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Compensation lists of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, filed in the company's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed today that $108,505 was paid in 1934 to George B. Cortelyou, president; $57,929 to Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman; $78,815 to Frank W. Smith, member of the executive committee, and $45,474 to Oscar H. Fogg, vice president.

ROCHESTER, May 21. -- To Dr. George H. Whipple, Nobel Prize winner, of the University of Rochester has been tendered the post of director of the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research in New York City, as successor to Dr. Simon Flexner.

More than 1,000 persons attended a public auction last night of forty-four small properties foreclosed by mortgage companies in the Brooklyn Real Estate Exchange at 189 Montague Street, near Fulton Street. The night's sales totaled $230,000.

District Attorney William C. Dodge removed himself and his staff yesterday from the racket investigation that has been conducted for nearly three months by the March grand jury. He agreed to appoint a special prosecutor from a list of six lawyers to be submitted by the grand jurors.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, in applying today for permanent registration of its securities, failed to throw light on the nature of its $39,115,000 investment in "marketable securities," an item which had given rise to differences with the New York Stock Exchange.

The former Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress, and her new titled husband, Count Court yon Haugwitz-Reventlow, arrived here yesterday morning at the Pennsylvania Station on the Curleyhut, the private coach of the Countess's father. Franklyn L. Hutton, which carried the cross the continent from San Francisco.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,706,949, after all deductions, for the ten months ended on April 30. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.70 a share on 735,664 no par common shares.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 21. -- The annual flower show of the garden department of the Bronxville Woman's Club was held today in the auditorium of the clubhouse here. The stage represented a French flower mart and had a background of flowering trees and hanging baskets of lilacs.

Many luncheon, tea and dinner parties were given yesterday at the Garden Festival in behalf of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery which marked the formal opening of the Park Lane Summer Gardens. The proceeds were donated to the needs of the nursery, founded in 1910 by Dr. and Mrs. Henry Dwight Chapin to shelter and care for homeless children until permanent homes in suitable environment could be found for them.

TRENTON, N.J., May 21. -Granting the State's request, the Court of Errors and Appeals today ordered the defense's opening address and its summing up at the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann included in the appeal record. The court recently granted a similar request by defense counsel that the prosecution statements be included.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- In the first direct move toward more stringent regular, ion of broadcasting programs, the Federal Communications Commission today summoned twenty-one radio stations. several of them prominent, to appear here Oct. 3 to "prove that their continued operation will be in the public interest."

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Final arrangements for President Roosevelt's personal appearance at the Capitol tomorrow to deliver his veto of the Patman Bonus Bill were completed early tonight when the Senate broke a five-hour filibuster by Senator Long and voted 44 to 4 to accept the House resolution for a joint session of Congress.

THERE was a Little turn for the better over yonder at St. Anne's-on-the-Sea yesterday, where the British amateur golf championship is running its riotous course. But it's too early to start cheering from this side of the ocean. The echo might be a sour note by the time it reached the battlefront by the whispering waves.

PARIS, May 21. -- Gifts that the liner Normandie will carry to President Roosevelt and to several American cities with French names were viewed this afternoon by Ambassador and Mrs. Jesse I. Straus at the House of American Nations.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Prices of grains fluctuated erratically today on the Board of Trade, spreading, back-spreading and local operations furnishing most of the trading. May wheat dropped early to a new low mark for the season, but toward the last short covering in that grain and in rye made the close at net gains of 1/4 to 5/8 cent a bushel on wheat and 3/8 to 7/8 cent on rye.

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP). -- Babe Ruth hit his first home run in more than a month and contributed two spectacular running catches today as the Braves broke Tex Carleton's two-year spell over them and downed the Cubs, 4 to 1, to even the series at one game apiece.

DETROIT, May 21. -- The Ford Motor Company will immediately return to the $6 a day minimum wage, an increase of $1 per day, it was announced today. More than 81,000 workers in this district will participate in the increase, and an unestimated number throughout the country.

LONDON, May 21. -- The British Cabinet held a special session today to put the finishing touches on the government's military policy, which is to be outlined in the defense debate in the House of Commons tomorrow.

PARIS, May 21. -- America's four-player contingent to the French hard-court tennis championships registered comparatively easy victories in early round matches today, but some of them appear to be headed for trouble in the third round tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- One obstacle, the need of a Presidential endorsement, was all that stood tonight in the path of a speedy House vote on the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, already passed by the Senate.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 21. -- The hopes of the 1,200,000 jobless in Illinois for early resumption of relief were dashed late today and they faced the prospect of receiving no Federal or State aid again until July 1.

It is now contemplated that the annual meeting of the International Paper and Power Company, previously adjourned to tomorrow, will be further adjourned to June 12 so that stockholders will have a reasonable opportunity to study the annual report made public yesterday, it is stated in the report.

HONOLULU, May 21 (AP). -- Two destroyers, the Buchanan and Decatur, part of the "Great White Fleet" which has been defending Oahu Island in the United States naval maneouvers, were in Pearl Harbor today for minor repairs.

The franc maintained a steadier tone in the foreign exchange market yesterday than for some days and closed unchanged in terms of the dollar. As a result of this steadiness, less gold was engaged in Paris yesterday for shipment here. The amount was $9,000,000, compared with $20,000,000 the day before.

Durable goods, including practically every variety of factory equipment, hold the centre of interest for industrial purchasing executives this year, exhibitors represented in the "inform-a-show," operated in conjunction with the twentieth annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, said yesterday.

Prize winners in costume design and fashion illustration were announced yesterday by officials of the New York School of Design, whose fortieth annual exhibition of students' work is now in progress at 625 Madison Avenue. The exhibition will be open every weekday until May 30 and on Monday, Wednesday and Friday evenings until 10 P.M.

A suit to test the constitutionality of the NRA Ice Code Authority was started yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd in Brooklyn. The court reserved decision on an application by the Kings County Ice Corporation of Brooklyn for a temporary injunction restraining the Ice Bureau, which is the Code Authority for the industry, from interfering with the company.

LONDON, May 21. -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain, during the second reading debate on the Finance Bill in the House of Commons tonight, referred to the war debt to the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- A subsidized national theatre to put America on a par with European nations was urged today by Lawrence Tibbett, the opera singer.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 21. -- A group of the teams entered in the Meadow Brook tournaments which start early next month engaged in three games on the club's field today. In one, the Greentree team of Jock Whitney, with Thomas Hitchcock Jr. playing well at No. 3, deefeated a Red side, 12 to 9.

Ralph R. McKee, vice president of the Board of Education, broke ground yesterday for the new high school that is to be erected with PWA funds at Tottenville, S.I., while residents of Tottenville and surrounding communities, who have been urging the new school since 1909, declared a half holiday in recognition of the event.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday was the smallest of any week this year and the third consecutive week to show a decrease. However, the total was slightly above the number listed in the corresponding week last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Sharp differences of opinion were revealed today among members of the House Ways and Means subcommittee which, with Donald R. Richberg, drafted the administration-sponsored substitute for the resolution to extend the National Industrial Recovery Act.

A juror in Supreme Court wanted to get a closer view yesterday of one of the pictures offered as an exhibit in the $250,000 suit of Eileen Wenzel, former show girl, against Louis J. Ehret Jr. In his haste the juror prodded Miss Wenzel's attorney, Moses Feltenstein, in the ribs, with the result that Justice Aaron J. Levy declared a mistrial.

As a departure which he said he hoped would bring the Metropolitan Opera closer to its public and result in a more sympathetic understanding of its purposes and its problems, Edward Johnson, new general manager of the opera association, inaugurated what is planned as a series of press conferences yesterday afternoon.

RYE, N.Y., May21. -- A newcomer in the women's metropolitan golf championship, Miss Marion Morgan of Apawamis, accounted for the only triumph resembling a form reversal in the opening match play round of that tourney today.

A national reserve corps of men and women equipped for State and Federal public service, like the Army Reserve Corps, was advocated by Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce in an address last night before the Ohio Society of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ATLANTA, May 21 (AP). -- The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company was held today by the Regional Labor Board to have violated collective bargaining provisions of the National Recovery Act and the Cigarette Code.
Dogwood in the month of May -- such a lavish display of snowy bloom, transfigured by Spring sunshine!

Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University and former Secretary of the Interior, has been elected president of the Motion Picture Research Council, succeeding Mrs. August Belmont, who resigned last June. Dr. A Lawrence Lowell, former president of Harvard University, will continue as honorary president.

LAWRENCE of Arabia was killed when his motor cycle, going fifty or sixty miles an hour through a village street, struck a bicycle on which a butcher's boy was riding. Such is the testimony given before a coroner's jury.

The Washington County Museum of Fine Arts, Hagerstown, Md., receives a trust fund of $15,000, a number of works of art and an interest in the residuary estate of Martin Borgord, who died at Riverside, Calif., on March 25. This was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- President Roosevelt was urged in a resolution introduced by Senator Tydings today to call an international conference in Washington to discuss the settlement of war debts, reduction of armaments with an incidental five-year arms holiday, stabilization of currencies and means to revive world trade.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21. -- Juan Ignacio Pombo, 21 years old, Spain's flying cavalier, became the youngest aviator ever to span the Atlantic today when he roared to a stop at Natal, Brazil, after a 16-hour 55-minute flight from Africa.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during April at 85.3 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 92.9 per cent during March this year, and 105.5 per cent during April last year.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BERLIN, May 21. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler decreed today an elastic universal military service law that gives him virtually unlimited powers to draft for service all able-bodied non-Jewish German men between the ages of 18 and 45.

Stockholders of the American Smelting and Refining Company at a special meeting yesterday approved the reduction in the stated value of the common stock from $39 1-3 a share to $10 and the retirement of 16,000 shares of the company's second preferred stock which had been acquired.

Fordham Prep gained its twelfth straight baseball victory and continued to lead the Manhattan-Bronx division of the C.H.S.A.A. by turning back St. Ann's Academy at Fordham Field yesterday, 4 to 3. Trailing by 3 to 1 in the final inning, Fordham scored once on a misplay, tallied again when Farley tripled and then triumphed as Erickson singled to score Farley.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21. -- Passage of the Patman bill by Congress resulted from "the biggest piece of coercive lobbying ever brought to bear upon Congress," it was charged today by Mrs. E.A. Strong of San Marino, Calif., in her annual report to the National Society of New England Women as third vice president-general and legislative chairman.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- The broad buying movement in hogs that developed on Monday continued today and prices rose 25 cents a hundredweight to the highest mark since October, 1930, the top being $10. Including the processing tax of $2.25 a 100 pounds, which the packers pay, the outside level was $12.25, a figure which has not been equaled since July, 1928, when there was no processing tax in effect.

Ludwig Juht, a member of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, gave a contra-bass recital at Steinway Hall last night. The contra-bass is not frequently played as a solo instrument, but Mr. Juht has apparently chosen to follow the path of the leader of his orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, who was a virtuoso of the instrument before he addressed himself exclusively to conducting.

A suit for $1,129,533,000 filed here last July by Robert A. Gilchrist against the Grain Stabilization Corporation and thirty-two other defendants, alleging misappropriation of Federal Farm Board funds, has been thrown out of court by Federal Judge John C. Knox, it was revealed yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia and Oswald W. Knauth, relief director, were attacked in the Board of Aldermen yesterday by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley, who said they had distorted and garbled figures on relief complaints received by the Mayor's complaint bureau.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit arrived in New York City yesterday afternoon and started preparation of his speech to expound the principles of his National Union for Social Justice at a mass meeting at Madison Square Garden tonight.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 21. -- The unconditional release of Amadeo Barletta, former Italian Consul, held incomunicado for six weeks by the Dominican Government on a charge of plotting to kill President Rafael Trujillo, is reliably reported.

Fashion shows transmitted to the homes by television are "as sure as fate," according to Frank Presbrey, chairman of the board of the Frank Presbrey Company and one of the deans of advertising, who is 80 years old today.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, May 21 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt observed coal mining operations at first hand today and then told graduates of "People's University" tonight that "we must educate ourselves to study changes and to meet these changes."

BOSTON, May 21. -- Of the $21,000,000 in securities of the Seaboard Utilities Corporation and the Railroad Shares Corporation bought by thousands of investors from the bankrupt C.D. Parker Co., Inc., of Boston, less than $100,000 will be salvaged, Attorney General Paul A. Dever indicated today.

At least 800 additional nurses are needed in the twenty-six city hospitals if the institutions are to be placed on the same footing as representative private hospitals, Dr. S.S.
