Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, said yesterday in making public the annual report of the Division of Nursing of his department.
Fourteen small flats and one dwelling, comprising eleven parcels, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions in Manhattan yesterday. The results were as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- An indictment of the Omnibus Banking Bill as a possible creator of business uncertainty and as likely to force banks out of the Federal Reserve System was delivered today by the United States Chamber of Commerce.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21. -The third day of the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Society of Daughters of the Revolution in the Garden City Hotel was passed in hearing committee reports and adopting resolutions.

SEATTLE, May 21. -- Mary Pickford, returning to the legitimate stage in her first full-length drama in twenty-six years, proved to a Seattle audience last night that she still merits the title "America's Sweetheart."

TRENTON, May 21. -- Upholding the constitutionality of the law creating the State Milk Control Board, the Court of Errors and Appeals ruled today the statute was directed to a "legitimate end," that is, the protection of public health and welfare.

The Equity Corporation, an investment company, in accordance with its program of cooperating in the effort to simplify the Founders group of investment companies, is inviting approximately 100,000 holders of common stock of the United Founders Corporation to exchange shares at one share of their stock for three-tenths share of Equity common stock.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 21. -- W.H. Stubblefield, racing driver, and his riding mechanic, Leo Whittaker, both of Los Angeles, were killed late today when the car which they were attempting to qualify for the 500-mile Memorial Day race hurtled over the wall at the southwest turn of the motor speedway here.

National Maritime Day will be observed in many cities throughout the country today, in accordance with a proclamation by President Roosevelt calling for special exercises in honor of the 116th anniversary of the sailing of the Savannah, first steam-propelled ship to cross the Atlantic, from the port of Savannah.

The degree of Graduate in Pharmacy will be conferred upon sixty-four candidates at the 105th annual commencement exercises of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University at 8:20 o'clock this evening in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.

I observe in THE NEW YORK TIMES that the Police Commissioner has expressed the desire to assist the poultry dealers of this city in their war on racketeers by issuing the permits necessary to enable these merchants to possess and carry firearms.

More than 250,000 trade union members were ordered yesterday by their organizations to stop work this afternoon in a protest against the relief wage scale set by President Roosevelt for the government's work-relief program, and several organizations, including the Knickerbocker Democrats, sent protests to the President against his wage scale order.

Probably no other address which President Roosevelt has made stirred as much enthusiasm in the financial community as did his denunciation yesterday of the Patman Bonus Bill and of currency inflation in general; marketwise, the message was received calmly, as the Senate's vote today on the bill will give the cue.

VIENNA, May 22. -- The Austrian echo of Retchsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech is extremely unflattering. The press generally is highly indignant over his references to this country, which, it is felt, were inspired, as usual, by a feeling that Austria is already part of the Third Reich, although, unfortunately at the moment, under foreign occupation.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- A widespread slump in retail trade last week, attributed largely to unfavorable weather conditions, was reported today in the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business in thirty-three cities.

The board of trustees of Lehigh University, Bethlehem, Pa., accepted yesterday at a special meeting here the resignation of Dr. Charles Russ Richards as president of the university. The resignation will be effective at the close of the fiscal year, Aug. 31.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 22. -Mrs. Raymond Gunnison won a tricolor in the cultural class and Mrs. James Baird received the tricolor in the artistic arrangement class at the Spring flower show of the Scarsdale Garden Club presented here this afternoon at the Scarsdale Woman's Club.

GENEVA, May 22. -- The speech of Adolf Hitler is having a divided reception in Geneva. More neutral and internationalist quarters, with some exceptions, find it constructive enough to provide a basis for resumption of negotiations if others have not already made up their minds that there is no use in negotiating.

One professional bail bondsman pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a charge of perjury committed in February when he supplied a bond for a gunman, and two others indicted on charges of conspiracy and subornation of perjury surrendered in the same court.

LOS ANGELES, May 22. -- The fire hazard involved today halted hand pumping of ready-refined gasoline from backyard water pumps, whose owners have reaped a small fortune for the past several days by drawing from a gasoline lake formed by leakage at a near-by refinery.

Doubtless not all the persons demanding the continuance of the NRA in substantially its present form for two years are actuated solely by a concern for the national welfare. Some wish to keep their NRA jobs in Washington or on Code Authorities; others, representing some business unit, wish to continue to control prices and trade practices in their own interest.

The Rev. Wilfrid Parsons, editor of the Catholic weekly America, declares in the current issue of that publication that the Nye-Sweeney bill to establish a government bank, advocated by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, would tend toward "all the old evils of bad banking with a great many new ones besides."

NEWARK, N.J., May 22. -- Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York, in an address today to more than 100 members of the Bond Club of New Jersey at its monthly luncheon in the Robert Treat Hotel, declared that the finances of the Federal Government "are far from the danger point, regardless of the alarmists."

Although a second day of clearing weather in the western and central parts of the Cotton Belt created selling pressure again, and prices on the Cotton Exchange declined nearly a dollar a bale at one time, the market turned upward in the last hour yesterday to close unchanged to 5 points higher on the day.

The skyline around Times Square is being perceptibly lowered by the simple process of pulling down theatres which OSCAR HAMMERSTEIN built and erecting "taxpayers" on their site. He was a colorful genius who thought in terms of great auditoriums.

The various reactions to the signing of the Feld-Crawford "fair trade" bill remind me of an item in that estimable "History of New York" by Brodhead. He recounts that on Dec. 17, 1679, or 256 years ago:
HANOVER, N.H., May 22. -- Darkness ended a twelve-inning battle between Dartmouth and New Hampshire in an 8-to-8 tie today.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The reaction here to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech before the Reichstag yesterday on European affairs was generally favorable, if his remarks are to he taken at their face value.

TORONTO, May (Canadian Press) -- Making a vigorous recovery in the second half, the touring Scottish Football Association eleven defeated a team of Toronto Star 3 -- 1, before 10,000 spectators today. Each side scored once in the opening half.

GENEVA, May 22. -- Dr. H.J. Wollner, consulting chemist in the Treasury Department, urged the governments in the Advisory Opium Committee of the League of Nations today to cooperate in developing "police chemistry" against illicit drugs. He stated narcotics were being prepared more and more deceptively to facilitate smuggling and illicit use.

While Father Charles E. Coughlin was holding his rally in Madison Square Garden last night an anti-Coughlin meeting was being held in Columbus Circle under the auspices of the West Side Council Against War and Fascism. The council, which says it is non-partisan and non-sectarian, has headquarters at 177 West Ninety-fifth Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 22. -The Legislature passed today the long deadlocked bill to provide State funds for relief, and an end to the acute relief crisis in the State appeared in sight when assurance was received that $5,000,000 Federal funds would be granted for the remainder of May.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- The Pennsylvania varsity crew, in its final test before meeting Navy and Harvard in the Adams Cup regatta at Annapolis on Saturday, was beaten by the Penn A.C. over a two-mile course on the Schuylkill tonight.

Tallying the winning run in the last half of the eighth and extra inning, the Horace Mann School for Boys baseball team downed Hackensack High, 10 to 9, yesterday at Horace Mann Field and closed its season with an undefeated record in nine games.

The sailing yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines of the American delegation to the International Labor Conference at Geneva received special recognition from President Roosevelt in a message from Washington setting forth the high importance at the session's purposes.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Some of the outstanding points made by President Roosevelt in his message vetoing the Patman Bonus Bill were:

BOSTON, May 22 (AP). -- Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University and former Secretary of the Interior, has accepted the presidency of the Motion Picture Research Council, it was announced here tonight by Stephen P. Cabot, acting chairman of the council's national executive committee.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Simultaneous cooperative action among nations to revive foreign trade by restoring price structures, stabilizing exchange and removing artificial trade barriers was declared imperative today by Secretary Hull.

A group which opposes John Graubard in a contest for control of the United States Express Company issued yesterday a statement denying the measure of support by stockholders claimed by Mr. Graubard. The group contends that David A. Smith is president of the company in opposition to the claim of Mr. Graubard that he is president.
Plans for the city reception to the french delegation arriving on the Iner Normandie on June 3 were discussed yesterday by the Mayor's committee at City Hall.

Prominent persons paid honor yesterday morning at a requiem mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral to Marshal Josef Pilsudski of Poland, who died in Warsaw May 12. With them, a throng that filled the cathedral heard the dead patriot praised by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle as one who might be likened to Washington and Lincoln.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 22. -- Hard hitting behind the effective pitching of Jimmy Connors gave Lehigh a 7-to-4 victory over Rutgers University today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 22. -- Paralleling the Catholic Legion of Decency movement, a campaign to unite 22,000,000 Protestant women in the United States in a decisive drive for "decent and better motion pictures" was started here today.

PITTSBURGH, May 22. -- Colonel Bill Terry's machine, though still moving on its few remaining spare tires, went thundering out of here tonight in a manner that should cause considerable rejoicing back home.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The American Sugar Refining Company in 1934 paid $76,800 compensation to Earl D. Babst, chairman of the board; $42,500 to W. Edward Foster, vice chairman, and $48,377 to Joseph F. Abbott, president, a registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission today showed.

Jacob Goldschmidt, German banker and former head of the Darmstaedter and Nationalbank, who was on the executive boards of more industrial concerns than any other German, declared at his apartment in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel yesterday that his present stay in this country had no connection with any official business on behalf of the Reich.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 22. -- The forty-fourth annual convention of the National Society of the Daughters of the Revolution was concluded tonight with a meeting of the national board in the Garden City Hotel. About thirty officers and trustees, including the twelve newly elected trustees, were present.
The Beck-Brown Realty Co., Inc., assigned a mortgage for $30,000, a half interest, on 132-136 W. 32d St., to Joseph Fybush, who then assigned this half interest to Harriet G. Fybush.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS W.Va., May 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. William B. Hines gave a dinner last night at their place on the Midland Trail to celebrate the birthday of Mr. Hines's brother, Major General John L. Hines, retired Chief of Staff, U.S.A.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Rallying to the cry that the Clark resolution extending the National Industrial Recovery Act for ten months only was "legislative sabotage" and would mean "complete disaster" to hundreds of codes of fair competition, 1,500 business men in Constitution Hall adopted today a resolution for extending the act for two years, as proposed by President Roosevelt.

The International Paper Company, manufacturing subsidiary of the International Paper and Power Company, reported yesterday a net loss of $2,413,866 for 1934, after $595.849 profit from bonds redeemed in the year. This compared with a net loss of $4,430,528, after profit of $913,937 from bonds redeemed, in 1933.

Paul S. Clapp, vice president of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, took the stand late yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer and a jury in the $500,000 breach of promise suit brought against him by Miss Katherine Leary Bond.

SALEM, N.H., May 22. -- The sensational winning splurge of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's string of horses, both here and at Belmont, continued at Rockingham today when Bachelor Dinner, with Jockey J. Johnson up, scored a thrilling victory in the $2,500 added New England States Handicap.
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP). -- Jesse Haines pitched a fine game for the Cardinals today and the world champions scored a 3-to-2 victory over the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Friends and opponents of the Patman Bonus Bill reacted immediately to President Roosevelt's personally delivered message. Followers of Senator Thomas and Representative Patman, bonus leaders, were critical, while, on the other hand, bonus foes praised the speech.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- The Senators made it two straight over the Browns today, winning, 5 to 2, behind Earl Whitehill's pitching. Whitehill allowed eight hits, one of them a homer by Pepper in the eighth.

Joseph L. Steinmetz took the stand yesterday before Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. and a jury in General Sessions and in choking tones described a happy honeymoon that had ended with the slaying last Nov. 26 of his bride of a fortnight and her companion, the Rev. Joseph J. Leonard, in the Knights of Columbus Hotel, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. May 22. -- Police Judge Louis Taylor of the village of Mamaroneck was arraigned before Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley this afternoon on a charge of grand larceny. An adjournment was granted until June 5 and bail was set at $2,000.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it would support the policy of port differentials on water-rail traffic in the intercoastal trade despite the report submitted to the Shipping Board by Examiner M.G. de Quevado, the board's examiner, attacking the principle.

Rod-and-reel fishing for broadbill swordfish in Block Island and Montauk waters generally does not bring results until July, but commercial men open their harpooning activities early in June, traveling about forty miles offshore in search of these great specimens.

No one was surprised when the House of Representatives, after listening coldly to the President, promptly proceeded to overrule him by more than a two-thirds majority. That result had entered into every forecast and calculation. Mr. ROOSEVELT himself must have known that it was foregone.

Conflicting opinions as to housing congestion and rentals in Harlem were expressed yesterday by witnesses at a hearing of the subcommittee on housing of the Mayor's commission investigating conditions in that area.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -President Roosevelt's declaration against future "war profiteering" in his bonus veto message today stirred Senate munitions investigators to renewed efforts to bar the making of bulky profits from the shipbuilding program under the pending $460,000,000 Naval Appropriation Bill.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Approval of budgets by the National Industrial Recovery Board was asked today by the Code Authorities for five divisions of the paper and pulp industry. For the year 1935, the bogus wrapping and packing industry proposed a budget of $5,724; the fiber board division, $7,500; the leather board industry one of $5,800, and the soda pulp, $3,686.92.

The city of Chicago yesterday awarded to a group of banks in Chicago a refunding issue of $7,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds of 1935, seconds series, the proceeds from which will be used to retire a like amount of callable refunding bonds of 1934 bearing 5 1/2 per cent interest.

A throng that was a reincarnation of the multitude that stormed the old Garden to hear William Jennings Bryan in his arraignment of the gold standard in 1896 milled through the streets around Madison Square Garden last night.

CHERAW, S.C., May 22 (AP). -At his unmarked grave in an old churchyard here tribute was paid today to the memory of Captain Moses Roger, master of the steamship Savannah, which sailed out of the Georgia port of that name 116 years ago on the first transatlantic voyage of a steam-propelled craft.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, Based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Loans and discounts, including rediscounts, of national banks on March 4 were $7,489,904,000, or $1,252,000 greater than on Dec. 31, 1934, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, reported today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 22. -- If Max Baer holds James J. Braddock lightly as a challenger for his title he is not indicating it in the manner in which he is preparing himself for the defense of his heavyweight crown against the New Jersey boy June 13.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 22. -- Three members of the faculty of the New Jersey College for Women testified today that Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the college's German department, was pro-Nazi.
BOSTON, May 22 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell spotted the Indians five runs today before the Red Sox put on two six-run drives and gave him his sixth victory of the season by a 12-5 margin.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress today in which he vetoed the Bonus Bill was as follows:

Although there are many dangers still confronting business, recovery is on the way, "inevitably, relentlessly and unstopped," Dr. Neil Carothers, director of the College of Business Administration of Lehigh University, declared last night at the twentieth anniversary banquet of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -The Tennessee Valley Authority was attacked today by Representative Montet of Louisiana as using "land shark practices" to force the Aluminum Company of America to cooperate in a unified development of the Tennessee River basin.
CINCINNATI, May 22. -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America opens its 147th annual general assembly in the Taft Auditorium here tomorrow.

Chalmers Wood of Johnson Wood, chairman of the committee formed to effect a settlement of unlisted trading in Alleghany Corporation prior preferred $2.50 stock on a when-issued basis, announced yesterday that the aid of the American Arbitration Society would be invoked to settle the controversy.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Once, when the late Alexander P. Moore of Pittsburgh was Ambassador to Spain, he was invited by King Alfonso, whom he entertained if he did not edify, to go with him to a rural fiesta. The peasantry yelled their heads off for His Catholic Majesty, and Alfonso asked the Ambassador what he thought of it.

The directors of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra will meet this afternoon with leaders of women's clubs at Steinway Hall to organize a subscription campaign for the orchestra's coming season. The speakers will be Antonia Brico, conductor of the orchestra; Mrs. Harold V. Milligan and Mrs. R.C. Bolling.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Unless Congress provides specifically for continuation of existing imposed Liquor Codes in passing proposed NIRA extension legislation, the country will be without protection from abuses of the liquor traffic, Joseph H. Choate Jr., chairman of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, told the House Ways and Means Committee today.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Grain markets were little affected by the President's veto of the bonus bill today. While a small dip and a violent rally on the Board of Trade followed issuance of the message, the rally was due almost entirely to professional buying, and the wheat market reacted faster later than it had advanced.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley approved today the liquidation of the Westchester Title and Trust Company and the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company, both of this city.

Hammering the offerings of the venerable Sam Jones and the younger Joe Vance for a total of fourteen hits, the Yankees frolicked through a 13-to-5 conquest over the White Sex yesterday in a game that was a comedy of errors.

KENT, Conn., May 22. -- The Choate nine vanquished Kent by 7 -- 0 today, Stevens yielding only four hits and striking out fifteen. The victors made six safeties, including a homer by Albinger. Jackson led the Kent batters with a triple and a single.

Despite the rise in the price of scrap steel, which would normally forecast a gain in operations, a further decline in the rate of activities at the steel mills is expected, according to The Iron Age's weekly summary of the steel industry.

GENEVA, May 22. -- Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, vainly added today his efforts to those of Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, to persuade Premier Mussolini of Italy through his representative, Baron Pompeo Aloisi, to accept League of Nations intervention in his dispute with Ethiopia, which she demands in accordance with her covenant rights.

LONDON, May 22. -- In a clash between shouting, jeering Communists and mounted and foot police tonight preceding the arrival of King George and Queen Mary at the civic jubilee reception and ball held in London's historic Fifteenth Century Guildhall, the Communists, singing the "Internationale," shouted: "Your fine robes would buy us bread!" and "Our families are starving!" as the police pushed them back.

There will be an opening this evening at the Masque Theatre, the play being "Weather Permitting," from the pen of Edward Sargent Brown. It is about a millionaire and a girl, and some of those who will be around are Viola Frayne, Ruth Holden, Len Doyle, Matthew Smith, Harold De Becker and Marjorie Dalton.

A bequest to Dartmouth College, estimated to be more than $700,000, which may not be used for athletic activities or in connection with the study of "dead languages," is contained in the will of Emil Bommer, wealthy Brooklyn hardware manufacturer, who died on May 16.

The report of the United Carbon Compny and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on March 31 shows net profit of $477,633 after depreciation, depletion and Federal taxes. This was equal to $1.21 a share on 394,327 no-par shares of capital stock.

Fordham enjoyed only one big inning in its meeting with the Brooklyn College nine at Fordham Field yesterday, but that one drive proved sufficient and the Rams triumphed, 4 to 0. The Maroon tallied its four markers in the second after two were out on five successive blows.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22 (AP). -Claiming victory in his word battle with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, Governor Martin L. Davey suddenly withdrew today a warrant charging him with criminal libel.
The current exhibition of paintings by a group of New York artists at the Montross Gallery has been extended one week, closing June 1.

A 16-year-old boy, who admitted that he set fire to the house in which he lives four times in the last month, was arrested and charged with arson yesterday by detectives in the Bronx. The boy, Benjamin Speigel of 1,419 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, is reported to have confessed after questioning by John Cashman, Assistant Fire Marshal; Lawrence Peltin, Assistant District Attorney, and detectives.

The New York Life Insurance Company, which for some time has held the Hotel Vanderbilt, at Park Avenue and Thirty-third Street, under assignment, took over the property at a foreclosure auction sale yesterday. The insurance company made a bid of $50,000 over a mortgage of $2,366,000.

Elimination of "not only price-fixing, but of price-fixing devices in future codes" is being asked by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced here yesterday. Irving C. Fox, Washington representative on codes of the association, stressed this in a communication sent yesterday to Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House.

Class elections for 1935-36 and appointments of undergraduate club officers were completed yesterday at Fordham College. William Farley was elected president of the senior class and Eugene J. Audi was named president of the Athletic Association.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22. -- Colgate overwhelmed the Army nine, 9 to 2, in a loosely played game today.

Plans filed by architects yesterday included a storage building costing $835,000 for the Department of Sanitation, a new $400,000 apartment house in the Bronx and various projects for altering existing structures.

Cavalcade, 3-year-old champion last year, made a return to competition at Belmont Park yesterday and was defeated by Head Play in a race which disappointed many, but surprised few among close followers of racing.

A plan whereby Jersey City will retire $2,000,000 of back taxes owed to the State of New Jersey was announced yesterday by Arthur Potterton, Director of Revenue and Finance of the city. He said negotiations had been completed through Norman S. Taber Co., whereby the city would receive an additional line of banking credit on new loans of $4,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt delivered in person to a joint session of Congress his veto of the Patman Soldiers' Bonus Bill. He announced approval of the $1,000,000,000 work relief allotments recommended last week by the Advisory Committee on Allotments.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England. May 22. -- W. Lawson Little Jr., Dan R. Topping, Robert Sweeny and Richard D. Chapman have set such a hot pace in the British amateur golf championship that at the end of the third round tonight they are offering a combined American challenge to British golf prestige.

CINCINNATI, May 22. -- Big George Earnshaw made his first start as a National League hurler today and had no luck. By getting to him for five runs on six hits in five innings the Reds scored their first triumph of the year over Casey Stengel's Dodgers, 5 to 4, and dropped them further behind the Giants.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York:

RYE, N.Y., May 22. -- Continuing to play some of the best golf of the tourney thus far, Miss Marion Morgan, one of the district's newest stars, advanced through the second round of the women's metropolitan championship today.
Gordon Carroll, a member of the editorial staff of The New York Sun, will become managing editor of The American Mercury next Monday, the publishers of the magazine announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Largely because retail trade and payrolls expanded more than seasonally, currency in circulation from Jan. 23 to April 24 showed a net increase of $110,000,000, or somewhat greater than is usual at this time of year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its May bulletin.

Herr HITLER'S speech on foreign policy holds out a number of fair promises, but they are vitiated by the fact that the speaker is the man who claims the right to annul solemn treaty obligations without the consent of the other side. All through the Reichstag address there sounds this note of unilateralism.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22. -- Yale today swept Brown University into a 6 -- 4 defeat through an eighth-inning rally that erased a two-run lead. The spurt netted four runs, and averted what seemed certain defeat.

With the period of grace on a defaulted payment of $2,464,505 bond interest almost elapsed, the Western Pacific Railroad has failed to reach an agreement with bondholders to avert foreclosure proceedings, it was disclosed yesterday at the office of the company.

The current naval manoeuvres were described in an addresshere yesterday by Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr. as "the test of a defensive plan -- which may become offensive in tactics -- for holding our position in the Pacific against any nation."

Prices of commodity futures were generally steady in quiet trading here yesterday. The deadlock existing almost a week between buyers and sellers of raw sugar was broken and sugar futures recovered moderately. In the cash markets, rye, dairy products, tin, lead, rubber and cotton were higher, while wheat, Corn, oats and lard were lower.
ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, May 22 (AP). -- A crowd of 3,000 followed W. Lawson Little today in his match with J.P. Zacharias.

BOSTON, May 22 (AP). -- An elderly former Princeton professor who interrupted his literary researches last night for a visit to a Boston night club, told police today that friends he made at the night club had stolen money, his watch, a pair of shoes and two volumes of Shakespeare before they left him this morning.

SHREWSBURY, N.J., May 22. -- The pair of majestic sycamore trees that figured in a Revolutionary War battle and now stand in the middle of Sycamore Avenue here, have just had their right to their position legally and permanently guaranteed after six years of dispute, uncertainty and litigation.
Jacob R. Lefferts has added sixty-five acres to his cabin and bungalow development in Matawan. The tract fronts a mile on Lake Lefferts, giving the development a total frontage of three miles.
BALTIMORE, May 22. -- The appointment of Ernest Schelling as conductor of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra was announced today by Frederick R. Huber, municipal director of music.

WASHINGTON, May22 (AP). -- Revised estimates of the 1934 cotton crop announced today by the Department of Agriculture place production at 9,636,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, compared with 13,047,000 bales for 1933. Ginnings were 9,636,073 bales of 500 pounds each for 1934.

The New York Stock Exchange will admit to trading today stocks and bonds of Swift Co., one of the "Big Four" of the meat packing industry, whose securities hitherto have been listed on the Chicago Stock and New York Curb Exchanges.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., May 22. -- Notable advances in the realms of safety, speed and efficiency of aircraft were demonstrated here today at the annual engineering conference of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics before some 300 leaders in aviation, comprising the most representative gathering in the history of the organization.

A few years ago a list of America's twelve greatest living women was made by a committee of men (among them NEWTON D. BAKER, HENRY VAN DYKE and BOOTH TARKINGTON). It included the name of JANE ADDAMS. But every such list, even a much smaller one, boasts her name, and it is usually at the head and not for an alphabetical reason alone.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 22. -- One of the first players to go out for second and third round matches in the British amateur golf championship today was Daniel R. Topping of Greenwich, Conn., who won by a one-hole margin from Ernest Millard, a London golfer.

A plan to reduce the number of election districts by about 600 with a resultant saving to the city of at least $180,000 in the cost of conducting elections was presented yesterday to the Board of Elections by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 (AP). -- President Getulio Dornelles Vargas of Brazil arrived today on the battleship Sao Paulo for an official visit as airplanes droned overhead and harbor sirens shrieked a welcome.

PARIS, May 22. -- In official circles in Paris Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech is regarded as "marking the removal for the present of the atmosphere of tension which has existed during the past three months."

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt, setting a historical precedent by appearing before a joint session of Congress today to deliver a veto message in person, rejected the Patman Greenback Bonus Bill. He spoke in face of the certainty that he would be immediately overridden by the House.

PARIS, May 22. -- The left-handed placement of the brilliant French doubles team of Christian Boussus and Marcel Bernard proved too much for Wilmer Hines and Henry Culley today and the Americans were eliminated from the French hard court championships, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 3, in a third-round match.
CINCINNATI, May 22 (AP). -- President Roosevelt tomorrow night in Washington will press a key switching on lights for the first night baseball game in major league history.
A five-year development program of the Boys Clubs of America, to begin next January, was outlined yesterday at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, May 22. -- Sir John Gilmour, the Home Secretary, according to tax returns, held as recently as April 16, 3,066 ordinary shares of stock in Vickers, the great armament firm, W. Arnold Forster on behalf of the National Peace Council told the Royal Commission on Arms today.

Senator WAGNER'S "Labor Relations Bill," already approved by the Senate, has now been favorably reported by a House committee and may speedily be sent to the President, unless opinion in the lower branch of Congress can be brought to realize how much harm and confusion it would cause.

Since the arrest two years ago of Samuel Skoblow, who is to be sentenced on arson charges in Kings County Court next Monday, professional incendiarism has been virtually wiped out in ]rooklyn and fire insurance losses in that borough have dropped from about $7,000,000 a year to about $3,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, May 22. -- Rather than work at cross-purposes, each trying to outmanoeuvre the other, the Americans and the British should be viewing the problem of monetary stabilization as they would view a joint military operation, Sir Josiah Stamp, British banker and railroad executive, observed here in a discussion of international financial affairs.

Possibly because the veto had been discussed and forecast so extensively, the financial community showed astonishingly little response yesterday to President Roosevelt's address to Congress. The stock market did seem to mark time rather deliberately while the message was being delivered, but when this was ended, it was hardly possible to say whether the course of trading had been affected.

After declaring in a note that he had fought for sixteen months against the urge to kill another man, Harry M. Confess, 45 years old, a gift shop proprietor of 27-33 Pacific Avenue, Atlantic City, N.J., shot himself dead yesterday noon in a room at the Hotel Edison, 234 West Forty-seventh Street, according to the police.
NEWARK, N.J., May 22. -- The Newark Bears were held to two hits by Joe Mulligan, husky Holy Cross alumnus, today and dropped the second game of their series with the Syracuse Chiefs, 4 to 1.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 22. -- Cornell blanked Rochester, 10 -- 0, in its final non-league game today, blasting out twelve hits as Bill Hall and Bill Roundey held the visitors to two safeties, one a double by Robeson.

BERLIN, May 22. -- While eagerly awaiting the world's echoes to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's thirteen-point program for European peace with German honor, the government today sounded a preliminary call to the colors for two classes of the nation's man power -the classes of 1914 and 1915 -- for mustering in June.
LONDON, May 22. -- Today's reply of the British Government in Parliament to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech of last night was in two voices.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Hogs were not in such urgent demand here today as they were on the two previous days and with larger receipts at most Western markets prices here were steady to 5 cents a hundredweight higher. The top price was up 5 cents above yesterday's to $10.05, the highest since October, 1930.

ALBANY, May 22. -- A yield of $51,000,263 in taxes imposed on New Yorkers' 1934 incomes, the largest in five years, was seen today by Tax Commissioner Mark Graves as an indication that "we are on the way back to economic recovery."

PARIS, May 22. -- A six-point program to defend France's gold-backed currency against devaluation was studied by the government today, as it prepared to ask Parliament for extraordinary powers to effect budgetary economies.

Mrs. Oharles E. Adams, the Mary H. Rogers cottage on South Lain St.; John G. Jackson, cottage of Robert H. Brush on Halsey Neck Lane; Mrs. Otto Seldenberg, the Arthur Price cottage on Cooper St.; Miss Neva C. Taylor, the Charles Corrigan cottage on Corrigan St.; Dr. Fenton Taylor, the William-H. Drew cottage on Hill St,; Southampton (L. l.) rentals by G. L, GIIsey Co.
BOSTON, May 22. -- The Ford Motor Company reported today an increase of $3,759,311 in its surplus as of Dec. 31, 1934, over the preceding year, bringing the total to $580,276,560.

BERLIN, May 22. -- Maria Menke, Sister Neophyta, mother superior of the Cologne House of the Order of the Augustine Sisters, was sentenced today by the Berlin Criminal Court to five years at penal servitude on a charge of having smuggled money over the border into Belgium to reduce the debt on the sisterhood's Cologne hospital.

The Bankers Trust Company joined yesterday the lengthening list of big banks in this city in expressing opposition to the proposed Banking Act of 1935. In a study of the bill sent to shareholders by S. Sloan Colt, president, the Bankers Trust asserts that the proposed measure cannot cure the major defects in the national banking system because it does not even recognize them.

Irving T. Bush issued a statement yesterday replying to the criticism by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch of the methods by which Mr. Bush is said to have obtained sufficient proxies from holders of the common stock of the Bush Terminal Company to control any meeting of stockholders.

C. Byron Sloane, 40 years old, of Sands Point, L.I., member of a socially prominent family, was seriously injured about 10:30 o'clock last night when he accidentally fell from a second-floor French window of a restaurant at 1,015 Madison Avenue, between Seventy-eighth and Seventy-ninth Streets.

S. S. Kresge Co., ground floor of 168-70 Dyckmal St. for tell year, with five-year renewal, at reported minimum annual rental of $10,000, The plot, 0x200, is occupied by a garage which is to be altered for the tenant by the owner, the Michael Hoffman estate. J. J. Secoles, Inv., Is the contractor, Volz , Inc., arra.uged the lease.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- More than a thousand answers to questionnaires mailed to protective committees throughout the country have been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its inquiry into reorganization proceedings, made by direction of Congress.

STOCKHOLM, May 22. -- With Stockholm festively decorated, King Gustaf of Sweden, King Christian of Denmark, Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark and Princess Ingrid of Sweden, who will become his bride Friday, went this morning to the central railroad station to greet German Princes, headed by former Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm.

A comprehensive plan for a national theatre organization, intended to foster theatrical production with the aid of Federal funds, revive the "road" and relieve unemployment within the industry, was presented before the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority yesterday by Frank Gillmore, president of Actors Equity Association.

LEWISBURG, Pa., May 22. -- Robert Jay Marks, 20, a Bucknell College freshman, who lives at 42 West Fifty-eighth Street, New York City, killed himself just before noon today with a revolver as he sat in his dormitory room.

LONDON, May 22. -- The police tonight broke up a large band of unemployed demonstrators attempting to reach the Guildhall before King George and Queen Mary were due to arrive for the Silver Jubilee ball given by the Lord Mayor and Lady Mayoress.

PARIS, May 22. -- Rentes continued to improve on the Bourse today, closing 50 centimes to 1.15 francs above yesterday's levels. Stocks were irregular. They opened weak, but rallied in the latter part of the session, led by Royal Dutch Oil, and regained the early losses.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., May 22. -Lionel Roberts, local legislator and director of the Virgin Islands Company, President Roosevelt's rehabilitation experiment to make the islands self-supporting, denounced fellow-legislators and the West Indian Company, allegedly a foreign corporation, in a fiery speech at a special session of the Legislature today, charging preferential legislation against the interests of the people.

SWAN LAKE, N.Y., May 22. -- Whoever loses the fight when Jimmy McLarnin and Barney Ross clash for the former's welterweight championship of the world at the Polo Grounds on Tuesday night will have no alibi to offer as far as condition is concerned.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22. -- The Evangelical Lutheran Ministerium of Pennsylvania and Adjacent States at its 188th annual convention here voted overwhelmingly today in favor of a merger with the East Pennsylvania Synod.

Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins gave a dinner last night in the Pierre roof garden for Grand Duchess Marie of Russia, Prince and Princess Paul Chavchavadze, Mr. and Mrs. Anderson Dana, Mr. and Mrs. Alden S. Blodget, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Colgate, Mr. and Mrs. Chester G. Burden, Mr. and Mrs. Lee J. Perrin, Prince Serge Obolensky and John Farnham.
Today the New York Public Library, formed through consolidation of the Astor Library, Lenox Library and the Tilden Trust, will be forty years old.

BOSTON, May 22. -- Port practices in New York, against which Boston has been complaining for years because of their effect upon the volume of shipping in Boston Harbor, will he investigated again by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
BOSTON, May 22 (AP). -- A feminine voice on the other end of the line wanted to know: "Do you want a story on the Harvard-Wellesley crew race?

Before a howling, booing crowd that packed Madison Square Garden to the roof last night, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin attacked President Roosevelt and declared that if capitalism stood in the way of social justice that system should be "constitutionally voted out of existence."

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The finding of the naval court which inquired into the loss of the airship Macon off the Pacific Coast on Feb. 12, filed today and approved by Secretary Swanson, declared that the cause of the accident was unknown, but might have been "a gust of wind or the giving way of some part of the ship's structure."

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Criticisms by labor leaders and members of Congress that the wage scales under work relief as announced by President Roosevelt are too low drew today from Harry L. Hopkins, the Relief Administrator, the defense that the rates, ranging from $19 to $94 a month, were "substantially just to all."
The text of Father Charles E. Coughlin's address at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

Only two weeks after foreclosing the four-and-a-half-story American basement dwelling at 544 West 114th Street the East River Savings Bank has resold it to the 546 West 114th Street Corporation, Kielman A. Schuddekopf, president. Mr. Schuddekopf has been active in the purchase of Morningside Heights houses.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 22. -- With another well-balanced team, New Jersey today retained possession of the Stoddard Bowl, emblematic of the metropolitan district golf championship.

The manuscript of a "memoir in the form of a novel," by George Santayana, philosopher and poet, was received yesterday by Charles Scribner's Sons. The book is called "The Last Puritan," and it has to do with the life and personality of a certain Harvard student whom Mr. Santayana met while he was teaching there and whom he came to think of as a true representative of New England.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP). -- Before 24,000 spectators, the largest crowd ever to witness a boxing program indoors, Chicago's Golden Gloves champions remained unbeaten tonight in international competition, conquering a team of eight stouthearted Italian warriors, five bouts to three, at the Chicago Stadium.

Harlem presents many difficult problems. It contains some of the most densely populated areas in the city, mostly inhabited by Negroes, very large numbers of whom are unemployed. Housing conditions are bad. The tuberculosis rate is even higher than on the East Side.

Three robbers, two of them armed, held up the Ross-Pennell Company jewelry store at 677 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, shortly before 5 P.M. yesterday and escaped with loot valued at $75,000 without attracting the attention of the many persons passing by.

At their first regular meeting since the election of Charles R. Gay as president, the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday elected standing committees, approved the retirement next year of Ashbel Green, secretary of the Exchange, and created the new post of executive vice president at the suggestion of Mr. Gay.

James A. Lanze, 36 years old, a boss truckman, was so pleased at 6 o'clock last evening when he was found guilty in General Sessions merely of first-degree manslaughter at the end of his first-degree murder trial that he profusely thanked the prosecutor, George M. Carney, and the jurors.

Editorial comment of newspapers of varying political beliefs in some of the leading cities of the country is virtually unanimous in approving President Roosevelt's veto of the Patman Bonus Bill, Some of the editorials in part are as follows:

Public hearings on the tactics of electric operating companies in New York City in connection with electric rates will be held all through the Summer, John E. Mack, counsel to the legislative committee investigating public utilities, said yesterday.
ROME, May 22. -- Italian governmental circles today interpreted parts of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech as indicating German refusal to attend the forthcoming Danubian parley.

Donald Stralem, 13 rooms duplex, in 941 Park AV., through Douglas L. Elliman C0.; S. Marshall Kempner, 10 rooml, in 983 I'lrk AN.i Lee 'attlson, in 180 E. 79th St., through Madison Realty Co,; Tishman Realty and Construction Co., lessors.
The New York Central Railroad's pension system, which is supported by the company, is to be continued, Frederic E. Williamson, president, announced yesterday to employes.

Municipal expenditures for public recreation increased from $27,065,854 in 1933 to $41,864,630 last year, according to findings of the National Recreation Association made public yesterday at the association's annual meeting at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt's action in going to the Capitol to deliver a veto message attracted the largest gallery of spectators seen at a joint session in many years. Joseph Sinnott, veteran doorkeeper, estimated that 5,000 requests were received for the 553 seats at his disposal.

O.S. Dean in your issue of May 13, writing about the valuation of Muscle Shoals power plant, states: "Fifteen years' obsolescence in electrical equipment in this day and age is a very large portion of the original cost."
Hunter College students observed yesterday the twenty-first annual Council Day at formal chapel exercises in the main building the the institution, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue.

The Ballard School, the educational department of the Central Branch, Y.W.C.A., will hold its annual graduation exercises at 11 A.M. today in the Y.W.C.A. auditorium, 610 Lexington Avenue. Sixty-one young women will be graduated from the secretarial class and seven from the food service training course.

BERLIN. May 22. -- The absence from Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech to the Reichstag last night of anything in the nature of an appeal to France, anything that might produce an invitation to direct exchange between Paris and Berlin, is accounted for in foreign political quarters as probably due to a consideration of British sensitiveness, in view of Britain's initiative in connection with intergovernmental conversations in recent months.

The Circus Saints and Sinners Club, which boasts of undermining the dignity of industrialists, bankers, politicians and literary men it initiates into its ranks, hazed Mayor La Guardia yesterday and made him a Sinner.

Younger members of society headed by Mrs. Frederick S. Moseley Jr., who have been aiding the sale of tickets for the premiere showing tonight of the motion picture, "Escape Me Never," starring Elisabeth Bergner, at the Radio City Music Hall in behalf of the Carroll Club, will also act as ushers and sell programs at the benefit.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- A sharp campaign for the office of president general of the National Society of New England Women ended today with the election of Mrs. Parlan Semple Jr. of the Montclair (N.J.) Colony. She received 311 votes, as against 181 cast for her rival, Mrs. Edward B. Huland of the Larchmont (N.Y.) Colony.

Vanished creatures that roamed the plains of Montana 50,000,000 years ago, believed to be the earliest link in the mammalian ancestry of man, will be the object of a hunt during the next four months by an expedition of the American Museum of Natural History, headed by Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, assistant curator of vertebrate palaeontology.

MUKDEN, Manchukuo, May 22. -The resignation as Premier of Cheng Hsiao-hsu has precipitated a reshuffle of the Cabinet and the State Council. The reorganization is headed by General Chang Chinghui, former Defense Minister, as Premier.
The companies in the Consolidated Gas system will file today with the Public Service Commission a formal offer to reduce light rates for general consumers in New York City.

After several years of manufactured agitation on the Italian border of Abyssinia the world has been told in plain terms by the mouthpiece of the Italian Government that interference between AByssinia and Italy will not be tolerated.

A wreath of palm leaves, fashioned about a silver-plated lifebuoy, was cast into the water at the Battery last evening in tribute to deceased American sailors at services conducted by the National Maritime Association in observance of National Maritime Day.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- New York's work relief projects will be federally administered, but in fullest cooperation with existing local agencies, city officials were assured today following conferences with President Roosevelt and others associated with the new program.

The New York Curb Exchange suspended trading yesterday in common stock of the Stein Cosmetics Company, Inc., pending investigation. It stated that, having been informed that such stock of the company as had not been deposited under a reorganization plan could not participate in the reorganization it would seek an explanation from the company.

LONDON, May 22 (AP). -- An offer of 20 per cent of the world's wheat export trade has been made to Argentina by other "Big Four" delegates and already has been flatly rejected by the Buenos Aires government, it was revealed today by a high authority as the world wheat conference opened.

PARIS, May 22. -- At a conference this morning between Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin, Louis Germain-Martin, Finance Minister, and Jean Tannery, governor of the Bank of France, regarding measures to be taken to meet the huge budgetary deficit, it was decided that Parliament would be asked to give the government full powers to take whatever measures it considered necessary.

The Central Park Zoo received yesterday a white spider monkey, the only known one in the world. Like the specially prized frog of the American Museum of History, it is an albino, which means it is an extremely rare freak of nature. More than that, it has blue eyes instead of the pink usually associated with albinos.

THE fact that he is now the Man Higher Up has had no effect on James J. Dykes, the manager of the White Sox. James used to toss off his words lightly and cheerfully when the White Sox were down in the swamp. But now that the White Sox are away up yonder, James has to weigh his words and don the dignity of a league-leading manager.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Three officers of the Kennecott Copper Corporation received compensation of more than $75,000 each in 1934. D.C. Jackling, chairman of the operating committee, led these with $101,410, the company's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.
OSSINING, May 23. -- Thomas Saunders, saved from execution, expressed indifference today as to whether he lived or died.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- An assertion that constitutional rights of citizens prohibiting the taking of property without due process of law are "brushed aside as lightly as though the Constitution did not exist" by the Wheeler-Rayburn bill, which would dissolve public utility holding companies, was voiced in a minority report on the measure made today by four Republican members of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

The profit and loss deficit of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway increased $13,709,822 from $17,944,835 to $31,653,677 in 1934, the report for that year discloses. A $3,129,706 charge for retired road and equipment and the $10,638,307 loss suffered in 1934 were the chief items accounting for the increase in the deficit.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Sorrowful over the fact that eight men had been killed in the fleet manoeuvres, naval officials, nevertheless, said today that the sea was still the safest place for sailors and that more of them were killed on land than at sea.

Retail deliveries made in the metropolitan area by the United Pari cel Service showed an increase of 4 per cent for the week ended May 18, executives of the organization reported yesterday. For the four weeks' period ended on that date, however the deliveries showed a decline of 2 per cent under those of a year ago.

CINCINNATI, May 23. -- A Wagner-Brahms-Strauss program is not, upon the face of it, a matter of novelty, but a program which projected the music of two of these composers in a significant and memorable way was given this afternoon as the third concert of the thirty-first Cincinnati May Music Festival in Music Hall and was acclaimed with special enthusiasm by the public.

Raking Roosevelt policies as creating a recovery based upon moratoria, government borrowing and currency debasement, Dr. Lewis H. Haney, Professor of Economics at New York University, warned the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, yesterday that inflation is coming and advised them to build up a six months' supply of materials by Fall.

HAVRE, France, May 23. -- The Normandie, which is the biggest, possibly the fastest and certainly the most luxurious liner in the world, was formally put in service here this evening by President Albert Lebrun with a remarkable party.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- An early favorable report, probably Tuesday or Wednesday, on the Doughton resolution extending the National Industrial Recovery Act for two years and providing limited price-fixing and imposed codes with Presidential consent was in prospect today as the Ways and Means Committee neared the end of a long line of witnesses, most of whom favored its enactment without change.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Plans for the refunding of bonds of Cook County and the Forest Preserve, some of which are in default and others of which will mature by next Jan. 1, were offered today to the two governments by their president, Clayton F. Smith.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- Four issues which should be considered by the nation's wheat farmers in voting in the national referendum Saturday were pointed out today by Secretary Wallace.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 23, -- At the last chapel service of the year this evening at Vassar College, Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president, announced the list of prizes awarded to members of the graduating class.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- A secretly developed navy radio amplifier, capable of conveying a person's talking voice more than a mile, is to be made available for use by President Roosevelt in addressing huge crowds in the open air.
No change was apparent in any section of the money market. Demand for funds was light, and quotations were steady for all grades.
BOSTON, May 23 (AP). -- The rallying Tigers, headed by Hank Greenberg, slammed their way past the Red Sox into the American League's first division today with a 5-to-3 victory in the series opener.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Conferring broad powers on the Secretary of Agriculture to license processors and distributers of farm products, to pay farmers to increase as well as reduce production and to use an estimated $100,000,000 from customs collections to subsidize exports, the long controverted amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act were again started today on the journey through the House.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 23. -- Henry Picard, smooth-swinging South Carolinian who is now ensconsed at the Hershey Club in Pennsylvania, and Jimmy Hines, Garden City Country Club professional, shared honors in the opening round of the metropolitan open championship today.

Rosita Forbes, English writer and traveler, described in an interview at the Hotel Gotham yesterday a tribal "fire dance" that she witnessed in the interior of Dutch Guiana after having penetrated the jungles with six half-breed Indians and a Negro as her only companions.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Among corporation salaries for 1934 reported to the Securities Commission today were:

Generally higher prices were recorded on the local commodity futures markets in heavier trading yesterday. Sugar futures led the advance. Rubber and hide futures were moderately lower. On the cash markets, raw sugar, zinc, tin and wool tops made new high-price levels. Rye, corn, cocoa and silk also advanced.

BOSTON, May 23. -- Those who "stir uprisings and create discontent in the hearts of the poor" were scathingly denounced here today by Cardinal O'Connell, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, in an address to delegates attending the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the Massachusetts' Catholic Order of Foresters.

RYE, N.Y., May 23. -- In a day marked by unexpected triumphs, Miss Ruth Adel of Queens Valley, the present holder of the Long Island title, today eliminated Mrs. Leo G. Federman, New York State champion and tournament favorite, to reach the semi-final of the women's Metropolitan Golf championship.

A meeting of the senior committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's subscription drive for 1935-36 was held yesterday at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street. Mrs. Richard Whitney, chairman, completed the personnel of the committee. Plans for the campaign were outlined.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 23. -- Two of the teams entered in the Meadow Brook polo tournaments which start next month galloped through a practice game on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club today and several of those on other teams took part in the round robin on No. 2 field.

Deploring current splits in the Fusion administration, Bernard S. Deutsch, Aldermanic President, called last night for a united front of all anti-Tammany elements in the city to insure another Fusion victory in 1937.

LONDON, May 22. -- Five Conservative back-bench members in the House of Commons today notified Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, that they would no longer "receive the party whip," which in American political parlance means that they would read themselves out of the party.

With the plaintiff weeping freely, attorneys summed up yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Aaron Steuer and a jury in the $500,000 breach of promise suit brought by Miss Katherine Leary Bond against Paul S. Clapp, 44-year-old utility executive formerly associated with Herbert Hoover in the Department of Commerce.
PALMER, Alaska, May 23 (AP). -- Men lately off the relief rolls in the Middle West drew forty-acre farms out of a hat here today.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The half-a-hundred business chiefs composing the administration's Business Advisory Council decided today in a special meeting not to publish their reports on government activities, be they critical or favorable.

A dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share on the common stock was declared yesterday by directors of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc. The company has been paying 6 1/4 cents extra and 6 1/2 cents regular, quarterly.

The share market did little more than back and fill yesterday with the trading pace slightly increased and the closing irregularly higher. The Senate's vote to uphold the Presidential veto of the Patman bill, which, of course, had been expected generally, came after the market had closed.

A battle for control of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, which began in Detroit last April when J. Walter Drake, a stockholder, attempted to throw the company into receivership, was brought into this district yesterday. Federal Judge John C. Knox signed a restraining order directed against Mr. Drake and six other defendants accused of having usurped the office of directors.

BOSTON, May 23. -- Peter Dana of Holderness, N.H., 19-year-old great grandson of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, failed today, because of rain, fog and strong headwinds, to complete in twenty hours a flight from San Diego to the East Boston airport in an effort to establish a new transcontinental speed record for junior sportsman pilots.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP). -- Manager Walter Johnson of the Indians gave Glenn Myatt, catcher, his unconditional release today and sent home Willie Kamm, veteran third baseman, "for the good of the ball club."

Textile High School's unbeaten baseball team, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, clinched the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division P.S.A.L. title by defeating Curtis, 12 to 3, yesterday at George Washington High School Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- Efforts to surround the $460,000,000 Naval Appropriation Bill with restrictions to curb profits on the one hand, and on the other to keep future navy manoeuvres out of what were called "dangerous" waters, fell today before administration objections in the Senate.

Executives of investment trusts who have been ascertaining the sentiment of heads of corporations in which the trusts have large investments report that there is a general feeling that the second half of the year will bring rising prices of commodities and increased profits for business.

Father COUGHLIN'S rhetoric starts from the premise that the American workman has failed to share the benefits of increased wealth made possible by modern industrialism. Thus he says, of the prosperous years before 1930, that the "astounding and frightful figure" was "a steady, devastating decrease in employment and in wages "also."
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- President Roosevelt met with the Advisory Committee on Allotments of the Work Relief program.

How dead is a dead language? Dartmouth College has just received a bequest of three-quarters of a million dollars to be used for any purpose other than athletics or instruction "in the so-called dead languages."

MOSCOW, May 23. -- The Soviet has at last broken its silence on Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech. It let it be known today that it regarded that speech as a hypocritical, contradictory and somewhat ridiculous fabric of evasions and falsifications, with only one real meaning -- Germany is preparing for a war of revenge.

An agreement in principle has been reached between the Swedish Match Company and the International Match Corporation on virtually all substantial matters of common concern, it was announced jointly yesterday by Jacob Wallenberg, representing Swedish match interests, and J.C. Traphagen, representing International Match interests.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 23. -- Irving Fisher, Yale economist, told the convention of Kiwanis International today that "the growing conviction the depression is nearing its end is justified."

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga., May 23. -- An outspoken attack on Secretary Morgenthau's recent declaration in favor of a government-owned and controlled central bank was made here tonight by R.S. Hecht, president of the American Bankers Association.

A test of the new telephone-television cable will be made next April on a line between this city and Philadelphia, it was revealed here yesterday by engineers of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The experiment is designed to indicate the practicability of television for everyday use, such as permitting people to see each other over the long-distance telephone.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- The grain markets fluctuated erratically in narrow limits today, with outside trade light and most business professional except further purchases of wheat by mills. Millers are estimated to have taken 750,000 to 1,000,000 bushels of futures from the wheat pit in the last two days, presumably removing hedges against flour sales.

PARIS, May 23. -- Miss Helen Jacobs, America's ranking woman tennis player, and Jean Borotra and Jacques Brugnon, France's aging idols, all went down to defeat today as the French hard-court championships moved into the semi-final round.

David A. Reed, former United States Senator from Pennsylvania and a leading Republican, made a tentative appeal last night for conservative Republicans and Democrats to join in support of candidates opposed to the Blew Deal and to political demagogues.

Two Brooklyn hold-up men, who were described by the judge as two of "the most desperate crooks in the country," were permitted to plead guilty to reduce charges yesterday during their trial in Kings County Court for the murder of a night watchman.

ROME, May 23. -- If Premier Benito Mussolini is disturbed by the anxiety felt abroad over the developments in East Africa, he shows no outward sign of worriment. Never has he appeared jauntier, more self-confident and more determined than when seen last night at the fag end of a long series of conferences.

The operations of moonshiners in mid-Manhattan, on a children's play block fifty feet from a parochial school, a church and a subway station, were revealed at 3 P.M. yesterday when plainclothes men raided an old stable at 325 West Twenty-fifth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, and found a 1,000-gallon still.

During the past two years I have had opportunities of observing and studying some inside phases of the New Deal and of the obstacles which apparently are hampering our progress toward recovery. While the New Deal has undoubtedly accomplished some of its objectives, the question is often asked, Why is its progress so spotty and irregular?

The construction and preliminary tests of apparatus for generating penetrating X-rays for the treatment of internal cancer, which, it was said, "possess several advantages as compared with similar machines hitherto available," were announced here last night by Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, at a meeting of the board of directors of the Research Corporation.

CLEVELAND, May 23. -- Major league baseball leaders announced today that every one of the sixteen teams in the two circuits will be represented by at least one player in the all-star game in Cleveland Stadium July 8.

The Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a profit of $622,150, after Federal taxes, depreciation, depletion and other charges. This was equal to $1.12 a share on 552,222 $100 par shares of 6 per cent preferred stock excluding 28,721 shares in the treasury.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Aspirants for the 1936 Gubernatorial nomination drew scant comfort tonight from Governor Lehman's assertion that he is giving "no consideration or thought whatsoever" to whether he will seek re-election.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities in the United States increased in the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., the total being $5,081,168,000, compared with $4,326,348,000 in the corresponding week last year.

LONDON, May 23 (AP). -- Complete collapse of international efforts to raise and stabilize world wheat prices was averted today when the life of the world wheat pact, due to expire Aug. 1, was extended one year.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 22, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, a decrease of $9,000,000 as compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.
LONDON, May 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Following is the text of the address by Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, at the meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday:

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 23. -- Negotiations for purchase of the American Trust Company, California banking house, by the Bank of America were reported under way this afternoon and the report was not denied by officials of either of the two institutions.

Organization of the Toilet Goods Association, designed to unify the trade activities of manufacturers and importers of perfumes, cosmetics and allied products, was perfcted yesterday at the final session of'a three-day "all-industry" conference held at the Plaza Hotel.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 23 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits in the Bank of Canada increased more than $6,000,000 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement issued today. The reserve in United States funds rose almost $2,500,000.

On the ground that its rules were inoperative, unenforceable and too expensive, the Code Authority of the Scrap Iron and Steel Trade has voted to liquidate its operations on June 16, when the National Industrial Recovery Act expires, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Schwartz, chairman of the Code Authority, after a meeting at the Commodore Hotel.

Gold certificate reserves of the Federal Reserve System again rose to a new high record in the week ended on Wednesday. The weekly statement of the system, published; yesterday, showed a gain of $28,949,000 to a total of $5,820,788,000. The week's rise compared with a gain of $25,000,000 in monetary gold stocks of the country in the same period, which carried them also to a new high record of $8,762,000,000.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- The Illinois Securities Department on Dec. 4, 1934, canceled the license of Turivas Co., thereby barring the concern from doing business in the State. The principal office of the concern was at 33 North La Salle Street, with branches in New Orleans, Atlanta and Wilmington, Del.

A turbulent session in which tears, laughter, shouts and admonitions from the court came in quick succession, attended yesterday the closing testimony of Joseph L. Steinmetz, 22-year-old divinity student accused of the murder of his 17-year-old bride, Ruth.

More adequate support of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem was asked last night by Norman Bentwich, former Attorney General of Palestine, in his address at a dinner tendered him at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel by Felix M. Warburg, Roger W. Straus, Arthur M. Lamport and other members of the governing board of the American Friends of the Hebrew University.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 24. -- Arrested in the International Settlement at the request of the French Government, which seeks his extradition. Mikhail Abranovich, 53-year-old Yugoslav, is charged with complicity in the murder of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Foreign Minister Louis Barthou of France at Marseilles list Oct. 9.

Restoration of thirty properties throughout the city owned by religious or charitable organizations to the tax-exempt rolls was announced yesterday by William Stanley Miller, president of the Board of Taxes and Assessments.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Two prize cows, a calf, a half dozen sheep and ten ducks gave a realistic touch last night to the "County Fair," the annual charity function of the Hotel Association of New York City, held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt.

Paul Hoft of Philadelphia, Middle Atlantic champion, scored an upset by defeating James Howell of the Salem-Crescent A.C. last night in the feature heavyweight special bout on the program of amateur boxing staged by the Seventy-seventh Division Association at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Henry D. Thoreau's verdict that "All sights and sounds are seen and heard both in time and eternity; and when the eternity of any sight or sound strikes the eye or ear, it is intoxicated with delight," seems justified by both birds and trees this May morning.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 23. -- Lady Variell, who has arrived at the Greenbrier by motor from Palm Beach, Fla., gave a luncheon at the Greenbrier Casino for Mrs. Frederick H. Button today after the women's putting tournament.

BUCHAREST, May 23. -- A Rumanian delegation consisting of Dr. Nicolas Titulescu, Foreign Minister; Manolesco Strunga, Minister of Commerce, and Nicolas Tabakovitch, president of the State Railways, will leave Bucharest early in June for Moscow, where the delegation will sign a railway convention for resumption of traffic on Rumanian and Russian railroads.

The Museum of Modern Arts Summer show of nineteenth and twentieth century painting and sculpture will be opened June 5. Meanwhile the museum is offering a small exhibition of contemporary European commercial printing. It opened to the public yesterday, installed in the galleries on the ground floor.

The bond market marked time yesterday, pending word as to the action by the United States Senate on the soldiers bonus bill. Transactions on the Stock Exchange fell almost half, or to $7,908,400, against $16,250,200 on Wednesday. United States Government loans were inactive in a turnover of $1,198,400, compared with $8,114,200.
LONDON, May 23. -- The Cabinet evidently had a second thought today concerning the program for trebling the air force as announced yesterday in Parliament.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 23. -- Frederick Todd, former United States commercial attache at Havana and expert on business economics, ended his life at 5 P.M. today by shooting himself in the mouth with a pistol on the sidewalk of Stonebridge Road here.

Prosperity beckoned yesterday to the Players' revival of "Seven Keys to Baldpate," which will open next Monday night for the traditional week. The seat sale started in the morning and by noon some $1,400 had passed through the National Theatre's wicket at a scale which calls for $4 for the opening night, and thereafter $3 in the evening and $2.50 for matinees.

BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP). -- Further testimony on the "pooling" of electrical power so that the Conowingo Power Company, which serves territory adjacent to Conowingo Dam, does not know where its energy is generated, was received by the Public Service Commission today in its investigation of the rates and charges of the company.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 23. -- Mrs. Charles Pluckey of Mount Kisco won the low-gross award in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Brooklawn Country Club today. Mrs. W.B. Miller for the second time this season took the low net.

New York State personal income tax rates are stiff these days, but at least they are producing revenue again. Commissioner GRAVES estimates that collections this year, on last year's incomes, will mount to $51,000,000. That compares with recent years, in round millions, as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The National Industrial Recovery Board is preparing to recommend to President Roosevelt that he cancel the two executive orders which permit bids of 15 per cent under the posted prices of goods when government sales are being sought, it was announced today by Donald R. Richberg, acting chairman of the board.

The Greenwich Sinfonietta, Gerald McGarrahan conducting, will give a concert at the Bronx County Building tonight. Rudolf Forst's "Kammersymphonie" will receive its first performance. Works by Purcell, Mozart, Debussy-Szathmary, Pierne and Brahms also will be played.

LONDON, May 23. -- Further charges that highly placed persons, including officials, hold shares in armament firms were made today before the arms inquiry commission in a memorandum on behalf of the Communist party of Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Senate's action in sustaining the President's veto of the Patman Bonus Bill, with its inflation feature, is expected in administration quarters to go far to make easier the task of the Treasury of financing the $4,000,000,000 relief program by orthodox borrowings.

THERE it goes again. In staid old England, too. They have another masked marvel in the British amateur golf championship. Last year it was James Wallace, the timber trimmer from Troon, who hewed to the line and gave haughty favorites the axe until he ran against Lawson Little in the final.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 23. -- About 125 members of the foreign division of the National Board of the Y.W.C.A. and guests were entertained at a garden tea given by Mrs. John French at her home here this afternoon. Mrs. French, who was formerly vice president and chairman of the executive committee, is now member at large of the board.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- In killing printing-press inflation for this session -- but not necessarily a cash bonus -- the Senate today resolved itself into some interesting categories.

Praising the "vast" amount of energy and money expended by private philanthropy, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared yesterday that no matter how extensive government charitable enterprises may become the bulk of the burden of charity "must continue to rest on the shoulders of private initiative."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23. -- Julius S. Ripple, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, said today that many bankers who suffered large paper losses on securities are now selling them too soon on the recovery.
ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP). -- The Phillies have declared war on Dizzy and Paul Dean.

GENEVA, May 23. -- Further joint pressure today by Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, and Pierre Laval, French Foreign Minister, on Baron Pompec Aloisi, Italian delegate to the League of Nations, brought no definite progress on the Ethiopian deadlock, but some hope, though still faint, of preventing a break.
