NEW ORLEANS, May 23. -- Eight counts charging violations of the 1933 Federal Securities Act were filed against Turivas Co. of Chicago and twenty of its officials and agents in an indictment returned by the Federal grand jury here late today to District Judge John McDuffie.
Leases of space to apparel firms featured business rentals yesterday.

Former Governor Smith made a plea to the public here to aid the hospitals, the financial needs of which and other problems were discussed yesterday at the eleventh annual conference of the Hospital Association of New York State at the Hotel New Yorker.

Contrary to popular belief, the imports that the United States brings in from foreign countries provide employment for millions in this country and an increase in imports would help raise the volume of jobs, Chester H. McCall, Special Assistant Secretary of Commerce, told the members of the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, yesterday.

Seven properties, including a fifteen-story apartment house at 7 Gracie Square and the twelve-story Rossmann Building at 160-62 East Fifty-sixth Street, were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Rallying in unexpected numbers to the support of President Roosevelt in his opposition to prepayment of the bonus, the Senate today sustained his veto of the Patman "greenback" bill by a margin that placed in question the ability of the ex-service men to force full cash payment of the adjusted service certificates at this session of Congress.

MUNICH, May 23. -- As an aftermath of the violence that swept over Munich last week-end, a fresh attack was made on the Jewish community last night. The walls of the chief synagogue were chalked with swastikas and the windows of several Jewish stores were broken.

Four men and two women, professional bondsmen, were arraigned in General Sessions yesterday on indictments alleging they perjured themselves in court by denying property they offered for bail already was pledged as surety on other bail bonds.

Members of the Junior Auxiliary of the Columbus Hospital will hold a Maytime fete tomorrow night in the ballroom suite of the Pierre for the benefit of the children's wards of the hospital and the Nurses Home Building Fund. Flowering trees, lilacs, apple blossoms and smilax will be used in the decorations.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, spoke last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania at a meeting of the Hebrew Teachers Association of New York, which had called a one-day "stoppage" in 250 Jewish religious schools in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- The Federal Allotment Board recommended today the distribution of $155,360,600 of work relief funds, including $131,000,000 for relief activities during June.

With the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap heading a card of five well-filled races, the United Hunts Racing Association will hold its annual Spring meet on the Charles V. Hickox estate near Roslyn, L.I., this afternoon. The first race is listed for 3:15 P.M.

William O'Connor of 248 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, chauffeur for Anthony T. Higgins, a blind man and former news stand proprietor, was declared a hostile witness yesterday in General Sessions by Frank E. Carstarphen, Assistant District Attorney, while he was testifying for the State in the trial of three men on indictments growing out of the news stand graft investigation last year.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 23. -- Richard D. Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., was not only the first American but the first player to start in the fourth round of the British amateur golf championship, and one did not have to watch him long before discovering that he is a player of real class.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest point of the year to date.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Hope that the retail code will be retained practically as it is was expressed today by Kenneth Collins, assistant to the president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., New York, in a talk before the Chicago Federated Advertising Club.

A new record for the Hollis Stakes, first run in 1915, was set at Belmont Park yesterday when Victor Emanuel's Miss Merriment dashed down the Widener chute in 1:10 4-5 for six furlongs. This is short of Balko's great track mark of 1:09 2-5, but it lopped a fifth of a second off the time made by Frank G. when he won the Hollis in 1923.

Mrs. Julia Hoyt, society woman and actress, who is recovering from pneumonia, arrived yesterday morning on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by her mother, Mrs. W.L. Robbins; her sister, Mrs. Sara H. Marsh, and her personal physician, Dr. Edward Livingston Hunt.

The companies in the Consolidated Gas system filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission new rates for electric current in New York City, reducing the charges to consumers by $7,566,500 a year. The rates, if accepted by the Public Service Commission -- which is expected -- are scheduled to go into effect July 1.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, announced yesterday he had sent to District Attorney Dodge for grand jury action the transcript of testimony before him recently that two men, who successfully had passed the municipal civil service examination for patrolmen, had paid money to John Flaherty, now in the Tombs, to have their names placed on the eligible list.

Organized labor stands ready to mobilize all its economic strength to force the adoption by Congress of what it considers to be its "Bill of Rights," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday afternoon at a huge rally in Madison Square Garden called by the trade unions of the city.

A collection of little-known works by Lewis Carroll, made by Professor John Francis McDermott of Washington University, will be issued by Duttons this Summer under the title "The Russian Journal and Other Selections From the Works of Lewis Carroll."

While the city is preparing its condemnation case to aid in the acquisition of the twelve-block public housing site in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the Federal Government is continuing to close as many titles as possible by private negotiation, according to Dwight L. Hoopingarner, associate director of the Housing Division of the PWA.

The city of Portland, Ore., announced last night that it had awarded $4,158,000 of bonds to two competing syndicates, whose bids were the highest of several which were entered. The split award consists of $2,080,000 of 3 1/2 per cent and $2,078,000 of 2 1/2 per cent bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- Reports showing that some officers and large stockholders recently have sold more of their corporations' securities than they bought were made public today by the Securities Commission.
The daily press has published protests against the wage scale fixed by the administration for the work-relief program, and doubtless Congress is by now flooded with telegrams to the same effect.

LONDON, May 23 (Canadian Press). -- A sparkling century by R.E.S. Wyatt failed to save Warwickshire from defeat at the hands of Surrey in a county cricket championship game concluded today at the Oval, the Southern team winning by ten wickets.

A total of $166,811.08 raised to date in the silver anniversary $329,000 campaign of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the committee, at a luncheon at the Bankers Club, 129 Broadway.

WESTON, Conn., May 23. -- The town of Weston was holding on today to an old dirt road, now part of the front lawn of Franklin P. Adams (F.P.A.), and trying to do something about a new dirt road built on property owned by the New York columnist's wife.

CINCINNATI, May 23. -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph Anderson Vance, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Detroit, was elected this afternoon Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

The Hudson River Steamboat Company submitted to Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday an agreement which it proposes to put into effect with the Hudson River Navigation Company, operator of the Night Line, whereby passenger and freight business between New York and Troy and Albany would be divided between the ships of the two lines.

Characterizing the opponents of social security legislation as selfish and dictatorial, Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, told the annual dinner meeting of Phi Beta Kappa Alumni last night that "we ought to have and are going to have a social security program."

PARIS, May 23. -- It was a black day on the Bourse today, with an extremely agitated atmosphere. Rentes fell sharply, while international stocks were particularly favored along with certain French industrials.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Reversing a recent trend, wholesale commodity prices advanced slightly during the week ending May 18, the composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics moving to 80 as compared with 79.9 the previous week and 73.5 a year ago.

A pet show was held at East Side House Settlement, 540 East Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon in connection with Festival Week, which began last Friday with an exhibition of children's arts and crafts.

"The Girl From Tenth Avenue," a Warner-First National production with Bette Davis and Ian Hunter, opens this morning at the Capitol. Eva Le Gallienne will appear on the stage in Sutro's one-act play, "The Open Door."

The dissenting opinion from the American Federation of Labor demonstration for the extension of the NRA was voiced in Union Square yesterday afternoon at an orderly gathering of more than 6,000 left wing members of the organization's needle trade and allied unions.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Relief officials decided today that a more liberal public works loan and grant plan was needed to induce cities to take full advantage of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program, but they were unable to fix upon a plan which would meet the approval of President Roosevelt.

BARNEGAT, N.J., May 23. -- Two fawns, believed born during the extensive forest fire in the Ocean County woods last Sunday and deserted by their mothers, have been found and are being reared by human protectors, it was disclosed today by wardens attached to the Forked River Game Farm, who have been checking damage done by the flames.
Several business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
Staging a three-run rally in the eighth inning, the St. John's University baseball team downed the Boston College nine, 5 to 4, in an uphill battle at Dexter Park yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23. -- The Federal Government was pictured today as the eventual owner of "at least" 30 per cent of the homes whose owners are debtors of the Home Owners Loan Corporation by John R. Umsted of Philadelphia, president of the Pennsylvania Title Association, at its fourteenth annual convention in the Hotel Claridge.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- A permanent plan for adjusting disputes involving the operation of the "stretch-out" or specialization system in the wool industry was recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Wool Textile Work Assignment Board, formed after the textile strike of last September.

MILFORD, Del., May 23 (AP). -- A boy who said he is Edward Serine, 17, of Brooklyn, N.Y., walked into the local police station and related that a group of men in a blue sedan kidnapped him while he was on his way to school, kept him blindfolded several hours and pushed him out of the car at the outskirts of Milford.

A deal in the Dyckman Street section involving the taxpayer containing ten stores at the southwest corner of Nagle Avenue and Elwood Street was announced yesterday. The property was sold by the C.S.C. Operating Corporation to Richard M. Lederer.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- A towering fly ball off the bat of Kiki Cuyler that seemed to whirl about in all directions under the pressure of a spanking breeze, raised no little havoc with the Giants today as Colonel Bill Terry brought his battered forces into action against the Cubs in the opening clash of a three-game set.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The momentous vote on the President's veto of the Patman Bonus Bill came at the end of nearly five hours of debate before galleries so packed that even Senators' wives had to sit on the steps in the aisles.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Reforming their ranks after their major defeat in failing to override the President's veto of the Patman bill today, bonus leaders made plans to drive through some other form of immediate cash payment at this session of Congress.

HONOLULU, May 23. -- Admiral H.E. Yarnell, commandant of Pearl Harbor, announced officially today that 165 warships would berth at the naval base, starting Saturday. He thus broke the official silence of naval authorities since the war games started.
Although showers fell in Southern Texas, the weather generally continued favorable for the cotton crop yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 8 to 13 points.

After the last research worker had put away his spectacles last night at the New York Public Library, the staff forgot about work in a gay celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the institution, through the consolidation of the Astor, Lenox and Tilden Foundations.

M.H. Sheffield says in his letter that if a municipally owned electric light and power plant should, like the city-owned and operated water plant, carry on for seventy-eight years before it found it necessary to increase its rates, it would be doing better than any privately owned and operated utility that has come to his notice.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- On the eve of the State committee meeting tomorrow to investigate charges of radicalism in universities and schools in the State, the Rosenwald Family Association today sent a check for $10,000 to Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago.

BERLIN, May 23. -- Although an exact official ruling on the matter was not yet available, it was stated in authoritative quarters today that in theory at least the new German conscription law applied, among others, to all German-Americans between the ages of 18 and 45, whether they were United States citizens or not, unless they clarified their status with the German authorities.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Cardinal Hayes and Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle attended yesterday morning the first public celebration of the golden jubilee of a Poor Clare nun in this country, when they assisted at a solemn high mass in observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the Rev. Mother Mary Seraphim's entry into the order at the chapel of the Poor Clare Monastery at Schurz and Hollywood Avenues, Throgs Neck, the Bronx.

FERNDALE, N.Y., May 23. -- Barney Ross and Jimmy McLarnin, whose fight for the world's welterweight championship is only five days off, were subjected to thorough physical examinations today by Dr. William Walker of the New York State Athletic Commission's staff.

Sir Gwynne and Lady Evans, Mrs. Otto H. Kahn, Harrington Mann, portrait painter; Mrs. James B. Haggin and Gilbert Miller are among the prominent persons sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. Others leaving on the ship for Cherbourg and Southampton include:

Sixty-eight young women received diplomas at the commencement of the Ballard School, the educational department of the Central Branch, Y.W.C.A., yesterday morning in the organization's auditorium, 610 Lexington Avenue. Sixty-one were graduated from the secretarial classes and seven from the courses in food service training.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- A recommendation that Colonel Alexander E. Williams of the Army Quartermaster Corps be dismissed from the service was handed down today by a general court-martial.

Dominated again by weakness in grains, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices receded 0.3 point to 126.1 in the week ended on Tuesday. Other items, including hogs, hams and pork, cotton and other textiles, rubber, hides and leather, gasoline, lead, tin and zinc, advanced.

A group of twenty-three representatives of leading clubs and civic associations went yesterday on a tour of the city's three largest penal institutions, the penitentiary on Welfare Island, the new Riker's Island penitentiary and the House of Detention for Women.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission released today a summary of the reports of stock transactions and holdings of officers, directors and principal shareholders of listed companies for April which were received by the commission between May 1 and 10.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Employment in those industries reporting to the Bureau of Labor Statistics increased by about 120,000 persons in April, but payrolls were decreased about $300,000, traceable primarily to reductions in the bituminous coal industry, according to a statement by Secretary Perkins today.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Creation of a national labor mediation service, independent of the Department of Labor or any of the government agencies charged with the interpretation of labor law, is advocated in the final report of an investigation of the government's role in labor relations, made by a special staff of the Twentieth Century Fund.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 28. -- A system of financing in which the government gets its revenue through an inflationary policy of borrowing rather than through taxation is directly in conflict with fundamental American democracy, Edwin W. Kemmerer, Professor of Finance at Princeton, financial adviser to foreign governments and an expert on money, declared here tonight.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 23. -- Escaping the detonations of two golfing whizzbangs in the persons of H.G. McCallum, Scotland, and J.L. Black of Wales, W. Lawson Little Jr. sidestepped into the last eight of the British amateur golf championship today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23. -- An undergraduate at the New Jersey College for Women testified today that she knew of two students who recently signed a letter in support of Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the German department, because they were afraid that if they refused to do so he would hold it against them.

Every university could wish for her sons such honor as the mother of the sons of Zebedee sought for them: to sit in the first places. The moral of the scriptural incident was that only the Omniscient One could make such appraisal. Mr. EDWIN R. EMBREE, in his Atlantic article, has done a daring deed in undertaking to determine the seating order of American universities on the basis of "scholarly eminence."

Outrunning all estimates, forty Senators voted yesterday to uphold the President's veto of the Patman bill. On its original passage, only thirty-three Senators opposed it. What is the explanation of this gain for the President's side, and the failure of his opponents by 9 votes to muster a two-thirds majority against his veto?

Maurice L. Farrell, senior partner of F.S. Smithers Co., the sole holdover from the 1934 committee on public relations of the New York Stock Exchange, was elected yesterday chairman of that group. Henry R. Winthrop, a non-member "governing member" of the Exchange, was named vice chairman, while E.H.H. Simmons was reelected chairman of the law committee.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga., May 23. -- Eight billion of the ten billion dollars of foreign securities "underwritten by American investors" are still outstanding, Charles M. Mills of New York, of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., told the Georgia Bankers Association convention today.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., May 23. -- Taking the "poor prisoner's oath," and the privilege it carries, James H. Rand Sr., founder and a director of Remington-Rand, was freed from charges of income tax evasion in District Court today on cash payment of $153.60, which he said was tall the money he had in the world.

ALBANY, May 23. -- The end of bootlegging is in sight, according to Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner. He said today, in making public figures of the State's receipts for April from beverage taxes, that they "substantiate my recent contention that bootlegging is decreasing," adding that "if present effective enforcement efforts are continued, I confidently predict that the illicit liquor industry will eventually be smashed."
An indication of the return of prosperity was seen yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters in the rapid decrease in the number of persons who set fire to their property.

RUMSON, N.J., May 23. -- Robert H. McCarter, former Attorney General of New Jersey and prominent Newark lawyer, who maintains a large estate on Rumson Road here, was fined $10 last night by Police Recorder Jere J. Carew on a charge of "driving through fire lines, nearly running down a fire police officer, and failing to heed a police whistle."

CHICAGO, May 28. -- An audit of the office of the Cook County Clerk during the twenty-four years' tenure of Robert M. Sweitzer now County Treasurer, disclosing a shortage of $380,959 in his accounts and $32,625 in interest on funds he administered, a total deficit of $413,584, was presented to the County Board today.
PARIS, May 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

ALBANY, May 23. -- Governor Lehman, in a statement to newspaper men today, declared that he had not discussed with any one his future plans as to whether he would be a candidate for renomination in 1936. He declared:

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA en route from Midway Islands to Pearl Harbor, May 23. -- The loss of a twin-engined long-range patrol plane, the 6P7, which "spun into" the Pacific forty-two miles south of the Midway Islands Tuesday night, killing its crew of six, curtailed the climax of the third phase of the navy's annual manoeuvres.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 (AP). -- Approximately 10,000 fans, including 5,000 women, turned out today to honor a former popular Pittsburgh player, Walter Maranville, and saw the Pirates score a 7-to-1 victory over the "Rabbit" and the Braves.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Considerable support for an amendment to the Tennessee Valley Authority Act which would prohibit sale of power at less than cost of production developed in the House Military Affairs Committee today.

Six concerts in Carnegie Hall will be given during its second season by the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Antonia Brico and sponsored by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and other prominent women, according to plans made public yesterday afternoon at a meeting of representatives of women's clubs and musical organizations in Steinway Hall.

Business is ready to bound upward in a real recovery movement which would bring the country great prosperity, but it is held back by "unsound" New Deal legislation now pending before Congress, according to statements made yesterday by three of the most important steel masters of the United States.

BERLIN, May 23. -- Because he published an article stating that Nazi party functionaries were not empowered to compel civil employes and party members to subscribe to party newspapers, Herr Schaefer, the editor-in-chief of the Koelnische Zeitung, was fined 500 marks by the press court in Cologne today [the mark is currently quoted at 40.27 cents].
ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 23 (AP). -- Here are the pairings for the quarter-final round tomorrow in the British amateur golf championship:

John Reggione, 38 years old, of 2,467 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx, a paroled convict, was shot five times through the body and instantly killed last night while walking with his 12-year-old niece in West Broadway about fifty feet south of Houston Street.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses will face the opposition of several West Side civic organizations to his plan for parkways connecting the West Side express highway with the proposed Hendrik Hudson Bridge, when the matter comes before the Board of Estimate at City Hall this morning.

For the first time in the history of public school education in this city, mothers and grandmothers received public school diplomas just like their children's as the Board of Education graduated a class of sixty-four aliens yesterday before an audience of 3,000 at Carnegie Hall.

PARIS, May 23. -- Faced with a heavy and increasing flight of capital, the council of the Bank of France today raised the discount rate from 2 1/2 per cent to 3 per cent. It simultaneously brought other rates into line.

The degree of Graduate in Pharmacy was conferred upon sixty-four candidates at the 105th annual commencement exercises of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University, held last night in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.

"Prevailing high winds have been the real flies in the angler's ointment," writes Clayton Seagears of Middletown, reporting on the weekend prospects for Catskill trouting. "For days on end stiff breezes have whipped the Beaverkill, Willowemoc and Neversink, making fly fishing all but impossible.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP). -- Miss Esther Sears, Boston society girl and daughter of Dr. George G. Sears, Harvard Medical School professor, was killed today in a three-story plunge which authorities said occurred while she was walking in her sleep.

Over fifty years ago a Dutch botanist noted that the Evening Primrose was throwing off new varieties. Hybridization would have been a ready explanation. He tied bags over the flowers. Still the "sports" appeared. Out of this work came the mutation theory of evolution -- a theory which postulates that new species are created not after age-long change but suddenly.

No permanent harm has been done by the production of "Weather Permitting," which was acted at the Masque last evening. It is an innocuous comedy by Edward Sargent Brown which was tried out during the Summer of 1933 at Magnolia, Mass., a North Shore town that has an otherwise good reputation.

It would not be fair to the well-meaning gentleman who are conducting the current experiment in planned electrical economy in the Tennessee Valley to give too much weight to all the detailed strictures contained in the Controller General's first audit of the books of the TVA.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP). -- Miss Esther Sears, Boston society girl and daughter of Dr. George G. Sears, Harvard Medical School professor, was killed today in a three-story plunge which authorities said occurred while she was walking in her sleep.

Over fifty years ago a Dutch botanist noted that the Evening Primrose was throwing off new varieties. Hybridization would have been a ready explanation. He tied bags over the flowers. Still the "sports" appeared. Out of this work came the mutation theory of evolution -- a theory which postulates that new species are created not after age-long change but suddenly.

No permanent harm has been done by the production of "Weather Permitting," which was acted at the Masque last evening. It is an innocuous comedy by Edward Sargent Brown which was tried out during the Summer of 1933 at Magnolia, Mass., a North Shore town that has an otherwise good reputation.

It would not be fair to the well-meaning gentleman who are conducting the current experiment in planned electrical economy in the Tennessee Valley to give too much weight to all the detailed strictures contained in the Controller General's first audit of the books of the TVA.

Former Mayor James J. Walker won yesterday in the legal dispute over his responsibility for hotel bills for the party accompanying him to San Francisco in 1931 to aid Tom Mooney. Justice Vincent Lippe in City Court decided that the defendant must pay only the $516.51 expenses of himself and his valet.

ST. LOUIS, May 23. -- Frank Frisch's Cardinals downed the Dodgers in a ten-inning struggle today, 8 to 7, dropping the Stengel clan into third place. The Cardinal manager struck the winning blow, a bounding single over Jimmy Jordan's head that scored Pepper Martin from third.

WAKE ISLAND, May 23 (By Wireless). -- After a thrilling contest, the last seemingly insurmountable obstacle to making this barren island and is two neighbors habitable was overcome when a 30-foot four-ton motor launch bulldozed its way across the shallow channel from the ocean into the lagoon.

CINCINNATI, May 24. -- Night baseball came up from the minors for its first big league tryout tonight, and 25,000 fans and the Cincinnati Reds liked the innovation. Some of the affection of the Reds for the nocturnal pastime was because they defeated the faltering Phillies, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A warning against liquor dealers using advertising that might be seized as ammunition by supporters of a bill now pending to prohibit all interstate liquor advertising was voiced today by Chairman Choate of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration.

The real irrepressible conflict in this country is not between the plain people and the international bankers, but between those who count veto majorities in Congress by starting from opposite ends. When the House overrides President ROOSEVELT by 322 votes to 98, the left-handed school of thinkers argues that the bonus advocates needed two-thirds in a House of 435 members.

A stock sales offer made by the Chatham Phenix National Bank and Trust Company in 1929 to its employes was held by City Court Justice Louis Goldstein in Brooklyn yesterday to be a "sales talk" rather than a legal contract, and an employe who sought to recover $1,100 paid for purchase of the bank's stock won a judgment against the bank and the Chatham Phenix Corporation.

The silvery shad are swarming into the waters of the Salmon River in Connecticut these days, drawn back to the spawning grounds of their ancestral home by that instinct with which nature so mysteriously endowed them.

In J.H. Moseley's communication on government ownership of public utilities he states that the Hydroelectric Power Commission of Ontario has failed. It would be worth Mr. Moseley's time to read the recent report of the commission.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, which, at the behest of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, is preparing a plan of reorganization to be completed by July 1, has submitted to insurance companies and other large bondholders proposals for a reduction of its interest burden, it was disclosed yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 24. -- Members of the Fairfield County Bar Association at a meeting today rejected the application of five New York lawyers for admission to the Connecticut Bar. In the past any recognized New York lawyer who had been practicing for five or more years in that State was admitted to the Connecticut Bar upon formal application.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP). -The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Conde Nast Publications, Inc., of New York City with unfair competition, alleging that the firm contracted with garment manufacturers to feature their garments in the magazine Vogue, published by Mr. Nast.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, en route to Pearl Harbor, May 24. -- With the planes of the patrol squadrons winging their way above Laysan, French Frigate Shoals, Nihoa and other coral islets, the flying and surface forces of the United States Fleet were reaching Hawaii tonight.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 24. -After permitting Jimmy Hines and Henry Picard to bask in the limelight with their 69s in the opening round of the metropolitan open championship yesterday, Paul Runyan, slightly built Metropolis professional, cut loose today to take the lead at the half-way mark with a total of 141.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on the application of Robert J. Seymour of Carmel, N.Y., for the appointment of receivers for the National City Company, now known as the City Company of New York, and for the removal of the liquidating directors of the company.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 24. -- Miss Grace Le Gendre of Rochester, for eleven years treasurer of the Business and Professional Women Clubs of New York State, was nominated for president of that organization at the opening session today of its annual convention here.

Eleanor Schmaus, 13 years old, who disappeared from her home at 218 Eckford Street, Brooklyn, May 6, and Henry J. Simpson, 35, a bachelor, who formerly was organist at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, 129 Kent Street, Brooklyn, were picked up at Saugerties, N.Y., last night and taken to Kingston, N.Y., according to information sent to the police here early this morning by Deputy Sheriff Fluckiger of Kingston.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24. -- Was reading today where the Federation of Women's Clubs was going to have a hot election. The woman in line for the presidency (she is now first vice president) they all admit has every qualification.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- An increase in outright Federal grants for public works projects from 30 to 45 per cent of allotments and a cut in interest rates on public works loans from 4 to 3 per cent were approved today by President Roosevelt in order to encourage cities to partake to the fullest extent in the $4,000,000,000 work relief program.

With five States and thirty-seven municipalities in the market next week with bonds aggregating $24,164,577, the new financing will show a slight increase over this week. On the basis of revised figures, this week's total of issues up for award was $22,032,001.
LONDON, May 24. -- Sir Herbert Samuel today, at a National Liberal Federation conference approved the government's move to give serious consideration to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech.

Operation of surface car lines on Eighth and Ninth Avenues by the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation until a bus franchise has been awarded was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board restored to the calendar, from which it was stricken last week by order of Mayor La Guardia, the application of the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation for a franchise for the routes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 24. -- Dr. Lionel D. Edie of New York, economist, said today at the annual convention of the New Jersey Bankers Association that four years of currency collapse throughout the world are drawing to a close and that four years of currency reconstruction will begin with 1936.

The recent commemoration at Colby College in honor of Elijah Lovejoy, who gave his life in the defense of free speech, serves to recall what Abraham Lincoln had to say about the tragedy at Alton, or rather about the "lawlessness and mobocratic spirit" that was then abroad in the land.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Assurances that there will be a general standardization of forms of report for all banks connected with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, comprising most institutions in the country, were given today following a conference of banking authorities.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP). -- A broader program of strictly bilateral trade agreements not extending benefits of the "most-favored-nation clause" was urged tonight by George N. Peek, special foreign trade adviser to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A $5,941.34 budget submitted by the Code Authority for the air transport industry to cover code administration expenditures from Jan. 1 to June 15 was temporarily approved today by the National Industrial Recovery Board.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24. -- With the quiet efficiency with which the United States Navy meets all problems at sea, ranking officers of the Naval Academy were completing plans tonight for the biggest day that Navy rowing has seen in recent years.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Vice President Garner will be President Roosevelt's running mate again in the campaign next year, Postmaster General Farley said today in declaring that the defeat of the Veterans Bonus Bill would have no appreciable effect on the campaign, and predicting a sweeping Democratic victory.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Consolidated Film Industries paid to its president, H.J. Yates, $63,000 in 1934, its registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. B. Goetz, executive vice president, received $42,820, and M.H. Lavenstein, a director and employe, $32,395.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Reports of increasing Japanese influence in Siam were declared today by Prince Damras Damrong Devakula, the Minister of Siam, to be utterly without foundation.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 (AP). -- A long homer by Rupert Thompson of the Braves with the bases full in the ninth sent four runs across the plate today, but the Pirates, with an early lead, weathered the storm and triumphed, 7 to 6. Paul Waner's one-hand catch of Babe Ruth's drive, 400 feet from home plate, was another highlight of the otherwise listless game.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 24. -- Foreign Minister Eduard Benes's newspaper, Geske Slovo, declares that Konrad Henlein, leader of the Hitlerite party in this country, will not be received by any Minister or Czech political personality.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell will preach his farewell sermons tomorrow at the Westminster United Church, Winnipeg, Manitoba Province, Canada, and Sunday, June 2, he will preach his first sermons as minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, this city.

PORTLAND, Me., May 24 (AP). -Maine's perfectly balanced track and field forces, favored to recapture the New England intercollegiate title after a four-year lapse, gained an advantage over nineteen sectional rivals by qualifying thirteen men during today's trials.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has taken a voice in the management of a key unit in the Van Sweringen railroad system, the results of elections at the annual meeting of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway disclosed yesterday.

At the fifteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York, held at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club yesterday. Prescott Bush of Brown Brothers Harriman Co. won the Bond Club Championship Cup in golf. Mr. Bush, among the Class A players, turned in a score of 71 gross and 66 net on the club's main course.

HOHOKUS, N.J., May 24. -- Brass Tacks, an engaging smooth fox terrier owned by Jerry R. Collins of Oyster Bay, L.I., and handled by Leonard Brumby, was named best of 378 dogs shown today in the fourth annual bench show of the Ridgewood Dog Fanciers Association.

United States Government bonds were firm on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday with trading heavier than on the preceding day. A block of Liberty 3 1/2s was sold at 100 4/32, off 31/32 point. The conversion privilege for these bonds expired on Thursday.
PORTSMOUTH, England, May 24. -- The American yacht Yankee today had her first sail in her full J class rig on this side of the Atlantic.

RAPID CITY, S.D., May 24. -- Airmen and scientists were gathered today in the 450-foot erosion pocket in the Black Hills eleven miles from here to complete preparations for the 1935 National Geographic-Army Air Corps stratosphere flight.

Opposition to the plan of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to link the northern terminus of the West Side express highway with the proposed Henry Hudson Bridge by means of a $6,000,000 parkway running through Riverside Park led the Board of Estimate yesterday to defer action until June 14.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 24. -- Members of society who have their country homes on the North Shore of Long Island assembled at the ringside this afternoon for the steeplechase events on the program of the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Association, which were run over the new course on the estates of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Hickox and Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hutton.
Money market was quiet. Little business was done, and what there was of it ran to replacements. Quotations were unchanged.

Frederick Todd, former United States commercial attache at Havana, who committed suicide on Thursday near his home at Montclair, N.J., left a note charging that he was forced to resign his government post in 1931 because of his "absolutely correct reports" to Washington about the financial condition of the Machado regime in Cuba, it was learned yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., May 24. -- Regarded as among golf's unknown two years ago, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, the former Polly Andrews, today set a new mark in the women's metropolitan championship by gaining the final round in her first quest of the crown.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP). -Collecting eighteen hits, including five by Left-fielder Vosmik, the Indians battered the Athletics, 12 to 2, to win the series opener today.

Stone Webster, Inc., reported yesterday for the year ended on March 31 total earnings of $824,422, compared with $720,043 in the preceding twelve months, and net earnings of $85,285 after expenses and taxes, in contrast with a loss of $117,068 the year before. Net income after all charges was $71,596, against a net loss of $133,313 in the preceding year.

Interborough Rapid Transit Company employes were warned of agitators who are "trying to create unrest and discontent" among them, who are suggesting violence and who are threatening, employes with personal injury, in a formal statement issued yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the company.

DEVON, Pa., May 24. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's entries captured two blue ribbons today as the annual Devon horse show got under way. Her first triumph came when Spring Hope led in the model hunter lightweight class, with Dimsavin of the Sifton Stables, Toronto, taking the red.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 24. -- W. Lawson Little Jr., the defending champion, will meet Dr. William Tweddell of England in the final of the British amateur golf championship over thirty-six holes tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The House Military Affairs Committee, by a vote of 13 to 12, decided today to table the McSwain bill strengthening and clarifying the powers of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
LONDON, May 24. -- The fanfare of fifty trumpets echoed through vast Albert Hall tonight as the King and Queen arrived for the jubilee command concert of British music.

The Federal Government was rebuffed yesterday in its effort to salvage some revenue from liquor brought into the country by traveler after its original defeat on duty-free liquor by a White Plains young woman.

Commodity futures generally were lower in fairly active trading here yesterday. The weakness in wheat and other grains was a factor, as were the general uncertainties on the foreign currency situation. On the cash markets dairy products rose and all the grains and rubber declined.
The following standing committees of the New York Stock Exchange met yesterday and elected officers:

ALBANY, May 24. -- Nine men and women were named by Governor Lehman today as members of the Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council. Under the law, the Governor was authorized to name three representatives of the public, three employer representatives and three employe represntatives.

Timothy J. Sullivan, vice chairman of the Board of Aldermen, was unanimously elected Tammany leader of the Eighteenth Assembly District South by members of the Democratic County Committee of the district last night at a meeting in the organization's clubhouse, 1,451 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The $460,000,000 Naval Appropriation Bill was passed in the Senate today by a vote of 55 to 18 and sent to conference, as House approval must be obtained for $11,960,000 which the Senate added to make a total of $100,000,000 for constructing two dozen new ships and continuing sixteen others.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 24 (AP). -- W. Lawson Little Jr., of San Francisco tomorrow will be striving to emulate the "doubles" scored in 1886 and 1887 by H.G. Hutchinson and in 1900 and 1901 by Harold H. Hilton, both Britons and the only players in the history of the championship to turn the trick.

BELGRADE, May 24. -- German Aviation Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering has changed his plans, which were to arrive in Belgrade Sunday in order to avoid having to come in contact with the French delegation which arrived here today and also in order not to be present when the memorial ceremonies honoring the murdered French Foreign Minister Louis Barthou take place Sunday.

A commander without a command, Daniel Harris, 89-year-old Civil War veteran, will march Memorial Day with other than a G.A.R. unit for the first time since he joined the Grand Army of the Republic in 1868.

In your issue of today appeared an interesting letter from Philip L. Watkins under the caption, "It Was Different in 1679." In drawing attention to the difference in the law as it existed 256 years ago and up to last Friday, and the new Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Bill signed by Governor Lehman, Mr. Watkins concludes with the sentence, "One wonder how far from our forefathers' wisdom we have strayed."

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Continuing his reciprocal trade program in the face of attack, Secretary Hull held an hour's exploratory conversation today with Alexander Troyanovsky, the Russian Ambassador, looking to a possible trade understanding or agreement with the Soviet Government.

BERLIN, May 24. -- Contrary to interpretations yesterday of the new German Conscription Law, naturalized American citizens of German birth or extraction will not be liable for military service under the law. They will be allowed to serve in the German army, navy and air force only with the special consent of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler.

SHANGHAI, May 24. -- Shanghai, which was already suffering severely from the depression, was further seriously shaken today by the collapse of the "Raven companies," when the American-Oriental Banking Corporation failed to open its doors.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Authorizations and commitments by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in April increased substantially over March, principally because of a loan of $28,978,900 to the Colorado Southern Railway and one of $5,000,000 to the Baltimore Ohio.

Two more men were convicted of first-degree arson in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon on the testimony of Sam Skoblow, confessed "torch" in fifty-three incendiary fires in this city, that they hired him in 1933 to start a blaze in their silk store at 53 Allen Street.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The new form 1-M for the registration of brokers and dealers transacting business on over-the-counter markets was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, calling for information on which the commission may base decision as to eligibility of the applicants.

A little bird with gay markings, but a sad expression, ended a three-day sojourn in a candy store yesterday, and was taken to the shelter of the A.S.P.C.A. at Twenty-fourth Street and Avenue A. The bird did not like candy, anyhow, according to Mrs. Lena Cohen, owner of the store at 833 West 181st Street.

Nicholas (Nick) Montana, 36 years old, who, according to a statement issued in District Attorney William C. Dodge's office yesterday, is "the leading overlord of vice in the city of New York," was arrested early yesterday morning in Washington Heights on a charge of compulsory prostitution.

Arthur H. Young, vice president in charge of industrial relations of the United States Steel Corporation, declared last night that he would prefer to go to jail or receive a conviction as a felon than accept any provision of the Wagner Labor Disputes bill, which has already passed the Senate.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area did not display much change during the week, volume being about the same as in the preceding week. The general experience of department stores was that sales ran slightly under last year's figures for the period.

An opera management committee, consisting of John Erskine, chairman; Lucrezia Bori, Cornelius N. Bliss and Allen Wardwell, has been appointed by the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 24. -- Prime Minister MacDonald was at Buckingham Palace again today for the second time this week. This was the seventh consultation the King had had with his Ministers within a fort-night.

ST. LOUIS, May 24. -- Surprises never cease where Casey Stengel's Dodgers are concerned. Big Leslie Munns, hitherto just another hurler on the Brooklyn staff, today out-pitched the great Dizzy Dean and lifted the Flatbush team right back into second place.

George Keeler, 35-year-old boss stevedore, who worked under his wife's maiden name of Donovan, was murdered in bed on the second floor of his home at 1,607 East Forty-third Street, in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, about 5 A.M. yesterday.

VATICAN CITY, May 24. -- Severe words of condemnation for the German theories of eugenics and sterilization were uttered by the Pope, today in an audience he granted to delegates to the International Hospitals Congress, which is sitting in Rome.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24. -- A farm magazine in Iowa, once owned by Henry A. Wallace, and four other farm papers were ordered today to pay a judgment of $30,000 for alleged violation of the Sherman anti-trust law in an unlawful conspiracy in restraint of trade.

VIENNA, May 24. -- Memories of the pomp of the great vanished empire were revived yesterday afternoon when at Schoenbrunn Palace an Emperor Franz Josef exhibition was formally opened by President Wilhelm Miklas. It will remain open until October.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The leadership of persons high in the councils of the Roosevelt administration was exerted today to keep Governor Lehman in line as an available Gubernatorial candidate in 1936 and thus insure a solid Democratic front in New York State for the Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- President Roosevelt made it clear at a press conference that if a bonus rider were attached to the Social Security Bill he would veto the measure. He expressed support for the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill and conferred with leaders on this and NRA legislation.

BUDAPEST, May 24. -- German Aviation Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering, accompanied by his wife and a suite of eight persons, began his Eastern European "political honeymoon" with a semi-regal reception at the Budapest airdrome at 1:30 this afternoon.

BERLIN, May 24. -- Rather than betray their convictions, twenty-two Protestant pastors are still held in concentration camps, having deliberately chosen to remain there. This week they were offered their release if they would sign a statement confessing their imprisonment resulted from illegal activities and promising not to read publicly further protests issued by the Confessional Synod or Brotherhood Council. All refused, and their imprisonment continues.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP). -- A warning that failure to develop chemical talent now will cripple the country in the future was voiced tonight by Dr. Charles A. Kraus of Brown University in accepting the Willard Gibbs Medal for his achievements in chemistry.

The past week must go into the records -- the records of this corner, at least -- as just another week and little more. But that was to be expected, what with Summer coming on apace and night life being taken more leisurely.

UNLESS there's a slip 'twixt the cup and the lip, Lawson Little should come home again with the British amateur golf title. In a sporting way that will be a major operation, a distinguished achievement. If he makes it!

The Rev. William Bogert Walker of St. Petersburg, Fla., who is 90 years old and was graduated from Columbia College in 1865, will attend the commencement day exercises of Columbia University on June 4, it was announced yesterday.

SANTA FE, N.M., May 24. -- Mrs. Raoul Whitfield, former wife of William H. Vanderbilt, was found dead today of a self-inflicted bullet wound in the ranch house on the estate of her estranged husband, the author.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, denounced "witch hunters" here tonight in a speech in which he referred to Charles R. Walgreen, chain drug store owner, as "inconsistent" in his charges that communism was being taught at the University of Chicago.

Declaring that a resolution backed by three Borough Presidents to put relief work on a contract basis here would embarrass him with Washington, Mayor La Guardia succeeded yesterday in blocking the measure in the Board of Estimate at City Hall.

Groups representing more than 30,000 individuals in New York City have asked for application blanks to join the New York three-cents-a-day plan for hospital care, under which a subscriber is assured of twenty-one days of hospital care for the payment of 90 cents a month, or $10 a year.

Miss Katherine Leary Bond, 37-year-old restaurant employe and former beauty parlor worker, won a verdict of $15,000 from a Supreme Court jury yesterday in her $500,000 breach of promise suit against Paul Spencer Clapp, vice president of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation. The jury, which heard the case before Justice Aron Steuer, was out for an hour and fifty minutes.

Many of the 220,000 families on home relief have been required by their landlords to supplement the relief rent checks issued by the city under threat of eviction, Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, was informed yesterday.

The Manhattan Council of the Girl Scouts has good news for girls between the ages of 8 and 16 who have no hope of getting to a camp in the country this Summer. Plans have been made by this organization, in cooperation with the Park Department, to bring something of camp life to them within easy reach of both the West Side and the East Side of Manhattan.

Urging a government subsidy to merchant shipping to meet the competition of foreign fleets which are aided by their governments, R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, declared yesterday that the United States could not hope to hold a permanent place in international commerce without adequate tonnage of American flag registry.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- The market for hogs here today was steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. The top price was lifted 5 cents to $10.15 exclusive of the processing tax, but the day's average was unchanged at $9.85. Stock yards interests report a smaller percentage of sows in the arrivals at leading markets than normal for this season of the year.

With the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, Omaha, certain to be a confirmed favorite despite the prowess of the eight others, the sixtieth Withers Stakes will be run this afternoon at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- An overwhelming vote for continuance of the AAA production program is expected by officials when, with all the ceremony attending a local political election, wheat producers in 1,328 counties in thirty-seven States, ballot tomorrow on whether they wish the program to go on after the end of the present crop year.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Liquidation by scattered holders of May grain contracts, especially corn and oats on the Board of Trade put too much weight today on the markets to be absorbed by the limited outside speculative buying, and prices dropped rapidly.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A recommendation that President Roosevelt by proclamation change Thanksgiving Day from Thursday to the last Tuesday in November, to encourage the consumption of more fish and other sea food, was made to Secretary Roper today by the fish advisory committee, of which Bernarr Macfadden, publisher and physical culturist, is chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Drastic changes in the administration-sponsored Doughton resolution to reinforce and extend the NRA for two additional years were proposed to the Ways and Means Committee today by General Hugh S. Johnson, former Recovery Administrator, as the House group prepared to perfect the measure prior to rushing it through that chamber early next week.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP). -Buck Newsom celebrated his pitching debut with the Senators today by shutting out the league-leading White Sox, 10 to 0. The right-hander, purchased from St. Louis this week for $50,000, held Chicago to five hits.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 24. -- The garden section of the Contemporary Club of this city held its annual Spring flower show this afternoon in the auditorium of the clubhouse. The flower show committee included Mrs. Lewis B. Kaufman, chairman; Mrs. Mirabeau C. Towns, Mrs. Wheeler E. Gambee and Mrs. William Thompson.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A clause in the omnibus banking bill providing the strongest possible barrier to encroachment on the independence of the Federal Reserve Board was urged today by Adolph C. Miller, a member of the board, before the Senate Banking and Currency Subcommittee.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 24. -- The discovery in Eastern Finland of an extensive organization engaged in espionage among Russian emigrants, with the resultant arrest of some officers of the former imperial army and a handsome woman with extensive social connections, is attracting apprehensive attention among Russian refugees in all European countries.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Notice was served by President Roosevelt today that he would again veto legislation for payment of the soldiers' bonus, even if this came to him in the form of an amendment to the proposed Social Security Bill.
The outstanding volume of bankers' acceptances fell $52,487,245 in April, to $413,372,771, which was $199,756,366 under the level of a year ago, the American Acceptance Council announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 24. -- Today's session of the trial of John J. Corbett and Frank J. Walsh I.R.T. subway guards, and Harold Wollinsky, columnist, for assault was taken up by the testimony of Louis A. Freedman, a mechanical engineer and elevated sign equipment manufacturer of 308 West Seventy-second Street, Manhattan, who said he saw the three beating George Howard in the Times Square subway station on Nov. 6.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The long-standing dispute with Argentina over this country's embargo on Argentine meats on account of hoof and mouth disease was adjusted today through a sanitary convention signed by Secretary Hull and Dr. Felipe Espil, Ambassador, which permits application of a "rule of reason" in such embargoes based upon actual conditions.

The Burns Brothers Coal Company, through Gardner Pattison, its president, filed a petition yesterday in Federal court seeking authority to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. Judge Robert P. Patterson approved the petition and continued the debtor in possession and control of its property.

Jan Klepura's latest musical film for Gaumont British, "My Song for You," opens an engagement today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Supporting the Polish operatic tenor are Sonnie Hale, Eileen Marson and Gina Malo.

CINCINNATI, May 24. -- The exceptionally fine chorus of the Cincinnati May Festival, which had already proved its prowess, distinguished itself this evening by a virtuoso presentation of a work which as a whole is new to America, and a second work that had not been heard before outside of England.
PARIS, May 24. -- A day of feverish financial and political activity has left the government's situation just as serious as it was financially, but somewhat improved politically.

The subcommittee on health and sanitation of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem, at a hearing yesterday afternoon, heard Albert M. Boyce, special investigator for the commission, tell of "the disgraceful inefficiency" of the physical equipment of the Harlem Hospital, a city institution.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- With the aim of having plans ready for immediate use in a national emergency the Navy Department is having a new type of speed boat submarine chaser, with high speed as the basic characteristic, designed by W. Starling Burgess, designer of the America's Cup defense yachts Enterprise and Rainbow.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
PRINCETON, N.J., May 24. -- The Princeton interscholastic tennis tournament progressed through four rounds of play today without a single upset being recorded among the seeded stars.

The week-end schedule lists no formal departures this evening from Broadway, but there is some admitted uncertainty. "The HookUp," which must make away at the Cort for the arrival of "Knock on Wood" next week, had not made up its mind last night about closing or moving to another house.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 24. -- Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the German department of the New Jersey College for Women, once denounced the late President Woodrow Wilson as a "schweinhund," according to testimony given here this afternoon by Miss Ruth Wagner of Elizabeth, who was graduated from the college in 1933.

Manhattan has its albino frog and its albino monkey, but, thanks to Mrs. C.R. Whipple of Hoosick Falls, N.Y., the Bronx now has an albino tadpole, and beginning today anybody can have a look at the unusual specimen in an aquarium in the reptile house of the Bronx Zoo.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 24. -Without cutting loose with anything like record-breaking efforts, Ohio State's brilliant Jesse Owens and Michigan's beautifully balanced team dominated the trials for the thirty-fifth annual Western Conference track and field championship meet today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- Overhauling of this country's "antiquated" electoral and judicial systems was recommended to the American Academy of Political and Social Science today as a step that would enable voters themselves to control their government and would help combat the frequently expressed fears for the future of the democratic form of rule.
BOSTON, May 24 (AP). -- The Red Sox evened their series with the Tigers today, 8 -- 4, behind rather shaky pitching of Bob (Lefty) Grove.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Revisions of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill for control of public utilities and the elimination of many holding companies have not removed its "objectionable features," Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, told his stockholders today.

The Board of Estimate turned a cold shoulder yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's proposal to construct a municipal power plant to serve as a cost yardstick for electric rates to consumers in the metropolitan district. First it defeated his resolution for authority to ask the Federal Government for a $45,000,000 loan to finance the project.

LONDON, May 24 (AP). -- The shortest wheat conference since international efforts to boost prices began two years ago ended tonight after finally agreeing to the extension for one year of the world wheat pact, with all government control undertakings suspended indefinitely.

MEXICO, D.F., May 24. -- The labor conflicts in Mexico are now seriously affecting the newspapers, as the only newsprint manufacturing concern in the country is still closed, its workers having walked out ten days ago and appealed to the Supreme Court against a district court ruling that their strike was illegal.

AURORA, Ill., May 24. -- From out of the clouds dropped a new threat today to challenge Omaha's rule of America's 3-year-olds. He is Sun Portland, owned by Mrs. Silas B. Mason of Lexington, Ky., which conquered Roman Soldier by a neck in a thrilling finish to win the $10,000 added Illinois Derby, closing the twenty-one-day meeting at Aurora.

I have on hand new item of Nov. 7, 1934, which states that in a certain election distrit--240 Vrest Thirty-eighth Street -- where there is only one single voter, the city spent 500, and the Election Board had to spend a whole day to have the single voter cast his ballot.
After four disappointments, Rogers Hornsby's lowly Browns played their first game of the season with the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium and scaled, what for them, are dizzy heights.
For the first time since Mayor La Guardia and his Fusion administration took office in January, 1934, one of his assistants was forced out of office under fire yesterday.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 24 (AP). -- Opening a new attack on the Blue Eagle, former President Hoover today described use of "bureaucratic coercion" and the "boycott" to enforce the NRA as "not American" and predicted that labor would not long stand for monopolistic and Fascist practices.

The "menace" of Japanese textile import lies primarily in their low prices, and only to a minor degree in the volume of imports. Thus, the apparently innocent statistics -- less than 1 per cent of domestic production -- measuring the extent of Japanese competition in terms of physical volume are misleading and do not present a true portrayal of Japanese textile competition.

That the present procedure dealing with vice offenders is outmoded, ineffectual and futile and that the Women's Court should be abandoned entirely are among the recommendations contained in a report of the Women's Court Committee of the Welfare Council of New York City, made public yesterday.

A reunion of former parishioners and friends of old St. Andrew's Catholic Church, Cardinal Place and Duane Street, marked the Maytime dance and fete given last night as a tribute to the pastor, Mgr. William E. Cashin, and to raise funds for the support of the work of the church.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- A gloomy picture of trade conditions in France, with sentiment for the future "by no means optimistic" and relieved only by a decline in unemployment, was presented today in the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business abroad.

The sensitivity of Radio Corporation stocks over the last few months has been one of the more interesting stock market developments, and the successive advances and falls of the issues have been accompanied by reports that a plan to deal with the arrears of dividends on the B preferred stock by some sort of reclassification plan was about to be announced or that no such plan was ready.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Although there may be any number of good and sufficient reasons why the enfeebled Giants ought to be absorbing a lot of punishment, the Cubs, for the life of them, could not come up with a single one this afternoon.

GENEVA, May 24. -- The committee of thirteen named by the Council of the League of Nations on April 17 to study economic and financial sanctions against treaty repudiators opened its session today with a proposal by France for a European protocol aimed particularly at establishing an embargo on raw materials.

ROME, May 24. -- In a brief address to a great crowd of war veterans and Fascists gathered in Rome for the celebration of the twentieth anniversary of Italy's entry into the World War, Premier Benito Mussolini again affirmed his intention to follow the course he has mapped out for the nation.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- President Roosevelt gave orders today for "full speed ahead" on the House bill for a two-year extension of the National Industrial Recovery Act, threw his support to the principles enunciated in the Wagner Labor Relations Bill, and made the measure as it will be amended and clarified part of his "must" legislation.

The Bush Terminal Buildings Company reported yesterday for 1934 a net profit of $94,866 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This included $109,998 excess of par value over the cost of bonds bought and retired through the sinking fund. The profit is equivalent to $1.35 a share on the outstanding 70,000 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Opposition to commercial operation of the coaxial cable telephone-television system between New York and Philadelphia, which the American Telephone and Telegraph Company purposes to start soon on an experimental basis, was expressed to the Federal Communications Commission today in a letter filed jointly by the Western Union Telegraph Company and the Postal Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The police broadcast an eight-State alarm yesterday for Michael Ortiz, 17 years old, who departed for "the West" on Tuesday to seek fame and fortune as an artist, taking $1,800 in cash, his father's savings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 24. -- Oswald G. Villard Jr., '38, and Norman L. Hope, '36, both of New York City, were among the winners of the annual awards at Yale today. Villard won the leading McLaughlin Memorial prize for excellence in English, and Hope, the Scott prize in French literature.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., May 24. -- Bee keepers from three States today witnessed the first public exhibition of a newly developed stingless bee, which is the result of six years' crossbreeding and inbreeding, at the apiary of Henry Brown at Burleigh, about two miles from here.

A writer stated recently that "the one thing that causes more accidents and deaths than anything else is the New York rule permitting autoists to go ahead against a red light to turn into the flow of traffic." I doubt if this is true.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 24. -Mrs. T.W. Hawes of Canoe Brook today won the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, scoring a 92 over the Plainfield Country Club course.

Nathan Hale, descendant of the Revolutionary patriot, who holds a post in the city Department of Public Welfare, stood before an audience in the "silk stocking" Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club last night and denounced the relief system of the city as mainly under the control of Communists and Tammany Hall.

GENEVA, Saturday, May 25. -- With Premier Mussolini of Italy retreating enough to prevent a break now with Geneva over the Ethiopian dispute, the League of Nations Council unanimously adopted at 1:37 o'clock this morning two resolutions maintaining the League's jurisdiction in this dispute and substantially meeting the aims with which the Ethiopian delegation came to Geneva.

One curious aspect of the present industrial problem was rather forcibly indicated by this week's speeches at the convention of the National Purchasing Agents Association. All of them conveyed the belief of delegates that the hour had come when the country's consuming industries must make good the "underbuying" of the past five years.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP). -Two sudden developments today involving John Barrymore, screen actor, and his wife, Dolores Costello, bolstered persistent Hollywood rumors that the film couple were approaching a definite parting of the ways.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 24. -There are some cases in which it is hardly necessary to preen one's self on being a true prophet, and this British amateur golf championship provides one of them. W. Lawson Little Jr. of California, defending champion, is in the final, where I and a great many other prophets have always thought he would be.

CINCINNATI, May 24. -- Refusing to accept the recommendation of one of its most important committees, the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America voted today to reject the proposal for the immediate merger of its Board of National Missions and its Board of Christian Education.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24. -Harvard beat Cornell's nine twice today on Soldier's Field, scoring 11 to l0 and 11 to 4, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League doubleheader.

While not stimulating to any marked degree, because variations were more outstanding than a definite trend, reports on trade developments this week revealed the advantage on the up side, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Industrial activity recovered somewhat from the average of the week preceding, the agency states, but distribution at both retail and wholesale continued to be hampered by adverse weather conditions.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 (AP). -More than a dozen drivers, despite track danger signals, sent their racing cars through practice spins at the Indianapolis motor speedway today. Qualification trials for the annual 500-mile race May 30 resume at 1 P.M. tomorrow.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows, quotations are in cents:
After being announced several times previously, Havelock Ellis's study of French literature, "From Rousseau to Proust," is definitely to appear this Fall, Houghton Mifflin announce.

John W. Garrett, former United States Ambassador to Italy, and Mrs. Garrett are among the passengers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex. Others leaving on the ship include Mgr. Giuseppe Fietta, Apostolic Nuncio to Haiti; Giovanni Martinelli, operatic tenor, and:

Registration of the millionth dog by the American Kennel Club was a notable event in the kennel world yesterday. The governing body presented a special certificate to Miss Catherine E. Coleman of Newport, N.H., for her Shetland sheepdog Sheltieland Alice Grey Gown, which will go down in American dog history as the bearer of the number.

Wheat farmers all over the country are to vote today for or against continuing the crop-curtailment plan of AAA. There is not much doubt about the outcome of this poll. Farmers are being asked whether they wish to continue to receive cash bounties for crops they do not need to grow.

A plan for a different distribution of the cash and securities offered by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company has been filed by Robert J. Levy, a noteholder and member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Robert J. Levy Co., in the United States District Court in Baltimore.
LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP). -Whether war veterans will organize another "bonus army" to march on the nation's capital was left tonight to a decision to be made by Major General Smedley D. Butler.

Luigi Maino, who was described by the police as a former member of the Italian Parliament, committed suicide shortly after 6 o'clock last night aboard the Italian liner Rex at Pier 59, North River and Eighteenth Street. His body, partly clad, was found in a bathtub of the ship's infirmary.

The reviewers will be telling us a great deal for the next few weeks about the sociology of the Italian PARETO, which, though published in Italian and French nearly twenty years ago, has just been translated into English. In this great four-volumed work PARETO tells us that he is not trying to reform society, or to make any "practical application" of his theories, but merely to describe things as they are.

An exhibition called "One Hundred and Fifty Years of Russian Painting" opened privately yesterday afternoon at the Hammer Galleries, 682 Fifth Avenue. Beginning today, this work will be on public display for a fortnight. Between eighty and ninety pictures have been hung, some of them lent from private collections or by the artists; a great many -- among them paintings formerly in Russian palace collections -- belonging now to the Hammer Galleries.

Mr. GREEN of the American Federation of Labor seemed for some time after he became president of that organization to be a sensible and steady-minded labor leader. In recent months, however, his head appears not to have been able to bear the excitement. It takes the form with him of repeated threats of a general strike.

A suit for an accounting and appointment of a receiver was filed yesterday in Federal court against Remington Rand, Inc., makers of office equipment, and the corporation's board of directors, who are accused of waste and misconduct that has caused losses running into many millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP). -- The War Department announced today the Federal Government would undertake a flood control project in the Wallkill River to benefit approximately 25,000 acres of rich garden truck land on the New York-New Jersey boundary.

The mounting monetary crisis in Francs yesterday brought further large withdrawals of gold for shipment here, an accelerated rise in sterling and a fall in the discount on forward francs to 25 points, equal on an annual basis to more than 15 per cent.
NEWARK, N.J., May 24. -- The Syracuse Chiefs made a clean sweep of their series with Newark, defeating the Bears, 2 to 1, today for the third victory in as many days.

With cotton outside of the government collateral diminishing rapidly trade price-fixing orders found comparatively few contracts available on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices steadied to end with gains of 1 to 4 points.
LONDON, May 24. -- There will be no secession of States from the Commonwealth of Australia by act of the United Kingdom Parliament.

The Consolidated Gas Company's formal offer to the Public Service Commission contemplates a reduction in the rates for electric current to consumers in New York City aggregating $7,566,000. The percentage of reduction for residential consumers varies from around 2 per cent for the typical apartment dweller or small householder who uses thirty-five or forty kilowatt-hours a month up to nearly 50 per cent for the chap who uses 500 kilowatts or more.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 24 (AP). -- Four intersectional games appear on the Western Conference football schedules for 1937, tentatively approved at a meeting of football coaches and athletic directors today.

Federal Judge Byers in Brooklyn reserved yesterday decision on a motion by Archibald Palmer, counsel for a group of stockholders of Adolf Gobel, Inc., which is in reorganization proceedings, for the appointment of trustees to handle the property of the corporation.

A phial of deadly South American Indian arrow poison is one of the objects on view at the fourth annual exhibition of scientific pharmacy which opened yesterday at the College of Pharmacy of the City of New York, 115 West Sixty-eight Street.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 24. -- Mrs. William C. Wright's gelding Silverskin scored a runaway victory in the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap, feature of today's Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association which was held in the pastoral setting of the Wheatley Hills on the estate of Charles V. Hickox.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- At Palo Alto Herbert Hoover declaims once more against the NRA and promises to deliver at Stanford University yet another speech in his campaign for renomination. At Madison Square Garden Father Coughlin denounces essential policies of the administration. In the Senate radical Democrats attack the veto of bonus-inflation as "political suicide." The newspapers controlled by William Randolph Hearst ring with denunciation on the same theme.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 25. -- Students at Vassar College went on record this week as favoring a change in the present marking system, and while no definite plan has been formulated, Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president, and some members of the faculty agree with the students that the new curriculum, fully in effect this year, requires a radical change in the method of rating academic standing.

I am justified in the assertion that the economic condition of the average slave in the South before emancipation was far superior to that of the average farmer now engaged in the production of cotton. It will, of course, be understood that I am not now and never was a defender of the institution of slavery.
Leaders of both major political parties were stirred last week by the publication of an Albany dispatch saying that Governor Herbert H. Lehman was determined not to be a candidate for re-election.
