WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A sudden rift in the cloud of doubt concerning the fate of the NRA has disclosed the existence of what were interpreted in some quarters as brightening gleams of hope for a two-year extension of the NRA or an extension to within seventy-five days of the period requested by President Roosevelt.

PROFESSOR JOAD has a timely subject, and makes clear from the first that he is greatly concerned about it. He believes in liberty, which he regards as essential to progress, and makes an admirable analysis of its nature, throwing in in passing a wealth of epigrammatic statements which tempt one to inordinate quotation.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The movement for cash payment of the veterans' bonus at this session of Congress sank to a low ebb today, following the declaration by President Roosevelt yesterday that he would veto any bill to which it was attached, even if it were the most essential part of his legislative program.

AS the shadow of the year 1936 begins to fall across the political horizon -- and, by the same token, the economic horizon -- the great, troubled area of the Middle West comes into the spotlight. From that region, primarily, will come the voice that will decide whether Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal are to have a second term and, if not, by whom and by what they will be replaced.

Policy questions will come up for the first time, in addition to budget and organization matters, at the meeting of the executive committee of the American Retail Federation to be held on Tuesday at the Hotel Chatham, it was stated yesterday by President C.O. Sherrill, who arrived here yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore to attend the meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- House leaders made plans today to pass a bill continuing the National Industrial Recovery Act for another two years, as desired by the administration, and to put the issue squarely up to the Senate. Under procedure as mapped today, the Ways and Means Committee would report its measure Monday and the House would pass the bill before adjournment Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Confirming informal expressions by government officials, Attorney General Cummings announced today that no request would be made to the Supreme Court for a rehearing on the Railroad Retirement Act, declared unconstitutional recently.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 25. -- Gettysburg's nine defeated Army today, 13 to 4. The Pennsylvania collegians punished both Stokes, the Army's starting pitcher, who lasted four innings, and Segrist, his relief, collecting fifteen hits, eight of them being extra-base drives.

EXCEPT for a lone performance here and there, the season has definitely come to an end, and it is time once again to look back over the records. Perhaps the most superficial aspect of these records is the numerical one, but it nevertheless bears a certain witness to the tendencies of the times and has perhaps some value on that score.

HERE is more information about the All-Nations Prize Novel Contest, mention of which was made in this column some weeks ago. The countries participating in the contest are the United States England, France, Canada, Germany, Hungary, Denmark, Sweden, Spain, Italy, Holland, Norway and Czechoslovakia, and manuscripts may be submitted in the language of any of these countries.

Yes, I have run short of money. I have been foolish. Long ago I found out what income I needed for retirement and set it aside to be invested. The rest I spent on friends and books and pictures and motor bikes and joys of sorts.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 25. -- With the Navy leading by 2 to 0 and two out in North Carolina's half of the fourth, the visitors scored eight runs after Knapper had thrown wildly to first and missed an easy chance to retire the side. The final score favored North Carolina, 11 to 8.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The New York bankers, in their opposition to the administration Banking Bill now pending in Congress, are at issue with most leaders of the American Bankers Association, Marriner S. Eccles, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board and leading advocate of the bill, declared in a speech tonight over a National Broadcasting Company network.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25. -- Unless new funds can be made available at once, either from Federal or State appropriations, the work of eradicating the Dutch elm-tree disease in New York. New Jersey and Pennsylvania may be halted, it was revealed here today.

THERE was credit enough to be widely distributed in the record performances on May 17 and 18 of the TWA laboratory plane, the Douglas DC-1. Not only did it bring back a number of important world records to the United States in difficult categories, but it showed without peradventure the stamina of American transport planes and of the engines which power them.

LONDON, May 25 (AP). -- A Nazi demand for recognition of Germany's right to hold colonies was revealed here today as Great Britain and Germany launched diplomatic exchanges calculated to give substance to the peace suggestions Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler made in his Reichstag speech Tuesday.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 25. -- On the spacious Allen Athletic Field of Smith College more than 200 girls participated today in their annual field day.

QUIETLY, Sam H. Harris went about acquiring another play five weeks ago, this one the farce about show business called "Sing Before Breakfast," John Murray (who hid for a while behind the pseudonym of Michael Croyden) is co-author of it with Allen Boretz; they are, in fact, still writing it, this time under Mr. Harris's supervision, and it will be tested during the Summer.

GENEVA, May 25. -- The session of the League of Nations Council that ended today saw a struggle between the League and one of its members over an elementary issue. It is whether a great armed power can now prevent the League even from beginning to apply to it the covenant's normal peace-making procedure.

Progress in impressing upon some Senators the untoward implications in the "intrastate persons" clause of the Clark resolution and cementing of their amicable relations with representatives were the chief achievement of the "march" on Washington last week by business men and code and association executives, they reported here yesterday.

Further opposition to the recent application for an order demanding a license for a motion-picture theatre at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street was disclosed yesterday in the Supreme Court, where Justice John F. Carew has the matter under advisement.

BUENOS AIRES, May 21. -- Delegates of all twenty-one Pan-American republics will meet here on May 26 to inaugurate the Pan-American Commercial Conference, in a new endeavor to suppress some of the obstacles that impede inter-American trade.

Retailers are planning for greatly increased June volume on the supposition that the unfavorable weather which has prevailed cannot last much longer, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 23. -- Support of the administration in its determination to maintain wage scales on relief projects at levels considerably below prevailing wages in industry is sufficiently strong in the Southwest to constitute almost unanimity of approval.

BUENOS AIRES, May 25. -- The Bolivian delegation to the Chaco peace conference, headed by Foreign Minister Tomas Manuel Elio, arrived today by a special train placed at its disposal by the Argentine Government.

Large and small retailers are watching with marked interest the plans being formulated by manufacturers in this State to avail themselves of the permissive right to establish minimum retail prices for trade-marked products under the Feld-Crawford "fair trade" law, recently signed by Governor Lehman.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 25 (AP). -- Governor Park stated tonight that he would release Monday his decision whether Walter McGee must hang for kidnapping Mary McElroy, and in Kansas City McGee prayed long in his cell.

BERLIN, May 25 (AP). -- A nation-wide drilling exploration of German soil to a depth of 10,000 feet was said today to have revealed oil wells "similar to those in Pennsylvania and West Virginia," that are expected to make the Reich's army and industry free from the necessity of importing foreign lubricants.
RYE, N.Y., May 25. -- The famous golf cup emblematic of the women's metropolitan golf championship, won by some of the nation's greatest players today went to Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- The Wagner Labor Disputes Bill was denounced today by R.E. Wantz, president of the Illinois Manufacturers Association, as a measure that would promote industrial unrest rather than peace.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, May 25. -- W. Lawson Little Jr. of San Francisco won the British amateur golf championship for the second year in succession today by defeating Dr. William Tweddell, 1 up, in what officials here agree was the most terrific thirty-six-hole battle in the history of the tournament.

The calling of all Home Owners Loan Corporation 4 per cent bonds, totaling $325,000,000, for retirement at par on July 1 instead of in 1951, the year when due, featured last week's bond redemption announcements. Other calls, most of them for future months, included entire issues of domestic corporation bonds and numerous small amounts of municipal bonds.

The National Labor Relations Bill, which I introduced, passed the Senate on May 16 and is fairly certain to become law before the adjournment of Congress. This measure is designed to plug the loopholes that have been bored in Section 7a of the Recovery Act by two years of uncertainty and evasion.

The very interesting discussion why the number of patent applications is diminishing leaves in the inventor's mind no doubt of the real cause. The trouble is not with the inventors but rather with the Patent Office fees and recent financial conditions.

AN alliance of cheap and intelligent labor with modern machinery and large-scale vertical capital organization has given Japan booming exports in the greatest depression yet known. The foundation of her competitive power is the practically unlimited labor force, accustomed to economical ways, and able to live cheerfully on money wages which would mean grinding poverty to Americans with their more complex wants.

PARIS. IF ever fashions were able to help a girl be all things to all men, the new midseason ones are! One evening she may swathe herself in voluminous, metal-striped muslin veils, like an Arabian Nights Princess; the next she may go romantic in great-grandmother's black chantilly shawl and grenadine frock.

MADISON, N.J., May 25. -- Champion Milson O'Boy, superb Irish setter owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York and handled by Harry Hartnett of Harrison, N.Y., was crowned best of 3,175 dogs exhibited today in the ninth annual bench show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., May 25. -- Clarence Stanley has been made successor to the late H.C. McEldowney, becoming first vice president and virtual head of the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh at 38 years of age. The company is controlled by the Mellon interests.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 25. -- Outstanding figures of the theatre are on the faculty and lecturer staff of the Institute of the Theatre which Union College will sponsor for eight weeks this Summer, it was announced today by Dixon Ryan Fox, president of the college.

ISTANBUL, May 25. -- The fourth general congress of the Republican People's party has just terminated in Angora. In a country like Turkey, where the single-party system prevails, the congress is a notable event, furnishing occasion for a review of the country's political activity of the preceding four years and giving an idea of future policy.

OUR great national parks are no longer merely scenery; they have become educational centres providing visitors with opportunities to interpret and appreciate history, both natural and national. Recently the Park Service, aided by PWA funds, has turned its attention to the construction and equipment of museums.
Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch announced yesterday that he would introduce a local law providing for a new system of collecting small fines at the next session of the Board of Estimate.

LOS ANGELES, May 25. -- Charging cruelty and habitual intemperance, Dolores Costello Barrymore, blond former movie actress, sued her handsome-profiled actor husband, John Barrymore, for divorce today.

VIENNA, May 25. -- A government decree incorporating the Austrian Army into the Fatherland Front and providing that future army recruits may be taken only from the ranks of the Front was regarded by authoritative circles tonight as a severe setback to the Fascist Vice Chancellor, Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg.

After his "small slam" of 1934, when he equaled the feat of Bobby Jones in winning both the British and American amateur titles in the same season, William Lawson Little Jr.'s successful defense of his English crown came as no surprise in spite of the vagaries of sport's most 'umbling game.

THE sidewalk cafes are blooming again, tables and chairs are glistening with new green paint, new awnings are up, evergreen hedges and flower boxes are fresh and gay, and they are here earlier this year than last.

WITH Decoration Day almost here, every one feels that Summer is about to begin. City folk will be scampering out of town at every opportunity. Thus picnicking is symbolical of the season. There are many new ideas to make picnics more of a joy.

BERLIN, May 25. -- From time to time the high authority in New York which pays the bills of foreign correspondents here puts up to them as suggested subjects for forthcoming dispatches questions somewhat embarrassing for a frank response from German soil.

THE standard biographies of William and Catherine Booth by Harold Begbie and Commissioner Booth-Tucker -- still remembered in the United States, where he was active for several years-may not deserve all the scorn that is poured upon them by Mr. Ervine.

LONDON. THE celebration of the King's silver jubilee has set many pens to work at the task of appraising the national achievements in various fields of activity during his reign, and in these retrospects -- some of them remarkably skillful pieces of workmanship -- literature has not been overlooked.

IN OUTDOOR furniture, mobility -- a quality developed to a high degree this season -- adds greatly to possibilities of use and comfort. Chairs and chaise longues equipped with rubber-tired wheels may be placed easily in sun or shade at the caprice of their owner and with them may be trundled a tea table, bookstand or eves a perambulating bar.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 25. -- Henry Picard, towering Hershey Club representative, who has been rapidly forging his way to the top in professional golfdom, today annexed the metropolitan open championship.

CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP). -- The Reds made it two in a row over the Phillies today with a 4-to-3 victory, the one-run margin coming from a double by Riggs and a triple by Goodman in the seventh. The Reds' other runs were put over in the fifth on hits by Meyers and Sullivan.

LONDON, May 25. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today. Interest was still centred on foreign exchange movements in Lombard Street. After further selling and higher rates against gold currencies, at first under the lead of francs, quotations subsequently tended to fall on control buying.

AGATE HOUSE, in the Petrified Forest National Monument in Arizona, is being restored with government funds. Parts of this prehistoric cliff dwelling are built with pieces of gleaming petrified wood; no one knows which tribe of Indians constructed it, or how long it has stood.

Because next Thursday is Memorial Day pastors will preach patriotic sermons today. Many will speak in their sermons of a movement to obtain national observance of the day as an occasion for homage to the "Heroes of Peace" as well as of war, which has been started by a group of leading clergymen and laymen active in religious work.

GENEVA, May 25. -- Illicit narcotic traffic was not diminished in 1934, despite effective supervision of manufacture, improved international cooperation and increased police work, according to the report of the League of Nations Narcotics Seizures Committee today. Instead, this traffic appears to have increased.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 25. -- The East will send two of the best crews it has had in years to the starting line at Poughkeepsie next month.

PEIPING, Sunday, May 26. -- Japanese troops who came through the Great Wall into North China recently administered severe punishment yesterday to Chinese irregular forces that had been operating in the neutral zone south of the Wall.

SPRING weather is often deceiving in a way that is not generally recognized. One expects it to be uncertain and shifting, but the garden beginner often fails to realize how quickly, after a few days of more or less continuous wind, the surface of the soil may dry out.

Young women headed by Miss Jane Robb Murdoch are taking an active interest in the plans for the bundle-luncheon in aid of the Prosperity Shop, which will be held Tuesday at the Ambassador. Each guest has been requested to bring a package of useful articles suitable for resale later at the shop, which is a permanent thrift shop maintained for the benefit of various charitable organizations.

Distribution of merchandise at both wholesale and retail continued unsatisfactory last week in most of the Federal Reserve districts as the result of unseasonable weather conditions. In those sections where the weather was clear and warm store sales showed sharp gains, increases being particularly heavy in the St. Louis and Dallas districts.

Running the fastest mile of the meeting, eight furlongs in 1:36 3-5, Rosemont from the Foxcatcher Farms of William du Pont yesterday defeated William Woodward's Omaha to the surprise of most in a crowd of 25,000 which thronged Belmont Park.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 25. -- Providence College defeated the Holy Cross nine today by 4 to 1, the defeat being the first for the Crusaders in fifteen games this year.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 25. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Reich Minister of Aviation, is being subjected to unusually caustic remarks in certain sections of the Finnish press in connection with the bestowal on him by President Svinhugvud of the insignia of Finland's highest order.

Thomas A. McGoldrick of Brooklyn, president of the student council of Manhattan College, has been chosen as the outstanding student of the class of '35. He was elected as the most typical Manhattan College man and the one who had done the most for the college.

Mayor La Guardia has written to Police Commissioner Valentine, asking him to cooperate with the Board of Education's Summer playground program by instructing his men to educate children to use playgrounds instead of the streets for play.

ONE person out of every hundred in the United States was injured in an automobile accident last year, it is reported in the current issue of the National Safety Council's publication, Public Safety. This estimate is based on a total of 1,250,000 injuries and a population of approximately 125,000,000 persons. Going further with this I proportional presentation of the subject, the report continues:

It was Homecoming Day on Old Rose Hill yesterday, but Fordham's base runners failed to rise to the occasion. They reached home only twice in a contest with their ancient baseball rivals, Boston College, and the latter triumphed, 3 to 2.

SAN REMO, April 30, 1935. WITH a mounting of "La Sonnambula," Toti Dal Monte protagonist, in the Teatro del Casino Municipale, the music capital of the Italian Riviera opened its annual opera season recently. It was a worthy contribution to Italy's current Bellini celebrations.

THERE are profits and prophets in Hollywood, and David O. Selznick, the producer of such operas as "Dinner at Eight," "Viva Villa" and "David Copperfield," has managed in his time to accumulate much of the former by being one of the latter.

TURISMO" is today's most potent word in the lexicon of Mexico. It is not difficult to understand why. Within the last two years the travel tide has turned from Europe to countries south of the Rio Grande, drawn primarily by a comparatively favorable economy in the neighboring North American republics and influenced by a new Conquest of Mexico in which the pen of the American writer has replaced the sword.

LONDON, May 3. A PECULIARLY English joke is not, perhaps, the most appropriate of subjects for an article in these columns, and, if an excuse be needed for discussing Reginald Arkell's dramatic version of "1066 and All That," which is a burlesque of English history, it must be the lame one that, however wide the Atlantic may be now, Americans and Englishmen had William the Conqueror and many of his successors in common.
BERLIN, May 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of May 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
The wages to be paid under the works program will, in general, provide the workers with almost twice as large a monthly income as they have been getting under relief.

"Lexicon," senior year book of the School of business and Civic Administration of City College, will make its appearance for the first time this month, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean Justin H. Moore.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 25. -- Thomas Hitchcock Jr., veteran of many international engagements, turned in an excellent performance today on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club, in leading Greentree to a 14-to-9 victory over the Old Westbury riders.

Despite the uncertainty which continued to prevail with regard to the future of the NRA, retailers last week began to give more attention to the placing of Fall orders. The view gained among retailers, as among other business men, that the prospect of inflation is now beginning to loom up more definitely and may be a substantial factor in Fall operations.

In view of the efforts being made by the government to enlarge the area of national parks and national monuments, I would suggest that some attention be given to the possibility of including the Dismal Swamp area of Virginia and North Carolina.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25 (AP). -- Samuel H. Crooks of Rumson, N.J., stocky Rutgers University senior and former intercollegiate outboard champion, drove his Dragon 5 to victory today in the Delaware River sixty-four mile outboard marathon from Trenton to Philadelphia and return.

ONCE more the time has come when the irrepressible children of the theatre, sick of Winter and pent-up city life, are casting hopeful glances toward those remodeled barns and rustic shacks, with their hayloft balconies and box-stall stages, which go by the name of "Summer theatres."

FOR a number of reasons few things could have been more welcome than the thoughtful, majestic performance of Brahms's symphony No. 4 with which Bruno Walter marked his transfer from Columbia to Victor and thus commenced what promises to be a richly productive phase in his recording career (Victor Album M-242).

FRAGMENTS of glass dug from the soil of Virginia have inspired antiquarians to establish two unique museums -- one at Jamestown, the other at Yorktown. In them will be assembled bottles, beads, jars and ornaments of various kinds, manufactured in America's first glass factories.

School officials attending the conference on truancy and delinquency tomorrow night at the Board of Education Building will give particular attention to the question of the continuance or abandonment of the New York Parental School. They will hear the views of civic, religious, social welfare and other leaders.

TWO Times Square landmarks, the Loew's New York and Criterion Theatres, will succumb to the ravages of a wrecking crew early next month. Built by Oscar Hammerstein in 1895, the double-theatre building was originally known as the Olympia.

The recent editorial, letter and article in THE TIMES on the subject of the first public school recall a remark of the late Andrew S. Draper, New York State Commissioner of Education, that "the American public school did not come in through the Cape Cod route." His meaning was more fully expressed as follows in an address before the Holland Society of New York:

Seemingly unperturbed at the refusal of the Board of Estimate to approve his $45,000,000 municipal power plant project, Mayor La Guardia insisted yesterday that the project "is not dead." He said he would fight to force a city referendum on the proposal.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Sales of merchandise at both wholesale and retail are lagging behind last year, but merchants blame the recession wholly on the abnormally cool weather, and look for a burst of activity when it ends. Buying is best in staples and house furnishings items.

With a number of code authorities due to be liquidated, regardless of the form of extension that the NRA takes, the Code Authorities accounts section of the NRA has issued tentative requirements for the winding Up of these groups. The Scrap-Iron Code Authority, which voted last week to terminate on June 16, will follow the procedure outlined by the accounts section. although it may be later modified in varying degrees.

PITTSBURGH, May 23. -- Western Pennsylvania soft-coal operators, who were particular sufferers from cutthroat competition prior to NRA, found encouragement in the conferences in Washington this week looking to holding and advancing the gains for stabilization of the industry.

MUNICH, May 25. -- Citizens of Munich fought with Nazi pickets today as the anti-Jewish boycott broke out again in a form unequaled for disorderliness and thoroughness since the nation-wide boycott of April 1, 1933.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 (AP). -- W. Lawson Little Jr., who won the British amateur golf championship at St. Anne's-on-the-Sea today, kept faith with his dad.

"Therefore, Mr. Speaker, I return, without my approval, House of Representatives Bill No. 3896, providing for the immediate payment to veterans of the 1945 face value of their adjusted service certificates."

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The procedure under which Colonel A. E. Williams was tried this week by army general court-martial on charges growing out of testimony before the House Military Committee concerning an alleged loan of $2,000 by a salesman-lobbyist is based upon military law that has evolved out of the dim past.

DESPITE all efforts to wipe out cockfighting by State law, many an old barn in this country is still the scene of battles royal, as testified by the recent confiscation of seventy-five roosters on a New Jersey farm. Such "mains," or tournaments, as are held today must be in secret, and in an obscure spot, but in early days cockfighting was a sport of kings.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Debits to individual accounts as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 22, aggregated $7,247,000,000, or 1 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, and 12 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

PORTLAND, Me., May 25. -- The first 12-foot vault ever made by Paavo Waltonen, a determined young Finnish-American youth from Boston, today enabled the Northeastern track team to gain its first New England intercollegiate title with only one-twelfth of a point to spare.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 25. -- Skids marked the resumption today of qualifying trials for the 500-mile race to be run Thursday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

THE cruise season is again at hand. All up and down Fifth Avenue tourist agents sit smugly in their ivory towers, babbling of Norway and Sweden, France, England, Russia and Iceland. Department stores circularize the world with smooth paper portraits of les chapeaux nouveaux pour la rue de la Paix -- or just plain boat deck.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 23. -- Texlahoma, a forty-ninth State in the Union, comprised of counties in Western Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle, with a combined population exceeding a million, would be created if a proposal being placed before citizens of both States were approved.

With the prospect of spending two and a half years studying architecture at the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris, four young students in somewhat guarded and mysterious fashion entered upon a three-week test period yesterday morning at the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects, 304 East Forty-fourth Street, to compete for the society's twenty-eighth annual award.

The new customs regulation which prescribes that incoming residents of the United States may bring in only one bottle of perfume of a given mark has caused a considerable increase in the volume of detail work for the inspectors and consequent delays in the examination of baggage.

VIENNA, May 25. -- Your correspondent learns on good authority that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg will deliver a speech to the Austrian Federal Council Wednesday which will be a reply to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's recent Reichstag address.

LONDON, May 25. -- A pessimistic picture of the outlook in the world if present policies are continued was given by Sir George Paish, distinguished economist, at the annual conference of the National Liberal Federation at Blackpool today.

AMERICA is wearying of excitement. For two years the nation, stirred profoundly, devoured the Roosevelt bread and watched, exhilarated, the Roosevelt circuses. Now, just past the midpoint of the President's first term, it is once again proving that group enthusiasm can endure only so long before reaction sets in.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 25. -- Springfield defeated Williams, 7 to 2, today, after being held scoreless for five innings by Walter Fuchs. In the sixth the Indians reached him for two runs and a four-run attack in the seventh inning clinched the game.
The world's welterweight championship will be the prize at stake when Jimmy McLarnin and Barney Ross clash for fifteen rounds, or less, in the ring at the Polo Grounds Tuesday night.
LONDON, May 25. -- The International Wheat Advisory Committee concluded today its present London sittings, which were devoted to discussing the future of the international wheat agreement.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- The league-leading White Sox pounced on four Washington pitchers today to score an 8-to-3 victory over the Senators, evening the series.

When the French Parliament convenes on Tuesday it will apparently be asked by the Flandin Government for emergency powers similar to those which POINCARE sought and obtained in 1926. France is experiencing a recurrence of economic and financial difficulties.

Lack of sufficient data to compare the wage scales, announced last week for the President's work-relief program, with the direct relief payments, hampered retailers in their analysis of what the work-relief program might mean in the way of trade stimulation.

The fingerprints found on the weapon which killed Theodore Raybourne are those of a man who has been dead for more than a year -- or so the records say. Stan Lake, a private detective, who is in the Raybourne house on another errand, undertakes to find out how this could be.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 25. -- Rita Machado, 18 years old, a niece of former President Machado of Cuba, was injured early today when an automobile in which she and five others were riding overturned in a collision in Pennsauken Township at what is known as "Dead Man's Corner."
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 25 (AP). -- The estate of Alfred I. du Pont was valued at $32,736,933.63 in a petition filed as his will was probated today.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- The Oliver Farm Equipment Company, convinced that more favorable times are ahead and that now is the time to write off capital losses, proposed today a plan of reorganization which will be voted upon June 25 at the annual meeting of stockholders.

It may be that hostilities between Italy and Ethiopia are postponed rather than averted by Premier MUSSOLINI'S sudden acceptance of that arbitration of his African difficulties, under the auspices of the League of Nations, which he had long been resisting. It may be that the war party saw no loss of purpose in agreeing to arbitration for the remainder of the period that troops cannot effectively operate in East Africa because of the rainy season.

ATHENS. -- As result of an eight-day revolution begun by Venizelist officers who feared that Premier Tsaldaris intended to bring back royalty to Greece, subdued by him with many denials that his pledge to support the republic had ever been in danger, Greece is facing a growing prospect that her throne, vacant for twelve years, will be occupied by a king.
CALLANDER, Ont., May 25 (AP). -- The Dionne quintuplets will be a year old Tuesday.

The American Civil Liberties Union took a hand yesterday in the case of three women technicians of the Columbia University Medical School, who charged they had been dismissed from the school because of their peace activities.

THE police of Brodshire are reluctant to ask for assistance in apprehending the murderer of Captain Scoles, Chief Constable of the county. They have what they consider convincing evidence as to the identity of the murderer, and they do not anticipate much difficulty in finding the man.

CERTAIN phases of floral decoration are just now beginning to receive full appreciation by the majority of flower lovers. Although the types of arrangement are far from new, they have endless possibilities for the creation of original and unusual designs.

DETROIT, May 23. -- The announcement of the return Of the $6-a-day minimum wage to Ford Motor Company employes, coming fourteen months after the forced reduction of the minimum to $5 a day during the worst of the depression, is a reiteration of Henry Ford's faith in his own "share-the-wealth" program, voluntarily embarked upon in January, 1914.

In shooting at the Bonus Bill, President ROOSEVELT aimed also at other targets. His veto message really contains a program which he has laid down for his Administration. It will be against all forms of inflation of the currency, which would have been involved in the Patman bill.

If you are fed up with those supermen, the brilliant amateur detectives who are always compelling the reluctant admiration of their rivals on the regular police force, then you should by all means meet Michael Vestry. Mike is an earnest young man who is convinced, as who is not, that there is something wrong with the world. He believes that the remedy lies in the strict application of scientific principles.

SUMMER usually offers broadcasters, dissatisfied with their time schedules, an opportunity to shift to what may be considered more productive hours. Those who sign off for the Summer generally relinquish time and waves which others may capture by contracts.

A boom in inboard racing this season on the eastern regatta circuit is indicated by the registration this month of sixteen new craft with Commodore Charles F. Chapman, secretary of the American Power Boat Association Racing Commission.

SWEEPING changes are being made by the British Broadcasting Corporation in the empire station at Daventry. The service may be said to have passed the experimental stage and to have embarked upon a new era of extensive development.

GENEVA, May 25. -- The last act of the League of Nations Council, the first regular session since Japan's effective withdrawal, was to meet in unusual secrecy this evening to consider one problem that this presents -- China's desire to get back her Council seat.

NEW YORK has still a little of the fishing village left, as may be seen in early June when the shad come up the Hudson on their way to the spawning grounds in the shallows of fresh water. Every year they come -- tens of thousands of good square meals.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 25. -- Taking revenge for a one-run defeat administered before an Alumni Day crowd last Saturday, Pennsylvania's baseball team today downed Princeton, 5 to 4, on University Field. Andy Barton went the route for the victors, holding the Tiger batsmen to eight hits and striking out four.

One phase of double taxation of estates as imposed by the Bureau of Internal Revenue was decisively defeated in a recent decision of the United States Supreme Court. (Ernest M. Bull, executor and trustee of the estate of Archibald H. Bull, deceased, against United States, decided April 29, 1935.)

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25. -- Harvard subdued Yale, 8 to 4, at lacrosse today, outscoring the Elis, 3 to 1, in the first period and increasing their lead in every succeeding period except the last, in which each team registered once.

SHOPWORN as the words "fascinating" and "stimulating" may be, one hardly could dispense with them in speaking of this book by Gina Kaus. After closing it one feels that it deserves a leading place in the season's biographical literature.

BERLIN, May 25. -- The Boerse was weak today. The downward tendency was attributed to realization selling by speculators and public indifference to the market. Lignites fell rapidly, Eintracht losing 3 1/2 points and Niederlaustizer declining 2 1/2.

Several beach clubs which for years have been popular with members of society on the North and South Shores of Long Island, as well as at Sound resorts of Westchester and Connecticut, have drawn up their plans for the Summer season. The forecast of the organizations this Spring indicates an active season of festivities and sports.

WOMEN and children first is not only the law of the sea. It is also the basic assumption on which Manhattan's economic and social life is predicated. Papa commutes from the suburbs so the kiddies can frolic in the sunshine and learn the facts of life from the birds and flowers.

MISS KERR'S new novel, which was originally serialized in The Saturday Evening Post, is a well-written narrative that without false sentiment or heroics, without villains or heroes, and without pseudo-profundity or other weaknesses of the professional popular magazine stories, holds the interest all the way through without insulting the intelligence.

HOLLYWOOD. WAY DOWN EAST" is coming back by way of the West. The play that raised the picture business from its nickelodeon depths into the realm of art, that inspired the first censorship drive and lured $14,000,000 from the customers' pockets is to reach the screen once more, this time under the wing of Fox and the personal supervision of Winfield Sheehan.

FEW rulers in the world are so well guarded as Joseph Stalin; and the measures of protection taken in behalf of the other key figures in the Soviet regime have been intensified since the assassination of Sergei M. Kiroff, who had been looked upon by many in the U.S.S.R. as the logical successor to Stalin, in the event that Stalin should pass from the scene.

The third annual contract tournament of the Long Island Bridge League will open on Monday, June 3, at the Eagle Building in Brooklyn. It will be the first metropolitan tournament played since the new international code of rules became effective March 31. Competition will continue until June 9.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Biff, a 14-to 1 shot in the betting, surprised 18,000 spectators today by winning the $5,000 added Chicago handicap, opening feature of the thirty-one- day meeting at Washington Park.

As soon as the Work-Relief Bill was passed it was a foregone conclusion that the Passamaquoddy project for harnessing the tides of Northeastern Maine would become a reality. Hardly had the President's signature dried when $10,000,000 was appropriated merely for the preliminary work.

The Textile High nine turned back Tottenville by 11 -- 4 at the losers' field yesterday for its thirteenth triumph of the season and its eighth straight victory in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division of the P.S.A.L. tournament. Romersa, Textile hurler, allowed only seven hits while his mates collected fourteen.

LONDON. ALEXANDER THE GREAT" KORDA, as some enthusiastic admirers insist on calling this modest little Hungarian, marches steadily on his way to primacy in the British film world. Mr. Korda came to England with a high reputation won in Hollywood, but to the general public here his name was unknown until his production of "The Private Life of Henry VIII" put him in the front line of directors.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 25. -- It is still too early to see clearly what will be the final effect of last Sunday's elections on the government, but it is clear that the existing coalition under Premier Jan Malypetr will have to find new allies.

WHILE this book is an admirable and comprehensive handbook for making and playing fist puppets, it is really a more inclusive and more generally interesting volume than that term usually connotes, because of its author's wide and intimate knowledge of her subject and her enthusiastic belief in its possibilities.

Cooler weather last week resulted in lighter receipts of fresh vegetables from Long Island and other near-by sections in the wholesale markets, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, head of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

A POOL is always an addition to the rock garden. At the base of the moraine or in any low spot, with a bit of boggy ground about, it increases the effect of a miniature landscape as well as affording the gardener an opportunity to grow certain moisture-loving plants which will not tolerate ordinary rockery conditions.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Nearly a million persons on relief and thousands of relief workers temporarily severed from the payroll are feeling easier in their minds today. Passage of the Horner Sales Tax Bill, shorn of its emergency clause, has stimulated strong hope that the Federal authorities will extend immediate aid.

THE dreaded iceberg is already sending liners and other ships into the Summer transatlantic lanes. Ice moving rapidly from the north has just led steamship companies to use Track "A," the most southerly route, for the first time in several years.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 25. -- J. P. Morgan's black and gold yacht Corsair, which generally rides at anchor at Morgan Memorial Park here about this time of year, signalizing unofficially the opening of the yachting season, will not be at her mooring this season, it was disclosed today.

A 6,000-MILE stretch of the Transsiberian Railroad, from Manchouli to Moscow, crossing the Siberian plains and the Urals, is a unit of the route that will be taken this Summer by six groups of travelers on their way around the world. The first group will sail June 8 from Seattle via the American Mail Line and others will sail at intervals during the Summer.

ROCHESTER, May 25. -- With French and American flags waving in unison, Western New York farmers, who inherited from the Jesuit missionaries the art of apple culture, saw pretty 17-year-old Irma Carolyn Singleton of Lockport crowned their "apple blossom queen" at near-by Brockport today by Count Charles de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General at New York.
Behind some brilliant relief pitching by Marcus Russo, the Long Island University nine defeated St. John's University, 5 to 4, in a fast ten-inning game at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Liquidation by holders of May grain contracts was under way today on the Board of Trade, although it was not so general as yesterday. May corn led the decline and sold off 1 7/8 cents at the extreme to a low of 83 cents a bushel, which was 7 cents under the high point of the week.
IN some localities one of the most annoying of garden troubles is the hollyhock rust. It not only makes the hollyhock unsightly and weakens them, but it will destroy the plants if left unchecked.

PARIS, May 25. -- Soon after the convocation of Parliament Tuesday, the Government will place before it several bills to reorganize and strengthen the military forces and to meet the large expenses that program will entail. Parliament will also be asked to ratify heavy extra expenditures during the parliamentary recess for national defense.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- This government would welcome an early international agreement on currency stabilization and reduction of trade barriers and is willing to take the initiative in calling together the leading countries of the world to confer on ways and means, it was learned today from an authoritative source.

One of the reasons veteran and seasoned skippers of power cruisers avoid rocks, sand bars and mud banks and bring their yachts to a railway in October with hulls as undamaged as they were in May is because they have learned to rely on the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey.

TAKE the Little fellow first. He's the top amateur golfer of the world by a long shot, even if a Birmingham dentist was pretty close to him in the breezy stretch on the Lancashire shore yesterday. Banging onward toward the finishing pole, Lawson's game began to give just a trifle at the seams, and there was the persistent dentist prying away at the Little lead and begging him to "open a little wider, please."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 25. -- North Shore society was largely represented this evening in an audience of nearly 1,000 at a performance of the opera, "Cavalleria Rusticana," with scenes from "Il Trovatore," and "The Flying Dutchman," in the Huntington High School auditorium.

THOSE who boast or deplore the fact that woman's place is no longer exclusively in the home may be surprised to learn that, although the female of the species gets about more than she used to, she still seems more cautious than man in her goings and comings.

The operations of eleven Bell System companies during the first quarter of this year showed gross revenues $1,715,412 ahead of the same period in 1934, but net earnings, after expenses, taxes and depreciation were $2,216,615 below the 1934 period, making the 1935 position $3,932,027 less favorable from the standpoint of security holders than last year.

The remaining furnishings of Ivy Hall, Jericho, L.I., the country residence of the late Judge Elbert H. Gary and Mrs. Gary, will be offered at auction tomorrow morning on the premises under the auspices of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

IN marked contrast with the silence that fell over ships of old when they sailed away on maiden voyages, the new French liner Normandie will be virtually a broadcasting station from the time the giant craft shoves off from Havre on May 29 until she is serenaded in New York harbor on June 3. Short waves will flash novel programs shoreward throughout the voyage and the networks will rebroadcast.

EXAMINATION of this handsome two-volume work arouses admiration for the qualities that went into its making -- the long, patient, scholarly and exhaustive research covering every phase of its subject, the carefully sorted and classified arrangement, the presentation with its style adapted to the character of the material under treatment.

The main mystery theme in this story deals with the attempts of Paul Randolph to run down the criminals who kidnapped his father, accepted ransom money for his return and failed to keep their part of the bargain. Paul has learned that a $20 bill, part of the ransom, money, has turned up at a place called Harmonton, and he goes there under an assumed name in search of further information.

ANOTHER of those thick red octavos has been added to the long series of annual auction records known as "American Book-Prices Current." This institution has been forty years agrowing and the present volume indicates a landmark, not only because of the rounding out of a decade, but because it shows definite signs that it has reached the interesting age where life is beginning to stir again.

LONDON, May 25. -- Whatever mental reservations the British Government may have concerning the sincerity of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's latest peace proposals, its members will proceed immediately on the assumption that the proposals are genuine and offer another opportunity to stave off an impending armament race.

Tribute to Robert Moses as Park Commissioner was paid yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at a luncheon given in Mr. Moses's honor in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center by the Municipal Art Society and other civic organizations. Mr. La Guardia also praised the cooperation of Federal agencies and President Roosevelt which, he said, has made extensive park improvements possible.

Suggestions that assessments levied for old-age benefits and unemployment insurance under the pending Federal social security legislation be combined into one tax and that funds collected annually for pensions be gauged to meet only the approximate current disbursements are contained in a special report sent to its membership yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
LAS VEGAS, N.M., May 25 (AP). -- Mrs. Emily Davies Vanderbilt Thayer Whitfield, who committed suicide at her Dead Horse Ranch home Thursday night, will be buried in New York.

When the yachtsman lays a course eastward, whether for fishing or for just a lazy, vacationing sort of a pleasure cruise that may last a week-end or a fortnight, he is certain to make use of two of the oldest harbors on Long Island. The twin anchorages of Greenport and Dering Harbor have played a role since the days when boating consisted only of the paddled canoes and dugouts of the Indians.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, May 26. -- A clear victory for continuation of the wheat production adjustment program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration in 1936 was indicated by accumulating returns from yesterday's referendum of the nation's wheat farmers.
Plans made to continue the 12-cent loan for the 1935 crop sent prices on the Cotton Exchange 2 to 15 points higher yesterday to close at the top.

Sixty-eight per cent of the graduating class of Columbia College will continue their studies in graduate and professional schools after receiving the Bachelor of Arts degree in June, it was disclosed yesterday by Nicholas M. McKnight, associate dean.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Pressing relentlessly on behind the machine-like screwball delivery of Carl Hubbell, the Giants today wrenched the final encounter of their three-game series from the Cubs, 3 to 2, leaving a gathering of 12,500 feeling both puzzled and depressed.

Memorial services for two New York University professors whose inventions contributed "to world civilization and the advancement of all mankind" will be held next Tuesday afternoon at the university's downtown centre by the Greenwich Village Historical Society and the State Education Department.

IN "First Symphony" Mr. Pulsifer offers us eighty-three sonnets, unified by a common theme and built into an architectonic whole. For a sonnet "sequence" is more than a sequence of sonnets. Hence Mr. Pulsifer's poems must be judged both on their merits as individual pieces and as a unit.

VIENNA, May 15, 1935. THE musical world owes a debt of gratitude to Dr. Paul Stefan of Vienna for his recently published edition of Otakar Sourek's life of Dvorak. It is a singular fact that, apart from the Czech Sourek's four volume work (the first part of which appeared in 1916, the last in 1933), no adequate full-length biography of Dvorak exists.

For a brief space yesterday at the Stadium 27,000 baseball fans were resigned to an even split for the Yankees in their first double-header of the season against Rogers Hornsby's St. Louis Browns. But in the end the McCarthymen romped off with both ends of the twin bill. The scores were 3 to 1 and 8 to 7.

THE Annapolis Valley of Nova Scotia, made classic by Longfellow's "Evangeline" -- the largest stretch of apple country in the British Empire -- will celebrate during the first three days of June, the 302d anniversary of the first blossoming of its apple trees.

NEW ORLEANS, May 24. -- The law firm of Long Sandoz plans an active season when Senator Huey P. Long, senior member of the firm, returns to Louisiana from his duties in Washington. This newly organized legal firm with only two members has been appointed attorneys for the Louisiana Tax Commission, a body named by Governor O.K. Allen admittedly at the suggestion of Senator Long.

ST. PIERRE, Miquelon, May 25 (AP). -- A future bleak as the surf-swept rocks of the three tiny islands which comprise this remnant of France's once mighty North American empire tonight faced the colony's handful of fishermen habitants.

The Society of Stoopnocracy, a philanthropic organization functioning under a motto of "Charity With Hilarity," has taken over the Moonlit Terrace of the Biltmore for June 4 as a pro-opening celebration for the benefit of the Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

AMHERST, Mass., May 25. -- Wesleyan downed Amherst, 12 -- 4, in a Little Three game today, the visitors reaching three Amherst pitchers for eleven hits and taking advantage of seven Amherst errors. Epple, Amherst first baseman hit safely three times to lead in batting for the day, while Palumbo hit well for Wesleyan.

Commander Douglas H. Eadie, head of the Staten Island squadron, newest unit of the United States power squadrons, announced yesterday that fourteen men and three women had finished the instruction course in small-boat piloting and received their certificates.

ST. PAUL, May 25. -- Nine-year-old George Weyerhaeuser, kidnapped in Tacoma, is a great-grandson of Frederick Weyerhaeuser, son of a German immigrant who started working in a sawmill at $1 a day and died a millionaire, having founded the great Weyerhaeuser timber empire.

Those familiar with the Orient will recall the tremendous post-war boom enjoyed by the city of Shanghai, the centre of our sphere of influence in the Chinese Republic. The boom continued long after the depression overtook the rest of the world.

GREENVILLE, Me., May 25. -- Using a specially designed fishing fly named for Governor Louis K. Brann, Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania today successfully emerged from a hard-fought battle with an eight-pound trout, the largest caught thus far during Governor Brann's party of 200 on a three-day fishing excursion at Moosehead Lake.

James Harvey Rogers, Professor of Political Economy at Yale and Fellow of Pierson College, has become a member of the advisory committee of the Geneva School of International Studies, Professor Alfred Zimmern of Oxford University, director of the school, announced yesterday.

VILFREDO PARETO was born in Paris in 1848; he died in Switzerland in 1923. He was the son of a French mother and of an Italian father, a patrician of Genoa and an exiled patriot of the Risorgimento. The boy was taken to Turin at the age of 11, when his father, who was an engineer of some prominence, accepted a post on the Italian railways.

At a conference with labor union officials and administration advisers on Friday, President Roosevelt committed himself to the principles of the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, a proposal which has been hailed by leading unionists as the Magna Charta of Labor and condemned by industrialist on the ground that it would mean government-imposed.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 25. -- The Brooklyn Cricket Club triumphed over the Newark Cricket Club by a margin of 69 runs today at Watsessing Park. The Newark players batted first and were all out for 61, to which A. Conners contributed a well-earned 39, not out.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Special administration efforts to meet labor criticism of the work program wage scale were disclosed today as the total asked by Federal agencies from the $4,000,000,000 fund jumped $195,163,350 to nearly $237,000,000.

IN five years student membership in the National Orchestral Association, of which Leon Barzin is conductor, has grown from 105, the total for the season of 1930-31, to 167 in the season of 1934-35, according to a summary of its activities issued by the organization.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Payment in 1934 of $250,000 compensation to Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, and $180,000 to Eugene G. Grace, president, was disclosed in the corporation's registration statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 25. -- Colgate won both games of a double header from Syracuse today, taking the first by 7 -- 5 and annexing the second by 10 -- 2. Ed Hickey allowed Syracuse only two hits in the nightcap.
Mr. and Mrs. Clarence G. Sheffield of 975 Park Avenue gave a dinner last night in the Pierre roof garden. Their guests included:
HARTFORD, Conn., May 25. -- A Harvard pew end, presented by a group of Harvard men, will be unveiled and dedicated in Trinity College Chapel at vesper service tomorrow afternoon.

DENVER -- Once again the silver camps stir with life. For Leadville, Creeds, Aspen and a score of other forgotten hamlets of the San Juan range a revival of the prosperous, prodigal days of the Eighties and Nineties is predicted.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25. -- Harvard struck at the Yale Field jinx with considerable vehemence today to rout both the Eli jinx and the Eli track team with the same deft motion. For the first time in twenty years the Blue bowed to the Crimson at New Haven, the Cantabs making this particular victory quite emphatic with a 22-point margin, 78 1/2 to 56 1/2.

ALBANY, May 25. -- The commission created by the Legislature to make a survey of State aid and the financial and tax relations between the State Government and its municipalities was announced at the Executive chamber today.
Policemen killed on duty were likened to the heroes of a war yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine at the annual memorial exercises at Police Headquarters.

PLEASED with the success of her correspondence with the Apostles -- a thoroughly one-sided correspondence, to be sure -- published as "By Post to the Apostles," Mrs. Homan has written a new series of cheery, gossipy notes addressed to Saint Francis of Assisi and his friars -- Bernard, Giles, Juniper, Elias and Leo.

The heroic dead of United States wars will be widely honored here on Memorial Day, Thursday. Parades and exercises will be held throughout the metropolitan area. There also will be services today in many churches, as well as other observances.

THIS is a Roman Catholic novel, conceived in the religious spirit and dedicated to the Catholic conception of human brotherhood. As a social document it conforms to the spirit of the recent papal labor encyclical and the views of the English Distributists.

MADISON, Wis., May 25. -- Governor Philip F. La Follette's $209,000,000 State recovery plan, to be initially financed by $100,000,000 from the Federal works relief fund, is already the target for a Democratic attack and opposing forces are preparing for a bitter fight next week.

Miss Hope Gatins heads a group of younger members of society aiding in the arrangements for the supper dance in aid of the Vanderbilt Clinic Auxiliary which will take place on Tuesday at the House of Lords. A feature of the entertainment will be an "Amateur Audition," in which several young men and women without previous professional experience will take part.
LONDON, May 25. -- The greatest satisfaction is felt in London that wise statesmanship prevailed to avert a threat of open hostilities in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute.
Under powerful floodlights, about 500 men an dboys vied last night in the swirling dust of the Lewisohn Stadium for the metropolitan bugle, fife and drum corps championships.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., May 25. -- The annual May luncheon and the presentation of two one-act comedies were features of the season's final meeting of the College Club of the Oranges held today in the Woman's Club of Maplewood. About 200 members were present.

A world weary of strife and hungry once more for the fundamentals of Christianity was described yesterday morning by General Evangeline Booth, international head of the Salvation Army, who returned late Friday night to New York City after making a three-month tour of Europe, Asia, Australia, New Zealand and the United States.

THE first drawings ever made by an English artist in North America have turned up at the British Museum, where they are rapidly becoming a centre of interest for all students of early Americana. They were done by John White, who was Governor of Sir Walter Raleigh's Virginia Colony in 1585 and in time became the grandfather of Virginia Dare, the first English child born in America.

CLIFF BERGERE, who claims the distinction of being the first man to leap from a speeding plane onto a motor boat going forty miles an hour, pulled himself out of the wreckage of a smashed automobile, dusted his clothes and grinned up at the camera man.

The low yield of high-grade bonds, coupled with fears of inflation, is causing some Wall Street investors to study the merits of lending funds to beneficiaries of large trust estates, taking the trusts themselves as security. Although relatively rare in this country, security trust loans, are well established in London, where there are numerous "reversionary interest" concerns, one of which is more than eighty years old.

A little known source of collateral for bank loans to railroads is disclosed in the reports of the railroads for 1934. This source consists of advances made by the railroads to the Railway Express Agency, which they control, and which in some instances run into millions of dollars.

Employment for more than 500 men and women and instruction and entertainment for 48,000 persons weekly have been provided by a program of music education and music in recreation, according to a report submitted yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, by Mrs. Frances McFarland, manager of the works division's educational and social music unit.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 25. -- An amateur hunt-race meet will be held here under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds, on Decoration Day, on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

THERE were flush times in the show business when Broadway first saw a piece called "Seven Keys to Baldpate," which The Players are reviving tomorrow, for one week only, as their annual festival offering. The Players, soaked in the traditions of their founder, Edwin Booth, used to revive only Shakespeare or Sheridan, or "The Beaux's Strategem," or similar mellow classics.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 25 (AP). -- Miss Mary E. Hughes of Louisville, who headed the Women's Division of NRA, today called upon women of the nation to present a solid front for continuing the National Recovery Act "as long as the President desires."

IN "Three Englishmen" Gilbert Frankau has gone to the roots of English life for a story which, despite its length mud its leisurely pace, must impress many readers with its soundness and its fidelity. It will not impress all readers, particularly those who believe that the world was profoundly changed by Freud and by the war.

This account of the boyhood of the great Jewish philosopher comes under the heading of books written to supply information and owes its interest to the striking and famous central figure rather than to anything in the writing or construction of this story-biography.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin came to New York last week with his campaign to turn his National Union for Social Justice into an "articulate, organized lobby of the people." At Madison Square Garden Wednesday night he addressed 23,000 persons (5,000 of them in the basement, where they could hear but could not see him).

Madison Square Garden, in the heart of New York City, says the eminent Professor Wotan von Dunkel, is a perfect expression of the anarchy that dominates life among the North Americans. Anything is liable to happen in Madison Square Garden, and usually does in the course of a season.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 25. -- A strong Lawrenceville track and field combination captured the New Jersey State prep school title for the fourth consecutive year at Peddie School today as nearly 300 scholastic athletes competed in the seventeenth annual championships.

THE return of legal liquor has brought back the demand for diamond-back terrapin, and on Grand Isle, La., is one of the greatest "farms" in the world. There during the last twenty years more than 1,000,000 terrapin have been hatched, raised and barreled; they have been shipped by boat and train into the great restaurants of the country, especially those along the Atlantic seaboard.
New Utrecht High School's more or less perennial track champions won the invitation meet sponsored by George Washington High School yesterday at Washington Stadium.

The American Petroleum Institute will not send a representative to the meeting called for May 28 in Washington by Wirt Franklin, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, to consider the extension of the NIRA and permanent oil legislation such as the Thomas bill, according to a letter from Axtell J. Byles, president of the institute, to Mr. Franklin.

Pounding three City College pitchers for a total of eighteen hits, the Manhattan College nine routed the Beavers, 19 to 7, in the second game of their home-and-home series yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. The game was cut to seven innings by agreement.

THE author of this excellent history of the World War is a veteran of the tragic struggle and a scholar of distinction. His treatment is non-technical. He has had access to the best authorities. As he says in his preface,

DUBLIN. -- Since his return from his recent trip Alderman Alfred Byrne, Lord Mayor of Dublin, has been busy conferring with Irish trade organizations on the question of initiating a vigorous Irish trade drive in the United States.

After a long and distinguished career at Scotland Yard, Inspector Cardby retires and opens a private detective agency, taking his young son Michael as a partner. In this, the story of their first case, Michael runs away with all the honors.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 25. -- The Spring Flower Show of the Mount Vernon Garden Club was held here this afternoon in the gymnasium of the Washington Junior High School.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- President Roosevelt will probably sign an order early next week, making it possible for the $900,000,000 land-use and rural rehabilitation program of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program to get under way immediately.

To one who has devoted his business life to banking, who long since discovered the way to the heart of the client is of necessity through the pocketbook, an approach as intimate as that of priest or doctor, the campaign against bankers as a class evidences loose and shallow thinking and is a dangerous type of generalization.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 25. -- Two world's records in model airplane flights were broken at Hadley Airport near here today as more than 250 model airplane enthusiasts from ten States took part in the annual Eastern outdoor airplane contest of the L. Bamberger Aero Club and the Model Airplane News.

"We Italians are very circumspect before reaching any decision, but once we have made up our minds we march straight toward our objective and never turn back," Signor Mussolini told a great crowd of war veterans and Fascists Friday in Rome. This apparent reference to the Italian-Ethiopian quarrel was loudly cheered.

RYE, N.Y., May 25. -- Sailing in light, fitful breezes, forty-eight boats in a dozen classes opened the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound's championship series today in a regatta conducted by the American Yacht Club.

LET us assume, for the sake of a Sunday article, that it is possible to regard Miss Bergner without excitement. Then we can say that in the fine British screen version of "Escape Me Never" she does not explode on our senses with quite that air of an unexpected miracle which marked her Broadway appearance in the play.

PITTSBURGH, May 25. -- Rising to the glorious heights of his heyday, Babe Ruth, the sultan of swat, crashed out three home runs against the Pittsburgh Pirates today but they were not enough and the Boston Braves took a 11-to-7 defeat before a crowd of 10,000 at Forbes Field.

Recent announcement that a leading store may act to refinance the preferred stock of one of its major subsidiaries in order to take advantage of the lower rates prevailing in the money market has attracted widespread interest in retail circles.

PROGRESSIVE change in the development of racing cars is exemplified at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in this year's crop of speed machines entered in the annual 500-mile Memorial Day race next Thursday.

TORONTO, Ont., May 25. -- Twenty-nine gold mines in Ontario, milling an average aggregate of 18,630 tons of rock every twenty-four hours, have reported for April a production of gold bullion valued at $5,598,123, or an average recovery of approximately $10 a ton in Canadian funds.

A percentage of the proceeds of a series of four luncheons to be held in the near future at the Versailles will be devoted to the need of the Goddard Neighborhood Centre. The first luncheon will be held on Tuesday, when a feature of the entertainment will be a showing of the latest costumes for vacation and beach wear.

HAVING been away from Tulluco for two years or so and having done a good job in capturing a murderer and taking him out of that nest of bad men, Lelargo, and, moreover, being tired of rambling about and fighting other men's battles, young Red Clark had come to the point of wanting to settle down.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 25. -- Following the leadership of its newly elected president, Leslie C. McDouall of Newark, the New Jersey Bankers Association went on record today as unanimously opposed to the proposed Banking Act of 1935 in its present form.

A plan to make "inquiries" into the plight of Protestant opposition churches in Germany, for whose aid requests have come to the American Section of the Universal Christian Council for Life and Work, was adopted last week at the annual Spring meeting of the council at the George Washington Hotel.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., May 25. -- Charles Merritt, 27-year-old pilot, of 409 King Street, Port Chester, N.Y., and Ross Sayers, 15 years old, of 601 West 190th Street, were slightly injured today in taking off in an airplane from the Langeloth estate here, where they made a forced landing after encountering motor trouble.

Twelve-year-old Charles de Tavara, who has been missing for a month from the home of his mother, Countess Beatrice de Tavara, at 250 West Seventy-third Street, was found yesterday in the children's shelter of the Briar Hill Welfare Home at Freehold, N.J.

Six subsidiaries of companies whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange notified the Exchange yesterday that they did not intend to apply for permanent registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The companies and their securities were as follows:

Bunching all five of its hits in two innings, the undefeated New York Athletic Club nine yesterday scored a 4-3 victory over New York University at Travers Island. It was the third successive victory for the Winged Footers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- With upward of a thousand guests expected at the Greenbrier by the middle of the week, the colony here for the Memorial Day week-end is expected to be exceptionally large.

PARIS, May 25. -- The Mayor of Sens, Dr. Andre Dupechez, was lured into an ambush early this morning and left for dead after having been badly beaten. It was first thought that his skull had been fractured, but the doctors now believe that it is not and hope to save his life.
DODGE CITY, Kan. -- Rain in the high plains country, the heaviest in four years, has done more than restore the morale of the farming empire. Following are some of the results of the precipitation:

ANNAPOLIS, May 25. -- Unlike several of the celebrations of recent years, "June Week" at the Naval Academy for 1935 will be wholly within the month from which it takes it name, and will not cut into the last few days of May, as has been the custom.

Of all the authors who are today writing informational books for little children none do so with more imaginative understanding than the Petershams. "The Story Book of Earth's Treasures" is as successful and even more attractive than "The Story Book of the Things We Use."

IN "The Pragmatic Revolt in Politics," Professor Elliott traced through its various forms the recent reaction against the "political rationalism" of parliamentary democracy in Europe, with special reference to fascism. He now applies the pragmatic test to the Constitution of the United States and proposes a drastic plan for reforming it.

TEN years have passed since the appearance of Miss Keating's first novel, "Fame," a book which, if nothing else unusual, was an astonishing production to have been written by a girl of 16. Her fourth and latest is naturally a large improvement upon her first, in characterizations, purpose, material and all other departments.

HERE comes that same H.V. Morton who went "In Search of" England, Wales, Ireland, Scotland with such fascinating results. His thousands of American readers who have been charmed by the historical imagination, the poetic vision, the sensitive appreciation of beauty and human interest, the recreative description of his travel books will find here very different kind of volume.

Is there a common Christian life, a unifying Christian faith? Catholics and Protestants alike call themselves Christians, worship the same God, follow the same Master, read the same Bible, aspire after the same holiness. Is the unity to which these common experiences point great enough to make the Christian's church one in fact and not merely one in name?

About 100 young men will be selected from among the applicants for training as "aviation cadets" in the Third Naval District, it was announced yesterday by Lieutenant R.F. Hickey, commanding officer of the Naval Reserve Aviation Base at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn. Applications will be received at the airport, where the candidates will be examined.

THIS Margaret Mead is a dangerous person. She goes down to New Guinea, studies primitive tribes for two years and comes back with a book like a bomb that she drops into the complacent, fundamental conviction of the Occidental world, both scientific and social, that the sexes are innately different in their psychological attributes and that the male is dominant by right of brain and brawn.

John McAuliffe, who recently resigned as chairman of the American Steamship Owners Association because he disagreed with other members on shipping legislation, asserted yesterday that he considered government subsidy for merchant shipping essential.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 25. -- Although seniors at New Jersey College for Women consider Franklin D. Roosevelt the greatest living international figure, they favor the Republican party. This was disclosed in the annual senior poll, in which the members of the graduating class selected Secretary of Labor Perkins as the woman they most admire in contemporary life.

NEWCASTLE, County Down, Ireland, May 25 (AP). -- Miss Grace Amory of West Palm Beach, Fla., drew Mlle. F. Tollon of St. Cloud, France, as her opponent for the first round of match play Monday, after qualifying today in the women's British open golf championship with a thirty-six-hole total of 165.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25. -- "State Legislatures of the nation have done more in the last three months to restrict the liberties of citizens than was clone during the whole of the World War," it was declared tonight by Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Social Philosophy at the New York School of Social Research, at the fifty-fifth annual convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations of New Jersey in the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here.

Adolf Hitler laid down last week the terms upon which he is ready to make peace with Europe. For many weeks he had been on the defensive while French, British, Italian and Russian diplomats traveled, negotiated and signed agreements. Last week it was his turn.
ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- The veteran Bill Hallahan starred in a relief role today as the Cards romped away with the final of the series with the Dodgers, 10 to 3.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 25. -- Frankie Parker of Lawrenceville and Jack Behr of Scarborough, first and second seeded players, advanced to the final round of the Princeton interscholastic singles tennis tournament today. Parker won from Carlton Rood of Poly Prop, while Behr conquered Gerard Podesta of Montclair Academy.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Although the first major skeet tournament of the season does not occur until next week, the second annual Virginia State championship with an open class for out-of-State shooters on June 7 and 8, skeet has already taken the leading place in the sports life of the community.

CINCINNATI, May 25. -- Two memorials were presented today to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America asking it to investigate the Presbyteries of Philadelphia and near-by Chester.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 25. -- Seated in the bow cockpit of the referee's launch, President Roosevelt today traversed three times the famous regatta course of the Naval Academy as he watched the crews of Harvard, his Alma Mater; the University of Pennsylvania and Navy test their strength in the Adams Cup races.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- Princeton University lightweights closed a successful season by winning the varsity 150-pound race for the Joseph Wright Challenge Cup in the thirty-first annual American Henley on the Schuylkill River today.

IT is perhaps strange that the State of New York should have waited until 1935 to enter upon a campaign to attract tourists, residents and industries. The New England States, Florida, California and other Commonwealths long ago advertised themselves to the nation, but New York has failed to exploit its merits.

Three bandits with no respect for the police held up the owners of the concern of Freedman, Cohen Horn and seven other fur workers yesterday in the firm's shop at 150 West Thirtieth Street, within 200 feet of the West Thirtieth Street police station.

RECENTLY an appeal was sent to the State Commissioner of Education urging him to take action toward reducing the size of classes in New York City public schools. Documented with numerous citations and supported by educators, administrators and teachers, the appeal set forth advantages that might follow such reductions.

OMAHA, Neb., May 23. -- The most important consideration of the administration's work-relief wage scale in the Middle West is its relationship with farm wages. Of 297 counties in Iowa, Nebraska and Kansas, 217, with more than half the population of the section, are in the 5,000 to 25,000 classification.
The advent of the 1935 nautical season will be marked with the establishment of two new yacht clubs on the North Shore of Long Island and a reorganized unit in the region of the Great South Bay.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- An organized effort by women to counteract by oratory what she termed "the demagogues deliberately influencing mass sentiment" was suggested today by Grace Morrison Poole, retiring president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

More than 250 members of the Democratic Junior League attended a luncheon, bridge and fashion show yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Ambassador in honor of Miss Estelle J. Bonner, retiring president of the organization. The proceeds were given to the league's social service bureau for the assistance of needy families.
