MISS MONROE, the founder of the magazine Poetry and the friendly editor of so many poets to this day, and the veteran, as she says, of two or three poetic revolutions, has written verse for forty-odd years with a singular consistency of mood and style.

BERLIN. THE three books which lie before me today would make particularly fine gifts, I believe, though the first two presuppose recipients of widely different taste and mental outlook. The appearance of all three volumes is extraordinarily luxurious, and their beauty is enhanced by interesting illustrations.

The family of Frederick Todd of Montclair, N.J., who committed suicide on Thursday, refused yesterday to give permission for Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader, to make public the manuscript of a book written by Mr. Todd. It was said on behalf of the family that no statement would be made until after the funeral tomorrow.

NANKlNG. -- Political activity as a means of increasing Chinese influence in Tibet is not now contemplated by the National Government, according to leaders of the Chinese mission to Lhasa where posthumous honors were conferred upon the late Dalai Lama.

LONDON. -- Mr. Ramsay MacDonald makes no secret any longer to his intimates of his irrevocable decision to retire from the post of Prime Minister. This means that before the month of June is out Stanley Baldwin will have to accept the succession and reconstruct his government.

IN this period of continued unrest in Europe. when threats of war and of social revolution { loom on the horizon, the livesI of public figures are more than ever endangered. Four men in particular -- Adolf Hitler. Josef Stalin. Benito Mussolini and Mustapha Kemal-are so exposed.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 25. -- The Blue boat defeated the Gold four-oared crew today in the regatta which was among the features of the annual intramural activities at Choate School. The winner's margin was a length and a quarter.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BOSTON, May 25. -- The local wool market has been sensationally active during the last three weeks and prices have been strong. The turnover so far this month is estimated at 50,000,000 pounds and quotations are up approximately 20 per cent on the average.

BALTIMORE, May 25. -- Principals in all the public schools of Baltimore have until Fall to rid their schools of all parent-teacher associations affiliated with the Maryland or the National Congress, Arthur S. Richmond, president of the Baltimore City Council of Parents and Teachers, said today.

Draw an engineer or a chemist into a discussion of our economic problem and his solution is simple: Give us more discoveries and inventions. He cites the telephone, the automobile, radio and a hundred inventions to prove that he and his kind create new industries, satisfy new wants, make more work.

Tautog, or blackfish, are running in sizable schools in the rocky sections of parts of Cape Cod and along the south shore, according to word from Raymond J. Kenney, director of the Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Game.

A SHADE dolorous is the latest theatrical news from London, with an after-the-party air about it. Granting even that the jubilee could not last forever, and with it those happy nights at the box-office, last night's mortality list does seem a bit severe.

OUR MARY: In Seattle Tuesday night Mary Pickford returned to the legitimate stage, playing the title role in "Coquette," her first full-length drama appearance in twenty-six years. She took fifteen curtain calls, and the newspaper critics said: "A triumph brilliant and complete" (Post-Intelligencer); "Her performance was superlative throughout" (Times); and "The star's handling of the second and third acts highlighted an effective performance" (Star).

District Attorney William C. Dodge said yesterday that he has not received the list of six lawyers from the March grand jury from which he is expected to select a special prosecutor to conduct the grand jury's inquiry into vice, bail bond and policy rackets. He said that if he were not satisfied with any attorney named in the first list, the grand jury would submit a second.

TACOMA, Wash., May 25. -- The family of George Weyerhaeuser, 9 years old, lumber fortune heir kidnapped and held for $200,000 ransom, began negotiations with his abductors tonight for his safe return.

THE Spring and Summer of Felicity Ann Carter's twenty-first year provide a maze of happenings that make a happy, harmless tale. There is romance in abundance and a bit of intrigue, with the beauty of the story -- who wasn't Felicity Ann -- doubling in the part of the villain.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25. -- Yale defeated Cornell, 9 to 1, today before 2,000 spectators in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game and evened the annual series between the two universities. The triumph also gave the Elis sole possession of third place.

Falling oil pressure, which caused an overheated motor, forced Laura Ingalls, noted woman aviator, to land at Indianapolis at 7:45 o'clock last night (New York daylight time) on her flight to set a nonstop transcontinental record between Los Angeles and New York.
PARIS, May 23. -- Sharing the honors with the dazzling jeweled and feathered headdresses noted at the Saison de Paris diadem dinner were chignons composed of natural Parma violets or moss roses.

ACROSS the grassy mountain plateau edged with conifers, above which tower rocky peaks, a dark herd is driven by shouting cowboys. The animals charge into a high pole corral nearly a mile long, which narrows down to a "V" point.

The election of 148 New York University undergraduates to office in student organizations for the academic year 1935-1936 was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary. The list includes students from Washington Square College, School of Commerce, School of Education and the University Heights colleges.

Political, social and cultural trends in Latin-American countries were set forth in a program of addresses and music which marked the eighth semi-annual convention of the Pan-American Student League of New York, held all day yesterday in the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University, 400 West 117th Street.

Marked strength in Italian bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday resulted from dispatches indicating Italy's agreement to arbitrate her dispute with Ethiopia. Italy 7s of 1951 rose 3 points in moderate trading, and Milan and Rome 6 1/2s made slightly wider gains for the day.

CHARLES D. STEWART'S gentle and engaging essays have been appearing in The Atlantic Monthly for some thirty years. They generally pivot about one or another of our "fellow creatures," and frequently the least conspicuous of them.

IT is the habit of Presidents to have a confidant -- an individual outside the Cabinet circle to whom they can take all of their pressing problems, with whom they can discuss the worries of the day, even debate and argue when occasion offers.

JUST as the observance of Memorial, or Decoration, Day has been extended to honor not only the heroes of the Civil War but all who have sacrificed their lives in the nation's service, so has the holiday period which accompanies it become one of travel not only to historic but to scenic and recreational spots all over the country.

WHEN old Vance Coulter was murdered by an unknown assailant he left two sons, the wastrel Chalk and the industrious, struggling Jim, and a ranch that was in a bad way. Rustlers were driving off the best of the cattle.
ROME, May 25. -- The text of Premier Mussolini's address on foreign policy to the Chamber of Deputies today follows:

Recent developments show a more encouraging outlook for copper. The improvement thus far is comparatively slight, but it rests on two good foundations. First and most dependable is a better demand here and abroad.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 25. -- Announcement of the election of undergraduates to Princeton campus organizations was made today by Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college, as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 25. -- Dartmouth increased its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by defeating the second place Harvard nine for the second time. The Indians have captured eight league games in nine played and with three more contests to play have a comfortable margin over the Crimson, who have won six against three losses.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 25. -- Commencement activities started at Highland Manor School and Junior College last night with the presentation of the annual awards in athletics at a banquet. Misses Carol Lehman of Tarrytown and Shirley Coons of 25 Central Park West, New York City, were guests of honor as the outstanding students in all school sports.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The War Department today honored three New York State men with the award of two Distinguished Service Crosses and one Distinguished Flying Cross.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 25. -- Dr. Friedrich Johannes Hauptmann, head of the German Department of the New Jersey College for Women, admitted today that he recently wrote to Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Propaganda, asking for "some material for cultural propaganda, not political propaganda," which he intended to send "all over the United States."

LI FU TO, 82 years old and whilom motion-picture player, has made an honorable peace with his ancestors over the matter of his work before the Black Box with the One Glass Eye. He stares Fate in the face as unblinkingly as Fate stares at his own years.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N,Y., May 25. -- Resolutions, discussion, and action by the Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, in convention here, centred today on what was termed an "ominous trend" toward discrimination against employment of women in the United States.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 25. -- Miss Hope Tyson and Edwin H. Griffin, who will be married here on June 8, were guests of honor at a supper given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. E.E. Snyder of Old Greenwich. Mr. Griffin's mother, Mrs. Leonard A. Griffin, will give a tea in Old Greenwich for Miss Tyson next Saturday.

ADOLF HITLER is not so well guarded as might be expected. The precautions taken and the size of the guard depend entirely upon the occasion. He has been seen walking alone in the streets of Berlin, although probably plainclothes police have been somewhere about.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- President Roosevelt has it strongly in mind to appoint Frank C. Walker as Postmaster General to succeed James A. Farley, now that the latter has definitely decided to retire to direct the 1936 Presidential campaign.

A book which fills a need. Here in one volume is descriptive material and stories about types of Indians living in different kinds of country. The first chapter explains these divisions and tells why "The Forest Indians," "The People of the Plains."

ALBANY, May 25 (AP). -- Cold and drought have virtually halted farming in New York State, a survey shows. The State Department of Agriculture reported today that nearly all crops are four weeks late because of temperatures which have ranged from 10 to 30 degrees below normal this month.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- Memorial Day, next high point in the crowded series of Spring events in Atlantic City, will mark the opening of the Summer seashore season, and there are many signs to indicate that the season will draw huge throngs.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Of more than $500,000 paid to free kidnap victims in about a half dozen cases, $230,148.65, "or almost half," has been recovered, according to J. Edgar Hoover, director of "G" men.

LONDON, May 25. -- Teddy Knibbs, an invalid long bedridden in a hospital in London's East End, had a great moment today. He lay helpless in a wheelcot on the fringe of the crowd when the King and Queen visited Limehouse Town Hall during a jubilee drive through the city's poorest streets.

GENEVA, May 25. -- The Nazi government of Danzig backed down today and promised the Council of the League of Nations that it would abide by the verdict of a committee of jurists as to whether during and since the recent elections it had acted and legislated, as Catholics and Jews charge, contrary to Danzig's democratic Constitution, of which the League is the guarantor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25. -- Success of the "bursary student aid" plan, established at Yale by the aid of Edward S. Harkness incidental to the opening of the eight new residential colleges, today was pronounced as certain by The Yale Alumni Weekly.

FULLY sixty years ago the Russian chemist Mendelyev predicted the coming of the day when gas would be generated at or in the coal mine and piped hundreds of miles to cities. Scores of imaginative technicians repeated the proposal. Among them were such lights as the late Sir William Ramsay and Z. Ferranti.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- The American Federation of Labor accused "organized business" today of withholding 4,000,000 jobs as a protest against pending business control legislation.

TACOMA, Wash., May 25. -- Early today search for George Weyerhaeuser centred in Seattle as William E. Justus, Chief of Detectives, assigned his entire force of detectives for duty under W.K. Bowling, a Department of Justice investigator. Inspector Walter Dench said the authorities here were working on a "hot clue," but he would give no details.

ADVERSE weather in many sections of the country was again responsible for unsatisfactory trade results in the week. Low temperatures do not inspire buying of Summer goods in spite of the near approach of Decoration Day.

Increased patronage on common-carrier lines in New York City, reflecting, many believe, an improved economic situation, is shown by the 1934 report of the Transit Commission issued recently. For the first time since 1930 a marked increase in the number of riders on most means of local travel was noted.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 25. -- With the approach of the Memorial Day holidays and the opening of country homes on the North Shore, express cruisers, used to commute from Hempstead Harbor to offices in Lower Manhattan by many prominent business men, begin to appear at their moorings off Station 10 of the New York Yacht Club at Glen Cove.

EUROPE in the fourteenth century, was a mess. It was even a worse mess than it is today. For it had many more political divisions than it has now, and therefore its jealousies, its wars and conspiracies were considerably multiplied.

GLENVILLE, W. Va., May 25 (AP). -- A sizable group of the womenfolk here think Amanda Thompson, a housewife, would make a better chief magistrate than her husband, Roy Thompson, so the signs went up all over Glenville today:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 25. -- George H. Nettleton, Lampson Professor of English, will succeed Professor William Lyon Phelps as public orator at the 234th annual commencement exercises of Yale University, it was announced today. The exercises will begin Saturday, June 15, and close Wednesday, June 19, although many of the alumni here for the reunions will remain until after the Yale-Harvard regatta at New London two days later.

Howard Thurston, the stage magician, and his bride, the former Pauline Marks, who were married Friday night at Harrison, N.Y., sailed yesterday on the Clyde Mallory liner Shawnee for Jacksonville. Fla., where they will pass their honeymoon.

THE history of cartoon and caricature recently has taken on a new significance as a part of the general history of art. It is recognized not only on the side of its power to sway public opinion by irony, ridicule or contempt, but for its potency as eloquent design.

MAY is a tryout month for new broadcasts. At this season, after a Winter of topnotch acts, the listener is heard to complain, "the broadcasts are slipping badly; there is little worth while." But that does not necessarily mean the showmen have lost their knack. It merely signifies the Winter cavalcade has ended.

TWO operas will have what presumably will be their first American performances at the Eastman Theatre in Rochester tomorrow evening, when the opera department of the Eastman School of Music will stage Dohnanyi's "Tante Simona" and Marschner's "Der Holzdieb."

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Forty-four concessions to Sweden are provided in an unconditional most-favored-nation reciprocal trade agreement, signed today by Secretary Hull and Wollmar Bostrom, the Swedish Minister. Sweden accorded the United States concessions on sixty-four items.

SEATTLE, May 25. -- The mysterious disappearance in Tacoma of 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser recalled here today that when the lad's grandfather, John Philip Weyerhaeuser Sr., died at Tacoma a week ago Thursday the family's vast timber and other holdings were estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

PARIS, May 25. -- An all-Australia doubles final, which may have some bearing on selection of a combination to represent the Commonwealth in the Davis Cup play this Summer, resulted today from the semi-final and quarter-final play in the French hard court tennis championships.

CHARLES MARTIN TORNOV LOEFFLER was one of the most striking and distinctive figures that American music has known. His death last Sunday was the end of a curious and solitary artist's career. Born in 1861 at Muehlhausen, Alsace, Loeffler came to America in his twentieth year.

LIMA, Peru. WITH the completion of the Lima-Arequipa highway, now well under way, some of the most important centres of the ancient civilization of Peru will be opened up to tourists. The new road, which links the central departments of Peru and the port of Lima with the growing industries of the South, will follow in many places the old Inca trail, once traveled by the emissaries and armies of emperors.

CINCINNATI, May 25. -- At the graduation exercises of the Hebrew Union College here today the honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Law was conferred upon Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of Central Synagogue. New York City, who delivered the baccalaureate address.

While the Senate Finance Committee wrote a number of changes into the Social Security Bill, it failed to correct its most important defects. In the case of one provision in particular, it is difficult to believe that the way in which it would work out can represent the real intent of Congress.

Emphasis on sales possibilities of Summer wraps and lingerie, together with the promotion of the silver jubilee colors in neckwear, and the report of extremely active business in string knit dresses in the low-end ranges, feature the report especially prepared by Tobe, well-known fashion authority and merchandising consultant for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CINCINNATI, May 25. -- The thirty-first Cincinnati May Festival came to an end this evening, with the first performance of "The Stabat Mater" of Frederick Dumler, musician composer and business man of of this city, with Helen Jepson, Richard Crooks, Kathryn Meisle and Keith Falkner as soloists and the festival chorus and orchestra.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The action of President Roosevelt in vetoing the Patman "Greenback" Bonus Bill and the subsequent vote of the Senate sustaining his disapproval seem definitely to have put at rest the fear of deliberate currency inflation at this session of Congress.

THROUGHOUT his adventurous career Mustapha Kemal has been called on to meet open rebellion and secret plots: courage, his personal magnetism and, last but not least, his luck have enabled him to triumph over them all.

LONDON, May 25 (AP). -- The International Wheat Conference in a communique today announced that France received an increase of 13,000,000 bushels in her millable export quota to October, 1935. An increase in the glut of world stocks was forecast and the conference urged a revival of restriction measures.

TO many a bewildered parent Miss Adams's authoritative, sane book should bring reassurance and illumination. Psychologists, being themselves immersed in studies of the abnormal, have been so preoccupied with the abnormal in child development that mothers and fathers, reading their outpourings, have been appalled by the outlook for their offspring.

BRYAN WALLER PROCTER (1787-1874), who wrote under the pseudonym of Barry Cornwall, was an English poet of considerable reputation a hundred years ago. Today, as Professor Armour tells us, he is known only as the author of "The Sea" and as the father of Adelaide Procter, author of "The Lost Chord."

MADRID, May 25. -- Encouraged by recent intimations that the British Government is not satisfied with the international statute by which Tangier is governed, an influential group of conservative Deputies is now vociferously demanding its revision in the Spanish Cortes.

DURING its third transcontinental tour, to begin in October, Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe of Monte Carlo will appear with four symphony orchestras. The earliest of these appearances, as announced by Sol Hurok, will be with the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conducting, on Nov. 12, 14, 15 and 16.

President Roosevelt's action in increasing outright Federal grants for public works projects from 30 per cent to 45 per cent and cutting interest on public works loans from 4 per cent to 3 per cent was praised yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

THIS is a record in full and patient detail of a noble enterprise in behalf of an exiled people. Millions of Jews in the countries of Eastern Europe a half century ago found themselves in much the same plight as have many of their faith in Germany during the last two years.

BUDAPEST, May 25. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the German Air Minister, had a two-hour conference with Premier Julius Goemboes today, afterward visiting various sections of Budapest with several members of his party.

LOUIS GOLDING has managed to write a downright dull novel. Even those of his advocates who took considerable pleasure in "Magnolia Street" and "Five Silver Daughters" will be hard put to find a modicum of praise for "The Camberwell Beauty."

Contracts running into millions and calling for heavy stocks of raw materials and major factory equipment replacements will be placed in the immediate future by purchasing executives returning to their home offices after attending the annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents here last week.

Novel features are being planned by a group headed by Princess Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst for the dinner dance to be held on Tuesday evening at the Ambassador for the benefit of the National Republican Builders, Inc. The Louis XV Ballroom of the hotel will be transformed into a game room for the occasion.

The upholding by the Senate of the President's veto of the Soldiers' Bonus-Currency Inflation Bill draws natural interest to the action of Congress on other notable occasions of the kind. Two of the three previous "Bonus-Bill vetoes," those of Presidents HOOVER and COOLIDGE, were over-ridden by Congress.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Eltinge F. Warner have opened Cima del Mundo, their Summer residence. They entertained with a luncheon at the Maidstone Club today. Mr. and Mrs. Z.H. Simmons Jr., who have their yacht moored at the Devon Yacht Club over the week-end, brought luncheon guests.

AT the close of the season it is customary for the Theatre Guild to lift her skirts cautiously and to skip a little. That frivolous gesture is not always becoming to so staid a body. This year, for instance, the Guild has cut a few cerebral capers in the left wing by mounting a satirical revue entitled "Parade," which was written originally by Paul Peters and George Sklar for the Theatre Union in Fourteenth Street.

WHEN the people of the Philippines recently ratified their new Constitution by an overwhelming majority they began the last act of a drama that has been in progress since the islands were taken over by the United States from Spain thirty-seven years ago.

The case of a patient who probably will have several years added to his life because both frontal lobes of his brain were removed in a recent operation was discussed yesterday by Dr. Iago Galdston, head of the bureau of information of the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

MAYSIE GREIG'S specialty is feverish romance. In her stories lots of things happen, and at a rapid pace not too closely tied to plausibility. In "Sweet Danger" she has got into deeper water. Feverish romance is still the prime interest.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- With the observation that the country was "in an economic Spring, preceding the Summer of content," and the promise that President Roosevelt would take precautions "against any unseasonable frost to spoil the harvest," Postmaster General James A. Farley this afternoon laid the cornerstone of Philadelphia's new $4,500,000 postoffice building.

DEVON, Pa., May 25. -- The second day of the Devon Horse Show saw Edward Sifton, riding Iron Man, annex a second leg on the Geist Challenge Trophy in the Corinthian hunter competition today. It was one of the finest hunter exhibitions so far in the show.

THE Winter season, before making way for the so-called "grand" season, gave us a work which was awaited with considerable interest and received with every mark of satisfaction -- Vaughan Williams's Fourth symphony.

More than 450 financially depressed artists from the city's five boroughs exhibited their creations yesterday on fences and railings in historic Washington Square on the first day of the seventh Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition, which will continue until June 2.

MUSSOLINI'S personal safety is entrusted to a special section of the police force said to consist of 300 men; it probably includes many more than that. It is of interest to note that 300 men is also the strength of the special police section detailed to insure the safety of the King and his family.

THE Commonwealth of Australia boasts two of the most valuable air services in the world, each unique in its particular field. One is an unsubsidized airline which has always made money for its operators as well as for those who use it, and the other is the only government operated medical and surgical air service in the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24. -- Holding water and power rights in Yosemite Valley on which it has spent $80,000,000, San Francisco today faces a threat by Harold Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, to cancel them unless the municipality proceeds without delay to direct distribution of its Sierra power.

TO the Galahads of industry who "fought the battle of the NRA" in the sweltering offices of the Department of Commerce Building in Washington during the torrid months of 1933 this dissection of the anatomy of the NRA will make melancholy reading.

WITTY, exciting and provocative, "The Unpossessed" was a first novel which caused an unusual amount of stir. It dealt satirically, but at the same time compassionately, with a group of New York intellectuals who were represented as stranded and lost and incapable of effective action.

THE Winter season, before making way for the so-called "grand" season, gave us a work which was awaited with considerable interest and received with every mark of satisfaction -- Vaughan Williams's Fourth symphony.

More than 450 financially depressed artists from the city's five boroughs exhibited their creations yesterday on fences and railings in historic Washington Square on the first day of the seventh Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition, which will continue until June 2.

A fairly steady tone was restored yesterday to the markets for commodity futures, despite the further weakness in grains, and the more active staples went forward for the day. In the cash markets, losses were recorded in all the grains and cotton, while rubber advanced.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 25 (AP). -- Dr. Hugh S. Cumming, Surgeon General of the Federal Public Health Service, dedicated Lexington's newly completed Federal Narcotic Farm today to "instinctive demands" of the American people "that the sick and afflicted shall be set in the way of strength and hope."

Twenty thousand children and 5,000 parents converged on the East Green of Central Park yesterday morning for the third annual Free May Day Outing of the Michael T. McCarron Association, regular Democratic organization in the Fourteenth Assembly District of Yorkville.

MR. CLARK'S series of travel guides in which he shows the prospective traveler how he can be happy though thrifty while he sees with very satisfactory results the countries of Europe at an expense of only $50 for each one now covers, with these three new volumes, eight of those lands, and he has the rest of Europe in preparation.

WASHINGTON. AT the first national intercollegiate flying conference to be held in this country undergraduate pilots in attendance recently voted unanimously to form a National Intercollegiate Flying Club affiliated with the National Aeronautic Association.

Seven major gangs have monopolized the city's "racket" industry, according to a blacklist, prepared jointly by city and Federal authorities, which last week "leaked" into the hands of reporters. The activities of some of these gangs are now under scrutiny by the March grand jury.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 25. -- The garden tours of the Westchester County Children's Association was continued today with the showing of Dellwood Farms, the estate here of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Hammond.

Appointment of an opera management committee by the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, announced Friday, fulfilled the last of the six points enumerated in the program of cooperation laid down by the Juilliard Foundation at the time it agreed to join forces with the opera company in financing the next season.

Two men were arrested yesterday on a charge of receiving part of $70,000 in Treasury certificates stolen May 8 from the National Bank of Toledo, Ohio. Their arrest followed efforts to dispose of $8,000 worth of the certificates in two brokerage houses.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 25. -- The battleship Pennsylvania, flagship of Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, commanding the United States fleet, led about fifty men-of-war into port today for a week's stay before active resumption of the annual war games.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, May 25. -- The hole-by-hole description of the final-round match today for the British amateur golf championship between W. Lawson Little Jr. and Dr. William Tweddell follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 25. -- Pittsburgh won from Army on the track today, 67 to 59, taking eight first places to five for the Cadets. Fleming of Pitt was a triple winner, taking the 100 and 220-yard dashes and the low hurdles.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23. -- No organized protest has been manifest here against the slash in work-relief pay announced from Washington. Organized labor has taken no action, because there is still confusion as to whether the new scale applies only to workers on relief or also to workers on public works jobs financed from Washington.

FOND DU LAC, Wis., May 23. -- There will be no third party of any consequence in the campaign of 1936. That prophecy seems unassailable after recent events, and particularly since the Wisconsin Progressives in conference disclaimed any intention of moving outside their own bailiwick.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Business trends continued moderately downward in the week ended on May 18, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the domestic situation. Actual changes were slight.

ALTHOUGH this lively, and engaging personal narrative of a lifetime in aviation comes from the pen of one of the most technically competent engineers and designers which the young industry has produced, it maintains throughout the amateur spirit.

PARIS, May 25. -- France's internal problems have, during this week, suddenly loomed so large that already within a few days the importance at one time attached to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's speech of last Tuesday has faded. With a swiftness that is very disconcerting, it is the internal and not the external situation that has taken first place in public interest.

THE second year of repeal finds increasing agitation throughout the country in favor of temperance, the demand coming from repealists and from the dry forces. Naturally, the old question is raised: "What is temperance?"
AFTER six months' trial unemployed youth in Michigan is enthusiastic over two new institutions -- freshman colleges and aviation ground schools.

NEWARK, N.J., May 25. -- The Bears dropped into the second division today for the first time in three years when a 19-to-10 drubbing at the hands of Albany sent them tumbling from third place to fifth in the International League standing.

Attendant on the arrival of the new French liner Normandie on its maiden voyage here, a gala fete entitled "Starlight in Normandie" -- comprising a supper dance, cabaret and fashion show -- will be held on June 5 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

SALEM, N.H., May 25. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 4-year-old chestnut colt Identity, a strong favorite to win the New Hampshire Handicap at Rockingham Park today went down to defeat before a stunned crowd of 30,000. J.W.Y. Martin's Dark Hope, a 6-year-old brown gelding, clattered across the finish line first in the $5,000 mile and one-sixteenth test.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- The kidnapping of George Weyerheuser, 9-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. J.P. Weyerheuser of Tacoma, Wash., and demand for $200,000 ransom, today added to the list of spectacular cases which Justice Department agents have sought to solve.

Scientific demonstrations and short talks on scientific subjects will feature the "Physics Night" meeting of the Parent-Teachers Association of the De Witt Clinton High School to be held in the auditorium of the school on Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. An election of officers of the association for next year will be held at a business meeting preceding the program.

Many committees have been formed for the annual fair and tea at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney in Manhasset, L.I., on June 7 for the benefit of the Babies' Milk Funds of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP). -- The Athletics, with Jimmy Fox returned to his old post at first base, broke their losing streak by dividing a doubleheader with the Indians today. The Mackmen won the second game, 6 to 1, after the Tribe trounced them, 9 to 6, in ten innings in the opener.
PARIS, May 25. -- Further energetic measures to defend the franc from speculative attack and from the flight of gold were taken by the regents of the Bank of France today.

SEATED one day in a cafe of Berlin's Unter den Linden, Professor Schroedinger and Dr. Murphy discussed a book. It was to be a collection of Schroedinger's more philosophical lectures on the historical course of modern physics and the implications of the new thinking about the atom.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 25. -- Jesse Owens, spectacular Ohio State Negro, gave one of the most amazing demonstrations of versatility in track and field history today as he shattered three world's records and equaled a fourth to dominate completely the thirty-fifth annual Western Conference meet.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 23. -- Close of the most hectic week nationally in the already stormy career of the Tennessee Valley Authority finds this section of the valley in something of a dazed condition with regard to the government's "guinea pig" project for the Central South.

Senior week at Barnard College will begin Friday afternoon with the traditional "step-singing" in the Milbank quadrangle, it was announced yesterday. Miss Roselle Riggin of 559 West 158th Street has been appointed chairman of senior week activities, which will continue through the following Thursday.

For some time writers have been turning out books that tell in simple language about railroading and describe famous locomotive from the little Rocket of 1829 to recent models. It has been left for the authors of "The Story of Steam," however, to explain how the steam engine actually works in a way that is easily understood by the 7 and 8 year old.

ONE of the early Summer group shows which blossom in the galleries at this time of year opened last week at Milch's to run through June. This one, chiefly of landscapes, affords some striking contrasts and more than passing interest attaches to it.

ADULT education would be more effective if it ceased its efforts to attract the apathetic man in the street and concentrated on aiding the ablest minds, Professor Edward L. Thorndike of Columbia University argued before the annual convention of the American Association for Adult Education at Milwaukee last week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- A 100 per cent increase in the elimination of a certain type of cancer in rabbits by combining small daily doses of X-rays with applications of artificial fever is described in the second scientific report of the International Cancer Research Foundation, made public here today.
BOSTON, May 25 (AP). -- The Tigers made it two out of three over the Red Sox today, winning the odd game of their series, 3 to 2.

Pictures and a very brief text are supposed to take the youngest readers on a voyage around the world, starting in Greenland and proceeding through Scotland, Holland, Germany, India, China, Japan, Hawaii and back to the United States.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 25. -- In a fast and hard-riding polo game, played on Howze Field, Army's undefeated pool team rode to victory over Yale today, 8 to 5. The Cadets outrode and out-hit the Eli horsemen, scoring in every chukker except the last.

The interesting survey in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the useful, uninterrupted career for nearly sixty-three years with the same firm of William W. Hanold will attract widespread attention. At the age of 84 he may well think of retiring and enjoying a trip to the Old World.

For the second time in the eighteen-year history of the event, Poly-Prep was dethroned as the Athletic Association of Private Schools senior division track and field champion in the annual meet at Baker Field yesterday.

For the second time in the eighteen-year history of the event, Poly-Prep was dethroned as the Athletic Association of Private Schools senior division track and field champion in the annual meet at Baker Field yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25. -- As the first robins herald the coming of Spring, so the fact that the Summer tourist season will soon be in full swing along the water lanes of the Pacific, both off-shore and coastwise, is being brought to notice with the coming out of Winter quarters of many passenger vessels.

Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. has given to the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, most of her collection of modern works of art. The gift comprises 181 objects, the work of seventy-one American and foreign artists.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 25. -- Cornell's track team overwhelmed Princeton, 82 to 53, before 1,500 on Schoellkopf Field today, breaking five meet records and setting three new all-time Cornell marks in the process.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 26. -- Memorial Day religious services were held today in nearly all the churches of Westchester County. At Eastchester and New Rochelle, war veterans decorated the graves or soldiers dead.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 26. -- Making its first start in 1935 competition, Rudolph J. Schaefer's sloop Edlu sailed to victory today over Pellegrina and Zaida in the first special Sunday regatta held by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

BERLIN, May 26. -- A period of silence has fallen on European diplomatic circles since Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler made his thought-provoking speech before the German Reichstag and its subsequent cordial endorsement in the British House of Commons.

The Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday that certain employes in the five borough offices of the Chief Medical Examiner have been illegally receiving and pocketing fees for services for which the city makes no charge. The collecting is going on at the rate of from $20,000 to $25,000 a year, it declared, the total collections since 1918 being estimated at a minimum of $170,000 and perhaps as high as $400,000.

World spinners used less American cotton in April than in any, April in recent years and slightly less than in March, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. While consumption is low, it is being well maintained as a result of the recent improvement in yarn and cloth sales, the Service says.

CINCINNATI, May 26 (AP). -- While the echoes of his three home runs in Pittsburgh yesterday were still reverberating, Babe Ruth came to town today with the Braves, but Si Johnson struck him out three times -- twice swinging -- as the Reds took the first game of the series, 6 to 3.

PITTSBURGH, May 26. -- Buyers of steel have grown still more conservative as the time in which the NIRA would expire by limitation decreases and no legislation has been enacted to extend it. Only absolute and immediate wants are being filled, and steel men regard the demand, fairly well sustained, as indicating a healthy condition as to ultimate consumption.
A move to reduce the size of classes in the city's public schools and retain teachers who ordinarily would be dropped was revealed yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

CALLANDER, Ont., May 26 (AP). -- The crackle of brush fires, sweeping over a wide area, sounded tonight within a quarter of a mile of the hospital where the Dionne quintuplets are housed, and heavy smoke rolled over the back acres of Oliva Dionne's farm.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 26 (AP). -- A man was drowned in efforts to save his two children when thirty persons were hurled into the sea by collapse of the guard rail of a fishing barge today.

The intense public interest in solving the country's housing problem will be sustained for the next ten years or more, declares James B. Dusenberry, director of the Underwriting and Realty Division of the Federal Housing Administration, in a statement prepared for the American Institute of Architects, which begins its sixty-seventh convention in Milwaukee tomorrow.

The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children will celebrate its sixtieth anniversary tomorrow. It will report that in the past year it aided 32,000 Manhattan children. To date, the total is 1,898,000 children since the late Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry undertook the first legal rescue of a child as "a little animal" in 1875, when he found that only horses and dogs were protected by the law.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 26. -- Cecil Smith, hard-riding Texan, made his first 1935 Long Island appearance in the members' round-robin polo competition on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club today. Smith, playing at No. 2 for the Whites, tallied five of the seven goals credited to his side in a three-team round robin.

HAVING looked over Barney Ross and Jimmy McLarnin, Commissioner Bill Brown said they were in great shape for their debate at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night. And how about the Weather Man, Commissioner? If he comes out fighting, he'll stop those welterweights cold.

Henry W. Simpson, 29 years old, of 3 Park Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., erstwhile organist at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, 129 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, was held in $5,000 bail for hearing Wednesday after he had been charged with the abduction of 13-year-old Eleanor Schmaus of 218 Eckford Street, Brooklyn, before Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill in Williamsburg Bridge Plaza court in Brooklyn yesterday.

Approximately 600,000 New Yorkers contributed to the current fund of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee and oversubscribed the goal of $2,000,000 by 44 per cent, James G. Blaine, chairman, announced yesterday.

The indictment against society framed by a group of young people and their parents in Orange, N.J., two weeks ago is indicative of the wrong attitude toward life, according to Dr. Frank Oliver Hall in a sermon yesterday morning at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity at Seventy-sixth Street and Central Park West.

General Chiang Kai-shek, Chinese dictator, was praised yesterday for his cooperation with American missionaries, for his work in modernizing and improving social conditions in China and for fostering a spirit of cooperation among the Chinese by the Rev. Dr. Brewer Eddy of the American Board of Foreign Missions in a sermon at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway at Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- A claim for creating 250,000,000 hours of "indirect and industrial employment" for men working in iron and steel mines, mills and factories, was made today by the Public Works Administration.

BERLIN, May 25. -- Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht this week for the first time admitted that the State's system of work creation on credit is the cause of the present plethora of money and thus implicitly admitted the fact of inflation.

BUENOS AIRES, May 26. -- The Pan-American Commercial Conference opened here this morning with such a panegyric of the United States as had never been heard at any international conference. Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina devoted more than a third of his extremely long inaugural address to praise of President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull and the manner in which they had put their "good neighbor" policy into effect.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Sponsors of the Tennessee Valley Authority are interested primarily in building up a socialistic State, the American Liberty League charged today in attacking the Norris bill to enlarge and clarify the powers of the TVA.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Heartened by their success at sustaining President Roosevelt's veto of the Patman "green back" Bonus Bill, and seeking, too, to take full advantage of the favorable reaction from the country, administration leaders in Congress will start a "big push" this week for enactment of the remainder of the New Deal legislative program and early adjournment.

Defeating Harvard for the second time on Saturday, after the latter had subdued Cornell in both ends of a double-header on Friday, Dartmouth now needs only one victory in its three remaining games to assure itself of at least a tie for the title in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race.

CINCINNATI, May 26. -- A united Presbyterian militant front against war, liquor and child labor was urged this afternoon at a meeting under the auspices of the Boards of Christian Education and National Missions of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America, in the Taft Auditorium here.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., May 26. -- Commencement exercises for the National Guard and Reserve Officers' Class of the Signal School were held in the War Department Theatre here yesterday.

A car operated by a woman learner mounted the curb at Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street at 5:20 o'clock last night, knocking down Tour pedestrians but injuring none seriously. The driver, Miss Nellie Ryan, 26-year-old nurse, of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, was arrested on charges of third degree assault and operating a car in an area restricted against learners.

RYE, N.Y., May 26. -- Champion Heather Reveller of Sporran, hero of many a hard-fought show ring battle, today came back into the lists and once more emerged triumphant. This famous little Scottie won the title of best of breed in the annual Summer specialty show of the Scottish Terrier Club of America at Brookside, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Matthews.

Turning in an excellent exhibition, Paddy Shannon, striking bay gelding owned and shown by Hugh Gormley of Great Neck, L.I., carried off the $100 championship Hunter and Jumper Stake, a feature at the annual Staten Island Horse Show yesterday. Golden Melody, belonging to Miss Mary McCoy, was placed in reserve.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A considerable increase in competitive imports into this country is required to revive American foreign trade, according to a report of the Foreign Policy Association published today. It was written by David H. Popper, of the association's research staff.
John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland, is due to arrive today from Warsaw on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others coming on the Bremen from the Channel ports include:

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- A $31.750 pay check was shown in Security Commission reports today to have gone in 1934 to the average chief executive of an industrial corporation substantial enough to list its securities on a stock exchange.

The foreign exchange market was highly irregular last week. Sterling rose to a new high since last December, carrying the Scandinavian currencies with it, while the French franc was under pressure and sold down to the lowest in more than three months. In the Continentals, the belga and Swiss franc were firm, but the Holland guilder lost ground. The lira was unchanged.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Declaring that the big Federal works-relief program would greatly simplify the administration of relief in this State, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration reported today to Governor Lehman that about 2,200,000 men, women and children, or one-sixth of the State's population, were dependent on relief in March.

I would call attention to a hearing to be held by the Board of Estimate on June 14 to consider a proposal to acquire certain properties on the Brooklyn side of the Brooklyn Bridge for the purpose of beautifying the bridge plaza and the approach to Borough Hall.

PITTSBURGH, May 26 (AP). -- Fanning nine and allowing only seven hits, Darrell (Cy) Blanton, the sensational rookie, led the Pittsburgh Pirates to their fourth straight victory today by defeating the Phillies, 3 to 1.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 26. -- While attempting a right tail spin, a difficult aerial manoeuvre reserved for experts, Miss Freidel Braun, 28 years old, of 124 West Eighty-fifth Street, New York, lost control of a Fairchild monoplane this afternoon and crashed into the roof of a house on Concord Street.

The Junior Inspectors Club of the Department of Sanitation celebrated yesterday in the auditorium of Stuyvesant High School, Fifteenth Street and First Avenue, the enrolment of its one hundred thousandth member. Richard Donald Todd, 18 years old, of 64-91 Eighty-second Place, Elmhurst, Queens, a senior at Newtown High School, never expected that by applying for membership in the "J.I.C." he would provoke a fete attended by almost 1,000 cheering youngsters.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- A Brooklyn victory on Wrigley Field appears to be as much of a problem as ever. Duplicating their four hits off Bill Lee with a like number of errors, Casey Stengel's Dodgers went down rather meekly before the Cubs in the series opener today, 8 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- A general upturn in farm real estate values for the first time in more than a decade and an easing in the farm credit situation were reported today by the Agriculture Department and the Farm Credit Administration.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 26. -- James G. Dimond Jr. of Crestmont, with a score of 96 out of a possible 100, won the first annual metropolitan skeet championship today on the range of the Valhalla Skeet Club.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $7,533,885,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

While the statue fans of this great city have been bothering themselves no end over the fate of Civic Virtue, the bronze figure of one of the nation's great naval heroes has stood virtually unnoticed, protruding through the roof of a temporary shed in Madison Square for almost eight months.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 26. -- Five forest fires of serious proportions raged in up-State New York tonight as volunteer workers and regular fire fighters brought a score of minor brush blazes under control.

It is not easy, in surveying last week's markets, to discern the ebb and flow of financial sentiment. Although the 2,400,000-share business reached on one day of the preceding week was not repeated, transactions on the Stock Exchange continued large, compared with the season's earlier inactivity; nearly every day produced a "million-share market."

PARIS, May 26. -- There will begin tomorrow another momentous week in France's ever agitated history. Once more in the nine years of its turbulent history, the value of the franc will be the theme of a debate and for the same reason, namely, that the French Parliament will not or cannot keep its budget balanced.
Bright skies and a warm sun brought a touch of Summer to the city yesterday and attracted the largest crowds of the year to the beaches, parks and shore resorts.

A sale of used articles will be held at 356 Lexington Avenue today, tomorrow and Wednesday to raise money for the support of the Summer camp of the Boys Brotherhood Republic, a self-governing organization with a membership of 400 boys. An appeal has been made for discarded clothing, shoes, books, bric-a-brac, etc., and messengers will be sent to collect such contributions.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- The highest price for hogs since Oct. 18, 1930, at $10.15 a hundredweight, led to buying of lard and bellies by speculators here last week, and there were intimations of a possible squeeze of the May shorts, who have only five days to provide for their commitments.

Today promises to be one of the really impressive days of the theatrical season. Time may be dated from it ultimately, and historians may take a look at May 27, 1935, and run shuddering to their ledgers. They may not, too, but the outlook on the night before seemed rather good.

BERKSHIRE HILLS, Mass., May 26. -- Twenty members of the Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club, of which Maurice Woolverton of New Lebanon, N.Y., is president, rode this morning to Greenmeads, Richmond, where they were the guests at breakfast of Mr. and Mrs. Darwin Spurr Morse.

ARDSLEY-ON-THE-HUDSON, N.Y., May 26. -- Adolph Lewisohn, philanthropist and patron of the arts, who will celebrate his eighty-sixth birthday tomorrow at a dinner to be given by the City College Club, was host today at a party to fifty friends, whom he entertained by singing to them.

Reflecting the restriction in consumer buying in many sections as a result of unseasonable weather conditions, the wholesale markets here were less active last week. Considerable interest was centred in medium and low-end merchandise, and apparel and accessory lines for later in the season.

May I correct and clarify certain information given by me May 23 at the hearing of the Mayor's commission investigating housing conditions in Harlem? I then stated that while some sections of Harlem are badly congested, the area as a whole is not.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- New low prices for the season were made on the Board of Trade last week on all grains, with the close at almost the bottom. Net losses on wheat futures for the week were 3 1/2 to 3 5/8 cents a bushel; corn, 3 1/4 to 4 3/6 cents; oats, 7/8 to 6 1/8 cents; rye, 1 to 1 3/4 cents; barley, 4 1/2 to 6 1/2 cents.

If for the moment Republicans seem to be fewer than used to be their habit who can doubt that they are fitter? Theirs is the merry heart that goes all the day. In the words of VIRGIL, asked to write a motto for the Union League Club, "Don't you give in to bad luck but be bolder and bolder agin it."

NEWARK, N.J., May 26. -- The new city subway, opened at 5 o'clock this morning, was like a new plaything to more than 10,000 Newarkers during the day. It was estimated that many rode back and forth on the three-and-one-half miles of the new transportation system between the Public Service Terminal, in downtown Newark, to the end of the line at Heller Parkway, adjoining Branch Brook Park.

PASADENA, Calif., May 26. -- Extortionists who harried Herbert D. Ivey for $72,000 with the threat of death stumbled into a trap in seeking a payoff last night and left one man behind dangerously wounded as they fled before the gunfire of Federal agents and police.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26. -- After losing four straight games the Newark Bears snapped out of their losing ways today and defeated Albany in both ends of a doubleheader before 9,000. The scores were 14 to 2 and 4 to 3.
BERLIN, May 26. -- An undoubtedly officially inspired wave of praise for Dr. Robert Koch, discoverer of the tuberculosis bacillus, appeared in the German press this morning.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries made ordinary capital expenditures of $9,956,013 in 1934, mainly for additions and improvements to the electric transmission and distribution system, according to the pamphlet report, issued yesterday.

The combined celebration of the silver jubilee of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Barnabas and of the Rev. Michael A. Reilly as pastor of the church was held yesterday morning in the church edifice at 241st Street and Martha Avenue, the Bronx.

ST. LOUIS, May 26. -- The singular gyrations of the bedraggled Giants through the West took on an even more fantastic turn today when, within the short space of two hours and five minutes, they achieved what hitherto had appeared to be practically impossible, if not altogether inconceivable.

Bishop John Fisher and Sir Thomas More, who were canonized in Rome last Sunday, should be the modern woman's patron saints because they were "champions of womanhood, who fought and died for the rights of the married mother," the Rev. Henry Gebhard, professor of English at Cathedral College, declared yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Club for Nurses at the Hotel Commodore.

NEW HAVEN, May 25. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.7. which compares with 82.3 the week before, 82.2 two weeks before, 82.1 three weeks before and 81.8 four weeks before.

President Roosevelt has recognized that the way out of our depression is through the employment of those at present unemployed, and that their employment must come through private initiative. At the same time the administration has caused laws to be enacted which thoroughly discourage business men from entering upon new capital ventures or increasing activities in their present ventures.

LONDON, May 25. -- The London stock market moved rather erratically this week, but on the whole the trend of values was upward. There were, in fact, more favorable than unfavorable points in the market's situation.

The most gratifying fact in the report that Mr. JAMES G. BLAINE makes today as chairman of the Family Welfare Committee is that more than 500,000 persons subscribed to this fund, which exceeded by 44 per cent the minimum goal. It was hoped at the start to raise $2,000,000.

The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet most of last week. Some price-fixing by mills was reported. Active contracts closed on Saturday 1 point higher to 6 lower from a week earlier.

PARIS, May 26. -- Australia and England split a pair of titles in the French hard court tennis championships today as America's singles aspirants, Miss Helen Jacobs and Wilmer Hines, reached the third round.

Doubleday, Doran will publish shortly "Test Pilot," by Jimmie Collins, who lost his life in a crash on Long Island two months ago. Collins used to take navy planes up to 20,000 feet, cut loose in a power dive and pull out at 10,000 feet. The angle of the pull-out was the point of the test.

For the second time in six weeks three young bandits attempted last night to hold up the drug store of Max Canter at 3,826 Broadway, between 159th and 160th Streets, Center's son, Herbert, recognized one of the bandits and shot him through the stomach. The two others escaped after a chase in Broadway in which Canter fired two more shots, one of which may have taken effect.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP). -- Manager Jimmy Dykes of the league-leading White Sox personally conducted his team to a 5-to-3 victory over the Athletics in ten innings today.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Nine additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, involving issues aggregating $12,813,053.50, have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, chiefly for commercial and industrial issues.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-THE-HUDSON, N.Y., May 26. -- Memorial services were held this morning at St. Mary's Church, Scarborough, to honor the memory of the veterans of the First Provisional Regiment, New York Guard, with the Rev. Charles W. Baldwin conducting the exercises.

HIGHLAND MANOR, N.Y., May 26. -- "A good mathematician will make a better wife than will a good cook," Dr. Eugene H. Lehman told the girls of the graduating classes of Highland Manor School and Junior College, Tarrytown, N.Y., during the baccalaureate vesper services this afternoon.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- Lowering of prices for cattle in the United States resulted in decreased imports of Canadian animals, only five carloads reaching the market here last week, the smallest number since the inception of the movement.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Treasury decided today to try out another type of financing program by offering $100,000,000 of its long-term bonds, carrying 3 per cent interest, to the highest bidders, but in no case at less than par and accrued interest.

The Jewish people are the bearers of a holy and immortal message that will lead the world to freedom, peace and justice, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of the Free Synagogue declared in his confirmation sermon yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall.

SOFIA, May 26. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering arrived here today on the second phase of his "political honeymoon," in which he aims to add Bulgaria to the list of Germany's adherents in Eastern Europe, preparatory to the Danubian conference in Rome.

The marked increase in incipient tuberculosis among Negro children is seriously challenging the trustees of the New York Colored Orphan Asylum. The early years of the depression particularly struck hard at young children, when there was widespread lack of food, of proper housing and care.

Taking issue with Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau who recently advocated government ownership of the stock of the Federal Reserve Banks, the Guaranty Trust Company urges that, if a change in ownership of the stock is desirable, the stock should be transferred from the commercial banks to the public, instead of to the government.

Feeling he had a chance to strengthSn himself a bit along his secondary line, Terry executed two player transactions this morning involving a couple of spare catchers. Paul Richards, waived by all the other National League clubs, was sold for cash to the Philadelphia Athletics and Glenn fyatt, veteran backstop, recently released unconditionally by the Indians, was taken on by the Giants to fill Paul's place.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Production and unemployment in factories showed little change in April, residential construction continued to increase, but output at mines declined somewhat, the Federal Reserve Board said today in a summary of general business and financial conditions.

NEW ORLEANS, May 26, -- A1though the cotton market for future contracts was comparatively quiet here last week, there were periods of fair activity. Price flucnations were irregular, with new-crop positions easing substantially, although old-crop positions were comparatively firm.

PARIS, May 25. -- The overthrow of the bonus bill by the United States Senate, together with the declarations of President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull, produced an excellent impression here, financial circles being pleased to note that United States monetary policy has become orthodox again.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- Widely scat i tered rains over the Winter wheat sections of the Southwest revived the crop last week, and in many! parts the plant is begining to head, with conditions most favorable for filling. In the Central West all crops are generally in good condition, pastures have been revived, and stock generally is doing well.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- Those well-nigh impregnable Senate rules are under fire again -- this time by Vice President Garner.

LONDON, May 26. -- A strong protest against the new German law barring Jews from military service is made in a report of the joint foreign committee, presented by Leonard Montefiore at today's meeting of the Jewish Board of Deputies.

BOSTON, May 26 (AP). -- In a wild scoring game in which thirty players were used and twenty-seven hits were made off six of nine pitchers, the Red Sox today repelled the St. Louis Browns, 8 to 7, and returned to the first division.

LONDON, May 26. -- British amateur champion for the second successive year, his stranglehold on world amateur golf more secure than ever, W. Lawson Little Jr. has returned to London for a month's relaxation before competing in the British open at Muirfield.

It is significant to learn that nearly all of Mayor LA GUARDIA'S associates on the Board of Estimate are reluctant to support his plan for a municipal electric light plant. When the matter came up for discussion in the board last week Borough President HARVEY of Queens expressed the sensible view that the city should have nothing to do with power production and sale.

THERE is a poet who wanders lost and unheeded through Albert Halper's "Union Square." I am told that this poet was patterned more or less after Kenneth Fearing. Friends of Fearing insist that Halper traduces and caricatures him, and, as a matter of fact, he is made to appear a little ineffectual -- if, indeed, he is the character in the story.

Election of officers for 1935-36 in fourteen fraternities at Columbia University was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes, chairman of Pamphratia Council, the interfraternity governing body. The new officers are:

Everybody knew about JANE ADDAMS and about Hull House, but not everybody outside of Chicago knew that Hull House stood on Halsted Street. For the older generations today this Chicago street is associated with a totally different kind of institution from Hull House.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- Battering Walter Stewart and Thornton Lee for fifteen hits, the Senators defeated the Indians 9 to 4 today behind Bump Hadley's efficient eight-hit pitching. Stewart, former Washington hurler, lasted but three innings.

BERLIN, May 26. -- Authoritative sources disclosed today that the German military command planned a highly mobile infantry and artillery that would enable the army to move at eighty miles an hour "over almost anything except woods."

Stronger prices were the rule on the local commodity futures markets last week, although some hesitation was caused on Friday by fears of complete dislocation of the gold bloc soon and other influences. Hides alone declined among the actively traded commodities.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- Erratic action of the world's grain markets, especially those in the United States and Canada, have made them extremely difficult for the majority of traders to follow with any degree of profit. There is a growing feeling of uncertainty among all the operators, especially old-timers who have been in the business for forty and fifty years and have seen all kinds of markets.

BERLIN, May 25. -- The persistence of Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht and other Reichsbank directors in affirming that devaluation of the mark is inconceivable only serves to increase public anxiety over the future of the currency.

A campaign by housewives to bring about lower meat prices has resulted in the closing of hundreds of retail butcher shops since it was started last Wednesday by the City Action Committee Against the High Cost of Living, according to a statement issued yesterday at the committee's headquarters, 799 Broadway.

As chairman of the Family Welfare Division of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, may I make an urgent appeal for second-hand garments of all kinds that still retain some wearing qualities? Families on relief budgets are having to pay more for food now that food prices are rising, and they are consequently economizing on clothing.

The mercantile interests of the city have quietly organized a movement to free Fifth Avenue of the last of the parades that cause substantial losses in business -- the St. Patrick's Day parade which has been held annually on the avenue on March 17 for more than a third of a century.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP). -- Cook County authorities indicated today that Treasurer Robert M. Sweitzer would be allowed a week in which to repay the $414,129 he is said to owe the county.
Realty contracts in the city reported over the week-end show a continuance of demand for housing properties, especially in the Bronx.

MOSCOW, May 26. -- A unique and picturesque organization, the Society of Old Bolsheviki, many members of which had been in jail or exile under the Czar, was dissolved today by a decision of the Central Committee of the Communist party, of which Joseph Stalin is the leader.

The question is often asked, What are these "open market" operations about which so much has been said in the course of debate on the proposed Banking Act of 1935 now pending in Congress, operations to which almost miraculous powers over the prosperity of the country are attributed by monetary theorists and the orators?

Trapped by fire in his seventh-story apartment at 53 West Seventy-second Street, at Columbus Avenue, Harold Dart, 26 years old, a music teacher, hung by his hands from his windowsill at 11:15 o'clock last night so that he could be rescued by firemen on an aerial ladder that failed by six feet to reach the sill.

BERLIN, May 25. -- The Boerse responded to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Reichstag speech with an advance which was attributed partly to the relatively favorable reception of the address by the British Government and partly to the conviction that German rearmament would proceed, with favorable effects upon industrial profits and further aggravation of the status of the German currency.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y. 26. -- About 100 members of the New York Confederate societies and their compatriots and friends took part this afternoon in their annual joint observance of Memorial Day in front of the granite monument in Mount Hope Cemetery.
Service founded on love was held an important need of the moment by the Rev. Henry F. Hammer in a sermon yesterday morning at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- With "To entertain, not to educate," as their slogan, Philadelphia Orchestra members today announced their Summer concert season in Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park, starting on June 28, would have a "far more 'popular' and informal character than they ever had under a lay management."

Degrees will be conferred this evening upon twenty-seven candidates at the thirty-fifth commencement of the Biblical Seminary in New York, 235 East Forty-ninth Street. The Rev. T. Wilkinson Riddle, pastor of the George Street Baptist Church, Plymouth, England, will deliver the commencement address.

Six young Communists, one a woman, were arrested at an American Legion memorial service at the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon while distributing leaflets that bitterly assailed the Legion and called on the youth of the city to unite in a city-wide anti-war demonstration on Decoration Day.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- With two opinion days left, the Supreme Court tonight had in its keeping decisions on cases broadly and fundamentally affecting both industry and agriculture.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 25 (AP). -- Challenging Postmaster General Farley to run for Governor of New York State next year, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, predicted today that if he did "the world's greatest political massacre will follow."

An important aspect of the future of retail bookselling will come before the American Booksellers Association this morning at the Hotel Pennsylvania, where some 300 of its members registered yesterday at the opening of the two-day annual convention, in a discussion of the Feld-Crawford bill, adopted by the State Legislature a week ago.

Exceptions to the report of M.G. de Quevedo, examiner for the Shipping Board, which he submitted after an extensive investigation of shipping practices in the intercoastal trade, have been filed with the board by the Calmer and Shepard steamship lines, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A check of major kidnapping cases shows that victims were held from two to twenty-three days.

Champions or tailenders, they look alike to Vita Tamulis. The unbeaten Yankee rookie proved this yesterday when he baffled the Detroit Tigers, last year's American League champions, with his southpaw slants before the biggest crowd the Stadium has held this year, and registered his second shut-out in a string of four victories.

MEXICO, D.F., May 26. -- A serious labor conflict threatens at the local Ford plant. Workers charge that the company is trying to organize a company union in opposition to their union, and assert that the company has dismissed without reason several members of their union.
Jimmy McLarnin and Barney Ross, who will clash for the former's world welterweight championship at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night, engaged in brisk training drills in New York yesterday.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Unofficial returns in the AAA wheat referendum in New York State gave evidence today that a better than two-to-one percentage of farmers favored a continuation of the Federal Government's production control.

New York University has received more than 10,000 books during the past few months through the efforts of the Society for the Libraries, according to the Quarterly Bulletin of the Society published today. Donors of large collections included Felix M. Warburg, the Radio Corporation of America and the estates of the late Chancellor Emeritus Elmer Ellsworth Brown and Professor Henry G. Bayer.

MEXICO, D.F., May 26. -- Senorita Maria Elena Rivero, for whom Juan Ignacio Pombo was flying from Spain to Mexico, wept for four hours today upon learning that her cavalier had cracked up his plane in Brazil.
The hallowed hall of minstrelsy opened its portals last night to admit two newcomers to the circle with Honey Boy Evans, Bert Williams and the rest.

In winning two years in succession the British amateur golf championship young LITTLE of California made more than one kind of record. His game this year was not so overwhelmingly brilliant, especially in the finals, as it was in 1934. He had to fight harder for victory.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP). -- More than 50,000 pre-race fans jammed the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today as six more pilots with dazzling bursts of Speed qualified for the 500-mile grind on Thursday.

There is in the world today a struggle between intelligent people with no faith and with no beliefs which move them strongly, and child-like people who have deep emotions and impervious wants, who understand little of the society which they would remold nearer to their hearts' desire, the Rev. Dr. Justin Wroe Nixon, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church at Rochester, N.Y., pointed out in a sermon yesterday morning.

The March grand jury investigating vice and policy rackets has conferred with officials of the Bar Association of the City New York and of the New York County Lawyers Association in preparing the list of six lawyers from which District Attorney William C. Dodge is to select a special vice prosecutor, it was learned yesterday.

The trial of Joseph L. Steinmetz, 22-year-old Presbyterian divinity student, for the murder of his 16-year-old bride, Ruth, in the Knights of Columbus Hotel, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue, on Nov. 26 last, will be resumed today with opposing counsel summing up before the jury and Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. in General Sessions. The trial is in its third week.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- By starting old-age assistance now as provided in the Social Security Bill. State, Federal and local governments will save $1,000,000,000 a year by 1960. Senator Harrison estimated in a radio speech over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight.

LONDON, May 24. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on May 22 at 68.6. This compares with 67.2 a fortnight before, 66.7 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

PARIS, May 25. -- Fears of devaluation of the franc have spread in the last few days in a section of the French public despite the strength of the Bank of France and French private banks and the fact that it is technically much easier to defend the franc than the florin or Swiss franc.

LONDON, May 25. -- Pronounced unsettlement developed this weekend in the foreign exchange markets after a period of calm produced by the bolstering of the franc by the British Exchange Fund. The fund is continuing to support the franc, whose weakness is the result of a heavy outflow of gold from Paris and the political crisis which threatens to envelop France as a consequence of the financial situation now facing the French Treasury.

CHESTER, N.Y., May 26. -- A delegation of 100 brawny, sunburned men from Camp La Guardia, the New York City "human repair shop' for homeless men, crowded into St. Columba's Roman Catholic Church here today to witness the marriage of Ralph Rinaldo, 28 years old, to the daughter of a farmer who gave him a job.

VIENNA, May 26. -- A sensational statement was made today by Prince yon Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor of Austria, at the Heimwehr parade at Salzburg. It was to the effect that all recruiting for militant Fascist bodies had ceased and shortly that all who had joined them since the Febraury overthrow of the Socialist regime by the Heimwehr counter-revolution Would be discharged.

TOKYO, Monday, May 27 (AP). -- The Japanese navy invoked memories of past glories today in support of its fight for equal rating with the navies of the United States and Britain. It was Naval Memorial Day in Japan, the thirtieth anniversary of Admiral Togo's destruction of the Russian Baltic fleet in the battle of the Sea of Japan in 1905.

CHESTER, N.Y., May 26. -- A delegation of 100 brawny, sunburned men from Camp La Guardia, the New York City "human repair shop' for homeless men, crowded into St. Columba's Roman Catholic Church here today to witness the marriage of Ralph Rinaldo, 28 years old, to the daughter of a farmer who gave him a job.

VIENNA, May 26. -- A sensational statement was made today by Prince yon Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor of Austria, at the Heimwehr parade at Salzburg. It was to the effect that all recruiting for militant Fascist bodies had ceased and shortly that all who had joined them since the Febraury overthrow of the Socialist regime by the Heimwehr counter-revolution Would be discharged.

TOKYO, Monday, May 27 (AP). -- The Japanese navy invoked memories of past glories today in support of its fight for equal rating with the navies of the United States and Britain. It was Naval Memorial Day in Japan, the thirtieth anniversary of Admiral Togo's destruction of the Russian Baltic fleet in the battle of the Sea of Japan in 1905.
