SHANGHAI, May 26. -- Reports that Chinese authorities might investigate the factors involved in the bankruptcy of the American-owned American-Oriental Banking Corporation, which suspended operations here May 24, caused United States officials to investigate the possibility of obtaining relief from the deposit liquidation board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Controversy over the Administration's new Banking Bill has centred upon Title II, which proposes to make fundamental changes in the Federal Reserve Act. Unquestionably this is the most important section of the bill. But Mr. PERKINS and other witnesses testifying recently before the Senate committee have also put much emphasis on Title I, which proposes to change at one important point existing law with respect to the insurance of bank deposits.

The annual awards, amounting to $1,000, of prizes to contributors to The Bawl Street Journal, burlesque publication issued once a year by the Bond Club of New York, for material used In its 1935 edition went to thirty persons, it was announced yesterday.

More than 700 persons bowed in a memorial prayer for Jane Addams yesterday morning after John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, had told his congregation at Town Hall that she was "incomparably the greatest of American women in the same sense and to the same extent that Abraham Lincoln was the greatest of American men."

PORTSMOUTH, England, May 26. -- The great interest of the British public in yacht racing this year, due largely to the presence of Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee, was demonstrated today as hundreds of automobiles brought crowds to Portsmouth and Gosport to see the American yacht and other J Class boats preparing for the season's first regatta next Saturday.

Three thousand persons attended last night a benefit sponsored by the Physicians Equity Association of America, Inc., at the Center Theatre in Rockefeller City. The association recently announced plans by which it hoped to place the medical profession on a sounder economic basis.

Detective William Walsh, the lost child expert of the Bath Beach police station in Brooklyn, held 5-year-old Robert Fineberg on his knee yesterday and told him a horrifying tale of the terrors he would meet if he got lost again.

No permanent recovery will be possible until the world's trade barriers are reduced and its leading currencies stabilized. The need for the latter is not merely beyond question; with the difficulties now confronting the remaining gold-bloc countries, it has become urgent.

TACOMA, Wash., May 26. -- Forewarned that their kidnapped son had but three days more to live unless ransomed for $200,000, Mr. and Mrs. J.P. Weyerhaeuser worked in seclusion today to bring about a contact with the abductors and the return of George Weyerhaeuser, 9.

The French liner Champlain arrived yesterday from Havre with twenty passengers who paid $1,000 for passage. The ship carried no gold, no mails and no cargo. The loss on the westward voyage was estimated to be at least $40,000. The vessel carried a full crew and had to burn extra fuel to travel at full speed in order to arrive in time to sail at noon today with a good list of passengers.

The view that the Securities Act of 1933, as amended and administered, is not now an excessive handicap to industry is taken in a report released today by the committee on financial legislation of the National Conference of Business Paper Editors and the Associated Business Papers, Inc.

After the extraordinary support which President ROOSEVELT received in the elections of 1934, no jubilant word came from him. Other Democrats rejoiced with exceeding joy, but there is no record to show that Mr. ROOSEVELT expressed himself publicly in any way whatever.

ATLANTA, May 26 (AP). -- Amelia Earhart received a degree of Doctor of Public Service from Oglethorpe University today, when the university, founded primarily for the education of men, honored twelve outstanding American women with degrees.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The nation's dead were honored and the living were called upon to meet the challenge of the difficult present with renewed loyalty to American ideals and traditions, in addresses delivered today at the eighth annual massing of the colors at the Washington Cathedral on Mount St. Albans.

COPENHAGEN, May 26. -- Amid bright sunshine and countless flags, a hundred thousand Danes and Swedes welcomed Crown Prince Frederik and his bride, Princess Ingrid, on their arrival on the royal steam yacht Dannebrog this afternoon.

CLEMENTON, N.J., May 26 (AP). -- C. Mulford Scull of Ventnor, National Class C outboard champion, scored the first victory for the new Everett Shannon Memorial Trophy after a mishap today at the first of six regattas arranged by the Clementon Lake Outboard Club.

H.I. Peffer, president of the Seagram-Distillers Corporation, announced yesterday that his company would open an advertising campaign to try to convince the public that "driving and drinking do not mix." Mr. Peffer made this disclosure at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore of the information committee of the Moderation Foundation.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Encouraged by returns from Saturday's referendum, administration officials today began drafting new four-year benefit contracts for wheat farmers and looked with fresh confidence toward favorable Congressional action on Secretary Wallace's long-delayed proposal for "clarification" of the AAA Law.

Strolling quietly in the sunshine, a few passersby on West Thirtieth Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues were startled a few minutes after noon yesterday by the scream of a woman who had peered into a sedan parked in front of 325 West Thirtieth Street.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26. -- Seniors at the Newark College of Engineering indicated today their desire for a co-educational institution. In answer to "Should girls be excluded from N.C.E.?" one of the points of a questionnaire submitted to them, the seniors voted for the girls, 64 to 12.

A reduction of State and Federal taxes on wines and spirits to combat bootlegging is advocated and cooperation with Federal and State agencies in suppressing illegal liquor traffic is pledged in a platform adopted by the recently organized Retail Wine and Liquor Guild. The platform was made public yesterday by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the guild.

GREENVILLE, Me., May 26. -- Old Pop Masterman, 65-year-old dean of Moosehead Lake guides, leaned against the boathouse at the Squaw Mountain Inn dock, stroked his white beard reflectively, and remarked how times have changed.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 26. -- Freddie Fleischmann's Primrose poloists prevailed in a round robin with the Norwood Ramblers and Milton Untermeyer's Evergreen Farms at the Norwood C.C. today. Primrose tallied 8, Evergreen Farms 5 and Ramblers 2.

William C. Gordon, 11 years old, was the youngest reader yesterday at an overflow meeting in Rockefeller Center marking the close of the ninth annual celebration of Poetry Week. Per line read, he was certainly the most successful.

Ship owners engaged in foreign trade should be free to lower or increase freight rates at will in accordance with competitive conditions at foreign ports and should not be restricted by regulations of the United States Government, according to a report of a committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public last night.

LONDON, May 25. -- President Roosevelt's victory in the Bonus Bill struggle was received with considerable satisfaction in London financial quarters. It was regarded as a decisive defeat for the inflationists, although the supporters of a sound money policy probably have more obstacles to surmount before the danger of unsound, as distinct from sound and permissible, inflation has passed.

A crowd of 10,000, one of the largest ever to witness a polo match at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn, saw the First Division ride to a 6-1 victory over the Mitchel Field Aviators of Long Island yesterday.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. failed to appear as a speaker yesterday afternoon at the annual Memorial Day services of the Brooklyn Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars, because he had been requested to stay away for having supported the President's veto of the Patman Bonus Bill last Wednesday.

God's seeming indifference in allowing confusion and chaos to exist in the world today is part of His plan in the development of the personality of man, the Rev. Dr. J.C. Bacon, pastor of the Jesmond Presbyterian Church, Newcastle-on-Tyne, England, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.
GREENVILLE, Me., May 26 (AP). -- Mishaps today overtook one of the Governors attending the Gubernatorial fishing party of the Chief Executive of Maine.

Miss Marion Lloyd of the Salle d'Armes Vince topped the field of twelve contestants in the women's outdoor invitation foils tournament at the Hellman Estate in Flushing yesterday. The former national titleholder concluded an unusually fine performance with a clean sweep of five matches in the final round robin.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The text of the Treasury statement offering $100,000,000 of 3 per cent bonds was as follows:

Although the Securities Act of 1933 became law two years ago today, not a single suit to enforce the civil liability that it created has been recorded in any official report of legal decisions, it was pointed out yesterday by Charles H. Meyer, an authority on the law of Stock Exchanges and the author of books on this subject.
GREENVILLE, Me., May 26 (AP). -- Mishaps today overtook one of the Governors attending the Gubernatorial fishing party of the Chief Executive of Maine.

CINCINNATI, May 27. -- After long and heated discussion the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America late today refused to permit three Fundamentalist ministers to sit as commissioners. They were the Revs. H. McAllister Griffiths and Merrill T. MacPherson of Philadelphia and Carl McIntire of Collingswood, N.J.

A stocky, gray-haired man sat behind a classroom desk yesterday at the Herman Ridder Junior High School, 173d Street and Boston Road, the Bronx, ate lunch in the school cafeteria and marched with 3,000 pupils in a fire drill.

Walter B. Reade and Charles Bryan, heads of a chain theatre system, were arraigned before Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday. They had surrendered a few minutes before on a felony indictment accusing them of participation with three fugitives in the destruction of the interior of the Astor Theatre, at Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, of which Reade had been the owner.

Former directors of the National City Company, security affiliate of the National City Bank during the Charles E. Mitchell regime, should be held liable to stockholders for $1,708,703, Referee Frank C. Laughlin recommended yesterday in submitting to Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore his findings in the suit brought by minority stockholders.
LONDON, May 27. -- In death as well as in life Lawrence of Arabia may go without official recognition of what he did for his country in the World War.

LONDON, May 27. -- The Times of London, in a long chief editorial tomorrow, headed "Mr. Roosevelt's Problem," says it considers the prospect of stabilization of money in the near future highly improbable.

DEVON, Pa., May 27. -- The Dilwyne Farm Stables, owned by Mr. and Mrs. R.M. Carpenter of Montchanin, Del., triumphed at the third session of the Devon Horse Show today with King Vulture in the thoroughbred middle and heavyweight hunter class over the outside course.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Here is the gist of the three Supreme Court decisions in which the Roosevelt administration was reversed today:
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 27 (AP). -- Miss Mary McElroy, who resigned herself to death when kidnapped for $30,000 two years ago, succeeded today in saving her abductor, Walter McGee, from death on the gallows.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- The Indians put on a stirring ninth-inning rally today, but could not equal Washington's early scoring and lost their second straight to the Senators, 6 to 5.

On Mayor La Guardia's orders, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, began an investigation yesterday into the charge of the Citizens Budget Commission that employes of the Chief Medical Examiner's office have collected at least $170,000 in illegal fees.
Ray W. Sherman in his letter to THE TIMES pitches upon the most serious point of modern driving; namely, skill.

After kissing her three tiny children and clasping them close to her, an unidentified woman of about 35 jumped to her death from the roof of a tenement at 2,310 Second Avenue, near 119th Street, shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

The Bobby Jones of women's golf, Miss Joyce Wethered of England, arrived in the United States yesterday, ready and eager to embark on her career as a playing professional. The four-time winner of the British title reached here on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

A report outlining a policy of freedom of speech on the air and the elimination of propaganda from radio programs was submitted yesterday to the advisory council of the National Broadcasting Company by Merlin H. Aylesworth, president of the organization.

DETROIT, May 27. -- Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company and president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, said tonight he did not believe the Supreme Court ruling on the President's code-making powers would make any material change in conditions in the automobile industry.

A further bearing was held yesterday by Harry A. Gordon, former magistrate, acting as State referee in the receivership of S.W. Straus Co. on a claim for $1,500,000 for completion of the Majestic Hotel at Seventy-second Street and Central Park West, which it is alleged Straus Co. guaranteed.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking will hold graduating exercises at 8 o'clock tonight in the Brick Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, will speak on "Banking as Education."

ALBANY, May 27. -- The Adirondack forest preserve may be closed to visitors on Memorial Day if present conditions and forest fires continue, Acting Governor M. William Bray said today he had been in touch with Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne and that the latter has been directed to take extraordinary measures, not only in suppressing fires now burning, but also to prevent new ones.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Creation of a Federal Advisory Committee of five members, appointed by the President to function under the Federal Reserve Board, was urged before a subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee today by Adolph C. Miller, a member of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The that bankers and lawyers play in railroad reorganizations was stressed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission at a public hearing in its investigation of the affairs of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company.

Joseph Schechter, head of the Schechter Poultry Corporation, which successfully contested the validity of the National Industrial Recovery Act, declared last night that the cost of the legal battle was $60,000 and that he would have preferred to go to jail if he had known it would cost so much.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA AT PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, May 27. -- The navy has a "pearl diver" all its own. He is Garland Suggs, chief turret captain and master diver at the submarine base here. He has been called a human fish, as some of his exploits in the submarine escape training tank, where men are taught to use the navy's "lungs," are said to exceed those of South Sea pearl divers.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- By a unanimous decision in the Schechter poultry case the Supreme Court today held unconstitutional the National Industrial Recovery Act, due to expire by limitation on June 16, and, by voiding the 750 codes which are the heart of the National Recovery Administration and denying the right of Congress or its agents to fix wages and hours in intrastate trade activities, demolished the chief administrative recovery weapon of the New Deal.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP). -- With Vernon Wilshere, rookie left-hander, holding the White Sox to seven hits, well scattered, the Athletics stopped the American League leaders, 6 to 1, today.

The students in the 7B grade at Public School 35, Hollis, Queens, acclaimed a hero yesterday morning when 11-year-old William C. Gordon walked proudly into the classroom. He is the school poet who created a stir on Sunday when he read one of his verses at exercises in Rockefeller Center marking the close of Poetry Week.

CALLANDER, Ont., May 27 (AP). -- The five Dionne babies' first birthday anniversary is to be celebrated here tomorrow, the first in history to be observed by quintuplets. Preparation for the event went forward today as rain fell a few miles from the hospital and homestead, and more was promised to quench the forest fires that have been burning menacingly in this vicinity.
The storm of chain letters that swirled out of Denver and covered most of the country with nebulous promises has begun to recede, postoffice officials here reported yesterday.

PARIS, May 27. -- Powers not much less extensive than those Congress accorded to the President of the United States will be asked for tomorrow in the French Parliament by Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin to enable him protect the franc.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 27. -- Blame for the present political unrest was attributed to maladministration rather than any basic defect in the American form of government by Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, in an address here today at the 110th commencement of Hobart College and the twenty-fourth of William Smith College.

The annual campaign for funds to make it possible for needy city children to go to Summer camps was opened yesterday under the auspices of the committee on vacation homes and camps of the Children's Welfare Federation.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on May 22 shows increases for the week of $37,000,000 in total loans and investments, $143,000,000 in net demand deposits and $29,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $20,000,000 in time deposits and $33,000,000 in government deposits.

BERLIN, May 27. -- The Boerse was inactive today. Altogether the market was slightly nervous, the closing was fairly firm. Heavy industrial issues were quiet, Mannesmann gaining a. point. Machineries were inactive, with evidence of weakness, Berlin Iarlsruhe losing point.

The Roxy Theatre contracted yesterday for the exhibition of all Gaumont British film releases in this country during the coming season. In signing the contract Howard S. Cullman, managing director of the Roxy, said, "There is no longer any distinction to be made between Hollywood and British films."

Except for a lowering in the lenders' quotation for long-time money to one-quarter of 1 per cent, from three-eighths, nothing else occurred in the money market to excite interest. Even this shading in the charge for money running up to nine months failed to produce any business for the banks; in fact the inquiry for any length of time was negligible.

IT was fairly close all the way while Barney Ross and James Archibald McLarnin were whacking away for thirty rounds in two previous fights, and it may be difficult for the officials to sort out a winner in what will be a play-off and a pay-off at the Polo Grounds this evening, provided the Weather Man leads with his right.

Election of a Republican Assembly this Fall, with increasing prospect for a party victory in the State next year, was predicted yesterday by Melvin C. Eaton, State chairman, on his return from a trip through the central and western parts of the State.

Two incidental reasons for satisfaction with the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of the National Industrial Recovery Act must catch every eye. The first is that Chief Justice HUGHES spoke for a unanimous court. There can be no question now of asserting that the minority was right in a 5-to-4 decision; nor can there be invidious remarks about the Tories among the judges outvoting the Liberals.

The Midtown Galleries, 559 Fifth Avenue, opened yesterday an exhibition in which each of the pictures shown has been priced at $50. Among the artists represented are: M.A. Aldrich, Isabel Bishop, Francis Criss, Minna Citron, Vincent Drennan, Eugene Fitsch, Charles Logasa, Mary Hutchinson, Margaret Huntington, Paul R. Meltsner, Paul Mommer, Fred Nagler, William Palmer, Waldo Peirce, Doris Rosenthal, Saul, Anatol Shulkin and Marko Vukovic. There is also sculpture by Oronzio Maldarelli.

An abrupt cessation of buying activities in many of the more sensitive merchandise lines, particularly of Fall goods, was the first response yesterday of a bewildered business community to the Supreme Court decision, invalidating the National Industrial Recovery Act.

The Farm Bankruptcy Law, held yesterday by the Supreme Court to be unconstitutional, was not strictly a New Deal measure. To be sure, Mr. ROOSEVELT signed it, and in so doing praised its purposes. But he also said of it that it was "in some respects loosely worded" and "would require amendment."
The eleven girl graduates of Notre Dame College, Grymes Hill, Staten Island, received their diplomas yesterday from Cardinal Hayes. The commencement exercises were held on the campus.

LONDON, May 27. -- Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, received cheers and was publicly congratulated for his part in the Ethiopian settlement by George Lansbury, leader of the Opposition, today on Mr. Eden's first appearance in the House of Commons since his return from Geneva.

Louis Weiner, reputed by the police to be second only to Nicholas (Nick) Montana among New York's vice overlords, was taken into custody last night at Fifteenth Street and Irving Place and locked up in the East Twenty-second Street station. He was charged with having violated Section 2,460 of the Penal Code, which deals with compulsory prostitution.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The largest issue of securities of an industrial company which is not in process of reorganization to be offered to the public since the enactment of the Securities Act of 1933 will be placed on sale today. A banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer at 100 1/2 and accrued interest $50,000,000 of the National Steel Corporation's first collateral mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series, due on June 1, 1965.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., May 27. The most notable sale of thoroughbred dogs ever held in this country, making the only occasion on which a famous kennel has been dispersed by auction, was conducted today at the Scotsward Kennels of Mrs. C.B. Ward.
PORTSMOUTH, England, May 27. -- Gerard B. Lambert dropped a bombshell in yachting circles today with the announcement that his sloop Yankee would not compete in the Harwich regatta on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Immediate suspension of all NRA code enforcement was announced tonight by Donald R. Richberg, chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board, who appended to the announcement an appeal to employers to maintain the standards of labor and fair practice achieved under the code system.
The trial of Joseph L. Steinmetz for murder in the first degree will enter today its twelfth and probably its last day when Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. will give it to a General Sessions jury.

Experimentation in Washington today is holding back recovery and discouraging business men from developing forward programs, C.M. Chester, president of the General Foods Corporation, said in a speech yesterday before the luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The State Department of Labor has reversed its policy on enforcing Section 182 of the Labor Law as it affects hat check and cigarette girls in restaurants, it was indicated yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.
In your editorial on the proposed Banking Bill of 1935, printed on May 22, the following sentence appeared:

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- A controversy between Senator Norris and Controller General John R. McCarl over the Tennessee Valley Authority sharpened today as Mr. Norris voiced fear that the power rate "yardstick" on the TVA would be wrecked by court injunctions and audits.

While the implications of the Supreme Court NRA decision upon Fall merchandising were fully recognized by buyers in the market here yesterday, those here for Summer goods placed their orders fairly freely. At several leading buying offices, including two of the largest in the market, it was said that "if the week continues as active as today, there will be no complaint on the score of volume for quick delivery."

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The scene in the Supreme Court chamber today was one of the most dramatic in years as a capacity throng awaited the NRA decision. The place seemed electrified even before the nine justices filed in and on almost every face was a reflection of the tension which led Donald R. Richberg, NRA chief, to say to a friend:
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The concurring opinion in the Schechter NRA case, written by Justice Cardozo and joined in by Justice Stone, read as follows:

Fox Film Corporation, one of the oldest of the motion picture producing companies, and Twentieth Century Pictures, Inc., one of the youngest, will be merged soon, according to a joint announcement yesterday by the heads of the two corporations.

PHILADELPHIA. May 27. -- The garment and hosiery industries were warned here this evening by the heads of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the American Federation of Hosiery Workers that attempts to nullify gains made by the workers under the NRA codes would meet with resistance.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was offering to all its employes an opportunity to obtain group life insurance under the plan adopted at the recent annual meeting of the stockholders. The cost will be borne jointly by the corporation and the employes.
BELEM, Brazil, May 27 (AP). -- Juan Ignacio Pombo, with a cablegram from Mexico "too sweet to divulge" in his left vest pocket, decided tonight to fly on to "romantic Mexico."

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 27. -- Long Island capitalists figured in the purchase of the well-known Royal Pines Hotel, at Pinewald, which for a long time was held in receivership following the crash of the Pinewald development program of Benjamin W. Sangor, it is reported here.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Treasury will offer on or before June 15, a new series of notes in exchange for $416,602,800 in 3 per cent notes maturing at mid-June and $353,865,000 1 5/8 per cent notes falling due Aug. 1, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

Announcement yesterday of the coming offering of an additional issue of $100,000,000 of United States Treasury 3 per cent bonds due from 1946 to 1948 was accompanied by a moderate degree of selling of government loans on the market here. Bids will be opened tomorrow afternoon, just after the close of the market, and actual sale to the public consequently will be deferred until after Memorial Day.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew reserved decision yesterday after hearing argument on the application of Martin Mooney, reporter for The New York American, to sustain a writ of habeas corpus granting him freedom from a sentence of thirty days and a $250 fine imposed by General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig.

Once The Players used to revive classical warhorses for their Spring serenades, and it was necessary for friendly critics to be considerate. Last evening they treated the National Theatre to a tingling revival of "Seven Keys to Baldpate," with Mr. Cohan and a notable cast on the stage.
The award of graduate residence scholarships in Columbia University for 1935-36 to fifty-seven students, thirty of whom are women, was announced yesterday by Secretary Frank D. Fackenthal.

Florence Rogge, youthful ballet director at the Radio City Music Hall will have charge of its next stage production, "Rhapsody in Green," which will be presented on Thursday. Among the artists taking part in her first production are Jan Peerce, the tenor; Hilda Eckler and Marie Grimaldi, ballerinas; Nicholas Daks, Novello brothers, Joseph Castka, the Music Hall corps de ballet, the Rockettes and the Glee Club.

TRENTON, N.J., May 27. -- Three moves in the New Jersey Legislature tonight complicated and delayed definite action on the State's relief problem. Possibility of adjournment this week or a recess until Fall was ended when the Senate adjourned until next Monday night.

The management of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad 1 plans to discuss its reorginazation proposals within the next two weeks with officials of large insurance companies holding its bonds. The proposals Will Be subject to agreements reached at this and subsequent meetings.

Much of the blame for the failure of thousands of persons to obtain treatment for cancer in stages when it is still curable was put yesterday on the general practitioner who "discourages his patients from going to cancer clinics."

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 27. -- Officers and men who have come back from the Pacific war games on the fleet gathered here are telling tales of their experiences and hardships.

Although preferring to reserve comment until they had seen the official text of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the NRA codes, prominent Wall Street attorneys said yesterday that it seemed to contain a definite threat to the constitutionality of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Most commoditiy futures were higher yesterday and the other staples were fairly steady despite the lower prices for grain and cotton futures. On the cash markets lead made a new high price and wheat, rye, silk and rubber advanced, while cotton, corn, oats, flour and butter declined.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- The attitude of many business men toward the NRA ruling by the Supreme Court today was expressed in the words of Sewell Avery, president of Montgomery Ward Co., who a few months ago had asserted the retail code was illegal and unfair.
CANTON, Ohio, May 27. -- Twenty persons were injured today, one seriously, in a burst of gunfire and rioting at the plant of the Berger Manufacturing Company, where a strike began this morning.

HONOLULU, May 27. -- Stressing the peaceful mission of navies an "Aloha" message to the United States fleet was issued to the Honolulu press today by Teijo Tamura, Japanese Consul General in Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Federal regulation of the nation's $2,000,000,000 liquor business will be ended and the Alcohol Control Administration must cease to exist as a result of the Supreme Court's decision, Joseph H. Choate, administrator, told a mass meeting of FACA workers this afternoon.

Irving Eldridge, 128 3/4, of the East Side, and Jerry Mazza, 127 1/2, of Bensonhurst, boxed to an eight-round draw in the feature contest at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the show, the final one of the season.
NEWCASTLE, County Down, Ireland, May 27. -- Miss Mary Brown, the Argentine champion, was the only overseas survivor at the end of the first round of the British women's open golf championship today.

The existence of an American Legion poppy racket was disclosed last night in Night Court when two men, each with his right leg missing, pleaded not guilty to selling the flowers under false pretenses. Their statements to the police and Magistrate Jonah Goldstein resulted in the arrest of third man who was held in $10,000 bail for a hearing tonight.

The last of the Interclub Class B matches in the Long Island division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association brought victories in the series to the Woodmere and Women's National teams yesterday. Fifty-nine players went around the Pomonok Country Club links at Flushing in the final contests.

Alfred J. McCosker, president of the Bamberger Broadcasting Service, Inc., replied yesterday to charges of political control of the air, made by Howard Davis, former president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, in a speech May 18 in Waterville, Me.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- Prices of hogs reached $10.20 a hundred pounds here today, the best level since Oct. 17, 1930. With the exception of two Saturdays, the daily price on hogs here has been higher every day for the last fifteen days. Pork loins were 1 to 4 cents a pound higher than a week ago.

SALEM, N.H., May 27 (AP). -- The Greentree Stable's favored 2-year-old bay filly, Torita, scampered away with the major part of the $1,500 purse in the Nashua claiming race, featured event on the program today at Rockingham Park.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- A new bonus compromise was proffered to Congress today, but there was no indication that it would be accepted by the groups fighting for full cash payment.

JERICHO, L.I., May 27. -- The remaining furnishings of Ivy Hall, the country residence of the late Judge Elbert H. Gary and Mrs. Gary, totaling about 300 lots, were sold today at auction on the premises at morning and afternoon sessions for $10,337.50.

Details of the $5,000,000 of financing planned by Jersey City, N.J., were announced yesterday. The city will open bids, for which it formally addressed invitations to banks yesterday, on June 4. The financing will consist of two issues, $1,800,000 of serial funding bonds and $3,200,000 of general refunding bonds.

SALISBURY PLAINS, L.I., May 27. -- John O'Brien, pro at the Old Belleclaire Golf Club, and his amateur partner, Tom Huskins, collaborated handsomely today in negotiating a sub-par 67 to win the premier honors in an amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association over the No. 4 course at the Salisbury Country Club.

Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow and his bride, the former Barbara Hutton, and Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, are among the 1,600 passengers leaving tonight on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd for the Channel ports.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Highlights in the Supreme Court's decision in the Schechter case, involving the NRA, were:

The Hebrew Technical Institute will graduate a class of 107 students at exercises at 8:30 o'clock this evening in the large hall of Cooper Union, Dr. K. George Falk, president of the institute, will deliver an address. A motion picture of the institute in session, entitled "Learning Through Doing," will be shown.

How about the scores of thousands of telegrams that poured in upon President ROOSEVELT demanding the bonus? We are, in some respects, a volatile nation. Now that the bonus veto has gone over in such a big way there will be people to question the authenticity of all those telegrams to your Representative, your Senator and your President.

Attention of followers of the financial markets during the early part of yesterday was concerned largely with scanning the foreign news for possible clues to the immediate outcome of France's serious financial situation; during the final hour of business on the Stock Exchange the series of decisions of the United States Supreme Court which went against the New Deal claimed first attention.

Three shifts of workmen have been assigned to Pier 88, North River, in an effort to have it ready for the berthing of the French liner Normandie on her arrival here June 3, it was announced yesterday by the Public Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- Representative A.J. Sabath said today that "certain interests" had put a private detective on the trail of Murray Garsson, investigator for his special committee inquiring into so-called protective bondholder committees.

By a three-point margin, Evander Childs High School's track and field squad dethroned DeWitt Clinton as the Bronx P.S.A.L. team champion in the annual title meet held at Ohio Field yesterday. Scoring in ten of the eleven senior events and taking five individual crowns, Evander amassed 55 tallies.
Newspapers throughout the country express editorial satisfaction with the Supreme Court decision on the NIRA. Extracts as telegraphed to THE NEW YORK TIMES are as follows:

Unlike Patsy Grazzianni, the genial hot-dog vendor of Washington Square, Ercole Panessa, the elongated Italian bootblack, has many competitors who vie with him for the pedestrians with dusty shoes and a nickel in their pockets.

GREENVILLE, Me., May 27. -- Maine, with its 5,000 lakes and streams, is divided roughly into seven great fishing districts, comprising a vast recreational playground which last year attracted 35,000 visitors from outside the State.
BERLIN, May 27. -- Nothing has yet been heard in official quarters here about new American suggestions for a currency stabilization conference.

Responding to a united-front call by the Columbia University Anti-War League, representatives of more than thirty student groups met at Columbia last night to organize a Medical Centre defense committee to fight for the reinstatement of two instructors and three technicians who have been dropped at the Medical Centre.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Organized labor was dazed by the Schechter case decision today, fearing that its program of labor legislation, especially the Wagner Trade Disputes Bill, would be adversely affected within sight of its almost certain goal, passage in the House.
Appeals for public support of the neutrality legislation pending before Congress were made at a "Keep America Out of War" mass meeting in Carnegie Hall last night by the authors of those measures.

PICHER, Okla., May 27 (AP). -- Shouting "Let's tear down the union headquarters," 1,500 non-union lead and zinc miners from Miami, Okla., poured into Picher late today ahead of two National Guard units ordered here by Governor Marland to prevent threatened riots.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP). -- Although production of packing house commodities in April was 2 per cent greater than in March, the output was sharply lower than in April, 1934, the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank reported today.

SOFIA, May 27. -- The visit of General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Air Minister, took on added significance today, after he had received one of Bulgaria's highest decorations and spent the afternoon with King Boris, when it became known that a Bulgarian delegation recently secretly visited Berlin.

LONDON, May 27. -- Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, gave the affirmative reply of the British Government tonight to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's statement of his readiness to supplement the Locarno treaty by an air pact.

TRENTON, N.J., May 27. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann, under sentence to the electric chair for the murder of the Lindbergh baby, was visited at the death house in the State Prison here today by his sister, Mrs. Emma Gloeckner of Los Angeles.

The Union Bag and Paper Company reported yesterday a net profit of $418,085 after Federal taxes, depreciation and other charges for the twelve months ended on March 31. This was equal to $2.86 a share on 145,966 no-par capital shares, excluding 3,735 treasury shares.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 27 (AP). -- Surprised to learn that President Roosevelt had ordered the navy and Coast Guard to search for him, William B. Leeds Jr. reached here today and told of rough water preventing him from entering Bimini Harbor last night after a voyage from Miami in his 26-foot cruiser.

Frankly expressing great disappointment but declining to comment at length on the decision of the Supreme Court on the NRA, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, rushed back to Washington from New York last night to confer with legal advisers of the A.F. of L. He is expected to confer also with President Roosevelt today.

Assisted by Anita Zahn and a group of young dancers, Georges Barrere and the Barrere Little Symphony gave what was described as a "post-season" concert in the Town Hall last night to the delectation of an audience which derived the customary amusement from Mr. Barrere's explanatory witticisms and applauded him as commentator, conductor and solo flutist with the utmost impartiality.

Controller Frank J. Taylor testified in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday that he suffers from suffocating sensations caused by injuries to his heart and lungs in 1932 when a faulty gas heater in his home gave off carbon monoxide fumes one night.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- Congressional opponents of NRA today loudly applauded the Supreme Court's decision of unconstitutionality, while from some administration spokesmen came assertions that the damage could be repaired.

The traffic executive committee of the Maritime Association yesterday declared itself unalterably opposed to Federal legislation designed to eliminate or modify the fourth section of the Interstate Commerce Act, which deals with long-and-short haul movements of freight.

LONDON, May 27 (AP). -- Great Britain will "call" Adolf Hitler on his offer to abolish submarines when Anglo-German naval talks open here next Tuesday, well-informed quarters said tonight. Herr Hitler, in his speech to the Reichstag last Tuesday, offered to meet other powers in curbing armaments, even to the scrapping of U-boats.

LONDON, May 27. -- The most impressive fact in the world today is that the 3,000-odd mile frontier between Canada and the United States is utterly undefended, Lord Tweedsmuir, better known as John Buchan, the author and Governor General designate to Canada, declared at the Canada Club at a dinner in his honor tonight. G.H. Ferguson, Canadian High Commissioner, presided.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Supreme Court decision on the constitutionality of the National Industrial Recovery Act, as read by Chief Justice Hughes, follows:

Graduation exercises of the National Bible Institute and Union Missionary Training Institute will be held at 8 o'clock this evening in the institute auditorium, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street. The Rev. Arthur H. Gordon, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Middlebury, Vt., will make the commencement address.

The Supreme Court's decisions have thrown the whole New Deal into "black confusion," but a new statute can be written to preserve the principles of NRA, General Hugh S. Johnson declared last night in an address before the closing session of the American Booksellers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Ten representatives of brokerage firms in New England which are members of the New York Stock Exchange visited the Exchange yesterday to meet officials and to observe floor trading. After luncheon they met for a roundtable discussion with Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange; Maurice L. Farrell, chairman of the committee on public relations; Herbert G. Wellington, acting chairman of the committee on quotations and commissions, and other committee members.

Fifteen thousand Communists welcomed two of their heroes in Madison Square Garden last night. At 7:30 P.M. Robert Minor and David Levinson stepped off a train from Chicago at Pennsylvania Station. More than 1,000 friends were on hand to greet the victims of the recent kidnapping and beating at Gallup, N.M., and to escort them to the meeting.

CINCINNATI, May 27 (AP). -- The Reds scored their fifth straight victory today, defeating Boston, 9 to 5, as they found three pitchers for fourteen hits. It also was the Braves' fifth consecutive defeat.

TROY, N.Y., May 27. -- Granville Hicks, a leading exponent of Marxian criticism in American literature and literary editor of The New Masses, Communist weekly, has been dropped from the faculty of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, college authorities revealed today.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 27. -- The decision of the Supreme Court wiping out the NRA codes probably will mean the end of the Joseph law, New York State's NRA enforcement act, in the opinion of Henry Epstein, Solicitor General of the State of New York.

California continues to be the bright spot in the territory of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, according to S.T. Bledsoe, president. He said yesterday that the rest of the territory had been aided materially by rain and that this applied to places where grain had not been destroyed by dust storms.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Although high NRA officials announced that their subordinates were to carry on "business as usual" in the administrative field, the work of the NRA almost came to a halt today after the Supreme Court invalidated the NIRA.

LONDON, May 27. -After a quiet opening today, with speculative activity restricted largely because of uncertainty over foreign exchanges, the stock market became firmer, particularly industrial, aircraft, motor, iron and steel securities.

Eight operas, each to have two performances so as to provide sixteen nights of opera in all, will be given at the Stadium concerts this Summer, and there will be an equal number of evenings devoted to ballet performances.

The problems inherent in the present multi-lingual situation and the obstacles which languages have placed in the path of world peace and cooperation were discussed in a symposium yesterday which was combined with a reception for Dave H. Morris, Ambassador to Belgium, and Mrs. Morris at the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street.

Of the many commissions created by the Legislature to study current problems, none is more important than the one which is directed to make a survey of State aid to municipalities. It is cause for gratification, therefore, that Governor LEHMAN, at whose instance the commission was created, has been able to secure men of exceptionally high standing in the community, regardless of narrow partisan considerations, to conduct the survey.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 27. -- The 3-year-old boy who was found at 8:30 o'clock last night wandering along Webster Avenue, and later was taken by the police to White Plains while a search was made for his parents, was identified tentatively today by Mrs. Dorothy Church of 334 Glen Hill Avenue, where the boy had been boarding.

A volume containing thirteen short stories by Sinclair Lewis will be brought out by Doubleday, Doran on July 1 and distributed by the Literary Guild as a dividend. The title will be "Selected Short Stories."
BOSTON, May 27 (AP). -- Al Bejma's homer and Julius (Moose) Solters's triple, each with a runner on base, today paved the way for the Browns' 5-3 victory over the Red Sox.

BUENOS AIRES, May 27. -- The first plenary session of the Pan-American Commercial Conference this afternoon was devoted to organizing. The delegates elected per manent officers and then appointed six committees to study projects presented by various delegations and to recommend action on them.

Fifty-three boys and girls, averaging 12 years of age, were graduated yesterday afternoon by the elementary department of the Ethical Culture Schools, 33 Central Park West. The exercises were held in the school auditorium and Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, director of the New York Ethical Culture Society, was the principal speaker.

Tribute to the effectiveness of the fair trade practice provisions of the Retail Jewelry Code in combating trade evils, particularly misrepresentation, fake liquidations and auction sales, was paid yesterday by Burton A. Zorn, NRA trade compliance officer for New York, who addressed the twenty-sixth annual convention of the New York State Jewelers Association, which began yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

Both in his relations with the Executive and the Senate Mr. GARNER has been the perfect Vice President. It would be necessary to go back to MARTIN VAN BUREN to find an equally consummate player of a difficult part. Soaked in the traditions of the House, as its Speaker accustomed to a certain arbitrariness in the expedition of business.

William Lawrence, a private detective and brother of Patrolman Thomas Lawrence, was asked yesterday at the trial in Brooklyn Police Headquarters of the patrolman, his wife, Hortense, a policewoman, and Detective Michael Markey whether the patrolman had ever had his picture taken in Ravenhall's Baths at Coney Island with the late Frankie Uale, gangster.

CINCINNATI, May 27 (AP). -- A seven-point agreement by which union leaders said 2,200 workers at the Chevrolet-Fisher Body plant here would return to work tomorrow morning -- definitely ending a strike which began April 30 -- was reached at a mass meeting of workers here tonight.
In your issue of May 25 there appeared an interesting letter from Isaac Penson, under the caption "Election Law Changes Urged."
The famed Tigers, who won last year's American League pennant, were subdued yesterday at the Stadium as Johnny Allen cracked the whip and got results.

Barney Ross will make his second bid for the world's welterweight championship tonight, when he opposes Jimmy McLarnin, holder of the title, in a fifteen-round bout at the Polo Grounds. The contest, which will mark the third meeting between the pair, will be promoted by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

The State Controller's office continued to pay the salary of Supreme Court Justice Phoenix Ingraham for seven months after his death on April 30, 1934, it was disclosed in Surrogates' Court yesterday in an accounting by the executors of his estate.

A small-scale labor clash interrupted the flow of Broadway sidewalk traffic last night and there was a scattering of fist fights outside the George M. Cohan Theatre, a motion picture house between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, until the police intervened and arrested three men on a disorderly conduct charge.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- Testimony intended to produce "circumstantial evidence" in support of the old charge that Andrew W. Mellon did not actually dispose of his bank stocks when he became Secretary of the Treasury in 1931 was admitted today in his income-tax hearing.

TACOMA, Wash., May 27. -- Racing against the deadline set for payment of $200,000 ransom, the parents of 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser met secretly today with officials while Department of Justice agents began a search for "at least three men" as the suspected kidnappers.

PARIS, May 27. -- There was much superficial agitation on the Bourse today, but finally, after the result of the French Cabinet meeting became known, calm was restored and, on the whole, prices closed satisfactorily.

Authentic Summer weather arrived in the city yesterday, holding the temperature in the 80s throughou the afternoon, with a high mark of 84 at 3:30 o'clock. The average temperature was seven degrees above normal for the date, which is 64.

John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland, returned yesterday on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line on a vacation. He will visit his home in Milwaukee before going back to his post. Mr. Cudahy ridiculed the idea that a war cloud hovers over Europe and that Poland is a tinder box, citing Poland's foreign policy as outlined by her Minister of Foreign Affairs, Jozef Beck.

Once the United States was the Land of the Lyceum. To foreign nations it is still the giver of moral lectures to other countries. According to a more or less jocose legend, almost every Englishman or Englishwoman that comes over here is apt to give lectures to which an admission fee is charged.

BERLIN, May 27. -- The hardiest plant in the world is hope. It can survive the cruelest chills and endure more blistering heat, more storms and more lack of nourishment than any other human attribute. Perhaps this is so because in its hardiest manifestations it is the product of dire need.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The government is completing plans to take over administration work relief in New York City, it was disclosed today after Mayor La Guardia had visited Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, in his offices here.

TACOMA, Wash., May 27. -- The following text of the ransom note received by the Weyerhaeuser family on the evening of the day George Weyerhaeuser was kidnapped is verified by investigators as authentic:

The filly Esposa, owned by Mrs. William Ziegler Jr. and third last year in the Hopeful, surprised a good many at Belmont Park yesterday by a driving neck victory in the mile of the feature Calverton Purse. Wayne Wright, leading rider of the Winter season, had the mount and finished strongly to withstand the challenge of Mrs. Payne Whitney's Cheshire, piloted by Silvio Coucci.

It is not often tha late May brings along two major openings on one evening; tonight, however, will provide the exception. A play called "Knock on Wood" will carry its satire of Hollywood agencies to the stage of the Cort Theatre; and "The Young"Go First" -- which tells of the CCC camps -- will try life at the Park.

A former American Ambassador to Germany expressed himself as believing in the sincerity of Adolf Hitler's peace speeches -- Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman, five days ago in Bedford, N.Y. Having been a member not only of the German Parliament, but also of its Committee on Foreign Relations, and being well and reliably informed about the foreign policy and the intentions of the Nazis, may I say a few words about this very strange statement:

CHICAGO, May 27. -- Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Mid Victorian, a longstriding daughter of Victorian-Black Betty, took the Woodlawn Purse in a six-furlong test at Washington Park today, leading Slim Rosie to the wire in a driving finish.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27. -- Three places are still open on the Yale-Harvard track and field team which will cross the Atlantic to meet Oxford and Cambridge this Summer, according to an announcement made tonight by the Yale Athletic Association, but all will be filled by Saturday.

France's currency crisis appeared to be deepening yesterday as the franc fell further in the face of continued large gold shipments and the market for franc futures fell away in disorder. Quotations on ninety-day forward francs fell to a discount of nearly 22 per cent below parity.

Speaking before members of the New York Employing Printers Association at its annual meeting in the Hotel Astor yesterday, Frank J. Smith, president of the United Typothetae of America and chairman of the National Code Authority of the Commercial Printing Industry, pleaded with the printers to maintain their trade association work regardless of whether or not the NRA was found constitutional by the United States Supreme Court.

Wall Street's first reaction to the news of yesterday's three decisions of the Supreme Court invalidating the NIRA and the Frazier-Lemke Act and overruling President Roosevelt's removal of a Federal Trade Commissioner was in general one of rejoicing.
PARIS, May 27. -- Another of France's tennis idols faded out of the picture tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Supreme Court found the NIRA, the Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Act and Presidential removal of a Federal Trade Commissioner invalid.

Ten fire-engine companies from lower Manhattan were rushed to Staten Island late yesterday afternoon while all available Richmond County forces battled with a fire that destroyed two buildings and caused property damage estimated at $50,000 in the business section of Port Richmond.

Rare books and art objects worth "at least $50,000" were destroyed yesterday by a fire in the library of the five-story home of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Davis at 130 East Seventy-fourth Street, and a furniture cleaner at work there received second and third degree burns of the hands and face.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 27. -- Denying charges that he had spread propaganda for the Nazi cause among students at New Jersey College for Women here, Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the German Department, said today that when Adolf Hitler came into power he cautioned his instructors not to talk to students about events in Germany.

ORANGE, N.J., May 27. -- Preliminary plans for an Institute of Family Relations in the Oranges and Maplewood will be made next month to meet a demand of groups of young persons for sex education and preparation for marriage, it was announced here today by the Council of Social Agencies, a unit of the Welfare Federation.

While July cotton contracts held yesterday around the level of 12 cents a pound on the Cotton Exchange, new-crop deliveries came under more pressure. After prices had held steady at a slightly lower level for several hours, the United States Supreme Court's decision on the NRA codes increased the weight of contracts in the last half-hour of the session and quotations closed at the bottom with losses of 2 to 19 points.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27. -- Don Kellett, Albany second baseman, made International League history today with two home runs in the fourth inning, the second with the bases full, to climax an eight-run rally at the expense of three Newark pitchers.

The housewives' campaign for 24-cent meat, or a reduction of 10 cents a pound, which began last week in the Bronx and Brooklyn with a consumers' strike, was carried forward in Manhattan yesterday by the City Action Committee Against the High Cost of Living, with headquarters at 799 Broadway.

Jesse Stuart, school teacher and farmer in the Kentucky hills, whose poetic work of more than 700 sonnets, "Man With a Bull-Tongue Plow," was published last Fall by E.P. Dutton Co., Inc., is paying his first visit to New York.

Charges that the Empire Trust Company made loans through "dummies" at more than the legal rate of interest and exacted the payment of "bonuses" for the loans are made in an accounting suit against the bank, disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.

The holdover March grand jury submitted to District Attorney Dodge yesterday a list of lawyers from which the prosecutor last Tuesday agreed to select a special Assistant District Attorney to present evidence in the investigation of the policy and bail-bond rackets and vice conditions in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- The Supreme Court refused today to interfere with the twenty-five-year sentence imposed on Dr. Alice L. Wynekoop, Chicago physician convicted of the operating-table murder of her daughter-in-law.

ATHENS, May 27. -- The movement to restore the monarchy in Greece has been considerably strengthened by the active participation of Nicolas Politis, Greek Minister to France and a skillful advocate among monarchists at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Law was unanimously declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court today on the ground that private property cannot be taken for public use without just compensation.

As the renting agent for Prospect Park's new zoo, former Governor Alfred E. Smith gave a pep talk to a committee of prominent Brooklyn residents named by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll to promote the development of the zoo.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 27. -- State Senator Percy Camp, testifying here today in Supreme Court hearings into methods by which criminal libel indictments were returned against William H. Fischer, local newspaper editor, by the September term grand jury of last year, admitted Mr. Fischer's right to editorially hold the Republican county organization morally responsible for the official acts of its elected candidates and to criticize public officials who fail in their law enforcement duties.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27. -- The various phases of better housing and the work accomplished by the women's division of the Federal Housing Administration throughout the country, were discussed here today at a joint luncheon of the Women's Health Federation of America, Inc., and the women's division, Newark Better Housing Program, at the Robert Treat Hotel.

The attitude of the Actors Equity Association toward the unsettled question of Sunday performances in the legitimate theatres of this State, already approved by the Legislature, was discussed yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the association, held at the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President Roosevelt's action in demanding removal of the late William E. Humphrey from the Federal Trade Commission was held illegal by the Supreme Court today.
June relief expenditures aggregating $18,000,000 were authorized by the Board of Estimate at a special meeting at City Hall yesterday.

A drastic change will be made in the procedure of the chief medical examiner's office so that fees collected there will go into the City Treasury instead of into the pockets of employes, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 28. -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, in session here, expressed concern today on the present status of Christian churches in Germany.

The executive committee of the Republican State Committee, meeting yesterday at the National Republican Club, heard a report from Melvin C. Eaton, State chairman, on his recent trip through the central and western parts of the State and approved the suggestion of Colonel Cornelius W. Wickersham for the formation of a State-wide lawyers' advisory committee.

A large dinner dance featured by a progressive tournament of indoor games was held last night at the Ambassador for the benefit of the general fund of the National Republican Builders. Many of the committee members and subscribers entertained parties at the dinner.

An "Amateur Audition" was the feature of a supper dance given by the Vanderbilt Clinic Auxiliary last night at the House of Lords to benefit the auxiliary's social service work. The audition enlisted several young men and women of society without previous experience as supper-club entertainers.

STAUNTON, Va., May 28. -- Staunton paid further honor today to the memory of its most illustrious son, Woodrow Wilson, as his widow, Mrs. Edith Bolling Wilson, unveiled a portrait of the wartime President.

LONDON, May 28. -- Following the lead given last night by Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, who said in his Albert Hall speech the surest guarantee of world peace would be the collaboration of the British Empire and the United States, Anthony Eden today extolled Anglo-American friendship as of first importance.

Wall Street's second thoughts on the voiding of the NRA, as reflected in the financial markets yesterday, were torn between its first approval of the long-range implications of the event and its later misgivings over the deflationary consequences of suddenly scrapping all existing codes.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- The Supreme Court's decision invalidating NRA codes is expected to clear some 400 cases from the dockets of lower courts.
The Park Department called a halt yesterday on its Spring planting activities because of the sudden advent of Summer and the prolonged dry weather.

St. Ann's Academy turned back the Power Memorial nine in a free-hitting contest at Macombs Dam Park yesterday, 13 to 6. Howard McKee, the victors' second baseman, got four hits in as many times up and executed an unassisted double play in the fourth inning.

WARSAW, May 28. -- For the last few days the pro-government newspapers, headed by the official Gazeta Polska, have been publishing special correspondence from all over the world giving detailed descriptions of the memorial rites for Marshal Josef Pilsudski in other capitals.

An inspection of two of the ninety-one charitable agencies affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies was made yesterday by 300 members and guests of the women's division of the federation.
Mayor La Guardia will fly to Albany and back today to mark the anniversary of the first flight from Albany to New York twenty-five years ago by the late Glenn H. Curtiss.
NEWARK, N.J., May 28. -- The Bears took the first game of their series with the Baltimore Orioles today, triumphing by 6 to 3.

Following the advance of its official discount rate from 2 1/2 per cent to 3 last Thursday and from 3 to 4 last Saturday, the Bank of France yesterday fixed a 6 per cent rate. This rapid raising of the French market's bid for money was obviously designed to check the outflow of home and foreign capital.

With Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, appealing to the nation's employers to make no immediate changes in hours or wages and to protect the collective bargaining rights of labor, business and industrial leaders strove yesterday to maintain the worth-while features of their codes of fair competition.

In a newly revised edition of his "The Last of Free Africa," published by Appleton-Century, Gordon MacReagh, explorer and authority on Abyssinia, declares that neither the natural defenses of Ethiopia nor the warlike spirit of its people could give Italy any serious trouble.

Colonel Robert R. McCormick, chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association committee on the freedom of the press, who is editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, issued the following statement yesterday in New York:

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia School of Journalism sent telegrams yesterday to various organizations of editors and publishers, congratulating them on maintaining "the freedom of the press under the NRA."

The Theatre of Action, which of old was known as the Workers Laboratory Theatre, moved uptown last evening and installed on the stage of the Park a play called "The Young Go First." It is a drama about the Civilian Conservation Corps, written by Peter Martin, George Scudder and Charles Friedman, some, or all, of whom are alumni.

NEWARK, N.J., May 28. -- A motion to dismiss the $6,000,000 damage suit against the Gillette Safety Razor Company and Otto Roth, Inc., Newark subsidiary, will be argued before Federal Judge William Clark tomorrow. At the close of the hearing today.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- In a match of 102 rounds lasting two hours and fifty-five minutes, and culminating in the correct spelling of "intelligible," Clara Mohler, 13 years old, of Summit County, Ohio, won today the national spelling championship and $500 in cash.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Tide Water Oil Company announced yesterday an increase of 5 per cent in salaries and wages, effective June 1. About 46,700 employes of the New Jersey company earning $5,000 or less yearly will be affected and the domestic payrolls of that organization will be increased by $4,000,000 annually.

LONDON, May 28. -- While difficulties in the French Treasury seem temporarily surmounted, financial opinion here holds the crises of the franc will become recurrent and with each crisis more serious than the last, with no real chance of improvement until the budget is balanced.

LONDON, May 28. -- The King and Queen honored a "queen" of the London theatre this afternoon by attending a matinee at Drury Lane, arranged by The London Daily Telegraph to celebrate the stage golden jubilee of Marie Tempest. Miss Tempest, who made her debut on May 30, 1885, immediately became a star and has remained a beloved star for fifty years.

The Rev. Dr. John Henry House will celebrate his ninetieth birthday today at the Thessalonica Agricultural and Industrial Institute near Saloniki Greece, it was made known yesterday by the New York office of the institute, 17 East Forty-second Street.

The decision of the Supreme Court holding the NRA codes unconstitutional has caused the United States Attorney's office in this district to suspend all actions begun or contemplated under the National Recovery Act pending advices from Washington and a more thorough study of the decision.
The address of Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the Merchants Association of New York follows:

Seventy-seven students will be graduated from the Fieldston School in Riverdale, a unit of the Ethical Culture Schools, at commencement exercises at 10:30 A.M. today. Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, director of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, will address the graduates.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- President Roosevelt moved today to rush the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program into actual operation by signing an executive order making available for immediate use over $1,000,000,000 of the relief fund.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Dust Girl, running for the Shandon Farm, owned by Patrick and Richard Nash of Chicago and cleverly rated by Jockey H. Albrecht, captured the feature race at Washington Park over a muddy track today.

BERLIN, May 28. -- The Boerse was somewhat stronger today. Heavy industrials climbed steadily, Mannesmann gaining 1 1/4 points and Kloeckner 1 3/4. Lignites also gained, Rhenish Browncoal rising 3 points. Electricals were stronger, Schuckert gaining 3 1/2 points and Siemen's Halske advancing 2 3/4. Chemicals were strong, while shippings were inactive.

Price reductions, initially on cigarettes, books and toilet goods, followed closely yesterday upon the Supreme Court decision invalidating the NRA codes. Some of the department stores, in meeting the cuts, reduced the price of cigarettes from $1.20 to 99 cents a carton.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared yesterday that Samuel F.B. Morse's ignorance of the "best scientific thought a century ago saved him from impediment in his early experiments with the telegraph." Dr. Chase spoke at the unveiling of memorial tablets to Morse and Professor John W. Draper, pioneer in photography, at the University's Washington Square Centre.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,605,300 barrels, against 2,650,300 in the preceding week, a drop of 45,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 27,800 and 19,850 barrels, respectively, in the daily average output of California and Oklahoma accounted for the decline.

Martin Mooney, New York American reporter, must serve his jail sentence imposed for failure to answer certain questions before the grand jury, Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew ruled yesterday. Justice Carew dismissed the writ of habeas corpus sued out by Mr. Mooney in an effort to retain his freedom.

In an unexpectedly sharp advance, net operating income of the first sixty-five railways to report for April increased by 9.1 per cent to $28,680,000, compared with $26, 302,000 in April, 1934, while gross revenues increased from $214,371, 000 to $222,650,000, or by 3.9 per cent.

BOSTON, May 28. -- Support of NRA principles was voiced widely in New England industrial and labor circles today as it appeared that a fight would be waged to retain many features of the act invalidated by the Supreme Court.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP). --With big Jim Weaver pitching six-hit ball and fanning seven, the Pittsburgh Pirates moved a little closer to the first division today as they turned back the Phillis, 3 to 1, to win the series by two games to one.

JOHN HENRY HOUSE, who was born ninety years ago today, is celebrating his birthday at the American Farm School which he founded thirty years ago just outside of Salonika. He went to the Balkans as a young man, learned to speak Bulgarian and Turkish and was the first educator to attack the Macedonian problem from the point of view of the "subsistence farmer."

Real estate men and builders generally received with a feeling of relief yesterday the news that the Supreme Court had held the NRA codes unconstitutional. The decision was looked upon as "reassuring."

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group for the second quarter of this year are estimated at $63,571, 466 by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. They were $58,708,391 in the corresponding quarter of last year and $18,122,717 in the first quarter of this year.

Twentieth Century's break with the United Artists Corporation to join Fox Film was accompanied by the resignation of Joseph M. Schenck as president of United Artists, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Schenck had been president of both United Artists and Twentieth Century.
LONDON, May 28 (AP). -- A hard blow to the prestige of President Roosevelt was the view reflected today in press comment on the United States Supreme Court's NRA decision.

Louis E. Kirstein of William Filene's Sons Company was elected chairman of the board and of the executive committee of the American Retail Federation at the organization meeting yesterday of the incorporators of the federation at the Hotel Chatham.

The Connecticut Board of Fisheries and Game announces that 18,000,000 pike perch fry, hatched from eggs obtained at Lake Champlain under a cooperative arrangement with the Vermont Fish and Game Department, will be introduced into three lakes this week.

Uncertainty over the possible effect on farm legislation and the Bankhead act of the Supreme Court's NRA decision brought foreign liquidation on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. For a time prices yielded $1 to more $1.50 a bale, but a positive assertion later by Senator Bankhead that growers would be able to obtain loans of 12 cents a pound on the 1935 crop steadied the market.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- President Roosevelt is expected to go to the nation by the end of this week with a formula designed to salvage as much as possible from the wreckage of the NRA.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 28. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, the former Polly Andrews, newly crowned women's metropolitan golf champion, scored a brilliant 38 on the homeward nine for a total of 81 and the low gross prize in the Westchester-Fairfield weekly tournament over the Siwanoy Country Club course today.

Financing of $15,500,000 for the San Diego Consolidated Gas and Electric Company will be done today by the offering of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1965, priced at 101 accrued interest. The flotation is being handled by an underwriting group consisting of the First Boston Corporation, H. M. Byllesby Co., Inc.; W.C. Langley Co., Byth Co., Inc.; A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., and Edward B. Smith Co.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Higher prices for hogs have led in the last two days to an increase of 43 per cent in the receipts at eleven Western markets. The top price of $10.20 a hundredweight reached here yesterday was equaled today, although the general market was 5 to 10 cents net lower.

CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds ran up their longest winning streak in about four years -- six straight games -- today as they fell on Flint Rhem and Ben Cantwell for 18 hits and defeated the Boston Braves, 13 to 4.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- With all labor boards, national, steel, textile and regional, suspending operations in consonance with the President's order following the Supreme Court decision on the Schechter case, the administration was confronted with its first critical labor problem today in the breakdown of wage negotiations in the bituminous coal industry.

Denmark has made a substantial economic recovery in the last two years, according to a report of a survey of business and financial conditions in that country which will be released today by the Institute of International Finance, an organization conducted jointly by the Investment Bankers Association and New York University.

Federal relief was characterized by General Hugh S. Johnson yesterday as "the most expensive and wasteful sharing that we could devise," at the final report luncheon of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army in the Hotel Biltmore.

A sizzling pace and an accompanying rapid fire of punches brought back to Barney Ross of Chicago, who only recently gave up the lightweight title, the world's welterweight crown last night at the Polo Grounds in fifteen rounds of spectacular fighting against Jimmy McLarnin, Vancouver veteran, before 40,000 fans.

The Prosperity Shop and the Stage Relief Fund were the beneficiaries of a luncheon and fashion show held yesterday at the Ambassador. Each subscriber brought an article of rummage for sale at the Prosperity Shop at 1,279 Third Avenue, which donates funds to several charitable organizations.
Sitting on a rubbing table, his left hand dangling in a pail of cold water, Barney Ross greeted every caller to his dressing room with a quick smile.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP). -- A barrage of home runs, including Bob Johnson's eleventh of the season, gave the Athletics a 6-to-5 decision over the White Sox today. Chicago held the league lead, however, as the Yankees also lost.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28. -- Time trials filled the starting field for the Indianapolis Motor Speedway's Memorial Day 500-mile race today with thirty-three of the speediest racers ever entered in the auto classic.

In announcing the results of operations of Remington Rand, Inc., the year ended on March 31, James H. Rand, president, stated yesterday that the directors were "formulating a plan for reclassifying the capital stock, which they believe will be advantageous to the stockholders, improve the capital structure, provide for adjustment of accrued dividends and pave the way for the refunding of the company's outstanding 5% per cent debentures on a more profitable basis."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 28. -- Iris were the featured blooms of the second community flower show of New Rochelle, which opened here today in the auditorium of the New Rochelle Woman's Club, under the auspices of the Conservation Council, the American Iris Society and sixteen organizations of New Rochelle.

The daily newspaper publishers code committee, after a meeting yesterday, issued a statement asserting that "affairs of the code committee will be liquidated promptly" after expiration of the newspaper code June 16. The text of the committee's statement follows:
We have read recently of the existence of a so-called alien racket. The weakness of our naturalization laws encourages the present state of affairs.

As far as Vernon (Lefty) Gomez concerned, the rumor that Hank Greenberg seldom hits at the Stadium is absolutely without foundation, because almost single-handed the angular Detroit first baseman brought about the downfall of the Yankees yesterday.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, May 28. -- Oahu with its shining beach and thundering surf was an "invaded" island today, with 20,000 sailors, many of them newcomers to Hawaii, strolling through Honolulu's streets or lying on the sands at Waikiki.

The preliminary pamphlet report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company for 1934, dated May 24, states that more than 68,000 holders of debentures of the company have exchanged more than $175,000,000 principal amount under the plan of rearrangement of debt capitalization, and that sufficient debentures are held to make more than two-thirds of the total amount outstanding.

High school students gifted in the arts will be trained in the new city high schools of music and art which will open in existing buildings this September, Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, Dr. Walter Damrosch and officials of the Board of Education.

Jacob Maged, the Jersey City tailor who was jailed a year ago for an NRA code violation, became a bit temperamental yesterday after discussing the Supreme Court decision upsetting the act, and made two trips around the block chasing a photographer who had taken a picture of him despite warnings.
