WASHINGTON, May 28. -- A statement on the NRA made today by the directors of the National Association of Manufacturers read as follows:
PARIS, May 28. -- Tomorrow afternoon around 5 o'clock, France's new liner, the Normandie, will set out from Havre for New York.

Fordham University's batsmen blasted twenty-three hits off five hurlers to defeat City College, 23 to 13, at Fordham Field yesterday. Coaches Jack Coffey of Fordham and Harold Parker of C.C.N.Y. decided that their teams had enough at the end of the seventh inning after the Rams added three runs to their total.
TACOMA, Wash., May 28. -- The kidnappers of George Weyerhaeuser were believed to be laying final plans tonight to attempt collection of $200,000 ransom and deliver the boy to his parents.
ONCE he was merry but now he's forlorn. Meaning Gordon Stanley Cochrane, manager of the Detroit Tigers and once the life of any baseball party.

MOSCOW, May 28. -- A campaign to increase the population of the Soviet Union, in order more fully to exploit the natural resources of one-sixth of the land area of the globe, was launched today by the leadership of the Communist party.

SALEM, N.H., May 28. -- Running just two-fifths of a second behind the track record of 1:37 2-5, the Ascot Stable's Stocks, with Jockey G. Seabo up, flashed across the finish line at Rockingham Park today, winner by a nose over Don Guzman.

Barney Ross's weight was announced as 141 pounds as he and the champion, Jimmy McLarnin, went to their respective corners. The titleholder tipped the scale at 144 3/4, an advantage of three and three-quarters pounds.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Congress will be asked to give to the Treasury power to license distillers and regulate liquor imports in the belief of those who hold that the Supreme Court decision on NIRA calls for new regulations for the liquor traffic.

Passengers sailing tonight for the Channel ports on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin include Prince Rudolf von Hohenlohe-Langenburg and his mother, Princess Anna; Prince and Princess Adolf von Schaumburg-Lippe, Baron Oscar von der Lancken-Wagnitz, Count Constantin von Pfeil and the Countess, Vicomte Rene de Bourbon-Busset, Countess Alexandra von Schlieffen and:
ITHACA, N.Y., May 28 (AP). -- A new proof of Einstein's law that mass and energy are the same thing in different guises was announced today at the Cornell University Department of Physics.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

" Let 'Em Have It," a Reliance production depicting the activities of the Department of Justice agents, opens this morning at the Rivoli. Included in the cast are Richard Arlen, Virginia Bruce, Alice Brady, Bruce Cabot and Harvey Stephens.

BOSTON, May 28. -- A campaign to preserve the benefits of the NRA practices regarding wages, hours of employment and child labor, through mutual agreement among the industrial States of the nation, was started here today.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- In a decision, affecting ten corporations and about 200 industrial plants, the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that the practice of carriers who pay shippers to operate their own switching facilities is illegal.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Moving to give further aid to home owners, President Roosevelt signed legislation today authorizing the issuance of $1,750,000,000 more Home Owners' Loan Corporation bonds and amending in important respects the Home Owners' Loan Act, the Federal Home Loan Bank Act and the National Housing Act.

I am getting very much fed up with the constant, unvarying charge by all of the New Dealers that the motives of their opponents are unworthy. The same thing appears again in the Quotations column on the editorial page of yesterday's TIMES over the names of President Roosevelt and Rexford Tugwell.

The Mexican Republic paid official homage to Amelia Eearhart last night at the St. Moritz Hotel with a dinner in honor of her record in making the first non-stop flight from Mexico City to New York. Eduardo Villasenor, Consul General for Mexico in New York, was host to a party of forty leaders in aviation, literature and journalism in her honor.

For the first time in recent years the Treasury is offering a bond issue to be sold on a competitive basis to the highest bidder. This is its regular practice with respect to short-term discount bills, maturing in four, six or nine months. By taking advantage of this method it has obtained money at extremely low rates of interest.

SHANGHAI, May 28. -- Seizing upon the extraordinary pretext that the assassination several weeks ago of two Chinese editors who were putting out pro-Japanese newspapers in the Japanese concession of Tientsin were politically instigated, Japanese Army heads in North China, backed by Kwantung army leaders in Manchuria, are reported to have made drastic demands upon Chinese civilian and military chiefs of the Peiping-Tientsin area.
Following is the text of the address by Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, before the Harvard Business School Club last night at the Harvard Club:

Ogden L. Mills, who was Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, attacked the Eccles Banking Bill last night as a "thoroughly bad measure," which would put this country back five centuries in national fiscal policy. Mr. Mills spoke on "The American Government and the Federal Reserve System" at the annual dinner meeting of the Harvard Business School Club of New York, held in the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Board of Higher Education adopted resolutions yesterday making uniform appointment and promotion procedure, salary grades, schedules and schedule conditions in Hunter, City and Brooklyn Colleges. The board met in the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

On July 1 the city will begin to transfer persons on home relief to work relief, in anticipation of the new Federal program, and those who refuse to take jobs, preferring to receive relief without work, will be stricken from the rolls, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- An inflationary bill came into new prominence today after the wrecking of the Frazier-Lemke Farm Mortgage Moratorium Act.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- The luscious hams, breakfast bacon and other appetite-teasing meat packers' products depicted for years in huge advertisements on the side of railroad refrigerator cars are rapidly disappearing.

The National Title Guaranty Company of 185 Montague Street, Brooklyn, and eight of its officers and directors were named in an indictment handed to Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn yesterday by a special Federal grand jury. The bill charges conspiracy and using the mails to defraud in the sale of mortgages and mortgage participation certificates.

ATLANTA, May 28 (AP). -- Under strict observation at his home on Northside Drive following an attack of appendicitis, Bobby Jones, the retired golf king, was unable to leave today for New York where he was scheduled to play in an exhibition match on Thursday.

Two "rebels" in their respective fields -- Norman Bel Geddes, industrial and stage designer, and George Howe, architect -- have joined forces in anticipation of what they believe will be a "revolution in design for industry and for the architectural arts."

Virtually all trade groups here stopped action yesterday on code, label and compliance questions until meetings scheduled for next week, when it is expected that definite information from Washington on procedure will be available. Hope was expressed that in the meanwhile the President and Congress would arrive at a solution that would preserve the best features of the 750 codes voided by the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). --Cleveland got to Buck Newsom for three runs in the eighth inning to overcome an early Washington lead and beat the Senators in the last game of the series today, 5 to 4.

ATHENS, May 28. -- The Duke of Kent, formerly Prince George of Britain, was eliminated today from conjecture as a possible occupant of the Greek throne, of which Greek monarchists are urging immediate restoration, by an authorized but informally delivered statement of Sidney Waterlow, British Minister to Athens.
Dr. Beliserio Porras, three times President of Panama, yesterday announced his candidacy for that office at the election in June, 1936, at a press conference in his suite in the Park Central Hotel.

The California and Washington varsity crews drew the favored lanes yesterday of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta at Poughkeepsie on June 18. The Golden Bears will row in the No. 1 lane, nearest the west bank of the Hudson, while the Huskies will have No. 2.

Despite great hopes, we have not discovered the secret of stabilizing our economic life, Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, said in an address last night at the graduating exercises of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the affairs of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company delved today into the proposed reorganization plan which was made a condition by the Interstate Commerce Commission to the granting of loans to the railroad by the RFC in the Spring and Summer of 1932 in an effort to head off a receivership.

Surrogate James A. Foley adjourned yesterday until June 4, hearings on the construction of the will of Mrs. Emma T. Gary, widow of Elbert H. Gary, United States Steel Corporation official, who died on April 5, 1934. The executors requested the court to pass on the acceptance of Mrs. Gary's bequest of art objects to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LONDON, May 28. -- The further rise in the French bank rate caused a sharp improvement in the franc in the foreign exchange market today. Trading on the Stock Exchange was restricted, although industrials again provided exceptions, particularly textiles, rayons, motors, aircraft, tobaccos, Cables and Wireless and Dunlop Rubber.

The Schechter NRA decision of the Supreme Court came at a time when the nation was at the crossroads between continuing its democratic form of government or changing to a strongly centralized government with a dictatorship as a definite possibility.

Songwriters whose lyrics havei been household words for almost[ half a century came yesterday from widely scattered places to pay tribute to James W. Blake, famous author of "The Sidewalks of NewI York," at a solemn high mass at! the Church of the Guardian Angels, Tenth Avenue at Twenty-first Street.

ST. LOUIS, May 28. -- The nation's automobile dealers tonight took up their NRA code of fair practices where it was cast down by the United States Supreme Court and prepared to carry it on by "mutual consent."

Business and industrial leaders, as well as Code Authority executives, were striving yesterday to salvage the worth-while features of their codes of fair competition while awaiting advices from Washington as to the outlook for Federal legislation to aid in this effort.

The expectation that President Roosevelt would reach a decision by the week-end on steps to save what he could from that part of his recovery program wrecked by the Supreme Court's decision against the NIRA was expressed in Washington.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, signed yesterday an order directing James C. Van Siclen and C. Walter Randall, trustees in reorganization proceedings for the Bush Terminal Company, to appear before him on next Monday and show cause why a motion made by the trustees should not be reargued.

Inquiries made yesterday of a number of the nation's leading insurance company executives drew responses from those questioned, without a single dissenting voice, that the insurance companies would not start a rush of foreclosure actions against mortgaged farms or demand that the owners immediately come to terms over their debt arrears.

The Mayor's commission investigating conditions in Harlem was accused yesterday of being only a "smoke-screen" to cloak the real abuses that exist in that area, while Mr. La Guardia himself was called "insincere" when he appointed the commission.

Although the day of the horse-drawn ambulance has passed, service of this nature was renewed yesterday in Times Square and vicinity, where it will be continued for another week. The occasion is the seventy-fifth anniversary of Flower Hospital, at Sixty-third Street and the East River -- "twenty-five minutes by horse-drawn ambulance from Times Square."

A fashion parade of Park Avenue "debs, dowagers and doggies," directed by Mrs. Pleasants Pennington, for the benefit of the homeless dogs cared for by the Bide-a-Wee Home Association was held yesterday afternoon in the gardens of the Park Lane Hotel.

After reading Senator Hastings's minority report, also signed by Senator Metcalf and Senator White of the Senate Commerce Committee on the hearing of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill, the only conclusion that can be reached is that this bill is unnecessary from every economic angle and is so framed that it will permit the Federal politician to use the electric utilities as a football much in the same manner as the railroads have been used.

Prices of commodity futures dipped sharply in a heavy volume of trading yesterday. The selling affected not only the staples that have been the beneficiaries of New Deal legislation which now is in doubt, but also all other commodities excepting the ordinarily inactive metals.

With other stocks skittering downward yesterday, the public utilities advanced in price against the general trend, owing to the crushing blow dealt at New Deal legislation by the United States Supreme Court decisions on Monday. Utility executives were inclined to be most cautious in their estimates of the situation, however, and were much more interested in reports that the Senate had begun discussion of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill than in other topics of the day.

A plea for contributions of books and periodicals to be shipped aboard merchant vessels for the use of seamen was issued yesterday by Mrs. Henry Howard of Newport, founder and president of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, at the fourteenth annual meeting of the association.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Indications that a soldiers' bonus measure along the lines of the Vinson bill would be pushed by bonus advocates as a sequel to the President's veto, were given today after a meeting. The Vinson bill would provide prepayment without furnishing a method of financing.

The R.O.T.C. unit of City College will hold its annual military field day at 3 o'clock this afternoon in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. More than 500 students will pass in review before Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area.

Two bandits who attempted to rob Dr. Max Chidekel in his office, in the apartment house where Mayor La Guardia lives at 1,274 Fifth Avenue, on the southeast corner of 109th Street, met with such resistance early last night that one of them leaped through a plate glass window and was captured by the crew of a passing radio car. The second man escaped.

That a good 3-year-old can concede weight and beat older horses was demonstrated at Belmont Park yesterday when G.H. (Pete) Bostwick's Allen Z. came from behind in the mile of the featured Harlem Claiming Stakes to score by a half length.

PARIS, May 28. -- A financial and economic dictatorship to defend the public credit, restore economic activity and maintain the national money was asked this afternoon in the French Parliament by the Flandin government. Whether that request will be granted, however, is not certain.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- The will of Jane Addams, founder of Hull House, was filed today with the clerk of the Probate Court. Personal property valued at $10,000 and a farm near Cedarville, Ill., was disposed of in the document, which was drawn on May 22, 1934.

Out of the welter of conjectures as to the immediate future of trade and industry as a result of the wind-up of NRA enforcement, the markets arrived yesterday through the trial-and-error method at the conclusion that some deflation will have to be faced.

Concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and operas to be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium will be broadcast exclusively by WOR this Summer, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the stadium concerts, announced last night in an address over that station.

BUDAPEST, May 28. -- Premier Julius Goemboes, speaking in Parliament today on the military budget, formulated Hungary's demands as universal military service with a two-year period with the colors, equality with the Little Entente in the right to rearm, and a strong air force.

A division of sentiment within the ranks of the Actors Equity Association regarding the acceptance of Sunday performances in the legitimate theatres of this State was indicated by the test vote taken at the annual meeting of the association on Monday.

DEVON, Pa., May 28. -- With perfect weather and a crowd of about 10,000 present, the fourth day of the Devon horse show and country fair saw the first champion crowned today when Seaton Solitude of the Seaton Hackney Farms triumphed in the novice harness event.

The new Hayden Planetarium which will be opened in September as a unit of the American Museum of Natural History is destined to be the mecca for visitors and students of astrology from all parts of the world, Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, director of the museum, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- NRA and its codes, as law-maker and laws, are dead. Dead also is the present effort to extend Federal regulation over any industrial activity that does not clearly and directly affect the flow of interstate commerce. The Supreme Court's unanimous decision disposed of these two things.

After deliberating fourteen hours and fifty-five minutes, a General Sessions jury at 2:05 A.M. today returned a verdict of manslaughter in the first degree against Joseph L. Steinmetz, 22-year-old divinity student, for the murder of his young wife.

PARIS, May 28. -- Fighting for its gold by every legitimate means that orthodox gold standard rules place at its disposal, the Bank of France again raised its discount and other interest rates today. Nevertheless, the enormous drain on its gold stocks continued and the best-informed sources estimated today's losses at about 1,000,000,000 francs [about $65,800,000].

By the process of matching cards, Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Lido gained the first award in the second amateur handicap event of the season for Long Island Golf Association players at the Queens Valley Golf Club yesterday.
The time has arrived for lovers of our country and upholders of its institutions to come forward vigorously and enthusiastically in support of the President.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Some leading Republicans expect an increase in business following the Supreme Court's invalidation of the NRA to result in at least temporary advantage to the administration from a political point of view.

Pairings and starting times for the 162 golfers who will constitute this year's field in the national open championship at the Oakmont Country Club next week were announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association.

I read with interest THE TIMES editorial about Puritan eugenics. You mention as "priggish" "The Adams Family," because the book emphasizes the noteworthy people of that family, which was what it was designed to do.

Gina Pinnera, soprano, gave a recital at the Town Hall last night, flouting the convention that the music season has no excuse for being at the end of May. Miss Pinnera sang a program of mid-season length and variety embracing selections by Gluck, Brahms, Grieg, Verdi, Rossini, Richard Strauss and a concluding group by Americans -- Heart Mitchell, Mauro-Cottone, Grace Austin, Harden Church, Charles Maduro and Frank Grey.

The crowd was slow in arriving for the Ross-McLarnin fight last night although the gates were opened at 6, and for a time the promoters were beginning to doubt if their estimates would be reached. This was because the bleacher seats were only about half filled at 8 o'clock and it was thought that the rush at the opening of the gates would fill these sections.

Forty-eight faculty members at Columbia University joined yesterday in sending a petition to Dean Willard C. Rappleye in protest against his dismissal of three technicians and two instructors from the Columbia Medical Centre staff. The petition demanded their "unconditional reinstatement," declaring that the dismissals had been without "adequate reason or explanation" and constituted a "serious interference" with the rights of teachers and students.

The New Orleans Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Power and Light Corporation, has applied to the Federal Court in New Orleans for authority for reorganization under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act. A hearing on the application will be held on June 17.

Little actual disturbance followed the decision of the Supreme Court with respect to NRA. The chief shock fell upon Administration officials and members of Congress. Their first feeling was one of astonishment and chagrin; but presently they began putting their heads together to see if there were any way of salvaging parts of the wrecked Recovery Act.

Commissioner of Markets William Fellowes Morgan Jr. agreed yesterday to investigate the complaints of high meat prices made by the militant housewives' group which has organized a consumers' strike and forced the closing of several thousand butcher shops in the city during the past week.

Eleven indictments were reported to have been voted yesterday against nine persons by the holdover March grand jury in its investigation of bail bond abuses in the courts. The bills are expected to be handed up to Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions today.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Looking to the White House for guidance on further procedure on the New Deal program, Congressional leaders set themselves to the immediate task today of preventing a befuddled membership from doing anything rash in the light of the Supreme Court decision invalidating the NIRA.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- A strike "mobilization order" affecting 36,000 organized workers in the coat and suit industry of New York went forward today from President David Dubinsky and the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Morris gave a theatre party last night for Mr. and Mrs. James B. Alley, whose marriage took place recently in Washington, taking their guests to the Plymouth Theatre for the performance of "Accent on Youth" and later to the roof garden of the St. Regis for supper.

ALBANY, May 28. -- The "Battle of Pompey Hollow," started by a trivial argument between a school teacher and a school trustee over the display of an American flag, ended today in the ousting of both principals.

SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK, Calif., May 28. -- Two army aviators and two civilian motion-picture men were killed today in the crash and burning of a bombing plane of the Thirty-first Bombardment Squadron two miles north of Lodge Pole, near Giant Forest.

BOSTON, May 28 (AP). -- The last-place St. Louis Browns hammered Lefty Grove and Wes Ferrell for thirteen hits that totaled twenty-five bases today while defeating the Red Sox, 6 -- 5, in the rubber game of the series.
CALLANDER, Ont., May 28. -- The Dionne quintuplets had their first birthday party today in the presence of their legal guardians but with their own parents conspicuously absent.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Sixty students who submitted posters in the recent contest of the humane education department of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals have won prizes and honorable mention.
Sixty students who submitted posters in the recent contest of the humane education department of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals have won prizes and honorable mention.
Bigger America's Cup yachts were foreseen by C.P. Burgess, whose brother, W. Starling Burgess, designed the defenders Rainbow and Enterprise, in a talk last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Although the material is novel, the style is familiar in Allen Rivkin's "Knock on Wood," which was played at the Cort last evening. It is Hollywood satire through the keyhole of the office of a firm of artists' representatives. Schuyler Hugo are dynamic and extravagant fellows who do business in a boisterous racketeering style and know how to square the opposition by buying off the enemy.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Amended to meet objections of proprietary medicine interests, the Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill was passed in the Senate today with neither discussion nor a roll-call, and sent to the House.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Capital assets of public utility holding and operating companies examined by the Federal Trade Commission had been written up "in value over cost, in one way or another, more than $1,400,000,000 on a combined basis," the commission charged in its final report today to the Senate on the financial practices of holding companies and their subsidiaries.

PARIS, May 28 (AP). -- Roderich Menzel, the towering Czech, and Adrian Quist, young Australian Davis Cup player, smashed their way into the quarter-finals of the men's singles in the French hard court tennis championships today as rain halted the feature match in the women's division between Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., and Miss Anita Lizana of Chile.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Hearings on the New York Stock Exchange's application to strike from its listing and temporary registration securities of the Broadway Seventh Avenue Railroad Company and the Laclede Gas Light Company were set for June 12 and 13, respectively, by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

BERLIN, May 28. -- The Supreme Court's annihilation of the NRA throws President Roosevelt's entire economic social program into turmoil, and paralyzes any efforts Washington may have had in mind to call an international currency and tariff conference, according to the first impressions in German quarters.
The twenty-first commencement exercises of the Professional Children's School were held yesterday at the Martin Beck Theatre, 302 West Forty-fifth Street.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 28. -- A week's program in observance of the tenth anniversary of the founding of Brookside School was brought to a close today when more than 150 boys and girls took part in a round-the-world cruise pageant, which featured costume dances of the various countries.

The expected abolition of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration as a result of the Supreme Court NRA decision will have little effect on the liquor industry in New York State, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, said yesterday.

Secretary ICKES made a fine plea for academic freedom in his commencement address at the University of Alabama. One of the best things about the speech was not forgetting to mention that our democratic liberties have more than one enemy.

For the first time this month weekly buyer registrations showed an increase over the previous week. The total was also well above the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 557 as against 537 in the preceding week and 431 in the same period last year.
Money market continued quiet in business and unchanged in quotation. No special inquiry for time money was noted following the cut to one-quarter of 1 per cent on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Richard A. Corroon, president of Corroon Reynolds, Inc., drew $55,000 compensation in 1934, of which $7,500 was for services as chairman of the board of R.A. Corroon Co., Inc., a subsidiary, the corporation's report to the Securities and Exchange Commission has disclosed.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- An operating deficit of $254,664, about two-thirds of which was chargeable to opera, was reported today by the Philadelphia Orchestra Association for the 1934-35 season.

The rise in the Bank of France rate to the "panic" level of 6 per cent yesterday, combined with further heavy gold withdrawals from that institution and somewhat conflicting reports as to the reception accorded by the Chamber of Deputies to the plea of the Flandin Ministry for dictatorial financial and economic powers, deepened the concern felt here over the crisis in the franc.

Edward M. Baringer of Gloversville, was elected president of the New York State Retail Jewelers Association at the closing business session yesterday of the association's twenty-sixth annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker. He succeeds Samuel Feldman of Brooklyn, who presided at the convention sessions.

OTTAWA, May 28. -- Harry Stevens, a Conservative party champion of "regimentation," united today with Tom Moore, president of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada, in minimizing the effect of yesterday's NRA ruling on the Canadian Government's "New Deal" program.

Bidding for new municipal issues was spirited yesterday. The largest loan was an offering by the City of New York of $6,000,000 of special corporate stock. Ten underwriting houses and banks figured as principals, divided into two competitive groups in their quest for it.

Barney Ross is a resident of Chicago but claims New York as his birthplace. The swarthy, grim-visaged battler who won the welterweight championship for the second time last night was born at 258 Rivington Street on the lower East Side on Dec. 23, 1909.

Yesterday the Citizens' Appeal for the Salvation Army in this city came officially to an end, though several committees and canvassers who have not completely rounded out their work will quietly keep at it. The fund collected during the past few weeks is virtually $400,000.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Adoption by every store in the country of a discount policy on cash sales was recommended today by Dr. Herbert J. Tily, president of Strawbridge Clothier, a local department store, and of the National Retail Council.

The Supreme Court's decision in the case of the NIRA naturally overshadowed its decision in the Federal Trade Commission case the same day. But the latter will also merit a prominent place in American constitutional history.

Mayor La Guardia assailed yesterday the United States Supreme Court for its decision nullifying the NRA as an encouragement to wage reductions. He demanded adoption of a Constitutional amendment to circumvent the court's opinion and make possible uniformity of social and economic legislation for the entire nation under control and administration of the Federal Government.
TRENTON, May 28. -- The Republican State Committee today elected Henry W. Jeffers Sr. of Plainsboro, Middlesex County, chairman to succeed E. Donald Sterner of Belmar, new State Highway Commissioner.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Grain traders were unable today to understand fully the ultimate influence of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the NRA codes, and they are awaiting an announcement from Secretary Wallace on plans of the Department of Agriculture.

Bids for 500 new subway cars for the city's independent system were received yesterday by the Board of Transportation. Informal computation of the bids showed that the city would have to spend nearly $19,000,000 for the new equipment, which will be needed as extensions of the present system are opened.

ALBANY, May 28 (AP). -- A recent legislative act providing for the appointment of a Buffalo Sewer Authority for the purpose of ending pollution of the waters of the Niagara and Buffalo Rivers and Lake Erie was held constitutional by the Court of Appeals today.
Definite assurance that Rosa Ponselle, Lawrence Tibbett, Lotte Lehmann and Lily Pons will return to the Metropolitan Opera next season was given yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

BELGRADE, May 28. -- While Minister of the Interior Velia Popovitch and Dr. yon Heeren, the German Minister to Yugoslavia, waited at the Skoplje airdrome to receive General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the German Air Minister, on his arrival in Yugoslavia today in accordance with his final arrangements telephoned from Sofia, General Goering passed over their heads with the three planes conveying himself and his suite and landed 185 miles away at Mostar.

GENEVA, May 29. -- After only four days of general discussion the committee of thirteen to study non-military sanctions against future treaty repudiators, which the League of Nations Council in condemning Germany named on April 17, adjourned today.

The Western Pacific Railroad yesterday requested holders of its $49,290,100 of first mortgage 5 per cent bonds of 1946 to assent to their conversion into new fixed interest 4 per cent bonds and income bonds. Interest on the bonds was defaulted on March 1 and the period of grace on the obligation will expire on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- While widespread agitation has been going on for prepayment of the soldiers' bonus, during which care of the war-crippled veterans has been lost sight of, the Veterans Administration has been steadily liberalizing the regulations for the payment of compensation to these casualties and their dependents.

PARIS, May 29. -- Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin's chances of obtaining full powers from Parliament to take measures to prevent devaluation of the franc were seriously compromised today when the Finance Committe of the Chamber of Deputies rejected his request by 25 votes to 15, with one abstention.

Columbia will send a squad of thirty-two oarsmen and coxswains to Poughkeepsie on Saturday to prepare for the Intercollegate Rowing Association regatta on June 18, it was announced yesterday by Manager William Bouton.
Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General and Prothonotary Apostolic of the Archdiocese of New York and rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, will be 79 years old today.

BOSTON, May 29 (AP). -- Some of the most complimentary remarks ever made about a boat were said by Jack Parkinson today upon his return to Boston after helping sail the sloop Yankee to England for a Summer's racing with Britain's fastest yachts.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Crotty gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Dr. and Mrs. William L. Grady, Mr. and Mrs. Terence O'Gorman, Mr. and Mrs. James Dougherty, Mr. and Mrs. John Horan, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Christiansen, Miss Ann McParlan, Miss Margeurite Brunbaum, James F. Hart and George Dougherty.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 29. -- The multitude massed tonight for the annual speed spectacle in the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, a modern counterpart of Rome's Circus Maximus.

A test suit to force the city to restore the cuts made in 1932 in policeman's pay was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by State Senator A. Spencer Feld on behalf of Joseph P. Moran, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. A favorable ruling on this suit would set a precedent for forcing restoration of the pay cuts of firemen and school teachers as well.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Electric Home and Farm Authority, an adjunct of the Tennessee Valley Authority, created to improve the quality and decrease the cost of electric appliances and arrange their purchase by consumers, is wondering whether it will die premature death on June 16.

Retail trade here has picked up Sharply this week, with the best showing for the month thus far being made by department stores here. The rise in temperature spurred the sale of Summer goods which had been lagging, and response yesterday to Memorial Day promotions was reported brisk.

" Them's the Reporters" and that's the theatre. Being drenched in the glamour of the daily press, Phil Kanter of The Bronx Home News has written a drama about the unsung district men. It had a public hearing at the Ethel Barrymore last evening.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29. -- A conference of representatives from all the New England and Middle Atlantic States on working hours and conditions, and probably on all labor regulations previously covered by NRA codes, has been set tentatively for June 29 at the Essex and Sussex Hotel in Spring Lake, N.J.

One of the by-products of the Supreme Court's ruling on NIRA has been a hasty decision by the Senate to recommit a pending bill proposing to enlarge the authority of AAA. It had been favorably reported, had been given a preferred place on the calendar and seemed slated for early adoption. Now it has been sent back to the Senate Committee on Agriculture for further study and revision.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Warning the nation that the effect of the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case "is to blow away, at one puff, far more re-employment than the administration has projected or even imagined in its public works program," General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA administrator, expressed his conviction tonight that legislation could be passed, within the limits of the decision, to save the NRA.

SANDS POINT, L.I., May 29. -- The Sands Point Bath Club here inaugurated its Summer season tonight with a gala dinner and supper dance which drew a large attendance from many North Shore homes and New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Secretary Hull objected today, under circumstances expected to prove effective, to provisions in pending ship subsidy bills and the Eastman Water Carrier Regulation bills which would grant authority to the government to regulate rates, fares and charges of foreign ships with reference to traffic into and out of United States ports.
Quiet conditions prevailed in the credit market. Demand was light, and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

Staging a strong second-half attack after trailing at the intermission, 3 -- 1, the Manual Training High lacrosse team conquered Erasmus Hall, 7 -- 5, yesterday at Erasmus Field to capture the city P.S.A.L. championship.

PORTSMOUTH, England, May 29. -- Yankee will commence her British racing season on June 6 and 7 at Southend, on the Thames Estuary, when all the other J Class boats, except Britannia, will compete for the first time against the American yacht.

What about the laughter which rocked the United States Supreme Court when the now historic chicken case had its hearing a few weeks ago? The reporters said it was probably the most full-hearted display of merriment in the history of the august tribunal.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Recapitalization of Remington Rand, Inc., as outlined yesterday, provides that each share of outstanding first preferred and second preferred stocks are to be exchanged for one share of 5 per cent prior preferred stock of $25 par value, one share of $6 cumulative stock and one-half share of its common stock.
NEWARK, N.J., May 29. -- Newark took its second game in a row from Baltimore today, 9 to 5. Rain halted the contest at the start of the ninth.

A line on the champion of the handicap division and the leader among the 2-year-olds will be afforded this afternoon at Belmont Park when Cavalcade meets a strong field in the historic Suburban Handicap, and Coldstream and White Cockade face keen opposition in the Juvenile stakes.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 29. -- The Springfield College baseball team downed Wesleyan today, 12 to 1, for its seventeenth victory this season in twenty-one games.

The last holiday of the theatrical season finds twenty-three plays and musical shows giving matinees this afternoon. For some, Thursday is the normal midweek matinee time, others shifted about and a few stuck in an extra performance in order to care for the expected crowds.

As it passed the House and as it has been reported out by the Senate Finance Committee, the Social Security Bill provides that the contributions to the unemployment insurance funds are to be paid entirely by employers. This is contrary to the practice of virtually all foreign unemployment insurance plans with the exception of that of Russia; to each of these the workers contribute.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Prices of hogs were affected today by the easing in demand for pork loins, although the loss was small. Top grades of hogs were only 5 cents a hundredweight cheaper than yesterday, the first decline since May 10, but butchers' hogs, ranging around 250 pounds, were down 15 to 30 cents.
Streets will tremble under the tread of marching feet today and the air will vibrate to martial music and the soft notes of Taps as the city observes Memorial Day with tributes to its wartime dead.

Down the air trail from Albany to New York, which the late Glenn H. Curtiss blazed twenty-five years ago yesterday, a modern air transport carrying Mayor F.H. La Guardia, thirteen other passengers and a crew of three flashed yesterday in 50 minutes 20 1/2 seconds.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A more than seasonal decline drove the value of American exports in April to $15,077,000 below 1934 levels, the total value of shipments abroad falling to $164,350,000, as compared with $179,427,000 during April, 1934, and $184,603,000 in March of this year.

The Countess of Cavadonga arrived here yesterday from Havana to meet her husband, the former Prince of the Asturias, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain. The former prince is due this morning on the liner Washington.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the formation of the firm of Vietor, Common Co. of Buffalo by Frederick Vietor, Robert C. Common, Ralph S. Terry, Frank G. Quinn and Nathan Oppenheimer Jr., and Charles M. Kennedy, special partner.

Without questioning your sincerity and impartiality, I feel that your criticisms of Senator Wagner's Labor Relations Bill imply a certain misunderstanding. There seems to me no basis for disapproval of this bill.

Principal interest in the bond market yesterday centred in the tendering of offers by banks and other institutions for bonds comprising the new issue of United States Treasury 3s of 1946 to 1948. The deadline on which tenders would be accepted had been set by Secretary Morgenthau at 4 P.M., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Applications for $65,956,816 to be expended on Federal projects under the new works program in all parts of the country and ranging from scientific and clerical to construction work, were made public today by the Division of Applications and Information, headed by Frank C. Walker.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -- President Roosevelt stepped into the Puerto Rican relief controversy today with an executive order establishing the new Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration, with resulting assurances that long-delayed relief work would get under way in the island by July 1.

Claude G. Bowers, Ambassador to Spain, will arrive today on the Conte Grande. He expects to stop at the Fifth Avenue Hotel for three weeks. He hopes to do research necessary to complete his forthcoming study of Washington Irving's life in Spain.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Congress sank into a state of lethargy today awaiting word from the White House as to how to proceed to salvage the preservable features of the NRA.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration announced yesterday that to help speed up the Federal works program and simplify procedure it would take over all purchasing of materials as of June 1. Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the TERA, wrote Mayor La Guardia to this effect.
Mayor La Guardia won his election in Brooklyn by a snug majority, most taxpayers believing that his election would mean better conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- For a third time in as many days it becomes the duty of a reader of the Washington official mind to record the fact that the rigid interpretation by the Supreme Court in the Schechter case of what is "interstate commerce" has presented the largest of the problems growing out of the demolition of NRA.
SAN DIEGO, May 29. -- The exposition, depicting four centuries of progress, opened amid the cannonading of salutes, the blare of brass and the rattle of drums.

The former Prince of the Asturias, now the Count of Covadonga, son of ex-King Alphonso XIII of Spain, is arriving today from Paris on the Washington of the United States Lines to join the Countess, the former Edelmira Sampedro. Others coming on the ship are:

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The date on which trading in unlisted securities on exchanges must terminate was extended today by the Securities and Exchange Commission until May 31, 1936, the statutory limit set by the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

The wills of John Muir and William D. Hutton, former members of the New York Stock Exchange, which were filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday, disclosed that both men left small estates. The petitions for probate valued the estates at less than $10,000 each.

ON BOARD THE NORMANDIE, at Sea, May 29. -- At 6:19 o'clock this evening the Normandie eased from her pier at Havre and started her maiden voyage to New York, carrying with her the pride and prestige of France.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29. -- George R. Plunkett, Harvard's monocyclist-juggler-zitherist, heaved a fervent sigh of relief today as he assembled his monocycle, his Indian clubs and his zither for a pre-breakfast spin over his customary course between the Weeks and Anderson Bridges in Cambridge.

The Fordham freshman baseball team closed its campaign yesterday by turning back the previously unbeaten Textile High nine, 11 to 2, at Fordham Field. The victory was the seventh in eight starts for the Maroon yearlings.

Warner Baxter's latest starring picture for Fox. "Under the Pampas Moon," will be presented this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Appearing with Mr. Baxter are Ketti Gallian, John Miljan and J. Carroll Naish. "Rhapsody in Green" will be offered on the stage.

As the political crisis involving the franc tightened yesterday, an additional $32,000,000 of gold was taken from the Bank of France for shipment here, making a total of $ 220,000,000 engaged since May 8.

The resolve to maintain the regulatory provisions of the Legitimate Theatre Code, which marked the first cooperative effort of the several branches of the industry to work harmoniously for the good of the whole, was expressed yesterday by William A. Brady, chairman of the defunct Legitimate Theatre Code Authority.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that voluntary action by industry to save the wage, hour and fair trade practice provisions of the NRA codes, while commendable, would not suffice to assure a maximum of observance.

The Aviation Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net loss of $85,992 for the quarter ended on March 31 after expenses, depreciation, minority interests and other charges. This does not include $482,773 loss by American Air Lines, Inc., or $1,536 profit for Canadian Colonial Airways.

Leaders of the steel industry said yesterday they were determined to maintain wages, hours of work, fair trade practices, and other beneficial features of the Steel Code. Gains traceable to the code would be consolidated, they said, by voluntary, individual action of the principal companies.
A squall which passed over the city late yesterday afternoon brought a 15-degree drop in temperature after the mercury had climbed to 86 degrees, the highest recorded here so far this season.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Planning to press for enactment by this Congress of his Labor Disputes Bill, inimical to the company union, Senator Wagner is convinced that the bill is constitutional despite doubts raised by the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter NRA case.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., May 29 (Canadian Press). -- Twoscore French seamen were sought with waning hope tonight off Newfoundland and fears were growing that they had gone to the bottom of the sea aboard the St. Malo schooner, Marechal de Luxemburg.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP). -- Walter Johnson didn't wince a bit when he gazed straight into the eyes of his interviewers and, in an unfaltering voice, said:

An unpretentious citizen, never seeking praise or preferment but ever devoting himself to this community's good was ALFRED E. MARLING. It became a city habit to turn to him when there was a cause that needed assistance or a wrong that needed resistance. When a committee on structural changes in the State Government was formed in 1919 Mr. MARLING was made its chairman.
The National Child Labor Committee declared yesterday that the decision of the United States Supreme Court declaring the NRA unconstitutional meant a return to child labor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP). -- The Braves presented Babe Ruth with a victory for one of the "Babe Ruth Days" he has been having around the National League, gaining an 8-to-6 decision over the Phillies today. The Babe, however, had to be content with a floral offering.

Sylvester Lantaric, 16 years old, but tall for his age, was arrested last night and locked in the East 104th Street station on a charge of homicide after two of his four sisters had accused him of beating his 3-year-old brother, John, to death.

LONDON, May 29. -- It is reasonably certain that Ramsay MacDonald is going to be the British Prime Minister for only nine days more. It is now confidently expected that his resignation will be accepted by King George on Friday of next week, when Parliament will adjourn for the ten-day Whitsun recess.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 29. -- Army won from Bucknell on the diamond today by a score of 11 to 1. The game was called at the end of the fifth inning because of rain. Monahan, the Bucknell hurler, was ineffective and received poor support.

LATONIA, Ky., May 29 (AP). -- The first triple of the Kentucky season was completed when W.F. Knebelkamp's lightly regarded Lillian Uhl accounted for the Highland Stock Farm Purse, feature attraction today at Latonia.

BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, May 29. -- Hundreds of troops were rushed today to the copper belt in Northern Rhodesia to protect whites, including many Americans, in the serious rioting that has broken out among the more than 9,000 natives on strike.
With one of the finest entries available, comprising a total of seventy-six horses, the Fairfield and Westchester hunts meet will be staged today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club at Rye, N.Y.

PARIS, May 29. -- Miss Helen Jacobs continued her relentless march through the French hard court tennis championships today, but the only other American representatives, Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Con, and Wilmer Hines, former star at the University of North Carolina, were summarily eliminated.

More than 500 students in the R.O.T.C. unit at City College passed in review before Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, and representatives of military and civic groups at the annual Military Field Day of the college yesterday afternoon in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The American Safety Razor Corporation's directors declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share, placing the stock on a $5 annual basis. In the previous quarter the company paid a regular dividend of $1 and 25 cents extra.

William Heuttmann, quartermaster of the United States liner President Harding, received the Distinguished Service Medal of the lines yesterday morning for bravery in rescuing a woman. Kermit Roosevelt, vice president of the lines, made the presentation on the sun deck of the ship in the presence of Captain Giles C. Stedman, her master, and other officers of the staff, shortly before the ship sailed for Plymouth.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Charley (Red) Ruffing wasn't pitching so well today at Griffith Stadium when the Yankees opened a two-game series with the Senators, but he was hitting like a fiend and the result was the same. The McCarthymen stopped Bucky Harris's boys, 7 -- 4, in an abbreviated game.
Reduction of cigarette prices below 12 cents a package does not mean that the cigarettes are exempted from the 2 per cent sales tax, it was explained yesterday.
Arthur Krock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night in an address over the radio that the good-neighbor policy of the United States is a hope and not a reality.

Only those persons now on relief who decline to accept jobs "without apparently justified reason will be reported to the relief agencies for such action as they may finally decide to be appropriate," Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 29. -- Uncertainties in the United States and France caused a slump in the volume of trading on the Stock Exchange today, operators adopting a waiting attitude. British funds recovered sharply, while foreign bonds were dull, with German issues lower.

MOSCOW, May 29. -- Plans for the erection of the Palace of Soviets, which is to be seventy feet higher than the Empire State Building and thus will be the tallest, as well as the largest, structure in the world, have been found feasible, and construction is expected to start soon, it was learned today.

PARIS, May 29. -- The United States Supreme Court's NRA decisions have given France a decided impression that President Roosevelt's New Deal policy has met a decisive check. In that sense it is being viewed with relief in Conservative circles here, which always have been apprehensive that the New Deal would lead toward a radical and more radical policy, with repercussions upon the European social system.

Frightened selling continued in evidence in most commodity futures markets yesterday, but the declines were more moderate than on Tuesday. The volume of trading was not affected by the approach of the holiday, which will limit the ranks of traders for the remainder of the week.

TOKYO, May 29. -- Vice Admiral Sadakichi Takahashi, commander-in-chief of the Japanese fleet, said the United States and Britain had a superiority complex regarding Japan, in an address today at a public meeting celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of Admiral Heihachiro Togo's defeat of the Russian fleet.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Reports that wage and hour "chiseling" had already begun in various parts of the country were received today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

LONDON, May 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody "probably" will rush straight home to California after she plays in the all-England tennis championships at Wimbledon, she told The Associated Press today, "without waiting for anything at Forest Hills."

Picketing and student demonstrations continued yesterday in front of the Columbia University Medical Centre as petitions and protests poured in upon Dean Willard C. Rappleye demanding that he drop dismissal proceedings against the students and reinstate the staff members dismissed in the last week.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29. -- Joseph Frederick Kenna, 30 years old, of 406 Clinton Avenue, this city, former convict and one time patient in a hospital for the insane, was arrested here today for murder in connection with the fatal stabbing of Miss Anna Schmid, a domestic servant, in Montclair last May 8.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad today invited bids for what is believed to be the largest equipment order of the year. In some quarters the announcement was regarded as signalizing the beginning of a definite upturn in the heavy goods industry.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Grain markets of the nation were under pressure today from liquidators who were tired of working against adverse conditions. Prices in all trading centres either declined to new low levels for the season or to within a small fraction of the bottom and closed weak.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- With a reasonable recovery in business, an opportunity to compete equitably with other means of transport, freedom from laws that prevent carrying out economies and relief from laws which would increase their expenses, the railroads would be "a very great factor in leading the country back to prosperity," J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, told the Association of Commerce and other organizations today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 29. -- The opening round of play in the American championship of the International Players Association was interrupted midway in the program today on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 29. -- Memorial Day will be observed in Greenwich with many social and sporting events.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The text of General Johnson's radio speech tonight was as follows:
Of all the Memorial Day baseball battles to be waged today none will draw a larger or more interested crowd than the clash at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Results of Fleet Problem XVI in the naval manoeuvres in the Pacific were hailed as "highly gratifying" today by Secretary of the Navy Swanson, although he expressed sorrow over the fatalities that had occurred.

LONDON, May 29. -- Seventeen 3-year-olds, one American-owned, will make up the field for the Derby, it was revealed today with the withdrawal of Lord Derby's Bobsleigh and announcement of final acceptances.

ORANGE, Texas, May 29 (AP). -- The Rev. Edgar Eskridge, 40, Baptist minister and vice crusader, was arrested late today as the suspected shotgun slayer of Police Chief Ed J. O'Reilly, whom he baptized into his church several months ago.

More than 4,000 disabled World War veterans in government hospitals in the eastern half of this State and in New Jersey will straighten shattered bodies today in a Memorial Day salute to their comrades who died overseas.

The fight for the Bonus Bill, with the President's veto of it, unquestionably tended to dim and blur some of the sentiments associated with May 30. To commemorate those who gave their lives in war is not made easier by efforts of survivors of the battlefield to commercialize their service.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, May 29. -- The main body of the ships of the United States Fleet, fueled, provisioned and ready for the sea since yesterday, prepared to bid "Aloha oe" to Hawaii today. The greatest armada that ever visited Pearl Harbor will get under way tomorrow and Friday and will stand eastward for San Diego, Calif., in the final phase of its annual manoeuvres.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered effective immediately the applications of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company (committee) and Tastyeast, Inc., for registration of securities on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, respectively.

SALEM, N.H., May 29 (AP). -- Jockey Maurice (Moose) Peters, a leading rider in 1934, returned to the scene of his earliest triumphs today and rode T.H. Somerville's Pretty Night, an outsider, to a stirring victory in the Harvard Handicap, feature race at Rockingham Park.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull reciprocated today the sentiments voiced by Stanley Baldwin, British Lord President of the Council, for collaboration of the British Empire and the United States in the interests of peace, and the sentiments of Anthony Eden, British Lord Privy Seal, for Anglo-American friendship.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Business gave signs of some slight improvement last week and there were indications of a somewhat more hopeful attitude, the Commerce Department reported today in its weekly survey covering conditions in thirty-three cities.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 29. -- Babe Young's homer in the fifth inning, with Gene Coyle and Ed Estwanick on the bases, clinched victory for Fordham over Yale today. The score was 7 to 2. The ball, hit to deep centre, bounded over the fence and into the freshman diamond, nearly duplicating his circuit blow of last year when these same rivals met.

It is no longer permissible to net stonecats in waters inhabited by trout. Minnows are "fish" now, just like their big brothers. If taken for bait they must be used for bait in hook and line fishing and for no other purpose. Frogs may no longer be stored after the close of the season in a storehouse designated by the Conservation Department.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 29. -- Although nursing minor injuries on both hands, Max Baer is making steady progress in conditioning himself for the defense of his heavyweight title against James J. Braddock in the Garden Bowl June 13.

THE jolly surprises of last week on the big league diamonds were the way the Giants kept whizzing through the West on crutches and the warning winning streak of the Cincinnati Reds. Not a bad team, those Reds. Kampouris, Riggs and Myers have rounded out a brisk infield, and the pitchers are taking heart since they have been getting a little help at bat and afield.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 29. -- "Wedding Belles," a colorful pageant featuring the modeling of wedding gowns from 1835 to the present, was a feature of the annual garden party of the Upper Montclair Woman's Club today at the home of Mrs. Guy Gk Clark, who acted as hostess. The party, in charge of Mrs. Harry S. Carlson, was attended by about 500 members and guests.

New financing continued yesterday its accelerated pace of the week when approximately $17,000,000 of new loans, all in the State and municipal field, were sold to banks and underwriting houses. Several of the smaller items were placed privately and no re-offering to the public is expected.

Entries for the ocean race from Newport to Bergen, Norway, starting June 8, closed yesterday with seven yachts committed to making the 3,050-mile passage, Herbert L. Stone, chairman of the race committee of the Cruising Club of America, announced.
TACOMA, Wash., May 29. -- The deadline fixed by the kidnappers for raising $200,000 to ransom 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser passed tonight without yielding any indication of his fate.

VIENNA, May 29. -- Before the nominated members of the Austrian Diet, which was ordered to assemble for one of its rare meetings for the purpose, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg today replied to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's criticisms of the Austrian regime in his recent Reichstag speech.

DEVON, Pa., May 29. -- The fifth day of the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair was marred by one serious accident and another painful spill and a heavy downpour, accompanied by a windstorm, which turned the oval into a sea of mud and water today.

All the security markets and most of the commodity Exchanges in the United States will be closed today in observance of Memorial Day. The banks and financial institutions will be closed and the foreign exchange market here will not be active.

TRENTON, N.J., May 29. -- Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan denied today the petition of Edward J. Reilly, former chief counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, for an order forbidding disbursements from the prisoner's defense fund pending determination of the lawyer's suit for $22,398.
CINCINNATI, May 29. -- Another clash between the Fundamentalists and Modernists marked the closing session today of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

No material reduction in the wage scale will result from the Supreme Court's decision ruling the NIRA unconstitutional, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday. He added that the General Motors Corporation is not contemplating any reduction.
The members of the squads entered were announced yesterday by the Intercollegiate Polo Association for the title tournament which starts on Saturday, June 8, at Governors Island.
LONDON, May 29. -- The British Government again turned a cold shoulder to the idea of an international conference on currency stabilization today and the shoulder seemed a bit icier than usual.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -- President Roosevelt was reported authoritatively tonight to have reached an understanding with drafters of a Tennessee Valley Authority expansion bill, designed to speed the measure through the House.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The first White House press conference held since the Supreme Court invalidated the NRA showed the President today in the role of a seeker after information that may be used as a pattern for future action.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Following is the text of Owen D. Young's statement before the Senate subcommittee at a hearing on the Omnibus Banking Bill:

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A fight on the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utility Holding Company Bill began in the Senate today after strong and unsuccessful protests that the legislation contravened the Constitution by affecting intrastate commerce just as the Supreme Court held was the case in the National Industrial Recovery Act.
Four women leaders of the meat strike announced yesterday their intention to carry their protest against high prices to Mayor La Guardia.
To continue the procedure permitted by the NRA law, now declared unconstitutional, will probably involve many in violations of the Sherman and Clayton acts.

Fees and allowances aggregating $212,509 were granted yesterday by Federal Judge Mack to counsel, engineers and others in connection with the pending receiverships of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Francis R. Hart, president of the United Fruit Company, received $58,450 compensation in 1934, and Samuel Zemurray, managing director, got only $1,010 in director's fees, the corporation's registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 29. -- By way of preparation for next week's national open championship, Willie Macfarlane, the 1925 titleholder, tied the course record at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today with a 67.

Affirmation of the old Jewish law under which religious sanction of a divorce may not be granted to a deserted wife without consent of the husband was voted yesterday by about 200 members of the Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada, meeting at the Broadway Central Hotel, 673 Broadway, near Third Street.

The steel trade was stunned and left in confusion by the United States Supreme Court's decision that the NRA codes were unconstitutional, according to The Iron Age's weekly summary. Uncertainty as to the future of prices was offset, however, by a belief that the decision ultimately would release the pent-up demand for capital goods, the magazine said.

LONDON, May 29. -- The United States New Deal crisis and the French currency crisis combined today to throw a shadow over London's financial markets and provoke much editorial speculation concerning what the next steps will be in both countries. Generally, however, the London Stock Exchange displayed a remarkable steadiness.

Three men on trial on a conspiracy indictment growing out of the investigation by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, into alleged grafting in news-stand licenses, were cleared of the charge yesterday by a jury. Judge Otto A. Rosalsky, at the close of the State's case by Assistant District Attorney Frank E. Carstarphen, granted the request of the defense lawyer, I. A. Rosenberg, for a directed verdict of acquittal.

PARIS, May 29. -- Henry Berenger, former Ambassador to the United States and now president of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, in speaking at an Anglo-American newspaper correspondents' luncheon today gave the first official reaction that has been voiced in France to Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's recent speech, and on the whole it was favorable.

The Public Service Commission's first hearing on the new reduced electric rates proposed by the Consolidated Gas System was enlivened yesterday by an objection by Chairman Milo R. Maltbie to one feature of the rates proposed by the companies.

The Association of National Advertisers, Inc., announced yesterday that a communication had been sent to Governor Harold G. Koffman of New Jersey, vigorously opposing the bill now before the State Assembly providing for the registration of trade-marks, labels, advertisements,

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 30. -- News of the invalidation of NIRA by the Supreme Court of the United States was received here with great interest. It is interpreted in Communist circles as demonstrating that the brain trusters' dream of economic revolution in the United States without the destruction of existing political institutions was absurd.

The price war in cigarettes, books, toilet goods and liquors intensified yesterday and, coupled with the warmer weather and heavy pre-holiday advertising, drew the largest crowds of shoppers to stores since last Easter, Price reductions, following the end of the NRA code restrictions, were made on a large number of items, among which cigars, radios, films and some types of sporting goods were most prominent.

Before our departure for a brief whirl at salmon and trout fishing in Moosehead Lake, we were discussing plans for the trip with an angler whose fishing has been restricted to waters of the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The troubles encountered in 1932 in getting an agreement among bankers, insurance companies and railroad officials on a reorganization plan for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company so that an RFC loan could be obtained in an effort to head off receivership were reviewed today by Robert T. Swaine of Cravath de Gersdorff, Swathe Wood, then general counsel for the railroad.

THE TIMES is making a useful contribution to efficient and economic administration of the civil service of the city in bringing to public attention the various elements involved in the proposed reclassification of positions.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A warning to the government to "do nothing and to threaten nothing more" to shake the confidence of American business men was uttered today by Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company and a director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, testifying before a Senate Banking subcommittee on the Omnibus Banking Bill.

WHEN review copies of Carl Carmer's "Stars Fell on Alabama" reached certain newspaper sanctums in the Deep South, local editorial writers rose in their wrath to protest the calumny visited upon them by a dam-Yankee who had taught at the university in Tuscaloosa and had proved to be an ungrateful viper. Yet to Northern readers, "Stars Fell on Alabama" seemed about as fair a portrait as could be managed.

Four orphaned brothers and sisters, all in good shape except Tommy, 7 years old, who lacks a front tooth or so, left the care of the State Charities Aid Association yesterday for a new home in Connecticut.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., May 29. -- More than 500 members and their guests attended the dinner dance tonight at the Atlantic Beach Club here, which formally opened for its sixth consecutive season. The entertainment began with aperitifs in the newly decorated Cafe Atlantique and continued with dinner and dancing on the terrace and in the dining room.

An unemployed man helping himself to junk brass accidentally set off a gas explosion about 11:40 o'clock yesterday morning that demolished a four-story building at 404 East Twenty-first Street, wrecked two adjacent buildings at the corner of First Avenue and caused injuries to eighteen persons, three of whom were in a serious condition last night.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Roosevelt officially opened the California Pacific International Exposition at San Diego tonight with a telephoned address in which he hailed the new world fair as demonstrating "the courage and confidence with which our people now look to the future."

Noel Scaffa, private detective, who, according to his own estimate, has recovered and returned stolen jewelry valued at $10,000,000, was arrested last night by Department of Justice agents working from the Division of Investigation. The Federal authorities refused to divulge the charge on which he was being held, but Scaffa's attorney, Isidor Bregoff of 521 Fifth Avenue, told The Associated Press that it was suspicion of perjury.
Action of outside markets and confusion in wholesale dry goods quarters had a depressing effect on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices broke $1.50 a bale to end with losses of 26 to 28 points.

PARIS, May 29 (AP). -- American women, housekeeping methods and motion pictures will be three primary items of interest to Mme. Albert Lebrun, wife of the President of France, on her first visit to the United States.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 29. -- Two local organizations have appealed within the last twenty-four hours to Governor Harold G. Hoffman for action on the alleged pro-Nazi activities of teachers of German at New Jersey College for Women, it became known here today as the investigation by a special trustees' committee of Rutgers University went into its seventh day.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but broke again, closing generally below yesterday's levels, although in the final minutes of trading some firmness was evident. Heavy industrials were mixed, with no significant changes occurring, and potashes were quiet but firm.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- More hopefulness in regard to currency stabilization is apparent here than previously. It is felt Great Britain may decide that provisional preliminary stabilization should be undertaken, if the gold bloc collapses.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has come to the conclusion that the only way to maintain the city's parks properly and keep them from getting run down and worn out is to provide many more playgrounds in existing parks as well as in new locations devoted only to recreational use.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The Rev. Otto Goetler, Franciscan monk, who had charge of the financial affairs of the monastery of Wald Breitbach, in the Rhineland, was sentenced today to ten years' penal servitude and fined 350,000 marks after he had confessed to smuggling several hundred thousand marks across the border to Holland contrary to exchange-control laws.

BOSTON, May 29 (AP). -- Unsteady pitching and fielding marred the free-hitting game which ended with the Boston Red Sox defeating the Philadelphia Athletics, 10 -- 9, today. The Hub team used four pitchers in this series opener.

PITTSBURGH, May 29. -- The value of the R.B. Mellon estate was placed at $21,615,170.15 by H.A. Phillips and E.B. Clarke, appraisers, in an inventory filed with the Register of Wills today, Real estate was not included in the report.

HAVANA. May 29. -- John Barrymore sailed into Havana harbor today on his 250-ton yacht Infanta and informed reporters that he would not contest his wife's divorce suit and that he was not in love with Miss Elaine Barrie, 19-year-old actress.

The forty-third annual commencement of the Spence School took place yesterday forenoon in the assembly hall of the school building, 22 East Ninety-first Street. Twenty-two young women received diplomas in the presence of their families, friends and alumnae. Miss Valentine L. Chandor, headmistress of the school, presided and presented the sheepskins.

It had always been Jimmy McLarnin's ambition to retire from the ring as the welterweight champion of the world. But it appears as though the Vancouver battler, who dropped the 147-pound title to Barney Ross on Tuesday night, will not realize that hope.

Retail stores here employing 100,000 workers will keep the hour and wage schedules prescribed in the NRA retail code despite the Supreme Court decision on the NIRA, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Retail Code Authority, announced last night. About 62,000 of these workers are employed in department stores.
PARIS, May 29. -- The situation of the franc remained unchanged today as all operators and speculators awaited the result of the political struggle.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP). -- The world champion Cardinals pounded young Gene Schott today and won their series opener from the Reds, 6 to 3, taking revenge for a five-hit defeat handed them by the Cincinnati rookie hurler earlier in the season.

OTTAWA, May 29. -- Prime Minister Bennett stated in Parliament today that legislation would be introduced probably next week to give the government power to revalue gold if such a step were deemed desirable.

Appeals by Code Authorities and trade associations for a maintenance on a voluntary basis of NRA provisions were buttressed yesterday, when the National Electrical Manufacturers Association urged members to observe all features of their code. The group comprises manufacturers in every branch of the electrical goods field.

Mr. OWEN D. YOUNG'S testimony before the Senate subcommittee on the Banking Bill, and the speech of Mr. OGDEN MILLS to the Harvard Business School Club, provide in each case a particularly clear analysis of the objections to that measure as it stands. Mr. YOUNG spoke as a member of the New York Reserve Bank's directorate during a dozen years; Mr. MILLS, as Treasury Secretary, has been a member of the Federal Reserve Board.
BERLIN, May 30. -- The German position on the proposed Western European air pact has been officially communicated to the British Government, it was announced here today.

The policy committee of the Northern Cotton Mills announced here yesterday that it had endorsed the resolution to continue to do business as before the Supreme Court decision on the NRA codes, adopted at a meeting of cotton textile men at Washington on Wednesday.

LONDON, May 30. -- The stock markets still were subdued today, awaiting further developments in the situation in France and the United States, but firmer. British funds were little changed. Foreign bonds were quiet. Among the industrials Rolls-Royce, Cables and Wireless, Courtaulds, Cunard and Dunlop Rubber were firm.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Federal and municipal housing authorities are collaborating in investigating various sites for further slum clearance and low-cost housing projects in New York City, it was revealed today by Colonel Horatio B. Hackett, assistant PWA administrator and former director of the PWA Housing Division.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- A rapidly developing competitive drive for mortgage business is under way in the United States and this activity will double in the next six months, Morton Bodfish of Chicago, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League, stated today before a Senate banking subcommittee.

LONDON, May 30. -- The late Colonel T.E. Lawrence's own full story of the Arab revolt, "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom," of which only about 100 copies were privately printed, bringing fabulous prices when marketed, will soon be available to the public in a regular edition.

In the hour before they stepped into their place in yesterday's Memorial Day parade, the G.A.R. men sat on a bench at Riverside Drive and Eighty-eighth Street and talked of Shiloh, Vicksburg, Mobile Bay and Sheridan's march to the sea.
BUENOS AIRES, May 30. -- The Chaco peace negotiations have again encountered a dangerous stumbling block in the famous Hayes award.
LONDON, May 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The New York Rowing Association staged a renewal of its Memorial Day regatta on the Harlem River yesterday with Princeton University oarsmen as guests, and the guests went away with most of the laurels.
