Officers of the United States Army and Navy, including several former leaders of military and naval forces, joined yesterday with members and guests of the Veterans Corps of Artillery, Military Society of the War of 1812, at the annual Memorial Day luncheon of that organization in the Hotel Pierre, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street.

The New Deal policies are "the sketchiest and most incomplete anticipations of the real planning that is demanded," according to H.G. Wells. Mr. Wells's final chapter in the series he has written on the New Deal is published in the current Collier's Weekly.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Curbing of the Tennessee Valley Authority's domination of near-by private power areas and regulation of its surplus sales were indicated by Chairman McSwain of the House Military Committee today to be embraced in pending amendments to the TVA Bill.

Park Commissioner MOSES, in speaking of conditions in some of the parks and playgrounds, states that from many sections have come reports of "miniature dust storms being blown up on windy days." This is figuratively true of the gusts of criticisms that "blew up" about various park projects, even when undertaken and carried forward with such great vigor and promise of eventual success.
ATLANTA, May 30 (AP). -- Laying plans for voicing his anti-Roosevelt sentiments in the 1936 Democratic Convention, Governor Eugene Talmadge today took over the National Committeemanship for Georgia.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 30. -- Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin entertained with a reception for 400 this afternoon at the Hedges, one of East Hampton's oldest homesteads, dating back to 1652, which was an early Summer inn here in 1870 and was reopened yesterday.

LATONIA, Ky., May 30 (AP). -- The Long Run Stable's Marynell, a recent graduate from the ranks of claiming platers, finally convinced skeptics she is entitled to consideration in the best of company when she accounted for the Memorial Day Handicap before an enthisiastic crowd of 15,000 today at Latonia.
NEW ORLEANS, La., May 30. -- The sky was the limit here tonight when gambling houses opened in the city and the suburban parishes of Jefferson and St. Bernard. Great crowds celebrated the occasion.

ALBANY, May 30, -- A straight $3 registration fee for all passenger automobiles was advocated today in a resolution adopted by the directors of the State Automobile Association, Frank J. Smith, chairman of the legislative committee, announced.

TOKYO, May 30. -- The Japanese Army in North China has again adopted the principle of acting first and reporting afterward. The War and Foreign Offices received dispatches concerning the latest tension only this afternoon.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP). -- E.F. Seagram's Stand Pat raced to an easy victory over Azucar, winner of the $127,000 Santa Anita Handicap, in the one and one-sixteenth mile Colonel Alger Memorial Handicap before 20,000 fans today.

Cardinal Hayes, the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of the archdiocese, and other Catholic dignitaries attired in their colorful vestments participated yesterday morning in a solemn pontifical mass commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale Avenue and 263d Street, the Bronx.

PARIS, May 30. -- "American industry should set an example of self-restraint in this difficult period of readjustment after the NRA's set back." Myron C. Taylor, who is in Paris, said today in an interview. In the following statement which he drafted for publication, Mr. Taylor intimates that the steel industry is going to seek to avoid upsetting labor conditions.

LONDON, May 30. -- The vague and misleading reply that Prime Minister MacDonald gave last night in the House of Commons to a question on stabilization caused so much confusion that it was considered worth while in Whitehall circles today to give an officially inspired and apologetic explanation.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Only three days have passed since NRA was demolished by the Supreme Court as a constitutional implement of recovery, but the reaction in the capital and in the nation has changed. Those who cheered in the name of partisanship and tradition are quiet in sober second thought.

An anti-war parade of 15,000 men, women and children through the lower East Side and Madison Square culminated in a near-riot about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in front of the main office of the Emergency Relief Bureau, 902 Broadway, at Twenty-first Street, where six paralytics had staged a "hunger strike" since 2 P.M. Wednesday.

The hope of bringing all the consumers in America together in one great cooperative was expressed here yesterday at the annual dinner and meeting of the Easter States Cooperative League by E.N. Bowen, secretary of the national group.

The projected campaign to be launched against the gypsy moth by four CCC camps about to be established in the western part of Massachusetts, appears in appalling contrast to the present attitude of the Federal Government toward the much greater menace of the Dutch elm disease.

Operation of the Independent Subway System, from its beginning on Sept. 10, 1932, to Jan. 1, 1935, netted the city a revenue which was far below the amount needed to meet the fixed charges on the bonds and other securities allocated to the completed lines, according to a report submitted by the Board of Transportation to Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate.

Among possible substitutes for NRA, mention is frequently made in the Washington dispatches of the Guffey bill. It is concerned only with a single industry, the mining of soft coal, but some members of Congress find in it a rough pattern which might be applied in the case of other natural-resource industries.

In the old days in Spain, a stagecoach having overturned, the driver approached a prostrate passenger and politely inquired if he were killed. The equally polite answer was: "Not entirely." A similar reply might honestly be made today by the New Deal, painfully getting up from the roadside where it had been thrown by the decision of the Supreme Court.

VIENNA, May 30. -- A report to the newspaper Telegraf from Dubrovnik [Ragusa] declares that following conversations between Pierre Laval, the French Foreign Minister, and the Yugoslav Minister in Paris, the substance of which the latter telephoned to the Foreign Office in Belgrade, General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the German Air Minister, has been requested by the Yugoslav authorities to refrain from any kind of political or propagandist activities while he is Yugoslavia's guest.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 30. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club lacrosse team defeated the Syracuse University ten, 8 to 5, today in the first of a series of two games. The second game will be played Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The stockholdings of Clarence H. Mackay in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were placed at 80,748 shares in the corporation's registration statement made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Edward J. Berwind, a director, was the second largest holder among officers and directors, with 70,800 shares.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The Treasury's offering of $100,000,000 of 3 per cent long term bonds to the highest bidders who offered more than par resulted in an oversubscription of about 170 per cent, and $98,779,000 of the tenders have been accepted, with the government realizing a premium of $3,085,207, Secretary Morgenthau stated today.

About 150 men, women and children, all descendants of Civil War veterans, made an annual Memorial Day pilgrimage yesterday afternoon to the graves of fifty G.A.R. soldiers on Harts Island. They placed wreaths at the foot of a monument among the plots and small American flags where each body lay in a section only a stone's throw from Potter's Field.

Mayor LA GUARDIA, the first air-commuter in the grand manner between New York and Washington, now has a pied-a-terre in the national capital. The Sinking Fund Commission on Wednesday voted to lease a suite of three rooms for his use on Jackson Place.

PARIS, May 30. -- Marcel Bernard, best of France's younger tennis generation, smashed his way into the quarter-finals of the French hard-court championship today and perhaps won himself a singles berth on the Davis Cup team.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Despite a deficit fast climbing above the $3,111,000,000 mark, Democratic leaders in Congress contended today that they had found a way of more than balancing next year what they call the "normal" budget.

EATONTOWN, N.J., May 30. -The Monmouth County Country Club poloists defeated Princeton University and Eastland Farms in a round-robin match at the Monmouth Club today. The club team tallied eight goals, Princeton six and Eastland Farms five.

Persons who would be shocked at the idea of standing on a street corner and accepting dimes from passersby, have no hesitancy in requesting other people to solicit alms for them by means of chain letters. In fact, they seem to glory in their role of mendicants.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30. -Making his first appearance before a metropolitan gallery, Robert Ramillon of France defeated Herman Petersen of Larchmont today as the eight seeded favorites reached the quarter-finals of the American tennis championship of the International Players' Association.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- With the preponderant sentiment of the members of the National Industrial Recovery Board favoring quick action by President Roosevelt in the crisis precipitated by the Supreme Court's decision in the Schechter case, it became known today that influential advisers of the President were at odds as to the best means of coping with the situation.

TORONTO, May 30 (Canadian Press). -- While waiting for the New York market to resume business tomorrow, mining stocks on the Exchange here pursued a leisurely course today, with prices displaying more strength than weakness. Senior stocks, particularly those listed in the New York market, had a small turnover, and only a few of the secondary issues changed hands in volume.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30. -- The Ida Lewis Yacht Club opened officially for the season yesterday with a members' breakfast at the clubhouse. Dr. Horace P. Beck presided in the absence of Commodore Marion Eppley, who, as a naval reserve officer, is with the United States Fleet in the Pacific.

MOSCOW, May 30 (AP). -- The issuance and circulation of illegal scrip by local organizations has resulted in the arrest of sixteen persons, including the presidents of four city Soviets, and brought a severe public reprimand to Moisey Kalmanovitch, Commissar for State Livestock and Grain Farms.

It is wholly understandable why Supreme Court decisions mark milestones in the history of American statesmanship. Many were negative, it is true, but by that very token they have usually indicated that there was a sounder solution of a particular problem than that embodied in the legislation declared unconstitutional.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell was charged with dividing a double-header when the Red Sex won the opening game, 7 -- 4, and dropped the second in eleven innings to the Athletics, 13 -- 8, today before a crowd of 32,000.
PARIS, May 30. -- Memorial Day was celebrated throughout France today with the traditional ceremonies of decorating the graves of American soldiers who fell during the World War.

With the Polo Grounds packed to the girders with the largest crowd in National League history, Bill Terry's Giants yesterday downed the Brooklyn Dodgers in both ends of the Memorial Day double-header, 8 -- 3 and 6 -- 0, Freddy Fitzsimmons scoring the shutout in the afterpiece and allowing only two hits.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 30. -- Two men are missing and are believed to have been drowned, and eight others were rescued after a collision at 2 o'clock this morning in the Hudson River near here which resulted in the sinking of the tugboat Russell No. 2 of the Newtown Creek Towing Company of Brooklyn.
NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- Newark concluded a short home stay today by dividing a double-header with Baltimore.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30. -A triple, a pass and an error paved the way for a sixth-inning scoring spree to give Harvard a 3-to-0 verdict over Brown in their annual Memorial Day game today.

Montague Adair, textile machinery manufacturer, of 1,997 Park Avenue, disclosed yesterday that he received a letter from Park Commissioner Robert Moses in which Mr. Moses explained just what his position was on the West Side improvement controversy.

LONDON, May 30 (Canadian Press). -- Middlesex defeated Essex by an innings and 41 runs in a county cricket championship match concluded at Lord's today. Essex has yet to win in the competition, having lost five straight.

BERLIN, May 30. -- Ascension Day -- Himmelfahrt in German -- is observed as a general holiday virtually throughout Continental Europe, but here an old custom extending back to time immemorial imparts to it a special flavor different from that of all other days.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The Supreme Court will sit Monday for the last time before the Summer recess. Only five cases are available for decision.

SALEM, N.H., May 30. -- William R. Coe's 3-year-old bay gelding Pompeys Pillar, a 25-to-1 shot, raced to a decisive victory in the $10,000 added Decoration Day Handicap over the mile and a sixteenth route at Rockingham Park today.

The application of port interests for improvement of the Buttermilk Channel to provide a width of 1,200 feet and a depth of 40 feet has been rejected by the army engineers, who favor a compromise on a 1,000-foot width, however, according to a report made public yesterday by Colonel G.R. Lukesh, engineer in charge of the North Atlantic district.

COLORADO SPRINGS, May 30. -- Torrential Spring rains sent devastating floods rolling down creeks at the eastern edge of the Rocky Mountains late today, sweeping three persons to their deaths, leaving seven missing and paralyzing transportation and communication.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- Dewey Hanover, black gelding trotter, owned by J.P. Ryno of Plainfield captured the Class A event, featured of the season's opening matinee of the load Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- A Yankee barrage of unprecedented intensity disturbed the quiet calm of the capital today as the McCarthy juggernaut trampled the Senators in a holiday twin bill and gained the top of the American League standing for the first time this season.

DANVILLE, Ky., May 30 (AP). -- A victory of peace "no less renowned than war" was celebrated today with the unveiling of a monument to the pioneer heroine of a remarkable scientific drama staged here 126 years ago in the office of a daring frontier surgeon.

A four-day holiday opened at the beaches and resorts near the city yesterday with the arrival of thousands of men, women and children by automobile, bus and train. Many planned to stay in cottages and hotels through Sunday.

The Socialist party of New York rejected yesterday a proposal by the Communist party for a "united front" to fight wage reductions and dislocation of labor standards, which both parties charge will result from the decision of the Supreme Court declaring the NRA unconstitutional.
More than 35,000 persons viewed the parade of 15,000 men, women and children along the Grand Concourse yesterday in the Bronx's annual Memorial Day celebration.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30. -- Graduates of Cornell University's Law School, which had its commencement today, heard Dr. Stanley King, president of Amherst, condemn encroachments on freedom of thought, expression, teaching and learning and assert that "this freedom is the breath of life to most of the men engaged in education and yet it is never permanently won, never guaranteed, never universally recognized."

Six persons were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday in minor disorders growing out of the housewives' strike against the high prices of meat. Leaders of the City Action Committee Against the High Cost of Living and the United Council of Working Class Women declared that the strike was still "going strong."

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP). -- A crowd of 40,430 fans, the largest in the history of local baseball aside from world series play, flocked to Forbes Field today to see the Pirates and Cubs divide their double-header.
Investors figured as buyers of several parcels of real estate in deals announced yesterday. The trading, although mild, was scattered over three boroughs. Some of the properties were sold by banks.

The twenty-three Broadway shows which gave holiday matinees yesterday gambled with the weather -and, on the whole, they lost. The weather was fine for Belmont Park and the Polo Grounds, but not so good for Times Square. One attraction drew a dismal total of $30.

Mayor LA GUARDIA flew from Albany to New York in 50 minutes and was moved to many reflections. "We are living in an age of change. Yet some things hold fast. Planes go 250 miles an hour, but the old Constitution still holds.

Passengers on a liner inbound from Europe and some denim-clad sailors on an outgoing Italian freighter were among the few witnesses yesterday to the only American Legion memorial service held at sea here.

Gaining twenty-two points in the three field events, All Hallows Institute recorded the big upset of the 1935 outdoor scholastic season by winning the senior team title in the ninth annual city C.H.S.A.A. track and field championships at Poly Prep Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

LONDON, May 30. -- The famous great mace and sword of the old city of Galway, Irish Free State, were bought for William R. Hearst for his Welsh castle, St. Donat's, in Glamorganshire, for 5,000 at Sotheby's today. [The pound is currently worth about $4.93 1/8.]

WARSAW, Poland, May 30. -- What may be regarded as the Polish Foreign Office's first statement of policy since Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death appeared today in the semi-official Gazeta Polska, suggesting that Foreign Commissar Litvinoff of Russia and Chancellor Hitler should demonstrate the usefulness and soundness of Poland's policy of bilateral non-aggression agreements with her two neighbors, Soviet Russia and the Reich.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 30. -- For the second time within a week, John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Greentree quartet, with Tommy Hitchcock Jr. playing the leading roles conquered the Old Westbury poloists at the Meadow Brook Club today.
Plans for new homes were announced in connection with sales of properties just closed in Westchester County.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 30. -- Amherst routed Williams, 15 to 7, today, hitting the offerings of three pitchers for a total of fourteen blows, including two homers and five triples.
LONDON, May 30. -- Members of the American colony attended Memorial Day service at St. Margaret's, Westminster, today. Canon Carnegie officiated.

Several large farms and estates in Bucks County, Pa., have been purchased by New York residents through J. Carroll Molloy, broker. The 120-acre Stopp estate in the New Hope section was bought by Dr. John R. Clark of Columbia University, and the John P. Sears estate known as Bridgegate, on the Old York Road at Holicong, was sold to John C. Knight of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

PEIPING, China, May 30 -- The Japanese Army will again come southward in great force, this time intending to include the Peiping-Tientsin area within the zone demilitarized by the Tangku truce, unless all its demands are met without qualification, says a formally worded warning served yesterday afternoon upon the Chinese authorities of both the threatened cities.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Nine planks of a platform on which a new NRA could be erected, retaining the effective features of the present structure, are suggested by Dr. Louis Lorwin, until recently of Brookings Institution, and now economic adviser to the International Labor Organization at Geneva.
In New York, throughout the nation and in other parts of the world Americans paid homage yesterday to their war dead in observance of Memorial Day.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- A stiff battle between Roosevelt and Talmadge forces in the Georgia preferential primary a year hence was forecast in Democratic circles here today upon word of the Governor's election as Democratic national committeeman from Georgia.

The Reliance International Corporation, an investing company associated with the Equity Corporation, has acquired for cash the National Securities Investment Company's holdings of stock of the American, British Continental Corporation, consisting of 59,417 shares of preferred stock, and 461,542 shares of common stock.

The Eccles Banking Bill involves no new principle. The effect of the proposed changes will be to increase the facility to inflate or deflate bank credit, which is already too easily done under the present Federal Reserve Law.

Before a stunned throng of 35,000, which looked in vain for the champion, Cavalcade, Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Head Play yesterday won the forty-ninth Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park in the smashing time of 2:02 for the mile and a quarter.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP). -- The world champion Cardinals climbed past Chicago into a second place berth in the National League today by taking both games of a double header from the Reds before a crowd of 18,000.

The High School of Commerce replaced George Washington yesterday as track and field champion of the Manhattan Public Schools Athletic League. Although Commerce won only one of ten events at Baker Field, a generous share of second, third and fourth places boosted its point total to 40.

LONDON, May 30. -- Reliability and safety in the operation of an airline are best served by multi-engined airplanes capable of completing under good control all required flights after partial engine failure, Donald Douglas, American aircraft maker, declared before the Royal Aeronautical Society tonight.

THE aftermath of the recent welterweight whirl was more bitter than the bout. Jack Dempsey and the judges saw Barney Ross winning comfortably practically all the way. Thus it was announced that the verdict was unanimous. But if they had counted the volunteer votes around the ringside, there would have been half a dozen confused verdicts.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP). -- The revamped Browns unloosed a 16-hit attack on four Detroit pitchers today to score a 10 to 7 victory in the first game of a holiday twin bill. But they had nothing left for the second game and Tommy Bridges held them to three hits, while the Tigers triumphed, 2 to 0.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP). -Precedent in official tennis matches was broken today as an amateur and a professional faced each other in preliminary Davis Cup play at the Merion Cricket Club.

By actual count of Baker Taylor Company's sales throughout the country from April 15 to May 18, "A Few Foolish Ones," by Gladys Hasty Carroll, was the most popular novel, with "Young Renny," by Mazo de la Roche, not published until May 15, second.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Pacific coast ship owners informed the Labor Department today that unless the longshoremen and seamen's unions called off strikes regarded by them as violations of the arbitration awards arranged last Summer they would declare the agreement void and hold their ships in port pending developments.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Warning against radical reforms, Senator Dickinson of Iowa, in a Memorial Day speech at Arlington National Cemetery today, urged devotion of Americans to the ideals of government as guaranteed by the Constitution.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- A report that the swastika banner, emblem of Nazi Germany, would be displayed here, caused the cancellation today by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of a reception on the City Hall steps to members of German singing societies here for the opening of a three-day singing festival of the Northeastern Saengerbund at the Sussex Avenue armory.

While several thousand crowded the street in front of the centuryold Roman Catholic Church of St. Nicholas, 135 East Second Street, more than 1,500 occupied the church to take part in the solemn high mass yesterday in celebration of the golden anniversary of the ordination as a priest of the Rev. John A. Nageleisen, pastor of the church.

Business space leases announced yesterday included a few contracts for entire floors. Kearton Nagle, electrical manufacturers, leased from the Socony Vacuum Oil Company the ground floor and part of the second floor in 553-557 West Twenty-fifth Street. Dwight, Voorhis Perry were the brokers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30. -The gray cinders of the Harvard Stadium were ready today to receive the spiked-shoe assaults of the athletic army that will cross the Charles River tomorrow and Saturday for the fifty-ninth annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A.

An unscheduled bit of realism in the double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" at the Hippodrome last night resulted in a physician being summoned to dress a wound in the face of Rocci Pandiscio, the Alfio of Mascagni's operatic thriller.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 30. -- By making one of his characteristic last-hole finishes at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today, Gene Sarazen prevented Miss Joyce Wethered, English star, from opening her American tour with a victory.

New York money market closed for holiday. Wednesday's closing rate for Stock Exchange call loans one-fourth of 1 per cent; for 60-day time loans, one-fourth of 1 per cent; for prime commercial paper, three to four months, three-fourths of 1 per cent.

TACOMA, May 30. -- The terse statement of a prominent Washington State officer that kidnapped George Weyerhaeuser would "be returned alive" suddenly pierced the almost impenetrable silence tonight surrounding the boy's abduction.

J. Carlisle Peet asserts that speed laws are of little value, and that skill in driving alone should count and that many accidents occur at slow speeds. The number of accidents occurring at slow speeds is insignificant; such accidents are of much lesser degree.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 30. -- The assertion that the trustees committee investigating alleged pro-Nazi activities of German teachers at New Jersey College for Women "will take that course of action which will assure justice" was made by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, in a baccalaureate address at the college here this morning.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 30. -- Seven mothers carried a large banner bearing the words "There shall be no more war" in the Scarsdale Memorial Day parade this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- An assertion that there are "at least a dozen" Republicans who could defeat Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1936 Presidential campaign was made today by Charles Curtis, Vice President in the Hoover administration.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30 (AP). -- New Rochelle High School, Westchester County champion, today captured the thirty-first annual Brown University interscholastic track and field meet by half a point. Worcester Academy was second.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The possibility that a Supreme Court decision may invalidate the Agricultural Adjustment Act has been "overestimated in certain quarters," Senator Capper declared today in a radio speech.

WINNIPEG, May 30 (Canadian Press). -- The wheat market plodded along through another dull trading session today, although small gains were made. Absence of offerings eased a three-day selling pressure and enabled quotations to close 1/2 to 3/4 cent higher with May at 82 1/4 cents and July at 83 3/8.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- Wild-riding Kelly Petillo of Los Angeles, driving a cream-colored streak of thunder and lightning, today won the fastest 500-mile automobile race ever staged on the Indianapolis speedway, as death again put its stamp on the 25-year-old spectacle.

The New Deal method of proceeding as long as possible under a constitutionally doubtful statute before hazarding a Supreme Court decision is reminiscent of the "na'aseh v'nishmah" mentioned in Exodus 24, vii, which has been translated, "we will do and (then) we will listen."

BERLIN, May 30. -- The German press, which is not allowed to publish reports of arrests of Protestant pastors here, is devoting considerable attention to the persecution of the remaining Protestant clergymen in Soviet Russia.

ON BOARD THE STEAMSHIP NORMANDIE, May 30. -- Over smooth seas and under clear skies the Normandie, largest ship in the world, is speeding toward New York at an average of twenty-nine knots. She has done stretches on this her maiden voyage as high as 29.5 knots, and officials are highly pleased with her performance.
A five-run rally in the sixth inning enabled the New York A.C. nine to defeat Brooklyn College at Travers Island yesterday, 7 to 3.

PARIS, May 30. -- At the request of Louis Germain-Martin, before he resigned today as Finance Minister, a judicial inquiry opened on the possibility of prosecuting speculators against the franc. The Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies suggested such a move the last year, and it falls in with the government's charges of an international speculative attack against the franc.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Creation of a policy committee to present a tentative platform to the Republican National Convention is being considered by party leaders.

The Park Department's ubiquitous flagpole, which already has participated in four playground openings, will be moved to a fifth next Wednesday when the playground at Schermerhorn and Third Street, Brooklyn, is dedicated.

The first local outdoor official A.A.U. swimming meet of the season, held yesterday at the Manhattan Beach pool, was featured by the triumph of Miss Erna Kompa, Women's Swimming Association star and metropolitan back-stroke champion, over Miss Dorothy Forbes of the Camden Y.W.C.A. in the 220-yard back-stroke handicap.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated the Braves in both ends of a double-header today before 18,000 fans, winning the first game, 11 to 6, and the second, 9 to 3.

Degrees will be conferred upon seven candidates, and thirty undergraduates and twelve post-graduate students will receive diplomas at the commencement exercises of the Institute of Musical Art, which will be held at 8:30 P.M. today in the institute's concert hall, 130 Claremont Avenue.

THIS column feels like offering itself to the alienists. It is almost ready to agree with the Rev. Wilbur Glenn Voliva that the earth is flat. It is practically willing to admit that Mr. "Cash-and-Carry" Crandall, ex-promoter of dance marathons, had a racket that was a perfect expression of the fundamental sanity and health of America.

U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, May 30. -- The destroyers of the United States Fleet, the "tin cans" of the navy, got under way and stood to sea all day today as the fleet continued its sortie from Pearl Harbor.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP). -- Evergold, star racer from the Nash Brothers' Shandon Farm, did most of his running in the stretch today to score an easy triumph in the $5,000 added Blue and the Gray Memorial Handicap before a holiday crowd of 30,000 at Washington Park.

With Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, taking a keen interest in the play, the testimonial match for the benefit of the veteran, F. Fitzmaurice Kelly, whose jubilee was celebrated, was contested on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston yesterday.

LONDON, May 30. -- The British Government has received from Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, the German Ambassador, the draft scheme of a Western European air pact that Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler would approve as a supplement to the Locarno treaty.

VATICAN CITY, May 30. -- Pope Pius XI will celebrate tomorrow his seventy-eighth birthday. Despite stories circulated from time to time that he is suffering from some serious ailment he is still in excellent and vigorous health and can complain only of the minor maladies of age.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- William Bagley, 25, of 829 Park Avenue, New York, and Miss Gertrude Spring of Bristol, Pa., were killed at 3 o'clock this morning when an automobile ran off a sharp curve on the Bristol Pike a mile south of Morrisville, and struck a tree.

The advantages of a democratic, Fascist, socialistic or communistic government for the country in the future were expounded last evening by four speakers in a symposium at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

MADISON, N.J., May 30. -- The Hartley Dodge Memorial Municipal Building, presented to the borough by Mrs. Marcellus Hartley Dodge, wife of the munitions manufacturer, in memory of her son, M. Hartley Dodge Jr., who was killed in France in an automobile accident in 1930, was dedicated here this morning before a crowd of 5,000.

Alfonso de Bourbon, eldest son of the former King of Spain, arrived here yesterday morning on the liner Washington for his first visit to the United States. He was met at the pier by his wife, the former Edelmira Sampedro of Cuba.
The curiosity of two radio car patrolmen resulted yesterday in the arrest of two men suspected of having robbed the pawnshop of Goodman Edelstein of 2,629 Third Avenue, the Bronx.

An appropriation for air-cooling and improving the ventilation of the Metropolitan Opera House has been made by the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, it was announced yesterday. The sum was said to be about $100,000, bringing the total spent on modernizing the theatre to $500,000.

SHANGHAI, Friday, May 31. -- The Japanese Army's formal representations concerning the North China situation coincided yesterday with a secret military conference in Shanghai, whither Lieut. Col. Sen Amemiya, attache in Nanking, hurried.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 30. -- An attempt by Captain Charles Sims of the ferry Paunpeck to stop the dangerous sport of canoeists riding across the Hudson in the suction behind the Yonkers-Alpine ferryboats failed today to the captain's embarrassment and the ducking of a deckhand.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 30. -- Bagatelle, Alvin Untermyer's second winner of the day, captured the two-and-a-half-mile Fairfield Plate Steeplechase, which featured the inaugural hunts meet of the Fairfield and Westchester hounds, held today at the old Bowman Park, which is now the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

DEVON, Pa., May 30. -- The Devon Horse Show came to a successful close today, with King Vulture, chestnut gelding from the Dilwyne Farm, owned by R.R.M. Carpenter of Montchanini, Del., being judged champion hunter of the exhibition.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP). -- Jane Addams's labor of love is to be carried on. Officers and trustees announced a decision today to establish a "Jane Addams Memorial Fund" to continue her work at Hull House, the social centre among the West Side tenements where the humanitarian toiled for nearly a half century.

In today's Collier's Weekly Mr. H.G. WELLS completes his observations on the New Deal. To such a veteran demiurge the policies framed at Washington are but "the sketchiest and most in "complete anticipations of the real "planning that is demanded." They are the schemes of individuals or little groups and "have none of the breadth "of a science to which millions of "minds have contributed."

For some time there has been talk in Germany of a European agreement respecting armaments in the air. Broad hints of such a scheme were contained in HITLER'S recent speech. Now it is stated that a draft plan for it has been sent from Berlin to London, and at the same time submitted to the Governments of France, Italy and Belgium.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- An assertion that government legal experts, including some in the Department of Justice, believed unanimously that the Supreme Court's decisions voiding NRA codes and the Railroad Pension Act did not affect President Roosevelt's social security program was voiced in a radio address tonight by Senator Harrison, one of the Democratic leaders in the Senate.

Fox Film Corporation will release fifty-four feature pictures and 110 short during the 1935-36 season, according to an announcement yesterday coincidental with the opening of the company's sales convention in Chicago. This list is exclusive of the twelve pictures scheduled for production this season by Twentieth Century Pictures, recently merged with Fox.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30. -- Next Monday has been set for the second pioneer flight of the Pan American clipper ship over the Pacific, according to information here, but no announcement of the flight has yet been made by Pan American Airways.

Hundreds of persons, including a large group of children, on the dock at the foot of East Twenty-first Street at noon yesterday saw the rescue of a 10-year-old girl by a man who also was credited by the police with saving another man who had gone to the girl's aid.

PARIS, Friday, May 31. -- At the end of one of the most dramatic sessions ever held, the Chamber of Deputies early this morning refused Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin's request for full powers to defend the national money, restore the financial situation and set the economic machinery of the country to work.

Fox Film Corporation will release fifty-four feature pictures and 110 short during the 1935-36 season, according to an announcement yesterday coincidental with the opening of the company's sales convention in Chicago. This list is exclusive of the twelve pictures scheduled for production this season by Twentieth Century Pictures, recently merged with Fox.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30. -- Next Monday has been set for the second pioneer flight of the Pan American clipper ship over the Pacific, according to information here, but no announcement of the flight has yet been made by Pan American Airways.

Hundreds of persons, including a large group of children, on the dock at the foot of East Twenty-first Street at noon yesterday saw the rescue of a 10-year-old girl by a man who also was credited by the police with saving another man who had gone to the girl's aid.

PARIS, Friday, May 31. -- At the end of one of the most dramatic sessions ever held, the Chamber of Deputies early this morning refused Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin's request for full powers to defend the national money, restore the financial situation and set the economic machinery of the country to work.

BERLIN, May 30. -- Amid a world disturbed by war alarms and upset by planned economies and gold worries, Germany, as seen from the inside, is apt to appear to the casual visitor like a blessed isle of peace and plenty.

RYE, N.Y., May 30. -- Persons of social prominence from Westchester, Connecticut, New York and Long Island attended the race meeting this afternoon on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds.
A good deal of legislation affecting the anglers and hunters of New York was enacted at Albany during the recent session, but the bill which many sportsmen deemed the most important was sidetracked.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The old hostility between General Hugh S. Johnson, first NRA Administrator, and Donald R. Richberg, later Blue Eagle chief, was reported today to have revived, with Mr. Richberg resenting General Johnson's reappearance in Presidential NRA counsels.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 1. -- The alarms created by the Japanese Army's demarche in North China are subsiding rapidly. Ambassador Chang Tso-pin of China saw Foreign Minister Koki Hirota yesterday and stated that Nanking accepted two of the army's demands, namely removal of Governor Yu Hsueh-chung of Hopei and his troops from Tientsin and disbandment of anti-Japanese organizations.

Earthquakes have taken heavy toll of human life and caused enormous property damage during recorded history. One compilation of records in the Christian era makes them responsible for the destruction of 800 cities and the loss of 1,300,000 lives.
Several flats and business buildings were included -in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

This, officially, is the last day of the 1934-35 theatrical season. And, as if to salute the beginning of the not so good old summertime, at least three regular attractions will say good-bye to it all this evening. (A fourth departure, "Seven Keys to Baldpate," was of course limited to the Players' traditional one wegk of revival.)

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 31 (AP). -- With Ohio State University students in the front ranks, Columbus Packing Company strikers and their sympathizers clashed in a thirty-minute pitched battle with 200 policemen and detectives today.

Legal action against Columbia University was threatened in behalf of six students of the College of Physicians and Surgeons who received notification yesterday that they would be refused admittance next year.

The body of Anne Quinlan, 23 years old, a maid employed in the home of Dr. Samuel Atkin at 125 Riverside Drive, between Eighty-fourth and Eighty-fifth Streets, was taken from the Hudson River off Duffy's Yacht Landing, a jetty at the foot of Eightieth Street, at 1:20 P.M. yesterday, by a police launch. A boatman had seen it in the water.
The fourth annual meeting of the 122d Cavalry Racing Association will be staged today on the estate of Major Phelps Montgomery at Mount Carmel, Conn.

Senator WAGNER insists that his much-disputed Labor Relations Bill is constitutional despite the Supreme Court's decision regarding NRA. In the Schechter case the court held, first, that Congress had illegally delegated legislative power to the President; and, second, that the famous Poultry Code was void because it attempted to regulate activities which affected interstate commerce only indirectly.

MADRID, May 31. -- The trial of Louis Companys, former President of the Generalidad of Catalonia, and of six former members of the autonomous region's Executive Council was concluded today before the Tribunal of Constitutional Guarantees, the highest court in the land.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,475,000,000, a decrease of $1,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in May was the heaviest since February, 1934. The most active day was May 16, when sales amounted to 2,341,740 shares. Sales for the month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were 30,438,423 shares, compared with 22,408,195 in April, and 25,343,000 in the same month a year ago.

Penitentiary terms not to exceed three years each were imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Benjamin Silverman, 41 years old, of 1,162 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, and Edward Wheatle, 36, a Negro, of 234 West 142d Street, described as "bankers" in one of Harlem's policy rackets.

Nelson B Clark, 62 years old, defeated Progressive party candidate for Governor of Massachusetts in 1916, was sentenced in Special Sessions yesterday to an indeterminate penitentiary term of not more than three years on a charge of possessing a pistol.

With the three-ply E.R. Bradley entry of Black Helen, Bloodroot and Bird Flower certain to be a confirmed favorite, the Coaching Club American Oaks, longest test in this country for fillies, will be run this afternoon at Belmont Park.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The New York Stock Exchange is considering the feasibility of permitting non-member bond dealers and brokers to share in the Exchange's commissions on business they originate for execution on the floor of the Exchange, it was announced yesterday by the special committee on bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- Obviously concerned over the future of the AAA, Secretary Wallace today announced after a conference with President Roosevelt that a search would be made for amendments to the farm adjustment act to carry on the program.

Widespread wage cuts and increases in working hours as a result of the invalidation of the NRA were predicted by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, State NRA Compliance Director, yesterday. At the same time the International Ladies Garment Workers Union launched a movement to resist such a trend by legislation and otherwise.

LONDON, Saturday, June 1. -- W.A. Myatt, in a dispatch to The Daily Mail from Quetta, capital of Baluchistan, says the most fearful toll in the earthquake there yesterday was taken in the native quarter and the bazaars, where people lived huddled together in almost suffocating congestion.

KARACHI, India, Saturday, June 1. -- An extensive area along the valley of Baluchistan, in which the town of Quetta, the capital of Baluchistan and an important military and railway centre with 60,000 inhabitants, is located, was devastated early yesterday morning by one of the worst earthquakes in Indian history.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Liquidation and lower prices dominated the grain markets today on the Board of Trade. Crop reports were more favorable except that Illinois corn lands are too wet to permit planting. Northwestern crop conditions are the most favorable so far this season.

BERLIN, May 31. -- The Official Gazette announced today the confiscation of 41,004 marks belonging to Professor Friedrich Dessauer, noted X-ray specialist and former Reichstag member for the defunct Catholic Centre party. He is now living in Turkey.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell arrived here from Winnipeg, Canada, yesterday morning to take up the pastorate tomorrow of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. He will preach at the 11 A.M. and the 4:30 P.M. services and he will address the Young People's Society at 5:45 P.M. at their weekly meeting.

ALBANY, May 31. -- Acting Governor Bray today commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence imposed upon Frank Kiekart, the last one of the gang of seven men who participated in the hold-up of the First National Bank of Bellmore, L.I., which resulted in the deaths of Ernest L. Whitman, a bond salesman, in April, 1924, and an innocent by-stander.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that a Summer vacation for him was out of the question this year because of the difficulties involved in running the city government. He was asked about his plans for the Summer.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 31. -- Alex Gerard of Peddie today won the private secondary schools' golf championship of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association, scoring 74, 73 -- 147 at the Locust Grove Golf Club course. It was the second consecutive victory in the event for the Long Island lad, whose father is professional at the National Links, Southampton.

As a result of the currency crisis in France, the largest Shipments of gold on record from that country for a month arrived here in May. Effort to bolster the franc and end the drain on the country's gold stocks through three successive increases in the rediscount rate failed to halt the withdrawals.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 31 (AP). -- A plot to blow up vital parts of the Colt's Patent Firearms Manufacturing Company's plant here was disclosed by authorities today as they made ready to ask the Superior Court for bench warrants for the arrest of the gang alleged to be involved.

TACOMA, Wash., May 31 (AP). -- The needle of suspicion in the $200,000 George Weyerhaeuser abduction swung tonight over an array of shady specialists in murder, kidnapping and robbery, but again pointed most frequently to remnants of the Karpis gang.

Judge Paul Myron Lineberger, counsel to the Chinese Government; Courtenay Crocker, Antonio S. Moreira, Frederic Peralta, E.T. de Monte, Franz Staub, Arthur J. Morriss, Marchesa Vahdah de Bonis and Miss Marion Valle are among the passengers sailing today for Havre via Plymouth on the French liner Lafayette.

The present conflict between the government and the church in Mexico was discussed yesterday afternoon in an interview by Charles S. Macfarland, whose new book, "Chaos in Mexico," will be published today by Harpers.

KARACHI, India, May 31. -- Three tremendous rumbling earth shocks shattered the northwest frontier city of Quetta early today, killing an estimated 20,000 Europeans and natives. It was feared the death toll would go much higher with receipt of reports from outlying districts, especially that between Quetta and Kalat.

LONDON, May 31 (AP). -- George Stoner, 18-year-old chauffeur, was sentenced today to die for the murder of Francis Rattenbury, his elderly employer, but the jury in Old Bailey freed Mrs. Alma Rattenbury, the victim's widow and mistress of the condemned youth.

BERLIN, May 31. -- The political and currency crisis in France failed today to influence the Boerse and the tendency continued firm throughout the session. The further development in the industrial situation was viewed in Boerse circles with a show of optimism and this feeling gave the market for mining and steel shares a pronounced element of strength, with Hoesch, Kloeckner, Vereingtesthal, Mannesmann and Harpener showing gains ranging from 1 1/8 to 3 points.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 31. -- A superlative team from the land of superlatives, the University of Southern California, made good the boast that it was the strongest combination ever sent East from the Coast by virtually clinching the fifty-ninth annual championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. today.

LONDON, May 31 (Canadian Press). -- The return to form of Harold Larwood, famous English bowler, was in a large measure responsible for Nottinghamshire's victory over Hampshire at Nottingham today in a county cricket championship match by an innings and 241 runs.

Night operating facilities at the Harlem Hospital, a city institution, were characterized as "inefficient and inadequate" by Dr. Ralph H. Young, a Negro associate surgeon at the hospital, at a hearing of the subcommittee on health and sanitation of the Mayor's Commission on Conditions in Harlem, held yesterday afternoon in the Seventh District Municipal Court, 447 West 151st Street.
Francis Hackett, whose biography, "Francis the First," is a best seller, has sent to Doubleday, Doran the manuscript of a novel, "The Green Lion."
Fifty years with the one employer brought a medal last week to two city librarians. Others received medallic recognition for ten and twenty-five years' service.

A group of 109 brewers from all parts of Germany arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland to make an extensive tour of the large breweries in this country. Their itinerary includes Milwaukee, St. Louis, Chicago, Detroit, Washington and Philadelphia.
PARIS, May 31. -- The Bourse confounded all prophets by not only opening today and carrying on business as usual but showing distinct evidence of calmness, sang-froid and even strength.

Offerings of new bond issues this week reached a total of $73,509,500, the largest for any one week since that ended on April 26 last, when the total was $112,310,000. This week's total compared with $42,757,000 last week and $10,139,000 the previous week.

The Bowmark Realty Corporation, David Rose, president, has completed assemblage of its site at the northwest corner of Second Avenue and East Eleventh Street by purchasing the old Stuyvesant mansion, it became known yesterday.

THE prophets and professors go delving into deep places and come up with large charts and cute little index figures to show whither we are drifting in an economic way. There's the international gold flow index, the blast furnace index, the scrap metal index, the wheat crop index, the auto, raw wool, roller skate, doughnut and pogo stick indexes, all with charts to match.

DENVER, May 31. -- Boiling waters of a tri-State flood, born of Spring rains on the eastern slope of the Rockies, raged eastward toward the already rising Missouri tonight, leaving twenty-two dead, more than a score missing, reports of other deaths and property damage in the millions.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- A report that no Americans were believed to be in the Quetta earthquake zone was received by the State Department today from Joseph G. Groeninger, United States Consul at Karachi, India.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- An assertion that the Schechter decision put no legal obstacles in the way of enactment of the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill was made today in a legal opinion presented to the legislative committee of the National Conference of Bituminous Coal Producers by a special drafting committee headed by Thurlow G. Essington of Chicago, former State Senator.

Stocks and commodities declined sharply yesterday following the publication by news tickers of President Roosevelt's reaction to the Supreme Court's NRA decision. It was the third consecutive downward movement in the financial markets since the court ruled NRA unconstitutional last Monday.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Using his press conference as a medium, President Roosevelt told the country in connection with the NRA situation that it must make a decision between vesting nationwide control over social and economic conditions in the government, or returning to the haphazard control of the States.

Four more men were in government custody yesterday and held in bail in the investigation growing out of the hold-up at a Coral Gables hotel, Jan. 26 last, in which jewelry valued at $185,000 was taken from Mrs. Margaret Hawkesworth Bell of this city.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 31 (AP). -- Judge Charles I. Dawson, whose recent adverse decisions on important New Deal legislation attracted national attention, late today announced his resignation from the United States Court, Western District of Kentucky. He stated he would return to private practice in order to make provision for the future of his family.

The price war in books and cigarettes following the lifting of NRA code restrictions continued unabated yesterday, with certain department stores showing determination to slash prices to extremes to outdo competitors.

William Travers Jerome, former District Attorney and foe of Tammany, left a net estate of $144,356 when he died on Feb. 13, 1934, the transfer tax appraisal revealed yesterday. The gross estate, before deduction of debts and expenses, was $155,812.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Practically complete returns from the May 25 wheat referendum showed today that 86.6 per cent of all farmers voting in the wheat-producing sections favored continuance after this crop year of the AAA adjustment program for the commodity.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Polo swings into the full stride of its new season this week-end with several attractive matches scheduled. Thomas Hitchcock Jr., the famous internationalist, announced at a luncheon of the Sands Point Club held at the Hotel Commodore yesterday that the Port Washington club, where high-goal games have been a weekly fixture for years, would start its new season tomorrow.

Although a number of developments this week left some confusion in their wake, there were more than sporadic indications of renewed life in trade currents which were hastened by bolstered activity in both productive and distributive branches, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

Seton Porter, president and a director of the National Distillers Products Corporation, received a salary of $75,400 in 1934, according to the company's application for permanent registration released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 31. -- Henry Hazlitt, member of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial staff, was the principal speaker here today at the ceremonies which accompanied the announcement of winners in the fifth annual Hopwood contest at the University of Michigan.

OTTAWA, May 31 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's automobile industry is becoming too expensive for the country to maintain, George Coote of Alberta declared today in the House of Commons. Apparently it could be kept alive only by exceedingly high tariffs.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- The cloud of doubtful constitutionality cast by the Supreme Court's NRA decision over other New Deal operations spread today to the Securities Exchange Commission, but officials of that agency intimated they were determined to go ahead until formally restrained.

MOSCOW, May 31. -- The problem of the homeless waifs, orphans of the civil war and of the economic disturbances since the early days of the Soviet regime, was finally "liquidated" today by a decree of the Council of People's Commissars.
Voluntary adherence to the NRA principles developed yesterday as a number of industries speeded the work of formulating programs similar to those over which the Blue Eagle ruled.

CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., May 31 (AP). -- The fund being raised by a weekly newspaper here to reimburse Joseph Schechter of Brooklyn for the cost of his legal battle against the NRA amounted to about $30 tonight.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 31. -- Declaring that the proposed child labor amendment would centralize too much power in Washington, Michael F. Walsh of Brooklyn, State deputy, told delegates to the convention of the State Council of Knights of Columbus here today that he was emphatically against such a step.

Pioneer Pictures will make two films in Technicolor for release through RKO Radio this season in addition to "Becky Sharp," which has been completed and will be shown for the first time on Thursday, June 13, at the Radio City Music Hall.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were much larger than a year ago, the business week then containing only five days because of Memorial Day. The total for the twenty-two leading cities in the last week as reported by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $4,689,790,000, against $3,486,856,000 a year ago.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

With price cuts and weather proving stimulating factors, retail trade continued to reveal improvement as the week approached its close. The betterment was fairly marked in comparison with the results of the previous week. Department stores in the metropolitan area were credited with slight increases over the same period a year ago, as against sales declines for most of the month just closed.

Interest rates for call loans on both Exchanges here in May remained steady at the record low levels established in mid-April, despite an increase in stock market trading. Demand for new accommodations was light, activity in placing loans being centred on renewals of expiring obligations. Funds, already well above requirements, increased because of the shrinkage in borrowings.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 31. -- George Voigt and Mrs. Leo G. Federman, winners of the New York State mixed foursomes championship last year, made an auspicious start toward the defense of their laurels at the Seawane Club today.

BERLIN, May 31. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, head of the delegation now in London to discuss Germany's naval rearmament and presumably also to exchange views on the projected "air Locarno," was appointed by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler today an Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary in a special mission.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke yesterday more than 3/4 cent, or about $4 a bale, following the White House statement intimating that the United States Supreme Court decision, if followed in all its implications, would seem to indicate that the Federal Government had no control over any national economic problem inclusive of agriculture.

Definite evidence of twenty-four instances of payments of sums of money to "fixers" by aspirants for city jobs has been brought to light so far by his investigation, Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard revealed yesterday. He said that as each case was completed the evidence was being turned over to District Attorney Dodge.

Dividends declared in May made the largest total for a month since last November and increased sharply over a year ago. By comparison with payments ordered in May, 1934, twelve of the fifteen classifications under which the declarations are tabulated showed gains this year.

The contribution of the youth of Asia to a movement for a universal religion among members of various races and creeds was discussed yesterday under the auspices of the New History Society at headquarters of the organization, 132 East Sixty-fifth Street.
Although the current run of weakfish in Peconic Bay has not produced many big fish, catches on Decoration Day indicated that the larger tiderunners were appearing in increasing numbers.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- A bill to liquidate all existing farm mortgages, as well as all mortgages foreclosed since 1920, to guarantee the farms, debt-free, to "deserving farm families," and to prevent any future mortgaging was introduced today by Representative Peterson of Georgia.

The objections of Secretary Hull to the proposals of the Eastman and Copeland Bland Merchant Marine Bills vesting regulatory power in a Federal body over freight rates on foreign ship lines serving American ports were supported yesterday by James W. Ryan, counsel for Isbrandtsen-Moller Co.

There have been many earthquakes, resulting in the loss of more than 250,000 lives, since the beginning of this century. The principal earthquake disasters in the period (figures up to 1934 compiled by The Associated Press) were:

ROME, May 31. -- The development of events in France is being watched in Italy with the closest attention, not unmixed with a certain apprehension, as it is felt that if France abandoned or were forced off the gold standard there might be far-reaching repercussions in Italy, especially as regards Premier Mussolini's struggle to maintain the lira's gold parity.

The twelve-story office building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street is to be altered at a cost of $300,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Shreve, Lamb Harmon, architects.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- Party leaders in general were unresponsive today to the proposal of William R. Pattangall, Chief Justice of Maine, for a union of conservative Republicans and Democrats to replace the New Deal with a "constitutional government."

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Further evidence that the Federal Reserve Board was itself divided over the administration's banking bill designed in part to strengthen the powers of the board was given today when George R. James, a member, testified in opposition to Title II before a Senate banking subcommittee.

PARIS, May 31, -- For the ninth time since the present Chamber of Deputies was elected just three years ago a new government has been formed tonight. It is much the same kind of government as most of its predecessors, but has a new titular head in Fernand Bouisson, who for years past has been elected and re-elected President of the Chamber of Deputies.
Mayor La Guardia came into City Hall early yesterday morning with two business-like nightsticks under his arm, causing the impression that he had stripped them from policemen on his way downtown.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union made plans yesterday for a strike of 40,000 workers in 1,350 coat and suit shops in New York City in the event that negotiations for the renewal of the agreement, expiring today, failed to bring about a peaceful settlement.
LONDON, May 31. -- Great Britain will insist upon parity in any air agreement with Germany, Anthony Eden, Lord Privy Seal, told the House of Commons today.

ON BOARD THE LINER NORMANDIE, May 31. -- The world's greatest liner broke the speed record for commercial ships in its run from noon yesterday until noon today, despite a twenty-five-mile head wind and adverse currents.

Commodore Bobby Sanford, a showman by profession and a commodore by circumstance, stood amidships on the Buccaneer in Tappan Zee last night and declared the showboat season open on the Hudson River. He has done this before.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Reviewing events leading up to the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company receivership on Nov. 1, 1932, Robert T. Swaine, general counsel for the railroad until October, 1934, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that every effort was made to avert the receivership by the voluntarily application of a reorganization plan.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP). -- Goose Goslin came back from the Tigers' bench, to which he was exiled for weak hitting, to lead his team to a 6-5 triumph today over the Browns. The victory gave Detroit an edge in the three-game series after they had divided the double-game holiday bill.

SALEM, N.H., May 31. -- Spixi, J.U. Gratton's consistent a-year-old chestnut gelding, won the Salem Centre Claiming Handicap today, beating Happy Knot and Carisbrooke in a driving finish to annex the feature at Rockingham Park.
PARIS, May 31 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Completing the greatest rush of work it has ever handled, the stock list department of the Stock Exchange forwarded yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission the last batch of applications for permanent registration filed before the deadline, which was today.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 31. -- Henry V. Hogan, '36, of West Orange, N.J., has been elected captain of the Princeton track team for 1936, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. Hogan, who runs the middle distances, is also captain of next Fall's cross-country team.

The retirement of Herbert L. Pratt as chairman of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the company. It was stated that Mr. Pratt, who was forty years in the service of Socony-Vacuum and its predecessor companies, was taking advantage of his privilege to make use of the company's retirement plan.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP). -- Crackle, Mrs. A.M. Creech's 5-year-old chestnut horse, broke in front and remained there all the way to capture the six-furlong Lafayette Handicap at the Detroit Fair Grounds today. Crackle paid $7.60 on a $2 ticket and covered the distance in 1:14.
Kandahar, which has suffered a severe earthquake, is the capital of a province of the same name in Southeastern Afghanistan. It has about 60,000 inhabitants.

On June 10 the Grass Roots convention of selected Republicans from nine Midwestern States will be open for business in Mr. LINCOLN'S Springfield. The high-minded and unselfish politicians who called the convention specifically excluded candidates and talk of candidates. They were trying to find out the principles of the new Republican party which is to be born.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31. -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, will confer baccalaureate degrees on 179 seniors at the New Jersey College for Women tomorrow morning at the fourteenth annual commencement exercises.

NEWARK, N.J., May 31. -- The festival concert, feature of the twenty-ninth annual song festival of the Northeastern Saengerbund now in progress here, was given in the 113th Infantry armory tonight by a chorus of 4,000 men and 800 women, assisted by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, before an audience of more than 20,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- President Roosevelt by inference left it to Congress today to decide what if any Federal control over the liquor industry should supplant the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, which, he said, was killed by the Supreme Court's NRA decision.

Two large apartment houses on the upper West Side, the nine-story Press Club Building in William Street and several tenement houses were bought in at foreclosure sales held yesterday. Auctioneers offered eight Manhattan properties, all of which were bought in by the plaintiffs.

The newly amended public enemy law which, if upheld by the courts, would enable the police to "harass" criminals and racketeers with short jail sentences, received its first test yesterday before Magistrate David Hirshfield in Pennsylvania Avenue Court in Brooklyn.

State and municipal financing next week is expected to be smaller in volume than it was this week, when securities sold to banks and underwriting groups reached $30,614,557. The calendar for next week list loans totaling $13,960,811 for which bids have been asked.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Fortified by a veritable avalanche of telegrams and letters from all parts of the country begging him to "do something," President Roosevelt decided today to send Congress in a few days a bill designed to stem the tide of deflation that has been rising with increasing momentum in the nation's industrial centres since last Monday when the Supreme Court "threw out the baby with the bath" in the Schechter case decision.

GENEVA, May 31. -- Former Governor John G. Winant of New Hampshire arrived here this evening to begin his duties as assistant director of the International Labor Office. He and Charles E. Wyzanski Jr., Solicitor of the Department of Labor, came to represent the United States on the governing body of the ILO at the meeting that began today.

The first adult giant armadillo ever to curl his armored body on United States soil was swung out of the hold of the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland shortly after the vessel docked late yesterday afternoon.
BOSTON, May 31. -- The Giants today trampled the Braves under two defeats to stretch their winning streak to seven straight and lengthen their National League lead to five and one-half games.
The kosher butcher shops that have been closed this week in various sections of the city because of the consumers' boycott against high meat prices will reopen on Tuesday. Some will be open tonight.

It is a little hard to understand the jubilation of conservatives at the Supreme Court's decision. True, the NRA is done for; but it was at least as unsatisfactory to radicals as it was to conservatives. The need for an organization of business which the NRA was designed to meet has not been removed; and it takes an optimist of the first degree to think that much can be done by voluntary cooperation.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- On the Basis of President Roosevelt's discussion of the situation now confronting the nation as a result of the Supreme Court's definition of interstate commerce, opponents of the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utility Holding Company Bill argued in the Senate today that the measure invaded State jurisdiction.
The Curtiss Manufacturing Company declared a common dividend of 25 cents, the first payment of the kind since April 1, 1932.

IT would be quite a trick to write a full biography of Catherine of Russia. Her years were so rich with accident and luck, so filled with common sins and bizarre contrasts, that even the least inspired biographer may appear a Strachey merely by noting down the facts. At the beginning there is a Cinderella story. Catherine was the unwanted daughter of a stuffy princeling, disliked by her mother and of no apparent promise.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- Leading a general assault on par that saw the course record shattered three times, Clarence Ehresman, Eagles Mere, Pa., pro, posted a brilliant 67 today to go out in front in the Philadelphia P.G.A. invitation golf tourney.

Sugar futures declined the limit of 25 points yesterday and other staples except coffee and some of the metals were easier. President Roosevelt's views on the questionable constitutionality of the AAA and the Securities Act was responsible for the heavy selling in sugar.

CINCINNATI, May 31 (AP). -- Shaky fielding and the unsteadiness of Al Hollingsworth, rookie pitcher, were the principal factors tonight in enabling the Pittsburgh Pirates to win, 4 to 1, from the Cincinnati Reds in the second night game in major league history.

Practice makes perfect. If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. You can't teach an old dog new tricks. We have been taught these mottoes since our earliest days, and most of us believe in them implicitly. Along comes JAMES L. MURSELL, a Professor of Education, in The Atlantic Monthly, and challenges them all.
VATICAN CITY, May 31 (AP). -- Pope Pius celebrated his seventy-eighth birthday today by observing his most rigid schedule of work in years.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has rejected a plan which would give the Bronx an amusement centre similar to that operated by the Westchester County Park Commission at Playland, in Rye, Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons revealed yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP). -- The combined pitching efforts of Clint Brown and Mel Harder and a lot of loose play on their own part combined to shove the White Sox deeper into second place in the American League today as the Indians won the series final, 6 to 2.

LONDON, May 31. -- Following the fall of the French Cabinet, the British authorities came in today with powerful support for the franc in the foreign exchange market here. Buying all francs on offer, they held the spot exchange at around 75 1/4 francs to the pound, but extraordinary rates were paid for limited forward business, with dealings recorded at 82 francs to the pound for delivery three months hence.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 31. -- At the end of a protracted session of competition marred by rain and suspension of play, William Tilden, George Lott and Robert Ramillon of France were holding brackets tonight in the semi-final round of the American professional championship of the International players Association at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

TORONTO, May 31. -- Equipped with the world's second largest telescope, a reflector seventy-four inches in aperture, the David Dunlap Observatory of the University of Toronto was opened at Richmond Hill near here this afternoon.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 31. -- In an abbreviated seven-inning game the Tufts College baseball team, taking advantage of two Harvard errors and the wildness of Tittman, the Cambridge hurler, defeated the Crimson nine, 6 -- 1, today. The game was called with one out in the last half of the seventh because of rain.

McCOOK, Neb., May 31. -- Unconfirmed reports that two Southwestern Nebraska villages were washed from the map, and that an undetermined number of persons drowned reached here today as floods swept Southwestern Nebraska, washing out highways, railroads, communication lines and homes.

The award or three silver medals, each accompanied by a cash payment of $250 by the National Committee of Award of Theodore N. Vail Medals to employes of telephone companies, was announced yesterday. The committee considered thirty-three bronze medal awards made by the Bell System companies for acts of "noteworthy public service" in 1934 before making its decision.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The right of the government to regulate nation-wide economic and social conditions in the United States was made the paramount political issue by President Roosevelt today.

I am fearful that this tempest in a teapot over the decision in the NRA case, which is in my judgment readily capable of sane solution in a modified and less all-embracing form that will still preserve its leading manifest advantages, will divert the attention of the country that should now be concentrated upon the equally important pending Banking Bill.

PARIS, May 31. -- Miss Helen Jacobs drew a step closer to the French hard-court tennis championship, a major title she never has won, as play moved quietly today into the semi-final round in men's and women's singles.

KANSAS CITY, May 31 (AP). -- A smashing clean-up of "all the major bank robberies in the Middle West" was claimed tonight by Federal authorities with the arrest of six men, headed by Walter Holland, alias "Irish" O'Malley, accused ring-leader in the kidnapping of August Luer of Alton, Ill.

Mayor La Guardia was served yesterday afternoon with papers in a suit seeking his removal from office on the ground that he is holding two official posts in direct violation of Section 1549 of the Greater City Charter. The other post cited in the action is membership on the PWA Advisory Committee on Allotments to which the Mayor was appointed by president Roosevelt early in May.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- When the legal time for filing expired this evening, applications for permanent registration had been filed by 1,646 companies whose securities are listed on national Exchanges, leaving about 600 yet to come.

Friends of President ROOSEVELT will be the first to regret the address which he made to the newspaper correspondents yesterday, and of which he authorized publication. One of the things most admired in Mr. ROOSEVELT, all through his term, has been his calmness and poise of spirit. Modest in victory, he has been cheerful in defeat.

With meat prices rising almost to pre-depression levels, angry housewives picketing storage plants and retail stores, and with thousands of butcher shops closed, New York City is beginning to feel at first hand the effects of the great drought of 1934.
The cities of Chicago, Detroit and Rochester, N.Y., announced yesterday plans for redemption of bonds or other indebtedness.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 31. -- The State House of Representatives approved a bill today providing for the immediate construction of the Merritt Parkway through a $15,000,000 Fairfield County bond issue, after it had been told that the Federal Government was ready to contribute $6,750,000 toward the project.

A refunding loan of $950,000 for Arizona, proceeds from which will be used in part to extinguish five bond issues floated from six to nine years before the State had been admitted to Statehood in 1912, brought premium bids yesterday at Phoenix from five banking groups.

Crowds thronged the local headquarters of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles at 155 Worth Street all day yesterday to renew their driving licenses, which expired at midnight last night. About 60,000 persons during the day obtained new permits at that office of the bureau alone and 150,000 in all boroughs of the city, it was estimated by I. James Brody, in charge of the bureau.

RICHMOND, Va., May 31 (AP). -- J. Murray Hooker, Democratic State chairman, said today that he knew nothing about plans for a meeting, probably in Richmond, to discuss a coalition of right wing Democrats and Republicans.

BALTIMORE, May 31. -- Dr. Chester C. Groff, formerly a physician in Ozone Park and Richmond Hill, Queens, was found dead today in a hotel room with a note beside him addressed to the Coroner. It explained that he had taken poison because he was suffering from an incurable disease, and said no autopsy would be necessary.

Following a hectic afternoon of mass picketing by several hundred sympathizers in front of the Emergency Relief Bureau at 902 Broadway, seven paralytics on "hunger strike" in the bureau offices began to break ranks last night, when four of their number went home.
