PARIS, May 31. -- The financial situation improved somewhat today as the Bank of France calmly met all demands for gold and the Bourse, contrary to last night's reports and all prophecies, not only opened but showed greater strength in every department.

Fernand Emile Honore Bouisson, the new French Premier, was born at Constantine, France, on June 16, 1874, and became a Deputy for Marseilles before he was 35 years old. Almost from the beginning of his career he has been associated with the Socialist party.
]usiness iv The credit market was small, resulting in a steady array of quotations which howed no variation from preceding levels.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today tossed the big family quarrel between Manager Walter Johnson and Third Baseman Willie Kamm right back into the hands of Alva Bradley, owner of the Cleveland Indians.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, May 31. -- One hundred and thirty ships of the United States Fleet were homeward-bound tonight after five weeks of manoeuvres extending from the arctic to the tropics.

The first patient under the new three-cents-a-day plan for hospital care was admitted yesterday to Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, for an emergency operation, after an enrolment for one week and the payment of a quarterly instalment of $2.60, it was announced yesterday by Associated Hospital Service of New York of 370 Lexington Avenue, the organization in charge of the plan under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund.
SYRACUSE, May 31 (AP). -- The Chiefs made it four victories in as many games when they beat Newark tonight before 5,000 fans. Syracuse scored four unearned runs to beat the Bears, 4 to 3.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today tossed the big family quarrel between Manager Walter Johnson and Third Baseman Willie Kamm right back into the hands of Alva Bradley, owner of the Cleveland Indians.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, May 31. -- One hundred and thirty ships of the United States Fleet were homeward-bound tonight after five weeks of manoeuvres extending from the arctic to the tropics.

The first patient under the new three-cents-a-day plan for hospital care was admitted yesterday to Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, for an emergency operation, after an enrolment for one week and the payment of a quarterly instalment of $2.60, it was announced yesterday by Associated Hospital Service of New York of 370 Lexington Avenue, the organization in charge of the plan under the auspices of the United Hospital Fund.
SYRACUSE, May 31 (AP). -- The Chiefs made it four victories in as many games when they beat Newark tonight before 5,000 fans. Syracuse scored four unearned runs to beat the Bears, 4 to 3.

The money supply in the form of individual deposits subject to check in member banks of the Federal Reserve System has risen to a point where it approaches the pre-depression level, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review, published yesterday.

William R. Hayward, suspended principal of Theodore Roosevelt High School, the Bronx, took the stand in his own defense yesterday at his departmental trial before a committee of the Board of Education and denied charges that he borrowed money from his teachers, misapplied funds and had been guilty of "conduct unbecoming a principal."

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would appoint Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. as Chief City Magistrate at the end of this month to succeed James E. McDonald, who in turn will succeed Special Sessions Justice Thomas F. McAndrews.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The immediate reaction in Congress to President Roosevelt's statement of the issue created by the Supreme Court's decision against the NRA indicated that the legislative branch might not be ready for so great an expansion of Federal powers as he seemed to suggest.

Led by United States Government loans, the bond market continued to drift lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange, although selling was not active. An exception was the foreign group, which reacted rather sharply. French Government bonds lost 1 to 4 points more.

Pleas of not guilty to separate indictments accusing them of forcing young women to live immoral lives were entered in General Sessions yesterday by Nicholas Montana, 36 years old, the ex-convict officially denounced as the "vice overlord" of the city, and Mrs. Gussie McInerny, 60, who has served two workhouse sentences.

Without presuming to comment on the merits of any case passed upon by the United States Supreme Court or any other court, or on the undoubted impartiality or legal acumen of the justices themselves, neither of which is in question, it is perhaps permissible to consider the following:
An additional $29,000,000 of gold was engaged in Paris yesterday for shipment here, making a total of $249,000,000 taken from the Bank, of France since May 8 for transfer to the United States.

Due primarily to the great congestion in the betting ring on Memorial Day, a further decision to improve facilities at Belmont Park has been reached, according to an announcement yesterday from the New York State Racing Commission.

Credit for Hollywood's advance in the moral and artistic standards of motion-picture production of the last few years was given yesterday , the General Federation of Women's Clubs and other similar groups, by their representative in the film capital, Mrs. Alice Ames Winters.

WESTWOOD, N.J., May 31. -- Mrs. Mary Lee, 45 years old, who lives in a one-family house at 217 Kimberkermack Road, Oradell, near here, held at bay with a pistol the Police and Fire Departments, two marshalls and a seargeant-at-arms who tried to serve her with an eviction notice today.

PARIS, May 31. -- During his speech last night in defense of his demand for full powers to deal with the situation, Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin accused American newspaper correspondents in Paris of deliberately circulating false news in a campaign for devaluation of the franc.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31. -- Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, who has been accused of disseminating Nazi propaganda while serving as head of the German Department at New Jersey College for Women, was defended here today by four students in German from the women's college.

Another week or two and the dove of peace will be brooding over some of this nation's most conspicuous sore spots. Arms will be laid down. Border forays and frontier incidents will cease. Provocative demonstrations will be a thing of the past.

Gone is one of the last of the stalwarts of civil service reform, WILLIAM DUDLEY FOULKE of Indiana. He gave himself to many causes -- woman suffrage, proportional representation, the World Court -- but this one was always dearest to his heart. "Fighting the Spoilsmen" was the title of one of his books, and it reveals something of the martial spirit with which all his efforts were imbued.

Ambassador Claude G. Bowers arrived here yesterday on his first visit since his appointment to the Spanish capital two years ago and found in the United States a new spirit, which he said he believed was reforming Americans into more real, more humane and happier human beings.

ROME, May 31. -- For the second time in less than one month Italy is making military preparations on an extensive scale, entailing mobilization of great numbers of men, in view of the Ethiopian situation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- The University of Pennsylvania eight-oared crew, which virtually swept the East in winning the Blackwell, Childs and Adams Cup races this Spring, today accepted the invitation of the University of California at Los Angeles to participate in its invitation regatta at Long Beach, June 28 and 29.

The pamphlet report of the Pennsylvania Electric Company for 1934 shows the company has completed the liquidation of various short-term obligations resulting from the notes which matured in 1932. The 6 1/2 per cent convertible notes due on July 1, 1934, and the 7 1/2 per cent convertible notes due on Aug. 1, 1935, were called for redemption and paid by means of a bank loan.

A large number of American companies whose bonds are payable either in United States or foreign currencies were relieved yesterday by a ruling of the Appellate Division of the obligation to pay United States citizens in anything but dollars of the present devalued gold content.

Ringed with mountains that run up to 11,000 feet, Quetta, lying in a fertile plain at an elevation of 5,500 feet, developed from a cluster of mud huts in 1840 to a city that in 1931 had a normal population of 60,000. In Summer this station on the Afghan frontier, which had become a favorite mountain resort of the British official and military population, saw an increase of about 50 per cent in its inhabitants.
LATONIA, Ky., May 31 (AP). -- With week-end interest focused on tomorrow's running of the Latonia Derby, today's eight events were given over to selling platers and 2-year-olds.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., May 31 (AP). -- A salvage crew worked in forty feet of water in the Hudson River here tonight to raise the tug Russell II and recover the bodies of two men believed to have lost their lives in the collision between the tug and the motorship Chester yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Construction of a trans-Florida ship canal at a first year's cost of about $25,000,000 has been tentatively approved by work relief officials. Running from Jacksonville to a point about 100 miles above Tampa, the canal is expected to cut about 700 miles off the route from the North Atlantic to the Gulf of Mexico.

ROME, May 31. -- For the second time in less than one month Italy is making military preparations on an extensive scale, entailing mobilization of great numbers of men, in view of the Ethiopian situation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- The University of Pennsylvania eight-oared crew, which virtually swept the East in winning the Blackwell, Childs and Adams Cup races this Spring, today accepted the invitation of the University of California at Los Angeles to participate in its invitation regatta at Long Beach, June 28 and 29.

The pamphlet report of the Pennsylvania Electric Company for 1934 shows the company has completed the liquidation of various short-term obligations resulting from the notes which matured in 1932. The 6 1/2 per cent convertible notes due on July 1, 1934, and the 7 1/2 per cent convertible notes due on Aug. 1, 1935, were called for redemption and paid by means of a bank loan.

Ringed with mountains that run up to 11,000 feet, Quetta, lying in a fertile plain at an elevation of 5,500 feet, developed from a cluster of mud huts in 1840 to a city that in 1931 had a normal population of 60,000. In Summer this station on the Afghan frontier, which had become a favorite mountain resort of the British official and military population, saw an increase of about 50 per cent in its inhabitants.

A large number of American companies whose bonds are payable either in United States or foreign currencies were relieved yesterday by a ruling of the Appellate Division of the obligation to pay United States citizens in anything but dollars of the present devalued gold content.
ALBANY, June 1 (AP). -- More than 2,000 men and women competed today in thirty-one cities of the State for sixty-five civil service jobs.

Columbia University's 181st commencement will open at 4 o'clock this afternoon with the baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel and will continue until Tuesday evening when, at outdoor exercises in front of the Low Memorial Library, President Nicholas Murray Butler will confer about 4,600 bachelor, graduate and honorary degrees, 400 certificates and diplomas.

KARACHI, India, Sunday, June 2. -- Thirty thousand persons, including 200 Britons, are now believed to have lost their lives in Quetta, the capital of Baluchistan, in the earthquakes that devastated a wide area Friday morning.

Seven men found guilty by Magistrate David Hirshfield in the Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, of violation of the Brownell Public Enemy Act, were sentenced yesterday to ninety days each in the workhouse. The convictions and sentences were the first under the act making it a crime for persons with criminal records to consort with others in the same class.

A close contest for control of the Assembly, now held by the Democrats 76 to 73, at the general election is indicated by surveys made by leaders of the major parties, it was learned yesterday. There is one vacancy due to the death of Louis A. Cuvillier, veteran from the Twentieth district, since the close of the legislative session.

BALTIMORE, June 1. -- Maryland's 1935 motor-boat season was launched officially today, with Governor Harry W. Nice participating in the commissioning ceremonies of the Maryland Yacht Club's twenty-sixth year. The club's fleet was out in full dress parade and a National Guard unit fired a salute at the inaugural conducted by Commodore W. Tilghman Hemsley.
LONELY ISLE ROYALE, pushing its lovely shores up through the green, cold waters of Lake Superior off the Michigan mainland here, may soon become the first national park of the Central Western States.

PARIS, June 1. -- Under Premier Fernand Bouisson France seems likely to be ruled with a firm hand. The man who for nine years has kept order in the Chamber of Deputies with a judicious mixture of dignity, severity, good humor, wit, application of the rules and an energetic use of the clanging bell that takes the place of a gavel, seems likely to apply the same methods to ruling the country.

IN reviewing the accomplishments of the season, one item that is likely to escape attention because it is concerned with the activities of another field is the increase in the part played by concert dancers in theatrical productions. Several years ago it was distinctly news when Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman staged the dances for "Americana."

The first trickle of Federal funds from the new $4,000,000,000 public works reservoir is expected to reach New York City about July 1. And simultaneously, according to Mayor La Guardia, the city's home relief roll of 200,000 will begin to dwindle as rapidly as the money opens up new avenues of employment.

ROME, June 1. -- The Italian economic situation is in a transitional stage, striving to attune itself to new conditions brought about by the policy of "balanced exchanges" recently adopted by the government.

ONE of the fastest steam locomotives in the world has just been delivered to the German National Railroad Company by the Borsig Locomotive Works in Berlin. It makes 109 miles on forced runs and an average of 93.2 miles per hour on usual runs. This speed is attained partly through the use of a streamlined encasement which covers the entire locomotive.

THESE are the days that begin to show up the difference between lawns which have been well treated in the Spring and those which have not. Turf that has been well watered and cared for is still green and luxuriant, but many plots are already beginning to become starved and brown looking.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June l. -- Four records were smashed and two others were equaled as Montclair, Cranford and Long Branch High Schools captured team championships in the seventeenth annual New Jersey Interscholastic A.A. track and field meet today at Essex Field.
ROME, June 1. -- The Italo-Ethiopian Conciliation Commission will hold its first sitting in Milan next week.

Plans to salvage the basic features of the invalidated NRA codes will be considered by a number of large trade and industrial organizations at meetings called early this week, it was learned yesterday.

MOSCOW. -- Any fair observer in Russia, whatever be his attitude toward the Soviet experiment, must recognize that the material conditions of living are steadily, albeit slowly, improving. But any fair observer must also discover that the Soviet Union, whatever its future may be, falls far short now of being the "workers' paradise" which people in the outside world sometimes picture it as being.
IT is called "One Hundred and Fifty Years of Russian Painting" -- the exhibition recently opened at the Hammer Galleries, 682 Fifth Avenue, booked to remain until June 8.

Investors and traders should realize that the chief function of the security markets is the maintenance of "a medium of investment and not the provision of a gambling house which will enable them to get rich quickly," says Charles H. Meyer, an authority on stock exchange law, in the current issue of The American Scholar, a quarterly publication of the Phi Beta Kappa scholastic fraternity.

OPPELN, Germany, June 1 (AP). -- Father John L. Asmenn, German-born American Jesuit, who said he was naturalized at Buffalo, N.Y., in 1920, today revealed that Nazi police had secretly ordered him to leave Germany because he defended religion against the new pagan movement.

During the next few weeks returning alumni will gather in festive mood at the chapter houses of the Greek-letter fraternities. How many of these complacent gatherings will give serious attention to the fact that numerous college chapters, especially in the East, have deteriorated, in morale in recent years, thus threatening the existence of the entire fraternity system?

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., June 1. -- Three putts on the nineteenth green beat George J. Voigt and Mrs. Leo G. Federman, last year's winners, in the quarter-final round of the New York State mixed foursome golf championship at the Seawane Club today.

The first session of a three-day convention of the Churches of Positive Christianity, Inc., was held yesterday morning at the Hotel Astor. About 100 persons from various sections of the country attended.
LATONIA, Ky., June 1. -- Turning on the power in the final sixteenth, Tearout from D.B. Midkiff's stable took the fifty-third running of the $15,000 added Latonia Derby handily today.

Delegates from New York State to the triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at Detroit June 4 to 12 will leave the city at 8:45 o'clock tonight from Grand Central station, and will be joined at Albany by the New England delegation.

Three gunmen, unmindful of policemen in the immediate neighborhood, held up Mrs. Grace Bristed Jackson, a great-great-granddaughter of the first John Jacob Astor, and about eleven other persons in her travel agency at 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, just off Fifth Avenue, at 11:45 A.M., yesterday, and escaped with more than $4,000 in cash and jewelry.

NO more timely book could be published than this one, coming out on the very heels of the Railroad Retirement decision. That decision makes it more certain than ever before that the conflict in the Supreme Court between liberalism and conservatism is to shape the future of this government.

TORONTO, Ont., June 1. -- The value of metal production from Ontario's mines, smelters and refineries in the first quarter of 1935 amounted to $29,517,953 in Canadian funds, up 5.9 per cent from the same quarter of 1934. The increase was in nickel and copper, while gold, silver and cobalt showed small declines.

To the student of constitutional law the Humphrey case, decided by the Supreme Court on Monday, is fully as interesting as the Schechter decision, for it writes a new chapter in the history of the appointive and removal power of the President.
JAPAN has started a new one-hour daily international short-wave broadcast picked up in the United States at 8:30 P.M., Eastern standard time.

BALTIMORE, June 1. -- Terming the Supreme Court's NRA ruling "probably as important" as the Dred Scott decision affecting slavery, Maryland's Republican Governor, Harry W. Nice, today proposed that Governor Lehman of New York call a conference of all State executives to seek "a remedy."

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 1. -- Dr. William S.A. Pott, former member of the faculties of the University of Virginia and the University of California and now connected with General Motors Corporation, has been named president of Elmira College.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 1. -- Two small incendiary fires caused minor damage about 1 A.M. today to the front and rear entrances of the St. Cecilia Carmelite Convent, a three-story frame building, but failed to cause any excitement among nineteen nuns who remained inside while firemen quickly extinguished the flames.

ONE of the most admirable institutions developed by Mussolini's Italy is the Rassegna Nazionale, or National Review of Contemporary Music, held every two years in Rome by the National Fascist Musicians Syndicate.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., June 1 (AP). -- Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, tonight asserted that, regardless of the Supreme Court's action, a policy of establishing maximum hours, minimum wages and the abolition of child labor was here to stay.

A NEW line of cars, designated the De Luxe Airstream Eight, is announced today by the Chrysler Sales Corporation. The line comprises six body styles on a wheelbase of 121 inches with 105 horsepower from the motor and two body styles on a 133-inch wheelbase with 110 horsepower.

HERE and throughout the country the Roosevelt administration has marshaled its forces for the greatest and most comprehensive attack on unemployment in history. Congress has appropriated $4,000,000,000 for the campaign and this huge sum is to be used, largely as President Roosevelt specifies, in transferring the government's relief "clients" from relief rolls to payrolls.

PARIS, May 23. -- The opening of the great exhibition of Italian art, which has been so much heralded for the last few weeks, was the social and artistic success that was anticipated. It was also the official opening of the Paris social season.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1. -- Optimistic in spite of increasing flood conditions resulting from excessive rains over the western part of the State, Nebraska stockmen are holding down shipments to the Omaha market and getting, on the whole, markedly better prices than a year ago.

OTTAWA, May 30. -- When the United States Supreme Court justices blasted the NRA out of legal existence this week they fired a shot heard around the whole Continent of North America. Ottawa copied its "New Deal" program from Washington, and if its rejection in the United States holds it may follow that example, too.

MILWAUKEE won the grand award in the traffic safety contest held under the auspices of the National Safety Council last year. In the current issue of Public Safety, the council's monthly periodical, Tom A. Burke, the editor, tells how the city did it.

GENEVA, June 1. -- China executed 263 violators of her anti-opium law last year, her delegate, Victor Hoo, informed the League of Nations Opium Advisory Committee today in his annual report. Six of these were cured addicts who relapsed, eighteen were illicit makers, twenty-six were illicit transporters and 213 were illicit sellers of narcotics.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Consumption of meats has practically overtaken supplies in the United States, probably for the first time on record, creating a situation which stock men say is the most drastic that the country has known.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A marked change of front was perceptible today on the part of leading Senators of both major parties with regard to President Roosevelt's appeal to the nation on the Supreme Court's NRA decision.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 1. -- Andover's track team scored a 101 2-3-to-24 1-3 victory over Exeter today to make a record score for this annual dual meet. Exeter scored only one first place outright and Andover showed great strength but broke no records.

With the codes established under the National Industrial Recovery Act now scrapped, the Investment Bankers Association of America is seeking a substitute for the code under which it has been operating. Officers of the association said yesterday that the fate of the investment bankers' code was as obscure today as it had been early last week when the United States Supreme Court's decision was handed down.

Depression diets are causing many cases of eye diseases, especially among school children, that may result in a heavy toll of blindness in future generations as well as in the present, Dr. Emanuel M. Josephson of this city said yesterday in a paper at the twenty-third annual meeting of the Eugenics Research Association at the American Museum of Natural History.

THE great Spanish dramatist of the Golden Age, Lope de Vega Carpio, surnamed the Phoenix of Spain, this year holds the centre of the Spanish literary world's stage. The third centenary of his death, Aug. 27, 1635, is being commemorated, not only in Spain and Hispanic America, but in all countries.

Mauls and riveting tools may be thumping against the hulls of many new craft at the shipyards in this busiest boating season in years, brokers' offices may be swamped under new orders and charters and yacht clubs may be gay and prospering with hosts of new members, but for the real index of motor boating one must visit the New York Custom House.

ANOTHER theatrical season has passed into such history books as accept gaudy and bizarre material. It ended its career after the close of business last evening, mourned by a sincere few and frowned upon by many others.
DENVER, May 30. -- In spite of their reverses during the last two campaigns, the Republicans, are preparing for 1936. The party is hopeful that it can make considerable gains seventeen months hence.

PREPARATIONS have been about completed for the second stratosphere expedition from the now-famous semi-circular canyon in the Black Hill of South Dakota. Within the next three weeks, perhaps this week, the world's largest free balloon, carrying two, perhaps three men, a great variety of scientific instruments, more than a score of recording cameras and a total load of nine tons, will rise above the pine-clad hills and drift, as it climbs, into the southwest.

The agreement between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and three groups of manufacturers in the cloak and suit industry expired yesterday, and if negotiations for its extension fail to reach a settlement the union is prepared to call a strike of 40,000 cloak workers in some 2,000 shops at the end of a two-week truce that has been granted to the manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A continued moderate recession in domestic business, but with no production changes of particular significance, was noted by the Department of Commerce in the week ended May 25, the weekly survey today revealed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1 (AP). -- The Syracuse Chiefs reached a .500 average for the season today, handing Newark its second straight one-run defeat of the present series, 6 to 5. It was the fifth victory for Syracuse over the Bears against no defeats this season.
After an unsettled first hour on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, prices recovered about $2 a bale and closed at gains of 25 to 34 points.

THIS attempt to portray a force that has achieved such proportions and consequence that it already excites apprehension is by far the most comprehensive and detailed study of propaganda that has yet been made. Chiefly the work is, as its subtitle describes it, an "annotated bibliography."

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Although leaders of business and industry have acted quickly to meet the challenge of the Supreme Court's decision wiping out the NRA, they have bumped up against realities as great as their new responsibilities.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1. -- Southern California won the fifty-ninth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and championship today, but Keith Brown of Yale stole the show.

MOUNT CARMEL, Conn., June 1. -- The Old Mill Farm's Rod made the most of an excellent ride by Sidney Hirst to capture the Nutmeg State Steeplechase, feature of today's hunts program of the 122d Cavalry Racing Association. The races were held over the picturesque triangular course on the Mountain Glen Farm of Major Phelps Montgomery.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 1. -- The third annual faculty-alumni forum will be the opening event on the six-day program arranged for the 188th commencement week of Princeton University. Graduation exercises will be held on the campus in front of Nassau Hall Tuesday morning, June 18, according to the schedule released today by Dr. Wilson Farrand, '86, of South Orange, N.J., chairman of the commencement committee and clerk of the board of trustees of the university.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 1. -- To preserve the assets of the Kingston Coal Company, Judge Benjamin R. Jones today named Walter S. Oliver of Wilkes-Barre and James H. Pierce of Scranton receivers after operations were halted when employes refused a proposal whereby the mines would operate in return for a refund of half of the June earnings and other concessions.
"The Polish Republic is not pro-German, as it is the common conception here," declared John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland, in an interview at his offices at 100 Broadway.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- With the selection of sponsors for eight Southern States to amend the eighth annual rhododendron festival from June 10 to 15, plans are rapidly taking shape for what promises to be the largest fete ever given here.

THIS is a slender little book, but it is compact of information about those mysterious factors of diet, the vitamins, their importance in conserving health, providing vigor and adding to the length and value of life. It tells in approximately what amounts they should be ingested every day and what foods form the most prolific sources for each one.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 1. -- A better method of selecting judges, increased respect for the law among the people and a drastic raising of the requirements for admission to the bar were advocated today as the necessary moves to restore the steadying influence of the legal profession over the affairs of the American public.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Circumstances under which a $400,000 trust fund was created for the readjustment managers of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad were reviewed today at a continuation of the hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission into the railroad's affairs.
Decreases in prices of beef, cotton and grains reduced The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 124.6 on Tuesday from 126.2 the week before.

Since the founding of this nation, the American people have been searching for the right answer to the question raised by the President in his talk to the newspaper correspondents last Friday. Under a Federal system of government, in which power is deliberately divided between the States and the Union, for the very purpose of safeguarding the liberty of the individual, what are the proper limits of centralized authority?

RUMSON, N.J., June 1. -- Princeton's polo quartet, which clashes with Yale next Saturday in the opening intercollegiate match at Governors Island, defeated a strong Rumson team today on Herbert Memorial Field, 8 to 7.

Holding that industrial buying is not subject to the type of influence which brought a wave of cutthroat competition in the retail field in the wake of the NIRA ruling, purchasing executives for large corporations are adhering to buying policies mapped out before the Supreme Court's decision, a canvass here disclosed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1. -- Steamship operators here took heart today from news that thousands of lumber mill workers of the Northwest will return to their jobs Monday morning. The strike involved at its height almost 50,000 union labor men.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- A deluge of selling on the Board of Trade today swamped buyers of wheat and broke prices to the lowest levels on the crop. The main selling influence early was the pessimistic tenor of President Roosevelt's remarks yesterday in regard to the course of commodity prices if the AAA should be declared unconstitutional.

William Thompson Jr. was the first casualty in the seeded ranks as the eighteenth annual open tournament for the Brooklyn tennis championship started yesterday at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. No. 7 on the list, which is headed by Gregory Mangin, Thompson was upset by William Lurie, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, in a second-round match.

Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer, made public yesterday the names of the two children whose essays were rated highest among those of about 100,000 children attending 100 schools in New York City in a recent traffic safety contest.

FROM time to time men find themselves deeply moved by some great experience. It happened that this reviewer attended the Bach Festival in Bethlehem, Pa., and listened to the lovely Passion according to St. Matthew and the majestic Mass in B minor, that passionate exposition of "the beauty of holiness."

CAIRO, June 1. -- The Italo-Ethiopian dispute has brought to a conclusion the long-standing negotiations of the Egyptian and Sudanese Governments and the Ethiopian Emperor for the construction of a dam in Lake Tsana.

THE Radio City Music Hall issued a revised picture schedule the other day. The list, subject to change, is presented herewith: Jot down "Our Little Girl" for Thursday. The girl of the title is none other than Shirley Temple.

TO students of English literature it has long been known that the original of the Rebecca of Scott's "Ivanhoe" was a lovely Jewess of Philadelphia named Rebecca Gratz, of whom Scott learned from Washington Irving, who was her devoted friend through many years.

A meeting will be held at Utica, N.Y., early this month to discuss a plan drawn by the Governor's committee to control interstate milk traffic in the New York market, it was announced yesterday by Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Commissioner of Agriculture and chairman of the committee.

Public offerings here of new securities in May changed markedly from those in April. Bond flotations, although larger than in May last year, were the smallest since February, while stock offerings were the largest since May, 1931. Industrial financing was prominent in the new financing, which was more diversified than a year ago.

A shiver runs through the mountains that separate Afghanistan and Baluchistan. In a few minutes 20,000 lives are snuffed out as half a dozen towns and hundreds of villages are reduced to ruins. The story of Formosa, scarcely a month old, is repeated with even heavier emphasis on tragedy because the area afflicted is vaster, the loss of life greater.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 1 (AP). -- The five-man American Davis Cup team on which the United States is pinning its hopes of wresting the world's tennis supremacy from Great Britain completed its intensive training on home soil today and began to break camp preparatory to embarking for England Wednesday.

VIENNA. -- "Letters From Exile" is the title of a recently published book containing letters written by the Pretender, Archduke Otto, to various Mayors of towns and chairmen of organizations which during the last four years have elected him honorary citizen or president.

A derelict yacht is sighted from a steamer on its way from Nova Scotia to New York. Fleming Stone, who is a passenger on the steamer, scents a mystery and boards the yacht along with the officer sent to examine it. He finds a dead man on the deck of the yacht and another in the hold.

Many dramatic scenes have taken place in the French Chamber of Deputies. There the Clemenceaus, the Poincares, the Briands and the Herriots have stirred Parliament and the people with their eloquence; there men whose names are written large in French history have won great victories and have gone down to defeat.

Lloyd's Register of American Yachts issued its thirty-third edition last week with a listing of 5,541 of the principal pleasure craft and with the usual sections devoted to yacht clubs, owners' private signals in colors, Lloyd's earliest American counterpart and predecessor was "Fox's Yachting Annual," first issued in 1872 when only nine "screw steamers" represented the power craft and when James Gordon Bennett was commodore of the New York Y.C.

MEXICO, D.F. -- Mexico, which is a country that produces more silver than any other in the world, has completely removed that metal from its own currency. The situation breaks into paradox from almost any angle.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 1. -- The Williams College Athletic Council today appointed Anthony Plansky, former Georgetown University star and once the national decathlon champion, head coach of track, succeeding Charles F. Seeley, who will retire this month after thirty-seven years of service.

MADISON, N.J., June 1. -- Dr. John H. Finley will deliver the commencement address at the sixty-eighth annual graduation exercises at Drew University on June 11, it has been announced by Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of the university.

After a drunken party in her apartment in Philadelphia, Miss Betty Sloan is found lying dead on the floor. A post-mortem reveals that she has been poisoned. The District Attorney, who has but little confidence in the heavy-handed chief of county detectives, engages Jabez Twombley to work on the case independently.

PITTSBURGH, May 31. -- Whether inquiry is made among spokesmen for the United Mine Workers or operators, the situation in the soft-coal industry, with the threat of a strike of 350,000 miners on June 17, is recognized as a race between provision of a stabilizing system and chaos.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Mixed conditions in South American business, but with favorable signs in several countries, contrary to seasonal tendencies, were reported today in the Commerce Department's weekly survey of foreign markets of the United States.

MARIETTA, Ohio, June 1. -- Coach Ten Eyck's green Rutgers crew stroked its way to an impressive victory over five other college octets in the Mid-America Regatta today, nosing out the third varsity shell of the University of Pennsylvania by a half length.

With the drastically amended Copeland Pure Food and Drugs Bill passed by the Senate last week during the general furor caused by the NIRA decision, early action by the House on the measure, which has been months in the making, was predicted here yesterday by leaders in both industries and by members of the advertising fraternity.
The NRA decision of the Supreme Court will have a political importance equal to that of the Dred Scott case.
PARIS, June 1. -- Jubilation reigned in financial Paris today. It was almost unanimously believed the latest battle of the franc had been fought and won.

ANY month that offers a heavyweight championship bout has at least one red-letter day on the radio calendar. June is one of those months, and the 13th will be a big night on the air if the weather man orders clear atmospherics over the big open arena at Long Island City where Max Baer will meet Jimmy Braddock.

The one-man feat of record-breaking by Jesse Owens, Ohio State's great Negro athlete, this Spring has provided many thrills for followers of track and field. The Middle-Westerner's performances are without a close parallel in the annals of track.

NOW that the Reichswehr of republican Germany has stepped forward as the formidable force of an entire nation in arms General Werner von Blomberg, the Third Reich's Minister of War, is the target of worldwide curiosity.

SIR GUY STANDING, Knight Commander of the British Empire, stood serenely in the centre of the crowded room giving a splendid impersonation of a man who really didn't mind having his one-day vacation spoiled by the mass interview that Paramount had arranged.

While awaiting world monetary stabilization, which depends on action by the United States and Great Britain, France is facing no little trouble with the franc. On the result of the fight which the new Bouisson Cabinet says it will make for the maintenance of the gold value of the French unit hinges perhaps the status of the moneys of all of the countries making up what is called the Gold Bloc.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- Into the fight against the Wheeler-Raburn bill to abolish public utility holding companies was thrown today a hitherto unpublished report by the Commerce Department's business advisory council, recommending modification of the measure.

BEGINNING on the morning of Carol Malone's marriage to young Lane Beckett, editor of The Center Falls (Wis.) Chronicle, this simple, but capably handled, story traces the disturbed first half-year of their life together. Carol is 19, a spoiled, pretty girl, indulgently reared and supported by her admirable widowed mother, Lynn, who is still handsome at 38 and fit to be the wife of any mature man who sees her sterling worth and charm.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 1. -- William Tilden of Philadelphia and George Lott of Chicago came through to the final round of the first American championship of the International Players Association today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The President told reporters at his press conference on Wednesday that the "spot news" was being made in the communities of the nation, not in its capital. On Monday the Supreme Court had handed down a decision destroying the NRA; the rest of the week the communities of the nation were engrossed in the task of digesting and understanding that momentous opinion.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1 (AP). -- Governor Hoffman said today the "element of danger" in the scrapping of the NRA codes was "the surprising and apparent unwillingness in high places to accept this vital and unanimous determination by the Supreme Court."

A report drawn by its committee on internal trade and improvements and made public by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, declared the Wagner labor disputes bill, now before Congress, is injurious to national welfare and will fail in its purpose to diminish the causes of industrial strife.
New York's most active works project last week was the dock and berth for the world's largest ship, the Normandie, expected to arrive tomorrow on her first voyage from France.

The report that the Pope, whose birthday was celebrated yesterday, will spend a vacation period in the papal villa at Castel Gandolfo must lead some who have not altogether forgotten their Aeneid to turn to the eighth book, which foretells the founding by the son of Aeneas of the city that once stood upon its site:

AMERICAN gardeners who were not privileged to join the "garden pilgrimage" to the great decennial international flower show -- "Flora" -- held this Spring in Holland will undoubtedly be interested to learn of some of the new plants which have won honor here.

Three of the six cripples who began a "hunger strike" last Wednesday in the offices of the Emergency Relief Bureau, 902 Broadway, to enforce their demands for more relief for the handicapped unemployed, were still encamped in the bureau offices yesterday.

Fighting grimly to hold their position of eminence, only recently attained, the Yankees battled the Red Sox to an even break in the double-header at the Stadium yesterday and so contrived to retain their lead in the American League flag race. A crowd of 33,000 viewed the proceedings with a feeling that a difficult situation had been rather satisfactorily circumvented.

Port Jefferson is not only a snug harbor but a providential one. If cruising yachtsmen of today instead of the forces of erosion and the glacier age thousands of years ago were to gouge out a haven along the sometimes mean and finicky Long Island Sound, their poll for the best-situated anchorage would surely be "Port Jeff."

THE title is provocative. It has mystery and rhythm. It is a challenge to the imagination, and to the amateur versifier it is a distinct temptation. Southeast of Zamboanga, where the natives dance the tanga, the traders sin and drink bad gin, the guns go banga-banga.

Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., a defendant in an accounting suit by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for the Sonora Products Company, was required to post a bond of $100,000 to obtain permission to leave the country until Sept. 1, it became known yesterday through papers filed in the Federal Court.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP). -- The Athletics won both ends of a double-header with the Washington Senators before a crowd of approximately 12,000 fans today, taking the first game, 5 to 0, and the second, 7 to 3.

CHEYENNE, Wyo. -- After two months of the sales tax Wyoming citizens have become thoroughly tax conscious, because for the first time in the history of the State every one is paying taxes directly -- which is in itself a novel experience.

"Fresh-water anglers who are not afraid of being charged with heresy by their fellow-trouters ought to take a fling at Peconic Bay weak-fishing while the run is on and learn what it is like to catch fish," writes R.F.

A much longer but not "bigger and better" circus than the famous Barnum show was staged yesterday afternoon by boys and girls of the ghetto on the lower East Side, at the Madison House, 226 Madison Street. The performance lasted five hours and had a cast of 101.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 1. -- Mrs. Dwight Morrow, author and widow of the noted statesman, received the honorary degree of doctor of laws today at the fourteenth annual commencement at New Jersey College for Women.

The New York Stock Exchange indicated yesterday for the first time that it does not intend to challenge the constitutionality of Federal regulatory legislation, when Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, stated that such action had not been considered.

THE other day I realized that it was just twenty-five years since I first began working on a motion picture set. Such a span of years furnishes a comfortable excuse for a bandying of reminiscences, and I have been asked to set down a few of my own recollections.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Leaders of organized labor, bewildered by the first impact of the Schechter case decision, are now rallying their forces on the economic and political fronts in an endeavor to save what can be saved of the wreckage created by the Supreme Court's unanimous ruling.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity dates brought the total for May to $96,370,000, against $38,328,000 in April and $7,232,000 in May, 1934. The week's calls, which were large in the aggregate despite the holiday, were nearly all for payment in months following June.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 1. -- The eighth annual Glen Head Horse Show was held on the Stephen H. Townsend estate today under ideal weather conditions. A good-sized gallery witnessed the twenty-one events on the program.

VIENNA, June 1. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, creator and commander of the German air force, general of the anti-aircraft artillery coordinated with it, Minister-President of Prussia, President of the Reichstag, Master of the Hunt and Forests and the Reichsfuehrer's special good-will delegate to Sweden, Italy and Poland -- in other words, Adolf Hitler's second self -- is making a sort of post-honeymoon tour of the Balkan States.

FLOWERS and fruits, vegetables and nuts -- these are the usual harvest of a garden. It is not customary to cut water flasks, drinking cups, hanging baskets, bird houses and darning eggs, yet there they are, all of them practically ready-made in the garden where gourd vines grow.

Commodity markets were generally lower yesterday, further reflecting the generally bearish interpretation of the comments of President Roosevelt on the MIRA decision. The rally in the franc, however, because of the change in the French government was considered a countering influence.

NOW that the theatre season has drawn to its official close and the reports of the inevitable bookkeepers are being filed in the proper places, it is timely that something be said of the sales which were made this past season of the motion picture rights to Broadway shows.

FOUR Mozart operas during a span of five weeks form the attractive program of the second opera festival at Glyndebourne, England, where, in the heart of Sussex and on the grounds of an Elizabethan manor house, stands a theatre that has attracted wide attention for the character and quality of its undertakings.

MANY owners of small places have gone on, year after year, without the enjoyment of water lilies because they believed that a running stream, or at least a large, deep pool, was essential to growing them.

GENEVA, June 1. -- The NRA decision, coming just before the annual International Labor Organization's conference, has raised the question here whether the Washington administration would not be able to carry out some of its labor policies, now apparently blocked as unconstitutional, through its treaty-making powers.

PARIS, June 1. -- This Third French Republic has survived so many shocks and emotions that a change of government like that which has been taking place during the last forty-eight hours is scarcely more important than the change of a Secretaryship in the United States administration would be.

OF the three novels by Ernst Lothar this last. "The Loom of Justice," is not only the soundest dramatically but it is also the most honest in its delineation of character. Herr Lothar has a streak of cynicism which has hitherto vitiated his excellent craftsmanship.

THE question of the ultimate destination of scarce or unique literary treasures may be answered with a fair degree of satisfaction by an examination of the great institutional libraries. A case in point is that of the almost complete collection of Johnsoniana at Harvard.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- Holy Cross bombarded Ted Horton, Yale's first-string pitcher, for nineteen safeties today, defeating the Elis, 14 to 4. The victory increased the Crusaders' season's string of victories to 17 in 18 games. Nearly 4,000 persons, the largest attendance of the season, saw the game.

Evelyn Fagan, 13-year-old daughter of John J. Fagan, a stock broker with offices at 26 Broadway, was killed at 7 o'clock last night by an empty runaway automobile a few doors from her home at 1,749 Popham Avenue, the Bronx.
TIFFIN, Ohio, June 1 (AP). -- A terrific bomb explosion demolished the front porch and badly damaged the home of Charles E. Miller, president of Heidelberg College early today.

QUETTA, India, Sunday, June 2. -- Floods accompanied the fires that raged through devastated Quetta last night, threatening to swell still further the toll of dead and injured taken by the earthquakes. Some places on the outskirts of the city were flooded to a depth of several feet.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 1. -- A goal by Will Welch in the final period gave the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club lacrosse team a 7-6 triumph over Syracuse University today. The victory gave the winners a clean sweep of the two-game series, they having triumphed on Thursday, 8 to 5.

What has long been expected as the next stage in the Far East appears to be under way. Japan swings into action again in North China. Demands have been made, with intimations that troops will advance unless the terms are met.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 1. -- With mishaps playing a prominent though not necessarily serious part, fifty-eight boats sailed in the sixty-third annual regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today. It was the third event in the Y.R.A. championship series.

THE section of the Meadowbrook Parkway between Southern State Parkway and Merrick Road, Long Island, was opened for south bound traffic last Thursday, so that Memorial Day motorists would have an additional access route to Jones Beach and Long Beach.

PARIS. SINCE praise comes better from strangers than from members of one's own family, it is gratifying to see an important French commentator agreeing with the American observer in finding the films of Hollywood better than France's production.

With governmental control over the wages and hours of most workers eliminated by the Supreme Court decision voiding the NRA, a new foundation for governing business practices might be laid, with the old fair-trade practice rules sponsored by the Federal Trade Commission as the basis, Gilbert H Montague, an authority on constitutional law and closely associated with several code groups, said here yesterday.

THE Honorable John Byng was in his young manhood a soldier, being a lieutenant colonel in the Foot Guards until just before he began these diaries, when he resigned and entered the civil service. Thereafter he used his vacation time traveling about over England and Wales, mostly by horseback.

A collection of furniture and decorations, the property of Mrs. Newton W. Gilbert, with additions from other sources, will be auctioned on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons by the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc.

At the ninetieth commencement exercises of Fordham University, beginning Monday, June 10, and ending Wednesday, June 12, approximately 1,000 degrees in course and five honorary degrees will be conferred.

YOU go to Quebec and then take Route 2. That was the way the Duchess answered her companion when he asked her the location of Gaspe. He was all for a Summer in France, but the Duchess reminded him of the depreciated dollar and various other drawbacks, so, as the saying goes, they compromised on Gaspe -- with excellent results.

Seventy-three students were graduated last night by the First Institute of Podiatry, 52-55 East 124th Street. The commencement exercises were held in the Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street. J.W. Duffield delivered the commencement address.
BERLIN (AP). -- Being the wife of General Hermann Goering, the picturesque first lieutenant of Adolf Hitler, is no unalloyed pleasure for Frau Emmy Sonneman-Goering, former actress.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- Spurred to action by Dr. Frederick C. Redfern's hope that his son, Paul, is still alive, the State Department today planned a careful investigation of the curious story told by Tom Roch of finding the missing aviator living with South American jungle Indians.

ROME, June 1. -- The curiosity caused by a communique stating that Premier Mussolini and high army officers had attended a demonstration by Senator Guglielmo Marconi of an invention made by him has been increased by an admission by the inventor of wireless.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 1. -- Owen D. Young, addressing more than a hundred leading industrialists of America here today at the Industrial Research Conference of Purdue University, declared that modern housing was the "new industry" needed to take up the employment slack and lead the way out of the depression.

IN the American Federation of Arts' new American Art Annual (Vol. 31), we find the useful reference material long characterizing this publication, except that the biographical directory of artists been withdrawn, to make its appearance next Autumn as a separate volume entitled "Who's Who in American Art."
ROME, June 1. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's view of the compromise reached at Geneva last week on the next step in the Italo-Abyssinian conflict is simply that it provides a period of truce.

The youngest master in the New York-Havre trade of the French Line came to port last week on the Lafayette on his first voyage as master in the service. Captain Etienne de la Garanderie has just been appointed to command the Lafayette to succeed Captain Jules Chabot, who was transferred to the Ile de France. Captain Rene Pugnet, formerly of the Ile de France, is master of the new Normandie.

W'HITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- This resort has been designated as the eastern entrance to the chain of parks and national forests now being established in West Virginia by Federal and State governments. Cooperating with park authorities, the town will launch immediately a five-year plan for beautification, including the marking of the Dry Creek battlefield and the construction of a new road along Anthony Creek.
DETROIT, June 1 (AP). -- The White Sox defeated the Tigers, 5-4, today, although outhit, and gave Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe his fifth defeat of the season. Ted Lyons went the route for the victors.

THE Normandie, the largest ship afloat, is thrashing her way toward New York. The greatest mass of steel and machinery ever to sail the sea is finding herself, in Kipling's phrase; shaking her huge body together into one integrated structure.

HAVANA, June 1. -- Simultaneously with the re-establishment today by the government of the original 1901 constitution in a somewhat modified form President Carlos Mendieta announced that he would not be a Presidential candidate in the elections that are expected to be held at the end of this year.

BERLIN, June 1. -- An open threat to disestablish the churches in Germany unless they bow to the National Socialist State was voiced today by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, in a speech before 20,000 Nazi leaders in Thuringia assembled for a festival at Erfurt.
Golfers from the four corners of the golfing earth are gathering at Pittsburgh for the national open championship, which starts on Thursday over the famous Oakmont Country Club course.

Senior week will begin tomorrow at New York University for nearly 4,000 seniors and will culminate on the morning of June 12, with the conferring of degrees by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase at Ohio Field, University Heights. Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary, announced yesterday that a series of dinners, boat rides and class-day exercises had been scheduled.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1. -- "My name's Leonard Ruziska. Yes, I'm the undertaker at Arapahoe. Sure, I'll give you an interview, but it can't be a long one. The water's eating at the foundation of the house now.

Plans are being completed for the "Starlight in Normandie" supper dance, cabaret and fashion show to be held on Wednesday in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

IT was something more than a week ago that Tecumseh, on the way to an academic afternoon at Belmont Park, encountered George White. Having remarked on the coincidence of their meeting, and after an exchange of notes on the day's favorites, both gentlemen got down to business -- show business.

Spurred by price reductions and more favorable weather, retail sales in the metropolitan area improved last week. For the first time in nearly a month department store sales volume showed a slight increase over the corresponding period a year ago.

Proposals to alter the procedure or the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court have been thick in Washington since the NRA decision. One plan is to have Congress pass an act declaring that no decision of the court shall be binding unless concurred in by two-thirds of the judges.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Racing the last ten miles with a darting pain in his side, Pat Dengis of Baltimore, a comparative novice at distance running, today won the national A.A.U. marathon championship by a 200-yard margin in two hours 53 minutes 53 seconds.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 1. -- A fantastic method of self-destruction apparently was succeeding tonight at City Hospital, where Stephen Liarsky, 26-year-old wanderer, lay unconscious with the deadly venom of a black widow spider he had had sent from California coursing through his veins. Physicians admitted that they knew of no way to combat the poison.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 1. -- Columbia's squad of thirty-two oarsmen arrived at the Blue and White boathouse at Krum Elbow today and quickly settled into the routine of training that will carry them to the intercollegiate regatta on June 18.

PARIS, May 30. -- Paris is busy preparing new hats for the big month of June. Reboux will launch the largest felt shapes ever seen. Their brims extend way over the shoulders. They are in rich medieval colors, and are trimmed with contrasting ostrich fronds that sweep out of the crown drapery, following the general line of the hat rather than forming an extraneous trimming.

In connection with the eighty-seventh anniversary of its founding, the East River Savings Bank is carrying on a campaign to eliminate accounts of depositors who for twenty years or more have forgotten or neglected their savings deposits.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Strike orders expected to affect 400,000 bituminous coal miners in twenty-eight States, effective at midnight June 16, when the present wage agreement expires, were sent out today from the office of the United Mine Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The epochal decisions last Monday of the Supreme Court have served to impress once more upon the consciousness of the country an apparent but often forgotten fact: that the national government is a government of limited authority and definite structure whose powers and functions are defined and enumerated in a written Constitution.

The sophisticated moviegoer may feel that the movies have taken Greeley's advice to the young man too literally and gone West with a vengeance, but fortunately only a few of our 80,000,000 annual American moviegoers are sophisticated. Probably 79,000,000 of them are still devotees of the old Western horse opera.

NEWARK, N.J., June 1. -- A fine inning by H.S. Cockeram of Brooklyn which yielded thirty-eight runs and the effective bowling of R.S. King, P.B. Green and E.J. Atwood helped the Brooklyn Cricket Club defeat the St. George of Orange eleven at Watsessing Park in Bloomfield today.

About two years ago, when Middle Western farm communities had a series of violent uprisings against foreclosures on land, half the States in the Union adopted mortgage moratorium laws deferring payments on principal. One of these statutes (Minnesota's) came before the Supreme Court in January, 1934, and was sustained, 5 to 4, as a legitimate exercise of emergency power "for the protection of a basic interest of society."

THE recent suggestion of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt that a new and comprehensive guidebook of the United States be written has drawn attention to the fact that the first and last Baedeker of America was printed twenty years ago.

VIENNA, June 1. -- The desperate efforts of the police to locate the headquarters of the illegal Nazi news sheet, the Illkor, and to arrest the authors of this publication, which has been greatly annoying the Austrian authorities because it has evidently been compiled from first-class news sources, have finally been successful.
ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., June 1. -- More than 300 persons attended the Turf and Field Day dinner held this evening at the Atlantic Beach Club.
Twelve prizes and awards, including four fellowships, to Barnard College students were announced yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve.

THE FOX-TWENTIETH CENTURY deal revealed this week provided the town with the first major bombshell of a season that, local seers predict, will be marked by production changes and explosions. The affair occurred without warning, and, as would be natural in a place in which gossip and rumor are the principal products, with celluloid second, speculation is rife over the import of the union.

Twenty owners of new motor boats finished yesterday afternoon in the Hudson at Edgewater, N.J., the annual long-distance cruise that has come to be the certain sign of the opening of a new season for power craft. In perfect formation, the fleet of Richardsons began to close in after passing under the George Washington Bridge to come to a stop at the Undercliff Boat Works after a seven-day run from North Tonawanda, N.Y.

AS parents sometimes have favorites among their children so an author often thinks more highly of one of his works than of any of the rest, though he is not always willing to divulge his private opinion on the matter.
Two detectives whose careers in the New York Police Department have been as uneven as changing Police Commissioners could make them received promotion yesterday from Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1 (AP). -- Business has pulled itself out of the depression and will advance without the aid of the NRA, in the opinion of Jerome D. Barnum, publisher of The Syracuse Post-Standard and president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 1. -- Three games were played on Meadow Brook Fields today among the players preparing for the opening of the club's tournaments next week-end. The club had hoped to open International Field, but last night's rains caused a postponement there.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The election contest against Senator-elect Holt, 29-year-old West Virginian, was boiled down today to the one question of eligibility as regards his youth.

Many members of society in this city and on the North Shore of Long Island are actively interested in the annual fair to be held on Friday at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney in Manhasset, for the benefit of the Babies' Milk Funds of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The first formal notice of war-debt payments due from thirteen countries on June 15 has been sent by the State Department to Finland, the only government that has thus far paid her obligation in full on every due date.

ST. LOUIS, June 1. -- Miss Helen Stephens, 17-year-old Missouri track sensation, tied one world's record and smashed one national and one meet record today in the annual Ozark A.A.U. outdoor meet for girls.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 30, -- California is getting acquainted with a new Herbert Hoover, a man who has come completely out of his shell and takes an increasingly active and genial part in its affairs.

LOUISVILLE, June 1 (AP). -- A call for women to patronize merchants who voluntarily continue NRA codes was made today by Miss Mary E. Hughes, who directed the national sign-up of women to support the Blue Eagle in 1933.

WHEN St. Sophia, the great cathedral church of old Byzantium -- and after 1453 A.D. a centre of Turkish Moslem worship -- was opened recently as a museum of Byzantine art, it was considered a fitting moment to excavate the forecourt and lay bare the old atrium, buried deep in broken masonry.

Although a small field reported at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday, the shooting was exceedingly close. Three gunners each had 47 out of 50 targets in the scratch contest. They were H.K. McCloughan, F.C. Chapman and M.E. Grout.

THE fifth annual American Folk Song Festival will be held on June 9 in the foothills of the Northeastern Kentucky mountains, near Ashland. The setting is a natural amphitheatre in front of a windowless log cabin made famous by Jean Thomas, author of "Traipsin Woman." Miss Thomas is founder of the American Folk Song Society and directs the festival.

Puerto Rico, which President Harding once called "our Caribbean State," would become a State in fact under a bill now before Congress. A delegation of Puerto Ricans, headed by Rafael Martinez Nadal, president of the island's Senate, is now in Washington for a public hearing on the bill before the House Committee on Insular Affairs.

DR. ROULE, who is, as the title page of his new book says, Professor at the National Museum of Natural History in Paris, is one of those satisfactory naturalists who proceed from the particular to the general.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 1. -- Brilliant relief pitching by Bill Gottlieb gave N.Y.U. a 7-to-5 victory over the Princeton nine on University Field today.

Senior week activities at Manhattan College, preliminary exercises to the commencement on Tuesday, June 11, will open Thursday evening with a dinner of the graduating class at the Hotel Taft, according to the schedule announced yesterday by E. Barry Mergardt, general chairman of the program.

BILLIE BURKE, an ebullient person, has a trick of meeting questions and questioners with a contemplative, detached stare suggestive of a kitten's apparent indifference toward the ball of yarn that has not yet begun rolling.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 1. -- Max Baer went through the hardest workout of his training campaign today when he went nine full rounds of boxing against an assortment of sparring partners.

AN obscure trail leading over the Albanian Mountains to the Adriatic Sea is still called the Road of Death. In 1915 the Serbs marched 60,000 prisoners of war over this trail in the dead of Winter without the formality of a supply train, bound for Italian prison camps, while Serbia was being overrun and laid waste by the Austro-Hungarian armies.

THE youth hostel idea, made popular by thousands of young hikers who annually throng the roads of Europe, has been adopted by New England in an effort to encourage travel afoot and to introduce the beauties of the New England country to the nation. A chain of hostels at which young transients may be housed at minimum cost will be opened on June 22 in Vermont, New Hampshire and Massachusetts.

The British Secret Service suspects Guelda Burtoff, the beautiful girl with the scarred throat, of being a spy in the pay of some foreign power. Young Arthur Fitzmaurice doesn't believe it, even when it seems almost certain that she is implicated in the kidnapping of his father, the Right Honourable Samuel Fitzmaurice, England's Foreign Secretary.

LAST Summer's drought and the preceding cold Winter intensified the search for weather-resistant crops by fifty State and Federal agricultural experiment stations. Plants are being tested indoors and out in climate machines that simulate all extremes of weather -- cold, heat, aridity, excessive rainfall, Explorers are striking through jungles and climbing mountains in a dozen foreign countries in search of plants that grow successfully under unusual weather conditions.

SUMMER in the New York galleries has come with -- perhaps unprecedented -abruptness this year. Summer shows already current have ere this been reported, but will be again referred to, briefly, in the warm-weather advance survey here offered.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP). -- Grand Slam, carrying the silks of the Bomar Stable of Detroit and packing top weight of 122 pounds, conquered a band of fifteen star 2-year-olds in the season's first important juvenile race in the West at Washington Park today.

STAGE FRIGHT: Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, veteran of sixty years on the stage as opera, concert and inspirational singer, faced the lights and cameras for her first motion picture last week -- and succumbed to stage fright. She became confused, forgot her lines and left the set in tears.

New York, largest entrepot for meat products in the country, was stirred last week by a strike against high meat prices begun by rebellious housewives and belligerent butchers. The trouble is now almost entirely confined to the kosher butchers.

Several men were questioned by Assistant District Attorney McGuinness at the Stagg Street station in Brooklyn early today in connection with the hijacking yesterday of a truck containing $25,000 worth of underwear in Bloomsbury, N.J.

PARIS. THOUGH the French textile creators do not present any special fabric showing for the midseason, the Paris couturiers' collections shown at that time are likely to be particularly interesting from the point of view of material and color forecasts.

MOSCOW, May 31. -- The campaign for increased population started this week by the Communist party is the most recent of several efforts and tendencies suggesting that in family relationships the Soviet Union is moving toward the "right."

CALLANDER, Ont., June 1 (AP). -- An action at law to challenge the "State rule" of the Dionne quintuplets may be the next act of their parents in an effort to regain control of the infants, now in their second year and endowed with $200,000 accrued from the sale of various privileges.

Unless there is further socialization and development of education with relation to democracy, the country will face "a dictatorship by default," John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, told 1,000 teachers of adult classes yesterday in the Washington Irving High School.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 1 (AP). -- Early returns from the soldiers' vote on a constitutional amendment containing clauses similar to the United States National Industrial Recovery Act, indicated tonight the measure would fail.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 1. -- Dr. Frederick C. Ferry, president of Hamilton College, will be guest speaker at the 169th anniversary commencement of Rutgers University on Saturday, June 8, it was announced today by President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers.

Vocational guidance will be a feature of the post-examination weeks of the Hunter College seniors. The gayeties of Senior Week will be preceded by a class meeting on June 10, which will be devoted to answering practical questions about the vocational futures of the graduates-to-be.
The German Consulate General here gave out yesterday the following information with regard to payment of the Young loan coupon due yesterday, based on an announcement by the German Government:

MOTIFS inspired by the sea are this year especially prominent in the furnishings of the country home. Curtains and upholstery textiles have designs of ships, anchors and sea gulls; metal garden furniture has a nautical flavor; carpets and rugs are ornamented with rope.

O. HENRY, short-story writer extraordinary, born William Sidney Porter, laid down his pencil twenty-five years ago this week and "went home in the dark" to such reward as awaits a man who has lightened the cares of this world for multitudes of people.

McCOOK, Neb., June 1. -- Reports were received here late tonight indicating that the rampant Republican River was receding after bursting its banks in a flood, accompanied by tornadoes, that caused 37 known deaths and brought assertions from relief officials that they feared at least 250 persons had perished.

PEIPING, Sunday, June 2. -- An eight-point program has been formulated for North China by the Japanese army which will be presented to a conference of Chinese leaders at Hankow about Friday. General Chiang Kai-shek will preside at the meeting.

RELATIVELY few New Yorkers have ever seen a city policewoman -- at least to recognize one -- but now this member of the force ca readily be distinguished, for she has a new uniform, and this Summer she will be on duty at the beaches and other resorts where great crowds gather.

WITHIN 30 minutes' travel from Manhattan lies a public playground area of some 48,000 acres. Parts of this Interstate Palisades Park are known to thousands of New Yorkers; some have been used by them for years; but few of the hikers, campers and picnickers who have refreshed themselves in its great wooded stretches have any conception of the deep recesses that lie behind its more obvious and accessible points.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- House Liberals today opened a campaign to revise the Constitution, asserting they sought to have it meet modern economic needs and the crisis arising from the smashing of New Deal legislation by the Supreme Court.

CALLED in to investigate the kidnapping of a radio crooner, Jerry Todd soon finds that he has a murder case on his hands as well. Only one other person knows that murder has been committed, and that person has the best of reasons for saying nothing about it.

HOSPITABLE country hostesses amass quite a collection of household gifts from grateful guests during the Summer. They're entitled to them -- nobody can deny it. There are many new gadgets that city people can take to them, and entertain hopes of being invited again.

Far more important to the American people than the fact that the Supreme Court of the United States has decided that the NIRA is unconstitutional is what that decision implies. That is, that apparently nobody knows what the laws of the United States are except the Supreme Court.

SIR CHARLES ELIOT and J.W.T. Mason have written two interesting works on the religion of Japan which will bring to the West a further understanding of the religious forces operating in the culture of the Island Empire.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 1. -- Bill Weir, the University of New Hampshire's ace hurler, was driven from the mound in the fifth inning today as the Harvard nine tallied five runs to triumph, 8 to 5.

DENVER, June 1. -- The flood death toll neared forty tonight in Colorado, Wyoming, Texas, Kansas and Missouri. The missing exceeded two score and many of them were believed dead. Property and crop damage estimates ranged upward from a conservative $5,000,000.

THE amateur botanist, and all who would like to be amateur botanists, of this city and its surrounding neighborhoods will gladly welcome this excellent handbook by the head curator of the museums and herbarium of the New York Botanical Garden.

OAKDALE, L.I, June 1 -- To Len Bourdette, Sea Cliff High mile ace, and New Utrecht High School's well-balanced squad went the principal prizes in the second annual La Salle Military Academy interscholastic track and field meet on the academy's picturesque campus today.

HERE is a dashing Western thriller written in Amos Moore's best style. And even if based in part on utterly impossible premises, the reader is kept in such a whirl of excitement and suspense that he loses sight of that fact until the plausible yarn is finished.

BEGINNING today, the air passenger from New York may reach any major city on the Pacific overnight. Heretofore only Los Angeles was attainable by a truly overnight journey, over the lines of TWA, Inc. Now United Air Lines, putting on Boeing 247 D's to compete with the Douglas liners, has announced a new schedule.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- Congressional bonus advocates began to talk today of seeking a compromise in their deadlock with President Roosevelt over full payment of the veterans' certificates.
Manhattan's newly found power was again in evidence yesterday as the Jasper nine hammered three Rutgers pitchers for a total of sixteen hits to gain a 15-to-3 victory at Manhattan Field.

PROBABLY no contemporary American writer has done more to interpret Russian developments to the English-speaking public than has William Henry Chamberlin. His dispatches on current events in the Soviet Union, which appeared in The Christian Science Monitor, have, like those of his distinguished colleague, Walter Duranty of THE NEW YORK TIMES, maintained a high level in journalism.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and subsidiary company reported yesterday a net loss of $133,515 for the twenty-six weeks ended on Feb. 23, after amortization of film costs, depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other deductions. This contrasted with a net profit of $38,855, or 37 cents a share on 103,107 no par shares of $3.85 preferred stock, for the twenty-six weeks ended on Feb. 24, 1934.

CLEVELAND, June (AP). -- Governor Davey, commenting here today on the overthrow of the National Recovery Act, praised its "humane purpose," but made a plea for the preservation of States' rights. He addressed an alumni group of Case College of Applied Science.

MORE seasonal weather brought an upturn in retail trade last week in most sections of the country. In some cases the improvement was not enough to push volume ahead of a year ago, but in others there were gains ranging up to 10 per cent.

THERE actually was an Evangeline, and her memory is to be perpetuated by a national park area surrounding the little Catholic churchyard in St. Martinville, La., where she sleeps, the yuccas waving above her grave and the rippling waters of Bayou Teche crooning a lullaby.

STOCKHOLM, June 1. -- "Prosperity Island" was the name applied to Sweden the other day by a visiting American economist. He took, perhaps, an unduly favorable view of the situation in a country new to him, and which certainly has its problems to grapple with like any other, though they may be hidden to a casual observer.
