BERLIN, June 1. -- The upward movement on the Boerse which already had raised the stock index 15 per cent above the level at the beginning of this year continued today.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, in a general order to his department yesterday afternoon, announced that the Board of Education would open the playgrounds of the city's public schools for use of children after school hours and during the Summer vacation.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 1. -- Lafayette High School of Buffalo, N.Y., and Kent School of Kent, Conn., finished their one-mile national scholastic rowing championship final in a dead heat today on Lake Quinsigamond and became co-champions in the first regatta sponsored by the Schoolboy Rowing Association of America.

WHENEVER radio program policies are discussed, interpreted or endorsed the spotlight is cast upon the cornerstone of American broadcasting. The inscription reveals it is dedicated to "public interest, convenience and necessity."

UTICA, N.Y., June 1 (AP). -- Irving M. Ives, minority leader of the Legislature, asserted in an address here today that the Democratic party rushed its financial program through the recent session of Legislature without giving the people of the State time to offer objections or propose alternatives.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 1. -- The 2,300-year-old tragedy of Euripides, "The Bacchae," was interpreted to an audience of about 900 persons on the Bryn Mawr College campus this evening at a performance designed to present Greek drama as the ancient Greeks themselves did it.

The outcome of the AAA wheat poll was a foregone conclusion. Officials of the AAA, acclaiming the favorable vote as a triumph for "economic democracy," actually are congratulating themselves on their progress toward "bureaucratic autocracy." Once again the American farmer has been sold a gold brick, although he does not know it yet.

A concerted attack intended to topple another important pillar of the New Deal structure was launched here last week when protectionist interests opened fire on the reciprocal trade agreement operations of the administration.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, June 1. -- The arrest by German political police of a Finnish woman, Aino Brander, who was kept in custody for two days in Berlin and treated as a criminal because the police suspected that she had Communist leanings, has caused sharp resentment in Finland and resulted in diplomatic action.

A month ago I wrote to Senator Pat Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, pointing out that administratively NRA was discredited with the courts, and that under the circumstances it would be best to transfer to the Federal Trade Commission the authority of NRA over business cooperation through the medium of exemptions from the Anti-Trust Laws for approved industry agreements.
THERE is, the cable admits, a little of everything coming into London's theatres this week. The evidence:

Wasn't it Mr. Burbank who said that when eggplant was crossed with milkweed the result was pudding? Now is "The Scoundre!" pudding proof of much besides the fact that the eggplant of reason can be overflavored with the milkweed of sob-stuff?

FOUR Carmens, each differing from the others, were visible on the stages of Moscow recently. There was, first, the production of Bizet's opera at the Bolshoi Opera House, a conception that the Moscow News called "scintillating but inclined to be traditional."

ONCE more the place of meat in the American diet is a subject of debate. The relative shortage of meat, the result of drought and other conditions and the protests of buyers in the face of rising prices have brought the discussion to the fore and moreover, have led to the closing of hundreds of butcher shops in New York City.

LONDON, May 10. SINCE the last article in this series was written a week ago, there has been but one new production in London, "The Flying Trapeze," and that preceded the jubilee. Since Monday, when the King drove from Buckingham Palace to the thanksgiving service in St. Paul's, the theatre has been content to rest upon its existing laurels while the population has drifted in dense thousands about the mummated streets.

Everything still is topsy turvy with the Dodgers. Van Lingle Mungo, ace of the staff, was knocked out in the third inning of the first game of yesterday's double header with the Phils at Ebbets Field, but Stengel's boys won that one, 8 to 4, with Lefty Clark at the helm.
ATLANTIC CITY. -- Still fined with Memorial Day visitors, Atlantic City begins a Summer season crowded with a wide variety of business and pleasures.

In connection with the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Pathologists to be held in Atlantic City next Friday and Saturday, an intensive seminar will be held in New York, earlier in the week, on the subject of the early diagnosis of cancer.

NEW YORK hikers are being brought closer to green spaces and purling brooks with the inauguaration of new trains penetrating the beauty spots of this and surrounding States. In addition to hikers' specials, whose destination may be anywhere from October Mountain in Massachusetts to Western New Jersey, there will be the elusive "mystery" train taking off for parts unknown each Sunday morning until after Labor Day.
PARIS, June 1. -- For the fifth successive year, Miss Helen Jacobs failed today to win the French hard court tennis championship. Her defeat surprised experts.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 1. -- Colgate defeated Syracuse in baseball today, 14 -- 6, with every man on the Colgate team getting at least one extra base hit.

IF anybody knows how the Middle West feels about the situation in the United States this year and what the Middle West intends to do with or to the major political parties next year the person in question is William Allen White, the Sage of Emporia.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- James M. Beck, former Republican Representative from Pennsylvania and active in constitutional controversies, declared tonight that any attempt to revive the NRA "would precipitate a constitutional crisis more grave than any since the Civil War."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 1. -- A marble head, believed to be a portrait in sculpture of the Emperor Valerian I, who ruled Rome in the second century, A.D., has been unearthed in the Agora market place of ancient Athens, according to Professor Edward Capps, American chairman of an expedition of the American School of Classical Studies, which is now nearing the end of its annual four months' digging on the site of the Agora.

DREDGES dip steadily these days in the effort of the Federal Government to keep the harbor of New York always up to date. The giant French Line steamship the Normandie will shortly come to New York on her maiden visit, and the huge British liner Queen Mary will enter the transatlantic service next year; hence a preparation of facilities has been necessary.

STANLEY CASSON, an English archaeologist, has here provided a particularly excellent little book for those who want an outline of the fundamentals of archaeology, coupled with information of its latest developments. He has written several books on archaeology and sculpture, was for three years assistant director of the British School at Athens and is now an instructor in classical archaeology at Oxford.

ZOUNDS! Here's "that demmed elusive Pimpernel" again. After cloak-and-swording his way through half a dozen novels or so he appears now as an actual Englishman who went to Harrow with Pitt, knew the Prince of Wales, won the admiration of Nelson, complicated the stream of English poetry by rescuing Wordsworth from the guillotine and had lots more adventures calling for Egads, Gadzooks, and the Savoyard's big, big D.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1. -- June week, the commencement period at the Naval Academy, concluding its ninetieth year, began today with a program of athletic, social and military events.

ST. LOUIS, May 31. -- When the "grass root" Republicans meet in Springfield, Ill., on June 10 and 11 for the "trail blazer" convention that will have a definite bearing on campaign plans for next year, Missouri will be represented by 1,500 delegates, chosen during the past week in the thirteen Congressional districts of the State.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1. -- Army and Navy met in two sports, track and baseball, on the Plains today, and the Cadets won both contests, defeating the Middies, 68 1-12 to 57 11-12 in the track meet, and by 10 to 4 on the diamond.

NOW that we are heading into the Summer calms, when it is the tradition of the cinema to be commonplace, it may be useful to regard the achievement of the past two months. To consider the best films of April and May is to be pleasantly aware of the screen's variety and brilliance in the Broadway film sector.

LONDON, June 1. -- With the Aga Khan's Bahram an even-money favorite to take the Derby at Epsom Downs on Wednesday, never before has one man, according to the betting, had the great classic so much at his mercy. The famous Indian sportsman's other candidates, Hairan and Theft, are equal second choices at 10-to-1, and all other horses named to start are merely "long-odds chances."

Forty undergraduates and twenty-one alumni of the School of Business and Civic Administration of City College have been elected to membership in Beta Gamma Sigma, national honorary business fraternity, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean Justin H. Moore. City College became affiliated with the national fraternity this term and Epsilon Chapter was formed to replace Sigma Delta Epsilon, the college's own honorary business society.

A reduction of $140,000 on the assessed valuation of property owned by former District Attorney Thomas C.T. Crain and members of his family was sought yesterday in an action filed in the Supreme Court.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 1. -- "Follow through as you would in a game of golf, if you don't you will be very much disappointed," Cardinal Hayes said today in an address to the graduating class of Marymount College.

IN the early stages of gardening practically all plants were grown because of their economic value. Such gardens engaged the attention of the earliest horticultural writers. Infinitely slow changes brought the strictly ornamental garden, which did not reach its greatest vogue until the last century.

The great Northcliffe once said something to the effect that it is the dastardly privilege of the newspaper to slug a man when he is down. Your Brooks Atkinson seems to have exercised that privilege beyond the limit last Sunday in his remarks about the Theatre Guild.

WHEN you come to think of it, geographical exploration is only the first step in acquainting ourselves with the earth. It reflects no great credit on the human species that it took it about a million years to find out that the earth is a sphere.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- Concern lest wide variations in grain prices may result from abolition of NRA's code for grain Exchanges was expressed today in administration quarters.

In a letter published by THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 20, Sanders Burch referred to an article on food prices written by Calvin B. Hoover, consumers' counsel in the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, and published in this newspaper on Sunday, May 12.

The spotlight is on Alaska once more. Prominent in developments are the arrival of colonists in an FERA project to place about 1,000 men, women and children upon homesteads in the fertile Matanuska Valley; agitation for an army air base near Fairbanks; increased development of aviation within the Territory, and the McNary bill, passed by the Senate, for the construction of the Alaskan stretch of a highway to connect Southern Alaska with Seattle.

I have been quite interested in reading from time to time your descriptions and references to a water trip by motor yacht through the Erie Canal, St. Lawrence River and return to New York by way of Lake Champlain and the Hudson River. To a complete landlubber it is attractive and would be an unusual experience.

The prospects of trade with Great Britain are improved, but a more definite tariff policy in the United States is required to carry business to its proper volume, according to George E. Krepley, manager of the westbound freight department of the United States Lines.

THE Canadian National Railways operate well equipped traveling hospitals in Pullman coaches, which, in their errands of mercy, cover the 23,000 miles of the company's system. They are in command of an experienced medical practitioner, frequently assisted by a trained nurse.

Senator GLASS has stated that public hearings on the Banking Bill will be concluded on Monday, after which the matter of changes in the draft as it now stands will be discussed by the committee. It is therefore timely to restate briefly and simply the nature of the controversy.

SIXTEEN years ago this June the greatest of all wars was brought to an end and there was negotiated the most comprehensive and elaborate series of treaties and associated agreements ever put into writing. The map was redrawn. A League of Nations was established.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 1. -- Cervantes, 7-year-old bay gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Carver of Westport, Conn., and shown by Mr. Carver, was named champion hunter at the second annual Edgewood Park Horse Show, staged on the grounds of the Edgewood Park Junior College today.

IN this year of Jubilee, perhaps no royal building in England will be of greater romantic interest to the public than Kensington Palace, built in 1689 by William and Mary. Here 116 years ago Queen Victoria was born; here she passed her sheltered girlhood under the tutelage of her indomitable mother, the Duchess of Kent; and here, too, was born the future wife of Victoria's grandson, the present Queen of England.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- A definite decision against any present increase in tax rates was disclosed today by Congressional leaders as they mapped a drive to put a tax bill on the statute books within thirty days.

EDWARD JOHNSON, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, sailed last week for a tour of Europe that will take him to London, Paris, Berlin, Prague, Vienna and Italy. His chief purpose for the jaunt is, in his words, "a search for that rara avis, a fine singer."

THE twelfth annual presentation of awards of the Music Education League, Miss Isabel Lowden, president, will take place at the Town Hall on Tuesday evening, June 11. In all, 482 awards, the gift of Samuel Klein, will be presented.

PROFESSOR FERGUSON has written an elaborate foreword to show that he has not given in this book a mere history of music, such as musical historians have presented for 150 years. Besides the history, he declares that he offers an expanded view of the field more narrowly covered by the many current books on musical appreciation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- Professor Irving Fisher of Yale University said today that he did not agree with Owen D. Young, who testified before the Senate Banking Committee that Title II of the Omnibus Banking Bill should be shelved.

RECENT years have brought a steady stream of books about the Zionist movement and its endeavor to establish a new homeland for Jews in Palestine. books that have looked upon the developments there from every angle and considered it with varying degrees of superficiality or seriousness.

CODE abolition by court decree left automobile manufacturing in a mixed position. More than a year of NRA regulation of both production and distribution finally had reached a stage where conditions were regarded as fairly well stabilized, but subject to change under pressure should occasion arise.

IF you are a student or teacher with $300 or $400 in your pocket, the keys of Europe are yours this Summer. While ordinary tourists make what shift they may with obstinate exchange rates, many a nation is slashing railway fares and visa fees for the privileged intellectual.

TACOMA, Wash., June 1 (AP). -- John H. Dreher, who grew up in the Pennsylvania Dutch country, slept undisturbed tonight for the first time since George Weyerhaeuser was kidnapped a week ago yesterday noon.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 1. -- Miss Hope Knowles of Great Neck, L.I., seeded first in the draw, led the field into the quarter-finals today in the Anne Gumming Memorial Tournament for the girls' tennis championship of New Jersey.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Rebuffed in her effort to gain an amateur standing in the game she took up only two years ago, Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, the girl wonder athlete from Texas, today decided to market her 260-yard drives and personality on the fairways by turning golf professional.

Albert J. Contento, known as Al Howard, a night club operator, and Charles J. (Broadway Charlie) Stern, two of four men arrested by Department of Justice agents in connection with the theft of $185,000 in jewels from Mrs. Margaret Hawkesworth Bell in a Florida hotel last January, were released yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

LONDON, June 1. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today. Outstanding in other markets was continued activity in foreign exchanges. Considerable excitement attended the large volume of business transacted, francs again provided the feature, showing sharp recovery on more confident views regarding the financial situation in France, closing at 74 21-32 to the pound. Dollars also were better at $4.92 1/4.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). -- All the crime fighting forces of the Department of Justice were unleashed today for capture of the kidnappers of George Weyerhaeuser.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition 100 photographs of stage and screen celebrities from the collection of Harold Seton, a member of the society. The majority of the photographs date back to the middle and last decades of the nineteenth century.

They say these Japanese golfers are pretty good, all six of them. Which probably means that they will finish six down at Oakmont. No pretty good golfer will stroll off with the open crown from that field. It will take a crack player, with both arms full of luck.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 1. -- James J. Braddock entertained a crowd of 400 spectators at his training camp today with six grueling rounds of boxing. According to many of the experts who watched him, he is already in fine shape and appears more formidable with each session.

PERHAPS the most difficult problem in the use of flowers for decorative purposes, is that of successful table arrangements. So many horrors are being perpetrated just at present in this field that one almost hesitates to discuss it.

A NEW fuel injector, supplanting the present carburetion system in several types of army airplanes, has been announced by the Air Corps. This new device is deemed of particular interest in view of the rapid advancement and development of fast, long-range airplanes.

IN all medieval history no two linked names are more impressive and provocative of thought than those of Pope Gregory VII and Matilda, Countess of Tuscany. Helen White has taken these two, told the story of the epic fight they waged with Henry of Germany, and, while keeping, in all essentials, to the actual facts, has produced a glowing, large-actioned drama that is not only stimulating but is romantic in the best and widest sense.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The interest of the colony now is focused on the most important event of the June sports calendar -- the Virginia State skeet tournament, which will take place on Friday and Saturday of this week on the Homestead skeet field.

PRAGUE, June 1. -- An account of callous treatment of Austrian young women and girls arrested for distributing forbidden Socialist party literature or attending party meetings is given by a woman who was an Austrian prisoner in the current number of the Austrian Socialist organ Arbeiter Zeiting, which is printed by Socialists in exile in Czechoslovakia.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1. -- Authorities of the United States Military Academy announced today that John D. Bristor of 225 Gregory Avenue, Passaic, N.J., would be graduated No. 1 in the class of 1935 for distinguished excellence during his four years at the academy.

TORTILLA FLAT is the tumbledown Section of the town of Monterey in California. Here live the paisanos, a mixed race of Spanish, Indian Mexican and assorted Caucasian bloods. In Mr. Steinbeck's humorous and whimsical tale they appear as a gentle race of sun-loving, heavy wine-drinking, anti-social loafers and hoodlums who work only when necessity demands and generally live by a succession of devious stratagems more or less outside the law.

Scenes enacted last week at the massive gates of the Bank of France at 1 Rue de la Vrilliere, Paris, when long queues of citizens waited to push franc notes through the wickets for bars of gold, were reminiscent of the dark days here in March, 1933, when our own Old Lady of Liberty Street was besieged by those clamoring for gold coin.

CULTURE NOTE: One of the outlets for the American artistic urge has been plugged. At the order of the Interstate Commerce Commission, railroad refrigerator cars, which have served as canvases for pictured hams, bacon and other meat packers' products, are being repainted.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June l. -- A whirlwind finish by Gene Sarazen, former British and United States Open champion, today enabled the diminutive Italian and Jess Sweetser to defeat Miss Joyce Wethered and Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare in an 18-hole best-ball exhibition at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

ROSS VARNEY, known all along the border as El Tecolote, The Owl, most notorious of bandits, and who could see in the dark, rode north from Texas on the trail of a man who had killed his friend -- and he had just one thought in his head. But as he approached the town of Rayo he met the prettiest girl he had ever seen.
ONE of the novelties of June broadcasting is expected to be the U.S. Army Air Corps-National Geographic Society expedition into the stratosphere.

THAT the great Hungarian poetic drama. "Az Ember Tragediaja." by Imre Madach, although written seventy years ago, should now be presented to English readers in a fitting poetic rendition is a matter of the highest literary importance.

The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the distributions ordered by the directors at their last meetings:

Staging a rally with two out in the last inning, the St. John's University baseball team defeated Savage Institute, 3 to 2, in the final game of the season for both teams at Carey Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The teams played seven inninings by agreement.

OMAHA, Neb., May 31. -- Announcement of results of the wheat poll has given rather emphatic confirmation of the solidarity of AAA support as asserted by the farmer lobby during its recent invasion of Washington. A decisive affirmative vote was anticipated in this section, but the overpowering one-sided nature of the poll exceeded expectations.

Graduating students of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America were told yesterday that the life of a rabbi could be made a happy one despite the "problems" and "perplexities" that face the Jew today. The statement came from Rabbi Benjamin A. Lichter in a baccalaureate sermon at the Seminary Building, 531 West 123d Street.

BERLIN, June 1. -- Germany has no rackets, but the Nazi police have now completed a system of crime prevention by the systematic observation and control of known criminals that is probably far more thorough than the new methods developed by the New York police.

A broken condenser tube cut the speed of the new French liner Normandie to twenty-eight knots for twelve hours yesterday as the world's largest vessel plowed toward this city in quest of the blue ribbon for speed on the Atlantic.

PARIS, Sunday, June 2. -- A German memorandum asking explanations of some passages in the Franco-Soviet treaty has been delivered at the Foreign Office. It asks how certain passages of the treaty can be reconciled with stipulation of the League of Nations covenant and the Locarno treaties and is therefore more juridical than political.

LONDON, May 31. -- The very large section of the British public which believes there should be closer understanding between this country and the United States has been greatly encouraged this week by statements from the highest government sources favoring Anglo-American collaboration.

Considerable confusion marks the wholesale markets as the result of the Supreme Court decision voiding the NRA and the staple wholesale lines are at a standstill, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Prices, however, have not changed, the report says.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine there appeared recently an article entitled: "New Light Shines on the Story of the Bible," by P.W. Wilson. Several statements and inferences are made in the article which need modifying so as to be more in harmony with the well-established results of anthropology, archaeology and biblical scholarship.

Charges that pressure exerted by "big money" interests had influenced Dean Willard C. Rappleye in his dismissal of six students, three technicians and two instructors from the College of Physicians and Surgeons because of their anti-war activity were made yesterday at Columbia University.

THE French Line flagship Normandie, the largest and fastest ship afloat, is nearing New York on her maiden voyage. This notable example of the shipbuilder's art takes her place in the mighty fleet that constitutes the transatlantic ferry between New York and Europe, as the first vessel to exceed 1,000 feet in length.

HARWICH, England, June 1. The big yachts started their racing season today in the Royal Harwich Yacht Club regatta when T.O.M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger Endeavour scored a fine victory over Velsheda, with Shamrock third.

Two score youngsters of Great Neck, who already have learned to splice ropes, manipulate small boats and handle themselves in a real yachting manner, have achieved a rare distinction, according to yesterday's announcement by Philip H. Dennler.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1. -- Through the arrest today of Guy Calhoun, 45 years old, of Indianapolis, Ind., the police made known an attempt to steal a valuable formula for the manufacture of brake linings from the Thermoid Rubber Company.

SOME of the most realistic film criticism being written these days is to be found in the comments of small-town exhibitors in the "What the Picture Did for Me" section of The Motion Picture Herald. Here are a batch of thumb-nail critiques, reprinted with The Herald's permission:

Various members of Congress have advocated that the way to meet the Supreme Court decision against the constitutionality of NRA is the often difficult one of an amendment to the Constitution. For months, in anticipation of the possibility of an adverse ruling, a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee has had under consideration the proposed Costigan amendment.

BOSTON, May 31. -- Two weeks of tension came to a happy climax on Tuesday in Maine. The Federal Allotment Board approved the Passamaquoddy project on May 16. Now that the President has signed the order making $10,000,000 available the people are sure that it is not all a dream.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals picked up a full game on the idle New York Giants and shoved the Chicago Cubs down to fourth place today by winning both games of a double-header, 4 to 3 in twelve tense innings and 4 to 1, before the biggest crowd of the Wrigley Field season, 20,693.

THE momentous decisions handed down by the Supreme Court last Monday have brought into the sharpest focus the question of the relationship among the three branches of the national government and again directed the attention of the nation to the commanding position which the court holds as the interpreter of the document which has been the guiding force in the growth of the Republic.

VIENNA, June 1. -- A report that War Minister Werner yon Blomberg had extracted from Julius Streicher a promise to suspend publication within six weeks of his anti-Semitic journal, the Stuermer, is published in the Weltblatt. This publication has access to private sources of information in the Austrian Chancellery.

A reunion dinner will be given by the graduates of Public School 6, Manhattan, on Thursday at the Hotel Warwick in honor of Magnus Gross, teacher of the first graduating class of the school forty years ago. Richard Kelly of 233 Broadway, one of the graduates of the first class in 1895, is chairman of the dinner committee.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP). -- The fine relief hurling of Ivy Paul Andrews gave the Browns a 7-to-3 victory over the Indians in the first game of a doubleheader today, but the long bat of Earl Averill, who poled two home runs, caused them to drop the nightcap, 4 to 2.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics today estimated the total wheat area for harvest this year in twenty-six counties at 190,954,000 acres, as compared with 185,276,000 acres in 1934 and 191,132,000 acres in 1933.

IN all candor Yeats says that he wrote the material in this book just for the sake of writing after a two-year period when he had not written any poetry at all. So what we have here is simply some five-finger exercises of a genius and the accompanying commentaries.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Forrest A. Harness and Harold Huling, Assistant United States Attorneys General, arrived from Washington today and began preparations for the new trial on June 11 of Samuel Insull, who, with eight co-defendants, is charged with violation of the bankruptcy laws.

Mayor La Guardia was unperturbed yesterday by the suit filed against him demanding his removal from office on the ground that he holds two official positions in violation of Section 1549 of the City Charter. The action, filed on Friday, is based on the Mayor's membership on the PWA Advisory Committee on Allotments, a non-salaried post to which he was appointed early in May by President Roosevelt.

LONDON. -- The presence in London of a few American officials and experts inquiring into the problem of monetary exchanges has started the rumor here that conversations on the subject of stabilization have begun in earnest. This is not true, of course, and the speeches of Mr. Morgenthau and of Neville Chamberlain represent the situation so far as it has gone.

The latest in a series of entertainments arranged for the philanthropies of the Stoopnocrats, member of the Society of Stoopnocracy, will be a supper dance on the Moonlit Terrace of the Biltmore on Tuesday night. The fete will benefit the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and will be a pre-opening celebration for the remodeled Biltmore roof garden.

MUKDEN, Manchuria. -- Manchukuo has declared the export of silver coins and bullion to be illegal, but there has been an astounding amount of smuggling of the metal, especially along the Yalu River between Manchukuo and Korea.

A prompt effort to preserve the good parts of the NRA codes and make them fit the constitutional structure must be made, it was declared yesterday by Charles L. Bernheimer, chairman of the committee of arbitration of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., June 1. -- Governor Nice, in an address to the graduating class at the University of Maryland today, called for maintenance of the constitutional form of government and declared "we must not be led away by the alluring but futile promises of the experimentalist and the extremist."
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 1 (AP). -- The pattern set by the kidnappers of Charles F. Urschel was seen tonight in the kidnappings of George Weyerhaeuser and Edward G. Bremer.

THE 1935 Talbott Festival of the Westminster Choir School will be held Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the school, Princeton, N.J., under the direction of Dr. John Finley Williamson. The festival will be held in conjunction with the annual commencement.

IN this modern world doubtless there are still girls who long for a caveman lover, bold, strong and brutal. A popular magazine tells as fact the story of a little girl of kindergarten age who enjoyed having a small boy drag her round by the hair, by request.

TACOMA, Wash., June 1. -- George Weyerhaeuser, kidnapped heir to a lumber fortune, was released today for $200,000 ransom, and tonight, spurred by indications that they had found a trail, searchers pressed the West's greatest manhunt for the kidnap gang, believed to be that of Alvin Karpis.

Despite the widespread efforts to retain present hour and wage schedules in the primary textile industries, the extremely vulnerable position of several of them at this time, created serious concern, particularly, among cotton goods sellers last week.

THE Franklin Institute in Philadelphia has recently presented the John Price Wetherill Medal for 1935 to Robert E. Naumburg, the inventor of the Visa-graph, through whose agency a scientific miracle is being wrought.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The United States Steel Corporation, in its registration statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission, has declined to disclose individual compensation and stockholdings of officers and directors on the ground that such publication "would be conducive to disturbing the morale of the organization and detrimental to the best interests of the registrant and its stockholders."

IN his new book, "American Messiahs," which Simon Schuster will publish on June 5, the writer, who calls himself "The Unofficial Observer," will consider the important political figures who are operating outside the New Deal, recording their careers, pondering their growing influence and weighing their chances of becoming presidents or dictators.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 31. -- Wisconsin's Legislature is puzzled, even bewildered, over Governor La Follette's Federally approved $209,000,O00 work-relief program, which includes $100,000,000 in aid from Washington. The Progressive-controlled Assembly is responsive to everything the young Governor wants, but the more conservative Senate is in doubt.

The first important women's tennis fixture of the seas takes place next week-end when the Sears Cup matches begin on Friday at the Richmond County Country Club on Staten Island. In anticipation of the event, Mrs. George W. Wightman, tennis mentor, writes that the Boston team will not be picked till the first of the week.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Seventeen per cent of the people of the United States are on relief. But, from State to State, the proportions of people who make up the relief rolls vary widely. They range from 37 per cent in South Dakota to 7 per cent in Delaware.
Fordham's baseball team climaxed one of its most successful weeks of the season yesterday and closed its home campaign with a decisive 10-to-1 triumph over Seton Hall at Fordham Field.

The Supreme Court decision abolishing the NRA will affect even class-room attendance, and public school officials believe there may be an increase in the issuance of employment certificates to children of 14 and 15 years, with a change in enrolment figures.

HARTFORD, May 31. -- The dominant rural majority in the House of the Connecticut Legislature underscored its opposition to the New Deal this week by rejecting two bills urged by organized labor. One was a measure sought in Connecticut for more than a decade to reduce to forty-eight hours the work week for women in manufacturing and mechanical establishments.

The proposed Banking Act of 1935 will be the principal subject of discussion at the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association at Lake George next week-end. Marriner S. Eccles, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, has promised to attend and speak in behalf of the bill, or, if unable himself to attend, to send another official of the Reserve Board to speak for him.

LARNED, Kan. A FARRIER'S forge, sixty-nine years old, that was used to shoe eavalry horses of Indian fighters in the Eighteen Sixties, now helps care for the feet of farm horses. Brought to Fort Larned when that army post was a protection to wagon trains passing on the old Sante Fe trail, it served for twenty years.

Stimulated by more favorable weather conditions, retail buying in various sections of the country last week showed gains over the previous week's figures. Although the decision nullifying the NIRA created considerable confusion in both the manufacturing and distribution divisions, reports from the various Federal Reserve districts indicate that there was little change in industrial operations.

A sharp rally in French Government bonds of 4 1/2 to 12 points marked an otherwise dull market in bond trading yesterday. The Paris loans, which had been weak earlier in the week, responded to the announcement that a new French Cabinet had been formed, under Fernand Bouisson, with full authority to act in the emergency that has been threatening the maintenance of the nation on the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- One of the most immediate results of the Supreme Court decision invalidating Title I of the National Industrial Act was to dissipate completely the "big push" which administration leaders in Congress had started to apply to the remainder of the New Deal legislative program.

With the higher discount issue outstanding, several developments of major importance began to take form at the week-end as retailers and manufacturers here tried to feel their way out of the welter of confusion which followed the voiding of the NIRA by the Supreme Court.

A NEW sedan known as the Country Club model, mounted on a 124-inch wheelbase, is announced by the Hudson Motor Car Company. The car is priced at $880 f.o.b. Detroit. The engine is said to develop 113 horsepower. With an aluminum high-compression cylinder head, which is available at extra cost, it has an output of 124 horsepower.

BETTER times are coming to the fishermen who comb the waters off Passamaquoddy Bay in Maine, for the schools of sardine herring appeared early this Spring and in sufficient numbers to keep both Canadian and American factories busy.
HANOVER, N.H., June 1. -- Dartmouth became the 1935 champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today by taking both ends of a double-header against Columbia by 5 to 1 and 11 to 7.

ROBERT McNAIR WILSON is a Scotch physician who is also a student and writer of history. In this avocation he quickly became fascinated by the Napoleonic period and immersed himself in its study until it has become one of the keenest interests in life.

Nine persons were arrested last night during a skirmish between Newark Collective Theatre, a group of amateur actors, and the Newark police, who objected to an attempt to perform three one-act plays without a permit. All were locked up without bail charged with unlawful assembly.

The recent chain-letter mania seems to have run its spectacular course. In its wake, however, is a series of astonishing requests -- petitions, not for dimes, but whisky, hay, postage stamps, dates with college girls, elephants, political cooperation to bolster sagging party lines.

RYE, N.Y., June 1. -- The waterfront garden of Charles N. Edge at Parsonage Point, this place, was opened to the public this afternoon in the series of garden days sponsored by the Westchester County Children's Association. Mr. Edge received the visitors.

June always brings to Professor von Dunkel's desk a wealth of literature about New England's outstanding charms as a Summer playground. And always it reminds the good Professor how New England confronted him with two of the most difficult puzzles in his entire study of the life and civilization of the North Americans.

BOSTON, May 31. -- Instead of the codes -- interstate compacts. What cannot lawfully be done under NIRA can be done by voluntary agreements among the States. Uniform State legislation should be just as effective as Federal laws.

Mathematics as correlated with poetry and music is demonstrated at the annual mathematics exhibit, on view at Teachers College, Columbia University. Under the direction of Dr. William D. Reeve, head of the mathematics department at Teachers College, the exhibit features hundreds of geometric instruments, graphs, historical illusions, charts, priceless manuscript and pictograms.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses decreed yesterday that the Sanitation Department must stop its dumping operations at Orchard Beach in the Bronx June 8, and, furthermore, that all Sanitation Department equipment must be off park property by that date.

LIMA, Peru, June 1. -- The arrival today from the United States of Martin Conboy, former United States Attorney at New York City, and Ira A. Schiller, attorney representing Hugh Wells of the New Orleans-Tampa-Tampico Air Lines, is expected to speed action in the case involving the detention of four planes belonging to the company which are held here by Peruvian authorities at the request of the United States State Department.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The kidnapping business is on the downgrade. That is the conviction of the Bureau of Investigation officials in the Department of Justice despite the ransoming last week of little George Weyerhauser from the home of his wealthy parents in Tacoma, Wash.

HIGH POINT, N.C., June 1 (AP). -- R.J. Riggs, a 36-year-old filling station operator, was found nailed to a cross near here early today and officers, terming him a "religious fanatic," quoted him as saying he had his young son "crucify" him in a plan to win a reconciliation with his wife.

DETROIT, June 1. -- The triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs will open in Detroit Tuesday for a ten-day meeting. About 4,000 delegates, representing 2,000,000 women, are expected to attend.

When the G-men started shooting kidnappers and gangsters down like the dogs they are, everybody said kidnapping was ended. I wrote THE TIMES that not even the G-men could stop kidnapping so long as the profit motive held out even a long chance to criminals. I predicted just what would actually happen, and immediately afterward Robinson kidnapped Mrs. Stoll and is still at large with the ransom money.

A 14-year-old boy from the section of Paris that corresponds to New York's East Side will step ashore tomorrow when the French liner Normandie docks on her first trip here. He is Roger Echogut, and in his visit he is acting as "ambassador of good-will" from the boys of Paris to the boys here.

HERE are the 125 spots on, under and above Manhattan or just outside it which are, to the eye of Vernon Howe Bailey, most worth looking at. Persons who live outside of town may, if they have not too much pride of hearth, welcome this volume, with its attractive pen drawings, as an easy means of making an armchair visit to the city.

DETROIT, June 1 (AP). -- Santan, the Seagram Stable's star juvenile, beat Beauflower by a nose in a driving finish today to win the $2,000 St, Clair stakes, five-furlong dash for 2-year-olds at the Fair-grounds.

ONE of my farmer friends in North Dakota recently said to me: "The trouble with you scientists is that you come around just in time to tell people why they've failed. Now why don't you tell them before it's too late?

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Administration officials today were reported to be considering a specific plan for a "quick" method of amending the Constitution by what would be the equivalent of a popular referendum, so that the people might, within sixty days, declare their will on the problems posed by the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case.

Opinions on the ruling of the United States Supreme Court regarding the NRA will be voiced in sermons today. There will be baccalaureate sermons preached in several churches. Many parishes will observe the annual Children's Day. The Children's Day program in some instances will mark the close of Sunday schools until Autumn.

TOKYO, June 1. -- The Chinese central government, like the Japanese civilian government, is anxiously working for peace, but the military leaders on both sides are recalcitrant. While Akira Ariyoshi, Japanese Ambassador to China, and Chang Tso-pin, Chinese Ambassador to Japan, at a luncheon celebrating the exchange of Ambassadors were reiterating their desire to promote a rapprochement, army authorities were asserting the independence of Foreign Office control.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The next step in development of AAA farm plans will be formulation of a continuing program for wheat.

Of the letters, relative to the controversy regarding the patent system, the one of S. Colum Gilfillan, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 12, is interesting, because it reflects the socialistic point of view regarding patent property.
ON BOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, June 1. -- The fleet's departure from Pearl Harbor yesterday marked the end of the least active but probably most important phase in the annual manoeuvres.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- In a brilliant stretch drive of sub-par golf, Sid Brews, hard-hitting South African invader, today captured the Philadelphia P.G.A. invitation tournament and shot into a frontline position among the threats in next week's national open.

GENEVA. -- Doubt regarding the durability of what recovery the world has had, belief that national efforts have gone about as far as they can and that world action is needed for further progress is expressed in the annual report of Harold Butler, director of the International Labor Office.

ALGERNON BLACKWOOD, the creator of Dudley and Gilderoy, has written a tale which instantly courts comparison with those perennial classics of childhood dear to the hearts of adult readers. Indeed "The Fruit Stoners" itself may conceivably become such a classic -- containing as it does some of the fragrance and innocence of youth, and a certain amount of wistful nonsense, and a great deal of excellent and musical prose writing.

After the opening of "Sketch Book" tomorrow night, the Summer doldrums of the stage will set in (possibly until late next month) and the theatre will heave a long sigh. Looking, then, considerably into the future, we see:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 2. -- Diplomas will be awarded tomorrow afternoon to sixty-five graduates of Upsala College, East Orange, at commencement exercises beginning at 2:30 o'clock. Dr. Arlo A. Brown, president of Drew University, will deliver the address.

The insecurities of the unemployed are more pronounced in the present mechanized civilization than they ever were in the "pre-technical age," the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr of Union Theological Seminary said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.

The excellent expose of the lack of a "good-neighbor" policy on the part of the United States given this evening over the radio from Washington by Arthur Krock, and of our unreliability when professions are put to the test, makes admirable information for those uninformed on our historical fickleness in obligations.
DETROIT, June 2 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin predicted tonight that the Blue Eagle of NRA, or its equivalent, would rise, like the Phoenix of old, from its own ashes.

OXFORD, Neb., June 2. -- Darkness slowed the work of rescue crews in the desolate flood-riven Republican River Valley tonight, with the number of known dead placed at eighty-six but with scores as yet missing.

Announcement of the grant of fellowships and scholarships totaling $19,800 in the Advanced School of Education of Teachers College, Columbia University, for 1935-36 was made yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, director.
MANILA, P.I., June 2 (AP). - Senator Jose A. Clarin President pro tempore of the Philippine Insular Senate, died here today after a two-month illness caused by a lung tumor.

WASHINGTON, June 2. - The interesting room where the Supreme Court has sat for seventy-five years and which it will occupy for the last time tomorrow will be preserved in its present form and availed of only on special occasions, Senate leaders indicated today.

GENEVA, June 2. -- The Swiss people decisively rejected by a vote of 566,242 to 424,878 today a recovery plan which was intended to meet the depression along some New Deal lines, especially in regard to governmental borrowing, spending and centralization.

All sight-seeing buses, banned since March 15 from Times Square, Herald Square and other focal midtown points, are now being barred from parking in crosstown streets, it was learned at police headquarters yesterday.

The French Chamber voted out Premier FLANDIN, ostensibly because he asked sweeping powers with the right to govern by decree. Thereupon,M. BOUISSON formed a new Cabinet and announced that he would seek a vote of confidence on his proposal to demand sweeping powers so that he could govern by decree and send the Deputies home.

PARIS, June 2. -- England and Germany today divided honors in the French hard-court singles championships, Fred Perry, the English ace, taking the men's crown and Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling the women's title.

More than 1,600 persons yesterday morning heard the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, for six years pastor of the Westminster United Church, Winnipeg, Canada, preach his first sermon as pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

A wilderness more impenetrable than our pioneer forefathers ever knew is faced by man today, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Several large local professional traders here who had been on the bull side and controlled the market for the May delivery were still bullish on corn last week and were credited with buying July corn on weak spots, as many parts of the Corn Belt had too much rain, which is delaying planting of the new crop.

Residents of the Connecticut sector of the New York metropolitan region will read the latest dispatches from Hartford with mixed feelings. On Friday the State House of Representatives approved a bill providing for the immediate construction of the Merritt Highway through Fairfield County, paralleling the Boston Post Road, but several miles inland.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP). -- So-called small business men in Pennsylvania saw the lion's share of the retail trade go to their large competitors last year.

The Merchants Association of New York and the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, through their presidents, advised employers yesterday not to take advantage of the Supreme Court's NRA decision to reduce wages and increase working hours.

Evidence that game fish problems are receiving serious consideration in the plans formulated by the National Fishery Advisory Committee is provided in a report forwarded recently to Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A total of 4,260,423 families were receiving emergency aid under the general relief program in April, or 3.6 per cent fewer than in March, according to telegraphic reports, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, said today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 2 (UP). -Syracuse won both ends of a double-header with the Newark Bears today, but it took ten innings to decide the second, 8 to 7, after the Chiefs had romped home in the first, 10 to 4.
DETROIT, June 2 (AP). -- The Tigers pounded four White Sox pitchers for fourteen hits today to win, 10 to 5, and split the two-game series here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 (UP). -- After viewing the slow-motion camera's picturization of the wreckage caused by the latest of the West Coast track and field tornadoes, Eastern track officials today consoled themselves by reviewing the mighty feats of their eight I. C. A. A. A. A. champions.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Declaring that the decision of the Supreme Court in the NRA case must be interpreted as a severe and stunning blow to economic advancement and the progress of social justice, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, tonight called a special meeting of the executive council of that organization for Thursday.

DURHAM, N.C., June 2. -- Duke University's magnificent new chapel was dedicated this evening at an impressive service. This morning Dr. William P. Few, rounding out twenty-five years as president of the university and its predecessor, Trinity College, preached the baccalaureate sermon.

Four essential features that answer the question, "What Is the Church For?" are worship, fellowship, instruction and service, the Rev. Dr. Herbert Booth Smith of the Los Angeles Emanuel Presbyterian Church declared yesterday as guest preacher at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

More than 4,000 members of the Holy Name Society of the Department of Sanitation, attending the fourth annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor yesterday morning, heard speakers assert that religious faith was the "greatest guarantee against the spread of communism" and other radical thought in the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 2. -- Max Silverstein of New York, Grand Master of the Independent Order B'rith Abraham, pleaded for Jewish unity as the organization opened its annual convention here today on the Garden Pier.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., .June 2. -- Delegates were arriving here today for the" Opening of the third annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute at the Hotel Traymore tomorrow. More than 1,000 executives of light and power companies in all sections of the country will attend the four-day session.
After the exhibition they had witnessed yesterday at the Stadium, the 20,000 fans left the park satisfied that they had seen, for the first time this year, the true strength of the Yankees.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,978,656,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Folklore came into its own yesterday as perhaps never before in mid-town Manhattan when folk-dance and choral groups representing some thirty nations assembled on the Central Park Mall to engage in an elaborate festival sponsored by the Folk Festival Council of New York.

Much of our thinking today must be radically altered, because it is based on "petrified morality," the Rev. Edmund Melville Wylie said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth street and Park Avenue.

Contracts let for residential building during the first two weeks of last month were 80 per cent ahead of the corresponding period in May, 1934, in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reports. In the area covered by the report there was a total of $22,072,500 for the first fifteen days of May this year, as compared with, only $12,421,500 during the corresponding fortnight last year.

A plan for relieving the tax burden on real estate by substituting a State-wide selective sales tax to be collected by the State and redistributed to the cities on the basis of assessed valuations was announced yesterday by the People's Alliance of Greater New York, Inc., of 11 West Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- A five-run ninth-inning rally, climaxed by Jimmy Collins's homer with the bases filled, and some effective relief pitching by Dizzy Dean gave the St. Louis Cardinals their third straight victory over the Cubs, 6 to 5, today before a crowd of 8,956.
A new double-feature program consisting of "Air Hawks," featuring Wiley Post, the aviator, and "Justice of the Range," with Tim McCoy, will open this morning at the Criterion.

LONDON, June 2. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, German special commissioner for disarmament questions, who a few days ago received ambassadorial rank from Reichs-fuehrer Adolf Hitler, arrived in London by air today to confer with the British on Herr Hitler's expressed desire to have naval tonnage up to 35 per cent of the present British strength, disregarding the Versailles treaty.

Mayor La Guardia has abandoned his plan to ask for a PWA loan of about $57,000,000 for construction of the Sixth Avenue subway, it was indicated yesterday. Instead, he will endeavor to finance the project with an issue of long-term city bonds.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Trade interests in all lines in this territory have made strenuous efforts to prevent demoralization as the result of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the NRA. Announcements by many leaders suggest a desire on their part to keep employment and wages at the present levels so far as possible and to work together for the maintenance of a good volume of business.

More than 500 persons attended the closing exercises yesterday of the Religious School of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun at its Community Centre, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street. Dr. Israel Goldstein, rabbi of the congregation, presided, and the speakers included Isidor S. Schweitzer, chairman of the school board; Edgar H. Bauman and Rabbi Samuel M. Segal, the educational director.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- It is a feeling in the grain trade in the United States and Canada that there is too much government regulation for the markets to operate for the benefit of the consumer as well as of the producer. Supplies in the United States are the lightest that the trade has ever seen.

ST. CHARLES, Va., June 2 (AP). --Three big rattlesnakes refused to bite the Rev. George Hensley, Holiness revivalist, who says his "faith cure" is healing a previously bitten arm, as an excited throng shouted and prayed at open-air services today.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Lard stocks in Chicago at the close of May were 44,439,427 pounds, a decrease of 8,257,650 pounds in the month. A year ago, stocks were 117,099,926 pounds, present stocks showing a decrease of 72,660,499 pounds in the year.

PARIS, June 1. -- The formation of a new government has immediately produced a changed tendency on the Foreign Exchange market and there is every reason to hope that it will cause a turn for the better in public opinion. It must not, however, be forgotten that the fears for devaluation of the franc were caused by the budget deficit and Treasury difficulties.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 2. -- Miss Joyce Wethered. Great Britain's premier woman golfer, scored the first triumph of her American tour today when her partner, Sid Brews. South African open champion, putted sensationally to post a 72 over the difficult Ridgewood Country Club course.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Receipts of cattle here last month were 140,000 head, or 62,000 fewer than a year ago. The number was the smallest for any month since March, 1933, and the smallest for a May since 1886.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- An offer of $10,000 for the perfection of a device which will eliminate the hazards of flying in fog was made today by Godfrey Cabot, vice president of the Federation Aeronautique Internationale and pioneer member of the National Aeronautic Association.
BOSTON, June 2. -The Giants suffered their first shut-out of the season today and Clydell Cattleman went down to his initial defeat after a string of five successes.

Showing to excellent advantage, Brian Boru, sprightly brown gelding owned and exhibited by Miss Frances Robbins of Southampton L.I., carried off the hunter championship in the third annual Queens County Horse Show at Hillside Park, Flushing, yesterday.

Jenny Ballou, book reviewer and short-story writer, of New York City, and E.P. O'Donnell of New Orleans, have received the first Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowships of $1,000 each. Miss Ballou intends to write a novel with revolutionary Spain as a background.

The United States Supreme Court's decision invalidating the NRA will be beneficial in the long run because it abandons arbitrary wage and price fixing in the opinion of the National City Bank as expressed in its monthly bulletin, published today.
Schwabacher Co. have moved to 52 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Department of Commerce applied today to the Division of Applications and Information of the President's work relief program for $58,759,000, to be expended on airport improvements throughout the country, including the installation of devices enabling "blind landings" in bad weather.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 2. -- A clear, hot day and one of the largest opening day gatherings the club has had saw the return of polo to .the Sands Point Club today with Greentree starting fast to defeat Roslyn, 13 to 6.

Popular views about the "Sunday driver" are borne out by the detailed figures on motor accidents. The casualties of 1934 were discussed by Representative LUNDEEN of Minnesota in a speech in-the House a fortnight ago.

Tackling what it describes as "the hardest certificate mortgage problem in the State" the State Mortgage Commission announced plans yesterday for reorganizing the $24,349,026 Series C-2 issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2. -- Closely-contested polo games were the order of the day at the Meadow Brook Club, for two of the three six-period matches played today were decided by the slim margin of one goal, while the other resulted in an 8-all deadlock.

American holders of certain types of defaulted German securities are in a position to enforce payment in full of the principal and interest, according to a statement yesterday by Jacob Chaitkin of the law firm of Chaitkin Martinson, who represent holders of Gelsenkirchen Mining Corporation, Siemens Halske and other German dollar bonds.

Commodity futures were generally easier last week following the decision of the Supreme Court holding the NRA codes void. Sugar futures suffered the widest decline in more than a decade, with about a quarter of a million tons traded. In the cash markets rye was higher, while wheat, corn, flour, cocoa, dairy products, lard, tin, cotton, silk, wool tops, rubber and hides were lower.

Persons who worked with Jane Addams -- social workers, peace advocates and a host of others representing twenty-nine organizations in which she had been active -- went to Town Hall last night to pay tribute to her memory.

NEW HAVEN, June 1. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.3, which compares with 82.7 the week before, 82.3 two weeks before, 82.2 three weeks before and 82.1 four weeks before.

CHECKING up on the rising rookie pitchers: John Henderson Whitehead of the White Sex is a side-arm, fast-ball pitcher. Lefty Joe Sullivan of the Detroit Tigers throws a zippy knuckler. Cy Blanton of the Pirates has a good fast ball and a Wicked, curve. "Vitamin V" Tamulis of the Yankees relies on a fair curve and grand control.

ON BOARD THE U. S. S. PENNSYLVANIA, at sea, June 2. -- The United States fleet was steaming eastward at twelve knots tonight after a quiet Sunday, the first lull in the navy's arduous war game in many days.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine submitted his annual report for 1934 to Mayor La Guardia yesterday, showing an increase of major crimes by about 15 per cent over 1933. Murder and manslaughter cases decreased, but felonious assault, assault and robbery and burglary cases increased.

NEW ORLEANS, June 2. -- The cotton market here alternated between periods of fair activity and extreme quiet last week. There was considerable early buying of new-crop positions, principally January and March, by government agencies in replacing cotton sold to the trade by the cotton pool.

Smilingly, Harry Pfleger, 14-year-old sufferer of a complication of virulent bone and blood diseases, prepared for his eighty-third blood transfusion, his eighty-ninth operation, last night in the solarium on the fifth floor in New York Hospital, overlooking the East River at Sixty-eighth Street.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 2. -- Forty-seven young women will be graduated tomorrow from the Kent Place School for Girls in this city. The commencement will be held on the campus, with an address by Henry Noble McCracken of Vassar College.
ALGIERS, Algeria, June 2 (AP). - A searching party found the bodies of an Englishwoman and an Englishman on the scorching Sahara sands today and rescued two Frenchmen who were near death from thirst.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- Representatives of 400 local labor unions, claiming a membership of more than 200,000, prepared today for a wave of strikes to prevent wage-cutting and extension of hours as a result of the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the NRA codes.

LONDON, June 1. -- Formation of the new French Government on a national basis was followed today by a substantial rise in francs, the Paris rate dropping to 74 5/8 francs to the pound, while the discount on three-month forward francs fell from 6 3/4 to 3 francs to the pound.

Columbia University seniors will hold their annual promenade this evening in John Jay Hall, starting at 9:30 and continuing until 2. Edwin K. Large, permanent vice president of the senior class, is general chairman of the prom. Under his direction John Jay Hall has been decorated with college colors, fraternity banners and blue and white flags.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The constitutional powers of the Federal Government are amply sufficient to care for any existing emergency, "if faithfully and patiently employed," Senator Borah said tonight in a radio speech over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A total of $245,393,700 of the 4 per cent bonds of 1933-51 of the Home Owners Loan Corporation called for redemption on July 1 have been exchanged for new four-year bonds of that corporation carrying 1 1/2 per cent interest, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Treasury's deficit at the end of the fiscal year, according to late estimates, may be under $3,500,000,000, as compared with a forecast of $4,869,000,000 made by President Roosevelt in the budget message which he sent to Congress in January.

SYRACUSE, June 2. -- Reasserting what he termed the duty of universities to present the truth, regardless of the political, social or economic interests cast upon it, Chancellor Charles W. Flint opened Syracuse University's two-day commencement program this morning with an appeal to the graduating class to help preserve academic freedom.

As a native Puerto Rican, friendly toward the American people, who sincerely hopes that the United States will continue as a stabilizing power among the various political factions of the island, I wish to speak my own mind on this matter.

A "political hobby headed by an irresponsible cleric," may lead to disastrous consequences in the form of anti-clerical movements and in lawmaking through minority pressure groups, the Rev. Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins, professor in the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his sermon at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

IN THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 2, 1934, a headline appeared: "French Acquit 5 Shot for Mutiny in 1915; Widows of Two Win Awards of 7 Cents Each." A world of profoundly bitter irony lay behind the headline; just how bitter Humphrey Cobb shows in his "Paths of Glory" (Viking Press, $2.50), which is the Book of the Month Club choice for June.

Because of their high standard of merit, the ten leading scores submitted for the Elfrida Whiteman Scholarship will be heard a second time by the judges before the selection of the winner. Paul Whiteman founded the scholarship, giving the winner two years at a music college or institute, in memory of his mother.

The decline on the markets, following the Supreme Court's unanimous decision against the NRA as it was administered, is one of those incidents which have to be considered psychologically. The decision involves a change of methods. To those who believed that the act and the manner of administering it were responsible for the business recovery which occurred, the change foreshadowed at least uncertainty.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 2. -City Hospital officials tonight acquitted an imprisoned black widow spider from California of implication in the suicide attempt yesterday of Stephen Lisowski and asserted that the man is dying from an overdose of a narcotic obtained for him by a nurse at the hospital.

Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, called on the institution's graduates at its annual commence merit exercises yesterday to help dispel the theory, which he termed unfounded in history, that the Jews are a race.

Everything about the Normandie reflects the spirit of this generation. Her size, her speed of some thirty knots, her promenade deck for dogs, her kitchens that cover twenty-three acres, her first-class dining room so big that it could accommodate the hull of a liner of the Eighties, her twenty-three elevators for various duties, her funnels, so capacious that each could embrace the two Holland tubes -- these are the very embodiment of technical progress.

Warmer weather last week resulted in an increase in the distribution of Summer merchandise, particularly women's sports wear. Retailers sent orders to the market for immediate deliveries of spectator styles and repeated calls were received for natural and high-colored linen suits and for coats in various materials in white and pastels.

BOSTON, June 2. -- Babe Ruth received his unconditional release as a member of the Braves tonight from President Emil E. Fuchs after a day of strife in the Boston club's office, during which the Bambino announced his intention of requesting permission to go on the voluntary retired list.
ON BOARD THE LINER NORMANDIE AT SEA, June 2. -- New York will get its first chance to see the great French liner Normandie early tomorrow afternoon.

The cotton futures market was dominated most of last week by the NRA upset. When the decision was announced on Monday, prices declined only moderately, but they continued their downward trend on the two following days. On Friday, following the holiday closing, they dropped 61 to 67 points on the President's statement of the consequences that might be expected from a discontinuance of crop control.

BERLIN, June 1. -- The Gold Discount Bank's new issue of promissory notes, as a means of absorbing superfluous cash and providing commercial banks with short-term investment, had an immediate effect on the money market. Within five days it is estimated that 150,000,000 marks of new notes have been sold.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP). -- The Indians pushed the Browns deeper into the American League cellar today, defeating Hornsby's men, 6 -- 2.

BERLIN, June 1. -- The centre of the week's financial interest was in the French franc crisis, the outcome of which is regarded as determining the future of the Dutch and Swiss currencies. With a collapse of the gold-bloc rates it is considered that negotiations for general stabilization could be initiated with some prospect of success.

BABYLON, L.I., June 2. -- The re-enactment of historic naval encounters in miniature is being considered by the Long Island State Park Commission for the edification of visitors to its extensive park system.

Police Commissioner VALENTINE has removed one unhappiness from the lot of a policeman. Anticipating the hot weather, he has already mollified its atrocities by deciding against the warmth that was added last year by the "problem" of the shirt of the coatless policeman.

TACOMA, Wash., June 2 (AP). -- The home from which little George Weyerhaeuser was missing for a week in the hands of kidnappers today underwent a change. The window shades, down for a week, were raised and curtains were drawn back.

Humor and pathos are often near together. They blend inextricably in a coalition of Republicans of the Right and Democrats of the Right, suggested last week by a couple of respected, stern and unbending Democrats. Chief Justice PATTANGALL of Maine resigned in order to devote himself to the union of Jeffersonian Democrats and Republicans.

SHANGHAI, June 2. - Foreign circles in China, are becoming deeply perturbed over what they regard as the indifference of their home governments concerning the gigantic scope of the projected Japanese expansion in North China.

Tom Zachary pitched nine innings and struck out nine men and Jimmy Bucher and Danny Taylor hit home runs at Ebbets Field yesterday. Unfortunately, however, the Phillies won the game from the Dodgers, 7 to 5.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 2. -- Forty-two years old and still going strong, William Tilden added another major crown to his almost countless string of conquests at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP). -- In a game marked by rousing finishes on both sides, the Athletics beat the Senators today 3 to 7. The Senators, in their last time at bat, tied the score at 7-all, but the Mackmen came back in their turn to push over the one run needed to gain their fourth straight.

The annual commencement activities of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College at Stapleton, S.I., began last night with services in Trinity Lutheran Church on Beach Street, Stapleton. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Francis Sutter, acting president of the college.

Nearly a million men, women and children left their homes here yesterday to visit near-by beaches and resorts. Attendance figures at the beaches were the highest in recent years for early season crowds.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 2. -- A plea for greater tolerance for the beliefs of others was made today by President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University in his baccalaureate address to members of the graduating class in Kirkpatrick Chapel.

The importance of the magistrates' courts in this city has often been stressed. It cannot be stressed too highly. In the court of a magistrate more people in New York get their ideas of justice and the law than anywhere else. As things are, the magistrates' courts can best be improved, not by statutes or charter provisions altering their jurisdiction or procedure, but by seeing to it that their personnel is the finest obtainable.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Volney Davis, former convict, lieutenant of Alvin Karpis and indicted with him in the $200,000 Bremer kidnapping, is believed to have been hurried out of Chicago by airplane today under a heavy guard of Department of Justice agents.

The award of twenty-two Summer scholarships for graduate study in the history of art in Paris and of thirteen scholarships to undergraduates for a year's study at the Sorbonne, Paris, was announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education, 2 West Forty-fifth Street.
CARPINTERIA, Calif., June 2. -- Twenty-five pioneer stage drivers and their wives feasted at a barbecue here today, swapping yarns about hellish roads and high water, and Black Bart, the road agent.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The next forty-eight hours should tell whether it will be possible to enact legislation coping with the problems presented by the Schechter decision before the NIRA expires June 16.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 2. -- The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Auxiliary Bishop of Boston, and Shane Leslie, Irish author, made addresses at commencement exercises of the University of Notre Dame today.

ALBANY, June 2. -- Seven legislative enactments intended to minimize the danger of fraudulent practices by unscrupulous real estate brokers and salesmen, and strengthen existing license laws, have brought wider powers to the State Department, Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, said today.

The new 3-cents-a-day plan for hospital care in the metropolitan area was endorsed as a constructive step toward meeting the high costs of illness in a statement signed by ninety New York physicians, which appeared yesterday in the first issue of the Associated Hospital Service's bulletin.

The New York State Bankers Association sent yesterday to its members a statement of recommendations for changes in the proposed Banking Act of 1935 calling for a reduction in the amount of the annual fee for deposit insurance and for postponement or modification of Title II of the measure.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 2. President Gabriel Terra was fired upon while visiting the Maronas race course today and was wounded slightly.
PROSPERTOWN, N.J., June 2. -Amelia Earhart, whose aerial exploits have thrilled the world, made her first parachute jump here today. She dropped from a height of 115 feet.

Jose de Capriles of the University Fencing Club, the national junior epee title holder and former collegiate champion, added the national outdoor epee crown to his honors in a day-long competition yesterday on the strips of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island by taking four of five bouts. Thirty-four competed for the laurels.

TOKYO, Monday, June 3. -- With the removal of Yu Hsueh-chung and his division of old Manchurian troops from Hopei Province, the situation in North China is likely to improve, some observers here believe. News from China is viewed as indicating that Chiang Kaishek's aim is to avoid a quarrel with Japan.
Spiritual guidance is as important for youth during vacation time as through the school term, the Rev. Thomas L. Graham declared yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Anglo-American division of the University of Moscow Summer session, which opens in Moscow July 16, will include 350 men and women, representing every phase of American education, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 2 (AP). -- The largest balloon ever built was unloaded today at the bottom of a deep natural bowl in South Dakota's Black Hills, from which the second National Geographic-Army Air Corps stratosphere flight will start, perhaps this week.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The status of important pending legislation in Congress is as follows:
Two small boys went for a joy ride yesterday morning in an automobile that had been parked at the curb in front of the apartment house in which they lived at 600 Academy Street.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP). -- Power of the courts to hold laws unconstitutional today prompted Senator Norris to describe American Government as "a government by injunction."

Developments in France where the Chamber of Deputies refused the request of Premier Flandin for full Dowers to defend the franc, resulting in the collapse of the Cabinet, stirred the foreign exchange market here last week.

Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said yesterday July 1 would be the effective date of the new law regulating "private service bureaus" which help fee-paying applicants to obtain car registration and driving licenses.

BAY SHORE, L.I., June 2. -A Brown, 25 years, old, a parachute jumper, of 140 1/2 Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn, was critically injured late this afternoon when he fell 1,000 feet into the waters of Lake Ronkonkoma while making an exhibition jump.

Admonishing the graduating class to lend ethical and spiritual leadership to the world rather than become "professional and hired defenders of Jews," Rabbi Stephen S. Wise yesterday conferred three honorary degrees and ten Rabbinical degrees at the tenth annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.
