PENDLETON, Ore., June 2. -- A motor-car load of hard-riding suspects in the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping apparently slipped through the guard lines of a formidable police army in Oregon's Bad Lands today, but the great man hunt continued with an ever-widening scope.

LONDON, June 1. -- Because of its dramatic suddenness, the United States Supreme Court's decision on the NRA codes startled financial and business interests here and momentarily led to some confusion and apprehension. This found reflection principally in the commodity markets, where prices fell sharply.

HEWLETT, L.I., June 2. -- Charley Shelden of Siwanoy and Mrs. A.U. Hodney of Quaker Ridge won the New York State mixed foursome golf championship at the Seawane Club today when they defeated Ray Torgerson and Miss Ruth Adel, representing the Queens Valley Club, 4 up and 3 to play, in the eighteen-hole final.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, June 2. -Although the Yevtitch government, in its anxiety to create the impression that the dictatorial epoch is at an end and the Croat Peasant party returned to the Parliament it has boycotted since January, 1929, has launched stories that the Opposition bloc would today decide on its parliamentary program, the Congress of the bloc has formally decided as the result of the recent elections to continue to boycott Parliament.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A remarkable parallel between Abraham Lincoln's opposition to the Supreme Court's decision in the Dred Scott case and President Roosevelt's sharp comments on the implications of the Schechter case decision was disclosed today by an examination of the speeches of the Civil War President.

Alexander J. Robertson, member of the New York Stock Exchange; Lloyd W. Georgeson, C. Edwin Warner and Henry Evans Gray have announced the formation of Robertson Georgeson, with offices at Fahnestock Co., 1 Wall Street.
Yesterday was the ninth and final day of the seventh Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition. Officially, it ended at dusk; actually, it lasted longer.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The text of Senator Borah's radio address tonight was as follows:

PITTSBURGH, June 2. -- Now that the decision of the United States Supreme Court on the National Industrial Recovery Act has deprived the "code of fair competition for the iron and steel industry" of all legal force, it is uncertain what, if anything, the steel trade will do as a body pending consideration of the subject by counsel.

QUETTA, India, June 2 (AP). -- Shocks, some of which were fairly severe, continued to shake this earthquake-stricken region today. One started a big mountain slide outside the city, but no further casualties were reported.

A scale model of the Spanish Castillo Cave, recently excavated by archaeologists as an example of the culture of 40,000 years ago, has been placed on view in the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced yesterday. The model, which includes a reproduction of the ancient Roman settlement of the town of Puente Viesgo, represents the steep slope of Castillo Peak in the Cantabrian Mountains and the cave high above the village.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 2. -Champion Leading Lady of Wildoaks, the lovely wire-haired fox terrier bitch which is the star of the kennels of Mrs. R. C. Bondy Goldens Bridge, N.Y., today won for the fifteenth time the honor of being named best in an America all-breed dog show.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 2. -- A challenge to youth to aid in setting up a new quality of human relationship in order to "live a good life" was directed to the graduating class of Swarthmore College today in a baccalaureate sermon by Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 2. -- A sunny week-end has brought many New Yorkers to East Hampton inns.

DELHI, India, June 2. -- Quetta, Baluchistan capital and once beautiful city of 60,000 inhabitants, which was devastated by an earthquake Friday with the loss of more than 20,000 lives, including 200 Britons, is being abandoned, and some of the ruins are being dynamited.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 2. -- Wilbour Eddy Saunders, acting headmaster of the Peddie School since February, will be installed as headmaster tomorrow morning in the Baptist Church here. Dr. Alfred E. Stearns, headmaster-emeritus of Phillips Academy of Andover, Mass., will make the principal address.

BERLIN, June 2. -- The progress of the House of Commons debate on the proposed Western European air pact appears to fit in with German expectations only so far as these concur with the British desire for early conclusion of an air accord complementing the Treaty of Locarno.

Fifty-three of the nation's leading swordsmen, grouped in their respective specialties of foil, saber and epee, have designated to commence training for places on the American Olympic fencing team to compete in Berlin next Summer. The personnel of the squad was announced yesterday by Leon M. Schoonmaker, president of the Amateur Fencers League of America and chairman of the committee in charge of preparations.
Recently I had occasion to spend a few hours in one of our magistrates' courts. Several years have elapsed since I visited one. I was astounded at the change that has taken place.

Marietta College in its own centennial celebration is beginning today what should be the first step in the observance of the 150th anniversary of the passing of the Northwest Ordinance of 1787. This document "belongs with "the Declaration of Independence and "the Constitution," as Senator HOAR said, "one of the three title deeds of American constitutional liberty."
Although several games still are to be played in the Eastern Inter-collegiate Baseball League, Dartmouth clinched the title by winning both games of its double-header with Columbia on Saturday.

An increase of 25 per cent in rents paid to rooming house owners by the Home Relief Bureau for cases lodged with such owners was demanded by I. William Garfield, attorney for the Greater New York Rooming House Owners, Inc., in a letter addressed yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, Emergency Home Relief Director.
LAKEHURST, N. J., June 2. -- Four persons were killed and eleven were injured in two automobile accidents this afternoon in Ocean County.

Non-resident aliens should be made exempt from taxes on profits made through trading in commodities or securities in order to stimulate our trade with other nations and to increase domestic business, according to a report to be presented on Thursday at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 29 there appeared four letters to the editor unanimously voicing opposition to the Wheeler-Rayburn bill. Although the objections by your four correspondents varied, I believe that the bugaboos contained therein embrace a common superficiality and exemplify widespread public misconception of the true issues involved and therefore should not go unchallenged.

LARCHMON, N.Y., June 2. -- Arthur Knapp, sailing Melville Q. Griffiths's Kenboy, again led the Interclub fleet in the first special Sunday regatta of the Horse Shoe Harbor Yacht Club today Twenty-five boats, of various classes competed in the day's events.

Informed opinion in building circles points to the salvaging of the best features of the NRA and the creation of an industry-controlled method of dealing with the problems left in the wake of the Supreme Court's decision, according to Myron L. Matthews in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.
Among the passengers due today from the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Stuttgart are:

The dramatic story of how a peaceful agricultural valley in Southern Nebraska was suddenly inundated by a raging flood was told by survivors early this morning in a short-wave broadcast from McCook, Neb., over WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The sum of $32,000 has been contributed toward the guarantee fund of $50,000 required for the Lewisohn Stadium series of concerts, which begins on June 26. At a meeting of the concert committee yesterday, at the home of Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, plans were discussed for raising the remaining $18,000.

In the first four months of this year the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service cared for 1,944 communicable disease patients in a total of 39,688 cases, according to a report made public yesterday by Miss Marguerite Wales, the general director.

Summaries of travel conditions supplied by ship lines and tourist agencies and borne out by the monthly survey of the American Express Company, indicate that June will set a new high mark in passenger traffic for recent years. This month is generally considered a yardstick in gauging the prospects for the Summer season, and travel men already feel that this year's figures will be the best since the onset of the depression.

In answer to Mr. Hamlin's suggestion of a three-cents-a-day plan for dental care, may I point out that, whereas hospital care can be provided against in such a manner because it is not a certainty, dental care is required periodically, and although it cannot reasonably be met by a rigid plan, it can and should be prepared for by budgeting.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 2. -Premier Mohammed Tewfik Nessim Pasha's Cabinet, whose position has been shaky for the past fortnight, is safe again, at least for a few months.

VIENNA, June 2 (AP). -- Vice Chancellor Prince Ernst von Starhemberg punctured rumors that he already was Austria's dictator or was planning to assume dictatorial powers by publicly pledging loyalty today to Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg.

Secretary of Labor Perkins returned to Washington early this morning after two days of conferences here on means of preserving code labor gains. She left confident that the situation was not "entirely hopeless" and that voluntary agreements and legal authority to enforce contracts would assure maintenance of many NRA advances.

NEW ROCHELLE. N.Y., June 2. -- Cardinal Hayes will preside at the twenty-eighth commencement of the College of New Rochelle tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock, when degrees will be conferred upon 151 young women.

In his twenty-two seasons in the major leagues -twenty as a regular player and two more on part-time duty -Babe Ruth not only amassed a total of seventy-six records to attest his prowess as a player, but also established himself as the greatest gate attraction ever in the national pastime.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., June 2. -- Two polo games were staged at the Norwood Country Club today. In the first, Freddie Fleischmann's Primrose four dropped an 8-7 decision to Milton Untermeyer's Evergreen team, and in the second Meadow Farms downed the Norwoods, 5 -- 2.

Favored by almost flawless Spring weather, nearly 1,000 students, accompanied by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and other faculty members, marched across the college campus and converged upon St. Paul's Chapel yesterday afternoon to participate in the baccalaureate services that opened the 181st commencement exercises at Columbia University.

LONDON, June 2. -- King George's combined birthday and jubilee honors list, issued tonight on the eve of his seventieth birthday, gives no clue to any contemplated changes in the government. In the peerage there are six new baronies and one promotion, but none is a reward for services in the Cabinet with the suggestion that services are to be terminated.

Consumption of cotton in the first nine months of this season, from Aug. 1, last, to April 30, was 19,145,000 bales, compared with 19,288,000 in the corresponding period last season and 18,194,000 two seasons ago, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2. -- Assailing hypocrisy, whether in citizenship or religion, Rear Admiral Sydney K. Evans, in the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of the Naval Academy, declared there was "good reason to believe that our national pastime is not baseball or football, but the all-year-game of, in rough phrase, 'passing the buck.'"

Formation of a new group, the League of Democratic Voters, with John Romayne as executive member, was effected yesterday to oppose Dennis J. Mahon, Tammany leader of the Ninth Assembly District, at a meeting at 2,574 Broadway.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Favorable weather conditions for the crops, with considerable improvement last week, led to liquidation and a lowering of prices on the Board of Trade. Prices were at the lowest of the season on wheat and oats, while corn and rye were slightly above the low level.

Your editorial "Another Conference?" refers to the most important problem awaiting solution by the world's governments today. The writer of this editorial question is rather timid, however, when he says that "the world's trade barriers have to be reduced" when they should be entirely removed, and world free trade should take the place of the cumbersome and expensive system of exchanging the world products today.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 2. -- On the campus of the National Farm School, overlooking the institution's 1,200 acres of fertile Bucks County farmland, trees were dedicated this afternoon in memory of fifty-one persons, active in the advancement of American Jewry.

A group of men on the beach at Arverne, Queens, yesterday morning saw a woman drown after her effort to force her 3-year-old son to die with her had been frustrated by a rescuer who fought her off from the boy.

MOSCOW, June 2. -This is commencement season in Soviet Russia as well as in the capitalist world, and for the first time since the Bolshevist revolution graduating students are being honored with class-day exercises.

TACOMA, Wash., June 3. -- A motor car found abandoned in Seattle was disclosed tonight to be a vital clue in the government's determined drive to trap George Weyerhaeuser's kidnappers, now indicated as being members of a Northwest criminal gang.

Backed by Reconstruction Finance Corporation funds, eighty-five banks and life insurance companies joined hands here yesterday to make available to investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates loans which are expected to aggregate $50,000,000 or more.

THE Boston blow-off was a jolly party. Leave it to the Babe to do things on a grand scale. When he picked a fight with Judge Fuchs it wasn't over any rowboat. No, siree! It had to be the Normandie, the biggest ship afloat. If the dispute had been about architecture, the Babe would have made it the Empire State Building that came between them.

The Sorkin Music Company, which has been in Philadelphia for eighteen years, is to move its business to larger quarters at 251 Fourth Avenue, where a floor of 6,200 square feet has been rented. The company is a jobber and wholesaler of musical instruments.

BERLIN, June 3. -- The Boerse opened today in a reactionary mood, due to strengthening of the franc, which pushed inflationary fears into the background. The losses for the day rarely exceeded 2 points, but spread over the entire list, with heavy industrial and electricals leading the decline.

In the interim of hesitation last week the House of Representatives cut its sessions short. Democrats were averse to debate until they knew what they were required to say. Fortunately, the absence of business did but spur the pursuit of an old pleasure. On Friday the House met at noon and adjourned eleven minutes afterward until Monday.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 3. -- If President Roosevelt had been let alone, he probably would have led us into better and more prosperous conditions, George F. Johnson, chairman of the board of Endicott Johnson Corporation, shoe manufacturers, told 17,000 of his workers who gathered in two parks in Johnson City and Endicott after work today to voice their approval of company policies.

ATHENS, June 3. -- General George Kondylis, War Minister, said today on his return from an electoral tour in Thessaly that a plebiscite on the proposed restoration of the monarchy would be held thirty days after next Sunday's elections and that a 75 per cent majority would be necessary before former King George could be asked to return to the throne.

The city has abandoned arithmetic and is trying to prove that two and two make only three in its unification negotiation with the Interborough and Manhattan Railway companies, Nathan L. Amster, president of the Manhattan company, declared in a statement issued yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a farewell dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for Mr. and Mrs. Earle K. Williams, who are sailing today for Europe. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Price, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Carpenter, Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Zabriskie, Mrs. Madison Lewis, Mrs. Peterson Phinney, Miss Christine Brown, Wesley Moore, Richard Smythe and Robert Loughborough.

Fraturtina Grabowski, 49 years old, of 56-02 Sixty-first Street, Maspeth, Queens, a widow with seven children, was arrested last night charged with beating her son, Chester, 13, to death with a poker. Mrs. Grabowski was locked up in the Glendale police station to await arraignment today in Ridgewood magistrate's court on a charge of homicide.

HAVANA, June 3. -- Senoras Xidmara O'Halloran and Conchita Valdivieso and Emilo Pinel, Honduran Consul, were acquitted today by the court-martial now sitting at San Seivrie military post in the trial of twelve members of the Joven Cuba captured on May 8 following a battle with armed forces at Fort Morrillo, near Matanzas, when Dr. Antonio Guiteras, former Secretary of the Interior, was killed.

Not the least proud of the hundreds of passengers who streamed down the gangplanks of the Normandie was Roger Echogut, a 14 year-old French boy, who, until offered the ocean voyage by the Paris Soir and the French Line, had never before been outside of Paris.

Mme. Albert Lebrun, wife of the President of France, and others of the French delegation that arrived yesterday aboard the liner Normandie were guests of honor last night at a dinner given by the City of New York in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. About 850 persons attended.

Under a very capable ride by Jockey Don Meade, Alvin Untermyer's Gold Foam yesterday captured the featured Napeague Purse at Belmont Park, with the favorite Silversmith three parts of a length away and Gallant Prince third. Meade's quickness in jumping his field at the break probably decided the issue then and there.

The great new French liner Normandie completed her maiden voyage safely yesterday afternoon and brought the continent of Europe a few hours nearer to the United States. The world's largest ship had proved she was faster than all her older rivals.

Professor Irwin Edman of the Department of Philosophy delivered the annual oration at the public ceremonies of the Columbia College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, held yesterday afternoon in the Harkness Academic Theatre at the university.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Without explanation and in few words the Supreme Court denied today a request of New York City for a review of its fight to have its contracts with the Interborough Rapid Transit Company construed and enforced by State courts and also to prevent Thomas E. Murray Jr., Interborough receiver, from repudiating the company's 999-year lease of the Manhattan elevated lines.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The RFC will adopt a new policy of filing its own railroad reorganization plans with the Interstate Commerce Commission for roads in financial difficulties in which it holds a financial interest, Chairman Jesse H. Jones stated today in discussing Western roads whose own plans for reorganization have been proceeding slowly.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on May 29 shows decreases for the week of $8,000,000 in total loans and investments, $32,000,000 in time deposits and $56,000,000 in government deposits, and an increase of $66,000,000 in net demand deposits.
BERLIN, June 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of May 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, addressed the fifty-nine members of the graduating class and more than 400 guests of the Horace Mann School for Boys yesterday at the school's annual commencement exercises in its gymnasium.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday afternoon that he would appoint Harold H. Corbin of the law firm of Miller, Boston Owen, a Deputy Assistant District Attorney to gather the evidence for the investigation of rackets by the March grand jury of New York County.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3. -- Executors of the estate of the late Dr. John T. Dorrance lost their fight today in the Federal court for a preliminary injunction restraining New Jersey from collecting inheritance taxes amounting to $12,247,333.

The Maharajah of Kapurthala, one of the ranking Princes of Northern India and one of the wealthiest men in the world, arrived yesterday on the Normandie to spend about ten days visiting in New York and Washington. He was accompanied by his second son, Prince Amarjit; a secretary, an attendant, a valet and a cook.

CONCORD, N.H., June 3 -- Arthur P. Morrill, who formerly was Speaker of the New Hampshire House of Representatives, president of the State Senate and member of the Governor's council, and had been candidate twice for the Republican nomination for Governor, died last night at his home here after a long illness.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3. -- King Peter has received from a Polish schoolboy inventor named Biajenkowski a small plane that is run by electricity. It was brought from Poland by Senator Popovitch, who represented Yugoslavia at Marshal Pilsudski's funeral.

TROY, N.Y., June 3. -- Miss Anne Morgan, president of the American Woman's Association and a commander of the Legion of Honor of France, received the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters at the commencement exercises of Russell Sage College today.

VIENNA, June 3. -- Many more arrests were made today in connection with the Illkor, illegal Nazi news sheet. The wives of Dr. Hermann Senkowsky, a high employe of the Ministry of Finance, and Dr. Erich Stiassny, former Nazi newspaper man, who were seized last week, were among those arrested.

QUETTA, India, June 3. -- There was another earth shock of moderate intensity in Quetta today, and survivors of Friday's disaster stood spellbound as they saw a large distant hill that was a landmark of the district split asunder.

Although steamships cannot yet compete with the thirty-hour Atlantic crossings of airplanes, present-day speeds would seem miraculous to the persons who acclaimed the record crossing of the Savannah in twenty-six days in 1819.

The realization that his days as a regular player were at an end and his disinclination to fill the role of a promotion figure in the twilight of his career -- these were the influences back of Babe Ruth's sudden decision to sever relations with the Boston Braves and put what he thinks is only a temporary halt to his baseball days.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 3. -- Former President Herbert Hoover told the members of the Drake University graduating class today that they were entering life "at one of the most crucial periods of American history since the Civil War."

The numerous times you have praised President Roosevelt of late for his actions in vetoing the Bonus Bill reminds me of a drowning man grasping for a life line. You cannot find many opportunities to praise our President, but when such an occasion does arise you overdo it.

A "poison squad" consisting of four young women and sixty-eight young men volunteers at the New York Homeopathic Medical College has been undergoing tests to determine the effects of certain poisons. This was revealed yesterday by Dr. Linn J. Boyd, head of the department of pharmacology of the college, at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Homeopathy at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Normandie's maiden voyage proved her an extraordinary ship, a new triumph in maritime design and engineering. The world had already heard of her colossal size. Much had been written of the luxury of her appointments, of the beauty and grace of her lines, and of her record-breaking speed, but what probably impressed observing passengers most was her qualities as a ship.

The creators of the New Deal seem to have failed to distinguish between the literal and the metaphorical meanings of the term. They have the noblest of motives, but they seem to think that a New Deal in the metaphorical sense can be handed to the people in about the same way that a new deal can be made in poker.

ROME, June 3. -- At least thirty African subjects of Italy and an undetermined number of Ethiopians are reported to have been killed in one of two clashes on the Eritrea and Italian Somaliland frontiers. Both conflicts are said to have been caused by Ethiopian incursions into Italian territory.

A pageant depicting the history of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson, was staged yesterday afternoon by the student body as part of the celebration of the college's twenty-fifth anniversary.

MONTREAL, June 3. -- Women are denser in the head than men and "thick headedness" is often associated with thick hips, Dr. Hector Mortimer, research associate in Biochemistry at McGill University, told the American Neurological Association opening its annual meeting here today.
BALTIMORE, June 3 (AP). -- Jack La Rocca allowed nine scattered hits tonight and withstood a ninth-inning threat as Newark gained a 5-to-4 victory over Baltimore.

Exhibitions opened yesterday at the Ferargil Gallery, the Gatterdam, the Marie Sterner and the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club, 21 East Seventy-sixth Street. At the club is being shown work by school children of the Fifteenth Assembly District.

George Turtle Brokaw, retired lawyer and sportsman, who died on May 28 last, named his widow, Frances Seymour Brokaw of 60 East Sixty-seventh Street, residuary legatee and an executor in his will, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, June 3. -- Planes roared across the skies and speeding ships furrowed trails across blue waters today as the United States Fleet engaged in spectacular tactical exercises some 1,800 miles west and south of San Diego.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, speaking at the annual class day exercises of Columbia College yesterday afternoon, urged members of the graduating class to "keep young" and to lead a life full of service to their fellow-men.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- President Roosevelt signed the Farm Credit Act of 1935 today and administration officials immediately hailed it as offering an opportunity for many tenants to buy their own farms.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- Two teams tied for first at the Essex County Country Club today in one of the biggest pro-amateur best-ball golf tournaments ever held by the New Jersey P.G.A. The leaders in a field of forty teams were Bill Malcolm of Essex County, paired with Jack Sharkey of Crestmont, and Johnny Kinder of Jumping Brook, paired with Russell Hoblitzell of Colonia.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 3. -- A public holiday has been declared at Beechworth, Victoria, for June 15, when T. Parkinson will begin pushing S. Evans in a wheelbarrow from Beechworth to Mount Buffalo Chalet for a wager of $100. All Victoria is eagerly watching the preparations for the contest, and one conservative newspaper publishes a column-long article expressing the feelings of the wheelbarrow.

BUENOS AIRES, June 3. -- The Stock Exchange had a boom today as a result of the government's inflationary measures in connection with the establishment of the new Central Bank. Sales of securities mostly government bonds, exceeded 7,000,000 pesos, which is equivalent to a $7,000,000 day on the New York Stock Exchange.
PRAGUE, June 3. -- For the first time since the beginning of kidnapping of anti-Nazis on foreign soil by German political police a victim has been freed following a foreign protest.

Leonard Hartman, metropolitan clay-court titleholder, led the field into the quarter-final bracket yesterday, in his quest for the Brooklyn tennis championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. The former Columbia player disposed of George L. Titus, home-club champion, 0 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Probably the groups which have formed in the capital since the President last Friday discussed the need of new Federal sanctions to meet modern social and economic conditions are samples of the divisions into which the whole people of the United States have fallen on the great forthcoming issue.

The gold bloc crisis came to a spectacular end yesterday when the currencies of France, Switzerland and the Netherlands rallied strongly, routing speculators who had counted upon their early collapse. The rally cut off the flow of gold from Europe to the United States.

Joseph A. Greenfield, former Deputy Commissioner of Purchase, who has been seeking to succeed Alderman David A. Mahoney as Democratic leader of the eastern part of the First Assembly District, won the unanimous support of the twenty-four election district captains last night, at a meeting in the Young Men's Tammany Club, 48 Madison Avenue.
Last night the annual Beaux-Arts Institute of Design traveling scholarship in sculpture, valued at $1,200, was awarded for the twelfth and last time.

The builders of the Normandie provided against all kinds of hazards, and if they had only known they would have done their best to prevent their fine new ship from doing serious injury to Babe RUTH. Yet the Babe need not rest too heavy on the conscience of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique.

BOSTON, June 3 (AP). -- While his right hand was still tingling from Babe Ruth's hearty farewell handshake, Bill McKechnie, manager of the sorely beset Boston Braves, today branded the newly retired home-run slugger as a detriment to his ball club.

The modern trained nurse must be able to minister to the mental worries of patients through a knowledge of psychology and psychiatry, Dean Effie J. Taylor of the Yale School of Nursing declared last night at the opening of the annual convention of the League of Nursing Education.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 3. -- Senator A. Harry Moore, speaking at the Peddie School commencement in the First Baptist Church this afternoon, made his talk on opportunity and referred to the problems that confront us and which will have to be solved or met by the younger graduates, because the older generation does not seem to do so.

American readers are at present most interested in economics, with fiction second, according to a survey report made in the current Wilson Bulletin for Librarians. By far the favorite style of writing is the "condensed-factual." Individualistic and "witty-epigrammatic" styles are next in popularity.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- President Roosevelt told Donald R. Richberg not to dismiss the NRA employes and made known that he had called conferences for tomorrow with Congressional and Cabinet leaders. He conferred with Speaker Byrns and with work relief leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Julian Ortiz will entertain members of the Pennsylvania Society of Mayflower descendants at Balmy, their residence in Greenville, Del., on Saturday afternoon. They will be assisted in receiving by their daughter, Mrs. Forrester H. Scott, and Mrs. Casper Gordon Sharpless.

The body of Professor Lorenzo Dow Covington, explorer and Egyptologist, who was considered an authority on the history of the pyramids and the Sphinx, lay unclaimed yesterday in the city morgue at Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- A decision that work relief projects for which the cost of materials is low will receive preference in apportioning the rest of the $4,000,000,000 fund, a course adverse to some large projects proposed for New York City, was made today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments, which met with President Roosevelt at the White House.

PARIS, June 3. -- Premier Fernand Bouisson will present his Cabinet to the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow with a demand for "extended powers" to act without parliamentary control until Oct. 31 for defense of the franc, restoration of finances and improvement in the economic situation, and there is every expectation that he will get a large majority.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LONDON, June 3. -- Startling and convincing revelations by a number of owners and trainers on what is going to happen in Wednesday's great race at Epsom Downs were made today at the London Press Club luncheon, over which Major J.J. Astor presided, and almost immediately the Aga Khan's Bahram became the odds-on favorite at 10 to 11 for the English Derby.

Sunday's Swiss referendum on economic policies has a highly interesting bearing on the European "gold bloc's" position. This plebiscite was not called to pass judgment directly on the devaluation question, but the proposals submitted were of such a nature that, according to prevalent opinion, their adoption would have made currency devaluation inevitable.

SELINSGROVE, Pa., June 3. -- A plea to the graduating class of Susquehanna University to "break with tradition and precedent," if necessary, in order to accomplish "worthwhile" things was voiced today by Governor Earle in the commencement address.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 3. -- Columbia's oarsmen had the Hudson to themselves for the last time tonight, as Coach Hugh Glendon sent his varsity and two freshman boats upstream for an easy paddle on calm water. Syracuse, scheduled to arrive today, postponed its departure and will not reach Highland until tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Supreme Court today agreed to rule next Fall on the constitutionality of part of another New Deal measure -- the Home Owners Loan Act of 1933.
BALTIMORE, June 3 (AP). -- A renewal of the Pimlico Futurity as one of the country's rich stakes for 2-year-olds was announced today by Matt L. Daiger, secretary of the Maryland Jockey Club.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- An agreement providing for continuation in the commercial treaty with Germany of sections other than those containing unconditional most-favored-nation clauses was signed today by Secretary of State Hull and Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador.
Money market persisted in its quiet state. Business was chiefly of a routine character and quotations unchanged for all classifications.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 4. -- The consensus here now is that if the danger of a coup by the Japanese army in North China existed it has been headed off by the civilian authorities.

As if in proof that their outburst of long-distance hitting the day before was anything but an accident, the Yankees continued their robust clouting at the Stadium yesterday. To the complete discomfiture of the Philadelphia Athletics and to the vast entertainment of 8,000 New York well-wishers, they again found the range for one home run, two triples, two doubles and four singles.

Legal action is planned against Columbia University to bring about reinstatement of the six students and three technicians who charge they were dismissed from the Columbia Medical Centre because of their pacifist activities, Osmond K. Fraenkel, counsel of the New York City committee on academic freedom of the American Civil Liberties Union, declared yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden gave a tea at their home, 7 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon in honor of the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, who came here from a pastorate in Winnipeg last Friday and on Sunday took up the pastorate of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Control of the Penn-Southern Power Company, created to own five former Insull operating companies in Eastern States on behalf of creditors of two of the bankrupt holding companies has been sold to E.P. Furber of Boston for an amount exceeding $900,000.

Nineteen individuals, including Joseph (Socks) Lanza, reputed "czar" of the fresh-water fish market at Peck Slip, and eight corporations, two of which are trade associations and one a labor organization, went on trial yesterday before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson and a jury for violation of the Anti-Trust Laws.

Many extreme things have been said about the NRA decision by the Supreme Court, but no one has proposed to disregard or defy it. Until it is modified or reversed, it is the law of the land and must be observed. This is conceded even by those whom it most deeply offended.
LATONIA, Ky., June 3 (AP). -- Mudlarks had their inning at Latonia today. Heavy rain over the weekend resulted in two substitute races and reduced the various field to six and seven contestants.

LONDON, June 3. -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald now expects to leave London for his home in Lossiemouth, Scotland, on Friday after the adjournment of Parliament for the Whitsuntide recess and immediately following the King's acceptance of his resignation as Prime Minister.
Industry and business pressed their efforts yesterday to maintain observance of NRA wage and labor standards and code rules of fair trade practices on a voluntary basis.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 3. -- Long Jim Barnes, whose competitive golf is now limited, came back into the winners' column today as he and Paul Cavanagh of the South Bay Club, Bay Shore, captured the Long Island Golf Association's pro-amateur tourney at the Garden City Country Club.

SALEM, N.H., June 3 (AP). -- The 3-year-old filly Pantoufle sped to victory at Rockingham Park today, covering the mile of the featured Lexington Purse in 1:38 2-5, one second behind the track record.

The American Veterans Association, which has been fighting the proposed advance payment of the bonus, was urged by its publicity and advertising committee last night to back legislation in the present Congress that would make the adjusted compensation certificates negotiable for their current value.
Warren Hull, who has appeared in musical comedy and has been heard over the radio with Beatrice Lillie, has been signed by Warner Brothers and will leave for Hollywood within a few days.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- The upward surge of the Cardinals ended today when they dropped a 6-to-2 decision to the Cubs for their first defeat in seven games. The defeat set the champions four full games back of the pace-setting Giants, who were idle.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 3. -- Alex Watson of Hudson River and Fred Moore of Dunwoodie, who used to play together in Scotland, joined forces today in a pro-pro event of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club and won the competition with a dazzling 65, seven under par figures.
BOSTON, June 3 (AP). -- A. Barry Bacon of Boston was elected president today of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, at the annual meeting attended by about 6,000 members.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 3 (AP). -- Glad, he said, to "get it off his chest," Volney Davis, member of the Barker-Karpis gang, pleaded guilty here today to conspiracy to kidnap Edward G. Bremer, St. Paul banker, for $200,000 ransom.

The next time Gerard Ingram, 9 years old, of 21 Gautier Avenue, and his chum, Harry Killian, 11, of 221 Harrison Avenue, both of Jersey City, decide to walk from the Bronx to their homes across the Hudson they are going to follow the sun and they are not going to ask directions of a single New Yorker.
Employes of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads held their first flower show yesterday in the auditorium of the Y.M.C.A. in the Pennsylvania Station. There were 108 entries.

Although the Securities and Exchange Commission originally requested that all applications for permanent registration of listed securities be filed thirty days before the statutory deadline, July 1, corporations may still submit their applications and have them declared effective before that date, according to information which the Stock Exchange has received from Washington.

BUENOS AIRES, June 3. -- The Chaco peace negotiations are on the verge of a complete breakdown. There was little prospect tonight that they could be held together even long enough to permit inauguration of the much-hoped-for direct negotiations between the Bolivian and Paraguayan Foreign Ministers.

The New York City Alumnae Association of the Bryn Mawr Summer School for Women Workers in Industry made public yesterday a report criticizing the Byrn Mawr board of directors for barring the workers' school from its campus this year.

The New York Cotton Exchange yesterday re-elected John H. McFadden Jr. as president. Mr. McFadden is senior partner of George H. McFadden Bro. and served the Exchange as vice president for three years, before becoming president last year.

The second annual fly and bait casting tournament for the metropolitan amateur championships will be held on Conservatory Lake in Central Park June 15. Entries are not restricted to contestants from the metropolitan area and representatives of New Jersey and Connecticut clubs again are expected to compete.

Total newspaper advertising linage of Manhattan and Brooklyn stores showed an increase of 2.5 per cent in May in comparison with the same month a year ago, according to Media Records, Inc. The total linage last month was 3,061,759, as against 2,987,320 in 1934.

Official greetings from President and Mrs. Roosevelt to Mme. Albert Lebrun, wife of the President of France, were transmitted on board the Normandie yesterday morning by Richard Southgate of the Protocol Division of the State Department.
Purchase of a North Bergen factory corner featured the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday:

BUFFALO, June 3. -- A proposal of Federal pensions for the Confederates was made as New York's veterans of the Civil War gathered here today for the annual State encampment, Grand Army of the Republic.

The isolation of a new hormone that seems to control the water balance of the body in the same manner that insulin controls the sugar balance, and that relieves a form of diabetes, known as diabetes insipidus, was reported yesterday at a seminar on early diagnosis of cancer at Memorial Hospital, by Dr. Russell S. Ferguson, director of the urological research laboratory of Memorial.

STAATSBURG. N.Y., June 3. -- Challenging President Roosevelt's position on the Constitution and the NRA decision of the Supreme Court. Ogden L. Milts in an address here tonight said the President, "our most eminent neighbor," "yearns" for the powers of government such as exist in other countries.

At the annual meeting today of stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, Christy Payne, vice president, treasurer and a director, will retire, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Payne, who has spent his entire business life of forty years in the Standard Oil group, retires under the company's annuity plan in furtherance of a desire made known to his fellow directors some months ago.

LONDON, June 3. -- King George celebrated his seventieth birthday anniversary today, and as he had fully recovered from his recent chill he participated in the brilliant annual ceremony of trooping the color in honor of his birthday.

In the dullest bond market since Feb. 11 United States Government loans rallied moderately yesterday. They closed 1-32 to 6-32 point higher. Transactions throughout the entire list on the Stock Exchange totaled $6,692,300, compared with $8,574,800 on last Friday.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- All interests were in the market for hogs today because of the light receipts, and prices were 5 to 10 cents a hundred-weight above Friday's level. All grades of hogs shared in the advance. The top price, $10.10, was 5 cents above the level at the close on Friday and 10 cents under last Monday.

Barnard College seniors held their annual promenade last night at Barnard Hall, which was decorated with the college colors, blue and white. Dancing began at 9 and continued until 1:30 with an intermission at midnight for supper.

Columbia University will confer 4,463 degrees in course upon students and post-graduates at the university's 181st annual commencement exercises today. In addition, 392 diplomas and certificates will be awarded.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 3. -- The yacht Veracity sailed for Cocos Island yesterday with a crew representing Treasure Recovery, Ltd., the British stock company whose previous expedition was ousted by Costa Rican troops last year.

LONDON, June 3 (Canadian Press). -- Derby maintained its place at the top of the county cricket championship table today, defeating Hampshire by an innings and 104 runs. D.M. Smith gave a brilliant batting display for the winners, hitting up 225 runs.

Three cripples of the original group of six who had been besieging the offices of the Emergency Relief Bureau at 902 Broadway since last Wednesday, finally obtained a forty-five-minute interview yesterday with Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and director of the bureau.
Non-citizens would be restrained from making street-corner speeches under an amendment to the Code of Ordinances filed yesterday by Alderman Lambert Fairchild.
Muriel Carlson, 10 years old, of 1,731 Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, was notified yesterday that she was the winner of an Irish Hospital Trust Sweepstakes residual prize worth about $30,000.

Mgr. M.J. Lavelle last night presented the Cardinal Hayes Awards for Literature, sponsored by the Catholic Writers Guild of America, to the winners from among fifty entrants from Catholic colleges of the metropolitan area. The presentation was made at the Guild building, 128 West Seventy-first Street.

PITTSBURGH, June 3. -- With a few exceptions the 139 professionals and 23 amateurs who will start the annual chase for the national open golf championship on Thursday played a complete round over the 6,981-yard Oakmont course today and all agreed the 300-odd traps are only incidental hazards compared with the fast, velvety greens.

The man who was lost overboard in the storm which struck the Norwegian yacht Sandefjord, bound for Newport to engage in the Newport to Bergen, Norway, ocean race, was 27-year-old Kaare Tveter, it was learned yesterday as some of the details of the tragedy at sea came to light.

Mme. Albert Lebrun, the central figure in the city's welcome of the Normandie, seemed to be mildly bewildered yesterday by the fervor of the reception, but thoroughly confident that she was among friends.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- His proposal for quick ratification of a constitutional amendment to circumvent conditions such as were created by the Supreme Court's decision in the Schechter case was described tonight by A. Mitchell Palmer, former Attorney General.

About $120,000,000 was spent on work relief here in the past twelve months, the works division reported yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, on the occasion of the first anniversary of the division's operations.

The markets assumed yesterday a more confident tone as the selling movement of last week in securities and commodities, following the upset of the NRA, seemed about spent. News that the gold-bloc nations had tightened the defenses of their currencies gave some assurance.

PINE BEACH, N.J., June 3. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman will be the principal speaker at commencement exercises of the Admiral Farragut Naval Academy here tomorrow morning. The exercises will begin at 10:30 o'clock, Gov. Hoffman also will present the Harold G. Hoffman Medal for General Efficiency to a student not yet named.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- A sharp attack on public utility holding companies, with the words "robbers," "thieves" and "swindlers" used frequently to describe them was made in the Senate today by Senator Norris, author of the TVA Act and arch foe of the so-called "power trust."

MEXICO, D.F., June 3. -- At least one hundred and fifty persons were drowned today in the villages of San Pedro and Actopan, twenty miles from the capital, when a cloudburst was followed by the overflowing of the Actopan River, causing a landslide in which many houses on a hill were buried.

The Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on March 31 a net income of $2,448,150, including $89,140 profit on bonds and debentures redeemed and after all charges, including $42,698 loss on exchange.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- Miss Kathryn Bragaw of the Essex County Country Club led the field by one stroke at the end of the first round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship at the Rock Spring Club today. She had an 87.

The proposed Federal regulation of the freight rates of ships, American and foreign, serving American ports was defended as a boon to American shippers and a protection against indiscriminate rate-cutting, in a statement yesterday by Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, ship owners and operators.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- A long fight to subpoena records of the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh in connection with Andrew W. Mellon's income tax case was won today by the government.
Robert W. Capps of the Zimmerman, Alderson, Carr Company was elected yesterday president of the New York Produce Exchange to succeed Samuel Knighton, who is completing his third year as president.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 3. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors approved today the award of $1,388,440 in contracts for the construction of a new county home for the indigent of East View, replacing a 100-year-old structure. The final award of contracts must await Federal approval as a Federal grant has been made available by the PWA to pay part of the cost.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday and closed with losses of 7 to 14 points. The changes had a range of $1 a bale. The lowest prices were made at the opening on execution of over-Sunday selling orders. The best quotations were in closing dealings.

Mayor La Guardia informed Federal housing officials in Washington yesterday that the city was going ahead with its part in the Williamsburg low-cost housing project with great speed. Only yesterday the city received court permission to condemn 225 required parcels.

The New York Central Railroad Company obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Carew writs of certiorari requiring a court review of the 1935 assessments on the Grand Central Terminal and nearby office buildings. The railroad asserted the $32,000,000 valuation placed upon the terminal was excessive and asked a reduction to $29,400,000.

LONDON, June 3. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, head of the German delegation that is to begin naval talks with the British tomorrow, was received today by Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, in their private rooms at the House of Commons and afterward by Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, in his Admiralty Office.

The tenth anniversary of the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, will be observed at noon today when a fifty-pound birthday cake will be served to a group of small children by a debutante committee, headed by Miss Betty Kip.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3. -- The new Skuptchina [lower chamber of the Yugoslav Parliament] opened today with all Opposition Deputies absent except one Bosnian Moslem who had not learned about yesterday's Zagreb resolution to abstain from attending Parliament as a protest against alleged government terrorism and corruption at the last elections.
McCOOK, Neb., June 3. -- Nebraska counted its dead from last week's floods and tornadoes tonight as it battled against new flood threats in the Platte River valley.

An agreement recorded yesterday shows that, in a mortgage for $170,000, held from the E. S. Building Corp. on 549-55 W. 156th St., at 5 per cent, the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis, Minn., owns a superior interest of $85,000 and that the executors of the will of Kimball C. Atwood own the remainder.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Registration of $10,000,000 of 6 per cent sinking fund bonds, Series H, due June 1, 1949, by the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation under the Securities Act of 1933 became effective on May 29, thus paving the way for their listing on the New York Stock Exchange under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- White in Washington Mme. Lebrun will be entertained at dinner by President and Mrs. Roosevelt.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3. -- With the commencement crowd approaching its peak and in pleasant weather, one of the programs of June Week at the Naval Academy was presented today.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Objection to employment of certain commodity price indexes in ascertaining the value of utility properties was expressed by a majority of the Supreme Court in deciding today against the Maryland Public Service Commission's attempt to force lower rates on the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Promulgation tomorrow by President Roosevelt of a new program to supersede the unconstitutional National Industrial Recovery Act was clearly indicated at the White House tonight.

The city of Detroit is expected to enter the market this week for a loan of approximately $2,500,000, which will be used to purchase $2,672,245 of 4 1/2, 5 and 5 1/2 per cent water bonds. Investment bankers interested in Detroit's refunding program did not indicate what they would be willing to bid for the prospective new loan.

Most commodity futures were irregular yesterday in fairly active trading. Sugar futures recovered about a third of their losses of last week in heavy trading. On the cash markets, wheat, rye, flour, cotton, silk, rubber, eggs and tin declined, while corn and butter advanced.

Two officers and three delegates of the American Federation of Master Barbers were arrested yesterday in the offices of Attorney General Bennett's Anti-Racket Bureau on charges of coercion, conspiracy and violation of Section 340 of the General Business Law.

The gains of 11 to 16 points in sugar futures yesterday were the broadest advance in ten years and the third largest movement of prices for any one day in that period. The losses of 12 to 17 points on last Tuesday and of 22 to 25 points on last Friday established new records for the extent of daily price changes since 1925. In yesterday's
ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- In the first day's play of the Essex County junior championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club today, all matches were decided in straight sets and all favorites survived.

Speaking last night to the graduating class of the New York University School of Retailing at a dinner in the restaurant of Stern Brothels department store, 41 West Forty-second Street, I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, declared:

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- A new bonus compromise proposal, which proponents today hinted they thought acceptable to administration forces, will be considered tomorrow at a meeting of leading Congressional advocates of cash payment legislation.

SYRACUSE, June 3. -- Although Sir Josiah Stamp, a director of the Bank of England, pointed out dangers which he said are menacing democracy in a troubled world, he sounded a hopeful note in his address today to 1,062 graduates at the annual commencement exercises at Syracuse University.
LONDON, June 3. -- Unemployment in Great Britain remained nearly stationary during May although it had been expected to fall below 2,000,000.

Federal Judge J. Foster Symes of Colorado, who came here to help relieve a congested calendar caused by a shortage of judges in this district, literally listened yesterday to the first case tried before him in New York.
Two middlemen's groups acted last night to retain the features of their respective extinct NRA codes at meetings in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
New York bestowed upon the incoming Normandie yesterday the type of welcome it usually reserves for a visit of the nation's fleet.

John J. Halleran, Commissioner of Public Works in Queens, made public yesterday an order he issued to Raymond G. Pollard, Deputy Public Works Commissioner, to pay a fine of $111 into the general fund of the city for using a city car to travel to Georgia.

Carrying forward their announced determination to oust James C. Sheridan as Democratic leader of Queens, twenty-three men, members of the county executive committee, last night adopted a plan to declare the leadership vacant next Monday.
I. Benjamin Kraut, formerly a partner in Simons, Blauner Co., has opened an investment department with Blauner Co. at 1,441 Broadway to deal in unlisted securities.

LONDON, June 3. -- The plan of converting a number of streets in congested areas into children's play streets and prohibiting through automobile traffic in them, already tried in New York, is to be adopted in London, Leslie Hore-Belisha, the Minister of Transport, told the House of Commons tonight.

BOSTON, June 3. -- Formation of the Research Associates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a group of leaders and organizations in business and industry who will contribute to the financial support of important research, was disclosed by Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, at the reunion dinner of Technology alumni tonight.

Babe Ruth, breaking off his comeback with the Boston Braves amid an outburst of bitterness after only three months of his three-year contract had elapsed, last night found his major league baseball future in doubt, if not entirely behind him.

The United States merchant marine stands in danger of being outdistanced in world trade unless Congress takes suitable action, P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Hoboken.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Reviewing its record on aid to industry, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today that from its organization on Feb. 2, 1932, up to May 8, 1935, it had authorized loans of $75,948,041.81 to industrial and commercial applicants, while participating banks had taken an additional $4,060,265, making a total of $80,008,306.81 made available.

The monthly index number of commodity prices published yesterday by Dun's Review shows a decline during May of slightly more than 1 per cent. The present index number stands three-fourths of 1 per cent above that of Jan. 1; it is 6 1-3 per cent higher than a year ago and is the highest reached on June 1 of any year since 1930.

Three large West Side structures were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Three smaller Manhattan structures also were bid in, another parcel was withdrawn and a schedule sale was postponed.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Supreme Court through Chief Justice Hughes today appointed an advisory committee of distinguished lawyers to aid in a study of methods for simplifying Federal court procedure.

A six-story apartment house to be built at 175-79 Second Avenue, northwest corner of Eleventh Street, will cost $200,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Sugarman Berger, architects. The Bowmark Realty Corporation, David Rose, president, of 752 Brady Avenue, the Bronx, recently obtained a $250,000 building loan on the site, occupied in part by the old Stuyvesant mansion.

WEYBRIDGE, England, June 3. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, who defaulted to Miss Helen Jacobs in that memorable match at Forest Hills twenty-one months ago, returned to competitive tennis today with an authoritative 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0 victory over an 18-year-old English girl, Miss Jill Notley, in the second round of the St. George's Hill tournament.
A dividend of $5 a share on the preferred stock applicable to arrearages was declared yesterday by the Sangamo Electric Company's directors.

GENEVA, June 3. -- As a result of the NRA decision by the United States Supreme Court a non-committal attitude will be taken at present toward the question of reduction of hours in the International Labor Organization conference opening tomorrow, by the American employers' delegate, Samuel Lewisohn, chairman of the American Management Institute and vice president of the Miami Copper Company.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP). -- Representatives of Northeastern States arrived here tonight to enlist the aid of the Department of Labor in a uniform State legislation drive.
SYRACUSE, June 3 (AP). -- Unemployment relief and tax collection were pictured at the New York State Conference of Mayors today as the chief causes of municipal officials' troubles.

The McKim Fellowship, one of the coveted prizes among architectural students, was awarded to Mrs. Florence Delport Bezy at the annual dinner of the Alumni Association of the School of Architecture of Columbia University to the graduates of the school, held in John Jay Hall last night.

DETROIT, June 3 (AP). -- Dark Zeni of the Fairfield Stables won the Grand Rapids Purse, feature of the program at the Fair Grounds today, covering the mile in 1:44 for the first victory of his career. Seven 3-year-olds went to the post to compete for the purse of $800.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in Now York:

OTTAWA, June 3. -- Canadians gave a mixed reception today to the news concerning the bestowal of King's birthday honors on some of their fellow-citizens. Appreciation was expressed in varied quarters of the fact that almost without exception those honored had distinguished themselves in art, literature and public service, instead of in the acquisition of wealth.

A memorial service for Harry Acton, ship news columnist of The New York American, who died aboard the Ile de France on his way to board the Normandie for her maiden transatlantic voyage, was held last night under the auspices of the Seamen's House Y.M. C.A.
ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP). -- A wild fourteenth-inning scoring spree, climaxing a close see-saw battle, today gave the Indians seven runs and an 11-to-4 victory over the Browns.

The manager of Father Major J. Divine's Peace Restaurant at 2,289 Eighth Avenue, who gave his name as A. Callender, showed up three hours late yesterday at a State Labor Department hearing to answer charges of refusing to post hours of labor for his help.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during April, given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1934. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign good re-exported.

LONDON, June 3. -- Sir Austen Chamberlain, addressing the first meeting of the eighth session of the International Studies Conference on Collective Security today, said he knew of no substitute for the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- After a week of inactivity occasioned by the Supreme Court's invalidation of the NRA the House resumed its legislative function today and under the most drastic procedure passed in record time the Commodity Exchange Control Bill and some fifteen others of less importance.

City officials were encouraged slightly -- ever so slightly -- yesterday at news from Washington that the Federal Government at last was moving toward payment of the city's claim for $764,143, incurred seventy-three years ago for arming and equipping 15,000 Civil War troops.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Declining to make the occasion anything out of the ordinary, the Supreme Court today left the chamber it has occupied in the Capitol since Dec. 4, 1860. To the casual observer the court's session, conducted with usual severe dignity, would have been only one more decision day.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 3. -- The Tennessee Valley Authority and other New Deal public ownership projects have built up a craving for electrified homes as never before, speakers said today at the opening of the third annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute.

As recovery from previous depressions has often been connected with the growth of great new industries, such as the automobile and radio manufacture, the hope has sometimes been expressed that the new industry which may expedite the pace of recovery today will be air-conditioning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- Economic recovery began throughout the world in the Summer and Fall of 1932, but stopped in this country after the Presidential election, according to Walter H. Newton, secretary to former President Hoover, and Professor William S. Myers of Princeton University, who began a series of articles in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post.

Sir Henry Wellcome, founder of the Wellcome Bureau of Scientific Research, will arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. Others coming on the ship from Southampton via Cherbourg are Harold Nicholson, author; John V.A. MacMurray, United States Minister to the Baltic States; Jack Lovelock, the New Zealand athlete, and:

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Tammany leadership of the Fifteenth Assembly District, appeared last night in the role of a patron of the arts at the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club, 21 East Seventy-sixth Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 3. -- Four justices of the peace of Hempstead township will not receive their $500-a-month salaries until they have made up for $10,000 in fees collected from dog owners, Supervisor A. Holly Patterson announced today.

In the parlance of sport, from one of the fields of which he borrowed many of his fireside metaphors, President Roosevelt "cannot take it." He had unmercifully lambasted his opponents, had done everything to muss up their plays, called them all kinds of names and most lightly impugned their motives.

TRENTON, N.J., Tuesday, June 4. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman forced the passage of his bill for a 2 per cent sales tax to finance emergency relief in the New Jersey Assembly early today. The measure was approved by a vote of 31 to 27. The concurrence of the Senate is believed certain.

BERLIN, June 3. -- According to hints from German shipping quarters tonight, the North German Lloyd liners Bremen and Europa will take up the battle for the "blue ribbon" of the Atlantic, which has just been won by the French liner Normandie.

This evening is Earl Carroll's. Amid the customary pomp and circumstance, the second edition of his "Sketch Book" will arrive at the Winter Garden to take its stand as a revue based on a show girl's conception of the history of the U.S.A.

Impartial shipping men and other technical observers who arrived on the Normandie yesterday pronounced her a great marine achievement despite certain faults which were evident during the voyage, such as the vibration in the aft quarter of the lengthy structure.
Stockholders of the Paramount Publix Corporation took two steps yesterday toward putting into effect the reorganization plan approved recently by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Winding up its hearings on the administration's omnibus banking bill in a session at which testimony was in general favorable to its principles, the Senate Banking Subcommittee prepared today to turn the controversial measure over to the full committee for final drafting.

Democratic leaders in Congress are said to have decided definitely against any move to increase taxes at this session. Only one revenue bill is in the making. It will merely re-enact certain existing "nuisance taxes" which are due to expire either on June 30 or on July 31.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 3. -- The Edison Electric Institute, comprising executives in the power and light industry throughout the country, opened a three-day convention here today with a series of fighting speeches.

Washington dispatches report that preference will be given, under the new Federal work-relief plan, to projects in which the cost of materials is relatively low. This is in order to hold down the cost of creating opportunities for employment. The President has pointed out to his Advisory Committee on Allotments that if 3,500,000 jobs are to be made available by the expenditure of $4,000,000,000, the average cost per person must be held to about $1,140.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The drive for cash payment of the veterans' bonus at this session of Congress was virtually abandoned today when backers of the vetoed Patman bill announced that they would delay further efforts until January, and in the meanwhile "take the issue to the country."

BERLIN, June 4. -- The Reich Press Chamber, supreme guardian of the journalistic and editorial ethics of the Third Reich, lost no time today in barring from their profession the editors of confessional and secular newspapers that published a statement by the episcopate of the Archbishopric of Breslau which reserved judgment on the actions of members of Catholic orders convicted of currency smuggling.

Development of a comprehensive system of public health centres in all parts of the city will be a focal concern of the La Guardia administration during the remainder of its term, the Mayor pledged yesterday.

ALBANY, June 4. -- A ruling of the municipal Civil Service Commission of New York City, classifying the clerk and deputy clerk of the municipal courts in the competitive class, was upheld today by the Court of Appeals in reversing the Appellate Division and Special Term, which had granted a mandamus.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- A "stop-gap" program to continue the National Recovery Administration for nine and one-half months in skeletonized form, but stripped of basic powers held unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, while the administration studies other steps that can be taken, was announced today by President Roosevelt at a press conference.

DETROIT, June 4. Socially and formally, with music, pageant and oratory, the General Federation of Women's Clubs Inaugurated its first triennial convention tonight in the auditorium of Masonic Temple here. It is indicated that the eight days will constitute one of the liveliest chapters in the organization's history.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Vigorous attacks on the constitutionality of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill to eliminate "unnecessary" public utility holding companies were made by Senators Dieterich and Hastings today as debate proceeded in the Senate, with a final vote Friday expected by some leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The outstanding passages textually of General Johnson's radio speech today were as follows:

Members of the Society of Stoopnocracy, who designate themselves as Stoopnocrats, gave a supper dance last night in the Moonlit Terrace atop the Biltmore for the benefit of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The fete was a pre-opening celebration for the terrace, which has its formal opening for the season today.
The Museum of Modern Art opens to the public today its Summer exhibition. The diverse showing will remain through September, but individual pictures and groups will be changed from time to time.

More than 1,000 trained nurses from all parts of the country, attending the annual convention of the National League of Nursing Education, applauded Dr. William Heard Kilpatrick, Professor of Psychology at Teachers College, Columbia University, at a meeting in Carnegie Hall last night when he told them he did not like the word "trained."

Earnings of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey so far this year have been about equal to those in the first five months of last year, Walter C. Teagle, president, said yesterday in reply to a stockholder's question at the company's annual meeting in Newark, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- Termination of the office of "special adviser to the President on foreign trade" was believed tonight to foretell an official finish to the long conflict between Secretary Hull and George N. Peek over international trade policies.
LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 4. -- "Let Braddock carry the fight to Baer's body, and the world's heavyweight championship will change hands."
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- A new drive for ratification of the child labor amendment, growing out of the need to supply safeguards lost by children with the passing of NRA codes, was predicted today by Mrs. Roosevelt.

Two Manhattan properties, a Bronx plot and two parcels in Amityville, L.I., were auctioned by Joseph P. Day yesterday in his first special sale this year. About 100 persons were present in the salesroom at 18 Vesey Street.

George B. Cortelyou will retire as president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York after twenty-six years in that office on July 1, and will be succeeded by Frank W. Smith, who will continue as president of the New York Edison Company.

Extension of the use of arbitration to settle claims in all fields of insurance was urged yesterday by speakers at a luncheon conference at the Hotel Astor called by the special committee of lawyers of the American Arbitration Association. About 200 persons attended the luncheon, including representatives of most of the insurance companies with offices here.

A bill to limit the liability of American ship lines in case of accident or loss of life or property has been submitted by the American Steamship Owners Association to the Senate Commerce Committee and the House Committee on Merchant Marine, it was announced yesterday by Ira A. Campbell, counsel to the association.

Two high school girls, aged 14 and 15, who had just completed a tour of their neighborhood to invite chums to a birthday party next Friday, were killed last night near their homes in Winfield, Queens, when they were struck by an oil truck at Laurel Hill Boulevard and Sixty-seventh Street.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered more than $2 a bale yesterday and under aggressive buying ended with gains of 40 to 45 points.

Dean Virginia G. Gildersleeve of Barnard College, speaking at the annual class-day exercises in Barnard Hall yesterday afternoon, advised members of the graduating class to develop a certain degree of skepticism to mix with their natural enthusiasm toward life.

Federal Judge J. Foster Symes, visiting jurist from Colorado, had more musical entertainment yesterday in his court in the Woolworth Building, and saw a further display of tin-pan alley temperament at the resumption of Ira Arnstein's suit for plagiarism against the E.B. Marks Music Corporation.

Stephen Royce, son of the late Professor Josiah Royce, has recently recounted a tale of the days of Eliot, Shaler and Royce which seems to have a certain pertinence today. He said that there was a man, greatly admired by Professor Shaler, who was in danger of missing his degree because he was hopeless in the languages and his English was particularly bad.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt's plea for complete custody of her 11-year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, was brought yesterday before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court by Mrs. Vanderbilt's attorney, Nathan Burkan.

TRENTON, June 4. -- Through support supplied by the Democratic minorities in the Senate and Assembly, Governor Hoffman won his long fight today for a sales tax to finance emergency relief. After passage of the administration bill in the Assembly at 2 o'clock this morning, when Democrats gave it twenty of the needed thirty-one votes, the Senate adopted it late this afternoon by a vote of 13 to 6.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- President Roosevelt announced that he would ask Congress to keep the NRA as a skeleton fact-finding organization, and forbid government contracts with employers not living up to labor conditions of codes. He told Congressional leaders to press for passage of the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill and the Guffey Coal Bill.

WEST ORANGE, N. 5., June 4. -- A strong finish after an uncertain start enabled Miss Kathryn Bragaw of Essex County to maintain her lead at the end of the second round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship at the Rock Spring Club today.

The ninety-eight young women graduates of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson, were urged to work for social security and world peace as they received their degrees yesterday afternoon from Cardinal Hayes.

More than 4,800 men and women received degrees, diplomas and certificates last night at the 181st annual commencement exercises of Columbia University. Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace was among ten distinguished persons to whom honorary degrees were awarded.

CLEVELAND, June 4. -- The American Newspaper Guild should oppose the Wagner Labor Disputes bill and seek, instead, a constitutional amendment safeguarding labor's rights, the 150 delegates to the guild convention here were told today by Paul Frederickson, vice president of the New York unit, reporting on behalf of the New York delegation.

Attorneys representing some important copper interests considered yesterday legal phases of the NRA situation in the industry. Unofficially it was stated that there are several ways in which the copper industry may cooperate without the violation of existing anti-trust laws should there be no further legislative move in Washington.

KANSAS CITY, June 4 (AP). -- Flood gorged streams swept new paths of destruction in the Missouri Valley today, inundating a large part of Manhattan, Kan., and threatening overflows at Topeka and the lowlands of Kansas City.

THE "unofficial observer" who wrote last year's "The New Dealers" may mask a literary trust consisting of several bright-eyed Washington correspondents, or may be another pseudonym for the ubiquitous and protean and not entirely consistent John Franklin Carter. But whatever the identity of this wise-cracking chauffeur of the political rubberneck bus, it must be said that he knows how to conduct a tour with flair and eclat.
The full report of the Committee on the Public Utility Holding Company Bill to the Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce and approved by it, is as follows:

The number of families on home relief has more than doubled in the last twelve months, according to a report submitted by the Home Relief Bureau yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

After hearing the protests of Columbia University medical students that they had been barred from further study because of anti-war activity, Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, declined to attend the university's commencement exercises last evening.
BALTIMORE, June 4. -- At the commencement of Goucher College held today 150 graduates from twenty-one States and the District of Columbia received the Bachelor of Arts degree.

According to the legend in the program, Earl Carroll's "Sketch Book," which was put on at the Winter Garden last evening, is "a new hysterical historical revue," or "a history of these United States as seen through the eyes of a chorus girl." If that sounds a little too imposing, rest assured that it is also an average Earl Carroll show designed for the footless Summer trade.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said tonight that the federation accepted President Roosevelt's NRA plan as a "temporary measure, probably about all that can be done under the circumstances."
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Statements for the registration of securities on national exchanges have been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by thirty-six more companies. They follow:
