WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Mme. Albert Lebrun, wife of the President of France, stepped lightly from a New York train at 1:40 o'clock this afternoon and was officially, though informally, welcomed on the platform by Secretary Hull.

A dozen Manhattan properties, including a fifteen-story apartment house at West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results were as follows:

BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP). -- Newark was handed a 13-to-9 setback by Baltimore tonight in a wild battle that saw nine pitchers parade to the mound. The Bears got thirteen hits to fourteen for the Orioles.

DANZIG, June 4. -- The Nazi Government of Danzig today decreed a virtual financial blockade of the Free City's territory in order to stem a panic precipitated by rumors that additional devaluation of the currency was imminent.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 (AP). -- A trail of tragedy which started with the finding of the stabbed body of a girl near a beach drive and led to a tree where her killer and former friend had hanged himself was followed by police today in an effort to learn the motive of the two deaths.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP). -- Catcher Gabby Hartnett led the Cubs to a one-sided 10 to 2 victory over Cincinnati in the opening game of their series today by hitting a homer, a triple and a single to drive in six runs. In all, he scored three times himself.

The National Student League charged yesterday that several senior students of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn have been denied admittance to various colleges and universities because of their activities on April 12 in the nation-wide students' strike against war.

Private corporations needing city policemen for guard duty would be required to pay for each policeman at the rate of not more than $10 a day under the terms of a local law introduced in the Board of Aldermen yesterday by Alderman Donald L. O'Toole, Brooklyn Democrat.

Although insured for $1,000,000, the 726-carat Jonker diamond, which is included in the freight of the United States liner President Roosevelt en route to New York, is being transported at a carrying cost of only 65 cents. The diamond, said to be the largest uncut gem of its kind in the world, is consigned to Harry Winston of Rockefeller Center.

Observations of New Jersey sportsmen concerning the propagation of birds and game in that State through careful management show that progress is being made in this work, George C. Warren Jr., president of the State Fish and Game Commission, declared recently.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- It would appear that Herbert Hoover, even after his experiences in the campaign of 1932, holds the President's political gifts lightly. This is to be gathered from his statement at Chicago today that the issue in 1936 will be whether the country is to change to a "European" form of governme4t.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -Although he was touched for nine hits, Wesley Ferrell kept them scattered today and the Boston Red Sex defeated Washington, 3 to 2, for the Senators' eighth consecutive loss.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- A proposal to revive the recently invalidated Frazier-Lemke Farm Moratorium Act, rewritten to conform to constitutional limitations, was submitted to Congress today in a bill by Representative Lemke.

The will of Robert James Eidlitz, president of the building concern of Marc Eidlitz Son, Inc., filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, bequeathed one-half of his interest in the concern and $85,000 to his employes and servants. It also bequeathed 65 per cent of his residuary estate to nine charitable and religious institutions after the death of his widow.

John E. Otterson, president of Electrical Research Products, Inc., was elected president of the newly reorganized Paramount Pictures, Inc., yesterday afternoon at the first meeting of a new board of directors which had been elected at a stockholders' meeting in the morning.

A ninety-day code "truce" and the creation of a new NIRA regulating interstate commerce within the limits of the recent Supreme Court decision was advocated in a plan adopted yesterday by 150 representatives of local code authorities.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was steady to firm yesterday. Transactions were $9,489,400, against $6,692,300 on Monday. Sales of United States Government bonds were double those of the day before, amounting to $2,488,400, against $1,244,300.

In abandoning the Philippines the United States will sacrifice the largest chrome deposits in the world and substantial stocks of iron, manganese, gold and other metals of which Japan stands in immediate need, Judge John W. Haussermann, president of the Benquet Consolidated Mining Company and the Balatoc Mining Company, Manila, warned yesterday in an address before foreign traders at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- Mental sluggishness frequently noted in brain workers during the post-luncheon period is due not to the necessity of their "warming up" again, as has sometimes been suggested, but to "brain anemia," resulting from "an unwisely heavy noon meal," the National Office Management Association was told here today.

DUBLIN, June 4. -- Coming changes in the British Cabinet have revived hopes here of an Anglo-Irish accord. Although government spokesmen are preserving a significant reticence, sentiment in the Irish Free State is more favorable to a resumption of negotiations with the British than it has been since the beginning of the dispute three years ago.

Ernest E. Beauvais, a managing clerk employed in the Emergency Relief Bureau in Brooklyn, was at home last night, but not to an interviewer who visited his brownstone rooming house at 65 East Fifty-fourth Street to find out where he had been earlier in the day when Deputy United States Marshals and police were looking for him.
PARIS, June 4. -- The fall of the Bouisson Cabinet today came on the heels of striking evidence that the reversal of the recent flight of French capital had been consolidated.

Substantial progress was made by the security and commodity markets yesterday, with closing prices at or about the day's best level. Stocks manifested a cheerful tone throughout on the Stock Exchange in total trading of 867,000 shares, compared with about 600,000 the day before, and final prices were up from fractions to 4 points; bonds were steady; wheat and cotton closed strong.

The President appears to be acting discreetly in the matter of saving what he can of NRA. He is not asking impossible things of Congress. It was well known, in fact, even before the Supreme Court decision, that extensive revisions of the National Recovery Act were being prepared for submission to the House.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- An application was made today by the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation for an issue of $9,765,000 in 3.5 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, whose proceeds would be used in part to retire 5 per cent obligations totaling $8,882,000.

NEWTON, Mass., June 4. -- The varsity baseball teams of Rutgers and Boston College played a 3-3 eight-inning tie at University Heights today. The game was halted to permit the Rutgers team to catch a boat for New York Rutgers tied it in the seventh when Roy Lins, the Rutgers pitcher, drove home Tom Rooney with a double.

Although Humphrey Cobb's "Paths of Glory" had an advance sale of 12,065 copies and bookstores were thus well stocked, reorders amounting to more than 2,000 copies have been received by the publishers, Viking Press, in the two days since publication.

Alfred E. Smith cut a two-foot birthday cake yesterday to mark the tenth anniversary of the Opportunity Shop, maintained by the tuberculosis committee of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor at 46 West Forty-seventh Street.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP). -- Defeated by the Browns, 11 to 1, the White Sox today suffered further disaster when Jimmy Dykes, their scrappy manager, was carried off the field with a sprained ankle.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The $400,000,000 allocated by the Advisory Committee on Allotments for highway, road and street work and for grade-crossing elimination under the work-relief program was allotted today by Secretary Wallace.

In the presence of representatives of various French societies here special gifts sent on the new French liner Normandie by the France Amerique Society were formally presented at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the office of Consul General Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle in Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Guffey Coal Control Bill, pending on the Senate calendar, and the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, already passed by the upper body and awaiting action by the House, were put on the administration "must" list today and marked for early action as President Roosevelt signified his purpose of using them as corollaries to the proposed skeleton NRA.

Firmly convincd that a four-minute mile is within the realm of human possibility, but a bit reluctant to believe that one will be run at Palmer Stadium on June 15, Jack Lovelock arrived from England last night on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4. -- Max Silverstein of New York was reelected for a fifth term as Grand Master of the Independent Order of B'rith Abraham at the closing session of its annual convention here today.

The application of the Consolidated Gas system for permission to consolidate its two largest operating companies, the New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company, was filed late yesterday afternoon with the Public Service Commission.

For technical reasons the Board of Elections yesterday rejected the plan proposed by PAUL BLANSHARD, Commissioner of Accounts, to eliminate 600 local election districts. President COHEN called it "illegal, unusual and confusing"; Mr. BLANSHARD retorts that this is mere "quibbling."
MEXICO, D.F., June 4. -- Flood waters receded today from the valley of Mexico, leaving many of an estimated 400 dead buried in mud.

The report of the General Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1934 records that in connection with a request that holders of $1,215,350 of 5 per cent notes, due Aug. 15, 1935, agree to a one-year extension of half the notes on the condition that affiliated interests purchase the remaining half, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation has extended the $6,037,000 of notes it holds to 1939.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 4. -- Although Max Baer will depend heavily on his noted punching power to retain his heavyweight title, he does not intend to be short of boxing skill when he steps into the ring against James J. Braddock in the Garden Bowl June 13.

LONDON, June 4. -- The Anglo-German naval conversations opened today with a few perfunctory words of welcome by Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, who immediately thereafterwithdrew, leaving the negotiations for this country to experts: Robert L. Craigie of the Foreign Office, Vice Admiral C.J.C. Little and Captain V.H. Danckwert.

BERLIN, June 4. -- The Boerse cast off its reactionary mood today and turned firm and active, the best gains exceeding 5 points. Part of the purchases came from blocked-mark accounts, but the bank situation in Danzig may have revived inflationary fears.

Mayor La Guardia expressed disapproval yesterday of the United States Supreme Court decision that would keep the Interborough Rapid Transit Company under the jurisdiction of the Federal court. He declared that the decision was "just in keeping with the NRA decision."

Due to the holiday buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the previous week. However, the total was slightly above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

SYRACUSE, June 4. -- The general session of the New York Conference of Mayors heard a proposal today that a permanent State traffic commission be established to do away with "patchwork" local systems.

Town Hall was crowded last night at the eighty-seventh commencement exercises of La Salle Academy, when the largest graduating class in the history of the school received their diplomas from Mgr. Michael J. Lavell, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

It took the House of Representatives fifteen minutes on Monday to put through a bill proposing to regulate the complicated machinery of the commodity exchanges. There was no real debate. There was no attempt to consider the measure in detail. Some one, to be sure, did ask casually whether it was constitutional.
MOSCOW, June 4. -- The Soviet Government announced today the signing of a credit agreement with Czechoslovakia which is significant for three reasons.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning A. Wilfred May attempts to answer arguments against the Wheeler-Rayburn bill. He gives the railroads as an example of an industry that "it is difficult to understand how the railroads have conceivably suffered from political demagogy."

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Prices for hogs here declined today 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight in a rather slow market. The top price was $10.05. The day's average was $9.80, a decline of 5 cents from yesterday. Most sales were at $9.55 to $9.95, compared with $9.80 to $10 on Monday.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 4. -- Retirement of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh from active connection with Transcontinental and Western Air as technical adviser was announced today by Henry B. du Pont, chairman of the TWA board.
Definite action to assure price stability and the maintenance of code wage and hours schedules was taken by trade groups here yesterday.
Several leases for expansion were among the business rentals reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 4. -- Former President Herbert Hoover charged here today that the Roosevelt administration was proposing a "European form of government" for the United States.

Representatives of sixty of New York State's sixty-nine breweries adopted a code of fair competition similar to the code which existed in the industry under the NRA at a convention yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

A difference of $10,000 in two bids for a new issue of $5,000,000 Jersey City, N.J., bonds determined the winning award, which was made yesterday to a group headed by Lehman Brothers. The high bid was $4,820,000 for 4 per cent bonds; the second bid was $4,810,000.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Bearish private crop reports on small grains brought selling on the Board of Trade early today, carrying prices down, but comparatively little buying in the last hour caused an upturn. The result was net gains on wheat of 1 1/4 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel, except the June, which rose 1 7/8 cents on limited business.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Moving descriptions of the plight of New York's slum families, which drew expressions of sympathy from Senators, were given today before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor, which is holding hearings on the Wagner bill to create a Federal Housing Division in the Department of the Interior.

ROME, June 4. -- The entire Italian press today emphasizes the two new Italo-Ethiopian clashes announced yesterday, reaching the conclusion that such episodes can mo longer be regarded as isolated or fortuitous but must be considered as symptoms of Ethiopia's deliberate hostility toward Italy.
There will be an addition to the labor supply in Southern California next week when Joseph P. Halman of Friesland, Holland, arrives with his wife and nine husky children of a total of eighteen.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,000,414,467 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price of all listed shares on June 1 was $26.50, compared with $25.77 at the beginning of May.

IT seems that they won't stop swinging in baseball's Boston tea party until every one around the place has had a chance to come to bat and hit a loud foul. The last one to have his cut was Bill McKechnie.

The loss of an $8,000 pearl necklace by a woman guest at one of the receptions held abroad to celebrate the departure of the French liner Normandie on her maiden voyage to the United States was made known here yesterday by the offer of an $800 reward for the return of the gem.

BERLIN, June 4. -- The secret State police, the National Socialist counterpart of the former Bolshevist Cheka, is a law unto itself and its actions are not subject to judicial review, according to a decision rendered by the highest Prussian administrative court.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4. -- A directed verdict in favor of the Gillette Safety Razor Company of Boston, Mass., and its subsidiary, Otto Roth, Inc., of Newark, was returned in United States District Court here today in the $6,000,000 anti-trust suit brought against them by the Clark Blade and Razor Company, and the Clark Blade Selling Company, both of Newark.

Having increased the chances of life for young children, medical scientists are now concentrating on lengthening the life span of adults by fighting against such old-age diseases as cancer and diabetes, which longer life has made increasingly prevalent.
Following is the text of the address by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, delivered yesterday at the 181st commencement of the university:

DETLOIT, June 4 ta, -- Chatterfol, the Saddle Spur Stables' 5-yeaxold gelding, staged a rush in the stretch today to beat Injustice By a head in the Ealamazoo Purse, sixfurlong feature, at the Detroit race track. The track was muddy and the time was 1:15%.

Efforts to arbitrate protested trades in Alleghany Corporation preferred stock on a when-issued basis have been complicated by the action of one of the corporation's bondholders in applying to the United States Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari to block consummation of its reorganization plan, William F. Unger, counsel for one of the parties to the trading controversy, said yesterday.

The method of assigning officials for boxing bouts was explained once again yesterday at the weekly meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission. In view of the heated discussions, which followed the recent Barney RossJimmy McLarnin battle, Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan, as chairman of the commission, clarified the situation.

The eighth annual expedition of United States Davis Cup forces will sail from New York for England on board the United States liner Washington at noon today in quest of the trophy lost to France in 1927 and held by England for the past two years.

AUGSBURG, Germany, June 4. -The third conference of the Confessional Synod began here today with prominent opponents of Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller's administration present. The Rev. Martin Niemoeller and Bishop August Marahrens of Hanover are two nationally known Protestant leaders attending the session, which will act on questions of policy.

The plan of Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, to eliminate some 600 election districts in the city to save upward of $180,000 a year, was termed impracticable and illegal yesterday at a hearing on the proposal held by the Board of Elections.

LATONIA, Ky., June 4 (AP). -- The success which has attended the stable of H.W. and W.J. Young, Louisville sportsmen, continued as Best Bid annexed the Elmwood Purse, feature on today's eight-race card.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 4. -- Playing in a steady, drizzling rain, the remarkably high entry of seventy-five competed in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one day tournament at the Cherry Valley Country Club today, and of that, number thirty-two returned cards.

The Supreme Court was warmly praised by President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University yesterday for stopping, through its NRA decision, "those who would turn this Federal republic of ours into a highly centralized political and economic despotism under the mask of social reform and progress."

The nine-foot scale model of the U.S.S. Saratoga, constructed for the Long Island State Park Commission at a cost of $1,500, was challenged yesterday to a miniature naval encounter by Oleg Stroukoff, 12 years old, of 19 East Forty-ninth Street, on behalf of his 39-inch model of the U.S.S. Arizona.

The plan for compulsory retirement of employes adopted yesterday by the trustees of Consolidated Gas Company came as a surprise to the executive and operating personnel of the company and was a shock to many, particularly because of the affection held by all employes for Mr. Cortelyou.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4. -- Captain Kidd, veteran little bay gelding, owned by Captain and Mrs. Frank de K. Huyler of Rye, N.Y., and jumped by the former, today captured the individual military championship, the leading event on the card of the first day of the seventeenth annual West Point Horse Show.

For a long time, very likely, persons will keep turning up who were on that first passenger list of the Normandie. Among the theatre's representatives was Tom Barrows, back after five weeks, of which he spent two days with Scan O'Casey in Battersea Park, just outside of London.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- A new "self-liquidating" plan for employing jobless actors and theatre hands, under which the government would advance $3,000,000 to put fifty-three companies on the road, will be presented tomorrow to the work-relief leaders, Harry L. Hopkins, Secretary Ickes and Frank C. Walker.

LONDON, June 4. -- The record-breaking Normandie has won the international blue ribbon trophy, presented by Harold K. Hales, M.P., but will not receive it for some months, as it must go first to the Rex, the previous holder of the transatlantic record.
M'COOK, Neb., June 4 (AP). -- Hundreds of homeless families were cheered tonight by news that the Federal Government will provide funds to reconstruct the flood-ravaged Republican River Valley.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- An assertion that a constitutional amendment was not necessary to meet the NRA situation was made by General Hugh S. Johnson today before the Advertising Club of Washington in a speech which also went out over a National Broadcasting Company network.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- In a new move for collection of alleged damages, six former air mail carriers whose contracts were canceled by Postmaster General Farley on Feb. 9, 1934, filed suit today in the United States Court of Claims for $3,665,282.04.

Reports from Scranton, Pa., that mine operators in the anthracite industry, acting through the Anthracite Institute, had appointed a "dictator" to coordinate and regulate the industry were confirmed here yesterday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 4 (AP). -- When the Syracuse oarsmen left here today they were pointed for a double objective -- the Hudson races and the California sprint regatta.

The captains and the kings depart. Only last year JOHN THEOFEL, leader of the Democratic party in Queens and ally of Mr. CURRY, was deposed from his high office. Mr. JAMES C. SHERIDAN was inducted into it, graciously blessed by Mr. FARLEY, who looked for his aid "in bringing about complete harmony."

SHERMAN, Texas, June 4. -- Wood alcohol playfully pilfered from a school laboratory brought death to two Austin College students and left thirteen others ill tonight. College heads began an investigation.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,575,900 barrels, compared with 2,605,300 in the preceding week, a decrease of 29,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 28,850 and 13,400 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and California were the most important changes.

One of the most widely known of recent contemporary American paintings, "The Tornado," regarded by many as John Steuart Curry's finest pictures, has been bought from the Ferargil Galleries, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, by the Hackley Art Museum, Muskegon, Mich.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 4. -The will of Mrs. Elsie Stillman Rockefeller, widow of William G. Rockefeller, was admitted to probate by Judge Harold L. Knapp in the probate court this morning.
Apartment house deals in the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

A good many people are angry with the United States Supreme Court for trying to yank this country out of the 160,000 horsepower electro-turbine Normandie age and back into the horse-and-buggy age. Yet it seems only the other day that a great many people were saying this country needed more than anything else a vigorous horse-and-buggy revival.
Conditions in the money market showed no change. Turnover was limited to renewals and quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

A four-alarm fire in a row of unfinished stores in the Brighton Beach district of Brooklyn spread to two adjoining apartment houses early yesterday morning, causing about 130 families to abandon their homes in night attire. None was injured and the flames were under control in less than an hour.

Although there was a decline in the number of failures in the retail and manufacturing divisions in the holiday week which ended May 30, as compared with the previous week, defaults in the wholesale group showed an increase, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LONDON, June 4. -- The Stock Exchange was quiet today, with little speculative activity previous to the holidays, but there were some bright features. British funds continued in demand and strengthened further. French bonds reacted in the foreign section of the market.

The Swedish-American liner Kungsholm was steaming across the Atlantic last night with 1,450 passengers, including one who wants to be alone. The recluse is traveling under the name of "Karin Lund." Motion-picture audiences the world over know her as Greta Garbo.

More than 500 delegates, the largest number to attend any of its conventions since that held in Quebec in 1930, will participate in the weekend session of the New York State Bankers Association at Lake George, it was announced yesterday.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, at a special meeting yesterday, approved the issuance of bonds in an amount not exceeding $100,000,000. The new bonds are not to be issued until all bonds outstanding are called for redemption.

Russeks Fifth Revenue, Inc., reported yesterday, for the year ended on Feb. 2, net sales of $3,634,701, compared with $3.295.879 in the preceding year. Net profit after taxes, depreciation and other charges was $102,280, equal to 82 cents a share on 125,000 shares of $5 par capital stock.

Sharp gains were numerous in the commodity futures markets yesterday, although some staples, namely coffee and cocoa, were moderately lower. On the cash markets, gains were scored by all the grains, dairy products, silk and rubber, while tin and printcloths declined.

More than 200 friends and relatives witnessed the induction of thirty-eight Hunter College students into Nu chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa last night in the Hunter auditorium, Sixty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue. Dr. Max Lerner of Sarah Lawrence College and Harvard University addressed the group on "Scholarship and Man's Inhumanity."

After her triumphal entrance into the harbor on Monday the Normandie tried yesterday to become a workaday ship busily discharging cargo and taking on supplies in preparation for the return voyage on Friday.

A tribute to the liner Normandie as a symbol of good-will between France and the United States was expressed last night by Henri Morin de Linclays, general manager of the French Line for the United States, at a dinner held aboard the huge ship at her pier.

Declaring that the city faced a deficit of $30,000,000 in its 1936 budget, Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, said last night that this shortage could be met only by abolishing unnecessary positions and by pay cuts. He addressed about 100 members of the Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 4. -- The speed and fitness of the Aga Khan's three English Derby horses, Bahram, Hairan and Theft, favorites tonight in the order named, have, in the words of one gaily attired professional tipster, "almost knocked the bottom out of our business."

PITTSBURGH, June 4. -- Japan's six golfing shotmakers who will compete for the national open championship descended on Oakmont today and showed the galleries some of the shots they hope will help one of them carry the crown beyond the Pacific shores.

Wagner College on Grymes Hill, S.I., conferred a degree yesterday on a young woman graduate for the first time in its history, at the fiftieth commencement exercises in the college auditorium, where twenty-five men also received degrees.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 4. -The second day of the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute was opened by Thomas N. McCarter, veteran public service operator, with a presidential address in which he declared "the kid-glove stage has passed."

As between Democrats, it is THE TIMES against William Rogers with me. The gagging Mr. Rogers in his Sunday evening radio patter sought diligently to give the impression that not since George Washington drove out the British had the Supreme Court ever been unanimous up to the NRA ease.

Representatives of about twenty insurance companies and savings bank raised objections yesterday to a plan of reorganization put forward for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad by its management. H.A. Scandrett, president, started for Chicago after the meeting, leading to the belief that he would consult his directors on amendments to the plan.

Forty-two students will be graduated by the Harriette Melissa Mills Training School for Kindergarten and Primary Teachers, 66 Fifth Avenue, at its twenty-sixth commencement exercises this morning at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

TACOMA, Wash., June 4. -- The trail of George Weyerhaeuser's kidnappers warmed tonight with discovery of the passing of the first ransom bill in Eastern Oregon, and a statement by a Department of Justice spokesman that the case would "break wide open in forty-eight hours."
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The White House announcement today on the NRA read as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Vastly broadened powers rivaling the inquisitorial authority of the Federal Trade Commission were granted to a special House committee today on the eve of its investigation into alleged lobbying activities and trade practices of some of the largest individual and chain mercantile establishments of the country.

Loans on securities to member firms decreased $12,024,417 in May, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The month-end total was $792,541,031, compared with $804,565,448 at the close of April.
BOSTON, June 4 (AP). -- Babe Ruth will not have to buy the uniform he wore as a member of the Boston Braves.

MARIETTA, Ohio, June 4. -- Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company; Dr. Willard L. Thorpe, former chairman of the NRA Advisory Board, and Dr. Edward S. Parsons, retiring president of Marietta College, were the principal speakers at the college centennial exercises today.

Declaring that the demise of the NIRA has enhanced the importance of the Wagner Labor Relations Bill to industry, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, chairman of the New York Regional Labor Board, a former Supreme Court Judge here and one-time law partner of Senator Wagner, asserted yesterday that "there is nothing in the measure which should cause serious concern to fair-minded business men."

LONDON, June 4. -- This city today honored the memory of Jane Addams with a service organized by the British section of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. The service was held, appropriately, at St. Martin's in the Fields, known as "the parish church of the down-and-outers."

GENEVA, June 4. -- The tenth International Labor Organization conference opened here today with forty-eight of the sixty-two member nations represented, including the United States for the first time.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 4. -- The monthly statement of the Bank for International Settlements, issued tonight, shows that the monetary agitation in May had only a slight effect on its funds, which declined nearly 2,000,000 Swiss francs. Central bank deposits for their own accounts dropped 7,000,000 francs, but gold bar deposits increased 4,000,000 francs. The bank's liquidity remains unchanged.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Prospects for the Winter wheat crop are the best in recent years. The average of estimates of five local crop experts on Winter wheat is 469,000,000 bushels, compared with 449,000,000 in May and a government report of 432,000,000 bushels on May 1.
I would like to thank you for your editorial headed "Time for Faith" in last Sunday's issue, and particularly for that part which points out the detrimental character of NRA legislation as a whole.

The seventy-fifth annual commencement of The New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital will he held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this evening at 8:30 o'clock. The program is being held in conjunction with the annual convention of the American Institute of Homeopathy in honor of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the college and hospital.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Gillespie and their daughter, Miss Julie Gillespie, gave a dinner last night at the Weylin. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. C. Waring Gillespie, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Busch, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Brandt, Mrs. Henry L. Gillespie, the Misses Christie Gillespie, Sonia Lie and Mary Markoe Holsman; Jonas Lie, Henry T. Jameson and Lucius Beebe.

People usually cite statistics with the greatest confidence who are least acquainted with the raw materials from which the statistics are compiled. An interesting instance of this, pointed out by the National Industrial Conference Board, is the frequent statement that "2 per cent of the people own 60 per cent of the national wealth."
ANNAPOLIS, June 4. -- The presentation of the colors, next to the graduation ceremonies, the high point of June Week, took place at dress parade this evening at the Naval Academy.

PITTSBURGH, June 4. -- Manager Frankie Frisch tonight warned Dizzy Dean, star hurler for the world champion Cardinals, he would be suspended and fined $5,000 if he repeated the squabble which ended in a near fist fight today between Dean and Joe Medwick, his clouting team-mate.

Boris Shumiatsky, head of the Soviet motion-picture industry for the last five years and leader of a delegation of Russian film experts here to study American production methods, said yesterday that the Soviet had decided to veer away from propaganda pictures and planned to stress cultural, esthetic and entertainment values in the future.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- In an effort to salvage as much as possible of the labor provisions of the NRA, representatives of fourteen States met in the Department of Labor today and heard Miss Frances Perkins declare that the Federal Government is ready, "under the Constitution," to cooperate with the States in the maintenance of standards connected with hours, wages and conditions of employment.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENN SYLVANIA, At Sea, June 4 (by Wireless). -- From shortly after dawn to well after dusk the United States fleet glided and countermarched across the blue waters of the Pacific today, conducting gunnery drills and tactical exercises.
The new experimental towing tank of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken was opened formally last night before about sixty representatives of educational engineering and shipping circles.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Peggy Sims Leffingwell, daughter of Mrs. William Elderkin Leffingwell of Watkins Glen, N.Y., and the late Mr. Leffingwell, New York State Senator, to Lieutenant Donald Wesley Gladney Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wesley Gladney of Lewisville, Ark.

The feud between the March New York County grand jury and District Attorney William C. Dodge, which had been smoldering for weeks, with occasional declarations from both sides that all was harmony between them, was brought into the open yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 4. -- Cornell moved toward reorganization of its athletic set-up with the appointment by President Livingston Farrand today of three members of the board of athletic policy which will operate athletics directly under the board of trustees.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- The Westchester County Park Commission had under consideration today a proposal to bar New Yorkers from Westchester parks. The prospect of lost revenues, however, made the officials hesitant.

A new record for the Swift Stakes was set at Belmont Park yesterday in the thirty-fifth running of this old sprinting test, which goes back to 1885 at Sheepshead Bay, when Mantagna dashed home in 1:23 4-5, first in a field of nine.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Our monetary system, if left uncontrolled, will serve to "intensify booms and depressions," Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said tonight in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System in an hour sponsored by the Consumers' Committee of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education.
News yesterday afternoon that the new French Cabinet had fallen upset the New York foreign exchange market. Dealers were wholly unprepared for this sudden change.

PARIS, June 4. -- By the narrow margin of two votes, after a count and recount in an atmosphere of intense excitement, Fernand Bouisson's four-day-old Cabinet was defeated this evening on its first encounter with the Chamber of Deputies.
Olga 3'. W. Hilliard gave to Ernest E. M. Bullowa a mortgage for $9,000, payable l three years hence at 6 per cent, on the southeast corner of 2d Av. and 75th St.

SCRANTON, Pa., June 5. -- The Banking Bill which is pending in Congress was denounced and defended by speakers addressing more than 600 delegates at the annual convention of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association today.

Despite the fact it was her second full day in port, the new French liner Normandie attracted thousands of persons to her pier at West Forty-eighth Street yesterday. Five thousand went aboard, paying 50 cents each for the privilege of passing through the liner's public rooms and inspecting other sections of the vessel.
Reports of earnings of subsidiaries of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation for the quarter and the twelve months ended on March 31 follow:

For the benefit of the Roslyn District Nursing Association the gardens of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Curtis at Willowmere, their place in Roslyn, L.I., will be opened to the public next Tuesday afternoon. Several varieties of roses, some of which were brought to this country from Lyons, France, by the late Admiral Aaron Ward, who formerly owned the estate, will be in bloom.

BERLIN, June 5. -Quotations on the Boerse moved upward today, electricals and public utilities leading. L G. Farben, the stock market's bellwether, jumped 4 points. Heavy industrials were strong and lively most of the day, but reacted slightly before the close.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 5. -- All city policemen must attend church services at least every Sunday by order of John J. Roegner, who was elected Public Safety Director here last May 14. The order appeared today on the bulletin board at police headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Plans for breaking down the nation-wide code-enforcement structure of the National Recovery Administration were considered today, following President Roosevelt s promulgation of "stop-gap" legislation designed to hold a skeleton NRA organization while bowing to the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating code enforcement.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 5. -- Concerted action by all municipalities to obtain at the next session of the Legislature "the help cities deserve in view of the funds they turn over to the State," was urged tonight by Mayor La Guardia of New York City in an address before the New York State Conference of Mayors.

NEW SUFFOLK, L.I., June 5. -- Frank Johnson, whose general store is the headquarters for anglers sailing from this port for the Peconic Bay weekfish grounds, believes that the time has come to call a halt to unnecessarily large catches during the early Spring run.

SHANGHAI, June 5. -- Although the present tension in Chino-Japanese relations pertains primarily to the North China situation, nevertheless potentialities of similar serious troubles exist in many other parts of China today.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A move to drive back into committee the bill to abolish public utility holding companies ran head-on today into charges by Senator Brown, Democrat of New Hampshire, that the whole utility holding system was a "racket" engaged in "juggling cash" and stripping investors.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 5. -- A former Princeton all-round athlete, August F. (Fred) Kammer Jr. of Baltusrol, won the medal in the thirty-fourth amateur championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association at the Essex County Country Club today. He had two rounds of 73 for a 36-hole total of 146.

ANNAPOLIS, June 5. -- On a perfect "June Week" day and in the presence of thousands of spectators, the honor men of the Naval Academy's graduating class received their prizes this afternoon. A varied program marked the final day preceding graduation, ending tonight with the farewell ball given by the class of 1936 to the seniors.

AUGSBURG, Germany, June 5. -- "The man who is determined either to conquer or to die will most likely conquer," was the tenor of a sermon preached by Dr. Karl Koch, president of the Augsburg Confessional Synod, tonight in St. Anna Church before a large congregation.

In THE TIMES of June 2 the New Jersey Highway Department is reported as planning various pieces of road construction. Some of us here in North Jersey wonder why most of these are being carried on in places where there is comparatively little need for extra highway facilities, to the rather complete neglect of many urgent needs in this part of the State.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5. -- Holy Cross scored its eighteenth victory in nineteen starts this season today by beating Harvard, 8 to 1, in a twilight game, called at the end of the seventh because of darkness.

The degree of Master of Laws will be conferred upon twenty-six post-graduate students at the New York Law School commencement, to be held this afternoon in the headquarters of the school on the third floor of 253 Broadway. James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany and a graduate of the school in the class of 1892, will deliver the address.
Thirty-six young women received their degrees from Cardinal Hayes yesterday afternoon at the commencement exercises of the College of the Sacred Heart, Convent Avenue and West 133d Street.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously and irregulary yesterday in a range of about $1 a bale, the list ending 9 to 12 points lower than on Tuesday.

PARIS, June 5. -- The first important political figure among those accused of helping the late Alexander Stavisky to defeat the law in his Bayonne Municipal Pawnshop financial machinations went on trial today.

For the quiet and admirable statement made by the President on Tuesday evening he has received almost universal and deserved praise. Industrial leaders have hastened to pledge to him the cooperation which he requests. It is a calm and businesslike procedure which he outlines.

BOSTON, June 5. -- Before one of the smallest crowds of the season here the Dodgers today divided a double-header with the Braves. About 1,500 fans were on hand, threatening weather keeping many away.

Professor H. Parker Willis of Columbia University characterized the Eccles bill yesterday afternoon as "the most dangerous banking bill introduced in the past ten years." He spoke at a conference of the New York City, Long Island and Westchester sections of the New York State League of Saving and Loan Associations, held at the Hotel Commodore.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5. -- Mrs. J.H. Whitney of Upperville, Va., and New York, today carried away the hunter championship as the seventeenth annual West Point horse show came to a brilliant conclusion on the parade ground of the United States Military Academy.

MARIETTA, Ohio, June 5. -- Following the graduation of sixty-nine students at Marietta College commencement today, honorary degrees were conferred on thirteen men in connection with the centennial program of the college. The recipients were:

HELEN WADDELL, whom Columbia made a Doctor of Letters, had previously been doctored by Belfast and Durham. She richly deserves her honors. She is a scholar, and a ripe and good one, in medieval literature. Her studies, anthologies and translations of the Latin verse of the Middle Ages are classics on the subject.

A vigorous protest against listing antique dealers as sellers of secondhand goods was registered yesterday before License Commissioner Paul Moss by representatives of the Antique and Decorative Arts League, 20 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Frank O'Connell, 17-year-old senior at George Washington High School, Manhattan, died last evening while running in the relay trials of the Public School Athletic League's senior high school track and field preliminaries at Wingate Field, Avenue K and East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn.

COPENHAGEN, June 5 (AP). -- Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow asserted today that he and his Woolworth heiress bride, the former Barbara Hutton, would reside in Europe because of "fear of gangsters" in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Mme. Albert Lebrun, ending her brief visit here today, did what many other distinguished guests have done when she laid a floral wreath on the tomb of George Washington at historic Mount Vernon.

The sale of the George Washington Hotel at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street scheduled for yesterday was postponed to June 12. The action was to have been held in an action by the Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee, against the Club Hotel Corporation of New York, involving $1,764,317.

Benjamin Bergman, alleged leader in an extensive alien-smuggling and naturalization-fraud ring, was found dead at 9 A.M. yesterday, his half-clad body sprawled in a hallway outside a room on the fourth floor of the Williamsburg branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 179 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- An easier tone prevailed in the market for hogs today, especially at the close. The market was steady in the early trading. The top price of $10.05 a hundred pounds was the same as on the previous day and the average was unchanged at $9.80.

Sixty-four members of the graduating class of the Cornell University Medical College will take the oath of Hippocrates and receive their medical degrees at commencement exercises at 4 o'clock this afternoon in the auditorium of the medical college at 1,305 York Avenue.

A few facts visibly emerge from the bewildering incidents of Tuesday in regard to the French Parliament and the new French Ministry. One is that Paris was as much surprised as was New York at the upsetting of the Bouisson Cabinet by a vote in the Deputies of 264 to 262, only a few hours after the same Deputies had voted confidence by 390 to 192.

BERLIN, June 5. -- Despite dividend limitations and impending export promotion levies on industrial earnings, the German stock exchanges have been staging an upward movement that has produced stock quotations which had not been seen since before the bank crash of 1931 and which today assumed the proportions of a regular boom.

LONDON, June 5. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury delivered a plea for a clean slate for Germany in addressing the Upper House of Convocation of the Church of England at Canterbury today. He declared the fact seemed to emerge that Germany must now be recognized no longer merely as a defeated power forced to accept conditions imposed upon it, but a nation entitled to an equal place among other nations.

Twenty-two pickets, including one woman, were arrested last night in West Forty-Second Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, following a demonstration that resulted in the sending in of a riot call and complete stoppage of all traffic for fifteen minutes.

Sigmund Spaeth, the self-avowed "tune detective" who discovered years ago that "Yes, We Have No Bananas" was simply a combination of parts of the Hallelujah chorus in Handel's Messiah, Balfe's Bohemian Girl and a Wagnerian opera, had an opportunity yesterday to explain his views to Federal Judge J. Foster Symes.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- An assertion that if the government's housing program was to be a success, Federal loans to municipal housing authorities should be outright loans and not part loan and part grant, was made before a Senate hearing on the Wagner Housing Bill today by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

MADRID, June 5. -- Luis Companys, former President of the Catalan Generalidad, and six former members of the autonomous region's Executive Council were convicted today of military rebellion and sentenced to thirty years' imprisonment each by the Tribunal of Constitutional Guarantees, which takes the place of the Senate in Spain and is the highest court in the land.

Pledges of voluntary action to maintain NRA wage and hour schedules and to prevent the return of child labor and sweatshops grew in volume yesterday as industrial leaders, corporations and trade associations throughout the country put themselves on record against a revival of "cut-throat" competition at the expense of labor.

The newly decorated roof garden of the Hotel Astor was opened for the Summer season last night with the largest attendance in its history. The formal opening began with a dinner-dance in the Belvedere restaurant and continued later in the evening with supper and dancing in the outdoor terrace cafe.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Besides the NRA stop-gap extension legislation an amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act, these proposals are held by leaders to be necessary of enactment before the present Congress session ends:

TOLEDO, June 5. -- Some of the largest industries here were forced to shut down, throwing thousands out of work, and other plants operated on a restricted scale as electricians and office workers of the Toledo Edison Company went on strike today.

SALEM, N.H., June 5. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt entered three horses in the Dartmouth Handicap today at Rockingham Park, Dreel, Dogmata and Bachelor Dinner, and they finished in that order, to make the $2,500 added feature race a family affair.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., June 5, -- There was an exceptionally large midweek arrival list today at the Greenbrier, Among the newcomers were Landon Humphreys of Green Acre Farm, Far Hills, N.J.; his daughter, Miss Suzanne Humphreys; Mrs. Frederic Humphreys and Frederick E. Humphreys.

There is still some doubt in Wall Street as to the probable effects of the termination of NRA on price levels of goods. The conviction is growing, however, that so long as credit remains abundant, the passing of NRA can administer only a temporary check to a rise in prices.

BUENOS AIRES, June 5. -- The Chaco peace negotiations entered today another apparently insolvable impasse over the so-called Hayes Award. Bolivia again refused to accept arbitration unless the Hayes zone of the Chaco was included in the territory submitted to arbitration.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Treasury securities bearing the gold clause will be accepted at their face value in payment for income taxes due June 15, Secretary Morgenthau ruled today.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, AT SEA, June 5. -- The exercises of the United States fleet today were marked by an impressive mid-ocean rehearsal for the San Diego (Calif.) aerial parade in which planes of all types from the battleships, cruisers and carriers participated.

LONDON, June 5. -- Sitting for what probably was the last time in his life at the head of a table for an international function, Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald today entertained at a luncheon at 10 Downing Street Joachim von Ribbentrop and Chancellor Hitler's other delegates to the Anglo-German naval talks in London.

One hails with approval Senator Borah's radio speech printed in full in THE NEW YORK TIMES. In upholding the right of citizens to decide changes in the Constitution, the Senator from Idaho displays that calm wisdom which people may not utilize in a period of national stress, but which nevertheless has endured through all civilization as the most certain method whereby the greatest measure of happiness and freedom for man may be attained.

Plans to enforce the collection of the New York City and New Jersey sales taxes will be discussed by officials of this city and of New Jersey as soon as the New Jersey sales tax bill has been signed by Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 5. -- Hope for the future of the United States depends more on the youth of this country now than ever before, former District Judge James P. Mylod, Newark attorney, said here today in a commencement address at Seton Hall College.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 5. -- The Rev. Remsen Brinkerhoff Ogilby, president of Trinity College, addressed the forty graduates and 600 guests of the Peekskill Military Academy in the James B. Ford Auditorium on the campus here today in the school's 102d commencement.

TOKYO, June 5. -- Statements by the military authorities reveal that the crux of the army's demands in North China is the removal of Governor Yu Hsueh-chung of Hopei, a former Manchurian general, and his army of former Manchurian troops from the frontier districts, where it is alleged they form a constant focus of disaffection.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A revised Agricultural Adjustment Act, designed to bring the administration's farm recovery program within the limitations laid down by the Supreme Court in the Schechter case and shut off threatened litigation, was rushed to the Capitol today with instructions that it follow the NRA resolution through the legislative mill.
We have today received the Citizens Budget Commission bulletin, "Food for Thought," with its Will Rogers appeal for "governments to live as cheap as the people."
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that its action in withholding temporary registration on the New York Stock Exchange from $10,000,000 of Brooklyn-Manhattan Rapid Transit Corporation bonds, did not, at least in so far as the commission's authority to promulgate regulations is concerned, come within the scope of the Supreme Court ruling in the Schechter NRA case.

BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP). -- Newark made it two out of three in the series with Baltimore today, winning, 6 to 3, behind the southpaw Marvin Duke, who baffled the Orioles until the ninth, when he was yanked in favor of Kleinhans.

Norman-Lila Estates, operators, who recently bought the five-story apartment house at 712-718 West 176th Street, between Broadway and Fort Washington Avenue, from the Citizen's Savings Bank, resold the property yesterday to Solomon Ginsburg for all cash over a first mortgage.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 5. -- The current trend of the stronger preparatory schools to teach what was formerly college work and of colleges to advance the character of their work into the field of the graduate school was described as one which "has great promise" by Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, at the annual commencement of Bryn Mawr College today.

Retail trade both here and out-of-town has shown improvement this week, reports here yesterday indicated. More favorable weather in many sections has spurred turnover, which has been further stimulated by price cuts and strong emphasis on popular price merchandise.

Walter Stucki, Swiss Minister to the United States, and Mrs. Stucki, and Luis Miro Quesada, Peruvian Minister to Switzerland, are among the persons arriving today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others coming on the ship are Henry Nielsen, Danish champion runner, and:

MANY strange things been have written about Lafcadio Hearn, the half-Irish, half-Greek minor artist of the nineteenth century whose erratic life was a confused pattern of flight from an industrial civilization which he romantically loathed. But there has been nothing quite so curious as the book by Kazuo Koizumi, his eldest son by his Japanese marriage ("Father and I: Memories of Lafcadio Hearn," Houghton-Mifflin, $2.50).

Having refused to attend the Columbia University commencement exercises Tuesday as a sign of protest against the university's treatment of six medical students, Acting Mayor Bernard S. Deutsch wrote yesterday to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, explaining his reasons in detail.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The more one sees of the Presidency at close range, the more one wonders why any citizen should "run" hard to get it. Mr. Roosevelt and Mr. Hoover both did that. It is not at all surprising that each should now desire re-election as vindication: that wish comes from emotions and instincts irrepressible in man.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A denial that the American Retail Federation was engaging in lobbying and subversively attempting to influence legislation, as charged in a House resolution, was made today before the special committee investigating trade practices of large chain and other mercantile establishments. The dnial eame from Colonel Clarence O, Sherrill, president of the organization.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 5. -- The recent Supreme Court decision upsetting the NRA has aroused so much interest in the Republican "grass roots" conference here Monday and Tuesday that headquarters was flooded today with new requests for accommodations.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Speculative sentiment in grains is wavering, although it is largely bearish on wheat and moderately bullish on corn. Favorable crop reports from the Northwest tend to keep that section a little bearish, but many traders in Chicago are beginning to believe that wheat is low enough, as all futures are selling under 90 cents a bushel and each day brings nearer the harvest in the Southwest.

C.V. Whitney and Mrs. Payne Whitney divided the honors in the main events at Belmont Park yesterday as the former's Bright Plumage scored in the Radiant Purse and Mrs. Whitney's Black Buddy was first in the Gladiator handicap.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Activities of the "Mellon" protective committee for St. Louis-San Francisco bonds were aired today before a hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at which W.O. Douglas, chief of the commission's protective committee division, introduced a reply to a 'commission questionnaire disclosing that no member of the committee held any Frisco obligations.

CHICAGO. June 5 (AP). -- With homers by Chuck Klein and Ken O'Dea accounting for the three-run victory margin, the Cubs again defeated Cincinnati, 5 to 2, today for their third straight victory before 1,229 fans.

PITTSBURGH, June 5. -- Frankie Frisco, manager of the world champion St. Louis Cardinals, tonight dismissed as "so much pop off" the tirade of Dizzy Dean against his teammates as an outgrowth of the row on the Cardinal bench during yesterday's game with the Pirates.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Intending to end soon after July 1 its program of buying preferred stock and capital notes of banks the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today warned banks that have sought funds but have not complied with conditions governing, such assistance should do so soon, and that those contemplating applying for additional capital should do so by July 15.

The first woman to be sentenced to serve a term in jail for contempt of Federal court in this district went yesterday to Jefferson Market prison, where she was to remain for sixty days, unless she produces records sought by a grand jury, which is investigating a customs fraud.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 5. -- "Alabama" Pitts, who is to leave Sing Sing prison here tomorrow on parole after serving five years of a long sentence for a hold-up in New York, was informed tonight that the offer of a job as outfielder for the Albany Baseball Club had been withdrawn because of his criminal record.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Donald R. Richberg on plans for breaking down the code enforcement structure, and with others on the NRA situation.

Cooper Union will hold its seventy-sixth annual commencement exercises tonight in its historic Great Hall. Diplomas, certificates, post-graduate and bachelors' degrees and prizes will be awarded to 290 graduates of the Institute of Technology, the Day Art School, the Night School of Engineering and the Night School of Art.

LONDON, June 5. -- Labor's final attack on the India bill was beaten off tonight by the government in the House of Commons, which gave the measure its third reading by a vote of 386 to 122. The biggest legislative effort ever attempted by the British Parliament is now certain to become the law affecting 350,000,000 persons in India.
EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 5. -- The Aga Khan's colt Bahram, the 5-to-4 favorite, won the English Derby today as every racing tipster said he would.

The report of the Pan American Foreign Corporation and subsidiaries, which are controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, for 1934 was issued yesterday and showed a net income of $13,920,755 after Federal taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization, retirements, interest, minority interest and other charges.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP). -- Paradisical overcame a slow start in the $1,500 Selfridge Field Handicap at the Detroit track today to win handily from a small but classy field. She ran the six furlongs over a heavy track in 1:15 1-5, and paid her backers $12 for $2 in the mutuels.

Ambrose Moore, 33 years old, a patrolman who had been on the police force for nine years when he was suspended last December, interrupted his trial in Bronx County Court yesterday morning to plead guilty to a charge of felonious assault in the second degree.

The scopometer, a new apparatus for making physical and chemical determinations of the vital constituents of the human body, which is being hailed by physicians as a highly important new device in the early detection of disease, was demonstrated yesterday before the American Society of Clinical Pathologists at the laboratory and longevity service of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Newark, N.J.
Business in the money market failed to develop a feature. Beyond routine requirements little else was reported. Quotations remained steady.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, June 5. -- A Russian galleon, sunk outside Helsingfors in the Russo-Swedish war in 1721, which was believed to have been carrying a gold and silver cargo valued at about $5,000,000, was located today by a salvage company after lying undisturbed for two centuries on the bottom of the Gulf of Finland.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 5. -- The Syracuse varsity eight today saw its most serious shake-up of recent weeks. Joe Jacobs suddenly appeared in camp and was given a seat at No. 5. Nunan, who has been rowing at No. 3 in the varsity boat, was set back to the same seat in the jayvee eight.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 5. -- Making an unprecedented take-off for a water-going aircraft by getting on the step and into the air with only one of its two engines functioning, the new Sikorsky S-43, believed to be the world's fastest amphibian, made its first flight here today.

The volume of trading in commodity futures decreased materially yesterday although prices generally displayed a firm undertone. In the cash market, wheat, rye, tin, silk and rubber were higher, while corn, oats, butter and cotton were lower.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 5. -- Diplomas were presented to fifty students at the commencement exercises of the Edgewood Park Junior College, Greenwich, in the Second Congregational Church today.

Pig iron production in May, according to The Iron Age, totaled 1,727,095 tons, or 55,713 tons a day, compared with 1,663,475 tons, or 55,449 tons daily, in April. The gain in daily rate was one-half of 1 per cent. The number of active furnaces on June 1 was ninety-seven, unchanged from one month previous.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- A three-base blast by Mel Ott in Baker Bowl today saved the Giants from a twin setback at the hands of the Phillies and gave Carl Hubbell his seventh triumph of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Broad amendments to the Wagner Labor Disputes Bill, said to have the President's approval and designedI to remove doubts as to its consti-I tutionality were written today intot the measure.

The sixth anniversary dinner dance of the Central Park Casino will take place in that restaurant tonight. A portion of the proceeds will be donated to the Social Service for Cancer, of which Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark is chairman.

GENEVA, June 5. -- About 200 unemployed young men and a few girls sought today to make more real to the International Labor Organization conference the question of the unemployment of youth. Including representatives of almost every shade of opinion, from Catholic to Communist, excepting Nazis and Fascists, they marched to the Electoral Hall where the conference is in session.

DETROIT, June 5. -- A storm of applause approving a reference to future attempts to legalize the NRA swept the auditorium of the Masonic Temple tonight as delegates to the triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs responded to an address by Dr. Waldo E. Stephens, instructor in government at Columbia University.

HAVANA, June 5. -- Army headquarters immediately ordered the commander of the Fifth Military District to take over the hunt for the kidnappers of Antonio San Miguel. The military commander was directed to use all available facilities to find the six men who
That first setback finally caught up with Vito Tamulis, the Yankees' freshman pitching sensation, yesterday at the Stadium.

PARIS, June 5. -- The political crisis has brought the expected reversal in the financial trend, which had previously improved sensationally when the government of Fernand Bouisson was believed to be safe.

United States Government loans and all classes of corporate issues moved moderately higher in more active trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The turnover was $10,737,800, compared with $9,489,400 on Tuesday. Transactions in government issues were $2,667,800, against $2,488,400 the day before.

Plans for a general strike of 3,000 butcher workers in kosher meat markets throughout the city were discussed yesterday by the executive board of the Hebrew Butcher Workers Union as 90 per cent of the stores resumed operation in the face of the continued campaign by housewives against high meat prices.
VILLANOVA, Pa., June 5. -- Degrees in course will be awarded to 200 graduates at Villanova College commencement tomorrow.

Patrolman Thomas F. Sheahan, whose father, also a policeman, committed suicide in 1930, shot himself through the right temple last night in front of the home of President Roosevelt at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street, where he was on fixed post, and died twenty minutes later in Lenox Hill Hospital.

A bitter life is GRETA GARBO'S when it comes to embarking or debarking in the port of New York without attracting notice. She is always slipping up or down the third-class gangplank and always getting caught by the photographers or the reporters, or both.

Confusion incident to a report from Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday attributing to Henry B. du Pont, chairman of the board of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., the statement that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had retired as technical adviser to the company, which has been known as the "Lindbergh Line," was cleared up yesterday by a statement by Mr. du Pont made at the offices of the company in the General Motors Building, 1,775 Broadway.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 5. -- For the past month James J. Braddock has been asked at least a thousand times a day, "How do you feel?" and a thousand times a day Jim has answered, "Fine," "Great," "Swell."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 5. -- Delegates to the American Newspaper Guild's national convention had a hectic session today in which, ultimately, the convention voted a resolution as favoring an industrial union for newspapers. As proposed it would include employes in the business, promotion, clerical and perhaps circulation departments.
Activity in the Bronx continued to feature the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- While plans were completed today for an important NRA policy meeting tomorrow of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, indications appeared that labor might sponsor legislation similar to that of the Guffey Coal Control Bill for other basic or natural resource industries.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Abbot Low Moffat, Republican Assemblyman from the "silk-stocking" Fifteenth district for seven years, is not expected to be a candidate for re-election this year, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A new bill to put control of the trade in arms, munitions and implements of war in a National Munitions Control Board was introduced today by Senator Pope, acting for the Munitions Investigating Committee.

DEERFIELD, Mass., June 5. -- Graduation exercises for a class of 144 seniors of Deerfield Academy were held this morning. Dr. Edward I. Park gave the commencement address. A concert by the Glee Club followed.
The recession in steel bookings following the sudden termination of NRA has been smaller than was expected, according to the weekly summary of the industry issued yesterday by The Iron Age.

The Empire State, training ship of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy, left her berth at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday morning on the first leg of her annual trip to Europe. She carried 155 cadets when she started on a short cruise in Long Island Sound, during which she will calibrate her compass and prepare for her trip abroad.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., June 5. -- Frederick S. Snare of the Garden City Golf Club, a former national senior champion, tied for the day's low gross honors in the opening round of the metropolitan senior golf championship at the St. Andrews Golf Club today.

Two Brooklyn schools, New Utrecht and James Madison, gained a point apiece toward the city P.S.A.L. senior high school track and field team championship during the trials for six events held last evening at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

" Voodooism and revolutions have been so over-emphasized that natural history has been neglected in Haiti," said W. Stephen Thomas, who is sailing today on the Pastores of the Colombian Line for Haiti, where he will spend a month collecting plant specimens for the New York Botanical Garden.

A program calling for the production of forty-two feature-length films during the 1935-36 season was announced yesterday by Universal at the second session of its annual sales convention at the Stevens Hotel in Chicago.

Strictly business: "The Great Waltz" celebrated its last midweek matinee at the Center yesterday with a gross of $4,278,50 out of a potential capacity of $4,416. This at a $2.20 top and in defiance of the fact that the theatrical season was supposed to have closed last week.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- Lefty Grove walked Cliff Bolton with the bases filled in the tenth inning today to force in the winning run and give Washington a 5-to-4 victory over the Red Sox -- the Senators' first triumph in their last nine starts.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 5. -- Miss Gertrude Dubey of the home club and Mrs. Carl H. Donner of Baltusrol tied for the Women's New Jersey Golf Association championship with fifty-four hole totals of 267 at the Rock Springs Club today. They will meet in an eighteen-hole play-off for the title tomorrow.

BRANFORD, Conn., June 5. -- The will of Alfred E. Hammer, former iron manufacturer, which was probated today, bequeathed his estate to his wife and four children. The personality is about $400,000 and the total estate about $1,000,000.

CHRISTCHURCH, England, June 5 (AP). -- Freed five days ago by a jury on charges of slaying her husband, Mrs. Alma Rattenburg, 38, plunged a dagger through her heart and slipped into a lily-covered stream, an autopsy of the recovered body revealed today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5. -- Felix Morely, editor of The Washington Post, will make the commencement address at the School of Education of Rutgers University in the Rutgers gymnasium tomorrow afternoon. Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university, will confer 190 degrees, 2 in Doctor of Education, 1 in Master of Science, 38 in Master of Education and 149 in Bachelor Science in Education.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Within a few hours today after Senators of both parties had sharply questioned the constitutionality of President Roosevelt's reciprocal trading agreements, the Senate in ten minutes ratified six treaties and paved the way for consideration and probable approval tomorrow of the international traffic-in-arms convention.
More than 1,575 slugs and improper coins have been dropped into turnstiles of the Independent subway each day since it opened its first link on Sept. 10, 1932.

Vital social and economic problems, "long crying for solution," are confronting medicine, and in the years to come will assume even greater significance to medical men than purely scientific aspects of their profession, Dr. Frank P. Graves, president of the University of the State of New York and State Commissioner of Education, said yesterday.

Trial of a suit for $300,000 damages brought by Ollie V. Kessler, former government auditor, against the Mercur Corporation of 15 Whitehall Street, its officials and two army officers -- Colonel F.H. Pope and Lieut. Col. W.A. Danielsson -- began yesterday before Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston.

Certificates will be presented to thirty-seven women who have completed a year's course of study of women's legal rights and liabilities at graduation exercises this evening in the main building of New York University at Washington Square.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 5. -- Despite his lofty position as king of the heavyweights, Max Baer took a sound cuffing in his training camp today, where he is preparing to defend his title against James J. Braddock June 13.

LONDON, June 5 (Canadian Press). -- Treacherous pitches caused by rain assisted bowlers in reaping the biggest harvest of wickets for any single day's play in first-class cricket so far this season. Play was curtailed in practically all games today and three teams were dismissed for scores under the century mark.

The Feld-Crawford "fair trade" bill, signed recently by Governor Lehman, which permits a manufacturer to set the price at which his trade-marked merchandise may be sold at retail, is destined to be subjected to the tests of the highest courts, Charles E. Murphy, attorney and former president of the Advertising Club of New York, declared last night.

A fete entitled "Starlight in Normandie" and comprised of a supper dance, cabaret entertainment and fashion show, was held last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

The Meadow Brook Club has announced an entry of ten teams for their tournaments, which start on Sunday, with the first game bringing together Aknusti and Gulf Stream for the Third Westbury Challenge Cups. As teams are eliminated in this competition they will start play for the Meadow Brook Cups, the second tournament of the season.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 5 (AP). -Bahram's time today was two seconds slower than the track record made by Hyperion two years ago end equaled by Windsor Lad last year, but was considered good in view of the condition of the turf, which was soaked by an early morning ra4n.

LONDON, June 5. -- An intensely practical British outlook on foreign affairs will emerge from the forth-coming Cabinet reconstruction, diplomatic observers predicted today, with British policy concentrated on two main objectives. These are:

Two men were drowned about 8 o'clock last night when the coupe in which they were driving home to their families hurtled over a stringpiece and plunged into thirty feet of water between Municipal Piers 11 and 12, Stapleton, S.I.

With seven years of unsuccessful quest written into the records, another American Davis Cup team sailed on board the United States liner Washington at noon yesterday to undertake the reclamation of the world's championship team tennis trophy held by England.
LONDON, June 5. -- A 35,000,000 London transit development project was announced today. The program is expected to take five years to complete.

A THIN chap but a stout runner, that's John Edward Lovelock, lately from London. He is medium in height and slim of build. He has a fine crop of sandy-red hair with plenty of curl in it. He has a cheerful outlook on life and a quietly humorous turn of speech.

The ancient story telling of the award of prizes to those Greeks who had done most for their country in time of greatest peril has been revived in association with the name of E.W. BEATTY. The generals being the voters in the Greek award, each voted for himself for the first prize, but all agreed that the second should go to THEMISTOCLES.

HAVANA, June 5. -- Antonio San Miguel, president of the Guantanamo and Western Railway and one of the wealthiest men in Cuba, was kidnapped at 6 o'clock this afternoon on Vento Road in Vibora, a suburb of Havana, by six armed men who were dressed as soldiers.

Steps toward the formation of a new body to be known as the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board to maintain fair trade practices and wage and hour provisions were taken yesterday by the Coat and Suit Code Authority, which immediately reconvened as a permanent organization committee, following a meeting at which the Code Authority was formally liquidated.

BERLIN, June 5. -- Adolf Cardinal Bertram, Archbishop of Breslau, today issued a statement over his signature which accepted the view of the secular authorities regarding the violations of foreign exchange regulations committed by members of Catholic orders and announced canonical proceedings against the offenders.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5. -- Karl Sherry, Providence College, pitcher, shut out Yale, 2 to 0, today with only four singles to provide the most brilliant pitching of the season against the Elis.

Vincent C. Peppe, Greenwich Village real estate operator, who attempted suicide in April, 1934, after he had been asked to resign from the Board of Standards and Appeals, hanged himself yesterday from a bannister on the second floor of a dwelling at 32 West Eleventh Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5. -- Francis Colsson Kelly, 52 years old, of 529 West 186th Street, New York banker, was killed last evening when an automobile in which he was riding skidded on Route 25 in North Brunswick Township and crashed into another car. Mrs. John Roberts of 8 East Fifty-fourth Street, New York, his aunt, was seriously injured, and William Lindale, 33, of Larchmont, N.Y., a friend, who was driving, also was hurt.

While struggling to escape down a staircase of the thirteen-story building at 19 West Thirty-fourth Street yesterday morning, Charles Barton, 29 years old, of 158 West Seventy-fifth Street, was shot in the left leg by Detective Thomas J. Coleman.
