Fourteen major prizes in the Irish Free State Hospital Sweepstakes in yesterday's Derby at Epsom Downs went to Americans.

KANSAS CITY, June 5 (AP). -- Flood waters of the Kaw River, rushing over its valley in Eastern Kansas, broke through the north end of the Lewis Levee four miles northwest of Lawrence, Kan., at 9:30 o'clock tonight and residents in the lowlands of North Lawrence were evacuating their homes.

DETROIT, June 5 (AP) -- Tommy Bridges recorded his seventh straight victory with the Tigers today, getting a 5-to-4 decision over the Indians with a two-bagger in the ninth that scored Gerald Walker with the winning run.

Directors of the Foundation Company have decided not to apply for permanent registration of its common stock which, under the terms of the Securities Exchange Act, will be dropped from the New York Stock Exchange list on June 30, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange.
PARIS, Thursday, June 6. -- Politically, this new crisis in French affairs caused by the defeat of the Flandin and Bouisson Cabinets in close succession is extremely serious.
The Homestake Mining Company declared the usual monthly extra dividend of $2.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 5. -- President Roosevelt's proposed "Codeless NRA," under which business would cooperate voluntarily in the extension of practices built up under the Blue Eagle, was endorsed today by Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Commissioner Ordway of the Civil Service Commission only too modestly upholds the good of reclassification of civil service grades of employes. May I add a view of employes, including myself?

LONDON, June 5. -- Lord Trenchard has resigned the post of Commissioner of Metropolitan Police after three and a half years spent in reorganizing Scotland Yard. His work was described by The Times tonight as an administrative achievement that, of its kind, had few parallels for scope, speed and completeness.

PITTSBURGH, June 5. -- Oakmont, scene of the national open championship in 1927 and again honored by being selected for this year's test, hummed with activity today as 159 golfers got in their final practice rounds.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The registration statement of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, revealed payment of $63,000 compensation to H.S. Wherrett, president, and $72,000 to H.A. Gait, vice president and president of the Southern Alkali Corporation, a subsidiary. Edward Pitcairn, vice president, received $18,000; R.L. Clause, vice president, $48,000; J.H. Heroy, vice president and president of a subsidiary, $27,500; H.B. Higgins, vice president, $48,000.

The Standard Capital Company, a new concern to finance independent motion picture productions, has leased space in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, J. Cheever Cowdin, the president, will maintain his personal offices in 40 Wall Street. The other officers are Lawrence W. Fox Jr., vice president, and Margaret Sullivan, secretary and treasurer.

A community music centre in which will be housed all the music projects now being conducted by the Works Division will be established by the Emergency Relief Bureau at 93 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Oswald W. Knauth, executive director.

For the second time in three days a General Sessions jury before Judge Otto A. Rosalsky yesterday acquitted a professional bondsman on a perjury indictment in the first trials growing out of the March grand jury's investigation of bail bond abuses in the courts.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5. -- Counsel for Dr. Lienhard Bergel, German instructor at New Jersey College for Women, who charges that he is being unjustly dismissed, asked today for data bearing on the number of Jewish students enrolled in the Women's College.

The Railroad Credit Corporation has returned $23,548,324, or 32 per cent, of the $75,422,000 raised from the proceeds of emergency freight surcharges to the contributing railroads, it was announced yesterday. Of this $14,038,000, or 19 per cent, was returned in the year ended on May 31, 1934, and $9,510,000, or 13 per cent, in the year ended May 31 last.

Two New York State Amateur Olympics, Johnny Clinton and Jimmy Cleary, captured titles last night in the 147 and 112-pound class bouts of the first boxing tournament staged by the Catholic Boys Club of New York and Westchester County.
Mrs. Lee Ballin gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Mr. and Mrs. Donald Walton, Miss Isabel Lee, Douglas Ballin Jr., Charles Disbrow and William Haldt.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., June 5. -- General Hugh S. Johnson in an address here today cited specific definitions by Congress of interstate commerce, unfair competition, monopoly and monopolistic practices which, he said, will withstand judicial attack, as the foundation of an enduring national recovery plan likely to produce beneficial results.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Wilcox bill to authorize the construction of permanent air corps stations throughout the United States, Alaska and overseas possessions passed the House today with other military bills and with practically no debate.

After carefully reading and comparing statements made by those who are antagonistic to the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating NRA, I am forced to conclude there is at least one characteristic common to all such adverse criticism, to wit, a lack of sympathetic understanding of the philosophical principles of human rights and liberties incorporated in that most beneficent of political documents, the Constitution of the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5. -- The third annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute closed here tonight with the belief apparently firmly established among the 1,200 utility executives present that the electric power and light industry is to be the first one nationalized.

Hilda Burke, American soprano, has been engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Association for next season, it was announced yesterday after a cablegram from Edward Johnson, general manager, was received at the Opera House. Negotiations with Miss Burke began before Mr. Johnson went abroad and they were completed by him there.
Solid hitting and a barrage of home runs by the New York Athletic Club nine sent the Manhattan team down to a 10-to-4 defeat at Manhattan Field yesterday.

Shirley Temple returns to the screen of the Radio City Music Hall today in "Our Little Girl," a Fox production featuring Rosemary Ames, Joel McCrea and Lyle Talbot. The stage show, a Russell Markert production, is titled "Spotlights."

BOSTON, June 5 (AP). -- Losing a final plea for a reprieve, Murton and Irving Millen and Abraham Faber prepared tonight to go to the electric chair, probably tomorrow night, for murder. They said farewells to their relatives in State prison today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 5. -- Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will make the address tomorrow morning at the graduation exercises of the Westminster Choir School of Princeton. Dr. John Finley Williamson, president of the school, will award Bachelor of Music degrees to a class of thirty-three.

ROME, June 5. -- Almost simultaneously with the opening meeting in Milan tomorrow of the Italo-Abyssinian Conciliation Commission -- or the Italo-Franco-American Conciliation Commission, as the Italian press prefers to call it -- the first contingent of the Italian Sabauda Division will be embarking in Cagliari for East Africa after having been reviewed by the Under-Secretary of War and the Secretary General Of the Fascist party.

Public offering will be made today of $29,500,000 of the Commonwealth Edison Company's first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds due in 1965, priced at 98 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.68 per cent. The proceeds will be used to redeem the company's outstanding issues of $17,500,000 first mortgage 5 1/2s, Series G, due in 1962, and $12,000,000 collateral mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series E, due in 1960.

TOLEDO, Thursday, June 6. -- Less than twenty-four hours after electrical workers of the Toledo Edison Company went on strike, a mass meeting of union members voted, 237 to 22, early today in favor of returning to work immediately, pending the outcome of negotiations on a 20 per cent wage increase.

LONDON, June 5. -- A feature of the stock market today was a rise in oils following better overnight news from Wall Street. Chief interest however, centred in the foreign exchanges, with the franc active on the latest political news from Paris.

OTTAWA, June 5. -- Amendments to the Dominion Companies Act to bring it into line with the recommendations of the Royal Commission, which recently reported on Canada's economic set-up, were introduced into the House of Commons today by the government.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 5. -- Josef Lampersberger, the German fugitive who was kidnapped from Czechoslovakia by German political and uniformed police and was released two days ago, declined today to reveal what happened to him in Germany.

New Jersey has at last been driven to a 2 per cent sales tax as the surest means of raising needed revenue. A combination of parties in the Legislature finally gave Governor HOFFMAN the legislation which he favored. The State's most urgent fiscal requirement is for relief of the unemployed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 5. -- The Tennessee Electric Power Company of Chattanooga received the Charles A. Coffin Medal here today, at the convention of the Edison Electric Institute, for distinguished service to the public and the electric industry during 1934.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Legislative efforts were started in earnest today to trim the New Deal down to fit the Supreme Court's interpretation of the Constitution, pending whatever efforts President Roosevelt later may make to modernize the basic law of the nation.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP). -- The Browns, led by Jack Knott who turned in a two-hit performance, today snapped the eight-game winning record of John Whitehead, young White Sox pitching star, and defeated Chicago, 2 to 0.

The problems of the nursing profession, including the need for changes in school standards, were discussed yesterday at the convention of the National League of Nursing Education, which opened on Monday at the Hotel Roosevelt. Nearly 1,000 delegates from various parts of the country are attending.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 5. -- On the eve of his seventy-seventh birthday, Samuel Untermyer said at "Greystone," his estate here, this evening that he felt "things were at last looking up" and that he was a "firm believer in the policies of President Roosevelt" to lead the country out of the depression.

The American Institute of Architects issued a statement yesterday calling upon the building industry to act through the Construction League of the United States "to preserve the valuable elements" in the NRA construction codes.

To reach the large number of readers who have made the acquaintance of Mary Ellen Chase through "Mary Peters," Little, Brown are publishing in August a new edition of her earlier novel, "Uplands," which appeared first in 1927.

Members of the Emergency Relief Bureau were blocked in their second attempt to increase administrative salaries yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted an additional $872,000 for June relief with the distinct understanding that no increases would be given to those earning more than $30 a week.

Roger Echegut, the French boy who arrived on the Normandie as an ambassador to boys of this country, experienced a bewildering social round yesterday. Soon after his arrival from a visit to President Roosevelt he posed for a portrait painter at the Boys Club of New York and then went to the Empire State Building roof to make a succinct appraisal of Al Smith.

TACOMA, Wash., June 5. -- A mysterious motor trip, presumably in search of the hiding spot where kidnappers held him, was made today by 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser in company with Federal agents, in was learned tonight.

Unfortunately, there are millions of people who cannot yet read and who cannot think for themselves. These people, and a goodly number of them are radically inclined, accept as gospel what other people, of passing fame, say.

After receiving yesterday from the State Insurance Department a pile of documents to support the State's claim that the New York Title and Mortgage Company should be liquidated, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler gave directors and stockholders of the company until next Thursday to produce evidence that the company is in a condition to be reopened for business.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 6. -- Mrs. Tully O. Buckner received the tricolor for an exhibit of three hybrid tea roses in the cultural class and Mrs. George E. Andrews won the tricolor in the artistic arrangement class for a display of iris at the flower show of the White Plains Garden Club, held today at the Community Church here.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Presidential approval was reported stamped today on a draft of new legislation to create a permanent Federal agency for controlling the liquor industry.

Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area, made public yesterday at Governors Island the lists of successful candidates chosen to attend this year's Citizens' Military Training Camps at Plattsburg Barracks and Fort Niagara, N.Y.

Retail package deliveries made in the metropolitan area by the United Parcel Service for the week ended June 1 showed an increase of 8 per cent, it was reported yesterday. For the four weeks' period ended on that date there was a gain of 1 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Prices of hogs dropped 5 to 25 cents a hundredweight today, the latter on heavyweight hogs and sows. Scattered lots, averaging 200 to 225 pounds, sold at $10, but it was difficult to get more than $9.85 at the last.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 6. -- Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, 25-year-old baseball and football star of Sing Sing, left the prison here this morning on parole after serving five years and two months of an eight-year sentence for a new York hold up.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- President Roosevelt transmitted to Chairman Rayburn of the House Interstate Commerce Committee an opinion of Attorney General Cummings that it would be unwise to ask the Supreme Court for a rehearing on the Railroad Retirement Act.

GENEVA, June 6. -- The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations yesterday heard a British report on prosperity in Palestine. The financial position continues sound, the report said. Revenues from customs remain sufficiently high to enable the extension of various services to meet the demands of an increasing population, while reducing some taxes.
PARIS, June 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
THORPE-LE-SOKEN, ESSEX, England, June 6. -- Death took another of Britain's great war heroes today, leaving only one outstanding leader, Viscount Allenby, alive.

DETROIT, June 6. -- Directly or indirectly, the NRA and its future continued today to focus the attention and interest of the General Federation of Women's Clubs in its deliberations at the triennial convention here.

For the second successive night picketing disorders in Forty-second Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues brought out police reserves last night. Seven arrests were made, bringing the total for the last two days to twenty-nine.

PITTSBURGH, June 6. -- The Pirates climaxed a climb from fifth place in the National League standing to second in a little over a week's span today when they turned back the Cardinals, 2 to 1, to move a half game ahead of the losers.
QUECHEE, Vt., June 6 (AP). -- Herbert Hoover came into Calvin Coolidge's native Vermont today to fish.

BUENOS AIRES, June 6. -- Rivalry between the peacemakers has further slowed the Chaco peace negotiations. It was intimated tonight in circles close to the mediators that little more could be done until the Chilean Foreign Minister, Miguel Cruchaga Tocornal, arrived in response to an invitation that Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina sent to the Foreign Ministers of all the mediating nations.

About 1,500 persons attended the seventh annual members' visiting day at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon. This was more than twice the number present on visiting day last year.

The 1,520 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $43,719,824,364 par value as of June 1, had a total market value of $39,617,835,876, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. On May 1 there were 1,531 issues, aggregating $44,266,533,356 par value, which had a total market value of $40,147,199,897.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose to a new high level this week at about $2,425,000,000, it was indicated in the Federal Reserve's weekly report as of Wednesday, published yesterday. This compared with the previous high record of about $2,350,000,000 which had been maintained for several weeks.

The World War battle of Vimy Ridge, one of the two most famous victories of the late General (later Field Marshal) Byng, was part of a British attack on the Hindenburg line on a front of twelve miles in April, 1917.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Spreading operations between the near and new crop deliveries in wheat, buying of July and selling of September by local as well as Southwestern interests, combined with reports of floods in the Southwest damaging the wheat crop, and with more disposition to buy on weak spots, were features today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Bill amended in an attempt to make it conform to the definition of interstate commerce laid down by the Supreme Court in the Schechter case was reported to the House today by the Labor Committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 6. -- Harold W. Garton of Lord Taylor captured low net honors with 82 -- 18 -- 64 in the sixteenth annual golf tournament of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York at the Century Country Club today.

A decline of $59,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement, published yesterday. The drop was the result of liquidation of loans, partly offset by increases in investments.

If all the accidents in the United States spread through the year 1934 were recorded as of one day, it would be as if all the people of the State of Pennsylvania were suddenly laid low by accident, one-half of the people of Pittsburgh crippled for the rest of their lives and every person in Allentown killed.

The use of work relief funds to carry out projects of the Regional Plan Association was urged yesterday at a conference on city planning and the annual meeting of the association, held consecutively in the Hotel Biltmore.

Through love, charity, understanding and sympathy, kindergarten and nursery school teachers can exert "an untold influence" on children, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday in an address at the commencement exercises of the Froebel League School, 112 East Seventy-first Street.

Mrs. Frank Jay Gould, who is sailing today on the Normandie, gave a large dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the Maharajah of Karpurthala. Before it she gave a reception in the White and Gold Room of the Plaza.
Jersey City will have the first tax sale in its history this Summer, Mayor Frank Hague announced yesterday. He said that tax arrears since 1931 aggregated $20,000,000.
The city of Buffalo announced yesterday that it would sell on Monday $2,500,000 tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness dated June 15 and due on Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Publication of correspondence purporting to have passed between former President Hoover and Mr. Roosevelt as President-elect during the banking crisis of 1933, appearing in an article in the current issue of The Saturday Evening Post, was supplemented tonight by a dispatch to The Minneapolis Journal from George A. Benson, its Washington correspondent.

LONDON, June 6. -- London will present a marked political contrast to Paris tomorrow when one British Government will follow another without a ripple of excitement and without the slightest uncertainty as to what is going to happen next.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 6 (Canadian Press). -- Substantial increases in production of silver, lead and zinc in March compared with the same month last year were reported today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Payment to New York City of its $764,143.75 Civil War claims against the government is being blocked in the House, it was learned today, by Tammany Democrats who do not want this 73-year-old debt settled while a Republican is Mayor.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 6. -- An unknown golfer, Alvin F. Krueger of Beloit, Wis., stole the whole show at Oakmont today when, late in the afternoon, he brought home a 71 to lead the field for the first eighteen holes of the thirty-ninth national open championship.

Disturbed by a week of listening to shrill cries of "We want work, not charity!" workers at the Emergency Relief Bureau at 902 Broadway, on the corner of East Twentieth Street, took matters in their own hands at 3:45 P.M. yesterday.
CIVITAVECCHIA, Italy, June 6. -- A detachment of 100 Italian flame throwers left here today to introduce the latest type of European armaments into East Africa.

Suggestion that the death of Benjamin Bergman, alleged leader of an alien-smuggling ring, may have been a murder, Herman J. Rubenstein, Bergman's attorney, said last night that he would ask the police or the District Attorney to investigate. He pointed out that his client had been "on the spot" between the government and his own accomplices.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The possibility of far-reaching tax legislation which might include even a graduated inheritance levy as proposed earlier in the session by Secretary Morgenthau was mentioned today among administration leaders as they began informal discussions on plans for extending the list of "nuisance" excises which expire on June 30.

The C.V. Whitney string will be represented by a worthy colorbearer in the National Stallion Stakes, it was demonstrated at Belmont Park yesterday when the Dis Donk colt Triumphant won at the first asking in a dash down the Widener chute.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Disclosure of the manner in which officers of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation ran up debts of nearly $1,000,000 to the corporation was made today when an offer was filed before Federal Judge William H. Holly for a compromise settlement of the obligations.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6. -- Four hundred and thirty-nine graduates of the Naval Academy received their diplomas amid roaring applause today in a ceremony which was much shorter than usual because of abandonment of several traditional customs.

Lord BYNG of Vimy took his title from a victory in April, 1917, which in those days of stalemate was impressive. But a bigger achievement in its further consequences was BYNG'S surprise attack at Cambrai, in November, 1917.

LONDON, June 6. -- The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council today delivered two judgments which in effect meant that Canada had the right to bar appeals to the highest British court in criminal cases and that the Irish Free State had the right to abolish appeal to the Privy Council, representing the King, in all cases.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A finding that the Morro Castle ship disaster was due to "failure of the human element," and that the Mohawk tragedy was due to "faulty" ship design was made today by the Senate Commerce Committee in a preliminary report.

So far housing has been one of the disappointments of the New Deal. A great deal has been promised but comparatively little accomplished. It takes time to plan, finance and design the new buildings and to acquire sites for them. All sorts of obstacles have been encountered, among them the inability of the public authorities themselves to make up their mind what they wanted to do and how they proposed to do it.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A charge that activities of the Plymouth Consolidated Gold Mines, Ltd., were designed "primarily to extract gold and silver from investors in this country for the benefit of the promoters and only incidentally to extract gold and silver from mines in distant Mexico," was made by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, June 6. -- Steaming slowly across one of the best cruising grounds in the world -- the vast Pacific between Hawaii and California -- the United States fleet was approaching San Diego tonight with only about 920 miles to steam before the scheduled arrival at San Diego Monday morning.

The first official appearance in New York of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd since his return from Little America and the Antarctic was marked last night by a dinner in his honor at the River Club, 447 East Fifty-first Street. During the evening Charles Davila, Minister from Rumania, presented the highest aeronautical honor of his government to the admiral.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will sail this afternoon on the new liner Normandie of the French Line.

PUNTARENAS, Costa Rica, June 6. -- Thirteen treasure hunters, including Commander and Mrs. F.C. Worsley, departed today for Cocos Island on the yacht Veracity. The little ship was loaded to the gunwales with equipment supplies, which men worked all night to load.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 6. -- Crew Coaches Ed Leader and Don Grant today selected a squad of forty, including thirty-five oarsmen and five coxswains, to leave Sunday for the Yale training quarters at Gales Ferry, above New London, for the annual regatta with Harvard on the Thames June 21.

The loss of a purse containing $75 and two small diamond rings and its return, undisturbed, to the owner, Mrs. Charles Crane, 68 years old, of 22 West Fifty-fourth Street, brought a hornet's nest of trouble for her yesterday.
A moving subway train was the scene yesterday of one of the most daring hold-ups listed among the unsolved crimes on the Brooklyn police records.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 6. -- A new world's record for altitude is in prospect for the Explorer II, the stratosphere balloon which, as soon as weather permits, will take off from the forest-crowned canyon in the Black Hills near here.

Charles Henry Meltzer, former music critic and translator of opera texts into English, will observe his eighty-second birthday today. There will be a reception in his honor at the Greenwich Village Inn at 4 P.M.
ROME, June 6. -- The newspaper Messaggero today published a front-page accusation that Great Britain had arranged a subsidy with Emperor Haile Selassie to give the Ethiopian troops regular pay.

General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig ruled yesterday that J. Richard Davis, attorney for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, racketeer, must hand over to the March grand jury records and documents showing bank accounts and other information about Schultz and five other men said to be intimates of Schultz.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- A "moderate" recession from the Spring peak of business activity was reported today by the Commerce Department.

Many dinners were given last night at the sixth anniversary dinner dance of the Central Park Casino. Part of the proceeds will be donated to the Social Service Fund for Cancer, of which Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark is chairman. More than 500 guests were in the throng which filled the pavilion, terrace and rose-paneled ballroom of the Casino.

Unless reports from the Illinois Springfield have too much hopeful color, the conference of selected delegates from nine Midwestern States which begins there next week will be attended by a goodly number of Republican salvagers. The decision of the Supreme Court on the NRA is said to have stimulated the brethren.

In his address at Columbia University Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said that the Allied Powers had failed to disarm in accordance with, the pledge given in the Versailles treaty. Here Dr. Butler commits a mistake which is commonly made.

MOSCOW, June 6. -- The Spring planting of grain is now virtually complete throughout the Soviet Union. So swift has been the planting and so abundant the rain that experts of the Commissariat for Agriculture are predicting a bumper crop, far above last year's.

MOSCOW, June 6. -- Dr. Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, will be received on his arrival Saturday for a three-day visit as a great statesman of a small country with which the Soviet Union is on terms of the closest international friendship.

Members of the graduating class of Manhattan College were urged last night to be "transmitters of Catholic truth" throughout their lives by Brother Alphonsus, dean of the School of Arts, last night. More than 150 seniors were assembled at the Hotel Taft for their class dinner, which opened Senior Week festivities.

Henry Nielsen of Denmark, who broke Paavo Nurmi's world 3,000-meter record last year by five seconds, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for the Princeton invitation meet at Palmer Stadium a week from tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Governor Earle, in an address at La Salle College commencement today, declared for a "strengthened, amplified, extended" New Deal.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Worried by a strike of employes in the mayonnaise manufacturing firm of Mrs. Schlorer's, Inc., Mrs. Ann Schlorer Smith, the treasurer, attempted suicide by slashing her throat and wrists with a razor blade today in her home, 819 North Sixty-fourth Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 6. -- Mrs. C.P. Luckey of Mount Kisco for the second time in the last few weeks won the low gross prize in today's handicap tournament of the Westchester Fairfield Golf Association over the Bonnie Briar Country Club's links.

BELGRADE, June 6. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the German Air Minister, arrived here this afternoon with his bride. From Dubrovnik he motored to Mostar, where the party took three airplanes to Belgrade. General Goering piloted the leading machine.

The trustee of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, in reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act, reported yesterday for 1934 a loss of $310,575 after certain interest charges, depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes, loss on sale of investments, provision for losses of affiliated companies, scenarios and continuities written off, but before interest on unfunded debt of parent company, interest on subsidiaries' debt guaranteed and subsidiary preferred dividends. In 1933 the net loss was reported as $4,384,064.

PARIS, June 6. -- With political circles in a ferment and reports coming from abroad that the whole world had its eyes on the French franc, the Bourse, the exchange market and financial quarters generally gave what can be characterized only as an amazing example of calmness.

MUNICH, June 6 (AP). -- The statement that obedience contrary to the command of God cannot be given by the church and that no power in the world can release it from its duty of obedience to God is the feature of a memorandum to the Hitler government adopted unanimously by the Augsburg Confessional Synod, which concluded its conclave this evening after long-drawn-out discussions during the day.

After the Civil War when we wanted to return to gold, Secretary Seward said: "The way to resume specie payment, is to resume specie payment." So the way to have peace is to have peace. Who wants war? Not the young men just out of college looking forward to a career with a home, wife and children.

LONDON, June 6. -- Grace Moore, who has won great popularity here as a movie star, made her debut before a London audience in Covent Garden tonight as Mimi in Puccini's "La Boheme." She received a tumultuous reception and took eight curtain calls after the first act, many in the crowded audience standing as they applauded and cheered.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Detailed figures tending to show that the Petroleum Code had resulted in substantial increases in employment, payrolls and weekly earnings were made public today in a report by the Petroleum Labor Policy Board to Secretary Ickes.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Growing opposition to sections of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill, which would abolish public utility holding companies, will result in definite softening of these provisions, with administration approval, it was asserted in informed quarters today.

Winners of the 1934 national championship competition for big game hunters have been announced by the judges, Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of the New York Zoological Park; Horace Albright, former director of national parks, and Dr. James L. Clark, vice director of the American Museum of Natural History.

Helen A. Keller, who, though blind and deaf, learned to speak, said last night that the invention of the talking book was for the blind the greatest invention since the introduction of the Braille system.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The text of the American Federation of Labor statement tonight on reported effects of the NRA decision was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Now that it seems certain that important modifications in the Wheeler-Rayburn bill will be agreed to by the administration (amendments long forecast in these dispatches and described in adjoining news columns), some interesting questions and reflections arise.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 6. -- Bill Brown of the New York State Athletic Commission watched James J. Braddock in his workout today, and went on record as saying that the challenger is in splendid shape for his championship fight with Max Baer at the Madison Square Garden Bowl.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, who was born in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, upheld yesterday the city's action in acquiring, over property owners' objections, twelve square blocks of land for the Williamsburg low-cost housing project.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 6. -- After the first round of the open golf championship, the Oakmont course still is in wonderful condition. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for some of the players. In the early firing they practically massacred themselves.

Cooperation of the nursing profession with other professions and the raising of standards were urged by educators and leaders in the field of nursing at yesterday's session of the annual convention of the National League for Nursing Education at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The State of California sold yesterday at auction a new issue of $5,000,000 of bonds to a banking group composed of the Bankamerica Company, the American Trust Company, the Anglo-California National Bank, Blyth Co., Inc.; Mitchum, Tully Co.; Schwabacher Co. and E.H. Rollins Sons.

Harold H. Corbin, partner of former Governor Nathan L. Miller in the law concern of Miller, Boston Owen, withdrew yesterday his consent to appointment by District Attorney William C. Dodge as special prosecutor for the March grand jury in its investigation of rackets in this city.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A slight decline in commodity prices during the week ended June 1 was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the composite index stood at 80.2, as compared to 80.3 for the preceding week and 73.9 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Large corporations reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission today the following salaries:

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, a decrease of $1,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., June 6. -- Rex Beach added a chapter to his golfing experiences today by winning the metropolitan senior championship with a 36-hole aggregate of 161. The 58-year-old novelist, competing in this tourney for the first time, turned in an 80 at the St. Andrew's course on his second round and led his chief challenger for the title, Frederick S. Snare of the Garden City Golf Club, by a single stroke.

Roger Echegut, "ambassador" from the boys of France, looked indifferently on $2,300,000 that was put into his hands yesterday. For him the vital event in a bewildering round was an old-fashioned swim in the nude.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Over the lone protest of Senator King and without a roll-call, the Senate ratified today the 10-year-old traffic-in-arms convention to prevent the importation of arms into a country without its consent.

The 1935 campaign for funds by the Catholic Charities netted a total of $779,675 in contributions, according to a report made yesterday by Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, its president, at a meeting of the board of trustees at 477 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- The first rivers and harbors improvement authorization bill in five years coursed through the Senate Commerce Committee today after being amended to legalize several hundred million dollars of existing and new projects.

A pledge to maintain the wages and hours provided by the NRA Steel Code, and to preserve its standards of fair competition, was given yesterday by more than 200 executives representing virtually the entire steel industry, at a meeting at the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Empire State Building.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 6. -- Fulfilling a promise made in Paris last July, Mme. Albert Lebrun paid a return visit here today to Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, at the "Summer White House."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 6. -- Mrs. Carl H. Donner of Baltusrol defeated Miss Gertrude Dubey of the home club in an eighteen-hole play-off for the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship at the Rock Spring Club today. She scored an 83 and Miss Dubey a 90.

Sixty-four members of the graduating class of the Cornell University Medical College received their degrees yesterday afternoon at the thirty-seventh annual commencement exercises, held in the college auditorium at 1,304 York Avenue. Eleven prizes for excellence in studies were also awarded.

Cardinal Hayes will elevate thirty-nine young deacons to the priesthood at 8 A.M. tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Most of them will say their first solemn masses Sunday morning in the parish churches in which they were reared.

The Morro Castle Safety at Sea Association, whose members include survivors and relatives of victims of the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters, announced yesterday that it would seek a Congressional investigation of the lobby which it charges is maintained in Washington by American ship lines.

The Associated Merchandising Corporation has formulated no future trade practice policy and will carry on "normal buying in all lines for current needs" and all buyers' meetings planned before the Supreme Court decision will be held as usual, it was announced yesterday by Colonel P.J. Reilly, executive director of the corporation, following a meeting of the general merchandise managers of the buying agency.

Accusations of "fabrication" of letters and misrepresentation of the record were exchanged yesterday in the court room of the Appellate Division as attorneys completed their argument on Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt's appeal from Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew's ruling on the custody of her 11-year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt.

CROOKSTON, Minn., June 6 (AP). -- One person was killed and nearly a score injured late today when a stampeding elephant crashed through a row of seats in a capacity filled tent of Atterbury Brothers Shows.

" Public Hero No. 1," a Metro production, with Lionel Barrymore, Chester Morris, Jean Arthur, Joseph Calleia and Paul Kelly in the cast, will be presented this morning at the Capitol. Sophie Tucker will offer her "WHN Music Hall Revue" on the stage.

EMPORIA, Kan., June 6 (AP). -- Warren W. Finney, former Kansas capitalist, died tonight of a bullet wound inflicted by himself as officers waited to take him to the State penitentiary to start serving a 36-to- 60 year sentence for embezzlement.

Seventy-two students will be graduated from the high school department and fifteen from the grammar department of All Hallows at commencement exercises this evening at the Town Hall, 123 Vest Forty-third Street. This year marks the twenty-fifth of the school's foundation.

Though it is willing to abandon NRA, except for a shell of its former self, the Administration plainly has no such intention with respect to AAA. In fact, it is seeking to strengthen the legal structure on which its whole farm program rests, and for this purpose a new bill has been sent to Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A White House conference today brought a tempering amendment to the bill to abolish public utility holding companies.

Fourteen students received degrees of Bachelor of Science, Naval Architect and Marine Engineer yesterday at the thirty-ninth commencement exercises of the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, Sedgwick and Webb Avenues, the Bronx.

GENEVA, June 6. -- The International Labor Organization conference voted today, 96 to 26, to give its urgent attention to the question of remedying unemployment among the young, which means adopting its recommendation thereon at this session instead of next year.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 6. -- Horse show followers in the metropolitan district will come here tomorrow for the opening of the annual Tuxedo Horse Show. Mrs. David Wagstaff is president of the committee. Luncheons, dinners and a dance incident to the show are planned.

Science has made no progress whatever in the last half century in combatting the diseases that attack persons in the middle-age group, Senator Royal S. Copeland, who is a physician, told 600 persons gathered last night at the annual dinner of the American Institute of Homeopathy at the Waldorf-Astorta.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A simple "stop-gap" resolution, 100 words long, to prolong until April 1, 1936, the life of the National Recovery Act, one-time keystone of the New Deal structure, was recommended to the House today by its Ways and Means Committee, but with a clause repealing all powers granted to the President in the basic Act to approve or impose codes of fair competition for business.

Two lower East Side merchants who, in March, 1933, hired Sam Skoblow, confessed incendiary "torch," to start a blaze in their establishment at 53 Allen Street, were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 6. -- The rulers of the Hudson reached here today from California and began active preparations for the defense of their title in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 18.

Prices of commodity futures continued irregular yesterday in desultory trading. Cocoa, cottonseed oil and wool tops were slightly higher. In the cash markets wheat, rye, cotton, dairy products and lard advanced, while corn, lead, tin, silk and rubber declined.

The united Protestant Sunday school children of Brooklyn, more than 100,000 strong, reasserted their faith yesterday by marching in the 106th anniversary parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union. About 10,000 of the children paraded before the large reviewing stand on the Long Meadow in Prospect Park.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- By a roll-call vote of 76 1/2 to 47 1/2, delegates to the American Newspaper Guild's national convention here approved today a report that favored affiliation with the American Federation of Labor.

CHESHIRE, Conn., June 6. -- Fifty-six students will be graduated from the Roxbury School tomorrow at its commencement exercises, at which the Rev. Dr. Orville A. Petty of New Haven will speak and Arthur N. Sheriff, headmaster, will announce the prizes and awards.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe blew up in an amazing manner after pitching six hitless innings today, but despite their skyrocket ride the Tigers managed to defeat the Indians, 10 to 9, in ten innings and move into a tie with their opponents for third place in the American League.

A slender, graceful span across the Cape Code Canal in Massachusetts and a sturdy highway bridge near Omaha, Neb., were adjudged the most beautiful bridges of steel in the seventh annual competition sponsored by the American Institute of Steel Construction.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Representative Isabella Greenway of Arizona is going to New York this week-end on a momentous mission, to meet her second grandchild.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 6. -- Greeted by nearly a hundred well-wishers of a city aroused by a decision excluding him from organized baseball, Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, Sing Sing prison's star athlete, arrived in Albany today "sure rarin' to go" as a member of Albany's International League baseball club.

Being a taxpayer and somewhat civic minded, I have studied the charts of the Park Department's projects and expenditures published recently with more than passing interest. These figures reveal $10,299,000 will be spent to complete eight swimming pools now under construction in the five boroughs.

The President's "stop-gap" plan, abandoning all attempts longer to enforce any of the provisions for working conditions or "fair-trade" practices formerly existing under the NRA codes, has had a strange effect upon the opinions of some of his critics. Those who had lately seen the NRA only as a "tyranny," a "nightmare," an unmitigated obstacle to recovery, are now indignant because the President is rejecting it completely.

OTTAWA, June 6 (Canadian Press). -- A drop of almost $3,500,000 in deposits of the Bank of Canada was shown in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada, issued today. The reserve in United States funds in the same period dropped more than $2,000,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 6. -- After deliberating more than twelve hours a jury that has been hearing evidence here since May 21 in the trial for second-degree assault of Frank J. Walsh, John J. Corbett, I.R.T., subway guards, and Harold Wellinsky, newspaper columnist, reported to Supreme Court Justice Albert C. Conway at 4:30 this morning that it could not agree.

Lacking any new factors which tended to induce new buying, the markets drifted aimlessly yesterday. Stocks were easier at the last; bonds gained a little as prices fluctuated narrowly; grains closed irregularly lower, and cotton options were up 7 to 11 points.

This may as well start with some notes on persons. George M. Cohan, for instance. Mr. Cohan, emerging from many weeks on the road and one in the Players' revival, said the other day that his tour was not so strenuous. He had, in fact, a good time.

The first women's tennis event of the Summer season which can claim more than purely sectional interest begins today on the courts of the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, as singles play in the ninth annual Sears Cup intersectional team matches is scheduled to get under way at 2 o'clock.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 6. -- Elimination of the defending champion, J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan River, and Robert A. Lester of Baltusrol, runner-up a year ago, marked the first two rounds of the thirty-fourth New Jersey amateur golf championship at the Essex County Country Club today.

After several years of comparative inaction, the League for Less Noise opened a campaign yesterday to lessen New York's noises and thus make the city a better and more healthful place in which to live. The initial program will have as its objective a reduction in the number and harshness of automobile horns -- especially those of taxicabs.

BOSTON, Friday, June 7 (AP). -- The brothers Murton and Irving Millen and Abraham Faber, machine gun killers, were put to death in the electric chair at the Massachusetts State prison early today for the murder of Policeman Forbes McLeod in the hold-up of the Needham Trust Company on Feb. 2, 1934.

Cooper Union conferred 290 diplomas, certificates, post-graduate and Bachelor of Science degrees last night at the seventy-sixth annual commencement exercises held in the Great Hall. At the same time, twenty-six scholarships and forty-three prizes for excellence in academic work were awarded.

Music experts, a "tune detective," an organist and a cantor, as well as attorneys and habitues of Tin Pan Alley, came in swarms yesterday to Federal court and exchanged charges and angry glances during the last day of the trial of Ira B. Arnstein's plagiarism suit against the E.B. Marks Music Corporation.

East Eighty-sixth Street, the Broadway of the German-American section of Yorkville, was thrown into disorder shortly after 8 o'clock last night when a lone mechanic, incensed by a twelve-foot anti-Semitic sign, pitted himself against an organization billed as the "National Socialistic Workers party of America (Aryan Americans)."

RED BANK, N.J., June 6. -- The annual flower show of the Neighborhood Garden Club was held at the Molly Pitcher Hotel here this afternoon. The sweepstakes prize for the best single specimen exhibited was won by Mrs. Joseph Honigman, with a poppy.

Production of steel ingots in the United States last month amounted to 2,602,054 gross tons, or only about 4,000 tons less than in April, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. In May, 1934, when production hit its peak for the year, the total was 3,352,788 tons.

The New York Exchange for Woman's Work celebrated yesterday the fifty-seventh anniversary of its founding with a large luncheon in the exchange restaurant of its headquarters at 541 Madison Avenue. Mrs. Robert C. Ream, president, acted as hostess to members of the board of directors and others interested in the exchange and reported on the progress of the organization.

WARWICK, N.Y., June 6. -- A Paterson (N.J.) detective and an escaped bandit were killed today when Paterson police and New York State troopers brought the fugitive to bay and shot it out with him on the Main Street here.

The Irving Trust Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share, thereby placing its stock on an annual basis of 60 cents, compared with an annual dividend of $1 a share paid previously. The dividend is payable on July 1 to stock of record of June 12.

SHANGHAI, Friday, June 7. -- Complying with one of the Japanese Army's demands for the settlement of issues in North China, the Chinese Government today removed Yu Hsueh-chung, a former Manchurian General, from the Governorship of Hopei Province.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 6. -- Announcement was made here today by S.H. Fabian of the Fabian Theatres of Brooklyn that the five RKO and Proctor's theatres in Albany, Troy and Schenectady and four Farley theatres in the last-named city had been taken over on twenty-five-year leases.

TACOMA, Wash., June 6 (AP). -- New steps by George Weyerhaeuser to aid authorities in tracking down his kidnappers were disclosed tonight when Federal authorities released descriptions the 9-year-old boy had given them of the house where he was held.

BERLIN, June 6. -- Responding to yesterday's official measures and to warnings against over-speculation, the Boerse opened today with a sharp reaction in which many prices were marked down 2 to 5 points. Selling was confined to professionals, however, and the turnover was small, with the result that buoyant factors reasserted themselves and half of the day's losses were wiped out before the close.

A reception for Claude Farrere, recently elected to the French Academy and now here as a member of the Presidential party on the Normandie, was held at Rockefeller Center yesterday. It was sponsored by French and European publications with offices here. M. Farrere is author of "History of the French Navy" and is now at work on a "History of India."

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Eighteen persons will visit Germany and Austria this Summer and Fall for study of conditions and educational methods, under grants from the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation, announced here today.

Only $80,369 has been raised by the women's division of the United Jewish Appeal, said Mrs. Percy Richard Limburg, chairman of the division, speaking yesterday afternoon at a garden party at the home of Mrs. Joseph Stroock, 998 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Grant of millions of dollars in Federal aid for New York City's $150,000,000 low-cost housing and slum clearance program, now understood to include a $20,000,000 project for Hallets Cove, L.I., hinges upon the Justice Department's approval of New York's titles to remaining property necessary for the $12,000,000 Williamsburg project.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 6. -- Crews and handicaps were announced today as the race committee of the Cruising Club of America began inspection of the six yachts awaiting the start of the ocean race to Bergen, Norway, on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- President Roosevelt made public tonight an informal opinion by Attorney General Cummings discouraging any effort to obtain from the Supreme Court a rehearing of argument in the Railroad Retirement Act ease in which the court held the act unconstitutional.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Defying the board of Cook County Commissioners, which unanimously ordered his ouster as County Treasurer and appointed a successor, Robert M. Sweitzer, 67-year-old veteran Democratic leader, barricaded himself with thirty special detectives in his office for about six hours tonight after declaring firmly his intention to hold the place as a fort.

The Federal Government caught up yesterday with an elusive Negro whom it has characterized as "the shadow" and charged him with counterfeiting. He was Sherman L. Cole, 35 years old, of 605 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn. Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, held him in $2,500 bail for the grand jury.

LONDON, June 6 (AP). -- The engagement has been announced of Miss Francesca Cagiati of New York to Viscount Acheson, son of the Earl of Gosford, whose second wife is Mrs. Beatrice Claflin Breese of New York.

WEYBRIDGE, England, June 6. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody was forced to use all her tennis guile and summon every stroke she has before she could subdue 21-year-old Miss Mary Hardwick, English girl, in the quarter-final round of the St. George's Hill tournament today.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange was enlivened by active buying for government account yesterday, following dullness in the morning. Under a demand for new-crop positions as the pool substituted futures for all spot cotton released, besides mill price-fixing in the July, quotations moved up sharply a dollar a bale to end with gains of 7 to 11 points.

Although bank clearings for the five days ended on Wednesday were higher than those of the previous full week, they fell short by 5.7 per cent of the total for the corresponding week of 1934, which covered six days. Twenty-two leading cities in the United States, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., showed clearings of $4,727,250,000, compared with $5,015,159,000 a year ago.
ROME, June 6. -- The Italo-Ethiopia conciliation commission, composed of two Italians, one American and one Frenchman, held its first sitting at Milan this afternoon.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 6. -- Resenting somewhat the criticism that his training is unimpressive, Max Baer livened the proceedings in his camp today as he came to the final week of preparation for his title fight with James J. Braddock a week from tonight.

Plans for a new $1,000,000 building to house the Family Court Division of the Domestic Relations Court in Manhattan were made public yesterday by Presiding Justice John Warren Hill. It is proposed to have the structure erected with PWA funds.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Relief rolls must provide 90 per cent of the labor used on the $400,000,000 road and grade-crossing elimination program under the $4,000,000,000 work relief appropriation, regulations prepared by the Bureau of Public Roads of the Department of Agriculture provide, it was learned today.
FORT VICTORIA, Rhodesia, May 20 (By Mail). -- The famous Tokwe River hippopotamus, idol of thousands of tourists, has been shot.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 6. -- Favored by the weather, which, although threatening at times, remained clear, the first day of the national open championship attracted a crowd of close to 5,000, which augurs well for an enormous gate when the real fighting starts on the final 36-hole round on Saturday.

KANSAS CITY, June 6 (AP). -- The crest of the Kaw River flood swirled down upon Kansas City tonight as an army of dike defenders swarmed along a nine-mile system standing between the raging waters and a populous industrial region.

ROME, June 6. -- Reports persisted in Italian official circles tonight that Pope Pius planned to reorganize the conclave for the election of future Popes. Death has reduced the number of Cardinals to the unusually low figure of fifty, compared with the possible but never reached maximum of seventy.
PARIS, Friday, June 7. -- For the third time within a week President Albert Lebrun asked Pierre Laval yesterday to try to form a Ministry and under pressure from all sides he accepted.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 6. -- Assemblyman Samuel Pesin of Hudson County declared today that questions bearing on alleged anti-Semitism at New Jersey College for Women "were irrelevant" to the investigation being conducted into the German Department of the college by a special committee of Rutgers University trustees.

Demand for high-grade bond issues on the Stock Exchange strengthened yesterday at moderately higher prices. United States Government loans and prime railroad and industrial issues were fractionally higher. The utilities as a group were a shade lower, but this was attributed by dealers to a natural letdown following their fairly sharp rally earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today at its inquiry into the affairs of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company that the fact he had represented interests owning various types of securities of the railroad had not embarrassed him in acting as chairman of the consolidated bondholders committee.
SALEM, N.H., June 6 (AP). -- Boston Brook, Colonel W.A. Jones's 3-year-old brown colt, slithered over a heavy track at Rockingham Park today to capture the Londonderry purse.

Net operating income of the railroads in April increased for the first time since December and for the second time within a year, figures issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads disclosed. With the exception of last December, monthly net figures had shown declines for every month since April, 1934.

Coincident with the sale yesterday of $29,500,000 of Commonwealth Edison Company 3 3/4 per cent bonds and the public offering scheduled for today of $25,000,000 of the American Rolling Mill Company 4 1/4 per cent debentures, plans were announced by two other companies for new financing in the amount of $60,000,000.
LONDON, June 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes:

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Refusal today of the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh to produce its records as evidence in the government's income tax case against Andrew W. Mellon left the next move up to the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Colonel Joseph I. McMullen, chief of the patents section of the Army Judge Advocate General's office, was indicted today by a District of Columbia grand jury on charges of accepting fees from a concern lobbying against a tax bill.
HAVANA, June 6. -- Ransom of $286,000 was demanded today by the kidnappers of Antonio San Miguel, president of the Guantanamo Western Railway and one of the wealthiest men in Cuba.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
SOUTHEND, England, June 6. -- Gerard B. Lambert's American yacht Yankee triumphed today in her first race in British waters, which was marred by mishap and tragedy.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Deeply disappointed with President Roosevelt's decision to be satisfied for the present with a mere "skeleton NRA," the executive council of the American Federation of Labor today declared that adoption of the emasculated NIRA Senate resolution was "a surrender to the opponents of national recovery."

The cold, factual record of resolutions adopted and pledges made by the steel, textile and other industries, with regard to the maintenance of NRA code principles, does not show the fervor with which business men are cooperating in their efforts to preserve wage rates and standards of fair competition.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 6. -- Eighteen students received diplomas today from William P. Jefferys, a trustee, at the annual commencement of the Greenwich Country Day School.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., June 6. -- Connection of the Western producer with the Eastern consumer, thus enlarging the market for both agriculture and manufactured products, and low cost hydro-electric development were pictured at a public hearing today as benefits to be derived from the proposed ship canal to connect the St. Lawrence and Hudson River via Lake Champlain.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices slipped one-tenth point to 124.6 on Tuesday from 124.7 (revised) on the Tuesday previous. The losses, The Annalist said, were greatest among those commodities that would be most affected if control by the AAA was invalidated, including especially wheat and flour, cotton, hogs and lard and dairy products.

The task of reviving American industry is too great for the Federal Government, but business has the power to recover if it has a reasonable opportunity to do so free from uncertainties, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, told members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at their monthly meeting yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, June 7. -- President Agustin P. Justo formally inaugurated the new Central Bank of Argentina this afternoon at a ceremony attended by the entire Cabinet. The bank has been established in a building formerly occupied by the Gold Conversion Office in Calle San Martin.

MAMARONECK, L.I., June 6. -- Mrs. John R. Spader won the sweepstake prize and also was the winner of the tricolor in the artistic arrangement class at the flower show of the Garden Club of Mamaroneck held here this afternoon at the Masonic Hall.
of the Japanese demands in North China.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 6. -- The body of Elwood Rue, 84 years old, of 255 Westfield Avenue, Elizabeth, a retired contractor, was found late last night on the grave of his wife in East Windsor Cemetery with a revolver bullet in the head.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- Behind the five-hit pitching of Henry Coppola, a rookie starting his first game, the Senators shut out the Red Sox, 3 to 0, today, to win the series.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP). -- A rise in the domestic price of wool in May following several months of declining quotations was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull made it plain today that the administration considered the reciprocal tariff program constitutional and intended to proceed with it.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- Jimmy Wilson's Phils banged two home-runs and nine doubles today, but the six hurlers he was compelled to toss into the fray couldn't suppress the rollicking Dodgers, who came from behind with a four-run rally in the eighth and were ahead at the finish, 11 to 9.
BUDAPEST, June 7. -- Tibor Eckhardt, political leader who last week vainly challenged Premier Julius Goemboes to a duel, fought a duel today.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Hogs weighing 13C pounds were picked up readily today at prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. The top price for today was $10, the same yesterday, but 10 cents lower than two weeks ago.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 7. -- Smooth green turf a high blue sky. Light white clouds floating airily along in a stiff southwest wind. From a perch on a mound above the fifth green the Oakmont Club banner could be seen flying straight out in the breeze from the flagpole atop the clubhouse on the distant hill. That was the brilliant setting as the second round of the national open golf championship got under way.

TOKYO, June 7. -- Nanking's reply to the Japanese Army demands relative to North China having been found unsatisfactory, the War Office today sent fresh instructions, in which Foreign Minister Koki Hirota concurred, to the army in China.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 7. -- Need for organized publicity to increase the rental of safe-deposit facilities was stressed today at the annual convention of the National Safe Deposit Association by Judson H. Scott, superintendent of the safe deposit department, Rochester Trust and Safe Deposit Company, Rochester, N.Y.

Officers, directors and the principal holders of stock of a company whose securities are listed on a Stock Exchange must file reports of their holdings on or before the tenth day of the calendar month following the effective date of the permanent registration of that company's securities, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday reminded presidents of corporations whose stocks are traded on the Exchange.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:
From the cup-like starboard tip of the protruding bridge of the Normandie, Mme. Albert Lebrun smiled good-bye yesterday to America.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Voluntary codes set up by industry must, in the light of the Schechter decision of the Supreme Court, comply with the anti-trust laws, President Roosevelt declared today as demobilization of the NRA moved a step further with the resignation of Donald R. Richberg as acting chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7. -- Belief that prices will double as a result of the devaluation of the dollar and other government operations, was expressed at a round-table discussion this afternoon at the annual meeting of the Harvard Business School Alumni Association.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, At Sea, June 7. -- The United States Navy is "highly efficient and we need have no fear of invasion of our coast," Admiral William H. Standley, chief of naval operations, said in an interview yesterday.

AMARILLO, Texas, June 7 (AP). -- Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President, and Governor James V. Allred tonight staged a sharp impromptu debate on the issue of State's rights versus principles of the New Deal on the floor of the Texas convention of young Democrats.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- An assertion by President Roosevelt that he had given no thought to the subject of taxation for more than a month failed today to quiet persistent reports that the administration would soon recommend far-reaching legislation of this character, possibly the inheritance levy recently suggested by Secretary Morgenthau.

BOSTON, June 7. -- The position of the Yankees atop the American League standing became a bit precarious today as the forces of Joe McCarthy cracked into an annoying defeat in opening a four-game series with the Red Sox.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP). -- Reaching four Philadelphia pitchers for sixteen hits, Washington today defeated the Athletics, 11 to 6, in the opening game of the series. The Senators tallied six runs in the seventh to overcome a three-run lead.

TACOMA, Wash., June 7 (AP). -- An airplane search for the "two-gabled" house where kidnappers held little George Weyerhaeuser was disclosed tonight as police speeded up their widening hunt for the abductors.

With her thin blue pennant of victory fluttering like a dark string in the yellow smoke from her funnels, the new liner Normandie sailed yesterday on her first voyage from New York to Plymouth and Havre.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The social program planned for his administration was restated by President Roosevelt today in less than 250 words in response to a request made during the running fire of questions at a White House press conference.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

American shipping men still believe in the feasibility of smaller ships, despite the influence of the new French liner Normandie, in port last week. Although the grandeur and size of the ship impressed American designers and operators as a step in advance of anything previously given the sea, they came away with the conviction that the ship was too large for practical purposes.

Manager Bill Terry took matters into his own hands yesterday when it looked as if a protracted over-time session was on tap at the Polo Grounds. With a line single that whistled over the head of Pinky Whitney, the Giant pilot rammed home the run that gave the league leaders a ten-inning triumph over the Braves, 3 to 2.

SOUTHEND, England, June 7. -- Thousands of yachting enthusiasts were disappointed today when a gale forced the cancellation of the second race between Gerard B. Lambert's American sloop Yankee and the big British yachts. As the tide started to flow, the force of the wind increased and the gale, which had been blowing all night, made it impossible for the boats to get under way.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 7. -- There is little likelihood that the stratosphere balloon, awaiting favorable weather for a take-off in its canyon dock in the Black Hills near here, will leave the ground for at least two days.

GENEVA, June 7. -- In a speech that struck several new notes in the International Labor Organization conference and made an unusually strong impression, Dr. Walton Hale Hamilton threw the United States Government's weight today on the side of a world forty-hour week and collective bargaining.

That three-quarter mile world's record that Gene Venzke has been hankering for a good many years will be the Penn stylist's objective today at the 134th track and field games of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island. The three-quarter-mile special will be the chief attraction of a well-arranged meet that is expected to draw a capacity crowd of 8,000 to the picturesque setting on the Sound.

Retail trade showed e fair degree of improvement during the week with general expectations that, if weather conditions are favorable today, an extremely heavy turnover will be noted. Estimates yesterday indicated dollar volume was running at about 4 to 5 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

PARIS, June 7 (AP). -- The draw for the Franco-Australian Davis Cup tennis eliminations was made today. Jack Crawford will play Andre Merlin and Vivian McGrath will meet Christian Boussus in the opening singles matches tomorrow.

The four topseeded players occupied positions in the semi-final round bracket in the eighteenth annual open Brooklyn tennis championship as play ended yesterday at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. They were Gregory Mangin, Leonard Hartman, Frank Bowden and Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, ranked in that order.
" Arrowsmith," with Ronald Colman and Helen Hayes, will be revived at the Globe for an indefinite engagement starting this morning.
U. S. l)eparlment of Agr. h:0iture. Meat trade conditione and wholesale prices in ,New York;

John Kaul Jr., 5 1/2 years old, who disappeared from Fifty-fifth Street near the East River, Thursday evening, was still missing early today, but a large squad of policemen had a possible clue with which to work on in their efforts to determine whether or not the boy had been kidnapped or drowned.

Announcement that Mrs. Mary McLeod Bethune, Negro founder and president of Bethune-Cookman College, Daytona Beach, Fla., had won the 1935 Spingarn Medal was made yesterday by Oswald Garrison Villard. Mr. Villard is chairman of the Springarn Medal Award Committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

This department is childishly fond of the comical Jimmy Savo. It has been for some time -- long before the boys began to hail him as "the second Charlie Chaplin." Therefore, his debut on Thursday evening as the star entertainer at the Versailles Restaurant was awaited with keen anticipation.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 7. -- Six boats and forty-four men were ready tonight to begin a great sporting adventure, the transatlantic race from this port to Bergen, Norway.

Stevens Institute of Technology will confer the degree of Mechanical Engineer upon seventy-nine members of the senior class, at its sixty-third annual commencement exercises in Hoboken at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Six graduate students will receive the degree of Master of Science.

A bond issue of $9,400,000, underwritten by S.W. Straus Co., Inc., to construct the Majestic Apartments, at Central Park West and Seventy-second Street, was exhausted when only about forty-five of more than 200 apartments were completed for occupancy, according to testimony yesterday in the hearing on charges of fraud made against Straus Co. before Harry A. Gordon, as referee, in the office of Louis F. Schultze, 9 East Forty-sixth Street.

No more than 5 cents a month will be saved by at least 70 per cent of the residential consumers of electricity under the new rates proposed by the six electric companies of the Consolidated Gas system, according to a memorandum submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

The city of Cleveland, Ohio, yesterday sold to Edward B. Smith Co., Merrill, Hawley Co. of Cleveland and the Illinois Company of Chicago a new issue of $300,000 of paving and sewer bonds. The winning bid was 100.309 for 3 1/4s. The bonds, dated June 1, 1935, will be due on Sept. 1, 1936 to 1946.

Activity subsided somewhat yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. The list appeared to be marking time pending announcement of plans of the United States Treasury and other government agencies for new financing. Transactions were $8,390,700, compared with $10,961,900 on Thursday.

Mrs. Adeline Cardway, 42 years old, was found dead at 4:15 A.M. yesterday in the kitchenette of the two-room apartment she occupied with her husband, Colonel Frederick Cardway, at 277 Park Avenue. Three burners of the gas range were open.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- As a culmination of almost two years of research, Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, submitted to the railway regional coordinating committees today a list of suggested reforms in freight service which, if put in effect, would run sharply across methods and procedures followed for many years in railway offices, freight yards and "on the line."

FAIRFIELD, N.J., June 7. -- Breaking 132 birds in a row, Fred S. Tomlin, Glassboro professional, today went on to score 149 and win the honors in the preliminary shoot of the thirty-second competition conducted by the New Jersey State Amateur Trap Shooting Association.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 7. -- There is no getting away from it, Max Baer prefers clowning to anything else in his training workouts.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The text of William Green's radio speech tonight was as follows:

The New York Title and Mortgage Company, five of its subsidiary corporations and six of its officers were indicted yesterday by a special Federal grand jury on charges of mail fraud and conspiracy growing out of its sale prior to 1933 of so-called guaranteed mortgages and certificates.

Medical and hospital authorities recommended higher standards for schools of nursing yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the National League of Nursing Education, held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, June 7. -- The first communique issued tonight by the Foreign Office in connection with preliminary naval conversations between Great Britain and Germany, which began in London four days ago, announces that the delegates are taking a week's holiday.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 7. -- Hunter and jumper competitions held the interest of the spectators today at the opening sessions of the annual Tuxedo Horse Show in the picturesque natural amphitheatre in Tuxedo Park.

Chalmers Wood, chairman of a committee of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms formed to help to settle protested trades in Alleghany Corporation $2.50 prior-preferred stock on a when-issued basis, announced yesterday the formation of an arbitration board to act in the controversy.
An intensive campaign against one of the most voracious of predators -- the snapping turtle -- has been started by the Southern New York Fish and Game Association.

The Zonite Products Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1934 a net loss of $164,390, after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, and including operating losses of $321,857 in the wines and spirits division and write-down of inventories.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday that he would appoint no one as Deputy Assistant District Attorney to take the place of Harold H. Corbin, who, on Thursday, withdrew his consent to serve as special prosecutor in the March grand Jury's investigation Of rackets and vice conditions.

ROME, June 7. -- The Italo-Ethiopian Conciliation Commission, at the end of its second three-hour sitting at Milan today decided to adjourn to June 25, when it will meet at Scheveningen, the Netherlands. The preparatory part of its work has been completed, and the procedure to be followed has been decided upon.

The new British Prime Minister announced his new Cabinet yesterday. It turns out to be very much like the old, except that there has been a certain shuffling of names and portfolios, with the addition of a handful of new men. Perhaps the appointment most unexpected was that of Sir SAMUEL HOARE as Foreign Secretary.

A symposium on "The Master and Apprentice System as a Method of Art Instruction" will be held at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, at 2 o'clock this afternoon. There will be two speakers, H. Lincoln Rothschild of the Fine Arts Department, Columbia University, and Professor Eugene G. Steinhof, director of the Department of Design at the Beaux, Arts Institute of Design.

Television, of a clarity almost equal to home movies, is now a reality in Montreal, according to William Hoyt Peck, New York inventor, who spent the day here yesterday on business and returned to Canada last night to undertake the second phase of television's development in the Dominion.

HELSINGFORS, June 7. -- The Soviet policy of creating a "safety zone" along the Finnish frontier by moving the local population of Finnish origin to Central Russia and substituting Russians is now reported to be nearing completion.

Charges made by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in Washington Thursday night that industries which he listed were cutting wages and lengthening hours as the immediate result of the NRA decision by the Supreme Court, were denied yesterday by most of the companies named in the federation survey.
