CHICAGO, June 7. -- Sentiment in the wheat trade was bearish today and the local element on the Board of Trade was disposed to sell on every little upturn in prices, thus making bulges hard to hold. At the same time the one in corn was moderately bullish and in oats and rye it was bearish principally.

LONDON, June 7. -- Stanley Baldwin for the third time in his political career became Prime Minister of Great Britain today, replacing Ramsay MacDonald, who was compelled to retire chiefly because of failing health.

The statement yesterday by President Roosevelt that price pacts would not be permitted if they conflicted with the anti-trust laws was the subject of much discussion in one or two industries which are attempting to form voluntary codes and continue virtually as they were under the NRA.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 7. -- The gardens of twenty-one Summer estates here will be opened this season to public view on Wednesday afternoons. In other years the day has been Tuesday. The beneficiary will be the Newport Civic League.

HAVANA, June 7. -- Despite Cuba's greatest man hunt, the military and police have failed to locate the kidnappers of Antonio San Miguel, wealthy 78-year-old president of the Guantanamo and Western Railway, who was seized Wednesday and held for ransom of $286,000.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 7. -- James J. Braddock today eased off in his training long enough to celebrate his twenty-ninth birthday. This took the form of a small dinner party and a visit from his mother, Mrs. Elizabeth O'Toole Braddock, who sees him in all his bouts, and a delegation of friends from North Bergen, N.J.

The Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., and subsidiaries, including the Gatineau Power Company, reported yesterday for 1934 a consolidated gross revenue of $9,360,974, after loss on exchange, compared with $9,292,048 in 1933. Net income after all deductions was $2,290,306, in addition to which there was a profit of $89,140 on bonds redeemed, making total additions to surplus $2,379,446, compared with $2,471,968 in 1933.

Among the 1,900 passengers sailing tonight for the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Widener. Mr. and Mrs. P.A.B. Widener, Mrs. Chauncey M. Depew. Prince Chlodwig Hohenlohe-Schillingsfuerst and the Princess.

There was salmon fishing in City Hall Park yesterday morning for the first time in the memory of the city's oldest residents. It was successful, too, and Stanley Howe, Mayor La Guardia's secretary, landed a ten-pound Maine salmon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7. -- The crews of Syracuse, Columbia and California had the Hudson to themselves for the last time today as each completed double workouts in preparation for the intercollegiate regatta on June 18.

A book by Edouard Herriot, French political leader, college professor and enthusiastic amateur musician, is on the Macmillan Fall list. It is "A Life of Beethoven," and is an interpretation of Beethoven and his work in the light of his times.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 7 (AP). -- A fourfold expansion program of the Department of Justice by which it will help to train local police and prison officers at a national "crime institute" was outlined tonight by Attorney General Cummings in a speech at the tercentenary of the First Congregational Church.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP). -- West Main raced to his third consecutive victory at Washington Park today when the 5-year-old son of Westwick-Mantle, captured the Chicago Heights Purse at six furlongs by a head. Johnny Longden rode the winner, which races for C.A. Peck.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Organized labor's determination to fight for a constitutional amendment forbidding the Supreme Court to invalidate any act of Congress and its refusal to accept a skeletonized NRA were voiced tonight by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a speech over an N.B.C. network.

William Woodward's Omaha is expected to get the acid test this afternoon which will stamp him the 3-year-old champion when the sixty-seventh Belmont Stakes is run at Belmont Park. The race, which will gross about $50,000, is patterned after the Epsom Derby and is over the testing route of a mile and a half.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, June 7 (AP). -- Lord Stanley's Quashed, coming from behind, as did Bahram in the Derby, today took the measure of sixteen other 3-year-old fillies in the 157th running of the Oaks.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the most violent and erratic of the week, ending with net losses of 10 to 14 points.

DETROIT, June 7. -- Secretary Wallace, upholding the efficacy of the AAA, was the final speaker tonight at the close of an absorbing day of the current triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs here.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 7. -- Strict adherence to the Constitution and rebirth of the Republican party under the name Constitutional party are the dominant notes sounded tonight by Republican leaders arriving for the conference of ten Midwestern States.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP). -- The White Sox reached three Detroit pitchers for sixteen hits, including Zeke Bonura's tenth homer, today and needed all of them to with-stand the Tigers' persistent bombardment of Ted Lyons, 9 to 8. The victory enabled the Chicagoans to gain a game on the Yankees, who now lead them by two games.

Since the basic need of the railways is more traffic, and since traffic cannot be provided merely by the whisk of a pen or a roll-call in Congress, the President's message yesterday leaves the basic problem of the carriers unsolved. At various points, however, he has proposed measures which, if approved by Congress, would place the railways in a better position to take advantage of any increase in industrial activity.
There was no feature to the business in the credit market. Turnover continuing light, the quotations for all classifications remained unchanged.

MOSCOW, June 7. -- A cry of chivalry toward women went up today in this land where women are so emancipated they work with pick and shovel in subway tunnels, sweep streets, drive trucks, and plow and reap in the fields, besides having equal rights in the more learned and less onerous callings.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 7. -- Dr. Frederick C. Ferry, president of Hamilton College, will give the address at the 169th anniversary commencement of Rutgers University in the Rutgers gymnasium tomorrow morning. Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university, will confer 223 baccalaureate degrees and twenty-eight advanced degrees.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 7. -- Liver extract which has saved many victims of pernicious anemia has been discovered to be a remedy for agranulocytosis, a mysterious new blood disease, it was reported today before the fourteenth annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Pathologists at the Hotel Madison.

Raymond J. Healey, 22-year-old would-be "American Hitler," received a three-hour hearing in night court last night on a charge of disorderly conduct for his part in the display of an anti-Semitic sign on East Eighty-sixth Street Thursday night, which caused a riot in the heart of the German-American neighborhood.

Captain Alfred W. Peterson, who was master of the Ward liner Havana when she was grounded Jan. 16 on the Mantanilla reef, in the Bahamas, was declared guilty of an error of judgment in navigation, in a report made yesterday by Captain Karl C. Nielsen and James Smith, local steamboat inspectors.

Professor JERVEY in his address as University Orator on Commencement Day at Columbia carried over into the field of economic activity and into the realm of intellectual or imaginative life the law of liberty which DANIEL WEBSTER pronounced in oft-quoted words in that charming city of the South which is now "so gently sleeping-off a rich and turbulent past": "Liberty exists in proportion to wholesome restraint."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 7. -- A public links golfer, Dominick Morano of the Branch Brook Golf Club in Belleville, reached the final round of the thirty-fourth New Jersey amateur championship at the Essex Country Country Club today.

With the general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America deciding to raise a $1,000,000 fund to increase its membership and "to protect the present hour and wage standards of our workers," the joint board of the Dressmakers Union announced yesterday it would stage labor's first demonstration in New York City today against the possibility of attack on the thirty-five-hour week under the Supreme Court NIRA decision.
Europe. Fri- Thurs- Week Year Fri- Thurs- Week Year day. day. Ago. Ago. The value of the dollar on the day. day. Ago. Ago. RUMANIA--Par 1.0127 cents

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 7. -- Mrs. Robert Wyld of Garden City won with her display of iris the highest honors in the flower show of late Spring and early Summer blooms, held by the Garden City-Hempstead Community Club today in the Casino.

Two of the oldest college rivals, Yale and Princeton, are scheduled to meet in the opening game of the 1935 intercollegiate outdoor polo championship this afternoon on Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island. The contest will begin at 2:30 o'clock, the starting time having been advanced from 4 o'clock as originally announced.

The B. Seiden Hat Company and the William F. Chiniquy Company, both of Chicago, began suit in the Supreme Court here yesterday for an accounting and for a receiver for the Millinery Code Authority of this city and the National Millinery Code Authority.

In April Secretary MORGENTHAU, warning that Congress would have to provide new revenues to pay the soldiers' cash bonus, suggested a Federal graduated inheritance levy, imposed at the same rates as those in the Federal income tax, and estimated that this would raise $300,000,000 to $600,000,000 additional a year.

Twenty persons accused of hav-I ing defrauded the city by obtaining! home-relief or work-relief funds l were arraigned before Justices Dale, Kemuochan and Gresser in Special Sessions yesterday. It was the largest number of cases of the kind ever placed on the calendar of that court.

New York and Boston gained the final round of the ninth annual series of intercity tennis matches for the Sears Cup yesterday on the turf courts of the Richmond County Country Club at Dongan Hills, Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Great Britain again defaulted today on her war-debt payments to the United States when Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, informed Secretary Hull in a note that no payment would be made on $465,132,541.78 due on June 15.

Trading in commodity futures was virtually at a standstill on the local markets yesterday. Price changes were insignificant as traders adopted a cautious attitude in the face of contradictory interpretations of the government's policy.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- With Cook County authorities victors in last night's "battle" to oust Robert M. Sweitzer from the barricaded office of County Treasurer, prosecution of Mr. Sweitzer was being considered today and the 67-year-old veteran Democratic leader was planning a legal fight to regain his post.

Residents of East Seventy-ninth Street who formed a committee to oppose the invasion of their residential district by a motion-picture house won in Supreme Court yesterday over Henry Mandel, builder, Justice John F. Carew denied Mr. Mandel's application for a mandamus order to compel the city to grant him a license for a theatre at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 7. -- Joseph Stoddard, 41 years old, who with three other prisoners shot his way out of the State Penitentiary in Trenton four years ago, was captured last night in the home of Edwin J. Stewart at 130 Glenwood Avenue, after a struggle with eight men.

At Tuskegee Institute in Alabama, founded by Booker T. Washington, Negro students are learning by actual daily work how to earn their way through life. Because some one supplied the tools a few years ago, thousands of Negro boys and girls have developed into upstanding and useful citizens.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in May amounted to $24,924,234,564, a gain of slightly less than 1 per cent over April but 8.6 per cent in excess of the turnover in May of last year.

ST. PAUL, June 7 (AP). -- Volney Davis, who pleaded guilty Monday to conspiracy in the $200,000 Edward G. Bremer kidnapping after his capture in Chicago, was sentenced to life imprisonment in the Leavenworth penitentiary in Federal court here late today.

How much light, as distinguished from heat, after all, was shed by Senator Borah in his recent radio address on the problems raised by the Schechter decision? One can but applaud his directing public attention to the fundamental truth that only by a constitutional amendment may Congress be vested with powers of general regulation over industry, by which is meant the power to fix prices, wages and hours.

Although hampered in some respects by readjustments, which usually follow important legislative changes, trade movements continued to show a trend toward improvement, reflecting an undercurrent of confidence, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc..

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., June 7. -- John C. Makepeace, president of the Hyannis Trust Company of Hyannis was re-elected today president of the Massachusetts Bankers Association at the annual meeting here in the New Ocean House. Sidney M. Price, cashier of the First National Bank of Malden, was chosen vice president, and Raymond C. Dexter, vice president of the Second National Bank of Boston, was made treasurer.

Seventy-two students were graduated from the high school department and fifteen from the grammar department of All Hallows, an Irish Catholic boys' school, at commencement exercises last night at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

BERLIN, June 7. -- Yesterday's reactions on the Boerse were followed today by resumption of the upward movement. Gains between 1 and 2 points were frequent and in some cases reached 3 or 4. Official warnings against overspeculation, however, together with the impending holiday interruption of business, made the turnover rather smaller than usual.

RUMSON, N.J., June 7. -- The annual flower show of the Rumson Garden Club, staged on the Riverlands, the estate of Bertram H. Borden, this afternoon brought out a profusion of brilliant blooms and arrangements.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- President Roosevelt today urged favorable action on bills that would extend Federal supervision to the commerce of highways, waterways and the air, but modified his original plan for unified control over all transportation in legislation at this session of Congress.

Medicine is moving toward new achievements in the conquest of disease so rapidly that physicians and surgeons must devote themselves to post-graduate study if they wish to remain in the van of their profession, homeopaths were told yesterday during the closing sessions of the ninety-first annual convention of the American Institute of Homeopathy.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 7. -- A large gallery of spectators witnessed the twenty-seven well-filled classes at the opening of the Tuxedo Horse Show today. Several hundred residents of the park and horse show followers from the metropolitan district attended the afternoon session.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 7. -- The thirty-eight graduates of Good Counsel College were warned by Cardinal Hayes at their commencement this afternoon that they faced a more difficult struggle in the world than previous classes because of changed conditions.

PITTSBURGH, June 7. -- The Central Labor Union here, challenging pledges against changes in code hours and wages made by employers who, in labor's opinion, fought to destroy the NRA, called upon local unions today to campaign among unorganized workers and to strengthen union membership.
The board of managers of the New York Produce Exchange appointed yesterday the following committees for the fiscal year 1935-1936:

The State of Arkansas has offered to buy with sinking funds now available approximately $2,150,000 of its refunding obligations, the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis reported yesterday through its correspondent here, W.P. Sharpe.
Anent your editorial "The Merritt Highway," I am moved to cry "Hold!" and "Give the devil his due."

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Amendments to clarify the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utility Holding Company Bill so that it specifically will not apply to intrastate business were accepted in the Senate today as the drive began to lessen the harsher provisions of the measure and to bring a final vote upon it next week.

The Royal Dutch Company reported yesterday for 1934 a net income of 38,131,575 florins after expenses, taxes, interest, exchange adjustments and other charges. This was equivalent, after dividend requirements on the 4 per cent preferred stock, to 7.56 per cent on the 503,624,000 florins of ordinary stock.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Heywood Broun was re-elected president of the American Newspaper Guild by acclamation at the Guild's national convention today, but against Jonathan Eddy, the Guild's executive secretary, so powerful an opposition was organized that he won re-election only after the Rockford, Ill., delegate, controlling three votes, had switched his support to him.

Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commanding the Second Corps Area, announced yesterday the names of 1,833 men who have been selected from New York, New Jersey and Delaware to attend the Citizens' Military Training Camp at Camp Dix, Wrightstown, N.J.
OAKMONT, Pa., June 7. -- Jimmy Thomson, a golfing Adonis who is also a Samson in strength, vaulted to the top of the field in the National open championship today.

A resolution declaring that "this is no time to disturb code practices which make it difficult for manufacturers to observe the previously prevailing NRA wage and hour provisions of their codes" was unanimously adopted by the Association of Buying Offices at a meeting held here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP). -- The Reds swamped the Pirates today under a fifteen-hit attack, including three homers, and scored an easy 13-to-4 victory in a game that was called at the end of the seventh inning because of rain.

A request that their congregations observe the festival of Pentecost, or the descent of the Holy Ghost, tomorrow has been sent to the pastors of non - liturgical churches throughout the country by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America through its department of evangelism.

The supreme importance to the nation, even in an age of great social experiments, of personal moral standards and ethics was stressed yesterday by irs. 17ranklin D. Roosevelt and Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, speakers at the graduation ex ercises of the Todhunter School at I the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

WASHINGTON, June 7, -- Relief officials strove desperately today to draft regulations which would permit the entire $4,880,000,000 work relief program to operate under the rule laid down by President Roosevelt Monday that preference be given to projects involving low material costs.

John Barrymore, who returned yesterday from a yachting cruise to Havana, said that he had proposed a $75,000 cash settlement and title to certain property to his wife, Dolores Costello Barrymore, who filed suit for divorce in Los Angeles last month.

The share market on the Stock Exchange edged higher yesterday in the slowest trading since April 4, and for the second time this week the total was less than 600,000 shares; prices moved within narrow ranges throughout the day. Bonds were irregular in a quiet market. Commodities closed lower.

William Berg, Republican leader of the Eleventh Manhattan Assembly District, has started a revolt against Chase Mellen Jr., county chairman, with an appeal to his fellow district leaders to call a special meeting of the Republican County Committee to curb Mr. Mellen's power to appoint inspectors of election, it was learned yesterday.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that it had certified to the Securities and Exchange Commission applications for permanent registration of the securities of 200 listed issuers and had been notified by eight companies that they would not file applications.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 7. -- More than 2,000 persons, including several hundred children between the ages of 2 and 15, attended the annual garden late and fair at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney, for the benefit of the babies milk fund of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County.

The film rights to "Dodsworth," Sidney Howard's adaptation of the Sinclair Lewis novel, have at last been sold by Max Gordon. Samuel Goldwyn is the purchaser, and $160,000 is the price -- the highest paid this season for any dramatic offering. Since the play is booked for an extensive tour beginning next Fall, the film will not be released until October, 1936.
State and municipalities plan to offer next week new issues of securities amounting to $35,897,290. This week's revised total of such financing is $17,260,811.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie with Mrs. Butler to attend the annual conferences in Europe of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, of which he is the chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- A resolution to extend the National Industrial Recovery Act until April 1, 1936, but repealing the powers delegated to President Roosevelt to approve or prescribe codes of fair competition, was rushed through the House today by a vote of 264 to 121. All efforts to amend the bill were beaten.

Antique dealers feel hurt because the Commissioner of Licenses will not make a distinction between pieces of vertu and second-hand refrigerators. To the commissioner any object is second-hand, whether it was previously owned 400 years ago by one of the Medici in Florence or six months ago by one of the Joneses on Ninth Avenue.

EASTON, Pa., June 7. -- Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University, criticized today what he termed efforts to check freedom of inquiry, opinion and teaching, He was the commencement speaker to the 100th graduating class at Lafayette College, which conferred on him the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- President Roosevelt plans to remain at Hyde Park until Wednesday morning, when he is scheduled to speak and present diplomas to the graduating class at West Point.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- An expectation that by Monday or Tuesday a new NIRA measure will be completed by the American Federation of Labor for submission to Congress was voiced today by members of the federation's executive council on adjourning the special meeting called to consider the emergency to labor growing out of the Supreme Court's Schechter ruling.

MONTREAL, June 7 (Canadian Press). -- The city of Montreal today concluded arrangements for floating public loans amounting to $12,943,000 and for refunding a one-year loan made in London of $6,065,500. The new money will bear an average interest rate of 3.835 per cent.

WASHINGTON. June 7. -- Spurred by a published report that they were blocking government payment of the 73-year-old Civil War claim of New York City for $764,143, Tammany Democrats in the House moved today to have the claim measure brought up for action and disclaimed any part in the opposition that had thus far held the bill in committee.

TORONTO, Ont., June 7. -- There is no thought now of reorganization of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., J.P. Ripley of New York, vice president of the company, said here today when he attended a meeting of holders of first mortgage gold bonds.

In accordance with a resolution adopted on Wednesday by the directors of the American Petroleum Institute, Axtell J. Byles, president of the institute, has notified the Federal Trade Commission that the industry soon will take up the question of revising its code with respect to marketing practices authorized by the commission on June 12, 1931.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Political thrusts at the alphabetical agencies of the New Deal have set officials to hunting about for new names to replace the letters by which they have been known.
The skill of Police Emergency Squad 6 was credited yesterday by physicians with saving the life of an eight-pound baby boy born at 10 A.M. in the Park East Hospital, 114 East Eighty-third Street.

Noel C. Scaffa, private detective who makes a specialty of recovering stolen jewelry, was indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury, which accused him and six others of conspiracy to violate the Stolen Property Act, and accused him alone of perjury.

BUFFALO, June 7. (AP). -- Accused of abusing his lions and tigers to make them snarl and "put on a good show," Clyde Beatty, whose dally chore is handling a big cage full of the animals, today invited his critic to come into the cage with him and "pet the kittens if he thinks they are so tame."

PARIS, June 7. -- The franc strengthened sharply in the foreign exchange market here today in reaction to the satisfaction of financial circles over Pierre Laval's success in forming a government "to defend the currency."

WEYBRIDGE, England, June 7. -- Unleashing a powerful attack that was reminiscent of the old days. Mrs. Helen Wills Moody crushed Miss Billy Yorke, English girl, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, today and stormed her way into the final round of the St. George's Hill tennis tournament.

Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, listened for more than two hours yesterday afternoon to demands made by two delegations on behalf of the crippled unemployed and the Writers Union which have picketed the offices of the ERB at 902 Broadway for nearly two weeks.

Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard announced yesterday that he would seek to have Raymond G. Pollard, Assistant Commissioner of Public Works in Queens, jailed for contempt of court as a result of Pollard's refusal to be sworn or to answer questions as to his official activities.

LEIPZIG, May 31 (By Mail). -- A "chamber of horrors," just opened in the Grassi Museum here, shows an extraordinary collection of objects in some pseudo-Nazi make-up or other, thrown upon the home market by tradesmen.

Next Wednesday night a "key meeting" of the New York Young Republican Club will decide the club's stand on national issues. The New York State Young Republican Platform Committee has built a platform. Some of it has fallen down since the Supreme Court decision on the NRA, but enough is left; more than enough, perhaps, for some Republicans who are not too young.

To the vast delight of an audience which rallied to meet her at the Venice Theatre, Mimi Aguglia, the Italian actress, returned to the New York stage last night. In the pleasurable excitement of the occasion it made no apparent difference that Mme. Aguglia, a tragedienne, had for her vehicle a rollicking farce. "Signori, Il Figlio E' Nato" (Gentlemen, the Baby Is Born), by Franco Lalli.

ATHENS, June 7. -- Growing unrest is reported in Macedonia and Western Thrace among traditionally Venizelist populations. Partly as result of the Monarchist movement, the Communists are reported to be tightening their hold on the cities of Xanthos, Serres, Drama and Kavalla.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7. -- A report from London indicating that the British Bondholders Association, representing subscribers to Chilean loans, had recognized officially that Chile's proposal for part payment of its foreign obligations was the best arrangement that could be expected under the existing circumstances has caused quite a stir in the press here.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the affairs of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company turned today to the part played by Robert T. Swaine, former general counsel for the railroad, in the framing of Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act handling railroad reorganizations.

Twenty-one boys were graduated yesterday from the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson. Dr. Alfred E. Stearns, headmaster emeritus of Phillips Academy, Andover, delivered the commencement address which marked the close of the twenty-eighth year of the school.

All the skill three young men with a flair for bagatelle could display proved unavailing yesterday when Jacob Mirowsky, proprietor of a stationery and candy store at 145 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, was found guilty in Bronx Special Sessions of maintaining a room for gambling.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 7. -- If news circulating in certain well-informed political circles tonight is correct, the true purpose of the political honeymoon of General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Air Minister, is at last revealed here as a grandiose scheme on the part of Germany to supplant France in Central and Southeastern Europe by creating a great anti-Russian bloc under German dominance from the North Sea to the Adriatic.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 7. -- Well before the flying boat Yankee Clipper was tied to the wharf at the Pan American airport here former Governor Theodore Roosevelt waved greetings to more than 150 officials and old friends who had gathered at the airport to say hello to him.

GEORGETOWN, Del., June 7. -- On a scaffold enclosed within a high board fence, Mrs. May H. Carey, 55 years old, and her eldest son, Howard, 27, were hanged at dawn today for a murder committed more than seven years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, June 7. -- The Bolivian and Paraguayan Foreign Ministers sat at the Chaco mediators' table today for the first time since the peace negotiations began, eleven days ago. Their meeting was arranged in a desperate effort to prevent the collapse of the negotiations.

MILWAUKEE, June 7. -- Lacking something of being his usual spectacular self, but still the sensation of the meet, Jesse Owens of Ohio State won three events tonight and bettered an accepted world record as he helped the Buckeyes keep the Central Intercollegiate Conference track and field championship safe for the Big Ten.

LONDON, June 7. -- Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today defined Great Britain's attitude in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute and denounced Italian press attacks on Britain. He emphasized there was no reason why British and Italian interests in Ethiopia should not be harmoniously developed side by side.

PARIS, Saturday, June 8. -- Authority to take whatever measures he and his Ministers might think necessary to save the frane was granted early this morning to Premier Pierre Laval by the same Chamber that last Tuesday night and last Friday morning refused the same authority to his predecessors, Pierre-Etienne Flandin and Fernand Bouisson.

After hearing Mrs. Ida Kasich, public school teacher, accuse Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, of having assisted her husband in sending her illegally to Bellevue Hospital psychopathic ward, Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew yesterday ordered a transcript of the testimony sent to Mayor La Guardia so the Mayor might "make his own investigation.''
A free scholarship is offered to an outstanding voice by the New York Madrigal Society, Marguerite Potter, founder.

The American Federation of Labor criticizes the President's "stop-gap" plan for NRA as "a surrender to the opponents of national recovery." Experience may readily prove the contrary. There are many economists, including those who made an exhaustive study of the question for the Brookings Institution, who believe that NRA was in certain fundamental respects a substantial handicap to recovery and an obstacle to the increase of employment.
WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The test of President Roosevelt's transportation message to Congress today was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Collateral trust notes issued in connection with instalment purchases are not exempt from registration under the Securities Act of 1933, John J. Burns, general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, held today.

The New York State Bankers Association will open its annual three-day convention today at the Hotel Sagamore, Bolton Landing, Lake George, with more than 500 bankers in attendance, the largest gathering of the association in five years.

TIENTSIN, China, June 7. -- While Japanese officials were making preparations today for the arrival here of considerable army reinforcements, Lieut. Gem Yoshijiro Umezu, commander of Japan's troops in North China, expressed complete confidence that he would not have to use armed force to settle the existing crisis with China.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 8. -- At "Grass Roots" headquarters, credit for the distinctive name for the Republican conference here is given to Kansas.

WHILE a stately marble tomb of imperial proportions lies half-completed and abandoned a few miles from Mukden, the coffin of Chang Tso-lin, the man for whom it was designed, slowly gathers the dust of time and the ashes of dead dynastic aspirations in the courtyard of a little Chinese temple, where the old city wall casts a shadow over the poorer section of the town.
TRENTON, June 8. -- Opening exercises of the fiftieth anniversary reunion of Bordentown Military Institute were held at Bordentown today.

NOT until later in the Summer will the public be in a position fully to appreciate the significance of Mrs. Rockefeller's gift to the Museum of Modern Art. The pictures constituting the collection she has presented are to be exhibited cumulatively until at length the entire collection is on display.

Eighteen players representing the Suburban Chess League of New Jersey, including the Bloomfield, Irvington, Rutherford, Polish, Log Cabin and Progressive clubs, visited the steamship Europa of the North German Lloyd Line yesterday and defeated the liner's Chess Club, 11 -- 7.

MOSCOW, June 8. -- The charges on which Abel S. Yenukidze, old Bolshevik and long a leading Soviet official, was expelled from the Communist party yesterday, were made public today. They lacked somewhat in precision but were accompanied by furious denunciations in Pravda and Izvestia editorials, such as preceded the expulsions and trials of Gregory Zinovieff and Lev Kamerieff last Winter, following the assassination of Sergei Kiroff.

IT will be many a day before a group of onlookers, many of them engineering exports, others lay observers, will have a greater thrill than that provided for them entirely unexpectedly at the first test flight of that remarkable new amphibian, the Sikorsky S-43.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 8. -- Although heavy rain handicapped the gunners at the North Jersey Gun Club today, Louis R. Slocum of Trenton, N.J., finished with a total of 198 to win the thirty-second annual New Jersey Trapshooting Association championship.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 8. -- The largest gathering of physicians on the North American Continent and possibly in the world, including about 8,000 from the United States and 2,000 from Canada, will take place here this week, when the American Medical Association, largest organized medical body in the world, and the Canadian Medical Association will hold their first joint meeting.

KANKAKEE, Ill., June 8 (AP). -- The story of Kankakee's own "Alger boy," Frank D. Waterman, was told today by boyhood friends in a wooded grove along the river as citizens of this community dedicated a twenty-five-acre public park in his honor.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 8 (AP). -- To an audience of lawyers, Associate Justice James C. McReynolds of the United States Supreme Court proposed two toasts last night -- one to the Constiution, the other to the President.

With a lapse of more than forty-eight hours since the mysterious disappearance of John Kaul Jr., 5 1/2 years old, the police last night were focusing their search on the story of a taxicab driver, who said he saw a woman with a crying boy drive away in another cab at about 6 P.M. Thursday at Sutton Place and Fifty-sixth Street.

Awards were made last week at the eleventh annual competition for small sculptures in white soap in the mezzanine gallery of the R.C. A. Building in Rockefeller Center. The prize-winning carvings, with other selected entries, will be on public view in the gallery until June 28.
CLEVELAND, June 8 (UP). -- The Indians scored a 3-to-2 victory today over the Browns before a crowd of approximately 5,000 persons.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area responded to more favorable weather last week and sales increases ranging up to 4 or 5 per cent over the same period last year were reported by department stores here. The gains in volume were well distributed among a variety of Summer apparel and sports wear, main-floor accessories, shoes, gloves, millinery and home wares.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- A private message from President Roosevelt asking passage of the bill to abolish public utility holding companies, with its present drastic provisions, was brandished today by Senator Wheeler in an effort to beat aside opposition to its quick passage Monday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 8. -- Two resolutions, one critical of New Deal policies, the other offering concrete, constructive prescriptions for recovery, have been drafted for adoption by the Midwestern conference of ten States, meeting here next Monday to rejuvenate the Republican party.
In giving this book a friendly recommendation to the reading public, Sir William remarks:

DEVELOPMENT of a new telephone-television cable by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is doing much to revise television plans, and is putting a new complexion on the art, according to experts who are formulating charts for the future.

Larger expenditures for public school education in the city next year were foreseen Friday when the mechanics of budget making were set in operation with recommendations for additional services in 1936.

IT is a terrible tale that Mme. Dombrowski unfolds, this history of Paraguay in the Eighteen Sixties. Many of the characters seem bizarre, unbelievable, yet the main events of the story are solid facts of history. Don Jose Gaspar Tomas Rodriguez de Francia was the son of a mule driver, a Brazilian half-caste who, migrated with his family to Paraguay.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 8. -- Under weather conditions that marred baseball, tennis and other sports, the Baltimore City College lacrosse team crushed the Brooklyn All Stars, 12 -- 6, for the national scholastic championship today.

ON the sidewalks of Whitehall in London there may be seen, any of these days, a man whose desire it is, apparently to look like everybody else. For years people as they passed him in the street have not troubled to bestow on him a second glance, and he, on his part, has been no less content to go about his business incognito.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HELSINGFORS, Finland, June 8. -- Ezio Gray, Italian Deputy and leader of the Fascist intellectual organization in Rome, was greeted here today as Premier Mussolini's special representative. He came to present to Finnish Fascists two large bronze busts of the Italian Premier.

AN inquisitive microphone will be sent afield to eavesdrop on New Yorkers twice a week. The program is listed as "The Voice of the City." Beginning tomorrow at 8 A.M., and every Monday thereafter WEAF's hook-up will be assigned to pick up "daily scenes in which the average New Yorkers constantly participate, yet with which the general public is not familiar."

THIS book, which suffers from the obvious limitations inherent in its compression into 177 small pages of twelve essays by nine different persons from five countries, focuses popular attention upon the major international political problem of this generation.

CALLIGRAPHY has been called the most subtle of all the arts of China. It is certainly one of the most personal. For centuries the subject has fascinated the Chinese, to whom the study of calligraphy may be anything from an avocation to a career.

LILY PONS was taken gently to task by Reynaldo Hahn in a recent issue of the Paris Figaro after her first appearance at the Paris Opera in "Lucia." Miss Pons, it appears, had said in an interview that France was slow to recognize her merit and that she had to go to America to achieve success.
Your recent editorial "A Neo-Darwinian" gives an incorrect and inadequate view of the relationship of De Vries to Darwin and to Morgan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- The Westchester Workshop's Little Opera Company this evening completed the celebration of its first anniversary by presenting "Cavalleria Rusticana" and two acts of "Martha" at the County Centre here.

CLAREMONT, Calif., June 8. -- A sprightly 5-foot figure in cap and gown, Mrs. Lillian G. Gist, 80-year-old great-grandmother, stepped forth today from a group of youthful companions and received the Master of Arts degree from the Claremont College.

IN the rush and excitement of the music season enterprises that deserve credit and support are passed by with comparative lack of attention. The record of the Steel Pier Grand Opera Company of Atlantic City is an organization that merits a review of its achievements.

Strong efforts will be put forth by women's consumer organizations to continue the use of a label in the garment trades to indicate that the merchandise has been made under fair wage and hour conditions. Resolutions will be sent out tomorrow to manufacturers in apparel lines and to retailers by the women's advisory committee of the National Garment Label Campaign.

NO Sunday article this week. The same wretched thing happened last year at the corresponding time, which is June, which is an idyllic month out of doors. Readers with abnormal memories may recall that last year Tipper, who is Eli's collie, tore up the article before it could be dispatched to the printers.

Electus D. Litchfield, president of the Municipal Art Society, will formally open an exhibition dealing with the parks of New York City in the International Building at Rockefeller Center tomorrow at 2 P.M., it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- In the face of a prospective renewal of wholesale defaults by European war-debtor nations, Secretary Hull today pledged the United States to continue to be thoroughly vigilant in attempting to collect all foreign obligations due this country from any source.

A request that some provision be made to use contractors on work relief construction projects, as is done on PWA projects, has been submitted to Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, by the Building Trades Employers Association.

A plea for a moratorium on amendments to the Multiple Dwellings Law passed this year and in 1934 has been made to Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, by a delegation of property owners and representatives of real estate associations.

Rapid expansion in the scale of buying being done in this market by Russia was revealed here yesterday with the announcement that the Soviet has purchased a total of $12,548,000 worth of raw and finished goods here since Jan. 1. The purchases include $5,500,000 spent for cotton by Russia since mid-April.

NEXT to her diplomats, Britain's most efficient propagandists are her historians. They are even more tangible, for their work is pertinently accessible. Diplomatic decisions are often forecast by their dicta, frequently shaped by them.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Mounts for the Greenbrier Polo Club, which holds its first scheduled matches on June 29 and 30, are beginning to arrive, with eighteen more due next week from Harvard and Yale Universities.

During May automospheric pollution here averaged 1.33 tons a cubic mile, according to figures made public yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist at the Federal Meteorological Observatory in Central Park. The pollution was .13 of a ton greater than the average for April and .07 of a ton more than in May last year, he said.

THOUSANDS of Americans are planning to join the Summer cruises over the Seven Seas. From New York they will lay their course to lands of sun and lands of snow; to where the azure of the Spanish Main laves storied cities of the New World, and across the Atlantic to the ports of the Mediterranean.

WITH a light production schedule in effect during recent weeks, Universal announced that nine films would be launched within the next fortnight. The quite pretentious "Diamond Jim," with Edward Arnold and Binnie Barnes, has been completed, and tomorrow "Magnificent Obsession," with Irene Dunne, will be the first of the new crop to get under way.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- With Selena Royle, Broadway actress, in the role of Phaedra, the Yale Dramatic Association will offer Euripides's "Hippolytus" as its thirty-fifth annual commencement production. Under the direction of Halsted Welles, performances will be given next Friday and Saturday evenings and the following Tuesday in the Yale University Theatre.
Close attention to details often pays dividends in fishing. Conversely, neglect or carelessness may bring disappointment even when conditions are favorable for success.

LONDON, June 8. -- Stanley Baldwin's resumption of the Premiership and the assignment of Sir Samuel Hoare to the Foreign Office, which are the two outstanding features in the reconstruction of the British Government, will mean, so far as foreign policy is concerned, no alteration in fundamental principles, but there will be changes in methods.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 8. -- Haverford College graduates were urged to explore in the sphere of social justice rather than in the field of material culture by Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The London Times, in a commencement address here today.

RICHMOND, Va., June 6. -- During June the Relief Administration in Virginia is conducting a re-employment drive designed to take as many persons off relief as possible by placing them in private employment. This is said to be the first drive of the kind attempted in the country.

GENEVA, June 8. -- The first International Labor Organization conference including the United States as a full member and the nineteenth to be held began this week its month's session, which is devoted mainly to the matter of world-wide reduction of hours in five industries.

The citation by Louis Stark in THE NEW YORK TIMES, referred to by Walter Lippmann in The Herald Tribune, of Abraham Lincoln's strictures, during the Lincoln-Douglas debates on the Dred Scott decision, as precedent and authority for the President's ex parte and public criticism of the Schechter poultry decision, is beside the point.

Shipments of Georgia peaches to the New York markets are steadily increasing in variety and volume, and fancy, large, well-colored fruit met with a moderate outlet, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, head of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

ONE of the world's most important flower shows, held each year at Chelsea, England, has just closed, with a record attendance -- a phrase which seems to be applicable to all of this season's leading shows.

RESUMING his preoccupation with New York low life, Mr. Clarke here tells an entertaining, somewhat squalid tale whose scenes take in various quarters of the city during the past thirty years. The heroine, incongruously named Kelly, first-born of an Italian bootblack and his consumptive wife -- in the year 1904 -- grows up a natural little lady despite the disadvantages of her birth and environment.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Now, more than ever before in its history, the American Trade Association movement is on trial. Already well developed, if not matured, at the close of the Civil War, it grew rapidly during the years of this country's industrial and commercial expansion.

An exhibition of garden designs by school children was opened yesterday in the lecture hall of Horticultural Hall of Rockefeller Center. If these fifty-four designs can be taken as a fair sample, New York children want water in their gardens.

IN this book of highly ingratiating English renditions of Herman Wildenvey's poems we have the work of one who is certified to us by Knut Hamsun as Norway's leading lyric poet. To this reviewer's thinking, Mr. Wildenvey is not a lyrist in quite the sense we have come in this country to use the word.

KATHLEEN NORRIS is remarkably skillful at playing variations upon a single theme. She has written approximately fifty novels, mainly concerned with modern American marriage, and nearly every one of them promised to catch a fresh and topical angle of that rather tormented subject.

Essays on "Safeguarding the Home Against Fire" are being written this month by pupils of the fifth to eighth grade in the public schools for 240 silver medals to be awarded in October in the competition sponsored annually by the city's Department of Buildings in cooperation with the New York Board of Fire Underwriters.

AMES, Iowa, June 2. THE "less corn and more culture" idea of the new farm program is making rapid growth in Iowa. On June 19 it will burst into blossom in a Statewide performance of "The Bohemian Girl" opera given by a cast of 150 men and women who are actually engaged in farming.

FOLLOWING a conference of nationally known educators on its campus, Reed College at Portland, Ore., has announced its intention of applying the so-called Bennington plan to a group of freshmen next Fall. Under that program, as used at Bennington College, Bennington, Vt., there are no required courses.

STATION VPD, Fiji Islands, sent strong signals into the New York area during the past week on 13,070 kilocycles. The schedule is 12:30 to 1:30 A.M., Eastern standard time, daily except Saturdays and Sundays. Tests are frequently carried on until 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning.

This curious contribution the reviewer has picked up and laid down many times since it reached his desk. Each return was based on a tantalizing wish fully to apprehend the author's idea, the gist of a thesis that promises more than is ever clearly argued.

In connection with THE NEW YORK TIMES recent editorial "The Worker's Part," it may be of interest that the unemployment-insurance measure which has been enacted in New Hampshire does provide for employe contributions. The measure carried the endorsement of organized labor in the State and the New Hampshire Manufacturers Association.

DETROIT, June S. -- Two suits against the Hupp Motor Car Corporation and its present board o1 directors, challenging the right of the directors to hold office, were dismissed today by Judge Ferguson in Circuit Court.

PITTSBURGH, June 6. -- The most significant trend of the week in the controversy over the Guffey Bituminous Coal Control Bill, which would establish a national commission for the industry, district boards, a labor board and a code of fair practices, was the increased stress given in the revision of the measure to marketing conditions.

VACATION beckons! Is it going to be a jaunt to a dude ranch where fresh winds blow across Western plains; a sail to Nantucket where the gayly colored butterfly fleet rocks on blue waters; a cruise to the West Indies with the hot sun burning on bleached decks, or a few weeks in New England, where golf courses lie at the foot of gently rolling hills?

HAVANA, June 8. -- Abductors today released the wealthy Antonio San Miguel, 78-year-old president of the Guantanamo Western Railway, and his chauffeur and gardener, all of whom were kidnapped last Wednesday. The ransom of $286,000 was not paid.

The Hapag Lloyd liner Stuttgart came to port last week in the commend of a new master, Captain Claus Stehncken. He replaced Captain Carl Hagemann, the regular master, who is in command of the General von Steuben on a series of cruises to the Mediterranean.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 8. -- With Stormy Weather and Vamarie showing the way, six sailing yachts disappeared into the fog today, bound for Bergen, Norway, in the longest and possibly the rarest of all sporting events, a transatlantic race.

A BRITISH Foreign Secretary had brought his country to the verge of war. The Labor party assembled a vast meeting in London. They had advertised it as an "All-Party Conference Against the Imminent Threat to Peace," but most of those present were Socialists determined on the adoption of a resolution pledging themselves to bring about a general strike in the event of war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., June 8. -- The lounge of the Nippon Yusen Kaisha's crack liner Asama Maru was the scene of a unique reception before her departure for Japan this week. It was attended by the Mayor, Angelo Rossi; Collector of the Port Charles Dunbar and Collector of Internal Revenue John V. Lewis.

Because today is Pentecost, or Whitsunday, as it is called by some communions, pastors will preach sermons on "The Descent of the Holy Spirit." There will be a more widespread observance of Pentecost by other than liturgical churches than heretofore because such recognition is being urged by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

With the publication in 1922 of Mrs. Coleman's "Creative Music" there has been a steadily growing tendency to include in the early musical training of children the experience of making simple musical instruments on which they can play and for which they can compose tunes.

TIENTSIN, China, Sunday, June 9. -- Japanese forces north of the Great Wall are shifting into position, a spokesman asserted today, preparatory to "coming south for action" should China fail to meet Japan's North China demands to "our satisfaction."

AND now, this department sheds its Winter raiment, pulls on an old shirt and trousers, anoints itself with sunburn oil -- and bids the Summer welcome. For the following annual compendium of rural playshop wares is evidence that the season has arrived.

NO picture of the season would be complete without some account of activities in that great field which is classed together by New York with an unmistakable sense of metropolitan condescension under the title of "the road."
THE termite is one of the oldest known insects in the world, and, contrary to the impression of most of us, its career has not always been a destructive one.

The difficulties faced by aliens in trying to support themselves and their families, daily are becoming more severe, according to Harold Fields, writing in the current issue of the Harvard University Quarterly. Mr. Fields, who has made a study of the alien since 1928, sees a serious problem in these "invidious distinctions."

RENO, Nev., June 8. -- Mrs. Elizabeth Hall Rathbone received a decree of divorce here today from Norwood Rathbone of New York on grounds of cruelty. They were married in New York on Feb. 8, 1922. An agreement for custody and support of their two children was based on a percentage of income.

HERE is an adventure story for adults. If our pulp magazines threw over the good old formula -- the impossible hero and his ineffable gal, the heroic and happy ending, the totems and taboos of the Spanish War era -- rid themselves of the Comstock Lode and their vulgar and decadent sentimentality, "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre" would be a serial to their liking.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 8. -- A greyhound, Southball Moonstone of Halcyon, led a smart field of 733 dogs in the North Westchester Kennel's Club's show at the Lawrence Farms today. A steady downpour failed to dampen the spirit of enthusiastic spectators who braved the weather until William H. Reeves of Canada made the final award.

BOSTON, June 8. -- Nearly all leading industries in New England have announced their intention of continuing, for the present, at any rate, the wages and maximum hours prescribed by the now defunct codes.

HAVING heard from the star, the color designer, the property man, the carpenter, the script girl and the third assistant yes-man of "Becky Sharp," it seemed -- to the earnest young man from RKO-Radio, which is releasing the new all-color film -- only equable to have a few words from its director, Rouben Mamoulian.

MANY Americans often become oppressed by the impression of sameness as they motor about their countryside, and long for foreign lands. They wish to tour Europe and see quaint people with picturesque habits who dress differently and live in old, odd houses.

PARIS, June 8 (AP). -- The Paris edition of The London Daily Mail quoted former King Alfonso of Spain today as denying the right of his eldest son, the Count of Covadonga, to the title of Prince of the Asturias, which would make him heir to the non-existent Spanish throne.

THIS is the time of year when the early bird catches the worm. It is a sad time for the worm no doubt, but it is the heyday of the year for those happy mortals to whom the charm of birds is one of the eternal verities of life.

Plans were instituted last week by a number of trade associations to revive interest among members and to broaden their programs, now that code authorities have gone by the board, executives of various groups reported here yesterday.
" It is high time," said the President in a message to Congress Friday, "to deal with the nation's transportation as a single, unified problem."

Repairs to the paving on First Avenue, between Sixty-ninth and Seventieth treets, led indirectly last night to the rescue of three women and two men who were being covered by the revolver of a hold-up man in an Atlantic and Pacific store at 1,277 First Avenue.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 8 (AP). -- Racing in a rough sea kicked up by a fifteen-mile northeast wind, Rex Boy, owned by Charles F. Reckher, Severna Park, won the Mayor Howard W. Jackson Cup today at the third annual June Week regatta, sponsored by Johns Hopkins University at the Annapolis Roads Club.

ENGINEERING students trained to independent thinking and investigation in so-called honors courses have been generally more successful in finding jobs and in making good on them than students educated by the older assignment and recitation method in American education.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Increasing additions to President Roosevelt's already crowded "must list" of legislation for this session have caused Congressional leaders to look askance at any estimate of a final adjournment day. Deepest pessimists set the day somewhere in September; more cheerful prophets say between the middle of July and Aug. 1, these latter taking into account the ever-compelling pressure of a torrid Washington Summer.

STATES' rights, an issue long quiescent, has within the past two weeks become once more the major point of contention in our national life, an issue transcending in interest -- and in importance -- the whole of President Roosevelt's program of reform.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 8. -- Max Baer is supremely confident that when the verdict is announced in Madison Square Garden Bowl Thursday night the heavyweight championship crown will still adorn his curly locks.

LONDON. THIS year is not only King George's twenty-fifth on the throne; it marks also the twenty-fifth year of the "Sailor King's" ownership of the famous cutter Britannia, one of the most remarkable racing yachts ever built.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 8. -- Carl Jahn, 90 years old, and his wife, Augusta, 89, who live in the Colburn Memorial Home on Clinton Avenue here, celebrated today the sixty-sixth anniversary of their marriage. It took place in New York City on June 8, 1869.

BUENOS AIRES, June 8. -- The Paraguayan War Office this afternoon announced the destruction of Bolivia's Sixth Infantry Division at Ingavi on the far northeastern part of the long battle front. The Sixth Division contained approximately 5,000 men and formed part of Bolivia's Third Army Corps.

IN furnishing or rearranging the country home, the effect most frequently sought is one of comfortable simplicity. Simplicity is interpreted variously from season to season, but constant elements are maple and fruitwood furniture, fireplaces, hooked rugs, flower prints, gay chintzes, old-fashioned wallpaper or pine-paneled walls.

A tentative platform for presentation to the Republican National Convention in 1986 that has been drafted by executives of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs was made public yesterday by George H. Sibley, president.

EVERY ONE who has ever been on shipboard is familiar with that feeling of isolation from reality which a sea voyage connotes. One is a new person, suspended between worlds, and for a time all that matters is the small cosmos of the ship.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- In what promises to be the largest and perhaps the liveliest sectional political convention of this generation, Republicans of nine Corn Belt States are now moving on Springfield, Ill., to a "grass-roots" convention which formally assembles Monday.

PRINCE A. LOBANOV-ROSTOVSKY, scion of an aristocratic Rusian family, who has worked his way up from the unenviable position of a penniless refugee to that of assistant professor at the University of California, first appeared among American writers two years ago, when his book "Russia and Asia," an excellent historical study of Russia's relations with Asia, was published.

ABOUT 150,000 students with baccalaureate or graduate degrees are emerging in the United States this month into a world which, as one college president said to a student assembly the other day, does not want them.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- After a series of years of deficient rainfall over much of the Corn Belt, especially that part west of the Mississippi, the subsoil is again drenched. Not for five years has the ground been so fit to support lush plant growth. The pessimists, who last year were predicting the onset of a permanent desert in Western Nebraska and the Dakotas, have been silenced.

Skippers of near-by units of the United States Power Squadrons had their annual shake-down cruise last week when the first of the Summer series of rendezvous was held at Lloyd Harbor under the direction of Commander Harold Dudley Greeley of the New York Squadron, who is also serving as national rendezvous chairman.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 8. -- The gates of Hyde Park House were figuratively closed by President Roosevelt today as he settled down, in the small library, to four days of planned activity on deferred business.

LONDON, June 8. -- The most important aspect of the reconstructed British Cabinet concerns the consolidation of its attitude with respect to foreign policy. Now that Sir John Simon has been removed from the Foreign Office, all the key positions are held by Conservatives, Stanley Baldwin, Sir Samuel Hoare and Anthony Eden.

SALEM, N.H., June 8. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's racers dominated today's stake events at Rockingham Park. His two-year-old old bay colt Winter Sport took the $5,000 added juvenile handicap, with a length to spare over Postage Due, his more famous stablemate, while Identify accounted for the first section of the $2,500 White Mountain Handicap for three-year-olds and up.

Art training in America is too theoretical, Ely Jacques Kahn, director of education of the Beaux-Arts Institute, told about 100 art teachers from New York public and high schools yesterday afternoon at a symposium meeting at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Senate opponents of the wrecked recovery law announced today they would demand full repeal of provisions permitting exemptions from the anti-trust laws, and served notice that when the resolution came up Monday they would ask to have it sent to committee for the making of such changes.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- The construction of a huge defensive air base on an island in Lake Champlain was disclosed today by a member of the House Military Committee to be under consideration by some national defense advocates.
Heavy showers halted play in the final of the ninth annual Sears Cup team tennis matches yesterday as New York was leading Boston by a slight margin.

PORTLAND, Me. THE annual Spring drive of pulpwood and long logs is on in Maine. From the back country streams and brooks filled with the Spring high water have borne the timber to the lakes and ponds and river banks where the ice goes out later.

The dispute between District Attorney Dodge and the March grand jury that has long been investigating vice has produced such a confused situation that the public is bewildered. But if one talks to old-time policemen and men attached to the Criminal Courts Building who have been familiar for years with the varying phases of this subject there is nothing either new or difficult to understand about it.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 9. -- A movement in "certain Chinese circles to establish a self-governing zone" in the Peiping and Tientsin areas as soon as Nanking troops have withdrawn in compliance with Japan's demands was reported today in dispatches from Peiping to the newspaper Nichi Nichi.
OAKMONT, Pa., June 8 (AP). -- Samuel McLaughlin Parks Jr. after winning the open-golf title today, said to newspaper men:

THE Rip Van Vrinkle Bridge, spanning the Hudson between Catskill and Hudson, will be opened for traffic early in July, according to present plans. The bridge, built at a cost of about $2,500,000 under the direction of the New York State Bridge Authority, will link the two main highway I routes paralleling the Hudson, and is the only vehicular bridge between Poughkeepsie and Albany.
Directors of the International Power Company, Ltd., declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the preferred stock on account of accumulations.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 3. -- The Brazilian-American commercial pact, now before Congress, is expected to meet with some opposition before its final ratification or rejection.

The American Cotton Manufacturers Association, representing about half the spindles in the industry, advised the Cotton-Textile Institute yesterday that the association's members would make no changes in the conduct of the textile industry as a result of the invalidation of the NIRA.

Neither rain nor the resultant slippery turf prevented the start of the annual intercollegiate championship polo tournament at Governors Island yesterday, and Yale, waging a gallant uphill fight, conquered Princeton in the final minute by a 3-to-2 count.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 8. -- Harold S. Vanderbilt, skipper of Rainbow in the America's Cup races last year, sailed his M boat, Prestige, to victory today in the fifty-first annual Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. It was the first appearance since 1931 of Prestige, and she showed to advantage in defeating Windward, owned by George Lauder Jr., by more than six minutes over a 14 1/4-mile course.

Forty-eight members of the graduating class at Manhattan College were inducted into Epsilon Sigma Pi, scholastic honorary fraternity, at the Class Day exercises yesterday. Inclement weather made it necessary to hold the exercises in Smith Auditorium.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 8. -- John J. Tierney of Syracuse, N.Y., a star of last season's football team, today was announced the winner of Niagara University's most coveted award, the Niagara Medal, as outstanding in the senior class.

If some of the thousands called upon to make addresses in schools, colleges, universities, seminaries, class celebrations and the like are in need of helpful material, they are likely to find it in a volume entitled "The President's Page," by Dr. WILLIAM LOWE BRYAN, president of the University of Indiana.

Raymond J. Healey, 22-year-old sponsor of the "National Socialist Workers Party of America," was convicted of disorderly conduct in Night Court last night. He was charged with posting a sign in Yorkville on Thursday night which incited a riot.

While some branches of business were retarded by uncertainties over the NRA situation, retail sales activity continued to show improvement last week in various sections of the country, under the influence of more seasonable weather conditions and special promotional events.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 8. - Dominick Morano, 21-year-old Belleville star, today became the first public links golfer to win the New Jersey amateur championship in the thirty-four years of its history.

The Abraham Lincoln rigl School handball team captured the Brooklyn p. S. A. L. championship for the second straight year when r it subdued James [adison, 3 -- 2 yesterday on the loser's courts in a play-off match. With thee issue standing at a 2-all deadlock, Seymour Litsky and Dan Fuer con~ quered Henry Coleman and Arnold 1Ruden, 21 -- 14, in the final double test to retain the crown for the visitors,
National business ethics have been improved by the NRA, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday before sailing on the Europa.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 8. -- Graduate Manager of Athletics Major L.D. Worsham of the United States Military Academy announced today that 131 cadets who participated in Spring sports would be the recipients of awards. The sports that will come in for recognition include baseball, track, lacrosse, pistol shooting, polo, golf and tennis.

PUBLIC opinion is deeply stirred by a drama that has developed in Mexico. It is not a claim to the control of oil or minerals that today is in question. The issue is religion, and it is sharply, even bitterly, controversial.

France has had ninety-six governments since the Third Republic was established in 1871. Since the end of the World War she has had thirty-two, nine of which have come and gone during the last three years. This week-end the ninety-seventh government, headed by Pierre Laval, is in office, fortified by a 324-to-160 vote of confidence given by the Chamber of Deputies early yesterday morning.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 (AP). -- A revamped line-up brought dividends today to Manager Frankie Frisch as his Cardinals ended a three-game losing streak to down the Cubs twice in a doubleheader before a ladies' day crowd of 20,000. The world champions took the first game, 5 to 4, and eked out another one-run victory in the eleven-inning nightcap, 6 to 5.

INCESSANTLY the old political struggle goes on in France. Time and again truces are arranged, but these do not last. The Third French Republic seems never able to do better than to bring about an armistice between the warring factions.

With the retirement of GEORGE PUTNAM the Lighthouse Service has lost its veteran chief. His was a time-honored office. The furnishing of proper aids to navigation was one of the earliest concerns of the Federal Government, and the most eminent of the founding fathers all had a hand in it.

Harold Seton, who is said to own the largest private collection of photographs in the country, recently presented to the Naval War College at Newport, R.I., original photographs of ranking navy officers of the Spanish-American War to augment other rare photographs he bestowed on the college a year ago.

A GOOD way to start picking one's hot weather wardrobe is to glance through an atlas. Therein one finds that New York and environs are only a little north of the fortieth parallel of latitude. Reading from left to right across the Atlantic Ocean, Manhattan's relative position to this parallel is the same as that enjoyed by Madrid, Rome and Barcelona.

NO contrast could be more complete than that between the embodiment of the old regime at the opera in Giulio Gatti-Casazza, twenty-seven years in authority, and the Metropolitan's physical presentment of its new deal in the person of Edward Johnson.

THE Pan American Clipper is continuing its test flights over the Pacific, this time as far as Midway Island, with a stop at Hawaii, another step in the conquest of the ocean by air. That the flight is possible is due largely to the work of Igor Sikorsky, designer of this huge mechanism, who has been largely forgotten in the drama of flying big ships for long distances over water.

LONDON, June 8. -- Following his resumption of the Prime Minister-ship last night, Stanley Baldwin today addressed a great open-air Conservative party meeting at Himley Park, the estate of his friend, Lord Dudley, in Worcestershire. Many thousands of his political followers were there from all parts of the Midland counties and fifty-three Parliamentary constituencies were represented on the platform.

Three somewhat thin and discursive essays by the English critic who years ago invented a widely quoted phrase, "significant form," compose this volume. Autobiographical criticism, it may be called, full of the reactions of Mr. Bell, who seems delicately to hint that he is one of our epoch's Great Lovers.

It is not to be denied that a large part of the country welcomed the termination of NIRA. This is not difficult to understand. Except for prohibition, probably no law in our history was administered as poorly and evaded as widely as this statute.

Denying the application of Mrs. Hildred P. Gude, wife of Oscar J. Gude Jr., for the income from a trust fund left by her father-in-law, Oscar J. Gude, founder of the General Outdoor Advertising Company, and terming it "premature," Surrogate James A. Delehanty ruled that the allocation of the $111,800 fund rested with the trustee of the estate, in a decision announced yesterday.

EXTENSION of the airway map and constantly expanding airport development have greatly increased the facilities for flying to the national parks of the United States. Many of the famous parks, long served by railroads, now have landing fields close by as well, bringing their scenic wonders and camping places still closer in time to city dwellers the country over.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 8. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey received honorary degrees of Doctors of Laws this morning at the 169th commencement of Rutgers University in the Rutgers Gymnasium.
PARIS. HAND-KNITTED clothes fulfill the elegant woman's desire for individuality in dress tempered with distinction. They may be in any of the smart mediums of the moment: silk, fiber, wool, linen.

Although producers of durable goods have been the most outspoken opponents of the restrictive measures of the Recovery Act, the elimination of the law will have only a minor effect in speeding the upturn in the heavy industries, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by engineers and manufacturers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 8. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering left for Berlin this morning by airplane. Representatives of the King and the Cabinet said farewells to the German Air Minister at the airfield.

LONDON, June 8. -- After Anthony Eden's public protest in the House of Commons yesterday against Italian press abuse of the British Government, it now remains to be seen how Sir Samuel Hoare, the new Foreign Secretary, will react to today's attack on Great Britain by Premier Mussolini.

Medical men should strive to preserve the spirit of tolerance and liberty in the United States and thwart the wave of anti-intellectual terror that is engulfing Europe, Dr. Emanuel D. Friedman, Professor of Neurology, New York University College of Medicine, told the graduating class yesterday at class day exercises in the Carnegie Lecture Hall, 338 East Twenty-sixth Street.
DETROIT, June 8 (AP). -- Three men realized $4,000 each on $2 wagers today when the daily double at the Detroit track paid the highest price in local turf history.

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., June 8. -- Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University was the speaker today at the commencement exercises of the forty-eighth and largest class of Mount Hermon School. It was the first class to be graduated under David R. Porter.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- Three thousand alumni of Princeton University will return to the campus this week to participate in the annual class reunions and other festivities of the six-day commencement period. Two new features appear on the program.

BUFFALO, N.Y. POPULARITY of Summer cruises on the Great Lakes has caused four major lake passenger lines to increase their 1935 schedules. Cruising on the Great Lakes traces its increasing interest to several causes, the major one being a reflection of the ocean cruise business.

The "red flag list" of the Boy Scouts of America was explained in detail yesterday by Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive, to offset the impression left by the recent speech of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt at the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Scouts National Council in Chicago.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 8. -- Colgate came from behind today to score an 11-9 victory over Manhattan in a loosely played game staged before a crowd of 2,000, including hundreds of alumni present for the commencement week-end.

If Congress approves a State Department request, the United States Legation in China will be raised to embassy status. This will increase the number of American Ambassadors to seventeen, only three more than existed a decade ago.

In "The Magic Fountain" the story of Ponce de Leon is briefly told for children of 7 to 8, with many pictures in color and black and white. Both drawings and text have a suggestion of facetiousness, and although the author-illustrators have labeled their tale "another really truly story," they treat their subject with a flippancy that is adult rather than childlike.

MAY 31, 1935, was the twenty-fifth anniversary of the signing of the first comprehensive Motor Vehicle Law to be adopted by the State of New York. The signer was the present Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, then prominent as Governor Charles Evans Hughes.

VINALHAVEN, Me., June 8. -- A little Belfast excursion steamer, Castine, lost in a dense fog, struck on bay ledges off this island today and heeled on her beam, flinging many of an excursion party of seventy-five Grangers overboard.

Thirty-seven tenement dwellers from the lower East Side took an all-night bus ride to Washington last week, carrying a petition signed by 25,000 other residents of the slums. Their mission was to support a bill which would create a Federal Housing Division in the Department of the Interior and give it $800,000,000 for the replacement of unfit houses.

TORONTO, Ont., June 8. -- For the fiscal year ended on March 31 McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., announced in its twenty-third annual report a net profit of $3,691,676, equal to $4.63 a share, against $3,674,938, or $4.61 a share, for the preceding year.

ROME, N.Y., June 8 (AP). -- Bringing to a climax a three-day battle, the Disabled Veterans of the World War in annual convention today re-elected Paul B. Mercier of Utica for a third term as State commander. The vote was: Mercier, 63, Milton D. Cohn of Buffalo, 54.

IT is unfortunate that for so many years the sole viewpoint upon the early history of this country was that of scholars and writers who, themselves deriving from the Eastern seaboard and usually its northern part, held that section to be the only origin of consequence.

AFTER much advance cannonading in which all the siege guns of a highly volatile industry were called into play, "Becky Sharp," the first feature-length production to be filmed in the new three-component Technicolor, will invade the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The inaugural stands in front of the Capitol had not yet been dissembled when a group of men representing the principal farm organizations of the country met in a room of the Harrington Hotel here to discuss a new agricultural law that was to carry out the New Deal for farmers.
