WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Generally improved conditions, but without any showing of a pronounced rise, were reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of business in thirty-three domestic cities.

With the Queens County Handicap as the opening feature, the Summer meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will get under way at Aqueduct tomorrow to run for twenty-two racing days. John E. Cowdin, president, has announced that the enhanced value in the five featured stakes has so increased the number of entries that one of the most successful meetings in the history of the club is expected.

CHEVROLET production will continue at full capacity during June, and possibly over a longer period, W.E. Holler, vice president and general sales manager, announced last week, on his return from a coast-to-coast trip. Dealers, he said, have a large number of orders on hand, and the plants are working hard to fill them, so that prompt delivery of most models may be promised.

JOVIAL alumni celebrating reunions on a dozen or more campuses this week and next will doff their carnival costumes and settle down in their old classrooms after commencement for days of serious study.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, June 8. -- Faster and more modern auxiliaries are the chief need of the United States fleet, this year's naval manoeuvres, which end with the arrival of the fleet at San Diego Monday, have indicated.

Much to his disgust, Henry Hyer, private detective, is called upon to find a dog which has disappeared from the kennel of a woman who has gone in for breeding pedigreed canines. Since the call comes from his best friend, a lawyer named Jocelyn, Hyer accepts the commission and quickly finds himself in the midst of a murder mystery, in which Jocelyn is innocently involved.

PARIS, June 8. -- Premier Pierre Laval won a smashing victory today in the Senate. He received a vote of 233 to 15, with fifty abstentions, for his defense of the franc program. It seems fairly certain that his government and France will have four months of relative political calm before them.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company made public yesterday a letter addressed on June 4 to Senator Burton K. Wheeler charging him "with misstatements about the company on the floor of the Senate, apparently in acceptance of slanderous and false allegations by hostile witnesses before his committee, although he had denied the company 'even five minutes of time' to demonstrate the untruth of those allegations."
AN avid public recently had a picture of the President of the United States using the White House press conference as a forum for advocating his opinions regarding a Supreme Court decision.

BACK in 1930 Dr. Wolfgang Klemperer, vice president of the Soaring Society of America and German soaring pilot No. 1, came to Elmira in search of a site at which to stage the first national soaring contest. As a result of this visit a mountain top, known as South Mountain, overlooking the Caton Avenue Airport, which is two miles from the postoffice, was declared to be a feasible site for such use.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- The government today dismissed the charges against six of the ten men under indictment on charges of violating the Federal Bankruptcy Laws in their operation of the Corporation Securities Company, an Insull subsidiary.

DALLAS, June 6. -- Rebirth of States' rights, as a vital political issue rather than a sentimental keepsake from the old South appeared strongly probable this week as the New Deal's attack upon the Supreme Court decision invalidating the NRA reverberated throughout the Southwest and produced challenging rebuttals from strongholds of traditional Democracy.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Warrenton junior hunt, formerly the Warrenton pony show, has sent out prize lists for its sixteenth annual show, which will be held on Saturday, June 22. This is the oldest pony show in America, and is licensed by the American Horse Show Association and governed by its rules.

The application to the Public Service Commission for permission to merge the New York Edison Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the United Electric Light and Power Company, is the first step in a plan to unify the companies in the Consolidated Gas system, which has been under consideration for many years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 8. -- A new protective substance against peritonitis, greatest surgical risk in abdominal operations, already has been tried on 2,000 persons with virtually 100 per cent success, it was reported here today before the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Pathologists.
PEIPING. -- Although Japan and China have not been technically at war since 1895, they have actually been at war since the Summer of 1931.

THIS writer knew New Orleans before he visited the city. He knew it because Manon Lescaut died there in the last act of Puccini's opera, on "a vast plain in the borders of the territory of New Orleans. The country is bare and undulating, the horizon is far distant, the sky is overcast."

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Despite threats which developed today among Senatorial critics of the NRA, administration leaders in the upper Chamber remained confident of passing before Sunday the "stop-gap" plan for continuing the recovery agency.

Automobile production and sales last month were larger than in May last year, but smaller than in April, 1935, according to statements yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association and the General Motors Corporation.

EXETER, N.H., June 8. -- Thomas S. Lamont, '16, son of Thomas W. Lamont of New York, was reelected president of the General Alumni Association of Phillips Exeter Academy at the annual Alumni Day meeting here today. More than three hundred alumni returned for the day, which included the Exeter Andover baseball game.

WARSAW, June 8. -- Official Poland manifested its dissatisfaction with the Soviet-Czechoslovak mutual assistance pact when Foreign Minister Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia was slighted by the government yesterday during a stop of two hours here en route to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Assurance that the Public Works Administration will be permitted to complete the program it has begun and make full use of resources still at its command was given in an executive order of President Roosevelt, made public today, extending and liberalizing the authority of the PWA.

FAR from being a dry-as-dust pursuit, says Mr. Winterich. bibliography is as absorbing an enterprise as criminology. It involves many of the identical principles, he continues, listing by way of illustration a knack of deduction, the application of common sense and an appreciation of the fundamentals of psychology.

Approximately $20,000,000 of working capital would be required to put into practical operation the pooling plan proposed for New England railroads by Allan M. Pope, president of the First Boston Corporation, he said yesterday. This amount, he stated, could be raised readily.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 8. -- The Tuxedo challenge cup, one of the most prized trophies of the annal Tuxedo horse show, will remain in competition for at least another year. At the final session of the annual exhibition today, the trophy was taken by Miss Priscilla St. George, riding her little 3-year-old chestnut mare, Prune's Own Ginger Snap.

WINNIPEG, Man., June 8. -- Within the last twenty-four hours a new Wheat Board Bill has been drafted for the Dominion Government in Ottawa, providing for a 100 per cent compulsory wheat pool in the Prairie Provinces, Manitoba, Alberta and Saskatchewan.

New Utrecht's glory on the track continued undimmed for the twelfth consecutive year as the Green and White amassed 36 points yesterday to capture the thirty-first annual Public Schools Athletic, League senior high school track and field championship at Wingate Field, Brooklyn.

CANTON, N.Y., June 8. -- A modern symposium on politics, with Owen D. Young in the role of Socrates and a scholar in Greek literature in that of the student, was disclosed today during the annual Alumni Day exercises at St. Lawrence University.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before their dates of maturity were in good volume but for smaller amounts than in several preceding weeks. Most of the calls were for future months, with redemptions by municipalities predominating.

MOSCOW, June 7. -- The conclusion this week of a credit agreement between the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia is of considerable importance, both economic and political. For the first time a bourgeois State has given to Soviet Russia the sort of terms it wants and believes it is warranted in demanding.

LO _NDON, June 8. -- It is a great mistale to delay building up peace machinery becg. use of apprehension about the attitude of the United States, declared Allen W. Dulles, American delegate, yesterday at the closing session of the eighth International Studies Confarence on Collective Security.

BOSTON. -- Rhode Island will have no constitutional convention this year. The third special session of the General Assembly to be held in two years ended recently with an all-night vigil in which several bills of major importance were passed by arrangement between the leaders of the two parties, and the Democratic Governor agreed, not to demand the enactment of the measure for a referendum on the convention issue.

FROM the nation's fruit-growing areas come reports of abundant crops, and into the city is flowing a constantly increasing volume of early fruits to satisfy the appetites of New York's seven million. Red and black cherries from the Pacific Coast are plentiful and gorgeous in their coloring; Maryland is sending luscious strawberries; North Carolina is shipping blackberries; sidewalks of the wholesale markets of Washington Street are piled high with crates of pineapples, fragrant and spiny.
GATEWAYS to the traveler's America swing open with the approach of Summer, and from every hand come reports indicating that the coming months will witness a great movement of tourists.

Dartmouth will make a renewed bid to regain the intercollegiate championship in outboard racing this year, with a team of six, one a junior, one a sophomore and four freshmen, in the sixth annual college and schoolboy hydroplane regatta on Lake Quinsigamond, Worcester, Mass., June 29-30.

Of the five New York City emergency tax measures enacted for relief purposes in the latter part of last year, one has been repealed -- namely, the income tax. Three of the remaining four, the sales tax, the personal property tax and the tax upon gross receipts, are currently yielding revenue, and the fourth, the estate tax, although functioning in so far as administrative machinery is concerned, is nevertheless biding its ultimate fate.

One of the major upsets in ring history will be provided Thursday night in the event Max Baer, Livermore, Calif., boxer, loses his world's heavyweight championship to Jimmy Braddock, New Jersey challenger. The bout is scheduled for fifteen rounds and will be held in the Madison Square Garden Bowl at Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The "obiter dictum" found by the President in the NRA decision of the Supreme Court of United States revives an issue older than the nation itself. This issue of centralization of power in the Federal Government has also recurred time and again during the history of the Republic.

Whaling has gone for good from Sag Harbor. Its cod-fishing days are ended, too. There will be no more Shinnecock or Montauk Indians hunting buffaloes, foxes, wolves or wildcats along its shores, and it is unlikely that its earliest name of Wigwagonock, which the white man found in 1640, will ever be used again.

Buying tempo slowed down considerably in commodity markets last week as industrial purchasing agents took time out to watch price and other trends in the light of developments since the Supreme Court's decision nullifying the NIRA.

A plea to members of the American Institute of Steel Construction to continue to observe the present standards ofwork and employment, despite the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the NRA, was issued yesterday by C.G. Conley, president of the institute.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- A.A. Baroni's Top Row, which came here recently from California, captured the revival of the Great Western Handicap, at a mile and a furlong, before 17,000 spectators at Washington Park today.
The Scottish Football Association's unbeaten soccer team will conclude its United States invasion this afternoon when it meets an all-star combination at the Newark School Stadium.

The well-intended efforts of business men to preserve the NRA codes on a voluntary basis leave them in practically all cases open to triple damage suits under the anti-trust laws by either disgruntled buyers or competitors, trade association lawyers declared here yesterday.

Charles F. Ronayne in his admirable review of my book, "Goethe and the Jews, a Challenge to Hitlerism," which appeared in your issue of April 21, takes exception to the subtitle by declaring: "While the book gives no real clue to Goethe's probable attitude to Hitlerism," * * * I regret to state that I am unable to concur with him in this view.

THIS Summer's train travelers will see a change in railways since last year greater than that which has been witnessed in a generation. A revolution in train speeds has been achieved, and it seems that sixty miles an hour between all important centres -- New York, Chicago, Washington and the West Coast -- will soon become the standard railroad rate.

Year by year the ranks of the city's lawbreakers increase. Last year police arrested one out of every thirteen of the city's population. The total was 556,640, according to Police Commissioner Valentine's annual report -- an all-time high and 17 per cent more than the figure for 1933.
Auction catalogues have been received here of the notable J.P. Morgan collection of miniatures, which is to be sold at Christie's in London on June 24, 25, 26 and 27.

TO the radio actor, even to the veteran who has faced the microphone time after time, the broadcasting of drama is a baffling art. They confess there is a mystery in the technique; they miss the audience and the cues applause can give them.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 8. -- Holy Cross defeated Harvard for the second time this week today, setting down the Crimson, 8 to 3. Roy Bruninghaus, Crusader ace, was found for nine hits and fanned eight, while Bill Lincoln allowed one more and struck out four. Threatening weather kept the attendance down to 1,500.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 8. -- Entries from Mrs. Samuel Schiffer's Kilkare Farm of Elberon, N.J., were the most consistent performers as the ninth annual Watchung Riding and Driving Club horse show was staged today. Six blues were annexed by horses in the Schiffer string during the show.

RENO, Nev., June 6. -- Across a wide area, extending in an arc from Denver southwesterly through Arizona and New Mexico to this Central Nevada point, the drought, except for scattered areas, is history.

IN the short time the Minneapolis Orchestra has been recording it has covered an extraordinarily varied field, with a tendency toward the more traditionally minded moderns. The latest additions to the series are an album of selections from Johann Strauss (Victor M-262), Enesco's Rumanian Rhapsody No. 1, and An American Overture by Roy Harris (8629).
PARIS, June 8 (AP). -- Reversing last year's results, France and Australia battled to a stalemate in the opening singles matches of their Davis Cup tennis quarter-final series today.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- New regulations under the extended National Housing Act, which permit loans up to $50,000 each to be insured by the FHA for modernization of industrial plants and equipment, opens a new building market, Stewart McDonald, acting FHA administrator, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- A Treasury compilation showed that war debt payments of $811,678,329 will be due the United States from thirteen foreign nations on June 15. This government stands to receive only $165,453.

PARIS, June 8. -- France had its first real showdown on devaluation in these past ten days of political crisis, and when it came to a pinch the champions of currency amputation melted away like snow in Spring-time. France surprised perplexed foreigners in a number of ways during this period, but in none more than the ease with which the devaluationists were routed.

THIS is a timely book, few persons understanding the complications that have brought about strained relations between the United States and Japan which must be composed if a serious rupture between the two countries is to be avoided.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 8 (AP). -- The possibility appeared tonight that the minor baseball leagues will definitely bar Alabama Pitts, erstwhile Sing Sing prison athlete sought by the Albany Senators of the International League, and place the final decision squarely in the hands of Commissioner Landis.

Two tons of counterfeit coins -- 1,560,000 of them -- cascaded into Long Island Sound yesterday, propelled by willing police hands. They were the involuntary collection of the Independent Subway System, which has been garnering them through turnstiles at the rate of 1,575 daily since the system opened on Sept. 2, 1932.

LATOMA, Ky., June 8 (AP). -- C.R. Thompson's Mary Terry, daughter of Terry and Milfoil, made a show of her opposition to account for the fifty-third running of the Clipsetta Stakes, the feature at Latonia today.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Some 100,000 employes of railroad and railroad equipment companies have received direct employment, and another 100,000 persons indirect employment, through the $200,000,000 railroad program, now virtually completed by PWA, Secretary Ickes stated today.

AMHERST, Mass., June 8. -- For the second time this season big Jack Epple, Amherst sophomore, proved a puzzle to the Massachusetts State batters while his mates pounded out a 10-2 victory before a State commencement crowd of 1,500.

Near York University will open its 103d commencement program today at 4 P.M. with baccalaureate services in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library at University Heights. The program will end Wednesday morning when Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will confer degrees upon approximately 4,000 candidates at the commencement exercises on Ohio Field.

AUCKLAND, N.Z. -- Signs of a radical landslide at the national elections next November were revealed at the recent municipal contests. Everywhere Labor gains were marked. Auckland, the largest city, has a Labor Council for the first time in its history, the radicals having captured fifteen seats out of twenty-one but having failed to seat their candidate for Mayor.

A testimonial luncheon attended by 400 persons was given yesterday for Miss Josephine Beiderhase, an assistant director of city health education. Miss Beiderhase will retire at the end of the present school term after nearly forty years with the Department of Education.

With the situation generated by the invalidation of the NIRA as a major topic of discussion, approximately 5,000 retailers representing stores all over the country, will attend the Summer convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association which begins in Chicago tomorrow and continues until Thursday.

ST. LOUIS, June 8 (AP). -- The crest of the Missouri River's second most disastrous overflow in history passed into the Mississippi here tonight as a new but probably trivial flood menace lurked in its tributaries.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 8 (AP). -- Search for the kidnappers of George Weyerhaeuser, 9-year-old Tacoma lumber heir, was concentrated in this vicinity tonight after twenty bills identified as part of his $200,000 ransom turned up here.

Amid the pelting rain at Travers Island yesterday, Chuck Hornbostel beat Glen Dawson and Gene Venzke in their heralded three-quarter-mile battle. But ahead of all of them at the tape with a cyclonic finish was Joe Mangan of the New York A.C., unfurling the masterpiece of his career.

TRENTON, N.J., June 6. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman this week won his five-month fight for a 2 per cent sales tax to finance emergency relief, but his companion measure for an income levy to ease the burden on real estate disappeared in the struggle.

GRANT WOOD has supplied an essay that serves to launch a new pamphlet venture called the "Whirling World Series," edited by Frank Luther Mott and published by Clio Press, Iowa City, Iowa. The little brochure (price, 90 cents) is very attractively presented, printed with real taste and without ostentation on excellent stock.

TRENTON, N.J., June 8. -- Setting forth that several sections of Justice Thomas W. Trenchard's charge to the jury contained "manifest error," the defense counsel of Bruno Richard Hauptmann filed today an amendment to their appeal from Hauptmann's conviction of slaying the Lindbergh baby.

COME up and see me some time," she said, and she said it once too often. The danger of the oft-invited guest is that sooner or later he accepts. Here was I, going aloft to keep an appointment with a lady who had publicly admitted she was no angel.

BOLTON LANDING, LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 8. -- Bankers from all sections of the State, members of the New York State Bankers Association, opened their annual convention here today with a larger attendance and more cheerful frame of mind than on any occasion since the first year of the depression.

BERLIN, June 8. -- Germany is momentarily facing the strange task of stopping an all too buoyant stock market from running away into a boom that might seriously interfere with the government's financing of its tremendous labor creation and armament programs, by which the National Socialist regime undertook to abolish unemployment and make Germany again one of the strongest military powers in the world.

BATH, N.Y., June 8 (AP). -- A declaratory judgment granting the petition of David Rumsey 3d of New York City, for legal assurance of proper maintenance and restriction of the Rumsey family's private burial plot here, was filed today with the Steuben County Clerk by Supreme Court Justice Edwin C. Smith.

Bonds of all classifications were generally firm in yesterday's abbreviated trading day, United States Government issues advancing 1-32 to 5-32 point and foreign obligations gaining moderately, with French bonds up 1 1/2 to 4 7/8 points. Transactions amounted to $4,399,900, compared with $5,158,600 on the preceding Saturday.

FOR those condemned by fate, fear, inclination or responsibilities to the dull routine of a thoroughly commonplace existence, pyrotechnic figures such as Byron have an unfailing appeal. That such men do exactly what they wish in spite of convention -- and do it with a grand gesture -- brings to the narrow lives of the intellectual shut-ins who read about them a certain vicarious romance.

NOT for long can travel-minded America stay away from European shores. For several years past Americans remained at home. Ships once heavily laden with travelers had to be laid up for the Summer, and foreign hotels and shops languished alarmingly.

IL DUCE'S BLACK EYE: Benito Mussolini, with one eye blacked and with several scratches on his right cheek, attended a reception last week at the British Embassy in Rome. (It was explained that he had been thrown from his horse and he had landed on his face.)

Featured by the drive of manufacturer groups in the women's apparel lines to preserve fair trade practice rules, considerable headway was made during the week toward stabilization of the confused market conditions which followed the invalidation of the NRA by the Supreme Court.

A wave of price-cutting, threatening demoralization of the entire grocery industry, opened in the metropolitan area last week, as a result of the lifting of the NRA code restrictions, manufacturers, jobbers and retailers admitted yesterday.

WEYBRIDGE, England, June 8. -- Betting commissioners, who a week ago were offering 4 to 1 against Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's chance at Wimbledon, cut their odds to 2 to 1 today after watching her defeat Mrs. Elsie Goldsack Pittman in the final round of the St. George's Hill tournament, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.

BERLIN, June 8. -- A decade of social unrest combined with political and economic upheavals is in store for Europe if the predictions of British sociologists, economists and scientists set down in a symposium that will appear in tomorrow's edition of the Berliner Tageblatt should come to pass.

The gross tonnage of the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will be increased to 85,000, according to advices received here yesterday from Glasgow, where it previously had been said that her tonnage would be 73,000.

There is something almost hypnotic in the endless flow of books on English art. Yet there really was, and is, an English art. And Mr. Collins, Surveyor of the King's Pictures, head of the department of research in art history at the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, California, and formerly Keeper of the National Gallery, performs his present task with comprehensive thoroughness.

RETAIL sales moved higher in the week under the influence of more favorable weather conditions and the spur of intensive advertising and clearance prices. Local stores reported volume running 4 or 5 per cent above a year ago, while from other centres of the country gains up to 12 per cent were mentioned.
For a time the police in the Bronx didn't know what they were hunting. Some said it was a deer and others that it was a goat.

ALL along the Maine coast a new industry has grown rapidly in the past few years -- Worms! The worms dug are the blood and the sand worm commonly known as clam worms. They are from four to twelve inches long and are found abundantly in the mud and clam flats along the shores.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 8. -- An exhibition of blossoms and two garden tours have been arranged for Tuesday afternoon in the North Country colonies and several thousand visitors are expected to view them.

WITH the recent completion of the motor highway from Laredo, Texas, to Mexico, D.F., a new approach has been provided for the tide of travel to Mexico. Already a stream of automobiles is traversing this modern hard-surfaced road that extends through deserts, mountains and jungles for 783 miles.

VIENNA, June 8. -- The political honeymoon of General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Air Minister, in Southeastern Europe, ending this week with a visit to Belgrade, is one of the many signs in Central and Southeastern Europe of Germany's desire for foreign political success, working hand in hand with Nazism's desire to establish outposts abroad.

An uncommon but easily recognized yacht burgee will make its appearance on Sound waterways this season in increasing numbers. The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club's familiar New Moon, worn by track men and athletes of other sports for many years, is to be encouraged among the club's yachts-men.

MONTREAL, June 8 (Canadian Press). -- In combating crime, the United States has not yet learned the importance of using all the scientific devices available, Sanford Bates director of the Bureau of Prisons, United grates Department of Justice, told the delegates to the American Public Welfare Association at a luncheon meeting here today.

The letter of Henry Edward Warner published in the Sunday TIMES of June 2 suggests a novel and glorious plan to curb kidnapping. It says: "If the kidnapper is known beyond a doubt, let his picture and description be posted broadside with instructions to all citizens, not to inform or arrest, but to kill this man on sight."

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Austen Bolam laments the fact that the Supreme Court of the United States has such vast power as to nullify an act of Congress. In affairs of human beings certainly some human being or beings have to have vast power. Vast power was attempted to be lodged by the NIRA in the President.

SWITZERLAND, the land of electrified railways and spectacular automobile roads, is keeping pace with the trend of the times by promoting aviation. The land of the Alps covers an area of only 15,737 square miles, but this seemingly limited flying territory offers a variety of scenery which cannot be duplicated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 8. -- The mechanism known to radiologists as a "teleradium," or radium pack, a recently developed device for attacking deep-seated cancers, will be discussed here Monday morning at the opening session of the two-day meeting of the American Radium Society, composed of 140 cancer specialists in the United States who are in charge of practically all the radium in this country.

THERE is an octogenarian in London who has lived two lives. With his sad eyes, grim jaw and Irish brogue, Carson used to be, once upon a time, the irreconcilable Orangeman, champion of coercion in Ireland and die-hard in his opposition to any form of Home Rule or other tampering with the Act of Union.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- The Athletics, with a three-run drive in the ninth inning today defeated the Senators, 4 -- 8, and evened the current series.

I appreciate the attention paid to my book "Wish and Wisdom" in THE TIMES Book Review of May 12. I regret that inadvertently the review variously ascribed to me a purpose foreign to my thesis, beginning with the heading "More Confirmation of Barnum."

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 8. -- "Alfalfa Bill" Murray, who always has taken his coffee black and his democracy straight, threatened tonight to bolt the "Roosevelt party" and "join the Republicans or any other group -- if necessary to save the Constitution."

IN Berlin the Nazis restore conscription with much the same effect on Europe as a salvo of heavy guns. General Goering announces that his air fleet is second to none, end another bang reverberates into Moscow, Rome, Paris and London.
Robert T. Curley, who will graduate from Fordham College on Wednesday with the degree of Bachelor of Science, will be the ninth of his family to graduate from the university. The others were:

BOSTON, June 7. -- The textile mills of New England will continue to operate under the codes. By voluntary agreement they will abide by the same regulations which have controlled them for almost two years.

DETROIT, June 8. -- From the problems of national affairs which have riveted their attention for a week, delegates to the triennial of the General Federation of Women's Clubs turned today to the errand of exploring the convention city and its environs.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 8. -- A group of ten men will attempt this month to scale Mount Waddington, Canada's "killer mountain," which has turned all others back.

PLEASANTVILLE, ir. Y., June l 8. -- The Pleasantvtlle Garden Club held a flower show yesterday in St. John's parish house. Mrs. E. Holmewood was winner of the sweepstake prize in the cultural classes and Mrs. Beatrice Sanborn of that in the artistic arrangement classes.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Considerable increases in employment and payrolls in the petroleum industry in 1933 and 1934, during which time the government was attempting to regulate the production, refining and marketing of oil, are reported by Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics.

Finally realizing that the instability of men's wear products arises from selling goods on a "blind" basis, the industry this year is starting on an era of definite brand name merchandising, B. Goldsmith Jr., secretary and treasurer of Alfred J. Silberstein, Inc., declared here yesterday.

Probably the great public still associates the exploration of the stratosphere with efforts to find out more about the nature and source of the cosmic rays. If there were no other purpose in ascending to a possible height of fourteen miles, all the thought, labor and money that have been expended on the Explorer II, a balloon as high as a thirty-story building when inflated, would be wasted.

BERLIN, June 8. -- The Whitsuntide holiday recess, which virtually began yesterday and will extend to next Tuesday, completely dominates the German scene, even to the exclusion of public interest in political happenings in London and Paris.

KANSAS CITY, June 8 (AP). -- Miss Helen Stephens, 17-year-old Fulton (Mo.) farm girl, today bettered by two-tenths of a second the world's 100-meter dash record for women held by Miss Stella Walsh. She ran the distance in 11.6 seconds as compared with the old record of 0:11.8. Last Saturday at St. Louis Miss Stephens tied the record.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- Announcement of the election of Yorke Alien Jr., '36, of New York City, as president of the International Relations Club of Princeton University and of Thomas S. Jones, '36, of Hinsdale, Ill., as president of the university glee club, has been made here by Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college.

WHEN he turns from writing plays to writing novels, Ferenc Molnar has a method of his own -- a method so characteristic and so distinctive that he is not far short of having invented a new literary form. He applies it with equal appropriateness to whatever body of material happens to attract him.

Kelpie was a wild pony, whose mother had been killed, so that the foal had to fend for himself with the other ponies on the moor. The first friend he makes is Tammas, the little gypsy boy, who is almost as lonely and neglected as the pony. Patiently Tammas works to tame and train Kelpie and, as he has a way with horses, he finally surprises Farmer McKyle by showing him a well-broken pony.

Fine rain obscured the cinder lot behind Hudson Guild in West Twenty-seventh Street yesterday. A knot of boys strove patiently to patch sagging-edged holes in the roof of their shack. From a fourth floor window of the Guild, Alice Miller watched.

In the wreckage of the NRA program, caused by the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case, the President started last week the task of building anew. For the reconstruction of NRA, the only tool he laid his hand to was of tackhammer potency -- a Congressional resolution authorizing a skeleton organization without control over codes, wages or hours of labor.

The national conference of State liquor administrators will meet in Cleveland Thursday to discuss means of plugging the loopholes in liquor control opened when the FACA went out of existence as a result of the Supreme Court ruling on the NIRA.

THE development of tourist trade has become a national interest in many lands, according to the evidence furnished in the widespread studies of the problems of the visitor and the numerous provisions for his comfort and security.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Visitors are pouring into the capital in increasing numbers for the sixty-first annual council of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP). -- John Barrymore, answering divorce charges of his wife, alleged here today that she once held him captive aboard his yacht, stifled his artistic career and worried him into flight to New York and England.

There falls due this week the regular semi-annual instalment on the European war debts. No one expects that the United States will receive more on this occasion than it received six months or a year ago: namely, a single cash payment from Finland, amounting to about $165,000 -- or less than one-tenth of 1 per cent of the whole amount due.

MADRID, June 8 (AP). -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora issued a decree today authorizing presentation to Congress of the projected revision of the Military Code, which would establish a series of the most severe penalties for espionage, both in war and peace times.

Mayors and business representatives of more than twenty-six seaport cities of the United States will begin arriving in New York City today to attend the first national Conference of Seaport Cities on International Trade, opening at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 8. -- Declaring that the Supreme Court had stopped the country as it was overstepping "the landmarks of democracy," Bainbridge Colby, in an address before West Virginia bankers today, said he welcomed "a spirit at last in Washington of conformity, if not respect, toward our American system of government."
A national committee to sponsor a nation-wide commemoration on Oct. 4 of the 400th aniversary of the first Bible printed in English has been formed. The personnel of the committee follows:

LONDON, June 8 (by Wireless). -- It may seem extraordinary that any one will travel 6,000 or more miles in order to hit a ball over a net on a special patch of green turf, but so it is, and as long as people are interested in games Wimbledon will retain its international flavor.

Lively trading developed in the short session on the Cotton Exchange yesterday when concentrated buying of a line of October contracts for about 25,000 bales, recently distributed, turned an early loss into an advance of nearly $2 a bale. Closing gains were 17 to 26 points.

Slashing onward through a drenching rain and slippery footing, Omaha yesterday won the historic Belmont Stakes before 25,000 persons in a manner definitely to establish himself as the champion 3-year-old of 1935. He brought to his owner, William Woodward, the distinction of being the one man to have bred and owned two triple crown winners.

BOSTON, June 8. -- The Yankees and Red Sox battled each other all over Fenway Park for something like five and a half hours today, but not a fan in a gathering of 20,000 was able to detect where either had gained the slightest advantage.

OMAHA, Neb., June 6. -- On the heels of an impressive showing of the popular strength of the AAA, the disquieting thought comes to the Corn Belt that perhaps its benefits have all been unconstitutional. Maybe the AAA would be erased, as the Blue Eagle was, by a judicial decree reminding Congress that its powers are limited and, such as they are, to be exercised by itself instead of delegated to administrators.

Far from the haunts of racketeers and counterfeit coin passers, 4,000 firearms of various types and sizes, two tons of slugs ($32,650 worth to subway turnstile chiselers) and 450 slot machines were carried forty-five miles up Long Island Sound yesterday afternoon and dumped in 150 feet of water at a point two and a half miles off Eaton Neck.

THE growing of perennials and rock plants in home gardens from seed is becoming more and more general. This practice offers many advantages: it widens one's range of choice till it includes scarce or expensive, new and rare varieties; it makes possible the planting of worth-while numbers of plants without much expense; and it provides plants that may be transferred to borders or rock gardens with a minimum of check or setback.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 8. -- Two persons were killed and three others injured, two of them so severely that they were not expected to live, in a head-on collision of two automobiles on the Somers Point-Ocean City Boulevard at 11:30 o'clock tonight.

The ninetieth commencement of Fordham College begins this morning at 11 o'clock in the University Church with the celebration of the baccalaureate services. All the new graduates of both branches of Fordham College, numbering nearly 400, will attend, wearing academic gowns.

THE ranchers of Southern Utah man were the willing slaves of Black Belle Dawson because of her beauty and her man's size ability with a horse, a gun and a pack of cards. That is, all but big Jake Yager and his gang of outlaws who inhabited Hell's Fringe Flats, on the south-

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Twelve days have passed since the Supreme Court handed down in the NRA case what lawyers call an "opinion," but what actually and instantly takes form as the organic law of the land. In those twelve days it has been completely demonstrated that, though at first only a few recognized the fact, nothing of such widespread effect has come from the court in many years.

MONTREAL, June 8 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal track and field athletes today evened a defeat suffered earlier in the season at Vermont when they outscored three colleges from that State, Middlebury, Norwich and Vermont, 75 points to 57.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 8. -- The crew of the stratosphere balloon Explorer II and the scientists associated with the expedition busied themselves today with the last details of preparation while they awaited good weather.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The fact that nature is fond of going from one extreme to the other in her distribution of rain has just been illustrated in the lately drought-stricken Central Plains States, where heavy downpours have swollen some of the western tributaries of the lower Mississippi, causing disastrous floods.

Approximately half a million persons used one or more of the services of Travelers Aid in this country last year, according to an announcement which will be presented today at the National Conference on Social Work at Montreal.

Completion this month by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the permanent registration of all securities listed on exchanges will pave the way for further disclosure during July and August of the ownership of the nation's major industrial corporations.

As a result of the Student Council and club elections which have been held at Hunter College in the past week, three students were elected by the council to executive positions in that body, and 103 students have been chosen to offices in twenty-six clubs.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- A tax measure, to which may be hooked new levies on inheritances and gifts, was started today toward House passage within a week.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- Members of the American and Canadian Medical Associations are coming into the city for their first joint convention from Monday to Friday in the municipal auditorium. They will hold a series of specialized separate sessions for the discussion of various fields of research.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- The annual sermon to the graduating class of the Yale Divinity School will be preached tomorrow by the Rev. Dr. George Stewart of the First Presbyterian Church, Stamford.

THE main hazard in writing a book about Napoleon's marshals is that Napoleon keeps getting in the way. There he looms all the time, heaping shadow on them. What good would he be without them? What good would they be without him?

In the issue of The London Economist at hand last week, appears perhaps the clearest statement yet printed of the actual questions at issue in last Sunday's Swiss referendum. As THE TIMES has previously stated, the question of currency devaluation was involved only indirectly.

FOR once in a way, here is a book which does not seem rankly overpraised by the bubbling enthusiasm of its blurb. "Bright Destination" is indeed a "delightfully mad, completely captivating, modern, picaresque romance."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8. -- Thousands of persons who came from many Eastern States to attend the Talbott Festival of the Westminster Choir School were turned away tonight from the relatively small chapel of Princeton University where, because of the rain, the event was held instead of in the Palmer Memorial Stadium as originally planned.
Pines Winterfront Company and Subsidiary -- Year ended April 30: Net loss after depreciation, interest, taxes and other charges, $263,090, compared with $80,970 loss in preceding year.

GENEVA, June 8. -- The employers' group in the International Labor Office conference dropped today its caucus ban on committee work on the forty-hour week to the extent of allowing employer delegates who desire to attend the right to do so, already taken by the United States and Italian delegates.

MOSCOW, June 8, -- Dr. Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, mutually pledged the most vigorous efforts to extend the collective security system to other States as the only effective guarantee of peace in addresses tonight following the first of their conferences on the troubled European situation, for which Dr. Benes arrived in Miscow today.

WEST POINT next weekend celebrates the sesquicentennial of the birth of General Sylvanus Thayer, the "Father of the Military Academy," whose genius did so much, a century ago, to start the institution toward the niche in fame which it occupies today.

IT took the Motor Vehicle Commissioner, the Legislature and the Governor of Connecticut, with the Motor Vehicle Commissioner of New York as an ally, to put an end to the silly interstate taxicab war that has been going on intermittently for the last three years.

We can hardly have too many good anthologies of poetry for children. The making of an anthology is a very individual matter; always in good collections of verse for boys and girls there is duplication of titles, always there are freshness and surprise.

When you assert in your editorial on the late Hugo de Vries that natural selection is no longer accepted as an explanation of the origin of species most biologists will agree with you. It is to be regretted that your lack of space made it impossible to show why the hypothesis is no longer tenable.
OAKMONT, Pa., June 8. -- Sam Parks Jr., former University of Pittsburgh golf captain, today became the national open golf champion of the United States.

FARMINGTON, Conn., June 8. -- Wet, slippery going and a difficult two-mile course took their toll in the Farmington Valley Plate Steeplechase, feature of the sixth annual hunts meet of the Farmington Valley Polo Association at the Polo Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (2P). -- Announcement of the organization of the Farmers Independence Council of America, dedicated to freedom of agriculturists from governmental regulation, was made today by Dr. E.V. Wilcox, secretary. He stated the purpose of the organization to be:

ROME, June 8. -- The Conciliation Commission charged with seeking a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy began sitting this week, but adjourned until June 25, to meet at Scheveningen, the Netherlands.

Three leading communications companies issued yesterday reports of earnings which showed gross revenues from operations higher in April than a year ago but little changed for the first four months of 1935 compared with the same period in 1934.

Cities operating under the city manager plan have weathered the depression better than those run by elected public officials, according to a survey made public yesterday by the National Municipal League.

TRAGEDY and comedy are judiciously intermingled in this thoroughly enjoyable story of murder in a Sussex village. The man who is killed is no loss to the community, and not a tear is shed over his grave. Nevertheless, murder has been done, and the forces of the law must do their best to find the murderer.

POLICE ORDERS: John J. Roegner the new Public Safety Director of Passaic, N.J., gave orders last week that every member of the police force must attend church (any church) every Sunday. To make sure that none of them fibs about it, the policemen will be required to undergo theological "quiz" sessions each Monday.

LONDON. ANOTHER peace treaty is likely to be signed shortly. The contracting parties will be the Book Society and the associated Booksellers of Great Britain and Ireland. Ever since the Book Society was started, about six years ago, its activities have been resented by many booksellers as a sort of poaching upon their preserves.

Stanley Baldwin, in his first public address since he succeeded J. Ramsay MacDonald as Prime Minister of Great Britain on Friday, outlined yesterday the program of his government in a talk broadcast from England over WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System and WJZ and the National Broadcasting Company network.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- A mythical kingdom will he set up in Asheville tomorrow morning for a week as the eighth annual rhododendron festival gets under way. Parades, pageantry and social affairs will be held. Thousands of acres of rhododendron are in full bloom in the mountains, adding color to the fete.

Ralph Altman, 26 years old, of 6 Charles Street, was shot near the heart by one of two hold-up men who attempted a robbery at 6 P.M. yesterday at the Colony Art Shop, Inc., 479 Sixth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, where his condition was said to be critical.

A remarkable collection of coins and other material used as money in different countries of the world has just been placed on exhibition in the main banking room of the Forty-second Street branch of the Chase National Bank, at 60 East Forty-second Street.

Miss Josephine Windle, tournament chairman of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, in speaking last week of Miss Joyce Wethered's professional golf debut in this country, remarked that the English star was hoping to reach the West Coast on her present tour but was still uncertain whether she would get beyond the Rockies.

The markets moved to a generally higher closing in yesterday's brief trading period. Strength in the metal stocks featured the share market on the Stock Exchange, where total transactions of 341,000 shares represented the slowest day's business since March 30; the listed bond market with sales of but $4,400,000 showed less than average activity for a Saturday.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP). -- Gus Suhr's triple with the bases full in the seventh inning was the crowning blow in a hitting carnival between the Pirates and Reds today and it paved the way for a 14-to-8 victory for Pittsburgh. The first baseman batted in five runs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- A large wooden statue of Old Bet, first elephant brought to the United States, was found near collapse today by members of the Westchester County Historical Society on their thirteenth annual pilgrimage to historical places in the county.

WILLIAM BUTLER YEATS will be 70 on Thursday, and that austere raven of Irish literature is to descend from his remote perch in Rathfarnham to attend a banquet given by the Irish Academy and the other Dublin literary societies in his honor.

THIS new volume of short stories unquestionably contains Erskine Caldwell's most powerful work. The most effective stories will be acclaimed both by those critics who cling to traditional standards and those of the left wing who say that art is determined by class interests.

THE keener the competition for jobs the harder it is for woman to find a place for herself outside the home. Her "new freedom" stands her in good stead when war or a high pitch of prosperity creates an abnormal demand for labor.

Between 11,000 and 12,000 students from all parts of the United States are expected to converge on the city next month for the thirty-sixth Summer session of Columbia University. Lectures will begin July 8 and continue through Aug. 16, registration days being July 3, 5 and 6.

AFTER weeks of conning the script, Henry Hathaway has got himself into the proper rapport, as the table-rappers would say, for the filming of "Peter Ibbetson." His previous venture, "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer," was a clamant success.

CHARLES BOYER and Hollywood are not exactly reconciled, but they are willing to give each other another trial. For six months of the year M. Boyer and Hollywood will be like this: (business of holding two fingers side by side).

OTTAWA, Ont., June 6. -- This week saw the introduction of the essential remaining measures of the government's New Deal program. It also brought statements from Prime Minister Bennett and Opposition Leader Mackenzie King which make it seem probable that Parliament will prorogue in another two or three weeks instead of sitting into late July.

The phantom figure of the four-minute mile will be fleeing before the three greatest eight-furlong men in the world on Saturday when Bill Bonthron, Glenn Cunningham and Jack Lovelock match strides at Palmer Stadium in the Princeton invitation meet.

MANILA -- A planned economy for the Philippine Islands has been suggested by J.M. Elizalde, head of Elizalde Co., one of the largest commercial houses in the Philippines, and chairman of the National Development Company, a semi-governmental enterprise.

THE author describes himself on the title page of this remarkable book as "Associate Professor of Political Science, University of Wisconsin," but "Boss Rule" is not the product of a cloister. No member of the Brain Trust ever penetrated more deeply behind the veil that traditionally separates the academic world from the world of practical politics.

A Frenchman keen on our politics said to an American the other day: "I suppose that the decision of the "Supreme Court against the President "will make it impossible for him to be "re-elected next year." The proper answer was: "We don't go so fast as that in this country."

THE Museum of the City of New York has opened to the public an exhibition of "New York in Fiction," which is to continue throughout the Summer. It is a loan exhibition, supplemented by material owned by the museum, of first editions of novels the scenes of which are laid in New York City.

It also brought statements from Prime Minister Bennett and Opposition Leader Mackenzie King which make it seem probable that Parliament will prorogue in another two or three weeks instead of sitting into late July.

No member of the Brain Trust ever penetrated more deeply behind the veil that traditionally separates the academic world from the world of practical politics.

More than 4,000 members of patriotic organizations marched three-quarters of a mile through a drizzling rain from West New Brighton to Port Richmond, S.I., yesterday in the annual parade of the Staten Island Flag Day Association.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Senate silver bloc will meet Monday with a view to exerting pressure upon the Treasury for the immediate fixing of the silver price at $1.29 an ounce and to formulate plans for combating rumors blamed for the metal's slump in world markets.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota was cited yesterday by W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican State chairman, as the type of man that next year's Republican National Convention should nominate for President. Mr. Macy made this suggestion in a statement issued here before he and Senator Nye left by automobile for Schenectady, where Senator Nye spoke last evening at a dinner of the Young Republican Club of that city

DR. FRIEDRICH BURGDOERFER is in a fair way to having an important decoration pinned upon his breast by the Nazis for a book of his which, like the works of Lothrop Stoddard and Madison Grant, warns us that the whites are threatened by inferior races.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 8. -- Leslie Pawson of Pawtucket, winner of the 1933 Boston marathon, today defeated Johnny Kelley of Arlington, Mass., this year's victor, by fifty-five seconds in the Donahue Memorial twenty-five-kilometer race.

A scattering of orders for Fall goods in the various primary textile markets last week led executives to hope that the much delayed Fall buying movement would get under way shortly. The time for shipments of such goods is rapidly approaching, it was pointed out, and with mills watching their production carefully, some buyers are likely to be "caught short" if they delay much longer.

FROM now until after Labor Day the calendar of events in this country provides spectacles and activities of endless variety. In near-by waters amateur yachtsmen are tuning up their boats for many regattas. Other sportsmen are thumbing schedules of their favorite games.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 8. -- Although low handicap players kept within a few strokes of par over a windswept course today, it remained for Andrew I. Cook to assume a commanding lead at the halfway mark of the first annual Lloyd Gwyer Memorial Trophy golf tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club.

The joint board of the Dressmakers Union held a parade of thousands of garment workers in the garment district yesterday as a show of union strength and as a protest against any change in the wages and working hours of the needle trades under the recent Supreme Court decision invalidating the NRA.

IT would be redundant at this stage of the game to say that John Taylor Arms is an authority on print making. His graphic work -- as, especially, in the March one-man show at Kennedy's we were privileged to see -- speaks for itself. Mr. Arms, limited or non-existent though the emotional appeal of his superbly made etchings may be, is a master craftsman.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Ten days after the Supreme Court's momentous decision in the Schechter case invalidating the NRA, and with it the codes of fair competition and their labor provisions, organized labor has decided on its program.

ATHENS, June 8. -- Greece goes to the polls tomorrow for the election of a Grand Parliament, to be substituted for the Chamber and Senate and to be especially entrusted with revision of the Constitution in order to strengthen the administration against party feuds.

Prices for wanted seasonal merchandise continue firm, although some excellent buys are obtainable from manufacturers finding themselves overstocked due to the recent inclement weather, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

HONOLULU, May 31 (by Mail). -- It was eight bells in the morning watch, and the Marine orderly came into the flag quarters on the U.S.S. Houston and said, "Sir, officer of the deck reports flagship, C in C, United States Fleet, standing in."

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The codes are dead. The Supreme Court, in the Schechter decision, wrecked the entire code structure, and President Roosevelt has decided to ask only "stop-gap" legislation, keeping the NRA as a skeleton fact-finding organization, pending the public reaction to the Supreme Court decision.

LONDON, May 16. THREE sharply contrasted plays have this week asked for London's attention. "Draw the Fires," by Ernst Toller, is an account of the German Navy's mutiny at Kiel in 1918 and a solemn attack on Prussian militarism; "The Miracle Man," written and chiefly performed by Seymour Hicks, is based on a novel by Frank L. Packard, and "The Mask of Virtue" is an adaptation by Ashley Dukes of Carl Sternheim's "La Marquise d'Arcis."
TACOMA, Wash., June 8 (AP). -- Federal men cloaked with increasing secrecy tonight their moves to solve the $200,000 ransom kid napping of 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser.

James G. McDonald, High Commissioner for Refugees Coming From Germany, returned on the Munson liner American Legion last week after a three-month survey of colonization possibilities in the Argentine, Brazil and Uruguay.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- Van Lingle Mungo cannot be defeated on his birthday. Even the elements conspire in his favor. Since he was 18 years of age the big fireball ace of the Dodgers has pitched and won a game on his natal day and today he kept the record intact by taking a five-inning decision, 3 to 2, in the first game of a scheduled double-header with the Phillies.

THE campaign of Wade Hampton in 1876 to wrest the government of South Carolina from the carpetbaggers was one of the turning points of Southern history in the reconstruction period and deserves a record by a competent hand.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. -- After four heats had been run off, rain forced cancellation of the remaining events on the Saturday matinee program of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

THERE is a certain fascination about plant propagation -- the making of new growth from old by means of cuttings -- that appeals to every gardener. While some plants, such as California privet and willows, are so easily grown in this way that they need merely be stuck into the ground and kept moist in order to form roots and grow, most species require more care.

ROME, June 8. -- In a speech delivered to an enormous crowd at Cagliari, Sardinia, where he reviewed the Sabauda Division prior to its embarkation for East Africa, Premier Benito Mussolini reiterated today his intention to go ahead with his plans in East Africa despite anything the rest of the world might think or say.

The sixty-third annual commencement of the Stevens Institute of Technology was held yesterday afternoon in the gymnasium on the campus at Castle Point, Hoboken. Five honorary degrees were conferred, scholarships and prizes were announced, seventy-nine seniors were graduated and six graduate students received degrees.

IF time and space could be jumbled so that Henry Ford, in the year 1935, could send an automotive expedition into the American West of 1935, with touches here and there of the Mexico and Peru of 1535, there might be a duplicate to the adventures described in this book.

THE title of this book is no more intriguing than its pictorial and textual contents and carries the implication that it speaks for the man who although really rich is compelled to endure poverty as well as for the man who, thinking himself poor, is in point of economic fact fabulously rich.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- The first week of training for the Poughkeepsie regatta of 1935 came to its close today, and tomorrow new arrivals will bring the rowing colony close to its top quota.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- The streamline train City of Portland reached North Western Station here at 10:30 A.M. today from Portland, Ore., after traveling the 2,250 miles between the two cities in 39 hours and 45 minutes, cutting 19 hours and 15 minutes from the old running time.
BALTIMORE, June S (P). -- "The irritation of a convalescent" was suggested today by Senator Rad cliffe, Democrat of Maryland, as an explanation of some of the criticism of New Deal recovery measures.

Columbia University this year distributed her favors with an even hand in the honorary degrees. She gave an LL.D. to Secretary of Agriculture WALLACE, who is as good a man as the New Deal can show, and she gave the same degree to Professor KEMMERER, who doesn't think the New Deal came down from Sinai, to put it mildly.

BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP). -- A torn dress and the handle of a broken knife were turned over to fingerprint experts today by police hunting a man who seized a 16-year-old girl in a woods here and was driven away only when the girl's brother stabbed him in the back.

THE music season, usually dull at this time of the year following the round of Winter performances and before the beginning of the outdoor series at the Lewisohn Stadium and in the parks, is enlivened this year by the concerts that the works division of the city's Emergency Relief Bureau organizes and the operatic presentations that Alfredo Salmaggi furbishes forth.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- The half-century fight over the demands of the railroads that they be allowed to reduce long-haul rates to meet water competition appeared today nearer some Congressional determination than in years.

THERE is probably no radio program that is good for all children or bad for all children, according to a recent report Mrs. S.M. Gruenberg of the Child Study Association made to the Radio Institute of Audible Arts. The problems of child training arising out of radio are, in the opinion of Mrs. Gruenberg, of an individual nature, varying with the type of child.

THE monumental study of the influence of motion pictures on children and youth made two years ago under the auspices of the Payne Fund by a Committee on Educational Research has ever since been yielding rich results as its several phases have been specialized in a series of twelve investigations and discussions utilizing the material thus collected and devoted each to a particular part of the general theme.

A textbook for detectives which goes deeply into scientific and psychological methods of crime solution has been written by Deputy Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell, dean of the New York Police Academy and Dr. Harry Soderman, European criminologist.

AMARILLO, Texas, June 8 (AP). -- After hearing James and Elliott Roosevelt, sons of the President, plead the cause of the New Deal, young Democrats of Texas went on record tonight as opposed to any change which would "destroy the Constitution."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- Discriminatory fees for non-residents of Westchester County at golf courses, pools, parks and beaches operated by the Westchester County Park Commission would cost taxpayers of the county $1,000,000 annually, Park Commissioners were told today by Herman W. Merkel, general superintendent of the county park system.

The echoes of a controversy in Missouri were heard yesterday in Wall Street when officials of Kansas City made it plain that they were in complete disagreement with an opinion recently handed down by Attorney General McKittrick of Missouri. The Attorney General held that the State had power to call outstanding bond issues, even though no callable provision was contained in the loan indentures, and refund them at lower coupon rates.

PARIS, June 6. -- The Toulouse Lautrec ball held at the historical Moulin de la Galette officially opened the big Paris season. Many authentic silhouettes and coiffures of the gay Ninety and Nineteen Hundred period were worn,

OAKMONT, Pa., June 8. -- Because his dad didn't think he was husky enough to play basketball and football after he had finished high school, Samuel McLaughlin Parks Jr. was urged by his father to devote his spare time to golf, a game at which he had shown a certain adeptness.

WHETHER or not sailors' knots have been listed among the art-crafts, they certainly should have that distinction, as any one who looks through this crafts-manly made book will be at once convinced. Many books have been written about them in various languages.

AMARILLO, Texas, June 8 (AP). -- After hearing James and Elliott Roosevelt, sons of the President, plead the cause of the New Deal, young Democrats of Texas went on record tonight as opposed to any change which would "destroy the Constitution."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 8. -- Discriminatory fees for non-residents of Westchester County at golf courses, pools, parks and beaches operated by the Westchester County Park Commission would cost taxpayers of the county $1,000,000 annually, Park Commissioners were told today by Herman W. Merkel, general superintendent of the county park system.

The echoes of a controversy in Missouri were heard yesterday in Wall Street when officials of Kansas City made it plain that they were in complete disagreement with an opinion recently handed down by Attorney General McKittrick of Missouri. The Attorney General held that the State had power to call outstanding bond issues, even though no callable provision was contained in the loan indentures, and refund them at lower coupon rates.

PARIS, June 6. -- The Toulouse Lautrec ball held at the historical Moulin de la Galette officially opened the big Paris season. Many authentic silhouettes and coiffures of the gay Ninety and Nineteen Hundred period were worn,

OAKMONT, Pa., June 8. -- Because his dad didn't think he was husky enough to play basketball and football after he had finished high school, Samuel McLaughlin Parks Jr. was urged by his father to devote his spare time to golf, a game at which he had shown a certain adeptness.

WHETHER or not sailors' knots have been listed among the art-crafts, they certainly should have that distinction, as any one who looks through this crafts-manly made book will be at once convinced. Many books have been written about them in various languages.

On June 15 war-debt payments are due to the United States from the thirteen nations to which we sent notices on June 1, but it is expected that of this number only Finland will pay. This little Baltic land is the only one among our debtor countries that has never missed an instalment, having consistently lived up to the agreement signed in Washington in 1922.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP). -- The White Sox, tail-enders last year, continued their annoyance of the Tigers, last year's champions, today by defeating Detroit, 3 to 2, for their eighth victory in ten meetings between the teams.

MR. BRASOL writes with great enthusiasm and gusto of his three Russian literary gods, and he manages to convey something of his fervor to the reader. He employs the Russian critical method of pre-Marxian days, stressing the social rather than the esthetic factor: a method which has its peculiar merits when applied to Russian literature, which fathered it.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- Alarmed by mounting post-repeal liquor smuggling, the administration today pressed Congressional leaders for quick action on new legislation to grant President Roosevelt power to declare customs enforcement zones fifty miles off the United States Coast.
EXETER, N.H., June 8. -- After trailing at the start, Exeter rallied to take the annual baseball game from Andover today by 8 to 5 before an alumni crowd.

A custom that has become increasingly popular with exhibitors at the Summer shows permits the removal of dogs before the advertised hour of closing. It has been adopted by most of the larger events as a factor in attracting entries, especially from owners living at considerable distances, who are thus enabled to reach home at a reasonable hour.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- The first of an estimated 2,000 advertising executives will reach Chicago tomorrow for the thirty-first annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America. The meetings of the three-day convention, which formally opens Monday, will be held in the Palmer House.

THE Blues Battalion is to Richmond what the Seventh Regiment is to New York. Formed as a company of light infantry in the year in which George Washington became President of the United States, the Virginia organization is senior by seventeen years to Manhattan's corps d'elite of citizen foot-soldiers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- Yale blanked Princeton, 6 -- 0, today before a crowd cut to 400 by the rain, which compelled the teams to begin the game forty minutes late and to play in a drizzle which twice increased to heavy showers. A downpour finally halted hostilities as the Tigers finished their half of the sixth.

NOT every one is fortunate enough to have a supply of Summer flowers ready to be plucked and worn with light dresses. New costume jewelry is designed to fill the need of a cool and demure touch which people feel when they are miles from a blooming garden.

BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP). -- A torn dress and the handle of a broken knife were turned over to fingerprint experts today by police hunting a man who seized a 16-year-old girl in a woods here and was driven away only when the girl's brother stabbed him in the back.

THE music season, usually dull at this time of the year following the round of Winter performances and before the beginning of the outdoor series at the Lewisohn Stadium and in the parks, is enlivened this year by the concerts that the works division of the city's Emergency Relief Bureau organizes and the operatic presentations that Alfredo Salmaggi furbishes forth.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- The half-century fight over the demands of the railroads that they be allowed to reduce long-haul rates to meet water competition appeared today nearer some Congressional determination than in years.

THERE is probably no radio program that is good for all children or bad for all children, according to a recent report Mrs. S.M. Gruenberg of the Child Study Association made to the Radio Institute of Audible Arts. The problems of child training arising out of radio are, in the opinion of Mrs. Gruenberg, of an individual nature, varying with the type of child.

THE monumental study of the influence of motion pictures on children and youth made two years ago under the auspices of the Payne Fund by a Committee on Educational Research has ever since been yielding rich results as its several phases have been specialized in a series of twelve investigations and discussions utilizing the material thus collected and devoted each to a particular part of the general theme.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Consumers of electricity are the "forgotten investors" of the country and current at reasonable rates must be guaranteed to them to operate the devices in which they have invested $13,000,000,000, Senator Wheeler said tonight in a radio speech in defense of the Utility Holding Company Bill.

Twenty New York policemen and ten firemen who distinguished themselves last year will receive medals from Mayor La Guardia at City Hall at noon Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. In addition, five widows, two mothers and a father will receive medals in behalf of policemen who died in the performance of their duty.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9. -- The 2 Per Cent Sales Tax Bill, in the hands of Governor Harold G. Hoffman for either approval or veto, drew the fire here today of labor leaders, grocers and members of the Clean Government Republican group of Essex County.

Two editions of "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom," the late Colonel T.E. Lawrence's famous story of the Arab revolt, will be brought out in the Autumn by Doubleday, Doran. "Revolt in the Desert," an abridgment of "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom," will be withdrawn.

Predicting a showdown in the conflict of opinion on the fundamental question of the nation's economic policy, with emphasis on tariffs and problems of foreign trade as they affect agriculture, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, calls for a drastic revision of high tariffs as a step essential to recovery.
PARIS, June 9 (AP). -- France will send a giant new transatlantic air liner, the world's largest flying boat, out to meet the Normandie at sea Wednesday morning.
J.H. Moseley, in a letter to THE TIMES, writes that the Ontario Hydro instead of paying for itself in thirty years as claimed has instead increased its debt.

NEW HAVEN, June 8. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.3, which compares with 82.3 a week before, 82.7 two weeks before, 82.3 three weeks before and 82.2 four weeks before.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Rising to the defense of the "brain trust," Joseph L. Hurley, Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts, told the graduating class of Georgetown University today that national and State problems "absolutely demand a thinking machine to suggest solutions and to plan for broader and more enduring efforts in years to come."

Former Representative Frederic Storm, member of the Fifty-seventh Congress, 1901-03, died at his home, 220-15 Forty-third Avenue, Bayside, Queens, yesterday afternoon, after a long illness, in his ninety-second year.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 9. -- The shooting of the annual small bore matches of the New York State Rifle Association which began here at Camp Smith yesterday, was concluded today. Ten events were run off in the two days of shooting. William Breuler of the Quinnipiac Rifle Club of New Haven and Eric Johnson of Hamden, Conn., took five firsts in ten events.

The Port of New York Authority will deliver tomorrow $2,500,000 of its special bonds to the State of New Jersey, fully liquidating advances made by that State toward the construction of the George Washington Bridge. The payment is incident to an arrangement entered into between the State of New Jersey and the Port Authority to pay the indebtedness far in advance of the originally contemplated maturity.

RYE, N.Y., June 9. -- William Tilden went down in defeat today as France gained a 2-1 lead over the United States in the international professional team match for the Bonnardel Cup at the Westchester Country Club.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 9. -- The difficulties of a nonconformist in human relations was the keynote of a baccalaureate sermon in the First Baptist Church here this morning by Dr. Homer P. Rainey, president of Bucknell University. Dr. Emory Hunt, president emeritus of Bucknell, and Dr. Milton G. Evans, president emeritus of Crozer Theological Seminary, shared the pulpit with Dr. Rainey.

Pope Pius cabled greetings yesterday to the Rev. John J. Hickey, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Sixth Avenue and Washington Place, on his celebration of the fortieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood.
Robert Elliott Owens, Grand Master of Masons in the State of New York, announced yesterday the following Grand Lodge appointments:
With a precedent set in a program of seven races for opening day and the Metropolitan Handicap winner, King Saxon, named for the featured Queens County Handicap, the Aqueduct meeting will open today.

BUTTE, Mont., June 9. -- An additional "break" in the search for the kidnappers of 9-year-old George Weyerhaeuser was reported here tonight -- seizure of a stolen Utah motor car from which a man fled, leaving behind a cache of ransom bills.

WASHINGTON, N.J., June 9. -- The sixty-first commencement exercises of Centennial Collegiate Institute at Hackettstown will be held tomorrow morning. The address will be delivered by the Rev. William Hiram Foulkes, pastor of the Old First Church of Newark, and Egbert J. Tamblyn, president of the board of trustees, will present the diplomas.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 9. -- One of yacht racing's rarities occurred today when Miss Lorna Whittelsey, women's national sailing champion, and Cornelius Shields piloted their Interclub craft across the finish line in a dead heat.

Rather than accept another day of enforced idleness, Bill Terry elected to play yesterday's scheduled game with the Braves, despite the weather and the fact that only 6,000 fans were present at the Polo Grounds, this being the slimmest Sunday crowd of the season.

LIMA, Peru, June 9. -- Martin Conboy, special agent of the United States Department of Justice, has during the past week been carrying on investigations at the United States Embassy and questioning voluntary witnesses who might be able to testify regarding the intended movement of the four Curtiss planes detained here since April 4 at the request of the Washington State Department.

The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut announced yesterday the appointment of a special committee to organize support among all State bar associations, boards of trade and chambers of commerce to advocate the passage of a bill recently introduced by Senator Robert F. Wagner restricting the practice of law before Government departments, bureaus, commissions and their agencies to duly licensed attorneys at law.

Tribute to the work of Abram Gustav Schulman, Associate Professor of Art for eight years at City College, who died on June 2 in Phoenix, Ariz., was paid at a brief funeral service held yesterday in the M. Hellman Funeral Chapel, 1,532 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The black-tasseled red fez of the Shrine appeared in increasing numbers today as the vanguard of the more than 100,000 visitors who are expected arrived here for the sixty-first annual conclave of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9. -- An apparatus which will help teach the deaf to speak with normal intonation has been designed at the Cruft Laboratory, Harvard University, by Frederick V. Hunt, Instructor in Physics and Communication Engineering.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $6,003,540,480. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
