A large share of the responsibility for "careless marriages and hasty divorces" was placed yesterday against clergymen whose attitude toward the marriage ceremony was described as "too lax" in a report made public by Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The status of important pending legislation is as follows:

Senator BORAH and some of his colleagues appear to be quite Justified in their suspicions of the House resolution, as it stands, prolonging the NRA. That resolution merely repeals "all provisions of Title I" of the National Industrial Recovery Act "delegating "power to the President to approve or "prescribe codes of fair competition, "and provisions for the enforcement of "such codes."

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 9. -- After showing the way to the field of seventy-eight starters in the opening round yesterday, Andrew I. Cook today easily won the first annual Lloyd P. Gwyer Memorial Trophy golf tournament at the Siwanoy Country Club.

The disappearance of 5-year-old John Kaul of 325 East Fifty-second Street from the vicinity of a Sutton Place playground on the banks of the East River at Fifty-fifth Street late Thursday afternoon was still unsolved last night, more than seventy-two hours later.
Abraham Wishkowsky, 112 years old, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital's psychopathic ward at 1:30 A.M. yesterday after having overindulged in food and wine.

The Power Corporation of New York sold 55,029 additional shares of common stock to the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation for $5,502,900 on Jan. 28, 1935, and the proceeds were used to meet the payment of principal and premium of $4,742,255 on first-mortgage bonds called for payment on Jan. 29, the annual report for 1934 shows.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 9. -- In the Illinois background and settings of Lincoln, the party's first President, thousands of earnest Republicans are gathered tonight to meet what they term another crucial period in the nation's history, redefine the party's attitude and lead the way to nation-wide opposition to the New Deal.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 9. -- No more boxing for Max Baer. The world's heavyweight champion sparred for the last time today and will not don gloves again until he defends his title against James J. Braddock in the Madison Square Garden Bowl on Thursday night.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Every time Christ spoke "he pitched a ball right over the plate for a strike" into the hearts of persons of all ranks and creeds, the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, Dean Emeritus of the Divinity School of Yale University, asserted yesterday morning as guest preacher at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 9. -- A suggestion that banks now subject to Federal regulation might seek to escape from the current trend of government banking legislation by becoming purely State banks was before delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9. -- With another fine exhibition serving as a parting flourish, the Scottish soccer team completed its tour of the United States and Canada today by scoring its eleventh straight victory in winning from another picked American team.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Germany's new conscript army, with its augmented influence as the sole bearer of arms in the Reich, will seek to prevent adventures abroad, the Foreign Policy Association said in a report made public today, the work of Mildred S. Wertheimer of its staff.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 9. -- Champion Milson O'Boy today repeated his glorious victory gained at the record-breaking Madison show, when he was declared best of the nearly 700 dogs benched in the second annual exhibition of the Orange Kennel Club.

A new drive by the La Guardia administration to expedite rapid transit unification is scheduled to begin about July 1 when Samuel Seabury, special counsel for the Board of Estimate, returns from a vacation in Europe, it was indicated yesterday.

That the "strike" waged since May 22 by the City Action Committee and the Council of Working Class Housewives against retail kosher meat establishments in various parts of the city, with the ostensible purpose of forcing a reduction in meat prices, was "in reality a campaign by Communists to destroy the Hebrew Butcher Workers Union" was charged yesterday by officials of the union.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., June 9 (AP). -- The United States Fleet, beginning July 1, will take up a three months' cruising-training schedule.

TACOMA, Wash., June 9. -- "A damned fine piece of work," was the way J.P. Weyerhauser Jr. described the arrests of Mr. and rs. Harmon WaleN and their alleged r eonfesstons in Salt Lake City that I they kidnapped his son George, 9, i for $200,000 ransom.

WARSAW, June 9. -- The first important change in army commanders since Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death was announced today. The Chief of the General Staff, General Gasiorowski, was replaced by General Juljan Stachiewicz, divisional commander.

Friends of Chase Mellen Jr. contended yesterday that about two-thirds of the members of the executive committee of the New York County Republican Committee had pledged themselves to support him for re-election. Mr. Mellen's term will expire in September and a new chairman will be named by the county committee elected at the primary on Sept. 17.

LONDON, June 9. -- A Reuters News Agency dispatch from Peiping said the situation in North China was relieved today by Japan's decision to withhold a threatened ultimatum in view of a conciliatory attitude taken by Chinese military leaders.

Frank Gorman, 21 years old, an unemployed truck driver of 423 West Forty-eighth Street, was arrested last night charged with larceny after he took an ambulance from in front of 529 West Forty-fourth Street, according to the police, and went for a ride "just for the fun of it."
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Fred Jacoby, North Bergen (N.J.) speed boat pilot, was the outstanding performer in the Shrine regatta on the Potomac River today, winning all five of the events he entered.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- With a man and his wife under arrest in Salt Lake City and another man identified as the possessor of $15,000 in ransom money, the Department of Justice announced tonight that it had "broken" the $200,000 kidnapping of George Weyerhaeuser at Tacoma, Wash.
Trailing of those accused of kidnapping George Weyerhaeuser by the passing of bills known by serial numbers to be part of the $200,000 ransom took the following course:

Two New York department stores offer art exhibitions this week. At Altman's paintings by contemporary American artists will be shown until June 22, and at Saks-Fifth Avenue, opening tomorrow, the Photographic Illustrators, Inc., will put on in an especially constructed fifth floor gallery an exhibition of photographs by its members.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, at Sea, June 9. -- The United States Fleet is due at San Diego early tomorrow morning after completing six weeks of some of the largest naval manoeuvres in American history.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9. -- Washington and Penn, contenders from the East and West, came to the Hudson today and settled into their training routine for the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on June 18.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 9. -- Mrs. Ben Witt Key had dinner in the Colonial Room last evening with Dr. and Mrs. E.L. Brown and Ned Brown, and Kenneth Ellis was the guest of the Marchesa Carignani and Mrs. Lela Vardell Johnson. Mrs. Johnson entertained Miss Mary Nicholson and Miss Polly Ingalls at dinner.

We live today in intellectual bewilderment and moral confusion, and the Church of Jesus is the only institution that can point the way out, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street.

A reiteration of his demand that the forthcoming International Penal and Penitentiary Commission meeting in Berlin be ignored by the United States Government was voiced by Samuel Untermyer in a letter to Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, made public here yesterday.

BERLIN, June 7. -- Money is in demand here because of the impending holidays and the quarterly income tax liability. On Friday day loans were at 3 1/8 to 3 3/8 per cent. The heavy increase in the Reichsbank's credits in the return for May 31 was normal in view of the great decline in credits in the preceding week.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Buying power in oats futures on the Board of Trade is not large and is well-scattered, as crop reports in the main are favorable. A large part of the trade recently has been in the way of transferring commitments from near to distant futures. Cash oats are in light supply, with the movement the smallest in years.

The twentieth anniversary of the consecration of the present edifice of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, at Broadway and 155th Street, was observed yesterday morning.

BERLIN, June 7. -- The vicissitudes of French Cabinet formations and the uncertainty of the future of the franc induced considerable nervousness in financial circles here, which was reflected in erratic movements of the stock market.

CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP). -- Ed Coleman's home run with one aboard and Fay Thomas's five-hit pitching gave the Browns a 2-to-1 victory over the Indians today. Hal Trosky pounded his eighth homer of the season to give the Indians their lone tally.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP). -- Disorder today marked the burials of the Millen-Faber gang, executed early Friday, when hundreds of curious spectators braved a heavy rain to witness the final rites for the men.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 9. -- The national outdoor saber championship, decided on an indoor strip in the gymnasium of the Montclair Athletic Club, was captured today for the fifth time by Norman Armitage of the Fencers Club. Rain and wet grounds produced the curious circumstance wherein the national title winner repeated his indoor performance of last April.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 9. -- A plea to keep open "the doors of the mind" in a world where doors were being "slammed" on every side was made to the graduating class of the United States Military Academy here today in a baccalaureate sermon preached in the Cadet Chapel by the Rev. Roscoe T. Foust, the chaplain.
LIMA, Peru, June 9. -- The government issued today a decree for stricter control of foreigners entering Peru. It aims principally at the exclusion of those who plan seditious propaganda.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- A rapid decline in prices of all classes of Canadian cattle imported into this market has eliminated all profit to shippers and there were no arrivals last week. Canadian cattle, however, are being shipped into the markets in St. Paul and Buffalo and the movement of foreign meats into the United States continues heavy.
NEWARK, N.J., June 9. -- The Newark Bears lost both ends of a double-header to the Toronto Maple Leafs today. The scores were 8 to 5 and 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- Thirteen United States destroyers of the Asiatic fleet are now on the way toward Tientsin, and a flotilla of submarines with a tender is en route to Chefoo, but Navy Department officials here said the movement of the naval vessels had no relation to Japanese action in the Peiping area.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Administration leaders in Congress were faced tonight with the prospect of a mad scramble for legislative preferment as a new week dawned with the fateful date of June 16 at the other end.

The first national Conference of Seaport Cities on International Trade will convene today at the Waldorf-Astoria to discuss means of stimulating international commerce through a fuller use of harbor facilities. The conference will last three days.

The shipments of motor cars by of passengers on transatlantic ships have become so great as to embarrass the lines, according to shipping men. All ships capable of carrying cars are reporting a heavy traffic, and in the last two weeks the volume has been unusually heavy.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Brokers and dealers on the over-the-counter markets are beginning to send in heir applications for registration on Form 1-M in response to the edict of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The first lists received were made public today.

Your editorial "Ownership of Wealth" is timely and interesting to the analyst and student of economics. The trouble with most statistical studies in this field -- the few in existence are frequently misused by emotional interpretation -- is lack of segregation between wealth represented by productive facilities, and on the other hand goods consumed personally by the general public.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 9. -- A new "medical shower bath" that enables physicians for the first time literally to wash away a number of fatal infections that attack the brain and central nervous system was demonstrated here today at the scientific exhibit of the first joint meeting of the American Medical Association and the Canadian Medical Association.

The cost of administering the NRA and its 578 codes in the two year ending this month has been $93,884,595, according to a report of a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Picketing by "atheist and pacifist" students at City College was attacked yesterday as "disobedience to lawful authority" by the Rev. Eugene J. Callahan, assistant supreme spiritual director of the Archdiocesan Union Holy Name Society of New York.

LONDON, June 8. -- The stock markets responded sharply to the highly encouraging French political news in spite of the restraining influence of the impending Whitsun holiday. Prices, particularly in industrial securities, again are generally moving upward.

FAIRFIELD, N.J., June 9. -- A consistent score for three days of competition earned Paul Holloway of Canoe Brook the all-around championship of the New Jersey Trapshooting Association in the thirty-second annual meeting of that body over the traps of the North Jersey Gun Club.
Spiritual progress has lagged behind material advance, the congregation of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, 131 West 104th Street, was told yesterday morning by the Rev. Charles C. Cole, the pastor.

The short stretch of the East Side's marginal highway known as Exterior Street was renamed yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia as Marie Curie Avenue in honor of the Polish co-discoverer of radium, who died in Paris last July a martyr to her discoveries.

ATHENS, Greece, June 9. -- Early reports on the light vote cast in the elections today gave a big lead to the combination headed by Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris and Field Marshal George Kondylis, War Minister.

Three 15-year-old Boys were marooned for nearly two hours in an oarless rowboat floating down the East River late yesterday. They were brought back to shore in a police launch after experiencing all the thrills of a rescue on the high seas.
LONDON, June 8. -- In its first stages the French politico-financial crisis almost completely dominated the financial markets here, but in its later dramatic developments it had much less influence.

ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP). -- A shower of lemons greeted Dizzy Dean as he came to bat today in his first home appearance since his squabble at Pittsburgh, but the jeers turned to cheers before the game was over as the loquacious Cardinal hurler held the Chicago Cubs to six hits and scored his seventh victory of the season, 13 to 2.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 9. -- The Harvard and Yale rowing squads, with their coaches and managers, arrived at their respective Red Top and Gales Ferry training quarters late this afternoon. The racing shells which preceded them by train are rigged and ready to go overboard at about 11 o'clock tomorrow morning for the initial workouts on the Thames River.

It is a pleasant thing to find a kettle of Spanish doubloons buried under the apple tree in the orchard, provided you own the orchard. It is equally pleasant to discover Congress in the act of digging up an old claim for $764,143.75 worth of soldiers and services rendered the Federal Government by the City of New York in Civil War days.
LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., June 9. -- Fit and ready for the most important fistic event of his career, James J. Braddock broke camp after his workout today.

Commemorating the nineteenth anniversary of the death of Sholom Aleichem, known as the Yiddish Mark Twain, a program largely drawn from his work was given at the Public Theatre on Saturday night, under the auspices of the Artef Players Collective.

A fashion show, to be known as "Midnight in Manhattan," will be staged during the supper hour on Wednesday on the Pierre Roof for the benefit of the Spring Farm Summer camp at Greens Farms, Conn. The camp is owned and operated by the Goddard Neighborhood Centre in the interest of boys and girls of the East Side.

Freedom confronts us on every hand, and yet we have made ourselves the most regimented people in history because we are not willing to take advantage of our freedom, the Rev. Dr. Irving H. Berg, pastor of Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church and chaplain of New York University, declared yesterday in a baccalaureate address before the graduating class of the university.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week continued sensitive to the French Cabinet crisis. Rates fluctuated nervously with the fall of one party and the re-formation of another. So far as the turnover was concerned not a great deal was involved on any day.

DETROIT, June 9 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin concluded a series of weekly radio broadcasts tonight with an appeal for liberalization of the laws permitting government regulation of interstate commerce and for passage of the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utilities Bill.

OAKMONT, Pa., June 9. -- Now that Sam Parks Jr. is wearing the open golf crown and all Pittsburgh is rejoicing thereat, it all goes to show the worth of ancient advice for open golfers -- to wit: Get home early.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP). -- What happens to the extra pennies the rising food prices have forced housewives to pay for steaks and chops?
PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP). -- Pittsburgh's rookie hurler, Cy Blanton striking out five, ran his record to 71 today as the Pirates made it two out of three from the Reds, winning by 7 to 4.

The "symposium" reported in yesterday's TIMES, in which OWEN YOUNG and his old teacher, Dr. GAINES, took part in a hotel lobby in Canton, N.Y., recalls one of ancient days in Greece when SOCRATES, having spent the day in the Piraeus, was persuaded by the prospect of seeing a torchlight race on horseback to spend the evening at the home of Polemarchus -- whence began PLATO'S Republic.

" Catholics throughout the world proclaim one faith, which has been tested by time, because that faith springs from truth itself," the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart of the staff of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York declared in a sermon at a pontifical mass celebrated yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral in observance of the Festival of Pentecost.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Formation of a national lawyers committee headed by Raoul E. Desvernine, chairman, and including John W. Davis, Frederic R. Coudert Jr., George W. Wickersham, Joseph M. Proskauer and Harold J. Gallagher, all of New York City, among its members, was announced today by the American Liberty League.
G.C. Blankner complains about "demagogues" and their appeal to those "who cannot yet read and who cannot think for themselves." He regrets that such appeal breeds discontent and trouble.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 9. -- Award of the John Addison Porter Prize, one of the outstanding annual prizes at Yale University, to Joseph L. Walsh of this city, a candidate for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy, was announced today at the university.

" The March of Time," the dramatized newsreel series issued monthly by the publishers of Time and Fortune magazines, will be released through the RKO Distributing Corporation beginning with next month's issue, it was announced yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, president of The March of Time, Inc.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Traders in corn on the Board of Trade think the market for July delivery is congested and that with too much rain recently in some of the best corn sections of the Middle West there may not be so large an acreage planted as was contemplated earlier.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 9. -- Officials of the Haverstraw Police and Fire Departments began today an investigation of the origin of the fire which destroyed the Haverstraw Union Free School late last night.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- International currency stabilization would be impracticable if dependent on prior adjustment of balance between cost prices in various countries, according to the International Chamber of Commerce in preparation for its biennial congress in Paris from June 24 to 29.

The La Guardia administration, about to begin drafting the 1936 city budget, is finding itself confronted with the necessity for making drastic cuts in expenditures or finding additional sources of revenue.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Eight additional applications for registration under the Securities Act of 1933, involving $19,609,430, were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WHEN authors get together they have a deplorable habit of talking about royalties, publishers, magazine editors, appropriate hours and conditions of work -- in brief, everything that may be comprised under the heading of "shop." This is most distressing to the starry-eyed layman, who likes to think of his novelist or essayist as an intellectual giant who continually ponders the high problems of human destiny.

The Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company announced yesterday that it had applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to convert $8,130,000 of outstanding bonds into a new series to be known as refunding mortgage bonds, Series D.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP). -- A quarter million shoes, every one for the left foot, went on exhibit today in the annual Autumn show of the National Volume Shoe Manufacturers Association.

Soviet official opinion now frowns upon slack marriage practices. And once more a startling likeness is manifest between the Soviet Government and the proud editor of The Homeville Banner. Last week The Banner was the first to announce that a new fire-house would be built.

Commodity futures were erratic last week, with the partial recovery in sugar futures a feature of the trading, while many other active staples continued weak or barely firm. In the cash markets, lead and tin alone were lower, while gains were scored by all the grains, dairy products, lard, cotton, silk, wool tops and rubber.
" Civil Servitus" writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES relative to salaries paid to court reporters in the Municipal Court, and reclassification of civil service employes.

ALBANY, June 9. -- Definite word will be given tomorrow by Warren C. Giles of Rochester, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Professional Minor Leagues, as to whether Edwin C. (Alabama). Pitts is to become a member of the Senators of the International League.

In giving a general outline of the policy which his new Government means to follow in foreign affairs, Prime Minister BALDWIN said some blunt and bold things. They related chiefly to countries under dictators. The ideal being stable government, coupled with freedom of expression, he ranked Great Britain first in that regard.
TACOMA, June 9. -- George Weyerhaeuser, 9-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. J.P. Weyerhaeuser Jr., member of the extremely wealthy lumber family, was kidnapped May 24 as he walked home from Lowell School.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 9. -- Nearly 1,200 Knights Templar from points throughout the State attended a reception to Colonel Walter Delamater, State Grand Commander, at the Hotel Gramatan, Bronxville, this afternoon, marking the official opening of the 122d annual conclave of the Grand Commandery of Knights Templar, to be held here.

DETROIT, June 9 (AP). -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg yesterday declined the offer of a newly organized Republican League to sponsor his Presidential nomination in 1936, and told its members he had "a deep conviction our party should not start discussing Presidential candidates at the present time."

TRENTON, N.J., June 9. -- Voluntary codes of fair business practice, supported through interstate compacts, were suggested as the most effective means of insuring a restoration of business confidence by Governor Harold G. Hoffman, in a letter today to Governor Olin D. Johnston of South Carolina.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- After grain futures had been sold nearly all week on favorable crop reports, especially on wheat, a movement to cover sales on the Board of Trade absorbed the comparatively moderate offerings and started prices on the upgrade, with wheat in the lead.

SALT LAKE CITY. June 9. -- A man and woman identified as Mr. and Mrs. Herman W. Waley were under arrest here tonight in connection with the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping. Their "full confession" was announced in Washington.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- A spirit of optimism was evident today among the nation's advertising executives as members of the Advertising Federation of America arrived here for the annual convention of the organization.

PARIS, June 8. -- The declaration by Premier Pierre Laval concerning the 1935 deficit, which will reach 11,000,000,000 francs, including the railway deficit and the Treasury embarrassment, denote that he does not wish to cloak the difficulties of the situation.

Commencement exercises of the Fordham College of Pharmacy this evening at 8 o'clock in the university gymnasium will begin the ninetieth commencement proceedings of Fordham College. James F. O'Brien, president of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association, will deliver the commencement address.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9. -- Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church, Boston, and trustee of Vassar College, stressed the spirit of generosity in the baccalaureate sermon he preached today to the 229 members of the graduating class who will receive degrees tomorrow.
PARIS, June 9. -- The political crisis that has just ended left two chief topics of conversation in France which concern problems of fundamental importance to the country's immediate future.

Cotton futures rose 33 to 49 points on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, contrasting with a decline of 78 to 93 points for the previous week. The spot situation was considered by the trade extremely tight as a result of the government's holding of about 5,000,000 bales exclusive of futures, and adverse crop developments in the form of excessive rains were factors in the rise.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Expansion of the Civilian Conservation Corps program to a new peak of 600,000 men and 2,916 camps will begin on June 15, and it will be necessary to enroll 328,570 young men and war veterans to reach this goal, Robert Fechner, director of the Emergency Conservation Work, announced today.

The Rev. Eugene Carson Blake, assistant pastor for the last three years of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at the entrance to Rockefeller Center, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the First Presbyterian Church at Albany.

Two months and five days ago yesterday 560 energetic brown trout flipped their tails and disappeared in the eddies of the vagrant Bronx River, under the aegis of State Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 9. -- For the first time in many months President Roosevelt gave himself over today to typical observance of a Sunday as it is marked in this long-settled community.
MULHOUSE, France, June 9. -- Socialist plans to guard Paris against any "Fascist attacks" were disclosed today. Paul Faure, secretary of the party, in an address at its national convention, asserted:

Representatives of more than 100 youth organizations met yesterday at the Hotel Astor, under the auspices of the youth division of the American Jewish Congress, to consider issues confronting them as Jews and to formulate a program to combat anti-semitism.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 9. -- Young horse show enthusiasts who in the past have filled the role of either spectator or exhibitor received a new treat today as they successfully conducted their own first annual junior horse show at the Round Hill Club.
The New York team successfully defended the Sears Cup in the ninth annual series of the intersectional tennis matches by turning back the Boston forces yesterday, 6 to 3.

If the wish of Manager S.E. Cochran of the National Theatre, Washington, is realized, Ethel Barrymore will tour under his auspices next season in a revival of her former success, "The Constant Wife." This is the Somerset Maugham comedy -- a "smash hit" of the 1926-27 season -- in which Miss Barrymore starred on behalf of Gilbert Miller and the Charles Frohman Company.

NEW ORLEANS, June 9. -- Trading in the cotton contract market here was fairly active last week and prices developed rather wide and frequent fluctuations. The general tendency of prices was upward, with a good recovery from the sharp break at the close of the preceding week:
BUCHAREST, June 9 (AP). -- Rumania was gripped today by a political crisis that many believed might precipitate the downfall of the present government and compromise the position of King Carol.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Conditional exemption of mineral rights and interests from registration under the Securities Act of 1933 is continued in a rule adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective June 10, when present regulations expire.

If it carries out its reported intentions, the conference of ten Midwestern States which opens today will disappoint the expectations of the Republicans in various parts of the country who have talked about "liberalizing" the party. Apparently, a straight stand against the New Deal, save for a necessary tenderness toward the AAA, is to be taken.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 9. -- Instead of making his patrolmen report their attendance at services at local churches each Sunday to their chief the following morning, Police Commissioner John J. Roegner decided today to put them on their honor.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 9. -- Coast Guardsman Henry Milliken of Base 9, located here, fatally wounded Herman Benson, chief of the Volunteer Fire Department of Woodbine in a reported attempt today by Benson to free three men who had been captured in a night raid on a still in the depths of Belleplain Woods.

The American people, says Secretary WALLACE in an article published today in Foreign Affairs, "are strong be-"lievers in the sacredness of exports "and the hellishness of imports." To this predilection, rather than to any tactics pursued by AAA, he ascribes the difficulties now confronting our chief export -- cotton.

Franklin D. Roosevelt has a vast reserve power and the world has not yet seen him at his real height, Dr. Charles Francis Potter said yesterday in his lecture at the First Humanist Society, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street. He predicted that a "social revolution is imminent."

Seniors at Manhattan College were advised yesterday to "teach Christ, preach Christ and be Christ" in a baccalaureate sermon delivered by the Very Rev. Edward A. Walsh, president of St. John's University of Brooklyn.

Except for spasmodic alternations of the franc's valuation, in response to rapid and bewildering changes in the French political picture, the course of last week's markets was uneventful. The week's recovery in stocks ("averages" declined 6 1/8 points in four days after the NRA decision, and in the next three business days regained 4 3/4) reflected accurately enough the shift of sentiment.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges pitched his eighth consecutive victory today as the Tigers turned on their season-long tormentors to beat the White Sox and Johnny Whitehead, 4 to 1.

BRIELLE, N.J., June 9. -- Francis H. Low, 23 years old, a Yale graduate, had on display here today what is believed to be the largest fish ever caught with rod and reel. It is a blue mako, or porbeagle, a species of shark, that weighed about 1,100 pounds.

The liberal education gives neither guarantee nor promise of success to its graduates, but makes of them "supernatural realists," the Rev. John S. Middleton, '20, told 350 graduates of Fordham College at 11 o'clock yesterday morning at the ninetieth baccalaureate service of Fordham University in the university church.

LONDON, June 7. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on June 5 at 68.1. This compares with 68.6 a fortnight before, 67.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- In an attempt to prevent what he called "the ruinous loss of our foreign markets for our farm exports," Representative Fish of New York said today that he would introduce in the House tomorrow a copy of the McNary-Haugen bill for the control and disposition of surplus agricultural commodities.

MOSCOW, June 9. -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Russian Communist party, received Dr. Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, in the Kremlin today and discussed threats to European peace and their joint efforts for security.

With the two games which were expected to have an important bearing on the rating of the teams called off due to bad weather last week, the conclusion of the college baseball season in New York City failed to produce a team with an outstanding claim to leading honors in the metropolitan intracity competition.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 9. -- Robert Fuller De Angelis, 20 years old, Westchester interscholastic hurdling champion last year, drove head-on into a tree on Murray Avenue in a dense fog early today and was killed.
Eagerness of one Eastern railroad to reduce its standard passenger rates calls attention to the present chaos in transportation costs.

ALBANY, June 9. -- New York State chartered 8,307 stock companies during the first five months of 1935, Secretary of State Flynn reported today. In May, 1,606 companies were formed, of which 877 had a capitalization of $14,968,734 with the remaining 729 authorized to issue stock of no par value.

The New Dance League held its third annual festival at the Park Theatre yesterday with two performances, the one in the afternoon being in the form of a competition by non-professional groups and the one in the evening a regular program by professional groups.

DETROIT, June 9. -- Rivalry for the post of president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, which will be settled here tomorrow by vote of the triennial convention, took an unexpected impetus over the week-end through the circulation of campaign literature.

Because the city sales tax has failed to produce enough revenue to enable the Board of Estimate to appropriate larger sums for relief, the Emergency Relief Bureau has been unable to increase generally the standards of relief as recommended by the Mayor's Committee on Unemployment Relief, Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and director of the ERB, was informed yesterday in a report by Theodore S. Farrelly, an assistant director.

Our car glides down the steep highway on Schooley Mountain, crosses the Musconetcong River Bridge and, a few moments later, rolls up to the trimly landscaped grounds of one of the largest fish factories in the world -- the A. Harry Moore hatchery operated by the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission.
We know that this country was in desperate plight when Mr. Roosevelt assumed office and that the plight was not of Mr. Roosevolt's making.
LONDON, June 9 (AP). -- Stanley Baldwin's wife, again hostess in No. 10 Downing Street, is as interested in public affairs as Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Treasury announced today its regular June financing program, an issue of 1 1/2 per cent Treasury notes of five years' maturity, in exchange for $416,602,800 of 3 per cent notes due June 15, and $353,865,000 of 1 5/8 per cent notes due Aug. 1.

A definite showdown between District Attorney Dodge and the March holdover grand jury over the question of a special prosecutor for the grand jury's vice and policy investigation is expected today when the grand jury reconvenes for its first meeting since Harold H. Corbin, appointed special prosecutor by Mr. Dodge, resigned because of protests by the grand jury, which had given the District Attorney a list of six other lawyers from which to choose.

MONTREAL, June 9 (Canadian Press). -- Offering has been announced for tomorrow by a syndicate of investment dealers and banks, headed by the Bank of Montreal, of the new bond issue of the city of Montreal for $12,943,000.

GENEVA, June 9. -- Professor Pitman Benjamin Potter, American member of the Italo-Ethiopian conciliation commission, returned here today from the meeting in Milan, expressing himself as "very well satisfied." He said the meeting had easily accomplished all he and Professor Albert de la Pradelle, the other delegate of Ethiopla, had hoped from it.
BUENOS AIRES, June 9. -- The Bolivian and Paraguayan Foreign Ministers have reached an agreement for a truce which it is hoped will bring about a definite termination of the Chaco War.

Patsy Grazzianni is the happiest man in the world. He hums Italian arias, preferably lullabies, as he pushes his frankfurter cafeteria through the streets, mumbling greetings to the passers-by and to the bootblacks who congregate about Washington Square Park.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 9. -- "Not religion as an inheritance from our fathers but religion as an individual value will enable us to meet the urgent problems of our time," said the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, in the baccalaureate sermon at Mount Holyoke College today.

PEIPING, June 9 (AP). -- Impending Chino-Japanese hostilities in North China appeared tonight to have been at least temporarily forestalled as a result of a conference between Japanese military officials and General Ho Ying-ching, Nanking War Minister.

BOSTON, June 9. -- In a sermon on "The Patriotism of a Mature Mind" at Boston University's baccalaureate services this afternoon in Symphony Hall, Dr. Daniel L. Marsh, president of the university, declared that "true patriotism does not consist in shouting and in flag-waving and loyalty oath-takings."

Featured by a steady demand for dresses in the various price ranges, buying of merchandise for immediate delivery was active in the women's apparel branch of the wholesale market here last week. Business was reported good in other branches of the market.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 9. -- Man is punished not for his sins but rather by his sins, according to a belief expressed in a baccalaureate sermon by the Rev. Dr. George Barton Cutten, president of Colgate University, to members of the graduating class today.

CANTON, N.Y., June 9. -- Dr. Richard Eddy Sykes, retiring president, preached the baccalaureate sermon at St. Lawrence University today and will award 130 degrees in courses at graduation exercises tomorrow.

A survey of the maritime policy of Great Britain from 1066 to 1766, tracing the development of its merchant fleet with the aid of navigation laws favorable to English ships, has been compiled by Henry C. Hunter, counsel for the National Council of American Shipbuilders, and Henry C. Wiltbank, a commentator on shipping and foreign trade.

PARIS, June 8. -- The position of the franc is exceptionally solid, since the gold reserve of the Bank of France would have to fall another 36,000,000,000 francs to reach the legal minimum cover of 35 per cent, supposing that liabilities remained at their present figure.

PARIS, June 8. -- The return of the Bank of France as of May 31 shows increases of 2,362,000,000 francs in bills discounted, 184,000,000 in loans against securities and 751,000,000 in loans against Treasury bills. Private banks have borrowed, thus, not only to meet withdrawals of customers' deposits, but probably also to come to the assistance of the Treasury by subscribing to government bonds.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- After throwing away repeated opportunities to score, the Senators today won a hard-fought game from the Athletics in the tenth inning, 5 to 4, and made it two victories in the three-game series.

A handful of muddy water thrown by 9-year-old Anthony Fontano on the Sunday-best dress of 6-year-old Josephine Cosentino started a quarrel that ended in the fatal shooting of both his parents in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

MONTREAL, June 9. -- Katharine F. Lenroot, in her presidential address to the National Conference of Social Work tonight, declared that "twentieth century social work will be only a stretcher bearer and minister of first aid if it does not interpret the frustration and the pain and help to justify the courage and the hope of the people."

Patrolman Harry Pray of the West Sixty-eighth Street station was taken to Roosevelt Hospital last night with bullet wounds in the left side and arm after he had been fired upon by a man standing near a parked automobile at Seventy-ninth Street and Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Complete solution of the Weyerhaeuser kidnapping case -- with the probability of new arrests -- was the goal tonight of determined Federal agents, combing the Northwest for William Mahan and possible confederates.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP). -- Sun Portland, Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Illinois Derby winner, and a contender for the $25,000 Detroit Derby to be run here next Saturday, defeated three other Derby hopefuls today in the $1,200 Derby Hope Handicap for 3-year-olds at a mile and one-sixteenth.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses and his staff have accomplished in two years an improvement in New York's parks which "none of us had expected in a generation," Electus D. Litchfield, president of the Municipal Art Society, declared yesterday at the opening of the Park Exhibition in the International Building at Rockefeller Center.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 10. -- Declaring that President Roosevelt is planning to move for an amendment of the Constitution for social and economic powers, Midwest Republicans in their "Grass Roots" conference today appealed to the country to uphold the fundamental law against "invasion of State's rights and individual liberty."

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10. The anticipated shake-up in Harvard's rowing squad was in evidence this noon when the crews at Red Top started away from the float for a paddle as far down stream as the submarine base, two miles distant.

GUAM, June 10 (By Wireless). -- This little garden spot in the Pacific, which for more than four centuries was cast in the role of a forgotten island, feels today that it is stepping into a place in world news.
The walls of Loew's New York Theatre, gathering place of the elite of the Gay Nineties, echoed yesterday morning the voices of actors who were leading stage personages at the turn of the century.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 11. -- An automobile driven by Richard Weatherby, a chain store clerk, of Liberty Avenue, Port Jefferson, ran over and killed his 2 1/2-year-old son, Richard Jr., late last night.

ATHENS, June 10. -- With about two-thirds the normal number of voters balloting in yesterday's election, the Tsaldaris-Kondylis adherents gained about 65 per cent of the votes cast, which were so adroitly distributed, however, that they won 287 seats of the Grand Parliament's 300, leaving the Metaxas Monarchists 7 and the Macedonian party 6.

The twenty-eighth annual Paris prize of the Society of Beaux Arts Architects, which has a cash value of $3,600 and which was competed for this year by 349 students in m twenty-one States, was awarded last night to P.M. Hefferman of Ames, Iowa, Harvard graduate student.

Former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade is entitled to a pension of $5,275.60 annually for life from the city, a Supreme Court jury decided after five minutes' deliberation yesterday at the close of a one-day trial before Justice Wasservogel.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 10 -- Mrs. Harold M. Lehman entertained more than forty New York women, all of whom have been active in the support of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, at a luncheon today at her home, 575 South Broadway.

MARIE CURIE is not only the first woman to have an avenue named for her on Manhattan Island but one of the very few persons, male or female, to be so honored. The cross-streets in the lower part of town carry many famous names. On the lower East Side the early Presidents are remembered in Jefferson, Madison, Monroe, Jackson Streets.

All classes of bonds except public utilities were higher yesterday on the Stock Exchange, under leadership of United States Government issues. Corporate bonds were traded actively. Transactions amounted to $9,247,400 compared with $8,390,700 on Last Friday.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 10. -- Harmon M. Waley, one of the alleged kidnappers of the Weyerhaeuser boy, plotted the abduction, local investigators believe, before he left this city on Jan. 16, after he and his wife had lived here on relief funds for three months.

Characterizing the suit as "poppycock," Corporation Counsel Paul Windels asked Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo yesterday to dismiss the legal action brought to remove Mayor La Guardia from office on the ground that he is holding two official posts in violation of the City Charter.

The mako caught on Saturday off Manasquan, N.J., by Francis H. Low of Woodmere, L.I., is the "heaviest unmutilated game fish ever taken on rod and reel by legal and accepted practices," Thomas Aitken, chairman of the record committee of the Salt Water Anglers of America, said yesterday.

The railroads serving New York will establish an optional loading service at their terminals here effective July 1, it was announced yesterday. A tariff published by the Trunk Line Association specifies that owners of freight will be permitted to perform loading service with their own employes or through any contract loading system they may desire, and that the railroads will perform it only when requested to do so.

Commissions in the Officers Reserve Corps of the United States Army will be presented to forty-five graduating students today at Class Day exercises of the New York University Colleges of Engineering and Arts and Pure Science in the Auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library, University Heights.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 10 (AP). -- Announcing the entries for the 1935 British open golf championship to be played at Muirfield starting June 24, the Royal and Ancient Association revealed today that Sid Brews of South Africa, last year's runner up, would not be permitted to challenge for the crown worn by Henry Cotton.

Back from his training camp in the Catskills, James J. Braddock made his first appearance in town yesterday since he began preparations for his heavyweight title bout with Max Baer in the Garden Bowl Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Battle lines for the final fight in the Senate on the Wheeler-Rayburn bill to eliminate "unnecessary" public utility holding companies were drawn today as an agreement was reached to vote at 2 P.M., tomorrow on amendments which would rigidly regulate instead of abolishing the companies, and to vote not later than two hours afterward on the bill itself.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 10. -- Out of his own early experience at the throttle, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, spoke today in defense of the cowcatcher on the railroad locomotive not only as a useful device for saving lives but also as justifying its name.
Several business properties, a church and various housing parcels were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Frank R. Hope, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, returned to his office yesterday after completing his annual 10,000-mile motor tour of the country renewing contacts with member firms. The two things that impressed him most, he said, were the indifference of members to the internal politics of the Exchange and their increasing opposition to New Deal policies.

Reiterating his conviction that no new constitutional amendment was necessary to keep the New Deal alive, General Hugh S. Johnson expressed confidence in an address here yesterday that the Supreme Court would return a favorable verdict in a test case based squarely on the underlying tenets of the NRA.
Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, said last night in a letter to Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, that there is justification for public utility holding companies.

PARIS, June 10. -- With Premier Pierre Laval's return to Paris tomorrow from his week-end at Auvergne, foreign affairs will again demand attention after more than two weeks devoted solely to the internal political crisis. As M. Laval is still Minister of Foreign Affairs he will pick up the threads where they were broken off, particularly concerning Ethiopia and Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Taking its first definite step to abolish interlocking directorates, the Federal Communications Commission, by a vote of 5 to 2, today denied the applications of ten of the most prominent figures in the industry to serve as an officer of more than one company or on more than one directorate.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on June 5 shows decreases for the week of $57,000,000 in total loans and investments and $73,000,000 in time deposits, and increases of $38,000,000 in net demand deposits and $70,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Dancing on the Mall in Central Park will be resumed for the Summer tonight, weather permitting, it was announced yesterday by the Park Department. The beginning of the department's outdoor dancing season will coincide with the opening of the Terrace Restaurant north of the Mall.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The administration's recommendation for regulation of the liquor traffic was submitted to the Ways and Means Committee today, but Chairman Doughton remarked that "it is so much bigger a problem than we had anticipated that we'll probably have to hold hearings."

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10. -- Cadet Joseph C. Stancook of the class of 1935, United States Military Academy, which graduates 276 new army officers on Wednesday, was the recipient of various awards at the annual athletic review this morning.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Unable to land at the municipal airport because of a fog which blanketed the airport and a radius of 150 miles around, a giant Douglas air liner of the Trans-Continental and Western Air, Inc., inbound on a non-stop flight from New York, made a forced landing tonight in a prairie near 130th Street and Cottage Grove Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Playing one of the best rounds of her career, Miss Edith Quier of Reading and Huntingdon Valley led the big field in the start of the women's Eastern championship golf tournament over her home course today with a card of 37 -- 38 -- 75, one under women's par.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company issued yesterday a statement taking exception to remarks of Senators Norris and Wheeler concerning the company which are contained in the Congressional Record. The remarks were made in support of the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utility Bill.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Less improvement in the prospects for the wheat crop was shown by the government report for May than had been expected by the trade. Recent private returns had suggested the possibility of a yield of 469,000,000 bushels, but this figure was 28,000,000 bushels in excess of the official returns issued late today, and in consequence was regarded by operators as a moderately bullish showing.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 10. -- More than 40,000 persons, including about 25,000 out-of-town visitors, lined the sidewalks along Valentine Lane and South Broadway this afternoon to view a parade of nearly 6,000 Knights Templar in colorful uniforms.

LONDON, June 10. -- An attempt to express the life of Christ in terms of the modern American gangster drama caused a religious uproar tonight in Birmingham, where John Furshard's play "Public Savior Number One" was produced in the Prince of Wales Theatre.

As chairman of the Civic Committee of the Parents Association of Public School 26 I have frequently come in contact with the Police Department in reference to the policing of the vicinity of our school and the neighboring section. I found the men very intelligent and always ready to listen to suggestions for improving police work.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 10. -- An enthusiastic Summer audience received Robert Raynolds's first play, "The Ugly Runts," in its world premiere at the Lydia Mendelssohn Theatre with enthusiasm here tonight.

Captain Jacob Martin reports that a six-and-one-half-pound sea bass, one of the largest of the current season, came in aboard the Sachem of Sheepshead Bay on Sunday afternoon after a trip to the Atlantic City grounds. The fish was caught by M. Friedman of Woodhaven and gave its captor the lead in the Sheepshead Bay tournament.

Charges made recently by the American Federation of Labor that steel companies in the Chicago district had lengthened their hourly schedules for employes, following the invalidation of the NRA by the United states Supreme Court, were denied yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The new hospital ship, built by St. John's Guild at a cost of $175,000 to carry mothers and children of the city on excursion trips through the harbor waters during the Summer, was dedicated yesterday afternoon at Pier A, the Battery.

OTTAWA, June 10. -- Purchase, storage and marketing of all Western Canadian wheat and other grains will become permanently and compulsorily a government operation if a bill introduced into Parliament today by Prime Minister Bennett becomes law.
HAMILTON, N.Y., June 10. -- Henry Ford received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the Colgate University commencement today.

Mrs. Molla Bjurstedt Mallory, former women's national tennis champion, was rescued from the East River last April 29 after she had plunged into the water to save her pet dog, Jerry, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mr. LOWDEN'S speech at the Republican convention at Springfield is a sound and dignified exposition of the rights of the citizen and the State under the Constitution. It is good that the fundamentals of American constitutional government should be taken up by a great party which has sometimes been a little careless about them.

Mayor LA GUARDIA'S initiative in calling a conference of the representatives of seaport cities to confer on foreign trade has apparently been welcomed by all of them. Friendly competition for imports and exports is well enough, but if they sink much further there will be little left to fight for.

Resolutions calling for renewed efforts to safeguard marriage were adopted yesterday by the Presbytery of New York, meeting in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Despite comparative inactivity, the markets were firm yesterday, with closing prices generally higher. What with the English and leading Continental European markets remaining closed for Whitsuntide observance; the Senate giving its attention to the resolution for continuing the NRA in abbreviated form and to the Utility Bill, and the silver bloc in Congress keeping out of the headlines, it was not surprising that the markets were disposed to drag along during most of the day.

MEXICO, D.F., June 10. -- Headed by Robert L. Hill, president of Rotary International, 300 Rotary governors and delegates forming the executive committee arrived today for a five-day meeting preceding the world convention. They came on two special trains from Chicago.

A YEAR ago Alfred A. Knopf published a remarkable novel called "The Death Ship," a sea story that came not from a Conradian aristocrat of the deep but from the depths of the forecastle. "The Death Ship" was shot through with the corrosive and bitter cynicism that is the surest sign of an underlying affection for a humanity which alternately betrays itself and permits itself to be betrayed.

A maxim that has been passed on from one generation to the next in America since the time of GEORGE WASHINGTON has been discredited if not disproved by a research conducted by a teacher in the university that very recently gave us a President of the United States -- Dr. H. DEWEY ANDERSON of Stanford University.
The Fordham School of Law will confer 318 degrees of Bachelor of Law at 4 P.M. today on the University campus in the twenty-eighth commencement exercise of the school.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 10 (AP). -- Faces flushed with anger, heated words and a court rebuke provided fireworks today at the Federal court trial of two attorneys accused of conspiracy in the $200,000 Charles F. Urschel kidnapping.

The work of tearing up the tracks of the old Madison Avenue trolley line, which was replaced recently by buses, already has begun. Labor from the Emergency Relief Bureau is being used, and the work is under the jurisdiction of the Borough President's office.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 10. -- Something of the strange political alliances that are taking shape in preparation for the 1936 Presidential campaign is revealed in the presence here of Milo Reno, erstwhile farm strike leader, as a sympathetic observer if not an active collaborator in the meeting of Republicans from the corn and wheat belt.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Justin Miller, special assistant to Attorney General Cummings, has been chosen to head the projected "Federal Bureau of Crime Prevention" in which local police officers, prosecutors and prison officials can be trained in scientific anti-crime methods.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10. -- United States Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois suggested tonight that the United States, by offering to act as an impartial, friendly arbiter, might aid in composing the differences of European nations and thus promote the cause of world peace.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 10. -- The anniversary exercises of the Yale Divinity School were celebrated this morning, followed by an alumni luncheon and a meeting of the Alumni Association, class reunions and a reception for the members of the senior class, who will receive their degrees at the university's commencement exercises, June 19.

The March grand jury which for nearly fourteen weeks has investigated rackets and vice conditions in New York County and has clashed with District Attorney William C. Dodge on its demand for a special prosecutor from the outside, was discharged yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- An application of the Consumers' Power Company of Jackson, Mich., for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of $18,594,000 in first lien and unifying mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series of 1935, due 1965, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Chrysler Corporation will pay on July 6, before maturity, $5,000,000 of the $25,000,000 loan obtained several months ago from banks in connection with the retirement on May 1 of the $30,150,500 of Dodge Brothers 6 per cent debentures.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The Senate received an amendment to the NRA resolution restricting the power of the President to suspend the anti-trust laws, passed a resolution extending the Emergency Transportation Act for one year, debated the Utility Holding Company Bill and recessed at 5:40 until 11:30 tomorrow.

In the spacious gymnasium of Evander Childs High School, the Bronx, the crack of ball against bat is heard these Summer afternoons as eleven blind students round out a program of athletic instruction that started "from scratch" three years ago.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10. -- Four major changes in collegiate education were described today by Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president, addressing the graduating class at Vassar College.

ALBANY, June 10. -- Wages and employment in New York State factories for the period from the middle of April to the middle of May declined in comparison with the preceding month, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today.

TIENTSIN, China, June 10. -- The new developments resulting from China's acquiescence in the Japanese demands regarding North China mean literally that the Chinese Government is relinquishing all power and authority in this vast area and retaining only the empty privilege of naming Chinese administrators who must be satisfactory to Japan to hold their positions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10. -- A warning that the American Medical Association, largest organized medical body in the world, will oppose the Federal administration if it attempts to incorporate any form of compulsory health insurance in its social security program was issued today at the opening session of the house of delegates of the association.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Money in circulation on May 31 amounted to $5,539,468,043, an increase of $61,507,270 over the previous month and of $182,095,995 over May, 1934, the Treasury reported today. The per capita circulation in May was $43.58 on the basis of a population of 127,096,000, compared with $42.40 a year ago, with a population estimated at 126,364,000.

DETROIT, June 10. -- Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson of Tulsa, Okla., whose ancestry is one-eighth American Indian, was elected president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs today in one of the most hotly contested campaigns on record.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Complying with the request of President Roosevelt, and over the objections of the carriers, the Senate passed today and sent to the House a joint resolution to extend for one year the Emergency Transportation Act which placed the railroads under a Federal Coordinator.
Business in money in the new week showed no change from the dull state which has prevailed for some time. Turnover was small and limited to renewals. Quotations were steady for all classifications.

The police continued dragging the East River in the vicinity of East Fifty-fourth Street yesterday for John Kaul, 5 years old, of 325 East Fifty-second Street, who disappeared from a Sutton Place playground on the river bank Thursday evening.

Benjamin N. Duke, tobacco man, was worth $7,496,447 net when he died on Jan. 8, 1929, it was revealed yesterday when the transfer tax appraisal was filed by Jacob Manicoff, supervisor of the Transfer Tax Bureau in the New York district.

The Maracaibo Oil Exploration Corporation notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that on June 17 it will surrender to the government of Venezuela, through its subsidiary, the Urdaneta Exploration Corporation, approximately 12,000 acres in the State of Zulia, District of Perija, reducing its acreage there, exclusive of royalty interests, to 25,000 acres.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 10. -- A plea that the distinction between knowledge and opinion be kept constantly in mind was made by Dr. Charles A. Beard, honorary chancellor of Union College, at its annual commencement exercises here today.

Showing the same blazing speed which has given him victory after victory, King Saxon yesterday won the Queens County Handicap through mud and from a formidable field as the Aqueduct Summer meeting got under way.

Eight factors determining employment in the teaching profession are discussed in a survey by Clyde R. Miller, Director of the Bureau of Educational Service, Teachers College, Columbia University, made public yesterday.

BOLTON LADING, Lake George, N.Y., June 10. -- The State Bankers Association ended its annual convention tonight with the installation of S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, as president of the association for the coming year.

CHESTER, Pa., June 10. -- A warning that there has been set up "a vicious circle of greater and ever greater armaments, which in the long run can only lead to impoverishment and economic suicide," was sounded today by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, in accepting the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at the commencement exercises of Pennsylvania Military College here.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The State Department is watching events in North China closely but is making no move for the present in the Chino-Japanese situation, nor is the Navy Department taking any steps.

Baroness Maud Levi took a stride ahead of the rest of the field in the defense of her New York State tennis title yesterday at the Jackson Heights Club as she advanced to the quarter-final round after two rapid matches.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Problems resulting from the invalidation of the NRA by the Supreme Court were the principal topics of discussion today by members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the first sessions of their four-day midyear meeting here.

Testimony in the trial of eight officers and directors of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, who are charged with violating the Federal Bankruptcy Law, will start today before Federal Judge Edwin S. Thomas in Brooklyn. The trial was begun yesterday, but the jury was not completed until late in the afternoon, when an adjournment was taken.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 10. -- Out of a "pea-soup" fog the United States Fleet steamed to anchorages in San Diego Harbor and Coronado Roads today, ending six weeks of manoeuvres which extended from the West Coast to Kure Island and from Hawaii to the Aleutians.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 10. -- Our time "is calling for qualities which only college men and women can supply," Dr. William E. Hocking, Professor of Philosophy at Harvard University said in an address today at the commencement exercises of Mount Holyoke College.

CARLISLE, Pa., June 10. -- With 30,000,000 radio receiving sets in existence in this country, "unconscionable demagogues and deluded theorists have a ready and effective means at hand of molding public opinion on a large scale," Josiah O. Wolcott, Chancellor of the State of Delaware, said today in the commencement address at Dickinson College.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 10 (AP). -- What is reputed to be one of the largest expense accounts ever submitted to the Federal District Court here is being reviewed by Judge John P. Nields in the bankruptcy case of National Department Stores, Inc., which is seeking reorganization.

BALTIMORE, June 10 (AP). -- Eleven midshipmen, members of the second class at the Naval Academy, were hurt in a street car-truck collision near here today. None of their injuries was believed to be serious.

Formation of a new trade practice organization, to be known as the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives, was announced yesterday following a meeting of representatives of trade groups in this field at the offices of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

The twelfth annual presentation of awards to the winners of the Music Education League's contests will take place tonight at the Town Hall. There will be 492 awards, the gift of Samuel Klein, merchant. It is estimated that about 15,000 children have shared in the earning of medals, silver cups, shields and certificates which go to the winners in solo and ensemble contests.

When the mist hung low over the market district at 6 A.M. yesterday Patrolmen Clarence Kittelson and Charles Goldinson of the Greenwich Street station, cruising in a radio car, came to an abrupt halt in front of the Corn Exchange Bank branch at West and Barclay Streets.

KINGSTON, R.I., June 10. -- Governor Theodore Francis Green of Rhode Island attacked Senator Huey Long for "injecting politics into education" in an address at commencement exercises of Rhode Island State College here today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 10. -- Following is the text of Frank O. Lowden's address at the Republican Midwest conference here today:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10. -- In order to broaden the use of certified milk, the pasteurization of part of the certified milk supply was suggested by Dr. Hugh L. Dwyer of Kansas City, president of the American Association of Medical Milk Commissions, in an address to the joint annual conference of that association, with the Certified Milk Producers Association of America, which opened here today at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 10. -- Eighteen indictments of the policies of the Roosevelt administration, the record of which was characterized as "subversive of our institutions and unsound economically," were adopted by the "Grass Roots" conference late tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP). -- Official records disclosed today that the government is potential owner of more than half of the supply of American cotton.

At home to the press yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Gotham, Leslie Howard announced that he would play Hamlet next season in New York under his own management. It will be his first appearance in a Shakespearean role.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Rallying in the late rounds after being outpointed earlier along the route, Tony Canzoneri, lightweight champion, won a twelve-round split decision victory over Frankie Klick of San Francisco in a Shrine-sponsored outdoor bout tonight.

Aug. 15 has now been set as the publication date of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "North to the Orient," a personal narrative of the Lindberghs' flight to the Orient in 1931. The book contains maps drawn by Colonel Lindbergh. Harcourt, Brace are the publishers.

Press censorship in Germany and in Italy is rapidly reducing itself to the absurd. It no longer deceives any one and in reality defeats its own ends. Instead of making people believe what the Government wishes them to, it makes them doubt everything that is printed that bears upon important internal policies and foreign relations.

The letter of Judge Crain concerning the granting of original jurisdiction to the Supreme Court naturally provokes attention. Undoubtedly, delays in a test of constitutionality are unfortunate. Too often the fait accompli plays an important part.

ATLANTA, June 10. -- Commissioner Linder in the Market Bulletin, official publication of his department, has attacked farm policies of the national administration. He was advised today by the Post office Department that he would have until June 20 to submit any statement he desired to make as to why the second-class privileges should not be revoked.

Manhattan College will confer 226 degrees in course and three honorary degrees this afternoon at the eighty-second annual commencement exercises on the campus quadrangle. Cardinal Hayes, a graduate of the class of '88, will preside at the exercises, which will start at 3 o'clock.

Diplomas will be presented to 101 graduates of the Savage School for Physical Education, 308 West Fifty-ninth Street, at the thirty-sixth annual commencement tomorrow night at Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Interest rates for public works loans under the $4,000,000,000 work relief program were raised from 3 to a maximum of 4 per cent by the government today, but the policy of making outright Federal grants covering 45 per cent of the cost of construction of public works projects was maintained.

MONTREAL, Que., June 10. -- "The recent Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case indicated important constitutional limits upon Federal action in the ordering of industrial life; it did not and could not wipe out all that we have gained," Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor in the United States administration, declared in an address to the National Conference of Social Workers tonight.

Arthur Krock makes a good point in his Washington letter when he says: "In the argument over the effects of the Supreme Court decision in the NRA case he sees hardly a reminder from any quarter that the demolished agency represented a sincere and mighty effort to improve the condition of affairs -- that many of its benefits will endure."

A loan of $2,240,000 reminiscent of the Civil War was awarded yesterday by the State of West Virginia to a Southern banking group composed of the Kanawha Valley Bank, the Charleston National Bank and Young, Moore Co.

Deputy collectors of the Bureau of Internal Revenue have been undertaking a nation-wide survey of the effect of the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the NRA on wages, hours and employment for the information of the Federal Government, it became known last night.

The Treasury's program of June financing, announced yesterday, will consist of an offer of $770,000,000 in five-year notes, paying interest at 1 1/2 per cent. None of this will be sold for cash. It is offered solely in exchange for two issues of notes maturing at an early date, both bearing a higher rate of interest.

An uptown apartment house resale and a theatre lease in Harlem were among the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. Seven properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- In a festival spirit joined in by many Washingtonians, thousands of Shriners took over the city today with such abandon that they ignored a strike of almost 4,000 taxicab drivers, who for twelve hours refused to transport passengers until the Public Utilities Commission permitted an increase in rates.

John C. Hammond and Dorothy Lee Hammond, his youthful bride of a year, were found, dead at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in their three-room penthouse apartment on the twelve-story office building at 49 West Forty-fifth Street.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 10 (AP). -- Senator Byrd declared this afternoon that if the Democratic party became the "instrument to attempt to destroy the rights of States by constitutional change, then our historic party will have betrayed every tradition of its past and violated the first principles of its existence."

CHICAGO, June 10. -- The program of Armour Co. of Delaware for refinancing $42,214,000 of 5 1/2 per cent bonds of 1943 moved a step closer to consummation today when holders of preferred stock at a special meeting approved amendments to the company's mortgage.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale lrce in New York:

CINCINNATI, June 10. -- Office and apartment renting conditions throughout the country present "the brightest picture in years, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was told at the opening session of its annual convention here today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 10. -- Between 500 and 600 marksmen of the New York National Guard and Naval Militia will take part in the week's shooting of the annual New York State matches now under way here at Camp Smith.

Yesterday was International Flower Shut-In Day. Through the generosity of the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association and the telegraph companies more than 20,000,000 blooms were given to about 1,000,000 shut-ins in the United States and Canada invalids, cripples, aged persons, hospital patients, young and old, who do not ordinarily receive flowers.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 10. -- The Federal Government worked swiftly tonight toward a clean-up of the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping case, but gave evidence it considers its round-up of the suspected gang far from complete.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- A limitation on the President's power to suspend the anti-trust laws for voluntary adherents to NRA principles was agreed to by administration leaders today in their effort to rush extension of a "skeletonized" Recovery Act through the Senate before the week-end.

PARIS, June 10 (AP). -- Jack Crawford's hard-fought five-set triumph over Christian Boussus today gave Australia a team victory over France and advanced the Antipodeans to the semi-final round of the European zone Davis Cup competition, with the German team as the next opponents.

BOLTON LANDING, Lake George, N.Y., June 10. -- A banking boycott of the Federal Reserve System to compel the Roosevelt administration to change its banking policies was urged here today by H. Parker Willis, former secretary of the Federal Reserve Board, who is credited with having played an important part in drawing up the original Federal Reserve Act.

While a crowd of 500 from the Columbia University section looked on, firemen succeeded yesterday morning in saving Claremont Inn from flames that for a time threatened to destroy the frame mansion that for more than a century has been a landmark on the knoll at Riverside Drive and 124th Street.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 11. -- With China's final acceptance of Japan's demands regarding North China announced by Major Takahashi, the Japanese military attache at Peiping, yesterday, the acute phase of the North China situation is closed.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 10. -- President Roosevelt today threw the weight of his personal influence behind a drive started by the Department of Justice to prevent abuses of the parole system.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The State Department is "delighted" with the turn developments have taken in the Chaco dispute, one spokesman said tonight in detailing some of the steps taken by our government in putting men on the scene for the talks looking to a peaceful settlement.

MOSCOW, June 10. -- A lengthy but vague communique was issued jointly by Dr. Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, and Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, this evening at the conclusion of the Foreign Minister's three-day conference here with M. Litvinoff, in which he also talked extensively with Joseph Stalin, Soviet dictator.

MADISON, N.J., June 10. -- Led by Elam M. Garton of Summit, 83 years old, the only surviving member of the class of 1872, more than 350 alumni of Drew University returned for Alumni Day exercises today. The program was opened with a meeting of the Alumni Council in Mead Hall, at which the Rev. Phillip S. Watters, president of the alumni, presided.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 10. -- The complete recovery of forty-four human patients from neuritis, a disease characterized by the painful inflammation of one or more nerve trunks, by the oral administration of the newly isolated crystals of Vitamin B-1, known as the "nerve vitamin," was reported here today at the scientific exhibit of the joint meeting of the American and Canadian Medical Associations.

New York City will open bids at 2 P.M. today on a new issue of $8,400,000 of special corporate stock notes dated June 14 and due on Nov. 14, with interest payable at maturity. Bidders are asked to stipulate the rate. The city will use the proceeds to take up a like amount of special corporate stock notes due on Friday.

FOOCHOW, China, Tuesday, June 11. -- The arrest of "ten young and vivacious girls," allegedly Communist spies under instructions to charm officials and assassinate them "when necessary," was announced by authorities last night.

Residents of Spuyten Duyvil in the West Bronx have launched a campaign to have the route of the Henry Hudson Parkway shifted from Spuyten Duyvil Parkway to the slope of the hill above the Tibbetts Brook Valley, it was announced yesterday by James D. Williams, a lawyer of 50 Broadway.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
