CHICAGO, June 10. -- President Roosevelt, in a message to the convention of the Advertising Federation of America here today, paid tribute to the "material" help accorded by that organization "in gaining ground for the recovery movements," and to its inspiration of "faith in the continued progress of the nation."

The French liner Normandie steamed 711 miles between noon Saturday and noon Sunday, a new rocerd for a single day's run on an eastbound Atlantic crossing, according to a message received yesterday from her master, Captain Rene Pugnet.

In a vacant lot beside the old Catskill Aqueduct at Morton Place and University Avenue, the Bronx, Joseph Curran, 12 years old, of 1,835 Harrison Avenue, was pounding away at rusty nails with a piece of iron pipe at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, fashioning a shack from waste wood.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10. -- Governor Hoffman and his foes in the Assembly reached another impasse tonight when the Governor withheld his signature to the 2 per cent sales tax bill for which he has been fighting since January.

MOSCOW, June 10. -- Love was ordained as the foundation of the Soviet social structure today by Pravda, the Communist party organ, and young Communists were warned they "must be capable of this noble feeling" under pain of public persecution.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, approved yesterday increases in the rates for workmen's compensation insurance averaging 6.8 per cent, effective July 1. He denied the request of insurance companies for a 16 per cent increase.

Trading was virtually at a standstill on the local commodity markets yesterday. Prices were mixed with few changes of importance recorded. On the cash markets, all the grains and silk advanced, and cotton, dairy products and quicksilver declined.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Under orders to kill at the slightest show of resistance, Department of Justice agents today maintained their search for William Mahan, former convict of many aliases, sought as one of the kidnappers of George Weyerhaeuser.

DOVER, England, June 10. -- Gerard B. Lambert's yacht Yankee, competing in her second formal race in British waters, finished behind W.L. Stephenson's Velsheda and C.R. Fairey's Shamrock V today as the Royal Cinque Ports Yacht Club's regatta opened. The race was for the King's Silver Challenge Cup.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 10 (AP). -- Silas H. Strawn of Chicago, former president of the American Bar Association, today denounced those who attack the capitalistic system while on the payroll of a university supported by "those whose industry and frugality have enabled them to make an endowment."

In accepting a plea of guilty to first-degree manslaughter yesterday from Joseph McCarthy, 35 years old, an ex-convict, General Sessions Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. criticized the State Parole Board for releasing McCarthy eight months ago from Sing Sing in advance of a minimum term he was to serve for a previous killing.

After hearing charges by two groups of meat and poultry dealers that violence and racketeering in the strike for lower retail meat prices was fomented by Communists, Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan informed the dealers he would call on Mayor La Guardia this morning to impress upon him the seriousness of the situation.

OF all the odd tales of pugilism, the story of James J. Braddock will match the best. Slow of foot and none too fast overhead, Journeyman James has been rambling the pugilistic roads for close to ten years and only recently did the long lane bring him to a happy turn.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The only real beneficiary thus far of the shadow-boxing which is or is not to be the preliminary of the great national debate on the Constitution is in Washington thought to be Senator Borah. The Democrats have quit talking about beating him for re-election in Idaho next year.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 10. -- Max Baer's entourage is firmly opposed to Arthur Donovan as a referee for the champion's fight with James J. Braddock. All from the titleholder down to the rubbing staff vote thumbs down on Donovan who is generally considered one of the most efficient arbiters on the list of the New York State Athletic Commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -- Frank Crowley, former Manhattan runner, and Joe Mangan, captain of the Cornell track team last year, have been added to the list of entrants in Princeton's second invitation track meet Saturday. Crowley will run in the two-mile event, facing Henry Nielsen of Denmark, among other stars, while Mangan will race in the feature mile against Bill Bonthron, Jack Lovelock, Glen Dawson, Glenn Cunningham and Gene Venzke.

BERLIN, June 10. -- Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler has been spending the Whitsun holiday in Bavaria, where incidentally he has conferred with Air Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, both of whom have been occupied with important political assignments abroad.

Real education is obtained not through "a vast store of information on many subjects," but through the mastering of a few, the Very Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, president of Fordham University, told the graduates of the Fordham School of Pharmacy last evening at the commencement exercises in the university gymnasium.

Reorders on Summer apparel continued to be received in good volume in the markets here yesterday, although turnover at the week was under expectations in a number of centres because of weather conditions. Sheer dresses in the lower end, particularly up to $7.95 retail, were in good demand in the new color combinations.

Following Saturday's advance of nearly $2 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost yesterday about half the gain and closed 9 to 14 points lower. With the Liverpool Exchange still closed and weather less unfavorable than recently, the market developed enough pressure to yield ground, but below 11 1/4 cents for October it appeared to meet resistance.

If August Vincent, who wrote in answer to President Butler of Columbia, will read the debates at the Royal Institute in London on Nov. 12, 1994, he will find that he is mistaken. He should read what General Smuts, Deputy Morgan Jones and David Lloyd George said about disarmament.

The United States must increase its imports if it is to increase its exports, Mayor La Guardia declared in an address of welcome yesterday before the first national conference of seaport cities on international trade, convening for three days at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A fiery verbal bout between Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, and Supreme Court Justice Carew yesterday in Justice Carew's court room closed with the accusation that the judge had damaged the commissioner's professional reputation and the retort that the commissioner's conduct had been "scandalous and outrageous."

BUENOS AIRES, June 10. -- Credit is given to Alexander W. Weddell, United States Ambassador to Argentina, for having saved the Chaco peace negotiations from collapse at a critical moment in the early hours yesterday morning.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., June 10. -- Forty-six students received diplomas from Dr. Charles H. Breed, the headmaster, at the commencement exercises of Blair Academy here this morning. Dr. Robert Clarkson Clothier, president of Rutgers University, addressed the graduates.

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, issued a warning at Aqueduct yesterday concerning the danger to local racing which lies in the move for pari-mutuel racing in the State of New Jersey. Mr. Swope announced that he had information the New Jersey pari-mutuel resolution would be passed this week, but reports from Trenton indicate that it will come up for a vote late this month.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 10. -- Denied permission to join the Albany Senators of the International League, Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts planned appeals to Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis in the hope that he will overrule the decision of the minor league's executive committee announced here today.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Despite the continuance of the meat boycott in New York and rumors that efforts were being made to extend it to other cities the market for hogs showed a firm undertone today, with the best showing 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher and other kinds about steady with prices on Friday.

Charles V. Bob, mining engineer and promoter, whose financial bubbles burst in 1930 with a loss to investors of $6,000,000, waited last night for a jury to find him innocent or guilty of an eleven-count indictment charging mail fraud and conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP). -- The Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, contending that Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr. had implied a "world war against Russia would be wise and advisable," has called on President Roosevelt to dismiss him.

GENEVA, June 10. -- The International Labor Organization conference postponed today's plenary session till tomorrow to give more time to persuading the employers' group to drop its boycott of the forty-hour week committee, no visible progress having been achieved today.

MOSCOW, June 10. -- The Communist party, possessing vast power with its control commission ramifying through every governmental department and economic enterprise, brought new pressure to bear today on the outstanding weakness of socialized production, at least in its present stage -- the generally inferior quality compared with the production of capitalist countries.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Winter wheat production for this year was estimated by the Department of Agriculture today at 441,494,000 bushels, compared with an estimate a month ago of 431,637,000 bushels, and an estimate of 435,499,000 bushels two months ago.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP). -- The Pirates let loose with a remarkable exhibition of home-run hitting today as they collected five circuit drives, three in succession in the eighth inning, to defeat the Reds, 14 to 1.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP). -- On the basis of outstanding performances during the season, 123 track and field stars from sixty-four institutions today were guaranteed transportation to the National Collegiate A. A. championship meet at Berkeley, Calif., June 21-22.

The John J. Kelly Mexican expedition, by means of which the Park Department hopes to fill some of those empty cages at the Central Park Zoo, gave a final hitch to its breeches at 4 P.M. yesterday afternoon and headed the nose of its 1930 coupe for the Rio Grande and Monterey.

Our Paris correspondent reports that the political crisis left in its wake considerable resentment on the Left side of Parliament against the great political power that they charged is exercised by the Bank of France. The dispute regarding the proper relationship of the bank to the French Government is one of long standing, and has been marked by several dramatic incidents.

MONTREAL, June 10. -- Charges that the American Medical Association and some of its State and local[ societies were attempting to thwartI the adoption of compulsory health insurance in the United States were made by Dr. John A. Kingsbury, former Commissioner of Charities in New York City and recently secretary of the Milbanks Memorial Fund. addressing members of the National Federation of Settlements in convention here.
Eighteen tanks of acetylene gas went up in flame at 10.40 A.M. yesterday in the Independent subway tube, forty feet under Rutgers Street, about fifty feet southeast of the East Broadway station.

If the police are right, John Gallo, 21 years old, of 86 Visitation Place, and Anthony Pardine, 37, of 291 Van Brunt Street, both of Brooklyn, are just children at heart; still as playful as they were in their kiddy-car days.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10. -- The agreement reached at Buenos Aires between Paraguay and Bolivia for the peaceful settlement of the Chaco War brought favorable comment in Chile. Editorials emphasize the significance of the new spirit that has prevailed, thanks to the energetic and persevering action of neighbor countries.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., June 10. -- Off to a whirlwind start, Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills and his 16-year-old amateur partner, Bob Zipse, finished at the top of the field of sixty-two teams in the Long Island Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament today.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., June 10. -- Norwich University conferred honorary degrees today at its annual commencement upon General Douglas MacArthur, chief of staff of the United States Army; Godfrey Lowell Cabot of Boston, manufacturer and writer; Dr. Allen Kramer Krause, president of the Desert Sanitarium in Tucson, Ariz., and Mauricio Nabuco of the Brazilian Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- On the eve of an important meeting of bituminous coal operators here tomorrow hope was expressed among operators favoring the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill that the measure, as amended, might be adopted in time to forestall a nation-wide coal strike on June 16 when the present wage contract expires.

Alexander Korda, production chief of London Films, announced yesterday, through United Artists, plans for a picture based on the life and exploits of the late Lawrence of Arabia. Permission to make the film has been received from the trustees of Colonel Lawrence's estate.
BALTIMORE, June 10. -- The commencement exercises of Johns Hopkins University will be held tomorrow, when Dr. Joseph S. Ames will preside for the last time as president.

Fearing that a family of five could not live adequately on her husband's small pay, Mrs. Margaret Corey, 29-year-old wife of a truck driver, killed herself and her three young children yesterday afternoon by flooding their four-room bungalow at 289 262d Street, in the Queens district of Floral Park, with illuminating gas.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10. -- The weather was the chief topic of conversation in the rowing colony on the Hudson today, because the weather was vitally important to the latest additions to the group. Washington and Pennsylvania, which arrived yesterday, were forced to pick their spots for workouts that were nothing like the ones their coaches would have liked to give them.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Representatives of the American Institute of Accountants will meet tomorrow with members of the Securities and Exchange Commission, including Chairman Kennedy, to discuss viewpoints on accounting principles which the commission has laid down in connection with forms for the registration of securities on the Stock Exchanges.

NYACK, N.Y., June 11. -- Mrs. A. Fischer Williams won the tricolor, the coveted award for the best exhibit in the show, at the opening today of the thirty-seventh annual flower show of the Nyack Garden Club. Several hundred people gathered at the Nyack Y.M.C.A. to witness the judging.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 11. -- Seven of the teams entered in the third Westbury Challenge Cup polo tournament, which will get under way at the Meadow Brook Club later this week, took part in practice matches on the J.S. Phipps estate today.

BERLIN, June 11. -- The concented campaign against "the speculative excesses" in the stock market produced a reaction in early trading today. Prices were marked down 1 to 3 points. Offerings, however, found ready purchasers and before the close a recovery set in, reducing the day's losses to 1 point and less.

That the late Lawrence of Arabia published a number of translations during the last few years -- though only one, a version of the Odyssey, was brought out in his name -- is reported by John Brophy, an intimate friend, in John O'London's Weekly.

A crowd of Negroes estimated by police to number more than 8,000 sought last night to get into the Berean Baptist Church, in Bergen Street near Rochester Avenue, Brooklyn for the funeral of Penney L. Craig, 39-year-old Negro singer.

Raymond G. Pollard, Assistant Commissioner of Public Works in Queens, must appear before Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore on Friday to show cause why he should not be committed to jail, Justice John L. Walsh ruled in an order signed yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 11. -- The text of the report of the resolutions committee to the Republican "Grass Roots" conference follows:

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The government will make available funds for a national theatre program, under which companies of unemployed actors and actresses will carry the drama to towns and cities all over the country, it was stated today at FERA headquarters.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP). -- Scoring seven runs in the first two innings, the Phillies today recorded a l0-to-4 triumph over the Cubs in the first contest of a six-game series.

GENEVA, June 11. -- The employers' bloc in the International Labor Organization conference, in a caucus today, heard the conference president, F.H.P. Creswell of South Africa, plead for them to drop their boycott against the forty-hour week committee.
Stockholders of the American Crystal Sugar Company, the former American Eeet Sugar Company, approved yesterday the plan of reorganization for the company at their annual meeting in Jersey City.
The American Museum of Natural History's rare albino frog had to yield the spotlight yesterday to the famous 726-carat diamond that Jacobus Jonker found on his South African claim in January, 1934.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11. -- The science of nutrition has paved the way for the medical profession to take the leadership in the utilization of new knowledge which now makes it possible for man to control his own destiny and evolve himself into a race of supermen.

OMAHA, June 11. -- Dr. Harold Stonier of New York, before the convention of the American Institute of Banking today, denounced Senator Long and Father Coughlin. Dr. Stonier is national education director of the A.I.B.
CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics captured both games of a double-header with the Indians today, winning the first, 4 to 2, and the second, 5 to 1.

A business argument between a delicatessen dealer and the baker from whom he had formerly ordered bread resulted yesterday in the fatal shooting of the baker in front of a vacant store at Morris Avenue and 144th Street, the Bronx, and the arrest of the delicatessen owner on a charge of homicide.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,643,300 barrels, compared with 2,575,900 in the preceding week, an increase of 67,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Four drivers were found guilty of operating automobiles while intoxicated, in Bronx Traffic Court yesterday by Magistrate William Farrell.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- Although the Supreme Court has cleared the atmosphere as far as NRA is concerned, the troubles of the newspapers are by no means at an end, according to Linwood I. Noyes, president of the Inland Daily Press Association, at its Spring convention.

Eight religious, charitable and civic institutions will receive eventually a large share in the estate of Alfred Erskine Marling, real estate authority, who died in his seventy-sixth year on May 29. His will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- A sluggish demand for fresh pork, which, according to some of the smaller packers, has existed more than a week, had a depressing effect on the market for hogs here today and prices were quoted at 5 to as much as 25 cents a hundredweight lower, with lard hogs showing the most loss.

MUSSOLINI continues to speak in scornful terms of the idea that any other nation has the right or duty to pass upon the dealings of Italy with Abyssinia. According to him, it is the sole concern of the Italian Government. No other country has any warrant for interfering in the matter.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday increased over those of the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The total, which was the highest since the week of May 8, was 618 as against 422 in the: previous week and 530 in the same period last year.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- Temple's baseball team downed the Princeton nine, 3 to 2, in a seven-inning twilight game on University Field today.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Notices of default on their war-debt payments due Saturday were given by Italy and Czechoslovakia today to Secretary Hull, an action expected, as are the defaults of nine other governments still to be heard from. Finland has paid in full, as in the past, and Great Britain has defaulted.

Robert L. O'Brien, chairman of the United States Tariff Commission, attacked the export bounty contemplated by the proposed amendment of the AAA, and P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine, declared that American trade should be handled under the American flag and no other, in addresses yesterday at the first national Conference of Seaport Cities on International Trade at the Waldorf-Astoria.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 11. -- Augustino Burns, a janitor, told the police today that a "rogues' gallery'' photograph of William Mahan looked like a man seen in the company of Harmon M. Waley while Waley and his wife were living here six months ago.

OTTAWA, June 11. -- Prime Minister Bennett was told by his former Minister of Trade, Harry Stevens, in Parliament today that the Premier's legislation for government control of Canadian trade and industry was inadequate.

A neat and labor-saving classification of Republicans has been getting itself established at Washington. It is also taken up, as if it were now a part of our political vocabulary, in dispatches from the Grass Rooters at Springfield, Ill. Party factions are spoken of as for or against Mr. HOOVER, and resolutions are either adopted or defeated to serve the purposes of Mr. HOOVER'S "foes."

WASHINGTON. June 11. -- Authority to issue $12,500,000 worth of refunding and improvement mortgage bonds. Series A. was asked of the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Toledo 8 Ohio Central Railroad, a subsidiary of the New York Central.

NEWARK, N.J., June ll. -- Newark inaugurated its night campaign under a new lighting system tonight by losing to Montreal, 7 to 6. Newark used five pitchers in a vain effort to stop the Royals, who completed five double plays, an unusual feat for night baseball.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., June ll. -- Diplomas were presented to forty-two officers and 143 enlisted men at 10 o'clock this morning at the fourteenth annual commencement exercises of the army signal school here. Major Gen. James B. Allison, chief army signal officer, who presented the diplomas, addressed the graduates.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 12. -- Formation of a new four-Province regime in North China, comprising Hopei, Shansi, Shantung and Chahar, is forecast by a Japanese press correspondent in Peiping. As such a new regime would be hostile to the Kuomintang (Nationalist party), looking instead toward Manchukuo and Japan, it is admitted that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's policy of unifying China would be destroyed as far as the north is concerned.
At the ninetieth commencement exercises of Fordham University this afternoon at 4 o'clock on the Fordham University campus 642 degrees in course and five honorary degrees will be conferred.

WASHINGTON, June ll. -- Resolutions demanding an investigation of the circumstances surrounding the writing of a newspaper article by Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., in which he is said to have suggested an international alliance against bolshevism, were submitted to the House and two of its committees today by Representatives Marcantonio of New York and Scott of California.
The New York Postoffice held yesterday its quarterly auction of unclaimed articles and found willing buyers for all but one of the 450 lots in the sale.

Trading in commodity futures yesterday gained momentum and price swings were wider with the resumption of activity, which coincided with the end of the Whitsuntide holidays abroad. Sugar, rubber and copper were the only staples to show marked strength, but few declines of importance were noted.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- Miss Edith Quier of Huntingdon Valley continued to lead at the end of the second round in the women's Eastern golf championship over her home course today, with an 81 which gave her a total of 156 for thirty-six holes.

The Music Education League's yearly competition for New York City school children has won the enthusiastic approbation of music lovers throughout the United States, Dr. Alexander Russell, former director of music at Princeton University, said last night at the twelfth annual presentation of awards by the league at Town Hall.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- Time trials by Jack Lovelock and Bill Bonthron today helped not a whit in revealing the likely winner of the great mile race that will feature Princeton's invitation meet at Palmer Stadium on Saturday. In fact they served to cloud the issue further.
LONDON, June 11. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody has not lost a match in her tennis comeback campaign, but she's in imminent danger of losing her old nickname, "Poker Face."

A news headline recently indicated that many slum residents prefer their present tenement houses. This is a startling, not to say shocking, concession. Yet in this admission we see the instinctive revolt of these poor inhabitants against the chimerical and deceptive promises made by Mayor La Guardia and Tenement House Commissioner Langdon Post.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- June, the month of roses, seems to have changed to the month of thorns for the United States and all that part of the world which owes us money. Within a few days after the ides of June, 1935, the future type of NRA must be settled and the threat of the bituminous coal strike must be met.

Endorsing a comprehensive program for the enforcement of fair trade practices in the industry, members of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, at a meeting last night at the Hotel Astor, authorized immediate action to "form bureaus and agencies necessary to insure complete observance of the established business standards."
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today additional applications for registration on form 1-M of brokers and dealers on over-the-counter markets.
The motion-picture rights to Albert Halper's novel "The Foundry" have been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Diplomatic recognition was accorded by the United States to Liberia today after a lapse of formal relations since 1930. It was given under conditions that mean the support of the United States for the government of President Edward Barclay in efforts to rehabilitate the country through correcting forced labor conditions that amount to virtual slavery, improving sanitation and strengthening the financial position of the government.

Sixty-eight reptiles, including three black spitting cobras, a rare and deadly species, and four so-called "flying" snakes arrived yesterday from Johore, Malay Peninsula, on the Blue Funnel freighter Glacus, for the Staten Island Zoological Society.
Peerless Laboratories, Inc., X-ray and electrotherpeutic, in 115 E. 23d St.; Leon Small Davldson, Inc., furs. in 127 W. 30th St.; Gross Siamon, furs, in 134 W. 29th St.; M. L. Hes, brokers.

An exhibition composed of prints in various mediums by members of the California Society of Etchers opened yesterday at the Grand Central Galleries, to be on until June 29. Forty-one artists are represented. The present showing contains prints that were exhibited in the society's twenty-first annual, in 1934, together with some work produced very recently.

The course of motor-car production, thus far in 1935, has provided so marked a contrast to that of other industries as to make the drawing of inferences perplexing. The Census Bureau's recent figures of American production in April show that, for the first time, the highest monthly output since 1929 was passed.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Moving to stamp out liquor running and other smuggling, the House voted today to give President Roosevelt authority to extend jurisdictional waters on coasts where smuggling is known to exist. The proposal now goes to the Senate.

TOKYO, June 11. -- In disclosing the clash on June 6 between Russian and Japanese troops along the Eastern Manchurian border, the Foreign Office intimated today that the affair was unimportant and would be settled locally.
BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, June 12. -- The signing of the Chaco truce was delayed last night by a Paraguayan objection to uncertainty as to when the truce should take effect.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11. -- John F. Dinan, Mayor of the Borough of Edgewater, N.J., was named in two indictments charging violation of the Internal Revenue Act, returned late this afternoon by the Federal grand jury to Judge Guy L. Fake, sitting in Federal court here.

TIENTSIN, China, Wednesday, June 12 (AP). -- A Japanese official frankly told The Associated Press today that Japan was prepared to cooperate in any spontaneous movement among the Chinese of North China toward friendly relations with Japan, even though it might lead to severance of the region from the central government at Nanking.

Between the more partisan critics and advocates of the Wheeler-Rayburn Holding Company Bill, adopted by the Senate yesterday, there is a great gulf fixed. From the utility magnates assembled in convention at Atlantic City last week came the thundering charge that the Federal Trade Commission's findings, on which the bill rests, are replete with "fraud, deceit, misrepre"sentation, dishonesty and downright "maliciousness."
Bill Terry's league-leading Giants yesterday lost both ends of a double-header to the sixth-place Cincinnati Reds at the Polo Grounds.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11. -- Good weather, the arrival of Cornell's varsity and junior varsity and intensive workouts for next week's intercollegiate regatta marked the most active day the broad Hudson race course has seen since Columbia led the way up here on the first of the month.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- A denial of a suggestion that the recent break in the silver market was caused by government operations, and factual assurances that the administration was following out the letter and spirit of the Silver Purchase Act of 1934, were sent by Secretary Morgenthau to Senator McCarran today in answer to the latter's recent query about the Treasury's dealing in the metal.

Max Denberg, an 18-year-old shipping clerk for an underwear concern, was forced into a taxicab at Broadway and Thirty-eighth Street at 2:40 P.M. yesterday by two men, robbed of $2,880.11 and several checks belonging to his employers, and left bound in an East Side cellar, according to the story he told the police an hour later.

Many Wall Street traders and investors, who have been awaiting the usual "secondary reaction" following the initial decline on the NRA news of two weeks ago, are becoming impatient. Instead of turning downward and providing canny investors with opportunities to make purchases several points lower than they were, most issues have been pushing ahead steadily.

TRENTON, June 11. -- Governor Hoffman signed today the bill passed by the Legislature for a 2 per cent retail sales tax to finance emergency relief. The Senate and Assembly are in recess until June 24, however, and in the one week remaining from that date to July 1, when the law goes into effect, amendments will have to be adopted to make it workable.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 11. -- Avoiding direct criticism of the administration's farm policy, the conference of Midwestern Republicans in final session today adopted a declaration of principles, including planks for a return of the gold standard, a modified McNary-Haugen Farm Bill and recognition of the principle of collective bargaining between labor and industry.

With its brisk advance yesterday on sustained investment buying and scattered speculative purchases prompted by various unrelated factors, the share market not only regained all the ground lost since the United States Supreme Court upset the NRA on May 27 but surpassed marks of long standing.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which is accused by the government of having a strangle-hold on the nation's music business, went on trial in Federal court yesterday for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

BERLIN, June 11. -- Thirty-eight persons, among them a number who played more or less important roles in the defunct German Republic, were deprived of German citizenship and their properties were confiscated today by order of Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior.

ST. LOUIS, June ll. -- Showing very little fear and practically no regard whatsoever for the condition of Rogers Hornsby's sadly depleted Browns, the Yanks grabbed off both ends of a double-header today to get an impressive start on their second swing of the campaign around the Western loop.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn began hearings yesterday in the appeal by teamsters' and longshoremen's unions and steamship companies from the injunction signed several months ago by Supreme Court Justice Burr J. Humphrey in Brooklyn which restrained them from interfering with the shipping of merchandise through non-union channels.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad (Nickel Plate) reported yesterday a profit and loss surplus of $19,824,603 on March 31, against $20,910,325 a year previously. Total assets were $288,907,991, against $285,491,798.

New York City yesterday awarded an issue of $8,400,000 of five months' special corporate stock notes to a banking group consisting of the Chase National Bank, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Salomon Bros. Hutzler and R.W. Pressprich Co., which offered a premium of $177 for the notes, carrying interest at 1.20 per cent.
The strains of the Harlemesque "Hot Coffee," echoed out over the meadows of Central Park at 8:30 last night, and the annual season of dancing on the Mall was officially opened.

PARIS, June 11. -- The Bourse had a disappointing session today, it having been expected that the market would react favorably to political peace. Rentes moved lower and French common stocks de clined moderately, while internationals were stronger.

GRANDMA, what great big threats he has, that Big Bad Baer! At the last moment he wouldn't fight if he didn't like the referee. That would be simply 'orrible. The spectators would have to line up and receive their ticket money back again and Madcap Max would have the pleasure of getting nothing at all instead of $100,000 or more, as the case may be. What fun that would be for him.

As a part of the Sanitation Department's effort to enlist the public in its campaign to keep the city clean, a truck with signs urging citizens not to throw papers and litter into the streets but to use the litter cans and baskets provided for the purpose, is touring the city.

A thorough search of the East River bottom at the foot of Fifty-fifth Street by two divers yesterday failed to disclose the body of John Kaul Jr., 5 1/2 years old, who mysteriously disappeared from that vicinity last Thursday night.

Judge John J. Freschi was listening to a long argument yesterday by one of the opposing lawyers in the General Sessions trial of John A. Dilliard, former president of the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company, on a felony indictment, when he complained that too much detail was being used in the arguments.

The directors of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild voted at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to work for the quick passage of the bill introduced in Congress by Representative Emanuel Celler of New York to prohibit the importation of liquor by individuals under their $100 personal exemption privilege.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Well-laid administration plans to complete Congressional action today on the resolution extending a "skeletonized" National Industrial Recovery Act until April 1, 1936, failed today when the Senate quit its leadership and sought to increase its own power over executive appointments.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 11 (Canadian Press). -- Edgar N. Rhodes, Finance Minister, today placed on the House of Commons order paper a resolution asking authority for the government to borrow up to $750,000,000 "for paying or redeeming the whole or any portion of loans or obligations of Canada and for purchasing and withdrawing from circulation unmatured securities of Canada."

YONKERS, N.Y., June 11. -- Everett R. Tomlinson, a banker of Batavia, N.Y., was elected today Grand Commander of the Knights Templar of New York State at the conclusion of the three-day conclave of the order here.

While high-grade bond issues held firm but dull, speculative rail bonds advanced sharply in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Total dealings were larger than on any other day in about three weeks, but the turnover in domestic corporation issues alone was the heaviest since July 26, 1934.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Accusing the Empire District Electric Power Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company (the Doherty System), of "squatting" on a waterpower site at Table Rock, on the White River in Missouri, without showing good faith or intention to proceed with a proposed $30,000,000 development, the Federal Power Commission denied today the company's petition for a two-year extension of the time in which to begin construction.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., June 11. -- War on the "rubber tire rustler," the modern cattle and horse thief, has been declared by ranchers of five Western States.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- After announcing that charges of violating the Lindbergh kidnapping act were to be filed against the kidnappers of George Weyerhaeuser, J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, late today branded as false published reports that additional arrests had been made including that of William Mahan, fugitive accomplice of Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Waley, who have confessed the crime.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The danger that democracy may disappear unless it advertises its virtues, the newspapers' influence in preserving that form of government, and the widening field for advertising due to government activities were dwelt upon today in addresses before the convention of the Advertising Federation of America.

Ancil Hoffman, manager of Max Baer, appeared before the State Athletic Commission yesterday to protest against the appointment of Arthur Donovan as referee when the champion defends his heavyweight title against James J. Braddock in their scheduled fifteen-round fight at the Madison Square Garden Bowl tomorrow night.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will confer 4,104 degrees and certificates upon one of the largest graduating classes in the history of New York University this morning at 11 o'clock on Ohio Field, University Heights, at the institution's 103d commencement.

The semi-final matches in the intercollegiate polo championship scheduled for this afternoon at Governors Island will pit Harvard, last year's winner, against Pennsylvania Military College at 3 o'clock and Army against Yale at 5. The victors in today's contests will meet in the final on Saturday.

The following official summary of stock transactions and holdings of officers, directors and principal stockholders of listed corporations was released yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission:

TACOMA, Wash., June 11. -- Alleging that in abducting George Weyerhaeuser they transported him across the Washington State line to Blanchard, Idaho, and Spirit Lake, Idaho, the Federal Government today filed Lindbergh Law kidnapping charges here against Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Metz Waley, held in Salt Lake City, and W.S. Grant, alias William Mahan, sought in Montana.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Assertions that continued failure of the government to enforce rights of labor along lines proposed in the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Bill would create "a menace to industrial peace that cannot be exaggerated" were made today by the House Labor Committee in a report bringing the measure to the floor.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 11. -- Opening exercises of the Graduate School of Banking, organized by the American Institute of Banking Section of the American Bankers Association in cooperation with Rutgers University, will be held here on next Monday night with Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company, New York, presiding.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 11. -- Conceding that the administration "has suffered a temporary setback" in the fight for national recovery, Postmaster General Farley predicted here today that nevertheless President Roosevelt would "find his way out of the present shoals into the channel of content and bring the ship safely into the port of prosperity."

ROSLYN, L.I., June 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. James F. Curtis opened the famous gardens of Willowmere, their estate on Hempstead Harbor in this village, this afternoon for the benefit of the Roslyn District Nursing Association. More than 500 cars brought visitors to the estate.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted registration of $1,130,820 of common stock of the Monsanto Chemical Company on the New York Stock Exchange, as requested on Form 7, effective upon notice of issuance of the stock.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 11. -- A feature of the flower show of the Larchmont Garden Club held today at the Larchmont Avenue Church house was a class for men. Stephen McClellan, C.L. Norris and J.L. Horsfall were the winners.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11. -- Cadets of the 1935 class of the Military Academy fell in for their last dress parade this evening as 5,000 spectators thronged the walks and filled the stands and benches bordering the historic plains.

Monday's Government report on grain crop prospects indicates that last season's shortage in American production, to which official inducements to cut acreage and a subsequent disastrous growing season both contributed, will this year be measurably made good. It will be remembered that the country harvested last year the smallest crop of wheat since 1893, of corn since 1894 and of oats since 1882, with similarly disastrous results in other cereals.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The St. Germans colt Cheshire, from the Greentree Stable of Mrs. Payne Whitney, scored in a mild surprise at Aqueduct yesterday when he was the easiest sort of a five-length winner at the end of the featured Fire Island Purse. The main contention in the race was supposed to come from George H. (Pete) Bostwick's Ariel Cross, which closed joint choice at 11 to 5 with the victor.

CINCINNATI, June 11. -- A plea to property owners to "uphold their rights of ownership against radicalism and various subversive factors which are seeking to undermine the foundations of American institutions" was made here today by Walter S. Schmidt of this city, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

A jury that deliberated thirty-one hours without arriving at a verdict on the innocence or guilt of Charles V. Bob, mining engineer and promoter accused of mail fraud and conspiracy, was discharged at 10:30 o'clock last night by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

Praising American beer and brewing methods, 109 German brewers returned to New York after a ten-day inspection tour to the Middle West, and were entertained last night by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce at a dinner-reception at the Hotel Astor.

At the annual meeting of the Life Underwriters Association of New York in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday, the following officers were elected for the ensuing year after reports had been received from the retiring president and secretary-treasurer:
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 11. -- We left San Diego last Dec. 19, and caught a storm on Jan. 30 thirty miles off the Mexican Coast. We rode heavy seas and fought high winds for 192 hours.
Present-day social trends were assailed yesterday afternoon by Professor Arthur A. McGivney of the Fordham Law School at the school's commencement exercises.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- Ronald Woodward of Indianapolis, 'coxswain of the Pennsylvania rowing squad for four years, was today awarded his varsity letter along with elevan Bed al{d Blue oarsmen, although he never had steered a first crew in a race.

An elaborate memorandum setting forth the Park Department's reasons for seeking a revision of the West Side improvement in so-called Riverside and Fort Washington Parks was made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Is Peconic Bay being overfished? That question is heard frequently at gatherings of salt water anglers of the metropolitan district this season. For, despite reports of a substantial increase in the number of big weakfish taken during the past week, there is general agreement that the early run of large fish is not measuring up to the standards of other years.

BALTIMORE, June ll. -- Retiring after fifty-one years as a member of Johns Hopkins University, Dr. Joseph Sweetman Ames, for six years president of the institution, appealed in an address at the commencement exercises today for the preservation of freedom of thought, which, he said, is faced with a menace "real and pressing."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11. -- Dr. George W. Grier of Pittsburgh was elected president of the American Radium Society at the close tonight of its two-day convention in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel here. Dr. Zoe A. Johnston, also of Pittsburgh, was chosen president-elect.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., June 11. -- The Bordentown Military Institute held its fiftieth annual graduation exercises today. The morning was devoted to the yearly review, military exhibition and competition drills. Brig. Gen. Frederick Bradman, United States Marine Corps, and a graduate of B.M.I. in 1898, reviewed the cadets and presented the military awards.

Foreclosure sales kept auctioneers busy yesterday when twelve auctions were held in Manhattan and thirteen in the Bronx. Although dwellings and small tenement buildings comprised most of the improvements, the list included a twelve-story structure at Wall and Water Streets, two large apartments on the upper West Side and the Hotel St. Regis at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated in a 15-point range yesterday to end 5 points higher to 3 lower than on Monday.

A preview of French Fall styles and beach novelties was shown last night in the Gardens of the Nations, Rockefeller Center, by the International Silk Guild. The collection included sportswear, negligees, day dresses and suits as well as dinner gowns.

The Southern California Edison Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission's office in San Francisco a registration statement covering the proposed issuance of $35,000,000 of additional 3 3/4 per cent refunding mortgage bonds.
Guy Bush, knocked out but undefeated in his last start against the Dodgers, took complete control of the situation at Ebbets Field yesterday in the opening game of the Western invasion.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., June 11. -- Establishing a new course record for women, Mrs. M.E. Risley of Echo Lake today won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament, scoring an 83 over the difficult Mountain Ridge Country Club course.

Shares of H.R. Mallinson Co., Inc., broke sharply yesterday upon announcement by the New York Stock Exchange that the company had decided not to apply for permanent registration on the Exchange under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The common closed at 5/8, off 1/4, while the preferred was quoted at 6, off 3.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 11. -- A short-wave radio experiment, characterized as one of the most elaborate studies in wireless communications yet to be attempted, it was revealed today, forms one of the important objectives of the National Geographic-Army Air Corps stratosphere flight to be made from a canyon in the Black Hills as soon as weather permits.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- A statement that it "cannot be correctly, assumed that a sort of sanctity attaches to a constitution of government because of it having come from the hands of wise men whose memory is cherished" was made tonight by R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, in an address made as he received the degree of Doctor of Laws from National University.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Speeding to meet a June 16 deadline, Congress adopted today and sent to the White House a joint resolution giving to officers of Federal Reserve member banks another three years from that date in which to repay outstanding personal loans from their own institutions.

RENO, Nev., June 11. -- Pearl S. Buck, the novelist, whose book, "The Good Earth," won the Pulitzer Prize, divorced her Presbyterian missionary husband, John Lossing Buck, this afternoon and soon afterward married her publisher, Richard J. Walsh, of New York, former husband of her close friend, Mrs. Ruth Abbott Walsh.

Miss Elizabeth Blackman, unseeded player from Detroit, provided the fireworks in the second day of the women's New York State clay-court championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday by upsetting Mrs. Henry C. Brunie, sixth seeded star, in three sets, 7 -- 5, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

Plans to enlist the cotton garment industry under a voluntary code of fair competition will be undertaken at an industry-wide convention to be held at the Hotel New Yorker on June 25 and 26, it was disclosed here yesterday when invitations were sent to 3,800 manufacturers in forty-two States.
LORAIN, Ohio, June 11 (AP). -- Frank Malloy, managing editor of The Lorain Journal, said that four members of the paper's staff were discharged today.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The government's estimate of a Winter wheat crop of only 441,000,000 bushels, or 28,000,000 below the average of recent private returns, failed today to have any material effect on the market, and prices on the Board of Trade dropped quickly after having a fractional upturn at the opening of trading.

BERLIN, June 11. -- The entire German navy, from super-modern armored cruisers to tiny and still somewhat mysterious auxiliary vessels, assembled at Kiel today for a festive "Naval Folk Week" designed to revive popular enthusiasm for the "war marine" and therewith lay a basis for the expansion now being negotiated at the Anglo-German naval conference in London.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Senate by a vote of 56 to 32 today passed the bitterly contested bill described by President Roosevelt as "legislation to provide for elimination of unnecessary holding companies in the public utility field," and by its opponents as meaning death or dismemberment of the great majority of such companies.

The first graduating class of the four-year, full-time high school department of the New York School of Printing will be graduated at exercises in the auditorium of THE NEW YORK TIMES this evening. Ten young men will receive diplomas, four of whom graduated from the two-year printing courses of the industrial high schools and then took two post-graduate years at the New York School of Printing.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- About $2,000,000,000 of the $4,000,000,000 work relief appropriation will be spent directly by the government instead of by the cities and other local units, relief officials said today.

ATLANTIC City, N.J., June 11. -- Photographs taken in pitch darkness by "black light," which reveal the existence of conditions of heart disease before they can be detected by other means, at a time when measures can be taken to forestall the oncoming of a possibly fatal heart attack, are on display at the scientific exhibit of the joint meeting of the American and Canadian Medical Associations.

LONDON, June 11. -- The Stock Exchange reopened firm and active after the holiday, with the exception of British funds which were overshadowed by the pending new trustee issues. The foreign section of the market was steady. French bonds improved on the currency situation.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- A plea that merchants refrain from price wars was made today at the midyear meeting of the National Retail Dry Goods Association by D.M. Nelson, vice president of Sears, Roebuck Co.
A syndicate formed by Henry Mandel has bought two properties on the East Side, it became known yesterday. They consist of a club building in the midtown area and a dwelling on the upper East Side.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 11. -- With six weeks of strenuous manoeuvres behind them, some 50,000 officers and men of the United States fleet, "home from the sea," were busy forgetting the "rigors of war" today in the pleasures of peace.

The first voluntary liquidation of an NRA Code Authority by filing an assignment for the benefit of creditors was begun here yesterday by the Code Authority of the Cap and Cloth Hat Industry, 1,170 Broadway.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 11. -- With the tasks set for himself during his visit here completed, President Roosevelt prepared tonight to resume his public functions tomorrow by going to West Point to present diplomas to the graduating class and then proceed to Washington.

" The United States Constitution has proved itself the most marvelously elastic compilation of rules of government ever written." The above quotation is from a radio address by a New York Governor, now President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and is printed in the Governor's official papers.

VIENNA, June 11. -- The recent bellicose utterances of Premier Mussolini of Italy, taken in conjunction with the manoeuvres of General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Air Minister, in the Balkans, have aroused a certain uneasiness in Austria and some other quarters, and not without reason.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York declared its opposition yesterday to the proposal to transfer the activities of the army engineers with respect to river and harbor work from the War Department's Engineers Corps to another Federal department under civilian supervision.

The Consolidated Gas system has invested $29,300,000 in cash in the Westchester Lighting Company since 1925 and has received more than $27,000,000 in dividends from the subsidiary over the same period, according to testimony yesterday before the legislative committee investigating public utilities.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 11. -- Yale today defeated a picked nine, which included in its line-up Earl Neal and Bruce Caldwell, former major leaguers; Ducky Pond, football coach; Albie Booth, Billy Neale and Malcolm Farmer, former Eli players, and three sons of Joe Wood, Yale baseball coach.
Money market was sluggish, business in all departments being limited to routine requirements. Quotations remained unchanged.

Aldermanic President Deutsch accused Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, yesterday of evading the real issue in the ouster of six medical students from Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons.
The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, placing it on a $1 annual basis, compared with 80 cents previously.

The combination of true Catholicism and true Americanism, as the best possible solution for current economic and political problems, was urged by Cardinal Hayes yesterday before an audience of 3,500 at the eighty-second annual commencement exercises of Manhattan College on the campus.

The police and relatives of Mrs. John C. Hammond scoffed yesterday at a story that she and her husband had been murdered by gangsters seeking papers alleged to have been entrusted to him by Al Capone.
Brokers added many names to the tenant rosters of apartment houses in this city yesterday. The renting was brisk on the East Side, with several new leases also signed for rooms on the West Side.
The visitor from Mars who drops in this week on Washington, D.C., will rub his eyes and wonder if the city hasn't gone much further back than the horse-and-buggy age.

MEXICO, D.F., June 11. -- Quoting Governor Refugio Bustamante of Morelos, the newspaper Excelsior this morning charged widespread mismanagement of finances by Mexican State governments, to the detriment of succeeding administrations.

Noel C. Scaffa, private detective, and four other men who were indicted with him last week for conspiracy to violate the Federal Stolen-Property Law, pleaded not guilty when they were arraigned yesterday before Judge William Bondy.

One year ago today President ROOSEVELT signed the Reciprocal Tariff Act, describing it as a hopeful means of checking "the Unprecedented shrinkage of world trade" and of recapturing foreign markets for our products. At the end of a year the experiment with reciprocity is still an experiment.

A few weeks ago an editorial comment in your paper concerning the condition of Nathaniel Hawthorne's grave in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery raised the question whether the plot was unkempt because the public no longer visited it.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox turned in some snappy fielding and timely hitting behind Robert (Lefty) Grove and Wesley Ferrell today to take both ends of a double-header from the Tigers, 3 to 1 and 5 to 2.

BERLIN, June 11 (AP). -- Richard Strauss, Germany's most distinguished composer of opera and lieder, today appeared likely to be ousted soon as president of the Third Reich's Musical Chamber. He was appointed to the office by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, on Nov. 15, 1933.

HAVANA, Cuba, June 11. -- The official state of war existing in all Cuba since March 11 last, ceased today with the formal restoration of the original Constitution of 1901, modified so as to provide for holding general elections at the end of this year.

RYE, N.Y., June 11. -- The Bonnardel Cup, emblematic of the world's professional team tennis championship, passed into the keeping of France for a year today as the representatives of the Tri-color won the final two contests of the series with the United States at the Westchester Country Club.

MADISON, N.J., June 11. -- Sixty-eight degrees were awarded at the sixty-eighth annual commencement exercises at Drew University on the Mead Hall campus here this morning. Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, gave the commencement, address.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 11. -- Champion Max Baer firmly reiterated his intention of not fighting if Arthur Donovan is assigned by the New York State Athletic Commission to referee his bout with James J. Braddock.

MOSCOW, June ll. -- The perilous but strategic geographical position occupied by Czechoslovakia played an important part in the conversations here of Dr. Eduard Benes, her Foreign Minister, with Joseph Stalin, Soviet dictator; Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff and Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff, it can be stated today.

TRENTON, N.J., June 11. -- Delivery today of $2,500,000 Port of New York Authority bonds for the State of New Jersey marked the conclusion of negotiations begun by Governor Hoffman before taking office. The bonds represent a compromise settlement of New Jersey's loan for erection of the George Washington Bridge.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP). -- Secretary Morgenthau locked up in his office tonight the first reports of a survey designed to determine the business effects of the Supreme Court's invalidation of NRA.

Another step in the ten-year effort of the American Council of Learned Societies to compile a definitive Dictionary of American Biography is taken with the publication this morning of the sixteenth volume of the work. The remaining four volumes are scheduled for publication by Autumn of next year.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP). -- The White Sox divided a double-header with Washington before 10,000 fans today, winning the second game, 9 to 3, after losing the free-hitting opener, 9 to 8.

Fourteen residents of Knickerbocker Village, the model apartment house block at Market and Monroe Streets on the lower East Side, have received letters from the Fred F. French Management Company, an affiliate of the company which erected the apartments, saying their leases would not be renewed on Oct. 1.

The final step in Vincent Astor's long legal struggle to gain full control of the Hotel St. Regis at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street was taken yesterday when he bought in the property at a foreclosure auction sale on a bid of $5,099,000. The bid was made for Mr. Astor by John Carrington Yates, his real estate agent, who said the hotel would continue under its present management.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 11. -- Charles H. Mayo Jr., son of the veteran Lido professional, today scored a 76 over the par 73 west course of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club to capture the low gross honors in an amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association.

The third underground hold-up since last Thursday was reported to the police yesterday by Ely Sabel, 30 years old, of 1,118 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, salesman for the Savoy Watch Company of 62 West Forty-seventh Street.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 11. -- Two engineers received honorary degrees of Doctor of Engineering at the commencement exercises of Lehigh University today when 259 degrees in course were conferred. These included 232 baccalaureate degrees, twenty-five master and two professional degrees.

The Actors Equity Association will embark soon on its national referendum to determine the sentiment of its members everywhere concerning Sunday night performances in the legitimate theatre. At yesterday's regular meeting of the council that body approved the proofs of the ballot that will be sent out, accompanied by a letter by Frank Gillmore, Equity president.

With seven indictments against him and the prospect of forty more, all for shaking down job-seekers under the pretense that he would use political influence to place their names on civil service eligible lists, John Flaherty, 46 years old, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions.
PARIS, June 11. -- The Bank of France suspended today its practice of making advances against gold bars in a further effort to discourage the already much-attentuated speculation.

Harold Pfleger, the 14-year-old boy who has undergone eighty-four blood transfusions at the New York Hospital since his admission last November, received yesterday afternoon what he previously had described as "the one thing in the world" he wanted most.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 11. -- Charles H. Mayo Jr., son of the veteran Lido professional, today scored a 76 over the par 73 west course of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club to capture the low gross honors in an amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association.

DETROIT, June 11. -- A resolution endorsing the principle of Federal legislation for the dissemination of scientifically regulated birth control information passed the triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs today by a vote of 493 to 17.

The eight weeks season of Stadium concerts, opera and ballet will open in the Lewisohn Stadium on June 26. The opening night will offer an orchestral program directed by Jose Iturbi, which will include the Mendelssohn violin concerto, with Albert Spalding as soloist.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11. -- About $38,000, not "half as much money as reported," has been accumulated through contracts for pictures, stories and endorsements for the Dionne quintuplets, Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, the Ontario physician to the famous babies, told the newspaper reporters of this city at a luncheon in his honor at the Hotel Traymore here today.

LONDON, June 11. -- The Prince of Wales made a friendly gesture toward Germany today before an enthusiastic gathering of British former service men. He told a conference of the British Legion that its president had made the suggestion, which commended itself to him, that a deputation from the Legion should visit Germany in the near future.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Imports of liquor for consumption, plus withdrawals from bonded warehouses, declined during May, the total standing at 517,122 proof gallons, valued at $2,318,249, as compared with 544,775 proof gallons for $2,519,342 in April.

A CRITIC who essays a history of the novel confronts the most embarrassing of dilemmas. If, like Vernon Parrington or Edmund Wilson or Granville Hicks, he happens to be cursed or blessed with a general philosophy that disregards the forms of expression in an effort to evaluate what the more sensitive men are thinking and feeling in the world, he will shortly discover himself in hot water with readers whose general test is esthetic.

The Reynolds Spring Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31 a net income of $116,808, after all deductions. This was equal to 81 cents a share on the capital stock. In the same period last year the company earned $89,391, or 60 cents a share.

LONDON, June 11. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, special German Ambassador, with his naval experts will return to London tomorrow, bringing, it is learned, Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's approval of naval terms agreed upon during the conversations before the Whitsun holiday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 11. -- Addressing the graduating class of 410 tonight at the University of North Carolina, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, the first woman to speak at the institution's commencement exercises, urged her hearers to go out into the world and seek new objectives with the view to making it a happier place for the underprivileged, particularly those in agriculture and industry.
BUTTE, Mont., June 11 (AP). -- A fresh trail of William Mahan was followed by squads of police tonight after his reported appearance at a hotel in Dillon, seventy-five miles southwest of here.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11. -- Permissive pasteurization was voted into the official "Methods and Standards for the Production of Certified Milk" here today at the close of a two-day joint conference of the Certified Milk Producers Association of America and the American Association of Medical Milk Commissions, which supervises their supply.

WASHINGTON, June ll. -- Inspired by a message from President Roosevelt telling them that they "practice the belief that gayety of spirit is a healthful reinforcement to the things that make life sane and sound," about 15,000 Nobles of the Mystic Shrine marched for two hours and forty minutes today in a colorful parade reviewed by Vice President Garner and watched by almost 100,000 spectators who lined the route.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 11. -- With about 300 riflemen of the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia taking part, five events in the New York State matches were shot here today on the Camp Smith range under the supervision of Lieut. Col. Henry E. Sauvet.

Undaunted by the pistols of two youthful robbers, Elaine Kahn, 5 years old, pleaded with them so earnestly yesterday noon to "please go away" and "please don't hurt my mother," that they finally departed without completing their hold-up.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 11. -- Alabama Pitts, erstwhile Sing Sing prison athlete barred from organized baseball because he is an ex-convict, was encouraged tonight by hundreds of telegrams and letters wishing him "good luck" as a complete review of his case was speedily drafted for the consideration of Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball.
BERLIN, June 11 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of June 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The twelve Federal Land Banks will call tomorrow for retirement, on July 1 $269,020,440 of their 4 1/2 per cent bonds. Arrangements are being made, W.I. Myers, Governor of the Farm Credit Administration, said, for a new issue of consolidated bonds which will be offered soon to provide funds for the redemption of the 4 1/2 per cent bonds.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- President Roosevelt may intervene in a few days to prevent a strike of 450,000 bituminous coal miners whose wage contract expires on June 16, with the end of the National Industrial Recovery Act, it was reported today.
BERLIN, June 11. -- The gesture of friendship by the Prince of Wales toward Germany urging a visit by a delegation from the British Legion is big news in Germany today.
BERLIN, June 11. -- The gesture of friendship by the Prince of Wales toward Germany urging a visit by a delegation from the British Legion is big news in Germany today.

Moved to action by the continued consumers' strike against retail kosher meat shops in this city and the protests of meat dealers that the strike was in reality a Communist enterprise, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he was seeking to ascertain the facts with a view to intervening.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull told the first national Conference of Seaport Cities on International Trade last night that international sanity required "both military and economic disarmament." He said extravagant expenditures in the race of armaments threatened to wipe out the gains already made toward economic recovery, and that "isolationism" threatened the peace, security and stability of governments everywhere.

PARIS, June 1. -- Before giving its approval the French Government is going to subject the Anglo-German naval agreement to long and searching study. The British Government's communication on the tentative accord is already in the hands of Foreign Office experts and their report will form the basis of the Cabinet discussion tomorrow before any formal opinion is expressed.
TOKYO, June 12. -- Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, today with heat described rumors that Emperor Kang Teh of Manchukuo was going to Peiping as entirely unfounded and too absurd for comment.

TIENTSIN, June 12. -- The Japanese Kwantung Army is moving 5,000 troops from Mukden to Shanhaikwan at the Great Wall. Eleven troop trains have already arrived at the Wall causing great traffic congestion.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Continued reports of a reduced demand for fresh pork and the warmer weather lowered prices of hogs today 5 to 25 cents a hundredweight, and the spread between the top and average quotations widened to 55 cents, compared with 25 cents a week ago.

In Dr. BLAIR'S death "the Domsie has slippit awa'." He was pre-eminently the Scottish "Domsie" in London at the head of the schools he served for twenty years. It was Scotland that gave him his intellectual nurture. As inspector of schools of the North of Scotland he must have learned the utter sacrifices which are made for an education.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 12,-Eighty-two students will he graduated tomorrow from the College of St. Elizabeth at Convent, N.J. near here. Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of Newark will preside at the ceremony and will confer the degrees.

ST. LOUIS, June 12. -- Being, from the very nature of their trade, a more or less calloused group of young men, the Yanks set out determinedly today to grab two more games from Rogers Hornsby's ill-starred Browns. But after clubbing their way to the front in the first engagement, 11 to 4, behind Vernon Gomez, something unexpected developed.

The indicated net loss of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in May was somewhat less than $200,000, according to Howard S. Palmer, president. The company credited $100,000 to operating expenses last month from funds released through the United States Supreme Court's decision on the pension law.

When the Silver Purchase Act of 1934 was passed a year ago, it was estimated that about 1,308,000,000 ounces of silver would be required, in addition to the 691,482,085 ounces then held by the Treasury, in order to achieve the ratio of 1 to 3 between the country's silver and gold stocks called for in the bill.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- A change was written into the omnibus banking bill today by the Senate Banking Subcommittee providing that all State banks not members of the Federal Reserve System and capitalized at $1,000,000 or more would on July 1, 1937, lose the privilege of having their deposits insured.
NEWARK, N.J., June 12. -- Newark and Montreal battled through five hours of baseball today and each won an extra-inning game.

LONDON, June 12. -- Dr. Auguste Piccard was present at the Science Museum at South Kensington today when the gondola of the balloon in which he made his ten-and-one-half-mile ascent in 1932 was presented to the museum by Jean Willems on behalf of the Belgian Fond National de la Recherche Scientifique. Max Cosyns, who accompanied Dr. Piccard, also was present.

Appointment of Dean K. Worcester, assistant secretary, to the new post of executive vice president was announced yesterday by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange. A constitutional amendment establishing the position was approved recently by the membership.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Miss Jane Findley Terrence Sargent and George Schuyler Tarbell Jr., who will he married Saturday. The other guests were:...

The gigantic fish caught with rod and reel last Saturday by Francis H. Low of Woodmere, L.I., was identified yesterday by Dr. John T. Nichols, curator at the American Museum of Natural History, as a specimen of the very rare white shark, or man-killer.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- A PWA report on housing conditions today pronounced them so bad over so great an area that they constituted a national emergency. It asserted that only Federal cooperation with States and cities could solve the problem.

A plea in defense of democracy against "the easy panacea, the cheap demagogue," and forces threatening the fundamental ideals of the country marked the address of Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University at the 103d commencement exercises yesterday morning at University Heights.

David Diamond, 20 years old, of Rochester, N.Y., has been awarded the Elfrida Whiteman Scholarship, given by Paul Whiteman in memory of his mother, for the best composition submitted in a contest open to composers, it was announced yesterday.

Establishment of a joint committee, composed of trade association executives in New York and members of the American Arbitration Association, to consider the drafting of a "model" voluntary trade agreement to be applied to industries in place of NRA codes, was voted yesterday afternoon at a meeting of representatives of forty-three trade associations at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

DOUGLASTON, L.I., June 12. -- Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Port of New York, won low net honors at the golf tournament of the National Democratic Club at the North Hills Golf Club today. Thirty members turned out for the event.

The share market experienced a little less insistent demand yesterday, but a demand, nevertheless, which contrasted favorably with the rather limited supply of seasoned investment stocks; the closing was irregularly higher, with the public utility issues intermittently declining and rallying, finally moving lower.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 12. -- Grant Carueth Wells of Weston, explorer, author and lecturer, filed a bankruptcy petition in Federal District Court today, listing assets of $4.50 in cash and liabilities of $11,350.02. The first hearing of creditors was scheduled by John Keogh, bankruptcy referee, for June 24.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12. -- Earnings of department stores and specialty shops were larger in 1934 than in the preceding year, the bureau of business research of the Graduate School of Business Administration of Harvard University announced today.
EATONTOWN, N.J., June 12. -- The Monmouth County Country Club polo team gave an excellent display of team work today in downing General Howard S. Borden's Old Oak four and the Poplar Farms riders.

PRINCETON, N.J., Thursday, June 13. -- While searching parties of 200 police, firemen, Princeton students and others were scouring the surrounding woods and hills for them, two little girls, daughters of prominent families, returned to their homes here shortly before 1 o'clock this morning, after a nine-and-a-half-hour hike, ignorant of the hue and cry that had been raised at their supposed "disappearance."
DETROIT, June 12 (AP). -- Lynwood Rowe checked the Red Sox with three hits today while his Tiger team-mates scored a 4-1 victory.

Five State witnesses testified yesterday in General Sessions at the start of the misdemeanor trial of Arthur V. Courtney, 29 years old, Queens saloon-keeper, on a conspiracy charge resulting from his having collected $800 for John Flaherty, political "fixer" now awaiting a possible ten-year Sing Sing sentence.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 12. -- The stratosphere balloon Explorer II will land somewhere in Northern Nebraska if the schedule of Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson for the flight work out as they have planned it.

Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, charged yesterday that rate reductions to electricity consumers in the past had been made "only to the extent that they were acceptable to the companies."

The fortunes of the Dodgers went to another new low yesterday and Manager Casey Stengel's already furrowed brow developed several new cresses. The Pirates overcame an early deficit and took the second contest of the series, 7 to 3.

TACOMA, Wash., June 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harmon M. Waley pleaded not guilty here tonight to Federal Lindbergh law and mail fraud conspiracy charges growing out of the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping and their bail was set at $100,000 each.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 12. -- In defeating Yale, 9 to 0, today, the University of Virginia administered the worst defeat of the season and the second shut-out in a fortnight to the Eli nine.

With speakers attacking the "Hoover philosophy of 1928" and the conservative Republican leadership at the recent "Grass Roots" conference in Springfield as well as New Deal measures, the New York Young Republican Club last night adopted a "liberalized" platform on national and State issues for presentation to the Alexandria Bay convention of the Association of the New York State Young Republican Clubs from June 21 to 23.

Prices of most commodity futures turned downward here yesterday. The market was fairly active. Sugar, rubber and silk were the only staples to make any advances. On the cash market declines appeared in all the grains, cotton and rubber, while cocoa and tin advanced.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- An amendment to the Treaty Navy Act of 1934, to enable shipbuilders to calculate more advantageously their profits and losses on government building contracts, was adopted today by the House. It now goes to the Senate.

LEESVILLE, Conn., June 12. -- Three anglers leaned against the railing of an old abandoned bridge just below the power dam here, their lines trailing in the current of the Salmon River, thirty feet below.

BILOXI, Miss., June 12. -- Vigorous opposition to President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the power of the Federal Government at the expense of the States and the suggestion of regional compacts between the States as a means of combating federalization were voiced by several Governors even before their annual meeting began here.

Triumphant, the C.V. Whitney hope which failed in the National Stallion Stakes, won his second race out of three starts when he was first in the Inwood Purse, main event yesterday at Aqueduct. The son of Dis Donc and Thais had to be much the best to score in a field of six, as he had all the worst of the racing luck.
