WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Word of the signing of the agreement in Buenos Aires for the cessation of hostilities in the Chaco was received with deep gratification here today.

In reply to a question put to him by a member of the Senate, Secretary MORGENTHAU defends the Treasury against any charge of lack of zeal in carrying out the silver policy prescribed by Congress. Making public for the first time complete and authentic figures, he asserts that during the ten months ending May 31 the Treasury acquired at home and abroad 421,497,000 ounces of silver -- or more than 13,000 tons of it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., June 12. -- On a second exploratory flight over westward seas, the Pan American Clipper, greatest of commercial planes, took off from Alameda Airport in San Francisco Bay this afternoon, searching for bad weather.

NANKING, China, Thursday, June 13. -- A crucial situation existed between Japan and China this morning, as an ultimatum demanding Chinese compliance with all the Japanese Army's demands in North China had expired last midnight without action by the Chinese authorities.

A recommendation that the cost of the West Side improvement under the original plan be met in part by an assessment on property owners probably will be made by Borough President Samuel Levy tomorrow when the Park Department's request for revision of the plan comes before the Board of Estimate.

Jack Cohn, vice president of Columbia Pictures, announced yesterday that arrangements had been completed whereby all the feature-length films to be made by Columbia in the 1935-36 season will be shown at theatres on the Loew's circuit in New York and throughout the country.

LONDON, June 12. -- Although he was suffering from bronchial catarrh and was ordered to take a fortnight's rest, King George was well enough this afternoon to go on a short automobile ride over his Sandringham farm.
The value of the dollar on the local foriegn exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 12. -- While the members of Harvard's freshman crew were approaching the boathouse tonight, the captain and stroke, James F. Chace, slipped and sprained his right ankle. The injury proved so painful that the squad physician was summoned. He bandaged the ankle and advised that Chace temporarily abandon rowing.

The Florsheim Shoe Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on April 30 a net income after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, of $306,724. The company had a profit of $280,483 in the corresponding period last year.

Max Baer and James J. Braddock have come through their training for their title fight in Madison Square Garden Bowl without accident, and both are reported by the Boxing Commission physicians who have examined them to be in the best of physical condition.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 12. -President Roosevelt told the 276 cadets of the Military Academy to whom he presented diplomas today, making them second lieutenants of the army, that "the greatest need of the world" was "the assurance of permanent peace, an assurance based on mutual understanding and mutual regard."

Three officers of the brokerage firm of Brown, Secord Co., 70 Pine Street, were arrested yesterday on a complaint charging violation of the law that makes it a misdemeanor for an officer of a corporation to countenance the omission of a material entry from its books.

LONDON, June 12. -- Iron and steels met further support on the Stock Exchange today under the influence of the favorable terms of the international cartel. British funds continued to weaken in expectation of more corporation issues and German and French bonds were easier in the foreign section of the market.

BOSTON, June 12. -- The world's champion St. Louis Cardinals climbed a step nearer the top of the National League ladder today, taking both ends of a double-header from the Boston Braves, 8 -- 6 and 5 -- 4.
BERLIN, June 12. -- The Boerse staged a fairly strong recovery today. The public ceased selling and went over to new purchases, although the turnover indicated a certain reticence.

GALESBURG, Ill., June 12. -- Declaring that the constitution of a political government must provide for developing and maintaining the constitution of an economic government under which men can enjoy life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, or that political constitution will prove to be a "mockery and a delusion," Donald R. Richberg, retiring head of the NRA, delivered the commencement address at Knox College today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- For the sixth time in her illustrious golfing career, Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr. won the women's Eastern championship today, with a fifty-four-hole total of 237, over the Huntingdon Valley course. She turned in a final card of 78.

The rally in speculative rail bonds was carried further in yesterday's trading in the bond market of the New York Stock Exchange. Gains of 1 to 4 points were piled on similar advances made on Tuesday. In contrast, utility issues fell as much as 1 to 5 points on the news of the passage of the Wheeler-Rayburn bill by the Senate.

ALBANY, June 12. -- Supreme Court Justice Schenck reserved decision this afternoon on the application of James A. Smyth, appearing for Maurice J. Burns, president of the John B. Donohue Association of Flushing, who seeks a mandamus to compel the courts to give Queens County four Senators and eleven Assemblymen instead of the two Senators and six Assemblymen it now has.
NANKING, China, June 12. -Authoritative Chinese quarters here said today that Japan had requested, and China had refused to grant, acceptance in writing of the following demands:

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Tax legislation will soon be before Congress, and a bill to extend the "nuisance taxes" is already prepared in the House, where revenue measures must originate. Encouraged by recent statements to the Senate Finance Committee by the Secretary of the Treasury, Congressional advocates of inheritance taxes seek an opportunity to attach the Treasury's plan to some House draft.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- Three prizes have been awarded to undergraduates in the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University, according to an announcement today by De Witt Clinton Poole, director of the school.

Auctioneers handled another long list of foreclosure sales of Manhattan real estate yesterday. They offered for bidding fifteen parcels, all of which were bought in by the plaintiffs in the court proceedings.

UNIVERSITY, Va., June 12. -- The greatest necessity of the present time is the eradication of the spoils system from government, Dr. David Russell Lyman of Wallingford, Conn., said in an address today at the exercises closing the 108th session of the University of Virginia.

ROME, June 12. -- The office of the Under-Secretary for Press and Propaganda has forbidden the entry of THE NEW YORK TIMES into Italian territory till further notice and has given instructions to the Ministry of Internal Affairs to seize all copies of the newspaper at the frontier from today onward.

Through a spectacular second-half rally, Yale handed Army its first polo defeat of the year, 10 to 9, at Governors Island yesterday to gain the intercollegiate championship final. Harvard advanced in the day's opening game by routing Pennsylvania Military College, 15 to 5.

Praise for the advent of the "brain trust" into business and government came from an unusual source yesterday. In what was declared to be the first time that a hotel had honored its receiver, the management of the Hotel St. Regis presented as a mark of its "utmost esteem" a bust of himself to Raymond Moley.

That new Sanitation Department anti-litter carnival truck is an unqualified triumph. People walking down the bigger avenues on Tuesday must have felt something like the poet whose heart leaped up when he beheld a rainbow in the sky.

The Bell Trophy, presented annually by Colonel Julius Ochs Adler for competition among regimental rifle teams of the Officers Reserve Corps in the Second Corps Area, has been won by the 424th Infantry. New York City's tank unit of the Army Reserve, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan at Governors Island.

Nearly 1,000 policemen will be required to handle the crowds at the Baer-Braddock title fight, it was stated at headquarters last night. They will be divided into three squads, one to handle the crowd, one for traffic and one to preserve order inside the arena.

The class of '35, Fordham University, will hold its Senior Ball this evening in the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker, beginning at 10 o'clock. More than 300 seniors and their guests will attend.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12. -- Martin Smith, a 30-year-old Kansas City man known to police as a gambler, was held by Federal agents today in connection with the disappearance of $590,000 Treasury notes in a New York bank six months ago.

Price-supporting government loans on cotton will, if continued, stimulate production in foreign countries to a point at which those countries eventually will grow enough cotton to supply all requirements of spinners outside the United States, and when that time comes, foreign markets for American cotton will be completely destroyed, according to Alston H. Garside, economist of the New York Cotton Exchange.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June, 12. -Emerging from the serious-minded conference of 5,000 Midwestern Republicans, mostly small business men and farmers, observers see one of the most earnest and genuine political movements in the last decade in this country.

CINCINNATI, June 12. -- Recognizing the grave possibilities in the threat of another strike of building service employes in New York, large property owners have consolidated their position so that any future difficulties will not find them unprepared as they were when trouble developed last Fall, Walter G. Merritt, counsel to the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations of New York, revealed here today.

PARIS, June 12. -- Under the influence of reports published in this morning's press regarding the government's financial plans, which were denied later by the Ministry of Finance, today's session of the Bourse was unsatisfactory. Rentes fell more than 1 franc in most cases and exchange rates moved against francs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 12. -- The Lawrence Farms Golf Club team of Bill Goldbeck and James Rushin traversed the Westchester Hills Golf Club course today to win the Westchester County pro-amateur tourney with a best-ball score of 62.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday finally approved of the plans for reorganization of the Allied Owners Corporation under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law. The only objection was from Murray Kraushaar, representing the Sabath Congressional investigating committee, who said the committee wished to look further into details of the sale of the Brooklyn Paramount Theatre by Allied Owners.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 12. -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech to the Military Academy graduates was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- A host of proposals to cope with the NRA situation, ranging from a constitutional amendment to a suggestion of Mayor Hoan of Milwaukee, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, that municipalities make wage and hour codes for public contracts, were advanced today.

Steel production showed a further seasonal decline of 2 points from 41.5 to 39.5 per cent of capacity and the scrap market exhibited a weaker tone last week. The Iron Age said in its summary, released today. Rumors of price concessions were current, the review stated, but quotations on pig iron and finished steel remained unchanged.

Views of public utility, leaders on the passage of the Wheeler-Rayburn Bill by the Senate on Tuesday and on the inclusion of the Borah amendment forcing elimination of all intermediate holding companies disclosed a wide diversity of opinion yesterday.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York took action yesterday to avert radical increases in tariffs on water-borne freight in the intercoastal trade. The conference at its monthly meeting voted to ask the intercoastal ship lines for a chance to submit the views of shippers before the tariffs are submitted to the Shipping Board for approval.

The National Steel Corporation has granted to a group of its officers and employes five-year options on 46,000 shares of its common stock at $40 a share, it was disclosed yesterday when the company listed on the Stock Exchange its recent issue of $50,000,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1965.

Al Lichtman, vice president in charge of distribution and general sales manager of the United Artists Corporation for the last nine years, will be elected president of the corporation at a board meeting to be held in New York on June 25, according to an announcement yesterday from the corporation's owners.

HAVRE, France, June 12. -- After having broken the German liner Bremen's record for a west-to-east crossing of the Atlantic and her own previous time for a passage across the ocean, the Normandie proudly steamed this evening into this gayly bedecked city to great acclaim, in which thousands of persons from the near-by countryside joined.

A nation-wide education campaign was begun yesterday by the National Health Council to stimulate intelligent interest in community health on the part of the citizens and taxpayers." The campaign will last five months.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- If business makes a substantial recovery in the next eighteen months, as expected, certain objectives must be attained to avert disastrous credit or currency inflation, Professor Malcolm P. McNair, director of the Business Research Bureau, Harvard University, warned here today in a talk before the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Statements regarding plans of action for tonight's heavyweight championship fight were given to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday by the principals, Max Baer and James J. Braddock, and their respective managers, Ancil Hoffman and Joe Gould.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Secretary Wallace declared today that the agricultural plank adopted by the "Grass Roots" convention so closely resembles the present Roosevelt farm program that if its principles should be carried over into the Republican national platform next year there may be no farm issue in the 1936 campaign.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- President Roosevelt was protected against "prosecution for contempt" following his recent criticism of the Supreme Court "by virtue of his freedom of the press," Colonel R. R. McCormick, publisher and editor of The Chicago Tribune, told the convention of the Advertising Federation of America here today.

The annulment suit brought by Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, against his wife, the former Countess Marie-Ann yon Wurmbrand-Stuppach, will be tried by a referee behind closed doors, without waiting for the testimony of European witnesses, according to two orders signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12. -- Manhattan and Brooklyn riflemen of the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia units firing in the State matches at Camp Smith here carried off nearly all the honors in today's events.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12. -Degrees will be conferred upon 171 candidates at the second annual joint commencement of Dana College, Seth Boyden School of Business, and New Jersey Law School at the Second Presbyterian Church here tomorrow night.

BUENOS AIRES, June 12. -- Buglers throughout the Chaco will sound "Cease firing" at noon Friday as a signal to suspend hostilities along the 530 miles of front. It is hoped this suspension of hostilities will be the definite termination of the war which Bolivia and Paraguay have been fighting for three years and which is estimated to have cost more than 100,000 lives.

TORONTO, June 12 (Canadian Press). -- No bids were made for the Ontario Government's $15,000,000 bond issue, which was to have been sold at noon today, and Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn charged that there was a "conspiracy" against the government.

Hitting cleanly and mixing judicious advance to the net with a hard driving game, Miss Grace Surber reached the quarter-final round of the New York State clay court tennis tournament at the Jackson Heights Club yesterday by defeating Mrs. Paul Haber of New York, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.

The American Medical Association in convention at Atlantic City has recently issued a statement condemning loose and at times fraudulent advertising concerning medicinal preparations. The Public Health Education Committee of the Bronx County Medical Society has always attempted to point out the dangers of self-medication in its radio work.

GENEVA, June 12. -- The International Labor Organization Conference unexpectedly decided today by a 57-to-49 vote to adopt the workers' resolution for a blanket forty-hour week convention that would become applicable to five industries. This decision involves rejection of the plan for separate conventions for each industry.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Complying with President Roosevelt's request, as the Senate had done recently in passing the measure, the House Interstate Commerce Committee today approved a year's extension from June 16 of the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act of 1933 and the office of Coordinator of Transportation for which it provides.
PROVIDED the Weather Man doesn't get peevish and wash out the program, the Big Bad Baer will bound into the Garden Bowl this evening and give James J. Braddock a shot at his glittering crown.

In his inaugural address as president of the American Medical Association, Dr. JAMES S. MCLESTER joined the ranks of those who believe that mankind is even now able to control its own evolution. If we will but "take "advantage of the new knowledge of "nutrition, a larger stature, greater "vigor, increased longevity and a "higher level of cultural development" are assured.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 13. -- The full force of the Roosevelt administration was pitted against the lung power of Senator Long of Louisiana in the early hours this morning in a final showdown in the Senate, with the resolution for a "skeletonized" extension of the National Industrial Recovery Act as the pawn.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- A thirteen-hit bombardment of Earl Whitehill, plus Ted Lyons's consistent pitching, gave the White Sox a 7-2 victory over Washington today and a 2-1 edge in the series.
WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Following is the text of the Chaco agreement signed by the Bolivian and Paraguayan Foreign Ministers in Buenos Aires today:

Award of a new issue of $2,672,000 of city of Detroit, Mich, refunding water system bonds was made yesterday to a syndicate comprising Lazard Freres Co., Inc.; E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Eastman, Dillon Co., Field, Richards Shepard, Inc.; A.G. Becker Co., Newton, Abbe Co., the Wells-Dickey Company and William R. Compton Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 13. -- President Roosevelt returned from Hyde Park and West Point and reviewed the Shriners' parade yesterday.

The group of unemployed artists and craftsmen who in January contributed $25 each toward a cooperative art venture in a loft rented for $25 a month in a city-owned building at 655 West Fifty-fifth Street found new quarters late yesterday afternoon, just in time to escape eviction today.

NANKING, Thursday, June 13. -- China cannot accept Japan's North China demands, national government officials said early today, because they would reduce China to the status of a "Japanese protectorate."

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Hope that the Anglo-German naval conversations will contribute to an eventual general limitation agreement among the principal powers in line with the principles of the two present naval treaties was expressed to Great Britain today by the State Department.

Additional industries yesterday went on record as favoring maintenance of NRA code provisions on a voluntary basis. They included luggage and leather goods manufacturers, the Eastern manufacturers of the sheep-lined and leather garment industry and shoe lace manufacturers.
Mayor La Guardia signed the deed yesterday to the parcels acquired by the city for the first unit of the Williamsburg model housing project.

Surrogate Foley approved yesterday the acceptance of the gift of Mrs. Emma T. Gary's art objects by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and directed the executors, Lewis Nixon Jr., Paul M. Hahn and Louis L. Levy, to proceed with the immediate sale of the jewelry in the bequest, which is estimated to be worth $469,200.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was quiet, within a 10-point range for most months, and prices ended at net losses of 7 to 12 points.

German gold bonds with a face value of $21,000,000, the largest single asset in the estate of the bankrupt International Match Corporation, were sold yesterday to the Aktieselskapet Actium Corporation of Norway for $6,300,000 cash, by order of Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy for the match company.

LONDON, June 12. -- Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, who associated himself last January with David Lloyd George in the latter's neglected plans for curing unemployment by public works, has now joined the Welshman in anticipating the next general election by urging British voters to select a Parliament and government that will adopt a firmer policy on war and peace.

Limiting divorces to but one ground in this State has created a sad state of affairs. Collusive divorces are planned every day. With them have grown up a large number of crooked detectives, hotel clerks, process servers and perjured witnesses.

BERLIN, June 12. -- Ernst Torgler, former Communist leader in the Reichstag, who has been in jail since his acquittal in 1933 in the celebrated Reichstag fire trial, has received his liberty, it was disclosed tonight.

MEXICO, D.F., June 12. -- A political crisis appeared to be developing in Mexico tonight after former President Plutarco Elias Calles had severely criticized political and economic conditions under the regime of President Lazaro Cardenas.

Raymond J. Healey, 22 years old, self-styled "American Hitler," was sentenced to sixty days in the workhouse for disorderly conduct yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in West Side Court.

The operation of the seaplane ramp on the East River at Thirty-first Street, New York's latest addition to its aviation facilities, was demonstrated yesterday for more than 100 Mayors here for the Conference of Seaport Cities.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 12. -- Mrs. Harrison Williams and J.P. Morgan tied today in the final count for the most points in the thirty-first annual Summer flower show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the main building of the Pratt estate.

The most direct route from Times Square to the Madison Square Garden Bowl is by way of the Eighth Avenue subway. This underground system runs from Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue to the Forty-sixth Street station in Long Island City, a short distance from the arena.

Advances in the organized fight against blindness and impaired vision are listed in the annual report of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, made public yesterday by Lewis H. Carris, the society's managing director.

BUTTE, Mont., June 12 (AP). -- A flurry of excitement prompted by the detention at Mobridge, S.D., of a transient removed from a freight train subsided somewhat today when Werner Hanni, Federal agent, removed the man to Aberdeen, S.D., and said he was not William Mahan, the fugitive wanted for complicity in the Weyerhaeuser kidnapping.

HAVANA, June 12. -- The body of Julian Guerrero, a secret policeman, was found riddled with machine-gun bullets this morning on the Central Highway near the town of Camito de Guayabal, twenty-five miles from Havana. He had been dead eight to ten hours.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 12. -- The isolation for the first time in crystalline form of the active principle in ergot, a goal science has been concentrating on since 1875, was rewarded here today by the American Medical Association with the gold medal in Class 1 exhibits, given to exhibits of individual investigations on the basis of originality and excellence of presentation.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harmon M. Waley, alleged accomplices in the kidnapping of George Weyerhaeuser, were secretly taken out of Salt Lake City today while the drive for a cleanup of the $200,000 abduction case was pressed on many fronts.

John A. Matthews, advisory master of the Court of Chancery of New Jersey, called upon the graduates of Fordham University at its ninetieth commencement exercises yesterday to seek Catholic principles of social justice by following the leadership of President Roosevelt.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12. -- Late this afternoon the rowing colony on the banks of the Hudson became complete when three crews of Midshipmen, officers and coaches rolled up to their camp opposite Columbia and all seven of the entries for next Tuesday's intercollegiate regatta were on the scene of action.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- An early showdown before the House Interstate Commerce Committee on the Wheeler-Rayburn Utility Holding Company Bill and defeat, in favor of regulatory control, of its requirement for outright dissolution of such companies by 1942, was predicted by some committee members today as Speaker Byrns failed in an effort to break the deadlock in a subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Favoritism in the past in awarding foreign air-mail contracts to Pan-American Airways is alleged by Postmaster General Farley in a letter to President Roosevelt, contained in a report of the special committee investigating air mail and ocean mail contracts, presented to the Senate today.

Mayor La Guardia took a novel step yesterday in pursuance of his policy of advancing career men in city service by announcing the promotion of Second Deputy Police Commissioner Vincent J. Sweeney to the city magistrates' bench.

The urgent need for concerted effort to build up style consciousness on the Dart of men and more general appreciation of the fact that social and economic success is directly attendant on personal appearance was stressed yesterday by William Goldman, president of Cohen, Goldman Co., at the first meeting of the men's clothing advisory committee of the Associated Wool Industries, held at the Manhattan Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22. -- Henry Nielsen of Denmark, holder of the world's record of 8:18.4 for the 3,000 meter run, who is favored to win the two-mile event in the Princeton invitation track meet on Saturday, took his first workout of the week on the fast Palmer Stadium track today.

I am prompted to write you following my reading of the traffic control suggestion to call attention to the fact that traffic officers will frequently permit crosstown traffic to operate against the red lights. In some emergencies this may be desirable, but the practice has become widespread, when no officers are on duty, to pay no attention to the red light and to keep going until traffic starts flowing in the opposite direction.

The treatment proposed by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in its coming reorganization, for $8,056,000 of Chicago, Terre Haute Southeastern Railway bonds, came up for discussion yesterday at a meeting here of the company's officials and representatives of about twenty, institutional holders of the bonds.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, who is presiding at the government's trial of an anti-trust action against the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, listened yesterday to a technical dissertation on radio broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- With a little wisdom "we could so strengthen and improve the League of Nations and the World Court that war would become as obsolete as dueling," Dr. Parker T. Moon, Professor of International Relations at Columbia University, declared today.

Eleven men were arrested in front of the Times Square and Liberty Theatres, in West Forty-second Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, last night as policemen, under the direction of Captain John Chalan of the West Thirtieth Street station, broke up what they described as an attempt to stage a mass-picketing demonstration before the two theatres.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- FERA officials plan to direct from Washington their program for putting the nation's unemployed actors and actresses to work on touring companies and to carry out the activity through the relief organization rather than through the offices of private producers, it was learned today.

DETROIT, June 12. -- In a ceremony broadcast over a national hook-up, Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson of Tulsa assumed the presidency of the General Federation of Women's Clubs at the Masonic Temple tonight. She was presented to the closing session of the triennial convention by the retiring president, Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole.

Some of those base hits which were lacking in Tuesday's double-header flew off the Giant bats yesterday at the Polo Grounds as the Terrymen collected sixteen safeties to rout the hustling Cincinnati club, 10 -- 4. With Carl Hubbell in command throughout, the Red menace that had reached such large proportions the other day was dealt with severely.

Sam H. Harris and Max Gordon will formally sign today the agreement with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer whereby the film company will fiuance all their Broadway productions during the theatrical season of 1935-36. The deal, most extensive of its kind ever arranged between Hollywood and Broadway, was completed on Tuesday.

LONDON, June 12 (AP). -- The Daily Herald said tonight Premier Mussolini was ready to call off impending hostilities against Ethiopia in return for a railroad concession linking Italy's two colonies in East Africa.

Al Roth, 133 1/2, hard-hitting Bronx lightweight, decisively outpointed Leonard Del Genio, 134 1/2, of Harlem last night in the feature ten-round bout of the opening outdoor boxing show at Dyckman Oval before 2,500 persons. Del Genio started fast but weakened in the second when subjected to a bitter body attack by Roth.

Viking Press reports that no book ever before published by it has caused such bidding for what are called "subsidiary rights" as "Paths of Glory," by Humphrey Cobb. Within a week after publication the publishers have been approached by nine motion picture companies, five theatrical producers, five dramatists, four newspaper syndicates, eleven foreign publishers, and thirteen literary agents in reference to some of these rights.

Municipally owned electric light plants in New York State have not been an unqualified success in reducing rates for the consumers, John E. Mack, counsel to the legislative committee investigating public utilities, declared yesterday.

SHANGHAI, June 12. -- Akira Ariyoshi returned here yesterday as Japan's first Ambassador to China with his own characterization of his mission as one of "friendship and cooperation" contrasting sharply with reports of impending Japanese military operations in North China, Nanking's desperate efforts to cope with increasing pressure by the Japanese Army and local repercussions to the critical Chino-Japanese situation.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Secret protocols alleged to embody the substance of the twenty-one demands presented to China by Japan in 1915 were attached to the Tangku truce of May 31, 1933, and go far to explain present events in North China, according to a report issued today by the Foreign Policy Association.

After a meeting of the Board of Education last night a score of representatives of anti-war, teacher-parent and unemployed groups took over the board room and protested vehemently against alleged militarism in the public schools.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP). -The Cubs and Phillies divided a double-header today. Chicago won the first game, 15 to 0, behind the five-hit pitching of Larry French, while O'Dea, Klein and Cavaretta hit home runs in the 16-hit attack of three Phil hurlers.

Louis Steinberg, operator and builder, who recently bought the southwest corner of Loring Place and 183d Street, has extended his holdings by purchasing the adjoining property from William J. Curley. E. Osborne Smith, Inc., was the broker in assembling the plot, which will be improved with a six-story elevator apartment house to cover the entire site.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 12. -- Playing their second match in as many days, the Long Island poloists conquered the Texas four, 12 to 8, on the J.S. Phipps estate today. The winning quartet presented a well-balanced attack, with Johnny Fell and Stewart Iglehart taking care of most of the scoring.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12, -- Dick Walsh Jr., son of the former Harvard half-miler, made his debut as a varsity pitcher today and beat Brown, 5 to 2, allowing only six hits. The young southpaw, who now may get a chance in the coming Harvard-Yale series, struck out nine hitters, three of them in the opening inning.

MONTREAL, June 12 (AP). -- Jonah J. Goldstein, New York magistrate, urged cooperation between courts and social agencies to abolish slums in an address before the National Conference of Social Work here today, which selected Washington for its 1936 session and Indianapolis for 1937.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Largely as a result of confusion concerning the effect of the Supreme Court decision in the NRA case on the powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission, registration of brokers and dealers who carry on transactions in the over-the-counter markets has been lagging.

News of the Banking difficulties in Switzerland added to the pressure on the gold-bloc currencies yesterday. The franc fell temporarily below the gold import point again, but was supported, while the Swiss franc and the guilder rallied, presumably on official support.

Five of seven former heavyweight champions who expressed opinions yesterday on the outcome of the Baer-Braddock fight picked the former to retain his title. The five are Jack Dempsey, Gene Tunney, Max Schmeling, Primo Carnera and James J. Jeffries.

Dean Virginia Glldersleeve of Barnard College will sail today on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. i Others sailing on this ship include Anna Stsn, actress; Walter Huston, actor; Sheila Barrett, British actress, and the following:

CHICAGO, June 12. -- General liquidation by scattered longs developed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade. A report that a combine machine had started to operate in early grain in the Iowa-Kansas territory caused fears of hedging pressure, and the selling disclosed a lack of support.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Despite a torrential rainfall, several thousand Shriners paraded for an hour before President Roosevelt tonight until the downpour forced the marchers to halt because they could no longer carry their musical instruments.

BOSTON, June 12. -- Long-range confidence but immediate perplexities in the power and paper business of the International Paper and Power Company, is the view that A.R. Graustein, president of the company, expressed at the annual stockholders' meeting here today.

One hundred and nine students will be graduated this evening at 8:15 o'clock from Fordham Preparatory School on the Fordham University campus. The Very Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, president of Fordham University, will address the graduates.

The Public Service Commission dismissed yesterday the complaint of Westchester communities against the commutation rates charged by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. Under existing conditions, the commission ruled, no rate cuts were justified.

Sixty feature pictures will be produced by Warners Brothers, First National and Cosmopolitan Productions during the 1935-36 season, it was announced yesterday as the company's sales convention began in Los Angeles. Six of the films will be made by Cosmopolitan.

Daggett Ramsdell, F.W. Moss, president, a beauty preparation concern, has leased a shop in the RCA Building. This will be its first beauty salon in the East, according to the Rockefeller Center management. A salon has been operated in Chicago for about a year.
The letter written by H. Boldt can hardly be judged as an answer to my letter published on June 5.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- With filings under the Securities Act of 1933 approaching record proportions for June, and the total since Jan. 1 at $897,720,000, Chairman Kennedy of the Securities and Exchange Commission declared today that at present "anybody who wants to finance securities seems able to do it."

President Roosevelt will be reelected in 1936 and a war will be waged in Palestine over the Suez Canal, but the status of Justice Crater's disappearance and other major mysteries was not changed by yesterday's psychic vibrations.
The chance of a lifetime, an opportunity that a few short years ago he never even dreamed of, comes to James J. Braddock of West New York, N.J., tonight.

At a time when public men are blown away from their old positions by every wind of new and seemingly popular doctrine it is refreshing to meet with one who does not alter when he alteration finds. The address by Secretary HULL yesterday at the Seaport Cities Conference in this city illustrates what we mean.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 12 (AP). -- Ethiopian officials accused Italian agents today of attempting to buy the support of some chiefs of the Province of Ogaden, across the frontier from Italian Somaliland.

LONDON, June 12 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody chalked up the eighth successive victory of her comeback campaign today and served due notice on the world of women's tennis that all the old potent magic gradually is returning to her racquet.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 12. -- Princeton got off to a flying start today as the annual regatta of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association for the MacMillan Trophy began at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

AGANA, Guam, June 12 (By Wireless). -- When the first clipper plane emerges from the clouds within sight of this forgotten island a few weeks or months hence it will have a reception unequaled in any part of the Orient or the islands of the Pacific in between.
Money market was dull. New business was small, most of the turnover being routine. Quotations were unchanged.

It is encouraging to learn that Commissioner LANDIS has asked for all the facts in the case of "Alabama" PITTS, the former Sing Sing football and baseball star who has just completed a term of five years for a former hold-up. Warden LAWES has testified that PITTS was a model prisoner.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- War Department applications for projects costing $9,398,222 under the $4,000,000,000 work relief program, including New York and New Jersey, were made public today. Among those in New York were:

Directors of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, in a letter addressed to stockholders yesterday, announced plans to clear up accumulated dividends on its preferred stock and place the issue upon a regular dividend basis in the third quarter of this year.

In commemoration of the pioneering flight from New York to Philadelphia and return, made by the late Charles K. Hamilton on June 13, 1910, Captain E.V. Rickenbacker will command a round trip flight between Floyd Bennett Field and Camden today.

Mr. MOSES'S usual sure sense of the salient facts in a park situation is evident in his report to the Mayor on the West Side improvement project. What are the criteria of a desirable plan? That the cost be moderate; that the work proceed as promptly as possible; that it avoid crippling existing park facilities while construction is in progress, and the whole scheme be consistent with sound principles of park planning.
CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP). -Despite three home runs, the Indians lost a free-hitting game to the Athletics today, 7 to 5. It was the Tribe's fourth straight defeat.

While Baroness Maud Levi was using her devastating chop strokes to defeat Mrs. William V. Hester Jr., 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, and gain her semi-final berth in the New Fork State clay court tennis championship yesterday, the rest of the high seeded quarter-finalists encountered plenty of difficulty in their matches at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Hope that passage of partial extension of the NIRA until April 1, 1936, might "break the ground for permanent legislation" at this session of Congress was voiced by Senator Wagner tonight in a radio speech on "The Supreme Court and the NRA."

ALBANY, June 13. -- The National Union for Social Justice, a Michigan corporation headed by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, filed today a copy of its charter for this State, which was approved by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State.

SEOUL, Korea, June 13. -- General Senjuro Hayashi, Japanese Minister of War, having completed a tour of inspection of Manchukuo, including a visit to Heiho, on the Siberian frontier, told The Associated Press today that he saw no possibility of any reduction of the Japanese forces in Manchukuo.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose to a new high record above $2,500,000,000 this week, it was indicated in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve as of Wednesday, published yesterday. The report showed a rise of $135,000,000 in member-bank reserves to a total of $5,049,000,000, the highest figure ever reached.

LONDON, June 13 (AP). -- The British racing public, still remembering Golden Miller's "million pound fall" in the Grand National, was stirred anew today when the Jockey Club administered a reprimand to Jockey Harry Wragg for his ride on the Aga Khan's Theft in the derby last week.

Legal responsibility for a $1,000 penalty imposed by the city because of arrests for prostitution in a building at 112 West Forty-fifth Street was charged yesterday to F. William Zelcer, Deputy Commissioner of Docks in Charge of Aviation, in an affidavit submitted in Supreme Court by the owner of the building, Dr. E. Harrison Griffin of 49 West Eighty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Senate Banking Subcommittee completed work today on Title 1 of the Omnibus Banking Bill, dealing with Federal deposit insurance, and were confronted immediately with the question whether to take up the expansion of Federal Reserve Board powers and revision of the Reserve System as the administration insists or discuss purely administrative features.

By the narrow majority of 57 to 49, the International Labor Office conference in Geneva decided in favor of a blanket forty-hour week agreement applicable to five industries. About a third of the delegates, largely representing the employers, refrained from voting. The vote was preceded by a debate extending over several days.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 13. -- The principle of voluntary health insurance for the provision of medical care to all classes of people, provided each locality works out its plan in accordance with its own conditions, was officially endorsed here today by the house of delegates of the American Medical Association, the supreme authority on medical policy of the United States.

The New York State Retail Meat Dealers Association declared yesterday that it would hold Mayor LaGuardia responsible for any damage suffered as a result of violence in the housewives' strikes against high prices. The association charges that the strike is directed by Communists.

The forty-first commencement of the School of Nursing of the Presbyterian Hospital was held yesterday on the lawn of the quiet garden of the hospital at Broadway and 168th Street. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the chapel, at Princeton University, addressed the seventy-one members of the graduating class.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 13. -- Further progress toward peace in Chaco now awaits ratification by the Bolivian and Paraguayan Congresses of the peace-making machinery set up by the mediators.

Captain Edward Vernon Rickenbacker, once a noted automobile race driver, who started his war service in France as one of General Pershing's chauffeurs, came back as America's leading ace in the air service. He was officially credited with twenty-five enemy planes.
UTICA, N.Y., June 13. -- Over 1,500 dairy leaders from seven States gathered here today favored the proposed State-Federal license plan for the marketing of milk from these States.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Paced by Mrs. Jonathan Thorne and Miss Barbara Stoddard, the New York team, holders of the Griscom Cup, gained an easy victory over Boston in the first of the three intercity women's golf matches at the Huntingdon Valley Country Club course today, winning by 10 to 5.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 13. -- Henry Gullen, secretary of the Royal and Ancient Club, ruling body of golf in Great Britain, today announced that Sid Brews's entry in the British open championship starting at Muirfield June 24 had been accepted.

The question whether wrestling matches are conducted "on the level" became an issue in Supreme Court yesterday at the trial before Justice Louis A. Valente and a jury of Mrs. Marie Swanton's suit to collect $20,000 from her former husband, Jack Curley, wrestling promoter.

James J. Braddock's dressing room was a scene of hilarious excitement when the new champion finally got through the crowd with the aid of a police escort and was able to close the doors behind him. Thousands swarmed around the door yelling wildly with joy.

GENEVA, June 13. -- The International Labor Organization conference voted 79 to 26 today to establish a committee on the forty-hour week, despite the fact that all employer delegates, except the American and Italian, refuse to sit in the committee.

It was just about the time that a small white coffin was being borne yesterday morning down the aisle of Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church, University and West Burnside Avenues, the Bronx, that an anguished lad of 12 was closeted with a gray-haired, kindly man in the justice's chambers of Bronx Children's Court.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 13. -- A new surgical technique for gall stone and gall bladder operations which already has been applied in 127 cases without a single death, whereas the mortality rate in these operations under the prevailing technique is 10 per cent, was demonstrated here today at the joint annual meeting of the American and Canadian Medical Associations.

LONDON, June 13. -- The stock markets were quieter and irregular today, except some bright industrial features. Iron and steel shares again were the most active on the list in the renewed demand after an early reaction on profit-taking. British funds improved in spite of prospects of dearer money toward the end of the month and the likelihood of several corporation loans in the near future.

CLEVELAND, June 13 (AP). -- The National Conference of State Liquor Administrators voted unanimously today to request President Roosevelt and Congress to set up an "appropriate tribunal" to carry on the functions of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, which collapsed through the recent Supreme Court NRA ruling.
Nearly 100 eminent engineers paid tribute to the public service and distinguished engineering career of Colonel William J. Wilgus last night at a dinner in the Engineers Club 32 West Fortieth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Developments in aviation as amazing in the next twenty-five years as those of the quarter century since Charles K. Hamilton made the first round trip flight between New York and Philadelphia were predicted here today at a luncheon commemorating Hamilton's feat.

Declaring that it was unwilling to submit to the terms of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Noranda Mines, Ltd., a Canadian corporation, notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that it would not apply for permanent registration of its common stock under the act.

Behind Japan's present moves in China are demands which would at least cripple the authority of the Nanking Government in the northern provinces, if not actually lead to the creation of a new "buffer State." The Japanese command has insisted on the withdrawal of various Chinese troops, on the dismissal of officials and their replacement with new appointees acceptable to Japan, and on the rooting-up of branches of the Nationalist party.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Business activity continued to contract last month, according to The Annalist, declining nearly to the level for December, 1934. Factors in the decrease were a greater than seasonal decline in automobile production and a smaller than seasonal increase in freight carloadings.

Paramount Pictures will produce sixty-five features and 211 short films for release during the new season, it was announced yesterday as the company's national sales convention opened at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 13. -- Ed Leader and Charley Whiteside, head coaches of the Yale and Harvard varsity crews, are striving mainly to keep their respective crews in top-notch physical condition for the races on the Thames River a week from tomorrow.

The twenty-ninth annual commencement of Cathedral College, preparatory department of St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y., was held last night at the Cathedral High School, 562 Lexington Avenue, in the presence of Cardinal Hayes and 800 clergymen and laymen who filled the high school's auditorium to capacity.

NEW HAVEN, June 13. -- Asserting that the Yale Art School did not intend to teach the "isms" or fields of specialization advocated in the field of art, Dean Everett E. Meeks said at the anniversary exercises tonight that attention has been drawn to the school because its students for the second time in recent years have won three fellowships at the American Academy in Rome.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The Boerse opened today with a firm undertone but turned soft later and closed fractionally lower. The turnover, however, remained small, as both the public and the professional traders assumed a policy of watchful waiting. Heavy industrials opened irregular, some fractional gains being countered by similar losses, except in Harpener, where a disappointing annual report reduced the quotation 1 3/4 points.

Six men, some of them armed, taped and bound three women and six men in the seventh-floor office of the Edward Wirtschafter and Company fur firm at 333 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets, at 4:30 P.M. yesterday and escaped with finished mink coats and mink skins valued by the police at $35,000.

Marvin Hedge of Portland, Ore., holder of the world's record for fly-casting for distance, will compete in the metropolitan amateur fly and bait-casting tournament at Conservatory Lake in Central Park tomorrow.
DANZIG, June 13. -- Theodor Loewy, a Latvian citizen and publisher of the Danzig Echo, a Jewish newspaper, was expelled from Danzig today by order of the police president.

ROME, June 13. -- It was officially announced today that David Darrah, Rome correspondent of The Chicago Tribune, had been expelled from Italy last night. He left suddenly without notifying the United States Embassy or getting in touch with his colleagues.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- This government is considering the possibility of following the example of Great Britain and France by sending a financial investigator to China, but no decision has been reached, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Overruling objections by his strongest supporters in the House, President Roosevelt insisted during a White House legislative conference today upon passage of his reform program at this session, even if such a course meant risking his own prestige and the various legislative measures involved.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 (AP). -- Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, approved today a plan that will almost double interest payments to holders of $50,747,000 guaranty contracts of the National Commercial Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Newark.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The restrictions on "non-Aryans" in German universities carried a step further today when formal instructions were issued that "non-Aryan" medical and dental students who had entered German universities since the Summer of 1933 were to be admitted to final examinations only in "special and exceptional cases."

Net profit of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries, including the Firestone Service Stores, for the six months ended on April 30 amounted to $2,155,084 after depreciation, interest, Liberian development expenditures, Federal taxes and other charges.
DETROIT, June 13. -- As Henry Ford watched his two millionth V-8 car run off the assembly chain at the Rouge plant today he found time to express some views on business.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Secretary Morgenthau indicated today that no major financing operation to raise new money would be undertaken by the Treasury prior to the end of the fiscal year June 30.

In an atmosphere of unfriendliness and the momentary possibility of an outbreak, Max Baer and James J. Braddock weighed in at noon yesterday at the offices of the State Athletic Commission. Deputy John T. McNiel supervised the weighing.

The Literary Guild selection for August will be "Voodoo Fire in Haiti," which Doubleday, Doran will publish late in July. A Viennese artist, Richard A. Loederer, is the author. He gathered material for the book while exploring the island making sketches for a series of woodcuts.
LONDON, June 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

In the safe of the Brooklyn Museum four of the ten valuable oil paintings stolen in 1933 are in secret storage because until a month ago the police had hopes of rapping the ingenious thieves who raided the institution, a high police official disclosed last night.

Three new films are listed on today's schedule. They are "The Glass Key," featuring George Raft, Edward Arnold and Rosalind Keith, at the Paramount; "Vagabond Lady," with Evelyn Venable and Robert Young, at the Roxy, and "People Will Talk," with Charles Ruggles and Mary Boland, at the RKO Palace.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13. -- The baseball game which Harvard and Princeton tossed out of the standing a few weeks ago because of an umpiring dispute was played off today. Again a controversy marked the Eastern Intercollegiate League battle, in which Harvard once more outscored the Tigers, 4 to 3.

PARIS, June 13. -- Former Premier Andre Tardieu's refusal to take office in either the Bouisson or Laval Cabinets has been much commented on in France and in the periodical 1935 he has set forth his reasons in his usual emphatic fashion.

In a telegram sent yesterday to Fred Lazarus Jr., the Association of Buying Offices, representing more than 2,000 small merchants throughout the country, endorsed the recently formed American Retail Federation and urged its accounts to affiliate with the organization.

OSLO, Norway, June 13. -- Sir Norman Angeli, recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1933, yesterday delivered the inaugural address at the Nobel Institute on the subject "Peace and the Public Mind" in the presence of King Haakon, Crown Prince Olaf, Foreign Minister Halvdan Koht, the rector of the University of Oslo and members of the diplomatic corps.
CHICAGO, June 13. (AP). -- Concentrating their fire on one big inning, the White Sox today pounded home nine runs in the fifth frame to defeat the Senators, 10 to 6, for the third straight time.

About 3,000 members of the Italian Dressmakers Union, Local 89, last night heard their leaders threaten to call a general strike if employers attempt to lower the hour and wage standards which were gained under the NRA. Meeting in the Hippodrome, the delegates adopted a resolution declaring the principles of the NRA were those of organized labor.

Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, the Callander (Ont.) physician who delivered the Dionne quintuplets, stopped over in New York last tight long enough to attend his first prize-fight, the Baer-Braddock bout, with two newspaper friends.

The sons of two famous horses, owned by two of the best-known members of the Jockey Club, came to the line so closely locked in the outstanding race at Aqueduct yesterday that none but the placing judges could separate them. They declared Thruster the winner.

Assurance that the new amendments to the Workmen's Compensation Law would in all probability not prove to be a great burden on insurance carriers and employers was given yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, speaking at a luncheon meeting of the Insurance Buyers of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 13. -- With every instrument in place and every delicate connection tested and retested a score of times, the crew of the stratosphere balloon Explorer II announced today that they are only awaiting word from the weather man to start.

Thousands of householders and business houses will display the flag from their windows today, and patriotic societies throughout the city will hold celebrations to commemorate the flag's 158th birthday. "The Star-Spangled Banner," to be played at many rallies, will have added significance.

As it seems obvious that the President and a large number of Congressmen care little or nothing about business men or business interests, except to try to get votes when running for office, I am going to suggest a remedy which I think will correct if not entirely cure this condition.
PARIS, June 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- A conviction that a substantial number of the 3,500,000 persons who are to receive jobs under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program will be at work in July was expressed today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- In a new legal assault on the New Deal six meat-packing companies of this area today filed separate suits in the Federal District Court asking that the Agricultural Adjustment Act be declared unconstitutional.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., June 13. -- The Dobbs Ferry Garden Club presented a flower show this afternoon in the Zion parish house here. Mrs. Howard S. Porter of Dobbs Ferry won the sweepstakes prize for the greatest number of points, and Mrs. Charles Learned, also of Dobbs Ferry, won the Robert Johnson Medal (awarded annually) for the outstanding exhibit.
PITTSBURGH, June 13. -- Orders to shut down every mine in Western Pennsylvania at midnight Sunday went out today from operators of both commercial and the so-called "captive" pits.
LIMA, Peru, June 13. -- In a message to the press tonight President Oscar Benavides expressed satisfaction over the signing of the peace protocol by Bolivia and Paraguay.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The navy's admirals were advised today by Representative Maverick of Texas to keep their mouths "shut" and do what they are "told."

Discrimination by union executives in the employment of Negro members of the Motion Picture Operators Union was charged yesterday by Granville M. Dick, Negro member of Local 306, at a hearing of the sub-committee on discriminatory practices of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem.
Dr. George Chatfield of the Board of Education was named yesterday as chairman of a committee to organize a work relief project aimed at surveying the problems involved in juvenile delinquency.

DANZIG, June 13. -- Before a crowded Volkstag, Arthur Greiser, President of the Danzig Senate, yesterday delivered a speech seeking to justify the devaluation of the Danzig currency and outlining his program to save the financial and political independence of the Free City as a ward of the League of Nations.

TORONTO, June 13 (Canadian Press). -- Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn stood firmly tonight by his decision to ignore representatives of any bankers' or investment dealers' associations which refused to bid yesterday on the Ontario Government's $15,000,000 bond issue, and he completed plans for handling the loan through the Provincial savings banks.
SHANGHAI, Friday, June 14. -Tension over the North China situation had abated somewhat here late yesterday as widely feared Japanese military operations in North China failed to materialize.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 13. -- A second season of Summer plays, began aboard the showboat Periwinkle tonight, with Skipper Larry Bolton, formerly of the Christopher Morley Company in Hoboken, at the helm.

Charles K. Hamilton did not survive many years to enjoy the fame and money which his New York-Philadelphia flight brought him. At the age of 32 he died in New York, less than four years after that trip, on Jan. 23, 1914. Although his career was brief it was packed with incident.

Commemorating one of the notable pioneering flights of American aviation, that made June 13, 1910, by the late Charles K. Hamilton, the Florida Flier, a fourteen-passenger transport under command of Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, flashed yesterday morning from Floyd Bennett Field to Camden and back in less than one hour.
Aimee Semple McPherson, Four-Square Gospel evangelist, arrived on the Italian liner Rex yesterday, hurrying homeward to report to her followers on the progress of religion in Far Eastern lands.

Chase Mellon Jr., Republican County Chairman, opened his primary campaign to retain his present post last night with the statement that he was seeking re-election at the request of the leaders of the Republican State organization.

Richard Backora, 11 years old, whose ambition is to be a commercial artist, executed a garden design that won first prize of $25 in the first annual Child's Garden Design Competition, sponsored by the Gardens of the Nations in Rockefeller Center, where the award was made yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The price which the Treasury pays for newly mined domestic silver will probably be kept at 77.57 cents an ounce, regardless of the lower price now being quoted in the world market, Secretary Morgenthau indicated today.

OTTAWA, June 13. -- Prime Minister Bennett introduced in Parliament today a permissive bill authorizing the government to revalue gold at the market price and to make use of the profit thus realized to form a currency stabilization fund on the lines of the British and American funds.
Under the caption "President's Responsibilities" George Foster Peabody dedicates the President as the sole representative of "the expressed wisdom of the whole Federal electorate."

CINCINNATI, June 13. -- Control of future building work to prevent a recurrence of the unsettled conditions which resulted from overproduction of space during the last boom period was advocated by Andrew Steers of Seattle, at the closing session today of the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows, Quotations are in cents:
ROCKVILLE, Md., June 13 (AP). -- Two men testified today that Mrs. Anne Lyddane plotted her husband's death and had paid them for his proposed assassination.
The small business involved in the day's money market brought no change in quotations, which continued steady.

CLEVELAND, June 13 (AP). -- Oral Hildebrand pulled the Indians and himself out of a slump today by defeating the Athletics, 6 to 3. The Indians had lost four straight and it was Hildebrand's first victory since May 20.

Mrs. William C. Martin gave a luncheon yesterday in the Rainbow Grill, Rockefeller Center. Her guests were Mrs. Leonard J. McKitterick, Mrs. Frederick Cone, Mrs. Edward C. McCullough, Mrs. Walter O. Ford, Mrs. George F. Breen, Mrs. Charles Lafayette Jones, Mrs. Leita de Rees, Mrs. Chester Stratton, Countess Filliponi, Mrs. James M. Campbell, Mrs. Julian Wilson, Mrs. Benn La Rue, Mrs. Stewart M. Sperry, Miss Elizabeth Glendenning and Miss Jeannette Aldrich.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, an Increase of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $32,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Among the several Summer exhibitions that opened this week is one at the Rehn Gallery, which brings into action a large number of Rehn "regulars." The show is divided into two parts. The middle rooms of the gallery are now occupied by a group of pictures specially priced for the Summer season.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 13. -- Striking advances in the treatment of such peripheral nervous disorders as sciatica, neuritis, neuralgia and facial paralysis through short wave diathermy were described by Dr. William D. McFee of Boston before the Academy of Physical Medicine here today.

Philippe Marcombes, a distinguished physician and French politician, was born in Clermont-Ferrand. He was a member of the Chamber of Deputies, representing the department Puy-de Dome since 1928, and belonged to the Radical Socialist party.
I read in your science section an article regarding the sale of old gold directly to the Assay Office.

Lower prices again were the feature of the fresh fruit and vegetable market yesterday. According to The City's Consumers' Food Guide, published by the Department of Public Markets, the only changes in meat prices were on some cuts of beef, which were reduced in certain retail shops.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

Bank clearings at the twenty-two principal cities throughout the United States for the week ended on Wednesday increased 3.9 per cent to a total of $4,776,778,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $4,599,382,000 for the corresponding week last year.

ST. LOUIS, June 13. -- Rating craftily off the pace during the early stages and then bearing down handsomely in the backstretch, the Yankees again ran rings around the Browns today by a margin of 8 to 3.

Production of new life insurance in May was 7.5 per cent less than in the same month last year, but for the first five months of this year, the total was 2.5 per cent greater than in the same period a year ago, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

A spectacular fire on the top floor of a five-story loft building at 113 Bowery, between Grand and Hester Streets, last midnight disrupted traffic on the Third Avenue elevated railroad as well as street car operations and automobile traffic to Brooklyn.

Five trade associations in the women's wear field were urged yesterday by Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, to restrain their members from pressing for greater discounts or other changes in the woolen fair trade practices.

REINSDORF, Germany, June 13. -- This village lay almost in ruins tonight, the victim of the greatest catastrophe in Central Germany's history. An explosion in the great Westphalian and Anhalt munitions works suddenly spread death and disaster to an extent that I cannot yet estimate.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 13. -- Captain Richard A. Devereaux of the 107th Infantry, Manhattan, who for several years has been one of the crack shots of the New York State National Guard, scored a perfect score of 100 at Camp Smith here today in the firing of the Governor's Cup.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- In a blaze Of color and pyrotechnics, the annual council of the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine ended tonight with a parade and great illuminated pageant.

Schemes and "rackets" to raise money for the support of Lutheran churches will hereafter be prohibited if a report of a special committee appointed a year ago to study the method of financing churches is accepted at the seventh annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP). -- The Cubs battled to a double triumph over the Phillies today by scores of 12 to 6 and 9 to 7.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 13 (AP). -- David Clendenin of Ardsley-on-Hudson, a graduate student at Yale, was fined $50 and placed on probation today in Superior Court here for his activities as a picket in the recent strike at the Colt's Patent Firearms Manufacturing Company.

Charles R. Gay, president of the Stock Exchange, is in Washington today to make the acquaintance of officers of the Securities and Exchange Commission. While in the capital he is not likely to use the residence at 2,416 Tracy Place which the Exchange leased a year ago for its headquarters in the capital.

Details of a temporary reorganization plan for the Chicago North Western Railroad, calling for a scaling down of interest charges over a five-year period, were presented yesterday to important holders of the company's bonds by Fred W. Sargent, president of the road, at a meeting in the offices of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

MOSCOW, June 13. -- Whether Europe will be torn by another war or be permitted to develop in peace will be decided within the next two years, in the opinion of Eduard Benes, Czechoslovak Foreign Minister.

Charles Kullman, American tenor, who has sung leading roles in Vienna, Salzburg, Berlin and London, has been engaged for the Metropolitan Opera for next season by Edward Johnson, general manager. Mr. Johnson, who is in London, cabled the announcement to the Opera House yesterday.

Bill Terry called upon Hal Schumacher and Leroy Parmelee for mound duty at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the pair of aces hurled the Giants to a double victory over the troublesome Reds before 10,000 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- The indifference of the average citizen was blamed for "the many deplorable conditions now existing" in an address by Scott M. Loftin, president of the American Bar Association, at the commencement exercises of Temple University today.
BOSTON, June 13 (AP). -- Deacon Danny MacFayden, making his first start in a Boston Braves' uniform, turned back the world champion St. Louis Cardinals today by a 3-1 margin.

MEXICO, D.F., June 13. -- "We protest energetically the declarations of General Plutarco Elias Calles published in today's press and declare we will defend the rights of the workers, especially that of declaring strikes, and will not desist from our aim for the economic and social improvement of wage earners."

The Phelps Dodge Corporation has reacquired 290,000 shares of its capital stock from the National Electric Products Corporation in settlement of "certain employe obligations,'' raising the company's total of treasury stock to 379,001 shares, it was disclosed yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange in its monthly report of reacquired stock.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 13 (AP). -- Electrical workers of the Toledo Edison Company, who returned to work on instructions of their International officers last Thursday after an eighteen-hour strike, voted tonight to renew the strike immediately and began picketing the plants.

Continued growth of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church, which annually pays out more than $1,000,000 to clergymen, their widows and orphans, was reported yesterday in the annual statement of its officers.
James J. Braddock has lifted himself, virtually by his own bootstraps, to the heavyweight championship of the world.

Lieutenant Henry A. Sebastian, former West Point football player, was tried by court-martial at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday on a charge of having sworn falsely and willfully that he was not married to Harriet Hagman Sebastian, former Vanities dancer, while he was a cadet at the Military Academy.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange eased several times yesterday to only a point or two above the low marks made late last week, the market met trade price-fixing orders in July on every slight recession, and a late recovery left the list unchanged to 4 points higher than on Wednesday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 13. -- Seventeen members of the West Point graduating class took wives today in the annual post-commencement marital rush.
Max Baer scaled 209 1/2 pounds and James J. Braddock 191 3/4 for the fight at the Madison Square Garden Bowl last night.

ROME, June 13. -- Wide currency is being given abroad to various reports of negotiations between Italy, Britain and France for the solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy on the basis of concessions by Ethiopia either to these three powers or to Italy alone.

REINSDORF, Germany, June 13. -- Reinsdorf, hunting for its dead in the sizzling hot wreckage amid the acrid smell of burning powder after today's blasts, resembled a bombarded village on a front line area tonight.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 13. -- Four Americans marooned on Cocos Island may be infected with treasure fever and not want to leave the place, it was indicated by information obtained here today. Captain Theodore Freeman, owner of the burned sloop Skukum, in a statement sent from Cocos says he requested a tuna fisher on April 26 to notify the United States Navy of the plight of the four men.

TRENTON, June 13. -- Federal Judge Philip Forman held the Mayor and four Councilmen of Asbury Park in contempt today for ignoring his order in their preparation of the city's budget. At the same time the court granted a defense motion dismissing the complaint against three other city officials.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Unless President Roosevelt acts within the next twenty-four hours to convene a meeting of bituminous coal operators and mine workers, a nation-wide bituminous coal strike affecting about 450,000 workers will go into effect on June 16.

MEXICO, D.F., June 13. -- A nation-wide general strike was threatened by Mexico's twelve most powerful labor organizations today as an answer to former President Plutarco Elias Calles's asserted anti-labor declarations Tuesday.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 13 (Canadian Press). -- A drop of more than $3,000,000 in deposits of the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday is shown in the bank's statement issued today. The reserve in United States funds for the same period declined more than $2,225,000.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Illinois members of the United Mine Workers of America tonight prepared to join the nation-wide strike called for June 16 after submitting to State operators demands for a thirty-hour week and 10 per cent increase in wages.
NANKING, China, Friday, June 14. -- The Nanking civil authorities have put the decision on the Chino-Japanese situation in North China up to Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 13. -- The commencement dance of the Taft School was held tonight in the school gymnasium, as the forerunner of the commencement exercises tomorrow in the Bingham auditorium. The Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, Dean Emeritus of Yale Divinity School, will make the graduation address and Horace D. Taft, headmaster, will present the diplomas.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13. -- For the first time this year the Hudson felt the blades of all the crews entered in the intercollegiate regatta of next Tuesday Morning and afternoon, Navy's varsity, junior varsity and plebes joined in the double rowing as sixteen eights dodged their way among ferries up and down the course.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Buying power in the grain markets was light today and prices on the Board of Trade dropped to new low levels for the season on all deliveries of wheat, rye and barley and on September and December oats before short covering checked the decline.

LONDON, June 13. -- Ambassador Tsuneo Matsudaira communicated to the Foreign Office today Japan's acknowledgment of the receipt from the British Government of its summary of the proceedings in last week's Anglo-German naval talks. Acknowledgment was also received from the United States today, leaving only France and Italy to be heard from.
Only 3,000 fans watched the Dodgers defeat the Pirates, 3 to 0, yesterday, but they were treated to some real thrills.

With the directors of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation scheduled to reach a final decision today regarding interest due on July 1 on the company's bonds, it was said in authoritative quarters yesterday that Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, had gone over the question thoroughly with officers and directors of the company for the last six weeks.

Referring to the letter of Thomas C.T. Crain suggesting broader powers for the Supreme Court of the United States "to declare by unanimous vote within thirty days after the enactment of a Federal law that an emergency existed making a speedy adjudication as to its constitutionality a matter of public importance," I beg to differ with the learned justice as to the advisability of such broader powers.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- President Roosevelt at a conference with House leaders overrode their advice in insisting that the House pass a holding company bill providing for dissolution and that the House accept the Borah amendment to the NRA extension resolution as passed by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- On the heels of an all-night session through which the Senate sat before it could smash Senator Long's filibuster against the NRA, one man again today (this time a member of the House) blocked the combined efforts of the Senate, President Roosevelt and the Democratic leadership of the House to legalize the skeleton NRA.

Enrolment in engineering and architectural courses in the universities and colleges of the country during the last five years has fallen about 25 to 35 per cent as a result of unemployment in these fields, while students in medical schools have increased, according to registration figures made available yesterday.

Primed for the supreme achievement of his career, Glenn Cunningham arrived here yesterday for the Princeton invitation meet, where once more he will pit his foot-racing speed, strength and intelligence against time in the classic mile.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 13. -- John Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer, is still standing off Sheriff C. Wesley Collins, who has been trying for five months to arrest him. Crempa was almost caught last night by three private detectives, who had been hired by the Sheriff to make the arrest, but the farmer's wife, son, daughter and neighbors rescued him from the law's clutches.

The largest number of relief fraud cases to be heard in the courts in any week since the Home Relief Bureau was established will come up today when twenty-one such cases will be presented. The largest calendar of relief fraud prosecutions heretofore was twenty cases.

PARIS, June 13. -- As the Ministers were assembling this morning at the Elysee Palace for the first meeting of Pierre Laval's new Cabinet Philippe Marcombes, Minister of Education was suddenly taken ill and died within a few minutes.

There is still some confusion about Ethel Barrymore s plans for next season. It was reported here last Monday that S.E. Cochran, manager of the National Theatre in Washington, was fairly aglow to send her on tour in "The Constant Wife."

TOKYO, Friday, June 14. -- The unceremonious departure from Peiping for Nanking yesterday of Ho Ying-ching, Chinese War Minister, injects an unforeseen element into the North China situation that is causing great concern to the Japanese Government as well as to the army on the spot.
