WITTENBERG, Germany, June 13. -- Fifty-two dead, seventy-five injured seriously and 300 injured lightly was the official estimate of casualties in the explosion at the Westphalian and Anhalt explosive works issued tonight by Otto Heidenreich, Nazi district leader, speaking on behalf of the government.

Little boys and girls were among the pickets outside the Board of Education building day before yesterday. At one point in the proceedings as chronicled in our news columns yesterday the elder pickets raised the cry, "We demand academic freedom!" The little ones were not found wanting. "We demand epidemic freedom!" they piped.

A penitentiary sentence of not more than three years was imposed by General Sessions Judge Donnellan yesterday on David Rudin, 35 years old, a lawyer, of 368 East Fifty-first Street, who formerly had a lucrative practice at 11 West Forty-second Street.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 13. -- Pennsylvania scored its third Eastern Intercollegiate League victory today, downing Cornell, 11 -- 10, on Center Fielder Bill Shanahan's home run off Phil Prose with none out in the last half of the ninth. Penn was the "home" team and will meet Cornell again tomorrow.
BILOXI, Miss., June 13. -- The conference of Governors opened here today with a bitter argument over the issue of Federal "dictation" to the States on work relief.

EAST WILLISTON, N.Y., June 13. -- Pete Ladislaw, who is in the United States Postal Department working on the night shift, came direct from his labors today and won the qualifying medal in the Long Island amateur championship at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.

Price declines were numerous in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar was an exception. It continued its advance and retained early gains despite dull trading. The market as a whole was more active. On the cash markets, all the grains were lower, while tin and rubber were higher.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 13. -- Governor Cross today signed the bill authorizing Fairfield County to issue $15,000,000 bonds so that $14,000,000 may be obtained from the Federal Government for the completion of Merritt Parkway in two or three years instead of the expected fifteen years.

Bids submitted by ten contractors for the construction of the New York approach and plaza of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel were opened yesterday before a large crowd in the commerce building of the Port of New York Authority. They ranged from $2,720,304 to $3,873,624.

After driving the yacht Bohemia, sinking after a collision in the Lower New York Bay Channel, full speed ahead to the side of the tugboat J.A. Williams, Captain William P. Carey, 57-year-old skipper of the Bohemia, a fishing boat, safely effected the transfer of her thirty passengers and six members of the crew at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Senator Long had two purposes in his filibuster, purposes unusual in the history of this form of legislative obstruction made possible by the rules of the United States Senate. He wanted, first, to reestablish his "nuisance value," damaged about two weeks ago when the Senate let him talk himself' down on another matter.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, June 13. -- The trial of thirty-nine leaders of the Estonian Front, soldiers' league, who are charged with unconstitutional activities, caused a sensation today when the president of the court-martial announced that the chief witness for the prosecution, a police official named Pipsar, had been taken ill and had disappeared.

The retirement of George F. Robinson as executive secretary of the Seamen's House Y.M.C.A. and the appointment of Clifford W. Petitt as his successor were announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the board of managers. Mr. Petitt has been serving as business secretary of the West Side Y.M.C.A.
DETROIT, June 13 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges pitched the Tigers to a 6-1 victory over the Red Sox today and at the same time stretched his winning streak to nine straight games.

The Roosevelt administration's leadership in the depression was declared a failure and business and industry were summoned to resume their normal role in the direction of the nation's economic life last night in a resolution adopted by the Union League Club at its monthly meeting in its quarters, Park Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Samuel Moscowitz, a retail fish dealer at 5 Belmont Avenue, Brooklyn, testifying yesterday for the government at the trial of twenty-seven defendants accused of violating the anti-trust law in the freshwater fish market, told Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson and a jury a story of what he said had happened to him when he tried to defy the alleged trust.

Collection of at least $1,000,000 in unpaid State income taxes owed by members of the staff of more than 140,000 New York City employes was predicted yesterday as the result of a collection drive begun by the State Tax Department in cooperation with the Finance Department of the city.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13. -- Dredging more than 2,000 feet below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, a Harvard University expedition has succeeded in taking fossil-bearing rock from the cliffs of the North American continental shelf for the first time.

WITTENBERG, Germany, Friday, June 14. -- Wittenberg, the old Luther town, was shaken to its foundations yesterday by an explosion that blew up part of the plant of the Westphalian and Anhalt Explosive Works in the suburb of Reinsdorf, fifty-two miles southwest of Berlin, with a toll of dead and injured whose total must still be ascertained.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses is to drop his revised plans for improving Riverside Park north of Eighty-third Street if the Board of Estimate at today's meeting decides against his ideas.
BUCHAREST, Rumania. June 13. -- The important question of fortification of the Dardanelles and the straits will be raised in concrete form at the Balkan Entente conference beginning next Thursday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13. -- Fifty students will receive degrees at the seventh annual commencement tomorrow of the Mercer Beasley School of Law of the University of Newark, which will be held at the Newark School of Fine and Industrial Arts on High Street. Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker, who will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws, will make the commencement address.

Free concerts under the auspices of the city's Emergency Relief Bureau will be presented tonight by the Greenwich Sinfonietta at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn, the Bronx Symphony Orchestra at Flushing High School and the Harlem String Trio at the 135th Street Branch Y.M.C.A.

A sharp gain in retail package deliveries for the week ended June 9, when the total rose 12 per cent over the same period a year ago, was reported yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the four weeks ended on that date the deliveries, made for approximately 260 stores in the metropolitan area, showed an increase of 5 per cent.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 13. -- Princeton pulled the championship of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association out of the fire today and with it the MacMillan trophy, but not before its two boats had experienced Long Island Sound weather of the most capricious sort.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 13. -- The Hitler regime is not disseminating propaganda "in the American sense of the word," Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the German Department at New Jersey College for Women, testified here today before a special committee of Rutgers University trustees.

Bond trading on the Stock Exchange slackened yesterday, prices holding steady except in the foreign group. French Government 7 1/2s declined 3 1/2 points on a small turnover, and Nord Railways also were weak. Other foreign issues ended with slight changes.

Relief at the signing of a peace treaty by Paraguay and Bolivia will be felt everywhere. The war between them has been one of the most insensate ever known. Its causes and objects were never well defined, and the long struggle in and out of an almost impossible terrain has been bloody and exhausting beyond all reckoning.
Sneak thieves stole $10,700 in Liberty bonds at 1:30 P.M. yesterday from a draft clerk's cage in the branch of the National City Bank at Grand Street and Bowery.
ISTANBUL, June 13. -- The law forbidding ecclesiastics of all sects in Turkey to wear clerical dress except at religious services took effect today.

The seven-week General Sessions felony trial of John A. Dilliard, former president of the State Title and Mortgage Company, nearly ended in a mistrial yesterday because of a remark made by Victor House, Special Assistant District Attorney, in summing up.

The proposal of the six electric companies of the Consolidated Gas System to raise to $2.50 the present monthly demand rate of $1 for commercial service was taken up by the Public Service Commission yesterday. The proposal is one element in the new rate set-up recently submitted to the commission.

TIENTSIN, June 13. -- Admitting the massing of a formidable force at Shanhaikwan, on the Manchuria-North China border, a high Japanese official declares this is "mere ly a precautionary measure against emergencies."

DETROIT, June 13 (AP). -- Head Play, Mrs, Silas B. Mason's star performer, raced to an easy victory today over Stand Pat, the place horse, and Azucar in the featured $5,000 Derby Week Handicap at a mile and an eighth.
NEWARK, June 13. -- The Bears got good pitching from an unexpected source today and defeated the Montreal Royals, 4 to 2, to even up the four-game series.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 13. -- Dick Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., today celebrated his first golf tournament appearance since playing in the British amateur championship with a sub-par round of 71 that won the qualifying medal in the Westchester amateur title competition.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Commitments to prisons, many the result of Liquor Law violations, are averaging 250 weekly above the corresponding period of last year and the Federal prison population at the end of May was 15,957, Attorney General Cummings stated today.

The large old-fashioned handkerchief with ample area for mopping a perspiring brow was the most popular article of wearing apparel yesterday as a piercing sun beat down on the city in the hottest day of the Year so far.

HONOLULU, June 13. -- The giant seaplane Pan American Clipper roared into Pearl Harbor at 6:26 A.M. (11:56 A.M. Eastern Standard Time) today, completing its second flight from California in perfect condition to blaze an air trail further across the Pacific to the Midway Islands.
The attempt of officials of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club to prevent disclosure in court of its financial affairs and contracts with minor league clubs failed yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- The first of 3,000 alumni arrived here today for their annual reunion week-end. They registered at their class headquarters, located in dormitories, hotels and even firehouses and garages.

NEWTON, Mass., June 13. -- Aided by excellent support on the part of his mates, Bob Roundy, Dartmouth hurler, twirled the Eastern Intercollegiate League champions to a 6-3 victory over Boston College at the Heights today.

LONDON, June 13 (AP). -- Three of England's four top-ranking women tennis players joined Mrs. Helen Wills Moody in she semi-finals of the Kent tournament today and thus made possible two successive days of the most strenuous competition the Californian yet has encountered in her come-back campaign.

MODANE, France, June 13. -- Expelled from Italy after having been arrested in his office last night by Italian secret police and held incomunicado for two hours David Darrah, for nine years Rome correspondent for The Chicago Tribune, arrived in this frontier town from Turin late this afternoon.

Twenty-five years ago CHARLES K. HAMILTON flew from New York to Philadelphia and return to win a prize of $10,000 offered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Philadelphia Public Ledger. It took him, all told, a day. Yesterday Captain EDDIE RICKENBACKER commemorated the anniversary of that performance by completing the same double journey in 58 minutes and 35 seconds.

New York City sold short-term home and work relief securities amounting to $6,700,000 yesterday at an interest rate of 1 1/4 per cent, according to Controller Frank J. Taylor. The financing was arranged through a city-wide banking group. The certificates of indebtedness were dated June 15 and are due on Oct. 15.

PARIS, June 13. -- Surprise and some consternation are expressed in the French press today at the German proposal in conversations with Great Britain that the German fleet should have a ratio of 35 per cent of the British strength in all categories.

Tomorrow is the deadline for payment of the second instalment on Federal and State income taxes, officials here warned yesterday. State returns, if not filed in person, may be mailed up to midnight, but the Federal quarterly instalment must be in the mails in time to be delivered before midnight.
TACOMA, Wash., June 13 (AP). -- A new tip in the hunt for William Mahan and his supposed sack of Weyerhaeuser ransom money spurred a weary army of police and Federal agents to fresh activity tonight.
The wholly unexpected happened last night under a hazy moon in the Madison Square Garden Bowl, which spreads over Long Island City's acres.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the concluding session of their four-day convention today passed a resolution which endorsed the American Retail Federation and empowered their board of directors to decide the question of affiliation with the federation.

Tears of happiness and relief streamed down the face of Mrs. James J. Braddock last night as the radio in the homo of her parents at 50 Twenty-fifth Street, Guttenberg, N.J., conveyed the news that she was the wife of the new heavyweight champion of the world, the man whom all the experts said would be beaten by Max Baer.

BUDAPEST, June 13. -- Erwin Garami, whose father, Ernest Gar-] ami, a former Cabinet Minister, died a few weeks ago, revealed today that a police captain had challenged him to a duel after beating him in a police station.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Hope was expressed today at the Securities and Exchange Commission that applications for registration by brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets would be speeded up as a result of the warning yesterday by Chairman Kennedy that in cases where the filings were delayed beyond July 1 the commission might not have time to examine and pass upon them by Aug. 1.

Max Beer's dilly-dallying and clowning caught up with him in the ring and he was unable to break the jinx that has toppled every champion who tried to defend his title in the great arena at Long Island City. So he lost the world's heavyweight championship to a determined and serious Jimmy Braddock.

Lily Pons, French soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, returned yesterday from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after seven weeks in France and England. She sang four times at the Opera in Paris, three of them opera appearances and the other a concert, and in England she gave the only command performance of the King's Jubilee celebration, singing at Covent Garden.

Well, I had a clear score to Philadelphia, anyway, and, taking all things into consideration, I think I had a clear score coming back. What happened to me at South Amboy differed in no wise from what daily befalls many automobilists. The porcelain in one of my spark plugs broke and I had to come to earth to replace it.
Efforts to speed the adoption of voluntary codes by industry will be taken at a number of meetings, scheduled for today and the rest of the month, according to announcements from a number of groups.

Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney gave a large theatre party last night at Radio City Music Hall for the midnight showing of the new Technicolor film "Becky Sharp," which had its premiere earlier in the day. Mr. Whitney is president of Pioneer Pictures, Inc., which produced the film.

PARIS, June 13. -- Nothing new transpiring on the government's fiscal projects, financial circles here concentrated attention today on the balance sheet of the Bank of France for the week ended on June 7, which contains graphic evidence of abnormal monetary tension.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Congressional leaders heard from President Roosevelt's own lips today his insistence upon prompt enactment of the NRA extension, Wagner Labor Disputes, Guffey Coal and Transportation Coordinator Extension Bills.

Betting on the outcome of the baer-Braddock fight was lighter than ever recorded in a heavyweight championship encounter, With Baer a prohibitive favorite at odds of 6 to 1, little money on Braddock was forthcoming. There even were bids of as high at 8 -- 1 and 10 -- 1.

The administration of criminal justice in the United States is still a disgrace today, as it was when former President Taft so characterized it during his term as Chief Justice, according to The Federal Juror, official publication of the Federal Grand Jury Association for the Southern District of New York.

The Lady of the Fountain, dispenser of mythical largess from a pedestal overlooking Fifth Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street, emerged yesterday from two years of enforced retirement behind a high green fence.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- A complete "new deal" for the White House kitchen, including rearrangement from the present inconvenient plan so as to bring it into harmony with the most advanced household ideas, was announced today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as one of her foremost Summer plans.

THE English critics are at it again. Delia Kuhn tells me that "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" fell flat in critical London, but here we have an average piece of melodramatic entertainment, "Cat Across the Path," by Ruth Feiner (Lippincott, $2.50), brought to American readers with a garland of accompanying plaudits by Sylvia Lynd, Compton MacKenzie, James Hilton, James Laver, C.E. Bechhofer Roberts and Ralph Straus.

BERLIN, June 13. -- After a seven month trial, the Berlin Appellate Court today rendered judgment against eight former managers of the governmental radio system, who had been charged with corruption and denounced by the Nazi press as representatives of the corrupt and decadent liberalistic system that the Nazis had abolished.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- A slight decline in wholesale prices during the week ending June 8 pushed the composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics down to 79.9 as compared with 80.2 for the preceding week. It stood at 73.8 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -- Physical exhaustion after fifteen and one-half hours of speaking terminated Senator Long's latest and longest Senate filibuster, but parliamentary strategy played a part.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Hall gave a farewell dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza before Mrs. Hall and her daughter, Miss Frances Hall, sailed on the Bremen. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Atcheson Harden, Mr. and Mrs. George Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Beebe, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sykes and Mrs. Oswald Kirkby.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP). -- West Main, C.A. Peck's 5-year-old son of Westwick-Mantle, got up just in time today to annex his fifth straight victory at Washington Park, conquering the Blue Ridge Farm's Dusky Devil, in the feature event at a mile.

MELBOURNE, June 14. -- The statues of the American-born sculptor, Jacob Epstein, in the Strand, London, whose projected removal from the new offices of the government of Southern Rhodesia has caused a controversy, may find a home in Australia.

There are no secrets of golfing success, according to Sam Parks Jr. of Pittsburgh, who skyrocketed to golf fame by winning the United States open last week. Concentration and confidence, according to the new champion, are the chief factors in winning tournaments.

Representatives of about twenty insurance companies and savings banks will meet officials of the Chicago North Western Railway on Tuesday in an endeavor to reconcile their views on a plan of the company for a deferment of interest.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Senate consideration of the Administration Social Security Bill began today, with early passage in substantially the form adopted by the House confidently expected, despite the announced purpose of Senator Long to make it the vehicle for his first major attempt to enact any part of his share-the-wealth program.

TROY, June 14 (AP). -- Granville Hicks, ousted Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute faculty member, will collect his last pay check tomorrow and leave for his Summer home at Grafton, where he will devote his time to writing.

I was interested in the news item published a few days ago telling how a physician prescribed a gift of a dog to his boy patient as a cure for a most serious illness. Several years ago our family physician did this very thing for my son with remarkable results.

A hearing of a subcommittee of the Mayor's commission on conditions in Harlem, held in the Seventh District Municipal Court, 447 West 151st Street, was broken up by a near riot yesterday afternoon when a court attendant, acting under orders from Municipal Court Justice Charles E. Toney, a Negro member of the commission, who presided, attempted to eject a Negro spectator from the court room.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14. -- Stories of a minor gland transplantation that enabled a man to grow a mustache, and another that caused a girl midget to grow an inch taller in three months, were told in technical reports here today at the meeting of the Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14. -- Yale's varsity crew had another four-mile speed trial tonight, the second distance test on the Thames River course since the oarsmen arrived from New Haven last Sunday.

Second-grade railroad bonds continued their advance yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The rise was somewhat more selective than on previous days, but gains of 1 to 3 points were made. Utility issues recovered from their recent weakness.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., June 14. -- Lawrenceville School opened its 125th commencement week-end tonight with the annual Spring declamation contest, at which John Woods, Archibald C. Rogers and Lorton Livingston were prize winners. Tomorrow afternoon diplomas will be awarded to 124 boys.
CONCORD, N.H., June 14. -- St. Paul's School graduated a class of seventy-four at exercises held in the chapel this evening when Reeve Schley of New York, president of the corporation, spoke briefly.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The filing of registration applications by brokers and dealers in the overthe-counter markets continues to lag, it was said today at the Securities and Exchange Commission. Only about 1,500 have been received out ou an estimated number of 8,000 to 10,000.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, paid his first visit to the offices of the Securities and Exchange Commission today and after a talk with Chairman Kennedy said that the present Exchange management was ready to cooperate with the commission.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14. -- Dr. Lienhard Bergel, German instructor at the New Jersey College for Women, who has charged that he is being dropped from the faculty because his anti-Nazi views conflict with those of Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the department, denied tonight that he has any sympathy with communism.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP). -- The Red Sox, paced by Bill Werber's two home runs, defeated the Tigers, 10 to 8 today even though the champions, with last year's pennant waving over their heads for the first time, collected almost twice as many hits.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14. -- One hundred and seventy-nine Princeton seniors will be graduated with honors next Tuesday, it was announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar. Of this number, twenty-four will receive highest honors, forty-nine high honors and the remainder honors.

Three hundred college and high school students of the city attended an anti-war meeting last night in Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street, east of Third Avenue, under the auspices of the Metropolitan Student Defense Committee.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 14. -- State troopers will enforce Oklahoma's prohibition laws after July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP). -- Curt Davis, ace of the Phillies last year, made his first start of the season today and gained a 5-4 triumph over the Cubs. Davis, who has been troubled with a sore arm ever since the season opened, permitted eleven hits but was strong in the pinches.

Flags fluttered in the warm breeze and a score of bands played in the canyons of Lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon during the colorful parade staged by the Sons of the Revolution as a part of their eighteenth annual observance of Flag Day.

Allow us to congratulate you on your able editorial on "Baldwin and Mussolini." The impasse which it has created between the great Italian Government and the world's most distinguished newspaper is of deed historical significance. The principle of freedom of the press and the freedom of speech is tested again in a celebrated case.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 14. -- The newly elected Parliament met today to consider the proposal of the mandates committee that opposition mandates should not be confirmed. After Interior Minister Popovitch, who arranged the recent elections, had spoken in support of the proposal, Deputy Janko Barichevitch moved that all opposition mandates be canceled because the members had announced their intention not to attend Parliament because of the alleged terror and corruption during the elections.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week aggregates $13,678,949, based on the latest computations, and compare with the revised total of $47,897,290 this week. The weekly average for the year to date now is $25,314,253.
WINDSOR, Conn., June 14. -- Eighty-nine diplomas will be awarded to members of the graduating class of the Loomis School tomorrow in the school chapel.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP). -- An order directing John G. Lonsdale, co-trustee of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad, to file suits against Speyer Co., J. W. Seligman Co., E.N. Brown, chairman of the Frisco board, and others to recover losses sustained by the road in stock purchases, was issued today by Federal Judge Charles B. Earls.

Senator LONG is said to have uttered a dire threat against Senator ROBINSON on one occasion. He would go into the State of Arkansas and undermine Senator ROBINSON'S position with the plain people by calling their attention to the fact that their Senator wears a vest edged with white piping in the Buckingham Palace style.

High temperatures spurred trade in Summer goods in the metropolitan area during the week and increases ranging up to 4 or 5 per cent over the same period last year were estimated for leading stores here. The demand covered the broadest variety of Summer items thus far this season and cut radically into some stocks.

Federal laws governing the inspection of merchant ships were declare inadequate in an address yesterday by Joseph B. Weaver, director of the United States Steamboat Inspection Service, before the Maritime Law Association of the United States. About 300 lawyers associated with the marine law and ship designers and builders attended the meeting aboard the Italian liner Rex.

Unable to meet an interest obligation of $1,270,000 on its bonds due on July 1, the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court asking authority to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 14. -- South Bend citizens, who forgot Notre Dame and football to watch the stars of the fairways open the battle for the Western open golf championship today, went home cheering an old familiar name -- Schwartz.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14. -- Another flurry of time rows today featured the practice sessions among the crews preparing for Tuesday's intercollegiate regatta. The Pennsylvania and Cornell varsities both went the full four miles downstream, and tonight Navy's three crews rowed three miles upstream, at a beat of 32 strokes to the minute.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York, and Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, are among the passengers sailing today on the Champlain of the French Line. Others are:
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, June 14 (AP). -- General Hugh S. Johnson told farmers from three States tonight that "the same forces that destroyed NRA are going to try to get the AAA by the same tactics."
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 14. -- The annual Westchester County horse show opened this morning on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here.

Last year 103 hospitals had to close their doors for lack of funds with which to carry on. In 1928 we had 6,825 registered institutions; but in the five years that followed 388 of them were forced out of service. Adding the loss for 1934, we find that in six years nearly five hundred hospitals were driven to the wall.

Summer temperatures continued here yesterday, although Thursday's high for the year -- 87 degrees -- was not reached. Warm winds blowing from the south and a bright sun drove the mercury to 85, the high for the day, at 3:15 o'clock in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Acting at almost the last minute to avert a threatened strike of 450,000 bituminous coal miners Sunday night, President Roosevelt at a White House conference today arranged a truce until June 30. The present terms of the wage contract will continue in effect pending Congressional action on the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill.

" Will Organized Labor's Demands Promote Recovery?" was the subject of a debate in America's Town Meeting series at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, under the auspices of the League for Political Education last night.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- With further changes designed to conform closely to the Supreme Court's decision in the Schechter case, amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act were unanimously reported today by the House Agriculture Committee.

EXETER, N.H., June 14. -- The annual prize night exercises of Phillips Exeter Academy were held tonight, with cash prizes totaling more than $950 and books, cups and other trophies distributed to students.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 14. -- Competing for the first time since his appearance in the British amateur, T. Suffern Tailer Jr., metropolitan amateur titleholder, today paired with Frank V. Burton Jr. and fashioned a sub-par 69, two under regulation figures, to tie W. Douglas Burden of Mount Kisco and Robert V. McKim of Meadow Brook for the medal in the qualifying round of the Piping Rock Club's annual invitation best-ball golf tournament.

By consent of the city, F. William Zelcer, Deputy Commissioner of Docks in Charge of Aviation, was brought in as a defendant yesterday in the city's suit to collect a $1,000 penalty assessed against the owner of a building at 112 West Forty-fifth Street because of arrests for prostitution on the premises.

Seventeen 1935 graduates of Lutheran theological seminaries have been accepted by the Rev. Dr. Ellis B. Burgess, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, for ordination next week in connection with the seventh annual convention which will be held in Jersey City beginning Monday evening and continuing through Thursday.

BUENOS AIRES, June 14. -- Hostilities in the Chaco ceased at noon today, exactly three years after the skirmish at Port Pitiantuta that started the war between Bolivia and Paraguay. The announcement of the cessation of fighting caused joyous celebrations throughout both Bolivia and Paraguay.
GROTON, Mass., June 14. -- Groton School today graduated twenty-nine young men, fourteen of them with honors.

The sharpest advances in recent weeks have occurred in the first grade industrial stocks, which yield from 3 to 4 per cent on the average. The relatively low return on these stocks prompts the question whence the demand for them is coming and whether they are not selling rather high in relation to earnings and prospects.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during May was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 469,250 bales of lint and 65,501 bales of linters, compared with 462,844 and 70,268 in April this year, and 519,299 and 63,448 in May last year.
In a letter, "The Ontario Hydro," published in THE TIMES, H.E. Patten tends to confuse the issues raised.

The Board of Education, at an unannounced special meeting on Thursday night, granted a request by Mayor La Guardia that the buildings of the New York Parental School in Flushing be turned over to the city to house mental defective patients now occupying a hospital on Randall's Island.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 14. -- Virginia defeated Brown, 12 -- 8, today, combining two singles, a double, a pass and two errors to score four runs in the thirteenth inning. The deciding markers were gained at the expense of Captain G. Alien Slader, the third Bruin hurler.

PARIS, June 14. -- It was possible to confirm today that part of the 4,355,000,000 franc increase in the discount portfolio of the Bank of France during the past month represents treasury bills which various banks discounted at the treasury's behest.

DANZIG, June 14. -- An appeal to all Danzig citizens and parties, including those whom the ruling National Socialist party until recently denounced as "separatists and traitors," to stand together in order to save Danzig's German character was voiced today by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, President of the Reichsbank, who arrived here to advise the Danzig Government on its currency difficulties resulting from the recent devaluation.

New offerings of bonds this week aggregated $17,106,000, all of the municipal classification, with the issues ranging in size from $8,400,000 to $70,000. Last week the total was $76,614,000, of which $55,000,000 represented corporation financing, and the balance State and municipal.
NEWARK, N.J. June 14. -- The Newark Bears won the opening game of their series with Rochester tonight, defeating the Red Wings, 5 to 3, before a crowd of 7,500.

A steady increase in the number of persons crossing the Hudson River into Manhattan by motor vehicles during the last decade despite a 10 per cent decline in all trans-Hudson passenger traffic was reported yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- The American Liberty League pledged itself tonight to fight to the last ditch any New Deal amendments to the Constitution to curtail State's rights or limit the powers of the Supreme Court.
OMAHA, Neb., June 14. -- An unidentified man was shot and killed and at least sixteen others were wounded tonight when rioting broke out in South Omaha for the third night in succession.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- The three-year investigation and prosecution growing out of the Insull financial crash ended today when Judge John C. Knox of the Federal court directed the jury in the third prosecution of Samuel Insull and his associates to return a verdict of not guilty.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

MINEOLA, L.I., June 14. -- Declaring that Rooseveltism is nothing more than Tammanyism with a Harvard accent, Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, predicted last night that the Republican nominee for President would defeat Roosevelt in 1936 and that the Republicans in this State would recapture the Assembly "by a handsome majority."

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- A possibility that the Omnibus Banking bill may be passed in separate sections, thus allowing swift enactment of those sections relating to Federal Deposit Insurance, and a chance, at least, of delay on Title 2, concerning Federal Reserve Board Authority, was seen when the Senate Banking subcommittee decided today to print the deposit insurance language in a separate bill.

HONOLULU, Saturday, June 15. -- The Pan American clipper will take off for Midway Island at 6 A.M. today from Pear Harbor. The flight is expected to take six or seven hours, according to J. Parker Van Zandt, the Pan American Airways representative here.

John A. Dilliard, president of the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company, who has been on trial for two months on an indictment charging that he published a false statement in February, 1933, of the company's financial status was found guilty early today of the third and fourth counts in the indictment, both charging a misdemeanor.

BILOXI, Miss., June 14 (AP). -- Voting confidence in President Roosevelt after refusing to go on record opposing Federal control of relief spending, the annual conference of Governors of the United States closed late today.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 14. -- Plans for a new $3,500,000 women's college at Middlebury were announced today. Construction of the first dormitory unit, to accommodate 125 women, a $350,000 project, will start this Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The administration policy to put 3,500,000 unemployed persons to work as quickly as possible through use of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief appropriation, cutting projects wherever necessary to fit the money available, was reasserted with new emphasis today by President Roosevelt.

Commodity futures were steadier in dull trading yesterday. Cocoa, coffee and sugar declined, while copper, cottonseed oil and wool tops advanced. On the cash markets gains were scored by wheat, rye, oats, flour, cotton and wool tops, while corn, rubber and coffee eased.

In a pamphlet entitled "What Price Dead Ducks?" and bearing the subheading "Shall There Be Some Waterfowl Left or None?" Dr. William T. Hornaday, director of conservation activities of the Permanent Wild Life Protection Fund, pleads for a closed season on waterfowl shooting in 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr. led the Philadelphia team to an overwhelming victory over Boston in the intercity Griscom Cup golf matches over the Huntingdon Valley course today, 12 to 3.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 14 (AP). -- A resolution recommending "careful consideration before divorcing home and work relief" was adopted today at the convention of the State Association of Public Welfare Officials.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP). -- Precursor, the Saddle Spur Stable's heavily played favorite, beat Sabula by half a length today to capture the $1,000 Highland Park Handicap, mile and one-sixteenth feature race at the Fair Grounds track.

WITTENBERG, Germany, June 14. -- According to an official announcement, forty-five bodies of workers who perished in yesterday's explosion at the Westphalia-Anhalt explosive works near here had been recovered by tonight, and rescue crews were searching the tangled mass of wrecked buildings for more.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- With an assertion that inclusion of the Anti-trust law amendment in the resolution extending the NRA provides a puzzle to business men in seeking NRA approval of voluntary trade agreements, Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, advised tonight that they turn to their trade associations and the Federal Trade Commission, which, he said, can eliminate unfair competition under existing laws.

Officials of companies manufacturing railway equipment have represented to the Washington administration that the government, as the leading creditor of the country's railroads, should initiate large-scale purchases of rolling stock, it developed yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale price in New York:

In describing the steady demand for stocks and bonds such as came into the markets yesterday, the seventh consecutive day in which the share market advanced, it may be necessary to distinguish between strictly investment buying and the purchasing that comes of the necessity of obtaining employment for idle funds -- funds which might be used elsewhere if satisfactory conditions obtained, as opposed to out-and-out speculative endeavor.

Rains over a large part of Texas for the fourth successive day and a prediction by Senator Bankhead that 13 cents a pound would be needed to cover loans and carrying charges and induce borrowers to release any substantial quantity of holdings resulted yesterday in a rise of 10 to 13 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange.

TACOMA, Wash., June 14 (AP). -- Nine-year old George Weyerhaeuser faced two of his alleged abductors in a reported identification attempt today while the hunt for William Mahan, a third suspect, went doggedly on in the Rocky Mountain West.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14. -- Circuit Court Judge William A. Smith entered a judgment today for $2,416,205 against Harry H. Weinberger of Passaic, founder and former president of the closed New Jersey Bankers Securities Company, in a suit brought by Nicholas L.A. Vecchia, receiver of the company, on an allegedly defaulted note given by Weinberger for $2,300,000, on Oct. 4, 1928.

For eight innings yesterday Lefty Bill Clark shut out the Pirates with one single and allowed only two more hits. But those two were doubles in the ninth and the Pirates took the game, 1 to 0, and the series by three games to one.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday that he had agreed to a conference at 11 A.M. Monday with the March New York County grand jury, which had investigated vice and racket conditions for several months. It was dismissed at its own request last Monday by General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig after District Attorney William C. Dodge had refused to designate a special prosecutor to continue the investigation.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 14. -- Defending his government's proposal to nationalize the purchase, storage and marketing of Canadian Western grain, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett told Parliament today that speculators had sold the government's wheat price-pegging agent, John I. McFarland, 35,000,000 bushels of Canadian wheat not at present in existence.

MEXICO, D.F., Saturday, June 15. -- The entire Mexican Cabinet resigned early this morning after a dispute over economic policies between President Lazaro Cardenas and former President Plutarco Elias Calles. The action climaxed a two-and-a-half-hour meeting of the Ministers behind closed doors at the Presidential Palace.

The Morosco will be without "Something Gay" and Tallulah Bankhead after tonight, and that is the sole departure from Broadway this week-end. The Adelaide Heilbron play opened on April 29 as a production of the Messrs. Shubert, from whom Miss Bankhead took over the management on June 3.

A Greek freighter that brought a cargo of coconut oil on Tuesday unloosed a swarm of insects which plagued the residents of Edgewater and Cliffside Park, N.J., yesterday and the day before and, carried by the wind, descended in vast numbers over lower Manhattan yesterday.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 14. -- Pleading for "the middle ground of common sense" in educational policy, Headmaster Claude M. Fuess declared today at the annual commencement exercises of Phillips Academy that in many "progressive" schools of the present day "softness and laxity have corrupted the recitation room."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 14. -- Rallying to save himself from defeat in the opening match-play round of the Westchester amateur golf championship, Willie Turnesa, 20-year-old member of the famous family of golfers gained the semifinal later today at the Sunningdale Country Club.

LONDON, June 14. -- Further intensification of London's air defenses will be made by the immediate conversion of eight territorial infantry regiments into anti-aircraft defense units, three forming new groups of anti-aircraft artillery and five forming searchlight units.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Legislation to carry out President Roosevelt's request for a permanent agency to take the place of the Petroleum Administrative Board wiped out by the Supreme Court's Schechter decision, was introduced today by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma in the form of a redraft of his Federal Petroleum Bill.

Encountering fewer impediments as the confusion of the two weeks preceding waned rapidly, trade continued to rise this week, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., which points out that the absence of serious labor disturbances and important changes in the price structure permitted freer operations in nearly all divisions.

On the advice of Dr. James H. Kimball, meteorologist of the United States Weather Bureau, George and Alfred de Monteverde, young Portuguese airmen, who were ready at Floyd Bennett Field to take off on a non-stop flight to Rome, postponed the hop indefinitely at 10:55 o'clock last night.

Most of those who have seen the new Technicolor picture at Radio City Music Hall, "Becky Sharp," have the sense of having been present at the birth of another revolution on the screen, comparable in importance to that which came with the first crude talking pictures.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14. -- Miss Lena Halpern of New York City, senior student in the Yale University School of Medicine, received today award of the Keese Prize for the most meritorious thesis. Miss Halpern took her B.A. degree at Hunter College and her M.A. degree at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Poland, Hungary, Latvia and Lithuania joined the war-debt defaulters today, announcing in notes to Secretary Hull that they were not paying their instalments due tomorrow, or their arrears.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The joint resolution extending the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act and the office of Coordinator a year beyond June 16 was signed by President Roosevelt today after the House had reversed the action of one of its major committees and restored a provision continuing an assessment of $2 a mile on railroads for financing of the Coordinator's office.

Puccini's "Tosca" will be performed under the management of Alfredo Salmaggi tonight in the Hippodrome. Principal parts will be taken by Della Samoiloff, Giuseppe Radaelli and Angelo Pilotto. Mr. Salmaggi will offer a twelve-week season of opera in the same theatre, beginning Sept. 12.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. William Dwight Symmes 2d of New York City presented to the trustees of Williams College today $6,000, to be used in any way the hoard desired, in memory of their son, William D. Symmes 3d, and his two classmates, Lloyd H. Crowfoot of Ashburnham and Julius Palmer of Providence, R.I., victims of the Ward liner Mohawk tragedy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14. -- Twenty-five million persons on relief in Canada and the United States are in danger of becoming unemployable by eating a relief diet too high in carbohydrates and too low in proteins for reasons of economy.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 14. -- A campus parade of nearly 1,600 alumnae today marked the Ivy Day ceremony at Smith College. The program ended tonight with the Smith College Glee Club giving a concert on floats anchored on Paradise Pond.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- A new demand for disciplinary action by the Navy Department against Rear Admiral Yales Stifling Jr., commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, for writing a newspaper article on warlike tendencies of Soviet Russia was promised today by Representative Marcantonio of New York after the House had tabled his original resolution.
CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP). -- Monte Pearson's wildness cost the Indians the final game of their series with Philadelphia today, the Athletics winning, 5 to 4.

WITTENBERG, Germany, June 14. -- When forty-five bodies had been brought out of the wreckage of the Westphalia-Anhalt munitions factory in Reinsdorf by tonight, officials said that only seven more dead remained hidden under the debris.

From his orange grove near Burriana, Huerta de la Cotorra (Plantation of the Parrot), Jose Iturbi sent by cable yesterday the program of the opening Stadium concert of the Summer season, when he will lead the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, on June 26.
TEANECK, N.J., June 14. -- The James Russell Lowell School, one of the first schools in the East to be built with Federal funds under the public works program, was dedicated here tonight.

The management of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad has agreed to surrender control of the line to the holders of its bonds in return for a reduction in its interest burden, according to an communication sent yesterday by the company to insurance companies and savings banks.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The Division of Applications of the Works Relief Program made public figures tonight to show that President Roosevelt had approved up to now allocations of $1,280,602,600 out of the $4,000,000,000 fund.

WEST POINT, June 14. -- The Thayer sesquientennial celebration opened here today and will continue for three days. The celebration is in honor of General Sylvanus Thayer, founder of the military academy, and members of seventy-five patriotic societies of this country are participating.
TOKYO, June 14. -- Conditions in Manchukuo, though improved, are still too disturbed to allow of a reduction in Japanese forces.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses illustrated his way of getting things done yesterday by awarding two construction contracts on the Henry Hudson Bridge over the Harlem Ship Canal barely four hours after the Board of Estimate had approved the approaches to the span.

Arthur V. Courtney, 29 years old, a Queens saloon keeper and former Sanitation Department employe, who was the go-between for John Flaherty, political "fixer" for persons seeking jobs through civil service, unexpectedly pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions.

PATRICK BALFOUR'S "Grand Tour" (Harcourt, Brace, $3.75) is the best thing of its kind since Peter Fleming's "Brazilian Adventure," now eighteen months old. Balfour and Fleming show many similarities in style. They write with a remarkable ease and they write remarkably well. Day in, day out, Balfour is the better reporter.

The three fastest milers in the long and tradition-studded history of foot-racing will match strides on the cinders at Palmer Stadium in Princeton this evening, prepared to add another epic chapter to the annals of the sport. When Jack Lovelock, Glenn Cunningham and Bill Bonthron flash over the finish line man probably will have come closer to the four-minute mile than he ever has before.

BERLIN, June 14. -- The crisis confronting Abraham Lincoln during the early months of his Presidency, which led to the Civil War, was discussed by Professor William E. Dodd, United States Ambassador, before members of the Carl Schurz Society of Berlin and its numerous American guests tonight.
MOSCOW, June 14. -- The mysterious wounding of Lyra, record milk-producing cow, gave rural detectives of Ivanovsky Province a puzzling case to unravel.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 14. -- Miss Elena Teresa Villa, daughter of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa, will be a debutante in Newport this Summer. She will be formally introduced at a dance to be given by her parents at Fairholme on Aug. 16, in tennis week.

TIENTSIN, China, June 14. -- If the hasty departure from Peiping for Nanking of Ho Ying-ching, Chinese War Minister, causes a political and administrative vacuum and paralysis of North China, "Japan will hold Nanking responsible, and by Nanking, of course, we mean Chiang Kai-shek, without whose sanction no measures can be made effective," said a Japanese diplomatic spokesman here today.

Cornelius F. Kelley, president of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, lost yesterday his fight to have his name removed from the list of qualified jurors in New York County when the Appellate Division reversed Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente's order striking Mr. Kelley's name from the list.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Our raw cotton exports in May amounted to 279,000 bales, valued at $18,247,000, as compared with 285,000 bales, worth $17,298,000, a year ago, the Textile Dixision of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack signed an order yesterday directing Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough, to pay $5,691,809 of interest on outstanding first mortgage bonds of the company. The payment will cover the six months ending July 1.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, stands out in the opinion of Republican National Committeemen, who have come here from the Grass Roots conference, as one of the leading candidates at present for the Republican Presidential nomination.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 14. -- A single by Johnny Mayer with two out in the ninth and men on third and second gave Cornell a 6-5 victory today and an even break in its two-day Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League series with Penn. The Ithacans dropped an 11-10 decision yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Reports that an important announcement would be made soon followed a White House conference today attended by Attorney General Cummings, Secretary Morgenthau, Solicitor General Reed and Herman Oliphant, general counsel of the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- President Roosevelt told newspaper men today that he was in general accord with the Guffey-Snyder Coal Stabilization Bill, and hoped that as a matter of sound policy the bituminous strike could be averted until the bill has been considered by Congress.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 14. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr., who left his Winter home in Ormond Beach, Fla., yesterday, arrived here late this afternoon on a special train, which stopped several hundred yards from the station to permit him to enter his waiting automobile and to avoid a crowd of more than 200 spectators and photographers waiting at the station platform.

LONDON, June 14. -- Miss Katherine Stammers, 21-year-old English girl, who is Great Britain's No. 3 ranking tennis player, upset Mrs. Helen Wills Moody in the semifinals of the Kent championships at Beckenham today by the crushing score of 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.
MOSCOW, June 14. -- Japan's new manoeuvres in North China are being watched here with silent concern. The depth of that concern is indicated by its very silence.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14. -- The Yale Dramatic Association tonight opened the 234th Yale commencement season by presenting in the University Theatre the classic Euripides drama, "Hippolytus," the Broadway actress, Selena Royle, portraying the role of Phaedra.

I venture to suggest that your Washton correspondent is in error in commending the British system of levies on estates and inheritances as "discriminating and non-confiscatory." On the death of the proprietor of a very large estate in Great Britain the Treasury levies 50 per cent of the total as death duties.
WARSAW, June 14. -- The financial crisis in Danzig caused by the devaluation of the gulden may develop into a first-class political crisis, as Poland's interests are at stake.

HONOLULU, June 13 (by Wireless). -- The latest flight of the Pan American Clipper over the California-Hawaii section of the trans-pacific air route to the Orient is an example of what air transport is capable of today -- mastering oceans through engineering foresight, scientific preparation and personnel training.

LONDON, June 14. -- The stock markets here were less active and irregular today, although there were some bright industrial features on the latest trade news and the publication of good reports and dividend statments. British funds generally improved further on fresh support.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 14 (AP). -- The Guarantee Trust Company of Atlantic City today asked the United States District Court for a stay in the execution of a judgment which would require it to pay interest on bonds of the Linwood Country Club of Atlantic City.

GENEVA, June 14. -- The United States workers' delegation submitted to the International Labor Organization conference today a resolution for it to study "those industries servicing the people's vital needs which by reason of under-consumption of their products are especially exposed to the stress of world competition."

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 14. -- Godfrey Preece of Westbury, L.I., had the honor of winning the first championship of the forty-second Westchester County Horse Show, which opened this morning on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club and will continue through tomorrow afternoon.

An annual saving of about $506,940 will result from a merger of the New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company, according to exhibits submitted to the Public Service Commission at a public hearing yesterday.

ALBANY, June 14. -- M.C. Cleveland, chief engineer of the Public Service Commission, has reported to the commission that there are 146 grade-crossing elimination projects, involving 278 crossings to cost over $53,000,000, to which Federal funds may be applied.

BERLIN, June 14. -- Scoring surprising one-sided victories in the opening singles matches, Germany's Davis Cup tennis team assumed a commanding lead over Australia today in their European zone semi-final series.

Ruth Eleanor McKee has received the gold medal of the Commonwealth Club of California for "The Lord's Anointed," selected as the best work of general literature written by a California author during the preceding year. It is a story of early missionaries in Hawaii, Miss McKee has delivered to Doubleday, Doran the manuscript for a second novel, "After a Hundred Years," which will be published in the Fall.

A handful of common sense is worth tons of speeches and resolutions about Federal centralization. If the tendency in that direction is to be stopped, says former Governor WINANT in Today, matters which are now within the authority of the States ought to be managed more efficiently.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Alleged negligence by ground employes of the Transcontinental Western Air Line, and a faulty weather prediction by the government forecasting service, were reported today by a Bureau of Air Commerce Accident Board to have been contributory causes of the crash of the TWA airliner Sky Chief, in Missouri May 6, in which Senator Bronson Cutting of New Mexico and four others were killed.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- A skeleton NRA, restricted solely to industrial research and effective until April 1, 1936, was legalized today when the House, after thirty-eight minutes of debate, accepted by a vote of 336 to 31 a Senate amendment to an extension resolution, and President Roosevelt affixed his signature.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 14. -- Although his crown tilted at a precarious angle twice today, A.W. (Laddie) Biggs, defending champion, is still in the thick of the fight for the Long Island amateur championship.
BOSTON, June 14 (AP). -- St. Louis and Boston split a double-header today, the Braves winning the first game, 5 -- 4, and the Cardinals the second, 8 -- 7, after a thirteen-inning struggle.

A year ago today James J. Braddock collected a purse of $250 from the Madison Square Garden Corporation for knocking out Corn Griffin in a preliminary to the world's heavyweight championship bout between Max Baer and Primo Carnera.

" Getting a skill," said Dr. John L. Elliott, is not the whole of education, but it is an important part of it, necessary under either communism or capitalism. He spoke last night at the closing exercises of the School for Printers' Apprentices and the School for Machine Typesetting at 220 West Nineteenth Street, which he helped found in 1912.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Oliver Buswell, president of Wheaton (Ill.) College, was placed on trial today before a Presbyterian Church court facing charges of failing to comply with a mandate of the General Assembly of that church.

Summer very definitely clamped down its hot hand upon nocturnal celebrations during the past week, sending those inflexible customers who persist to the al fresco havens in the suburbs, the sky-top roofs and those oases which boast -- along with other attractions -- of air-conditioning systems.
Sales and leases of a vacant plot, various dwellings and tenement houses and a hotel comprised realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

MONTREAL, June 14 (AP). -- Finding that there was "no prima facie proof of conspiracy," Judge Jules Desmarias today dismissed charges against the four Bronfman brothers, Allan, Harry, Abraham and Sam; F.S. Blair, David Costley and Barney Aaron, all of Montreal, and William Yule, Halifax.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Buying of wheat against sales of corn to close spreads, with a let-up in the persistent liquidation of the last two days, resulted today in a higher level of prices for the major grain on the Board of Trade. Wheat never met much pressure and closed around the best figures of the day at net gains of 1 1/4 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois was cleared today by Secretary Dern of charges preferred against him by the House Military Affairs Committee, but was reprimanded for "incorrect, unfair and misleading statements" in his testimony before the committee. He is not being removed as chief of the army Air Corps, as demanded by the committee after a long investigation last year into army procurement methods.
LONDON, June 14. -- Denials in the diplomatic world are of current use when a situation is delicate and premature publication is believed prejudicial to the success of negotiations.

Much has been written about the decorative character of the new subway stations to be opened in a few days in Newark. Photographic reproductions of the new Moscow subway also show very elaborate treatment of stations.

POTSDAM, Germany, June 14. -- There wasn't a more surprised person in the world today over Jimmy Braddock's rise to the heavyweight boxing championship than a former titleholder, Max Schmeling, but when the German battler regained his composure he announced he was willing now to go to America, provided he could meet Braddock in a title match.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Despite bearish reports regarding the demand for fresh pork and with top loins here reduced 1/2 cent a pound to 23 cents, a decline of 3 cents a pound in two weeks, sufficent shipping demand developed for the small offerings of hogs in the market here today to lift the price of selected offerings, averaging under 225 pounds, as much as 10 cents a hundredweight from yesterday's level.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Extension for two years of various "nuisance taxes" and the 3-cent postage rate for first-class non-local mail was recommended to the House today by the Ways and Means Committee in a joint resolution embodying the first tax legislation of the present session of Congress.

Justice Hyman Rayfiel of Special Sessions in Brooklyn, reviewing the first Brownell law test case, said yesterday that the law might eradicate civil rights, and warned that society sometimes plays "foul" by permitting policemen to induce persons to commit crime and then causing their arrest.

Economies carried out by the Southern Railway to offset reduced income are outlined in the report for 1934 by Fairfax Harrison, president. He pointed out that an increase in revenues from $76,148,103 in 1933 to $78,183,700 in 1934 was counteracted by a rise of $4,047,512 in expenses from increased wages and NRA codes for fuel and other supplies.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- President Roosevelt signed the joint resolution for skeleton extension of the NRA, after the House had accepted the Senate anti-trust amendment. He approved the resolution extending the Emergency Transportation Act, arranged a truce in the coal strike situation until June 30 and told his press conference that work-relief projects with high material cost must be trimmed.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 14 (AP). -- Flood waters took seven lives and rushed on in a widening tide of devastation tonight in Southwestern Texas.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 14. -- Williams regained first place in the Little Three today by turning back Amherst, 6 to 2, for the second time in three encounters. Harry Stevens, Purple veteran, held the Lord Jeffs to four hits, while Williams capitalized on Palmer's wildness and Amherst's loose infield play.

The sharp crack of hammer against wood and the thud of spade against earth will resound throughout the State today when virtually every community will join in the observance of National Better Housing Day under the sponsorship of the Federal Housing Administration.

Supporters of William Berg and Robert P. Levis, rival candidates for the Republican leadership of the Eleventh Manhattan Assembly District, joined forces last evening at a meeting of the Republican County Committee of the district to condemn Daniel J. Riesner, third candidate for the leadership, who has the support of Chase Mellen Jr., county chairman.

Herr HITLER is showing unexpected anxiety to come to terms with Great Britain in the matter of naval strength. His latest offer is far and away better than his previous boasting that Germany would have a war fleet equal to that of any other nation. He now proposes to ask for a German tonnage only about 35 or 40 per cent of the British.

BERLIN, June 14. -- The Boerse opened with a new attempt by professional traders to put down prices, but the public refused to follow and the market recovered the larger part of its losses and was able to register some gains. Heavy industrials recovered, under the leadership of Hoesch, which advanced three-quarters point on the day.

LONDON, June 14. -- "You can't sell whisky in America under an ordinary name. They want a Scotch name," said Joseph William Hobbs, an American trading here as J.W. Hobbs Co., export merchants, when he was sued at Westminster Court for 50 12s. 6d. as balance of an account for printing labels of varying names and designs for whisky bottles.
WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Bids for a new $11,110,000 Interior Department building to be constructed with PWA funds were asked today by the Treasury Department Procurement Division.

Four men and three women received workhouse terms in Special Sessions yesterday when they were found guilty of defrauding the city's home relief. All but two were found to have jobs or bank accounts. The court, at the request of defense lawyers, granted adjournments of trials of twenty-four other men and women on similar charges.

LONDON, June 14. -- Ambassador Quo Tai-chi of China called at the Foreign Office today to inform the British Government of his own government's resentment of the latest Japanese actions in North China.

The Black Decker Manufacturing Company, maker of electrical appliances, reported yesterday for itself and its subsidiaries a net income of $87,782 for the three months ended on March 31. This was after allowances had been made for taxes, depreciation, expenses and other charges.
BEDFORD, N.Y., June 14. -- The Historical Hall here was the scene this afternoon of the twenty-fifth annual flower show of the Bedford Garden Club.

Steps were taken at a meeting of leaders of the hosiery industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to submit to manufacturers throughout the country a voluntary agreement to continue NRA hour and wage provisions, to furnish monthly statistics and to conform to those rules relating to the marking of the quality and content of merchandise. The agreement would be binding until April 1, 1936.

The jinx that kept Leon Chagnon from the role of starting pitcher for close to two years camped doggedly on the Giant hurler's trail yesterday at the Polo Grounds when he started his first game since July 23, 1933.

Governor Lehman returned yesterday from a two-week vacation in Bermuda, immediately went into conference with members of the TERA at his home and left in the early evening for Washington for conferences on the relief situation with Harry L. Hopkins, relief administrator, and other Federal officials.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 14. -- Progress in Jewish education in this country has been recorded and Jewish community centres have also maintained high standards despite the depression, according to reports made today at the opening sessions of the annual meetings of the National Association of Jewish Centre Executives and the National Council for Jewish Education.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 14. -- With the Toledo Edison Company favorable to arbitration, but the union skeptical toward it, this city today awaited possibility of a truce in the strike of the company's electrical workers. Meanwhile, labor leaders moved to consider a sympathetic general strike.

Out of America's guild of leaders of the learned and the learners -- the thousand, more or less, of college and university presidents -- the oldest in point of service is this year to retire, Dr. ETHELBERT D. WARFIELD of Wilson College. Born in 1861 in Lexington, Ky., he had his undergraduate education in Princeton, his graduate work in the University of Oxford and his professional training at Columbia University.

About 2,500 school children of the lower East Side celebrated Flag Day yesterday morning with a short parade and exercises in Roosevelt Park, Rivington and Forsyth Streets. Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, delivered a speech on Americanism.

Detectives who had carried their investigation of the theft of ten valuable paintings from the Brooklyn Museum on April 29, 1933, into art centres throughout the United States and abroad during the futile two-year hunt disclosed yesterday that the negotiations for the return of four of the works required all the precautionary procedure of a complex ransom kidnapping.

Clusters of sweet peas from the estate of J.P. Morgan at Glen Cove, L.I., received six first prizes at the Gardens of the Nations' Sweet Pea Show, which opened yesterday in Horticultural Hall in Rockefeller Center.

With the confidence of his owner, C.H. (Pat) Knebelkamp, that he will win, King Saxon will go to the post this afternoon in the Carter handicap burdened with a top impost of 127 pounds. Whether the colt which won the Paumonok, Metropolitan and Queens County handicaps so handsomely can concede much weight to his seven rivals and still come home first, the seven furlong test will show.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP). -- A home run by Relief Pitcher Ed Linke with two on base in the eleventh today gave the Senators a triumph 16 to 11, over the White Sox before a ladies' day crowd of 18,000.

A dozen properties -- five in Manhattan and seven in the Bronx -- were bought in at foreclosure auction sales by plaintiffs yesterday. Dwellings and tenement houses dominated the auction list, which also included a garage and some vacant parcels.

Mrs. Emma Jacobs, one of New York's pioneer social welfare workers, celebrated her eighty-fifth birthday yesterday with some of the hundreds of persons she has helped to make happy. Known for many years as the "Guardian Angel of Welfare Island," Mrs. Jacobs attended a party given for the 1,500 inmates of the City Home on Welfare Island in honor of her birthday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 14. -- At the conclusion of the shooting of the State match, the only event today in the New York State National Guard matches at Camp Smith here, the presentation of cups and trophies was made to the winners by Rear Admiral Frank R. Lackey, commander of the State Naval Militia.

Joseph L. Steinmetz, youthful former divinity student, who was found guilty of manslaughter by a General Sessions jury May 28, in the shooting of his 17-year-old bride, Ruth, at the time he killed the Rev. Joseph Leonard, a Catholic priest, in the former Knights of Columbus Hotel, Nov. 26, was sent to Sing Sing yesterday for eight to sixteen years.

The Independent Guaranteed Mortgage Certificate Holders Protective Committee of 475 Fifth Avenue announced yesterday that it had sent to 7,496 investors in Series C-2 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company mortgage guarantee certificates an analysis of the plan for reorganizing this issue proposed recently by the State Mortgage Commission.

ST. LOUIS, June 14. -- In a stirring battle played in a vast silence the Yankees brought down the Browns in thirteen innings today, 4 to 3, to record their fifth and concluding victory in the six-game series.

The Larchmont Yacht Club's Junior cruise will be held from July 30 to Aug. 1, it was announced yesterday. The first run will be from the club to Price's Bend, the second to Stamford and the third back to Larchmont, according to present plans.

THIS is the travel notebook of a British novelist, who takes it for granted that the world is interested in her observations and reactions. The assumption is a fairly safe one, for although Miss Mannin is often opinionated to the point of irritation. she is honest in her attitudes and exuberant in her style of writing.

PANAMA, R.P. -- Heavy debts and adverse economic conditions are given as explanation for apparent lack of interest in Central America for the highway from Panama to Texas by George Curtis Peck, who has just visited the countries concerned as economic adviser to the road commission.

THE two Literary Fellowships of $1,000 each, offered on Jan. 4 by Houghton Mifflin Company for the purpose of encouraging and financially assisting writers of promise, have been awarded to Jenny Ballou of New York City and E.P. O'Donnell of New Orleans, La.

WHEN the depression struck the world, Argentina was as hard hit as many other countries. The reaction quickly rebounded to her larger cities and Buenos Aires suffered immeasurably. The capital of Argentina had enjoyed a meteoric rise from a town of 50,000 inhabitants in 1890 to a metropolis of 3,000,000 in less than half a century.

A social observer recently reported that the American people have lost their old and instinctive desire and willingness to work hard. Signs aplenty to appear to justify this view may be seen on every hand. A permanent aversion to work is the seamy side of relief too long granted.

The tiny Marconi-rigged sloop Spirit of Bermuda came into Quarantine under sail early yesterday morning and lay over to await dawn and official clearance by Public Health doctors and customs examiners.

OMAHA, Neb., June 13. -- To the wheat-growing farmers of Kansas and Nebraska, the June estimate of greatly improved crop prospects means the frequently repeated story of good fortune and misfortune sitting cheek by jowl.

PARIS. PAJAMAS fit particularly well into the new evening mode for Summer resort wear, in which the line between beach clothes and dressy frocks is almost indistinguishable. Schiaparelli has some in printed satins, over which are scattered large shadowy flowers in off shades of blue, mauve or pink.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15. -- Marching Peter, gray pacer, the property of William A. Parkhurst of Maplewood, won the Class A event, feature race of the weekly matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

A reminder that, unless Congress passes the Banking Act of 1935 or some substitute measure by July 1, the permanent plan of Federal deposit insurance will then go into effect was conveyed indirectly to banks yesterday by a circular issued by the Federal Reserve Board covering the computation of assessments under the permanent plan.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- A warning that State governments have received in the Supreme Court's ruling a "last chance" to handle their own economic affairs was sounded today at the opening session of the Council of State Governments by Henry W. Toll, former Colorado State Senator and executive director of the council.

Louis Lazar, 28 years old, of 247 Rivington Street, admitted in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday that he had shot and killed a man in Brooklyn two years ago for a fee of $500, of which he had received only half.

DETROIT, June 15 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers scored a double-barreled triumph over Philadelphia today in a twin bill that opened the Athletics' Detroit stand. The Bengals took the first, 10 to 1, and then ran up a count of 11 to 3 in the afterpiece.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- Scoring five runs in the ninth inning, Princeton defeated Yale, 8 to 7, before a Commencement Day crowd of 15,000 persons today.

Profitable operation of retail departments last year was the rule rather than the exception, a situation in marked contrast to that of the last few years, according to the survey of departmental merchandising and operating results for 1934 of department stores and specialty shops, issued during the week by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

TOWARD the end of the Southern Reconstruction era an obscure circus on tour was exhibiting at Red Valley, Ala., and there the equestrienne, Sarah Bates, suffered a fall from her horse which permanently crippled her right leg and retired her from the sawdust ring forever.

LONDON, June 15. -- A further indication of the reconstructed British Government's determination to achieve friendly relations with Germany was given today by a reference to foreign affairs that Sir Thomas Inskip, Attorney General, made in a speech in Salisbury.

The city's License Department increased its revenues and reduced its costs in 1934 and at the same time intensified its efforts to protect the public, it is shown by the annual report of the department, made public yesterday by Commissioner Paul Moss.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Winning the first polo match game of the season, played on Potomac Park field against the War Department polo team, the Loudoun Fauquier Polo Association officially started what is expected to be an active season.

Competition for the honor of winning the championship of the United States for thoroughbred dogs for the year 1935 is waxing exceedingly keen. Victory will go to the individual dog which wins the greatest number of best-in-group awards during the year.

Critical issues in American education will be discussed at six special conferences during the Summer session opening July 8 at Teachers College, Columbia, Dr. Milton C. Del Manzo, provost of the college, announced yesterday.

Only two other persons are known to have been in the house at the time when Veronica Baring was murdered. One of them is Miss Baring's stepsister, Bridget Western, and the other is Mrs. Rainham, who kept house for the two girls.

Holding there is no provision of law compelling returning residents to pay internal revenue taxes on cigars or cigarettes entered within the $100 personal exemption limit fixed by the Tariff Act, John G. Lerch, widely known customs attorney, yesterday said "any one who pays internal revenue taxes on such products and fails to contest the payment by filing a protest is making a voluntary gift to the government."

WITH the longest day of the year on the calendar for this week, the broadcasting studios are quiet, subdued realms compared to the activity that hums around them in the Winter season Many of the star performers have signed off and will not return until after Labor Day.
ST. LOUIS, June 15 (AP). -- A trio of Senators today led a 15-hit attack that netted Washington an easy 11-to-3 victory over the Browns in their series opener before a Ladies' Day crowd of 2,500.
In common with many of my business friends in the East, I am interested in the recent developments which resulted in the Grass Root Convention, its platform and objectives.
