THE new Moscow subway is more than a transportation system. It is a symbol, a test and a challenge. It is a symbol of what the exponents of communism promise that life in their form of society will eventually be -- comfortable and luxurious for all.

In addition to the measure continuing temporarily the life of a shadowy NRA, President ROOSEVELT has put twelve bills on his "must" list for the present session. It is quite likely that he does not expect a weary and perspiring Congress to adopt all of them before adjourning.

IRELAND has revealed a really remarkable number of fine authors during the past few years. Many of them, like Francis Stuart and Frank O'Connor, have not gained any great following in America. Others have pleased not only the book-reading public but, as in the case of Liam O'Flaherty through "The Informer," are becoming known to millions.

IF radio programs are to continue as in the past, it is essential that not only children but adults as well learn to discriminate between worth-while and objectionable, or, at least, valueless programs, Dr. Tracy F. Tyler of the National Committee on Education by Radio warned the General Federation of Women's Clubs at the recent conclave at Detroit.

LONDON, June 15. -- A small sum in very simple arithmetic seems to indicate that the optimism concerning favorable results of the pending Anglo-German negotiations on the general naval situation is premature. Germany demands a fleet 35 per cent as great as Great Britain's, based not on total tonnage, as Chancellor Hitler originally suggested, but on categories, according to a British amendment, which Berlin accepts.

WHAT may prove to be a momentous turning point in the development of air travel in the United States was emphasized by the recent trial flight of the newest Sikorsky amphibian, believed to be the fastest plane of this type yet produced.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 15. -- The Wesleyan nine defeated Williams, 5 to l, today before a crowd of commencement week guests and captured the Little Three baseball championship. The game was interrupted for 20 minutes by rain.
THE TIMES editorial, "Conditional Warning," recalled another warning given me forty-five years ago by the chief forester of that part of Lorraine taken by Germany in 1870.

Great Britain's unofficial "peace ballot," begun about six months ago and scheduled to come to an end on June 27, shows that at least 10,000,000 voters of that country are overwhelmingly in favor of the League of Nations, of general disarmament and of the abolition of the private manufacture of arms.

MOSCOW, June 15. -- More than a million more acres have been sown to grain this year than in last year's record planting, according to the Commissariat of Agriculture. The total is now 225,402,000 acres. This exceeds even the plan for this year.
MILTON, Mass., June 15. -- Fifty-one members of the graduating class of the Boys School of Milton Academy received diplomas at commencement exercises today.
Dominant in the current agitation for government ownership of banking or greater government control of the Federal Reserve Board is the quantitative theory of credit.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 15. -- The ten-day wait for good weather for the stratosphere flight is to be lengthened by at least forty-eight hours. Captain Randolph P. Williams, meteorologist of the National Geographic-Air Corps Stratosphere Expedition, said this afternoon that "a continued influx of southern air exist in Kansas and Nebraska with attendant cloudiness; there will be no inflation today and probably tomorrow."

HICKSVILLE, L.I., June 15. -- The navy's Grumman single-seater pursuit plane, one of the fastest combat ships in the world, was demonstrated here in public for the first time today at the annual Spring meet of the Aviation Club of Long Island.

Protective committees were formed yesterday to represent the holders of Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation twenty-five-year collateral trust 5 per cent bonds and debenture stock, due 1953, and 7 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock, following the filing of a petition by the company late on Friday to reorganize under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Net income of the Davega Stores Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended March 31 amounted to $166,495, after depreciation, amortization, provision for bad debts, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to 75 cents a share on 219,700 shares of $5 par capital stock, excluding 36,800 shares held in the treasury.

TROY, N.Y., June 15. -- The speedy greyhound today triumphed at the Troy Dog Show, part of the four-day horse show and county fair. Southball Moonstone of Halcyon, owned by Halcyon Kennel of Goshen, won the coveted title of best in show.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 13. -- Abandonment of all Lumber Code activities, including wage scales and hours, has resulted in the break-up of the Hardwood Manufacturers Institute, for thirteen years the official organization of the hardwood industry in the South.

THE most interesting event of this month is likely to be a dinner to be given -- still in the future as this is written -- by the Irish P.E.N. in honor of the seventieth birthday of W.B. Yeats. John Masefield, the English poet laureate, has been invited and Mr. Desmond McCarthy, the critic of The Sunday Times.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 15. -- After some of the most spectacular golf that has marked the tourney in years, 22-year-old Tommy Good-win of Winged Foot carried off the Westchester amateur championship at the Sunningdale Country Club today.

ANEW work by Florent Schmitt, the French composer, called "Suite en rocailles," had its premiere recently in Paris. It was written for the Paris Instrumental Quintet, which played the work. One critic wrote that the suite was notable for "its choice of ideas and refinement of writing, elements that were perfectly balanced in their proportions."

BE gay and at the same time soft and supple!" This is the message sent us from Paris in the lovely clothes that have arrived from the midseason openings. There is no question about it, the couture intends to keep us "Eastern."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 15. -- The family physician should be equipped with an intimate knowledge of psychiatry in order to adjust friction between husband and wife, or to rid the home of a trouble-making relative.

A NEW writer of mystery stories has been added to the Morrow list, which already included such reliable purveyors of puzzlement and thrills as Erle Stanley Gardner, R.A.J. Walling and Carter Dickson. The new man's name is Charles J. Kenny, and he writes of the adventures of Sam Moraine, an advertising expert who, bored with the commonplace business of inventing slogans and planning publicity campaigns, takes a flier in detective work.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 15 (AP). -- The stable of Paul Bowser of Fair Oaks Farm, Lexington, Mass., won the featured events on the opening day's card of the five-day light harness racing meet today.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 15. -- On the eve of the first Sunday commencement in the history of New England colleges, more than 1,000 alumni of Wesleyan University took part today in a series of events marking the 100th annual meeting of the Alumni Association.

With the sudden rise in the temperature in various sections of the country last week, buying of Summer merchandise, which had been delayed because of unfavorable weather conditions, spurted ahead sharply, particularly in many of the agricultural areas.

VIENNA, June 15 (AP). -- With "A Kingdom by September" as their slogan, monarchist movements in Austria and Hungary are gaining momentum. Leaders in both countries voiced the belief that something more than words was necessary if their hopes were to be realized soon.
A large section of business and industry is maintaining voluntarily fair standards of wages and hours set up by the NRA codes which expire today, surveys made public yesterday indicated.

PEOPLE, apparently, are learning to take care of themselves everywhere except on streets and highways. Deaths due to motor-vehicle accidents rose from 4,227 in 1913 to approximately 36,000 last year. Meanwhile, deaths caused by all other accidents declined from 78,233 in 1913 to about 65,000 last year.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 15. -- Today was alumnae day at Wellesley College. The graduating seniors, in the forefront all week, gave way most of the day to their predecessors. In the afternoon, however, they came forward again and joined the alumnae in the colorful parade of classes.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 15. -- Holy Cross increased its winning record to twenty-one out of twenty- two games by defeating Brown, 7 to 1, today.

ONE cannot read far in this discursive and repetitious but nevertheless remarkable book without noting the passionate devotion which Professor Du Bois feels for his race and its cause, and his utter scorn for many, if not most, of the historians and biographers whose views about reconstruction differ from his own.

An alert Textile High School nine capitalized on every opportunity to vanquish Brooklyn Technical High, 4 -- 0, at Farmers 0val yesterday in a P.S.A.L. semi-final game. The victors are listed to clash with Newtown High for the city championship at the Yankee Stadium Saturday.

MIDWAY ISLAND, June 15. -- The giant Pan American clipper alighted here at 1:40 this afternoon [9:40 P.M., New York daylight saving time], completing on time the first non-stop flight by a commercial plane between the Hawaiian and Midway Islands.

The theory that the United States is in process of evolving a new monetary system to supplant the old gold standard is advanced by William P. Shea in "Silver Dollars," a sixty-four-page book just published by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

AUSTRALIA has two broadcasting systems from which listeners may select programs. One handles commercially sponsored broadcasts; the other is government owned and operated. The commercial system has fifty-three stations, each limited in power to one kilowatt.

The notables in the world of cards will gather on Friday, June 21, at Skytop in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania for the forty-fifth annual congress of the American Whist League, the oldest card organization in the United States.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 15. -- Intercollegiate rowing comes to the climax of its season next week. On Tuesday, during the late afternoon here on the Hudson River, the crews of seven colleges race in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta.

BEGINNING July 1, broadcasts from London, heard in the United States at 10 P.M., Eastern standard time, Sunday, Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, will become a daily feature of the Empire Broadcasting Service. This decision to increase the number of transmissions is said to have been prompted by thousands of letters from listeners in Canada and the United States expressing appreciation of the experimental programs.

ABOUT twenty years ago I bought my first etching by Childe Hassam, a very small one, a little French boy standing near an old French woman who was cooking something in the open street on a brazier. It was printed on a page of an old account book, which on one side listed a delectable array of wines.

BELGRADE, June 15. -- Dargoutin Koyitch, Justice Minister, continued today in Parliament the attacks on Dr. Ante Matchek's Opposition block began yesterday by Interior Minister Popovitch. M. Koyitch declared amid applause from the majority:

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The last-minute postponement of the bituminous coat strike, which was scheduled to begin on Sunday night, represents another move by which the United Mine Workers hope to rescue the Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill from the Washington legislative whirlpool.

IN the more august ocean liners a modern yet definitely national type of decoration may be seen. Each new vessel sums up some of the recent art progress of the nation that launches it. It becomes a floating exhibition for those in distant ports, besides supplying a background of beauty for its passengers.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The government will operate directly the entire work relief program in New York State, but the TERA, State relief organization, will continue to care for unemployables and others receiving "direct" aid, Governor Lehman announced here today after a conference with Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator.
ROME, June 15. -- The Cabinet approved today the institution of the "Fascist Saturday." All work must cease at 1 P.M. Saturdays.

The comment which the Dictionary of American Biography increasingly evokes as this monumental work approaches its completion is that it is "invaluable " -- "indispensable." Especially is this the view of librarians. It will come to be regarded as an essential in every library of reference, public, school or private, in the United States.

RICHMOND, June 14. -- Loans to 136 industries in the Fifth District for capital outlays and expansions amounting to $8,332,000 have been made by the Richmond Reserve Bank, while sixteen others totaling $484,000 are pending. The applications rejected approximate the amount already loaned.

Facing numerous problems, but favored by the expectation that a 5 to 10 per cent rise in retail sales will be experienced this Fall as compared with a 2 per cent rise for the first five months of this year, buying activity for the coming season in major department store and specialty shop lines of merchandise will get under way in the next ten days.

MEXICO, D.F., June 15. -- The majority blocs of the Mexican Senate and Chamber of Deputies announced today that they would continue their support of President Lazaro Cardenas in his clash with General Plutarco Elias Calles over the six-year labor program.

Gregory Mangin added his name to the challenge bowl of the Terrace Club of Flatbush for the second time yesterday. The nation's thirteenth ranking player subdued Leonard Hartman in straight sets to win the eighteenth annual Brooklyn open tennis crown.

Battering four pitchers for eighteen hits Charley Grimm's Cubs yesterday romped away with the opening game against the Dodgers, 9 to 4, and tumbled the Stengel men into the second division berth that has been yawning for them for several days.

Fire that started in the canopy beneath which the bride-to-be was sitting, just before the wedding ceremony was to have begun, drove 250 relatives and friends into a stampede for the exits of a first-floor hall of The Mansion, 57 St. Mark's Place, just before last midnight.
BOSTON, June 14. -- The New England Governors and their advisory railroad committee met here today and once more their report, already a month overdue, is kept under cover.

HOW far may a modern producer of an opera go in modifying the traditions of its stage presentation? The question has a special interest for us in New York because of the new regime at the Metropolitan, and the promises of that regime to renovate and vitalize methods of operatic interpretation.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 15. -- Championship honors in the jumper division at the closing session of the forty-second annual Westchester County Horse Show today went to the veteran timbertopper, the chestnut gelding Salmo, owned and ridden by Patrick McDermott of Brookville, L.I.

Because today in the liturgical calendar is Trinity Sunday many clergymen will preach on "The Blessed Trinity: the Father and the Son and the Holy Ghost." Several pastors in the midtown Manhattan section will occupy their pulpits for the last time until Fall, as their Summer vacations will begin.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 15. -- Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, as a Smith College trustee, and Mrs. Roswell H. Rausch, chairman of the Alumnae Fund Committee, presented $150,000 to President William Allan Neilson at the opening of the Alumnae Assembly this afternoon.

WHEN it was decided to add a "child's garden" to the Gardens of the Nations at Rockefeller Center, New York's school children, under 12, were invited to compete in submitting designs for it. Fifty of the best designs are now on exhibition at Horticultural Hall.

THE current period, being the time when producers announce their lavish plans for a more gargantuan year, arouses only a modicum of excitement in the studios. Plans for the new year's product are frequently conceived within the fertile brains of the exploitation gentlemen and often have little bearing upon what finally reaches the screen.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 13. -- The danger of Communistic propaganda in the United States Navy, only a year ago "viewed with alarm" by some naval officers, today is negligible, a survey of the fleet's personnel and a study of their morale and loyalty during recent manoeuvres Indicates.

Walter J. Mahoney, 27-year-old lawyer, of Buffalo, has been chosen by the nominating committee of the Association of New York State Republican Clubs to succeed George H. Sibley of Manhattan as president of the association, the committee announced yesterday.
Heavy rains again in the Southwest, with more than four inches reported at Dallas, strengthened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with gains of 7 to 9 points.

NANKING, June 15. -- The Chinese Foreign Ministry issued yesterday a formal denial of reports that action under the Nine-Power Treaty had been initiated by the Chinese Government. The denial was motivated by dispatches from London saying that the Chinese Ambassador, Quo Tai-chi, had approached the British Government on the question of invoking the Nine-Power pact against Japan in connection with her North China activities.
A QUIET week for the London theatre is the cable's prediction, listing the entries as follows:

The American Medical Association, representing the organized physicians of the country, served notice on the government last week to keep its social security program out of the field of sickness insurance. Specifically, the doctors held that there must be no imitation in America of the insurance functions exercised, directly or indirectly, by most foreign governments.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The National Labor Relations Board was re-established by President Roosevelt by executive order today to continue in existence until July 1, 1935, subject to the limitations imposed in the new NRA Congressional resolution, as he spent the day and evening drafting an executive order to provide the new set-up for the NRA.

WINNIPEG, June 15 (Canadian Press). -- The Winnipeg Board of Trade protested today against the plan of dealing with the Canadian wheat situation that is proposed in the Canada Grain Board Bill, which had a second reading yesterday in the House of Commons in Ottawa.

THERE is nothing more exhilarating to smart women than to learn that a new color is looming on the horizon, especially when it is becoming to nearly every one. The latest addition to the Summer's color chart is cinnamon. It is appearing in accessories -- and very good-looking ones, at that.

New York's first outdoor motor boat show, plans for which have been under discussion for several weeks, was definitely assigned to City Island, the largest near-by yachting centre, at last week's meeting of the Marine Trades Association.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Three days after the hectic Senate scenes of Wednesday night and early Thursday morning, there is a preponderant view among Washington observers that the nuisance value of Senator Huey P. Long, self-styled Louisiana Kingfish, has suffered a considerable depreciation.

" Nine weeks have elapsed since the opening of the New York trout season," writes Brown Bivisible. "At this time a change will take place which will result in a lessening of Waltonian density on the streams. The initiate and wise anglers will continue to cast fuzzier fuzzy-wuzzies on finer and longer leaders, catching bigger and better trout.

LONDON, May 24. ROULETTE," by Harry Graham from the Hungarian of Laszlo Fodor, is a piece of which the commercial success or failure is peculiarly difficult to forecast. By the rules, it there are rule, it ought to have a run long enough to cover expenses but too short to make any one's fortune; but there are special qualities in it that give it an outsider's chance of taking the town.

THE future's stooped historians will be able to look back on the year 1935 as that of the social revolution in amusements. They will find the theatre changing, the movies changing, the radio changing -- all trying through their separate media to do the same thing, and each borrowing talents and theories from the others.
TOKYO. -- A school where soldiers' daughters will be trained to be soldiers' brides was opened recently with an enrolment of 247 students, all daughters of officers on the active or retired list.

WITH the coming of warm weather, New York's rapidly growing list of tropical fish dealers and importers are preparing for the big season. It is only during the hot months that the fish can be easily shipped in large quantities, because of their sensitivity to temperatures lower than those of the tepid streams of their homelands.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The House today voted restoration to Spanish-American War veterans and their dependents of the pension cuts put into effect by the Economy Act of 1933, concerning non-service-connection disabilities. The cost will make outlays for Spanish War veterans exceed the budget estimate for the fiscal year 1936 by $45,581,132, according to Frank T. Hines, administrator of the Veterans Bureau.

IF the voters and leaders who find neither the Republican nor the Democratic party strong enough meat for their change-hungry stomachs were to assemble in one big parade they would undeniably take a long time to pass a given point. As a matter of fact they appear to be marching in several directions and to be passing a dozen or more given points.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 15. --First observance of National Better Housing Day took place in Mamaroneck this morning, when ground was broken for a model home in the new development on the old Robbins tract in Orienta Avenue, according to Gates Ferguson, associate State director of the FHA.

OTTAWA, June 14. -- The fifth month of the present Canadian Parliament finds some ten measures in the New Deal program announced last January by Prime Minister Bennett in various stages of legislative undress. Only one, that establishing a $90,000,000 credit fund for the needy farmer, has received royal assent and is actually in operation.

THOSE who were fortunate enough to happen across the earlier novel by March Cost, "A Man Named Luke," realized that they had come upon an author with an eerie flair for intermingling fact and illusion. In Miss Cost's new story, "The Dark Glass," the web of fantasy and reality is even more subtly and intricately spun, with a consequent enhancement of that strange power which she exercises.

RENO. -- Nevada is rapidly pulling out of the depression, the fact being indicated by the declining number of people on relief. Last February the number on relief was approximately 12 1/2 per cent of the population. Now the comparable figure is 10 per cent.

On the evening of Tuesday, May 28, two theatrical productions clamored equally for attention from the dramatic departments of the daily newspapers. "Knock on Wood" was announced as a farce about the Hollywood agency racket.

COLLEGE life for thousands of students is far from the round of gayety popularly pictured. So a survey made by a faculty committee of the social life of the 10,500 students at the University of Minnesota indicates.

There were fascinating revelations at the joint meeting of the American and Canadian Medical Associations held at Atlantic City last week. Even the unimaginative must have been stirred by such headlines as "Lame Walk After Taking Pancreas Extract," "Nutrition -- Key to Super-Race," "Excess Sugar in Blood Not Necessarily Harmful," "Injected Olive Oil Prevents Starvation," "Fatal Ills Curbed by Brain Bath," "Growth Retarded by Pineal Extract" and "Artificial Fevers Cure Infections."

ANNA STEN insists there is no news in her parting from Samuel Goldwyn. It was just, she said last week before her departure for a European holiday, that they had agreed to disagree. The phrasing of that statement indicates Miss Sten's Americanization: she has become tactful and a borrower of words.

BUENOS AIRES, June 14. -- The signing of the truce agreement between Bolivia and Paraguay here Wednesday was the first definite step toward terminating the three-year war in the Chaco Boreal. It was a hesitant, tiptoe step out onto ice so thin that it may break at any moment before the goal of peace is finally reached.

President de Valera's more conciliatory attitude toward Britain and disposition to negotiate further trade agreements is credited in the English press to the ever-growing gravity of the Irish Free State's economic situation. Concerning this, The London Daily Herald, Labor organ, gives the following details:

I never saw the word, but all of us have seen the thing itself. And if the word does not exist, it ought to. Suppose we coin it. The first part, onoma (to) is the Greek for "of word"; the second part is the Greek for "fear": "onomatophobia," fear of words.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15. -- With a field of an even hundred players in the lists, the men's New Jersey State tennis championship started today on the clay courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

In the beginning of the depression it was only the "down and outers" who accepted welfare assistance, but every month finds more people no longer regarding it as a disgrace, but rather as an inevitable solution to their continued comfort and convenience.

ON the fifth floor at Altman's a new picture gallery was opened last Monday with a showing of oils and water-colors by a small group of American artists, most of whom are well known here. There are, for instance, water-colors by Joseph Webster Golinkin, George Pearse Ennis, Levon West, John Whorf and James Clymer.

Second-grade rails continued to supply the greatest trading interest in yesterday's bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade corporation issues were firm but dull, while United States Government securities showed little activity, although that little was at rising prices. Transactions in foreign issues were without much interest.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP). -- Out of a field of twenty crack 2-year-olds, largest ever to go to the post at Washington Park, Dnieper emerged triumphant today in the first running of the $5,000 added Washington Park Juvenile Stakes, with a crowd of 15,000 watching the thrilling race.

" I THINK that the most important part of my job is to represent properly the Stock Exchange to the public." Charles R. Gay, the newly elected president of the world's principal security market, was speaking in his office -- a Colonial room with paintings of Washington, Jefferson and Hamilton, engravings of Lafayette and Franklin and a ticker to bring news of the present into an atmosphere of the past.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration announced yesterday that the plowing had been completed for some 75,000 subsistence gardens which are expected to yield a crop of truck valued at more than $3,200,000 for distribution among unemployed needy persons on relief. Between 5,000 and 6,000 of the gardens are being planted in New York City.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The first of a series of Summer concerts by the North Carolina Symphony Orchestra and the annual golf tournament at time municipal links are events of the next two weeks. The symphony orchestra, which maintains Summer headquarters here and each year gives a series of concerts, will play its first program on Tuesday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15. -- The Wheeler-Rayburn Utility Holding Company Bill was criticized today by Dr. Karl Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology at the convocation of the Brown University Graduate School.

Three brothers who had been reported missing to the police by their father, George Hoyt of 845 Hart Street, Brooklyn, at 10:15 o'clock last night, were found dead shortly after 1 o'clock this morning under circumstances the police described as suspicious.

NO great amount of experience is necessary to convince the rose grower that disease and insect control must be made a routine part of cultural practices. Progressive gardeners recognize this necessity. Fortunately, practical measures for control, based on reliable experimental work, are available.

LEADERS of the new Germany are attempting to adapt the number of students in the universities to the actual need in the professions. Naturally this retrenchment in the number of admissions to the professional schools is affecting the student population in the secondary schools, inasmuch as the German Gymnasium exists mainly for the purpose of preparing students for the professional schools.

IN 1716 or 1718 (authorities are not in agreement) James Thomson's father, Thomas Thomson, a Scottish minister, obligingly offered to wrestle with a ghost that had got possession of one of his parishioners. The attempt proved rash, for the spook was the famous Woolie Ghost, and in the midst of his exorcism the Rev. Mr. Thomson suddenly died.

MR. FORD'S VIEWS: After he had watched V-8 No. 2,000,000 run off the assembly line at his River Rouge plant on Thursday, Henry Ford remarked: "The government has attempted to meddle too much with business. I'll make a million cars next year if they just let the police run the country.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15. -- Ted Kleinhans gave the best hurling exhibition of any Newark pitcher this season today when he hurled the Bears to a 3-to-0 triumph over the Rochester Red Wings. It was the third straight victory for the Bruins.

No harbor anywhere ever looms so welcome and needed to a cruising yachtsman out to the eastward on Long Island Sound as he wallows along with a beam sea heeling him over and with the prevailing afternoon winds from the south quarters as the magnificent haven of Duck Island Roads.
Baroness Maud Levi and Miss Norma Taubele vindicataed their first two seeded places in the New York State clay-court tennis championship at the Jackson Heights Club yesterday.

SILVER PLUME, Col., June 15 (AP). -- The side of a mountain on the crest of the Continental Divide slipped today a short time after flood water from fast melting snow threatened the historic town of Silver Plume and caused its residents to flee.
The American Medical Association discussed outstanding medico-social issues at its convention at Atlantic City last week, and heard the annual revelations of newly discovered diseases and cures.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 15. -- Tom Bilodeau came from first base to the pitcher's box in the ninth today to halt a threatened Tufts uprising and enabled Harvard to emerge with a 6-5 victory on a rain-soaked diamond before an alumni day crowd of 2,000.

LOS ANGELES, June 14. TAKING pot shots in behalf of the average man at everything from communism to capitalism, government by initial, with women's clubs, fascism and the biological urge among the numerous targets, the Nugents, pere et fils, on Tuesday night presented, under the auspices of the Pasadena Community Playhouse, their latest joint work, entitled "The World's My Onion."

THE Loan Exhibition of American Painting, held jointly in the M.H. de Young Memorial Museum and the California Palace of the Legion of Honor (on until July 8) has been assembled from public and private collections throughout the United States and is undoubtedly one of the most comprehensive showings of its kind ever held.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 13. -- Out of the "grass roots" convention of the Middle West Republicans, held here this week, the opinion was born that the Corn Belt must be reclaimed and the two wings of the party united under mid-Western leadership if Republicans are to have a chance to win the election of 1936.

Smarting under quotas, high tariffs and alleged discriminatory treatment, American exporters, in briefs to be filed in Washington tomorrow, will make a strong bid to retrieve $150,000,000 worth of business lost in the French market since 1929.

A fortnight's trial of the floor-trading regulations adopted by the New York Stock Exchange at the suggestion of the Securities and Exchange Commission has produced few complaints from floor members, it was said at the Exchange yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Preparations are in hand for the most important golf event of the Summer in these parts, the twenty-fifth annual Virginia State amateur tournament, to be held on the championship Cascades course July 4, 5, 6 and 7.

The proposal made in the House last week by Representative Patman calling for an amendment to the Clayton act to bar price differentials to chains and other large buyers, and requiring such differentials to be based on "service and functions," was not taken seriously in chain-store or other retail circles.

ST. LOUIS, June 15. -- While normal Summer weather has not prevailed in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week, there has been a slackening of rainfall and more sunshine which has been of material benefit in many lines.
WARSAW, June 14. -- Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death has speeded the work of reshaping Poland's political structure to suit the requirements of the new Constitution.

BERLIN, June 15. -- It is national socialism's boast that its greatest gift to a world, the history of which it confidently predicts that it will dominate the next thousand years, is the idea of racial unity as contrasted with a mere State unity that might comprise several races.

Thursday night, after he lost the world's heavyweight championship to James J. Braddock, the California playboy was insistent that he would never draw on another glove. No amount of money or persuasion would tempt him to enter a prize ring again.

On May 15 THE NEW YORK TIMES printed part of a report to the convention of the American Psychiatric Association regarding the mild form of insanity among some literary artists. I expected to have seen some remark about this bit of important news, but even Will Rogers overlooked it.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Faced with the unharmonious necessities of speed and the selection of low-cost projects, President Roosevelt was reported authoritatively today to have limited work-relief contributions on State and municipal PWA projects to a 45 per cent donation.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The Bourse maintained its watchful waiting attitude today. The turnover was small, and although the market was firmer at the beginning, a slight reaction followed so that most changes remained merely fractional.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 15. -- Finishing in a gale of wind accompanied by a heavy shower, Harold S. Vanderbilt sailed his Class M sloop Prestige to victory over George Lauder's Windward and a newcomer for the season, Herbert Hanan's Spartan, in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 15. -- "The recent decision of the Supreme Court must make us reflect on the possibility and rate of social change in America," Dr. Ben M. Selekman of Boston, president of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service, told delegates to the forty-sixth annual conference of social workers here tonight.

THE status of women in Turkey has vastly changed during the last decade or so, and this fact was brought out clearly to the foreign delegates at the International Alliance for Suffrage and Equal Citizenship recently held in Istanbul. Recognition of her new social and political status gave the Turkish woman confidence in playing hostess to those coming from abroad.

PITTSBURGH, June 14. -- Western Pennsylvania operators with almost unanimity are continuing with many other Northern producers to support the Guffey bill as a "little NRA" for stabilization of the industry.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Treasury books were closed today on the semi-annual payments of war debt installments, with only one country out of the thirteen having amounts due meeting the obligations.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- THE termination of the codes has resulted in the revival of the antitrust laws; and to make doubly certain that these statutes shall again become effective the resolution continuing NRA in skeleton form declares that any exemption from the anti-trust laws shall extend only to agreements approved by the President, which provide for collective bargaining, minimum wages, maximum hours and abolition of child labor, and prohibit unfair competitive practices.

IT is inevitable in a popular art like the cinema, which turns out films like automobiles and soap, that its practitioners must fall hack on reliable plot formulas. When a single studio contracts to make sixty pictures each season, the wretches who inhabit Writers' Row can hardly be blamed if their work is a trifle lacking in aspiration.

AN imagination defiant of logic and wisdom, exuberant enough to burst through the seams of form and coupled to an exquisite prose style, is certainly the indication of an important new writer. But there is something about a young talent that is always a little unexpected and embarrassing.

MERRILL MOORE is a young Boston physician who disposes of his spare time by entering long-distance swimming contests or writing sonnets The sonnets, although often notably excellent, are remarkable for one thing and that is their quantity.

The historic significance of what is now taking place in the Far East is not minimized by the fact that it has been discounted in advance. That has only cushioned the international shock as Japanese occupation of South Manchuria in 1931 was not cushioned.

FLORENCE, May 30, 1935. A WEIGHTY question, that had worried not a few high-brow theorists in the field of modern Italian opera, was settled with the recent premiere of Ildebrando Pizzetti's three-act music drama, "Orseolo," as the sole operatic novelty of the Florentine May Festival.

Completion of its revision of the Railway Bankruptcy Law by the House Judiciary Committee was hailed in investment circles as heralding the end of an impasse which for two years has prevented the reorganization of railways burdened by top-heavy financial structures.

The eight-day mystery of the disappearance of John Kaul Jr., 5 1/2 years old, ended yesterday with the finding of his body in the East River at the foot of Coster Street, the Bronx. There was no evidence of violence on the body. An autopsy showed the boy had drowned.

Income tax payers, who elected to meet their levy in instalments, crowded State and Federal offices throughout the city yesterday to pay their second instalment before the deadline for the June 15 assessment closed.

WHY pedestrians do not have full right of way over vehicular traffic at crossings is a constant puzzle to many visitors in New York City. At present the Police Department is conducting an intensive safety campaign. Those on foot are cautioned to cross on the green lights only.

The further away business draws from the Supreme Court decision against the Recovery Act, the better sentiment among industrial and trade executives becomes, according to comment in local business circles yesterday. Last week saw very few executives worrying about a general collapse, as they had been doing when the court ruling came out, although they admitted that it would be foolish to believe all uncertainty has been eliminated.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., June 15 (AP). -- A strange malady is crumbling the bones of Mrs. Alia Patterson, a 65-year-old farm woman and doctors say she will die unless the disease is checked.

Voluntary agreements, on which most industries pinned their hopes last week of retaining NRA benefits, can achieve the major aims of business for fair competitive practices, provided they do not embrace procedures obviously outside the law, Sol A. Herzog, counsel to several trade groups and a member of the Consumers' Goods Industries Committee, declared here yesterday.

In ceremonies that had much of the air of an Independence Day celebration, the metropolitan district joined with all of New York State yesterday in observing National Better Housing Day under the auspices of the Federal Housing Administration.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 15. -- The woman's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York has completed plans for two Westchester fetes.
ATLANTIC CITY. -- The National Headliners Frolic, opening next Friday for three days, will bring together some 200 celebrities at Atlantic City.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- Philadelphia wrested the Griscom Cup from New York today in a hard-fought contest at the Huntingdon Valley Country Club, 9 to 6. By recapturing the trophy they last held in 1931 the Philadelphians assumed the virtual championship of the East in women's team golf competition.

A trait very strongly developed among the North Americans, writes Professor Wotan von Dunkel, is the instinct for hearth and home. We see this when the Supreme Court of the United States declares 9 to 0 that FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT must not lay a destructive hand on the local poultry of the American people.
EDWARD ARNOLD isn't quite certain how he first decided to become an actor. But, looking over the years, he thinks he must have been inspired by his uncle, who played the bass fiddle in Tony Pastor's.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- Jack Lovelock of New Zealand raced to an easy triumph in the "mile of the century" at Palmer Stadium this scorching afternoon. Catching Glenn Cunningham at the head of the homestretch, he coasted, serenely and majestically, across the finish line to victory.
BERLIN, June 14. -- Among the flowers that bloom in this third Nazi Spring, none is being nurtured more tenderly right now than the mysterious seedling tagged "Anglo-German friendship."

MOSCOW, June 15. -- Professor Peter Lasareff, a member of the Soviet Academy of Science, declared today the normal life span of human beings should be something over 150 years. He revealed he had succeeded in prolonging the lives of daphnia (minute fresh water crustaceans) to four times their usual existence by the use of Roentgen rays.

A suit challenging the Federal Government's authority to force the surrender of gold owned in this country by a foreign corporation doing no business here was started yesterday in Federal court by the Swiss corporation Uebersee-Finanz-Korporation Aktien Gesellschaft against the Wall Street firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., 25 Broad Street, and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 15 . -- Employment has been given to about 4,000,000 persons under the Public Works Administration's $3,700,000,000 program, Secretary Ickes reported today, and all the original appropriation has been allotted within the time limit set by Congress.

SALEM, N.H., June 16. -- Breaking on top with a rush, the 4-year-old Identify, a chestnut son of Man o' War, today headed a parade of eleven crack thoroughbreds over the mile and an eighth distance of the $10,000 added Rockingham Park Handicap.
Manager Bill Terry went down the line through the names of fifteen of his athletes yesterday at the Polo Grounds before he came to the retiring Mark Koenig.

Calm and almost voluble, Peter Christ stood in the Police Headquarters' line-up yesterday morning and related why and how, some hours earlier, he had slain his wife, Stella, and wounded a man who, he said, had been visiting her.

Deeds in the formal transfer of the Riverside Church and adjoining land at Riverside Drive and 120th Street by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the church corporation were placed on record yesterday at the Register's Office in Manhattan. The property was donated to the church a few years ago by Mr. Rockefeller, who also was the chief contributer toward funds for erection of the $4,000,000 edifice.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Feeling that the White Sox had been clinging to their coat tails long enough, the Yankees today turned on the American League's surprise team of the year and swiftly brought about a result that disillusionized not only the Sox but a crowd of 10,000.

With the departure of Julius Fleischmann's massive 225-foot steel power schooner Camargo from Long Island Sound and the absence of J. P. Morgan's 348-foot black Corsair, which is in dry dock, local waterways are offering other large craft for view by countless small boats between the East River and Montauk.

WITH the Hauptmann case coming to public attention again on appeal, the value of circumstantial evidence in a criminal trial once more becomes a subject of interest and discussion. In the minds of many people there is a conviction that direct evidence based primarily on faith in the infallibility of the human eye is more dependable and conclusive than indirect or circumstantial evidence.

From 9 A.M. to dusk yesterday New Yorkers were treated to a scene that would have seemed more appropriate in the setting of the Adirondacks or the North Woods. The occasion was the second annual amateur metropolitan fly and bait casting tournament, conducted at Conservatory Lake in Central Park under the joint sponsorship of the Department of Parks and the Abercrombie Fitch Company.

Activity in the wholesale markets here last week was featured by a steady flow of mail orders in most departments, with a definite pickup noted on popular-price and low-end Summer merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Co.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 15 (AP). -- Ben B. Laska, dapper defender of kidnappers, was convicted by a Federal court jury today of knowingly accepting as a fee part of the $200,000 ransom paid in the abduction of Charles F. Urschel, oil millionaire.

PHOENIX. -- Arizona, jubilant a few weeks ago over the favorable United States Supreme Court decision in the Parker Dam case, is now in the depths of gloom over its chances of obtaining what it considers a fair share of water and power from Boulder Dam.

Certain changes recently made by the Senate Finance Committee in the unemployment insurance provisions of the Social Security Bill, which had passed the House, have introduced issues of such far-reaching importance to the whole movement as practically to divide the friends of unemployment insurance into two opposed camps.

The Merchants Association of New York has informed the House Committee on Banking and Currency of its opposition to the measure introduced by Representative Kopplemann of Connecticut that would create an intermediate credit corporation to aid in financing small and medium sized commercial and industrial establishments.

AUSTIN, Texas, June 15 (AP). -- Roaring winds joined flood waters tonight in a devastating attack on Central and Southwest Texas which left at least thirteen persons dead and scores missing. Losses to crops and property amounted to millions of dollars.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 15. -- A.W. (Laddie) Biggs, strapping representative of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in Huntington, today gained the final round of the annual Long Island amateur golf championship, in which he is defending titleholder.

FIVE million licensed anglers this year will whip streams, rivers and lakes the country over for trout, bass and other game fish. More than 440,000 anglers will cast Silver Doctors, Black Gnats, Royal Coachmen, Parmacheene Belles, White Millers and other lures upon the fish-filled waters of New York State alone.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., June 15. -- Tempestuous weather conditions marred the opening of the Eastern Horse Club's thoroughbred racing meeting at John R. Macomber's Raceland estate today.

GENEVA, June 15. -- Moving with unexpected speed, the International Labor Organization's hours committee adopted today, 31 to 2, a rough draft of its blanket convention establishing the forty-hour-week principle. The text of its only article, which will be put in final shape Monday by the drafting committee, including Charles E. Wyzanski of the American delegation, reads:

A familiar pair of heels was shown to the sprinters in the handicap division when the redoubtable King Saxon tow-roped his field in the featured Carter Handicap before 20,000 persons at Aqueduct yesterday. It was the seventh victory in eight 1935 starts for the C.H. Kneblekamp colorbearer. He was also defeated only once last year.

LOVE: In various ways the Soviet Government has sought recently to strengthen the ties of family life. Last week Pravda, the Communist party organ, helped along the movement by this statement: "Love is the whole foundation of the Socialist family. Without it, that family cannot exist.

MOUNT HOLYOKE COLLEGE next Autumn will begin a unique experiment in education. A group of not more than twenty freshmen, carefully selected, will be permitted to study only two subjects instead of the five which the conventional college prescribes.

TORONTO, Ont., June 15. -- The directors of Macassa Mines, Ltd., have declared a dividend of 5 cents a share, payable on July 2 to shareholders of record of June 17. This is the company's third dividend of this amount and the second this year, making a total of about $414,500 in profits paid to shareholders since production commenced two years ago.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 15. -- Declaring that we are entering a period of rapid and "largely unpredictable change," the Hey. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, Associate Professor of Systematic Theology and dean of students at Union Theological Seminary, New York, spoke at the 125th annual commencement exercises of Lawrenceville School here this afternoon.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 15. -- The trial of the Rev. Carl I. McIntyre, pastor of the Collingswood (N.J.) Presbyterian Church, for alleged insubordination struck an unexpected snag here today.

MAKING the most of the ordinary two-week vacation -- or the sixteen-day layoff brought on by the five-day week -- is an old problem, especially to New Yorkers. Too long a trip means too short a rest period, while too short a journey brings little novelty or change.

The possibility of withdrawal from the Federal Reserve System and, in the case of national banks, from the national banking system, as a protest against the Banking Act of 1935, was discussed by bankers last week as an aftermath of the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association.

To the skirl of a 100 bagpipes, 1,000 sons and daughters of Scotland paraded yesterday afternoon from the Caledonia Club, 131 West Fifty-third Street, to the Mall in Central Park, where the Robert Burns Memorial Association held its ninth annual program dedicated to the Scottish poet.

AFRICA is the Dark Continent not only because of the prevailing color of the inhabitants but because of the profound obscurity in which its life is hidden. How much news comes out of Africa? It does not broadcast over the radio or attract the Argus-eyed movie camera save as a preserve of big game.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 12, aggregated $7,054,000,000, or 3 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, which included five business days in most of the reporting cities, and 6 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 15. -- Karl Keller, an engineer, began a wide search today for his son, Alfred, 23 years old, who has been missing since he left home Thursday after suffering a nervous breakdown.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15. -- Dr. Lienhard Bergel, former German instructor at the New Jersey College for Women, declared as early as last March that if he were dismissed Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, head of the department, "will have to go, too," it was testified today by Mrs. Marga Holzman, wife of Dr. Albert Holzman, German department head at Rutgers University, of which the Women's College is a part.

HANOVER, N.H., June 15. -- Ted Olson, veteran Dartmouth pitcher, brought his season to a brilliant close today by shutting out Cornell with four hits, two in the ninth, to beat the Ithacans, 5 -- 0, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., June 15. -- Two persons were killed here today when the motor cycle on which they were riding crashed into a motor truck. They were Emerson Nichols, 21 years old, of 103 Broadway, Newark, and Miss Florence Pheriaylt, 17, of 68 Gouverneur Street, Newark.

DEPARTING from the age-old custom of pointing the path of rectitude to the young graduate, many commencement orators this year are throwing themselves wholeheartedly into the current debate over freedom of speech inside and outside college walls.
LOCUST VALLEY, June 15. -- Favorites were upset today in the first two rounds of match play in the annual invitation best ball golf tournament at the Piping Rock Club.

BOSTON, June 15. -- Retail trade in leading cities in the First Federal Reserve District during the last week has been at approximately the level of the same week a year ago. More seasonable weather has stimulated the demand for Summer wearing apparel.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- Led by the crew of the class of 1910, nine Princeton alumni eights gathered for the third annual informal Nassau alumni regatta on Lake Carnegie this morning. A crowd of 2,000 gayly dressed graduates and their families witnessed the event.

LONDON. IN the popular estimation Colonel Lawrence's achievements in active life far outshone his merits as a writer, but his writings have not escaped notice in the memorial tributes. According to The Manchester Guardian he has left one book which shows that he could write our language with a precision and a subtlety not unworthy to be mentioned in the same breath with Swift.

The current predictions of impending war between Japan and the United States have no foundation. It is true that there are irritating and unsolved questions. The relation of Japanese immigrants to the quota that the United States applies to other nationalities and the recognition of Manchukuo are "open sores."

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Assurances were given by Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador, today that American trade interests in North China had nothing to fear from the Japanese program in that region.

AMHIERST, Mass., June 15. -- Virginia met the first defeat of its Northern tour today when Jack Epple, Amherst pitching ace, set down the Cavaliers with five hits to win, 7 -- 3. The Jells got to Davidson, Virginia's starting hurler, for six runs and added another off Captain Orlin Rogers.

Its superiority apparent virtually throughout the match, Yale's smooth-functioning quartet rode to a 10-to-2 triumph over its arch rival, Harvard, on Morris Memorial Field at Governors Island yesterday in the final match for the intercollegiate outdoor polo championship.

THACA, N.Y., June 15. -- Cornell's senior week program of alumni reunions was marked today with an announcement, at the annual meeting of the Cornell Alumni Corporation, of the election as alumni trustees of George R. Pfann of Forest Hills, L.I., former football star, and Andrew J. Whinery of Newark.

NEW HAVEN. WITH the growing tendency toward higher altitudes for passenger flying on airlines and increasing interest in substratosphere ocean flying, the importance of a basic study of the physiological effects of rarified atmosphere on air travelers has become evident, according to Professor Yandell Henderson.
TROY, N.Y., June 15. -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today gave diplomas to 253 students at its 110th commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Following the conclusion of the CCC art exhibit, now being conducted at the National Museum in Washington, the work of twenty-six young artists in the CCC camps will be hung in the White House, the Treasury announced today.

No yachtsman ever lived who didn't at one time or another imagine he could plan and design the perfect craft. He likes to tinker, fuss and bother with his motor, draw pencil lines on a piece of paper.

Not long ago a committee called on John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, and insisted that he stop the Navajos's form of worship. In replying he said: "The prayer of the Navajo is as sweet and fine as anything in the old Bible."
TIENTSIN, Sunday, June 16 (AP). -- The streets of this city rang with machine-gun fire today as newly arrived Japanese troops put on a mock battle described by their officers as "a defense drill."

Automobile traffic in the vicinity of 111th Street and Manhattan Avenue was impeded yesterday morning as more than 20,000 children marched to Central Park in the twenty-first annual June walk of the Monongahela Democratic Club of the Eleventh Assembly District.

Diamonds, many of unusual size and value, largely make up the $421,975 collection of jewelry which was bequeathed to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Mrs. Emma T. Gary, widow of Judge Elbert H. Gary.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 15. -- Racing to meet the woman who within two hours would be his bride, a Philadelphia man was seriously injured here this morning when the automobile he was driving crashed into a cement pillar.

FOLLOWING up its festival performances of last Sunday, the New Dance League will this afternoon hold a conference on its activities and its policy, to which it has invited all dancers, whether affiliated or not, and a number of guest speakers.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 15. -- The annual garden party given by Marshall Field at Caumsett, his estate at Lloyd's Neck, this afternoon for the benefit of the fresh air work of Greenwich House in New York was attended by 500 persons.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- President Roosevelt's suggestion for a fifteen-day strike truce was unanimously ratified today by representatives of the United Mine Workers, including John L. Lewis, their president, and bituminous coal operators at a joint meeting here. The President acted yesterday on the eve of a threatened walkout affecting 450,000 miners.

IN his quiet, which is to say his usual, fashion, Arthur Hopkins is investigating a bold step -- nothing less than continuing run of "The Petrified Forest" after Leslie Howard leaves the play on June 29. To place another actor in Mr. Howard's role and footsteps would not, as Mr. Hopkins knows, be an unprecedented move.

Reorganization of the Federal Trade Commission, adoption of voluntary codes with arbitration clauses, and a constitutional amendment authorizing Congress to set up the machinery to fix minimum wages, maximum hours and prohibit child labor, were suggested to President Roosevelt yesterday.

WORKING out solutions of prize contests has become one of the nation's biggest industries. By means of radio, advertisements and all the force of ballyhoo, tempting awards, whose value probably ranges between $5,000,000 and $8,000,000 yearly, are spread before a public with more time at its disposal than ever before.

IT is about a year since the Canadian Government made the belated discovery that it had in the Dominion's tourist industry a potential source of wealth and revenue greater than that of the country's gold mines, greater even than its export wheat crop.

SUCCESSION planting is a term familiar to most amateurs, but one which too often remains only an idea and is not translated into practice. Vegetable growers soon learn that if they make but one sowing of such things as beets, beans, carrots on corn, they will reap only very limited returns.

DALLAS, June 15. -- Continued favorable weather in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District has been reflected in increasing business activity generally. Rains have fallen over most of the district, in a few localities amounting to cloudbursts, and farm operations are going forward satisfactorily except where fields are too wet for plowing.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Better weather and the presence of several important conventions brought a broad improvement in merchandising conditions. With temperatures in the eighties toward the end of the week, State Street stores had good shopping crowds which bought freely of warm weather apparel.

SOOCHOW. -- One of the most remarkable institutions in China is the Kiangsu Reformatory in Soochow, where efforts are being made to wean former Communist workers from their belief in Marxism, and to convert them into loyal supporters of the present government instead of standing them up before a military firing squad.

SOME of the epicures fear that the shore dinner is disappearing. Motorists look for this old New England meal and often have difficulty in finding the real thing. But it exists all the same. Many persons are confused by the name "shore dinner."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15. -- Department store executives reported a slight decline in sales during the week just ended, which was attributed in part to the closing of several schools. Otherwise, reports, the length of the Pacific Coast were favorable in character, with the exception of a few strikes, particularly those in Oregon and Washington, where lumber shipments are being held up.

The March grand jury for New York County, held overtime by its investigation into rackets and vice and by a conflict with District Attorney Dodge over the conduct of that investigation, asked Governor Lehman last week to appoint a special prosecutor who would go to the bottom of the situation.

President Roosevelt did some desk-thumping on Thursday. At a conference with administration leaders of the House he refused to be swayed by reports that many of the legislators felt he was going too far in his insistence on "reform before recovery."
GOSPORT, England, June 15. -- Gerard B. Lambert has decided to replace Yankee's box boom with one of the Park Avenue type.

CONSTRUCTION of a 172,000-square-foot addition to the press shop, and other improvements included in the $2,000,000 expansion program now in progress at the Fisher Body plant in Pontiac, Mich., will result in the employment of an average of 750 men from now until the end of the year, according to E.F. Fisher, general manager of the body-building division of General Motors.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13. -- Governor Frank F. Merriam's leadership has now been tested by his first five months as elected Chief Executive -- a position in which he had previously served for seven colorless and uneventful months after the death of James Rolph Jr. automatically elevated him from the Lieutenant Governorship.

James A. Hemstreet, automobile travel director since the days of the "horesless carriage" and formerly a resident of Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Pittsburgh, Pa. Mr. Hemstreet was 59 years old. Surviving are a widow, Mrs. Gertrude Hemstreet; a son, Albert; five brothers, Fred, Harry, Clarence, Percy and Raymond, and two sisters, Miss Josephine Hemstreet and Mrs. Florence Morle.

The Women's Bronx Bar Association, with headquarters at 369 East 149th Street, adopted a resolution yesterday urging the two major parties to nominate a woman for one of the four municipal court justiceships created for that borough at the last session of the Legislature.

MEXICO, D.F., June 15. -- Students joined labor in condemnation of former President Calles today after President Cardenas, at odds with Mexico's "strong man," forced his Cabinet and other high officials to resign.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Ten leading figures in the country's communications industry, including the presidents of four giant corporations, were told by the Federal Communications Commission this week that they could not continue as directors of numerous subsidiaries because they failed to prove such service would not be contrary to "public or private interest."

ALL through the season just concluded Thomas Wilfred has been giving weekly recitals on his clavilux, or color-organ, at the Art Institute of Light in Grand Central Palace. The unique institute -- half research laboratory, half demonstration theatre -- was formally opened in January, 1934, and now has a membership of about 400.

MUCH loose and vague talk about dictators and dictatorships, prospective, probable, desirable, has been babbled back and forth in this country during recent months, most of it with so little knowledge of the subject that this timely book, soundly rooted in extensive information, keen-eyed in its examination and suffused with a sense of humor, should help in clearing up the situation.

Ten new meet records were set yesterday at Travers Island in the Metropolitan A.A.U., junior track and field championships. All of the ten track events saw the juniors blasting standards, some by the margin of several seconds, others by split seconds.
MADRID, June 15. -- Under the leadership of former Premier Manuel Azana, Spain's political Left Wing is making a serious effort to reorganize.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A broad program for recovery and re-employment was adopted today by the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States to guide members of the organization during the year.
MILWAUKEE, June 15. -- The 700 shoemakers employed by the Nunn-Bush factory are going on a "yearly salary basis," assured of fifty-two pay cheeks a year whether business is good or bad.

BOSTON, June 15. -- Annual intellectural competitions between a team of Harvard students and teams from other colleges and universities for a prize of $5,000 and "emblems or insignia" for members of the winning team were provided for in the will of Mrs. Elizabeth Putnam, widow of William Lowell Putnam, Harvard, '82, and sister of Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell. Mrs. Putnam died June 5 and her will has been filed in Suffolk Probate Court.

THERE are few homes where a screen of living vines or plants will not fit in somewhere to afford much desired protection from the Summer sun. For porch sides, unshaded windows, the Summer house, or around a garden seat a temporary screen rather than a permanent one is often wanted, because all the sunshine possible is welcome in Fall and Winter.

Further protests against the differentials allowed by the government to domestic manufacturers competing against importers for Federal orders appeared likely yesterday as importers chafed under the lack of response to earlier complaints sent to the United States Treasury Department.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP). -- Although Boston collected 17 hits, the Indians included home rune by Berger and Hale among their even dozen today to defeat the Red Sox, 9 to 7, and keep in the American League's first division.

NEUROTIC obsessions and cultural decay are not the sole property of the much-abused South. They are equally present, according to Mr. Derleth, in such towns as Sac Prairie, Wis. -- where the blood of the original French and German settlers has become thinned and tainted and pride of ancestry is merely an empty mockery.

In recent numbers of The Saturday Evening Post, Professor WILLIAM STARR MYERS of Princeton and WALTER H. NEWTON, former secretary of President HOOVER, have collaborated in discussing "The Origins of the Banking Panic of March 4, 1933." The articles may have been prepared as a contribution to political controversy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15. -- Scholarships, diplomas and prizes were awarded today to Hopkins Grammar School students. A reception and dinner for the alumni tonight ended the three-day celebration of the school's 275th anniversary.

Ever since Japan entered the stage of world politics she has striven to create buffer States near her borders. She defeated China in the Chino-Japanese War of 1894-95 and took Formosa and later Korea. In 1931 she started her Manchurian adventure and proceeded to erect the "independent" State of Manchukuo.

Secretary of State Hull, in his address last week before the conference of Mayors of the seaport cities, exactly appraised the business situation when he remarked that revival of the durable goods and construction industries was the first necessary step for full industrial recovery.

Additions made last week to the list of bonds called for payment in the remainder of this month before their dates of maturity were few and consisted of municipal issues. Redemptions for future months continued large, with industrial companies, public utilities, land banks and New York City making the feature announcements.

IF no labor were needed to maintain a neat edge along the hardy border there would be more borders. However, some plants are sure to stray away from home to occupy space reserved for their neighbors, and the lawn grasses have the disconcerting habit of encroaching on the flowers.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Seating of Rush D. Holt, Democratic Senator-elect from West Virginia, was recommended by the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections today by a 10 to 4 vote. He will be 30 years old Wednesday and will then be eligible to take his seat under the Constitution, the committee decided.

LONDON, June 15 (AP). -- A statement by the Prince of Wales that only "misguided cranks" oppose military training in British schools has resulted in what is believed to be the first public criticism of speeches made by members of the present royal family.

THE eighteenth season of open-air concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, begins on Wednesday evening on the Mall in Central Park. The series will be known this year as the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.

Declaring that industry is faced with a real opportunity and a great responsibility, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men yesterday said that there is a general feeling throughout the country that "we are on the way back to recovery."

PARIS, June 15. -- There is another new Cabinet in France and a new Prime Minister and a shuffling of governmental posts in Britain. There are new parliaments in Hungary and Yugoslavia, and Italy has now definitely embarked upon a colonial adventure, the outcome of which no man can foresee.

IN "Montana Road" Harry Sinclair Drago has achieved an excellent American historical novel about the stirring times and scenes of the opening up of the Dakota Indian Territory in the early Eighteen Seventies, the gold rush to the Black Hills, the exciting and tragic last campaign of General George A. Custer, and the passing of the Sioux Nation as an independent people.

THE car has been sweeping along at a fast rate most of the day, past mountains, over rivers and through villages. As evening approaches, the inner man begins to assert himself. Where is the night to be spent? There is a closer peering to right to and left as villages flash by, and a consultation of maps, but no place looks inviting and the city is uncomfortably far away.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP). -- The Phillies stopped the rush of the Pirates by defeating Traynor's men in the ninth inning today, 6 -- 5, in the first game of the series.

DALLAS, June 13. -- The breach between traditional Democracy in the Southwest and the New Deal, brought into focus in the controversy over whether the Supreme Court's NRA decision had carried the country "back to the horse-and-buggy age," became sharply defined this week as the State debated the action taken by young Democrats of Texas in resolving to hold true to the States' rights.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 15. -- As hot with his putter as the broiling sun that wilted the field Johnny Revolta, the young Milwaukee golfer, shot into the half-way lead in the Western open championship struggle today with a 36-hole tally of 144 strokes, one under the score of his closest pursuer, Dick Metz of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP). -- The Navy put 433 lieutenants, Junior grade, chosen by the Junior Selection Board for Promotion, on the list for lieutenants. The list included:

JERUSALEM, June 15. -- A Legislative Council of Palestine will be established here soon, other rumors to the contrary. At a meeting of the High Commissioner and representatives of the National Defense party (Arab party headed by Ragheb Bey Nashashibi) Lieut. Gen. Sir Arthur Wauchope, the High Commissioner, said:

WESTBURY, L.I., June 15. -- A hard-hit 70-yard drive by J.C. (Cocie) Rathborne in the final half minute of play enabled the Meadow Brook Ramblers to conquer the Texas poloists, 9 to 8, in a hard-fought match on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

OH, them damn fools," said one Aran Islander, speaking of his relatives and friends. "Sure, 'tis only by chance that God threw the soul into them." And, in fact, it is wonderful that the islanders have not by this time turned into either birds or fish.

WITH retail sales in this area running 4 or 5 per cent ahead of a year ago, the recent improvement in trade continued last week. For the half month a slight gain is expected on the basis of deducting the extra business day in June last year from this period.
HANOVER, N.H., June 15. -- Class Day was observed with traditional ceremony today on the campus, in the Bema at College Park and at the base of Dartmouth's Old Pine.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Yesterday's upturn in wheat on the Board of Trade proved to be a flash in the pan, and while the market was fairly supported early today, bearish sentiment predominated and the July and September deliveries dropped sharply to new low levels for the season.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- The Yale and Harvard crews stowed away their shells and sweeps in their respective boathouses tonight after a strenuous week of manoeuvres on the Thames River.

ORDINARILY "A London Story" would be too colorless and unprecise a title, but applied to Mr. Buchanan's novel it is not inappropriate. The London tale in question is one of two brothers, extraordinarily unlike, who have different attitudes toward living and who are both deeply affected by the women whom they marry.

WHEN heavy water made its appearance the biologists were as curious about its effects as the chemists. Plants were moistened with heavy water, bacteria were soused in it, rats were made to drink it, even Ph. D's. were induced to swallow it and then to wonder what would happen.

Reaching George Robinson, Fordham sophomore hurler, for all of its runs in the sixth inning, the All-Brooklyn college baseball team downed the All-Manhattan nine, 6 -- 5, before 6,000 spectators at Manhattan Beach yesterday. The contest, the first of its kind to be held in the metropolitan area, saw twenty-six players from the nine major colleges in the city in action.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- With William L. Sexton of East Orange, only survivor of the class of 1863, as leader, 3,000 Princeton alumni marched here today in the annual "parade," highlight of the week-end reunion activities.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 15. -- The conference called by the Department of Labor to seek an amicable adjustment of the Toledo Edison Company strike was deadlocked late tonight after all-day sessions.

In one of your issues of last month you published an article about the Ionides Collection presented by Dr. Chauncey Brewster Tinker to Yale University, where he is holding the Chair of English Literature.

MOSCOW, June 15. -- A unique series of experiments in psychology, made possible by the discovery of identical twin boys, who speak a primitive spontaneous language of their own, has begun here in the Medico-Biological Research Institute.

More than 360,000 music lovers attended the 3,500 free indoor concerts given in public buildings of the city during the season ended yesterday, the concert branch of the Works Division reported yesterday to Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

WITHOUT the callow heroics usual to stories of the Naval Academy or West Point, "Brute" is a forthright, convincing tale of student life at Annapolis, its narrative centring in the three years of John Gentner's attendance there as a star heavyweight athlete.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Slugging Charles Lewy, 36 years old, a New York jeweler, as he walked through a crowded lobby of the Pure Oil Building, 35 East Wacker Drive, two bandits soon after noon today seized a bag containing uncut diamonds valued at $25,000 and escaped.

A three-year campaign designed to expand both the residential and industrial markets for electrical products on a national scale will be opened this week by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association. Acting under instructions from its newly formed business development committee, the association's staff is sponsoring a series of cooperative campaigns expected to embrace every branch of the Industry from household lamp producers to manufacturers of heavy industrial equipment.

Decidedly pessimistic as to the effect the adverse NR- decisionI will have on labor and business inI the next two years, Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, sailed yesterday on the French liner Champlain to attend the International Chamber of Commerce meetings in Paris.

Faced with the alternative of extending its fair-practice agreements with the help of the Federal Trade Commission, under the old Federal Trade Commission Act, or of submitting a voluntary code to President Roosevelt for his approval under the new NRA stop-gap legislation, the steel industry is weighing carefully the advantages of each course.

Excellent pitching by John Mooney and heavy hitting by George Stirnweiss featured as the Fordham Prep nine of the Bronx triumphed over St. John's Prep of Brooklyn, 5 to 2, in the final game for the city championiship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Dexter Park yesterday.

CANTON, N.Y., June 15. -- Twenty-seven American colleges and universities and eleven Canadian universities will be represented at the Conference on Canadian-American Affairs, which will open here Monday night with an informal dinner.

RYE BEACH, N.Y., June 15. -- Rain squalls and thunderstorms, which alternately between spells of flat calm and perfect water roughened with whitecaps the surface of the man-made salt water tidal basin adjoining Rye Beach and known as Playland Lake, probably prevented today one of the most remarkable successions of record-breaking in the history of outboard racing.

BERLIN. WHEN a nation undergoes a process of reconstruction and reorganization like that which the German nation has been experiencing during the last two years and still is experiencing today it is natural for these developments to have a powerful effect on its literature.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A defense against the findings of a Bureau of Air Commerce accident board that faulty weather prediction was a probable contributory cause of the fatal crash of the TWA air liner Sky Chief in Missouri on May 6 was made today by W.R. Gregg, chief of the Weather Bureau.

ALMOST overnight the American people have become intensely conscious of the fact that they have a Federal Constitution. The voices of Jefferson and Calhoun, of Hayne and Douglas are again heard in the land. A fierce light beats on the historic document, signed with so many misgivings, accepted with such reluctance, nearly a century and a half ago.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 15. -- A team representing the Bermuda Athletic Association, composed of the leading cricketers in these islands, will sail July 11 for a tour of the United States and Canada.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- The satirist who described the architecture of the modern steel frame tower as designed for the delectation of angels and aviators did not foresee that it would also come under devastating scrutiny by the tax gatherer.

LOS ANGELES. June 15. -- Six University of Southern California stars furnished the fireworks today as the great Trojan track and field team defeated Ohio State's crew, led by Jesse Owens, 9 to 6, before 40,000 persons.
