PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- About 1,500 men and women will receive degrees in course and six honorary degrees will be conferred at the commencement exercises of the University of Pennsylvania Wednesday morning.

NORTON, Mass., June 15. -- The centennial celebration, for which Wheaten College prepared all year, reached its culmination today with the production of "The Centennium" by a cast of 300 students and faculty. Written by Mrs. Ellen B. Ballou and Miss Louise Barr, members of the faculty, "The Centennium" told the story of the gradually changing place of woman in the world during the last 100 years.

MR. LEYBURN'S book is not, he assures the reader at the outset, "a history of frontiers," nor a romantic or biographic treatment of how frontiersmen have grappled with their environment. It deals rather with what frontiers do to men than with what men do to frontiers.

ESTABLISHING a central twenty-four-hour airline weather division at Washington, functioning closely with the headquarters branch of the United States Weather Bureau, Eastern Air Lines has instituted a widespread organization to analyze and disseminate weather information and advices predicated on air-mass analysis to the twenty-five stations on its three routes and to the twenty-five or more planes in flight during each full day.

THERE he stands, Lucky Jim. Who would have believed it, who would have dreamed it a year ago? Not Jim Braddock. World's champion? Why, Jersey James was a poverty-stricken pugilistic wreck. No money, No food, No job, No hope. A wife and three small children to support. A broken past and a dreary future.

LONDON, June 15. -- The Stock Exchange was closed today. Yesterday's Treasury bill tenders encouraged further hardening of discounts. The rate for three-month bills was three-fourths of 1 per cent to eleven-sixteenths of 1 per cent. Loans were in fair demand at one-half of 1 per cent.

Proceeding to a higher closing in a fairly substantial volume of business, the share market experienced again yesterday what is usually referred to as "selective" buying during the half-day trading period. The Stock Exchange thus rounded out eight consecutive days of advancing prices, enabling the averages to show the best gains of any week in exactly one year.

BERLIN, June 15 (AP). -- Australia's Davis Cup tennis team, temporarily at least, staved off elimination in the European Zone semifinals against Germany today by winning the doubles. Germany now holds a 2 -- 1 lead with two singles matches yet to be played tomorrow.

BUDAPEST. -- General Goering during his recent stay in Hungary, despite many engagements, was able to spare a few hours to visit the German villages in the vicinity of Budapest. Just before his visit the population of these villages had flocked together in thousands to welcome Field Marshal Mackensen.

Dog-tireo from the rigors of delivering what he termed "the greatest speech in history" -- it had lasted 15 hours 35 minutes -- Huey P. Long staggered out of the Senate Chamber Thursday morning, rubbed his stubbled chin and yawned. He had made his longest filibuster. And he had been licked.

BUDAPEST. -- General Goering during his recent stay in Hungary, despite many engagements, was able to spare a few hours to visit the German villages in the vicinity of Budapest. Just before his visit the population of these villages had flocked together in thousands to welcome Field Marshal Mackensen.

Dog-tireo from the rigors of delivering what he termed "the greatest speech in history" -- it had lasted 15 hours 35 minutes -- Huey P. Long staggered out of the Senate Chamber Thursday morning, rubbed his stubbled chin and yawned. He had made his longest filibuster. And he had been licked.

A CINEMATIC will-o'-the-wisp goes to ground at last this week when "Nell Gwyn" settles into the Rivoli on Wednesday. "Nell" has been knocked about a bit since Herbert Wilcox drifted in from England about a year ago with its several reels, neatly packaged, over his shoulder.

James L. O'Neill, a vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, has been selected to succeed Donald R. Richberg as head of the new NRA, it was reported yesterday on excellent authority. It was expected that President Roosevelt would announce his appointment in an executive order tomorrow.

TORONTO, June 15 (Canadian Press). -- The $15,000,000 issue of Ontario Government bonds on which no tenders were made this week has been withdrawn and in its place the government has substituted a $20,000,000 short-term issue, it was announced today.
J. George Frederick in his article, "Old Dutch Land Near By," presents in the main an interesting and sympathetic picture of the Pennsylvania German country.

While transatlantic ship lines report their most active season in five years, operators in the West Indies and South American trades also are finding it difficult to provide the desired accommodations in ships they had been accustomed in recent years to sending away with plenty of vacant space.

The board of arbitration selected last year to determine whether the Chinese Government had violated its traffic agreement with the Radio Corporation of America by making a subsequent traffic agreement with the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company has handed down a decision in the negative and ordered costs shared equally between both parties.

THE board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association adopted recently a resolution praising the career of the late Herbert Witherspoon, who died in the course of his activities as the Metropolitan Opera general manager last month.

Increasing consumer demand for retail grades for foods, clothing and household goods is reported by government bureaus at Washington. Government agencies especially active in fostering this movement include the Consumers' Counsel of the AAA, the Bureau of Home Economics and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

BOSTON, June 15. -- A new plan for replacing the NRA by retaining and enforcing salient code provision trough an extension of powers of the Federal Trade Commission was made public here today. The plan, while dependent upon the voluntary cooperation of industry, would have "teeth" in it, unethical or dishonest business men being placed in danger of Federal prosecution.

THE sidewalks of Harlem resound to sprightlier music than that heard on the East Side or West Side of New York, for carefree street vendors employ amusing jingles and syncopated rhythms in offering their wares. Market songs chanted and sung by Negro pushcart, horsecart and cook-shack sellers of foodstuffs impart an air of bustling hilarity to the curb commerce of the section.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Marking the opening of the Summer sports season at the Greenbrier, Julius Pollock Jr., winner of the first West Virginia State golf championship held in 1913 and winner eight times since, is among the stars who have filed their entries for the twenty-second annual meet, to be played at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club from July 1 to 6.
MIDWAY ISLAND, June 15 (Via Pan American Airways Radio). -- "Beautiful dash and without incident," Captain E.C. Musick, the Clipper's skipper, commented after her arrival here today.

ROWLAND HILL HARVEY, Associate Professor of History at the University of California, has written a life of Samuel Gompers which succeeds admirably in giving the picture of the man and the organization to which he devoted a lifetime.

NEW YORK CITY, two-way gate between the playlands of Europe and America, is fast losing a large proportion of her population in the exodus of city-weary natives to vacation lands beyond. But at the same time, as a vacation land in her own right, she begins to welcome her Summer visitors.

THOUSANDS of tourists annually visit the 600-acre W.K. Kellogg Bird Sanctuary of Michigan State College, fourteen miles northwest of Battle Creek, which serves as a practical "working laboratory" for college students and teachers interested in nature study and biology, and for graduate students carrying on research work.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 15, -- The firing of the New York State Rifle Association matches by the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia was concluded at Camp Smith here today with the running off of five pistol matches. Lieut. Col. Henry E. Suavet, under whose supervision the matches were shot, presented trophies to the winners of the pistol matches at the conclusion.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 15. -- A parade of 10,000 Integralistas (Fascists), scheduled in Sao Paulo tomorrow, has been called off. The Integralista leaders learned Communists proposed to attack them.

HOLLYWOOD. THE realignment of production activities, real and rumored, is causing some degree of concern in several branches of the industry that rarely come to the attention of the public but which perform vital chores in the making of pictures.

The power to impose taxes is, of course, an inherent and essential right of government. Necessarily some restrictions upon this power, however, are recognized by the taxing authority. In the case of the Federal Government such restrictions consist only of provisions of the Constitution of the United States bearing upon taxation, and these are essentially only in the nature of self-imposed limitations upon such powers.

WICHITA, Kan., June 15 (AP). -- Wiley Post's aging monoplane, Winnie Mae, which has carried him on two record-breaking flights around the world, failed him today in his fourth attempt to span the nation through the sub-stratosphere.

Negotiations for a settlement of debts are to be undertaken forthwith by the Colombian Government and representatives of holders of the dollar bonds of the government and the government-controlled Agricultural Mortgage Bank, according to an announcement made yesterday by the executive committee of the Colombian bondholders' committees, comprising James Henry Hayes, Fred Lavis and Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, secretary.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 15. -- The appointment of Kenneth E. Olson, Professor of Journalism at the University of Minnesota, as head of the Department of Journalism at Rutgers University to succeed the late Dr. Allen Sinclair Will was announced today by President Robert C. Clothier. Mr. Olson will start in September.

BRIAN PENTON, a columnist on a Sydney newspaper, has written a coarse, brutal and powerful novel that reveals cold intellectual force and honesty of purpose even while it betrays from chapter to chapter that the author entirely lacks that sense of awe and pity which alone would give adequate dignity and meaning to the terrible story he has to tell.

PARIS, June 14. -- Once more, this time under Pierre Laval, a compromise government has been formed in France with limited powers to solve the financial muddle into which the country has got through overspending its income.

VANCOUVER, June 15 (Canadian Press.) -- A tie-up of waterfront activity in every British Columbia port loomed today as a general strike call was issued by the Long-shore and Water Transport Workers Union of Canada. The union executives requested every affiliated local in the Province to cease loading ships.
THOUSANDS cry his name. At Churchill Downs on Kentucky Derby Day, at Pimlico for the historic Preakness, at Belmont Park for the Belmont arise the mighty thunders of:

ROME, June 15. -- Only two months ago Britain, France and Italy solemnly announced in Stress their determination to stand together in all future contingencies. Now the united front in which many saw the only hope of European peace has been shattered, at least temporarily, by a quarrel between two of the three nations, owing to conflicting interests in Abyssinia.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- President Roosevelt's command that House legislation on public utility companies must carry the "death sentence" for holding companies imposed by the Senate has brought a new clash between the Executive and his House leaders and intensified a situation created when the Senate, by only the narrowest of margins, complied with White House pressure to retain the drastic penalty.
ROME, June 15. -- The Italian Government tonight ordered the recall of silver money circulating in the country.
New York had its third successive day of heat yesterday with the temperature rising to a high of 86 at 5:20 P.M., eight degrees below the record for the date.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Ewing Y. Mitchell, Assistant Secretary of Commerce since June 21, 1933, was ousted today by President Roosevelt to make way for John Monroe Johnson of South Carolina, Secretary Roper's home State. The President at once sent Mr. Johnson's name to the Senate for confirmation.

BENIAMINO GIGLI, former Metropolitan tenor, will return to this country in the Fall of 1936 for concerts and radio and opera appearances. Arrangements for Mr. Gigli's return were completed last week in Italy by Frederick C. Schang, New York manager.

QUIN, the actor, asked if he ever remembered a Winter like last Winter, answered, "Not since last Summer." After behaving in a way to justify such a remark, June suddenly remembered her business and proceeded to turn on the heat. She had been anticipated by the reappearance of the annual suggestions about Summer Reading.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PRODUCTION activity in the automobile factories has reached a noteworthy development. Up to the end of May or within a few days beyond it, no less than five companies had built and presumably shipped more cars than their plants were able to produce during the entire twelve months of 1934.

SALAMANCA, N.Y., June 15 (AP). -- Heeding the exhortations of their leaders to "bar the doors to white interference on Indian lands," four of five reservations in New York State stood opposed today to accepting the Wheeler-Howard Indian Reorganization Act.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 15. --St. Francis Prep's doughty band of mermen, holder of the New York City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship, added to its glory by defeating a formidable field for the Eastern Senior interscholastic outdoor title at the eighth annual meet today.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A severe chastisement of Senator Long by Senator Ashurst, to which the Louisianan made only a feeble reply, was the climax of the short Senate session today during which agreement was reached to limit debate on the Social Security Bill on Monday.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., June 15. -- The seventieth prize day exercises of St. Mark's School today included chapel services, addresses in the Field House, where the prizes were distributed, and the awarding of diplomas to thirty-five graduates.

JOEL BARLOW was pilloried by his own generation in his native New England as a dangerous radical, but the descendants of those stern old Puritans now honor him as one of the most illustrious sons of Connecticut.

With titles to all of the twenty- two acres of land included in the Williamsburg housing project assembled and in the hands of the Federal Government, the dust should soon begin to fly on what will be New York City's first publicly constructed dwelling project.

With a view to raising the manufacturing standards and methods in the various branches of the country's package medicine industry, The Proprietary Association this week will launch a comprehensive program of research, built along permanent lines, through the reorganization of its scientific division, it was announced yesterday by Frank A. Blair, president.

The trials of twenty-seven former officers of five defunct mortgage title companies on indictments charging irregularities in the sale of mortgage certificates will be deferred until the Fall term of General Sessions, District Attorney William C. Dodge said yesterday.

PARIS. CONSCIOUS of the fact that in the last three years fewer American tourists have come to France and more have gone elsewhere, those in this country who live by the tourist trade have succeeded in getting the government and the public authorities to do something about it.

IF one seeks the threads of development in the drama variously known as the Conquest of a Continent, the Taming of the Wilderness and the Winning of West, one soon finds that there are certain key men whose life stories must be understood in order to realize what those threads mean and how they are woven together.

FRANK ROSS Jr. was the chief reason why Jean Arthur hurried to New York last week to spend her vacation instead of going to Lake Arrowhead, Yosemite, Hawaii or some covert spot in Beverly Hills. If that sounds like a gossip column item, it is only because Miss Arthur calls herself "Miss Arthur" and not "Mrs. Frank Ross Jr.," which is really the name.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 13. -- Tom Linder, whose theatrical efforts to stir up a spirit of secession and race hatred have been widely condemned in the South, now finds that the Postoffice Department is about to secede from The Georgia Market Bulletin.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Congress is expected to act within a day or two to retain for two years something like $500,000,000 of yearly revenue which is now being obtained through certain temporary taxes. The Ways and Means Committee of the House, where all tax legislation must originate, has recommended that the so-called "nuisance taxes," which bring in about $420,000,000 a year, be extended for a further period of two years.

DETROIT, June 15. -- Flashing a great burst of speed at the head of the stretch, Roman Soldier, stouthearted black colt from the Sachsenmaier Reuter Stable, beat a crack field of six other 3-year-olds today to capture the second running of the $25,000-added Detroit Derby.
SOCIAL consequences of the economic depression, quite aside from labor troubles and unemployment, are the subject of much discussion among those interested in philanthropic work.

TUCKAHOE N.Y., June 15. -- William Carpenter Jr., 18 years old, of 25 Highland Avenue, was fined $10 for shooting at clam shells with a nineteenth century muzzle-loader shotgun. The fine was levied Thursday night and the police here were still holding the gun as collateral today and wondering how the young man fired the ancient weapon without dislocating his shoulder.

CONNECTICUT is celebrating her tercentenary. In towns and villages pageants are recalling stirring events of the past. Exhibits of interest to historians, educators, geologists, lawyers and business men are being shown.

THE root of a broadcast's popularity is implanted in the listener's imagination. Therefore, the trick of the showmen is to play on the imagination with sound; to create a mental picture so the listener at the end of a routine day may revel in a pleasant illusion.

OMAHA, Neb., June 15. -- Omaha was under martial law tonight as the result of last night's street car strike rioting in which a man was killed and more than ninety persons, including women and children, were wounded.

The two most important examples of Chinese jewelry ever acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which are also among the most important known, will be placed on exhibition this morning in the museum's room of recent accessions.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 15. -- John Evers, manager of the Albany baseball team of the International League, visited Warden Lewis E. Lawes for an hour today at Sing Sing and brought with him, as a surprise guest, Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, former star athlete of the prison.

More than 1,900 men and women of the graduating class of City College will receive degrees, diplomas and commissions Wednesday evening at the eighty-ninth commencement exercises of the college in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

PARIS, June 13. -- The Prix de Diane at Chantilly, the first headliner of the June racing season at the most beautiful race course in France, proved to be a brilliant sartorial event. Frocks of supple material trimmed and put together with openwork or handwork, such as fagoting, hemstitching, embroidery, tucking, smocking, shirring were outstanding.

The appointment of three new members to the medical board of the Board of Education follows repeated requests for an adequate staff and draws attention to the scope of its work of examining teachers, pupils and administrative employes of the school system.

METZ, France, June 15 (AP). -- Two German Army planes fled post haste back into the Rhineland today with word that France was not joking when she said she intended to stop flights over her border fortifications.

TIENTSIN, China, June 15. -- Although the Japanese military headquarters in Tientsin officially announces the departure Tuesday and Wednesday of the Japanese garrisons in Peiping and Tientsin -- which were technically relieved this week by two transport loads of replacements from Japan -- foreign observers in Northern Chinese cities will not feel that the tension is genuinely relaxed as long as a formidable Japanese force is at Shanhaikwan, at the Great Wall.

THIS first novel by a young German woman now resident in London has been warmly heralded by English reviewers and recommended by two English book societies -- not without justice. It is a story which may conceivably attract wide attention, and which -- like "Grand Hotel," the novel with which it most instantly tempts comparison -- may contain the basis for successful stage and film plays.

THE attention of the music-loving world turns next month to Salzburg, ancient city of Austria and one of the most beautiful of the Alpine group. Its annual festival of operatic productions, orchestral and cathedral concerts is outstanding in the European Summer program and attracts thousands of visitors from all parts of the Continent, as wall as many from the United States.

More than 1,900 men and women of the graduating class of City College will receive degrees, diplomas and commissions Wednesday evening at the eighty-ninth commencement exercises of the college in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

PARIS, June 13. -- The Prix de Diane at Chantilly, the first headliner of the June racing season at the most beautiful race course in France, proved to be a brilliant sartorial event. Frocks of supple material trimmed and put together with openwork or handwork, such as fagoting, hemstitching, embroidery, tucking, smocking, shirring were outstanding.

The appointment of three new members to the medical board of the Board of Education follows repeated requests for an adequate staff and draws attention to the scope of its work of examining teachers, pupils and administrative employes of the school system.

The two most important examples of Chinese jewelry ever acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which are also among the most important known, will be placed on exhibition this morning in the museum's room of recent accessions.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 15. -- John Evers, manager of the Albany baseball team of the International League, visited Warden Lewis E. Lawes for an hour today at Sing Sing and brought with him, as a surprise guest, Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, former star athlete of the prison.

TWO new highway bridges across the Cape Cod Canal one at Bourne and the other at Sagamore, will be officially opened with ceremonies next Saturday. They replace two older and narrower structures, and are expected to permit the easy movement of the large volume of Summer motor traffic to and from the Cape.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Almost every Senator and Representative deplores the fact that by the Supreme Court's NRA decision the Federal Alcohol Control Administration has been shorn of its power to regulate closely our $2,000,000,000 liquor industry, but differences have arisen as to the form that new legislation, calculated to keep the liquor industry from "running wild," should take.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 15. -- Gifts amounting to more than $217,000 have been received by Williams College during the past academic year, officials revealed today at the annual June meeting of the Society of Alumni. The largest single contributor was a "friend" who gave $161,446, subject to annuity.
KIRBYVILLE, Texas, June 15 (AP). -- A man described as resembling William Mahan, sought in the Weyerhaeuser kidnap case, apparently had escaped tonight after a gun fight with officers.

VANCOUVER. -- The worst phase of the depression -- unemployment and its remedy -- is causing increased anxiety in Canada owing to the continued acts of lawlessness of members of relief camps in British Columbia. These camps as at present administered are being variously condemned as contributing to the unrest of those not yet absorbed in work.

The resignation of Deputy Controller William R. Donaldson and the promotion of John H. O'Brien to succeed him were announced yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor, Thomas P. Smith, now secretary of the department, will become executive Deputy Controller.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 16. -- The signs of the times "point to a change in the direction of some form of collectivism," the Rev. Dr. Julius Seelye Bixler, Bussey Professor of Theology of the Harvard Divinity School, told the graduating class of Cornell University in the annual baccalaureate sermon in Bailey Hall today.

BERLIN, June 15. -- While the week's annual statements of corporations were favorable, reports on present conditions indicate the business recovery has become much slower. If activity due to seasonal stimuli, which will cease in the Autumn, is eliminated, it seems likely that industry will be almost stationary, at, however, a much higher level than during the depression.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 16. -- The fifty-third training season of New York National Guard units at Camp Smith was started here today with the arrival of the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn, 1,100 men, commanded by Colonel Frank C. Vincent, and the Twenty-seventh Division Tank Company of Manhattan, seventy-five men, commanded by Captain Oliver Bell.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 16. -- Norwood Polo Club teams played a round-robin today before a large gathering of Summer residents of the shore section. The Red team, led by Nelson Asiel, was victor, tallying seven goals, to six for W. Foales's Yellow team and three for S. Erlanger's White squad.

MEXICO, D.F., June 16. -- Fifteen thousand Catholics paraded in this city this morning in a demonstration to impress 4,000 Rotarians, now here for their international convention, with their struggle for religious liberty.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 16. -- That the niblick and putter are mightier than the driver and brassie was shown today when Charley Mayo Jr. of Lido won the Long Island amateur golf championship by defeating A.W. (Laddie) Biggs of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 5 and 3, in the 36-hole final round.
A tired, disheveled man, who said he was Eugene Chauvin, 26 years old, of 5,596 Bannantyne Avenue, Montreal, walked into the West Forty-seventh Street police station at dawn yesterday.
Only a few years ago a sniff of wine or a whisky breath would have made Izzy Einstein jump for the nearest disguise and start hunting for speakeasies.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 16. -- With clouds hanging low over a great part of the Black Hills and thunderstorms reported to the east and south, the take-off of the stratosphere balloon Explorer II was again postponed today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,973,354,130. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Representatives of Federal, State, city and borough governments will take part in the ceremonies dedicating the Hillside Housing Development, the big PWA project in the Bronx, it was announced yesterday. June 29 has been set as the date for the dedication exercises.

The Civilian Conservation Corps will begin tomorrow enrolment of about 34,000 men and boys in all cities and towns in New York State, Frederick I. Daniels, executive director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Announcement of twelve additional registration statements involving $13,174,667, and a statement that total registrations in May aggregated $140,208,002, were made by the Securities and Exchange Commission today. The registrations, representing thirty-three issues in twenty-seven statements, made May the third successive month in which the total of new issues has exceeded $125,000,000, a record not previously surpassed except in July, 1933.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 16. -- Robert W. Ryle of Piping Rock and Edward S. Knapp Jr. of the Women's National today captured the annual invitation best ball golf tournament at the Piping Rock Club by turning back J.F. Billings of Morris County and M. Donald Grant of Seawane in the final round, 2 and 1.

The cautious, critical habit of weeding out petty faults here and there does not develop character, in the opinion of the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, dean emeritus of the Divinity School of Yale University. He spoke at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The status of major legislation in Congress is:

Dissatisfaction with the amount of information on the Japanese market available from government sources accounts for the fact that American manufacturers are financing independent inquiries into Japanese production methods, export plans and domestic market conditions, it was disclosed here yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, June 16. -- The cotton-contract market here was only moderately active last week. A general feeling of hesitation prevailed because of conflicting advices from Washington, the quiet foreign markets resulting from the Whitsuntide holidays and a keener interest in the progress of the new crop.

PARIS, June 15. -- The return of the Bank of France as of June 7 showed an increase of 951,000,000 francs in Bills discounted, which was subnormal for this time of the month. The circulation decreased 651,000,000 and private deposits 1,052,000,000 francs.
CHICAGO, June 16. -- Warm weather last week brought more general buying of seasonal goods, which gave retailers the best volume of business since Easter. Women's wear was in good demand.

The solution of life is found in the teachings of Jesus Christ, said the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Erdman of the faculty of Princeton Theological Seminary and president of the Presbyterian Foreign Mission Board, who was guest preacher yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

NEW HAVEN, June 15. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.3, which compares with 82.3 the week before, 82.3 two Weeks before, 82.7 three weeks before and 82.3 four weeks before.

Ministers of the Lutheran church are advised "to perform no marriage ceremony without earnestly expostulating with the bridal couple either before or during the marriage service" on the sanctity of their vows, in a report to be submitted at the seventh annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.

A report made public yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, executive director of the Regional Labor Board, for the nineteen months of its operation, showed that it settled 557 strikes and prevented 210 threatened ones. The actual strikes involved 175,904 workers.

Delivery of "The Rebel," the first fast, streamlined train to operate in the South, to the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad by the American Car and Foundry Company was announced yesterday. This makes the line the first operating as many as 1,000,000 passenger train-miles annually to be completely motorized.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 16. -- President William Allan Neilson will confer 471 degrees at the Smith College commencement exercises tomorrow. Four hundred and thirty will receive the degree of Bachelor of Arts and twenty-nine the degree of Master of Arts.

BERLIN, June 16 (AP). -- Germany eliminated Australia in the third round of the Davis Cup matches today. Gottfried von Cramm, German ace, defeating Vivian McGrath, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

ALBANY, June 16. -- Announcement of a plan to place the name of former Mayor John F. Hylan on the ballots as the 1936 Governorship candidate of the Constitutional Democracy Party was made today by Simeon J. Beckerman, who managed the circulation of the petitions of the Recovery Party last year.

The two New York State women's clay court tennis titles remained in the possession of the defending champions as Baroness Maud Levi defeated Miss Norma Taubele, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in the final round of the singles at the Jackson Heights Club yesterday, and Miss Taubele and Miss Grace Surber retained their doubles laurels by defeating the Baroness and Mrs. Henry C. Brunie, 6 -- 4, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 16. -- The second annual Sands Point Horse Show today at the Luckenbach estate on Port Washington Boulevard, Sands Point, was one of the most interesting country shows for this part of the North Shore. The proceeds will go to the Village Welfare Society of Port Washington.

PARIS, June 16 (AP). -- A Fascist leader was stabbed and seriously wounded by Communists, and student factions rioted in the Latin Quarter tonight as friction between extremists of the Left and Right increased.
Burglars entered the home of Michel Fokine, ballet master, at 4 Riverside Drive and escaped yesterday with loot tentatively valued at $25,000, police revealed early today.
" Intolerance of false belief is absolutely necessary," the Rev. John H. McComb, the new pastor, said yesterday morning in the Broadway Presbyterian Church at 114th Street.

Small craft operating near the lanes of transatlantic ships along the coast have taken the place of icebehgs further at sea as a menace to navigation, according to shipmasters arriving in port. The combination of June weather and carelessness on the part of operators of yachts and motor boats have made the situation at this time unusually serious.

THE TIMES published an account of an attempted hold-up of a local shop in which one of the salesmen refused to obey the command of the armed men to retire to the back of the shop. Instead he rushed at one of the men, attempting to knock the revolver out of his hand. In so doing he was seriously, perhaps fatally, wounded.

" The source of the church's power is from God, and not earthly goods nor fleshly energy," the Rev. John Linton, evangelist of Toronto, Ont., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ALDERSHOT, England, June 16. -- The British Army presented a historical pageant for charity last night and early this morning in Rushmoor Arena. It was acclaimed as "a lesson to the pageant master and stage director."

All interested in city planning and the development of the New York metropolitan district must feel in debt to the Regional Plan Association for its report on travel to and fro across the Hudson. The figures as published are most instructive. They are based on an actual count of railway passengers and commuters by bus and trolley and motor, over a period of weeks.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- There have been no Importations of Canadian cattle here in the last two weeks because of the break in the market here, but at other markets Canadian importations are still large. Since Jan. 1, about 83,000 cattle and calves have been shipped into this country.

MADISON, Wis., June 16 (AP). -- Predicting "grave consequences" from the "present mad armament race," Senator Nye appealed today for national support for such a program of peace and neutrality as was fathered by the late Senator Robert M. La Follette.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., June 16. -- Following is the text of the address by former President Hoover at the commencement exercises of Stanford University this afternoon on "The Essentials of Social Growth in America":
A new service available to the tired business man and to other persons is revealed in the latest issue of the Manhattan telephone directory, which is being distributed to 412,000 subscribers.

ALBANY, June 15. -- Employment, payrolls and hours for the construction industry advanced again in May. According to a statement today by Industrial Commissioner Andrews, employment advanced 11 per cent, payrolls 14 per cent and man-hours 19 per cent from April to May.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 16. -- Vincent Diauon, 27-year-old gunman, listed as one of the most-sought public enemies on the rolls of New York's recently organized State "Scotland Yard" and wanted here for a series of burglaries and assaults upon women, was shot and killed by police tonight in the crowded bar of the fashionable Mayfair Country Club atop Eagle Rock.

The Hebrew Orphan Asylum of the City of New York celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of the Betty Bruhl award last night by demonstrating the achievements of the orphans and presenting more than 100 awards to winners of the various prizes made possible annually through memorial and other funds.

Bradley Delehanty, head of the executive committee of the annual Cedar Valley horse show, which will be held on the Townsend F. Bailey estate in Old Brookville, L.I., on Saturday and Sunday for the benefit of Hope Farm, has announced the following additions to the horse show committee:

BERLIN, June 15. -- Uncertainty on the Reich's finances and the mark currency has contributed to the weakening of business. Banks are of the opinion that the government must ultimately come into the open as regards the real extent of the Reich's expenditure in the last two years.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP). -- A new disagreement between high administration officials and one of the most powerful congressional committees was uncovered today, this time on liquor control.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- A program for the development of Princeton University was submitted by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds to the Princeton National Alumni Association at its annual commencement meeting here today.
Mayor La Guardia issued an appeal yesterday, directed to the public, for support for his plan for a municipal power plant. A public hearing on the project is scheduled for Wednesday.

TOULON, France, June 16. -- The Riviera police hunted for a mysterious "blonde with green eyes" today while secret government agents questioned a young naval aviator charged with selling military photographs to a spy ring.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, June 16. -- Contrary to foreign and Chinese reports received here from Tientsin, every effort, it appears, is being made by the Chinese to comply with the recent Japanese demands and to avoid giving occasion for further demands.

HANOVER, N.H., June 16. -- The present-day college graduate, although brilliantly capable of playing a vital role in world affairs, too often lacks a sense of accountability to the past, President Ernest Martin Hopkins told members of Dartmouth's graduating class in his baccalaureate address this morning.

NANUET, N.Y., June 16. -- Fifteen thousand pilgrims to St. Anthony's Shrine here, augmented by outdoor picnics held by Masons in near-by places, jammed Rockland County highways today to such an extent that thousands of Sunday motorists were delayed many hours.

Excepting for the declining movement in coffee, the local commodity futures markets showed little changes in price last week and activity was at a reduced pace as traders held back to await developments in Washington on currency and other matters. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton, quicksilver, family beef and print-cloths eased, while lard, pork, tin, silk, rubber and hides advanced.

Degrees will be conferred upon seventy-four students of St. Peter's College in Jersey City this afternoon at the second commencement of the refounded college. St. Peter's was established by the Jesuits in 1878, closed its doors during the war when the faculty and student body went overseas, and was reopened in 1930.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- After intensive study of the evils of crime, twenty-five boys who have been graduated from the anti-crime course of the Boys Anti-Crime Council, University Settlement, in the lower East Side of New York City, had a real thrill today when they visited J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 16. -- Capably filling the place of John Hay Whitney in the lineup, Gerald Dempsey played a prominent role as the Greentree polo quartet tallied four times as often as Roslyn in winning today's match at the Sands Point Club by a 16-4 count.

OMAHA, Neb., June 16 (AP). -- Governor R.L. Cochran, acting through his authority as military dictator of Omaha, tonight ordered the streetcar company and the striking organized employes to arbitrate their difficulties.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

As a six-day-a-week rider on the West Side subway between Ninety-sixth and Chambers Streets, more often standing than seated, I have for the past several months utilized the running time in noting the reading proclivities in a comparative way between the men and women passengers that came within the range of my immediate vision.
LINCOLN, Neb., June 16. -- Nebraska's financial record for its fiscal year and for the biennium is written in a reassuring black while many other States worry over debts.

Reflecting the broadening in consumer demand as the result of more seasonable weather conditions, various branches of the wholesale markets here showed a sharp pick-up in activity last week. Orders placed by buyers who arrived in the market during the week and those received by mail stressed immediate shipments of all types of Summer merchandise, particularly white apparel and accessories.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., June 16. -- With exercises in the Methodist Episcopal Church here, a special convocation was held this afternoon for Milton University of Baltimore, which is affiliated with Webster University of Atlanta, Ga., one of the oldest universities in the South.

A steady procession of men, women and children paid their respects yesterday at the bier of John Kaul Jr., 5 1/2 years old, whose body was recovered Saturday from the East River in the Bronx after the boy had been missing for eight days.

AMSTERDAM, June 15. -- Dutch views on the outlook for the gold-bloc currencies are sharply divided. The gold standard protagonists assert a definite victory for the gold currencies over the depreciated currencies, which ought now to stabilize without expecting previous or simultaneous devaluation by the gold countries.

Nine theology students were ordained deacons and six others advanced from deaconship to priesthood at a two-hour service yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop William T. Manning officiated. Almost 2,000 persons attended the service.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 16. -- The Wyantenuck Country Club at Great Barrington, of which Frederick A. Pearson is president, had its first dinner dance of the Summer last night, with 200 attending. Mrs. Pearson, chairman of the entertainment committee, was in charge.

Lost and the object of a search in his native Greenpoint ten miles away, 6-year-old Arthur Maloney Jr. was found at 6 o'clock last night, drenched to the skin, frightened and almost drowning in Prospect Park Lake.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., June 16 (AP). -- A four-man expedition seeking a possible $100,000 in hijackers' cash today located the wreck of the one-time rum runner Dwight in fifteen fathoms of water in Vineyard Sound.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP). -- Despite an increase in total revenues last year of $5,481,811, or 8.07 per cent over 1933, the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company's net deficit after all charges for 1934 amounted to $14,201,818, against a net deficit of $13,054,477 in the previous year, it is shown in the annual report issued today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 16. -- Form players, who have been handed one surprise after another during this year of sports upsets, finally saw a heavy favorite triumph today as Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee captured the Western Open golf championship.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 16. -- Rainbow's End, charming chestnut mare owned by Miss Jeanne Nehrbas of Huntington, L.I., and ridden by James Thompson, was awarded the saddle-horse championship this afternoon in the final competition at the second annual Sands Point horse show.
BOSTON, June 16 (AP). -- The National Association of Cotton Manufacturers moved today to police the industry in the interest of code compliance.

MANILA, June 16 (AP). -- The mid-Pacific bases for Pan American Airways' new line from California to the Orient will be ready for the first flight to China in a few weeks, W.S. Grooch, in charge of construction operations, said upon arrival here tonight aboard the supply steamer North Haven.

Marl Sandoz of Lincoln, Neb., is the winner of The Atlantic Monthly prize of $5,000 for "the most interesting and distinctive work of non-fiction" submitted in the 1935 contest sponsored by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown. The prize-winning manuscript, entitled "Old Jules," was chosen from 582 manuscripts.

TROY, N.Y., June 16 (AP). -- Dr. William Otis Hotchkiss, president of Michigan College of Mining and Technology at Houghton, Mich., has been elected president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the board of trustees announced tonight. He will take up his duties in September.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 16. -- When a lady tips a waiter, that's not news, but when the First Lady of the land tips a collegiate waiter who has not waited on her, that's quite different.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP). -- Steps necessary to shift Federal deposit insurance from a temporary to permanent basis were taken today by Federal banking authorities.

NEW HAVEN, June 16. -- A bitter arraignment of Soviet Russia and strong criticism of the Fascist governments of Europe was voiced by President Angell of Yale University in his baccalaureate address marking the opening of the 234th commencement of the university.

THE Civil War has not been ended. The response to two reviews printed recently in these columns proves as much to me. Ever since I raised the question of the "truth" of Erskine Caldwell's short stories, "Kneel to the Rising Sun," correspondents have been arguing, pro and con. And W.E.B. Du Bois's challenging "Black Reconstruction" has likewise stirred up a rumpus.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 16. -- The Yale and Harvard crew training quarters presented a deserted appearance from 10 o'clock this morning until about 7 o'clock this evening as all the oarsmen, coaches and managers were aboard yachts enjoying excursion trips and having a day or respite from strenuous rowing.
DENVER, June 16. -- The chain letter has gone the way of miniature golf, but it left a deep imprint behind it. Here is what it did in the city of its birth:
Although two games remain to be played in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League, practically all the honors were decided last week, when every team but Columbia saw action at least once.

It is worth more than passing comment to observe in today's news that the colleges report marked declines in the enrolment of engineering and architectural students. While it is true that these professions have been severely hit by the decline in construction prevalent during the past six years, there are other causes besides unemployment which have affected registration.
A new American back-stroke record for women was created by Miss Alice Bridges of Whitinsville, Mass., as 10,000 persons looked on at the Oriental pool, Manhattan Beach, yesterday.

A heavy demand for modernized equipment is expected in railway circles if the recommendations of the report on freight service by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, is carried out. The improvements in passenger equipment which have attracted wide notice in recent years should be extended to freight equipment also, according to the report.
Dr. Mary L. Jobe Akeley, African explorer, will sail Wednesday on the Berengaria for South Africa where, alone, she will lead an expedition into Zululand to make an ethnological study of the natives.

The Senate seems to be on the verge of debating only perfunctorily and passing quickly the full Social Security Bill already passed by the House. It seems almost too late to hope that a measure of so sweeping a nature will receive the close and careful study it deserves. The case for splitting it into its constituent parts is a strong one.

GLASSBORO, N.J., June 16. -- A class of 122 graduates in the three-year course will receive diplomas at commencement exercises at the Glassboro State Normal School here tomorrow night from Dr. Charles H. Elliott, New Jersey State Commissioner of Education.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 16. -- Woodcock, agile bay gelding owned by Frank Bell of Bedford Village and shown by Miss Beverly Sanford, captured blues in two events for hunters, features of the amateur horse show staged by the Lawrence Farms today.

AMHERST, Mass., June 16. -- "Our present economic dilemma was caused not by ignoramuses but by intelligent men who did not have the dynamic resources to keep themselves straight," the Rev. Dr. Henry S. Leiper, American secretary of the Universal Christian Council, of New York City, asserted today in a baccalaureate sermon given to the Amherst graduating class.

The "Music Box Revues" are coming back to their namesake house in Forty-fifth Street. Sam H. Harris and Irving Berlin, producer and composer of the four shows which played there in as many seasons beginning in 1921, announced yesterday a new series of them.
STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., June 16. -- Another warning against any sacrifice of freedom in the search for economic security was sounded here today by former President Hoover.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- President Roosevelt's recent statement that the public utility holding company legislation was a positive recovery measure and would not destroy values was described by Senator Hastings in a radio speech tonight as "less than silly and without foundation."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Monday, June 17. -- The Rochester police service revolver with which Vincent Diauon, 27-year-old Rochester gunman, was armed when he met his death was stolen from detectives here who attempted to capture the long-sought fugitive last June 6.

MILL NECK, L.I., June 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Grover C. Loening were hosts this afternoon at a benefit fashion revue and tea on the terrace of their country home here for the Locust Valley Visiting Nurses Association.
Organization of the firm of Donoho, Moore Co., with membership in the New York Stock Exchange, has been announced. The firm will do a general investment business at 52 Wall Street.
Two men were drowned yesterday when a rowboat capsized in Jamaica Bay, near the Floyd Bennett Airport. A third man was rescued by three policemen. Four other occupants of the boat swam ashore.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 16. -- An impressive ceremony yesterday marked the linking by telephone of Bolivian and Paraguayan military bases throughout the Chaco war area. The communications system was installed to permit the neutral military commission effectively to supervise enforcement of the twelve-day truce.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16. -- Seeded stars prevailed today in the annual men's New Jersey State tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Lord HARDINGE of Penshurst is a distinguished diplomatist of the old school. He entered the service in the early Eighties. He has been Ambassador to Russia and France and Viceroy of India. For eight years he was Permanent Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- In answer to the question "What is for me the good life and how can I find and pursue it?" Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the senior class members in the annual baccalaureate sermon in the university chapel this morning that they must "take a long look ahead and decide today the sort of person they want to be in middle life and in old age."

Recent events have brought into sharp review not only President Roosevelt's factual reactions to the social and economic legislation of his administration but also those of his immediate advisers. To the student of current events and the man in the street, the thought has occurred that with ordinary legal and economic counsel as to policy, much of the humiliation and loss of prestige due to the devastating Supreme Court decision might have been avoided.

In Miss GRACE ABBOTT'S broadcast from the International Labor Office at Geneva on Saturday one detected many of the fine qualities which have marked her previous official work. She was speaking of the vote of the conference in favor of the forty-hour week.
Three young brothers found dead early yesterday in an ice box in their father's moving van in Brooklyn died accidentally, the police declared after an investigation.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Answering an urgent request from President Roosevelt, Congressional leaders will attempt this week to drive the Guffey Coal Bill toward final passage as a preventive against the threatened strike of 450,000 miners in the bituminous fields.

That terrific burst of speed unleashed by Bill Bonthron for second place in the "mile of the century" at Princeton on Saturday was a farewell gesture to foot-racing by the New York A.C. ace, it was learned yesterday. Bonny is through with the sport for good, just as he said last February.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16. -- Officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Newark will interview members of the national FHLB board in Washington, D.C., this week in an effort to persuade the board to rescind its recent resolution which would transfer the headquarters of the bank from the Raymond-Commerce Building here to New York.

QUEBEC, June 16 (AP). -- The 42,000-ton liner Empress of Britain, flagship of the Canadian Pacific fleet, was in collision in the foggy Gulf of St. Lawrence today with the collier Kafiristan, which was badly damaged by the impact. Three men are believed missing from the latter vessel, according to a message reaching the Canadian Pacific offices here tonight.

World production in industry showed a gain in April over the average in the first quarter of the year, according to a compilation by the National Industrial Conference Board. In all of the principal countries; except France, Belgium, Switzerland and Holland, the output was substantially larger than a year ago.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 16. -- An analysis of the American social, political and economic structure "with a view to correcting its evils and to building a better world" was urged here this morning by President Tyler Dennett in a baccalaureate address to the first Williams College class to graduate under his administration.
ATLANTA, June 16 (AP). -- Legal groundwork for a United States Supreme Court review of the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority has been laid.

The wire-enclosed haven for missing children at Coney Island, just off the busy beach under the Boardwalk at West Eighth Street, had a turnover of twenty-three children yesterday, the first busy day of the year.
VIENNA, July 16. -- There are relatively more foreign tourists in Austria this June than in any other Continental country -- relatively, that is, to the size of the country.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 16. -- Roy Manny's Bozo defeated fourteen rivals in the special Interclub Class race conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club today in a light easterly breeze.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16. -- Fire, believed to have been of incendiary origin, swept a six-story apartment house here at 3 o'clock this morning, endangering eighty-five tenants, causing burns and injuries to eight and doing $75,000 damage. Four alarms were required.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 16. -- Jose Padin, Commissioner of Education, in a public statement today asks island teachers not to think they will be replaced by the 300 continental teachers of English who are to come to Puerto Rico to offer intensive English courses in the upper grades of the island schools.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 16. -- "There will be no security, no prosperity, no contentment so long as clouds of war hang on the horizon." President Kenneth C.M. Sills deeclared at the Bowdoin College baccalaureate services here today.

Tung-Sol Lamp Works, Inc., manufacturers of metal radio tubes, flasher lamps and automobile lamps, purchased the five-story plant of the James A. Banister Shoe Company at 370-386 Orange Street, Newark. The buyers plan to erect a new structure adjoining the Bannister Building, according to Berry Bros., brokers in the deal.

LONDON, June 16 (AP). -- While rescue workers fought their way through tangled wreckage in search of further victims of a train collision near London which killed fourteen, another passenger train piled up near Glasgow today, injuring twenty-two persons.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Liquidation in the grain markets, which has been prevalent over the greater part of the world for some time, has lowered prices to levels that have caused an unusual amount of comment and at the same time placed the trade in a most uncomfortable position.
DETROIT, June 16 (AP). -- The Tigers collected seventeen hits today to triumph over the Athletics, 13 to 3. It was the third straight defeat for the Mackmen in the series.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Lester W. Herzog of Albany was appointed today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, to serve as Federal Works Progress Administrator for New York State. The selection of Mr. Herzog for this post, which was said yesterday by an administration official to be "of the highest importance," was announced without amplification or comment at the office of Mr. Hopkins.
Conscience and the way it functions was the subject of the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland's sermon yesterday morning at St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

HARRISON-ON-THE-SOUND, N.Y., June 16. -- More than 1,500 clubmen, their wives and guests attended the annual membership field day celebration at the Westchester Country Club this afternoon, with special golf, putting matches and sporting events as features.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A $300,000,000 "white collar" program, more carefully conceived than either of those carried out by the CWA or the "direct" relief administration, has been virtually completed by Harry L. Hopkins's Work Progress Administration.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 16. -- A century at cricket today went to the credit of A.A. Simpson of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in the New York and Metropolitan Association match with the Veteran St. George eleven at Warinanco Park. The New Mooners won, 177 to 69.

BERLIN, June 17. -- Anglo-German relations continue to engage the attention of an influential part of the German non-party press and a striking aspect of this is the daring with which a few editors have risked forfeiture of their official press permits by giving space to British criticisms of the German official procedure in the domains of culture and religion.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 16 (AP). -- Ben Shaw, Westville, N.J., today won the fifty-mile Langhorne auto racing championship. Three accidents which marred the qualifying trials resulted in the death of one driver.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 16. -- Five girls, accused of being inadequately attired for a stroll through Yonkers, received summonses today in a one-man crusade begun by Alderman William Slater of the Ninth Ward, who, assisted by a photographer and a motion picture camera, was determined to have evidence of his contentions.

CHARLESTOWN, Mass., June 16 (AP). -- In an address celebrating the 160th anniversary of the Battle of Bunker Hill, Postmaster General Farley said tonight that historical shrine "stands as the most familiar token of our national achievements."

MEDFORD, Mass., June 16. -- In a baccalaureate sermon at Tufts College today, the Rev. Dr. Lee S. McCollester, the college chaplain, called for "calm, sane and constructive leadership" in the world, for "freedom of the individual and the uplift of the masses."

WHEN Sam Parks Jr. won the open golf championship over the Oakmont course a week or so ago he scored a couple of double firsts. He was the first college graduate to join the golf professionals and beat them at their own game. Also he was the first fellow to begin golf by taking lessons and then go ahead to win a national championship.

Moderating temperatures brought benefits yesterday to men, women and children in and out of the city. To those obliged to remain in the city the high of 79 did not seem oppressive compared with the heat of the previous three days. Visitors at the resorts and beaches found the weather hot enough to enjoy bathing and lolling in the sun.

In the President's veto of the Bonus Bill he referred to the Civil War period of printing Treasury notes "having caused this nation untold troubles, economic and political, for a whole generation." Recalling from my boyhood days some of these troubles and the constant pressure now exerted in Washington for more fiat money, I wrote to the Secretary of the Treasury for information and received a reply as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- St. James's Church and the Church of St. Luke and the Epiphany, two prominent parishes of the Protestant Episcopal communion, have agreed to combine their leadership and resources in an effort to solve the "admittedly difficult problem" of a centralized city church, it was announced today.

The crook, so familiar in motion pictures, who carefully wipes his fingerprints from a polished surface with his handkerchief, no longer saves himself from detection if he inadvertently leaves the handkerchief as he makes off with the jewels.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 16. -- Among those playing on the Maidstone golf links this morning were William Carter Dickerman, Henry R. Sutphen, Theodore C. Corwin, H.J. Robertson Jr., Juan Terry Trippe, Howard Dean, Robert McCormick, Jorges E. Zalles, William Northrup, Howard Guthrie, Mr. and Mrs. John Lafayette Weeks and Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin.

Michael Razumni, who appeared here earlier this season with the Moscow Art Players, made his debut in Yiddish on Saturday night at the Public Theatre, Second Avenue and Fourth Street. His program consisted of four sketches and one-acters: "Peace Conference," "The Forsaken," "Man, Wife and Lover," by Evreinev and Razumni, and "The Living Corpse," which is no relation of Tolstoy's work, but a farce written by the actor himself.

TROY, N.Y., June 16. -- After taking every event in which she was entered, Spray of the Seas, seven-year-old gray mare of the Willisbrook Farm, Malvern, Pa., captured the grand championship of the Troy horse show, ending a four-day competition today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16. -- California's varsity crew, whose time trials last week were the most impressive on the river, was installed as the favorite when the Poughkeepsie book on Tuesday's Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta was opened tonight.

MIDWAY ISLAND, June 16 (By Wireless). -- With the first non-stop flight between Hawaii and Midway Island accomplished without incident, a span extending across half the Pacific Ocean has been completed in an aerial bridge to link America and the Orient.

The new plan for the West Side improvement does not represent essentially an improvement of Riverside Park, but, rather, just another motor highway. It omits the desirable features which have been urged for many years by the advocates of adequate recreational facilities.
WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Termination of fourteen national bank receiverships during May was announced today by Controller of the Currency O'Connor.

ROME, June 16. -- Premier Benito Mussolini took advantage today in a brief address, delivered in the Temple of Venus amid the ruins of ancient Rome, to several thousand former grenadiers to refer again, by implication more than in actual words, to the Italo-Abyssinian situation.

YONKERS N.Y., June 16. -- Annie, a "grayish" cat owned by Mrs. Ernest Piniella of 114 Alexander Avenue, in a frenzy of fear for the safety of her four kittens, inflicted a score of bites and scratches on Mrs. Piniella and two small children early tonight.

CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP). -- Mel Harder, ace right-hander of the Indians, held the Boston Red Sox to a feeble single in the second inning of the first game of a doubleheader today. The Indians won, 4 to 0, and went on to wallop the Sox, 9 to 3, in the second contest.

If the teachings and principles of Christ received practical application in men's daily lives, life would be a "fine adventure," the Rev. Frank W. Murtfeldt said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

No one can turn a colder eye on human motive than a hardened sports writer. On the eve of the Baer-Braddock fight it all seemed so plain. The contest should never have been foisted on the public. The proper odds against BRADDOCK were not the current 5-to-1 but might just as well be 100-to-1.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 16. -- Proceedings for the incorporation of a New Jersey unit of the National Federation of Small Business, an organization recently formed in this State to obtain Federal financial assistance for independent business concerns, will be started this week, it was announced here today by Clarence A. Appleton, president of the federation and a Newark attorney.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP). -- The Boston Braves turned the tide in the second game of a double header today and with a 15-hit batting spree defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7 -- 4, after losing the opener 7 -- 6.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP). -- The Phillies gained their second successive victory over the Pirates today, 12 to 4.
Cardinal Hayes presided in the sanctuary at solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, his presence imparting additional solemnity to the ceremonial in observance of Trinity Sunday.

The Giants were not fooled by Fidgety Phil Collins's new Cardinal uniform. He still looked like a Philadelphia pitcher to them. So they drove him out of the box with a five-run barrage in the first inning at the Polo Grounds yesterday before an out was made and coasted to a 7-3 victory over St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- James L. O'Neill, acting administrator of the new NRA, is on leave from the Guaranty Trust Company, New York City, of which he is operating vice president. In recent months he has been NRA code control officer.

Seventy-two men and women patients of Welfare Island institutions were solemnly confirmed yesterday afternoon by Bishop William T. Manning, who made his fifteenth annual visit to the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the northern end of the island.

While contractors and allied building interests seem to agree that some form of ethical standards is required for their industry as the result of the legal ruling against NRA, discussions in construction circles over the week-end indicated wide differences of opinion as to what form such regulation should take.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- The elements dealt the Yankees an unkindly blow today when, shortly after the McCarthy forces had showered the White Sox with a seven-run downpour that ran up the score to 8 -- 0, a deluge of rain broke up the first game of the afternoon's scheduled double-header and drenched a crowd of 50,000.

A proposal to establish a labor college as part of the newly-chartered Jewish Teachers Seminary and People's University was endorsed yesterday by representatives of 300 Jewish organizations at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Opposition to Borough President Samuel Levy's plan for an East Side express highway in Manhattan, from the Battery to 125th Street, was voiced yesterday by the directors of the First Avenue Association.

A new Community of Sisters has been established by Cardinal Hayes to cooperate with the Catholic Medical Missions and to assist at the headquarters of the Catholic Medical Mission Board, 8 and 10 West Seventeenth Street, according to an announcement by the Rev. Edward F. Garesche, director of the board.

MOSCOW, June 16 (AP). -- The newspaper Pravda, organ of the Communist party, charged today that Japan plans to carve a new empire out of Manchukuo, North China and Inner Mongolia and use it as a base for more extensive conquests.
WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The texts of President Roosevelt's Executive orders continuing the NRA were as follows:
N. Nickita challenges the figures given by me of the population of the Aegean Islands.
Three boys, two of them 13 years old and one only 11, stole a revolver from a policeman's coat in a Jamaica police station Saturday afternoon and embarked on a career of crime.

MIDWAY ISLAND, June 16. -- In a 500-mile flight that took the trailblazing Pan American Clipper 200 miles further into the Pacific along the projected route to the Orient, Captain Edwin C. Musick and his crew completed a series of calibration runs to check the powerful radio-compass station installed here.

MOSCOW, June 16. -- The first official forecast of this year's grain harvest was published today. Compiled by a commission of experts in the Kremlin from data sent in by local officials, it strengthens the prediction that this year's harvest will be the biggest in Russia's history and far larger than the crops of 1933 and 1934.

PITTSBURGH, June 16. -- Prices of pig iron, semi-finished steel and finished steel products have held rigidly since the "code of fair competition for the iron and steel industry" lost its legal force by the decision of the Supreme Court almost three weeks ago.
Sending five runs across the plate in the third inning, the Jersey City Red Sox blanked the New York A.C. at Travers Island yesterday, 6 to 0.

TOLEDO, June 16. -- Unless unforeseen obstacles arise the strike of Toledo Edison Company workers, which has threatened to lead to a general strike of all local labor unions, probably will be settled tomorrow morning on the following terms:

TOKYO, Monday, June 17. -- The Chahar affair has been settled by Governor Sung Cheh-yuan's complete acceptance of the Japanese demands. He agrees to punish the officials responsible for the recent incarceration of four Japanese, to suppress anti-Japanese agitation and to give guarantees for the future control of anti-Japanese movements.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The crisis of today and tomorrow was presented as the opportunity of the American Legion and accepted as such in addresses delivered at a special service held this afternoon in the ampitheatre at Washington Cathedral by the Legion in dual observance of their first "National Church Sunday" and of Father's Day.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- President Roosevelt, in executive orders tonight, set up an organization to carry out the skeletonized National Recovery Administration until April 1, 1936, as provided in Congressional passage of the resolution extending the recovery agency's life under restrictions limited by the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case.

Stocks of cotton in the United States and India at the end of May were much smaller than on the same date last year and two years ago, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. Stocks here were much larger than in pre-depression years, but those in India were smaller than the pre-depression average.
Three persons died yesterday of burns they received Saturday night when fire swept through The Mansion, 27 St. Mark's Place, just before a wedding ceremony was to be performed.

PARIS, June 15. -- The new government was expected, if not to act immediately, at least to give some outline of the measures it intended to take to set the budget situation straight, but it appears that a program has not been drawn up, even along general lines.

The first unit to enter the seventh annual renewal of the Lordship skeet tournament, June 29 and 30, was the Choate School for Boys team, which has won several matches from strong outfits in the vicinity of Wallingford, Conn.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16. -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, counseled against fear in the baccalaureate sermon today. "Face the future unafraid, no matter how dark it may appear," was his advice to the graduating class.

TIENTSIN, China, June 16. -- Watched by large crowds of Chinese and foreigners, including Japanese, the Japanese garrison here staged today a sham battle in the Japanese Concession under condition of actual warfare. The manoeuvres were held for the benefit of the newly arrived Japanese troop replacements.

Temporarily, the phrase "Grass Roots" is having a great run: Grass Roots Uprising, Grass Rooters Root, and so on. With such titles, solemn or facetious, do commentators on the Springfield conference refresh their souls. Evidently there is a curious felicity in the nickname, that is largely absent from the platform, whose makers had the task of damning and praising by implication or silence the Administration.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., June 16. -- The Nazi swastika swung peacefully in the June breezes today beside the flag of old Germany and the Stars and Stripes at the fifty-second Plattdeutsche Volksfest while 5,000 members of fifty German benefit societies took part in the opening ceremonies of the annual three-day festivities.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- More than 250 couples are expected to attend the annual senior promenade, highlight of the Princeton senior class day ceremonies, to be held in the university Gymnasium tomorrow evening.

Reassured as to the physical capacity of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody to undertake the assignment on the strength of her showing in English tournaments the past two weeks, the Wightman Cup committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association has designated the former champion as a member of the squad tentatively selected to defend the trophy in the international team match with the British women at Forest Hills, Aug. 16 and 17.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 16. -- The tournament polo season on Long Island got under way at the Meadow Brook Club today, with the Gulf Stream riders upsetting Aknusti, 11 to 7, in a well-played first-round match of the Third Westbury Challenge Cup event.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad shows in its report for 1934 a market loss of more than $2,000,000 on transactions in its own securities undertaken a short time before it entered bankruptcy. The report shows also that it lent $356,757 to "individuals and companies engaged in produce and fruit packing" and spent $371,569 in the "acquisition of orchard, farm and elevator."

LONDON, June 15. -- From being the leading feature in the financial situation, the foreign exchanges have fallen into the background, following the granting to the new French Ministry of the plenary powers which it demanded for protection of the franc.
NEWARK, N.J., June 16. -- Newark divided a double-header with Rochester before 7,000 fans today. The Bears won the first game, 9 to 5, and lost the second, 5 to 2.
LONDON, June 16 (AP). -- Political circles learned today that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin had decided to reject David Lloyd George's proposed New Deal for Great Britain.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 16. -- Members of the senior class of Trinity College heard the Right Rev. John I.B. Larned, Suffragan Bishop of Long Island, give the address at the baccalaureate service here tonight.

NORTON, Mass., June 16. -- "A hopeful belief about the future is not a purely intellectual theory, but is partly an attitude of will," Dr. Walter O. McIntire, Professor of Philosophy at Wheaten College, said in the centennial baccalaureate sermon today.

Summer vacations explain much of the lack of enthusiasm in church work, according to Rev. Robert H. Dolliver, who preached yesterday morning at the John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, of which he is pastor.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 16. -- Senator Carter Glass and eleven others received honorary degrees from Wesleyan University today as the commencement exercises closed with graduation of 115 members of the senior class. Master of Art degrees were conferred on sixteen graduate students.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP). -- Twenty-two of the nation's "sovereign States," through officially accredited delegates, joined today in an effort to evolve the beginnings of a concrete plan to remedy what they termed an outstanding defect of American polity -- lack of machinery for effective settlement of interstate problems.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 16. -- Delegates attending the annual session of the National Conference of Jewish Social Service today heard a review of Jewish economic adjustment problems in European countries, in Palestine and in the United States.

News stands on the city's curbs soon will be licensed, Commissioner of Licenses Paul Moss said yesterday afternoon at the seventh annual meeting of the New York Protective Association of Blind Newsdealers, Inc., at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP). -- The Browns divided a free-hitting double-header with the Senators today, taking the second game, 10 to 9, after dropping, the first contest, 17 to 8. The games, played on a rain-soaked field, drew only 2,500 Sunday fans.

Frank Craven, the actor-playwright, will join Miriam Hopkins, Edward G. Robinson and Joel McCrea in the cast of Samuel Goldwyn's production of "Barbary Coast," which Howard Hawks, the director, will soon place before the cameras.

The March New York County grand jury will present to Governor Lehman at 11 A.M. today its request for a special prosecutor and a special grand jury to carry on the investigation into vice, policy and gambling that it dropped after breaking with District Attorney William C. Dodge.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 16. -- Delivering the baccalaureate sermon at Hamilton College today, Dr. Robert Gardner McGregor of New Rochelle asserted that the two truths which men must learn in life are the existence of an orderliness of things and the fact that all men are not created equal.

NANKING, June 16 (AP). -- Prospects for a peaceful solution of the Chino-Japanese crisis appeared brighter tonight when official circles said the Chinese Nationalist Government had "definitely adopted a peaceful policy."

Last week's 5-point advance brought stock market "averages" to the highest figure since February, 1934, and within less than 2 points of the highest since 1931. n view of the accuracy with which in the long run the Stock Exchange has foreshadowed revival or reaction in the course of general trade, the season's movement has been interesting.

MEXICO, D.F., June 17. -- The political conflict between President Lazaro Cardenas and former President Plutarco Elias Calles ended today with a statement by Senor Calles that he was leaving for his Sinaloa ranch and stepping out of public affairs.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Jacob Berman, Federal prisoner and former Los Angeles promoter, whose testimony convicted Asa Keyes, onetime District Attorney of Los Angeles, now dead, of bribery, was held here today while his lawyers prepared for a habeas corpus hearing tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- In a study of the wheat problem under the Agricultural Adjustment Administration released today, the Brookings Institution asserts that wheat prices during the last two years were increased by the drought, plus the influence of the tariff, and to "some extent, dollar depreciation."
