Casey Stengel shook up his lineup and led with his ace yesterday in a desperate effort to shake off the worst losing streak that the Dodgers have had all year, but it availed him nothing.
The passenger list of the American Merchant liner American Merchant, due today from London, includes:

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 16. -- A warning that the social aims of Christianity should not be confused with the political means adopted to achieve them was sounded before Wellesley seniors today in a baccalaureate sermon in Memorial Chapel by the Rev. Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins, Professor of Pastoral Theology at the General Theological Seminary in New York.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 16. -- The United States Treasury played the decisive role in saving the franc in the recent crisis, Jean Tannery, Governor of the Bank of France, disclosed here today at the monthly meeting at the World Bank of the governors of Europe's central banks.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The new skeleton NRA, shadow of the original far-flung organization, began functioning today and sixteen voluntary codes, two in Washington and fourteen in New York, were awaiting the action of the new administration, of which James L. O'Neill of New York is the acting administrator.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company, its subsidiaries, affiliates, officers and directors, were restrained yesterday in a temporary order signed by Federal Judge Mack from transferring any assets of the Associated system, except in the regular course of business, without notifying creditors who have asked for reorganization of the company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 17. -- Greater Boston had its first taste of horseracing with pari-mutuel betting today as the Eastern Horse Club opened its three days of racing over the Clyde Park course at the Country Club.
Roger W. Babson is quoted as saying: "Our dollar now is worth only 60 cents abroad." "Abroad" covers a lot of ground, and except for a relatively small area, the statement is incorrect.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- A resolution demanding the removal of Josephus Daniels as United States Ambassador to Mexico was introduced today by Representative Fenerty of Pennsylvania, who called also for the strictest neutrality of this government and its officials in the "duel to the death" he alleged was going on between President Lazaro Cardenas and former President Plutarco Elias Calles.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting members banks in ninety-one leading cities on June 12 shows increases for the week of $86,000,000 in total loans and investments, $184,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $291,000,000 in net demand deposits, and a decrease of $26,000,000 in time deposits.

A preliminary meeting of American steamship operators, which may result in formal protest against the high price of fuel oil, was held yesterday afternoon at the Shipping Board Building, 45 Broadway. T.M. Woodward of the Merchant Fleet Corporation, the operating branch of the Shipping Board, came from Washington to address the group.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The action of the United States Treasury on May 30 in helping France support the franc and remain on the gold standard averted immediate danger of a currency devaluation warfare and represented a long step forward in promoting cooperative effort toward eventual stabilization, it is believed in many quarters here.

Liberal reorders on Summer lines and the arrival of a larger number of buyers to canvass the market and make August sales purchases, featured the start of the week in the markets here yesterday. The reorders on Summer goods reflected the effect upon store stocks of the brisk consumer demand last week. Sheer and cotton dresses, sports and beach wear and varied accessories ranging from handbags to millinery were in active request.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 17. -- Cornell University today graduated a class of 862.

Nearly sixty years after the death of one of America's most notorious autograph forgers, Robert Spring, his handiwork is still coming to light to plague collectors, it was revealed yesterday at the New York Public Library.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 17. -- The Westchester Playhouse at Mount Kisco, most popular of the Summer theatres in this county, opened tonight for its sixth season with June Walker in Molnar's "The Good Fairy."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17. -- Yale's commencement exercises today included anniversary law and medicine association meetings and the senior class day programs of the Sheffield Scientific and Engineering Schools.

To explain the mildly reactionary tendency of the share market yesterday, in the absence of anything in the news since Saturday to exert much influence marketwise, it is necessary to fall back on such stock phrases as "a healthy reaction" or "corrective" movement in the light of the series of daily advances lately.

The city of Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday a new issue of $1,181,000 of various improvement bonds for award on July 5. The bonds will carry a 4 per cent coupon and will he dated variously on Dec. 15, 1933, and May 1, 1934, maturing on Feb. 1, 1940 to 1958.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Exchanges of $416,602,800 in 3 per cent Treasury notes and $353,865,000 in 1 5/8 securities of the same type maturing on June 15 and Aug. 1, for a new issue of 1 1/2 per cent notes of five years maturity, amounted to $738,373,400, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

Improvements are being made at the Lewisohn Stadium in preparation for the annual series of concerts which will begin there on Wednesday evening, June 26. The changes include landscaping of the field, a rebuilt stage and a new amplification system.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 17. -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut, Francis P. Garvan, head of the American Chemical Foundation, and Bishop Maurice Francis McAuliffe of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Hartford at commencement exercises held at Trinity College here.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Application for registration by 1,800 brokers in the over-the-counter market had been received and filed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and another 500, which contained many omissions, had been returned to the ap plicants for revision.

Surf beat last night on Pacific atolls, and tall palms undoubtedly whispered in the breeze. But not for Robert L. Stevenson. In spite of his best efforts, he was home from the sea and safe asleep in his bed in Queens.

LONDON, June 17 (Canadian Press). -- For the first time in three years a bowler's aim has been achieved. Playing in a first-class county cricket match at Leicester today, Thomas B. Mitchell, Derbyshire trundler, captured 10 wickets for 64 runs.

OMAHA, June 17. -- Omaha street cars are in the barns by order of Governor R.L. Cochran. He had them taken off the streets at 10 o'clock this morning when the street railway failed to comply with his order that it name a member of an arbitration board by that hour.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The April decline in American exports, including re-exports, was caused by a decrease in buying of all "grand divisions" except northern North America and South America, the Commerce Department's monthly analysis said today.

Robert Stephen Johnstone, former General Sessions judge, who died on June 9, left his estate in trust to his three children, Helen P., Muriel W. and Edward L. Johnstone, all of 22 Midland Avenue, White Plains, it became known yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.
LONDON, June 17 (AP). -- Following are the foreign trade figures of the Board of Trade for May:

Whether by coincidence or by design, the Brookings Institution has published a commentary on certain phases of AAA which appears almost simultaneously with a full-dress report by that organization, covering the whole period from its establishment in the Spring of 1933 to the end of 1934.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Demand for hogs was fairly good here today, encouraging reports regarding distribution of fresh pork being in strong contrast with the semi-demoralized conditions in the markets for beef and lambs. Prices were steady to 10 cents lower a hundredweight than on Saturday, with the top steady at $10.

Si Goodfriend, who, man and boy, has watched baseball as a fan and a sport writer since the days of the Civil War, paid tribute yesterday, his eightieth birthday, to Babe Ruth, as "the greatest ball player that ever lived." He rates the late John McGraw the greatest manager.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 17 (Canadian Press). -- Collapsing before strong English bowling, South Africa was in a bad position today at the end of the second day's play in the opening cricket test with England. With nine wickets to fall, the touring players require 148 runs to avoid an innings's defeat.
CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP). -- The Indians defeated the Red Sox for the fourth straight time today, scoring by 11 to 2 and gaining a tie with Detroit for third place in the league standing.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 17. -- Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs of Richmond was chairman of the judging at the Pittsfield Country Club flower show and assisting her were Mrs. Samuel Gilbert Colt, Mrs. Brenton Crane Pomeroy of Pittsfield and Mrs. Max E. Butler of South Orange, N.J.

Mayor La Guardia issued a statement yesterday urging support of the benefit festival, the June Night Frolic, to be staged tomorrow night at the Yankee Stadium on behalf of the Jewish National Fund of America. Pointing out that New York City had "always occupied the first place" in the struggle to aid persecuted minorities, the Mayor continued:

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 17. -- At midday, in his guarded camp, Joe Louis was taking a comfortable snooze. There must be sleep in the air out here. When Carnera trained here he could be found snoring at all hours. They had a hard job waking Primo up last June to get him to Long Island to fight Max Baer, and it turned out to be mistake, after all.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Under the combined influence of the White House and the Summer's first tropical heat wave, Congress rushed forward with its work today, causing members to cast speculative eyes toward an adjournment date which Speaker Byrns said might be July 15.

HYACK, N.Y., June 17. -- The body of Mrs. Myrtle Best, 27 years old, former wife of Alexander Best, Manhattan insurance broker, was found dead of a bullet wound this afternoon in the home of John Candelmo, her first husband, at Valley Cottage, near here. Mrs. Best had been separated from Mr. Best for some months, according to the police.

MEXICO, D.F., June 17. -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, "iron man" and political dictator of Mexico, bowed out of the government picture today, leaving President Lazaro Cardenas to continue his Leftist program unhindered.

BERLIN, June 17. -- Despite some selling induced by the unexpectedly heavy levies for export promotion, the Boerse maintained its firm trend today inasmuch as the public continued to buy. Net gains, however, mostly were fractional and rarely exceeded one point.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Color was given to reports that Great Britain was contemplating some diplomatic move in the North China situation, and in that event would welcome our collaboration, when Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, conferred today with William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 17. -- With a second claim established on the Brooklyn championship cup, Gregory Mangin of Newark, started out in quest of his third leg on the Marcus Bowl today in the New Jersey State Championship at the Montclair A.C.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 17 -- Hailed as the pride of her college and glory of her country, Anne Morrow Lindbergh received the honorary degree of Master of Arts at the Smith College commencement this morning in the presence of her husband, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

The government adduced more testimony yesterday in Federal Court to prove that the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers has a monopoly on the nation's popular music in violation of the anti-trust law.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 18. -- Japanese Army staff officers, in conference at Hsinking, capital of Manchukuo, agreed today, according to a Rengo dispatch, that the first stage of the army's work in North China had been finished with withdrawal of the forces of former Governor Yu Hsueh-chung, the Chinese Central Government's troops and the gendarmerie.

Seeking to eliminate abuses in the taxicab industry and to provide better hours and wages for cab drivers, Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch plans to introduce a new taxicab ordinance in the Board of Aldermen at today's meeting in City Hall.

The Consolidated Gas system is paying $55,000 a year under a ninety-nine-year lease for an unused substation site at 512 Seventh Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets, according to testimony yesterday before the Public Service Commission. The hearing was on the new reduced rates for electricity filed with the commission by the system.

Governor Lehman was urged yesterday by members of the March New York County grand jury to supersede District Attorney William C. Dodge with a special prosecutor and to impanel a special grand jury to investigate organized vice, the policy racket and crime and their connection with law-enforcement agencies.

PARIS, June 17 (AP). -- France has informed Great Britain she could not agree to the proposed German naval rearmament program, it was learned from an authoritative source here. The French attitude was conveyed in a note handed to R.H. Campbell, British Charge d'Affaires, by Premier Pierre Laval.

LONDON, June 17. -- The French Government's reply to the British announcement that the Anglo-German naval parley had agreed on a German naval quota equal to 35 per cent of the British fleet will be presented to the Foreign Office tomorrow by the French Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The "death sentence" section of the administration's utility holding company bill has been unfavorably reported by a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee, and Democratic leaders have been assured that the full committee will sustain this report.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Allotments totaling about $42,610,557 for projects under the Work Relief program were recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Advisory Committee on Allotments.

TRENTON, N.J., June 17. -- At the request of J.H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, the 155 agencies of the Department of Motor Vehicles will be used for issuance of licenses to retailers throughout New Jersey in preparation for collection of the 2 per cent sales tax under the new law effective July 1.
A career upon the diamond is open to Edwin C. (Alabama) Pitts, former all-round athletic star of Sing Sing prison, Kenesaw M. Landis ruled yesterday in Chicago.

The Republicans who have just finished rooting up the grass tried to give the impression that they believe Mr. Roosevelt is bent on destroying the Constitution and, by implication, the Republic. I wonder if they really think this or expect others to believe it.

on the Anglo-German naval conversatlos. The subject, the Fascist C. overnmer. t said, was not one to be settled through bilateral Anglo German conversations, but in the light of the Arashington treaty and subseI quent naval agreements. Italy is ready to participate in such a conI ference, the note said, with an open !mind and a spirit of cooperation.
West Side housing transactions featured the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday. Nine properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales.
The five Brooklyn men who were the first to be convicted under the newly amended Public Enemy Law won a point yesterday in the test to determine the validity of the law.

The Museum of Modern Art has augmented its Summer exhibition and the supplementary examples of painting and sculpture will be placed on public view today. When the exhibition opened on June 5, a very interesting feature proved to be a group of oils, water-colors and drawings from the collection presented to the museum by Mrs. John D. Rockfeller Jr.

One hundred thousand cases of Canadian bonded whisky have been purchased by Oldetyme Distilleries, Inc., of New York, it became known yesterday. The first of four trainload lots is expected to reach New York next week. The purchase has a retail value estimated at $6,300,000.

" Parade," the Theatre Guild's venture into the not too familiar field of the revue business, will close on Saturday night. Opening on May 20, with Jimmy Savo as its featured performer, the show will have had exactly five weeks here, or the minimum run for the subscribers' money.

More extensive use of arbitration as a means of settling insurance controversies without litigation is favored by a large majority of the companies that have replied to a questionnaire sent out by the State Insurance Department, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.

MIDWAY ISLAND, June 17. -- With dawn this morning the trailblazing Pan American Clipper was speeding eastward back over the 4,000-mile course it had so methodically charted over the Pacific Ocean for the Pan American Airways' projected route linking the United States and the Orient.

At no other spot on the face of the continent is the field so ripe for missionary work as in New York City and the New York area, the Rev. Dr. Ellis B. Burgess, the president, declared last night at the opening session of the seventh annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York in St. Matthew's Lutheran Church, 83 Wayne Street, Jersey City.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17. -- The Bears took the first game in their series with the league-leading Buffalo team today. The score was 3 to 2, the visitors scoring both their runs in the final stanza when young Cecil Spittler weakened after allowing only four hits during the first eight frames.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Meeting with expert advisers to consider plans of procedure in its investigation of the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters, the Senate Commerce Committee was informed today that "160 fire traps are still afloat and carrying passengers," Chairman Copeland reported.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- A slight decline in the number of persons on relief in cities was reported today by Harry L. Hopkins, the Relief Administrator, as State Works Progress administrators conferred with him about starting the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- President Roosevelt in a speech to the State Works Progress administrators banned politics from the $4,000,000,000 relief program and expressed confidence that private industry would soon take up a substantial part of the unemployment slack.

Ministers and laymen of all Protestant churches were urged to intensify their support of scientific and spiritual work among lepers by five authorities on leprosy who spoke at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Advertising Club's building, 23 Park Avenue.

More than 600 of the 1,200 members of the Knickerbocker Village Tenants Association met last night in the basement of 10 Monroe Street, one of the houses in the village, to protest against the refusal of the Fred F. French Management Company to grant renewal of leases to fourteen leaders in the tenant group.

Medals, scholarships, honors and prizes will be awarded to fifty-five graduates and students of City College at the eighty-ninth commencement exercises of the college in Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow evening. The computation of the academic grades of other prize winners will be completed today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 17. -- The liberal arts colleges in this country are endangered by a prevalent feeling that they are "culturally fast getting into the position of the medieval monasteries," Dean Willard L. Sperry of the Harvard Divinity School said today in an address at the commencement of Williams College.

PITTSBURGH, June 17. -- The legislative committee which investigated the status of academic freedom at the University of Pittsburgh in a report today sidestepped a decision on the ousting of Dr. Ralph E. Turner, but upheld some charges made by liberals. The report said:

An attempt by the city to enforce the collection of rentals from electric companies for man-hole space under the city's streets was brought into the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday in a test suit started by the Brooklyn Edison Company.

BERLIN, June 17. -- For the first time since the war today German men of 20 and 21 years began to report to designated recruiting stations to be examined as to their physical, mental and racial fitness to serve in the newly created armed forces of the Third Reich.

In five minutes a jury in Judge Cornelius F. Collins's part of General Sessions returned a verdict of guilty of compulsory prostitution late yesterday afternoon against Patsy Pagluico, 45 years old, a rival of Nicholas Montana as "vice overlord" in the midtown district.

TORONTO, Ont., June 17. -- Sale of Ontario's new $20,000,000 bond issue through twenty-one provincial savings banks was opened today, and at the close of the day's business it was announced that sales amounted to $2,500,000.

Seeking to drive more than 3,000 miles across the continent at a total fuel cost of less than $8, C.L. Cummins, president of the Cummins Engine Company of Columbus, Ind., left City Hall yesterday morning at 11:15 o'clock in a Diesel-motored automobile.
AMHERST, Mass., June 17. -- President Stanley King conferred 134 degrees in course, eleven honorary degrees and three medals of distinctive service at the Amherst College commencement this morning.

Censuring the slowness with which dogs that have bitten persons sometimes are seized for examination by the Health Department, Magistrate Anna M. Kross, sitting in Harlem court, declared yesterday that she was "going to see that a more adequate system is taken in the future to insure the people's safety."

RYE, N.Y., June 17. -- Playing over the historic links of the Apawamis Club on which she recently captured the metropolitan title, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden today won the medal in the qualifying round of the thirteenth annual women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship.

MONTREAL, Que., June 17. -- A tentative offer by Bowater's Paper Mills, Ltd., of England in an effort to reorganize Price Brothers Co., in receivership, was reported in reliable circles here today. The report was coincident with the return here of Gordon Scott, receiver of Price Brothers, from London, where he was engaged in negotiations in this connection.

Ernest Hammer, 30 years old, of 435 East Sixty-sixth Street, a special patrolman at New York Hospital, was stabbed twice at 3:15 A.M. yesterday in a fracas with a group of men at York Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street when he remonstrated with two of them for annoying hospital nurses.

CANTON, China, June 17. -- The two rebel Cantonese cruisers Haichi and Haishen, which escaped from Canton by running the gauntlet between river forts, ran aground yesterday in the Canton River and offered to surrender, but were re-floated today and dashed away amid a hail of bombs from airplanes.

Five Internal Revenue agents walked into the bar-room of the Lundy Brothers Restaurant at Sheepshead Bay at 7:30 o'clock last night, confiscated bottled liquor valued at nearly $1,000, padlocked the bar and arrested an employe of the restaurant.
TORONTO, Tuesday, June 18 (Canadian Press). -- Ontario police are guarding Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn following threats against his life, made in the past ten days, The Mail and Empire says today.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- To the accompaniment of brief but caustic debate, continuation for another two years of excise taxes and the extra-penny first class postage rate yielding $500,000,000 yearly revenue to the Treasury, was voted today by the House. The measure, a joint resolution, now goes to the Senate.

DETROIT, June 17 (AP). -- The Tranquillity Farm's Cross Ruff captured the $1,000 Marquette Purse, feature at the Fair Grounds today, covering the mile and sixteenth route through the mud in 1:47 4-5 to lead Glynson and Shady Well to the wire.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- An emphatic exhortation that politics be kept completely out of the new work-relief program to provide a job for each of the 3,500,000 unemployed was voiced today by President Roosevelt, along with an expression of confidence that the present year would see private industry taking up "the greater part of this unemployment slack."

Having reached the exasperation point, Casey Stengel decided upon another wholesale shuffle of the Dodgers yesterday, a move even more drastic than Sunday's action, but for all his manoeuvring, the Stengelmen finished on the wrong end of a 5-3 score in their third meeting with the Chicago Cubs before 2,000 fans at Ebbets Field.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, was elected yesterday chairman of the investment banking house of Blyth Co., Inc. He will dissolve his own firm of C.E. Mitchell Co., which he organized last January as the first step in his return to an active Wall Street career.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 17. -- With conditions of an actual flight simulated as closely as possible, Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson held a rehearsal today of their forthcoming venture into the stratosphere. Previously Captain Stevens, under the spoken directions of the corps of scientists, placed in operation every one of the multitude of instruments in the gondola of the Explorer II and then turned them off several times.

HAVANA, June 17. -- A series of attempts to extort large sums from wealthy Americans and Cubans under threats of kidnapping, came to light today through a police move to protect the intended victims and trap the would-be abductors.
CLINTON, N.Y., June 17. -- Elihu Root, for sixty-one years a member of the board of trustees of Hamilton College, was a centre of attraction at the Hamilton commencement today.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- There is no apparent disposition on the part of Secretary Roper or among the Congressional leaders for a searching investigation of the charges and circumstances which have accompanied the dismissal by the President of Ewing Y. Mitchell of Springfield, Mo., as an Assistant Secretary of Commerce. Nevertheless, all aspects of the case will be fully aired.

The installation of new elevators in the Municipal Building will make it necessary for city employes to come to work on a "stagger" system beginning July 1, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan said yesterday.
HANOVER, N.H., June 17. -- Dartmouth College graduated its largest class today, when 474 seniors received their diplomas.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Removal of trade barriers and encouragement of foreign commerce were asked of Congress and the President today in a petition presented by the Mayors' Committee on Conference of Seaport Cities.

ATTICA, N.Y., June 17 (AP). -- The six prisoners who attempted to escape from deputy sheriffs near Canandaigua this afternoon were long-termers being taken from Attica prison to Syracuse for resentence on court order.

Heavy Sunday rainfall in western sections of the Cotton Belt influenced prices yesterday during early trading on the New York Cotton Exchange and quotations held around the previous closing levels throughout the morning. When weather details were posted showing only light showers in Texas in the twenty-four hours, with a more favorable forecast, profit-taking eased the list to losses of 8 to 12 points at the close.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- President Roosevelt's informal speech to the State Works Progress Administrators when he received them in his office today read as follows:

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 17. -- Frank Hutson of Bronxville, No. 4 man on the Swarthmore College net team, led the field into the semi-final round as play in the Hudson River tennis singles championship started at the Sleepy Hollow Manor Club today.

By the minute margin of .03 point, THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks on the New York Stock Exchange established yesterday its first decline since June 6, when the index showed an almost equally small recession. Prior to yesterday's trading the market had advanced in eight consecutive sessions and in twelve of the last thirteen sessions.

A sharp increase in the amount of modernization work in factories, office and apartment buildings, through the amendment to the National Housing Act recently signed by President Roosevelt, was forecast yesterday by speakers at a luncheon meeting in the headquarters of the Building Trades Employers Association, 2 Park Avenue.

The Giants met the one-time terrifying Dean jinx with light hearts and heavy bats yesterday, thumped Paul, the younger of the brothers, in quite boisterous fashion and romped off with their third straight victory over the world champion Cardinals at the Polo Grounds, 14 to 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17. -- Tom Mooney cracked the legal barrier today which for nineteen years has blocked his fight for freedom, when the California Supreme Court, by issuing a writ of habeas corpus, opened its doors to him for the first time.

While retailers and buying offices strongly protested that the activities of the large number of coat buyers now arriving in the markets here will be greatly handicapped by the restrictions on group showings, both the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and the Merchants Ladies Garment Association at a meeting here yesterday reaffirmed "the broad and inclusive ban upon participation in group showings by member firms."

It is gratifying to learn, from the formal statement of the French bank to the conference of central bank governors at Basle, that our Treasury rendered prompt and effective aid in the recent "Paris crisis." There were good reasons why this assistance should have been provided by the United States Treasury.

LAKE PLACID, June 17. -- A report denying contentions of some scientists that mental illness is greater among Jews than among non-Jews was read to delegates to the National Conference of Jewish Social Service and allied groups today by Dr. Benjamin Malzberg of the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- President Roosevelt's social security program, already approved by the House, was pushed today apparently to sure and rapid passage in the Senate under circumstances that indicated a final vote tomorrow afternoon.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 17. -- While several hundred persons viewed the body of Vincent De Aoun, 27-year-old gunman shot dead by a policeman Saturday night in the Mayfair Country Club at West Orange, the woman he had escorted to the club was held without bail today on a charge that she had harbored him.

BRASOV, Rumania, June 17. -- Political leaders of the National Peasant party voiced bitter criticism of King Carol, his intimate friend, Mme. Magda Lupescu, and the present Liberal government, at a nation-wide rally today.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 17. -- A drive on "accident repeaters," motorists who are involved in two, three and four accidents every year, has been started by the Nassau County Traffic Survey, a TERA bureau, it was announced here today.

PARIS, June 17. -- There was a moderate reaction on the Bourse today to the improved political situation which has followed the appointment of the Laval Cabinet. Rentes advanced between fifty centimes and one franc and the foreign exchange rate rose in favor of the franc.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- A feature of the annual Class Day exercises held by the seniors of Princeton University today was the presentation of awards and trophies for sportsmanship in various activities to outstanding athletes. Dr. Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the faculty committee on athletics, made the presentations in Alexander Hall this morning.
LONDON, June 17. -- The Tate Gallery, paying an unusual honor to Paul Manship, American sculptor, will open a big exhibition of his works tomorrow. The exhibition will continue until July 31.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Striking at five-to-four decisions by the Supreme Court, Senator Norris introduced in the Senate today a proposal for a constitutional amendment to prevent that court from ruling Congressional acts unconstitutional except by more than a two-thirds vote and only when actions have been brought within six months after an act takes effect.

LONDON, June 17 (AP). -- Each with an eye on a berth on the American Davis Cup team for the interzone final against the winner in the European qualifying round next month, four members of the United States cup squad survived the first round of play today in the Queens Club tournament with the loss of only two games among them.
Commander William A. Corn, U.S.N., took charge of the United States destroyer Dale when she was commissioned yesterday at noon in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn.

A 15-month-old boy was tossed out of his go-cart and through a store plate-glass window and his 6-year-old sister was knocked down at 6:30 o'clock last night when an automobile driven by a woman mounted the curb at 135th Street, twenty feet west of Broadway. Both children were seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The application on Form 7 of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company for registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $750,000 of $20 par value capital stock was ordered effective immediately today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
M'COOK, Neb., June 17 (AP). -- Smallpox developed in Southwestern Nebraska today on the heels of the latest Republican River flood, which caused at least one death.
PARIS, June 17. -- Mlle. Maryse Hilsz, French flier, broke her own women's world altitude record today by reaching 11,800 meters [37,704 feet] using a Morane-Saulnier 600-horsepower pursuit plane.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- The abandonment of the upper-class eating club system "in the best interests of Princeton" was advocated today by Peter P. Blanchard of Baltimore, president of the senior class, in the annual presidential address at the Class Day exercises held on the quadrangle behind Nassau Hall.

PITTSBURGH, June 17. -- Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, meeting here in a five-day convention, dwelt in his keynote address today on "the opportunities ahead" for labor, agriculture, industry, credit, foreign trade, and the political future.

The largest refunding bond issue, with the lowest coupon, in the history of the Federal Land Banks will be offered to the public this morning by a nation-wide group of banks and investment houses acting under the direction of Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent of the Federal Land Banks.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, asked the finance committee of the Board of Education yesterday to write into the school budget for 1936 a $300,000 appropriation for Summer sessions in the city's primary and secondary schools.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace, in a letter to all members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, asserted today that the proposed AAA amendments do not contain any authorization for a processing tax on newsprint.

Your correspondent Hugh McCormick seems to be irritated about the entire slum-clearance program and the progress of the Mayor and Tenement House Commissioner Langdon Post in getting the low-cost housing under way.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Good Gamble, winner of the Acorn Stakes, continued that young owner's sensational string of successes by taking the Rose of Sharon Purse, best race at Aqueduct, yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17. -- Harvard's varsity crew sprang a four-mile time trial this evening, surprising not only Yale's ever-watchful scouts but also many of the men at Harvard's Red Top training quarters.

WOOSTER, Ohio, June 17. -- Mrs. Otelia Compton, 76, put today on the broad shoulders of her son, Wilson M. Compton of Washington, economist, lawyer and secretary of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, the hood denoting the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 17. -- The Texas polo team rode into the semifinals of the Third Westbury Challenge Cup tournament by downing the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 10 to 9, at the Meadow Brook Club today in a second-round engagement.

WHITE PLAINS, June 17. -- The County Centre here has been transformed into a garden of color for the fourth annual Westchester County flower show, which opened this afternoon. The show was opened formally tonight at 8 o'clock by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, who was accompanied by the Governor. She was introduced by Mrs. Jane Deeter Rippin, chairman of the flower show committee.

A few hours before dawn yesterday morning a few late travelers saw a small boy with jet-black hair and large dark eyes climb briskly onto a train. In one hand he carried a black violin case and with the other he assisted his young brother, a pianist, up the steep steps of the dimly lighted Pullman sleeper.

SALEM, N.H., June 17 (AP). -- Mrs. M.J. White's 5-year-old chestnut mare, All Forlorn, broke the winning streak of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt at Rockingham Park today, taking the six-furlong feature race.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 17. -- By a vote of 311 to 48 employes of the Toledo Edison Company today decided to end their four-day strike on the terms indicated last night.
In the heart of the lower East Side, a few blocks from the house in which he was born, former Assemblyman Louis J. Lefkowitz was installed yesterday as a justice of the Municipal Court.

Supreme Court proceedings for cancellation of a $5,000,000 assessment for 1935 on property owned by the Frick Collection at Fifth Avenue and Seventieth Street were started yesterday. Justice John L. Walsh signed a writ of certiorari requiring the Board of Taxes and Assessments to submit to a judicial review of the assessment.

OMAHA, June 17. -- Governor Cochran, ordinarily a smiling, quiet man, assumed direct charge of the Omaha street car strike situation last night. He took over the power of a dictator when he demanded at a conference of company officials and strike leaders that each side name one arbitrator by 10 A.M. today and agree on a third if possible.

Commodity futures were generally soft in tone yesterday in light trading, despite some improvement in certain spot markets. Rubber futures alone were stronger. In the cash markets all the grains, lard and rubber advanced, while cotton, cocoa and tin declined.

The signing of Magna Charta fell on a June day in 1215. The barons at their meeting after Christmas had made their demands but King JOHN asked for delay until the end of April. However, the barons alarmed, it is said, by the preparation being made against them, took the field before that time.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 17. -- "American universities are the place, and the time is now, for the solving of this great human problem" of adjustment of life to a world "in which man, using the tools of science, is empowered to shape his world as he will,"

Joseph J. Canavan, State Parole Commissioner, ordered yesterday the return to prison of Michael Sedlak, 24 years old, of 1,579 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, for violation of parole. Sedlak was found on June 6 in a Rochester, N.Y., apartment raided by police as the hideout of De Aoun.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 17. -- The Graduate School of Banking, which opened here tonight under the joint auspices of the American Institute of Banking section of the American Bankers Association and Rutgers University, with an enrolment of 220 bank officers from thirty-five States and the District of Columbia, was described as a venture "unique in the history of education" by Harry J. Haas, vice president of the First National Bank of Philadelphia.
PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP). -- The Pirates reached three Philadelphia hurlers for twenty-two hits and a 12-to-5 triumph today in the third game of their series.
The city, blanketed yesterday by an oppressive heat that reached an intensity of 86 degrees at 4:30 P.M., received a respite at 8:30 P.M. when overcast skies poured out a drenching rain.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 17. -- While this country has passed the lowest depth of the economic crisis and recovery is well under way, "the situation in the international field is still deteriorating," Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, said today in an address at the commencement exercises of the University of Michigan here, where he received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

The Civilian Conservation Corps has proved its practicability. The recruits were taken from the ranks of the youthful unemployed, many of whom were members of families on home relief. The obvious benefits to the young man, his family, and the government have made this phase of the Emergency Works Bill the least criticized of all of the New Deal policies.
BOSTON, June 17 (AP). -- Wally Berger's strong hitting today paced the Braves to a Bunker Hill Day twin victory over the Reds by 8-3 and 5-1 margins.
Although salt-water fishing at some Long Island and New Jersey points was disappointing over the week-end, there were several developments which gave hints of exciting days to come.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 17. -- A plea "for the social application of knowledge to the problems of the city" was made by Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, at the commencement exercises of the University of Rochester today.

Peter Christ, 33 years old, who killed his wife, Stella, in their flat at 209 East Sixty-sixth Street last Saturday, mumbled a request for swift sentence yesterday before Magistrate Leonard McGee in Homicide Court.

During the past week another name has appeared on the front pages in bold type -- James Braddock, the new heavyweight champion. Just how important to the welfare of the United States is this conspicuous news?

MEDFORD, Mass., June 17. -- Attacking the New Deal by comparing it with a game of cards in which the deal was "stacked," Senator Carter Glass, Democratic Senator from Virginia, advised the graduates at the Tufts College commencement today to "make sure that too many cards are not passed to the players on one side of the table and too few to those on the other side."
The passenger list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, due here today from Southampton, via Cherbourg, includes:

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- With farm prices in 1934 still 25 per cent below the 1910-29 relationship to industrial prices, farmers must now realize that further improvement in their income "will depend on the increased activity, income and purchasing power of industrial groups," Chester C. Davis, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, said today in his annual report for 1934.

BAY SHORE, L.I., June 17. -- Without pausing for a well-earned rest after winning the Long Island amateur title yesterday, Charley Mayo Jr., paired with his father to take top honors in the one-day Long Island Golf Association pro-amateur best-ball tourney today.

GENEVA, June 17. -- Replying today to sixty speeches made at the International Labor Organization Conference on his annual report, the director, Harold Butler, concluded by stressing the need for international planning and action "if we are to have an abundant life."

A field of ninety-six golfers will tee off tomorrow in the qualifying round of the thirty-fifth metropolitan amateur championship, which is to he played on the Canoe Brook Country Club courses at Summit, N.J.
The financial needs for 1935 of the fifty-two hospitals participating in the United Hospital Fund were estimated yesterday at $9,440,000 by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the fund.

CANTON, N.Y., June 17. -- Closing the door to politics and nationalistic propaganda, Oven D. Young, a veteran of several international parleys, opened the first conference on Canadian-American relations here tonight with some animadversions on why such gatherings frequently fall short of their objectives.

Charles Carlino, 21 years old, described by James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, as the tool of a gang of lower East Side thugs who were hired to have stench bombs placed in theatres and other places in labor disputes and business rivalries, was sentenced to a three-month workhouse term yesterday.

A plan whereby the equity of the Western Pacific Railroad Corporation in the Western Pacific Railroad Company would be reduced is under consideration as a result of suggestions made by insurance companies in the pending reorganization of the last-named company, it developed yesterday.

James J. Johnston, in charge of boxing at Madison Square Garden, announced yesterday that he is planning a world heavyweight title bout between James J. Braddock, the champion, and Max Schmeling in the Long Island Bowl in September.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Operations of the RFC in May continued the moderate basis of previous months, disbursements totaling only $64,287,161, while repayments in the same period totaled $47,923,462.37. New authorizations amounted to $22,427,057.51.

ATLANTA, June 17 (AP). -- The right of the Alabama Power Company stockholders to intervene in a legal action which brought to test the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority was questioned today by members of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

BERLIN, June 17. -- After months of negotiation and organization the new German plan for export promotion through increased subsidies, which was announced by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Reich economic dictator, at the recent Leipzig Trade Fair, was put into effect over the week-end.

Two brothers, one 13, the other 11, and another boy, 13, were charged with homicide in the Jamaica Magistrate's Court yesterday. They were then taken to the Jamaica Children's Court and charged with delinquency on the ground of the theft of a policeman's pistol, with which one of them killed a drunken vagrant.

CANTON, N.Y., June 17. -- Closing the door to politics and nationalistic propaganda, Oven D. Young, a veteran of several international parleys, opened the first conference on Canadian-American relations here tonight with some animadversions on why such gatherings frequently fall short of their objectives.

BERLIN, June 17. -- Education Minister Bernhard Rust today faced the problem of whether to reinstate or not reinstate Professor Karl Barth, noted Swiss theologian and a leader of the opposition against Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, who was ousted from Bonn University last December by a verdict of the College Disciplinary Court.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Following two hours of oral arguments, the Grain Futures Commission today took under advisement for final judgment the case of Thomas M. Howell, Chicago grain trader, accused of creating a corner in the corn market in 1931.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 17. -- A program for long-range social security based on planned-in-advance public works projects today was suggested by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, in a commencement address before 300 members of the graduating class of Wellesley College.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 17. -- Sixteen eight-oared crews, which have been looking forward to the event since the day last Fall when they first came out for practice, will compete tomorrow in the three races of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association Regatta.

LENORE G. MARSHALL'S first novel, "Only the Fear" (Macmillan, $2), can be described in moral language as the dramatization of a battle between the real and the ideal. Or, in terms of common sense, it can be spoken of as a novel in which maturity triumphs over adolescence. It might even be called the literary exploitation of the phenomenon of schizophrenia, or "split personality."

Operations of the Budd Wheel Company in 1934 resulted in a net income of $111,944 after interest, depreciation, rentals, Federal taxes and other deductions. This was equivalent, after annual dividend requirements on 7,997 shares of $7 preferred stock on which accumulated dividends at the end of the year amounted to $17.50 a share, to 6 cents a share on 965,258 no-par shares of common stock.

The official disclosure of the part played by the Treasury's stabilization fund in supporting the franc recently bolstered confidence yesterday in the gold-bloc exchanges. The franc rallied 7/8 point to 6.60 5/8 cents, which was well above the gold import price; the guilder rose 14 points to 67.90 cents and the Swiss franc was up 6 points to 32.70 cents.

HELSINGFORS, Juno 17. -- Reversing last month's decision, the Finnish Athletic Federation today voted to continue the boycott on Sweden proclaimed in 1932 because the Finnish organization considered the Swedish sports leaders acted "incorrectly" in connection with Paavo Nurmi's disqualification as an amateur.

The United States Copper Association yesterday voted to take over all unfinished business of the Code Authority when it ceased to function and "in so far as it might be advised it was legal and proper so to do, cooperate in maintaining the existing standards and practices."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- The 47 Club of Radcliffe College will present to the college Wednesday a portrait of the late Professor George Pierce Baker, founder of the Radcliffe and Harvard courses in playwriting known as English 47 and 47a.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act broadening Secretary Wallace's powers to regulate production and marketing of principal farm commodities were started through the House today after being four times revised, the last time to bring them within the limitation set forth by the Supreme Court in the Schechter case.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Fred D. Thompson, Republican leader of the Thirteenth Manhattan Assembly District, has decided to resign, or at least not run for re-election, it was reported yesterday, thus adding to the difficulties of Chase Mellen Jr., county chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- In a denunciation of the Bureau of Air Commerce and the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection of the Commerce Department, Ewing Y, Mitchell, ousted Assistant Secretary of Commerce, who until Saturday had charge of those bureaus, made public today charges to President Roosevelt that "improper favoritism and graft" abounded within the two divisions.
MONTE CARLO, June 17 (AP). -- Rene Leon, who as head of the gambling concession here has been the "uncrowned king of Monte Carlo" disclosed today that he had resigned.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 17. -- The five young women who received summonses from Yonkers police yesterday on the complaint of Alderman William Slater of the Ninth Ward, who charged they were inadequately attired for appearance on the street, were dismissed by City Judge Martin Fay in Yonkers Court today when Alderman Slater declined to make a formal complaint.

Bonds were strong and active in yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Second-grade rails continued to provide the outstanding feature of the market, with issues in this group making net gains of one to four points. United States Government issues were mixed, with declines somewhat outnumbering advances and with price changes ranging from 1-32 to 3-32 point in both directions.

Circuit Judge Thomas H. Brown in Jersey City refused yesterday to strike out Bruno Richard Hauptmann's answer to a suit against him to collect $4,221 as a fee for James M. Fawcett, his first lawyer in the Lindbergh case. Fawcett fought the move to extradite Hauptmann to New Jersey for the murder of the Lindbergh baby.

Mrs. Fred Radnitz gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for the Count and Countess de Cavadonga. Her other guests were Senor and Senora Channo Sampedro. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. James Lenox Banks for Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell, Mrs. Morris de Peyster and Mrs. Talbot Ewart.

The brothers Damato -- Frank, who is 13 and Julius 11 -- and Lisbon Lawrence, 13, a Negro, stared unblinkingly at Magistrate Thomas F. Doyle in Jamaica Court yesterday as an affidavit charging them with murder was read aloud.

LONDON, June 17. -- In his new capacity of Foreign Secretary, Sir Samuel Hoare answered his first batch of questions on international affairs in the House of Commons today when Parliament convened after a ten-day recess. The most important request for information from members concerned the present situation in North China.

Accusations by a discharged employe are always open to suspicion. But President ROOSEVELT has directed the Department of Justice to inquire into the assertions made by Mr. MITCHELL, Under-Secretary of Commerce, whom Secretary ROPER had just dismissed for insubordination and other offenses.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 17. -- Tomorrow's chief event here is the exhibition of iris and peonies at Clinton Academy by the Garden Club of East Hampton. It will be open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Entries are open to any resident of the town.

Mrs. Dorothy Ernst Werle, a widow, of 333 East Sixty-eighth Street, whose 11-year-old son Frederick is a student at the Hunter College Model School, will be graduated tomorrow from Hunter College with a Bachelor of Arts degree.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17. -- Edward J. Berwind observed his eighty-seventh birthday anniversary quietly at his residence, The Elms, on Bellevue Avenue, today. He received a letter of congratulations from Mayor Mortimer A. Sullivan.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Decreasing stocks of corn at leading terminal markets and the failure of the country to sell grain to arrive, apparently regardless of the trend of the market, have resulted in some change in sentiment on the Board of Trade regarding this grain, and it took relatively little buying today by several leading commission houses to cause advances of 1 3/4 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel from the early low point.

Action with regard to the liquidation of the Fur Manufacturing Code Authority, which may serve as a precedent for winding up the affairs of all Code Authorities in this city, under the Supreme Court's invalidation of the NRA, was announced yesterday by James Flynn Hodgson, director of the Fur Code Authority.

MEXICO, D.F., June 17. -- President Lazaro Cardenas, consolidating his victory in the dispute with former President Plutarco Elias Calles, tonight appointed a new Cabinet to replace that whose resignation he demanded last Friday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17. -- Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, President of Princeton University, will confer degrees upon 475 seniors and 119 graduate students tomorrow at the 188th annual commencement exercises to be held on the lawn in front of Nassau Hall.

TIENTSIN, China, June 17. -- It was learned today that by tomorrow the Japanese armed forces in Tientsin and Peiping would have been reduced by half from the number stationed in the two cities last week.

HONOLULU, June 17. -- Bucking head winds most of the way from the Midway Islands, the Pan American Clipper plane landed at Pearl Harbor at 4:28 P.M. (10:58 P.M., New York time). She covered the 1,358 miles in 10 hours and 4 minutes, as against 9 hours and 13 minutes for her previous flight from Hawaii to Midway.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP). -- Frankie Parker of Milwaukee, who is seeded at the top, and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., ranked fifth, gained first-round victories in the opening of the national clay court title tournament today before rain halted play.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., June 17 (AP). -- One man was shot and seriously wounded today when six convicts, on route from Attica prison to Syracuse in a chartered bus, rushed their four guards in a desperate attempt to disarm them and escape.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 17. -- That the gold bloc is now safe from attack until Autumn but that no serious stabilization moves are likely before then seemed to be the general opinion among European central bank governors as they left here tonight after their regular exchange of news and views at the monthly meeting of the Bank for International Settlements.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 18. -- An exhibition of photographs by the Guild Hall Camera Club, showing scenes in East Hampton gardens, and of paintings of East Hampton dune scenes by Hamilton King opened today at Clinton Academy. Its opening was coincident with the Garden Club of East Hampton's iris and peony show here.

WASHINGTON, June 18.--Low-cost housing and slum clearance projects to cost $249,000,000 have been selected, and the PWA Housing Division is prepared to start work on them at once, Secretary Ickes and division officials revealed today.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Plans for refinancing by two of the big packing companies became known today. Thomas E. Wilson, president of Wilson Co., announced that the company will retire its entire present funded debt of approximately $17,000,000 through a new bond issue of $20,000,000 which will be offered about Aug. 1.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 18. -Louis N. Creighton, 56 years old, prominent Bayonne real estate and insurance broker, shot and killed himself today in the Town Club here after telephoning a friend to meet him at the club on business.

Abraham E. Lefcourt, builder of skyscrapers, whose realty holdings were estimated in 1928 at $100,000,000, had at his death virtually no assets aside from the insurance payable to his wife, the transfer tax appraisals of his estate revealed yesterday.

The elimination of Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, who assumed his duties only two months ago, from the new relief set-up as it will develop in this city under the expanded Federal work relief program, was considered probable last night after Mayor La Guardia outlined the plans being considered for New York under the Federal program.

OTTAWA, June 18. -- As chairman of a select parliamentary committee considering his bill to nationalize the storage and marketing of Western Canadian grain, Prime Minister Bennett refused today to disclose information regarding the operations of John I. McFarland on behalf of the government to stabilize the price of Canadian wheat.

Leaders of outstanding consumer groups rallied yesterday to the support of those units in the apparel industry which are formulating plans to create a new label to identify merchandise produced under wholesome conditions.

Spokesmen of maritime labor announced yesterday that the International Convention for Safety of Life at Sea had been taken up for consideration by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations and would again be fought by labor as a menace to the maintenance of favorable working conditions on merchant ships.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP). -- Slapped, G.T. Williams's 5-year-old gelding, overtook Miss Careful in the final strides of the Alma Purse, feature of today's card at the Detroit track, to win by a neck. The time for the six-furlong race in the mud was 1:13 4-5. Back Fence was third. The winner paid $7.40 for $2.
ASCOT, England, June 18. -Twenty Grand, Mrs. Payne Whitney's great thoroughbred, failed to place in the Queen Anne Stakes which marked his debut on English tracks today.

Speyer Co. have received a summary of the third annual report of the League of Nations Loans Committee of London from Eliot, Wadsworth, American member of the committee, discussing several questions of policy which arose in the last year and containing in its appendices a full set of documents, communiques and statistical tables.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 18. -- Mrs. F.J. Hauptmann, assistant instructor in the German department at New Jersey College for Women, testifying before the special committee of Rutgers University trustees here today, denied propaganda for the Nazi cause had been disseminated at the Women's College.

" Nell Gwyn," a British and Dominions production featuring Anna Neagle and Sir Cedric Hardwicke, opens this morning at the Rivoli. The film was scheduled to be released here about nine months ago, but was delayed because of censorship difficulties with the Hays office.

Mayor La Guardia in a new role as an amateur actor was the hit of a show, "Off the Record," given by the New York Newspaper Men's Club last night at the Hotel Astor. He wrote, directed, stage-managed, produced and played the star part in a sketch called "Any Newspaper Office, Any Time."

One very useful kind of relief employment is that conducted by the Nassau County Traffic Survey, a TERA bureau. Compiling the records in thirty-three village Police Departments in the six precincts of Nassau County, it found that 90 per cent of the automobile accidents recorded happened to motorists who were involved in two, three and more accidents.

The management of the Western Pacific Railroad agreed yesterday with insurance and savings bank officials on a plan of reorganization for the company calling for the issuance of new preferred stock and convertible income bonds. The plan is subject to modification, but will be submitted in substantially its present form to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation within a day or two.

SUFFERN, N.Y., June 18. -- Mrs. M.J. Fitzpatrick and Mrs. Morgan Hamilton, both of Sterlington, carried off the honors at the annual flower show of the Ramapo Valley Garden Club here today at the Hauvenkoff Country Club. Mrs. Fitzpatrick won six first prizes and Mrs. Hamilton, a sister of J.P. Morgan, won five.

It would hardly seem that any one could feel "blue" over the fact that June is a month of flowers -- unless one remembered that real blooms are preferable to artificial ones. Surely, bright, pleasant-faced little Catherine Rafferty, who is 12 years old, would seem to be the least likely type to worry over blossoms, real or otherwise.

Reporting for May, the Union Pacific Railroad showed yesterday an increase in gross revenues but a decrease in net operating income. About $159,000 was credited to operating expenses for the month, representing one-third of the amount charged for liabilities under the railway pension law.
LONDON, June 18. -- Two members of the American contingent fell as the Queen's Club tennis tournament entered the third round today.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- An increase of about 20 per cent in Federal tax receipts for the fiscal year as compared with 1934 is virtually certain. Treasury figures disclosed today as the fiscal year neared its close.

HSINKING, Manchuria, June 18. -- The Chahar trouble, arising from the overnight detention of four Japanese and reported attacks on Japanese and Manchukuoan troops in Manchukuo, will be thrown in with the North China situation and handled as a local issue, it was announced here this morning following a conference of Japanese Army leaders last night.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- Two fine-rowing Washington eights set the stage for the climax of a magnificent regatta by their victories in the freshman and junior varsity races today.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Critics of the New Deal, studying the reform bills now before Congress and listening to the debates, are becoming convinced that the measures reveal a continuing administration effort to "get around" the Constitution, as expounded by the present Supreme Court, and, if further court reverses come, to look to these to solidify public opinion in favor of modernizing the national charter.

OMAHA, June 18 (AP). -- Mrs. O.S. Hill of Kansas City, defending women's trans-Mississippi golf champion, crushed Mrs. E. De Vilbiss of Kansas City, 7 and 6, in an opening-round match of the 1935 tourney at the Field Club today.
NEW HAVEN, June 18. -- Fifty-three of the eighty-five living members of the Yale class of '85 were reunited here today.

Mayor La Guardia laid the cornerstone yesterday afternoon for a district health centre in the Bronx, the first of thirty similar buildings to be erected throughout the city in the administration's program of preventive medicine.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, characterized as "applesauce" yesterday the statement of President Roosevelt that politics must be kept out of the works relief program in the different States.

The question of exactly what a decorater is has so agitated the American Institute of Decorators that they agreed yesterday upon a new definition which they hope will soon achieve place in dictionaries, replacing present varied and -- to decorators -- indaquate definitions.

A theatrical tradition was shattered yesterday by the council of the Actors Equity Association when it voted to require that its members and those of the Chorus Equity Association receive "rehearsal expense money," or, in other words, out-and-out pay for rehearsals.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18. -Harvard captured the opening game of its baseball series with Yale, 4 to 2, before a commencement crowd of 6,000 today. The Crimson triumphed in the thirteenth inning, the longest Yale-Harvard game in nearly a quarter of a century.
Twenty-seven properties, including thirteen in Manhattan and fourteen in the Bronx, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday,
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows, Quotations are in cents:

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 18. -The electric eye, which has been applied to the needs of man in many ways, among them the opening and closing of doors, the counting of crowds and the sorting of cigars by the color of wrapper, has an important function to perform in the National Geographic-Air Corps stratosphere expedition.

BUENOS AIRES, June 18. -- Argentina's corn crop this year will break all records by a wide margin and provide an exportable surplus of 329,860,000 bushels, according to the estimate made today by the Ministry of Agriculture. The Ministry's forecast was for a crop of 452,709,000 bushels, which is 76 per cent more than last year's yield and 48 1/2 per cent above the average of the last five years.

PARIS, June 18. -- The British Government's action in signing this morning a naval agreement with Germany which constitutes a complete revision of the naval terms of the Treaty of Versailles is being commented on here with some severity.

George J. Ruch, mounted patrolman, who was restored to his post at Peck Slip in January, 1934, following his transfer to Canarsie, testified in Federal Court yesterday that his temporary exile had been caused by Jerome Kiselik, fish wholesaler, who disliked the way he had treated some of the market men.

With the present Washington administration advocating the socialization of the electric light and power industry, Mayor La Guardia has every reason to believe that his dream of a city owned and operated plant may be fulfilled soon. His efforts are relentless, and why not? He is certain of "about 87,000 consumers" who will be served as soon as he will build the plant with $45,000,000 borrowed from the Federal Government.

The delay in reaching a final agreement with the B.M.T. on rapid transit unification is the fault of the city administration and not of the Transit Commission, the commission declared yesterday in a formal statement.

LONDON, June 18. -- The first public tribute to Lawrence of Arabia since his recent death was paid by his distinguished associates during the "revolt in the desert" and afterward today at a memorial luncheon attended by more than 1,000 persons.

Four cruising "lush workers," who specialize in robbing lone passers-by on deserted streets, were routed at 5:20 A.M. yesterday by Patrolman William Carraher as they were about to hold up a victim against a building wall on Third Avenue at Twenty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Emily Ringling, wife of John Ringling, circus man, failed yesterday in her suit to collect $50,000 lent to her husband a few days before their marriage in 1930, and to set aside agreements signed in August, 1933, extending the loan and releasing certain of her dower rights.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 18 (AP). -Smoother sailing for the New Deal in the nation's courts was predicted today by Dean Charles K. Burdick of the Cornell Law School at the opening session of Cornell's new Alumni Institute.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Plans were made today by liberal Senate Republicans and some Democrats to try to increase Federal revenue by slapping new levies on the $502,000,000 Nuisance Tax Bill in the Senate.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday decreased in comparison with the preceding week and with the corresponding week a year ago. This was the first time in eight weeks that registrations were less than in the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- An administration bill to write into permanent law fair practice provisions of existing liquor codes, together with other restrictive provisions already in effect, was introduced today by Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -Awards to students of the University of Pennsylvania in recognition of their academic achievements were made public tonight on the eve of commencement exercises which will close the university year. Degrees in course will be given tomorrow to 1,409 men and women, while six persons will receive honorary degrees.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Immediate investigation of charges of graft and corruption within the Commerce Department was voted unanimously today by the Senate Commerce Committee. Meanwhile, Ewing Y. Mitchell, Assistant Secretary ousted by President Roosevelt made public a second letter to Mr. Roosevelt in which he made new accusations against Secretary Roper and his subordinates.

Documents which the Society for the Prevention of Crime unsuccessfully sought to have District Attorney William C. Dodge use in the recent March New York County grand jury's investigation of the policy racket were forwarded yesterday to Governor Lehman for use in his decision whether to supersede the prosecutor with an extraordinary grand jury.

Hamilton M. Laing of the Victoria-Saanich Inlet Anglers Association of British Columbia, writes interestingly of the chinook salmon, a species which may be introduced in local waters as an experiment. If Deputy Commissioner Herman Forster of the New York Water Department succeeds in bringing to catchable size 5,000 specimens now being raised at the Jerome Avenue pipe yards, the fish will be planted in Kensico Lake.

Every Summer when the taxicab drivers in New York find their earnings decreasing due to seasonal conditions, and particularly so since the depression came on, some individual with the grandiose statement that he represents "thousands of cab owners or drivers" appears with a proposal to "reduce rates."

Additional industrial and business leaders are identifying themselves with the large group that already has announced an intention to maintain the standards of wages and hours set up under the NRA codes, which expired on June 16 after their invalidation by the United States Supreme Court.
Fusion and Republican members of the Board of Aldermen swung into line with their Democratic colleagues yesterday to pass by a unanimous vote the compulsory residence bill affecting relief employes.

The three schoolboy-bootblacks of Jamaica, Queens, who have confessed they murdered a man last Saturday with a revolver stolen from a police station were fingerprinted yesterday at police headquarters in Jamaica.

LANSING, Kan., Wednesday, June 19. -- A maddened mob of 347 mutinous convicts sent up word early today from the Kansas Penitentiary coal mine, where they struck early yesterday for a new prison physician and better food, that "We'll stick it out until we die, if we have to -- but nine guards must die with us."

The first of a fleet of 105 sleek new buses for use on the routes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company was exhibited yesterday in City Hall Park by company officials. The buses will be used as replacements for those now in use on Fifth Avenue.

The pamphlet report of the United Gas Corporation for 1934 says that sales of natural gas increased 16 per cent in volume over 1933, and that customers directly served numbered 122,281 at the year-end, against 110,813 at the end of 1933.

In an address before the Citizens Union at its annual meeting at the Town Hall Club last night Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, declared that a serious relief situation existed in Harlem and warned that "a real crisis" was threatened unless steps were taken to remedy it.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- An amendment to the 1930 Tariff Act which would restrict unconditional most-favored-nation treatment under reciprocal trade agreements to nations which do not discriminate against American goods was introduced today by Representative Scrugham, Democrat, of Nevada.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP). -- Brico, from the Rosedale Stable of Chicago, captured the featured event at Washington Park today, leading seven other 3-year-old maidens through the mud over the mile route in 1:45 1-5.

The share market moved along with seeming confidence yesterday to an irregularly higher level as the day's news again failed to produce anything of a nature which might cause a change in sentiment. The great majority of holders of stocks continue reluctant to part with any considerable amount of their holdings, so that with only a moderate demand the market is able to move forward easily.
PRAGUE, June 18. -- Czechoslovakia, through Foreign Minister Eduard Benes, today held out an unexpected olive branch to Germany.

In 1933, almost 25,000 men filed applications for the patrolman's examination. The most exacting and difficult examinations, medical, physical and written were given these men. Of the 25,000 only 5,504 successfully reached the list of eligibles.

LANSING, Kan., June 18 (AP). -- The Kansas penitentiary here has been the scene of many escapes, mutinies and riots. The most sensational break occurred on Memorial Day, 1933, when eleven convicts fled with Warden Kirk Prather and two guards as hostages.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 2,724,050 barrels daily, compared with 2,643,300 in the preceding week, an increase of 80,750, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Virtually every producing area reported an increase, the largest being in Oklahoma, where the daily average was 44,500 barrels greater than in the week before.

The John Marshall College of Law in Jersey City at its fourth annual commencement exercises today will confer an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws on United States Attorney General Homer S. Cummings. An address on "Justice" will be given by the Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- For the purpose of supplying Congress with information useful in the drafting of amendments to the Securities and Exchange Act, the SEC began a hearing today on the reorganization of the Paramount Publix Corporation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 18. -- Needs of the banking world were described today to the students in the new Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University at a luncheon here by Dr. E.E. Agger, Professor of Economics and Business Research at Rutgers and member of the faculty of the graduate school.

BOSTON, June 18. -- Miss Jeanette Gow, 28-year-old daughter or Colonel Charles R. Gow, former Boston postmaster, was killed early this morning when she grasped the door handle of a parked automobile which had become charged with electricity from a fallen electric light wire.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A list of applications on Form 1-M for registration of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter markets, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, contained the following applications from New York City firms:

Two books by Rose Macaulay will be issued by two publishers this Fall. Harpers are announcing her "The Minor Pleasures of Life," an anthology of original and diverting ways of extracting pleasure from life. Macmillan announces for Fall publication "Personal Pleasures," by Rose Macaulay, in which she writes of the occupations she enjoys.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- It took hardy yachtsmen, seafarers who could don sweaters and pea jackets and pull on oilskins over them, to brave the rigors of this year's cruise up the Hudson and like it.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 18. -Miss Marion Fisher of Oak Ridge enlarged her list of successes in one-day tournaments of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by taking low gross honors for the third time at the Lido Golf Club today.

The depression is lifting, up New Canaan way, although the commuters on the 5:12 out of Grand Central on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad grudged the admission yesterday afternoon as they piled into the club car attached to the train this week after two and a half years of idleness.

OSLO, Norway, June 18. -- Leon Trotsky, noted Russian exile, traveling incognito, arrived today by steamer from Antwerp accompanied by his wife. Nothing had been known about his visit until the steamer arrived and consequently few people were on the quay. M. Trotsky immediately took a taxi to Hoenfoss, a small town northwest of Oslo.

Juan Perez, 25 years old, of 24 West 112th Street, described by his friends as a seaman, was shot and killed by Patrolman George Doane of the Wadsworth Avenue police station at 9:30 o'clock last night, in an apartment on the third floor of 1 Audubon Avenue.

Immediate construction of two six-story apartment houses is planned for a block front in Cruger Avenue by Bronxdale Estates, Inc., Jacob Janos, president, according to Richard M. Lederer, who sold the site.

Using tactics similar to those by which three robbers took $75,000 in jewels from a Fifth Avenue store about three weeks ago, three young men held up a jewelry store at 3,716 White Plains Avenue, between 216th and 217th Street, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon.

The Board of Estimate will hold its public hearing at City Hall at 10 A.M. today on Mayor La Guardia's proposal to apply to the Federal Government for a $45,000,000 loan to build a municipal electric light plant.

A formidable team of British polo players will come here in quest of the United States Open Championship at Meadow Brook in September, it was indicated yesterday when Louis E. Stoddard, chairman of the United States Polo Association, received a cablegram officially naming the members of the British squad.

Of late there has been a great deal of baiting of lawyers. A popular radio comedian in a scene in which he described his arrest was asked if he wanted a lawyer. He replied: "No, I do not need a lawyer, I am going to tell the truth." Enthusiastic applause from the studio audience greeted this clever sally.

A record total of 2,016 degrees, diplomas, certificates and commissions will be conferred tonight upon members of the graduating class of the College of the City of New York at the eighty-ninth commencement exercises of the college in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

JUDGE LANDIS made the proper and the popular decision in the "Alabama." Pitts case. The two things do not always go together, but the learned Judge hit a double this time. Now all that Pitts has to do to hold his job is to hit .300 or better against AA pitching. And Landis won't be allowed to go to bat for him there.
