LONDON, June 18 (Canadian Press). -- Rain today played havoc with the county championship schedule. All county games were concluded with indefinite results, but Cambridge University managed to complete the game with Essex, winning by seven wickets.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 18. -- Yale's varsity crew did not put in an appearance on the Thames River this morning as the senior oarsmen made a trip to New Haven to participate in the graduation exercises.

Declaring that it was clear that the specifications were prepared with the apparatus of two manufacturers in view as patterns, Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter enjoined the city yesterday from awarding contracts for $500,000 worth of fire-fighting equipment.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18. -- Despite the efforts of his wife and several neighbors to prevent him from carrying out his avowed intention of committing suicide, Frank L. Schrader, 62 years old, a retired New York jeweler, shot himself through the right temple with a revolver near the rear yard of his home at 177 Clove Road here tonight.

REINSDORF, Germany, June 18 (AP). -- Germany stopped its daily life and all industries stood still today in token of mourning for the sixty workers killed in the devastating explosion of the Reinsdorf ammunition works last Thursday.

A parked automobile a Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon rolled backward down the slight grade, toppled over a bakery wagon and mounted the sidewalk, causing slight injuries to a driver and three pedestrians.

LONDON, June 18. -- The naval expert of The Times of London figures that, if the totals of replacement tonnage for the United States and Great Britain are renewed at the forthcoming naval conference and if Germany receives a 35 per cent ratio, the Reich's quota in battleships will be 183,750 tons.

The eighteenth season of Summer concerts by the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conductor, will begin tonight on the Mall in Central Park. The series is known this year as the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts. Works by Wagner, Mendelssohn, Bach, Elgar, Goldman and Strauss will be on the program, and the new cornet soloist, David C. Rosebrook, will make his debut.

Another man was convicted speedily by a jury before Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday on a compulsory prostitution indictment handed up by the May grand jury in its investigation of vice conditions.

POTSDAM, Germany, June 18. -Max Schmeling is willing to go to America for a crack at James J. Braddock's new heavyweight title, but he isn't going until every possibility of getting Braddock into a European ring has been exhausted.
LONDON, June 18. -- With the appointment of seven junior Ministers, none of whom has Cabinet rank, the reconstruction of the government was practically completed tonight. The new appointees are:

Always in this month the fancy of Congress lightly turns to thoughts of an early adjournment. Speaker BYRNES has gladdened all hearts in the House of Representatives by announcing a schedule: "Pass ten bills and adjourn by July 15." This would seem simple and feasible enough, did one fail to consider the nature of some of those ten bills.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- An investigation is being conducted into the situation in the Winnipeg grain market, and several houses here that are members of the Canadian Exchange were asked today to designate whether their open interest in that market was speculative, spreading or hedges against cash wheat held in bond or duty paid. A like inquiry was reported three months ago.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 18. -- By whirling around the Engineers Golf Club course in record-tying figures this afternoon, Gene Sarazen annexed first money in the one-day thirty-six-hole open invitation tournament sponsored by the Long Island Professional Golfers Association.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18. -William H. Truesdale, former president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, who died on June 2, left the bulk an an estate reputed to be well over $1,000,000 to his three children. His wife died several years ago.
Dave Hennen Morris, United States Ambassador to Belgium, will be among those leaving today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others on the list include:

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- An unsuccessful attempt was made by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to serve a subpoena on J. Edward Jones, oil royalty dealer of New York, for the hearing on his application to register an issue of participating trust certificates in producing oil royalties, and the hearing was adjourned to June 27.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- California defeated Cornell's varsity today by three-fifths of a second for the championship of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. That meant ten feet of gleaming cedar shell at the end of one of the most grueling four-mile races the country has yet had.

OTTAWA, June 18 (Canadian Press). -- The Canadian dollar was worth about 60 cents in terms of gold, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett remarked in a debate on the new stabilization fund measure, which got second reading in the House of Commons last night.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Enactment of a cohesive policy of neutrality before another armed conflict breaks out in any part of the world was urged today by Phillips Bradley, Associate Professor of Political Science at Amherst College, in testimony before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, which is considering neutrality measures.

When a person buys a bottle of liquor today in a retail liquor store, he can be virtually certain he is getting genuine liquor and not a bootleg imitation, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, declared yesterday.

Leasing of space in the garment district in the midtown West Side section of Manhattan supplied the bulk of the business renting activity reported by brokers yesterday. Many clothing and millinery concerns took new or larger quarters.

The Greyhound Corporation, holding company for highway omnibus concerns operating in many parts of the country, has submitted to the New York Central Railroad a plan for coordinated passenger transport, it was made public yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18. -- President Angell told graduates of three Yale divisions today that they were faring forth into a world where "shrill and raucous voices" were assailing the foundations of American government.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- President Roosevelt directed James L. O'Neill, new NRA head, to have an impartial board study the extent of departures from code wages, hours and principles.

LONDON, June 18. -- The text of the British White Paper issued today disclosing the terms of the Anglo-German naval agreement as embodied in a note from Sir Samuel Hoare to Joachim von Ribbentrop and the latter's reply, is given below.

The keen sprinter Ariel Cross, carrying overweight and giving poundage under scale, according to age, to every rival in the field, won the Belle Harbor Handicap through rain and mud at Aqueduct yesterday to vindicate admirers who had stuck to the gelding through his recent defeats.

GENEVA, June 18. -- The hours reduction committee of the International Labor Office conference adopted today by a vote of 36 to 2 a resolution proposed by Professor Walton Hale Hamilton of the United States safeguarding wages against reduction by its projected forty-hour week convention.

The Glidden Company and subsidiaries announced yesterday that the net profit for the seven months ended on May 31 amounted to $1,505,546, after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent cumulative prior preference stock to $1.90 a share on 650,000 no-par shares of common stock.
LONDON, June 18. -- Robert Worth Bingham, the United States Ambassador, officially opened the exhibition of the works of Paul Manship, American sculptor, at the Tate Gallery today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 18. -The statement that Jews must devise and implement a well-planned cultural program to satisfy their needs for Jewish fellowship, self-respect, personal integration and religious orientation was made in the report of a survey presented to the Jewish conference meeting here today.

ROME, June 18. -- It is not improbable that the necessity for a Danubian conference here, which was announced in Stresa with a flourish of trumpets as being destined to take place almost immediately, will disappear entirely if negotiations that are known to be going on between Italy and Germany are successful.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A statement that there was evidence "of much cutting of wages and lengthening of hours" throughout the nation since the NRA codes were suspended was made today by James L. O'Neill, acting NRA administrator, soon after President Roosevelt had asked him to set up an impartial board to study the effects of code abolition.

Mayor La Guardia received the baseball teams of the Police and Fire Departments at City Hall yesterday with the announcement that he would take no sides in their annual baseball game, to be played at the Polo Grounds on June 29.

The Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations will conduct a Statewide campaign to arouse public attention to the "grave danger" of a reduction in State aid for education, according to an announcement from the committee yesterday.

Ira S. Wile, associate in pediatrics at Mount Sinai Hospital, addressed the twenty graduates of the School for Dental Hygienists of the Murray and Leonie Guggenheim Dental Clinic at its third commencement last night in the Julia Richman High School Auditorium, Second Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street.

It will be two years on July 1 since the two-cent local postage rate was "restored." In Greater New York the restoration was partial, curious and annoying. Whether the rate is two cents or three is no great matter; the amount of revenue to be attained should be the main consideration. But whatever the rate, it should be mlform.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 18. -Catalonian, Our Friend and Abonaki were the steeplechase winners at The Country Club in the second day's program of the Eastern Horse Club's forty-fifth race meeting today over the Clyde Park course. The races were held in cold weather and on a muddy track.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange held a slight advance for several hours yesterday, but some months broke $1 a bale in about twenty minutes when professional operators attempted to resell, and the list ended 7 to 9 points lower.

PARIS, June 18. -- The gesture of appreciation that Jean Tannery, Governor of the Bank of France, made at Basle for the aid that the United States and Great Britain gave the franc during the critical week at the end of May has revived France's faded hope for international stabilization before the end of the year.

The heat wave that prevailed here over the week-end gave way yesterday to considerably cooler weather that sent the mercury down to 56 degrees, only 4 above the record low for the date, and brought half an inch of rain. The Weather Bureau said there probably would be showers today and not much change in temperature.

RYE, N.Y., June 18. -- Overcoming a lead established by Mrs. Thomas Hucknall of Woodway, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden, metropolitan titleholder, today staged a winning finish to gain the quarterfinal round in the thirteenth annual Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Strong hopes that the Anglo-German naval agreement would contribute to a new limitation treaty on the ratio principle among the principal naval powers are entertained here, but it is realized that the accord announced in London may cause European complications.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. --President Ada L. Comstock will award 215 degrees to members of the graduating class of Radcliffe College tomorrow morning at the fifty-second commencement exercises in Sanders Theatre. Of the degrees, 157 are Bachelor of Arts, forty-eight Master of Arts and ten Doctor of Philosophy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 18. -- Despite the rain, there were many visitors today at the fourth annual Westchester County Flower Show, which opened at the Westchester County Centre here yesterday and will be continued through Saturday. The show is being held under the auspices of the Westchester County Horticultural and Agrictultural Association, Inc.
BERLIN, June 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 15 shows the following changes in the reichsmark:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18. -- Surprising indications of widespread sentiment favoring the proposal to abolish the upper-class clubs of Princeton University, as advocated by Peter Blanchard, president of the graduating class, at the Class Day exercises yesterday, developed today among the relatively few undergraduates still here.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey reserved decision yesterday after hearing Isidore J. Kresel, attorney, ask him to prevent the Federal Reserve Board from collecting $1,250,000 in $20 gold coins which are owned by a Swiss corporation and are held here by Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., bankers, at 25 Broad Street.

TACOMA, Wash., June 18 (AP). -Discovery of underground pits, indicating that the George Weyerhaeuser kidnapping had been planned long before it was carried out, became known today as Department of Justice agents prepared to lay secret evidence before a Federal grand jury tomorrow.

With activity spurting in many staples yesterday in the commodity markets, sugar reversed its improved trend and reacted, while coffee, after an early dip to new low marks, entered into a sharp rally. Weakness marked other active staples. In the cash markets all grains and tin advanced, while dairy products, cotton, rubber and silk went down.

WILDWOOD, N.J., June 18. -The story of a battle fifty miles off the New Jersey coast was related today by Captain Manuel Chalor, 31 years old, of the fishing trawler Nautilus, who suffered a badly torn arm when a fifteen-foot man-eating shark leaped into his dory and thrashed about snapping its jaws until driven hack into the sea by members of the crew.

LONDON, June 18. -- The London Times, explaining editorially how President Roosevelt has no intention of abandoning his reform program because of the setback experienced in the recent ruling of the Supreme Court, says:

After being in the doldrums for several sessions, the commodity futures markets came to life with enthusiasm yesterday, recent price trends being reversed with the resumption of heavy activity. Sugars weakened, with the market for the actual staple in another deadlock, but coffees rallied after falling more than a week and reaching the lowest level of the year.

TOKYO, June 18. -- Leakages of information from today's meeting of the new National Policy Council show that the government is seeking support for a serious effort to control naval and military expenditures.

Benjamin N. Cardozo, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, stood with head bowed last night as Yeshiva College conferred on him the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters at the fourth annual commencement of its School of Liberal Arts and Science.

ANCASTER, Ontario, June 18 (Canadian Press). -- Golfing class told in the first round of the Canadian amateur championship today and when the starting field of 131 was finished for the day there was not a startling upset in the list.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Further modifying amendments to Form A-2 for the registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933 by seasoned corporations were adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This is the simplified form prepared after many corporations had complained that the tremendous amount of data previously required made filing impractical and expensive.

Greta Garbo is not really the unfriendly, aloof personality of the shuttered taxicab window and the masking goggles, but a "shy girl, a frightened faun," according to her friend and admirer, May Robson, whose screen roles have endeared her to thousands as a "movie mother."
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- Ky Ebright, whose California varsity recorded its third consecutive victory in the Hudson regatta this evening, was quietly but fully content after the race.

LONDON, June 18. -- An Anglo-German naval treaty signed today gives Germany the right to have a fleet of 35 per cent of Great Britain's tonnage. Moreover, by special provision, Germany may have automatically 45 per cent of the British submarine tonnage, and under certain circumstances she may have equality with Great Britain in that category.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Government ownership and operation as the best policy for control of the American merchant marine, but government ownership and private operation as a practical alternative, were recommended to the Senate today by the special committee which has been investigating air and ocean mail contracts.

A total of 147 awards consisting of letters and class numerals, have been presented to New York University's athletes, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon following the approval of the board of athletic control and the undergraduate athletic board.

Lutheran clergymen who play golf but give no money to church benevolences were severely criticized by Fred H. Wefer, treasurer of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, yesterday afternoon. Mr. Wefer spoke at the synod's seventh annual convention in St. John's Lutheran Church, 155 North Street, Jersey City, N.J., where business sessions opened yesterday morning.

The Savannah Line steamer City of Chattanooga, which left her pier at the foot of West Eleventh Street at 5:15 o'clock last night bound for Boston with forty-five passengers, had a narrow escape from grounding on the rocks off the Battery seawall when she swung her bow to port to avert a collision with a railroad float under tow.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Passage by the Senate tomorrow of President Roosevelt's social security program was made likely today when that body agreed to go under a strict limitation of debate until the measure reaches a vote.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The first step of the new Works Progress Administration for New York State under the government's $4,000,000,000 relief program will be to establish in Albany a "clearing house through which will pass for consideration and approval all the projects for the State," according to Lester Herzog, the administrator, who is here attending the conference of State administrators.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., has bought the six-story building at 629-35 West Fifty-fourth Street which it held under lease to 1951, the Charles F. Noyes Company, the agent, reported yesterday. The structure was valued at $800,000.

BERLIN, June 18. -- The Anglo-German naval accord signed in London today has been received by Germany with satisfaction beyond measure. It is almost beyond the best that was hoped for. French disapproval viewed across the Rhine becomes in German eyes merely an agreeable salad for this delectable dish.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The view that a wave of strikes like those at Toledo and Omaha threatens unless the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Bill is enacted was advanced today by members of the House Labor Committee in persuading the Rules Committee to authorize procedure for consideration of the bill by the House tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, June 18. -- Speaking before the convention of the National Association of Credit Men today A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, denounced current pessimism among business men, industrialists and the public.

CANTON, N.Y., June 18. -- With negotiations for a reciprocal tariff treaty between the United States and Canada about to begin, speakers at today's session of the Conference on Canadian-American Affairs at St. Lawrence University urged that the existing barriers to trade between the two countries be lowered.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A compromise bill for amending the Tennessee Valley Authority Act, intended to break the deadlock which has held one of the administration's "must" measures in the House Military Affairs Committee for several weeks, was introduced today by a special subcommittee and referred to the full committee which may report it out on Thursday.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 18. -- Ralph Lannia, 38 years old, of Inwood, L.I., was found guilty of manslaughter in the second degree tonight by a jury before County Court Judge Cortland Johnson in county court here. The jury returned the verdict after five hours' deliberation.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Nervous about the poor chances of passing the Omnibus Banking Bill before June 30, members of the Senate Banking Subcommittee discussed today the possibility of initiating a joint resolution to continue the present temporary operations of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation until the banking bill can become law.

Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, obtained yesterday in Supreme Court warrants of attachment against the bank accounts of two alleged relief "chiselers." This was the first legal step in the bureau's attempt to recover relief money paid to persons not entitled to it.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 18. -The Board of Higher Education agreed at a meeting here tonight to approve the granting of a degree to Lester Rosner, president of the student council of City College, whose name was missing from the list of students recommended for graduation by the college faculty.

Francesco Pardo de Zela, 20-year-old son of the Peruvian Consul General, Pardo de Zela, was arrested in a jewelry store at 271 1/2 Amsterdam Avenue last night while he was forcing the proprietor, Charles Marshall, to empty his pockets of their contents, $11, at the point of a pistol.

On the eve of the anticipated battle at a Board of Estimate hearing today over their respective plans for extending the West Side express highway through Riverside Park, Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, and Park Commissioner Moses issued a joint statement last night announcing that a compromise agreement had been reached.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- An Agricultural Adjustment Act, radically altered throughout with the purpose of bringing it within the limitations laid down by the Supreme Court in the Schechter case, yet conferring powers on Secretary Wallace to regulate production and sale of many farm products, was passed by the House today without a record vote and sent to the Senate.
LANSING Kan., June 18. -- The menu for today in the State penitentiary where convicts seized a mine in protest over their food was:

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18. -- Although cut short slightly by intermittent showers, the 188th annual commencement exercises of Princeton University were held in the open air in front of Nassau Hall this morning with all the solemn academic pageantry dictated by tradition.

Hunter College will confer degrees on more than 800 students at its commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Special honors have been awarded to fifty-three students, of whom one is being graduated summa cum laude, five magna cum laude and forty-seven cum laude.

" Sea Cliff" in his letter of June 11 draws a logical inference from his scientific study of the reading matter of the male and female. It is not my intention to enter the very controversial field of the intellectual supremacy of one sex over the other. Chivalry demands, however, that reason be given for the apparent preference of the fair sex for the tabloids.

BERLIN, June 18. -- Under pressure of the new export levies and control measures taken by Dr. Schacht to stop "excessive stock speculation," the Boerse turned weak today. Although the turnover was small, the average drop exceeded 2 points.

Yesterday's report of the Senate Air and Ocean Mail Investigating Committee attacking Federal merchant marine subsidy policies and charging that shipping lines had wasted the taxpayers' money, brought a reply last night from Joseph P. Grace, chairman of the board of directors of W.R. Grace Co. He issued a statement as follows:

BERLIN, June 18. -- The list issued periodically by the secret police to newsdealers and bookshops citing newspapers and pamphlets forbidden in Germany contains today twenty-one such publications, all copies of which must be surrendered and any future copies of which must be returned.

PARIS, June 18. -- Meeting in the Louvre, where it was first assembled under Louis XIV, the French Academy today celebrated its 300th anniversary. Mario Roustan, the new Minister of Education, and several of the academy's forty "immortals" addressed the meeting, which was attended by a large number of official delegates from foreign countries as well as by a brilliant gathering of social and intellectual notables.

About one hundred delegates from Eastern States participated yesterday in the second annual Institute on Contemporary Jewish Affairs of the National Council of Jewish Women, in preparation for its third season next Fall.

OMAHA, Neb., June 18. -- Governor R.L. Cochran's demand for arbitration of the Omaha street-car strike was approved today by both strikers and the Omaha Council Bluffs Street Railway Company. The city has been under martial law since Saturday as a result of riots in connection with the strike.
An indignant Miss Stella Walsh arrived here yesterday prior to sailing this afternoon for a Summer in Poland. She will sail aboard the Gdynia-America liner Kosciuszko.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18. -- Eleven seniors of the Yale Law School have been elected to membership in the Order of the Coif, the national legal honor society for honor students in law. They are:

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 18. -Defending President Roosevelt from attacks made on him following his remarks about the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter NRA case, A. Mitchell Palmer, former Attorney General, told the Democratic State Committee of Pennsylvania here tonight that criticism of suggested amendments of the Constitution was a "flareback" from "an archaic, repudiated and defeated theory."

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Under an opinion by its general counsel, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, collateral trust notes of the type normally issued by finance companies and with a maturity of not more than nine months are exempted from registration under the provisions of Section 3 (a) (3) of the Securities Act of 1933.

William A. Brady is 72 years old today, but yesterday he was preferring not to think about it, though the telegrams were already arriving. The dean of active Broadway producers, he feared that some one might note his years and have faint doubts about that activity.

As a step in the school's endeavor to curb pupil retardation, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, recommended yesterday that the average size of 258 classes in sixty-five elementary schools, where retardation had been shown to be at a peak, be cut from 38.5, the city-wide average, to 28.

TRENTON, N.J., June 19. -- Another, and possibly the last, major legal battle over the life of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, under sentence of death for the murder of the Lindbergh baby, will be fought tomorrow before the Court of Errors and Appeals.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Saying that while the financial crisis among the railroads was due principally to the depression, political meddling was responsible for a large part of their trouble, Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy, outlined today to the American Association of Railroad Superintendents possible measures that he believed would help restore the roads.

Hamilton Township, N.J., awarded yesterday a new issue of $362,000 refunding 4% per cent bonds to M.F. Schalter, Noyes Gardner, Inc,; A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., and MacBride, Miller Co., whose bid topped the next highest offer by $90.

NEW HAVEN, June 19. -- Following are the citations of the candidates for honorary degrees at Yale today, with Professor Nettleton presenting the ten men and one woman recipient and President Angell presenting the degrees:

The elimination by the House Interstate Commerce Subcommittee of the provisions for compulsory abolition of holding companies from the Wheeler-Rayburn Public Utilities Bill was hailed as a constructive step at the annual meeting of the United Gas Corporation, a member of the Electric Bond and Share Company group, yesterday.

LAKE PLACID, June 19. -- Interest rates on long-term amortizing loans need not be reduced to less than 6 per cent in this State, according to John S. Fitzpatrick of Flushing, who spoke today at the forty-eighth annual convention of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the Lake Placid Club.
Rain and wet grounds caused the postponement of the major league baseball games scheduled to be played here yesterday, thus giving the teams involved their second successive day of rest.

There are three outstanding reasons why the adoption yesterday of the Wagner Labor Bill by the House of Representatives is to be regretted. First, the measure is of doubtful constitutionality. True, it has been changed in some respects, in an effort to make it stand up legally in the light of the Supreme Court's NRA decision.

The President has written to JAMES L. O'NEILL, Acting NRA Administrator, requesting that the latter's organization accumulate and report "accurate "information concerning the extent to "which changes occur in the main-"tenance of labor standards or fair "practice provisions of codes of fair "competition" in order to "counteract "any propaganda from private sources "which may be designed to promote a "special interest."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 19. -- The opinion that the Graduate School of Banking, which was opened on Monday at Rutgers University, will prove to be as valuable to bankers as medical clinics are to physicians and surgeons was expressed today by Willard E. Atkins, Professor of Economics at New York University and a member of the Graduate School's faculty.

Former United States Senator William M. Calder of Brooklyn yesterday recommended to Senator Hugo L. Black, chairman of the Senate Air and Ocean Mail Investigating Committees, that the Senate assume a direct responsibility for the government's grants to privately owned merchant ship lines.

Net fire claims incurred in Connecticut by all licensed companies in 1934 amounted to $3,261,913, compared with $3,547,630 in 1933, according to the annual fire and marine report of the Connecticut Insurance Department. The net premium income of all licensed companies from Connecticut fire business last year was $11,153,621, against $10,245,777 in 1933.
Several store buildings were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances recorded yesterday.

It is evident that the Governor is giving close attention to the charge that racketeering is showing its ugly head in this city. At his request the grand jury, which threw up its hands in disgust at the conduct of the District Attorney, has laid before him such evidence as had been presented to it.

John J. Kelly, genial host of the Central Park Zoo cafeteria, is finding out these days that expeditions are expensive luxuries. Mr. Kelly is the man behind the Park Department's one-man animal expedition to the wilds of Mexico.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Continuing its investigation of the reorganization of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, now Paramount Pictures, Inc., the Securities and Exchange Commission delved today into the activities of the committees that functioned to protect the holders of Paramount securities.

LONDON, June 19. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, the Foreign Secretary, in replying to questions in the House of Commons this afternoon, stated that Britain was keeping in close touch with the United States regarding developments in the Far East.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., June 19. -- The first execution under the Lindbergh Kidnapping Law was decreed today by Federal Judge R.L. Williams, who sentenced Arthur Gooch, Texas and Oklahoma outlaw, to die Friday, Sept. 13, for kidnapping two Paris (Texas) officers last November.

Captain Bob Bartlett announced yesterday that he would sail next Sunday for the north country on his faithful vessel, the Morrissey, which has served him on so many voyages. To organize a trip this year had been no easy task, the veteran skipper said.

Al fresco commencement exercises are one of the pleasant features of the early Summer landscape. It is not necessary to think back very many years to the time when the open-air graduation ceremony was the rare exception rather than the rule.

MOSCOW, June 19. -- Family life in Soviet Russia is fast becoming daringly respectable. The current campaign to increase the population by discouraging men and women from taking too much advantage of the easy marriage and divorce laws and to check a father's failure to provide for his children is now being reinforced by legal action where moral suasion seems insufficient.

The long controversy over the improvement of Riverside Park was settled yesterday when the Board of Estimate unanimously adopted a compromise plan calling for continuation of the West Side express highway along the Hudson River front and the roofing of the New York Central tracks as far north as 125th Street.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that, effective on July 1, the firm of Marshall Marshall would be formed. It will be composed of Levin R. Marshall, member of the Stock Exchange, and Martha J. Marshall. Effective tomorrow, the firm of Wenman, Pierce Brown will be dissolved, it was stated also.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 19 (AP). -- Voluntary part-time military training for every male Ethiopian got under way today. Officials asserted the empire could put an army of 800,000 well-armed men in the field.

DETROIT, June 19. -- Pressing relentlessly on, like a steam roller whose mechanism for bringing it to a stop has unexpectedly gone out of order, the Yankees wrenched both games of a double-header from the Tigers today to plunge a crowd of 27,000 into a gloom deeper than that which hangs over the purling waters of Lake Erie tonight.

PITTSBURGH, June 19. -- A warning that forced sales should be avoided was sounded before the convention of the National Association of Credit Men today by John Gerdes of the National Bankruptcy Conference. Creditors, he said, have much to gain and nothing to lose by permitting reorganization of corporations under the new regulations instead of insisting on liquidation.
RYE, N.Y., June 19. -- The Rye Garden Club held an open flower show here today at Christ's Church parish house. It will be continued tomorrow.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 19 (AP) -- An augmented program of six races consisting of seventeen heats was run off today at the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders Association meeting.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Benton gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Astor. Their guests were: Mr. and Mrs. George J. Willis, Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Justin, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Collins, Mr. and Mrs. Emory Parkes, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Quinn Jr., Mr. and Mrs. John Leahy, and Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Watson.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Amid signs of a growing schism between Harry L. Hopkins and Secretary Ickes, President Roosevelt hammered anew today on the necessity for low-cost work-relief projects of the type to be carried out by Mr. Hopkins's Works Progress Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Profiteering, collusion in bids and lobbying in connection with naval ship contracts as well as the disclosure of this country's naval secrets to other countries would all be prohibited or controlled under legislation introduced today by Senator Vandenberg of the Special Munitions Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commander of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was notified by Secretary Swanson today that the "navy considers it improper for officers of the navy to publish controversial comment on international affairs which might be construed offensive to foreign governments or their nationals."
Eight properties in Manhattan and ten in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Dwellings and tenements formed the bulk of the forced selling.

PARIS, June 19. -- With regret, and in some cases with marked indignation, today's French press records that the Anglo-German naval treaty signed yesterday puts an end to Anglo-French solidarity and all the efforts to maintain a common policy that were tried last February in London and later at Stresa and Geneva.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- An independent protective committee of security holders appealed to the Federal court here today to order the Baldwin Locomotive Works to pay the semi-annual interest of $313,158, overdue since March 1, on $10,438,000 of five-year consolidated mortgage bonds.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The New Deal's contribution to social security, called by some the most comprehensive measure of its kind ever adopted at any single session of any national Legislature in the world, was approved today in the Senate in the form of the Wagner-Lewis bill, by a vote of 76 to 6.
To the Editor of The New York Times:

RYE, N.Y., June 19. -- With Long Island Sound kicked up by a stiff northeast wind and rain making conditions anything but conducive to pleasure, the start of the American Yacht Club's eighty-mile race from Rye to New London tonight was postponed until 6 o'clock tomorrow morning.

The radical spirit at City College that has brought some of the students into sharp conflict with the college authorities flared up last night at the graduation exercises, held in the Great Hall at the college.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Clearing weather in the Southwest, with further beneficial rains in the Northwest and the failure of the wheat market in Liverpool to follow yesterday's late upturn here and in Winnipeg, led today to a right-about-face movement on the Board of Trade in many of those who had bought wheat yesterday.

A storekeeper in Harlem was wounded when he defied three armed Negroes who held him up at 11 o'clock last night and a shot fired by detectives pursuing the hold-up men struck a woman passerby before two of the fugitives were captured.

The trial of Frank Fox, president, and eight directors of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, on a charge of transferring assets of the corporation to bring about a bankruptcy, was recessed yesterday in United States District Court, Brooklyn, pending decision on whether the prosecution will be permitted to introduce a certain part of its evidence.

Ceremonies celebrating the installation of traffic lights along Avenue A from East Houston to Fourteenth Street were held yesterday at 6 P.M. at Essex and East Houston Streets. Essex Street is the continuation south of Avenue A.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied in sympathy with the rise in utility stocks at one time yesterday, sentiment reflected a change for the better in the weather west of the Mississippi River, and quotations ended at gains of 1 to 2 points.

The annual commencement exercises of the New York Stock Exchange Institute, an educational organization for employes of the Exchange and member firms, was held last night in the luncheon club of the Exchange. The thirty-four members of the graduating class were guests of honor at a dinner attended by more than 500 persons.

CANTON, N.Y., June 19. -- Canadians attending the conference on Canadian-American affairs at the St. Lawrence University replied today to criticism of their country's tariff policy toward the United States at an extra session they demanded for that purpose.

Francisco Pardo de Zela, 19 years old, son of the Consul General of Peru in New York, is to have a hearing before Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in West Side Court today on charges of robbery and violation of the Sullivan Law. He was held without bail yesterday.

For the last nine years the Biological Survey of the New York State Conservation Department has been conducting a comprehensive survey of watersheds, obtaining data to provide an intelligent basis for the administration of the State's fisheries resources.

TACOMA, Wash., June 19 (AP). -- Indictments charging violation of the Lindbergh Kidnapping Law, conspiracy to kidnap young George Weyerhaeuser and use of the mails to send a $200,000 extortion note were returned by the Federal grand jury today against three of the principals in the kidnapping case.
The seven four-story houses at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and 117th Street, taking in 2,143-49 Third Avenue and 205-9 East 117th Street, were purchased yesterday by Joseph L. Buttenwieser.

LONDON, June 19. -- Fervently begging that democracy should not be inflicted upon India, the Right Rev. Lord William Gascoyne-Cecil, Bishop of Exeter, during the second day's debate on the second reading of the India Bill in the House of Lords this afternoon, pointed to the United States to illustrate his denunciation of the democratic form of government.

Mass picketing in Forty-second Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, at 8:20 o'clock last night, the height of the theatre rush, halted street and pedestrian traffic for ten minutes. Thirty-five minutes more was required before policemen could restore things to normal.

The baccalaureate sermon preached at Harvard University by Dr. James B. Conant, its president, was severely criticized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. N.J. Gould Wickey of Washington, D.C., executive secretary of the Board of Education of the United Lutheran Church in America.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- Members of the graduating class of Radcliffe College were warned against becoming Amazons in the commencement address today.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 19. -- The chief complaint of Kansas State prison convicts against Dr. David Parker, prison physician, is that he is "too young and inexperienced." He was appointed in March, and Warden Simpson expressed surprise at the convicts' protest, saying that it had not been made to him officially.
ALBANY, June 19. -- Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck denied a petition today for a mandamus which would have opened the way for legislative reapportionment through the courts.
PARIS, June 19. -- Delegations from fifteen nations to the World Conference of Jewish ex-Service Men were warmly received in France today by municipal, national and educational authorities.

David O. Selznick, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer producer, will become a unit producer for United Artists when his Metro contract expires in August, it was announced yesterday. He plans to produce five or six pictures for United Artists release this season, thereby helping United augment a schedule which was seriously curtailed when Twentieth Century, its major producing affiliate, transferred to the Fox Film organization.

LANSING, Kan., June 19. -- Solitary confinement faced some forty Kansas Penitentiary prisoners tonight as officials moved to discipline leaders of a wild but bloodless mutiny which resulted in damage estimated at $25,000 to the prison coal mine.

ALBANY, June 19. -- Governor Lehman today invited District Attorney William C. Dodge to confer with him here tomorrow afternoon on the request of the March grand jury that he name a special prosecutor to investigate vice and racket conditions in New York City.

The stock market's electric response to the President's remarks yesterday on public utilities was perhaps the most direct and emphatic that has been accorded to any White House comment since the late President Coolidge's famous opinion that brokers' loans were not too high.

OMAHA, June 19 (AP). -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, defending titleholder, led the march of the favorites into the quarter-finals of the women's trans-Mississippi golf championship today by scoring a 7 and 5 triumph over Miss Betty Botterill of Salt Lake City, Utah's No. 2 ranking player.

JERUSALEM, June 1 (By Mail). -- The Rockefeller Museum of Antiquities, built through a gift of $2,000,000 by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the Palestine Government through Professor J.H. Breasted of the University of Chicago, has been completed.

ANCASTER, Ont., June 19. -- A powerful band of Western Canada golfers charged impressively over the Hamilton Golf and Country Club's picturesque fairways today and let it be known that C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville will find no easy path to his fifth Canadian amateur title.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Applications for registration of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, contained the following forty-one from New York City firms, (S) meaning sole proprietor, (P) partnership and (C) corporation:

Mrs. Gussie McInerney, 51 years old, indicted on a charge of compulsory prostitution, was permitted to plead guilty to the lesser offense of keeping a disorderly apartment in West Fifty-second Street, after her trial had started yesterday in General Sessions.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The text of President Roosevelt's tax message to Congress follows:

Lucy Cotton Thomas, 9-year-old heiress who has to get along on an allowance of $5,000 a month from the $2,000,000 estate left her by her father, Edward R. Thomas, is seeking an additional $340,000 to help her make ends meet. This was disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore appointed Edmund B. Butler of 50 East Forty-second Street, as her guardian at law to represent her in the action.

In the campaign of 1932 the outstanding issue was the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Millions of voters exchanged their electoral franchises for the definite promises of Franklin D. Roosevelt supported by the Democratic platform's pledges for the complete elimination of bootleg and illicit liquor trading, and the restitution to the taxpayer of the colossal sums which for twelve years had been diverted to the up-building of organized crime.

Brock Pemberton will shorten the Broadway list still further on Saturday night when he withdraws "Ceiling Zero" from the Music Box, where it has been since April 10. The Frank Wead play will not, however, disappear permanently. As already announced, Mr. Pemberton and Jack Waller, an English manager, will present it in London next season with an English cast.

After monopolizing the Long Island Golf Association's senior championship for three years, T. Henry Clarkson of the Old Country Club lost the crown last season to Gil P. Tiffany of Plandome. Yesterday, however, in the annual Old Timers tournament at the St. Albans Golf Club Clarkson staged a remarkable comeback.

DETROIT, June 19. -- Before a record attendance of members of the Automobile Manufacturers Association in the General Motors Building today reports indicated the largest production year since 1929, based on factory sales reports to date and estimates for the last half year, which would bring the total to 3,525,000 cars and trucks.

Allotments on the basis of possibly as little as three cents on the dollar appeared yesterday to be in prospect for cash subscribers to this week's offering of $239,000,000 Federal Land Bank farm loan 3 per cent bonds. An eleventh-hour rush of offers to exchange the called bonds for the new ones reduced to probably less than $30,000,000 the amount of bonds available for buyers who desired to pay cash.

The eighteenth annual season of open-air concerts by the Goldman Band opened last night on the Mall in Central Park despite the steady downpour. An audience of about eighty persons, counting policemen and newspaper men, listened to a ten-minute program, one of the shortest on record -- two marches by Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor of the band.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The NRA for the time being will not encourage industry to adopt voluntary codes, but will welcome information from business and industrial groups as to what steps they think should be taken to meet the situation caused by the Supreme Court decision in the Schechter case.

The Hunter College commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall yesterday were marked by sporadic interruptions from the balcony and a reprimand from the platform to the "disciples of discontent," who were attempting reprisals for the suspension of students for anti-war activities.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- President Roosevelt in a message to Congress asked inheritance taxes on very large estates and other tax increases aimed frankly at breaking up family concentration of wealth. The message asked higher gift taxes, higher income taxes on large incomes and a graduated scale of corporation income taxes.

BERLIN, June 19. -- Responding to the Anglo-German naval agreement, the Boerse rallied today from yesterday's slump, and while still irregular it was firmer. Shipping shares attracted particular attention. North German Lloyd and Hapag rising 1 1/2 points each, but they lost part of this gain later.
PEMBROKE, Ga., June 19. -- Those unofficial commentators on world affairs, the whittlers who used to hang around the rural stores, are vanishing because of a dearth of things to whittle.

Three editors and twelve other pickets, including several embryo authors, a few clerks and one man who said he was a "striker," paced nervously for more than three hours in cells in the West Forty-seventh Street police station last night while waiting for a patrol wagon to take them to Night Court.

Sufficient time has elapsed to permit both sides of the NRA controversy to take stock of the results from the famous court decision. In this connection it might be appropriate to quote the following by Thomas Babington Macaulay:

The recent gradual but irregular improvement in the bond market reached its peak for the month yesterday, when all classes of issues advanced except a few United States Government loans which, however, were steady to firm. Total trading was the most active since May 22.

LONDON, June 19. -- Having established control over Germany's naval construction by the bilateral treaty with that country signed yesterday, the British Government now proposes to take that agreement as a new point of departure in negotiations to get a multilateral naval understanding of all European powers as a useful prelude to the conference, including the United States and Japan, that is scheduled for this year.

RYE, N.Y., June 19. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden today defeated Miss Betty Pietsch of Tamarack, 7 and 6, in the feature quarter-final match of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Association golf tournament at the Apawamis C.C.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Sufficient information has been received in interested circles here concerning the break between President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico and former President Plutarco Elias Calles to indicate that the issues are fundamental.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 19 (AP). -- Swinging wide turning for home to escape the heavy going, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Identify today lost just enough ground to be nosed out by J.W.Y. Martin's Dark Hope in the $5,000 added King Philip Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth feature of Narragansett Park's inaugural program.

TIENTSIN, China, June 19. -- Revealing astonishing details of the magnitude and scope of Japan's new policy toward China, Lieut. Col. Y. Ishii, assistant chief of staff of the Japanese Tientsin garrison, in an authorized statement this afternoon, declared Japan's past policy of seeking the cooperation of regional Chinese militarists has been found faulty because Chinese militarists did not have the welfare of the people at heart.

OWASCO LAKE, N.Y., June 19. -- A superbly conditioned Primo Carnera went through eight rounds of sparring today, preparing for his fifteen-round fight with Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night.

WARSAW, June 19. -- Poland is seriously disturbed by the London naval agreement between Great Britain and Germany, which it is held will affect armaments in the Baltic. The Kiel Canal enables Germany easily to mobilize her entire fleet in the Baltic to threaten Russia and minor Baltic States.

MOSCOW, June 19. -- A self-appointed American "missionary" who started for Moscow more than a year ago to combat Communist Godlessness has been located just inside the Russian border, where he is detained by Soviet frontier guards.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he would strongly object to postponement of the sections of the Banking Bill proposing expanded powers for the Federal Reserve Board.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 19. -- Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Night Retreat, smartly ridden by Jockey Harold Clements, captured the twenty-fifth running of the Country Club grand annual steeplechase over a two-and-one-half-mile course at Clyde Park today.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The theory that there is a close, direct relationship between prices and the supply of monetary gold, as advanced by Professors George F. Warren and Frank A. Pearson, is rejected in a report prepared for the Brookings Institution by Charles O. Hardy.

LOS ANGELES, June 19. -- Termination of the long foreclosure proceedings involving the projected sale of the Richfield Oil Company of California and its remaining subsidiaries appeared imminent today when United States District Judge James set July 5 for hearing a compromise foreclosure decree submitted by attorneys for William C. McDuffie, Federal receiver in equity of the Richfield organization.

The pamphlet report for 1934 of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries shows gross revenues of $53,035,088, comparing with $57,513,332 for 1933, a decrease of 8 per cent. Net revenues were $21,715,836, against $24,066,720, a decline of 10 per cent, after operating expenses and taxes.

BERLIN, June 19. -- The first indication of what Germany intends to do with her newly won freedom to expand her present miniature navy to 35 per cent of Britain's naval strength, as provided in the Anglo-German naval agreement just signed, is revealed in an article in the Voelkischer Beobachter signed anonymously but authoritatively with three stars.
LONDON, June 19. -- The stock market continued quiet today, but the undertone remained firm. There was further investment buying of British funds. Foreign bonds generally were stronger.

The estate left by Charles Stillman, brother of the late James Stillman, financier, was valued yesterday in the transfer tax appraisal at $2,101,420 gross and $1,968,603 net. Charles Stillman, who retired in 1927 as a member of the New York Cotton Exchange, died on Nov. 15, 1933.
CHICAGO, June 19. -- Prices of hogs here dropped 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight today, but the demand was better than it had been recently and the best clearance in some days was effected.

UNION, S.C., June 19 (AP). -- Two men were shot and killed today in short-lived strike riot at the Monarch Textile Mill that brought Governor Johnston here from Columbia in a personal effort to bring peace to the warring factions.
Such editorial and other comment as I have seen on President Roosevelt's recent newspaper interview seems to have missed the true significance of the President's remarks.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 19. -- Joe Louis's mother, Mrs. Lillian Barrow Brooks, and three of his sisters, Vunies, Eualia and Emmarell, were among the most interested spectators today when the Detroit Negro heavyweight resumed training.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 19. -- Reduction of the membership of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors from forty-two to fifteen and refunding of the county's $104,000,000 outstanding bonded debt were chief among the recommendations in the annual report of E.M. Allen, president of the Westchester County Taxpayers' Association, made public here today.

The threefold program presented by President DODDS of Princeton is quite within the definition of her destiny as a "perfect place of learning," to quote a phrase of President WILSON'S. It is to be kept true to the ideal of a liberal education, with insistence upon "breadth "of understanding rather than voca-"tional expertness."

The demand for iron and steel continues to undergo seasonal shrinkage and the output of steel ingots has dropped 1 1/2 points to 38 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age says in its weekly summary. The publication states, however, that pressure against the price structure has not been nearly so severe as was feared when the Steel Code was nullified.

Industry's aim of developing voluntary agreements with which to salvage desirable features of former codes began to take definite form yesterday with the presentation of a tentative model agreement at a luncheon attended by 250 trade group executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP). -- A home-run outburst, featuring Hal Trosky's tenth and eleventh circuit drives of the season, enabled the Indians to defeat Washington, 10 to 5, in the second game of today's double-header after they had seen victory snatched from them in the last two innings of the opener.
Lower gross and net returns for May were disclosed in statements issued by railroads yesterday. The statements follow:
California's conquering oarsmen spurred on by their latest triumph in the classic Poughkeepsie regatta, already have their eyes on the 1936 Olympics.

BERLIN, June 19. -- It is now possible to reveal the text of the appeal for religious freedom submitted to the National Socialist government by the Augsburg Confessional Synod, comprising those parts of the German Protestant churches which have refused to be coordinated in the service of the Nazi National Socialist "Weltanschauung" [view of the world] and which met in Augsburg early this month to form a united front and agree upon a common policy.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- A prediction that air mail and passenger service over the Pacific would be an accomplished fact in the next year was made today by Harllee Branch, Assistant Postmaster General in charge of air mail, on returning from an inspection tour of prospective landing sites in the Hawaiian Islands for the service.

While black will undoubtedly retain its traditional leadership in the trend for early Fall, buyers believe that the novelty hues will prove quite popular during the course of the season. The strong vogue for the lilac tones in dresses and accessories during the latter part of the Spring season will be continued for Fall in the emphasis placed on the purple tones.

Z. Horiskoshi Co., imports and exports, are to move from 71 Madison Avenue to 119 West Fortieth Street, where the concern has leased the tenth floor. The Cross Brown Company arranged the rental for Ideal Investing, Inc., A.L. Hayman, secretary and treasurer.

TRENTON, N.J., June 19. -- Acting as a "common informer" under the Gambling Laws of 1877, William F. Zwirner of Merchantville filed suit for $3,600,000 against the Western Union Telegraph Company in the Supreme Court here today. He charged that the company had violated the gambling laws by accepting and transmitting chain telegrams.

Mrs. John Hay Whitney's erstwhile Futurity victor, Singing Wood, was the easiest sort of a winner through the mud at Aqueduct yesterday, as rain swept the Queens Jockey Club's course and the faithful few turned out for the races.

ROME, June 19 (AP). -- Heavy forces of Ethiopian troops, the Popolo di Roma reported today, are moving uninterruptedly toward frontiers facing on Eritrea and Italian Somaliland. The newspaper, basing its information on reports from other European capitals, said the latest survey indicated the Ethiopians were capable of putting into the field 500,000 men, at least 100,000 of them armed with modern rifles.

PARIS, June 19 (AP). -- France is discussing enlarging her navy in answer to the Anglo-German naval agreement which it was freely asserted, wrecked the 1922 Washington treaty. A naval race was forecast in quarters close to the Chamber of Deputies' Naval Committee as a result of the accord allowing the Reich to increase her navy to 35 per cent of Great Britain's.

DANBURY, Conn., June 19. -- Seventy-five young women, constituting the largest class in the last five years, was graduated from the Danbury State Normal School today, receiving diplomas from Harvey M. Thompson of Middletown, a member of the State Board of Education.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19. -- In a cold, slate-gray rain, the crews of Yale and Harvard today went through their last real work before the opening tomorrow of their sixty-fifth regatta, the oldest college sporting event in the country.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The list of large companies taking advantage of the favorable money market to refund outstanding issues at lower interest rates was augmented today when Armour Co. of Delaware filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for the issue of $48,000,000 first mortgage twenty-year 4 per cent sinking fund bonds, Series B, due on Aug. 1, 1955.
BOSTON, June 19 (AP). -- The Boston Braves and the Chicago Cubs divided two hard-fought games today, the Braves winning the first by a 2-1 margin and the visitors taking the second 3 -- 0.

Another man was arrested at police headquarters late yesterday afternoon in connection with the conspiracy through which John Flaherty, confessed "political fixer," is alleged to have obtained more than $200,000 from victims of his promises to have their names placed on civil service lists for jobs.

LONDON, June 19. -- Miss Helen Jacobs, American tennis player, will be presented by Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador, at the season's third royal court in Buckingham Palace next Tuesday. The Wimbledon tennis matches will begin next week, so Miss Jacobs may be seen on the tennis court earlier on the same day she goes to the palace court.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- A belief that about 10 per cent of those on relief rolls in New York State would be on work relief jobs by early July was expressed today by Lester W. Herzog, Works Progress Administrator for New York.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- In the gayly-festooned Harvard Stadium and on the vast lawn that is Soldiers Field, Harvard's sons this afternoon celebrated their most glorious class day in several years with a background of color that has seldom been surpassed.
Norman Armour, recently appointed United States Minister to Canada, and Mrs. Armour are among the persons due this afternoon from Europe on the French liner Normandie.

After a vexing day spent in attempting to start a hearing on disorderly conduct charges against eleven pickets, eight of them crippled or ill, Magistrate Overton Harris adjourned the case last evening and suggested that Mayor La Guardia take it over as a magistrate.

United States Attorney General Homer S. Cummings told 1,500 persons at commencement exercises of John Marshall College of Law in the New Jersey State Normal School in Jersey City yesterday afternoon that it was the duty of government to strive for justice and not merely execute the law as it found it and that government and justice must change as human nature and relationships change.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 19 (AP). -- The country's finest track and field athletes, with few exceptions, will match strides and strength in the National Collegiate A.A. championships here Friday and Saturday, but Brutus Hamilton of the University of California expressed doubt today any world's records would be broken.

TORONTO, June 19 (Canadian Press). -- With applications already received for $16,500,000 of Ontario's $20,000,000 of new bonds and $4,000,000 available if he desired it, Prime Minister Mitchell F. Hepburn said tonight that the loan had been subscribed.

GENEVA, June 19. -- The conference of the International Labor Organization adopted by a vote of 89 to 1 today a resolution aimed at extending the right of workers everywhere to organize. It was proposed by Shiichi Yagi, the delegate of the Japanese workers, who said they still lacked this right.

PARIS, June 19. -- Evidence that the internal strain on the franc has not by any means been entirely eased came today with the publication in The Journal Officiel of the Caisse des Depots figures covering the first half of June.

Members of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange will vote on July 2 on a proposal authorizing the board of managers by a two-thirds vote to appoint control committees of three members having broad powers to deal with trading situations which might arise to jeopardize the normal functioning of the Exchange.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of Eugene M. Lokey as executive assistant to the Exchange's committee on public relations. Mr. Lokey has been a member of the financial news staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES for nine years and recently has been in charge of financial advertising for THE TIMES.
" Becky Sharp," with Miriam Hopkins, Frances Dee and Alan Mowbray, begins today its second week at the Radio City Music Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP). -- In a clash with Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee, Joseph H. Choate Jr., chairman of the Federal Alcohol Administration, said tonight he would resign soon and return to private law practice in New York.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 19. -The weekly Wednesday night dinner dance at the m_nds Point Bath Club here tonight drew a large attendance of members and their guests in many separate dinner parties. George Vanderbilt gave a dinner at which his guests included Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Brandt, Miss Lucille Parsons, fiancSe of the host; Miss Gloria Baker, Miss Eleanor Young, Herbert Bayard Swope, Jr., WiLLiam Cleveland and Geoffrey Roche.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- After listening today for two and a half hours to Ewing Y. Mitchell's charges of favoritism, graft and corruption in the Commerce Department, the Senate Finance Committee summoned the ousted Assistant Secretary to appear before it again tomorrow with facts to back up the assertions and insinuations spread before it.

LONDON, June 19. -- David N. Jones, former Columbia University star, lent valuable aid to the American Davis Cup squad, and as a result the Stars and Stripes gained half the quarter-final round brackets in the London tennis championship at the Queens Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- Collecting six runs in the second inning, Yale triumphed by 9 -- 2 today before a commencement crowd of more than 6,000 and evened the annual baseball series with Harvard.

LONDON, June 19 (AP). -- Prince Aly Khan, 24-year-old only son and heir of the famed Aga Khan, Indian sportsman and head of the Ismaili Mohammedans, today was named corespondent in an undefended divorce suit involving two old and socially prominent English families.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Some of the main points of the President's message on taxes were:

Alderman Lambert Fairchild picketed four pickets at Broadway and Eighty-second Street yesterday until they appealed to the police, but were incongruously arrested. Although somewhat put out by the press notices given to his exploit, he was still determined last night at his home, 2,211 Broadway.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP). -- Valevictorian, an outsider in the betting, decisively defeated perhaps the classiest field of juveniles in the country today in the $5,000 added Woodward Stakes at the Detroit track.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 19. -- Faculty members at the New Jersey College for Women who have appeared as witnesses for Dr. Lienhard Bergel, dismissed German instructor, in hearings conducted by a special investigating committee of Rutgers University trustees, were described here today as "the left wing of the faculty" by Dr. Emil L. Jordan, German instructor.
LONDON, June 19. -- The recent friendly gesture of the Prince of Wales toward Germany came up in the House of Commons today and the government formally dissociated itself from the incident.

Trends in the commodity futures markets were reversed again yesterday as sugar, cocoa and copper advanced while coffee and cottonseed oil declined. The rise in sugar futures was in spite of a 7-point drop in the spot price to 3.28 cents, the first change since May 23.

MUNICH, June 19 (London Times Dispatch). -- It has been learned from Bad Reichenhall, a Bavarian mountain resort near the Austrian border, that the Summer Department of the Reich Chancellery is being established at a hotel there for the convenience of Reichsfuehrer Adolph Hitler.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 19. -- Roses were featured today at the Westchester County annual flower show at the County Centre here.

Hearings on the proposed merger of the New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light Power Company were closed yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission. Mr. Maltbie indicated that the commission would scrutinize carefully some items of the capital set-up of the New York Edison Company, Inc., the proposed successor to the companies sought to be merged.
A warning that any local unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor that admit Communists will not be recognized was issued yesterday by William Green, president of the federation.

OTTAWA, June 19. -- The decision of the United States Supreme Court against the NRA was quoted by Prime Minister R.B. Bennett today as a warning to the Canadian Parliament not to exceed its constitutional rights in enacting reform legislation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19. -- The condition of Yale University was reported as "sound in every part of its structure" by President Angell at the alumni luncheon today immediately following the 234th commencement.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 19. -- Even when Joe Louis is asleep -- which he seems to be most of the time -- the general staff moves busily around the Dr. Biers training camp here. This is probably the most extensive and Impressive general staff any heavyweight fighter took with him at a camp. Even Dempsey and Tunney lacked the pomp of Pompton and the big show with Shufflin' Joe.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The administration's Utility Holding Company Control Bill, stripped by the House Interstate Commerce Subcommittee of its provision for the compulsory dissolution of holding companies, but giving the Securities and Exchange Commission power over their future existence, was reported today to the full committee and the way was cleared for early presentation to the House.
ALBANY, June 19. -- Governor Lehman today heard a plea for clemency for Mrs. Eva Coo, convicted last Summer of killing her crippled handy man, Harry Wright, to collect his $10,000 insurance.
MACON, Mo., June 19 (AP). -- Dr. E.B. Clements of Macon, Republican National Committeeman for Missouri, was killed in an automobile accident near Monroe City, Mo., late tonight.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 19. -- Apparently the trip abroad to play in the British amateur championship did T. Suffern Tailer Jr. no harm, even though he only went to the fourth round.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP). -- Julius Solters, clouting St. Louis outfielder, was a rankling thorn to Boston pitchers today as the Browns divided a twin bill with the Red Sox, taking the nightcap, 6 to 3, after dropping the first game, 8 to 5.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- President Roosevelt's message urging inheritance and gift taxes, higher rates on large personal incomes and an increased graduated corporation tax came as a surprise to Congress, even though the President had discussed the matter of inheritance taxes with Congressional leaders recently.

A new book by the late Mark Twain is announced by Harpers. It is "Mark Twain's Notebook," from unpublished manuscripts edited and arranged by Albert Bigelow Paine. It will be published Oct. 3. Harpers will also publish another "new" Mark Twain book, a free translation of "Slovenly Peter," a German folk tale, made for the amusement of Mark Twain's own children.

Two former delegates of the American Federation of Master Barbers, charged with using strong-arm methods in building up the membership of the organization, were found guilty yesterday of coercion and conspiracy by a jury in Queens County Court.

Through Oswald W. Knauth, its chairman and executive director, the Emergency Relief Bureau disclaimed responsibility yesterday for deplorable social and relief conditions in Harlem as charged by Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, in an address Tuesday evening at the annual meeting of the Citizens Union.

The Holland Furnace CompanyI reported yesterday for the fiscal! year ended on ]arch 31 a net profit ! of $437,178 after taxes, interest, depreciation and other charges. This was equivalent, after allowing for annual dividend requirements on 10,715 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stocks, to 85 cents a share on 426,397 shares of nopar common stock.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP). -- A gift of $550,000 from Senator Couzens to the Federal Government to finance a 1,000-acre residence colony for part-time industrial workers in this area was announced today by William J. Norton, secretary of the Children's Fund of Michigan.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Bill to guarantee collective bargaining to workers of the country and restore the rights conferred by Section 7a of the Recovery Act, invalidated by the recent Supreme Court NRA decision, was passed by the House tonight without a record vote.

Following reports from California that Columbia and Stanford had entered a football agreement for next year, it was learned yesterday on Morningside Heights that the game will be played in New York on Nov. 28, 1936. Because Baker Field, the Lions' home grounds, seats only 32,000 persons, the Yankee Stadium and Polo Grounds are being considered as a site for the contest.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- A new taxation program providing for inheritance taxes on large bequests in addition to the present estate levies; higher gift taxes to prevent evasions; increased rates on very large incomes, and a graduated scale of tax rates for corporations in lieu of the current flat corporation rate of 13 3/4 per cent was laid before Congress today by President Roosevelt.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 19. -- Miss Barbara Stoddard of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club won the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day handicap tournament over the Wheatley Hills course today by scoring a gross 81.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew refused yesterday to remove Thomas B. Gilchrist and George W. Wickersham, general guardians of the property of 11-year-old Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, as parties to his order of last November awarding custody of the child.

An intimation by Mayor La Guardia that the Consolidated Gas system may control the votes of members of the Board of Estimate, and counter-charges by company counsel that the Mayor was playing "cheap politics," were features of a public hearing at City Hall yesterday on the Mayor's proposal to build a $45,000,000 municipal "yardstick" power plant.

An unexpected strike of three radio operators held the Manhattan of the United States lines at her pier yesterday for five and a half hours after her sailing time. She had been scheduled to leave at noon for the Channel ports and had aboard 1,089 passengers, her record this year, and 7,913 sacks of mail.
A cool, drizzly day reminiscent of April brought Summer shivers to the city yesterday as temperatures dropped to within two degrees of the record low for June 19.
LONDON, June 19. -- Two major surprises were registered today as the draw was made for the Wimbledon tennis championships starting next Monday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

NEW HAVEN, June 19. -- An invitation to Connecticut to joint with Virginia in order that "impious hands may not be put upon the Constitution" was addressed to the officers, graduating class and alumni of Yale University here today by Senator Carter Glass.

BERLIN, June 19. -- Second thoughts on the Anglo-German naval accord produced in the German press today expressions of gratification that bordered closely on jubilation. The tenor of them all is that Germany has regained her sovereignty and that the great cause of a European settlement upon lines acceptable to her has taken a long step forward.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June. 19. -- Mrs. Lewis Cass Ledyard of Syosset won the highest honors this afternoon in the first day's judging of the twenty-fourth annual rose and sweet pea show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society, which opened here in the parish hall of Christ Episcopal.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The House subcommittee draft of utility company regulation is a strong bill. Even though the "death sentence" in Section 11 for all but first-degree holding companies has been eliminated, the measure is of a piece with the objectives of the New Deal and redeems a campaign promise made repeatedly by the President.

Awards amounting to $1,360 were made in the second New York high school scholarship competition conducted by the Art Students League. It is reported that more than 100 members of the February and June graduating classes competed. Each scholarship, estimated as being worth $136, entitles the winner to study in any chosen Winter class at the Art Students League.

Ninety-two per cent of all of the consumers of the New York Edison Company's electricity are paying high rates because the company is supplying current at less than cost to special consumers, it was charged yesterday in a suit filed against the company in Federal Court under the Anti-Trust Law.

Evidence of discriminations and racketeering has been given to Mayor La Guardia's fact finding committee on food trucking, it was learned yesterday. The committee, which held a private meeting yesterday in the offices of its chairman, Dr. John A. Harriss, at 511 Fifth Avenue, will make a public report next Thursday.

CANTON, N.Y., June 20. -- Declaring that public ownership and unification of transportation systems was inevitable, Colonel William J. Wilgus, railroad engineer, told delegates to the Conference on Canadian-American Affairs today that it did not follow necessarily that private operation for profit must go.

LONDON, June 20 (AP). -- Donald Budge, California youngster, smashed his way to a three-set victory over his doubles partner, Gene Mako of Los Angeles, in the quarter-final round of the Queens tennis tournament today as rain held other American contenders idle.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A constitutional amendment, as a basis for revising all existing veterans' legislation and to take the question out of politics, was recommended today by the legislative committee of the American Veterans Association.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Passage of the Copeland-Bland bill to put regulation of ocean shipping in the hands of a Federal maritime commission and set up a United States merchant marine corporation with an authorized capital stock of $500,000,000 was recommended to the House today by its Merchant Marine Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- President Roosevelt addressed the State Rural Re-settlement Administration, stressing the social worth of this portion of the work relief program. He departed tonight for New London, Conn., to view the Harvard-Yale boat race.

Sunday legitimate theatrical performances became legal in New York City yesterday when Mayor La Guardia, with a swift stroke of his pen, signed the ordinance adopted unanimously in the Board of Aldermen last Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- The Pennsylvania varsity grew left tonight for the regatta at Long Beach, Calif.
