Before departing, the Red and Blue eight, which finished next to last at Poughkeepsie after going through the Blackwell, Childs and Adams Cup regattas undefeated over shorter distances, held its final Eastern workout on the Schuylkill.

The city administration will seek a popular referendum in the Fall on the question of municipal ownership and operation of an electric power plant for rate "yardstick" purposes, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday. The question will go to the voters, he declared, regardless of whether or not the Board of Estimate authorizes him to apply to the PWA for a Federal loan of $45,000,000 for construction of such a plant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20. -- Following are the citations of cause for which twelve honorary degrees were conferred today by Harvard University. The quoted statement after each name is the public citation made by President Conant. The matter in parenthesis is the identification officially supplied by Fthe university.

Patrolman Samuel Alexander of the Simpson Street station, in the Bronx, was tried in the disciplinary court at police headquarters yesterday on departmental charges growing out of the activities of John Flaherty, political job "fixer," in promising to have persons appointed and promoted to city jobs through getting their names on civil service eligible lists.

PITTSBURGH, June 20. -- Four words uttered by Al Jolson during a nation-wide radio program Saturday night were valued at $25,000 apiece today in a damage suit filed here against the comedian and the National Broadcasting Company by the Summit Hotel Company of Uniontown.

The Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin, arriving today from Hamburg, Southampton and Cherbourg, has among her passengers Dr. Walter F. Mueller-Schlenkhoff, the Mayor of Weimer, Germany. Others on board are:

Effective relief pitching by Al Smith, along with home runs by Bill Terry and Joe Moore, featured the 6-to-2 victory recorded by the Giants over the second-place Pirates yesterday at the Polo Grounds in the opener of their four-game series.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- The major fault in the structure of the Securities Act of 1933, according to the report of a special committee appointed by the American Bar Association, lies in its general language. The revision of this, the report says, would enable industry and securities distributers to be sure of their responsibilities and liabilities; and would enable lawyers to advise their clients with a greater degree of certainty.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 19, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,486,000,000, an increase of $10,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $14,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A thorough investigation of charges of "favoritism" and the "appearance of corruption" in the Department of Commerce, made by Ewing Y. Mitchell, ousted Assistant Secretary, has been started under the direction of Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General in charge of criminal prosecutions, Attorney General Cummings announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The pending bill for extension of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration is unsatisfactory to the Treasury in at least two respects, Secretary Morgenthau indicated today at a press conference.

NEWARK, N.J., June 20. -- Out of the combined earnings of himself and his wife since July, 1933, when he found work again, averaging about $25 a week, a Newark machinist has repaid to the Emergency Relief Administration $242.78, the exact amount of relief received by his family from June, 1932, to July, 1933.

Huey Lone should be lauded and his name should be inscribed among those who have "deserved well of their country'' for his filibuster. In saying this I have not in mind the worthiness or unworthiness of his cause. In fact, I have forgotten what it was, and assume that he was probably wrong, as on almost all questions.

Mayor La Guardia and Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch expressed disappointment yesterday at the impossibilities of getting a revised Greater New York Charter before the electorate of the city this Fall.
PARIS, June 20. -- Anthony Eden, British Minister without portfolio, arrived here this evening on an official visit in connection with the Anglo-German naval agreement signed in London on Tuesday.

PARIS, June 20. -- An order of expulsion against Colonel Francis B.V. Norris, whose operations in frozen German credits earned him the appellation of "mystery man" of European finance, has been issued by the French Government, it was stated today at the Surete Nationale.

A drive to curb the power of Chase Mellon Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, to designate inspectors of elections was halted last night at a special meeting of the committee held in Palm Garden, 306 West Fifty-second Street.

BUENOS AIRES, June 20. -- The Pan-American Commercial Conference closed its twenty-five-day session yesterday. Spruille Braden of the United States delegation was designated by the delegates to make the closing address.

ANCASTER, Ont., June 20. -- The West and East will fight it out over the Hamilton Golf and Country Club course for a Canadian amateur golf championship returning to the Dominion for the first time since 1932.

While industrial activity in May was lower than in April, a slight improvement was registered in volume of output in the first half of June, according to the monthly business survey issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Gold-certificate reserves of the Federal Reserve System rose $100,013,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high record of $6,119,488,000, according to the weekly report of the system, published yesterday.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange gained 5 to 9 points yesterday following a definite statement by Secretary Wallace that the cotton-loan program would be continued the coming season. This offset the effects of improved weather and the action of other markets.

Though it is possible, of course, that Kansas may be able to establish priority to "grass roots," it will have to go back much further than the present generation-probably back before the middle of the last century -- to establish that priority.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20. -- A different attitude toward the relative functions of local and Federal Government is necessary if this country is to avoid "destructive group warfare," Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, said today in an address at the commencement of Harvard University, which conferred upon him the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced amendment of the regulations governing first mortgage notes and bonds under the Securities Act of 1933.

Magistrate Overton Harris yearned for escape in Tahiti, as the second day of the saga of the crippled pickets, arrested in front of the Emergency Relief Bureau, spread itself yesterday, seemingly endlessly, in the record at the chief magistrate's court, 300 Mulberry Street.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 20. -- Bitter denunciation of the liquor situation, "which is getting worse all the time," marked the keynote address by the Rev. Dr. A.A. Shaw of Granville, Ohio, president of the Northern Baptist's national convention, opening here today. Nearly 2,000 delegates were in attendance and printed reports totaling 90,000 words were submitted.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Five hours of Senate debate on the question of when a Senator is a Senator was sufficient today to prevent Senator-elect Holt of West Virginia taking his seat as he had expected to do.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 20 (AP). -- Every plank in the program of it he Dairymen's League Cooperative Association was endorsed without a dissenting vote by 2,000 members and delegates attending the annual meeting of the association here today.

The development of an "artificial heart" and of a man-made "blood-stream," which enable science for the first time to keep the vital organs of man and animals alive and functioning indefinitely outside the body in what may be described as a "chamber of artificial life," is announced today by the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP). -- The White Sox divided two overtime games with the Athletics today, taking the second, 2 to 1, in twelve innings on consecutive singles by Radcliff, Hayes and Haas, after Jimmy Foxx's twelfth home run with Johnson on base in the tenth had given the Mackmen the opener, 5 to 3.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, assured Newark officials today that the Eastern airmail terminus would not be transferred from Newark to Floyd Bennett Field, L.I., unless it was shown that service would be materially improved and costs reduced.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Congress is being driven toward adjournment on July 15 against odds which daily add discouragements to its harried leaders.
OWASCO LAKE, N.Y., June 20. -- None of the anxiety that was so apparent in Primo Carnera when he was training for Max Baer a year ago was evident as the huge ex-champion did his traning stint today.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Describing reports of differences with Harry L. Hopkins as "made" news, Secretary Ickes said today "there is no rift, schism, clash, row, breach, break or misunderstanding between US."

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 20. -- Mrs. John M. Schiff of Northwood, Oyster Bay, won six blue ribbons and two reds this afternoon in the fruits and vegetables section at the annual rose and sweet pea show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society, which closed tonight in the parish hall of Christ Episcopal Church.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 20. -- Revelations that the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation in 1934 charged $36,474 for memberships in fifty-six clubs and associations to operating expenses created a furore at a rate hearing conducted here today by Maurice C. Burritt, Public Service Commissioner.

Communications between an informant and a newspaper reporter can only be made privileged by act of the Legislature, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in affirming the decision of Supreme Court Justice John F. Cater in the case of Martin Mooney, New York American reporter.

GENEVA, June 20. -- Ethiopia proposed today in a note to the secretariat of the League of Nations that the League Council send neutral observers at her expense to frontier regions as a safeguard against further incidents.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The ultimate happiness and well-being of a large segment of the nation's population hinge upon the efforts of the Rural Resettlement Administration, which alone of all the major divisions of the work-relief program is concerned more with the future than with the immediate present, President Roosevelt today told State Resettlement Administrators who visited him under the guidance of Administrator Tugwell.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 20 (AP). -- Greyhound's performance in winning the 3-year-old trot and the success of the Reynolds Stable featured the closing day of the Spring meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders Association today.

DETROIT, June 20. -- The delectable task of spread-eagling the American League field which the Yankees appear to have set for themselves with great determination continued to move along today with astonishingly fine results as the McCarthymen won their third straight game from Mickey Cochrane's slightly bewildered Tigers.

I learn with surprise that there has been published a German version of a volume of mine on "Pittura del quattrocento nelle Marche." (Fifteenth Century Painting in the Marches,) I have also received from London the news that an English version of that same volume is about to appear.

BELGRADE, June 20. -- The fall of the Yevtitch Cabinet, which had been awaited since the result of the last "managed" elections showed that a large part of the electorate was opposed to the continuance of Premier Bogolyub Yevtitch's semi-dictatorial regime, occurred tonight after a large number of its members, by resigning individually, had forced M. Yevtitch to place his resignation in the hands of Prince Paul, head of the Regency.

The Capitol and Loew's Metropolitan in Brooklyn this morning will offer Joan Crawford, Robert Montgomery and Franchot Tone in "No More Ladies," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production adapted from the play by A.E. Thomas.

Nicholas J. Imperato, 39 years old, a partner with five of his brothers in a produce business in the Bronx Terminal Market, was found dead with two .32-calibre bullet wounds in the head early yesterday morning beside his parked automobile in a vacant lot opposite his home at 109 East 153d Street, near River Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The text of the resolution of the railway labor executives calling for government control of railroads was as follows:

On July 1 the Treasury will redeem about $600,000,000 of the 2 per cent consols carrying the circulation privilege, in accordance with the plans announced on March 10. If it were to follow literally the course proposed then, namely, to defray the redemption of these bonds by deposit of gold certificates with the Reserve Banks, a sharp rise in excess member banks reserves, probably above $3,000,000,000, might be looked for.

A conference of spokesmen of the American Radio Telegraphists Association and the International Mercantile Marine Company will be held today to consider terms of a new agreement to govern the employment of radio operators on merchant ships owned by the I.M.M.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Allegations that the collapse of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, now Paramount Pictures, Inc., resulted largely from poor financiering, the payment of excessive salaries and officials, that millions of dollars were improperly distributed to common stockholders and that most of the current assets of the corporation were wrongfully hypothecated as additional collateral to banking creditors, were made at the hearing on the Paramount reorganization before the Securities and Exchange Commission today.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20. -- Sweet peas and cut annuals were the predominating blooms of the fourth day of the Westchester County Flower Show being held here at the County Centre.

TRENTON, N.J., June 20. -- In the calm, unhurried atmosphere of the Court of Errors and Appeals, the highest court in New Jersey, a setting far different from the hurly-burly of the trial court at Flemington, nearly six months ago, fourteen grave-faced, black-robed judges, most of them elderly men, heard today Bruno Richard Hauptmann's appeal from his conviction and death sentence for the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

KALGAN, Chahar Province, June 20. -- Wealthy Chinese, fearing that Japan's relentless penetration of China soon will engulf all Inner Mongolia, today were leaving this outpost on the caravan route across the Gobi Desert in numbers.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 20. -- An optimistic trend was evident today in reports of group chairmen representing districts of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, in convention here. All payments are on the increase, including those delinquent mortgages, they said.

In the introduction to his "Selected Short Stories," which Doubleday, Doran will publish on July 1, Sinclair Lewis comments that: "One of the things most interesting to the author, though perhaps to no one else, in rereading these stories, is the discovery that he, who has been labeled a 'satirist' and a 'realist,' is actually a romantic medievalist of the most incurable sort."

James P. Warburg tendered his resignation yesterday as vice chairman of the board of directors of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, effective June 30. He will remain as a director of the bank and will maintain offices in the Manhattan Company Building, 40 Wall Street.

It is impossible not to perceive the trail of politics over the President's message on taxation. Mr. ROOSEVELT himself clearly traces it when he calls some of his recommendations too "complicated and difficult to be de-"bated in the time remaining for the "present session of the Congress."

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Treasury will offer another $100,000,000 of 3 per cent bonds to highest bidders Monday, the last financing operation involving new cash to be carried out during the fiscal year, except the usual weekly sale of Treasury bills on a discount basis.

There can be no more card parties, dances, operating of roulette wheels, raffling of sofa-pillows or any other article; bazaars or sales of home-made pies and cakes to raise church funds with the authority of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- Miss Madora Thomson, daughter of Mrs. Douglas H. Thomson of Farmington, was married to Barclay Cooke of Paterson, N.J., this afternoon in the Farmington Congregational Church by the pastor, the Rev. Quincy Blakeley, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Drury, headmaster of St. Paul's School at Concord, N.H.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company of Chicago has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement of March 18 in connection with its plan for extension of the maturity of $14,823,000 principal amount of twenty-year 6 per cent gold bonds and $9,826,500 principal amount of 6 per cent gold notes for five years until Oct, 1, 1940.

TOKYO, June 20. -- Though money is cheap in Japan and trade is expanding, the Tokyo share market, after a year of falling prices, has reached a state of stagnancy that seems to some observers to portend something alarming, though they cannot guess what.

ROME, June 20. -- The ItaloEthiopian controversy is expected to come to the fore again in the forthcoming conversations between Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, and Premier Mussolini.

Interest on the 6 per cent debentures of the Colon Oil Corporation, of which $10,000,000 is outstanding, will be defaulted on July 1, Richard Airey, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting. He added that no definite program of reorganization was under consideration.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Railroad Reorganization Bill, designed to simplify corporate and financial readjustment proceedings, and particularly to facilitate the scaling down of fixed charges through amendments to the present Bankruptcy Act, was unanimously reported today by the House Judiciary Committee.

The inherent strength in the share market which has been apparent for some time was attested to further yesterday by the comparative calm with which the market withstood the shock of the President's new tax program which would deal severely with many corporations listed on the "Big Board."

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A dozen housewives from Chicago and New York demanded a Congressional investigation today of an alleged monopoly in food prices and heard Farm Administration officials explain that they were working toward a balance between supply and demand.

The section of the 1934 Milk Control Law of New York State which permits the sale of unadvertised brands of milk at one penny less a bottle than the minimum price fixed for advertised brands is "unreasonable, discriminatory and unconstitutional," according to Charles C. Burlingham, who was appointed a Special Master in the case.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- A list of 123 applications on Form 1-M for registration of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, contained the application of one foreign company, King, Boug, Stodgell Co., a partnership, Windsor, Ont.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The New York State Conservation Department is developing plans to make the reforestation areas which are now public hunting grounds more attractive to the sportsmen through a program of cooperative work between the Division of Lands and Forests and the Division of Fish and Game.
BRIGHTON, England, June 20. -- Twenty-nine German veterans of the World War, wearing swastika armlets, arrived at Brighton today.

PARIS, June 20. -- A plea for liberalism, both internationally and within nations, was made here today by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler before the American Club. The President of Columbia University called the United States Supreme Court's NRA decision the "most important happening in constitutional history since the end of the Civil War."

A new parkway or arterial motor road is a fine thing when completed, but across how many private heartaches and headaches the engineers are compelled to run it! Park Commissioner Moses says about the extension of the West Side express highway in Riverside Drive and beyond, "If we put this road where everybody wants it we could just put it in our pockets and do nothing about it."

This week's dispatches reported Germany's exports in May as running in value 4,400,000 marks ahead of imports. In May of 1934 the excess of imports was 42,200,000. This change in the "foreign trade balance" was not effected through increase of exports, which, despite inclusion of the Saar this year, were almost exactly the same as in 1934, but through reduction of 47,000,000 marks in imports.

Largely because of gains reported by some Western and Southern cities, bank clearings of the twenty-two leading centres in the United States rose in the week ended on Wednesday to the highest figure in six weeks. The clearings aggregated $5,899,502,000, against $5,583,962,000 for the same week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during May at 83.4 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 85.3 for April this year, and 98.2 for May last year.
LONDON, June 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

BERLIN, June 20. -- The Boerse was rather weaker today, although the price changes and the turnover remained small. Financial commentators now begin to admit that the new export levies have aroused some concern which the reported increase in industrial production for April is unable to counteract.

The prize winners in the first annual Child's Garden Design Competition, arranged by the Gardens of the Nations, began yesterday afternoon the construction of what is said to be the first skyscraper garden ever designed and built by children for children.

The Annalist reported yesterday that another sharp drop in prices for cattle and beef was largely responsible for a decline in its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 122.4 on Tuesday from 123.9 (revised) on the Tuesday previous,

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 20. -- J.U. Gratton's chestnut filly Paradun scored her first victory in nearly two months when she accounted for the fifth race at Narragansett Park today, a six-furlong sprint for 3-year-olds. The race featured the all-claiming card presented at the second day of the local track's first meet.

TRENTON, June 20. -- Andrew W. Mulligan of Camden filed suit today in the Supreme Court here to collect $26,910,000 in penalties against the Western Union Telegraph Company for allegedly conducting a lottery in connection with the "chain" telegram that recently proved a popular successor to the "chain" letter scheme.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Indications were very clear today that enactment of the new tax program projected yesterday by President Roosevelt would await another session of Congress.

Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, chief of the Attorney General's Bureau of Securities, announced yesterday that he had obtained an order from Supreme Court Justice Dore temporarily enjoining William F. Peterson, a securities dealer, of 70 Pine Street, from disposing of property allegedly derived from fraudulent practices, and requiring him to produce books and records of his transactions for examination in Supreme Court on July 1.

June Night Frolic, a mammoth variety show, was staged last night at the Yankee Stadium for the benefit of the Jewish National Fund of America. The estimated attendance was about 20,000 persons, with a small army of stage, screen and radio stars, musicians and technicians participating in the program.

Plans for the formation of a fair trade practice bureau in the dress industry were approved yesterday by a subcommittee of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, which has been studying the proposal, at a meeting in the headquarters here.

Supreme Court action to test the right of the Kashruth Association to force dealers in kosher poultry to permit Kashruth-appointed agents to affix metal leg-bands to fowl slaughtered according to orthodox ritual was started yesterday by the S.S. B Live Poultry Corporation of 2,692 Park Avenue, the Bronx.

TOKYO, June 20. -- Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's doll messengers of good-will came from the bridal suite of the Imperial Hotel today to the City Hall, where they were seated between Old Glory and the Rising Sun and were welcomed with martial music.

Your editorial "What Caused the Bank Panic" discusses with exemplary fairness the significance of the facts brought out in the series of articles by Professor William Starr Myers and Walter H. Newton in The Saturday Evening Post on "The Origins of the Banking Panic of March 4, 1933."

GENEVA, June 20. -- The International Labor Organization conference adopted today in the first test vote in its plenary session a blanket convention whereby the member governments approve the principle of the forty-hour week without a reduction of the standard of living, and undertake to facilitate measures to this end with separate conventions to implement the forty-hour week in each industry.

Price trends were mixed in the commodity futures market here yesterday, with trading somewhat less than on the two previous days. Declines in rubber and copper, with rallies in hides and coffee, stood out in the day's operations.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- President Roosevelt left tonight for New London, where he will witness the Harvard-Yale races tomorrow. His son, Franklin Jr., is a member of the Harvard junior varsity.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Although knocked down with a right cross to the jaw in the fourth round, Tommy Loughran, Philadelphia's popular heavyweight, gained a ten-round decision over Ray Impellittiere of New York at the Phillies ball park tonight before a slim crowd.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 10 per cent for the week ended June 15, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase in deliveries, made for approximately 270 stores here, compares with a rise of 12. per cent for the previous week.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- This government would not consent to limiting battleships to 25,000 tons with 12-inch guns, and cruisers to 7,000 with 6-inch guns, high navy officials who have attended recent naval conferences said today in commenting on Great Britain's suggestion to Germany for such a limitation of armament.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20. -- Eighty-three years ago the crews of Yale and Harvard met each other in the first intercollegiate sporting event this country had ever seen. Tomorrow, racing here, they will meet for the seventy-third time.
Editorial comment of newspapers in key cities throughout the country on the President's tax proposals is widely divergent. Excerpts of some follow:
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- President Roosevelt's remarks to the Regional Resettlement Directors were as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP). -- A combination of splendid pitching by Dizzy Dean and a home run by Jimmy Collins with one man on base in the fifth inning gave the Cardinals a 3-1 victory over the Phillies in the first game of the series today.

The directors of the Western Electric Company, Inc., voted yesterday to redeem on Oct 1, 1935, at 105 and accrued interest, the entire amount of $35,000,000 twenty-year 5 per cent debentures due in 1944, which is the sole funded debt of the corporation.

Mrs. Wilber Bloodgood gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests were Princess Pignatelli di Montecalvo, Mrs. James Culver Daily, Mrs. Morin S. Hare, Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, Mrs. Joseph B. Long, Mrs. Augustine L. Humes and Mrs. Marjorie Oelrichs.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 20. -- Two of the district's recently crowned champions, Dominick Morano of New Jersey and Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Long Island, will view the remainder of the thirty-fifth metropolitan amateur championship from the sidelines.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- After nearly twenty years of effort by the twenty-one standard unions to obtain "piecemeal" legislation dealing with the problems of the railway industry, the Railway Labor Executives' Association adopted today a resolution favoring "the immediate taking over of the railways of the United States by the Federal Government and the creation of agencies within the Federal Government to manage and operate them."

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Charging a "shameless abuse of radio broadcasting," by a group of advertisers "who are trying to make the youth of America 'alcohol conscious,'" Representative Culkin of New York introduced a bill today to prohibit the advertising of alcoholic beverages by radio.
Mayor La Guardia found occasion yesterday to criticize Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin of the Board of Education and Magistrate Overton Harris for public statements attributed to them.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Wholesale commodity prices made their third successive decline last week, the composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on the 1926 average, standing at 79.8, as compared with 79.9 for the preceding week and 74.6 a year ago.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- The wheat market has become a typical weather affair. Reports received today before the opening of the Board of Trade indicated little or no rain overnight, and a selling movement got under way which carried prices more than 1 cent a bushel below yesterday's final quotations and to the lowest mark for the season on the September and December, the former touching 78 7/8% cents.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer ruled yesterday that the Martin act could be invoked against officers and directors of a corporation even though no proof had been offered that they had participated in the sale of stock or knew of the misrepresentations and fraudulent practices engaged in by their corporation.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 20. -- A dressing room and a check room will be provided at the Yonkers terminal, of the Yonkers-Alpine ferry line without charge for the convenience of girls who wish to hike in shorts in Palisades Interstate Park, but who are forbidden by a local ordinance to pass through the streets of this city in abbreviated clothing.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 20. -- Showing to excellent advantage, Will Gallop and Cervantes, entries from Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Carver's stables at Westport, captured blue ribbons in two of the more important classes as competition in the ninth annual Watertown Horse Show started today.

Applications for listing the securities of two companies that hitherto have not been traded on the New York Stock Exchange are awaiting action by the committee on stock list of the Exchange, it was announced yesterday. They are the Greyhound Corporation, which has been traded on the New York Curb Exchange, and the Pacific American Fisheries, Inc., which has been traded on the San Francisco Curb Exchange.

LONDON, June 20. -- After Anthony Eden has tried to dispel in Paris the idea that in the new Anglo-German naval agreement there has been any real breach of the principle of Franco-British collaboration, Britain's Minister for League of Nations Affairs will proceed to Rome.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange have been asked by the Exchange, at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to report weekly until further notice their total volume of purchases and sales of listed stocks as principals, omitting transactions effected as brokers for others.

In conferring honorary degrees, the pleasantest incident of this commencement season has been the spontaneous tribute to CARTER GLASS. When bestowed on public men, the distinction is apt to be on the ground of achievement in public measures. The Brain Trusters and administrators of alphabetical bureaus have in this regard occupied the limelight.

DETROIT, June 20. -- If the "good cars hold out," Young Joe Louis, the Negro heavyweight, is going to receive a royal welcome from his home-town fans next Tuesday night when he climbs through the ropes in New York for his battle with the huge Italian, Primo Carnera.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- The national clay court championships at the River Forest Tennis Club today staggered into the fourth round after an eventful day's program of 104 matches, which saw the choice field of 128 narrowed down to sixteen competitors and which left four of the seeded stars resting on the sidelines.
CINCINNATI, June 20. -- A University of Cincinnati archaeological expedition cabled today it has found indications that "a fearful conflagration" destroyed Troy at about the time of the Trojan War.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20. -- Accused of embezzling about $14,000 of municipal funds in the last twelve years, John A. Schetty, 61 years old, cashier of the local Bureau of Water Supply, was held tonight in $25,000 bail for action of the grand jury when arraigned before Police Recorder Thomas B. Kaveny on the complaint of Otto A. Feth, superintendent of the bureau. He entered a plea of not guilty.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:...

Disregarding the warning of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, that unions admitting Communists would not be recognized by the A.F. of L., the International Fur Workers Union, A.F. of L. affiliate, yesterday entered into a united front with the Communist-controlled Fur Workers Industrial Union at a mass meeting of members of both organizations in the Manhattan Opera House.
Reading in Topics of The Times your remarks on the city's anti-litter truck reminds an old citizen of a time when New York was a fairly clean city.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Prices of hogs here early today were generally 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. But as soon as the aggressive buying was satisfied the market reacted and the close was barely steady. The top was lifted l0 cents to $9.80, while the day's average was up 5 cents at $9.25.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- The lure of the sea has caused the Rev. George G. Guinness, rector of St. James Church here, to surrender his pastorate for a first mate's post aboard the steamship Steel Trader of the Isthmian Line.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20. -- Herbert L. Bowman's quest for his third leg of the Marcus Trophy in the New Jersey State tennis championship met with an abrupt checkmate today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

PITTSBURGH, June 20. -- Joseph B. Eastman, railroad coordinator, still believes that the transportation industry can be saved "in spite of itself," he told the National Association of Credit Men today.

A sharp decline in stock prices at the opening of business and a rush of buying orders for tax-exempt bonds marked Wall Street's reaction yesterday to President Roosevelt's message calling for higher taxes on large incomes and inheritances, graduated corporation taxes, taxes on dividends received by corporations and suggesting the elimination in the future of tax-exempt bonds.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP). -- A home run by Ralph Winegarner, pinch hitting for Mel Harder in the eighth inning today, started the Indians on a three-run rally which enabled them to defeat the Senators, 8 to 6.

PARIS, June 20. -- The council of the Bank of France lowered the discount rate today from the abnormally high figure of 6 per cent, imposed during the recent political and monetary crisis, to 5 per cent. At the same time the collateral rate was reduced from 6 1/2 to 6 per cent, and the rate on advances against government bills from 6 to 5 per cent.

Two things which a great many persons were beginning to believe impossible happened yesterday. It stopped raining and the Dodgers won a game. The latter surprise came only after Brooklyn had dropped the opener of the double bill with the Reds at Ebbets Field, so the 6,000 fans who turned out had to be content with an even break.

RYE, N.Y., June 20. -- A strong finish of five par holes gave Mrs. Jonathan Thorne a 4 and 3 victory over Mrs. James R. Arneill Jr. in the semi-final round of the Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association tournament at the Apawamis C.C. today.

Officials of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad conferred yesterday with officials of insurance companies and savings banks on its reorganization plan, but failed to agree on the question whether the period in which part of the interest on its $106,395,000 of 5 per cent mortgage bonds is to become contingent should be five or ten years.

It is announced that art appreciation courses dealing with Oriental rugs and art of the Near East will be conducted by the Adult Education Project at the Metropolitan Museum from July 8 to Aug. 15. Sessions will be held every afternoon.
Several hours late as the result of fog encountered off the coast, the world's largest and fastest ship, the Normandie of the French Line, docked last night with 549 passengers.

The Savoy, Empire Company, Ltd., whereof Milton Shubert is the moving spirit, has acquired a dramatization by Miss Noel Pierce of "Gallows Orchard," Claire Spencer's distinguished novel of five years ago. It should arrive in the Fall. Miss Pierce was last concerned with Broadway as co-author of "Shooting Star," which served as a vehicle for Francine Larrimore two years ago this month.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20. -- The Westchester fete of the Woman's Committee for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Century Club here today attracted several hundred persons.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 20. -- More than 500 members and guests attended the ball given tonight in the Cameo Ballroom by the Society of Automotive Engineers as the concluding function of its Summer meeting.

Glorious Summer, the season of vacations, hot weather, picnics and the desire to escape city life, begins officially at 4:38 A.M., tomorrow, forty-six minutes before the sun rises for the longest day of the year.

Governor Lehman announced in Albany yesterday that he had summoned Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine for a conference in his home at 820 Park Avenue, in this city, at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow, at the request of the recently dismissed March grand jury to supersede District Attorney William C. Dodge in a general investigation of rackets.
NEWARK, June 20. -- Fred (Sheriff) Blake, an old Newark jinx, returned to Ruppert Stadium tonight and shut out the Bears, 4 to 0, to give Baltimore the first of a five-game series.

A two-year search by the Jewelers Security Alliance, several private detective agencies and the Police Department for "Crying Sam" Lowe, 55-year-old jewelry store sneak thief, ended suddenly at police headquarters yesterday morning when one of two men, arrested on a Sullivan Law charge, turned out to be the long-sought robber.

A strike of more than 35,000 workers in the cloak and suit industry in this city became inevitable yesterday as representatives of the Joint Board of the Cloakmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and the Merchant Ladies Garment Association, broke off negotiations and adjourned with hope for an agreement shattered.

Mayor La Guardia made a plea last night to all believers in good government, irrespective of party affiliations, to support him, in his endeavor to give New York City a truly non-partisan and non-political as well as economical and efficient administration.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 20 (Canadian Press.) -- Total deposits of the Bank of Canada increased more than $10,000,000 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement issued today by the bank. The reserve in United States funds during the same period increased more than $6,000,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20. -- Harvard University closed its 299th year today by bestowing honorary degrees on twelve men, including Professor Albert Einstein, physicist; Thomas Mann, German novelist, and Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture.

Finishing in a drive after having the early speed to jump his field, Alvin Untermyer's Gold Foam triumphed by a length yesterday at Aqueduct in the Island Park Handicap, which featured a seven-race program. The 3-year-old son of Golden Broom was as good at 5 to 1 in the betting and was timed in 1:37 over a track that was slow following the rains of the previous night.

The De La Salle Institute of 160 West Seventy-fourth Street will graduate thirty-seven students from its classical, or high school department, and eight from its grammar department at its eighty-sixth commencement exercises, to be held in the Town Hall, 129 West Forty-third Street, at 8:30 P.M. today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 20. -- Debate on he government's program opened yesterday in Parliament.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- About 500,000 women between 18 and 65 will be employed under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program on projects selected especially for them in a separate program.

Political committees, worried by lingering deficits, will turn yellow with envy at the fat financial condition reported by the chairman of the State Democratic Committee of Massachusetts. It has paid a debt of $16,000 that had hung on since 1928. It has $25,000 in the bank.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- A new offer of $350,000 in cash to settle the debt of the Rosenbaum family and its private enterprises to the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation was made today in Federal Court to Judge William H. Holly, before whom a plan for reorganization of the firm is pending.
RYE, N.Y., June 20. -- Sailing into the teeth of a spanking easterly, eighteen yachts started this morning in the American Yacht Club's annual eighty-mile Rye-to-New London race.

Miss Sarah Zuckerman, 21 years old, of 210 Madison Street, died at 1 P.M. in Beth Israel Hospital yesterday from burns she had received when fire swept through The Mansion, 27 St. Mark's Place, last Saturday night, just before a wedding ceremony was to be performed.

It is not often that the head of a Government department spurns an increase of power and responsibility, but Secretary MORGENTHAU did so yesterday. The question concerned the creation of a new Authority to take the place of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, which (being an offshoot of NRA) was one of the casualties of the recent Supreme Court decision.

In a letter sent yesterday to the 12,000 banks that are members of the American Bankers Association, R.S. Hecht, president of the association, advised the banks to take steps to qualify for permanent deposit insurance in case Congress should not pass the Banking Act of 1935 or a substitute measure before July 1, when the permanent plan is scheduled to go into effect.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- In open defiance of President Roosevelt's insistence upon outright dissolution of utility holding companies as an unnecessary evil, the House Interstate Commerce Committee today gave its approval to a subcommittee report urging deletion of the drastic "death sentence" provision from the bill passed by the Senate.

PARIS, June 20. -- The session of the Chamber of Deputies was interrupted with some excitement today when a young woman let herself down from the balcony to the main floor and then took a seat among the Deputies.

" Ore now being near to exhaustion and opportunities for other mining developments referred to in the last annual report having failed to materialize, a dividend of $1 a share in a partial distribution of assets has been declared," the board of directors of the United Verde Extension Mining Company stated yesterday.

For many years Edson Bradley and his wife, the late Julia Wentworth Williams Bradley, had been prominent in the social life of New York, Washington and Newport. They were known as lavish, though hot spectacular, entertainers. Their musicales at their beautiful Washington home, 1,328 Connecticut Avenue, were always features of the season at the capital.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP). -- Charles T. Fisher's Dixiana Stable scored a double today at Washington Park, Upholder winning the opening event and Erin Torch galloping to victory in the feature race.

THE score in the Harvard-Yale rowing classic to date is: Eli Yale, 38; John Harvard, 34; showing that the Johnnies from Cambridge need a full four-year course in victories to haul even with the watermen from New Haven.
MONTREAL, June 20 (Canadian Press). -- With 70 per cent of the offerings of fur disposed of, the four-day sale at the Canadian Fur Auction Sales Company, Ltd., ended today.

LONDON, June 20. -- Private armament firms were a disastrous failure at the beginning of the World War, Dr. Christopher Addison, wartime Minister of Munitions, declared today at a hearing before the royal commission on the private manufacture and trading in arms.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Criticism by House members of Secretary Morgenthau and the Federal Alcohol Control Administration today marked the quarrel between the Treasury and the House Ways and Means Committee over the type of Federal Liquor control to be used henceforth.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 20. -- On cinderpath and field tomorrow, 250 athletes from every section of the country will open an assault on times and distances expected to make the 1935 National Collegiate A.A. championship meet one of the greatest since the classic was founded.

BERLIN, June 20. -- The German Government today lifted a small corner of the veil covering the mystery -- or miracle -- of its financing of its job creation and armament programs by publishing a survey of the revenues and expenditures of the so-called ordinary budget for the last fiscal year, ending March 31.

As the old ferryboat Mount Hope neared its slip at the foot of East Thirty-fourth Street at 1:30 P.M. yesterday, laden with automobiles, there was a sudden lurch. Timbers creaked as the engines were reversed and the boat came to a stop.

Final preparations of the grounds of the wisohn Stadium will be made on Monday for the Summer season of concerts, opera and ballet, given with the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, beginning June 26. This will consist partly in the landscaping of the grounds and in the final details of installation of the sound-bearing devices, designed to convey the music as never before and to eliminate echoes in certain parts of the open-air auditorium.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 21. -Johns Hopkins University scientists were interested today in the announcement made in New York that Dr. Alexis Carrel, the medical scientist, and Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh have devised a machine in which animal organs could be made to live after having been separated from the body.
The increased turnover in stocks brought no compensating inquiry for money. Demand continued along routine lines and quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

Exhibits filed with the Public Service Commissioner yesterday showed that 1.5 per cent of the 4,372,463 monthly bills of commercial users would be larger under the new rate schedules recently filed by the Consolidated Gas System in behalf of its six electric subsidiaries.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 21. -- Colonel D. Walker Wear of the New York State Athletic Commission, accompanied by Deputy Commissioner Patrick Callahan, was a visitor in the training camp of Joe Louis today and after watching the Detroit Negro go through four rounds of boxing placed his official stamp of approval on him.

Constantinos D. Alexander sold to the 190 First Avenue Corp., Abraham Finkelstein, president, 190 1st Av. for a consideration indicated at $11,000, Mr. Alexander taking back a purchase money mortgage for $15,000, payable ten years hence at 41/2 per cent.
After holding a slight advance until the last hour yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved off to a loss of 5 to 8 points and closed at the bottom.

GENEVA, June 21. -- The governing body of the conference of the International Labor Organization, at a special meeting today, authorized Harold Butler, director of the International Labor Office, to invite all American members of the organization to attend a regional conference at Santiago, Chile, Dec. 30.

Samuel Mendell, 40 years old, of 3,396 Twelfth Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested on a bench warrant yesterday while on his way to work in the Municipal Building as a $2,900 topographical draftsman for the Board of Estimate. Mendell has been a Board of Estimate employe for the last thirteen years.

BERLIN, June 21. -- Some 15,000 Confessional Synod adherents, led by 102 bishops and pastors, including most of the prominent leaders of the opposition against Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller, gathered in and before the Emmaus Church in Berlin tonight for a divine service, the keynote of which was fervent and even fanatical determination to defy coordination in the National Socialist system and hold fast to their faith as dictated by their own consciences.

LONDON, June 21. -- Major Brunel Cohen, treasurer of the British Legion, announced today that he would be unable to accompany the British Legion delegation to Germany on July 13 at the invitation of the Reich Association of German Officers because he would be visiting Austria and Czechoslovakia with another Legion delegation having the same purpose.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21. -- The third successive decline in the New Jersey relief rolls was shown in figures for May made public today by the State Emergency Relief Administration. The number of persons on the rolls at the end of May was 554,875, compared with 616,779 in February, a decrease of 61,904, or more than 10 per cent.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 21. -- His Elegance, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel's veteran thoroughbred, was the outstanding performer among the hunters as the second day's program of the ninth annual Watertown Horse Show was completed on the grounds of the Watertown Riding and Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A decrease in May of 126,000 in the number of employes in factories and retail stores and a reduction of $3,900,000 in weekly payrolls in combined manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries surveyed by the Labor Department were reported today by Secretary Perkins.

War veterans and other citizens should be given preference over aliens in the apportionment of work under the $4,000,000,000 Federal relief program, Frederick C. Sasse, national commander of the United States Army Ambulance Association, said yesterday in his annual report at the convention of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

RYE, N.Y., June 21. -Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden today added the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association title to her metropolitan laurels when she defeated Mrs. Charles P. Collins, 11 and 10, in the 36-hole final.

A possibility of averting the threatened strike of 35,000 workers in the coat and suit industry appeared yesterday after the Merchants Ladies Garment Association had indicated its willingness to drop the contractor limitation clause in the renewal of the old agreement that expired on June 1.
Chang, the 10-year-old Indian elephant at the Central Park Zoo, proved once for all yesterday the old adage that an elephant never forgets.
PARIS, June 21. -- A creditors' meeting of the Societe Andre Citroen agreed today to terms for re-floating the company, which has been in judicial liquidation since last Fall.

The National City Bank of New Rochelle, the first bank to be made a defendant in the Federal government's investigation of the sale of so-called guaranteed mortgage bonds and certificates, was indicted yesterday by a special grand jury for mail fraud and conspiracy.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Choice hogs were in demand here early today at steady prices, but reports indicating fresh pork was weak to 1 cent a pound lower in the leading markets caused a weak close, with some sales around 10 cents lower than on Thursday.

Sophistication -- which, according to the night club Websters, is simply being naughty in a nice way -- was given a heavy workout during the last week with the arrival of two of the town's more "sophisticated" singers in tony East Side spots.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP). -- A $224,477,562 deficiency appropriation bill, carrying funds for construction of new public buildings in nearly every Congressional district in the nation, was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate.
Commencement exercises in the city's public schools will begin on Monday for the graduation of 69,000 boys and girls from forty-two high, sixty-two junior high and 618 elementary schools.

Two crippled pickets whom Magistrate Harris had refused to parole Thursday were freed yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus granted by Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore. In the meantime five more cripples were arrested for disorderly conduct while picketing the Emergency Relief Bureau, 902 Broadway.

MANCHESTER, Vt., June 21. -- Former Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts declared here tonight that a constitutional amendment was necessary if New Deal policies were to be carried out and that such an amendment would "spell the doom of American representative government."

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- In permitting an advertisement concerning an unregistered issue of $20,000,000 of debentures to be published in the United States, the Province of Ontario had no intention of selling any of the securities here, the Securities and Exchange Commission was informed in a telegram, made public today, from Harry C. Nixon, Provincial Secretary.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Rushing to completion its modified version of the Utility Holding Company Control Bill for action in the House next week, the Interstate Commerce Committee emphasized its break with President Roosevelt today by striking from the measure the thirteen-point indictment of "abuses" resulting from their past operations.
FrlThursWeek Ye2 day. day. Ago. Ago. The value of the dollax on the CZECHOSLOVA-WJ -- Par 4.18 cents Per cro.
ROME, June 21. -- Anthony Eden is expected to reach Rome Sunday evening or Monday morning and to limit his stay to one, or, at the most, two days.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 21 (AP). -Professor E.F. Burton, head of the department of physics at the University of Toronto, reported to the twelfth colloid chemistry symposium at Cornell University today that a metallic arsenic colloid treatment by intravenous injections had given encouraging results in treatment of sarcoma.

TACOMA, Wash., June 21. -- Curt pleas of "guilty" were voiced here today by Mr. and Mrs. Harmon M. Waley in the $200,000 George Weyerhaeuser abduction, and Waley was quickly sentenced to forty-five years in prison. The court rejected Mrs. Waley's plea, however, and ordered further consideration of her case.

Wall Street derived some amusement yesterday from published reports, originating in Washington, that news of President Roosevelt's tax plan had "leaked" to Wall Street on Wednesday in time to permit a few fortunate operators to reap the proverbial golden harvest.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 21. --H.T. Archibald's Candy Maid, 3-year-old Westy Hogan filly, displayed some of the form which brought her three victories in a row at the the recent Rockingham Park meeting when she won the six-furlong sprint which featured today's card at Narragansett Park.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP). -- It's Roman Soldier against the field in the $25,000 added American Derby at Washington Park tomorrow, and with only one or two exceptions, the field is the most fashionable yet to try for the rich prize since the race was revived ten years ago.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association, which directed the walkout of the operators of the United States liner Manhattan Wednesday noon, replied yesterday to criticism of its tactics in delaying the sailing of the ship five and one-half hours.

Remington Rand, Inc., issued yesterday an estimate of its earnings for April and May. This indicated a profit of $368,000 after Federal taxes and other charges, or $203,000 more than the profit for April, May and June of last year. The profit then was $165,000.

John Marquand, who found that three months in China equipped him with enough local detail to turn out two novels with Chinese settings, "Ming Yellow" and "No Hero," has now gone to Persia, where he expects to find the setting for at least one high comedy of adventure-international intrigue.

ALBANY, June 21. -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today that insurance companies doing business in the State must pay the full State tax, without regard to the levy imposed by New York City.

BERLIN, June 21. -- The Boerse was quiet today. The turnover remained small and price changes insignificant, although some specialties were able to profit from the continued, if repressed, interest in stocks. The purchase of German stocks is difficult, however, and connected with more than financial risks these days, as is indicated in a letter addressed to riniSter of Economics Hjalmar Schacht by Friedrioh Reinhart, president of the Berlin Boerse.
DETROIT, June 21 (AP). -- Renaissance, a 6-year-old bay, ran a game race in the Oak Park Purse at six furlongs today to beat Knights Hope by a neck in 1:13 2-5.

An indeterminate sentence of not more than three years in the penitentiary was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Jack Silverman, 48 years old, of 260 Riverside Drive, convicted last week of selling metal slugs in imitation of nickels for use in subway turnstiles.

Arthur Holden, a 66-year-old professional high diver out of a job, was stopped in an attempt to jump from the George Washington Bridge yesterday. The object of his proposed leap, he explained, was to prove to his old employer that he was fit to have his job back.

Omaha, 3-year-old champion, and King Saxon, handicap division star, will meet in the historic Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct today. The forty-seventh running of the stake, which now is at a mile and a furlong, is expected to attract a crowd of 25,000 persons.

John A. Dilliard was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi to a six-month penitentiary term on his recent misdemeanor conviction by a jury of publishing a false statement in February, 1933, on the financial status of the State Title and Mortgage Company, of which he was president.

Andre Spada, last of the Corsican "honor bandits," who confessed to twelve murders, had become a legendary figure during the eleven years he terrorized the island. The superstitious Corsicans believed he would never be taken alive, especially after one of the greatest man hunts the French Government had ever organized failed to track him down in 1931.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -In races that were packed with thrills, the Yale freshman and junior varsity crews defeated their Harvard rivals on the Thames this morning.

Dr. Charles V. Paterno, builder, and several corporate defendants are liable to tenant-owners of the Hudson View Gardens cooperative apartments for damages for misrepresenting the acreage of the property, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in a unanimous decision reversing Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy on the point.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Rush D. Holt of West Virginia took his seat in the Senate today after that body, by a vote of 62 to 17, had resolved all questions as to his eligibility because of his youth.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

The Emergency Relief Bureau announced yesterday that it recognized its employes' right to collective bargaining but that it could treat with them "only subject to the authority of the Federal, State and city governments."

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP). -- Vernon Kennedy, freshman right-hander, regained second place for the White Sex today by pitching and hitting them to a 5-to-3 triumph over the Athletics in the third and rubber game of the series, although Jimmy Foxx hit his thirteenth homer of the season with none on base in the ninth.

More than 14,000 banks in all parts of the country are members of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. They are operating under a so-called "temporary" plan, with a limited liability and insurance of deposits only up to $5,000. But this system is destined to end abruptly one week from today unless Congress takes action in the meantime.

The cat is out of the bag, the fish out of the net. Stocking the Bronx River with trout last Spring was "frankly a stunt to attract metropoli"tan attention to the work being done "by the State Conservation Depart"ment," Commissioner OSBORNE now confesses.

The Securities and Exchange Commission took steps in Federal Court yesterday to halt Secord Vanderpoel Co., Inc., from using the mails to sell securities. Nine officers of the company, including two men arrested last week on a State charge, were named as defendants.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Dr. A.J. McIvor Tyndall, a tall, vigorous, white-haired man, in the foremost rank of spiritualism, put on a private show yesterday in various suites of the Park Central Hotel where the second day of the annual convention of the General Assembly of Spiritualists was in progress.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- New NRA legislation is certain to be proposed before Congress adjourns, according to indications today as NRA officials conferred with members of the Federal Trade Commission.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 21. -"Newspaper advertising has tremendous advantages over other forms of advertising," Premier T.D. Pattullo stated today in connection with the Dominion-wide advertisements this weekend with which British Columbia is presenting its case for a changed relationship between Province and Dominion.
Conveyance of a Grand Street block front in Hoboken featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

With a trip to the national championships at Lincoln, Neb., as their objective, the best of the local crop of track and field athletes will compete today in the senior metropolitan A.A.U. title meet at Glen Park, Yonkers.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 21. -Jesse Owens, lithe Negro star of Ohio State, today gave 10,000 fans a preview of what may happen in the finals of the National Collegiate A.A. track and field championships at Edwards Stadium. He completely stole the show to place in four events in the qualifying trials.

ANCASTER, Ont., June 21. -The Canadian amateur golf championship today was assured for the eastern section of the Dominion when C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville of London, Ont., and Gordon Taylor Jr. of Summit, Toronto, came through the semi-finals with close victories.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Ralph T. Crane, vice president of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, was formally elected president of the Bond Club of New York yesterday at that organization's annual meeting. He succeeds Harry M. Addinsell, who is chairman of the executive committee of the First Boston Corporation.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 21. -- Baroness Maud Levi and Miss Norma Taubele, finalists in the New York State tennis championship at Jackson Heights, will meet tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock for the Eastern clay court title at the Montclair A.C.

VIENNA, June 21. -- The manuscripts of thirty-two songs by Hugo Wolf -- totally unknown to Wolf's biographers -- have just been brought to light by Dr. Karl Geiringer, director of archives of the Society of the Friends of Music in Vienna. Last year Dr. Geiringer also discovered four Shakespearean settings by Brahms and more than a thousand letters from eminent musicians to that master.

The public has read and heard so much about taxation, Congressional extravagance, waste in appropriating and spending the taxpayers' money, the enormous increase in the public debt from $1,225,145,568 in 1916 to $27,053,141,414. June 30, 1934 the causes of the economic depression and resulting unemployment, that a few figures collected and tabulated from the official publications of the United States Treasury should prove instructive.

Lieutenant Henry A. Sebastian, former West Point football player, who was tried by court-martial on June 13, was found guilty of having made two false official certificates while a cadet at the Military Academy, Major Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook, commanding the First Division, announced at his headquarters at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. CUYAHOGA, New London, Conn., June 21. -- Wearing a borrowed crimson necktie to show his Harvard allegiance, President Roosevelt spent today on the Thames River as an active observer of the Harvard-Yale regatta until rough waters forced, at a late hour, the postponement of the varsity race until tomorrow.

Charles Berwind Harjes gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza to celebrate his wife's birthday. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Schuster, Mr. and Mrs. Kenelm Winslow, Mr. and Mrs. Leo T. Kissam, Mrs. Noel Leggett, Mrs. J. Wuertz Edwards, Mrs. John A. McVickar Jr., Miss Murial Koch, Louis Ehret Jr. and Walter P. Chrysler Jr.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21. -The hopes of Louis Mowbray, curator of the Bermuda Government Aquarium, that two eggs laid several weeks ago by a female Galapagos penguin at the institution would be the first of that species to hatch in captivity have been disappointed.

The first known attempt at a holdup in the Custom House was revealed yesterday when Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, explained the presence of twenty armed customs guards in the building by revealing that three gunmen were routed last Monday afternoon by an elderly custodian, at whom one of them had pointed a pistol.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP). -- Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee, who usually waits for the final round to make one of his famous stretch runs, changed his tactics today by shooting into the lead with a 69 as the $3,500 Medinah open golf championship got under way.

The real opening of the Goldman Band concerts of the Summer season, which had been delayed by inclement weather, took place last night in Central Park before an audience estimated at about 10,000. The eagerness of this audience to hear the music was apparently only slightly dampened by moist weather and by brief early showers, which probably kept away a few, but did not discourage the many who attended.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 21. -- Dr. F.J. Hauptmann, German department head at New Jersey College for Women, who has been accused of telling his students that Woodrow Wilson was a "schweinhund," once said that the former President "was one of the best friends the German people ever had," Miss Mary Travis of New Brunswick, a graduate of the Women's College in the class of 1932, said here today.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler appointed three trustees yesterday to take over the reorganization of the $2,665,000 Series F mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, it was announced by the committee for the reorganization of Series F, 120 Broadway.

Five more city relief "chiselers," as James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, described them, received prison terms from Justices Dale, Gresser and Kernochan in Special Sessions yesterday. They had pleaded guilty to obtaining aid when they had jobs or bank accounts.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Acting on reports of a possible epidemic among 2,000 colonists moved by the Relief Administration to Alaska, the Senate today ordered Harry L. Hopkins to report immediately on the status of the project and conditions in the colony.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a rule concerning the certification by accountants of reports and documents in applications for registration on a securities exchange under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Manifesting the best strength of any day this year but one, the share market yesterday moved rapidly higher in heavy trading and many leading issues on the Stock Exchange closed with net gains of 1 to 4 points. In so doing, the market appeared to regard the President's pronouncements on new taxation in the light of political expediency, at least, from the standpoint of the timing of the message to Congress.

Lost over the city in a dense fog, an airplane flown by a pilot and a mechanic dropped into Buttermilk Channel in New York Harbor at 10:20 o'clock last night after a futile search for Newark Airport and an hour's wandering just above skyscrapers had almost drained its fuel tank.
DETROIT, June 21. -- The colossal frame of Schoolboy Rowe got right in the way as the Yankees visioned making a triumphant exit from this city today.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A movement to force action at the present session of Congress on President Roosevelt's new tax program, including inheritance levies on large legacies, higher gift taxes and increased rates on large incomes, both individual and corporate, was started today among Progressives in all the four parties represented in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- With about thirty accountants and engineers already in the field and an equal number on duty here, the Federal Communications Commission investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries is going "full blast," Paul A. Walker, chairman of the commission's telephone division, stated today.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 21 (Canadian Press). -- J.L. Ralston, a member of the House committee studying the Grain Board Bill, asked today that details of the operations of John I. McFarland as government agent to support the wheat market be presented to the committee.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The redemption of about $600,000,000 of 2 per cent consols on the call date, July 1, in connection with the retirement of national bank notes, will be met partly at least by the withdrawal of deposits the Treasury has with the banks, according to present indications of Treasury plans.
Fred toffman, in 301 V. 19th St.; litty Untrecht, in 349 W. 19th St.; ZHomer E Comstoek, in 365 W. 2Oth St.; James_.[ Wells Sons, Inc-, broker.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 21. -- Two of New Jersey's leading young exhibitors, Miss Cynthia Clews Wrightson of Orange and Miss Claire W. Faitoute of Short Hills, showed the best saddle horses as the fourth annual Plainfield Horse Show got under way on the grounds of the Plainfield Riding Club today.

LONDON, June 21. -- Secrets of Great Britain's troubles with munition workers during the World War were revealed today before the royal commission on the private manufacture and trade in arms when Dr. Christopher Addison, wartime Minister of Munitions, was examined on the possibilities of nationalizing arms factories.

The boys in the sculpture department of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design are unwilling to give up. The Beaux-Arts decided that, for lack of funds, it would have to discontinue the department of sculpture at the end of the current school year.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Although this year's food supply will be somewhat below the average of the last five years, it will exceed the 1934 domestic consumption by about 5 per cent and the 1933 consumption by about 9 per cent, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today.

HONGKONG, June 21. -- The two old cruisers, Haishen and Haichi, which deserted from Canton last week and have been sheltering at Hongkong, left this afternoon for the north, but just outside British waters, near Waglan, a newer cruiser, the Ninghai, appeared and fired twelve shots from a range of eight miles, apparently not hitting the ships.

EUREKA, Calif., June 21 (AP). -Ten persons were shot by police, one fatally, in fierce rioting today between about 250 strike pickets and 300 employes of the Holmes-Eureka Lumber Mill, scene of five weeks of labor unrest.

The French liner Normandie sails today for Havre via Plymouth on her second eastbound voyage with 1,600 passengers. Among those sailing on her are Dwight Davis, former Governor General of the Philippines, and his daughter, Miss Helen Davis; Justice Alfred H. Townley of the Appellate Division and Mrs. Townley, Breckinridge Long, United States Ambassador to Italy; Charles Davila, Rumanian Minister to the United States.

BERLIN, June 21. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, who invented most of the phrases that move present-day Germany, has just put out a new one. Presenting prizes awarded for essays written in to answer the question, "What books would you consider the best basis for a library in a labor camp?" he defended the Nazis' repression of intellectualism.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The Senate investigation of charges of maladministration in the Commerce Department "faded out" this afternoon after the Senate Commerce Committee, in an all-day session, heard with impatience the windup of testimony by Ewing Y. Mitchell, ousted Assistant Secretary, a spirited general denial by Secretary Roper and supporting denials by a squad of bureau chiefs.

MOSCOW, June 21. -- An interesting development now evident in Soviet Russia is the increasing frequency with which Joseph Stalin is mixing with his people. Perhaps it is a phase of the "new Stalin" which some have seen in his recent demands for greater consideration for the individual.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Bosch will celebrate the fortieth anniversary of his ordination tomorrow at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in West 123d Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues. At the 10 A.M. service, which will be in German, Dr. Bosch, who has been pastor of the church thirty-one years, will preach a reminiscent sermon.

CANTON, N.Y., June 21. -- The Supreme Court decision emasculating NRA ended the last hope of economic reforms in the United States without revolutionary changes in basic law of the land, Dean Howard Lee McBain of Columbia University said today in an address before the conference on Canadian-American affairs at the St. Lawrence University.
HONOLULU, June 21 (AP). -- The Pan American Clipper hopped for Alameda, Calif., at 3:01 P.M. [9:31 P.M., New York daylight-saving time] today from Pearl Harbor.

ALBANY, June 21. -- The Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council, in its first meeting here this afternoon after its members had been sworn in, wired to Congressional finance leaders urging that the unemployment insurance section of the Social Security Bill be amended so that the payroll tax would be based only on payrolls of employes eligible for benefits.

OWASCO LAKE, N.Y., June 21. -- Fear that Primo Carnera would have to break camp before schedule was dispelled today when Bill Duffy, one of the managers of the ex-champion, stated that he had received assurance from Bill Brown of the State Athletic Commission that Primo could remain here until Sunday.

PEIPING, June 21. -- Major Gen. Kenji Doihara, chief of the Japanese Army's special service mission in Manchuria, in an interview today declared the Japanese Army had no intention of creating demilitarized zone in Chahar Province.

The Continental Bank Trust Company, as trustee and plaintiff, bought in the fifteen-story Butler Hall apartments at the southwest corner of Morningside Drive and 119th Street at an auction sale conducted yesterday by Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21. -- The Newark Bears evened their series with the Baltimore Orioles tonight as they made eighteen hits in a 10-to-2 victory. Dixie Walker, Willard Hershberger and Don Heffner had three hits each.

PAULSBORO, N.J., June 21. -Pleading both poverty and guilt, Mrs. Laura Minniti began today a six-month jail sentence for selling a half-pint of "moonshine" whisky, leaving her six fatherless children to the mercy of the State. Paul, the father, committed suicide two years ago because of his grief at the disappearance of a seventh child, an older girl.

Twenty-five marine superintendents and representatives of the companies operating deep draught steamships out of the Port of New York attended a luncheon yesterday given by the French Line on the new super-liner Normandie. Captain M. Castelnau, assistant marine superintendent of the French Line, presided.

PITTSBURGH, June 21. -- If the government "continues to enter more and more into private business," the country may become a Socialist State before it realizes what has happened, Representative Samuel B. Pettingill, Democrat, of Indiana, told the National Association Credit Men here today.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine was accused yesterday of illegally refusing leaves of absence with pay to members of the Police Department who are scheduled to attend camp this Summer as members of the United States Army Reserve Corps.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -- Half sailing and half drifting over eighty miles, Douglas Kitchell's eight-meter Valkyrie, George E. Ratsey's sleek cutter Zaida and Jack Parkinson Jr.'s Fishers Island sloop Praxilla were victors in the American Yacht Club's annual Rye to-New London race which ended this morning.

The Giants instead of the Pirates swung the cutlasses yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and as a result the Terrymen are breezing along seven and one-half games ahead of Pie Traynor's band in the race for the National League flag. Their margin over the third-place Cardinals is eight games.

HARRISBURG, June 21. -- As Pennsylvania's General Assembly neared adjournment after one of the longest sessions in the Commonwealth's history, it passed today a graduated State income-tax law and balanced the budget for the 1935-37 biennium by increasing the "compromise'' tax program of the Earle administration and the Republican opposition to $125,000,000.

In his address at Yale the other day President ANGELL reminded the graduating class that democracy depends upon the responsibility of the individual. Unlike communism and fascism, or any form of the totalitarian State, democracy assumes that the citizen is capable of making the fundamental decisions.

The ferry line between Yonkers and Alpine, on the Jersey shore, promises checkroom facilities to cope with the Yonkers ban on excessively meager dress within its corporate limits. Young women from New York City out for a day's hike on the Palisades may now wear a skirt to and from the Yonkers ferry house and walk in shorts on the other side of the river.

In the wake of Thursday's selling of United States Government loans which, however, was well absorbed, the entire bond market on the New York Stock Exchange, including government issues, moved forward yesterday.
