Domestic corporation obligations were especially strong, several gaining 1 to 6 points. The Federal list rose 1-32 to 5-32 point.

H.A. Scandrett, president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, conferred yesterday by telephone with insurance and savings bank officials, and it appeared afterward that a compromise was likely to be reached on the chief point of dissension which has prevented the consummation of a reorganization for the line by July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Prospects for passage of the omnibus banking bill at this session of Congress were regarded as considerably enhanced today as reports went the rounds of the Capitol of a compromise which would save at least the form of the administration's banking program.

BALTIMORE, June 21. -- Attorneys representing holders of securities of the bankrupt Kelly-Springfield Tire Company and representatives of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company have agreed on a modification of the plan whereby Goodyear would take over Kelly-Springfield, Harry N. Baetjer, attorney, told Judge W. Calvin Chesnut in the Federal court today.

Immigration Commissioner D.W. MACCORMACK at a joint session of the House and Senate Committees on Immigration and Naturalization on Thursday presented statistics which tend to show that there has been gross exaggeration both of the number of aliens and of those that have entered illegally.
After reading S.T. Drutzu's interesting letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES I got the impression that it was not quite fair to the Mayor.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 21. -- In honor of Miss Edith Cluett and Joseph Philip Walker of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., who will be married tomorrow afternoon, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Geoge Alfred Cluett, gave a dinner for thirty persons tonight at Green River Farm, Williamstown. Mrs. William Howard Doughty will have a luncheon for the bridal party at Elscot tomorrow.

LONDON, June 21. -- The House of Commons today agreed without a division to guarantee payment of principal and interest on securities not exceeding 40,000,000 to be issued by a company formed by the British Treasury to improve London's transport facilities.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 21. -Two New Jersey golfers, Gene Homans of Englewood and John E. Parker Jr. of Essex County, will do battle tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final round of the thirty-fifth metropolitan amateur over the Canoe Brook Country Club's south course.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -The sense of humor of the human race is beyond comprehension. The postponement of the Yale-Harvard varsity race simply struck the collective funny-bone of the huge crowd of 75,000 at the precise spot where its risibilities were most sensitive.

ROME, June 21. -- Everybody in Italy is commenting upon the striking change in the public manner of Premier Bonito Mussolini. Il Duce smiles nowadays when he appears before crowds and he appears with increasing frequency.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., June, 21. -- Opposition to some of the more radical planks in the platform proposed by the board of governors developed today among delegates arriving for the annual convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, which began tonight with a meeting of the platform committee.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 21. -"Building and loan associations should give serious consideration to the threat of extinction which would be contained in the indefinite extension of activities of Home Owners Loan Corporation," Dr. H.E. Hoagland, member of the Federal Home Loan Bank, Washington, said today at the concluding session of the annual convention of the New York State Savings and Loan Associations.

YARMOUTH, Isle of Wight, June 21. -- Gerard B. Lambert's American sloop Yankee suffered her second defeat in English waters today when the Class J fleet was out in its full strength of seven yachts for the first time. T.O.M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger Endeavour took first place, H.A. Andreae's Candida was second and W.L. Stephenson's Velsheda third.

MOSCOW, June 21. -- The British Government has invited the Soviet Government to discuss the question of naval armaments, it was announced tonight by the Foreign Office in making public, in part at least, the substance of conversation between Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff and Viscount Chilston, the British Ambassador, yesterday.

Strengthened by the further widening of merchandise distribution, the surprising stability of manufacturing operations and the accomplishment of readjustments which had been a disturbing factor recently, trade this week revealed more indications of going forward, according to the review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 21. -- Mrs. H. Edward Manville of Pleasantville won a silver bowl today for a display of vegetable at the Westchester County Flower Show being held here at the County Centre.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. -Walter Lippmann of New York, Harvard '10, today attacked government leaders for failure to "declare a positive and coherent conception of the State." He delivered the Phi Beta Kappa oration at exercises which officially closed Harvard's commencement week.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -For the first time since 1898 a Yale-Harvard varsity crew race was postponed tonight. It was put off until 10:30 tomorrow morning, when, if conditions permit, it will be rowed upstream.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21. -- Dr. Vladimir Matchek, oft-imprisoned foe of the government, was rushed to this city today with signal official courtesies to consult with Prince Regent Paul on a solution for the crisis resulting from the resignation of the Cabinet of Premier Bogolyub Yevtitch.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP). -- The Browns dropped a 3-to-0 decision to the Red Sox today as a violent rain and hailstorm cut short their scheduled double-header after six innings of the opening game had been played.

The effort by President Roosevelt to put back to work 3,500,000 unemployed men and women has apparently been started. In his speech to his State chiefs the President issued strict orders for them to secure all necessary help from the relief rolls. This seems to be the necessary qualification, the supreme proof of financial need, the references for efficiency in order to secure work and the right to live.

BASTIA, Corsica, June 21. -- Firm in the conviction that he had been touched by divine grace and was going straight to heaven, Andre Spada, last of the Corsican bandits, went to the guillotine early this morning. He liked to be known as the Corsican Robin Hood, but French justice branded him as the vilest sort of criminal.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The national income has been larger this Spring than in any other since 1931, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its June bulletin, which took note of important advances in many industrial lines.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Short covering by houses with Eastern connections that were on the selling side several days ago was largely responsible for a sharp upturn in wheat today on the Board of Trade. The advance was helped by reports of heavy rains in parts of Oklahoma, which will tend further to delay harvesting.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A compromise measure diminishing some of the powers which the administration requested for the Tennessee Valley Authority was voted today by the House Military Affairs Committee, breaking a deadlock of several weeks. The vote to report is understood to have been 13 to 12.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order directing the disbursement by July 15 of $3,166,750 to holder of $12,667,000 of bonds of the Prudence Company, Inc., now in process of reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law.

LONDON, June 21. -- Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, made it clear in the House of Commons today that the speed with which the British Government concluded a naval agreement with Germany was necessary to get an agreement at all.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 21. -- The Chaco preliminary peace protocol was approved today by the Bolivian Congress by a vote of 69 to 3. Paraguay announced promulgation of the law ratifying the protocol, so the twelve-day truce on the Chaco front is now effective.

LONDON, June 21. -- America's No. 1 ranking amateur doubles team of Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn was unexpectedly ushered out of the Queen's Club tennis tournament today, but the No. 2 combination of Gene Mako and Donald Budge sped through two rounds without losing a set.

SUFFERN, N.Y., June 21. -"Uncle Dan" Beard threw some tomahawks at his Indian war posts this morning, worked on a piece he was writing as much as reporters and photographers would let him and read hundreds of congratulatory messages.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Stockholders of the Pure Oil Company were asked tonight to grant directors the authority to carry out a plan for refunding $27,500,000 in notes outstanding by the issuance of new notes carrying non-detachable warrants which give the noteholders the right to buy up to thirty shares of common stock for each $1,000 note.

PARIS, June 21. -- Tempers in Paris have been too much ruffled this past week by Great Britain's desertion from the common front for much progress to be made yet in discussing what is going to be done next.

In defiance of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who has announced that the A.F. of L. will revoke the charter of any affiliate enrolling Communists as members, the International Fur Workers Union met yesterday to consider the reinstatement of Ben Gold, president of the Fur Workers Industrial Union, and a dozen other Communist leaders.

WHEN Peter Christ tried to tell a sports editor on a tabloid newspaper one day last week how he had murdered his wife while their small son looked on and then ambushed her lover, the editor said: "It's a very warm day and I'm very busy." So Peter Christ pulled out a blackjack and pistol and started over again. That time he was listened to.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP). -A six-run attack which drove Paul Dean to the showers in the sixth inning gave the Phillies an 8-3 victory over the champion Cardinals in the second game of their series today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -Yale's baseball team today won the deciding game of the Harvard series, 6 to 2, before a Thames regatta crowd of 3,000. The innovation, which furnished a diversion during the long wait for the scheduled evening event, resulted in a pitchers' battle for seven innings between Ted Horton and Bill Lincoln.

" Sanders of the River," a London Films production based on the late Edgar Wallace's stories of the British commissioners in the African colonies, will have its Broadway premiere on Wednesday morning at the Rivoli. Chief among the players are Paul Robeson and Nina Mae McKinney.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- By allotting from the $4,000,000,000 work relief fund the sum of $23,000,000 for work on the Grand Coulee Dam, President Roosevelt made clear today that large Federal projects begun by the PWA would be continued under the work relief program.

NEW ORLEANS, June 21 (AP). -The Federal Government tonight took charge of about 1,400 employes of politically harassed New Orleans and started handing out FERA checks to garbage collectors who went on strike because they had not been paid.

Prices of commodities in the futures markets here held generally steady yesterday in a slightly heavier volume of business. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, oats, eggs, rubber and wool tops were higher, while corn, cotton, print-cloths and silk were lower.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21. -- An ordinance to license circulating libraries so their collections may be censored for salacious books has been recommended to Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein by Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld of Essex County. The prosecutor said some commercial libraries, operated in retail stores, were lending books that were "foul" and that merited suppression.

State and municipal financing in prospect for next week amounts to only $10,298,179, against $16,678,949 this week. The largest item is scheduled for Tuesday, when New Jersey will sell $2,500,000 3 per cent Port of New York Authority Series bonds, held in the State sinking fund.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- While Atlanta's mighty little man, Bitsy Grant, defending his national clay-court tennis championship at River Forest, today turned back another challenger with his usual genius for retrieving impossible shots, Big Bill Reese, a fellow-townsman, turned in the most astounding upset of the week.

FORT DEPOSIT, Ala., June 21 (AP). -- Issuing a statement from his cell that he killed John Norman, prominent druggist, and his wife last night, John Arant remained tonight in the jail at Montgomery for safe-keeping.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 21. -- Two youths presented a problem today to the Hoosier judge who sentenced them to life terms for the kidnapping of a Southern Indiana Sheriff.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 21. -- Wrought up by several recent railroad accidents, passengers attempted to wreck the Brazilian Central Railway shops on the outskirts of this city following a serious train crash this morning.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company issued yesterday a statement in which it held that President Roosevelt's remarks on public utilities on Wednesday upheld the soundness of the operating companies in the Associated system but that the remarks on the Associated's capitalization indicated "misinformation."

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Almost 2,250 applications for registration on Form 1-M of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities have been received to date, Securities and Exchange Commission officials estimated today. The New York firms in the list made public today by the SEC included the firm of Richard Whitney, who, as president of the New York Stock Exchange, led the fight against the bill creating the SEC.

Two sisters, who fled the jurisdiction of a New York court rather than testify against their brother, on trial for the murder of the husband of one, were held in bail of $1,000 each yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy as violators of the Fugitive Felon Act.

ROME, June 21. -- Italy's reaction to the latest Ethiopian appeal to the League of Nations will depend entirely on the weight given to it at Geneva. If, as Italy hopes and believes, it is not taken into serious consideration, there will be reason for the Italian Government to assume an attitude either for or against it.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Representative Boylan of New York today described as a "cowardly lie" what he considered assertions by Eduardo Villasenor, Mexican Consul General at New York, that the Catholic hierarchy in America was carrying on a "campaign against Mexico."
COLORADO SPRINGS, June 21 (AP). -- A proposal to merge four mission societies into two bodies was defeated today at the Northern Baptist Convention.

Captain EDEN, now a British Minister, had been an effective diplomatic agent for his Government in many countries before he himself took office. He is now in Paris conferring with a Frenchman who has also been taking part in diplomatic negotiations in several capitals.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 21. -- Close finishes marked the light harness meet at the E. Roland Harrimar Historic (half-mile) Track today, which got under way after a three-day postponement because of rain. Showers fell after the first heat of the 2:12 trot, but the card of five events was completed.

PIE TRAYNOR was having breakfast and Jewel Ens was having lunch, both at the same time and at the same table. Sam Watters, the secretary of the Pirates, was eating by himself in a near-by corner. Bill Benswanger, president of the Pittsburgh club, kept sauntering from one table to the other, talking of this and that.

Casey Stengel's Dodgers returned to the doldrums of defeat yesterday after their brief flash in the second game of Thursday's doubleheader. Chuck Dressen's merry Cincinnati youngsters trounced the Flatbush crew easily, 5 to 0, while a few more than 1,000 fans jeered their one-time favorites throughout.
Writing from Livingston Manor, Harry Darbee predicts a good weekend for trout fishermen who visit the Willowemoc and Beaverkill Rivers.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The piling up of excess reserves of banks to a new high level of around $2,500,000,000 and competitive bidding by banks seeking investments for their funds was seen by experts here today as the real reason for the decline of short-term interest rates almost to the vanishing point.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21. -- The Yale-Harvard races at New London proved the attraction for a number of members of the Newport Summer colony today. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince took with them on the yacht Lone Star their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kingsland, Mr. and Mrs. William Forbes Morgan and Charles D. Wetmore.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 21. -Thousands of the motorists and the railroad users here for the Harvard-Yale regatta today might have been irritated by the postponement, but it didn't make much difference to the yachtsmen on the spectator fleet.

With Arthur S. Kleeman as chairman, thirteen men from industrial and professional circles in the city have agreed to serve on a financial advisory board for the new Theatre Alliance. Mr. Kleeman, head of the financial Investment firm which bears his name, has been a patron of the project since it was organized several weeks ago.

NEWARK, N.J., June 21. -- Hegwig Echert, 16 years old, of 90 Avenue L, this city, was seriously wounded tonight in one of the most mysterious shootings the police here have been called on to investigate. The girl, accompanied by Miss Helen Schultz, 16, of 110 Magazine Street, was walking along Magazine Street when an automobile came around the corner of Rome Street.

Eight defense witnesses were called yesterday in the General Sessions felony trial of Nicholas Montana, alleged "vice overlord," on a compulsory prostitution indictment. The bill was based on the complaint of Mrs. Helen Morgan, who was the principal State witness at the start of the trial last Thursday.

Following a sultry June morning, the heavy cloud-pall of a thunderstorm makes 3 o'clock in the afternoon dark as late evening. Through the gloom the delicate white blossom-sprays of a syringa hedge across the street from my window, that are tossed by the gale preceding the rain, gleam like slender hands signaling sea warnings from a dim green shore.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The "brain trusters" of the administration received blunt notice today from Democratic Congressmen that the bills they draft in the future will be put through a close-meshed legislative sieve.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- President Roosevelt made known his insistence on adoption at this session of Congress of a constitutional amendment abolishing issuance of tax-exempt securities.
The general idea seems to be that nothing is happening.
Professor Handler of Columbia University has expressed the opinion that a constitutional amendment is essential if the Federal Government is to have the power to regulate labor conditions.
Social and economic conditions in Palestine are reviewed in a statement issued yesterday by William B. Ziff, president of the Zionist Revisionist Organization of the United States and Canada.

The statements and activities of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, radio priest, in the present-day "arena of politics" constitute "direct violations of existing canon law" of the Roman Catholic Church, in the opinion of the Rev. Edward V. Dargin, canonist for the Archdiocese of New York.

AFTER holding all those options on Helen Jerome's dramatization of "Pride and Prejudice," Arthur Hopkins has relinquished the last of them. The play had scarcely fallen from his hands -- and herein lies the news of the matter -- before Max Gordon acquired it. Just what Mr. Gordon intends to do with it, now that he has it, is another question.

The retail price of cigarettes will advance on Tuesday, ending the price war that has followed the invalidation of the NRA, it was announced yesterday by William A. Hollingsworth, president of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America.

BELGRADE, June 22. -- "I sincerely believe in the possibility of reaching an understanding with Belgrade," Dr. Vladimir Matchek, Croat peasant leader, told the local correspondent of the Zagreb newspaper, the Obzor, today.

Expenditures of the Federal Government for the last four fiscal years have amounted to $25,000,000,000, which is about equal to the total of all such expenditures between 1789 and 1914, the New York Trust Company says in the current issue of its publication, The Index.

NO one can attend a flower show these days without being impressed by the ever-increasing interest in the different classes of flower arrangements. Cultural excellence is still stressed, as of course it should be, but classes in which awards are based on artistic merit are constantly growing in number and in the attention accorded them by exhibitors and the public.

The unexpectedness of President Roosevelt's tax message to Congress late Wednesday afternoon, with its suggestions for heavier levies on the wealthy and on corporations, obscured momentarily all the "must" legislation that, in one way or another, affects the financial community.

PAWTUCKET, R.L., June 22. -- The Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt silks flashed to the fore at Narragansett Park today when the 4-year-old gelding Dreel won the $5,000 added Narragansett Handicap at six furlongs for 3-year-olds and upward. Captain Argo was second and Spixi third.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 22. -- Nancy, chestnut mare owned by Clarence Francis, turned in the outstanding performances today at the sixth annual horse show of the Bronxville Riding Club. She won three events, proving the best of the field in the lightweight hunter and the working hunter classes, then topping her day's work by annexing the championship hunter sweepstake.

THERE is a term coined by psychologists, romantic infantilism, which aptly describes the plight of Miss Marshall's heroine. It is, one might add, a fairly common complaint, and for that reason "Only the Fear" is more poignant than the average novel which deals with neurotic disorders.

THE Society of Automotive Engineers held its twenty-ninth annual Summer meeting here last week with upward of 1,000 of the foremost men active in the allied fields of land, air and water transportation in attendance.

After, the police reported, she had leaped from a rear window during a raid on her second-floor apartment at 1,730 Broadway, near Fifty-fourth Street, Florence Rose, 30 years old, was taken to the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital yesterday, suffering from a possibly fractured spine and lacerations of the legs, arms and face.

BENJAMIN APPEAL'S "Brain Guy," the story of a high-grade gangster, his rise and fall, was a first-rate and honest piece of work of the hard-boiled school. His new book is an entirely different matter. Although we go with an exploring party from New York to India, through mountain passes to Turkestan and back again, we seem to have been standing still all the time.

LOS ANGELES, June 22. -- Abandoning their burning observation plane at an altitude of 3,000 feet, three army fliers floated to safety with their parachutes near here today. The plane was returning to its base at Brooks Field, San Antonio, Texas, after participating in first wing manoeuvres at San Diego, Calif., this week.

Anthony Eden, Great Britain's traveling diplomat and recently appointed Minister to the League of Nations, is on the road again. In early Spring, after Adolf Hitler denounced the military clause of the Treaty of Versailles, he visited Paris, Berlin, Moscow, Warsaw, Prague and Stresa.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 22. -- Rain and records fell together today as the New York Athletic Club enjoyed its annual outing, the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships. This meet, which acquires more and more of a Winged Foot aspect with each passing year, was staged in Glen Park and, to no one's surprise, was won by the New York A.C. with the near record total of 122 points.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22. -New London's two boat race days brought an unexpected business flourish to this old whaling centre. Most of the visitors among the 75,000 who were here yesterday attempted to stay over for the varsity race this morning but less than half of them were successful in securing accommodations.

The recent Supreme Court decision declaring that the Federal Government had unwarrantedly invaded State rights by NRA's regulation of commerce has brought suggestions that the Constitution be amended to give the national government greater authority.

THE English devised a sentimental method of showing their admiration for Ben Davies, the veteran tenor, on the occasion recently of his golden wedding. An album was placed at the box office of Queen's Hall and friends and admirers of Mr. and Mrs. Davies inscribed their autographs.

OLD BROOKVTLLE, L.I., June 22. -- Competing in a field of two dozen, Miss Frances Robbins of Southampton rode her brown gelding Brian Boru to victory today in the class for working hunters, one of the leading numbers on the opening card of the second annual Cedar Valley Horse Show.
WIGGINS, Miss., June 22 (AP). -- One Negro was lynched and another was spirited into the woods and whipped in the course of twenty-four hours of mob rule by citizens in Wiggins today.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- One week has passed since an NRA organization, stripped of most of its powers, began operations under an extended charter, and during that time herculean efforts have been made to shape a new policy.

Forging to the front on the anchor leg, the New Utrecht High School 880-yard relay team captured the Red Star Trophy in the feature race of the third annual Red Star track and field meet at the Heckscher Playground, Central Park, yesterday.

FREDONIA, N.Y., June 22 (AP). -- The third destroyer to be named in honor of William B. Cushing, who destroyed the Confederate ironclad Albemarie in 1864 by a deed of spectacular daring, will be christened next November by Miss Katherine Cushing, his daughter.

The urge to take profits on a Saturday in Summer, particularly when Congress is in session, was present in the share market yesterday, but the situation was at all times well in hand and closing prices were substantially higher than on the preceding day.

TOPEKA, June 21. -- This week's Kansas prison mine revolt in which 348 inmates of the State Penitentiary at Lansing barricaded themselves in a mine shaft 720 feet under ground and defied authorities for twenty-one hours has brought the problems of handling crimes and criminals in this State forcefully to the foreground of public attention.

INFANTS who saw the light during the campaign of the Marne will be coming of age this Fall. It would seem that while they have been growing up as much ink has been spilled in describing, discussing and refighting the battle as blood flowed during its progress.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., June 22. -- Astronomical sights were trained tonight on a strange new visitor in southeastern skies, declared by Professor Otto Struve, director of Yerkes Observatory, to be a tailless comet.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Former President Hoover will be asked soon by Republicans opposed to his present political activity to declare his intentions as to the Republican nomination for President. He will be requested in a letter, which will be made public, to say whether he is an actual candidate for the nomination in 1936.

Without singling out any specific veterans' relief legislation or agency for criticism, delegates to the annual convention of the United States Ambulance Service Association adopted a resolution at their session yesterday morning in the Hotel Pennsylvania condemning tendencies in government which encourage "parasitism" instead of individual initiative and self-reliance.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Little change in business activity was noticeable in the week ended on June 15, and in the first half of June, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of the domestic situation.

The grievance committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York has tried unsuccessfully for more than two weeks to have former Municipal Court Justice Harold L. Kunstler appear before it for questioning, it became known yesterday.
PARIS, June 21. -- Since the World War ended in victory France has never had to swallow such a bitter pill as this last week's naval agreement between Britain and Germany.

While the market for prime bonds of all classes has been strong for several months, especially for those of the tax-exempt description, fresh evidences were furnished yesterday that the long-neglected bonds of lower ranking were again attracting the attention of buyers.

This little book tells of a 13-year-old girl's visit with her parents to the Salmon River country in Idaho, when men were prospecting for gold and life had the excitement and hardship of pioneering far from civilization. There is plenty of action and the story is told with a directness and simplicity that will appeal especially to young readers from 9 to 12 who are deterred by longer books.

GENEVA, June 21. -- With the exception of the London treaty, the Anglo-German naval accord is the first armaments limitation agreement reached since the ill-starred Anglo-French naval accord obtained by the previous Baldwin government in 1928.

A LARGE representative exhibition of the work of the famous French artist in glass, Rene Lalique, is open at Altman's. It includes with many additions the collection shown two years ago at the Pavillon de Marsan in the Louvre.

RADIO is an exceptional show shop. Performers, whether they be professionals in music and the theatre, or amateurs in all branches of entertainment, at some time or other seem to find their way to the "mike." The professional goes on the air to extend his domain and his art; the amateur to get a chance to become professional.

AUTHORITIES disagree on the question of how often early and May flowering tulips should be lifted. Some advise that it be done every year; others every third, fourth or fifth year, or even that the bulbs be kept in the soil indefinitely.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22. -- District Attorney Walter A. Ferris of Westchester County was requested today by Charles Poletti, counsel to Governor Lehman, to submit an answer to charges of neglect of duty filed earlier this week by the Westchester Council of Utility Rates Committees.

The sharp increase in sales of medium-priced automobiles, or those selling at figures next above the cars quoted the lowest, has marked the continued recovery of the automobile industry this year. Leaders among the manufacturers regard the trend as another sign of the general progress toward normal business conditions in this country.

PANAMA, R.P., -- A new triple entente composed of Japan, Manchukuo and El Salvador was formed upon the occasion of the visit of Emperor Kang Teh to Japan, when he received in special audience El Salvador's consul to Japan, Leon Siguenza.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22. -- The Princeton University Department of Geology will send out nineteen expeditions to study phases of geology in Newfoundland and the United States this Summer, it was announced here this week by Professor Edward Samson, chairman of the department.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 22. -- Resolutions asking Federal and maritime authorities to do their utmost to reduce fire hazards aboard steamships were adopted today at the closing session of the Eastern Association of Fire Chiefs after the 350 chiefs from New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland had discussed the Morrow Castle and other fires at sea.

PEIPING. -- Inside the city of Changli there is only one shop that sells narcotics, but outside the city walls there are thirty-six shops, of which twenty-two are owned by Japanese and fourteen by Koreans, selling heroin, morphine and opium quite openly.

More intensive use of fewer media by department stores resulted last year in newspapers receiving 66 per cent of the publicity appropriations of department stores, and 85 per cent of reporting stores indicate there will be no change in the distribution of publicity expense this year, according to the annual analysis issued yesterday by F.W. Spaeth, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

BOXED, handsomely bound, beautifully printed and containing truly superb color reproductions (180 plates, text 230 pp.), "A Catalogue of Chinese Pottery and Porcelain in the Collection of Sir Percival David," about which a preliminary notice appeared on this page some months ago, has now made its appearance, published by the Stourton Press in London.
THIS being the season of broiling sun, it is comforting to reflect that there is no dearth of cool headgear in metropolitan shops. These offerings are in many cases as new as they are numerous.

CLEVELAND, June 22. -- The Yankees spent a rather futile afternoon today chasing the Indians, which, even in olden times, was generally regarded as a profitless piece of business and apparently has not improved in the least.
LONDON.--The language pot has been set to bubbling violently in Finland. There are two official languages, Finnish and Swedish, and the two have nothing in common.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 22 (AP). -- State officials intervened today to obtain a new trial for two Huntington, W. Va., boys under sentence to serve life terms for the kidnapping of a southern Indiana sheriff.

Stopping off in New York after a two-week vacation in Bermuda, Governor Lehman took a hand last week in the controversy between District Attorney Dodge and the New York County grand Jury over the investigation of vice and rackets.

To base a judgment of the color film on the success of "Becky Sharp" as a dramatic entertainment is to become the spiritual kinsman of the fellow who predicted that the automobile would never supplant the horse.

WITH the most elaborate program since their inception, the Lewisohn Stadium concerts will begin their eighteenth season on Wednesday evening. Jose Iturbi has chosen favorite masterpieces for his opening program and Albert Spalding will be the violin soloist.

AS Summer vacations begin, American youth, seeking adventure and recreation at small expense, will have its first real taste of the pleasures of hostels or "hikers' inns" patterned after the European system. A "loop" of thirty-six hostels placed along a 400-mile trail through the White and Green Mountains of New England has just been opened by the American Youth Hostel Association, organized by Americans last Autumn and officially recognized by the International Youth Hostel Association.

Buyers who were in town last week making purchases for August coat sales seemed to agree that the market is producing better values in fur-trimmed cloth coats than have been seen for several years, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. August coat sales, therefore, are expected to be good.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The golden anniversary of the founding of Alpha Chi Omega will be observed on Friday night at the Greenbrier with a costume ball in the period of 1885. One feature of the evening will be a brief pageant telling the story of events leading up to the inauguration of the sorority.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Up-to-date information puts the labor situation in this section in a more favorable light as the smaller industrial plants display greater activity. This is particularly true of textile mills, of which there are many in this district, numbers of them having increased payrolls and are operating more steadily.

WHEN buses replaced trolley cars on the Fourth and Madison Avenue line last Feb. 1 some people wondered with sympathy what would happen to the motormen and conductors who had been employed on the line, many of them for long terms of years.

A new weapon for subduing rioters and other disorderly persons in New York was demonstrated Thursday in the form of an electric glove which will issue a 1,500-volt shock to persons resisting arrest or dispersement.

General Plutarco Elias Calles, for nearly ten years virtually Mexico's dictator, suddenly occupies that position no longer. This major change in some ways resembles our own "Roosevelt revolution," in that the people going out of power and the people coming in correspond in Mexican life to the solid business bloc and the idealistic New Dealers.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- For the first time Western cowboys are riding in rodeos here for the entertainment of visitors. The affairs are staged each Sunday afternoon at the Half Circle B Ranch of Carl Bauman near Asheville. The first rodeo, held last Sunday, attracted not only visitors but also hundreds of residents of Western North Carolina.

The various protective groups organized a week ago to consider plans for reorganization of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, which filed a petition under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act, are faced with numerous related factors which may require months of study before any workable plan can be presented.

PEORIA, Ill., June 22. -- Gerald Thompson, 25, confessed today to attacking and killing Mildred Hallmark, 19-year-old waitress, whose body was found in a ditch in Springdale Cemetery Monday. He was taken from Peoria to Bloomington to avoid mob violence, and a few hours after the prisoner's departure the coroner's jury returned a verdict charging him with murder in the first degree.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 22. -- Perseverance finally brought its reward to John E. Parker Jr., former Yale golf captain, in the Metropolitan amateur championship.

Efforts to reconcile the differences between manufacturers and wholesalers over the protective clauses which the latter wish to include in all contracts will be made on Tuesday when the executive committee of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute meets here with mill and selling agent groups.

With only one more trading session before notices on Tuesday, liquidation of an extensive out, standing interest in the July position brought active operations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed the list with gains of 4 to 9 points.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22. -- Heavy rains, combined with a normal reaction from active buying resulting from the season's first warm weather the previous week, slowed down retail trade by 30 to 35 per cent from the high mark of the previous week. Demand for seasonal lines was poor. Men's furnishings developed some strength, however.

THE United States has come to have its romantic police force -- the G-men -- one which already ranks in attraction with Scotland Yard and the Canadian Mounties, and which far surpasses the French Surete as a dramatic weapon.

SINCE this is another Dr. Priestley story, we find, as usual, that Inspector Hanslet of Scotland Yard is in charge of the investigation and is drawing the wrong conclusions from the facts placed before him. Again, as usual, Hanslet believes that he has the mystery solved except for a few minor details concerning which he wishes to consult his old friend. Dr. PriesUey.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A series of striking charts on population trends and national welfare has been produced by two government agricultural economists, O.E. Baker and T.B. Manny. They show that ten years ago the population of the United States was increasing by about 1,800,000 persons a year.

LONDON, June 22. -- As a prelude to the classic Wimbledon championships, starting Monday, America's No. 1 singles player, Wilmer Allison, completed a week of competition today by sharing the honors in two divisions of play in the Queen's Club tournament.

Omaha, nobody up, won the East Side turtle classic yesterday afternoon by thirty-two and a half lengths in forty-five seconds at the annual track meet of the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street.

JAPAN has inaugurated a new daily series of test programs for American listeners from midnight to 1 A.M. Eastern standard time. The waves are 14,600, 10,600 and 7,510 kilocycles (20.5, 28.3 and 39.9 meters).
DUBLIN, June 22. -- Alvin M. Owsley, United States Minister-Designate to the Irish Free State, reached Dublin this evening and will present his credentials to President Eamon de Valera soon.

MUKDEN, Manchuria. -- Although the proposed law governing Japanese emigration to Manchuria has not yet been passed, it is believed that the provisions will be based on the results attained by a colony already established in Suileng Prefecture.

Baccalaureate sermons and sermons in general for young people will be delivered today in many churches because this week will mark the close of the school year with thousands of graduates of high and grammar schools in the New York area. In all Catholic Churches, at the request of Cardinal Hayes, a vigil of six days of prayer for the ending of the persecution of the church in Mexico will begin.

THE PAN AMERICAN UNION is issuing for children, under the editorship of Heloise Brainerd, chief of the Division of Intellectual Cooperation, a series of brief biographies of Latin-American heroes. These biographies are designed to make American children acquainted with Latin-American patriots, ideals and customs, in the hope of inspiring true neighborliness.

Our present-day bureaucracy might be likened to the Titans of Greek mythology who had an incredible power for gaining in height, girth and insolence. They took the mountain Ossa and piled it on the mountain Pelion in an effort to reach the skies and grab the abundant life from the immortals of Olympus.

The United Synagogue of America announced yesterday it had received information from Jerusalem that actual construction had been started there on the new Jerusalem Synagogue and Centre. The project is being built with money raised in this country, and it was said the first unit would be dedicated in September.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21. -- After eighteen years of agitation, the Mooney case has been revived as an impersonal legal issue involving the appellate procedure of State courts and the extent to which that procedure is controlled by the Fourteenth Amendment.

The Bronx Chamber of Commerce began a campaign yesterday against open-air parking lots by sending a protest to all members of the Board of Estimate and asking legislation to abolish the "general menace."
The conductors and motormen who formerly guided the trolley cars of the Fourth and Madison Avenue line are, with few exceptions, the chauffeurs of the buses today.

In describing Americans as "Latins of the Anglo-Saxon race" Nicholas Titulescu, Rumanian Foreign Minister, opened what might turn out to be a diverting controversy. Among experts in the study of racial characteristics and blends, there exist sharp differences of opinion as to whether the tendency of our national picture is toward the British, as of old, or toward the European Continental, realizing, of course, that we are constantly forming a national character of our own.

JOSEPH SPENCER KENNARD, pleasantly remembered for many works on Italian literature, has written an ingratiating study of the Commedia dell'Arte and marionette theatre. If not so substantial a book as his history of the Italian theatre which appeared several years ago, it is still a delightful essay, filled with amusing incidents and handsomely illustrated.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., June 22.--The right wing of the Republican party took complete control of the convention of the Association of New York Young Republican Clubs here today.

THROUGHOUT the world the post-war years have brought revolutionary changes to the countryside. Agricultural systems are not easily disrupted, and rural social forms have a way of surviving pestilences, famines, revolutions -- and governments.

Since the new year I have seen 134 motion pictures and just about 15 per cent of these merit the space newspapers allot in the reviews. "G-Men" was a well-made picture, but, since all G-men are neither honest nor heroic, I could not approve of the production.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22. -- The restoration of stable trade conditions in the bituminous and anthracite coal fields will be effected by means of two recently proposed plans for control of the industry, it was predicted by speakers at the eighteenth annual convention of the National Retail Coal Merchants Association, which closed here today in the Hotel Traymore.

MANCHESTER, Vt., June 22 (AP). -- National standards in certain economic and social areas must be provided for common safety, A.A. Berle, City Chamberlain of New York, said today as he expressed preference for a constitutional amendment to bring about national action.

THE Bronx House second annual inter-settlement exhibition is being held, until July 2, in the basement gallery at the Ferargil. The work is classified as produced by adults, intermediates and children. Besides Bronx House, the following are represented: Educational Alliance, University Settlement, Greenwich House (especially commendable being the vigorous mural design by Louis Novara), Haarlem House, Jacob H. Schiff Centre, Riis House and East Side House.

Casey Stengel's hit and run-starved Dodgers ended their long famine at Ebbets Field yesterday and enjoyed their greatest feast of the season at the expense of the Reds. Scoring nine runs in one inning, they beat Chuck Dressen's youngsters, 17 to 4, with George Earnshaw registering his first National League victory.

About one-third of America's dwellings "are of a character to injure the health, endanger the safety and morals and interfere with the normal family life of their inhabitants." Private builders are unable to cope with this situation, which "constitutes a national emergency" with which "only the national government, with the cooperation of State and local housing authorities," is competent to deal.
DETROIT, June 22 (AP). -- The Tigers took both ends of a twin bill from the Senators today to come back within shooting distance of the top of the American League.

Fred Jacoby Jr., who has started the season as America's most consistent prize winner by victories in the Albany marathon and in last week's Playland championships, will head the several score of outboard drivers, both amateur as well as professional, in this afternoon's sixth annual regatta on the Hackensack River at Carlstadt, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The House Interstate Commerce Committee, openly antagonistic to President Roosevelt's demands for outright dissolution of holding companies, completed today its consideration of the Utilities Control Bill and ordered it reported to the House, stripped of its "death sentence," its provision for regulation of gas companies and its 2 per cent tax on intercompany dividends.
ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- Unfavorable weather conditions continue to be an adverse factor in practically all lines of trade and industry in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 22. -Until Henry Picard with his graceful, easy swing and sub-par scoring arrived at Muirfield there was a disposition among golf critics to believe that the British open championship, which starts here Monday, was going to be an all-British affair.
THE popularity ranking of broadcast shows is revealed in a nation-wide survey conducted by Radio Guide in which 1,256,328 votes were cast on 209,388 ballots.

LATONIA, Ky., Juno 22. -- Late Date, favored at odds of 13 to 10, disappointed the form players in the Enquirer Handicap, feature on today's racing card, the winner turning up in Open Hearth, at almost 12 to 1. My Blaze, even more of an outsider, at 17 to 1, took second place, with Fiji, the second choice, getting the show berth.

THIS new volume, the ninth in the scholarly and useful series. "Civilization of the American Indian," is admirable in the extent of the field which Mr. Thomas has explored and the painstaking care with which he has studied the archives he has brought to light.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 22 (AP) -- Inundation of Arkansas farm lands approached the half-million-acre mark today as the flood crest on the rampant Arkansas River neared Little Rock and, Pine Bluff.

While the interest-bearing debt of the United States Government on June 30 will be approximately $27,845,000,000, based on computations by C.J. Devine Co., Inc., the average interest rate on the debt will be the lowest for any year since 1916, immediately prior to the entrance of the United States into the World War.

WHEN the film industry threatened to move East, no one thought it would settle at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis. But that seems to have happened. Within six or eight weeks two picture companies have gone on location here and a third is threatening to follow.

BERLIN, June 22. -- Professor Karl Barth, noted Swiss theologian of Bonn University, whose dismissal recently was annulled by the Prussian Administrative Court of Appeals, was permanently retired today by an order of the Education Minister, Dr. Bernhard Rust.

LONDON, June 22. -- The stock markets were closed today. Silver recovered sharply in the bullion market to 32 5/16d an ounce for spot and 32 9/16d for forward delivery on Chinese buying. Gold was lower at 141s 1d an ounce. About 392,000 of the metal was sold.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on May 31 a net profit of $2,856,171 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent after dividend requirements on the $4 preferred stock to $3.36 a share on 585,414 no-par shares of common stock, excluding 14,586 shares held for employes.

Your recent article, "Snakes Have Character," stated what reptile students have recognized for years, viz., that the serpent, far from being man's enemy, is his unacknowledged friend. This fact, unfortunately, is little known or appreciated by the public.

LONDON. EVERY new anthology of poetry receives its individual allotment of praise and blame in the current reviews, but one seldom comes across an appraisement of this class of publication as a whole.

Holding that prices in many representative lines of merchandise may show more of a tendency next Fall to rise than to decline, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, marketing authority and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, declared here yesterday it would be "folly" for retailers to postpone their buying or cut orders under normal requirements.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 22. -- To cope with the reckless and drunken driving problem in Nassau County the county Police Department, with the cooperation of the village police and District Attorney Martin W. Littleton started a drive against incautious and drunken drivers at 11 o'clock tonight.

The churches of the United States are occupied with an annual and coast-to-coast stock-taking. Here are vast and varied agencies of worship and service that include 240,000 ministers, or 1 for every 500 persons in the country, and about the same number of churches.

DALLAS, Texas, June 21. -- The broad expanse of Texas, for years a happy hunting ground for stock swindlers who have defrauded the public of millions of dollars annually, will at last become a "close preserve," with the Department of State a stern game warden, if the new Securities Act just passed by the Legislature receives the proper support from those it is intended to protect.

LATE June in many gardens offers a bit of a breathing spell, but there are still plenty of activities to occupy the growers' spare time. One important practice, often overlooked, is to give some attention at this time to the annuals that are coming along.

MANILA. -- Although political leaders, from Manuel Quezon down to the city ward-heelers in Manila, are quick to attribute the presence of trouble in disaffected areas to economic hardships imposed by the United States, an examination of the grievances aired in public meetings indicates relatively little of this, but much political dissatisfaction.

DETROIT, June 22. -- Characterizing the critics of the Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin as "little literary gliders trying to hitch hike on the giant airplane of Father Coughlin's popularity," the June 20 edition of The Michigan Catholic comes to the defense of the priest in a front-page editorial headed: "Is Father Coughlin Breaking Canon Laws?"

EFFICIENCY of gasoline-powered model aircraft is showning marked gains as better design of the planes themselves and improvements in the tiny engines which drive them appear. During the Eastern States model airplane championships held at Hadley Field, N.J., a powered model of ten-foot wing spread made a continuous flight of 64 minutes 40 seconds, breaking all records for limited fuel consumption classes.
Scholastic honors have been awarded to 74 undergraduates of Manhattan College and second honor ratings to 122 undergraduates, according to the dean's honor list made public yesterday by the college.

SO far there is every sign that the knitting rage which has been with us these many months will continue unabated. Paris favors hand-knitted dresses and suits for individuality in costume. To abet this fad there are competent designers in New York who stand ready to supply the latest yarns plus designs to suit personal taste and any figure.

MANLIUS, N.Y., June 22. -- With a record number of alumni in attendance the sixty-sixth commencement program at Manlius School was completed here today with graduating exercises and announcement of winners of academic honors.

Almost midway between Montauk and Point Judith lies Block Island, the goal sooner or later of most cruising yachtsmen from New York. As season after season afloat add to their nautical experience they want to satisfy themselves about their own intrepidity.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- For that part of yesterday's crowd which stayed for this morning's postponed Yale-Harvard varsity race there was the sight of one of the most conclusive victories either crew has ever scored on this river. When Yale's crew "let her run" in Bartlett's Cove at the finish of the four miles upstream, the Crimson eight continued to row for forty-five seconds and finishes a little more than eleven lengths behind.

Christ Church of Quincy, Mass., has communion silver of great age given by the English sovereign of the early days of the American Colonies. Also there is a prayer book with the prayer for the King cut out, it is said, by a dagger. The present church is fairly modern, but the parish is believed to be the Mother Church of New England.

TORONTO, Ont., June 22. -- The shareholders of Peterson Cobalt Mines at their annual meeting approved a resolution for the formation of a subsidiary company to take over and develop the Nova Scotia section of its holdings in the Cobalt area.

SUPPLEMENTARY material, added last week, enlarges the scope of the Summer exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, which, as originally arranged, has already been discussed in these columns. The modern European typography show has been removed and in its place, on the ground floor, we find sculpture.

NEW LONDON, June 22. -- The Eastern Yacht Club's ocean race to Marblehead got under way this morning with thirty-one boats definitely starting. Three others get up sail after the committee had left Sarah's Ledge and were presumed to be competitors.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today a cash balance of $7,629,564.37 as of May 31, receipts in May having exceeded expenditures by $4,981,953.76. There was a carry-over from April of $2,647,610.61, according to the revised figures on May business, contained in the monthly report to Congress.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 22. -- Winners of the awards for ten journalistic achievements of the year were announced at the dinner of the second annual Headliners Frolic here tonight.

Jack Seaman and Lou Lubin of the Trinity Club advanced to the third round of the Metropolitan A.A.U. one-wall handball doubles championship, a round ahead of the field, by conquering Sol Gromet and Sam Lane, City College, 21 -- 6, 21 -- 20, in a second-round test at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 22. -- The Battle of Springfield, which was fought 155 years ago tomorrow along the banks of the Rahway River, will be commemorated here on this anniversary in the First Presbyterian Church, which was organized in 1745.

PARIS, June 20. -- Meyer's woolen, into the weave of which tiny bamboo logs are appliqued at intervals, is an exciting textile forerunner of the coming Winter collections. Hurel's black moire on which black patent leather oval dots are appliqued in a distinctive pattern is another striking novelty that indicates a trend to mix mediums.

GARDENERS who have already learned the delights that beds of Dianthus give while they are in flower now may add to their collections a new bright pink variety whose name, appropriately, is Delight. The British nurseries of Allwood Brothers, introducers of this novelty, exhibited masses of it at the recent Chelsea show in London.

ABOUT 820 acres of land have been added to Acadia National Park, Maine, through an act of Congress recently approved by President Roosevelt. The territory -- known as the Green Lake site -- can be easily patrolled by Acadia's regular rangers, and its transference from the Department of the Interior to the Department of Commerce thus involves no added expense.

The Social Security Bill has passed both houses of Congress, and in a few days the signature of the President will give it the finality of law. In consummating this measure, we shall have erected at least the framework of a shelter against the cold blasts of poverty in old age, deprivation in childhood, and unemployment in the prime of life.

Industry's ability to negotiate successfully voluntary agreements for the preservation of certain benefits of the recovery act will be tested severely this week, when the cotton garment industry, most battle-scarred of regimented business under the NRA, convenes here to formulate a new program.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- Every haven and cove on Long Island Sound and the harbors up Buzzards Bay way will have crowded anchorages tonight with visiting craft en route home from the boat races to their own club moorings in the New York and Boston areas.
Under conditions not quite befitting the occasion, Textile High School's baseball team won the city P.S.A.L. championship yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia named three prominent business men yesterday to constitute the Queens-Midtown Tunnel Authority, an agency set up by the Legislature this year to construct and operate a toll vehicular tunnel between Thirty-eighth Street, Manhattan, and Borden Avenue, Long Island City.

Work will start in July on the large addition to the group of buildings known as the Columbus Hospital Extension in West 163d Street, it was announced yesterday by Anthony J. De Pace, architect, who has just completed plans for the structure.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22. -- Jacob Berman, a Los Angeles oil promoter, who was flown to Alcatraz Island prison from Lewisburg, Pa., last night, faces three possibilities -- release tomorrow or thirty days hence or indefinite imprisonment until he pays a $16,000 fine for mail fraud.

COLUMBIA'S new management wastes little time in answering the frequent complaint that the companies are only interested in the beaten track along which quick profits are to be gleaned. To undertake the recording of nineteen sides of Bach's "The Art of Fugue" (Masterworks Album, 206) is by no means the same thing as selecting something from a foreign list of domestic re-pressing.

The fiftieth anniversary year book of the Memorial Hospital for the treatment of cancer and allied diseases declares that the institution is "strained to its fullest capacity to meet increasing demands for special cancer service." The institution celebrated its jubilee a year ago.

The scene of this story is laid in a large city hospital, and most of the characters are doctors and nurses. One of the nurses, who has been playing around with at least two of the doctors, is found dead shortly after she has assisted at an operation.

DUBLIN. -- Sixteen years ago, on June 23, 1919, Eamon de Valera made his dramatic appearance at the old Waldorf-Astoria in New York as the "President of the Irish Republic," a tall, gaunt, hawk-like, ex-professor of mathematics, self-conscious and uncertain, but with the burning fire of a great passion in his eyes, the vigorous leader of a forlorn hope.

ISTANBUL, June 22. -- Since the Mohammedan religion was disestablished in Turkey and the Republican People's party, which is the only existing political party, ordained that henceforth Turkey should be a lay State, various measures have been taken to assure that there shall be no parade of religion, which, according to principles lately enunciated at the party's congress in Angora, shall henceforth be "the private concern of the individual."

WHATEVER may be the explanation behind this intriguing literary mystery, whose authorship has been variously and speculatively ascribed to Jane Austen, Trollope and Broughton as well as to moderns -- Rose Macaulay, E.M. Delafield and Mrs. Thirkell have been mentioned -- who are thought to have assumed the literary cloak of an earlier manner, the book would be of very ephemeral and limited value were its only interest an academic one.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 22. -- Arrangements were made today at Camp Smith for the entertainment tomorrow of about 3,000 relatives and friends of the members of the 106th Infantry Regiment of Brooklyn. The 1,050 Brooklyn Guardsmen under Colonel Frank Vincent will pass in review before Postmaster Francis Sinnott of Brooklyn.

ALBANY, June 22. -- Governor Lehman today named six members of a temporary commission, set up by the 1935 Legislature, to study the effect of participation in interstate pacts to fix uniform standards for laws affecting the conditions of employment and the interests of labor and industry generally.

A LARGE segment of North China has now fallen under the domination of the Japanese. Faced by the possibility of military action if it refused, the government at Nanking accepted a series of Japanese demands which virtually destroyed its own control in the northern area.
BOGOTA. -- The mills of the gods grind no more slowly than the wheels of justice in Colombia, according to El Tiempo, which comments on recent threats of revolt of prisoners in jail awaiting trial.

A BEAUTIFUL mother of 38 who doesn't look a day over 30 is a difficult problem for a young girl. Until she was 19, Karen managed very well by yielding to every whim of her pretty and unspeakably selfish mother, Diana. Then trouble came along.

In a small lecture room at Christodora House a white-haired woman defended her plan for sweeping revisions of the social structure of the United States with the fervor but without the verbal fireworks of a Coughlin or a Long. She is Mrs. Prestonia Mann Martin, native New Yorker, but now the wife of Professor John Martin, lecturer on international relations at Rollins College, Winter Park, Fla.
ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP). -- The Browns capitalized on ten hits and their rivals' misplays to take the first of a four-game series from the Athletics today, 11 to 3.
HAVANA, June 22. -- Cuban general elections were officially set for Dec. 15 this year at a joint meeting today of the Cabinet and Council of State.

Export organizations last week launched a drive to break up what they term is an international confidence game through which Germany is victimizing Latin-American nations to the tune of millions in sterling and dollar exchange.

In the first comprehensive survey of the operations of the Federal Reserve Banks under Section 13b of the Federal Reserve Act, authorizing capital loans to industry, The Federal Reserve Bulletin, published yesterday, shows that out of $245,078,000 of such loans applied for $86,282,000 of loans and commitments were approved, $30,572,000 was actually advanced and $19,425,000 of commitments to make loans are outstanding.
SUMMER tourists stop below George Washington's feet to gaze up at the Morgan windows. White chalk on the paving at the mouth of Nassau Street asks passers-by, "If a man die, shall he live?"
Otto Scheer recommends trolling for striped bass on the Susquehanna River to anglers in search of a novel experience.

A CEREMONY that started in Wales a thousand years ago when poets, singers and musicians met annually to compete for prizes will again be staged from Aug. 5 to 11 at Carnarvon under the patronage of the Prince of Wales and the supervision of David Lloyd George.

DALLAS, June 22. -- Warm weather and sunshine, following two weeks of rain and storms over the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, has brought a decided upturn in retail sales volume. The improvement is the sharpest noted since the Easter holiday buying, and has extended to a number of lines, being particularly felt in clothing and household furnishings.

Your letter soliciting a subscription was received. You know the one about the old Negro who, when asked if he had "change for a ten," replied: "Course I isn't got de change, Boss, but I shore thanks you for the compliment." We would like to have THE NEW YORK TIMES. We haven't got the money. But "we thanks you for de compliment."

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The New Deal, with Congress working at high speed under White House pressure, assumed final outlines this week, and in the same week the President answered a question which has been asked in growing volume since his reforms were first pressed: "Where is the money coming from?"

Early Colonial coins and some of the privately minted California and Colorado gold coins sold for the highest prices yesterday at the auction of the Wendell C. Foster collection, conducted by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

ALBANY, June 22. -- Long Island well drillers who intend to operate after July 1 must obtain licenses from the Water and Power Control Commission, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, pointed out today. A bill passed by the 1935 Legislature makes the requirement.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 22. -- The fourth annual horse show of the Plainfield Riding Club, held yesterday and today at Vine Brook Farm, attracted a large number of devotees, both exhibitors and spectators.

THIS charming work is an interesting example of that very useful class of books, local histories, which so rarely get the attention they deserve. This one has an especially interesting and worthwhile theme, since it deals with the phenomena of a development common to all frontier regions.

Three attorneys of this city, each a practitioner for twenty years, were disbarred by the Appellate Division, on order made public yesterday at the court house, Madison Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

LONDON, June 22. -- At the final meeting in the Admiralty today of the British and German naval delegations on tentative building programs it was agreed that the German fleet would not at any time exceed the ratio of 35 to 100.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 22. -- The annual regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club, held off here today, attracted a large fleet, with most of the boats finishing despite poor conditions, when the waters of Long Island Sound were lashed by a severe storm.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Port of New York Authority reported to the Public Works Administration today that the new $37,500,000 midtown vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River between New York City and New Jersey is expected to "hole through by September, breaking all construction records for this type of work."

Regarding the descriptive term "Grass Roots," applied to the recent political conference in Illinois, writers to THE TIMES have been busy suggesting its origin and meaning. If no one were able to establish either, the case would merely repeat that of other political appellations in our past.

BOSTON, June 21. -- What has been called the "Cotton Textile Policing Organization," to compel the Northern mills to continue to operate in compliance with the terms of the now defunct code, has had nothing to do as yet.

I note that the exploit of Senator Huey Long in talking on the Senate floor for 15 1/2 hours has been exploited as the greatest filibustering achievement ever registered. If there is any honor in a record of that sort, I am entitled to the blue ribbon. IN, 1908 I was a member of the Texas Senate. Charges had been preferred against Senator J. W. Bailey.

Affected by severe storms, retail buying was less active last week in various sections of the country, with sales generally under those of the previous week, when weather conditions were more favorable, but ahead of the volume at this time last year in many instances.

ABOUT 2,000,000 young people are graduating this month from 30,000 public and private secondary schools in all parts of the country -- from Eastport to San Diego, from Bellingham to Key West. "Where do we go from here?"

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20. -- California's Legislature has passed a Chain-Store Tax Bill to force all chain-store groups operating in this State to pay $500 a year tax on each store above nine. The bill awaits the signature of Governor Merriam to become law.
ALBANY, June 22 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, New York State's New Works Progress Administrator, begun the gigantic task today of putting 300,000 New Yorkers to work by early Fall.

Fred Brandt, James Madison ace and holder of the national interscholastic 220-yard championship, turned in a dazzling performance in capturing the 200-yard free style, the feature event of the first annual P.S.A.L. outdoor swimming meet, held yesterday at the Raven-hall Bathing Park, Coney Island.
A substantial part of the motor boat interests of the metropolitan district will participate in the First Annual Outdoor Motor Boat Show next Saturday and Sunday at City Island.

WASHINGTON, June 22.--Federal work relief funds will be made available to pay 1,200 New Orleans garbage collectors, health and sanitary forces, Fire Department members and other city forces, Frank H. Peterman, new Louisiana Works Progress Administrator, announced today just before leaving that city.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 22. -- Governor Earle notified the Legislature today, as it prepared for final adjournment, that a special session next year to provide additional funds for unemployment relief was "inevitable."

SUFFERN, N.Y., June 22. -- Almost 2,000 persons took part here today in a colorful celebration honoring Daniel Carter Beard, national commissioner of the Boy Scouts of America, who was 85 years old yesterday.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 22. -- Setting an early rising record from his second sleep, Shufflin' Joe Louis appeared in the doorway of his stone lodging here at noon today. He was wearing a luxurious purple dressing gown over a pair of flaring red pajamas. He said it looked as though it would be a nice day after all. This was a long speech for Shufflin' Joe.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP). -- Paradisical, J.J. Collins's 3-year-old filly, an outsider in the betting, outran Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Sun Portland and F.M. Alger's Azucar to capture the $5,000 Pontchartrain Handicap at the Detroit track today.

WASHINGTON, June 22.--Senator Robinson, Democratic leader of the Senate, today joined those who are pressing for the enactment at the present session of the inheritance taxes and increased levies on wealthy individuals and corporations proposed by President Roosevelt.

RIDING the radio compass, which can use ordinary commercial broadcast stations as points of orientation, will soon become an accepted fact of airline operation and of private flying if experiments being carried out by the Bureau of Air Commerce along the midcontinent airway and individual tests of various types of compass yield the good results which now seem indicated.

DUBLIN, June 22. -- Two Parliamentary by-elections fought during the week gave straight fights between the de Valera and Cosgrave parties in Dublin and Galway Counties. Despite the fact that they were the first contests held since the general election in January, 1933, little interest was shown by the electorate.

LYMINGTON, England, June 22. -- For the second day in succession Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee trailed when the Class J fleet again raced in its full strength of seven yachts in the Lymington Yacht Club regatta today.

A fusillade of shots fired at 8 o'clock last night by gunmen fleeing from a hold-up at 89 Avenue A, terrified a score of persons in nearby Sixth Street as more than a dozen bullets ricocheted off the sidewalks and buildings, one of them striking a passer-by.

TRENTON, N.J., June 22. -- Under the new 2 per cent Retail Sales Tax Law effective July 1, the person or company making the last sale to the consumer will pay the tax to the State but must charge it to the consumer as an addition to the price, J.H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, said in a radio address yesterday.

DENVER. PERCHED on the granite slopes of the front range of the Rockies, near neighbor to the eternal snows, Central City, Col., is preparing to welcome devotees of music and drama to its fourth annual Play Festival under the sponsonship of the University of Denver.
MOSCOW, June 22 (AP). -- Leon Trotsky, famous Russian exile, was publicly accused today of inciting terrorists to strike at the Soviet Union.

PICTURED above is the visible part of a device designed to permit a person whose legs are paralyzed or otherwise unserviceable to operate an automobile. It was invented by A. Rivington Stone of Short Hills, N.J., and is being marketed as the Stone Full Power Car Control.

WITH many developed features, including increased comfort, more room, better vision, improved ventilation, greater passenger capacity and less weight, the new bus pictured above has been put in service between Detroit and Chicago by the Greyhound Lines, it is reported.

FLORENCE. ADRIANO GREGO seems to be a very young writer, at least so young that we have never heard of him and that he has never written a book before this "Due Fratelli" ("Two Brothers"), Florence, Vallecchi, 1935, which for a first novel shows signs of undoubted power.

NEW ORLEANS, June 22. -- With Federal Emergency Relief Administration checks in their pockets, the city's 300 garbage workers today called off their one-day strike for back pay and resumed their jobs of clearing the streets of litter, pending a settlement of their demands Monday before the commission council.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., June 22. -- From a rostrum overlooking rolling green hills, the New Deal was assailed and defended this afternoon in the light of what took place on this spot during the Winter of 1777-78.

WASHINGTON, June 22. A report that work is proceeding satisfactorily at the Matanuska (Alaska) resettlement project and that most of the colonists are happy and satisfied will be made to the Senate Monday by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal relief administrator .

THIS is really a different kind of travel book because the idea of spending a Summer in Europe by camping through the Balkans surely never occurred to many others and because it is not usual to find travel narrative interspersed with so much caustic humor and told in a style as unconventional as their method of travel.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a new batch of applications on Form 1-M for registration of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities. Those from New York City follow:

The jobbers in the cloak and suit industry, by insisting that the workers drop the clause for limitation of contractors in renewing the agreement that expired on June 1, are forcing a general strike of some 40,000 workers in the industry, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, declared yesterday.

END OF AN ERA: The homely philosopher of the country store cracker-barrel has become the Vanishing American, 1935 model. He is fast disappearing -- and a Pembroke (Ga.) storekeeper came forward last week with the explanation. Nowadays cardboard boxes, instead of soft light wood, are used for packing goods.

Just how unhappy are the young people today? The class orator at Harvard told his classmates that they must try to get more good out of their education than their fathers did. If not, "we can hope for even less happiness; for happiness comes harder today."

BERLIN, June 22. -- The Boerse closed the week with a fairly good recovery, which brought gains of 2 points in some instances. Heavy industrial shares rose an average of 3/4 point and several issues, including Hoesch, Kloeckner and Mannesmann, advanced around 1 1/2 points.

THE floods which recently have ravaged large sections of Southern and Western Texas furnished some novel -- and some harrowing -- experiences for motorists caught on highways truck by the rampaging waters. These experiences provided object lessons that less unfortunate motorists in other parts of the country fight well profit from.

NEWPORT, in Rhode Island, and Aiken, in South Carolina, have been called "the two capitals of sport in America." The glory of Newport has faded. But the renown of Aiken has grown as sport in this country has tended to absorb more and more the entire energies of the sporting set.

TWENTY-EIGHT years ago Dr. Alexis Carrel published the sensational news that he had succeeded in keeping a bit of a chicken's heart alive in a glass vessel. Fed with the proper food, washed delicately to rid it of its wastes, the fragment still lives and grows in the Rockefeller Institute.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 22. -- Miss Claire W. Faitoute's Blue Blazes won the saddle horse championship as the fourth annual Plainfield Horse Show came to a conclusion on the grounds of the Plainfield Riding Club today. Throughout the two days of the show, the entries of the Short Hills girl dominated the saddle horse classes, capturing five blues.

R. Stanley Dollar Jr. will pilot the "mystery" speed boat Uncle Sam as the sole American entrant in the international speed boat races at Paris on July 6. Dollar, together with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Stanley Dollar Sr., and his sister will sail from New York on Wednesday.

ALAMEDA, Calif., June 22 (AP). -- Completing its fourth flight between Hawaii and California, the Pan American Airways' pioneering Clipper seaplane came in "blind" today, ending an easy conquest of head winds and clouds over a 2,400-mile stretch of the Pacific.
The Congress of the United States rolled up its sleeves last week and demonstrated to a surprised nation an unsuspected capacity for doing work.
CHICAGO, June 22. -- Fillies do win derbies after all.

MR. HARTCHER has arranged, documented and examined about 450 American novels of the past forty years, an average that almost justifies the minimum demand of the book-of-the-month clubs. The nineteenth century background is a little scamped: "with respect to the novel * * * one can hardly go beyond the memory of men now living."
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
