WASHINGTON, June 22. -- With important administration bills still awaiting House action, leaders joined today with rank and filers of that body in the prediction that President Roosevelt's program faced further serious mutilation, unless there was a change in administration tactics, which, many consider, are depriving the House of its constitutional prerogatives.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 22. -- University of Southern California's powerful track and field team won the 1935 National Collegiate A.A. team championship today, but Jesse Owens, lithe Negro youth from Ohio State, won the thunderous applause of 18,000 fans.

The city of Dallas, Texas, which this year will celebrate its centennial, announced yesterday that it would enter the market on July 1 for a loan of $3,500,000. Whether this financing is in connection with the $3,000,000 expenditure planned for the celebration was not made clear in advices received in Wall Street.

WITHIN the covers of his book Shaw is his own playwright, producer, stage manager, actor, publicity agent and dramatic critic. He was the first to be so, and the first to make the printed play, with all these discursive attachments, entirely satisfactory and successful.

REDDING, Conn., June 22 (AP). -- The "beneficent friendship" that exists between France and the United States was cited here today by Andre de Laboulaye, French Ambassador, in an address extolling Joel Barlow, American patriot in the Revolutionary War and one time Ambassador to France.

IZZY AND MOE: Izzy Einstein and Moe Smith, who became prohibition's most famous team of detectives by using more disguises than even the correspondence-school courses tell about, got together (socially) again last week. The occasion was a bang-up party in New York in honor of the marriage of Izzy's son, Joseph, and of Izzy's own thirtieth wedding anniversary.

WASHINGTON these days is going through a period of inventory. The sprawling, infinitely busy village which is the nation's capital is trying to determine whether it is to have a fire sale, hang out the "Business as Usual" sign, or start an addition to the old establishment.

MR. WELLS has been coming over here so many years now, and appraising us so often, that we have almost ceased to think of him as the Visiting Foreigner. His comments seem less alien than those of other prominent Englishmen, partly, perhaps, because he often flatters us with obvious sincerity, but mainly because we feel him to be already half-American in temperament.

THE city of Buffalo has been enriched by the recently opened Lockwood Memorial Library, donated to the University of Buffalo by Thomas B. Lockwood. It is a beautiful building and a noble monument to book collecting, or the art preservative of the art preservative.

William Hayes, 9-year-old son of Charles Hayes, a Wall Street broker, of 42-35 161st Street, Flushing, Queens, was dying in Flushing Hospital last night of first-degree burns unaware that his brother, Charles Jr., 12, had died at noon in the same hospital of meningitis caused by a blow that William struck while they were playing.

The immediate tension between China and Japan has subsided. The results for the rest of the world remain to be assessed. The visit to the State Department by Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, and diplomatic interchanges among the other powers constitute the first efforts by the Western nations to sound their position.

ANOTHER big game fishing season has arrived. Almost within sight of Manhattan's skyscrapers keen and hardy anglers are responding to the call of the offshore waters and the music of the singing reel. For here, virtually within New York's front yard, the deeps of the Atlantic provide a teeming open preserve.

A WHIMSICAL book about a grand tour, and just as certainly a grand book about a whimsical tour, this record of travel on two continents should be required reading for every one who doubts that the British have a sense of humor, if indeed there are still literate people who believe that American tradition.

CANTON, N.Y., June 22. -- The conference on Canadian -- American affairs closed today with an eloquent plea from one of the Dominion's distinguished Liberals for United States leadership in a world movement toward social equality and economic security.

Chain stores, a restaurant which will be one of the largest in the Times Square district and a 1,200-seat motion-picture theatre are included in the plans for the two-story commercial building which soon will occupy the blockfront on the east side of Broadway, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., June 22. -- Following is the text of the platform adopted today by the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, Inc.:
DUBLIN, Irish Free State, June 22 (AP). -- President Eamon de Valera is working on the draft of a proposed treaty of peace with Great Britain, it was learned from a high source today.
NEWARK, N.J., June 22. -- Don Heffner's home run with two on in the seventh inning gave the Bears a 5-to-4 victory over Baltimore today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 22 (AP). -- Establishment of crime and accident prevention bureaus throughout the country to "strike at the roots" of the problem is planned by Andrew J. Kavanaugh, new president of the International Association of Police Chiefs.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 22. -- The group of climbers sponsored by the Sierra Club left here in motor cars today for Vancouver, B.C., from which city they will leave by seaplane for the base of Mount Waddington. This peak, Canada's highest south of the Alaskan border, has yet to yield to the mountaineering effort of man, and has taken the life of a climber who fell 800 feet from its slopes.

MANY troubles have befallen Broome, in Western Australia, one of the world's most romantic ports, and it seems as though the town, built on the pearl industry, will be extinct by 1938. In the last ten years its population has dropped to 300.
HYDE PARK. N.Y., June 22. --Returning to Hyde Park house this morning with Mrs. Roosevelt after attending the New London Regatta yesterday, President Roosevelt devoted himself today to relaxation.
OMAHA, June 22. -- Though the course is only a year old, employes and many executives in 4,000 American banks are attending classes on how to get along with the customer.

New York City's infant population is increasing, according to Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, who said yesterday that the upward trend in births which became apparent in 1934 was continuing. He pointed out that for the first 24 weeks of 1935 there have been 560 more births reported than in the corresponding period of last year.

The "Cubby" books, of which this is the second, belong to that group of animal stories that must be regarded as a very doubtful blessing. Children of from 7 to 9 years of age, who almost universally enjoy anything that purports to be an animal story, will probably read "Cubby Returns" if it comes their way.
LONDON, June 16 (By Mail). -- Down with high neck lines and out with the "stage" curtsy is the order for the royal courts of Tuesday and Wednesday.

THIS story is the first novel by Vance Randolph, whose several books about the picturesque people of the Ozark Mountains have provided entertainment as well as information for many a reader. Traits that made these folk-books memorable, Mr. Randolph's sharp delineations of character, tolerance and humaneness, reappear abundantly in "Hedwig," and combine to make the brief history of a girl born to poverty and reared in brutality a minor annal powerful in simplicity.

VIENNA, June 22. -- A study of the new decree issued this week by the Austrian Government for the reinstitution of the medieval guild system might be heartening to any hesitating inhabitants of free countries who are inclined to shamefacedness when confronted by Fascist propaganda and gibes that democracy has been outmoded by "modern" Fascist ideas.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22. -- General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt are making their firsu visit here for the present season. They arrived this afternoon from New York aboard their yacht Winchester. They are soon to occupy Beaulieu, their Bellevue Avenue home, which recently was opened.

GENEVA. -- What are the prospects of peaceful settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict by Aug. 25, when, the League Council has ruled and the parties have agreed, arbitration ends? What are the prospects of its then developing instead into an open conflict between Italy and the League?

WASHINGTON, June 22.--A nation-wide campaign for legislation to deport about 6,000,000 aliens as a partial solution to the unemployment problem was pressed today by 155 organizations, estimated by Representative Dies to represent 5,000,000 people.

Thunder rolled over Harlem yesterday. Rain pattered down on the Polo Grounds. But, through it all, echoed the clatter of Giant base-hits that gave the Terrymen an even split with the Pirates in a twin bill that attracted 24,000 fans.

GENEVA, June 22. -- The International Labor Organization's conference adopted definitely today by a 79 to 30 vote, its convention approving the forty-hour week principle and calling for separate conventions to implement it in each Industry.

IN the Tom Swamp Tract of the Harvard Forest at Petersham, Mass., stands a memorial tablet recently placed there in honor of the late Professor Richard T. Fisher, for twenty-seven years director of the Harvard Forest School.

FOR the first time since the Dutch in 1631 settled Lewes and Rehoboth Beach in Sussex County, Del., the citizens of those towns are to open their homes to display their heirlooms to the public. This event will occur on Old Sussex Day, Saturday, June 29, and the proceeds will go to the Wilmington Art Centre.
BOSTON, June 22 (AP). -- The Cubs pushed the Braves deeper into the National League cellar today, taking both ends of a double-header, 7 -- 4 and 5 -- 3.

ONE of the impressive developments of airline operation, full of promise for the future, was exemplified last week by the round-trip flight of the Sikorsky S-42, Pan American Clipper, between Honolulu and Midway Island, the second of the airline bases which are being established by Pan American Airways on its route between the United States and China.

RICHMOND, June 22. -- Two of five reporting lines did a smaller volume of business in May than in that month a year ago, the Richmond Bank reports. They were dry goods and shoes, whose cumulative sales for five months also were under the comparable 1934 totals.

No person, declares the Constitution, shall be a Senator who shall not have attained to the age of 30 years. That was why Rush Dew Holt of West Virginia, though elected to the Senate last November, has had no place on the roll of that branch of Congress.

TACOMA, Wash., June 22. -- For the second time Mrs. Margaret Waley insisted today that she be allowed to plead guilty to the kidnapping of George Weyerhaeuser, but Federal Judge E.E. Cushman again refused her entreaty and ordered entry of a not guilty plea.
SYRACUSE, June 22 (AP). -- A new Pompey Hollow "battle" was under way today, this time concerning expenses incurred during the controversy over the ouster of Miss Esther De Lee, school teacher.

RAPID CITY, S.D., June 22. -- After a prolonged study of weather conditions at Rapid City and east and south for 300 miles, it was decided this afternoon to await more sunlight an fewer clouds for flight of the stratosphere balloon, Explorer II.

LONDON, June 22. -- Other considerations apart, it is certain that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin would stand to lose in the coming general election if he refused the offer of a naval pact by Germany.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Harvesting of the new Winter wheat crop has been resumed in Kansas and Oklahoma as the result of favorable weather, and the weekly forecast indicated little precipitation for the coming week. Hedging sales from Texas were reported in the Kansas City market today.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 22. -- The annual horse show of the Bronxville Riding Club was held today on the grounds of the club, California Road, Tuckahoe.

NASHUA, N.H. JUST as dusk settled over the local airport one evening last week Colonel Clarence Chamberlin, transatlantic flier, took the little 700-pound wooden "air flivver" designed by Harry N. Atwood, Milford furniture company official, into the air for its first flight.

Mrs. Bertha Dreyfus, philanthropist and widow of Louis A. Dreyfus, a Staten Island chemist and manufacturer, celebrated her birthday yesterday by laying the cornerstone for a $200,000 wing she had donated to the Richmond Memorial Hospital at Princes Bay, on the south shore.

With a record field of 128 entered, the eighth annual men's Eastern clay court tennis championship tournament got under way at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday. More than thirty first-round matches were played.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- In a survey published today, William Ogburn of the University of Chicago said that Herbert Hoover might have been re-elected President had more voters in 1932 been paying monthly rentals of $80 and more.

BERLIN, June 22. -- This has been a notable week, diplomatically, for Germany. There is a tendency, as it closes, to look back with satisfaction upon the progress she has made within a brief period toward attaining again that position of equality as a world power to which the great war put an end.

It has been finally decided that the West Side Highway is to go northward along the water's edge of Riverside Park instead of traveling on a roller-coaster deck over the New York Central Railroad tracks and thus perpetuating the arrangement which cuts in two that narrow strip of vantage ground whither New Yorkers go to see the warships when the fleet comes in.

YONKERS, June 22. -- Small satisfaction it was to the police of this city today that Robert Deshefy, demon searcher-out of wrecked automobiles, was fined $25 yesterday as a conquence of his zeal in transforming collisions into business for his towing enterprise.

LEWES, Del., June 22. -- With fifteen members of the crew deserters, the Cities Service Company's oil tanker Watertown lay at anchor here today, unable to recruit enough seamen to continue a voyage to Port Arthur, Texas.

WARSAW, June 22. -- Polish-German trade negotiations will be resumed Monday and the Polish delegation left tonight for Berlin with instructions to obtain a normal commercial treaty replacing the provisional agreement signed a year ago.

There is always a temptation to put a cherished pet into the pages of a book; one realizes that this little volume has been a labor of love for the authors, and other dog owners will doubtless receive the cocker spaniel of these pages sympathetically.

MANY ingenious devices are now being used to contribute comfort and to add spaciousness of effect to penthouse terraces and city backyards. These wall-less rooms are as carefully planned as the indoor spaces they supplement.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP). -- Leaders of American Jewry were arriving tonight for what was termed one of the most important annual meetings of the Central Conference of American Rabbis in years.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 22. -- Many entertained parties at tonight's opening dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club. Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Carscallen gave a dinner for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Emil Stehli of New York and Glen Cove, L.I.
ATLANTIC CITY. -- The eighth season of productions in English by the Steel Pier Grand Opera Company will open here next Saturday night.

ROME, June 22. -- The outburst of severity on the part of the Italian Government toward the American press -- which has found expression in the banning of THE NEW YORK TIMES and the expulsion of David Darrah, Chicago Tribune correspondent -- follows a number of measures of a similar nature against British journalism.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22. -- Six professors retired from the faculty of Princeton University at the end of the current college year, it was announced today by Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college.

BRIGHTON, England, June 22. -- A message of greeting from the Prince of Wales to the German ex-service men now visiting Brighton was read tonight at a dinner given by the Brighton branch of the British Legion in their honor.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 20. -- When American speakers at the conference on Canadian-American affairs at Canton, N.Y., this week criticize the discriminatory features of Canada's tariff as against the United States they opened up a difficult subject.

In your summation the other Sunday you stated (unfortunately) that you would not review the picture's obvious merits, since you appeared to be in a minority of one. But you characterized it very excellently, I thought, as an intelligent "adult comedy of passion."

OMAHA, Neb., June 22 (AP). -With one of the finest performances in a woman's golf tournament. Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, the 21-year-old Kentucky champion, today won the trans-Mississippi title, defeating Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, 9 and 7.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22, -- A teletype message from Washington is believed to have saved the lives of a woman and her five children, who were taken from a gas-filled apartment here early today.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- Missourians generally are not vastly concerned over the malfeasances Ewing Y. Mitchell alleges he has uncovered in the Department of Commerce, but they do see in his blast against the administration a definite move by the Springfield (Mo.) attorney to expose the Pendergast Democratic machine in the State.

THIS careful study of the American labor problem suffers under the slight disadvantage of having gone to press before the Supreme Court stepped on the NRA. Its discussion of the New Deal labor boards and of labor provisions under the codes thereby takes on a historical flavor.

THE affairs of the American composer of serious music remain in a highly unsettled condition. He has more encouragement on the part of publishers and of certain institutions which award prizes and moneys for the printing of his music than ever before in history.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22. -- Something new for Westchester Summer theatre patrons will be the series of Sunday night light opera performances to be given in the picturesque outdoor theatre of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough-on-Hudson, beginning on July 14.

The ninth arrest in the so-called civil service racket in which smalltime politicians and men in city jobs are charged with having sold promises of civil service preferment for fees up to $1,000, was announced by Lyn Boston, Assistant District Attorney, who said that Louis Mondell, 42 years old, former proprietor of a civil service school, had been seized in San Francisco under the name I. Sutter.

MANY business men eat light luncheons in hot weather. They say that heavy meals at midday are unwise when work is to be done. Not only does this apply to the executive; his subordinates also find it good policy.

Professor HOWARD MCBAIN of Columbia maintained last week that it is a good thing to pass laws of doubtful constitutionality or questionable value. They serve to stir up public interest, he explained. They help the passage of other laws for which popular support is not yet secure.

AT the sixth annual national soaring contest, which begins at Elmira next Saturday, Lieut. Commander Ralph S. Barnaby, president of the Soaring Society of America, will act as referee. Entries of standard gliders and sail-planes have been augmented by entries of power gliders and of the four-passenger Gross glider this year.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP). -- With a homer and a double, Roy Johnson drove in four runs in the late innings today to give the Red Sox a 7-to-5 victory over the White Sox in the opening game of their series. The defeat dropped the Chicagoans back to third place.

A campaign to bring about Senate passage of the Jones amendment to the Agricultural Adjustment Act, which provides for bounties to increase exports of agricultural commodities and their products, will get under way in the textile field this week.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Johnny Revolta, curly-haired professional from Milwaukee, took a slight beating from par today, but reached the halfway post of the Medinah Country Club's first annual $3,500 open golf tournament with a two-stroke lead. Harry Cooper of Chicago is second.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22. -- Calling for "equal industrial rights with men," feminist leaders here for a regional conference of the National Women's party urged the formation of a women's bloc to act as a spear head in the fight for their objective.

To let a frog's heart throb in a bottle of serum is an old trick of the experimental biologist. More difficult is the performance of the Skin Clinic of the University of Berlin in keeping an embryonic human heart alive in a serum for a month. Dr. J.B.S. HALDANE'S success in growing unborn rats in cultures for short periods still arouses wonder and comment.

Mayor La Guardia acted yesterday to put a stop to the mass picketing of motion picture and other theatres throughout the city which has been causing increasingly frequent disturbances nightly, especially in West Forty-second Street off Times Square, and resulting in numerous arrests.

James C. Sheridan, Democratic leader of Queens, made an emphatic denial yesterday of the authenticity of two letters purporting to show that he had given two recommendations for political jobs for a financial consideration.

A HARTFORD wit, deep in the mysteries of book making and book vending, gives us here a variously pleasant volume whose title is hardly comprehensive enough. Authorship is a trade. Publishing is a trade. Why do we write? asks Mr. Mitchell.
Marking "Brooklyn Be Kind to Animals Day," 300 dogs and 250 horses marched yesterday in a Brooklyn parade, under the auspices of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Protesting against transfer from the Seamen's Church Institute at 25 South Street to Bowery lodging houses, 500 seamen, all recipients of Federal relief, held an open-air meeting yesterday afternoon at Coenties Slip and South Street and planned to picket the Federal relief offices at 902 Broadway, beginning Monday.

No new redemptions for bonds called before their maturity dates in the remainder of this month were reported last week. Redemptions for future months and refunding for refinancing purposes continued in large denominations. Bond redemptions for June to date total $206,276,000, compared with $96,342,000 in May, and $12,562,000 in June, 1934, at corresponding dates.
INFORMATION concerning a number of new thoroughfares serving metropolitan traffic has been issued by Earnest B. Bearnarth, travel director of the Automobile Club of New York, as follows:
GENEVA. -- The International Labor Organization, known as the ILO, has recently been adding to its reputation for usefulness gained through fifteen years.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 22. -- The National City Bank of Cleveland, effective on July 1, will allow maximum interest on savings deposits of 1 1/2 per cent on accounts up to $10,000 and 1 per cent on balances over that amount. At the same time, the National City is reducing mortgage interest rates from 5 1/2 to 5 per cent.

Combined efforts of manufacturers, jobbers and responsible retailers in the grocery industry have successfully checked the outbreak of price-cutting which broke out here and which developed immediately after the Supreme Court ruled the NIRA illegal, trade groups reported yesterday.

Six cripples, arrested on charges of creating a disturbance in front of the Emergency Relief Bureau, 902 Broadway, were paroled for a hearing tomorrow when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Overton Harris in Yorkville Court.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 22 (AP). -- Joe Kirkwood, the Australian trick-shot artist, with a 35, 34 -- 69, teamed with the American veteran Macdonald Smith to defeat W. Lawson Little, British and American amateur champion, and the British pro, Abe Bailey, 1 up, in the final full practice round for the British open golf championship today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 22 (AP). -- Applause echoed through the huge city auditorium today as a report proposing that the church enter realms of politics and economics was presented to the Northern Baptist Convention.

President Roosevelt has declared that in this democracy there is no place for an aristocracy of wealth with inherited membership and that current financial returns to an individual should be limited. He has urged the use of the Federal powers of taxation for the reductions of huge property accumulations and the fixing of maximum incomes.
THE 1935 convention of the American Guild of Organists will begin tomorrow and continue through Friday, with headquarters at the Hotel Astor. Charles Henry Doersam is warden of the guild.

The problem of railroad reorganization moved preceptibly forward last week through developments here and in Washington. Significant among the moves was the filing of a reorganization plan with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by the Western Pacific Railroad, which thus became the first line to take this step since Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, recently urged prompt action of this kind.

SUMMER resorts, to which thousands will be traveling by the end of the coming week, are rapidly changing in character. They are becoming more sophisticated, less haphazard. Their interests are shifting from the purely physical and sporting -- outstanding characteristics of ten years ago -- and turning toward the cultural and esthetic.

SIGHTSEEING tours by special trains are being run by one British railway. Now a newsreel theatre is to be introduced on the regular express service between king's Cross and Leeds next month. The moving panorama of the countryside is to vie with the silver screen in a darkened cinematograph car that will seat an audience of forty-four persons.

WHEN one is speaking these days of the ubiquitous Summer theatres (as who isn't speaking these days!) the phrase "from Maine to Virginia" invariably seems to crop up. By that inclusive definition more than geographical boundaries are set; appropriate emphasis is placed upon the name of Maine, quite by chance.

In his annual report as president of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., made public yesterday, George W. Hodges of the Standard Statistics Company said that the end of the NRA marked "a turning point in the struggle of American business men to improve their standards of accurate advertising and fair dealing."

Relatives, friends and charity will share in the estate of Benjamin D. Traitel, who was for many years in the marble industry and a former treasurer of the New York Building Congress, according to his will, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22. -- Panama Canal passenger traffic, east and west bound, is moving heavier for the first six months of this year than for the same period since 1930, according to Roy V. Crowder, passenger traffic manager for the Grace Line.

THIS collection of sketches and caricatures of thirty-seven eminent Canadians is a clever and entertaining volume. Not all of the persons to whom it pays its compliments are familiar to American readers, but enough of them are fairly well known and it is skillful and witty enough all through to give zest to its perusal.

FRANK WATERS has written one of those tales of the West which are competing with English, Scandinavian and other "sagas" for popularity with those who like long drawn out family histories. If it be true that every man's life has a novel in it, it is just as true that every family has the stuff out of which a saga (in the corrupted modern use of the word) may be fabricated.
Alfred and George Monteverde, brothers from Portugal, crashed at 6:38 o'clock last night in an attempted take-off from Floyd Bennett Field for a non-stop fight to Rome. The fliers were not injured.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- When Harvard's varsity crew paddled over to the Red Top boathouse from Bartlett's Cove, after being defeated by Yale today, there were but few persons on hand to greet the oarsmen. The men were cheered by the small crowd, notwithstanding the unusually sound beating administered by Yale.

CLEVELAND, June 22. -- The Missouri Synod of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, in convention here today, voted to close the Concordia Theological Seminary at Springfield, Ill. But in view of the close ballot, 266 to 265, a motion to reconsider the question Monday was passed immediately.

NOW that the midtown area has but six first-run theatres in action, a slight falling-off in the number of new films is noticeable. Only four houses are sure of new bills; two may hold their current offerings for another week.

Two persons were injured seriously just before last midnight when the delivery truck on which they were riding to Manhattan on the Manhattan Bridge struck a traffic stanchion in the centre of the roadway near the Hester Street approach.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, June 22. -- Several leading officials have been arrested in the Karelian Soviet Republic, where the political situation has grown tense, according to refugees who have just crossed the Russian frontier into Finland.

The Roosevelt administration has quietly built up "the most efficient political organization ever created under our system of government," asserts Paul Mallon, Washington political commentator, in the leading article. "The Party Line-Up for 1936," in July Current History.

BARCELONA, June 3, 1985. AT the Teatro del Liceu the opera season was followed, as usual, by a brief engagement of the Ballets Russes of Monte Carlo, one of the regular Spring visitors most popular in the Catalonian capital. Each of the twelve performances, delighted a full house in old favorites and later repertory items selected from an odd dozen mountings.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22. -- Thrilling rallies featured the two polo matches in the Third Westbury Challenge Cup tourney at the Meadow Brook Club today as the Aiken Knights and the Old Westbury registered impressive victories by the lowest possible margin.

NOW that the midtown area has but six first-run theatres in action, a slight falling-off in the number of new films is noticeable. Only four houses are sure of new bills; two may hold their current offerings for another week.

The reorganization plan for the Butterick Company, which has been attacked by holders of some of its debentures, has been referred by Federal Judge John C. Knox to Special Master Joyce. Judge Knox said he would urge the special master to expedite the hearings on the plan, and to report his findings by July 12, since the company was in need of cash.

THE late Colonel T.E. Lawrence's famous story of the Arab revolt, "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom," is at last to be made available to the general public. The English edition is to be published by Jonathan Cape and the American one by Doubleday, Doran Co., who will bring it out in the Fall.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, founder of The National Union for Social Justice. is battling in the Superior Court of Cook County for his constitutional right to free speech. So his attorney, Samuel A. Ettelson, asserts in a petition to force from the Chicago Park District a permit to hold on Soldier Field a meeting of Father Coughlin's politico-economic organization, said by his supporters to number 200,000 members here.

LEE McLEAN had killed three men -- because he was perfectly sure they needed killing. When he had been tried, convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment, becoming the first lifer in brand-new Malamosa prison, pride of the new State, he said: "You figure this out your own way.

LONDON, May 30. THIS week the great theatre of Drury Lane opened its doors to celebrate the jubilee, but by no means the retirement, of Marie Tempest. Such occasions are rare; the last, for Ellen Terry's benefit, was before my time, and its predecessor for Nellie Farren is wrapped in the mists of the past.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 22. -- Another festival has been added to the Nazi calendar. Last night and tonight hundreds of thousands of young persons and Brown Shirt rulers joined in the ancient pagan ceremonial of honoring the Summer solstice.

STUDENTS at the Pennsylvania State College who have been employed by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA) on college relief projects made better grades for the first semester of this year than fellow-students not working for the FERA, according to a recently completed study.

PITTSBURGH, June 21. -- The University of Pittsburgh drew censure this week from the committe of the lower branch of the Legislature that investigated the status of academic freedom at the institution, but no decision was reached in the case that brought the inquiry -- the dismissal last Summer of Dr. Ralph E. Turner, a Professor of History.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Chattanooga-Lookout Mountain Park, the gift to the nation of the late Adolph S. Ochs and associates, became today the property of the government.

BARBARA WEBB writes with loving appreciation of the misty mountain country of Virginia. She takes a weary little New York shopgirl, convalescing from pneumonia, deeply in love with a man not suited to make her happy, and transports her to the spacious atmosphere of a Virginia town and a fresh, Grade A romance.

MOSCOW, June 21. -- The Anglo-German naval agreement of this week has made a profound impression upon Soviet officials. It is interpreted as a letting down of France -- and indirectly of the Soviet Union -- by Great Britain; as a signal for a renewed and intensified naval armament race in which even the United States must in time join, and as a first-rate diplomatic victory for Chancellor Hitler.

CHICAGO, June 22.--Professor John H. Wigmore, dean emeritus of Northwestern University Law School, returned yesterday from Japan, where for two months he has been organizing the completion of the translation and editing of the Japenese records of justice covering the period 1600-1860.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 22. -- His Elegance, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel's noted thoroughbred, completed one of his most successful campaigns in the show ring by capturing the premier laurels in the $200 Hunter Championship Stake, a feature of the closing session of the Watertown three-day horse show staged on the grounds of the Watertown Riding and Country Club today.

IN A season which has had an unusual number of provocative dance compositions to its credit, none perhaps has been of more potential interest than Charles Weidman's "Traditions," which with the assistance of Jose Limon and William Matons, he has presented at several New Dance League performances.
RYE BEACH, N.H., June 22 (AP). -- James M. Beck, former Solicitor General, said tonight the people's acceptance of recent Supreme Court decisions was gratifying.

When the Jonkers diamond arrived in port ten days ago on the United States liner President Roosevelt the freight charge was only 65 cents. The value of the diamond was not definitely stated, but its worth was indicated by the fact that it was insured for $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP). -- Extensive safeguards for the $9,000,000,000 in gold and silver bullion piled up in the nation's four mints are planned by the Treasury Department.

NEWSPAPERS have been found better than textbooks in teaching retarded overage children in the Wilkes-Barre schools. The discovery, made in the school year just closing, is of special import because of the increase everywhere of overage pupils due to lack of employment.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Two inevitable foes of national clay court tennis, Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, tiny retrieving genius from. Atlanta, and Frank Andzeg Paikowski, known exclusively outside his neighborhood in Milwaukee as Frankie Parker, will meet at last for the championship tomorrow.

THOSE readers who have been charmed and entertained by Alice Grant Rosman's previous romances, and who expect to be charmed and entertained by this one, will not be disappointed. On the other hand, readers who found reason -- in such comparatively shrewd and solid books as "Benefits Received" -- to hope that she would turn her distinguished gifts as a story teller to more substantial uses, most certainly will be.

Writing in The American Mercury of "Sons and Daughters of the Depression" Mrs. KATHARINE FULLERTON GEROULD turns our lingering troubles to favor and to prettiness. In '31 and '32 "everybody" was poor or poorer or affected to be. There was a democracy and solidarity of poverty.

Commodity prices showed few changes and business remained steady in the month that has elapsed since the NIRA was ruled out by the Supreme Court, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents pointed out in its June report, released yesterday.
THE perennial interest of the English in where the name "Beefeater" originated was emphasized recently when the picturesque guards at the Tower of London were debarred from joining a trade union.

ALBINOS are a perpetual source of zoological speculation, but the pure white porcupine out at the Bronx Zoo, which recently gave birth to an eleven-ounce coal-black offspring, is just another proof of Nature's strange equations, according to Dr. Charles V. Noback at the zoo hospital.
VATICAN CITY, June 22 (AP). -- Pope Plus today named Mgr. Francis X. Ford of the Maryknoll Fathers Vicar Apostolic of Kaying, China, Mgr. Ford thus becomes Bishop.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday, after a two-hour conference with Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and others, that he had called for a copy of the minutes of the March grand jury, which has petitioned him to supersede District Attorney William C. Dodge in an investigation of vice and rackets in New York County.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP). -- A forty-hour work week, with time and a half pay for overtime, emerged today as a possible standard for all voluntary codes under the new NRA.

CONFLICTING emotions and aims have this mildly addled industry in an even more bewildered state than usual. While the studios, for the first time in history, deliberately are planning Inferior pictures to occupy the second spot on double bills, there is talk also of "Hamlet" and "Romeo and Juliet" and other "class" productions.

The President surprised Congress and the nation on Wednesday with an unheralded message in which he urged that the Federal tax system be revised in line with "the movement toward progressive taxation of wealth and of income."

VIENNA, June 9, 1935. NOT since Toscanini's last visit has anything so completely bowled over the Viennese as Victor de Sabata's "Otello." Overnight the gray, spare, suave, but ascetic-looking conductor of the Milanese Scala who appears a full fifteen years older than he is, has become the undisputed idol of the Staatsoper.

IN the preparation of this book, say its authors, those engaged upon it, "studied, researched. and finally consulted a dozen or more men whose names loom largest in the fields of mental hygiene, psychiatry, psychoanalysis." Then, having made a synthesis of all the information collected, copies of the manuscript were sent to the authorities who had been consulted and afterward the errors of fact they had pointed out were corrected.
Honors at contract bridge have been eliminated from tournament scoring in a new code of duplicate rules made public yesterday by the American Bridge League.

Charges that the Soviet Government is "ruthlessly breaking" the Litvinoff agreement by spreading propaganda in the United States were made yesterday by Ralph M. Easley, of the National Civic Federation in a letter to Senator Capper of Kansas, who is on the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.--The colony will have an opportunity next Tuesday of seeing in action the Japanese golfing team which has been playing a series of matches in the United States and Canada under the sponsorship of the P.G.A.

THE amateur hour is now radio's most meteoric show. It is a sweepstakes of the air, thriving on the theory that amateur's luck is beginner's luck. Gayly the amateur "entertainer" is spinning radio's wheel of fortune and broadcasting, which flared and spread as a craze in 1920, now finds a new craze originating within itself.

PROFESSOR SCHUMAN of the University of Chicago has spent eight months in Hitler-Germany and probably no book could more aid in the understanding of the spirit and the working methods of Nazism than his study of the pathology of Hitler's dictatorship.

On the same day, last week, that three children were charged with shooting and killing a penniless painter in a vacant Jamaica lot, seven other youngsters -- all under 17 -- appeared in the "line-up" at Centre Street police headquarters, charged variously with vagrancy, petty thievery and larceny.

Striding through the stretch to a rolling undertone of applause and surprise, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery yesterday won the historic Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct in world's record time. Beaten off behind him and finishing as named were King Saxon and Omaha, champions in their spheres, but forced to take the dust of a horse which at last found himself after five defeats this season.

The average American high school girl has as deep an interest and broad a knowledge of the the American Merchant Marine and its problems as has the average high school boy, according to a committee of naval experts selected by the Propeller Club of the United States.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 22. -- A great piece was cut from Niagara's old and famous Table Rock section on the Canadian side, adjudged dangerous because of crevasses, by a spectacular heavy blast of black powder just before noon today.

Dropping from a ground-floor window into a dark alley fifteen feet below, Milton Lambert, 36 years old, fugitive ex-convict who was fleeing from an apartment at 911 Traphagen Street, North Bergen, H.J., drew the fire of a squad of policemen early yesterday morning and was wounded fatally.

PARENTS making last-minute decisions on Summer camps for their children should be wary of those which boast that their young charges all gain in weight. Four investigators who have made independent studies for the physical education department at Boston University agree on this point.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Hanging on the walls of relief offices throughout Washington is a map of the United States curiously barred and crossed with lines that divide it into 307 districts. These are the work districts under the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program, and the map is the basis of the entire program of the latest and greatest drive on unemployment.

Since no one seems to rise to the occasion, may I protest against the current program of featuring Lincoln and Lee as our only great men of the Civil War period? Republics have often enough been stigmatized as ungrateful, and a monumental example would now be the oblivion of the one man who saved our American nation -- General Grant.

THE world overseas is sending to America for cactus plants. The Eastern Hemisphere, as if it did not have thorny problems enough on its bands, desires to monkey with nature's foremost buzz-saw. Scientists and economists over there turn speculative eyes toward this weirdest family of the vegetable kingdom.

WEATHER conditions were more or less the gauge of retail sales last week. Where they were favorable, volume ran well ahead of a year ago. In this area the rain held down business to a small increase of last year, when there was also a spell of bad weather.

Over loud-speakers and head sets in Sing Sing prison last week the inmates heard the news: Alabama Pitts, star of the Sing Sing baseball and football teams, had been admitted to organized baseball by former Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis.

A handsome young man who calls himself Phelim O'Ferrell turns up at the office of Luther Crone, a California lawyer, and announces himself as the long-sought heir to part of the estate of the late Lord O'Ferrell of Galway. Crone examines his credentials and sends him on his way to the Rancho de la Luna, where the attorney of the O'Ferrell estate is visiting another heir.

The latest issue of the Moscow monthly "Teatr i Dramaturgia" contains some extremely illuminating statistics on the state of the theatre in the Soviet Union. A study of the figures, with some added calculations of my own, reveals, for instance, that in 1934 the entire city population of the Soviet Union had an average of nearly three theatre attendances per person.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 22. -- Worcester Polytechnic Institute will begin its annual ten-day techniquest tomorrow. During this period a group of school boys who have completed at least three years of study in high or preparatory school and who are recommended by their school principals will have an opportunity to discover what engineering is, whether engineering education appeals to them, and whether they have real ability in that line of work.

PARIS, June 22. -- Nothing has been accomplished, but it is asserted that some "misunderstandings" have been cleared up by the Paris visit of Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs. Mr. Eden left for Rome this evening.

The Society of Restaurateurs, at a meeting at the Hotel Nassau, Long Beach, L.I., voted unanimously yesterday to maintain the minimum wages and maximum hours established under the Restaurant Code. Paul Henkel, president of the society, who presided, suggested that recalcitrant members of the industry might be brought into line by a State licensing system similar to that in Oregon.

PARIS. THE beach scene at Deauville, St. Juan, or any of the other resorts where the Famous Forty congregate, might easily be mistaken for one of the Folies-Bergere, were it not that a real sea replaces a back drop.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Efforts to establish an adequate national merchant marine have cost the government about $800,000,000 in the last fifteen years and have left very little to show for the money. Confronted by these facts, the present administration proposes to do something shortly in the hope of promoting a merchant marine more effectively and less expensively, but what the plan will be is as yet uncertain.

ROME, June 22. -- Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, is expected to reach Rome tomorrow evening for a series of talks with Premier Benito Mussolini which it is hoped will be concluded in a single day.

DODGE CITY, Kan., June 21. -The farm piture emerging in the high plains, where the wheat-allotment checks have made farmers conscious of parity prices for their chief cash crop, reveals a better informed, more quick to act and better organized farming population.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Merchandising locally was again washed out by persistent rainfall during the week. While there was a fairly good volume of trade with the larger department stores, the total volume was below normal for the month, and it is probable that the final June totals will show rather substantial losses by comparison with last year.

THERE is a peculiar fascination in traveling "topically" through England and concentrating on segregated "layers" of past centuries. Just now, following ceremonies in Durham Cathedral commemorating the twelve hundredth anniversary of the death of the ecclesiastical historian,

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP). -- Ripper Collins of the Cards hit his thirteenth and fourteenth home runs to take the National League lead today as the world champions beat the Phillies, 9 to 3 and 10 to 9 in a pair of slugging matches. The two teams made a total of 52 hits, St. Louis getting 31 and the Phils 21.

CHERBOURG, France, June 22. -- With a crew of six and carrying 3,170 gallons of gasoline, the French four-motored airplane Southern Cross left here today in an attempt to break the non-stop distance record. Its objective is Konakry, Africa.

NOW that Summer is officially here, the art world will be turning its attention increasingly to the activities of the out-of-town colonies, where Summer shows have already opened or are on the not distant horizon.

A movement to re-establish Flushing Bay as a boating centre was inaugurated during recent weeks with the organization of the Boca-Ceiga Boat Association. The group is comprised of outboard and inboard enthusiasts of not only the clubs in the vicinity of Flushing Bay but of several other sections.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22. -- The flower exhibits prepared by children attracted keen interest this afternoon at the Westchester County flower show being held here. There were more than 250 entries. The judges said that these displays surpassed any previous ones by the youngsters.

OTTAWA, June 22. -- A delegation of eight, representing 2,000 Western relief camp strikers, asked Prime Minister Bennett today for work, wages, social and unemployment insurance and the demilitarization of the camps. They were told by the Prime Minister that the government would not be "taken by the throat" and that they must return to their camps and cease trespassing on the railways.

Joe Louis, the man they call the Brown Bomber from Detroit, makes his bid for pugilism's "big time" Tuesday night at the Yankee Stadium, where he faces the huge Primo Carnera of Italy in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.

WHEN Huey Long and Milo Reno and Father Coughlin thunder their anathemas at the Roosevelt administration and the existing order, they are but carrying on an old American custom. The nature of their appeals, the remedies which they prescribe, fit nicely into political tradition.

THESE are the days that women take off in order that they may put on. Paradoxical? Not at all. They take off as much in the way of clothing as they can in order that they may enjoy the freedom of the beaches, and they put on -- tan, of course. A golden brown skin is good camouflage.

TWO million boys and girls are filing out of school and college this month to join the waiting throngs in the employment offices. Like thousands of their ten million predecessors since 1929, many will wait in vain. Yet beyond the office windows already gleams a prospect newly brightening for youth.

POLYGNOTOS VAGIS, the sculptor, has a new idea for Bryant Park. He wants to see incorporated there an open-air Museum of Contemporary American Sculpture. "Such a museum," he writes, "should have a far-reaching educational effect.

THE number of books on Elizabethan England would no doubt fill a small library. But to call this extensive and diligent work by Louis B. Wright just another such book would be to miss entirely its unique position in that long bibliography.

Early yesterday a 19-year-old youth and his 45-year-old father set out from their home at 365 First Avenue on a hunting expedition. Their object was wild game, preferably of the winged species; their equipment was a burlap bag and a sling shot; their destination was Central Park.

DAWSON SPRINGS, Ky., June 22 (AP). -- Leaving four persons dead, Kentucky's sixth flood threat of the year sloshed southward tonight before a trail of undermined dwellings and severed highways. Bridges were washed away and barns were blown down in storms in Central and Western Kentucky.
OMAHA, Neb., June 21. -- The thoughtful Corn-Belt farmer is beginning to wonder if livestock prices have not climbed just about as far as they ought to until consumer purchasing power catches up.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 22. -- Two amateur fliers were killed instantly at 7:30 o'clock tonight when a monoplane in which they were flying dropped 1,500 feet and crashed on a field near Nassau Boulevard and Argyle Road, Munson.

PARIS, June 22. -- Andre Tardieu presided today at the ceremonies of the laying of the cornerstone for the new room to be annexed to the Franco-American Museum at Blerancourt, in which will be placed a permanent exhibition of souvenirs of American volunteer ambulance drivers with the French army during the World War.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 23. -- Alabama Pitts, a few months ago just a Sing Sing convict with a flair for athletics, made the grade today to the satisfaction of 7,752 howling fans in his debut in organized baseball.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., June 23. -- Arthur Williams gave a luncheon today at Brook Corners, his country home here, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hobart Davis of New York, who will sail early in July for Scotland, where Mr. Davis will finish "Tree Toad," his new book which is to be published in October.

The slight upward trend since the beginning of the year in the number of persons on relief who have found employment in private industry continued in May, the home-relief division yesterday informed Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

The reform spirit that St. John the Baptist represented will always achieve more permanent results than "so-called revolutionary activity," the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington said yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. Dr. Darlington's sermon commemorated St. John the Baptist's Day, which will he observed today in many churches throughout the city.

OLD FIELD, L.I., June 23. -- Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation, released his eleven show horses from their stable on his Widewater estate here tonight because of danger of a fire spreading from a nearby burning garage. He then mounted to the stable roof, and with the aid of two guests, played water from a garden hose on the smoking shingles.

Wilho Winika, New York A.C. representative, yesterday added to his team's already huge point total accumulated in Saturday's senior metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at Glen Park, Yonkers, by capturing the postponed javelin throw at Travers Island.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- A "celestial nobody," a tiny speck in the heavens hitherto identified only by a number, has been revealed as the third ranking member among the spiral nebulae in the cosmic royal family of island universes, it was reported here today by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard University Observatory.

Regard for the Federal Constitutions of the United States and Canada should not stand in the way of "drastic modifications" in them if that is necessary for the prompt provision of social security, the Church Conference of Social Work declared yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 23. -- The twenty-first annual service commemorating the 155th anniversary of the Battle of Springfield was held in the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon under the auspices of the Passaic Valley Chapter of the New Jersey Society, Sons of the American Revolution.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- With indications of good crops of oats and hay, comparatively little new speculative interest is coming into the oats trade. Cereal processors are picking up a few futures on weak spots. Usually country holders in the best oats sections are asking for bids for new crop shipments late in August.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 23. -- The average American housewife becomes tired because she is not motion-minded, is the opinion held by Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth, consulting engineer, of 68 Eagle Rock Way, who will sail Friday on the American Banker for London, England, where she will address the Sixth International Congress of Scientific Management.

PARIS, June 22. -- The violent crisis recently experienced in France is now over, in the opinion of financiers here. The reversal of opinion which might have been hoped for has not occurred, however, and exported capital is not coming back and bears on francs are not covering.

The durable goods manufacturing industries have made more rapid progress toward recovery than the non-durable goods industries, according to a study of employment, payrolls and earnings for 1929 and 1935, and made by the National Industrial Conference Board.

DRESDEN, June 23. -- All is in readiness for the world premiere tomorrow night of Richard Strauss's eleventh opera, "The Silent Woman." This is an adaptation of Ben Jonson's comedy of the same name by the Jewish novelist, Stefan Zweig.

CARLSTADT, N.J., June 23. -- Fred Jacoby Jr., America's leading professional outboard driver, whose triumphs have been scored up and down the coast from New England to Florida, returned today to the waterway on which he learned to operate the skimming hydroplanes to win first places in the three professional classes on a regatta program of nine events.

DUBLIN, June 23. -- Maurice Twomey, chief-of-staff of the Irish Republican Army, who has been on the run from police for weeks, and Sean McBride, member of the I.R.A. executive council, came out from hiding for a few hours today.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., June 23. -- Battered by heavy waves as she crawled along the East Rockaway Inlet jetty with the aid of her husband and another man, Mrs. John H. Feinne of 67-01 Fifty-third Road, Maspeth, Queens, lost a handbag containing $2,000 in jewelry today as she clung to a rock to prevent the seas from washing her into the ocean.

Disappointed in their efforts to obtain a fair representation in the Legislature through the normal channels of reapportionment, certain residents of Queens sought a court order to compel the Secretary of State to certify on the ballots this Fall the names of two more Senators and five more Assemblymen from that county.

Cotton futures moved last week within about the same narrow range as in the previous week. Trading was in moderate volume, except for government operations, switching of commitments to new crop months and some Liverpool straddling.

OTTAWA, June 23. -- The Canadian House has pushed a bill authorizing the government to immediately revalue $91,000,000 of gold held by the Bank of Canada as reserve against the currency, and to use the profit as an exchange stabilization fund if the government decides to set up such a fund.

Attorney General John J Bennett Jr. will appoint a prominent attorney as a Special Deputy Attorney General to conduct the inquiry into organized vice and crime if Governor Lehman decides that District Attorney William C. Dodge should be supplanted, it was reliably reported last night.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 23. -- Drinking scenes in motion pictures were condemned at the Northern Baptist Convention today as delegates began consideration of a social action program which goes to a vote tomorrow.

Staging a concentrated drive in the last four chukkers, the Governors Island poloists overcame a three-goal handicap to down the First Division four, 8 -- 7, in the fifth and final game of the 1934 series for the Colonel Joseph H. Colyer Jr. Trophy at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.

One of the destructive tendencies in current thought is the fact that so much of our religion comes, not from God, but from man, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver said in his sermon yesterday morning at John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street.

World industrial production was generally higher in April than the average in the first quarter of the year, according to the monthly statement on foreign economic conditions issued Saturday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Output was considerably larger than a year ago in all the major countries except France, Belgium, Switzerland and the Netherlands, the board states.

TOKYO, Monday, June 24. -- The Chahar affair was settled last night when Major Gen. Kenji Doihara of Japan and General Chin Teh-chun, chairman of the Chahar provincial government, signed a memorandum embodying six agreed terms. These, as reported here, are:

SKYTOP, Pa., June 23 (AP). -- Baron Waldemar von Zedtwitz of New York and B. Jay Becker of Philadelphia won the all-American contract pair championship of the forty-fifth annual American Whist League Congress today with a top score of 498 1/2 points.

The increase in passenger traffic reported by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in 1934 resulted, at least in part, from improved service and equipment, Daniel Willard, president, says in his report for the year. Passenger revenue increased 3.56 per cent, while passengers carried increased 9.34 per cent and passenger-miles 7.06 per cent.

The net deficit of the institutions in the group operated by the Society of the New York Hospital last year was $756,455, which was $178,701 less than in 1933, according to its 163d annual report, made public yesterday. It was the first year of the hospital's operation at its new centre at Sixty-eighth Street and the East River.

The Summer theatre will take a full stride forward this week. Four new plays will have their world premieres, if that term is not too weighty for the rustic stages. The majority of attractions, as usual, will be revivals of plays already tested on Broadway.
DETROIT, June 23 (AP). -- Wildness of three Detroit pitchers -- Joe Sullivan, Clyde Hatter and Elon Hogsett -- was a major factor in the Tigers' defeat by the Senators today, 12 to 7.

Merle De Vore Johnson, illustrator, bibliographer and book dealer of 65 East Fifty-third Street, was reported to be in a serious condition at French Hospital last night following an automobile accident in which he was injured critically Saturday night.

BERLIN, June 23. -- The vast expenditures of the National Socialist government for its double program of eliminating unemployment and restoring Germany's military and naval power has raised the question in many minds both at home and abroad how long this spending process can be continued without producing national bankruptcy.

NEWARK, N.J., June 23. -- John Quartuccio, 67 years old, of 93 Winans Avenue, Cranford, N.J., sat in front of a voice-recording machine in police headquarters here yesterday and heard what police say was a reproduction of his own voice, boasting of arson jobs allegedly committed by him in the northern part of the State.

Thousands of persons who flocked to beaches, parks and picnic grounds yesterday enjoyed comfortable weather under fair skies accompanied by moderate temperatures. Nearly all the beaches reported record crowds.

The dance and music of Caribbean and South American countries was presented in a program at the Town Hall last night under the auspices of the magazine, The Americas, and its Spanish edition, Sin Fronteras. Billed as a "Latin-American Folk Festival," the program attracted a large audience that evinced signs of enthusiasm throughout the evening.
MONTE CARLO, June 23. -- Monaco, where fortunes are lost and won on the turn of a wheel, seethed with unrest today in a national crisis born of the depression.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 23. -- Music is again to be a daily feature at the Newport Casino. Beginning July 1 and continuing daily for nine weeks, there will be afternoon concerts by an instrumental trio. The daily concerts are being brought back, after an absence of two years, by the executive committee, headed by Arthur Curtiss James.

To reform the nation by years of the equalization of wealth is a splendid but rather idealistic plan. A better one would be to reform the people first and then distribute among them the wealth of the nation.

Prices tended down in trading that speeded or lagged by fits and starts in commodity futures markets here last week, the exceptions being coffee, wool tops and some standard tin months. In the cash markets all grains and wool tops advanced, but raw sugar, coffee, cocoa, dairy products, tin, cotton, printcloths, silk and rubber declined.

The protective committee for holders of bonds of the Kansas City, Fort Scott Memphis Railway Company of the St. Louis-San Francisco System says in a report to them that the trustees of the railway in their annual report for 1934 stated that the roadway and equipment had been maintained at a high and steadily improving standard.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- An "American labor policy" is being evolved, Secretary Perkins states in the annual report of the Department of Labor, made public today.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., June 23. -- Standing up to his eyes in water, a cigar in his left hand and a fish pole and line upon which a live fish still struggled in his right hand, the lifeless body of Arno Kerver, merchant and political leader, was found in Hart's Pond, a popular fishing resort near here today.

HAVANA, June 21. -- Exports from the United States to Cuba during the first eight months of the new trade agreement were valued at $36,823,447, against $21,264.378 during the corresponding eight months of 1933 and 1934, or an increase of $15,559,069.

Lon Warneke was a distinct menace to the Giants last season, but this year he is just another fellow named Joe. A crowd of 15,000 left the Polo Grounds yesterday firmly convinced that Warneke's mastery is over after the rampaging Giants had inflicted an 8-to-0 shut-out on Charley Grimm's Cubs.

BERLIN, June 23. -- Anglo-German relations continue to supply a prolific theme for German political speculation. Sunday editorials again today are preoccupied with reviewing the more profound political implications of the naval accord with Great Britain and its repercussions abroad.

LONDON, June 23. -- The first phase of the present European naval situation ended today with the departure of the German delegates, which was marked by a significant statement from their leader, Joachim von Ribbentrop. Also the Foreign Office issued a communique, a step that is most unusual on a Sunday unless the officials think a matter is of special consequence.

Many New York fresh-water fishermen are journeying across the Hudson these days to try conclusions with the black bass in New Jersey's well-stocked streams and lakes. The season opened in our neighboring State on June 15. In New York the campaign for the coveted bronzebacks starts on July 1, which is also the inaugural date in Connecticut and Pennsylvania.

After having denied himself to callers and conferences since he left Washington last Thursday, President Roosevelt took time last night, as he was returning to the capital, to chat gravely with a delegation of children in the Pennsylvania station.

Marc Connelly, whose play, "The Green Pastures," was purchased recently for filming by Warner Brothers, has been signed by the company to prepare the screen adaptation of the play and to officiate as co-director of the film, it was announced yesterday by Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- An additional $100,000,000 in 3 per cent Treasury bonds of the 1946-48 series was offered to the investing public today by Secretary Morgenthau.

Mr. RUSH D. HOLT, elected a Senator from West Virginia last Fall, reached the ripe constitutional age of 30 on June 10. He had wisely refrained from presenting his credentials at the beginning of the session and waited until he came to full Senatorial age. Friday he was admitted by a vote of 62 to 17, the minority consisting of four Democrats and thirteen Republicans.
An alert young woman secretary caused the arrest late Saturday night of an alleged confidence game operator who attempted to fleece her of $900 by use of the old underworld telegram racket.

NUREMBERG, Germany, June 23. -- A vast assemblage of 200,000 persons at the Summer solstice festival on Hesenberg Mountain listened to an address today by General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Reich Minister of Aviation and Prussian Premier.
BOSTON, June 23 (AP). -- For the second straight day a Gus Suhr homer turned the tide for Pittsburgh today when the Pirates took a double-header from the Braves, 4 -- 3 and 7 -- 4.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 23. -- For the past eight weeks a freezing east wind has been blowing from the North Sea across the links of the Honorable Company of Edinburgh Golfers, over which the British open championship starts tomorrow.

One is impressed with the frequent reference to the number of new automobiles seen on the highways, and the increase in gasoline and automobile license taxes, as evidences of renewed prosperity. They are no more evidences of substantial prosperity than the excessive construction of spectacular highways is an evidence of prosperity.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week showed little of the nervousness and wide fluctuations of earlier weeks. More settled political and financial conditions in Europe, particularly in France where the Chamber of Deputies is in recess, aided in the evenness of the market.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 23. -- The supremacy of Baroness Maud Levi in metropolitan tournament play was asserted once more today when she carried off the Eastern clay court tennis crown a week after winning the New York State title at Jackson Heights.

With Johnny Babich taking the worst beating of his brief major-league career, the Dodgers yesterday were flattened by the Cardinals in the first game of a double-header at Ebbets Field, 16 to 2, while nearly 20,000 fans booed themselves hoarse.

Irish societies of New York City are already planning to make next year's St. Patrick's Day parade not only the "biggest and best" they have ever organized, but to hold it again on Fifth Avenue despite a reported movement by merchants to have it shifted elsewhere to cause less interruption of business.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP). -- The White Sox and Red Sox divided their Sunday double-header before 30,000 today, Boston pounding out an 8 to 2 victory in the nightcap after Chicago had taken the opener, 4 to 2.

To any one acquainted with the plague spots of child labor which remain, the editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES "Labor and NRA" strikes too optimistic a note, with its easy concession that "doubtless even 5 per cent was too large a fraction" of the children 10 to 15 years of age to be at work.

Twenty-nine women and twenty men who have been taking an intensive course at the Salvation Army Training College, 1,771 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, since last September will receive their commission as officers tonight at the Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 23. -- Driving through a succession of thunder squalls and playing tag with lightning bolts during the night, D. Spencer Berger's schooner Mandoo in Class A. Parkman D. Howe's ten-meter Shawara in the racing division and Harrison Tweed's schooner Sewanna in Class B were victors today in the Eastern Yacht Club's ocean race from New London.

The Southern District Federal Court of Illinois has authorized the St. Louis Gas Coke Corporation to file its amended plan of reorganization dated June 1, 1935, and has authorized the trustee in bankruptcy, George B. Evans, to submit the plan to creditors and stockholders for their approval or disapproval.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- To check the reported increasing flow of untaxed and bootleg liquor to retail liquor stores and night clubs, the alcohol tax unit of the Treasury has requested an allotment of $1,086,941 from the work-relief fund. The allotment must have the approval of the President.

The signing of a long-term contract for an office and showroom building on Fifth Avenue in the midtown section was announced yesterday. The lease is for twenty-one years at rentals totaling $1,000,000 for the term.

The Treasury is offering today $100,000,000 in 3 per cent bonds, to be sold on a competitive basis to the highest bidder. This is the second such experiment to be made recently. A similar issue, offered last month, resulted in a considerable oversubscription and a substantial premium for the Government.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, June 23. -- Dr. Vladimir Matchek returned to Zagreb this evening and was welcomed at the station with great enthusiasm by huge crowds of his supporters.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP.). -- Salvage of the better trade features of NRA was voted today by representatives of all major millinery markets of the United States with the exception of the Pacific Coast, at a meeting called to form the "National Millinery Association, Inc."

BOSTON, June 23 (AP). -- A strike of about 200 seamen held five oil tankers of the Cities Service Company in four widely-separated ports tonight as the strikers laid plans to spread the tie-up to the remainder of the company's fleet of twenty-five ships. The men are demanding higher wages.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The status of major legislation pending in Congress is as follows:

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Bosch was likened to Martin Luther by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler in a sermon at St. Paul's Lutheran Church, 145 West 123d Street, yesterday morning. The occasion was the celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the ordination of Dr. Bosch, who, for the last thirty-one years, has been pastor of St. Paul's.

LONDON, June 22. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on June 19 at 68.1. This compares with 68.1 a fortnight before, 68.6 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP). -- The Reds came from behind in both games to defeat the Phillies today in a double-header, 6 to 5 and 5 to 2, before 7,500 fans.

BERLIN, June 22. -- Reich revenue from taxation in May was 663,000,000 marks, against 576,000,000 marks in May, 1931. The report on the 1934-35 budget issued belatedly by the Finance Ministry shows a relatively satisfactory result, the deficit not being in excess of official predictions, but it throws no light on the means of covering expenditures for rearmaments. The deficit was 354,000,000 marks.

With the departure Saturday midnight of the liner St. Louis with more than 900 passengers for Cobb, Southampton, Boulogne and Hamburg, the Hapag-Lloyd Line started a week's program of transportation that calls for the sailing from here of six ships with 5,800 passengers.

Promptly at 10 o'clock yesterday morning Captain Bob Bartlett eased his good ship, the schooner Effie M. Morrissey, out of her berth at West Brighton, S.I., to start the first leg of her ninth voyage to the Arctic.

Norcross S. Tilney of Orange, N.J., was the only seeded player active yesterday in the eighth annual men's Eastern clay court tennis championship at the Jackson Heights Club. The Princeton captain, seventh ranking entrant, moved into the third round with victories over two strong opponents.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, N.J., June 23. -- Seven New York gunmen, equipped with hand grenades, high-powered rifles, nine revolvers and automatic pistols, tear-gas guns and tear-gas bombs, were seized at daybreak here today by thirty policemen in a riverfront bungalow.

PARIS, June 23. -- What promises to be one of the most important world business meetings since the depression began six years ago will open here tomorrow when the International Chamber of Commerce starts its eighth biennial congress.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Determination "to do nothing that could be interpreted by any stretch of the imagination as interference with the freedom of the press" was expressed today by Secretary Wallace.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 23. -- With the veteran Cecil Smith setting the pace at No. 2, the hard-driving Texas four conquered the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 6 to 5, in the weekly high-goal polo match at the Sands Point Club today.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 23. -- Summer military ceremonies at the State encampment reservation here were started today when Governor Harold G. Hoffman reviewed marine reserve corps troops of a provisional regiment formed from New York, Philadelphia, Newark, Jersey City and Elizabeth contingents in training here.

These last-minute reprieves which are being granted to shows avowedly destined for the block are becoming as regular as Saturday night, what with business so uncertain as it is. Now it is "Ceiling Zero" which -- announced to end its engagement the night before last -- will continue by judicial order of Brock Pemberton, its producer, who found the week-end attendance too good for an execution.

Additional changes in the proposed reorganization plan of the Celotex Company were announced yesterday by William B. Nichols, chairman of the reorganization committee, who said the modified plan will be submitted to the Federal court at Wilmington, Del., for approval on July 1.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., June 23. -- Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, the new president of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, accepted today the offer of Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, to allow the Young Republican organization to participate in the councils of the Republican State Committee.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 23. -- Equal alimony for men and women and equal rights in breach of promise suits, if they are to be allowed, were demanded by National Women's Party leaders at the conclusion of a regional conference here today.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 23. -- Harry McArdle, who was pretty fast as a foot racer some five years ago, won his first canoe championship today on the glistening blue waters of Zachs Bay when he crossed the finish line in his aluminum craft, Wanderlust, to annex the title for canvas-decked class A sailing craft, the feature event of the Long Island regatta jointly sponsored by the State Park Department and The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

SEATTLE, June 23 (AP). -- Alaska's Matanuska Valley was pictured today as a "dusty, mosquito-infested country" instead of a promised land by thirty-one California transient workers after their return here from the government's colonization project.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Senator Borah went to the defense of President Roosevelt's new tax program today as the President's own leaders continued in a state of confusion over its immediate legislative future.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Another development in the contention over the Omnibus Banking Bill occurred today when Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, issued a statement asserting that bank deposit insurance would not expire one week from tomorrow, but would merely undergo a "transition from a temporary to a permanent form" of deposit insurance.

Wrestling with mortal woes, however hard they may seem, is a discipline of the soul which the "man of faith" will see as a blessing, the Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Savage, executive secretary of the New York Presbytery, said yesterday in his sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Thirty-seventh Street.

By direction of Cardinal Hayes, communicants of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York began yesterday a vigil of six days of prayer for the ending of persecution of the church in Mexico, which he declares is "the death struggle of humanity."
The report of the Governor's Commission on Unemployment Relief said that the following "conservative results" of the operation of the Home Relief Bureau were "worthy of enumeration":

MINNEAPOLIS, June 23. -- A remedy for sudden heart deaths from such causes as angina pectoris and coronary thrombosis, discovered in a daring new method of temporarily stopping human hearts, was described to the Summer meeting of the leaders of American science beginning a week's session here today.

The semi-annual award of medals and scholarships by the School Art League will be made to high school children at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Ten scholarships and seventy-seven medals will be awarded. The scholarships are awarded through competition and are financed through the cooperation of the league, the high schools and the art schools.
