Up in the "wilds" of the Hutchinson River Parkway, near its juncture with the Boston Post Road, more than 100 Boy Scouts, picked representatives from the troops of the fifteen Bronx districts, closed their tenth annual borough rally yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Traders in grain on the Board of Trade here who are short of corn are puzzled by the situation in the July, with an open interest of 15,455,000 bushels in that delivery. The open interest in all corn on the Exchange is 38,800,000 bushels.

BRADLEY BEACH, N.J., June 23. -- Factionalism in Zionist ranks throughout the United States was deplored by Morris Rothenberg of New York, president of the Zionist Order of America, in an address here today at the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Order Sons of Zion.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 23. -- Mrs. Irving H. Taylor, chairman of the Mainstone Club ladies' golf committee, announces the first ladies' kicker handicap match for Tuesday. The club's annual ladies' day will be held July 25. Among the events scheduled are a straight handicap, which will be played in the morning; a golf luncheon served at noon, and a driving and l putting contest in the afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP). -- Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta established himself today as a master of the clay courts, defeating Frank Parker of Milwaukee in the final of the national championships, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

PEORIA, Ill., June 23. -- Based on the first day's results, the experiment of Marshall Field Co. in sending a modern merchandising caravan into the Mississippi Valley on a quest for business among the retailers, instead of waiting for retailers to come to the store, will be a success.

Ordinarily a patient man, Lieutenant Cuthbert Behan of Brooklyn police headquarters was nettled at 3 A.M. yesterday when three youths reported the disappearance of an automobile containing a crate of twenty-five pigeons. The boys warned that unless the car was recovered promptly they would "call Mayor La Guardia."

In a discussion of the United States Supreme Court's decision on the NRA and its effects upon business recovery, the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of its publication, The Guaranty Survey, hails the ruling as "one of the most momentous decisions in the court's history," asserting that it has "removed some shackles from private trade" and has made business men in general more hopeful regarding the course of recovery.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., June 23. -- Led by Edmund H. Driggs Jr., the New York State amateur titleholder, the Garden City Golf Club aggregation today won the club team championship in the fourteenth annual tournament of the Long Island Golf Association over the 6,825-yard Timber Point course.
The training grind is over, and now Joe Louis and Primo Carnera are awaiting the bell that will send them into action over the fifteen-round route at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night.
In your issue of June 17 there appeared a letter taking exception to the requirements of the Engineers' Registration Law in this State.

LONDON, June 22. -- In the welcome absence of any excitement in international politics and finance, the financial markets here have been free to devote their attention to domestic affairs. A review of the political and financial situation at home leaves the market in an optimistic frame of mind.

The Power Authority of the State of New York, through its chairman, Frank P. Walsh, made public yesterday a letter to the members of the Board of Estimate, charging "misinformation" and "hasty conclusions" were contained in remarks made before the board by Joseph M. Proskauer, counsel to the Consolidated Gas system, at the recent hearing on a municipal power plant.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- No processing tax is proposed on newsprint under the amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act, Secretary Wallace said today in a letter to Jerome D. Barnum, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- July wheat last week was within a fraction of a new low record for the season, while September and December touched new low levels. Prices on other grains, although declining at times, failed to reach new low figures.

Holding that unemployment and public relief would remain as governmental problems for some years to come, the Governor's Commission on Unemployement Relief in a report to Governor Lehman on the administration of home relief in New York City, made public yesterday, urged that the City Charter be revised to permit home relief on a permanent basis and the ultimate consolidation of all forms of public assistance.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

To shake off life's heaviness and really appreciate the beauties of nature and the world, Christians were urged to don "the garment of praise," in his sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans, pastor of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

BERLIN, June 23. -- Christ's words "my kingdom is not of this world" has now become evidently an official theme of Nazi leaders in attacking the stubbornly independent attitude of the majority of Catholic and Protestant churches.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- The self-acknowledged "'No' man of Washington," Secretary Ickes, today fitted an aggressive defense of his policies into the inside story of the Public Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Encouraged by the marked increase in recent months in the privately financed building field, the Roosevelt administration has decided to concentrate once again upon the housing campaign of the Federal Housing Administration.

" Even the youngest amongst us is not infallible," said BENJAMIN JOWETT to his Balliol students. Some thought like that must have occurred to the leaders of the Young Republican Club of this city at Alexandria Bay on Saturday. At least they found out that the youngest politician among them was not invincible.

The estimated cost of new building construction and repairs for which permits were issued in May throughout the United States showed a slight advance over the preceding month and a marked gain over May one year ago, reports Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Eleven additional registration statements, totaling $62,528,337, of which $57,070,507 represents new issues, have been filed under the Securities Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP). -- Six pitchers failed to stem a Philadelphia batting onslaught today and the Browns dropped both ends of a double-header with the Athletics before 7,500 Sunday fans. The Athletics won the first game, 11 to 7, and the second, 13 to 3.

ATHENS, June 23. -- "Despite War Minister George Kondylis's shift to the monarchists, there can be no monarchist attempt to overturn the republic this Summer because the royalists are still too weak for revolution. That's why I feel free to leave for the United States tomorrow," declares former Premier Alexander Papanastasiou, who has taken Eleutherios Venizelos's place as chief of the Greek republicans.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Absence of leadership as well as of outside speculative trade, combined with indifference on the part of local professional traders, has placed the world's wheat and other grain markets in a position which the oldest men in the business here never have seen before.

DUBLIN, June 23. -- Wild scenes marked the Republicans' annual pilgrimage to the grave of Wolfe Tone in Bodenstown, County Kildare, today when thousands of the Irish Republican Army and the Citizen Army came into violent conflict.

Bishop William T. Manning dedicated yesterday the new chapel of St. Luke the Physician at Sea View Hospital, New Springville, S.I. The chapel, which will seat 200, was erected through contributions on land provided by the city, which operates the hospital.

Reports on the achievements of the conference of the International Labor Office were broadcast yesterday from Geneva by Harold Butler, director, and John G. Winant, assistant director. Their talks, made in response to questions put by Spencer Miller Jr. of the Workers Educational Bureau of America, were broadcast in this country by the WABC-Columbia network.

PEIPING, June 23. -- Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace's expedition to Mongolia to search for drought-resisting grasses and plants is proving a source of embarrassment to United States diplomatic and military officials here.

That the course of markets and of general business is apt to be dominated by the "psychology" of investors, producers and consumers, that the state of mind in such quarters is always influenced and sometimes absolutely shaped by events at Washington, and that recent developments at the capital have repeatedly been disquieting, every one recognizes.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 23. -- David Slade, counsel for Mrs. Eva Coo, announced today he had filed with Governor Lehman an affidavit indicating that Mrs. Martha Clift, Mrs. Eva Coo's accomplice in the murder of Harry Wright, was "hoaxed" before the trial to influence her testimony.

The B.M.T. is unwilling to let the tentative agreement for the city's purchase of its rapid-transit properties at a net price of $185,000,000 go to public hearings before the Transit Commission until similar agreements have been reached by the city with the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company.

Sixty-five thousand Zionists went to polling places in many parts of the nation yesterday to elect fifty-seven delegates to the nineteenth World Zionist Congress, which will meet in Lucerne, Switzerland, on Aug. 20. Early scattered returns, telephoned and telegraphed last night to the central election board here, indicated a victory for the slate put in the field by eight labor organizations.

The anti-religious laws of Mexico are a potential menace to the Government of the United States because they strike at a fundamental tenet of our Constitution "the right to freedom of religious conscience and belief," according to Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Pattick's Cathedral, who read Cardinal Hayes's pastoral letter on the Mexican situation at high mass yesterday.

BERLIN, June 22. -- The naval agreement with Great Britain, although welcomed in business circles, had no stimulating effect on the markets. The Boerse was dominated by the outlook for the French franc, which induced favorable judgment on the future of the reichsmark and therefore caused selling of stocks bought recently in fear of mark depreciation.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP). -- The arrest of Daniel Mercer, 45, special police guard at the Federal Reserve Bank here, on a charge of attempting to dispose of loot from exclusive Beverly Hills homes, was announced today by Police Lieutenant Samuel Miller, who estimated the value of the loot at $100,000.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., June 23. -- The pillow-fighting is over, and peace is settling over the disturbed area of Pompton. Shufflin' Joe Louis, the Dark Destroyer of Detroit, has stopped picking on his hired help and will now fill in the time gently and placidly until he shuffles into the ring against Primo Carnera, Il Ponderoso of the pugilistic world.

Administrative changes and appointments at Columbia University for next year were announced yesterday. Those named to serve on the university council until 1938 are Professor Harrison R. Steeves, Columbia College; Professor Austin P. Evans, faculty of political science; Professor Robert H. Fift, faculty of philosophy; Professor Hal T. Beans, faculty of pure science; Professor Paul R. Mort and Professor Benjamin R. Andrews, faculty of Teachers College, and Professor Noel T. Dowling, faculty of law.

The State Legislature will never again permit a recurrence of the conditions which existed before the collapse of the mortgage guaranty companies, Carl Pack, chairman of the New York State Assembly Committee on Mortgage and Real Estate, said last night in a radio broadcast over Station WOR.

NEW HAVEN, June 22. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82, which compares with 82.3 the week before, 82.3 two weeks before, 82.3 three weeks before and 82.7 four weeks before.

Two representatives of the Research Institute of Civic Development of Hanover, Germany, arrived here yesterday for a tour of this country to take motion pictures of seventy-seven cities, towns, villages and crossroads bearing the name of the German city.

An industrial self- government plan formulated by the National Association of Tobacco Distributers, Inc., which claims to have a membership of 3,100, has been put into effect in the wholesale tobacco industry, to replace the NRA code, it was announced yesterday by the association.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 23. -- Young Peter Grace, whose brilliant play featured Yale's recent march to the intercollegiate polo championship, had a field day in scoring as the Gulf Stream quartet defeated Great Island, 11 to 6, in an exhibition match on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,998,406,130. They consist of Treasury bonds, consols, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

J. Edward Jones, wealthy oil securities dealer who has been engaged for months in a legal tussle with the government, caused the arrest yesterday of a former investigator for the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission, who, he said, agreed to "fix things up" for $27,500.

LAWRENCE, L.I., June 23. -- Dorothea Kassady, 20 years old, a maid employed by William Brown, insurance broker, 20 Fulton Street. Atlantic Beach, L.I., was held without bail for further examination next Thursday on a charge of first-degree manslaughter this morning by Justice of the Peace Leslie J. Ekenberg.

ROME, June 23. -- Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, arrived in Rome at a few minutes past 7 o'clock this evening and his reception, though perfectly cordial, was distinguished by the greatest simplicity.

A conference of Socialists, consisting of representatives of State committees from New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Maryland and Connecticut, met at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Those there assumed the leadership in a drive for State legislation to save the labor provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

PARIS, June 23 (AP). -- Colonel Francois de la Rocque, leader of the powerful Nationalist veterans' organization, Cross of Fire, told 20,000 of its members early today that "the hour is near when the French people must rally to our banner."

IRVINGTON, N.J., June 23. -- The Irvington centennial celebration was opened formally here this afternoon on the athletic field of Irvington High School, with 1,500 persons attending. The program was conducted under the auspices of Catholic and Protestant churches and Jewish congregations. The centennial observance will end Nov. 19.

LONDON, June 22. -- The official French revelation that the United States exchange fund took an important part in protecting the franc during the recent crisis caused considerable comment. This is a change of attitude which is as significant as it was welcome, although from Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's recent statements it has been evident that the Washington administration has been thinking more about stabilization than it had done in a long time.

The country feels immensely proud of its G-men, and with good reason. The record set up by the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice in the anti-kidnapping campaign will stand up well, as RUSSELL OWEN said in yesterday's TIMES Magazine, with the work of Scotland Yard or any of the other great crime-discouraging agencies in foreign countries.

Folk dances by men and women in the native dress of the Finnish provinces were acclaimed by 12,000 persons who assembled yesterday afternoon in the Central Park Mall for the celebration of Midsummer Eve or Juhannus Juhla, one of the great annual festivals of Finland.

STAR LAKE, N.Y., June 23. -- Confidence in the recapture of the Assembly in November was expressed today by all those at the gathering of Republican members of the Legislature and party leaders at the Star Lake Inn.

Followers of the Red Hook Sand Lot League -- and their numbers are legion -- are in for a week of confusion. The heated contest between the Clipper Athletic Club and the Borinquen Athletic Club, leading teams in the league, will have to be fought out all over again.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, said today that well over half the Indians have accepted the opportunity to establish Federally-financed corporations for tribal activities.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 23. -- Despite the start last Sunday of what was believed to have been an anti-shorts-and-halter crusade by Alderman William E. Slater, who at that time ordered police to issue summonses to five young women so attired, scores of lightly clad girls strolled through a portion of Yonkers today unnoticed, officially, by the police.

The baccalaureate sermon preached at Harvard University by Dr. James B. Conant, its president, on Sunday, June 16, was criticized by the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod yesterday morning, in a sermon at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 23. -- Although the old crowd in Yugoslav politics, which has enjoyed the fruits of office since 1929 under the dictatorial system instituted by King Alexander, is dying hard, everything points tonight to Prince Paul's being successful in his unavowed but generally understood aim to liquidate the dictatorship completely.

CLEVELAND, June 23. -- Events of a sort not designed to put men in the best of humor plunged the Yankees into deep grief today as they dropped their second successive game to the Indians, 6 to 5, while a crowd of 23,000 gave unmistakable signs that it all met with their approval by setting up a fearful din.

The volume of traffic on the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's subway and elevated lines was smaller in May than in the same month in 1934, according to a report made public yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company.

Keeper of the Bees Priscilla Jaquith, whose thousand or so buzzing charges occupy a simple white beehive in the Gardens of the Nations on the roof of the eleventh floor setback of Rockefeller Center, spoke pridefully of the industry of her swarm yesterday, though she was somewhat ill at ease over the prospective duties of her post.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I, June 23. -- Championship competitions in the various divisions brought to a close the second annual Cedar Valley horse show today, with a good attendance drawn by ideal conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- During the speculative craze in the stock markets in February, 1929, a majority of five members of the Federal Reserve Board, of whom be was one, took over the responsibility of dictating policy, Adolph C. Miller, a member of the board since its formation, said in a detailed statement today covering developments from 1927 to 1929, inclusive, which culminated in the stock market crash in October, 1929.

A complete list of the commencement exercises in the city's senior and junior high schools, starting today and continuing through Thursday, was made public yesterday by the Board of Education. The schedule follows:

Fur departments in the wholesale market were unusually active last week, as many retailers have increased their appropriations for these promotions this season, while other stores which have not handled furs during the last few years are now reinstating them.
NEWARK, N.J., June 23. -- Newark ended its current home series today by dividing a double-header with Baltimore. The Bears won the first game 6 to 1, and the Orioles captured the second, 3 to 2.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 24. -- Acting on the recommendation of the New York County March grand jury, Governor Lehman today ordered District Attorney William C. Dodge to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate organized crime and vice as part of a three-point plan for the inquiry.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- A further slight decline in industrial production and in factory employment and payrolls in May was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board in its monthly summary of business conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Private shipbuilders were sharply assailed today by the Senate Munitions Committee, which, in a preliminary report on its long inquiry, recommended to the Senate the immediate enactment of bills designed "to prevent collusion in the making of contracts for the construction of naval vessels in private shipyards, to safeguard military secrets of the United States," and "to make public the activities of the shipbuilding lobby."

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The bill revising the Tennessee Valley Authority Act is in its present form so objectionable to the administration that it is a "pretty good guess" that President Roosevelt will veto it if it reaches the White House unchanged, according to Arthur E. Morgan, TVA director, who had a talk today with the President.

To round out its financial requirements for the current half year the City of New York plans to issue $47,400,000 of two-day revenue bills, to be dated June 27 and due on June 29. Part of the bills will be paid with cash and the balance converted into revenue notes.
MADISON, Wis., June 24. -- Professor William Ellery Leonard, 59, of the University of Wisconsin, poet and writer, will marry Grace Golden, 27, his former student and also a poet.

Sergius P. Grace, assistant vice president of Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., who was widely known for his demonstration lectures on scientific developments, committed suicide on Sunday by hanging himself in his apartment at Rye, N.Y., the Westchester County Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

Five large underwriting groups, comprising almost every large Wall Street bank and investment banking institution which engages actively in municipal financing, decided yesterday to withhold their bids for an offering by the State of New Jersey today of $2,500,000 Port of New York Authority 3 per cent Series F bonds.
DETROIT, June 24 (AP). -- Earl Whitehill of the Senators, once a Detroit hurler, was beaten by his former teammates in the fourteenth inning today, 9 to 8.
GENEVA, June 24. -- Bigger if not better than last year, the Armaments Year Book for 1935 was issued by the League of Nations today.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Allotments totaling $16,017,125 were recommended to the President today for his approval by the Advisory Committee on Allotments of the work relief program. The committee also asked allotment of $115,000,000 for the Emergency Relief Administration for direct relief needs for July.

The selection of twenty-four local athletes to represent the Metropolitan A.A.U. in the national track and field championships at Lincoln, Neb., July 3-4, was announced yesterday by Frank Hanlon, chairman of the track and field committee.

Before leaving for Washington yesterday Mayor La Guardia announced that immediately after his return he would take up with Oswald W. Knauth, chairman and executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, the question of putting into effect the recommendations made last week by the Governor's commission on unemployment relief.

BEAUFORT, N.C., June 24. -Thousands of young herons were cooked alive today in a forest fire which swept through the Lenoxville rookery three miles east of here, near the shores of Core Sound. Parent birds by the hundreds, perched in trees ahead of the flames, flew into the smoke over the swamp looking for their young.

While fair reorders on Summer merchandise were noted in the market here yesterday, attention has now shifted very largely to August sales and intermediate Fall merchandise. The number of buyers interested in cloth coats, who will arrive here this week, will be larger than last week, and with manufacturers' lines more complete it is expected that considerable business will be placed.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The Bankhead bill, authorizing a government guaranteed $1,000,000,000 bond issue to aid the tenant farmers to buy their own farms, was passed today in the Senate by a vote of 45 to 32 and sent to the House.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP). -- Fiorello H. La Guardia, Mayor of New York, indicated upon leaving a White House conference today that the Roosevelt administration and his own were in accord upon the appointment of a Works Progress Director for New York City.

Princess Aymon de Fancigny Lucinge, Baroness Karla von Muffling, Sir Alexander Murray, Captain F. C. Bradley, British Naval Attache at Washington, and Miss Virginia Vanderlip are among those due today from Channel ports on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 24. -- Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills, erstwhile Long Island champion, teamed with Charles Trunz today and shot a sub-par 68 to capture the honors in an amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Shelter Rock Country Club.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 24. -- Three of the four places in the semi-final round of the third Westbury Challenge Cup polo tournament were completed today when the Gulf Stream quartet upset the Long Island riders, 6 to 5, on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 24 (AP). -- Cancer still exacts a needless number of deaths, the Summer meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Minnesota State Medical Association was told today.
JASPER, Ind., June 24. -- Two Huntington, W.Va., lads, both in their teens, beamed today when an Indiana judge tempered the life terms imposed on them for kidnapping a county Sheriff.

DRESDEN, June 24. -- Richard Strauss's eleventh and latest opera, "The Silent Woman," had its world premiere here tonight. The hostile demonstrations that in some quarters had been predicted and feared because the author of the libretto, Stefan Zweig, is a Jew did not materialize.
Lay and clerical leaders of three faiths joined yesterday in a plea for spiritual revivification as a preliminary to any movement toward "real recovery."

Virtually all leading foreign exchanges moved higher against the dollar yesterday, led by the franc, which crossed par, in terms of the dollar, for the first time since March 12. With it went the others gold currencies, the guilder and the Swiss franc, which advanced 22 and 7 points, respectively.

The conference on Canadian-American affairs held last week in St. Lawrence University is a pioneering North American enterprise. It is declared to be the first time in the history of these two countries that unofficial representative citizens of both have met to take stock of the fundamentals in their interrelationship in all the varied fields of intellectual, economic, social and political activity.

This morning's newspapers publish quotations from addresse by Charles C. Burlingham and Dr. William Allen Nielson, president of Smith College, at the Harvard alumni luncheon at Cambridge, Mass. The burden of these messages was an attack upon recent Massachusetts legislation requiring teachers and professors in public and private institutions to take oaths of allegiance.

William A. Rabell, former assistant chief investigator for the Securities and Exchange Commission, pleaded not guilty to a charge of soliciting a bribe and was held yesterday in $1,500 bail by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on a charge of soliciting a bribe as a Federal officer.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 24. -Seventeen persons died today in the flaming wreckage of two planes which crashed at an airfield in Medellin, 200 miles northwest of here.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 24. -- The qualifying rounds of the British open golf championship began today at the Gullane and Muirfield courses, and the most exciting event of the day was Macdonald Smith's 66 at Gullane.

RYE, N.Y., June 24. -- Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., made an auspicious start in quest of its third straight victory in the Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament for private boarding schools when all six of its representatives came through the morning and afternoon sessions of play at the Manursing Island Club today.

Laurence Schwab and Frank Mandel, who went separate ways in June, 1932, after ten years of partnership, will reunite as a producing firm this Autumn. "May Wine," a play with music by Sigmund Romberg, and with a book adapted by Mr. Mandel from a novel by Wallace Smith and Eric Von Stroheim, will be their first show.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., June 24. -Commencement exercises at the Hotchkiss School were held today in the chapel. Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the University of Pennsylvania, delivered the address to ninety graduates.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24. -- The opinion that a greatly expanded volume of farm credit, especially short-time credit, would be required in view of existing and expected improvements in the economic status of agriculture, was expressed here tonight by W.I. Myers, Governor of the Farm Credit Administration, in an address before the Graduate School of Banking.

ROME, June 24. -- While Premier Mussolini and Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, who opened their conversations here today, did not discuss the Ethiopian question at any great length and, indeed, made only passing references to it, the subject will probably receive exhaustive treatment tomorrow.

Three well-known European writers, two of them exiled from Germany and the third from Italy, are on the new McBride list. The Germans are Emil Ludwig, who is represented with a biography of Masaryk, "Defender of Liberty," and Ernest Glaeser, author of "The Class of 1902," who has just completed a second novel, "The Last Civilian."

Plans for community action to save the city's voluntary hospitals from "operating insolvency" and to stop the pyramiding of deficits will be discussed at a luncheon today at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, under the sponsorship of Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Chamber.

Retailers in New York, Boston and Philadelphia were warned yesterday by the National Knitted Outerwear Association that bathing suit advertisements which contain fraudulent price comparions will be attacked by the organization as a protection to honest advertisers, the consumer and swim suit manufacturers.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 24. -- Dr. Adelberg Matthews, psychiatrist from the New York State Hospital for the Insane at Kings Park, tonight examined Dorothy Kassady, 20-year-old Atlantic Beach domestic, who confessed responsibility for the death of John L. Burness of Seacliff, whose body was found Saturday morning in his automobile in a friend's garage.

Your very temperate and constructive criticism of the President's message to Congress on taxation comes as a balm to those who had read widespread denunciations. Surely, to view the matter calmly, with poise and perspective, in lieu of the hysterical proliferations, is deserving of admiration and acclaim.

Strike action by more than 35,000 garment workers was approved yesterday by locals affiliated with the International Garment Workers Union at a meeting of union representatives in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.

BOSTON, June 24. -- The Boston Maine and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads must be saved from domination by the Pennsylvania and New York Central systems so that they may be free to choose routes to the South and West for goods shipped to and from New England.

WAITING for the weighing-in, there is a last chance for a short session of the old game of Guess Again. Some like Primo, Mussolini's gargantuan reservist. Some like Shufflin' Joe, the slant-eyed slugger from the River Rouge machine shop.

GENEVA, June 24. -- The League of Nations' annual review of world trade published today shows that in 1934 the United States passed Great Britain for the first time and became the world's chief exporter -- and at the same time in imports dropped behind Germany for the first time since the war, falling to third place.

Two American children, who had forgotten all the English they had known and could speak only German, after a stay of a little more than a year in Germany, were guests yesterday at the shelter of the Travelers Aid Society, 144 East Forty-fourth Street.

A 12-year-old girl and a 15-year-old boy will leave depression-stricken homes today to receive from Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Prizes of $150, awarded on the basis of "honorable character, conduct and record and proficiency in studies."
Melvin C. Eaton confirmed yesterday reports that he intended to seek re-election as chairman of the Republican State Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- An additional list of applications for registration by brokers and dealers in over-the-counter markets was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It contained the following from New York State and City, the symbols being: (s) sole proprietor, (p) partnership, and (c) corporation.

The old project for a vehicular tunnel from Thirty-eighth Street, Manhattan, under the East River to Queens has been revived again. It was actively promoted by midtown merchants during Mayor WALKER'S administration, but languished for lack of funds and because other metropolitan bridges and tunnels seemed more urgently needed.

Dental anesthesia used on three patients at Metropolitan Hospital who died last month after having teeth extracted contained "some impurity, probably mercury," but no responsibility for the deaths could be fixed, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, was told yesterday by the committee he named to investigate the fatalities.

TACOMA, Wash., June 24. -- After National Guardsmen, ordered here by Governor Martin, had dispersed today strike pickets around eight saw mills and lumber yards, rioting broke out tonight when non-union workers attempted to reach the business district on their way home from the mills.

GENEVA, June 24. -- The International Labor Organization Conference postponed today until 1936 its decision on two of five conventions to implement its recently adopted forty-hour-week convention and reserved final decision on the three others until tomorrow.

Presenting Uncle Tom Zachary with a 5-1 advantage in the first, to which they added two more runs in the third, the Dodgers seemed to have taken all the fight out of the Cardinals at Ebbets Field yesterday. As the innings rolled by and Zachary continued to puzzle the world champions, the outcome appeared settled, with only the final score in doubt.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge Gerry Chadwick, who are at their country home in Syosset for the season, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to introduce to society Mrs. Chadwick's daughter, Miss Dorothy Douglas Robinson.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 24 (AP). -- Acting on information gathered privately, Public Safety Commissioner H.E. Warren charged today that the Police Department maintained a "startling" alliance with crime and suspended Chief of Police Michael Culligan and four other officers, demanding the resignation of four more.

LONDON, June 24. -- The defeat of Wilmer Allison, seeded American player, in the first round and the narrow escape of former champion Jean Borotra from the same fate thrilled the crowd at the opening of the fifty-fifth Wimbledon championship tennis tournament today.

Mathematics, science and foreign languages, traditional stumbling blocks for many pupils, have been dropped from the list of subjects required for high school graduation by the Board of Superintendents. Announcement of the board's action was made yesterday as the first of the city's 49,543 elementary and junior high school graduates received the diplomas which entitle, them to enter high schools in the Fall.

James Canora, 19-year-old slingshot artist, and his father, Frank, 45, both of 365 First Avenue, whose foraging in Central Park last Saturday was ended abruptly by the police, pleaded guilty yesterday in Yorkville magistrates' court to charges of having violated the State conservation laws and a city park ordinance.

BERLIN, June 24. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, extended today for another year the existing complete moratorium on German long-term and medium-term indebtedness, including the Dawes and the Young loans.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 24. -Seventeen persons lost their lives today, including Carlos Gardel, Argentine movie star, when two trimotored Ford transport planes collided and burned at Olaya Herrera airport at Medellin, 200 miles northwest of here.

OTTAWA, June 24 (Canadian Press). -- Premier Bennett appealed to all law-abiding Canadians today to use their influence against the agitation behind the on-to-Ottawa march of the unemployed. He called the movement centring in the relief camps a menace to law and order.

HONGKONG, June 24. -- After considerable speculation and rumors the position of the two rebel Canton warships was clarified today by Admiral Chen, Vice Minister of the Navy, who is here aboard the cruiser Ninghai.

Federal and local public housing projects have been jeopardized by published reports of their discontinuance, it was charged in a letter to President Roosevelt made public yesterday at a meeting of representatives of thirty national groups under the auspices of the National Public Housing Conference.

Arriving by plane from Chicago, where they won the national clay court doubles title on Sunday, Berkeley Bell and J. Gilbert Hall made their first appearances in the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Trading in the markets here for commodity futures was highly mixed in character yesterday and generally larger than average in volume. Advances exceeded declines. In the cash markets raw sugar rose 5 points to 3.30 cents a pound, and corn, cocoa, lard, silk and hides also were stronger.

Horace E. Dodge, Detroit speedboat manufacturer, is defendant in three suits brought against him here by his second wife, Mrs. Muriel S. Dodge. The actions were disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice John L. Walsh signed an order permitting the service of the complaints three days after the legal time had expired.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Hogs were in narrow demand here today despite reports that prices of fresh pork loins in some Eastern markets had risen 2 cents a pound. The first sales were weak to 10 cents lower than on Saturday and final prices were lower from 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, the latter on heavy butcher hogs.
What promises to be the greatest heavyweight ring battle of recent years is scheduled for tonight in the Yankee Stadium, partly in the interests of charity.
COLEBROOK, N.H., June 24. -Many Summer homes were opened for the season in the White Mountains this week-end.

New York, with the greatest concentration of population in the world and a skyline ever pressing upward, nevertheless has within its five boroughs 40,000 acres, or sixty-two square miles, of vacant land, according to a report by the Mayor's committee on city planning.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 24 (AP). -- One man was believed to have been killed, another was critically injured and dozens of yachts were destroyed today as fire swept the Pilkington yacht basin near here.
In a recent article on your editorial page surprise was expressed at the limited number of pedestrians who cross the George Washington Bridge.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 24. -- Miss Norma Taubele of New York began the defense of her title in the women's New Jersey State tennis tournament at the Oritani Field Club today with a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Miss Katherine Johnson of Englewood.

Evidence indicating the existence of a causative relationship between typhus and a baffling disease of the extremities which leads to gangrene in its more serious forms is presented by Dr. Charles Goodman in the current Bulletin of the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Retaliating for limitations set by the Democratic leadership to confine general debate on pending legislation to the subject-matter of the bill under consideration, Representative Snell, the Republican leader, managed today to prevent six Democratic speakers from talking for more than a minute each in the House.
Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince and his symphonic ensemble of 100 young men and women began a series of eight concerts on the Mall in Central Park last night before an audience of about 5,000.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 24 (AP). -- Harold M. Vanderbilt and his three teammates from the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York led off the scoring in the opening round of the all-American contract team-of-four championship tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, June 24 (AP).-- New Orleans garbage workers laid plans tonight to quit work again tomorrow as Mayor Walmsley refused to resign at their demand and charged that Senator Long "inspired" their strike.

DEAL, N.J., June 24. -- Police and fire authorities were still at a loss here today to explain the origin of the fire which early this morning destroyed the sixty-four-room Tudor mansion home of William P. Ahnelt, retired president of the Pictorial Review Corporation, and caused damage estimated at $450,000.

Formal announcement of the candidacy of John W. Horan, assistant secretary of the Board of Water Supply, for Tammany leader of the Ninth Assembly District against Dennis J. Mahon, former Acting President of the Board of Aldermen, was made last night, following a meeting of his supporters at the Riverside Democratic Club, 632 West End Avenue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 24. -- After further negotiations with political leaders, former Finance Minister Milan Stoyadinovitch succeeded this afternoon in forming a Cabinet whose task supposedly is liquidation of the dictatorship, restoration of democracy and reconciliation of the Croats, Serbs and Slovenes.

Edward S. Greenbaum, trustee in bankruptcy of the Kreuger Toll Company, at a meeting of creditors held yesterday before Harold, P. Coffin, referee, submitted an offer of $765,000 for settlement of claims against four banking firms involving $4,250,000.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 24. -- Without a dissenting vote, the Northern Baptist Convention accepted today a report of the controversial Christian Social Action Commission and authorized the General Council to distribute it to individual churches for study.
The new British-made musical film opening this morning at the Cameo is "Her Song of Love," featuring Derek Oldham, Jean Adrienne, Vesta Victoria, Ronald Ward and Marjorie Corbett.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24. -- Retaining the title for a Long Island club, Richard Remsen and Richard Remsen Jr. of Cherry Valley captured the championship of the Father and Son Golf Association today when they returned a card of 82 -- 16 -- 66 over the links of the Garden City Golf Club.

The defense of the Reserve Board's discount-rate policies in 1927 and 1929, submitted yesterday by Mr. MILLER of the board, is interesting as a contribution to financial history. It appears from his statement that in the early months of 1929, when Wall Street speculation was already getting out of hand, the Reserve Board was sharply divided over the course to be pursued.
PARIS, June 24. -- Jean Chiappe, former Prefect of Police of Paris, was elected today President of the Municipal Council of Paris by 55 votes out of 90.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 24 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley asserted tonight that the NRA, despite the Supreme Court ruling that invalidated it, had provided sufficient impetus to business so that the momentum would carry the nation through to the recovery pledged by the Democratic administration in 1932.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP). -- Attacking the Alaskan colonization scheme of the Relief Administration as a "crazy adventure," Senator Vandenberg predicted in the Senate today that unless prompt remedies were taken the enterprise would result in a "major catastrophe."
Quietness prevailed in all sections of the money market, and quotations unchanged for day loans, maturity money and business paper.

Frank Fox, president of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, and eight directors of the corporation were exonerated in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday of charges of fraud and conspiracy in the transfer of assets in a bankruptcy proceeding.

BUENOS AIRES, June 24. -- Carlos Gardel was Argentina's undisputed national idol. As the telegraph and radio carried the news of his death to all corners of the republic, one phrase was on all lips, "Poor Carlitos!"

CHICAGO, June 24. -- The first skirmish between America's first business women golfers, Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, famous girl athlete from Beaumont, Texas, and Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., resulted today in a triumph for Miss Hicks, former national amateur champion.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on June 19 shows increases for the week of $120,000,000 in total loans and investments, and $36,000,000 in time deposits ad decreases of $21,000,000 in net demand deposits, $53,000,000 in government deposits and $63,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

PARIS, June 24. -- J. Theodore Marriner, counselor of the United States Embassy, made representations at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs today on behalf of his government against the bill before Parliament requiring physicians and dentists practicing in France to apply for French citizenship.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Continuation for another year of the temporary plan of insuring bank deposits was unanimously agreed upon today by the Senate Banking Subcommittee.

IN "Back to Work: The Story of the PWA" (Macmillan, $2.50), Secretary of the Interior and Administrator of Public Works Harold L. Ickes, the man whom Westbrook Pegler calls "the house dick of the Roosevelt administration," renders an account of his stewardship. It is a characteristic account, prickly with a zealous prejudice against financial slovenliness, graft in high or low political place, and the whole rigmarole of pork-barrel appropriations.

PARIS, June 24. -- The International Chamber of Commerce opened its eighth biennial congress here today with addresses that demonstrated that international currency stabilization and the reduction of trade barriers remain the primary objects of business leaders throughout the world.

A total of 162 lots auctioned last Saturday in Freeport, L.I., brought $52,782, Joseph P. Day, the auctioneer, reported yesterday. The owners, heirs of Ernest S. Randall, appointed Mr. Day agent to continue disposal of the remaining property at private sale.

Judge John J. Freschi granted a certificate of reasonable doubt in General Sessions yesterday to John A. Dilliard, convicted June 14 of a misdemeanor in publishing a false statement, in 1933, on the finances of the State Title and Mortgage Company, of which he was the president.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 25. -- Anticipating early settlement of all the military disputes in North China, the newspapers announce that Ambassador Akira Ariyoshi at an appropriate moment will reaffirm the Tokyo government's desire to cultivate better relations with China.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Plans to rush through the House tomorrow the Copeland-Bland Merchant Marine Subsidy Bill were worked out by leaders today.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

After quarreling with her father because he had refused her request for a dime, Conchetta Montaznino, 23 years old, of 1,567 First Avenue, committed suicide at 5:30 P.M. yesterday, according to the police, by leaping from the roof of a five-story building at Eighty-second Street and Second Avenue.

Scouting expeditions by a number of sportsmen who cruised the waters of Long Island and New Jersey over the week-end indicated that the two most important off shore Summer species -- small tuna and bluefish -- have yet to put it an appearance.

With bunting and signal flags waving, and well-wishers doing their best, one of the two twelve-meter international racing yachts, the first in this country, was launched at 6 o'clock last night from the shipyard of Henry B. Nevins, in City Island.

MADISON, Wis., June 24. -- The incapacity of humanity to manage the modern world economy, rather than any defect in the system itself, is to blame for the evils of modern-day life, Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, said today in an address to 1,500 seniors at the commencement of the University of Wisconsin here.

TRENTON, N.J., June 24. -- A coalition of Republican followers of Governor Hoffman and members of the Democratic minority tonight blocked efforts of the Assembly group led by the Speaker, the Rev. Lester H. Clee, to emasculate the new 2 per cent Retail Sales Tax Law by amending it to exempt all foodstuffs, clothing, fuel and medicine.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 24. -- The entertaining in honor of the season's debutantes has begun. Miss Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander, daughter of Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander, was the guest of honor this afternoon at a luncheon given by Mrs. Frederick W. Rhinelander at her home on Red Cross Avenue.

NANUET, N.Y., June 24. -- Clarkstown police under Chief Walter Liebert made a detailed search today of all public garages here and in near-by villages in an effort to trace the hit-and-run driver responsible for the death of Edward O. Dean.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The United States has no present thought of protesting to Germany against her violation in her naval agreement with Great Britain of the military clauses of the Versailles treaty, which are incorporated in the separate German-American peace treaty. This government not only has no desire to do that but is convinced American public opinion does not demand it.

The Brazilian naval training ship, the Almirante Saldanha, bound on her annual cruise, arrived at 11 A.M. yesterday at the navy yard in Brooklyn, where she will stay for eleven days before continuing her voyage to European ports.

PATERSON, N.J., June 24. -- Edward F. Gaffney and John J. Hughes, two of the eight men arrested in an armed camp at Mountain View yesterday, were identified in police headquarters here tonight as participants in the $427,000 Rubel Ice Corporation holdup in Brooklyn last August.

Establishment of an "information exchange bureau" on all phases of unfair trade practices was approved yesterday by the members of the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives at a meeting at the offices of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- President Roosevelt and his Congressional leaders in a sudden move tonight started a drive for immediate action on his wealth-sharing tax program, proposing to attach it to the joint resolution extending certain "nuisance" levies, which must be passed by Sunday midnight to prevent their expiration.

The police are investigating information hinting at a baseball scandal, Commissioner Valentine disclosed last night in a radio broadcast over Station WNYC. He was speaking of the annual ball game between the police and firemen Saturday at 2 P.M. in the Polo Grounds.

In Mr. Hoover's address at the graduation exercises of Stanford University he dealt briefly with the problem of what has come to be called "mass purchasing power." This problem, he found, "lies in a great area of unclarified national thought." Here, he found, "America has, however, developed one new idea -- that wages are linked to ability to consume goods; that the highest possible real wage is the necessary accompaniment of mass production."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 24. -- About 200 children attended the junior field day arranged by the woman's committee of the Federation for the support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies today at the Beach Point Club here.

When District Attorney Dodge returned to his home at the Hotel Olcott, 27 West Seventy-second Street, at 9:50 o'clock last night he met reporters waiting in the lobby who asked him if he would comment on the Governor's order.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- A pair of unrelated youngsters named Malloy, Jack of Princeton and Woodrow of Michigan, kept level with the Congressional course's par 72 today to take the lead in the first half of the 36-hole qualifying test of the National Intercollegiate golf championship.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 24. -- Complete control of tuberculosis within the next half century was predicted today by Dr, Louis I. Dublin, third vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, in an address before the National Tuberculosis Association, meeting in convention here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- An ecclesiastical trial for five ministers of the Philadelphia Presbytery, who have ignored demands of the General Assembly that they resign from the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions, was recommended today by a special judicial committee of the Presbytery.

Price movements in the markets yesterday were rather indecisive. Stocks were steady during the earlier trading and sold off in the last hour of business to close irregularly lower. During most of the day the market displayed little animation, and the shares dealt in on the Stock Exchange footed up to 1,116,000, compared with Friday's total of 1,517,000.

One of the bills on which the Administration desires action before Congress adjourns is a measure proposing certain amendments to the act creating AAA. Among other things, it would give the Secretary of Agriculture power to issue "orders" applicable to various handlers of vegetables, fruits and tobacco products.

BERLIN, June 24. -- A particularly virulent outbreak of mingled Germanism, Nordicism and neopaganism, which has marked the lighting of Summer solstice fires throughout Germany this week-end, provided a series of spectacles virtually unprecedented.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, acting yesterday through its counsel, John J. Burns, obtained an order signed by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey requiring A.A. Durante, head of A.A. Durante Co., 117 Liberty Street, and I.W. Goodwin, a salesman, to show cause today why they should not be restrained from selling oil royalties.

ALBANY, June 24. -- A municipality making a profit from operation of its own electric light plant may apply the earnings to tax reductions, Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Sehenck ruled today in the case of the village of Boonville. The village sought to stay the Public Service Commission from enforcing its order reducing rates until the Appellate Division has passed upon the question.

Jack Doyle, Irish heavyweight, making his first appearance in an American ring, knocked out Phil Donato of Brooklyn in 1:06 of the first round before 8,000 fans at Dyckman Oval last night. Doyle weighed 212 1/4, Donato 190 pounds. The bout was scheduled for eight rounds.

CLEVELAND, June 24. -- The squat, broad-shouldered Vitautas Tamulis, whom they call Vito for short, stuck his chubby left arm into the affairs of the Yankees today and brought their sudden downward flight to an abrupt end.

The Presbyterian League of Faith, a national organization of ministers and laymen who are Fundamentalists, at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the parish house of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street, adopted a resolution unanimously protesting against the unseating of three commissioners by the 147th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Cincinnati, Ohio.

LONDON, June 24 (AP). -- Four American Davis Cup players came through their first Wimbledon singles tests today, but four "free lances" from the United States joined Wilmer Allison in the trek to the sidelines.

Fleet representatives of two branches of the Whitney family were turned back in the Rosetint Purse at Aqueduct yesterday by the Stimulus filly Aperitif, which carried the Howe Stable silks. Aperitif raced strongly and well to score by a half length at 2 to 1.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, delivered a report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday accusing Assistant District Attorney Edwin J. Talley of "gross negligence" for failing to prosecute job-fixing charges against John Flaherty, former secretary to Municipal Court Justice Vincent Lippe.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Tenders for two series of Treasury bills totaling $100,000,000 offered June 21 were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today. They totaled $272,908,000, of which $100,010,000 was accepted, Secretary Morgenthau announced.

After a ten-day preliminary inquiry by the State Attorney General's office and the Department of Justice, the New York County grand jury began an investigation yesterday of the business activities of William F. Peterson, a guest at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, whose wife reported him missing several days ago, saying that she suspected he had been kidnapped.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 24. -- The first hero to be named in the British open golf championship is Macdonald Smith of the United States. He traversed the Gullane No. 1 course in the first qualifying round today in 66, which is a record for this newly altered links and equals his own score in the initial qualifying round of the open at Troon in 1923.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- President Roosevelt's demand for outright abolition of utility holding companies by 1940 was conceded today by some opponents of the proposal to have more than an even chance of House acceptance, as indications grew that Chairman Rayburn of the Interstate Commerce Committee might take the floor in opposition to the modified bill as reported.

The Cubs and the Giants passed the ball game back and forth at the Polo Grounds yesterday like a couple of jugglers with a plate. In the tenth inning the Chicagoans seized the very elusive victory, 10 to 9, to even the series count at a triumph apiece, but the Terrymen still managed to remain six and a half lengths ahead of their nearest pursuers, who now happen to be the Cardinals.
The Summer edition of the 1935 Social Register, just issued, shows that foreign travel among prominent families is "slightly better" than last year.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 24 (AP). -- Accounting for four put-outs and connecting with the ball each time at bat, although failing to hit safely, Alabama Pitts gave a satisfactory performance in his first game under the lights tonight as Albany nosed out Newark, 5 to 3, in an International League game.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Apprehension of increased hedging pressure rather than aggregate selling dominated the wheat market on the Board of Trade today, and prices declined moderately, closing 1/4 to 3/4 cent a bushel lower than on Saturday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 24. -- The Red Barn Theatre, a Summer playhouse in the heart of the North Shore colonies, was filled to capacity tonight at the opening of its fourth season and the premiere performance on any stage of Gladys Hurlbut's new comedy, "Mad Morning," presented by Arthur Hanna and D.A. Doran.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 24. -- The seeded stars in the national intercollegiate singles tennis championship romped into the third round of play as the battle for the title vacated by Gene Mako of Southern California opened on the clay courts of Northwestern University today.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders in a White House conference decided to attach his wealth-sharing tax program to the nuisance taxes resolution.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Convened as a result of President Roosevelt's intervention in the wage negotiations deadlock which threatened a nation-wide bituminous coal strike on June 15, the Joint Conference of Appalachian Coal Area Operators and Miners failed again today to reach an agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- In retiring about $599,724,000 of consols and $74,900,000 of Panama Canal bonds called for redemption on July 1 and Aug. 1, respectively, the Treasury will chiefly use funds obtained by drawing down deposits with banks and endeavor to avoid any sudden increase in the excess reserves of the banks, it was made known officially today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 24. -More than 2,000 persons attended the "Night of Sports" held here tonight in a large tent on the athletic field of the Bronxville schools. The sponsor of the event was the Leonard S. Morange Post, American Legion, of Bronxville, and Ellis A. Propp was chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- An amplifying system was installed in the House today to help members and the gallery follow the discussions, but Speaker Byrns was so annoyed by the deafening roar of his own gavel-thumping as magnified by a cluster of loud speakers above his head that the machinery will soon be removed, according to present signs.

Institutional buyers of government bonds followed closely the course of yesterday's bond market preparatory to entering bids on Secretary Mrorgenthau's new offer of $100,000,000 of Treasury 3s, due in 1946 and 1948. The bonds, on a when-issued basis, closed at 104 28-32, unchanged from Saturday and 24-32 point higher than the average price at which the previous offering at auction was sold by the government.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP). -- Does big business mean big profits? A search of an answer to that question, raised by President Roosevelt's proposal for a graduated corporate income tax under which larger corporations would pay a higher rate, disclosed today a large amount of uncertainty among some students as to the relation between corporate size and earnings.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP). -- The Reds defeated the Phillies, 6 to 4, today for their third straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- An extension of fifteen days to July 15 for permanent registration of securities having temporary status on national Exchanges was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Housing and business structures were included in the Manhattan and Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.

George C. Hanson, newly appointed United States Minister to Abyssinia, expressed the belief that there would be no war between Italy and Ethiopia when he arrived here yesterday to sail tomorrow for his new post. He is known as the State Department's "trouble shooter."

MINEOLA, L.I., June 24. -- Continuing its drive against automobile accidents, the Nassau County Police Department, through its chief, Abram W. Skidmore, applied today to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors for permission to organize a safety patrol. In urging approval of his request, Chief Skidmore was joined by District Attorney Martin W. Littleton, who referred to the number of accidents that had resulted in fatalities because of the lack of proper medical attention.

Operation of a $67,000,000 investment company by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway is outlined in a report filed by the C. O. with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The investment company, known as the Virginia Transportation Company, is carrying a $3,900,000 loan to a syndicate in which Patrick H. Joyce, president of the Chicago Great Western Railroad, is interested, the report says.

On Sunday morning the body of a man was found by the roadside near New York. He had apparently been hit by an automobile, thrown against a pile of rocks, and left there to die. There were no witnesses, and the driver of the car had sped away with the utmost callousness.

Faced with three sharply conflicting proposals, members of the cotton garment industry started deliberations yesterday at an emergency convention at the Hotel New Yorker to hew out a program for future self-government that will meet with the approval of the field's 3,300 members.

The acting NRA administrator is well advised in announcing that his organization will not encourage industry to adopt voluntary codes until it has determined whether, under the new law, useful voluntary codes can be put into force. Many industrialists still do not seem to recognize how restricted the powers are that the new NRA gives them.

The drop of about 2 cents an ounce in the price of silver in the world markets yesterday came as a surprise to many persons in the trade. For several weeks the price of that metal had been reasonably steady, although the Treasury in Washington was not a heavy buyer.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Since the timing and the rhetoric of he President's sudden tax message last week were political, subsequent political events have had their influence. What were not at first intended -- to try to rush through a completely new taxing philosophy in midsummer, and to apply surtax rates to legacies which cannot possibly be defined as "vast" -- may be tried.

LONDON, June 24. -- With the auctioneer's brief intimation that the whole collection would be sold without reserve, the sale of the late J. Pierpont Morgan's famous collection of miniatures began at Christie's today. The afternoon's total was 25,545.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 24. -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, the chief women's golf executive of the East, today took up a player's role with considerable success by winning the medal in the Long Island championship.

Evidence that holders of certificates in various mortgage companies in rehabilitation had been made the victims of unscrupulous reorganization committees has been obtained by the Congressional committee investigating real estate bondholders' reorganizations, it was made known yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP). -- Zeke Bonura's thirteenth home run with two men on base and faulty fielding by Manager Joe Cronin and Mel Almada today enabled the White Sox to beat the Red Sox, 6 to 4, and gain an even break in the series. Lefty Grove, who replaced Dusty Rhodes at the start of the seventh, was the victim.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The proposed reciprocal trade agreement with France, on which hearings opened today before a joint committee, was immediately opposed by the American wine industry, New York representatives protesting in the name of makers of sparkling wines, and Western representatives for makers of still wines, any reduction in tariffs on French wines.

There is a grave danger of war in China, which may involve both the United States and Japan, Kanju Kato, chairman of the General Council of Trades Unions of Japan, warned last night in his first address since his recent arrival in this country.
Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase yesterday announced that New York University had received $62,420.95 in gifts and bequests since March. Among the gifts were:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24. -- Henry L. Doherty, 65-year-old head of the Cities Service Corporation, testified in Supreme Court here this afternoon in defense of a suit for $138,750 brought by Kenyon B. Conger, that has been on trial before Justice William F. Bleakley for a week.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday, in an opinion written by Judge Martin T. Manton, that a jury had erred in convicting four defendants of violating the Federal Vote Fraud Laws in the election of 1932.

Final liquidation in July contracts preparatory to the circulation of notices this morning kept trading active on the Cotton Exchange yesterday with final quotations 6 to 10 points lower than on Saturday.

Final liquidation in July contracts preparatory to the circulation of notices this morning kept trading active on the Cotton Exchange yesterday with final quotations 6 to 10 points lower than on Saturday.
BEVERLY, Mass., June 24. -- Miss Louise Barbour, 17-year-old daughter of Professor H. Barbour of Harvard, has lent her Irish hunter, Quentin, to John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- To Harry L. Hopkins today was given the final say on where and how much shall be spent of $249,000,000 earmarked by President Roosevelt for Secretary Ickes's slum-clearance plans.

GENEVA, June 25. -- The nineteenth International Labor Organization conference closed today after adopting by one vote the convention to establish a forty-two-hour week in the glass bottle industry, and by 106 to 0 a recommendation of remedies for unemployment among the young.

George McAneny, chairman of the newly appointed commission to study State aid to cities and the financial and tax relations between the State government and its municipalities, entertained Governor Lehman and members of the commission at dinner last night in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
Apartment house deals in Manhattan and the Bronx featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.

LONDON, June 25. -- The Duke of Kent, a slim young figure in the scarlet uniform of colonel-in-chief of the Royal West Kent Regiment, led his mother to the throne in Buckingham Palace when Queen Mary held the third court of the Silver Jubilee year alone tonight.

The Emergency Relief Bureau warned yesterday about 25,000 merchants and landlords to whom it owes more than $160,000 to present their claims immediately, otherwise the validity of their bills might be questioned.

LONDON, June 25. -- Both cheers of approval and shouts of skepticism greeted an announcement in the House of Commons today that Germany had agreed never again to resort to unrestricted submarine warfare such as she practiced during the World War, notably in the case of the Lusitania and many other non-belligerent vessels crowded with defenseless passengers.

Frederick A. Tuttle, former acting Assistant Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, was indicted by the Federal grand jury yesterday morning, in connection with the Labor Department's investigation into naturalization and immigration frauds.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- A drive against "sell-and-switch" operators, a fraudulent stock promotion system which, it was contended, was particularly prevalent in New York and Chicago as a form of bucket-shop practices, has been undertaken by the Department of Justice under the Securities Exchange Act and with the Securities Exchange Commission's cooperation.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25. -- The Greenwich Garden Club sponsored a tour of gardens on the estates of five prominent women in the community this afternoon for the benefit of the founder's fund, which is being raised in memory of Mrs. Willis Marten of Philadelphia, founder of the Garden Club of America.

Surrounded by 500 cheering children and their less boisterous but equally enthusiastic parents, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday afternoon that special attention to the welfare of children was a primary objective of the city. A public health program, with special emphasis on the prevention of illness among the city's children, is a goal he has constantly in mind, the Mayor said.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 25. -- A sudden dispute that flared between Knoxville and Chattanooga last night when The Chattanooga News appeared with a long Page 1 story advocating that headquarters of the Tennessee Valley Authority be moved to that city from Knoxville appeared today to be a tempest in a teapot.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Miss Mary Elizabeth MacArthur, daughter of Mrs. Arthur MacArthur and the late Captain MacArthur, U.S.N., was married here today in the Church of the Epiphany to John Edgar Reyburn 2d, son of Mrs. Erwin Albert Morse and William Stewart Reyburn.

The eight West Side gunmen arrested last Sunday at Mountain View, N.J., were paraded in and out of their cells at Paterson (N.J.) police headquarters under strong guard yesterday as various hold-up victims and Northern New Jersey police officials called to look them over.

A check-up yesterday of last week's sale of $239,000,000 of Federal Land Bank obligations revealed that four records had been broken in handling the transactions. The loan was the largest ever floated for the land banks, the coupon rte was the lowest yet attained for that type of security, oversubscription was the largest and distribution to the public was on the widest scale yet achieved.

Criticism of the government's policy in the transfer of seamen on Federal relief from the Seamen's Church Institute to Bowery lodging houses, was expressed yesterday by the Rev. Harold H. Kelley, superintendent of the institute.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 25. -- One hundred giant toads from Hawaii have arrived at Brisbane to save sugar cane in Queensland from the ravages of a destructive beetle. The toads have been sent to a laboratory where they will be bred for distribution in the stricken areas.

SCHEVENINGEN, Netherlands, June 25. -- How much success Anthony Eden has in Rome with the Ethiopian question will be measured by the effect of his visit on the Italo-Ethiopian arbitration and conciliation commission, which began its work here today.

LONDON, June 25. -- Britain possesses the world's first entirely "robot" aircraft, wireless controlled, details of which the Air Ministry revealed today for the first time after experiments carried out in strictest secrecy for two years.
District Attorney Dodge announced yesterday that he would comply with the terms of Governor Lehman's order for a grand jury investigation of rackets in New York City.

The second dead heat of the current New York season was run at Aqueduct yesterday when Below Zero and Rough Diamond drove to the finish line in the Kildare Handicap so closely locked that the judges could not separate them. Below Zero was the heavily played favorite at 6 to 5, while Rough Diamond was a 20 to 1 shot.

" I knew in the fifth round that I would get him," said Joe Louis in his dressing room after the fight. "I hit him with a right in the next round and the blood spurted from his mouth. I dropped him the first time with a right to the face. I put him down the second time with a right to the jaw and finished him with a right and left.

DES MOINES, June 25 (AP). -- Paul Jackson of Oklahoma City, 125-pound golfer, fired a sub-par 72 over Wakonda's rain-soaked course today to lead a brilliant field of 185 players in the first eighteen hole qualification play in the trans-Mississippi tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- A joint resolution to continue until June 30, 1936, the present temporary insurance for bank deposits up to $5,000 was adopted without a record vote today in the Senate, which by this action sought to prevent the automatic death of the existing program at midnight next Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Testimony that the Food and Grocery Chain Stores of America, Inc., placed an "under-cover" man in the offices of the National Anti-Chain Store League to report the operations and intentions of that organization, was given today at a hearing of the special House committee appointed to investigate lobbying activities of the American Retail Federation.

Weakness was the rule yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, with uncertainties over the government's tax program and doubt on the constitutionality of processing taxes among the influences contributing to the ease. Trading was moderate as a rule, and few of the price changes assumed large proportions.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Loans to industry numbering 1,636 and aggregating $88,601,000 had been passed upon favorably by the Federal Reserve Banks up to June 19, one year after enactment of the law authorizing such loans.

The city of Boston, Mass., awarded yesterday to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Hemphill, Noyes Co. and G.M.-P. Murphy Co. an issue of $2,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes dated June 27, 1935, and due on Feb. 17, 1936. The award was made on a bank discount basis of 0.98 per cent plus $48 premium.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 25. -- Led by Baroness Maud Levi of New York, Eastern clay court champion, and seeded No. 1, favorites advanced easily in the second day's play of the women's New Jersey State tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25. -- A glimpse into the future when every movement of every bodily organ and function will become an open book to the scientists for diagnostic and treatment purposes was given to the delegates of the American Association for the Advancement of Science today by Dr. Percy Brown of Boston, one of America's pioneers in the development of the X-ray.

This morning's news may as well start with employment. Bulletin No. 1 finds George Abbott engaged as director of the script of "Jumbo," the greatest show in the Billy Rose office. For the same enterprise -- but these are performers -- Mr. Rose announces Barbette, a Neopolitan female impersonator; Dohoes, a "silver horse" from Europe; Robyn, a musical clown from Prague; the Stonleys, aerialists from Hamburg, and Vabanque, "the Algerian daredevil."

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Louis Piquett, former City Prosecutor, politician and attorney for gangsters, was found guilty this afternoon in Federal court of the charge of having harbored and concealed Homer Van Meter, John Dillinger's lieutenant, during the Summer of 1934 in Chicago, a few months before these outlaws were shot and killed by Federal agents.

ROME, June 25. -- Anthony Eden, at the conclusion of his mission here, appeared convinced that only sufficient concessions by Ethiopia could deflect Italy from her aggressive course in Africa. It would not be surprising, therefore, if the British Government were to submit proposals to Addis Ababa looking toward a peaceful setttlement on that basis.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- His second defeat in less than a week on the holding company issue was administered to President Roosevelt today, when the House Rules Committee rejected his demand for a record vote on the clear-cut question of outright dissolution of intermediate utility concerns by 1940.

HAVANA, June 25. -- A committee of the newly formed Social and Economic Union of Cuba today called on United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery to express the gratitude of all classes toward the United States Government and the Ambassador for their assistance and cooperation in the extended economic reconstruction of Cuba.

A book by Hirosi Saito, the Japanese Ambassador, is announced for publication in the Fall by Marshall Jones Company of Boston. It will be called "Japan's Policies and Purposes" and will be published on Sept. 12.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- A conference agreement on the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Bill was reached today with the elimination of the "unit" amendment, preventing the proposed National Labor Relations Board from designating the employes of more than one employer as a collective bargaining group, and also ratified their action of yesterday in striking out the amendment providing that nothing in the act should abridge freedom of the press.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- With pressure from a number of industries for NRA approval of voluntary codes, members of the Federal Trade Commission and representatives of the NRA conferred today, considered what might be done under the "skeleton" NRA and how the problem of compliance might be met if voluntary codes were accepted.

PARIS, June 25 (AP). -- The secretary of the Princess of Reuss, the former Mrs. Allene Tew Burchard of Jamestown, N.Y., said tonight that the Princess and her husband, Prince Henry XXXIII of Reuss, had been divorced, but declined to reveal any details.
