All the excitement at the weighing of Primo Carnera and Joe Louis yesterday was outside the State Office Building, where the ceremony took place. Louis could not break through a crowd of several thousand admirers as he sought to depart after being weighed and subjected to a physical examination.

With the Fusion administration striving to keep relief costs down to a reasonable minimum, the Emergency Relief Bureau asked the Board of Estimate yesterday for record appropriation of $20,531,000 for July relief.
Each year I am more impressed by the fact that New York City is a two-season town -- eight months of Winter, four months of Summer.

TACOMA, Wash., June 25 (AP). -- A statement: "National Guard forces are in control of the city," was issued tonight by Brig. Gen. Carlos A. Penington after troop reinforcements arrived to prevent further disorders in the crisis arising from the lumber strike.

The vigil of a Pekingese dog on the sea wall along Short Road at the foot of Ninety-first Street, Brooklyn, led yesterday morning to the discovery of the body of the dog's mistress, Mrs. Lila McCadden, 50 years old, of 302 Marine Avenue, Brooklyn, floating in the Narrows.

I agree most heartily with the general purport of your leading editorial of Sunday. But I object even more heartily to having remarks of mine misconstrued into a text for your critical comments. You say that I "maintained last week that it is a good thing to pass laws of doubtful constitutionality or questionable value."
If art lovers in far-away Texas fail to hear about New York's Summer art, music, dance and drama activities, it will not be the fault of the Municipal Art Committee.

Boonville is a village in up-State New York with a small electric-light plant of its own. Having financed extensions and gradually retired its bonds out of earnings, it had the choice of either lowering rates or maintaining them and devoting the balance to the reduction of taxes.

Members of the New York Young Republican Club are aggrieved by your editorial in this morning's issue of THE TIMES under the title, "Older and Wiser," in that it attributes to the club sponsorship of the draft of platform which had been circulated prior to the convention held at Alexandria Bay.

We are facing a community crisis in the maintenance of the voluntary hospital system. This was made clear at the meeting of hospital trustees yesterday when the experience of 1934 as revealed by statistics for 101 out of the 116 voluntary hospitals was presented and the even more serious situation for 1935 was set forth.

PARIS, June 25. -- France's real answer to the Anglo-German naval agreement was given today by the Naval Committee of the Chamber of Deputies. While adopting a report favorable to the construction of a proposed 35,000-ton cruiser, it declared France completely free from all naval restriction and invited the government to take measures so that France should have constantly in the Atlantic and in the Mediterranean sufficient naval forces to assure her security.

Attorney General Cummings's statement in Washington yesterday that this city is a headquarters for bucket shops drew a quick challenge from State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who asked for data and pledged his cooperation if the Federal official provides any evidence.

NEWARK, N.J., June 25. -- Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark announced today forty-three changes, promotions and new assignments of priests of the diocese. The appointments for thirteen assistants and twenty-four recently ordained priests will become effective Thursday, and for six pastors on July 3.

CLEVELAND, June 25. -- As the dispute between the Lorain unit of the Cleveland Newspaper Guild and The Lorain Journal entered its third week, Milton A. Schweid, Guild counsel, asked the Lorain County Common Pleas Court today to dissolve an injunction granted The Journal a week ago limiting the Guild to two pickets.
BERLIN, June 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 22 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

Whatever may be said of the intrinsic merits of estate and legacy taxes, nothing can be said for the proposal to rush them through in three or four days. No bill for the purpose has yet been even drafted, much less introduced and referred to a committee. It is stated that the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and Treasury officials are "racing against time" to throw together some kind of hurried measure.

Public offering of $30,000,000 Pacific Gas and Electric Company additional 4 per cent Series G first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1964 will be made today by a banking group consisting of Lazard Freres Co., Inc.; Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Blyth Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co., the First Boston Corporation, Dean Witter Co., Bonbright Co., Inc.; H.M. Byllesby Co., Inc., and E.H. Rollins, Sons, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Numerous changes in regulations designed to promote safety of passengers at sea, proposed by the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection Service, were approved today by Secretary Roper.

The preferred stockholders' committee of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation headed by Joseph P. Ripley, president of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., has addressed a letter to the 6,278 listed holders of the stock asking authority to act for them in court proceedings and in negotiations with other committees and representatives of the company.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The administration drive to jam President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing tax program through Congress within a very few days took positive form today when rates for imposts on inheritances and incomes were promulgated by Senate leaders.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, June 25. -- Following upon anti-Catholic disturbances here yesterday, new disorders tonight marked the end of a Eucharistic Congress held in this city.

The crowd that gathered at the Yankee Stadium last night to see Joe Louis trade punches with Primo Carnera was a reminder of the happy days of boxing when Jack Dempsey topped the heavyweights and was drawing million dollar gates with the magic of his famous left hook.
WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Rising meat prices had agriculture adjustment officials worried today over whether they might lead to a possible consumers' strike.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 25. -- Henry Cotton, holder of the title, and Richard Burton, rising young Cheshire pro, shared honors in leading the field with 141 apiece at the end of the qualifying rounds of the British open golf championship today.

The Giants snatched a game right out of the grasp of the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday and then the Chicagoans returned the insult with emphasis to take the second contest and even the series at two games apiece.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP). -- The Senators found little to puzzle them in the offerings of Schoolboy Rowe today and hammered the big right-hander for eleven well-bunched hits to turn back the Tigers, 7 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Designed to avoid the constitutional barrier which the previous Railroad Retirement Act was unable to hurdle, two rail pension bills were introduced today by Senator Wagner and Representative Grosser of Ohio.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- A new plan of reorganization for the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation providing for the transfer of the lease of the Northwestern Elevator in South Chicago to the Cargill Grain Company and the sale of the balance o the properties to a new concern, was presented today to the Federal District Court by Murry Nelson, head of a creditor's committee.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- A defense of Judaism as a religion rather than as a "civilization" or "system of cultural values" was stressed in the presidential address of the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson of New York tonight before the annual meeting of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

Nelson Trusler Johnson, the first United States Ambassador to China, was born in Washington, D.C., on April 3, 1887. He was a student in the Friends School in Washington from 1900 to 1906 and in George Washington University from 1906 to 1907.
LOS ANGELES, June 25 (AP). -- The earth is getting hotter all the time and some day it may take its place among the stars.

Premier MUSSOLINI'S Ethiopian enterprise, so hard to defend, has now reached what may be called the last stage of defense. It is addressed especially to Great Britain, that old friend that has been cold to this grandiose adventure. Our dispatch yesterday from Rome summarizes the official view.

The total number of unemployed workers in May was 9,711,000 as against 9,621,000 in April, showing an increase of 90,000 or 0.9 per cent, according to the regular monthly estimate of the National Industrial Conference Board made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Whether or not it succeeds, the President's attempt to force through Congress in five days an unheralded change in the revenue philosophy of the United States offers a real basis for constructive criticism when the country is ready to listen to it.

The odds are against customers who operate the "crane, claw and digger" type of slot machines found in drug and stationery stores and barrooms, Chief Engineer Thomas W. Rochester of the Police Department testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Aaron Steuer.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,728,300 barrels, compared with 2,724,050 in the previous week, an increase of 4,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 15,200 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma and a gain of 12,150 in Texas were the most important changes.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP). -- The University of Michigan captured most of the prizes in the national intercollegiate golf tournament today, easily winning the team championship while two of its stars tied with a Southerner for individual medal honors.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP). -- Miss Helen Hicks and Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, leading businesswomen golfers, gave some lessons on how to play the ancient game in a rainstorm today as they marched from opposite brackets into the second round of the women's Western open championship at the Sunset Ridge Country Club.

United States Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were quiet yesterday with changes narrow, a total of $745,200 changing hands, compared with $1,582,800 on Monday. All bond transactions on the Exchange were $12,073,200, against $12,394,300 the day before.

Bill DeLancey, the Cardinals' young catcher, yesterday chose the most opportune moment to deliver his first home run of the campaign, and with one crushing blow broke up a neat pitching duel at Ebbets Field between Paul Dean and Van Lingle Mungo, a couple of competent right-handers.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 25. -- Despite a rally that allowed her to square the match at the seventeenth green, Miss Ruth Adel of Queens Valley, the defending titleholder, was eliminated in the first round of the women's Long Island golf championship today.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, deplored last night the lack of congregational singing in the churches of the United States. He spoke at a choral evensong service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for the fourteenth convention of the American Guild of Organists.

The largest detachment of police ever assigned to a pugilistic affray practically formed a cordon about the Yankee Stadium last night. Fifteen hundred members of the force, including two emergency squads equipped with tear gas bombs and other apparatus, several high officials and more than 300 detectives, who mingled with the throng within the enclosure, made up the detachment.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25. -- The constitutionality of the law creating the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York was challenged this afternoon in arguments before Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley. Attorneys promised hurried briefs and the court indicated there would be a decision in time to send the case to the Court of Appeals before it recesses for the Summer on July 11.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Registration applications of 2,595 brokers and dealers in over-the-counter markets have been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and, while they continue to come in slowly, well over 3,000 are expected by July 1.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

A suit against the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, John S. Sumner, executive secretary, and Charles Bamberger, agent of the society, charging "conversion" of 14,000 copies of the magazine Jack Ketch, the Hangman, was dismissed yesterday by Municipal Court Justice Myron Sulzberger.
TRENTON, June 25. -- "Allah be praised," said Governor Hoffman late today when the Legislature reached final adjournment after having been in session since the second week in January.
BOSTON, June 25 (AP). -- The Braves pounded their way to a 7-2 victory over the Pirates today. Danny MacFayden, bespectacled Boston right-hander, held the hard-hitting Pittsburgh club to eight hits.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 25. -- Seven hundred woodland acres along the crest of the Palisades from the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge to the New York State line will be preserved from possible defacement and will be maintained as park property under the terms of a gift by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the Commissioners of Palisade Interstate Park.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 (AP). -- A "surprising and unexpected" decline in the Catholic birth rate was shown in a Wisconsin survey, the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told today by Professor S.A. Stouffer of the University of Wisconsin.

CLEVELAND, June 25. -- The Yanks were poised today to wind up a triumphant Western tour with a grand flourish, much in the manner of a brass band finishing its last number, when somebody blew a sour note.

With only two days remaining of the thirty-day period granted for filing new applications for refinancing of distressed dwelling mortgages by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, the New York State office in the Empire State Building was kept busy yesterday receiving the additional requests for help.

The dollar recovered yesterday, following its decline on Monday, and closed at about parity with the franc. Francs showed a net drop of 3/4 point to 6.63 cents, while the pound sterling was off 3/4 cent to $4.94 1/2. All other important exchanges followed these two toward cheaper levels.

RYE, N.Y., June 25. -- The march of the Choate School team toward its third straight leg and permanent possession of the Manursing Island Bowl was temporarily arrested today as one of its six representatives, Morton Davis, bowed to Donald M. Lay Jr. of Episcopal High, Alexandria, Va., in the third round of the Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament for private boarding schools at the Manursing Island Club.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 25. -- Shooting a perfect game, Charles Jordan of Scranton, Pa., was the only entry in two divisions of the national marbles tournament to make a clean sweep in the matches today as the Northern and Eastern sectional tournament got under way here.

The calibre of the opposition afforded the ranking array in the Eastern clay court championship improved markedly yesterday, with the result that one of the favorites passed from the scene and four others were carried to the maximum number of sets at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Moving for further economy of operation of rail carriers, Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, has recommended to the regional coordinating committees that a transportation fiscal corporation and a transportation trust company, both to be owned and controlled by the railroads collectively, be established in New York City.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Speculative interest in the grain markets on the Board of Trade was at a minimum today, with wheat easier, because of favorable harvest weather in the Southwest, while corn was somewhat firmer early because of unwanted rains over a large part of Iowa.
Two young passengers traveled alone from Callao on the Grace Line motor ship Santa Barbara, which arrived here yesterday forenoon.

Three physically handicapped boys, selected from public school classes as "most worthy of assistance" were announced yesterday as the winners of the M. Samuel Stern memorial prizes of $200 each. The awards will be made at 10 A.M. today in the office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The sharp division among American industries as to the advisability of a reciprocal tariff agreement with France was renewed today before the Tariff Commission when the silk and rayon, velvet, woolen and other branches of the textile industry urged maintenance of tariff walls, while cotton shippers, radio and anthracite coal interests strongly endorsed the proposed agreement.

After the usual preliminaries before introducing the principals in the heavyweight bout last night at the Yankee Stadium Primo Carnera's weight was announced as 260 1/2 pounds. The giant Italian had an advantage of 64 1/2 pounds over Joe Louis, who tipped the scales at 196.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP). -- Syl Johnson limited the Reds to eight hits, while the Phillies pounded a trio of Cincinnati hurlers for 14 safeties and a 10-to-1 triumph today.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- President Roosevelt appointed General Hugh S. Johnson to be Works Progress Administrator for New York City and conferred with several Representatives on TVA legislation. He received from Secretary Ickes proposals for twenty-four low-cost housing projects totaling $91,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25. -- Henry L. Doherty, head of the Cities Service Corporation, gave his interpretation of why Business behaves as it does when he testified this afternoon in the $138,000 suit brought against him for services rendered by Kenyon B. Conger, formerly in charge of his lower Manhattan real estate interests.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 25. -- A short shot from the side by the veteran poloist Benny Gatins, ten seconds before the final bell, gave the Great Island four a thrilling 7-to-6 victory over the Old Westbury riders in a third Westbury challenge cup match on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 25. -- Lieutenant R.L. Burke, private pilot for Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau and commandant of the Cape May Coast Guard station, set a new world's record tonight for amphibian planes with a load of 500 kilograms flying over a 100-kilometer course.

Revision of the present taxing and revenue system and the control of banking by business rather than political leaders were advocated yesterday by Leslie G. McDouall, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, in an address before the New York Financial Advertisers at a luncheon in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

Officials of copper companies are continuing to hold meetings in an effort to work out some arrangement which will not be in violation of anti-trust laws and which will stabilize the industry. It is understood that dissolution of the United States Copper Association, which took over many functions of the old NRA Copper Code, is being considered.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP). -- A substitute for a House bill making changes in the Air Mail Law was passed today by the Senate. It eliminates a proposed 20 per cent increase in mail rates and a limitation of $17,500 on salaries of contracting airline officials.

For the first time on record no notices were issued on the Cotton Exchange yesterday for first-notice day in an active trading position. In an effort to obtain and cancel as large a proportion of outstanding certificates as possible, the pool manager recently took over about 25,000 bales of actual cotton from the larger spot interests, leaving few certificates still out.

RYE, N.Y., June 25. -- John Marbach Jr. of the Westchester Country Club, a sophomore at Notre Dame, fashioned a dazzling card of 74 today to capture medal honors in the qualifying round of the annual Metropolitan Golf Association junior championship.

Plans for reorganization of the $13,200,000 BK guaranteed mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, covering 170 properties located chiefly in Brooklyn, were announced yesterday by the New York State Mortgage Commission, of which Wendell P. Barker is chairman.

Organization plans for an intensive campaign next Fall to raise a fund of $9,440,000 to save the city's voluntary hospitals from "operating insolvency" were discussed yesterday at a luncheon at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. About 250 men and women of national and international prominence attended.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 25. -- A three-year study of the question of service by Evangelical Lutheran ministers as chaplains in the United States Army and Navy was ordered by the Missouri Synod in convention here today. The question is important because of the Lutheran Church's strict adherence to the principle of the separation of church and State.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The dollar volume of trading in stocks and bonds on the twenty-one registered National Security Exchanges increased sharply in May and at $1,550,411,637 was 29.7 greater than in the previous month, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Joe Louis, sensational young Detroit Negro fighter, scored a technical knockout over Primo Carnera of Italy, former world's heavyweight champion, in the sixth round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout last night in the Yankee Stadium.
BIRMINGHAM, June 25 (AP). -- Collection of processing taxes from meat packers under the AAA was enjoined today as a court attack was started against the cotton processing tax here and in Macon, Ga.

The latest "billion-dollar bill" to receive the approval of the Senate is not earmarked as an Administration measure. However, a large majority of Democratic Senators voted for it. It proposes to create a new alphabetical agency, FHC, or "Farmers' Home Corporation."

MADISON, N.J., June 25. -- Trapped by sheets of flame shooting up through the flimsy interior of a six-room stucco house on the outskirts of this borough today, a mother clutched her 7-month-old twins in her arms and leaped from a bedroom window on the second floor.

Alexander Korda's London Films screen version of the late Edgar Wallace's novel "Sanders of the River" will be presented this morning at the Rivoli. Paul Robeson plays the name role, assisted by Leslie Banks and Nina Mae McKinney.

SELFRIDGE FIELD, Mich., June 25 (AP). -- Two flying cadets were killed here this afternoon when their planes locked wings during a formation flight and crashed into a marsh near the Army Air Corps field. They were Willis M. Darnell of Little Rock, Ark., and Robert C. Streator of Minneapolis.
More than twenty private detectives from Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street stores attended the arraignment in West Side Court yesterday of three women accused of shoplifting.

Cases of poison-ivy infection have grown more numerous in New York City during the past two or three years, and the fact that such cases have been appearing unusually early this Summer suggests that not all are traceable to the allurements of the countryside.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., June 25. -- Miss Nina S. Taylor, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Taylor, who have a country home on the Nissequoque River in this Summer colony, was introduced to society tonight at a large supper dance given by her parents in a gala setting of lanterns, flowers and music.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25. -- With the fastest field in history entered, the twenty-fourth annual Eastern interscholastic championship began today under ideal conditions on the old stamping ground, the Greenwich Country Club.
Coney Island's Boardwalk might be an old subject for an artist's paint brush, but if that artist is at the very impressionable age of 5 years, he will see in it exciting possibilities.
MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 25. -- All the American players here came safely through to qualify for the British open golf championship -- some easily and some by the skin of their teeth.
" Inch for inch and pound for pound, the gamest fish that swims."

While the last of his important holdings was being foreclosed, Albert L. Sire, an attorney and large property owner, who once had $10,000,000, committed suicide yesterday morning by leaping from the roof of the thirteen-story apartment house at 38 West Fifty-ninth Street, which he lost by default two years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Forty-six individuals with net incomes of $1,000,000 or more reported an aggregate of $81,558,981 in income for 1933 on which taxes were paid in 1934, according to the latest government compilation.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 25. -- Controverting Dr. Louis I. Dublin, who in a speech yesterday predicted complete control and eradication of tuberculosis in a half century, the National Tuberculosis Association went on record today as finding the disease the principal cause of death between the ages of 15 and 40, and the directors, in a resolution, called for an increased fight against the plague.

JUST to make sure that his candidates were off to a good start in the running, Bill Terry already has sent in his prize list to Frank Frisch for the National League side in the coming All-Star game. As manager of a pennant-winning combination last year, Frank wins the honor of leading the National League side this year and also choosing that side after looking over the nominations from other managers on the circuit.
ROCKFORD, Ill., June 25 (AP). -- Harry Cooper of Chicago staged one of his famous finishes today to take the Illinois open golf championship for the third straight year.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Unexpectedly stubborn opposition to the Merchant Marine Subsidy Bill, designed to substitute outright grants for the disguised aid furnished since 1928 to American shipping companies in the form of ocean mail contracts, upset plans of Senate and House leaders today to push the measure to early enactment.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today signed the $460,000,000 Naval Supply Bill, providing for a bigger navy, and the Senate quickly passed a measure providing for 1,032 more naval officers to man the added ships.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 25. -- Mrs. Henry C. Burnie and Miss Florence Le Boutillier, both of New York, were among the seeded favorites to reach the quarter-final round of the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championship on the Merion Country Club courts today.

Judge Cornelius F. Collins indicated in General Sessions yesterday that, unless the prosecution produced more substantial evidence against Nicholas Montana in his trial on a compulsory prostitution indictment, he would order a verdict of acquittal when the case was resumed today.

Charles Schlemmer, 54-year-old unemployed bartender, killed his wife, Gertrude, 41, then shot and killed himself at 10:15 o'clock last night in their tenement home at 332 East Ninety-first Street, between First and Second avenues.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 25. -- An unerring putter today enabled Mrs. Joseph J. Lawlor of Gedney Farm to score a fine 85 and win the low gross prize of a one-day women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament at the Century Country Club.
I was glad to see in THE TIMES that some employers were not increasing hours nor cutting wages since the Supreme Court decision.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Prices of hogs slumped here today, with weighty and plain quality kinds leading. First sales were weak to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday's low quotations, and the general close was down 10 to 20 cents.

A detective on the way to report for duty yesterday afternoon saw a youth taking a suspicious interest in various uptown antique shops, trailed him for three hours, seized him and got a confession which resulted in the young man's being charged with grand larceny.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 25. -- Nassau County police in cooperation with the Huntington police and representatives of the District Attorney's office of Suffolk County have broadcast a general alarm for the driver of an automobile which early this morning killed a man and a woman here and fled without stopping.

Effective on Oct. 1, the maximum rate of interest which may be paid by banking institutions chartered in this State, including savings banks, will be 2 per cent annually, according to a ruling of the State Banking Board, announced yesterday.

BERLIN, June 25. -- The premiere of Richard Strauss's opera "The Silent Woman" in Dresden last night was celebrated throughout Germany today as the year's major European musical event despite the fact that the libretto was written by a Jew, Stefan Zweig.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25. -- Regular weekly air passenger service between California and the Philippines will be started in september or early in October, V.E. Chenea, general traffic manager of Pan American Airways, indicated today.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 25 (AP). -- Harold S. Vanderbilt, Oswald Jacoby, B. Jay Becker and A. Mitchell Barnes, playing for the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York, won the all-American contract team-of-four bridge championship of the American Whist League today.

General Hugh S. Johnson, builder of the National Recovery Administration and its chief until Oct. 15, 1934, was appointed yesterday as works progress administrator for New York City, a post that entails the responsibility of supervising the expenditure here of about $220,000,000, ear-marked from the $4,000,000,000 work relief fund.

LONDON, June 25 (Canadian Press). -- County cricket championship results produced a shake-up among the leaders today. Derbyshire, although idle, maintained top honors, but Kent passed Warwickshire and Yorkshire to take the runner-up position.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- A tentative scale of rates for President Roosevelt's proposed new levies on inheritances, individual and corporation incomes, agreed upon today by Congressional leaders and Treasury experts, follows:

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Disposing of an estate estimated at $4,000,000, the will of Senator Bronson M. Cutting, New Mexico liberal, was filed here today, making many personal bequests and remembering Senator La Follette and his brother, Governor La Follette of Wisconsin, Mr. Cutting's associates in liberalism.

The New York Young Republican Club and the Young Women's Republican Club of New York adopted last night a resolution endorsing Chase Mellen Jr. for re-election as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee and pledging active support.

ALBANY, June 25 (AP). -- Albany won its second straight game from Newark, 6 to 5, tonight, scoring three runs in the last half of the eighth inning after the Bears had taken the lead with three tallies in the first half.

While efforts to push through adoption of the so-called' "fusion plan," calling for a supertrade association under the guidance of an executive vice president, by the cotton garment industry were tempo rarily checked yesterday, more than 100 delegates to the emergency convention at the Hotel New Yorker unanimously voted recognition of the need for "a central organization, representative of the industry."

An increase in services of the junior high schools, including 304 new teachers and additional supplies, at a cost of $627,000, was recommended yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, at a preliminary hearing on the 1936 budget at the Board of Education.

BERLIN, June 24. -- The Boerse fluctuated irregularly today but the general trend was downward, although regulating measures by authorities reduced business to a minimum. Heavy industrials were dull, with fractional changes both ways. Lignites were soft, Eintracht losing 2 1/2 points.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would regard an affirmative vote on his proposal to borrow $45,000,000 from the Federal Government for a municipal power plant as an endorsement of the power plant project itself. The question of approval by the Board of Estimate of his loan application to the Federal Government will come before the board on Friday.
PARIS, June 25. -- Speaking at a luncheon given in his honor by the French provincial press, Premier Pierre Laval today declared:

PARIS, June 25. -- The cause of international stabilization received what appeared to be a very serious setback this morning at a plenary session of the International Chamber of Commerce, when Lord Luke of Pavenham, reading a "statement of British monetary policy," placed his delegation firmly behind the wait and see policy of the British Government.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were the highest in two months. The total was also well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 702, as against 558 in the preceding week and 595 in the same period last year.

Many people will be surprised to learn that New York City has 40,000 acres, or sixty-two square miles, of vacant land, excluding such "permanent open spaces" as parks and cemeteries. City planners, however, have long been aware of this fact, now noted by the Mayor's Committee.

LONDON, June 25 (AP). -- In addition to Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Helen Jacobs, the American champion, Miss Dorothy Round of England, the defending titleholder, and Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling, recent winner of the French hard-court title, opened with straight-set victories today at Wimbledon.

Mayor La Guardia's declaration last week that the Fire Department would buy its equipment without any direction from a Supreme Court Justice had its aftermath yesterday before the Board of Aldermen when Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott was blocked in his effort to get $443,200 for new apparatus.

Governor LEHMAN has acted without precipitation, yet with vigor, in the matter of the vice inquiry in this county of New York. He first looked over the evidence carefully, and then announced that his survey and study of it had convinced him of the existence here of "organized vice."

TRENTON, N,J., June 25. -- No bids having been received today before 2:30 P.M., the time limit fixed by the State Sinking Fund Commission for an offering of $2,500,000 Port of New York Authority 3 per cent Series F bonds, the securities will be disposed of at private sale.

Joseph Louis Barrow is the full name of the latest star on the fistic horizon. He was born May 13, 1914, in Lexington, near Montgomery, Ala., the fourth in a line of children born to a humble cotton picker who was deep in debt and whose health was fast failing when his fourth child was born.

Industry awaits progress by the Washington administration in meeting the situation caused by the decision of the United State Supreme Court invalidating the NRA, Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, asserts in his report for the year ended on April 30, which was made public yesterday.

The Board of Elections awarded yesterday the contract for printing, stationery and supplies to be used in the primaries, during registration week and at the general election this Fall to the M.B. Brown Printing and Binding Company.

While the police yesterday made country-wide their quest for William F. Peterson as the promoter of a "get-rich-quick" investment scheme, in which at least $331,000 is involved, according to State Attorney General Bennett's office, four more witnesses were questioned before the New York County grand jury in its investigation.

MEDELLIN, Colombia, June 25 (AP). -- Investigators, examining the charred, twisted ruins of two transport planes that crashed here yesterday, today uncovered evidence that one of the pilots apparently shot himself rather than burn to death.

Awarding of eighty-one scholarships with a total value of $30,600 in the New York University School of Retailing for the academic year 1935-36 was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

LONDON, June 25. -- It was hoped that the Wimbledon tennis championship would attract a big crowd today, as all the takings were to be given to the King's Jubilee Trust Fund. The Duke of York was billed to occupy the royal box to see Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Dorothy Round make their first appearance in the centre court in their respective singles matches.

MEDELLIN, Colombia, June 25 (AP). -- Investigators, examining the charred, twisted ruins of two transport planes that crashed here yesterday, today uncovered evidence that one of the pilots apparently shot himself rather than burn to death.

Awarding of eighty-one scholarships with a total value of $30,600 in the New York University School of Retailing for the academic year 1935-36 was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary.

Eighteen properties were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Among the holdings were the eight-story San Jacinto apartment hotel at the southeast corner of Sixtieth Street and Madison Avenue, an eight-story apartment house at 511 West 113th Street and a seven-story warehouse at 542 Water Street.

United States District Court Judge Grover M. Moscowitz put in a few words yesterday on behalf of a Sheepshead Bay restaurant which is involved in a suit resulting from a raid by government agents June 17.

Interest was diverted somewhat from the bond market yesterday because of two major pieces of new financing; the United States Treasury offering of 3 per cent bonds of the 1946-48 series and the public sale of $30,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company first and refunding series G 4s of 1964.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Corporate security holders profited most from the boom in the Nineteen Twenties and suffered least from the depression in the Nineteen Thirties, according to a study made by the NRA research and Planning Division which became available today. For some days it has been in the hands of Senators interested in higher taxes.

Underwriters of municipal loans, who have been scouring the country for new offerings to meet the demand for tax-exempt securities, obtained yesterday additional information on the prospective financing to be done by the Highway Commission of the State of Oregon.

A prize for the best anthem submitted in the annual contest of the American Guild of Organists was awarded yesterday to Porter Heaps, organist of the New England Congregational Church in Chicago. The presentation was made at a luncheon held at the Hotel Astor in conjunction with the guild's annual convention, which opened Monday.
The following comment and criticism is inspired by Senator George W. Norris's proposal to superimpose the will of Congress over our Supreme Court and constitutional law.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 26. -- Many members of the Summer colony, as well as a large group from adjacent resorts, attended the lecture under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton which was given tonight in the auditorium of the new elementary school by D.B. Creager of the Long Island Laboratory of Plant Pathology.
Because of decreased tax receipts, the State deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30 probably will amount to more than $90,000,000, Governor Lehman announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- President Roosevelt's executive order establishing the National Youth Administration read as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- President Roosevelt declared at a press conference that he had never intended to suggest that his new tax legislation should be rushed through Congress before Saturday night. He set aside $50,000,000 of Work Relief funds for a youth program and held a conference on monetary matters.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 26. -- The double attraction of a new play and a new foreign actor, making his debut in this country, featured the opening for the Summer season of the Beechwood Theatre here this evening. The actor was Gaston Valcourt and the play a comedy entitled "Prelude," the first of ten new plays by Frederick Jackson which will be offered here this season.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP). -- Calumet Dick, a 5-to-1 shot carrying the silks of the Calumet Farm, owned by Warren Wright of Chicago, captured the feature race at one mile at Washington Park today.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Federal Home Loan Bank officials said today that the board would reconsider the decision to transfer the Home Loan Bank of Newark, N.J., to New York City and to change the name to "Home Loan Bank of New York."
OTTAWA, June 26 (Canadian Press). -- Eighty-one years old today, Sir Robert Borden celebrated his birthday.

The full text of the "Public Utility Act of 1935," as revised by the House committee, is not yet available for careful study. It is a lengthy and highly complex piece of legislation, already full of the scars of battle. It deals with operating companies as well as holding companies.

When the .gelo RcaZty Corp., paul :./ Santangelo, vice president, bought from the/ Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary the[ parcel at 44 Oliver St., at a price indicated / as $5,000, the corporation gave a purchase money mortgage to Robert V. Santangelo for $5,500, payable in five years at 6 per cent. This is a five-story tenement.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The objectives of the Youth Administration were outlined as follows in a White House announcement:

ARLINGTON, Mass., June 26 (AP). -- A man who, police said, was identified as Allen Upshaw, 53, wanted in Florida for alleged participation in. the $100,000 swindle of H.W. Wilmot, 65, of Montclair, N.J., in 1933, was arrested by a patrolman today.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 26 (AP). -- Sidney S. Lenz and Winfield Liggett of New York led the field in the American Whist League's contract pair whist title tourney at the end of the first session of play tonight.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 26 (AP). -- Cecil Spittler, Newark pitcher, fanned thirteen Albany batsmen tonight to establish a season's strikes out record, and the Bears triumphed, 4 to 2.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- At odds with utility holding company executives for the first time in its history, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States came out today in favor of the Utility Control Bill now pending before the House. This version of the measure would vest in the Securities and Exchange Commission broad discretionary powers to compel simplification and dissolution of present holding company structures.
PARIS, June 26. -- Ashtrays and other missiles were used today in a factional fight that marked the first meeting of the General Council of the Seine Department that was elected last May.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 26. -- Confirmation was given by the Yale Athletic Association tonight of the report that Yale had decided to drop water polo as a competitive sport on the ground that it is not beneficial to players. Several other large universities have already taken such action.

LONDON, June 26. -- The Prince of Wales in kilts, deputized to act for his father, King George, led his mother to the throne room in Buckingham Palace tonight at the last of the four Silver Jubilee courts.

Archbishop Policarp Morusca is arriving today from Bucharest on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to preside over the diocese of the Greek Orthodox Church in Detroit, accompanied by Bishop Joachim Popescu and Bishop Petre Prohnitchi.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 26. -- That medical science has not yet discovered a method of establishing artificial immunity to tuberculosis, despite the numerous efforts, was indicated today by discussion at the convention here of the National Tuberculosis Association.

TOKYO, June 26. -- Finance Minister Korekiyo Takahashi last evening openly threw the whole weight of his great prestige against the continuance of heavy domestic borrowing to meet the budgets of the Japanese Army and Navy.

A Philadelphia chapte. of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers has been organized with the following officers: Philip W. Knlskern, president; Frank P. Felton Jr. and Robert J. Nash, vice presidents; S. Craig Kane, secretary, and C. Harry Johnson, treasurer.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 26. -- Representatives of twenty-five States are expected to attend a conference here Friday and Saturday on interstate compacts to establish uniform standards of employment. Specific compacts on minimum wages, child labor and hours of labor will be considered.

After nearly 700 performances as the Ada Lester of "Tobacco Road," Margaret Wycherly forsook that role yesterday and started off on what would have to be called a well-earned vacation. She left for several months in Spain, and may or may not return in time to rejoin the show, which continues to do nicely enough at its new $1.65 top.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The dispatch from Panama that the United States had agreed to pay the $500,000 canal annuities in gold could not be confirmed late tonight at the State Department, where officials said they did not believe the government of Panama had made any such announcement.
BOSTON, June 25 (AP). -- The Pirates regained second place in the National League today as they humbled the Braves twice, by 4 -- 2 and 5 -- 1.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that Supreme Court Justice James E. Norton of Buffalo had ordered the liquidation of the Title and Mortgage Guarantee Company of Buffalo. When the company was taken over for liquidation in August, 1933, it had guaranteed mortgages and certificates amounting to about $20,000,000.

The Park Department has let a new refreshment concession in Battery Park to the Union News Company, despite an offer from an individual operator to pay the city twice as much for the privilege, it became known yesterday.
LONDON, June 26 (AP). -- Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., bowed to Miss J. Saunders of England, 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, in a first-round match of the women's singles at Wimbledon today.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Postmaster General Farley's recommendation for amendment of the law to permit prosecution for the transmission of "obscene," including contraceptive, literature at the place of receipt as well as of origin has roused wide protests, which have served to postpone indefinitely a report on the bills from the Postoffice Committees of the Senate and House.

Tuesday dispatches from England described the torments of "London's hottest June night in at least sixty-four years." The first heat wave of the season has made its appearance in the headlines. It is likely to evoke none too pleasant memories in the minds of most New Yorkers.

Grace Moore returns to the screen of the Radio City Music Hall today in "Love Me Forever," a Columbia production, directed by Victor Schertzinger and featuring Michael Bartlett, Leo Carillo and Robert Allen. "Who Killed Cock Robin," a new Walt Disney Silly Symphony in color, will supplement the feature film.

B.H. Hartogenis of Baltimore, an attorney, who owns 6 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds of R. Hoe Co., Inc., has filed a protest in Federal Court against certain requests for allowances made in the reorganization and equity proceedings of that corporation.

ROME, June 26. -- Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, left for Paris at noon today, leaving with Italians not only warm feelings of friendship and regard for him personally, but also keen satisfaction with the results of his mission.

The letter of Archibald E. Stevenson advocating bills requiring oaths of allegiance for teachers really shows very clearly what is the central objection to such laws. Mr. Stevenson says that if oaths of allegiance are required of judges, legislators, Presidents and other officials, they may also be required of teachers.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Applications on Form 1-M for registration of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission included the following firms from New York City and vicinity:

Uncle Robert, friend of the underprivileged children, was host yesterday afternoon at a party for several hundred youngsters from the gas-house district, the area between West Sixty-sixth and Sixty-ninth Streets and Tenth and Eleventh Avenues.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 26. -- A valuation of $2,871,758 was placed on the estate of Thomas A. Edison, the inventor, according to the first accounting filed today in the Surrogate's office in Newark. Mr. Edison, who lived in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, died Oct. 18, 1931.

H.H. Raymond, veteran steamship owner and operator and chairman of the board of directors of the AGWI Lines, resigned his post yesterday in a letter sent from his home in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, where he has been in virtual retirement for several years.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 26. -- When Henry Cotton stood 6 under 4s in the deluge of the eighteenth tee of the Muirfield course this morning, requiring only an easy 4 for a first-round card of 66, the British open golf championship looked to be all but over.

BUDAPEST, June 26. -- Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, the Austrian Vice Chancellor, today gave an interview to the newspaper Az Est on current political questions in which he declared that "the political situation in Austria can be regarded as absolutely consolidated" and there was "no probability of political upheavals."
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- An even dozen signatures tonight separated the House from a vote on whether it wants to issue $3,000,000,000 in new currency to refinance the nation's farm mortgages.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 26. -- The juveniles racing at the Narragansett Park track continued their assault on the five furlong record, already broken once since the meet opened a week ago, when the Wheatley Stable's good son of Hard Tack -- Swing On, Sea-biscuit, won the Watch Hill claiming stakes in 0:59 3-5 today.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- June filings of registration statements with the SEC broke all records for a single month today and brought the total since Jan. 1 to $1,051,655,936.65.

A tall apartment house on an East Side corner, a two-story building in William Street, a business structure in West Twenty-fourth Street and numerous dwellings and tenement houses were taken over by plaintiffs at auction sales in Manhattan yesterday.
General Hugh S. Johnson, newly named progress director for Federal relief projects here, conferred for almost an hour yesterday with Mayor La Guardia at City Hall on the duties of the new job.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 26. -- Miss Nancy Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen F. Noyes of Montclair, was presented to society this evening at a supper dance given by her parents at their home, Greyatone Gables. About 400 guests were present.
Lederle ,aboratories, Inc., an American Cyanamid Co. subsidiary, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The lessee has been in 511 5thAv. for sixteen years.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The President was entirely accurate when he told his newspaper callers this morning that neither he nor any White House attache is on record in support of the effort to push the new wealth-taxes through Congress by Saturday night. This is the legislative date of expiration of the nuisance taxes dealt wtih in the joint resolution to which Senate leaders sought to attach the new levies as a "rider."

Jerome D. Barnum, publisher of The Syracuse (N.Y.) Post-Standard and president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, made public yesterday a letter to Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace asking him to submit legislation to Congress specifically declaring that the government shall not have power to regulate or interfere with advertising under the proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

President Roosevelt's wealth-sharing tax program, so far as it relates to corporations, will draw the continuous fire of the nation's leading business men and financial leaders, a number who were asked for their opinions declared yesterday.

Changes resulting from the new plan for retirement of executives who have reached or passed the age of 70 and of the proposed unification of Consolidated Gas affiliates were announced yesterday. Shifts in the executive personnel, now being planned, will require about a month or two to complete.

Two incidents occurring simultaneously on opposite sides of the Atlantic offer an instructive contrast. In Paris the International Chamber of Commerce, with an American delegation present, is discussing the revival of foreign trade through removal of some of the tariff restrictions which have all but strangled it.

William R. Hayward, principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, was dismissed from service in the public school system by action of the Board of Education last night in sustaining a report of a special committee of the board which tried the principal on nine charges.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 26. -- Willie Turnesa and Udo Reinach of the Fairview Country Club captured the low gross honors in the Westchester amateur best-ball golf tournament at the Green Meadow Club today with a card of 68. Stewart Whitham and Alder Ellis of the Tamarack Country Club placed second, four strokes behind.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace today attributed the scores of suits piling up in Federal courts for recovery of processing taxes paid under the AAA to "precaution of attorneys."
For two days now Carol Stryker, director of the Staten Island Zoological Society's unfinished zoo at West New Brighton, has been listening for the snake's meow.

Following a study yesterday of a national cross-section of drug industry opinion growing out of the nullification of the NIRA, the executive committee of the institute at a meeting here announced its position to be in favor of "continuing the good crystallized by the National Retail Drug Trade Code."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 26. -- Charles D. Beckwith, retired Bronx contractor, won his three-year fight today for permission to operate a commercial bathing beach on his estate in Davenport Neck in a restricted, residential area. Thomas Kreuter, chairman of the local Zoning Board of Appeals, announced the board had granted to Beckwith the right to establish a beach club on his property, despite the zoning laws, if certain conditions were fulfilled.

Berkeley Bell, the top-ranking favorite, and John Nogrady, formerly of St. John's University, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Eastern Clay Court Championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 26. -- Billy Dettweiler, 17-year-old star from Georgetown Prep, today won the qualifying medal in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship with a total of 147 and Peddie gained the team honors for the first time in history.

Francis Italiano, better known to the police as Sebastino Mano, frequently arrested but only once convicted small-time racketeer, bookmaker and former bootlegger, was shot dead by two unidentified men yesterday afternoon in a crowded street in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn. His assailants escaped after a policeman had chased them several blocks and fired two shots.

BERLIN, June 26. -- Chancellor Hitler definitely entered the church conflict today through a decree promulgated tonight by the Cabinet taking the final decision as to the legality of the Protestant Nazi Reich Bishop's measures out of the hands of the regular courts and placing it in those of a newly created commission under the Reich Ministry of the Interior.

MERIDIAN, Miss., June 26. -- Fears that crystallization of vital units of their motor might suddenly end their endurance flight with a new world's record almost within their grasp, harassed Fred and Al Key, Meridian brothers, tonight as they entered the final 24-hour stretch separating them from their goal.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 26. -- Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, denounced President Roosevelt's tax program today as a "turn to experimentation through taxation," an attempt to "kill the goose" by drying up the sources of revenue and "hurried proposals directed toward the reshaping of the whole economy by the perversion of the power of taxation."
BERLIN, June 26. -- Compulsory labor service for all German young men and women was decreed at today's Cabinet meeting, the last one scheduled before the Ministers go on their Summer vacations.

BUENOS AIRES, June 26. -- Argentina's exports to the United States doubled in the first five months of this year compared with the corresponding period last year. The National Statistical Bureau's report for May values the shipments to the United States since Jan. 1 at 71,600,000 pesos, compared with 36,500,000 pesos at the end of May last year.

A new issue of $18,594,000 Consumers Power Company first lien and unifying mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series of 1935, due on May 1, 1965, will be placed on the market today at par and interest. The offering will be made by a banking group headed by Bonbright Co., Inc., and including the First Boston Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc., E.W. Clark Co. and Coffin Burr, Inc.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 26. -- Providing another surprise triumph, its third in as many games in the third Westbury Challenge Cup tourney, the Gulf Stream polo four, led by Terence Q. Preece, today rode into the tournament's final round by defeating the Texas quartet, 11 to 6, on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

New rate schedules recently submitted by the six electric companies of the Consolidated Gas System will result in higher rates for breakdown and auxiliary service supplied to commercial users, the Public Service Commission was told at a hearing yesterday.

District Attorney DODGE did not long delay in announcing that he would comply with Governor LEHMAN'S order in the matter of appointing a special prosecutor to take charge of the inquiry into racketeering and organized vice in the county of New York. He said to reporters: "The Governor is the boss, isn't he?"

Characterized by rather cautious trading, the share market drifted lower yesterday. Publication of the tentative schedule of new tax rates was, in itself, sufficient to give the market pause; and now it develops that the program may not be enacted as quickly as was originally indicated, although it is hardly to be expected that the hearings thereon will receive the time usually accorded to a subject of this importance.
LONDON, June 26. -- A fierce onslaught on the Anglo-German naval agreement in the House of Lords tonight was made in a debate on the naval and military situation.

HAMMONTON, N.J., June 26. -- The raspberry crop in this part of the State will be ruined in three days if the growers, who estimate their potential loss at $500,000, cannot get pickers to harvest the fruit. Ordinarily, nearly 1,000 men, women and children are hard at work in this town, Mullica, Egg Harbor City, Folsom and Buena Vista picking the berries at this season, but there are very few now.

Two gamecocks that looked a bit mangy but were "trimmed down," ready for fighting, were yesterday in the hospital of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Avenue A and Twenty-fourth Street.

Although he ruled that the "crane, claw and digger" type of slot machines were not in themselves a violation of the State penal laws, Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer refused yesterday to grant an injunction restraining the police from interfering with the operation of the machines, or from confiscating them.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., June 26 (AP). -- Breaking under the steady file of State witnesses who pointed accusing fingers at him, Walter (Irish) O'Malley, ex-convict, interrupted his trial late this afternoon to plead guilty of kidnapping August Luer, 79-year-old Alton banker and meat packer, on July 10, 1933.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 26. -- Mrs. Henry March, the leading player of the North Shore Country Club for the past nine years, put to use a knowledge of her home course in defeating Miss Rosalie Knapp, the medalist, over these links in the women's Long Island golf championship today.

SCHEVENINGEN, Netherlands, June 26. -- Oral argument before the Italo-Ethiopian conciliatory commission will be made by legal counsel representing the two nations probably next week. Ethiopia has designated Gaston Jeze, noted French jurist and counselor of the Ethiopian Legation in Paris, to present her case, while the argument for Italy will be presented by an Italian authority who is expected to arrive here soon.

BERLIN, June 26. -- The Boer-qe was comparatively inactive today. Heavy industrial shares had insignificant changes, although tarpener lost 1 points. Potash stocks were slightly weaker. Machinery shares moved little, but Berlin Karlsruhe lost 2 points.
After an early decline of a few points resulting from favorable weather and an easier stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed at gains of 3 to 9 points.

Making his first "run" to New York City, George P. Weik, 70-year-old locomotive engineer, accepted yesterday, on behalf of the Burlington Railroad, the 1934 E.H. Harriman Memorial Medal for Group A Railroads.

PARIS, June 26. -- A surprise victory for the United States delegation's proposal for immediate intergovernmental consultations on international stabilization was won today at the International Chamber of Commerce Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- A one-man filibuster by Representative O'Malley of Wisconsin blocked passage by the House today of the Merchant Marine Subsidy Bill, his purpose being to obtain a record roll-call.
WASHINGTON, Pa., June 26. -- The Yankees interrupted their pennant pursuit long enough today to defeat their Washington farm club in the Pennsylvania State Association, 12 to 2.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The House Banking and Currency Committee will consider tomorrow what action it will take on the temporary deposit insurance extension passed yesterday by the Senate.

About twenty-five years ago, when Clarence M. Woolley, chairman of the board of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Company, bought an oil painting in Florence, Italy, the seller unwittingly gave him a second picture, which is just coming to light.

The adoption of 21-year-old James Manzi by Mrs. Evelina Tietjen, a 74-year-old Brooklyn widow, who died twenty days later leaving her $70,000 estate to Manzi, was set aside yesterday by Surrogate George A. Wingate in Brooklyn.

Continuing the streak of winning favorites, Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Clocks, a full brother to Tick On and a son of Watch, from Sox, scored yesterday at Aqueduct by three lengths at the short price of 2 to 5 in the featured St. Carl Purse.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- The demand for fresh pork continues to be reported as slow, both here and in the East, and the local market was quoted as steady to a half cent a pound lower than yesterday at 16 1/2 to 23 1/2 cents. Owing to the slow movement, the demand for hogs was not aggressive and prices were steady to 5 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., and Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, famous woman athlete of Beaumont, Texas, did not even have to finish their eighteen-hole matches today to advance to the quarter-finals of the women's Western open golf championship.

Although seasonal forces are tending to curtail steel operations, the rate of production is holding at 38 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age, issued yesterday. Prices of scrap steel, which are regarded as a barometer of mill operations, are unchanged for the third consecutive week, and the magazine states that the industry is "manifesting staying powers which suggest that minimum levels for the Summer are being approached."

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company reported yesterday for the five months ended on May 31 an estimated consolidated net income of $2,385,510 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges.

THOMAS BURKE is a Londoner from away back. Unlike the London novelists, such as Walter Besant from Portsmouth, George Gissing from Wakefield, Arnold Bennett from Staffordshire, Jerome K. Jerome from Walsall, Pett Ridge from Kent, Michael Arlen from Lancashire, J.B. Priestley from Yorkshire and Thomas Moult from Derbyshire, he really hails from the throbbing nerve centre of the Empire.

Outstanding bankers' acceptances fell $38,617,524 in May to $374,755,247, the American Acceptance Council announced yesterday. The total was the lowest since the council began collecting records eleven years ago, and was $194,035,267 below the amount a year ago.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 27. -- Seven hundred Chinese troops were still fighting 150 Japanese serving as Manchukuoan frontier police near Tushihkow this morning, according to press dispatches from Hsinking, capital of Manchukuo.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Unfavorable weather reports from the Winter wheat and corn belts dominated the grain markets on the Board of Trade from start to finish today. Heavy rains in parts of Oklahoma and Kansas, where wheat harvesting has started, led to reports of delayed movement and of damage, and started buying that did not end until prices had advanced around 2 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish.

Oswald W. Knauth, director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, testified yesterday that he had ordered the arrests for disorderly conduct on June 6 in front of his offices at 902 Broadway as the case of the crippled pickets was resumed yesterday before Magistrate Harris in the court house at 300 Mulberry Street.

Ten weeks of freedom await 1,200,000 public school children tomorrow, when classes will be dismissed until Sept. 9, and "ten timely suggestions" for health and safety during vacation are offered by the Board of Education.

MUNICH, June 26. -- Further restriction of church rights is the object of an order issued by the Wuerttemberg Minister of the Interior. He forbids until further notice, "in the interests of the people and the State," the holding of public meetings and lectures organized by churches or religious associations, except when they take place within churches or are traditional institutions, such as processions and pilgrimages. The reason given for this action is:

PANAMA CITY, June 26. -- The government of Panama let it become known today that the United States had agreed to pay the Panama Canal annuities in gold. Washington owes Panama for two years, at $250,000 yearly, and Panama had heretofore refused to accept payment in devalued currency.

Trading was mixed and small in volume on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Moderate recoveries in sugar and coffee were the only important developments of the day. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, oats, flour, cotton and tin advanced, while wool tops made a new high record.

After organizing the Allied Cotton Garment Association, the future ruling organization of the industry, the 125 delegates to an emergency convention that closed at the Hotel New Yorker last night approved unanimously a voluntary code, providing for a 40-hour week and $12 and $13 minimum wages for the South and North, respectively.
I was greatly cheered and heartened by reading the editorials "What Caused the Bank Panic" and "Nine Men." It is a matter of no small moment that THE TIMES takes this emphatic attitude.

When John Wallace, 32 years old, a workhouse prisoner, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of having heroin in his cell last May 10, James J, Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, and Warden Henry O. Schleth of the institution revealed that a "high official" in a hospital on Welfare Island was suspected of being the leader of the narcotic traffic there.

NYACK, N.Y., June 26. -- Charles D. Towt, 83 years old, retired securities broker, had been missing for twenty-eight hours without a clue tonight as 1,000 policemen, firemen, State troopers, Boy Scouts and volunteers searched the swamps in South Nyack near the Towt estate on the Hudson River shore here.

Witnesses for the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad defended the company's practices at its New York terminals yesterday at a continued hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission into methods followed by the railroads in warehousing here.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The estate of Julius Rosenwald of Chicago won a substantial victory today in a final compromise settlement of a controversy over his 1929 income taxes.

The destruction by fire of the egret and heron rookery near Beaufort, N.C., several days ago was a blow to officials of the National Association of Audubon Societies, which has done excellent work in the protection of those species.

Revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in the first three weeks of June were 4 per cent higher than those of the same period last year, according to Howard S. Palmer, president, he said that freight revenues gained 7 per cent and passenger revenues per cent and that in the third week passenger revenues rose 4 per cent and freight revenues 9 per cent.

WOODBURY, N.J., June 26. -- The Rev. Clarence Davis, 55-year-old Negro minister, was sent to the Gloucester County jail here today in default of $1,000 bail on complaint of his former parishioners at Glassboro Lawns that he had stolen the church.

DETROIT, June 26 (AP). -- Rock X, the Tranquility Farms' 4-year-old bay gelding, came from behind in the stretch to win the $1,500 University of Detroit Handicap over six furlongs at the Detroit track today. The time was 1:11 3-5.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 (AP). -- Jean Borotra, the "bounding Basque," who is competing in the Wimbledon tournament, today named Rene Lacoste, also a French tennis star, and Major Gen. Pierre Alvin as his seconds for his duel with Didier Poulain.

BOSTON, June 26. -- A milk control board council of ten Northeastern States was formed at an informal luncheon meeting of milk control officials from New England, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Maryland this afternoon.

District Attorney William C. Dodge intimated yesterday that despite the fact that Governor Lehman had confined the field of his selection to four Republican lawyers he was still in a quandary about whom to appoint as Special Assistant District Attorney to continue the investigation into racketeering and vice in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- In a White House conference marked by privacy, monetary policies were discussed by President Roosevelt today with Secretary Morgenthau, Attorney General Cummings, Solicitor General Reed and Herman Oliphant, general counsel to the Secretary of the Treasury.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 26. -- Willis Ward, Michigan's versatile Negro athlete, made an impressive start in his first fling at all-around competition today when he took the lead in the national decathlon championship in the first day of competition.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- That "dictatorships are only temporary" was the statement of Alexander Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, addressing the Chicago Bar Association at its luncheon today.

ST. LOUIS, June 26. -- About 600 store executives, buyers, and heads of stock, and nearly that number additional minor store employes, have visited the innovation in wholesale merchandising known as the Marshall Field Co. Merchandise Express, on the first section of its 3,000-mile jaunt through the Lower Mississippi Valley trade territory.

LONDON, June 26. -- The Holbein portrait of Mrs. Pemberton, bought by Lord Duveen for 5,900 guineas at the sale of the J. Pierpont Morgan miniatures on Monday, will become the property of the British nation after twenty years' absence in America.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendations of the committee on stock list to list the common shares of the Pacific American Fisheries, Inc., the Greyhound Corporation and the Armstrong Cork Company.

STONY POINT, N.Y., June 26. -- To a class of nine graduates of the Stony Point High School in the thirtieth commencement since he was graduated from the same school in a class of three, Postmaster General James A. Farley suggested tonight a career in public service.

RYE, N.Y., June 26. -- With only two singles matches listed, play in the third annual Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament for private boarding schools at the Manursing Island Club today was devoted almost exclusively to doubles competition.

The Governors of the New England States may consent to the Pennsylvania Railroad retaining its control of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad if the trunk line relinquishes its domination of the Boston Maine, Rolland H. Spaulding, chairman of the New England Governors Railroad Committee, intimated after a meeting with railroad officials yesterday.

That's all in fun, of course. But there isn't any fooling about the fact that Joe Louis can hit. The Dark Destroyer from Detroit proved that in the Carnera carnival when he brought Il Ponderoso down in a series of rolling crashes.
BEDFORD SPRINGS, Pa., June 26. -- The Pennsylvania Bar Association today "received and filed" a majority report of its Federal law committee which denounced the New Deal and attendant legislation.

An invitation to visitors to view many parts of the park where the flowers are now at the height of their blooming period was issued yesterday from the offices of the Bronx Botanical Garden. Many parts of the garden are now banked with flowers and plants, the announcement said.
Joe Louis awoke yesterday to find himself being acclaimed as the greatest heavyweight developed since Jack Dempsey emerged as champion after battering down the giant Jess Willard in Toledo in 1919.

The Giants slapped a 5-to-2 defeat on the Cubs as their parting shot to Charley Grimm's Chicagoans yesterday at the Polo Grounds and provided a fitting finale to the invasion of the Harlem by the National League's Western wheel.

LONDON, June 26. -- The British Government, on the strength of what it has heard from Anthony Eden, British Minister for League of Nations Affairs, has the gravest anxiety concerning the Italian-Ethiopian dispute. War between those countries by October is now considered not merely a possibility but a strong probability.

Nicholas Montana, an ex-convict, who was recently characterized by District Attorney William C. Dodge as "the leading vice overlord in the city," was acquitted quickly yesterday by a General Sessions jury in his four-day trial on a compulsory prostitution charge.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- After a lively discussion in which Jewish leaders of the United States and Canada voiced their views on peace and war, the Central Conference of American Rabbis voted today to reject a "100 per cent pacifist" resolution pledging the members not to support war in any form.

The John Newbery Medal, awarded annually for "the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children," was presented this year to Monica Shannon for her book, "Bobby." The selection was announced yesterday at the annual convention of the American Library Association, meeting in Denver, Col. The book, [published by Viking, is a story of Bulgarian peasant life seen through the eyes of a growing boy.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 26. -- Mrs. Henry C. Brunie of the Brooklyn Heights Casino continued her brilliant play in the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States tennis championship at the Merion C.C. courts today by reaching the semifinal round.

The first publication of the proposed new tax schedules is accompanied by what are called "hastily gathered estimates" of the probable annual yield of those taxes. The total yield is placed at $340,000,000, made up of $40,000,000 for the increased corporation taxes, $200,000,000 for the inheritance levy, and $100,000,000 for the individual surtaxes.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The proposed tariff agreement between the United States and France was attacked before the Tariff Commission today by the lace and cotton thread industries as a menace to the existence of these and other American industries, with the employment of hundreds of thousands of workers held imperiled.

A jury of middle-aged business men who witnessed a private showing of "Ecstacy," the Czechoslovak film, in which an actress appears momentarily in the nude, decided yesterday that the picture was "obscene" and unfit for the American public to view.

With a live duck disguised as a Blue Eagle on his knee and a battered stovepipe hat many sizes too small on his head, General Hugh S. Johnson was the Fall Guy yesterday afternoon at the last luncheon until September of the Dexter Fellows Tent of the Circus Saints and Sinners Club at the Hotel Gotham.

Much of the mystery shrouding the speed boat Uncle Sam, which R. Stanley Dollar Jr. will pilot in the first annual international speed boat races at Paris on July 6, was solved yesterday as the 20-year-old Californian departed aboard the United States liner President Harding for Europe.
The Park Department will ask the Board of Estimate to purchase about ninety more acres of land at Marine Park on Staten Island, it became known yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 26. -- Henry Cotton, the defending champion, and Macdonald Smith, veteran American entry, share the honors of the first day of real business in the British open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- A picture of Alaskan "pioneering" with railroad service, radios, a hospital and a laden commissary represented Harry L. Hopkins's reply today to charges that the Matanuska Valley was a nest of disease and discontent.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- President Roosevelt said today that he believed government aid was absolutely necessary to obtain parity for farm prices.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP). -- The Phillies pounded three Cincinnati hurlers for fourteen hits, including a pair of home runs by George Watkins and one by Dolph Camilli, today to heat the Reds, 12 to 5, in the final game of the series.
A letter from Jacob Marks pointed out that the present requirements for a license are so stringent as to discourage able students from following the engineering profession.

LONDON, June 26. -- Sidney Wood of New York, Gene Mako of Los Angeles, Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and John Van Ryn of East Orange, N.J., members of the United States Davis Cup team, advanced to the third round of the men's singles in the Wimbledon tennis championships today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- Charles Yates, the defending champion from Georgia Tech, drove through the first two rounds of the national intercollegiate golf championship today with a pair of brilliant triumphs. He will meet Jack Malloy of Princeton in the quarterfinal round tomorrow.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 27. -- Japanese Kwantung Army troops and Manchukuoan forces have been ordered to attack on sight any Chahar troops that may be found within the borders of Manchukuo.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 26. -- Warning that great losses and sweeping social changes might result from the results of drought and erosion in the semi-arid parts of the Great Plains unless careful long-range planning superseded the haphazard methods of the past, Dr. Isaiah Bowman told scientists here tonight that facts more valuable "than all the gold in the Klondike" were buried in climatological records at Washington.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP). -- As three railroads in New England were reporting increased net earnings, Frederick H.
