Prince suggested today the formation of operating companies as the solution of railroad troubles. His plan, he said, would avert possible government ownership of transportation companies and would solve problems of financing and reorganization.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- President Roosevelt set aside $50,000,000 from work relief funds today to give more than half a million young Americans the educational and vocational opportunities of which the extended depression has threatened to rob them.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 26. -- At a tumultuous meeting this afternoon of the party headed by former Premier Bogolyub Yevtitch -- attended by only ninety Deputies out of the 300 elected on the former Premier's ticket -- it was decided to postpone a decision on whether or not to support the Stoyadinovitch Cabinet until after it had presented itself to Parliament.

The increase in the number of givers to the Children's Aid Society may also indicate a growing understanding on the part of the public that neither city, State nor Federal funds nor the funds raised by special campaigns for family relief, are available for the dependent children for whom the Children's Aid Society cares.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- A conference to adjust the divergent views of the Senate and House on the measure extending "nuisance taxes" and 3-cent first-class postage beyond midnight Sunday was tentatively arranged for tomorrow.

The world champion Cardinals, who arrived at Ebbets Field last Sunday in second place, departed yesterday a notch lower after dropping a stormy ten-inning thriller to the Dodgers in a game which was finished under protest by Casey Stengel.

Frank Hoey, who followed the ancient and classic occupation of shepherd within sight of the crowded towers of midtown Manhattan, retires to the country next Monday after thirty-two years with the Park Department. Still a confirmed lover of wild life, he plans to raise ring-tailed pheasants on his daughter's farm near Newburgh, N.Y.

The first woman professional bail-bondsman to be indicted recently in the investigation of bail bond abuses in the courts was convicted of perjury yesterday by a jury in Judge Bohan's part of General Sessions. She was Mrs. Ray Kornberg, 62 years old, of 615 Failes Street, the Bronx.

Professor Albert Einstein, speaking last night at a United Jewish Appeal dinner in his honor, said that the "moral distintegration and intensified national egoism" of the times requires all Jews to strengthen their ranks to preserve Jewry. Of foremost importance, he said, was the upbuilding of the settlement in Palestine.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 26 (AP). -- The State Senate's "Red hunt" investigating committee, which delved into assertions that communism was taught at the University of Chicago, in a majority report late today named one professor, Robert Morse Lovett, as "unpatriotic" and recommended that any violations of the State treason code be reported to the State's Attorney.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 26. -- The field of eighty-one which started in the annual Westchester district junior girls' tennis tournament last Monday was reduced to two on the courts of the Westchester County Club today, as Miss Louise Raymond of Scarsdale and Miss Elsie Link of New Rochelle, top-seeded players, gained the final round.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Acting promptly to make use of the funds authorized in the $460,000,000 Naval Supply Bill signed yesterday by President Roosevelt, Secretary Swanson made known today that bids for the construction of thirteen new vessels would be opened on Aug. 7. Money for these and eleven other ships was provided in the measure.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The rush order on the administration's wealth-sharing tax program was canceled today after an emphatic denial by President Roosevelt that he had ever intended or intimated that this important measure should be rushed through Cogress by Saturday night.

The contention that the increased tendency of consumers to "good times" and entertainment of one kind or another is responsible for holding down the size of the average sale was advanced in retail quarters here yesterday. It was held that this situation affords an explanation for the recent marked emphasis on popular and low-price merchandise.

A sudden change came yesterday o'er the spirit of the Administration dream in the matter of the wealth taxes. It seems evident that the White House was surprised and also disturbed by the sharp protests against indecent haste which came from within Congress itself and from many parts of the country.
l{ltymond A. Manny, in 1,060 Ps.rk Av.; Harry Low, in 111 E. 62d St.; Potter, l:fmllton Co., broker.

One of the most peculiar examples of the effects of red tape was the action of the Stock Exchange yesterday in devising a special listing of the common stock underlying the voting trust certificates of the Columbia Pictures Corporation. This new form of listing, strangely enough, does not grant trading privileges to the common stock.

The pamphlet report of the American Power and Light Company for 1934, issued yesterday, says that operating revenues of subsidiaries were 5 per cent greater than in 1933 and that despite a 15 per cent increase in taxes and additional expenses for materials, supplies and labor, the net revenues from operation increased 1 per cent.
MOSCOW, June 26. -- Data that are expected to reveal the basic nature of cosmic rays were obtained today in a surprise flight of a Soviet stratosphere balloon to a height of almost ten miles.

The Seamen's Action Committee, elected last Saturday by a majority of the 1,600 unemployed seamen who were removed during the last five days from the Seamen's Church Institute, issued a statement last night declaring that the ousted seafarers did not want to return to the institute under any conditions, although they found the Bowery lodging houses to which they were transferred insanitary.

The annual report of the General Electric Company, Ltd., of England for the fiscal year ended on March 31 shows a profit of 1,184,483 on trading and income from investments, compared with 971,481 in the preceding year. Net profit for the year was 633,558 after depreciation, directors' fees, debenture stock interest, pension fund provisions and transfer to tax reserves, compared with a net profit of 434,069 the year before.

RYE, N.Y., June 26. -- August Boyajian of Arrow Brook today advanced to the semi-final round of the twenty-second annual Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship tournament, which he won last year.

The New York Stock Exchange has sent to the presidents of all listed corporations and others having securities listed on the Exchange a clarification of a recent ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission granting an extension of time for the permanent registration of securities.
DES MOINES, June 26 (AP). -- The Middle West, burned by drought and choked by dust last year, tonight counted three dead and extensive crop and property damage from torrential rain.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew took occasion again yesterday to assail Commissioner of Correction Austin H. MacCormick for his part in helping to send Mrs. Ida Kasich, 30-year-old school teacher, to the Bellevue Hospital psychopathic ward.

The symphony concert at the Stadium on Wednesday evening under the most benign of weather conditions was the "official opening" of New York's "First Annual Summer Festival" as planned by the Mayor's Municipal Art Committee. This committee of citizens representing the various fields of art has the prime function of sponsoring and stimulating activities in music, art, drama and dance.

SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J., June 27. -- Supreme Court Justice Frank T. Lloyd at his Summer home here signed an order today directing State Tax Commissioner J.H. Thayer Martin to show cause Oct. 15 why the constitutionality of the Sales Tax Law, which becomes effective next Monday, should not be reviewed.

Leon Verrees, organist and choirmaster of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, Scranton, Pa., was announced yesterday as the winner of a $100 prize in the annual organ contest of the American Guild of Organists. The announcement was made by S.E. Gruenstein, the donor, who also is the publisher of The Diapason, an organists' journal, at a luncheon held in the Astor Hotel in conjunction with the guild's annual convention.

The Public Service Commission will take no action on the new rate schedules submitted by the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas System until after July 8, Chairman Milo R. Maltbie said yesterday. The schedules called for the new rates to become effective on July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Out of a mass of data and suggestions, a half dozen sections of government sought today to piece together machinery designed to start the National Youth Administration on a road which high officials said would be to a large degree permanent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- More than 100 Presbyterian Fundamentalists of the Eastern United States, at a six-hour meeting here tonight, drew up plans for a nationwide campaign aimed at "reformation" of the present church government, which they contended was in the hands of "tyrannical" Modernists.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange presented cross currents yesterday. High-grade issues led by United States loans advanced as second-grade bonds, influenced by a sharp break in railroad obligations, generally declined. The second-grade rails fell 1 to 4 1/2 points.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 27. -- One thing was clear before the second day's play in the British open golf championship was over, and that was that the American players will have some leeway to make up on the last day.

The National League yesterday decided to call six members of the League-leading Giants and a half-dozen of the world champion Cardinals to the colors in an effort to train its heaviest guns on the American League forces in the third annual all-star game to be held July 8 in the huge Municipal Stadium at Cleveland.

PEIPING, China, Friday, June 28. -- The drinking of a toast in champagne marked today the creation of a new demilitarized zone on China's northern borders and the ousting of the Nationalist party from Chahar Province when Chinese and Japanese delegates settled the Changnei incident.

Mayor La Guardia's insistence that the Brooklyn Bus Corporation, as a condition of receiving franchises for seven extensions to existing routes, permit its employes to organize their own unions was seen in transit circles yesterday as a definite menace to the success of efforts for a tentative agreement under which the city is to acquire the B.M.T. properties for $185,000,000 as part of a general unification plan.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 27. -- Formation of a labor party, with the American Federation of Labor taking the lead in the movement, was urged by Louis Waldman, New York State chairman of the Socialist party, at the open session here tonight of the National Labor Conference, held under the auspices of the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute.

The insistence of Joe Louis, the new sensation in the heavyweight ranks, to keep active by fighting gained a point for him yesterday when Mike Jacobs, promoter for the Twentieth Century S.C., who holds a contract for his next two fights In New York, released him for one bout during the Summer.
PARIS, June 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Amendments to the Tennessee Valley Authority Act intended to clarify and strengthen the Authority's powers were reported to the House today by the Military Affairs Committee, which split four ways on the issue.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 27. -- A verdict for Henry L. Doherty was returned this afternoon in Supreme Court here against Kenyon B. Conger, who sought to collect $138,750 in unpaid "salary."
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- President Roosevelt's gold message to Congress was as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- James L. O'Neill, Acting NRA Administrator, indicated today that the fair-trade practices in voluntary codes of fair competition would be put under the supervision of the Federal Trade Commission, and that the NRA would limit itself to the labor provisions of these codes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 27. -- With the Cunningham Syndicate's twelve-meter Cantitoe showing the way at the head of the fleet, thirty-five boats sailed around Long Island Sound courses in lively time today in the New York Yacht Club's eighty-fourth annual regatta.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP). -- Dan O'Mahoney, former Irish Free State soldier, stripped Jimmy Londos of his wrestling title claims by throwing him with a flying body scissors before 30,000 fans tonight at Fenway Park. The fall was registered after an hour and 16 minutes of rugged grappling.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 27. -- E.S. Davis gave a large reception this afternoon at the formal opening of the new lounge and patio of the Seven Ponds Inn. During the afternoon there was a program by entertainers.
OSSINING, N.Y., June 27. -- Mrs. Eva Coo, 43-year-old roadhouse owner, and Leonard Scarnici, 28-year-old gunman and bank robber, were put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison tonight.
LONDON, June 27. -- Forty per cent of the entire British electorate has participated in the great peace ballot that began six months ago and ended tonight at a mass meeting in Albert Hall.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Government insurance of bank deposits up to $5,000, under the existing temporary program, which would expire at midnight Sunday, will be extended for sixty days through a joint resolution approved in both Congressional branches today in remarkably fast time.
DETROIT, June 27. -- Howard Carter Dickinson, 52, New York lawyer and nephew of Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, was found shot to death in Rouge Park at 5:45 A.M. today.

Your recent editorial on the amended West Side plan as adopted by the Board of Estimate on June 19 should give comfort to the residents of Washington Heights, if that were possible. The plan as amended uses a beautiful park for highways. This in itself cannot be condoned, and it further contemplates the destruction of Riverside Drive north of 178th Street, making use of it as a northbound express highway.
Duke Ludwig of Bavaria and the Duchess are among those leaving tonight for the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus. Others on the ship include:

Marked by another day of listless trading in which prices showed but small recessions on the average, the share market closed steady. Transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated 736,000 shares, the smallest total for a full five-hour trading period since June 10.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 27. -- A picture of a new America freed from toil, hunger and disease with scientists and economists working together to create a "fairyland of achievement" was presented to the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science today by Dr. Charles E. Merriam, member of President Roosevelt's National Planning Board.

LONDON, June 27. -- The sale of the stamp collection of the late Arthur Hind, American philatelist, at Harmer's, closed today with keen competition for rare Hawaiian "missionaries," so-called because most of the specimens were found on letters from American missionaries there and they are now all the rarer because many specimens were lost in the San Francisco fire.
LOS ANGELES, June 27 (AP). -- Ten thousand students began matriculating today in perhaps the strangest school in the country.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27. -- Tennis comes first, Jean Borotra decided today, and dueling second.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Robinson Truesdale of 26 East Eightieth Street, New York City, and Westbury, L.I., introduced to society their debutante daughter, Miss Lucy Truesdale, at a dinner dance tonight at the Creek Club here.

BERLIN, June 27. -- Conscription of all German feminine youth for compulsory labor service, decreed yesterday in principle although not yet in practice, has thrown consternation into many German family circles, particularly among the well-to-do.

Charges by the Citizens Budget Commission that the Chief Medical Examiner's office had collected between $170,000 and $400,000 in illegal fees were found unjustified yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, who reported to Mayor La Guardia that the situation was not as serious as it had been pictured.

LONDON, June 27 (By Cable). -- Dr. Irving Langmuir, American Nobel prize winner in chemistry and scientist of the General Electric Company at Schenectady, N.Y., has been elected to foreign membership in the Royal Society, one of the highest honors British scientists can bestow on an alien scientist, it is announced today.

For the third successive week bank clearings for the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country continued substantially higher than those of a year before. The total for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $4,997,480,000, against $4,372,874,000 for the corresponding week a year ago, an increase of 14.3 per cent, against one of 5.7 per cent in the preceding week.

A report by Charles C. Dubuar, principal actuary of the State Insurance Department, recommending the standardization of contracts issued by fraternal insurance societies was made public yesterday by Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance.

Bearing a foreword by Alfred E. Smith, honorary night superintendent of the Central Park Zoo, an animal picture book for children will be placed on sale Monday at the Zoo restaurant and on the carretinas.
LONDON, June 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- An openly antagonistic House heard the administration's Public Utility Holding Company Bill denounced on the floor today as the first step in a plan for government ownership and operation of all utilities when Republicans launched a bitter attack on the measure.

Declaring that the city must cut its monthly relief contribution by about $2,000,000 for each of the next three months, Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch again criticized the relief administration under Oswald W. Knauth yesterday.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Two important railways, the Chicago North Western Railway, Company and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, decided yesterday to file petitions for reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.
Relatives and friends here of Howard Carter Dickinson were shocked yesterday to learn of his murder in Detroit and were unable to think of a motive for the crime unless it was robbery.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Among the broken precedents of the New Deal may now be listed the beginning of Congressional work on a basic taxation change in July, for the Ways and Means Committee will hardly be under way until next week.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Congress was asked by President Roosevelt in a special message today to outlaw suits for damages against the government arising out of the repeal of the gold clause in Federal securities on June 5, 1933, and to end any uncertainty that might arise over the Treasury's policy in dealing with holders of gold clause obligations.
LONDON, June 27. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, whose mission to China as a British Treasury expert to study conditions in that country has been already announced, will leave England on Aug. 10.

" There are no more sticks -- no more hicks." Thus Julia Coburn, fashion editor of The Ladies Home Journal, proclaimed what became the keynote of the symposium on trends in this country, held yesterday under the auspices of the Fashion Group at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Several hundred members and guests of the organization attended.

The steel industry will vigorously contest the constitutionality of the Wagner-Connery Labor Bill, E.T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation, said yesterday. This bill, which has been passed by the House of Representatives, restates Section 7a, the labor clause of the National Industrial Recovery Act.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning there appeared an editorial, "Codes and the New NRA," which undoubtedly was based on the release of June 18 by the Consumers Goods Industries Committee.

A $100,000 breach of promise action was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against Albert Francis Free, president of F.R. Tripler Co., Inc., and officer and director of the Chicago clothing firm of Capper Capper. Although the legal ban on such suits went into effect on May 29, the present suit is permitted since the papers were served on the defendant on May 4.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The end of a two-year fight to establish an independent, permanent national labor relations board, to promote equality of bargaining power between employers and employes and to diminish the causes of labor disputes, was in sight tonight after the Senate and House had approved the conference report on the Wagner-Connery bill.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 27 (Canadian Press). -- An increase of more than $7,350,000 in the deposits of the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday was shown in the weekly statement issued today by the bank. The reserve in United States funds decreased more than $3,790,000. Advances to the Dominion Government in the period totaled $989,000.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP). -- Driving five home runs, three of them by Pinky Higgins, third baseman, the Athletics overwhelmed the Red Sox, 14 to 2, today in the first engagement of a four-game series.

With a view to improving and expediting the quotation service for bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange a telephone quotation system similar to the present one for stock issues will be installed soon, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,477,000,000, a decrease of $9,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $9,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Liquidation of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, second largest of the mortgage guarantee companies, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, despite the opposition of the company's board of directors.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- A heavy oversubscription to the Treasury's second issue of $100,000,000 in 3 per cent bonds sold on an auction basis was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.
PARIS, June 27. -- Collaboration Between England and France in European affairs seems likely to be confined for some time to ordinary diplomatic channels.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 27 (AP). -- Ted Kleinhans, leading pitcher in the International League, struck out fourteen batters to break the season's record of thirteen, which was established last night by Cecil Spittler, also of Newark, as the Bears defeated Albany, 6 to 1, tonight. The victory gave Newark an even break in the four-game series.

Suzanne Fisher, American lyric soprano, has been engaged for next season at the Metropolitan Opera House, according to a cable received yesterday from General Manager Edward Johnson. Miss Fisher is the tenth new American added to the Metropolitan personnel for the coming season.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 27. -- Spiraling to a height of 18,100 feet in a plane above Cape May Harbor today Lieutenant Richard L. Burke, commandant of the United States Coast Guard station here, established the first altitude record for a light amphibian plane carrying a load of 500 kilograms, or about 1,100 pounds.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP). -- A 17-year-old farm girl who climbed over her father's back fence adjoining a golf club three years ago to take her first lessons at the game, today provided the thrills in the women's Western open golf championship as America's two leading women professionals swept into the semi-finals.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP). -- Charles Yates, defending champion from Georgia Tech, turned on a spurt of par golf today to eliminate Jack Malloy of Princeton, 5 and 4, and march into the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate tournament.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 27. -- Officers of Westchester's two largest mortgage companies were charged with evasion of their "moral responsibilities" in a presentment handed up to Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley today by the January grand jury.

If Mr. Archibald E. Stevenson had attended the Harvard commencement he might not have written the letter published by you June 27 -- and yet again he might. President Neilson's chief objection to the bill pending in Massachusetts was that it singled out teachers as a suspect class to be put under oath.

The Pompey colt, Nautch, which has presented such a problem to Captain P.M. Walker because of his habit of running out on the turns, was on his best behavior yesterday in the featured Ram's Horn Handicap at Aqueduct and won decisively in the six-and-one-half-furlong sprint.

Efforts to obtain for creditors in the United States of German corporations and municipalities an arrangement, which is at least as favorable to them as agreements already made by German borrowers with British creditors, will be resumed early next month.

Austin H. MacCormick, Commissioner of Correction, branded as "wholly untrue" yesterday charges made by a narcotic-addict prisoner that a $500,000-a-year traffic in narcotics was being carried on in the Welfare Island Penitentiary with the connivance of an "official" on the island.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27. -- Continuing their fight against the method of assessing railroads in New Jersey, nine roads today filed suits in Federal court here to restrain the State authorities from enforcing collection of the balance of 1934 taxes totaling $12,988,086.

In preparation for the redemption on next Monday of about $600,000,000 of 2 per cent consols carrying the national bank note circulation privilege, the United States Treasury notified yesterday banks throughout the country that it would withdraw $352,869,100 of the funds that it had on deposit with them.

Launching of the new Allied Cotton Garment Association, Inc., got under way yesterday, with the election of Herman A. Speh of the Drybak Corporation Binghamton as president until Sept. 1. Mr. Speh was one of the proponents of the original "fusion plan" and was active in pushing its adoption during the industry's convention here, which ended on Wednesday.

Although government bond dealers appeared still to be somewhat skeptical of the long range benefits that might result to the Treasury Department from its new auction-bid method of selling bonds, they obviously were better satisfied with the offering which was heavily oversubscribed yesterday than with the first operation of this kind.

MEXICO, D.F., June 27. -- The economic situation in Mexico has shown considerable improvement this year and, whatever fluctuation silver may show, the monetary system will not be upset, according to Eduardo Suarez, Finance Minister.

Witnesses for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company said yesterday that certain rates and charges of that carrier relative to warehousing here had not been increased to the point where they are compensatory, as was suggested by the Interstate Commerce Commission at the conclusion of an investigation in the Summer of 1932.

Unlike some other politicians, Mayor LA GUARDIA is a man of principle, with convictions of his own about public affairs. One of his theories is that electric current has come to be such a universal need that it should be distributed to consumers at cost, by public authority, like water. He is enough of a realist, however, to know that this goal cannot be attained now.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- By a meager eight votes, the House today gave approval to a measure designed to develop the merchant marine through government subsidies for both ship construction and operation.

Evidence that foreign central banks are still finding it necessary to support their currencies, despite the seeming steadiness of the foreign exchanges, was supplied by this week's Federal Reserve report, published yesterday. The report showed that foreign central banks had drawn down their deposits with the Federal Reserve Banks $3,463,000 in the week ended on Wednesday after having increased them $6,823,000 in the previous week.

Retail deliveries made in the metropolitan area by the United Parcel Service for the week ended June 22 showed an increase of 19 per cent, the largest rise for any week this year. The figure compares with an increase of 16 per cent for the week preceding Easter.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- More favorable weather for harvesting in the Kansas and Oklahoma Winter wheat areas counted today against the maintenance of yesterday's upturn in wheat on the Board of Trade, and with the local element bearish, prices dropped around 1 cent a bushel.

An investment banking group composed of Adams Mueller, George B. Gibbons Co., Inc., and J.S. Rippel Co. has submitted a bid at slightly under par, it was learned yesterday, for the $2,500,000 Port of New York Authority 3 per cent bonds, Series F, that were offered at public sale last Tuesday by the State of New Jersey but found no takers because of a technical flaw in the loan indenture.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP). -- The Braves started to bowl over the Phillies today, but after they had won the opening game of a doubleheader, 11 to 1, they ran into difficulties and the Phils even up with an 8-to-7 triumph.

John Flaherty, 46 years old, the former Tammany election district captain and former secretary to City Court Justice Vincent S. Lippe who defrauded 100 men and women city and Federal job seekers of $250,000 in 1933 and 1934, was sentenced to a four to eight-year Sing Sing term yesterday by General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27. -- Fencing faultlessly and exhibiting the characteristics of a smooth-going and dependable hunter, the bay mare Firenze Brumanna, owned and ridden by Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., today won the $500 stake for hunters at the twelfth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.
ST. JOHN, June 27. -- The Conservative Government of Premier L.P.D. Tilley was defeated today in the New Brunswick general elections, and A.A. Dysart, Liberal leader, will form the next government.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, sitting in Special Term, Part 1, in Brooklyn, handed down yesterday a decision denying the petition of James C. Sheridan, Democratic County Leader of Queens, for an injunction restraining the Democratic Executive Committee of Queens from meeting.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP). -- A barrage of extra-base hits that into eluded Hank Greenberg's twentieth homer and three other Detroit circuit clouts, gave the Tigers a 9-to-5 victory over the White Sox today.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 27. -- By the widest margin recorded in any of the eight matches to date in the third Westbury Challenge Cup polo tourney, Pete Bostwick's Aiken Knights routed the Great Island quartet, 113 to 4, today on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club in their semi-final round match.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 27. -- Sturgeon Cross, Atlantic County Relief Director, said tonight over the telephone from his home at Atlantic City that persons on relief who refused to pick berries would be stricken from the relief rolls.

In a debate last night on the subject, "Which Road to Recovery?" Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, charged that business conditions were ripe for prosperity but that the New Deal was blocking the path, while United States Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, predicted that New Deal measures would soon produce a great revival of business and industry.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- A "cross-licensing section" among railroads, providing for an arrangement by which all roads could enjoy the advantages of devices on which the patents are owned by one road, and the joint acquisition of patents which could be used for the general technical improvement of all carrier lines, were recommended to the regional coordinating committees today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- There were 2,158,919 live births in this country last year, a rate of 17.1 per 1,000 population, marking an increase over 1933, when the rate was 16.6, according to statistics made public today by the Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

NAME of a pipe! There is some writing of tennis and then, behold! M'sieu Poulain is outraged. M'sieu Borotra is challenged. A duel is on the tapis, as they say on the boulevards. Allez-houp! Et gare la belle!

BEDFORD SPRINGS, Pa., June 27. -- Attacks on the New Deal were made at the annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Bar Association here tonight by Scott M. Loftin of Jacksonville, Fla., president of the American Bar Association, and Harvey T. Harrison of Little Rock.

Bids for a contract for construction of the Bronx span of the Triborough Bridge were opened yesterday by the Bridge Authority at its offices, 111 Eighth Avenue. The McClintic-Marshall Corporation submitted a low bid of $1,093,753 for the work, which the authority's engineers had estimated would cost $1,186,000.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 27. -- Charles A. Whitcombe of Crews Hill, the second eldest of three famous golfing brothers, set such a pace in the British open championship today that neither Henry Cotton nor any of the visiting Americans could stop him.

First definite acceptance by any industrial group, since the Supreme Court's decision on the NIRA, of an enforceable agreement to preserve the benefits to labor and capital incurred under the NRA, was announced yesterday following a mass meeting of the Ribbon Manufacturers of America, held at the offices of the National Federation of Textiles, 10 East Fortieth, Street.

DUBLIN, June 27. -- More than 200 guests, representative of all aspects of contemporary Irish life, attended a dinner at the Hibernian Hotel tonight in honor of the seventieth birthday of Ireland's most distinguished man of letters, William Butler Meats, poet and playwright.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Challenging anew the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission, J. Edward Jones of New York, dealer in oil securities, failed to appear before the commission today in a stop-order proceeding aimed at a registration statement filed by him in May.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 27. -- The career of Billy Dettweiler, Georgetown Prep star, in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship came to an abrupt and totally unexpected end today. After winning the qualifying medal yesterday with a 147 at the Greenwich Country Club, Dettweiler today faced Robert (Butch) Riddle, fullback on the Peddle eleven last Fall, and was eliminated by 6 and 5.

The Milbank Memorial Fund, which is interested principally in public health, education and social welfare, expended $326,919 for projects and grants-in-aid during 1934, according to the foundation's annual report made public yesterday.

PALMER, Alaska, June 27 (AP). -- Six families of the 200 Middle West farm groups brought here for the Matanuska Valley colonization project "signed up" today to return to the States, officials disclosed, while a large group insisted emphatically that they would remain in the valley.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Nine outright PWA grants for New York City, totaling $17,348,529, received final approval today from President Roosevelt. Calculated to cover 45 per cent of the cost of constructing various types of projects, the grants to the city were among sixty-three, totaling $21,299,628, approved by the President in an effort to get the PWA program under way in many parts of the country.
Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, will be one of General Hugh S. Johnson's right hand men in the administration of work relief in New York, the general announced yesterday.

PARIS, June 27. -- The American policy of negotiating bilateral trade treaties received alternate blame and faint praise at today's session of the International Chamber of Commerce Congress. However, although the world's business leaders were skeptical of the work Secretary Hull is trying to do along that line, they all seemed to agree that his advocacy of the most-favored-nation treatment was wise.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Six proposals designed to aid recovery through a "fundamental reconstruction of our economic organization" were presented today before the annual meeting of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- More than 300 men and women lace workers from mill towns in Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania marched in on a Tariff Commission hearing today to protest against any reduction in duties on imported lace in the proposed reciprocal tariff agreement with France.

LONDON, June 27. -- Anthony Eden, Minister for League of Nations Affairs, returned to London this evening by airplane a day earlier than he had intended, and his curtailed visit to Paris was interpreted here as meaning that his conversation with Premier Pierre Laval today was as unsatisfactory as his discussions with Premier Benito Mussolini in Rome.

The expenditure of upward of $200,000,000 on a project by the Federal Government must, even in these days of lavish outpouring, compel attention and provoke inquiry. Yet in this case of the proposed ship canal across Florida, little but whisperings of the active promoters in Jacksonville and in Washington has been heard, even by those who have a vital stake in the matter.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 27. -- Dr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Pool gave a supper dance tonight at Highpool, their country place in this community, to introduce to society Mrs. Pool's daughter, Miss Mary Averell Harriman.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the appointment as assistants to parish pastors of thirty-eight priests whom he had ordained a fortnight ago in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Cardinal also announced the transfer of twenty-nine assistants from one parish to another.
A limited supply of contracts to meet a steady routine demand from the trade brought a 10-point improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, with gains 5 to 9 points at the close.

PARIS, June 27 (AP). -- The national defense budget of France reached a total of approximately 15,000,000,000 francs [the franc was quoted at 6.63 5/8 cents yesterday] with the approval by the Chamber of Deputies Finance Committee of an additional 1,106,000,000-franc appropriation last night and the authorization of 500,000,000 francs extra for arms and ammunition contracts for 1936.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Our New York State Young Republicans will be gratified to see that their Yankee brethren are full of the same enthusiasm and energy. There was a conference of New England Republicans in April, called by the State and national committeemen, but its proceedings attracted no great attention. It left no echo.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Active competition between local packers and shippers for desirable hogs lifted prices 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight here today, weights under 160 pounds showing the most gain. Some shipping orders were unfilled. The top price was lifted 20 cents to $9.70, while the day's average was up 15 cents from yesterday at $9.

RYE, N.Y., June 27. -- The existence of the Manursing Island Bowl, team prize in the annual Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament for private boarding schools, was short-lived as the Choate School netmen of Wallingford, Conn., clinched their third straight leg on the trophy today.

The plan of consolidation and readjustment of the Winnipeg Electric Company, the Manitoba Power Company Ltd.; the Northwestern Power Company, Ltd.; the Winnipeg, Selkirk Lake Winnipeg Railway Company, and the Suburban Rapid Transit Company, approved by the directors of the companies and protective committees for their bondholders, will be submitted to meetings of the various bondholders in Toronto and Montreal in August.

ALBANY, June 27. -- Without writing an opinion, the Appellate Division, Third Department, unanimously upheld Supreme Court Justice Schenck today in refusing a mandamus compelling Secretary of State Flynn to certify additional legislators for Queens County.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman intervened yesterday in the situation in the garment industry, where a strike of 40,000 workers has been threatened. He called a conference of the opposing factions, to be held today in the Executive Mansion in Albany.

FOWEY, England, June 27. -- Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee again was defeated today when the America's Cup challenger Endeavour, with her owner, T.O.M. Sopwith, at the helm, beat six other great cutters by nearly seven minutes in the regatta of the Royal Fowey Yacht Club, of which Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch is commodore.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 27, -- How deeply the Canadian Government became committed during its four-year effort to stabilize Canadian wheat prices was revealed for the first time today to the committee which is considering the proposed nationalization of Canadian grain marketing.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 27. -- A plea for wider acceptance of the county unit plan of health control was voiced today by Governor Lehman in an address before the annual conference of Health Officers and Public Health Nurses. Because counties have been slow in adopting such a program, he said, the district health staff of the State Department of Health has had to be extended and enlarged.

MERIDIAN, Miss., June 27. -- The airplane Ole Miss, piloted by Fred and Al Key, grimy but happy brothers, set a new world's endurance flight record at 3:13 1/2 P.M. today, after having been nearly twenty-four days in the air.

The Queens County grand jury, which had heard evidence against Frank d'Amato, 13 years old; his brother, Julius, 11, and Lisbon Lawrence, 13, the three Jamaica boys who had confessed the murder of William Walsh, 36, during a "hold-up" in Jamaica, reported yesterday, that they had found no indictment.

The New York Telephone Company yesterday served upon Controller Frank J. Taylor notice of an action to force the city to return $1,533,781.37, plus interest, paid by the company in accordance with the provisions of the city law levying a tax of 1 1/2 per cent on the gross revenues of public utilities functioning here in 1934.

Discussion of currency stabilization by the International Chamber of Commerce at Paris has been made interesting, first by the renewal of obstructive tactics by the British delegation, but more especially by the American delegation's adherence to the plan of early action and by the understood concurrence of the Chamber in the American attitude.

DUBLIN, June 27. -- Alvin Mansfield Owsley, the third United States Minister accredited to the Irish Free State, presented his credentials to Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council, at Dublin Castle today. The Minister, who was accompanied by Joseph Walsh, Secretary of the Department of External Affairs, drove in state from the United States Legation in Phoenix Park to the castle.

In a special message yesterday President ROOSEVELT asked Congress to enact a law whereby the Government never can be sued in the courts for violating the gold-clause contract in its bonds. If consent to such a suit has inadvertently been made, it is withdrawn; and refusal to give such consent is made absolute for the future.

TEANECK, N.J., June 27. -- A boy 13 years old and another 8 were drowned this afternoon when a home-made rowboat capsized throwing them and three playmates into the swift-flowing Hackensack River here.

LONDON, June 27. -- The outstanding tennis stars had to work hard for their victories today at Wimbledon. Fred Perry and Jack Crawford dropped sets, while Miss Helen Jacobs and Sidney Wood, Christian Boussus, Donald Budge and Baron Gottfried yon Cramm all had sets where they struggled beyond 5 -- all.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Burnham McKitterick gave a farewell dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Mrs. Walter O. Ford, who is sailing today on the Kungsholm for the North Cape cruise.
ATHENS, Greece, June 27. -- Troops have been ordered to Rethymnon in Crete to reinforce the constabulary, who are said by the Mayor to be unable to hold in check the angry anti-monarchist population.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Adoption of President Roosevelt's program for Federal inheritance taxes and higher graduated corporation income levies, as well as increased individual income taxes in the brackets above $1,000,000, will keep Congress in session for another two months, Speaker Byrns predicted today.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- John Dillinger's lawyer, Louis Piquett, former bartender and politician who became an attorney by the night school route and city prosecutor under Mayor William Hale Thompson, was sentenced today by Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan to serve two years in Leavenworth prison and pay a fine of $10,000.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., June 27.-Close games marked today's play in the Northern and Eastern divisions of the national marbles tournament being played here this week. There were matches tn four leagues in each division. League winners will! compete tomorrow morning in the division finals.
A Summer thunderstorm with lightning directly over the city, brought relief early last night after a sultry day of high humidity in which the temperature rose to a maximum of 81 degrees.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 27 t/P). -- Sidney S. Lenz, New York bridge expert, today won his second championship of the American Whist League Congress, teaming with another New Yorker and two Chicago district players to capture the combination team and pair whist championship in the closest kind of finish.

President Roosevelt's new tax program was assailed yesterday by the executive committee of the New York Board of Trade as "class legislation" aimed at exclusive direct taxation of the middle class and the wealthy to an extent "which in some cases will amount to confiscation."

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- President Roosevelt sent a message to Congress asking legislation to outlaw recovery suits because of the repeal of the gold clause. He approved allotments in the work relief program totaling $21,299,628.

TOKYO, Friday, June 28. -- With confirmation of China's acceptance of Japan's Chahar demands comes news from Hsinking, capital of Manchukuo, that the Tushihkow conflict is over, as the 700 Chinese troops that attacked 150 Japanese are withdrawing. Information from this danger spot has been extremely scanty.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 27. -- For the fourth time since 1931, when she came to the metropolitan district as Southern champion, Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake gained the final of the women's Long Island golf championship today.

To enjoy their biggest day of the campaign, the Yankees returned to the Stadium yesterday and scored a 15-5 victory over the Senators, burying them under an avalanche of nineteen base hits, one of which was Ben Chapman's fifth home run of the year. A crowd of 6,000 was on hand.
J. Gilbert Hall, the defending cup-holder; Frank Bowden and Julius Seligson gained their quarter-final brackets yesterday in the Eastern clay court championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
The Paramount this morning will offer "Men Without Names," the latest of the G-Men type of films. In it are Fred MacMurray, Madge Evans, Lynne Overman and Leslie Fenton.
Money market was stagnant. Demand for funds being light, the quotations for all classifications were carried forward without change.

The New York Curb Exchange has received a notice that the interest due on July 1, 1935, on Guantanamo Western Railroad Company 6 per cent first mortgage gold bonds, Series A, would not be paid on that date.

The isolation of a crystalline protein which possesses the properties of a virus and, by its action, is believed to be the virus itself made tangible and visible for the first time, is announced in the current issue of Science by Dr. W. M. Stanley of the Princeton station of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

WHEN Dr. Hans Zinsser, author of "Rats, Lice and History," weighed rodents and human beings in the balance and found the rodents to be the more respectable, inasmuch as they had failed as yet to evolve into a political animal, he must have been looking over the proofs of M. Lincoln Schuster's "Eyes on the World" (Simon Schuster, $3.75).

String quartets by Frederick Jacobi and Arthur Shepherd have been chosen for publication this year in the annual competition conducted by the Society for the Publication of American Music; it was announced yesterday. A. Walter Kramer is president of the society.

Transfer of unemployed merchant seamen from quarters in the Seamen's Church Institute to lodgings in the Bowery and other downtown sections of the city, has been completed under the direction of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- A list of applications on Form 1-M for registration of brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission contained the names of the following firms from New York City and vicinity:

Sharp criticism of Governor Lehman, the utility program he pushed through the Legislature last year, and of the Public Service Commission, featured the hearing held yesterday by the Mack committee investigating public utilities.

School is out today and by nightfall nearly half of the 1,200,000 enrolled will have discarded their books, retrieved last year's duffle and camping equipment and prepared for the annual migration to Summer camps.

Trading continued mixed in commodity futures here yesterday, only coffee and silk advancing. Other staples were steady to weak, with trading listless in tone. In the cash markets rye, tin, cotton and wool tops advanced, the last named to another high level, while wheat, corn, oats, lard and rubber declined.

" Kind Lady" will end -- or only interrupt -- its New York engagement tomorrow night at the Booth. Grace George, its star, will take a vacation of almost two months -- it is said that her contract contained a clause excusing her from hot weather performances -- and the show will accordingly suspend until Aug. 26, at the earliest.
Yesterday's closing quotations in the principal European markets follow:

Two large advance printings of new books are scheduled for this Summer. Harcourt, Brace have decided on a first printing order of 35,000 copies of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "North to the Orient," coming in August. Knopf will print 52,500 copies of Willa Cather's new novel, "Lucy Gayheart," before publication on Aug. 1.

Approval of the application of the New York Central Railroad to substitute twelve and twenty-six trip family fare tickets for the twenty-five and fifty trip tickets now in use on its Hudson, Harlem and Putnam divisions was announced yesterday by the Transit Commission.

Following the declination of each of the four Republican lawyers he had designated to head the new extraordinary grand jury investigation of organized crime and vice here, Governor Lehman invited the four men last night to a conference tomorrow, at which he hopes to persuade one of them to accept.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 27 (AP). -- Favorites were ambushed from every angle on their clay road to the national intercollegiate tennis singles championship at Northwestern University today, but the three choices beat back the attacks and emerged safely into the quarter-final round.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP). -- The validity of the New York Gross Sales Tax Law was challenged today in the Supreme Court in a petition filed by D.A. Schulte, Inc., operator of 125 chain stores in that State.

Governor LEHMAN'S announcement that this State now faces a deficit of $90,000,000 was made with an air of disappointment and even chagrin. But why should he feel that way about it? A deficit is almost the universal rule nowadays. Everybody is wearing one.
PITTSBURGH, June 27. -- Twelve of the twenty-three children of Mr. and Mrs. John Damp were with the elderly couple today as they celebrated their sixtieth wedding anniversary.

With more than 200 contestants entered, the seventh annual Great Eastern skeet championships will get under way tomorrow morning on the famous Lordship shooting grounds of the Remington Gun Club near Stratford, Conn. The program will end on Sunday evening.

The identities of brokers who figured in the sales of three memberships in the New York Stock Exchange in the last week at prices from $99,000 to $108,000 were made known yesterday. The latter price, which is the highest for this year, will be received by the estate of the late Percy A. Rockefeller.

Outdoor camp life within the city which will take underprivileged girls away from the sidewalks, hit-and-run drivers, heat and din of their usual existence was described by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman in a broadcast last evening following an inspection tour of cool and wooded sites in Van Cortlandt and Inwood Parks.

RYE, N.Y., June 27. -- Frank Strafaci of Arrowbrook today won the twenty-second annual junior championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Apawamis Club by subduing the defending titleholder, August Boyajian, also of Arrowbrook, 2 and 1.

BERGEN, Norway, June 27 (AP). -- The first competitor in the Newport-Bergen transatlantic yacht race reached the finishing point at Marstenen with the arrival of the ketch Vamarie shortly after noon, Eastern standard time, today. The Vamarie, owned by Vadim S. Makaroff of Oyster Bay, L.I., made the trip in 19 days 17 minutes and 10 seconds.

A movement to resist the efforts of the Federal Government to collect AAA processing taxes is rapidly gaining momentum in the food industry, leaders of the trade reported yesterday. Beginning shortly after the Supreme Court outlawed the NRA in the Schechter case, the movement has spread in various parts of the country during the last few days, a canvass of the food industry revealed.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP). -- Charles Yates of Georgia Tech and Johnny Fischer of Michigan, former winners of the crown, saw their hopes of another title fly away today before the withering fire of a pair of Southwesterners, Ed White of Texas and Fred Haas of Louisiana, in the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate golf championship.

CAMP TAMINENT, Pa., June 28. -- The people of the United States will not get low-cost housing on any scale commensurate with the needs until the housing question is made a major political issue, Langdon Post, Tenement House Commissioner of New York City and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, told the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute, now in session here.

Investment bankers who are seeking offerings of tax-exempt securities by States and municipalities to meet the strong demand for such investments that has been heightened by discussion of prospective increased taxes face a lean prospect for the early part of July.
BERLIN, June 28. -- The Boerse, which tomorrow will celebrate its 250th anniversary, continued today the upward price movement with increasing momentum and a larger turnover.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2S. -- Composed of two Harvard youths and a pair of veterans, the smooth-functioning Meadow Brook Ramblers conquered the Roslyn polo quartet, 8 to 6, today on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club as play started in the Meadow Brook Club Cups Tournament, an annual handicap event.

EASTPORT, Me., June 28 (AP). -- Eastport tonight paid tribute to Dexter P. Cooper, who brought home to his native heath $36,000,000 in Federal funds to build the giant Passamaquoddy tidal power project he conceived eleven years ago.

In the vanguard of next season stands Crosby Gaige's venture into Shakespeare, "Macbeth" and "Othello," co-starring Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper. Their season will open here on Monday, Sept. 23, after a Boston engagement beginning on Sept. 12. Rehearsals will start on Aug. 8.

ROME, June 28. -- Premier Mussolini stole enough time yesterday from his extraordinary cares, which have been increased greatly by the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, to spend a thoroughly rustic day among the peasants of the redeemed Pontine marshes, performing what has become a traditional ceremony of threshing the season's first wheat.

While waiting in line at the teller's window of the Continental Bank and Trust Company, 30 Broad Street, to cash a $1,500 check he had just taken at the point of a gun from a Pine Street stock broker, Joseph Sullivan, 57 years old, who said he was an insurance broker of 45 John Street, was arrested by detectives yesterday afternoon.

There it goes again. A Masked Marvel at Muirfield. There was a fine time in this corner getting the Perry problem straightened out. First flash from high over the sea: Fellow named Perry wins the championship. From Muirfield? Yes,from Muirfield. Must be a mistake. Something from Wimbledon, probably, mixed up in transmission. No need of getting excited over Fred Perry winning at tennis.

The "Floating Congress" of the Pan American Medical Association, composed of physicians and surgeons from North and South America, sailed shortly after midnight last night on the Queen of Bermuda for Rio de Janeiro with several stop-overs en route.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- At least $100,000,000 of work relief money will be spent on street repair and construction in and near metropolitan areas, Thomas H. McDonald, chief of the Bureau of Public Roads, announced today. New York City will receive a "substantial amount" of this, he said.

Mayor La Guardia said last night that Park Commissioner Robert Moses was talking "baby talk" when he threatened to resign from both the Park Department and the Triborough Bridge Authority unless he was reappointed to the latter post on Monday.
Pat O'Brien will have the role now being played by Osgood Perkins on the stage of the Vanderbilt Theatre when First National starts work on its film version of "Ceiling Zero."

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- In the face of what the House leadership regarded as certain defeat, President Roosevelt said at a press conference today that he was more eager than ever to see enacted the administration bill which would bring under Federal control all utility holding companies and eventually eliminate all but "primary" holding units.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- A bill, which would deny to holders of government securities the right to sue for damages resulting from devaluation of the dollar and abrogation of the gold clause in government contracts, but authorizing the exchange or redemption of all such securities offered for payment by Sept. 1, was introduced in the House today by Chairman Steagall of the Banking Committee.

HONOLULU, June 28. -- The Coast Guard cutter Itasca has returned from Jarvis, Baker and Howland Islands after having left Hawaiian youths on each island to make an hourly check of weather data for the United States Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP). -- Robert L. Lund, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, was reported authoritatively tonight to be resigning from the Roper Business Advisory Council.

The heaviest sentence thus far imposed on a home relief "chiseler" was pronounced yesterday in Special Sessions by Justice Dale, Gresser and Kernochan when they sent Frank Stubbs, 37 years old, to the workhouse for six months.

ROME, June 28. -- Much speculation has been caused in diplomatic and journalistic circles in Rome by the news that General Marie Gustave Gamelin, French chief of staff, left for Paris today after a twenty-four-hour visit during which he is believed to have conferred with Marshal Pietro Badoglio, Italian chief of staff, and other high army officers.
A Weehawken purchase by the Port of New York Authority for its tunnel to midtown Manhattan featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

The eleven pickets, eight of them crippled or ill, who were arrested for disorderly conduct in front of the Emergency Relief Bureau, 902 Broadway, on June 6, were found guilty yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Harris in magistrate's court, 300 Mulberry Street.

FALMOUTH, England June 28 -- The American boat Yankee, owned by Gerard B. Lambert, had another disappointment today, finishing last in the Royal Cornwall Yacht Club's regatta, Hugh Paul's trim, speedy Astra winning very easily.

Except for weeks in which large offerings of Federal Land Bank bonds were made, this week was one of the most active of the year to date for new bond financing. The total of issues offered was $71,153,000, against $249,851,000 last week, of which $239,851,000 represented financing for the land banks.

PEIPING, China, June 28. -- Noon today brought to an end a thirteen-hour period of martial law and panic, during which Peiping sustained an attack and bombardment from a mutinous remnant of the troops of Yu Hsueh-chung, ousted Governor of Hopei, who resented the order that they withdraw to south of the Yellow River.

An unexpected plea of guilty was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Louis Weiner, 60 years old, a midtown "vice overlord," as the State was about to call more witnesses in his trial on a compulsory prostitution indictment.

BUENOS AIRES, June 28. -- The Province of Buenos Aires has proposed to bondholders a scheme for the conversion and unification of the internal debt. The project provides for the unification of fifty-one series of provincial bonds into four new series, on which it is proposed to resume sinking fund payments after Jan. 1 next.
Commodity futures ruled higher on the Exchanges here yesterday, with trading light. In the cash markets grains, cotton, rubber and tin gained, while other staples were firm.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28. -- After five hours of debate in secret session the Presbytery of Philadelphia voted this evening, 72 to 39, to have five of its members tried in ecclesiastical court on charges arising from their refusal to resign from the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions.

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., June 28. -- Forty men leaped overboard from the stranded excursion fishing boat Comanche II this afternoon and, with the aid of life belts, waded about 100 yards through choppy water to dry land and safety.

PARIS, June 28. -- The release for publication here this evening of the text of the stabilization resolution the International Chamber of Commerce will adopt tomorrow morning at its closing session shows the United States delegation's victory against British opposition was complete.

Erroneous statements, if often repeated without correction, generally come at last to be accepted as established facts. This is particularly the case just now in regard to several aspects of the liquor problem.

Federal action to bar prison-made goods from interstate commerce was demanded yesterday by leaders of industry, labor, civic reform and prison reform associations. Three men and one woman, each speaking for one of the groups, urged at a meeting of the National Committee on Prisons and Prison Labor at the Hotel New Yorker that a Federal law be enacted to make it unlawful to transport prison-made goods across State lines.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 (AP). -- A new science of dust storm forecasting, revealing that the Pacific Ocean supplies the motive power for the great Midwest dust storms, was described to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

Charges of murder against Frank Damato, 13 years old; Julius, 11, his brother, both of 114-04 South Street, Jamaica, and Lisbon Lawrence, 13, of 105-04 Liverpool Street, Jamaica, a Negro, were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Hofmann in Jamaica court after Assistant District Attorney O'Hare had informed the court that the grand jury had refused to indict them and had referred their case to the Queens Children's Court.

Buying interest in the bond market turned largely yesterday to corporate issues, transactions in United States Government loans declining to $750,600 from $1,830,500 on Thursday. The turnover in corporate issues was $7,651,000, compared with $7,851,000, and for the entire bond market of the Stock Exchange it was $10,689,600, against $11,563,500.

PAINTER, Va., June 28 (AP). -- Militant Eastern Shore potato growers blocked the roads today and even shot tires from trucks which tried to carry potatoes into Maryland. Determined to force the price up to $2 a barrel, f.o.b., the farmers saw to it that the Eastern Shore potatoes, with the exception of authorized shipments by rail, stayed on Eastern Shore.

LONDON, June 28. -- A national defense loan was suggested by Winston Churchill in addressing a dinner of the Nineteen Hundred Club in honor of Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, last night. Both he and Sir Bolton stressed the importance of the maintenance of a large navy for defense of the empire.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP). -- The Indians scored a 6-to-5 victory over the White Sox in the opener of their series today, inflicting a sixth consecutive defeat on Whitehead, Chicago rookie. The league-leading Yankees, idle today, saw their lead reduced to three games.

A few of the companies with shares listed on leading securities markets which have filed temporary or complete registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission have protected themselves against any possible future doubt whether this constitutes complete acceptance of the Securities and Exchange Act or rulings made thereunder by inserting protective clauses.

On the eve of his conference with four attorneys in the hope that he may induce one of them to serve as a special prosecutor, Governor Lehman issued a call yesterday for an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court and a special grand jury to investigate rackets, vice and other crime in New York County.
The Summer list of approved books of the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee has just been made public. It contains 111 books. The complete list follows:

SUMMIT, N.J., June 28. -- Returning to competition after a lapse of two months, Miss Charlotte Glutting, New Jersey State champion, today clipped a stroke from her Canoe Brook Country Club course record to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament with an 81.

Catches of tuna in the New Jersey offshore grounds on Thursday indicate that the large schools which annually visit local waters may be expected to arrive shortly. That, at least, is the hope of offshore fishermen, waiting patiently for the signal that these grand fighters have appeared in sufficient numbers to warrant charter expeditions.

The first opera performance of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium, which had been postponed the previous evening because of bad weather, was given there last night. The opera was "Aida," mounted with full scenic accessories. The conductor was Alexander Smallens, making his first appearance this year at these performances.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 28. -- Mountain Romance, chestnut gelding in the stable of Miss Elsie B. Holdsworth of Seekonk, Mass., practically clinched the saddle horse championship of the twelfth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club today when he won the event for saddle horses shown in harness.

Max Schmeling, former world heavyweight champion, yesterday cabled his American manager, Joe Jacobs, accepting a match with Joe Louis, the Detroit Bomber who knocked out Primo Carnera, to be held in New York early in September.

The newly created State Mortgage Commission was threatened yesterday with a strike of elevator operators and other service employes in some 800 apartment houses in the Bronx. Louis Cooper, president of Bronx Local 10-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, warned the commission that unless an agreement was reached within a few days to stop discrimination against union employes the strike would be called.
The plans to open a High School of Music in New York were explained last night by Mayor F.H. La Guardia to the American Guild of Organists at a dinner given at the Hotel Astor.

Mustering all available strength in defense of the team title it has won for the last three years, the New York Athletic Club yesterday nominated a squad of thirty athletes for the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Lincoln, Neb., next Wednesday and Thursday.

Mayor La Guardia appeared little concerned yesterday over the taxpayer's suit brought to restrain payment of his salary on the ground that he is occupying a second position as a member of the President's Advisory Committee on Allotments.
CARDIFF, Wales, June 28. -- The British film censor, Edward Shortt, criticized the new American gangster films at yesterday's conference of the Cinematograph Association.

GENEVA, Switzerland, June . -- The League of Nations' statistical yearbook, just issued, shows that in the fifth year of the depression -- 1993 -- the death rate declined and the marriage rate increased nearly everywhere in the world, and generally in Europe the population rate rose.
NEWPORT, June 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Aldrich of New York are the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon A. Whitehouse, who gave a dinner at Eastbourne Lodge tonight. They will entertain again on Sunday.

Dr. Kurt Rosenfeld, former Minister of Justice of Prussia and Socialist member of the German Reichstag for twelve years, who fled from Germany on Hitler's accession to power after the Nazis had threatened to kill him on sight, yesterday received a bill from the Nazi government ordering him to pay 80,517 marks as principal and interest of a tax levied against him "for fleeing the country."

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP). -- Paced by Hank Greenberg who drove three home runs to send his mark for the season to twenty-three, atop both major league circuits, the Tigers filled the outskirts of Sportsmans Park with hits of every variety today to take both nalves of a double-header from the Browns, the first 10 to 1 and the second 7 to2.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Two unprecedented actions, one affecting two of the foremost Jewish religious bodies and the other advocating sweeping economic and political changes as an aid to recovery, marked the deliberations today of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.
NEWARK, N.J., June 28. -- Returning home tonight before a crowd of 8,000, the Newark Bears suffered their eighth straight set-back to Syracuse, 7 to 2.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 28. -- Byron Russell, veteran driver of Long Branch, today piloted his Rustle to victory in the Eastern 135-cubic inch hydroplane championship. The event featured the first half of the annual two-day, Atlantic City speed-boat regatta.

Mr. LLOYD GEORGE is girding his loins for battle. His is the chief name among the signers of a manifesto issued the other day. Presumably he is the composer of the document. Other signers are Mr. H.A.L. FISHER, Professor GILBERT MURRAY, Lord SNOWDEN and a number of Nonconformist clergymen.

TOKYO, Saturday, June 29. -- Japan needs a large increase in her forces in Manchukuo to hold the Soviet in check, General Senjuro Hayashi, the War Minister, informed the National Policy Council yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The joint resolution withdrawing the right to sue the United State on matters involving its bonds and currency reads as follows:
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LONDON, June 28. -- Red haired Donald Budge celebrated his debut on the Wimbledon centre court today by crushing France's seeded player, Christian Boussus, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 0. It was not an exciting match, for the slim, solemn Frenchman never found his game until the third set, when he began to attack the American Davis Cup player's forehand instead of his wing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 28. -- Prospects are not that inflation severe enough to cause further dollar devalution will come soon to this country, but inflation as an "ultimate development seems to be a very real danger," Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said tonight in an address on "The Prospects of Inflation" before the Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University.

Exemption from real estate taxation has been restored to forty-five properties owned by religious, charitable, philanthropic and educational organizations, the Board of Taxes and Assessments announced yesterday. The forty-five were among more than 800 hitherto tax-exempt properties in the city restored to the tax rolls by the board several months ago.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Two experienced amateurs, in a startling upset, abruptly ended the championship aspirations of America's two leading women golf professionals, Miss Helen Hicks and Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, in the women's Western open golf tournament today.

An amendment to the Banking Act of 1935 permitting banks to underwrite new issues of securities and exempting them from the civil liabilities imposed upon underwriters by the Securities Act of 1933 has been adopted by the Senate Banking Subcommittee, which has just finished revising the new bill, it was learned yesterday.
When the Giants mix with the Dodgers the resultant concoction brings a pleased smile to Memphis Bill Terry and a headache for Casey Stengel.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 28. -- Twelve seaplanes and amphibians, bearing sportsman pilots and their guests, left the beach of the Sands Point Bath Club here today at the start of the annual invitation cruise of the Aviation Country Club of Long Island.

MONTREAL, June 28. -- The value of exports of newsprint from Canada last month was substantially higher than in the previous month and also higher than in the corresponding month of last year, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics, which indicated that the gains in value were approximately in keeping with the increase in tonnage.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index, which is a component of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, dropped to 51.7 from 53.1 in the previous week. For the week ended June 23, 1934, the index was 57.5.

LONDON, June 28. -- Having had his "new deal" virtually rejected by the Cabinet, former Premier David Lloyd George struck the first snag today in his attempt to convert the "Council of Action" into a new political party.
Open-air parking spaces were brought under the building zone resolutions and classed as garages yesterday when the Board of Estimate adopted an amendment to the Building Zone Laws to that effect.
TRENTON, June 28. -- Until a court of competent jurisdiction decides otherwise, State Tax Commissioner J.H. Thayer Martin will proceed on the theory that the Sales Tax Law is constitutional.

KEYS FIELD, MERIDIAN, Miss., June 28 (AP). -- The flying Keys, Fred and Al, tonight apparently rode out a rain and thunderstorm, which, coupled with stabilizer trouble, threatened to end the flight in which they set a new world's endurance record yesterday.

The New York Public Service Commission authorized yesterday the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation to issue $9,765,000 first and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1965, to be sold at not less than 98 per cent to refund other bond issues and for other purposes.

Auctioneers put in a busy day at the Manhattan and Bronx marts yesterday when a total of thirty-four properties were sold at foreclosures in the two boroughs. Sixteen parcels were auctioned in Manhattan and eighteen in the Bronx. All went to the plaintiffs.

The recovery of almost five cents a bushel in wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday came somewhat as shock to some in the financial community who had been watching the prices of the cereal decline steadily in recent weeks on favorable crop prospetcs.

BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP). -- Dr. Raymond A. Pearson was asked today by the board of regents of the University of Maryland to hand them his resignation as president of the university Monday. The action was taken after consideration by the board of criticism of Dr. Pearson's administration.

Residential building contracts during the first half of this month totaled $25,779,200, which was almost equal to the total for the full month of June, 1934, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday for the thirty-seven States east of the Rockies.
Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday included the sale of an Eleventh Avenue corner for cash and sales of two buildings in the downtown area.

The steel industry's payroll in May was $46,493,536, compared with $45,890,244 in April, an increase of more than $600,000, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Operations were only 43.53 per cent of capacity, against 45.28 per cent in the preceding month, but May had one more working day than April.

POCOMOKE CITY, Md., June 28 (AP). -- Potato growers in Somerset and Worcester Counties, Maryland's Eastern Shore "potato belt," today were watching the progress of discussions between Virginia growers and commission merchants regarding the price of potatoes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 28. -- An audience of 1,600 persons, members of the North Shore Summer colonies and their house guests, attended the opening performance tonight at the Cove Theatre of the benefit show, "Glen Cove Capers of 1935," for which matrons, debutantes and sub-debutantes have been rehearsing for many weeks.

ALBANY, June 28. -- Warning that the bar must eliminate from the practice of law the unscrupulous and unworthy was given by Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals and Cornelius W. Wickersham at the opening here today of the Joint Conference on Legal Education in the State of New York.

Net profit of the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company and subsidiaries for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 15 was $2,353,948 after depreciation, taxes and other deductions. This was equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.30 a share on 1,813,092 no-par shares of common stock.
SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., June 28, --Commander and Mrs. Hugo W. Koehler gave a dinner tonight at their home in Herrick Road for Jacob E. Ridgeway of Philadelphia who is passing several days with them.

Due to its essentially destructive nature, the anti-Semitic movement in Germany may spread to other countries not now affected, James G. McDonald, League of Nations Commissioner for refugees, told members of the Bronx and Brooklyn Women's division of the United Jewish Appeal at a luncheon yesterday in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- Roy Henshaw, diminutive left-hander of the Cubs, came within a hair's breadth of pitching himself into baseball's hall of fame today as he limited the Pirates to one disputed hit and shut them out, 8 to 0.
