LONG BEACH, Calif., June 28. -- Two rugged crews from the Pacific Coast demonstrated convincingly to their Eastern foes that they have their work cut out for them in the National Collegiate sprint regatta as Washington and California swept to easy victories in the qualifying trials today.

RYE, N.Y., June 28. -- For the second consecutive year Jack Behr of Scarborough School gained the final round of the singles division of the Eastern Interscholastic invitation tennis tournament for private boarding schools by halting Frank Thompson, Taft luminary, by 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2 in the semi-final bracket at the Manursing Island Club today.

The closing of public schools yesterday for the Summer vacation was the signal for the release of thousands of city-bound children and the departure of the vanguard of the season's multitudinous campers.
OSLO, June 28. -- Sir Hubert and Lady Wilkins arrived here from Sweden tonight. Sir Hubert participated in both Ellsworth Antarctic expeditions with the Norwegian ship Wyatt Earp.

After surveying the local works relief field which he will direct as Works Progress Administrator for New York City, General Hugh S. Johnson returned yesterday to Washington to discuss local relief projects with Harry L. Hopkins, National Works Progress Administrator.

Three small fires, which were later found to have been set by an 8-year-old Negro boy who was on probation for having set similar fires last April, were discovered yesterday on the fourth floor of Public School 119, in 133d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. A pupil, noticing smoke issuing from a window, notified her teacher.

" Drive her!" were the last words called to the crew of Philip Le Boutillier's yawl Stormy Weather as she weighed anchor in Newport Harbor on June 8 to put to sea for the race to Norway. They hardly were necessary, as the yawl had a "driving" crew, but Roderick Stephens Jr., the skipper, and the others waved back what was taken as a promise to that end.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Efforts to postpone consideration of President Roosevelt's three-point tax program until the next session of Congress, or until a special session in the Autumn, ran into strong opposition today, and indications were that the efforts would be defeated by administration leaders in both branches.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 28. -- The red light is no stop-light for a crying baby, but the blue light often will make him cease his wailing, delegates to the American Association for the Advancement of Science were told today.
With William Woodward, his owner, bound for Europe, Omaha, the 3-year-old champion, will go to the post at Aqueduct today in what many observers consider his easiest race of the year.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 (AP). -- A statement that new observations of eighty-six nebulae confirm the fact that the velocities at which these "island universes" are speeding away from the earth increase with distance and reach a rate of 25,000 miles a second, was made today by Milton L. Humason of the Carnegie Institution's Mount Wilson Observatory, in a report at the annual meeting of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The Coast Guard set out today to obtain fast boats and modern equipment to deal with the smugglers that have sprung up to succeed the rum-runners of prohibition days.

Within a stroke of being carried to 5-all in the third set, Berkeley Bell, the ranking favorite in the Eastern clay court championship, turned back the surprisingly strong challenge of John Nogrady yesterday at 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4 to gain the semi-final round at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Three trust funds established by Cornelius Vanderbilt for the benefit of his son and daughters on Sept. 12, 1899, worth $11,802,600.46, have earned $16,263,996.74 and were valued at $8,612,316.12 on March 3, 1934, according to an accounting filed by Cornelius Vanderbilt of 640 Fifth Avenue, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney of 871 Fifth Avenue and the United States Trust Company, administrators of the funds.

J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil securities, who recently caused the arrest of a former employe of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the ground that the latter had solicited and accepted a bribe, filed a petition yesterday in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals attacking the Securities Act of 1934 as unconstitutional.

Today, at 1:52 P.M., an unshaven, ill-smelling piece of humanity came to my home from the local electric company and demanded an arrearage of $4 and some odd cents -- or off goes the current. I asked him for ten minutes' time to run out one block to get the money.

More than 14,000 passengers will sail today on twenty-five ships leaving New York for foreign ports -- a record for the last five years, shipping men said. On the corresponding Saturday a year ago sixteen ships left with 9,075 passengers.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The proposed amendments to the Agricultural Adjustment Act reverse Congress's original intention by permitting the imposition of processing taxes after the commodity involved has passed the price level represented by the pre-war parity price for the farmer, S. Clay Williams, president of the Reynolds Tobacco Company, charged in a brief filed with the Senate Committee on Agriculture and Forestry today.

SCOTLAND YARD is old-fashioned. It is short on gadgets, for one thing, with hardly an ultra-violet ray machine to its name. And it still makes a point of ploddingly capturing well-known criminals alive. Several factors make this unorthodoxy possible. One is that the modern English criminal breed is puny. The Dillinger gang alone, it is safe to say, could have licked them all.

Charges of fraud and conspiracy in the sale of two blocks of stock to the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company (Frisco line) were made yesterday in two suits for the recovery of more than $11,500,000, filed in the Supreme Court by John G. Lonsdale and James M. Kurn, trustees of the railway.
DUNCAN, Okla., June 28 (AP). -- Erle P. Halliburton, oil man, began a one-man fight today against what he calls "the dole."
CINCINNATI, June 28 (AP). -- With Paul Derringer effective when effectiveness was needed, the Reds triumphed over the Cardinals, 4 to 2, today.

GALENA, Kan., June 28 (AP). -- Twelve guards were besieged in the Eagle Mining and Smelter Company office near here tonight as strike sympathizers poured volleys of rifle and pistol fire into the wooden building.

The Board of Estimate formally approved yesterday a new revision in the Bankers' Agreement which will save the city upward of $270,000 in interest charges on short-term borrowings under the agreement in the second half of this year.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 28. -- Repeating a triumph that she scored shortly after moving to the metropolitan area four years ago, Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of Plandome won the women's Long Island golf championship for the second time by defeating Miss Barbara Stoddard of the Women's National, 4 and 2, today.

The refusal of migratory farm laborers to leave the security of relief rolls in New York and other cities for jobs on South Jersey berry farms began to cause harvest losses yesterday as weather conditions threatened destruction of more than two-thirds of the crop.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area was fairly active during the week. However, with the exception of two large stores here no sharp gains in volume over a year ago were noted. The average of department store sales for the week was estimated as about even with the same period of 1934.
Max Reinhardt, the German producer, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Ambassador, attended by leading figures in the theatre, literature and the arts and sciences.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 28 (AP). -- Russell Ball, 18-year-old Northwestern sophomore from El Paso, Texas, today scored a stunning three-set victory over Big Bill Reese of Georgia Tech to reach the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate tennis singles championship.

American manufacturers with vast sums and years of effort invested in the business good-will symbolized by their trade-marks have, during the past several months, been made the victims of an economically vicious form of racketeering.
An investment scheme of the Associated Gas system was denounced yesterday as a "swindle" and a "crime" at a public hearing held yesterday by the Mack utility investigating committee.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- President Roosevelt has completed the transmission of his legislative program to Congress, except for unforeseen eventualities that may require further messages, he said at a press conference today.

The National League's All Stars, who twice have bitten the dust, rely on their superior batting punch to turn the tables in the third annual inter-league battle to be played on July 8 in Cleveland's big Municipal Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- A total of 3,200 applications on Form 1-M for registration of dealers in over-the-counter securities has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the commission announced today.
OSLO, Norway, June 28. -- Philip Le Boutellier's yawl Stormy Weather won the Newport-to-Bergen yacht race after crossing the ocean in 19 days 5 hours 28 minutes and 10 seconds.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 28 (AP). -- The State of Vermont has plenty of wild animals which former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York may have for the Zoo at Prospect Park, Major James Brown, director of the Vermont Fish and Game Service, said today. A request for animals was referred to him by Governor Charles M. Smith.

BERLIN, June 28. -- The Berlin National Socialist organization is preparing to observe the first anniversary of the great party purge last year, which proved so fatal to many prominent men and women both in and out of the party. There will be a double mass demonstration tomorrow designed to testify to the movement's unbroken strength and solidarity and to drown unpleasant memories in a new victory celebration.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Registrations under the Securities Act of 1933 were received in unprecedented volume at the Securities and Exchange Commission today, bringing the total for June to $565,210,981. Filings received for docketing during the day aggregated $189,748,295.

PATERSON, N.J., June 28. -- The grand jury of Passaic County today returned seven indictments against the eight men who were arrested at Mountain View last Sunday in a bungalow heavily stocked with arms.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- If permanent NRA legislation is not enacted at the present session of Congress, President Roosevelt is said to have in mind a plan that would culminate in proposals for such legislation to be presented to Congress on Jan. 1, it was learned today.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Scott Inglis will preach his farewell sermon tomorrow morning at the historic Third Presbyterian Church, 40 Abington Avenue, Newark, N.J, terminating a pastorate of thirty-four years. Dr. Inglis is the dean of Newark pastors and the dean of Presbyterian pastors in the East as to the length of his pastorate.

TRENTON, June 28. -- Fines paid throughout the United States as penalties for violations of codes before the National Industrial Recovery Act was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court may be affected by the determination of an action instituted in the Federal District Court here today by the Cotex Corporation of Newark.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 28. -- The statement that confidence, "the most important of all attributes toward recovery," is coming back to the people was made by Lieut. Gov. M. William Bray today at the semi-annual meeting of the New York Hotel Association.

Unofficial reports that 35,000 bales of pool cotton had been sold to Russia, unfavorable crop accounts from the Southwest and a 5-cent bulge in wheat increased activity on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. After a slight opening advance, the market developed strength and an improvement of $1 a bale left quotations 17 to 20 points higher than on Thursday.
Mayor La Guardia's proposal to borrow $45,000,000 from the Federal Government to construct a municipal yardstick power plant was rejected yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
The treasure-hunting schooner Pilgrim returned to New York yesterday ending a voyage into the pirate haunts of the Caribbean which began on April 13.

Henry W. Gaines, who has commuted on the Long Island Railroad for fifty-eight years and three months between his home in Huntington, L.I., and his law office in lower Manhattan and never made a complaint, rolled out of the Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon in state on his last regular trip.

The Erie Railroad shows losses on 90 per cent of its storage-in-transit business in the New York area, David L. Gray, vice president in charge of traffic, testified yesterday before William P. Bartel, director of the bureau of service of the Interstate Commerce Commission, at hearings on warehouse practices here.

The Bristol-Myers Company, a chemical manufacturing firm, has leased about two-thirds of the twelfth floor of the International Building, Rockefeller Center. The lessee has been in 75 West Street for nine years.

The British amateur boxers who will meet the AIew York team in the first international Golden Glove championships at the Yankee Stadium on July 2 arrived yesterday on the Cunard-White. Star liner Majestic and received a great welcome as they marched down the gangplank for their first visit to New York.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The administration's Banking Bill of 1935, designed further to centralize control over currency and credit in the Federal Reserve Board, finished its stormy course today through the Glass subcommittee in the Senate.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Prices for light and medium weight hogs were strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher early today than they were yesterday, but they reacted and closed about steady. Heavy weights developed an easy undertone and closed as much as 15 cents lower, hogs of more than 275 pounds leading the decline.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- In preparation for another major transfer of the government's huge gold reserve, secret orders have been given, it was disclosed today, for the rush construction of a subterranean vault in the centre of an army post thirty-one miles from Louisville.

Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch refused to vote yesterday for a concrete conduit franchise for Columbia University, basing the action on Columbia's refusal to reinstate six medical students who were told that they could not return to the College of Physicians and Surgeons next year.

It is appalling how ignorant our boys and girls and our young men and women are in reference to the history of our great city. The average boy or girl knows that the island of Manhattan was purchased for about $24 worth of trinkets, and that Peter Stuyvesant had a wooden leg, and that the English took the city away from the Dutch in 1664.
In all our huge unemployment relief program why is no effort made to prevent, rather than cure, at least a part of the consequences of enforced idleness?

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- A "slightly improving trend" in business in Mexico in the first half of June, as witnessed by a moderate rise in freight carloadings, while wholesale and retail turnover continued at "more than satisfactory" levels, considering the season, was reported today in the Commerce Department's weekly survey of business in American foreign markets.

The Park Department has under consideration a plan presented by the National Association of Audubon Societies for preserving the remaining natural wild life areas in the city by making them bird sanctuaries, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- The Chicago North Western Railway Company filed a voluntary petition today in Federal court here for reorganization under Section 77 of the bankruptcy laws. Similar action by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad is expected tomorrow, when H.A. Scandrett, president, is to amplify the skeleton announcement of the company's intentions, made yesterday in New York.

The Republic Steel Corporation has sold in the open market approximately 30,000 shares of its holdings of Inland Steel Company stock, realizing more than $1,900,000. This cash will be held available for the retirement of two small bond issues which will fall due this year if it is deemed advisable to meet the maturities out of treasury funds.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 28. -- Eva Ware, 11 years old, was wounded critically at Hightstown at 9 o'clock tonight by Otto Kangus, a farmer, who discharged his shotgun at the child, mistaking her for a dog raiding his chicken coop.

New York has been allotted $11,360,000 of PWA funds to continue the construction of the large sewage-disposal plant on Ward's Island. That is good news. It is real money, and it can be turned into bricks, mortar and the different kinds of holes in the ground that are needed.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Reports of black rust in Winter wheat in parts of Nebraska, at two points in the Red River Valley in North Dakota and in Western Minnesota, combined with continued wet weather in the Southwest, threw the wheat market into a frenzy today.

DETROIT, June 28. -- A missing man of many aliases, and two women were sought by police today as they attempted to solve the mysterious murder here of Howard Carter Dickinson, New York lawyer and nephew of Chief Justice Hughes of the United States.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 28. -- The hog processing tax in the Agricultural Adjustment Act was ruled constitutional today by Thomas L. Gaskill referee in bankruptcy. He authorized the government to proceed to collect $23,519.79 in taxes owed by the firm for the four months before it filed an involuntary petition in bankruptcy last Feb. 25.

Vincent Ferrara, 48 years old, a baker, quarreled with Mrs. Ella Fazzalara, 37, yesterday morning in her apartment at 2,430-A West Second Street, Brooklyn, and after stabbing her six times in the face and body ran to a near-by elevated station and committed suicide by leaping in front of a train.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28. -- The Rev. Lester H. Clee, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church here and Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, was selected by the Clean Government Republicans of Essex County as their candidate for the Republican nomination for State Senator, to succeed Joseph G. Wolber, who has just become Circuit Court judge.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 28 (AP). -- The whist pair championship of the Women's Whist League went to Mrs. O.S. Baylies of Los Angeles and Mrs. George Morton of Chicago today by a wide margin of nine plus matches.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has extended temporary exemptions, granted ten Exchanges on Sept. 28, 1934, until Oct. 1, 1935, to afford time to complete hearings on applications for exemption, to permit the filing of reports on such hearings, and to permit consideration by the commission of these reports.

LONDON, June 28 (AP). -- Ten players in men's singles, including Sidney Wood of New York, Fred Perry's most formidable challenger, will battle it out tomorrow for five quarter-final berths at Wimbledon.
MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 28. -- For the first time since the World War the British open golf championship has been won two years in succession by Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The bonus marchers were told tonight by one of their leaders that General Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, had informed their representatives that a plan to pay the bonus to veterans who do not pay income taxes met with the approval of the administration, and that "from now on midnight oil will be burned to work out such a plan."

BUENOS AIRES, June 28. -- Monday has been set as the day for the inauguration of the Chaco peace conference, which will endeavor to arrange a direct agreement between Bolivia and Paraguay for the settlement of their boundary dispute.

The blood of a man stricken with yellow fever differs in no perceptible quality from normal blood. Yet there is something deadly in it. Filter it through porcelain and thus hold back the smallest microscopically visible bacterium and it is still deadly. Hence the term "filterable viruses."
BOSTON, June 28 (AP). -- Dolphi Camilli drove his fifteenth homer of the season with Johnny Moore on base today to end a ten-inning game and give the Phillies a 4-2 triumph over the Braves.

Washington dispatches speak of a spirit of "revolt" in the House, and to some extent in the Senate, at the prospect of having to stay all Summer in Washington in order to pass the wealth-taxes. Why use so offensive and insubordinate a term? It appears to be, rather, a case of homesickness.

Governor Lehman temporarily averted the threatened strike of 40,000 workers in the cloak and suit industry yesterday when he induced union leaders to delay action for several days until he could submit recommendations which, he believed, will avoid a conflict altogether.

Fire swept two seven-story buildings under construction on Fort Washington Avenue at 187th Street shortly after 3 o'clock this morning and firemen, summoned on five alarms from all over the borough, fought to keep the flames from spreading to adjoining dwellings.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 28. -- The last day of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers convention at Cornell today was featured by two technical sessions, one on electro-chemistry and electro-metallurgy under the chairmanship of M.R. Stansel of the General Electric Company, Schenectady, and the other on power transmission, with D.M. Simmons, chief consulting engineer, General Cable Corporation, New York, in the chair.

Showing an advance, although a small one, for the first time this week, the share market again moved yesterday within a narrow trading range, with transactions on the Stock Exchange amounting to 757,000 shares, compared with 736,000 on the day before.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- President Roosevelt signed the resolution extending the nuisance taxes and the three-cent postage and that extending the temporary bank-deposit insurance plan. He said at a press conference that he still wanted "death sentence" provisions in the Holding Company Bill and that, barring unforseen occurrences, he would send no more messages on new legislation.

ANTHONY TROLLOPE in his "North America" objected to putting to military uses "the prettiest spot on the Hudson" -- "one of the prettiest spots "which Nature, with all her vagaries, "ever formed." He wondered whether the "lads," as he called the West Point students, appreciated that they were studying amid "the sweetest "river, rock and mountain scenery "that the imagination can conceive."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in the State, now offered by dealers:

Marshall Field, grandson of the founder of Chicago's department store of that name and head of the investment banking firm of Field, Glore Co., will retire from the investment business early next month. The firm will retain its name, it was said, but Mr. Field will sever his connection with it.

Mrs. Hilda Peterson, 39 years old, wife of William F. Peterson, the fugitive alleged "get-rich-quick" investment promoter, was arrested yesterday on indictments charging theft and criminally receiving stolen money in connection with the manipulation of the Isco Service Corporation of 70 Pine Street, which was organized by her husband about a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Rebuffing President Roosevelt again, the House Rules Committee declined today to arrange parliamentary procedure recommended by him for consideration of disputed amendments to the Tennessee Valley Authority Act, which would have tended to make easier a coalition of all friends of the broader TVA powers contained in the Senate bill.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 28. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey cautioned the Interstate Conference on Labor Compacts here today to go slow in negotiating its proposed minimum wage, maximum hours and child labor agreements lest the States be led to act too hastily, without fully considering the results.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Plans are being developed for putting unemployed writers and newspaper men all over the country to work on an official "American Guide Book," which is expected to be an improvement on Europe's Baedekers, it was revealed at Relief Headquarters today.

Salvatore Spitale, one of the underworld intermediaries in the Lindbergh kidnap-murder case, and Salvatore Arcidiaco, also known as Dannie Brocco, were arrested shortly before 6 P.M. yesterday in the Mayfair Bar, 149 West Forty-eighth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, under the Brownell section of the "public enemy" law.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- What amounted to an open invitation to Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, to stop in Washington for conversations when en route to China to consult with the Chinese on monetary affairs was issued informally today by Secretary Hull.

While much of the advantage acquired during the early part of the year was lost during the quarter just ending, less hesitancy is now encountered in the placing of future commitments, with indications that the year's lows may have been touched by many trade divisions, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
GREENVILLE, N.Y., June 28 (AP). -- The body of 9-year-old Helen Glenn was found today in a near-by marsh, where it had been thrown after an attack and murder.

NYACK, N.Y., June 28. -- The body of an unidentified woman about 45 years old was removed from Rockland Lake today by policemen engaged in a continuation of the search for Charles D. Towt, 83 years old, retired broker, who has been missing since Tuesday.

The appeal from the decision of the Board of Education dismissing William R. Hayward, suspended principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, will be taken to the Appellate Division next Fall in accordance with a law passed at the last session of the Legislature, it was learned yesterday.

LIVERPOOL, June 28 (AP). -- Johannes Postmus, governor of the South African Reserve Bank, slipped away from Liverpool quietly today to talk over with United States and Canadian bankers the possibility of ending world currency wars.
Words, phrases and slogans are still being widely used to avoid thought. A phrase that is now much in the public eye is "mass purchasing power."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28. -- After overwhelming Bobby Jacobson in the semi-final round, 7 and 6, Fred Borsoldi, 18-year-old Texas star, representing Hill School, won the Eastern interscholastic golf championship today by beating Arthur Rogers of Belmont Hill in the final at the Greenwich Country Club, 5 and 3.

The course of Fall buying thus far has tended to follow the normal pattern and, as so far as August sales purchases are concerned, the orders placed in both cloth coat and fur lines are above expectations, reports here yesterday agreed. Much canvassing of the market has now been done and the way paved for substantial purchasing when buyers begin to arrive in large numbers during the week following July 4.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- The Chicago Northwestern Railway's management will not wait more than ninety days for investors for large institutions to accept its "comparatively mild" proposals for a plan of reorganization, Samuel H. Cady, vice president and general counsel of the road, said today.
Mayor La Guardia has reappointed Park Commissioner Robert Moses to membership in the Triborough Bridge Authority, it was announced yesterday at City Hall by Lester Stone, the Mayor's secretary.

MOSCOW, June 29. -- A sweeping reorganization of the work of the Komsomol -- the League of Communist Youth -- so as to humanize it and make it less a copy of the Communist party was announced yesterday. The reorganization was initiated and is guided by Joseph Stalin who, while approving the past work of the Komsomol, said the changing aspects of Soviet life now called for changed methods.

Magistrate Anthony F. Burke, sitting yesterday morning in West Side Court, ruled that by no stretch of the imagination could the presentation to a woman of a $1,850 two-and-one-half-carat diamond ring be construed as a theft instead of a gift.

GREEN pastures and free country roads are now calling to the gypsy folk who have spent the Winter in the city. The exodus has already begun. Ancient automobiles piled high with gayly colored cushions and hangings and swarthy children compose the caravans, but the departing stream is thinner, more sedate this season.

DANZIG, June 29. -- Two years of Nazi government in Danzig has brought the Free City to the verge of ruin. Suspended between Poland and Germany under a League of Nations protectorate, it may lose its financial independence.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The administration's commitment to a program of higher taxes on wealth, announced in President Roosevelt's recent message to Congress, marks an epoch. It is a new and definite indicator of the trend toward a redistribution of national wealth.

CONNECTICUT, in celebrating this Summer the 300th year of her emergence as a white settlement, not only is showing relics of her most ancient days but is pointing out that there still stand mills, dwellings, churches and gardens that date from her earliest decades.

Predictions of a notable increase in the use of talking films as promotional media by department stores and other retailers was made here yesterday by Meyer Bloomfield, who cited the widespread consumer interest in the Gesell child-development films of the Yale Child Clinic as evidence of the possibilities of film and merchandise tie-ups.

This Summer should be as good a time as any for motor boat skippers from the harbors on Long Island Sound to set a course west and south, instead of always heading east, and anchor for a week-end in one of the most beautiful waterways in the New York area.

Further declines in prices of grains and livestock sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices down to 121.6 on Tuesday from 122.4 on the Tuesday previous. The index is now the lowest since Dec. 31, 1934.

David M. Wood of Thomson, Wood Hoffman, municipal bond attorneys, said yesterday that preparations had been completed for the hearing tomorrow before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia of an important case which was expected to determine whether a State had the power to pass legislation making it mandatory for creditors to get permission to bring suit against its municipalities.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 29. -- Mankind has been increasing in size in the last century and as a result the men and women of today are two inches taller than those of 100 years ago, Dr. Edith Boyd of the Minnesota University Department of Anatomy reported to anthropologists today at one of the closing sessions of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

FIVE of the new films which invaded the local cinema sector last week will, in all probability, be still showing at their respective theatres when next Sunday rolls around. This means the current week will usher in only two new pictures, probably a record low.

EACH Summer a third of New York spends a day, a week or a season somewhere on Long Island. The Summer crowds throng a hundred golf courses, transform a hundred and more miles of coastline into an almost continuous bathing pavilion, glide swiftly through broad inland parkways, or more lazily across a myriad fishing grounds where tuna, swordfish, sea bass and weakfish abound.

ATHENS, June 29. -- At a meeting of Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris's Populist party today, attended by some 200 members of Parliament and several hundred other influential political personalities, the Premier declared that he would propose at the opening of Parliament Monday a plebiscite on restoration of the monarchy.

In a recent address on civic duty the President of the French Chamber, M. BOUISSON, demanded a finer spirit of national unity. He recalled the "sacred union" which bound together all Frenchmen in common aspiration and effort during the war. Individual ambitions were sunk in the common good.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- The resumption of music at the Newport Casino tomorrow afternoon marks a victory for the music advocates on the board of governors and brings to a close an agitation that has been going on for two Summers.

The difficulty that has attended every effort to stamp out rackets in Manhattan was shown again last week when the question of naming a special investigator and prosecutor arose. Thomas E. Dewey, who had been prorposed by the Association of the Bar of New York City as especially well-qualified to work up the facts against racketeers, was finally appointed, but only after four men suggested by Governor Lehman had refused the invitation to serve.

TORONTO, Ont., June 29. -- Canada is to lose two of her wealthiest citizens, and, incidentally, with their departure, the Dominion government's income tax revenue will be reduced by several million dollars.

To the bewilderment of the nation, Washington presented last week a curious act of now-you-see-it-now-you-don't legerdemain. It concerned two subjects that are always of great public interest -- wealth and taxes.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass.; June 29. -- Beating by less than five minutes the State law that prohibits horse racing after 7 P.M., the officials of the Yankee Circuit harness meeting squeezed ten events into the card today for more than 1,200 betting customers who poured $5,299 into the mutuels.

One of the books published this week is called "The Art of Inventing and What to Invent." The title makes it sound as if one could learn to invent as one learns to speak French or to play the saxaphone. To which RAYMOND F. YATES, the author of the volume, would probably reply, "Why not?"

BOSTON, June 27. -- The labor situation in the woolen textile industry has suddenly become serious. Nobody expected any strikes. Yet on Monday strikes closed seven mills of the Uxbridge Worsted Company -- four in Rhode Island, two in Massachusetts, one in Connecticut -- involving about 3,000 workers.

THE chorus from "Pinafore" beginning "Lightly Tripping" might well serve as a theme song for the modern traveler, vexed by the question not only of what to take, but what to take it in. Briefly, and happily, the old days of making a trip harassed with heavy, bulky impedimenta seem to have gone forever.

By returning a card of 48 -- 5 -- 50, W.J. Bode was both the high scratch and the high handicap gunner in the skeet shoot over the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club yesterday. He took the scratch trophy, leaving four other gunners, each with 50 full targets, to shoot for the handicap prize.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was requested yesterday afternoon to investigate an election held by the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers earlier in the day after members charged "machine candidates" won by fraud and racketeering.

THERE have been some famous mares in the history of the race track. Yet Professor Calvin P. Stone of Stanford University, if he is a betting man, would stake his money on stallions and geldings if we read aright the analysis of records that he publishes in the Journal of Comparative Psychology.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Elaborate preparations are being made for the celebration of the Fourth in the Berkshires. The Berkshires Hunt and Country Club at Lenox is having its opening dinner dance on Wednesday night. Mrs. Clarence Corey of New York has rented the Wite cottage on the club grounds and Mr. and Mrs. C.S. McClellan of Mount Vernon, N.Y., with guests, are to be at the club for a week.

Despite a widely circulated report to the contrary, well-informed local leaders of the major political parties expressed the opinion yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo would decide in favor of Mayor La Guardia in the taxpayer's action brought to restrain payment of his salary and to oust him from office on the ground that he is occupying a second public office as a member of the President's Advisory Committee on Allotments.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Absent from the draft of the AAA Amendments Bill, as approved by the Senate committee today, were the "freedom of the press" amendments proposed by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, which would have prevented the levying of any "compensating taxes" on imported newsprint and provided that nothing in the AAA amendments was to be construed as carrying authority to regulate advertising.

PALMER, Alaska, June 29 (AP). -- A "housecleaning" for the Matanuska colonization project, beginning with a reorganization of the commissary, was started today by Eugene Carr, "trouble shooter" for the Federal Relief Administration. Mr. Carr has taken over control from Don Irwin, resident manager.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- A plan for reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company was presented to Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today after he had approved as filed in good faith a petition for adjustments under Section 77 of the amended Bankruptcy Law.

The fame of T.E. Lawrence is so well assured that your correspondent, Jacob de Haas, is probably needlessly alarmed about any dispelling of the glamour surrounding his memory. Indeed, it seems possible that his memory may suffer more from unwitting exaggeration of his deeds.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 29. -- D. Stewart Iglehart gave a large supper dance here tonight at La Granja, his country home, to introduce to society his daughter, Miss Aide (Wendy) Iglehart. The guests included many members of the married set of the North Country Colonies, as well as the juniors and their house guests.

RUMSON, N.J., June 29. -- The dog show season in the East closed in a blaze of glory today with a record field being topped by a marvelous Scottie, Ch. Flornell Soundman, in the Monmouth County Kennel Club exhibition on the Harding estate.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 29 (AP). -- Revision of "our received ideals," not a constitutional amendment, is needed to meet the change in the social and economic order of the present century, Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School said today in summing up arguments on social effects of Supreme Court decisions affecting the "New Deal."
A timely single by Buzz Boyle off Carl Hubbell in the sixth inning gave the Dodgers a 3-to-2 triumph over the Giants at Ebbets Field yesterday. The wallop brought home Tony Cuccinello.

THERE is a tale in France that more than a century ago an eccentric millionaire left some millions of gold francs to the Sorbonne, with instructions to give the money to the first male who gave birth to a child. If the tale is true (we hasten to register our doubts) the sea horse -- Hippocampus to the experts -- ought to carry off the prize.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 29. -- A surprisingly strong Gulf Stream polo team, whose line-up had to be almost completely changed just before the tourney started, finished its quest for the Third Westbury Challenge Cup in victorious fashion today, defeating the Aiken Knights, 8 to 7, on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

I have read with great interest the letters published in your paper regarding the Josef von Sternberg picture, "The Devil Is a Woman." One of your correspondents takes the Legion of Decency to task for approving this picture while condemning the film, "Queen Christina," starring Greta Garbo.

RECENT revelations by the Federal Trade Commission that power companies were engaged in propaganda work in the schools and colleges and by the Senate munitions investigating committee that munitions interests had propaganda aims have aroused the interest of several leaders in American education.

MILWAUKEE, June 29 (AP). -- Poland's international policy is described by John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland, as entirely pro-Polish, the nation's destiny in no way connected with that of Germany or Russia.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Late Date, from the Brentwood Stable, today annexed the $5,000 added Championship handicap at a mile and a quarter, closing day feature of the Washington Park season. Calumet Dick, owned by Warren Wright of Chicago was second, with Mrs. John D. Hertz's Watch Him third in the field of six.

ERASURE of grade lines and the teaching of the first three years of elementary school as a unit will be attempted experimentally in a number of New York City schools next Fall. This and other departures from the traditional will be made in a further effort to eliminate retardation, individualize instruction and more truly adjust the school to the child.

THE Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, in a preliminary announcement for next season, its forty-first, reveals that it will give sixteen pairs of concerts. Among the soloists listed are Jose Iturbi, Percy Grainger, Severin Eisenberger, Winifred Christie, Carl Friedberg, E. Robert Schmitz, Jascha Heifetz, Nathan Milstein, Raya Garbousova and Ary van Leeuwen. Eugene Goossens remains as conductor.

BALTIMORE, June 29. -- A plan for reorganization of the Davison Chemical Company, the general terms of which were made public today, represents the agreement of three committees representing holders of securities of the company and its subsidiaries, it was said here today.

Boat-minded New Yorkers and those from Westchester and near-by Connecticut, too, spent several hours yesterday afternoon and will return today for more at City Island at the first outdoor motor boat show and demonstration ever held in the East.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 29. -- Baroness Maud Levi of New York defeated Miss Norma Taubele in the final round of the New Jersey State tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

AS far back as 1882 a German chemist, Kolbe, discovered that beef remained fresh even in Summer in an atmosphere of carbon dioxide -- the gas that bubbles in soda water, beer, ginger ale and champagne. Since then a score of inventors have duplicated these results.

THIS novel makes a double-barreled appeal for the reader's interest. For timeliness, there is the problem of how a well-educated young man with no job and no money is to make a living. For love interest, there are ladies three-deep in love with the penniless hero.
LONDON, June 29 (AP). -- Tornadoes, floods, electrical storms and stifling heat took a heavy toll in Europe today. Many persons died, and property damage was heavy.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 29. -- Wilbur Hess of Rice Institute, the boy from Houston whom they called "champ" even before the big fight began, and Leonard Patterson, a comparative newcomer to important competition, who hails from California Tech, came back with spectacular rallies today to join each other in the final of the national intercollegiate tennis singles championship.

PARIS. JUNE is the big outdoor month of Paris fashions. Every daytime social event of any importance whatever takes place against a background of trees, flowers, grass or clouds -- breakfast in the Bois; morning port (a new addition to the social ritual) in the garden; races in the early afternoon; garden parties later, and so on until after dark.

The holiday week-end festivities of the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I., will begin with a special Fourth of July dance on Thursday, which will be featured by a fireworks display staged from the point in front of the clubhouse. A shore dinner dance will be held on Friday and the following night a fete entitled "Dusk-to-Dawn Dance" will be held.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Allan C. Bakewell gave a dinner tonight at White Shingles, their place in Foster Road, for Mrs. Franklin S. Richardson, Mrs. Richardson, who will be joined next week by Mr. Richardson, arrived recently at The Gables for the season.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 29. -- Gilbert Hunt, the young Washington tennis player, lost his magic touch but found it in time today to defeat Guy Cheng of China, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 0, 7 -- 5, in the final of the Middle States tournament at Merion.

IN spite of the radical changes brought about in the life of the German people by the new social order, the old peasant customs are not only much in evidence but are undergoing a renaissance with the interest that American travelers are showing in the costumes and native folklore of the picturesque districts.

SUGGESTION has been made by Representative Virginia E. Jenckes of Indiana to the Federal Communications Commission that American short-wave broadcasters sign off with the "Star-Spangled Banner." It is pointed out that other nations conclude their international schedules with national anthems.

BERLIN, June 28. -- Paganism is no longer regarded in Germany as something humorous. The Summer solstice festivals throughout the Reich, which were attended by General Herman Goering, Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Julius Stretcher and other high officials, have revealed beyond hope of further concealment the tendency of Nazism to take on a religious or pseudo-religious character.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 29. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Man o'War colt Identify captured the Governor's handicap over a mile and a furlong in the record-breaking time of 1:50 3-5 today at Narragansett Park.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 29. -- Playing at a 4-under-par pace for the day, 20-year-old Willie Turnesa won two matches to gain the semi-final of the Briar Hills Golf Club invitation tourney today.

" VOX populi, vox Dei" is the way the ancients put it. In those days the voice of God -- and the people -- was conveyed to rulers by oracles, soothsayers, priests, consulting the entrails of chickens and the set of the stars.
Alma Luise Olson in her visit to Lindisfarne intimated, without actual declaration, that the island owed its foundation as monastery and missionary centre to St. Cuthbert in 670.
GARDEN CITY, Kan., June 29. -- Thousands of tractors putt-putting over the high prairies of the great plains are sounding a mechanical symphony of a country revived by rains.

TOMORROW morning bright and early some 25,000 youngsters will gather in church club rooms and parish houses in various parts of Greater New York in readiness for the opening of the Vacation Bible Schools. Five days a week through July and August they will draw and paint and sew and model, act in plays, and listen to stories from the Bible in a unique educational program.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 29. -- Yale's two-man team was well on the way to dethrone Rutgers as the national intercollegiate outboard champion today in the opening skirmish of the sixth annual titular regatta on Lake Quinsigamond. With Paul Sawyer Jr. of Pocono Lake, Pa., and Bedford Davie, Tuxedo Park, N.Y., doing the Blue's scoring, Yale led the Scarlet 2,763 points to 2,060 with half the battle over.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 29. -- California's Poughkeepsie conquerors proved today that they are oarsmen of speed as well as of endurance when they won the national intercollegiate sprint regatta in record-breaking time of 6 minutes 15.6 seconds.

LONDON. TWICE a year -- on New Year's Day and on the King's birthday -- a stream of distinctions, conferred for public services of various kinds, issues from "the fountain of honor." On account of the silver jubilee, this year's birthday honors list is an especially long one, but literature receives, as usual, scanty recognition.

MOSCOW, June 28. -- Though Soviet officials maintain their reticence to discuss the Japanese policy in North China, opinion here is that Japanese strategy is now moving toward encirclement of Outer Mongolia.

SKYTOP, Pa., June 29 (AP). -- The American Whist League's forty-fifth Congress Trophy in the pair whist tournament for top-scoring men members in the previous eight days of play was won today by Charles B. Little of Scranton, Pa., and Joseph Peck of Hartford, Conn.

JOHN DE MEYER might have found a title which would suggest the flavor of his novel much better than the colorless caption, "Bailey's Daughters." Nevertheless, we are not kept long in doubt. His opening paragraph is quite sufficient to fix in one's mind the atmosphere of the narrative to come.

The extraordinary growth of Sea Scouts in New York, many of whom are sons of yachtsmen, was demonstrated Friday when a bridge of honor inspection and review of the ships of the Manhattan Council took place on the training vessel Minas Princess at 133d Street and Hudson River.

Lefty Vernon Gomez scored his seventh victory of the current campaign yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, but by remote control. He was not around at the finish because the Washington Senators were gradually cutting into a six-run lead established early by his mates, and Manager Joe McCarthy thought it expedient to rush Johnny Murphy to the rescue.

MANY boys and girls of New York's tenement districts are asking whether they will have a trip to camp this Summer. They will, if the Children's Welfare Federation is successful in its efforts to awaken the public to the plight of thousands of youngsters faced with the prospect of spending the hot days in city streets.

VIENNA, June 29. -- "King Alexander was murdered at Marseilles last October and buried amid worldwide sympathy. But the ill-fated King really died only ten days ago, when the regency sent a royal automobile to take the Croat leader, Vladimir Matchek, to an audience in Belgrade."

THIS volume, a cross-section of Pound's critical views from 1913 down to the present day, is difficult to review. Pound has no formulated critical approach. His is the strictly personal attack, always, the touchstone of personal taste.

WELL, here I am, climbing into the cockpit of a Franklin secondary glider atop Hill No. 1. I have been waiting for just this opportunity for four long years. Now my chance has arrived through the courtesy of Youston Sekella, president of the Elmira Gliding Club, whose craft I am going to try to soar.

DANZIG, June 29. -- Faced with Polish retaliation against its banking and foreign exchange restrictions. Danzig's National Socialist government was forced today to make a number of concessions in the struggle for financial control of the Free City that is being waged between Germany and Poland.
Dr. Charles S. Little, superintendent of Letchworth Village, the State's institution for mental defectives at Thiells, N.Y., will complete twenty-five years of service at the colony tomorrow.

IF one has a yearning to sail the seas in one's own boat there is a craft waiting in the Galapagos Islands, the equatorial group west of Ecuador famed by a rapidly diminishing species of turtle noted for its tremendous size and delicacy of meat.

OUT of the depression has come a revival in horseback riding, as unexpected in the relation of cause and effect as this may appear to be. In the five years of the depression horseback riding has actually increased. A potent influence in the revival has been the improvement and the beautifying of the countryside.
ENGLAND is finding the television road full of pitfalls, with a morass of difficulty on either side.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- The atmosphere was cleared today for Philadelphia's Mayoralty campaign by a decision of the State Supreme Court upholding the constitutionality of the "Anti-Party Raiding Act," recently passed by the Legislature.

A few weeks ago Dr. J.W. STUDEBAKER, United States Commissioner of Education, in a national broadcast on "The Dilemma of Youth" stated that more than two million young people would be leaving high schools and colleges soon, most of whom would join the vast company of the unemployed.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, June 29 (AP). -- Robert G. Simmons, a Lincoln, Neb., Republican, addressing an Iowa Republican meeting last night, asserted that President Roosevelt's gold legislation message was an admission that the courts would not sustain his position on the gold payment clauses.

BENNINGTON, Vt., June 29. -- The second session of the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College will open Friday with a capacity enrolment of 143 students from all parts of the United States and Canada. The school convenes for a six-week period of concentrated study in all phases of the modern dance.

GOLD washing or panning has been undermining La Paz, the highest capital in the world. This Bolivian city is 12,200 feet above sea level in a ravine formed by the Choqueyapu River, a gold-bearing river that has been famous since the days of the Aymaras 2,000-years B.C.
