Because next Thursday is Independence Day patriotic sermons will be preached today, and many clergymen will make pleas for world peace. Today will mark the end of the church year and a week from today all the churches will be on their Summer schedule.

IN August, 1832, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, a tired and discouraged man near the close of his seventy-seventh year, wrote in a private letter to Associate Justice Joseph Story: "I yield slowly and reluctantly to the conviction that our Constitution cannot last.

The automobile horn has come to be recognized as an international nuisance and, in its disturbance of sleep and agitation of nerves, often a definite menace to health. In the opinion of many, it is also frequently a contributing cause of accidents instead of the aid to safety it is supposed to be.
HERSHEY, Pa., June 29 (AP). -- Ray Mangrum, long-driving Los Angeles pro, won the Pennsylvania open golf championship today with a 72-hole total of 290.

GALENA, Kan., June 29 (AP). -- Fighting broke out in picket lines in the strike-troubled lead and zinc mines of Northeastern Oklahoma today as order was restored by National Guardsmen in the Kansas sector of the Tri-State field.

House leaders warned him that he was bound to lose, but nevertheless the President at his Friday press conference declared himself more strongly than ever in favor of a law which not only would bring utility holding companies under Federal control but also would wipe out the practice of pyramiding holding company on holding company.

PARIS. WHEN Hollywood gives the American public Hollywood's version of Paris or some French literary classic it may satisfy the American public's ideas of things French, but seen from the seat of a movie house on the Champs Elysees, and particularly through Gallio eyes, it is only too liable to cause loud snickers, if not gnashing of teeth and tearing of hair.

Although an increase in their number is expected, employe associations or "company unions" for the purpose of bargaining with management on conditions of employment are noted in comparatively few stores, according to the tentative analysis, issued yesterday, of a study of employe benefits and welfare activities in department stores.

Call money rates on both Stock Exchanges here have remained unchanged since mid-April. One-quarter of 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange was charged last month for call loans, compared with 1 per cent a year ago. On the New York Curb Exchange, three-quarters of 1 per cent was charged, against 1 1/2 per cent a year ago.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- The ambitious program for great public works conceived by Governor Homer and Mayor Kelly when first a share of the Federal $4,000,000,000 was dangled alluringly before the eyes of Illinois and Chicago seems to be dwindling into something much less pretentious.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 29. -- Seven Seas, the new twelve-meter owned by Van S. Merle-Smith; Adrian Iselin 2d's Starboat Ace, Sam Pirie's thirty-footer Oriole and C.B. Stuart's Interclub Ariel were victors today in the fiftieth annual regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- Two Eastern women filed suits for breach of promise in Illinois today and asked damages totaling $300,000.

PAINTER, Va., June 29 (AP). -- The Eastern Shore Potato Growers Council adopted a code tonight which will break the three-day embargo on potato shipments. But its stringent terms will be enforced, as was the absolute shipping holiday, by farmer-pickets at railroad sidings, boat landings and the Maryland line.

THE tumult and the persons and the forces of today are dramatized in this book with enormous vitality. It is an uncommonly effective record of the past strange year of grace. By skillfully arranged photographic shots, headlines, significant statements and cartoons the climate of opinion and the course of events are reeled into a dynamic pattern of the news as history.

ELEVEN young men and women who have demonstrated unusual ability as graduate students of physical education at Teachers College, Columbia University, have been selected from a large group of applicants for a laboratory course in community recreation and camp leadership at the Westchester County Recreation Camps opening tomorrow at Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

While research should play a vital part of the work of a university, it should not occupy a more important role than teaching, according to the committee of the board of visitors to the Columbia University Law School.

PARIS, June 29. -- Once again the world's business leaders have solemnly declared their opinion that monetary stabilization and a lowering of trade barriers are imperative for a revival of world trade and the peace of nations.

Many, possibly most, of the visitors to the Brooklyn Museum who pass through the galleries dedicated at the moment to "Children's Art" and enter the Gallery for Living Artists, filled with its Summer offering of contemporary Hungarian paintings, will be sharply impressed by a likeness between the two exhibitions.

More than 3,000 children, representing six of the fifty-six election districts in the Fifteenth Assembly District, celebrated yesterday the first day of the school vacation with a June Walk in Central Park. The walk was sponsored by the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club, of which former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney is leader.

Scanning the financial and business horizon at the half-year for a glimpse of what may lie ahead for the next six months, in the light of what has just transpired, the observer is struck, first of all, by the spirit of hopefulness, which seems to be based on something more tangible than wishes.

Heading to the eastward tomorrow will be a number of the large racing yachts from near-by harbors bound for Buzzards Bay to take part in the Eastern Yacht Club cruise, which is expected to be one of the high lights of the yachting season for the large craft.

A FEW years ago Dr. Leslie A. Chambers read some papers before the American Association for the Advancement of Science on the effect of ultra-sounds on milk -- sounds so very high that no ear can hear them. The sounds killed bacteria -- shook them to death.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Larry French and Lon Warneke literally hurled the Cubs from fourth to second place in the National League standing today by turning back the Pirates in two defensive duels before 17,400 fans, 1 to 0 in twelve innings and 2 to 1.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Of the 586 certificates of automobile registration and licenses to drive that were revoked or suspended during the three weeks ending June 15, only thirteen were located in the Manhattan and Brooklyn districts, Charles 2,. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced today.

IT is popularly supposed that American cookery has no sauce of its own worth mentioning, yet the return of the gardening season serves to recall that vegetables were long known colloquially as "garden sass," and a vegetable garden as a "sauce garden."

An organized country-wide effort to bring about price stabilization in the food and grocery industry through the cooperation of manufacturers and distributers in creating a national conference committee to embrace all branches of the industry has been started here, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Several of the large White Mountain hotels are opening this week-end. On Saturday the Crawford House at Crawford Notch opened and over the Fourth of July holiday Colonel William Andros Barron, chairman of the recreational division of the New England Council, has asked many guests to join him for the week-end.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 29. Eva Ware, 11 years old, of Larchmont, N.Y., who was shot accidentally last night while playing in a field of rye at Hightstown, died today at 6:05 P.M. in the Fitkin Memorial Hospital. An hour earlier surgeons had held hopes for her recovery.

WASHINTON, June 29 (AP). -- Climaxing a week of superb golf, Ed White of Texas kept level with par today to defeat Fred Haas of Louisiana State, 5 and 4, in the final of the national intercollegiate championship.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., June 29. -- Henry Altyn, a pale-faced 13-year-old with twinkling blue eyes, won the National Marbles Tournament held here this afternoon in the Ringer Stadium, Sixth Street and the Boardwalk. Emblematic of his victory he was crowned with a diadem to cheering from 750 youthful admirers.

The body of a 40-year-old man found floating fifteen feet off shore in Long Island Sound at Port Chester, N.Y., yesterday was tentatively identified as that of Joseph Goodglass, whose disappearance was reported to New York police last April 22.

MUNICH, June 29. -- The Academy for German Law, which has been entrusted with the task of replacing the existing Roman law with German justice, concluded its annual session today with a festive ceremony at the University of Munich attended by Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler.

A central collection agency where provision is made for single payment of freight charges on goods shipped through or received at the Port Authority union inland terminal, when several railroads have participated in their movement, has been created for shippers and consignees in the port district.

A NEW form of sight-seeing in Paris, increasingly popular with visitors this year, is a trip through the city on a canal barge, which affords a novel view of the French capital. Winding along the Seine under the famous bridges and skirting the Bois de Boulogne to St. Cloud, the tourist sees an aspect of the city unfamiliar to those who do their sight-seeing from a boulevard cafe.

NEXT week-end -- if the weather be fine -- the Atlantic beaches from Cape Cod to Delaware Capes will be thronged with millions of people clad in 1935 attire. Diving floats and life lines will be in place; alert lifeguards on patrol.

A list of famous Americans, which the committee on nominations of the Hall of Fame electors voted "most worthy of consideration by the entire College of Electors for the eighth quinquennial election this year to the shrine on the uptown campus of New York University, was released yesterday by Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, director of the Hall of Fame.

ST. LOUIS, June 27. -- Missouri's new liquor law, passed by the recently adjourned General Assembly, became effective on May 9 when it was signed by Governor Park, but no effort was made to enforce it until a few days ago, when St. Louisians received a shock.

IN this novel of the California gold rush of 1849 the author tells first how the gold fever gripped the East. He gathers together varying groups of would-be gold seekers in Richmond, Va., Harden, Pa., Wisconsin, Massachusetts and elsewhere, and starts them on the long trek across the continent.

HAMMONTON, N.J., June 29. -- The lack of takers for raspberry picking jobs, which were spurned by relief recipients who preferred the dole, developed into a more acute situation today as the total of workers in the fields on the second day of the three-day harvest peak fell off considerably.

PARIS, June 29. -- A pistol duel early today between Jean Chiappe, president of the Paris Municipal Council, and Pierre Godin, his predecessor, left M. Godin slightly wounded in the thigh. Tonight the two men were still unreconciled.

The excellent photographs illustrating this account of a small boy's first visit to a farm are ample proof of his pleasure and his good fortune in having such a happy introduction to agricultural life, for they portray one of the most comfortable and fertile of the lush Middle Western farmlands.

LONDON, June 29. -- The most militaristic aerial display England has ever seen in a time of peace was provided today at the sixteenth annual Royal Air Force Hendon air show. The program almost exclusively displayed air warfare and anti-aircraft defenses, undoubtedly to justify Britain's air expansion since last year's display.

Latin-American countries present a "special opportunity" for German refugee intellectuals and openings already have been found for 100 professors and scientists, Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, special representative of the High Commission for German Refugees, reported yesterday after a survey of several months in South and Central America.

THESE days, when the rose gardens at Breeze Hill are thronged with visitors who come to see the very finest display of roses that we have ever had, in twenty-five years of rose effort, the writer finds it interesting to observe the observers and discover which roses they like best.

TRAVELERS to foreign countries this year will find shopping still the adventure it has always been, but less complicated because of the modernization of stores along American lines. Britain, which Napoleon once termed a nation of shopkeepers, now has one store for forty-four inhabitants, according to a recent census.
Vehicle congestion and crowds of visitors in gay mood brought scenes to the Chelsea waterfront at noon yesterday that had not been witnessed for six years.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Topped by a proposed $75,000,000 bond issue by the Consolidated Oil Corporation, applications for registration under the Securities Act of 1933 amounted today to $115,900,092, bringing the total for June to $681,111,073 and the total since Jan. 1 to $1,360,629,323.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby's erratic Browns regained their almost forgotten hitting skill today and, aided by eight passes, scored a 9-to-3 victory in the third game of their series with the third place Tigers.

A record month of bond redemptions, exclusive of United States Government operations, will be ushered in tomorrow when investment bankers will start work on their July schedule of underwriting a number of large refunding issues. The first important transaction will be the public offering tomorrow of $35,000,000 Southern California Edison Company bonds.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the committee on stock list to suspend dealings in voting trust certificates for capital stock of the General Refractories Company at the opening of business on July 10 or on such subsequent date as it may deem expedient.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 27. -- The constant and increasing attacks on the administration by Governor Talmadge and Tom Linder, Georgia's Commissioner of Agriculture, seem to have led to the impression that this State and the South in general are badly split over the New Deal, and that there is doubt whether Georgia and Louisiana will remain in line for Roosevelt in 1936.

LONDON, June 29. -- The quarter-final brackets in the men's singles of the Wimbledon tennis championships were completed today when Roderich Menzel of Czechoslovakia, Jack Crawford and Vivian McGrath of Australia, Sidney B. Wood of New York and H.W. (Bunny) Austin of England triumphed.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 29. -- Several dinner parties were given tonight before the junior dance at the Greenwich Country Club, which about 400 members of the younger set attended. Among those who entertained guests were Miss Katherine Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. duPont Lee; Miss Betty Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis N. Grant; Miss Renata Ingraham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold O. Ingraham, and Mr. and Mrs. Franklin G. Chapin.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Soviet Russia's dream for world peace and what it is doing to make itself a utopian nation, tolerant, advanced and economically sound, were expounded this week at the eleventh institute of the Norman Wait Harris Foundation at the University of Chicago by a group of speakers headed by Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Russian Ambassador to the United States.

In the present confusion and uncertainty several suggestions are advanced for amendments to the Constitution. One, although not new, seems to have been overlooked in the current discussion, and yet present events vividly evidence its importance and its merits.

The city collected $7,218,453.30 on account of the second instalment of its 2 per cent sales tax, excluding late mailed returns that will not be tabulated until tomorrow, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced last night.
RYE, N.Y., June 29. -- Many of the country and beach clubs of Westchester have made elaborate plans for the social and sport activities to be held in celebration of the Fourth of July.

VACATION travel in America by rail, road and sky this Summer bids fair to reach the highest point it has attained since 1929. That is the opinion of traffic managers, who report that both leading railroads and airlines have many more reservations and inquiries than were listed this time last year.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 (AP). -- The threatened duel between Jean Borotra, France's veteran tennis ace, and Didier Poulain, Parisian sports writer, has been called off, M. Borotra revealed today.

An early improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried July to within 10 points of the 12-cent level, but week-end profit-taking developed, causing a setback of 10 to 14 points and leaving the list 3 to 6 points lower.

MUKDEN -- As a result of unusual bandit activities along several isolated railroad lines, the State Railway Board is instituting new measures for the protection of track and traffic. These will include armored pilot and guard trains, air patrols and protective settlements along rights-of-way.

TIENTSIN, China, June 29. -- Foreign military observers here, watching the Japanese Army clutch North China ever tighter in its mailed fist, said today they believed Japan's leading motive was preparation for possible war with Soviet Russia.

Trading was quiet and prices steady to firm yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange, with holiday influences apparent. Continued buying of South American issues, although in smaller volume than earlier this week, was again observed. In this connection, the Government of the Argentine Nation was reported yesterday to have advanced funds to New York banks for the early sinking fund retirement of substantial amounts of two outstanding issues.

WHILE excursionists on the Maid of the Mist were loafing near Niagara's Horseshoe Falls one morning last week they saw first a flash and then a slab of rock thirty feet long and six wide leap away from the cliff and drop with a mighty splash and roar in the gorge.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The Supreme Court of the United States has been forced to move from the Capitol this week, because by the first Monday in October -- the 7th, to be exact -- it must sit for the first time in its $10,000,000 marble palace just across the way to the east.

A BURIAL urn of the Bronze Age, more than 3,000 years old, was recently dug up at Dudsbury, on the outskirts of Bournemouth, England. It was found on the site of an ancient barrow, circular in plan, about six feet high, and surrounded by a shallow ditch.

TOKYO. -- In deference to national sentiment certain changes have been made in the prayer book used by the Japanese Episcopal Church (Nippon Seikokwai), associated with the Protestant Episcopal Church of America and the Church of England.
DETROIT, June 29. -- Discovery, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's crack handicap star, romped home thirty lengths ahead of Azucar today to win an $11,200 purse and the Detroit Challenge Cup.

PARIS, June 11. RENE ROCHER; whose artistically ambitious and in many ways admirable management of the Theatre Antoine failed to maintain its financial existence nearly two years ago, has for some time been preparing a return to activity at the Vieux-Colombier.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- Robert E. Wood, chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co., has become the fifth national business leader to leave semi-official posts in the counsels of the New Deal within the past few days.

QUITE the strangest book of the season -- one of the most curious, perhaps, of all time -- is Marcel Duchamp's "La Mariee Mise a Nu par ses Celibataires Meme," issued in a very limited edition. Only a handful of copies, it is safe to assume, have reached, or ever will reach, these shores.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 29. -- The statement that legislation giving the Federal Government powers which the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional in its NRA decision will be passed by Congress within a year was made by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Cothing Workers and former member of the National Industrial Recovery Board, in an address before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute here today.

President Roosevelt, in his message on higher tax rates on great incomes and inheritances, repeated the recommendations of preceding administrations and leaders in both parties for a constitutional amendment to disallow future issues of tax-exempt securities.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young and their daughter, Miss Eleanor Young, gave a dinner for twenty persons this evening in honor of Miss Gloria Baker, their week-nd guest at Beechwood.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill, Kansas City star, captured the sixth annual women's Western open golf championship at the Sunset Ridge Country Club today. She administered a defeat to Mrs. S.L. Reinhart, Winnetka, Ill., 9 and 7, with the scheduled thirty-six-hole match ending on the twenty-ninth green.

THE town meeting is called one of America's oldest and most democratic institutions, designed for the discussion of common problems. Recently some one with a flair for history and radio showmanship recalled the significance of the old town halls in New England 150 years ago and wondered if the idea might be applicable to the microphone.

An important bit of legislation was adopted last week by the council of the American Power Boat Association at its first meeting since the reorganization in May. Recognizing that the season for inboard racing is rapidly nearing, Commodore Charles F. Chapman recommended that a rule change be made preventing an inboard hydroplane of a smaller piston displacement from claiming a record on a time trial in a larger class.

NEW ORLEANS, June 27. -- Conservative citizens who have no interest in politics except to see that New Orleans gets a good city government, and business men whose desire it is to have financial and industrial conditions what they should be, are disgusted with the cat-and-dog political fight now being waged here between Senator Huey P. Long and Mayor T. Semmes Walmsley.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- More than 250 etchings, wood block prints and lithographs, acquired within the last two or three years by the Library of Congress, were placed on exhibition this week for the first time. An interesting and highly creditable showing is made by the artists represented in the American group, which included 111 etchings, fifty lithographs and twenty-four block cuts.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Figures of the Foodstuffs Division of the Department of Commerce show a striking gain for the nation's sweet tooth in 1934. Sales of candy and competitive chocolate products during the year totaled 1,299,103,140 pounds, valued at $183,783,681, compared with a total of 1,166,776,455 pounds, valued at $162,275,660, in 1933.

The United States Government closes its books today on the fiscal year 1934-35 with the second largest peace-time deficit in the country's history. It will begin tomorrow a new fiscal year, in which the size of the deficit will depend primarily on the fate of the President's new work-relief program and on the new tax plans now before Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- Congress today reached the end of one fiscal year with a record of having voted to spend $8,200,699,773, most of it in the twelve months ending June 30, 1936.

TAGIL, U.S.S.R., June 29 (AP). -- The cheers of 1,200 spectators resounded in a Soviet court room today when six persons were sentenced to death for the murder of Grigori Bykov, Bolshevist author. Paul Pestov, former official of this Ural city Soviet, was one of the condemned.

In a departure from past banking practices the Bowery Savings Bank, largest savings institution in the country, has begun a direct mail campaign to persuade small home owners to borrow mortgage money from it.

One of the major reversals of the metropolitan season was witnessed on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday as J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., the defending titleholder, went down in defeat at the hands of Leonard Hartman in the semi-final of the Eastern Clay Court championship.

CENTRAL CITY, we are told, takes its name from the fact that it lies at, or near, the geographical centre of the United States. There is something about this name that conveys a sense not only of concentration but of radiation.

Facing a period of rising prices at a time when store inventories are the lowest in four years, home furnishings buyers meet the Fall buying season, ushered in by July, with authority to cover liberally on furniture, rugs, small house-wares, sterling silverware, draperies, lamps and a half-score other items, a canvass disclosed here yesterday.

IF sanity and reason marched with flaming banners and the beat of drums, this book would have a legion of interested followers and supporters. Unfortunately, however, the average human mind is so constituted that it prefers the sound and fury of Extreme Rights and Lefts, with the menace of fascism and communism hurled between them, to the quiet consideration of the possibility of avoiding either.

ONE of the new cafe jests, those little stories that are whispered in corners and not told out loud, because it concerns political personalities and events about which one does not jest out loud in Germany, reveals pretty correctly the current feeling as to conditions in the Reich.

The most elaborate amateur boxing tournament ever undertaken here -- the first international Golden Gloves series -- is scheduled for Tuesday night at the Yankee Stadium Under the auspices of The Daily News A.A. and with the sanction of the Metropolitan A.A.U. and the Foreign Relations Committee of the A.A.U.

OMAHA, Neb., June 27. -- Senator Norris is reported to have smiled when informed of the suggestion of his colleague, Senator Ed Burke, that Nebraska Democrats and Republicans join in handing him an uncontested election next year.

ABOARD THE S.S. NORTH HAVEN, in Mid-Pacific, June 29 (By Wireless). -- Pan American Airways' $2,000,000 pioneering expedition for a Clipper plane service between the United States and Asia is approaching its end. The argosy ship, the freighter North Haven, has been on the back track from Manila since June 19.

The crime with which this book deals was committed many years before the story opens, but the lives and destinies of the descendants of those involved are affected by it. Gerard Athered comes to England determined to prove that his great-grandfather was innocent of the murder for which he was sentenced to the convict camps of Australia.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- While farmers' cash income from sales of farm products and AAA benefit payments totaled $520,000,000 in May, as compared with $506,000,000 in April and $438,000,000 in May, 1934, a price decline in farm products for the month ended June 15 carried the farm price index down to 104, as compared with 108 on May 15, and 85 on June 15, 1934.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 29. -- The longest yacht race on this side of the Atlantic this season, the New Rochelle Yacht Club's 394-mile event for cruising craft around Nantucket Lightship, got under way this morning.

Exceptional interest is attached to the men's national A.A.U. outdoor aquatic championships, to be decided at a three-day carnival in Detroit, starting Friday. A swimming meet between Japan and the United States will take place at Tokyo in August, and results in the approaching title tests will determine the make up of the fourteen-man team slated for the invasion of the land of Nippon.

Lack of an adequate law for the reorganization of railroads increases the possibility of government ownership of those carriers, Louis B. Wehle of Marshall Wehle said yesterday. He is counsel for a group of insurance companies which has proposed a plan of reorganization to take the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway out of bankruptcy, which plan is opposed by the Van Sweringen interests.

RUMOR has long insisted that New York is one of the country's outstanding and most enticing Summer Resorts. Some of us may have inclined to skepticism, with a July or August sun blazing down on the pavements.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The United Mine Workers agreed late this evening to postpone a strike of more than 400,000 soft coal workers, ordered earlier in the day for Monday, and to extend existing wage agreements through July 31. The union acceded to the personal request of President Roosevelt, transmitted by Secretary Perkins.

The end of the fiscal year today finds the National Government with a deficit for 1934-35 amounting to about $3,500,000,000. This is far short of the $4,800,000,000 forecast by the President in his budget message of last January. Moreover, it is about $500,000,000 below the deficit for the fiscal year which ended in June, 1934.

BERLIN, June 29. -- On June 29, 1685, Frederick William, the Great Elector of Brandenburg, issued a decree establishing the Berlin Boerse. The Boerse celebrated its 250th anniversary today with appropriate firmness, even if that firmness was not entirely due to undivided optimism.

WHILE this story of Jane Adams and her miracle-like career was originally written with the intention of making it a book for young people, its publishers are wisely transferring it to their general list and seeking to find its appeal among adult readers.

THE road, the tires and the car of the past, present and future underwent scientific appraisal before the American Society for Testing Materials here last week. The occasion was a symposium incidental to a convention in which the results and possibilities of research were revealed.

TOKYO, June 29 (AP). -- The National Cash Register Company of Japan announced tonight its "consolidation" with the Nippon Cash Register Company, whereby the latter purchases licenses permitting it to manufacture under all existing patents owned by the National Cash Register Company of Dayton, Ohio, for Oriental markets.

WASHINGTON -- The law-abiding citizens in the United States should not be handicapped, in these difficult times of economic readjustment, by threats of wholesale and mandatory deportations and compulsory naturalization.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 29. -- Regaining courage and confidence after several years of depression, Australia is making plans for great expansion in two big industries, air transportation and motion pictures. International political policies and trade are likely to be affected by the plans considered by the Federal Cabinet meeting at Perth.

It was about time that the American Institute of Decorators should decide to tell the world exactly what a decorator is. Miss Nancy McClelland claims "that not a single one of all the thousand dictionaries in existence gives a proper definition of what these people (decorators) are or what they do."

Any attempt by industry to escape the proposed maximum corporation taxes by breaking up large organizations into smaller units can be effectively checked by the government, under a provision in the present law, Dr. Joseph J. Klein of Klein, Hinds Finke, accountants and tax specialists, declared here yesterday.

THE second Florentine Musical May, which ended its six weeks of activities some days ago, embraced a range of attractions considerably more comprehensive than the first "Maggio," in 1933, and constituted Italy's biggest musical event of the year.

The administration has finally determined to close and lock the door which was left ajar by the decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the gold-clause cases. The President has recommended that this be done through the enactment of a statute withdrawing the present privilege to sue the United States Government on any of its obligations containing the promise of payment in gold.

THIS volume in the "Modern World" series, which attempts a survey of historical forces, is aptly divided in two, the division roughly corresponding to fact and interpretation. Sir Robert Rait, the distinguished Principal of Glasgow University, rapidly and expertly summarizes the facts of Scottish history to the Union of the Kingdoms in 1707.

Miss Lenore Kight of Homestead, Pa., the outstanding woman swimmer in the country today, provided the highlight in the Metropolitan A.A.U. championship meet at Manhattan Beach yesterday when she bettered by three and two-tenths seconds her own previous American free-style record of 4:07.2 for the 300-meter course.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 27. -- While generally admitting, as Mr. Hoover said of prohibition, that the Farmers' Home Corporation Bill, more popularly known as the Bankhead bill to aid tenant farmers, is a noble experiment, social and farm leaders throughout the Midsouth are showing marked indifference to its passage.

There have been any number of efforts to build a Negro theatre, but each effort always ended in failure. The reason, chiefly, has been due to the fact that all groups in the field believed that the use of an all-Negro cast constituted the creation of a Negro theatre.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The National Youth Administration created by President Roosevelt last week is a way out of the destroying stagnation into which the depression has thrown hundreds of thousands of American youth.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27. -- A looping "ghost" bridge now spans half the two-mile channel on the deep-water side of San Francisco Bay; it extends from the city front to the central anchorage monolith, midway between the mainland and Yerba Buena Island.

THIS Year Book for 1934 brings down to date entries of continuing and developing interest in the Funk Wagnalls New Standard Encyclopedia and can be used as a supplementary volume for that work. But it is also planned for separate use solely as a year book and as such makes a convenient and efficient reference volume.

THE Carnegie Corporation in the several years of its existence has undertaken many different activities for the benefit of the community and has carried them through with success. None of these things has it undertaken recklessly.

LINCOLN, Neb. -- Bankless Nebraska towns have found a way to fill the financial void by recourse to the law authorizing cooperative credit unions. This statute was designed primarily to help industrial groups to carry on small cooperative savings and loan transactions under protection of the law.

Mrs. Nora Coote Aitken, widow of William B. Aitken, lawyer and former president of the Bronx Savings Bank, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at her residence, 12 East Ninety-seventh Street. Surviving are a son, Beckman Aitken; three sisters, Mrs. George G. Hollins of Montclair, N.J.; Mrs. Guy Rollo of East Orange, N.J., and Mrs. Clarence Hayward of Larchmont, N.Y., and a brother, Spencer Eyre Coote.

JESSE OWENS. Now, there's a messenger boy with speed. He's a page in the Ohio House of Representatives and when one of the legislators wishes to hurry a bill from the floor to Mr. Speaker, all he has to do is to signal to Jesse. The bill will get there in world's record time, even if Jesse has to make it a hurdling event. He can do that, too.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 29. -- An innovation in the educational program offered by Cornell University will take place this Fall when extra-mural courses, maintained at the same standards as those of comparable residence courses, will be offered to residents of New York State.

FROCKS that blow in the breeze -- that is one way to describe the exquisite new ones in sheer fabrics. The breath of Summer seems to be in them. Here they are ready to celebrate the Fourth of July. What could be more fetching than one of these diaphanous affairs for the dance at the country club that gives the Summer social season its impetus.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 29. -- One of the largest supper dances attended by North Shore society members for several years took place tonight at the Nassau Country Club when the committee in charge of the benefit revue, "Glen Cove Capers of 1935," which had its final showing at the Cove Theatre earlier in the evening, arranged a country party.

Two investigations were under way yesterday to determine the cause of a spectacular early-morning fire on Washington Heights that resulted in injury to six firemen and destroyed a nearly completed apartment house at Fort Washington Avenue and 183d Street.

LET ultra-violet rays play on foods and vitamin D is produced -- the one that prevents rickets. Has radium a similar effect? The Soviet Institute for Animal Breeding thinks it has answered the question. V. Sukharev tells the story in Front Nauki i Techniki (Scientific and Technical Front).

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29. -- Declaring that "American self-government is being destroyed before our eyes," former Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland, a leading figure in the Democratic party, stirred delegates to the fortieth annual convention of the Maryland Bar Association at a dinner here tonight with an attack on New Deal policies.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The publication this morning of some details of the Senate subcommittee's revision of the administration's 1935 Banking Bill, which were supposed to be kept in strictest secrecy until the bill was reported to the full Banking and Currency Committee on Monday, brought a suggestion from Senator Glass today of an investigation of "leaks" on this important measure.

ASBURY PARK. -- Art and the drama will hold the interest of Summer colonists along the North Jersey shore during the forthcoming week. Tomorrow evening marks the opening of the picturesque Shrewsbury Playhouse at Shrewsbury, and at the same time the theatrical season at the Deal Casino will get under way.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in June was slower than in May and the second slowest of any June in eleven years. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 22,339,512 shares, compared with 30,438,423 in May and 16,802,460 in the same month a year ago.

PANAMA. -- Although the "state of siege," which is a polite name for martial law, has been lifted for some time in El Salvador, reports coming here reveal that freedom of the press has not been restored.

The Hillside Homes, the largest PWA project in the East, covering five blocks on the west side of the Boston Post Road from Eastchester to Wilson Avenue, the Bronx, were formally opened yesterday afternoon by Governor Lehman and representatives of the Federal, State, city and borough governments.

THIS is the life story of a mountain guide, famous over half the world, who had made thousands of ascents, whose memory will be kept alive by peaks named for or by him in many mountain ranges and by the cairns he built on many a cloud-piercing mountain top which he had been the first to conquer.

THIS book will thrill and inspire all those interested in educational matters who are impatient with present-day schools and long to see educational aims and methods rejuvenated and informed with modern, forward-looking educational thought.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- As part of the policy of building up the navy to treaty limitations, Secretary Swanson awarded bids today for sixty bi-motored airplanes and their power plants, to be built at a cost of $8,507,037.

Lawrenceville School's five-man tennis team, which will play a series of matches in England, sailed from New York at noon yesterday aboard the French liner Ile de France. With Hugh K. Wright, a member of the faculty, as their director, the youths looked ahead with enthusiasm to both the voyage and the competition abroad.

There appeared recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES an article from Clinton, Conn., giving an account of the "oldest continuous ownership of land in the United States," based on a grant to John Stevens in 1675.
I have reason to assume that your readers will look with favor upon the movement that I am starting to bring back dinner concert music to the dinner hour.
BELGRADE -- This city has undergone a sudden and marked reduction in size.

HARDLY a week passes that O.O. McIntyre does not comb down his hair to show his tens of thousands of readers where the straw used to be. Not that it is there any more. He has scaled such heights that he now is in a position to "try to make lit'ry talk" with Elinor Glyn (she wrote "Three Weeks," and called Clara Bow the "It" girl).

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP). -- The Indians rifled two home runs, a pair of triples and a double off three Chicago pitchers today to defeat the White Sox, 6 to 5. The Sox tallied fifteen hits against Cleveland's nine, and Manager Jimmy Dykes used fifteen men in the contest, but to no avail.

AS their contribution to the Mark Twain Centennial celebration, which is being observed this year. Harper Brothers announce for Fall publication two hitherto unpublished books by Mark Twain. The first is "Mark Twain's Notebook," edited and arranged by Albert Bigelow Paine. This is described as a day-to-day record of the famous author's life. Mr. Paine says of it: "Tragedy, comedy, heresy -- his notebooks made up the record. Nothing has been modified, nothing changed.
JULY will add to the toll of programs dropping off the air for the Summer, and in the majority of cases broadcasts of the sustaining variety will fill the gaps.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Attributing the plight of Jews in Germany to "insane European antagonisms," Dr. Sidney S. Tedesche of Brooklyn told the Central Conference of American Rabbis today that "Israel is the phalanx against which the ranks of medievalism and hatred will break."

SOAP sculpture may be a humble art, but it is also the youngest and newest and, one might say also, the sprightliest. Mr. Gaba, who is an enthusiast about it and is probably the best known of its practitioners, has done much to popularize it by his work in the advertising field.

IF the passenger on the world cruise ship is not a linguist upon his return to his home port, it may be partly because he had too great a variety of languages hurled at him and his stays ashore were too brief.

ABSOLVED: The majority of an Illinois Senate committee which investigated charges that communism was being taught at the University of Chicago brought in a "not-guilty" report last week. The investigators asserted, however, that Robert Morss Lovett, Professor of English, was "unpatriotic." Professor Lovett, one of the nation's most distinguished critics of drama and literature, has been on the editorial board of The New Republic since 1921.

THE annual "swan upping" on the Thames between London and Henley begins on July 22 this year when the swan markers of the Kings and of the Vintners' and Dyers' Companies embark at Vintry Wharf to round up the swans and their cygnets and give them their identifying marks.

Although there were indications of some weak spots, due mostly to seasonal conditions, the trend of business in general continued favorable last week in most of the Federal Reserve districts throughout the country. Retail trade was strong in almost all sections, the hot weather and pre-holiday demand causing a brisk movement of Summer lines of merchandise.

The battle over the utilities is again being waged on many fronts. While the rival generals at Washington continued to rally their hosts last week, with much rolling of drums in anticipation of next week's critical vote in the House on the Holding Company Bill, Mayor LA GUARDIA, the principal champion of government ownership and operation in this city, lost his first serious encounter with the opponents of that policy.
WESTHAMPTON, L.I., June 29. -- Forty craft took part in the opening regatta of the yacht racing squadron of the Westhampton Country Club off the Speonk shore today in a light southwest wind.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 29. -- Ending a voyage on which all available accommodation was occupied, the Virginia of the Panama-Pacific Line is due here Monday.

Last week saw an influx of out-of-town buyers of ready-to-wear bent on obtaining merchandise for special sales, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. They were especially interested in obtaining cotton and washable silk dresses at off-prices.
MANILA, P.I., June 29. -- A bachelor was the Filipino women's hope today of retaining their right to vote.

ALTHOUGH not yet completed, the link of the Saw Mill River Parkway between Elmsford and Eastview will be opened to traffic on July 4, it is reported. Work remains to be done on the shoulders, and the grade separation at Elmsford is still under construction.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- Selection of the United States team of fourteen swimmers and a diver for the dual meet with Japan in Tokyo Aug. 16-18 will be made immediately after the National A.A.U. outdoor championship for men, which will be held in Detroit next week.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Senate leaders gave warning today that they would move to kill the administration utilities bill if the House did not approve the "death sentence" of holding companies.
CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP). -- The Reds today took their second straight game from the Cardinals, beating off a ninth-inning threat to win, 8 to 6.

THIS thirty-fifth year of the new century splits neatly in two at midnight and the screen department proposes to do something about it. To a violent admirer of the screen nothing is more odious than that species of ancestor worship which requires the film reviewer, on the last week of the year, to select the best ten photoplays.

LONDON, June 29. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin gave France and Italy today his emphatic assurance that the recent Anglo-German naval agreement meant no weakening of the ties between the former Allied powers of Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Wagner-McLaughlin bill, incorporating the American National Theatre and Academy and naming an imposing list of patrons of the arts as the original incorporators, was passed unanimously by the House late today.

The many social and economic programs on which the major nations of the world are now launched provide the international management movement with the broadest field in its history, Harry Arthur Hopf, president of the company that bears his name and chairman of the American delegation to the International Management Congress in London on July 15-20, declared here yesterday.

ROME, June 28. -- Any one looking for convincing proof of the shifting nature of international political affinities need only cast a retrospective glance over recent Italo-German relations. In a single year they changed from friendship to hate, then back to something approaching normal with a tendency to improve.

THE outstanding quality of Mr. Pinkerton is his infinite capacity for getting into trouble that does not concern him in the least. The poor, timid little man can't even raise a beard without involving himself in a veritable web of mystery and crime.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29. -- Frank Makosky weakened in the ninth inning today and the Syracuse Chiefs belted his offerings for five hits, scored four runs and beat the Bears, 10 to 6, in the second game of their series. Also it was the ninth consecutive game Syracuse has taken from the champions this season.

RETAIL trade gained last week in many sections of the country under the influence of warm weather and approach of the holiday. The increase here put figures even with a year ago. Demand ran principally to apparel and accessories.

DENVER, June 29. -- Teachers arriving in Denver from all parts of the country for the annual convention of the National Education Association opening tomorrow have apparently decided that the depression is over and that their time has come to reorganize their profession as a fighting force in the nation's social and political life.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 29. -- The dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club tonight was well attended. Commodore Ogden M. Edwards Jr. and Mrs. Edwards brought guests, as did their son. Harkness Edwards, and Mrs. Edwards.

PARIS, June 28. -- The defensive forces that safeguard Great Britain are an evolution of ten centuries of more or less defensive warfare. Their beginning goes back beyond the days when English munitions factories were old churchyards in which grew yew trees whence came the good longbows of Crecy and Agincourt and when the penalty for cutting down a yew tree was death.

IT has been a long time since the town has been in a production turmoil comparable to that which exists today. Many changes in operating personnel have been made and others are anticipated. As an executive on one major lot stated, "It's getting so you don't know whose throat to cut."

I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES a report that Dr. Raymond S. Stites, Professor of Esthetics at Antioch College, claims he has proof that "La Gioconda" (Portrait of Mona Lisa), the great masterpiece of Leonardo da Vinci, is the portrait of Isabella d'Este, the Marchioness of Mantua and not Monna Lisa Gherardini, the third wife of Francesco del Giocondo of Florence, which the world has believed for more than 400 years.

America's premier motor-boat racing event, the Gold Cup championship, will have its thirty-second running on July 27 on the new course laid out at Bolton Landing-on-Lake George that will bring the heats in full view of several vantage points on shore.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, June 29. -- The new Zeppelin LZ-129 is expected to make its first transatlantic flight from Friedrichshafen to Lakehurst, N.J., late in October, Dr. Hugo Eckener told me. The giant airship will carry fifty passengers and about twenty-five tons of mail and freight.

In 1911 cancer stood eighth in the list of causes of death in the general population. It has since risen to second place. Hence the anxiety of health authorities, the vigorous educational campaign conducted by public-spirited citizens and physicians, the quickened tempo of laboratory research.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 29. -- The appointment of Dr. Clayton M. Hall as head of the Department of Classics, and of Associate Professor Albert W. Holzmann as head of the Department of German in the College of Arts and Sciences of Rutgers University was announced today by President Robert C. Clothier.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The life of the colony will centre this week on the Cascades course, where the Virginia State amateur golf tournament will be held on July 5-7. The entry list bids fair to reach the 200-mark. The first day will be devoted to eighteen holes of medal play, and the thirty-two lowest scorers will qualify for the championship.

HOW true is it that a mighty intellect is lodged behind a high forehead? Dr. Ales Hrdlicka of the National Museum, who has been measuring heads for thirty years -- Indians, Egyptians, American and European whites, Negroes and Eskimos -- is able to answer.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- A hope that the new tax program would be confined by Congress to the topics outlined by President Roosevelt in his special message, and not be enlarged to include a general reconsideration of all Federal taxes, was expressed on behalf of the President today by Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee.

OSLO, Norway, June 19 (By Mail). -- Echo-sounding apparatus, now widely used on ships to make continuous records of bottom depth, can also be turned to good account in the fisheries industry in locating large schools of commercial fish.
NANTICOKE, Pa., June 29. -- The collapse of a rustic dance pavilion hurled some 400 picnickers into shallow, rocky Hunlock Creek today, injuring about 250 persons, at least four seriously.
LONDON, June 29. -- Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee finally won a race from T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour today after a long and discouraging series of defeats in British waters.

Safety and sanity, twin words whose meaning is annually urged upon Fourth of July celebrants, will also be the marks of conduct of the city authorities this year in attempting to suppress the sale and use of fireworks.
A wider range of activity becomes available to fresh-water anglers of New York State tomorrow with the opening of the season on black bass, one of the most popular of game species.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The sports and social program this week in Asheville includes a swimming exhibition at Beaver Lake featuring Miss Katherine Rawis of Miami. Dances at the Biltmore Forest Club, the Asheville Golf and Country Club and the George Vanderbilt Hotel, a recital at Grove Park Inn and a birthday golf tournament for men and women at the Biltmore Forest Club.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Truck gardeners in Cook County are suffering from over-abundant production. Last year they suffered from crop failure due to drought. The cool, wet Spring of 1935 has induced a record growth of all green stuff in this part off the country, and lettuce, spinach, radishes, beans, peas are plentiful beyond all market demand.

FRUITION of hopes long held by airplane designers with a sense of the future is to be found in the striking announcement last week of the British Air Ministry that it had successfully controlled full scale airplanes and seaplanes by wireless and used them for anti-aircraft target practice.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 29. -- The Interstate Conference on Labor Compacts, with delegates from sixteen States, closed its two-day meeting here today by adopting child labor and minimum wage compacts, which must be ratified by the State Legislatures and approved by Congress before they can become effective.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 29. -- A fashion show, band concerts and fireworks are among the entertainment features scheduled for the Fourth of July and holiday week-end in this Adirondack resort. The success of last year's program, sponsored by the Lake George Chamber of Commerce, has spurred the officials to greater activity to entertain the Summer colony, and indications are for a large throng.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29. -- Before a crowd of 5,000 persons, including Mayor Harry Bacharach, who viewed the spectacle from the yacht Juanita, Arno Apel of Atlantic City piloted his trim craft, Aguila Voladora, to the Eastern 91-cubic inch inboard hydroplane championship today as the two-day Atlantic City speed-boat regatta closed.

There are several Communists in this story, and there are two corpses, but neither of the corpses is that of a Communist. The only justification for the title is that the police are trying to prove that the two murders are parts of a far-reaching Red plot.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 29. -- The New Jersey State mixed doubles tennis championship reached the semi-final round stage at the conclusion of play at the Westfield Tennis Club today, with the four brackets filled by seeded teams.

PARIS, June 29. -- The International Chamber of Commerce, at a session that closed here today, took up the question of protection of news. The issue had been shunted from congress to congress for eight years, ever since the International Congress of Press Experts at Geneva in 1927 under the auspices of the League of Nations.

CHARLES FORD was for many years Jonathan Swift's most trusted friend, but the letters exchanged by these men, save for one included in full in the great edition of Swift's correspondence which was edited by the late Dr. Frank Elrington Ball, have not, hitherto been published.

Six refugees from the Dominican Republic, including Rafael Estrella Urena, a former Provincial President, will be allowed to return to their country, according to a bill passed by Congress in Santo Domingo and signed by President Rafael L. Trujillo.

The first six months of 1935 have been characterized in business and financial affairs by a contest between the recuperative force of increasingly abundant credit and the recurring shocks to confidence arising from political developments.

AT Blerancourt, sixty miles from Paris in the heart of the shrine, a new building will be erected by the American Field Service as a memorial to the Americans who served in that unit before the United States entered the World War.

LONDON. -- If texts of treaties have any value nowadays -- a fact disputed by a number of people -- then the Anglo-German naval pact just concluded possesses a feature which deserves special notice. It will be remembered that the pact says:

Within the next ten days, Correction Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick announced yesterday, 500 prisoners will have been transferred from the almost medieval cell blocks of the old prison on Welfare Island to the ultra-modern penitentiary on Riker's Island.

The ninth annual metropolitan canoeing championships will be held on the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park on Thursday. The entire Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association, as well as several extra-divisional clubs, will participate in the program of eighteen paddling events over the 350-meter sprint course.

THE reader's first reaction to this book is that its author and artist work together with notable and unusual harmony. Evidently, they are both fond of animals and birds and like to study their characteristics and guess what is going on in their brains when they do interesting things.

IN "Gentlefolk in the Making" John E. Mason has made a comprehensive survey and analysis of a field of literature of great interest, but little known to the general reader; much of the material, indeed, has never been published.

HARD luck in London is the motif of this novel. The business depression played its part in giving Jimmy Garden a raw deal, but his prime bad luck was in marrying Anna. A sensitive, intelligent, well-educated young man, he was fascinated by Anna's sturdy good looks, her efficiency, her strength of purpose to get on in the world.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- An unprecedented import movement of agricultural products in the first quarter of this year, and a noticeable shifting of American exports from Europe to other nations, were reported today in the quarterly analysis of "Our World Trade" made by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 29. -- The Crescent Athletic Hamilton Club defeated the Staten Island Cricket Club, 171 to 140, today in the annual competition for the championship of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association.

SEATTLE, June 27. -- The eighth week of the strike in the lumber and logging industry of Washington and Oregon found about 2,700 men returned to work, with National Guard detachments in each State on duty for the protection of any who need it.

DETROIT, June 29. -- Evidence that the Jackson sisters had fled Detroit hurriedly was uncovered this morning. In the belief that they had driven away with Schweitzer, police sent messages throughout the Midwest asking officers to be on the look-out for Schweitzer and the women and arrest them "for murder." This preceded the Fort Wayne arrests.

Muggy weather beset the city yesterday, causing widespread discomfort, although the day's temperature averaged only 77 degrees, five above normal. Fair and not much change in temperature with easterly winds was forecast for today.

Joseph P. Day, who has been elected a member of the board of directors of R.H. Macy Co., according to announcement made last week, has sold $1,500,000,000 worth of real estate in the past thirty years. The concern he heads celebrated its fortieth anniversary on May 1.

William Woodward's Omaha won the $7,500 added Dwyer Stakes yesterday as a champion should, going handily as he passed the judges and 15,000 cheering racegoers at Aqueduct. He ran precisely to the time mark of Man o' War, when that colt scored in 1920 -- 1:49 1-5 -- for the mile and an eighth.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N.H. -- With its postoffices open again, boat service on the lake resumed and 7,000 salmon released by the fish and game club slinking from pool to pool, this region has taken on an air of Summer.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Max Baer, the playboy of pugilism, was married in comparative secrecy today to Miss Mary Ellen Sullivan of Ithaca, N.Y.

It is good news that Mayor LA GUARDIA has decided to reappoint ROBERT MOSES as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority when his term expires tomorrow. Since the famous controversy with Secretary ICKES ended in the complete vindication of Mr. MOSES no one has so much as hinted that he lacked competence for this job.

SHOULD a high school worthy of the name require some study of mathematics, science and foreign languages for graduation? The decision of the New York City Board of Superintendents the other day to award a "general diploma" to students without such subjects, was attacked by Dr. John L. Tildsley, assistant superintendent of schools, as providing a "refuge for lame ducks" and sanctioning a "pretty poor type of education."

AT long last the cinema appears to be gaining recognition as an art rather than a post-graduate branch of the peep-show. A few months ago Grace Moore received the gold medal award of the Society of Arts and Sciences "for distinctive service in the arts."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 29. -- Dr. Robert G. Vance of the Waltham (Mass.) Skeet Club duplicated his performance of last year in defeating Dr. C.W. Scranton of the Roseland Community Gun Club of New Jersey in a shoot-off for the individual .410 gauge championship, feature event of the seventh annual Great Eastern skeet title tournament today.

THE Lewisohn Stadium concerts swing into their first full week tonight with ballet, opera and symphonic concerts taking their appointed places on the program -- that is, if the weather is kind. An inordinate amount of rain, save the mark! might wreak havoc with the programs.

MOST anthologies have the musty odor of museums about them. They formally exhibit pieces ripped from their context and awkwardly posed for our attention. Carl Van Doren, however, has approached the huge task of representing the prose classics of the world in a single volume by flinging academic formality to the winds and substituting therefor a concern only for the pleasure of the reader.

" The whole thing is on the knees of the gods," said Anthony Eden, Britain's young diplomat, when he returned to London Thursday, weary after his visits to Paris, Rome and Berlin. The "thing" Mr. Eden referred to was Britain's relations with France and the confused European situation.

WHEN Anna Sokolow recently presented her new group composition, "Strange American Funeral," at the Park Theatre in performance by the Dance Unit, she made two facts increasingly clear. One is that she is an exceptionally gifted composer with complete authority in the handling of a group, and the other is that it is impossible to dance to poetry, however excellent, which was not written especially for dancing.

INCIDENTAL to the erection of Boulder Dam there is arising near by a new vacation area in the hitherto worthless mountainous desert section of the Rockies. In the neighborhood of the dam, in Boulder City and around the vast lake that is forming be hind that construction, the by-products of the government's power-development project will be esthetic and recreational -- important to tourism.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Former President Hoover will formally announce late this Summer that he will not seek the Republican nomination for President next year, according to Republican Senators who were advised of his attitude this week.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 29. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Governor Lehman of New York are among the hundreds of delegates who will come to Williamstown next month for the Institute of Human Relations, authorities stated today.

THE last fifteen months in Russia have seen the publication of musical documents of exceptional value. There is an immense wealth of material in the State archives of Moscow and Leningrad, of which so far only the surface has been scratched.

After failing to persuade any of his first four nominees to serve, Governor Lehman announced yesterday that he would recommend to District Attorney Dodge that he appoint Thomas E. Dewey, former United States Attorney, as special prosecutor to investigate vice, rackets and other crime in New York County.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- The administration's controversial Omnibus Banking-Bill emerged today from a prolonged stay in the Glass Senate Banking Subcommittee. The bill goes to the full committee Monday.

The immediate release of political prisoners in Germany and asylum for them in this country was demanded by speakers at an anti-Nazi conference held yesterday afternoon in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Shares of leading banks had the strongest rally in months yesterday in response to the news of amendment of the Banking Act of 1935 by the Senate Banking Subcommittee so as to permit banks to underwrite new security issues.

Approximately 15,000 men will be enrolled for Summer school work in the trade and technical division of the New York City Adult Education Project, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the project. Registration will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday at the sixteen centres in the city and classes will begin on July 8 and last until Aug. 17.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- A last-ditch fight, in which patronage bargaining appeared to be playing a part, was waged by the administration today in an effort to bring wavering Democrats to support of the "death sentence" in the Utility Control Bill, passage of which is insisted upon by the President.

HAVING publicly renounced Broadway's ugly commercial snares, Leslie Howard has been shopping for vehicles that appeal to him. "Hamlet," his next effort, was of course in the open market, ready at hand and free of royalties, which has always been a great convenience.

FROM the rich assortment of the hardy garden containing generous plantings of annuals the gardener has enough material to make most attractive flower arrangements for the home. Now is the time to experiment with unusual combinations of color or line composition, or some simple structure in the "Japanese manner."

WHAT boy or girl has not dreamed of exploring a strange country as he or she deemed best, unhampered by the unreasonable precepts of determined adults? In this diverting story Marjorie Fischer gives full rein to just such a dream and the result fairly crackles with amusement and enjoyment.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- Senator William E. Borah of Idaho entered his seventy-first year today, apparently due to continue the enigmatic role that he has always played -- never quite a Presidential candidate, but always a dominant figure in Presidential campaigns.

The recent Supreme Court decision invalidated those portions of the National Recovery Act under which codes had been approved and placed in operation. There were more than 700 such codes. With them went a great number of amendments, interpretations and rulings, and an elaborate machinery of administration.

PEIPING, June 29 (AP). -- A wave of acute uneasiness swept Peiping, already alarmed by yesterday's mutiny of Chinese troops, with reports tonight that 300 armed plainclothes men, of unannounced allegiance and intentions, had slipped into the city.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- After collecting 52 cents for every dollar spent, the Treasury closed its books upon the fiscal year today with a deficit of nearly $3,500,000,000. The gross national debt is nearly $28,700,000,000.

BOSTON, June 29 (AP). -- Curt Davis held the Braves to seven scattered singles today and his Philadelphia teammates put on a four-hit barrage in the second inning to chalk up their third straight triumph, 3-1.

Possession being nine points of the law, the Fire Department baseball players brought the new Mayor's trophy to the Polo Grounds yesterday and felt duty bound to carry it away. They did. Before 40,000 vociferous enthusiasts the firemen upset the Police Department nine, 4 to 2, stopped the series victory string of the gendarmes at three straight and remained unbeaten in Municipal League play, with eight in a row.

Mutual bad feeling here and in Japan foreshadows an early end to the active trade in Japanese manufactured goods built up here in the years from 1931 to 1934, Leo Josefsberg, partner in the American Merchandise Company, manufacturers and importers of a wide variety of consumer items, said yesterday.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 30. -- The death list in the floods that devastated Southwestern Japan mounted to seventy-five this morning. The floods are subsiding, but a heavy rainfall in the prefecture of Fukuoka has swollen the Chikugo River dangerously, menacing the city of Kurume.

Two factions that are contending for the control of the United States Express Company, which has been in liquidation since 1914, bickered for three hours yesterday in the office of Edwin L. Garvin at 115 Broadway and adjourned with mutual expressions of hostility.

RIVER VALE, N.J., June 29. -- The New Jersey P.G.A. golf team defeated the touring Japanese six-some 8 matches to 1, at River Vale Country Club today, Tommy Miyamoto of Japan defeating Johnny Kinder, New Jersey P.G.A. champion, 2 and 1, to save his team from a shut-out.

IN London the difficulties of France -- which have not been solved but deferred for a few months -- are explained by reference to the year 1931, when the world's monetary and credit system began to crack. One has only to look at the figures to see that French prices have fallen, that French exports have shrunk, that French industrial production is at about its lowest point since the depression.

TO portray persons -- that is an early task of the artist. Landscape comes later -- the environment around the drama -- and it is landscape that is spread before our eyes in these pages. These are books of adventure into a rediscovered past.

Taxes on gasoline imposed by all the States reached a new high total of $565,027,000 in 1934, and, added to Federal gasoline taxes of $170,109,000, increased the cost of motor fuel by $735,136,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute from reports received from the United States Bureau of Public Roads.

New jumping courses, involving innovations in obstacles and requiring more daring on the part of riders, will be introduced for both the civilian and international military team jumping classes at this year's National Horse Show, which will take place in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 6-12.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Whether the Congress of the United States is composed largely of "die-hard" conservatives out of step with the times or of sound-minded patriots who see through sham and subterfuge to the greater glory of America may be a moot question, but there can be no doubt of one salient fact: Congress is developing an increasing readiness to scrutinize all "Brain-Trust" legislation placed before it.

GREENVILLE, N.Y., June 29 (AP). -- An adolescent butcher boy who plays the violin in a church choir, confessed to New York State's "Scotland Yard" tonight that he mistreated and killed the 9-year-old daughter of his pastor last Wednesday.

MOSCOW. PUDOVKIN, one of the great masters of the Soviet film and at present a teacher at the Film University of Moscow, is worried about the future of the film. He is in love with development, but does not like the particular trend of development which the motion picture industry is taking.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Consumer representatives were told by AAA officials this week that the government was powerless to reduce the retail prices of meat. The meat supply is the smallest in many years -- 25 per cent less than in 1934 and 20 per cent less than the 1929-33 five-year average.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 29. -- The rising tide of taxation in the United States, the constitutionality of the New Deal, prospects of peace in Europe despite recent developments in Italy, Germany and France, and social, political and economic problems of Latin America and the Far East are to be subjects at the Ninth Institute of Public Affairs, which will open Monday at the University of Virginia here and continue two weeks.

Photographs of the first of a series of small airplanes ordered by the Bureau of Air Commerce in an effort to obtain a "foolproof" machine for the wider development of private flying, not yet made available in this country, nevertheless have reached England.

BERLIN, June 29. -- A week-end rally and parade staged by Greater Berlin National Socialist units today went off according to schedule, but there were few external indications of great popular enthusiasm for this demonstration of party solidarity.
MERIDIAN, Miss., June 29 (AP). -- Weathering tempest and overcoming fire, Al and Fred Key, the long-distance Meridian fliers, today winged their way past 600 hours of sustained endurance flight.

PARIS, June 27. -- The most amusing accessories launched at the opening of the Grande Semaine were Talbot's tiny Second Empire folding parasols of sun ray-pleated black Chantilly lace or white pique made with ivory handles. Tilted and half closed; they could be used as fans.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The New York Stock Exchange's application to remove the common stock of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation from its list was denied by the Securities and Exchange Commission today in a ruling which took into consideration changes in the company's affairs since the action was begun.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- A series of temporary orders restraining collection of nearly $2,000,000 in processing taxes tonight marked a new development in the battle of big millers, textile and packing concerns to overturn the AAA.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- An extraordinary complex of moral opinion is developing over the question of legalizing and licensing handbooks for race-track gambling in Chicago. A bill authorizing a municipal ordinance for that purpose has been passed by the Legislature.

RUMSON, N.J., June 29. -- The all-breed dog show of the Monmouth County Kennel Club on the Harding Estate here today was attended by several thousand persons. There were more than 600 entries. A huge "big top" tent housed the six judging rings.

A STRANGE art is that of decorating the sword of the swordfish. The New England sword-fishing fleet starts out on the first run of the season to Georges Bank about the middle of June and the quest generally continues through September.

According to an announcement made yesterday by the American Kennel Club, all previous records for registration of pure-bred dogs were broken during the month of May. Figures just compiled reveal that 6,350 individual dogs were registered in the stud book.

TOKYO, Sunday, June 30. -- Official reports today declare that forty-three persons were drowned and eighteen missing in floods that devastede Southwestern Japan, the industrial heart of the empire, when the Belated rainy season broke at midnight Friday in the worst downpour the country has experienced in thirty years.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 29. -- The eighteenth Summer session of the Smith College School for Social Work will open next Wednesday with an enrolment of 250, the largest in its history.

The full significance of what has happened in European diplomacy in the past few weeks will not become generally apparent for some time. But there has been a most important development: namely, a shift in British foreign tactics, which, if it represents a new foreign policy on the part of London, may bring about widespread alterations in the political game of the Old World.

SOUTHAMTON. -- Celebrations varied in character have been planned for Independence Day, which usually marks the beginning of the social season in Southampton. In addition to house parties and the displays of fireworks which have become an established feature at many estates in the colony, colorful community undertakings will command attention.

What officials expect will be a history making Empire City meeting is scheduled to begin on Friday. the session including stakes with an added money value far in excess of that offered in any year of the track's history. The racing is to continue until July 27.

ROOMS in which the chief decorative elements are white often seem gratefully cool to the city dweller in Summer. White walls, of course, help to make a room larger than it really is; a coating of soft white often gives new grace to the old-fashioned details of Victorian furniture.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Business activity in the week ended on June 22 was maintained at a steady level, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly domestic survey.

PARIS, June 28. -- To last week's outburst of irritation and despondency over Great Britain's desertion of that famous common allied front that never existed except in resolutions since the war ended, there has been this week some reaction in Paris, which is on the whole encouraging.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox captured both ends of a double-header from the Athletics today, winning the first game, 6 to 4, behind Lefty Grove's pitching and slugging their way to a 13-to-6 triumph in the second.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 29. -- Showing consistently over the outside course and standing out under the conformation inspection of the judges, Double Entry won the championship ribbon for hunters in the final session of the twelfth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club today.

IF light can be controlled on the stage to create moods and atmosphere isn't it time that something were done with sound? Asking himself the question, Harold Burris-Mayer of Stevens Institute of Technology undertook research which may have a profound influence on composers of operas, dramatists and actors.

THE word "Spring" as part of a book's title leads one to expect something delicately imaginative. "The Enchanted Spring," however, is not, for instance, like Robert Nathan's delicious idyl, a work of imagination but of fancy; and some of one's disappointment is due to the inevitable contrast.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Revised in an effort to meet possible constitutional objections and carrying a provision designed to block suits to recover processing taxes, the AAA amendments bill today was ordered favorably reported by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- President Roosevelt's recent observation that "it is high time to deal with the nation's transportation as a single, unified problem" has again focused attention on chaotic conditions in the industry, viewed from the standpoint of a coordinated mechanism, and once more has reminded the country of the need for effective treatment of the question.
